tr: "Of course, sir; moreover, it also has the feature of being fashionable in the less polite societies of the world. Every savage can dance."
es: ––Certainly, sir, and it also has the advantage of being fashionable among the less distinguished societies of the world; all the savages dance.

en: Sir William only smiled.
vi: Sir William just smiled.
tr: Sir William just smiled.
es: Sir William sketched a smile.

en: “Your friend performs delightfully,” he continued, after a pause, on seeing Bingley join the group; “and I doubt not that you are an adept in the science yourself, mr Darcy.”
vi: - I applaud your friend's performance... He paused for a moment when he saw Bingley join the conversation group, then continued: - And I am certain that you are well-versed in the humanities, Mr. Darcy.
tr: Seeing Bingley join the group, he paused for a moment and continued, "Your friend dances wonderfully; I have no doubt that you are also skilled in this art, Mr. Darcy."
es: ––Your friend dances wonderfully ––she continued after a pause, seeing Bingley join the group–– and I do not doubt, Mr. Darcy, that you yourself are an expert in the matter.

en: “You saw me dance at Meryton, I believe, sir.”
vi: - I think you saw me dancing at Meryton.
tr: "Sir, you must have seen me dancing in Meryton."
es: ––He saw me dance in Meryton, I believe, sir.

en: “Yes, indeed, and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight.
vi: - Yes, that's right. I am extremely delighted with the view I witnessed.
tr: "Yes, of course; I quite enjoyed what I saw.
es: ––Of course, and it gave me great pleasure to see him.

en: Do you often dance at St. James’s?”
vi: Do you often dance at St James's Palace?
tr: Do you often dance at St. James?"
es: Do you often dance at Saint James?

en: “Never, sir.”
vi: - Never before, sir.
tr: "No, sir.""
es: ––Never, sir.

en: “Do you not think it would be a proper compliment to the place?”
vi: - Do you think that there should be proper praise for that place?
tr: "Don't you think that dancing is an appropriate expression of respect for that place?"
es: ––Don't you think it would be a compliment to that place?

en: “It is a compliment which I never pay to any place if I can avoid it.”
vi: - That is the praise I have never bestowed upon any other place, if I could avoid it.
tr: "It is a respect that I do not show to any place as long as I can avoid it.""
es: ––It is a compliment that I never give anywhere, if I can avoid it.

en: “You have a house in town, I conclude?”
vi: - I guess your house is in the city, is that right?
tr: "You have a house in the city, don't you?"
es: ––I believe he has a house in the capital.

en: mr Darcy bowed.
vi: Darcy just leaned over without saying anything.
tr: Mr. Darcy nodded.
es: Mr. Darcy nodded his head.

en: “I had once some thoughts of fixing in town myself, for I am fond of superior society; but I did not feel quite certain that the air of London would agree with Lady Lucas.”
vi: - There were times when I thought about settling down in the city because I enjoy high society, but it seems that the atmosphere in London does not suit Lady Lucas.
tr: "Once upon a time, I also considered settling in the city – I am interested in high society; but I was not sure if the air of London would be good for Lady Lucas.""
es: ––I sometimes thought about settling in the city, because I love high society; but I wasn't sure if the air of London would agree with Lady Lucas.

en: He paused in hopes of an answer: but his companion was not disposed to make any; and Elizabeth at that instant moving towards them, he was struck with the notion of doing a very gallant thing, and called out to her,—
vi: He stopped, waiting for an answer, but the young man was unwilling to say another word. Just then, Elizabeth was approaching them, and he suddenly had the idea to do something very chivalrous, so he called her:
tr: He paused in the hope of getting a response; but his friend was not inclined to reply; at that moment, seeing Elizabeth approaching them, he was seized with the idea of doing something bold and called out to her–
es: Sir William paused in the hope of a response, but his company was not willing to make any. Seeing Elizabeth approaching, it occurred to him to do something that seemed very gallant on his part, and he called her.

en: “My dear Miss Eliza, why are not you dancing?
vi: - Dear Eliza, why are you not dancing?
tr: "Dear Miss Eliza, why are you not dancing?
es: ––My dear Miss Eliza, why are you not dancing?

en: mr Darcy, you must allow me to present this young lady to you as a very desirable partner.
vi: Mr. Darcy, allow me to introduce this young lady to you as a most desirable dance partner.
tr: –Mr. Darcy, you must allow me to present this young lady to you as a very suitable partner.
es: Mr. Darcy, allow me to introduce you to this young lady who could be an excellent partner.

en: You cannot refuse to dance, I am sure, when so much beauty is before you.”
vi: I am sure you cannot refuse, when such a wonderful beauty is before you.
tr: With such beauty before you, I am sure you cannot refuse to dance."
es: I am sure you cannot refuse to dance when you have such beauty before you.

en: And, taking her hand, he would have given it to mr Darcy, who, though extremely surprised, was not unwilling to receive it, when she instantly drew back, and said with some discomposure to Sir William,—
vi: Then taking her hand, he should have led her to Darcy, who was very surprised but not entirely unwilling, but she immediately retreated and said with some embarrassment:
tr: Just as he was about to take Elizabeth's hand and give it to the very surprised but not unwilling Mr. Darcy, Elizabeth quickly withdrew her hand and said to Sir William with some discomfort–
es: He took Elizabeth by the hand with the intention of giving her to Darcy; who, although extremely surprised, was not going to refuse her; but Elizabeth turned her back on him and said to Sir William, somewhat disconcerted:

en: “Indeed, sir, I have not the least intention of dancing.
vi: - Actually, sir, I have no intention of dancing at all.
tr: "Truly, sir, I have no intention of dancing.
es: ––Really, sir, I had no intention of dancing.

en: I entreat you not to suppose that I moved this way in order to beg for a partner.”
vi: Please do not think that I came here to find a dance partner.
tr: I kindly ask you not to think that I came here to look for a partner."
es: I beg you not to assume that I came here to find a partner.

en: mr Darcy, with grave propriety, requested to be allowed the honour of her hand, but in vain.
vi: With all due propriety, Darcy requested the honor from her hand, but was refused.
tr: Mr. Darcy, with quite serious politeness, requested the honor of holding her hand, but in vain.
es: Mr. Darcy, with all propriety, asked her to grant him the honor of dancing with him, but it was in vain.

en: Elizabeth was determined; nor did Sir William at all shake her purpose by his attempt at persuasion.
vi: Elizabeth was resolute, and even Sir William could not sway her despite his efforts to persuade.
tr: Elizabeth was determined; Sir William also attempted to persuade her, but she did not change her mind.
es: Elizabeth was determined, and not even Sir William, with all his arguments, could persuade her.

en: “You excel so much in the dance, Miss Eliza, that it is cruel to deny me the happiness of seeing you; and though this gentleman dislikes the amusement in general, he can have no objection, I am sure, to oblige us for one half hour.”
vi: - Eliza, you dance so beautifully that it would be truly unkind if you did not grant me the pleasure of watching you perform. Although this gentleman does not like to participate in the game, I am sure he will not refuse to indulge us for half an hour.
tr: "You dance wonderfully, Miss Eliza, it is cruelty to deprive us of the pleasure of watching you; although this gentleman does not enjoy entertainment, I am sure he would not object to indulging us for half an hour."
es: ––You are excellent at dancing, Miss Eliza, and it is very cruel of you to deny me the satisfaction of watching you; and although this gentleman does not like this entertainment, I am sure he would not mind indulging us for half an hour.

en: “mr Darcy is all politeness,” said Elizabeth, smiling.
vi: Elizabeth smiled: - Mr. Darcy is just being polite.
tr: "Mr. Darcy is very kind," said Elizabeth, smiling.
es: ––Mr. Darcy is very polite ––said Elizabeth, smiling.

en: “He is, indeed: but considering the inducement, my dear Miss Eliza, we cannot wonder at his complaisance; for who would object to such a partner?”
vi: - It is true, my dear Elizabeth, but given the circumstances, it would not be surprising if he were willing to comply with us, for who could refuse someone like you?
tr: "Of course it is; but when you look at the reason, dear Miss Eliza, you shouldn't be surprised at his kindness –who could object to such a spouse?"
es: ––It is indeed; but considering what induces him, dear Eliza, we cannot doubt his courtesy; because, who could reject such a charming couple?

en: Elizabeth looked archly, and turned away.
vi: Elizabeth cast a mischievous glance, then turned away.
tr: Elizabeth cast a fleeting glance and walked away.
es: Elizabeth looked at them coquettishly and withdrew.

en: Her resistance had not injured her with the gentleman, and he was thinking of her with some complacency, when thus accosted by Miss Bingley,—
vi: To the young man, the opposition had not harmed her. He was thinking of her with a bit of satisfaction when Miss Bingley approached.
tr: The resistance she showed had not diminished her value in Darcy's eyes; the young man was thinking of her with a certain pleasure when Miss Bingley appeared beside him–
es: Her resistance had not harmed her at all in the eyes of the gentleman, who was thinking of her with satisfaction when he was approached by Miss Bingley.

en: “I can guess the subject of your reverie.”
vi: - I can guess the topic you are thinking about.
tr: "I can guess the subject of your dreams.""
es: ––I guess why you are so thoughtful.

en: “I should imagine not.”
vi: - I don't believe so.
tr: "I don't think so.""
es: ––I don't think so.

en: “You are considering how insupportable it would be to pass many evenings in this manner,—in such society; and, indeed, I am quite of your opinion.
vi: - I am thinking that it is unbearable to go through many evenings like this – in a society like this. Actually, I agree with you.
tr: "You think it's impossible to spend so many evenings like this – with these people, I mean; I agree.
es: ––He is thinking about how unbearable it would be to spend more evenings like this, in a society like this; and of course, I share his opinion.

en: I was never more annoyed!
vi: I have never felt as uncomfortable as tonight.
tr: I've never been so bored in my life!
es: I have never been angrier.

en: The insipidity, and yet the noise—the nothingness, and yet the self-importance, of all these people!
vi: The dullness, plus the noise, and on top of that, the condescending attitude of these people.
tr: The soullessness and noise of all these people, their meaninglessness and airs of importance!
es: What insipid people and what a fuss they make! How insignificant they are and yet how important they think they are.

en: What would I give to hear your strictures on them!”
vi: I want to do something to hear you condemn them strongly.
tr: I would give anything to hear your observations about them!"
es: I would give anything to hear their criticisms about them.

en: “Your conjecture is totally wrong, I assure you.
vi: - Please believe that your estimation is completely wrong.
tr: "You are mistaken in your guess.
es: ––His conjectures are completely wrong.

en: My mind was more agreeably engaged.
vi: My mind is feeling at ease.
tr: I had sweeter thoughts in mind.
es: My mind was occupied with more pleasant things.

en: I have been meditating on the very great pleasure which a pair of fine eyes in the face of a pretty woman can bestow.”
vi: I am contemplating with all the joy that a pair of beautiful eyes on the face of a beautiful woman can bestow upon me.
tr: I was lost in thought about the immense pleasure that a pair of beautiful eyes on a lovely woman's face can bestow."
es: I was meditating on the great pleasure that a pair of beautiful eyes on the face of a lovely woman can cause.

en: Miss Bingley immediately fixed her eyes on his face, and desired he would tell her what lady had the credit of inspiring such reflections.
vi: Miss Bingley immediately looked straight into his eyes, implying that she wanted him to reveal which woman had inspired such thoughts in him.
tr: Miss Bingley immediately fixed her eyes on his face and asked him to tell her which lady had the honor of inspiring such thoughts.
es: Miss Bingley stared at him, wishing he would tell her which lady had inspired such thoughts.

en: mr Darcy replied, with great intrepidity,—
vi: And Darcy boldly replied:
tr: Mr. Darcy answered with great courage–
es: Mr. Darcy, undaunted, replied:

en: “Miss Elizabeth Bennet.”
vi: - Miss Elizabeth Bennet!
tr: "Miss Elizabeth Bennet.""
es: ––Miss Elizabeth Bennet.

en: “Miss Elizabeth Bennet!” repeated Miss Bingley.
vi: - Miss Elizabeth Bennet!
tr: "Miss Elizabeth Bennet!" repeated Miss Bingley.
es: ––Miss Bennet!

en: “I am all astonishment.
vi: I am very surprised.
tr: "I am very surprised.
es: You astonish me.

en: How long has she been such a favourite?
vi: How long have you been fond of her?
tr: Since when has she been your favorite?
es: Since when is she your favorite?

en: and pray when am I to wish you joy?”
vi: And please let me know when I can congratulate you?
tr: –well, when shall I wish you happiness?"
es: And tell me, when will I have to congratulate you?

en: “That is exactly the question which I expected you to ask.
vi: - That is the question I was waiting for you to ask.
tr: "This is exactly the question I was expecting you to ask.
es: ––That is exactly the question I was expecting you to ask me.

en: A lady’s imagination is very rapid; it jumps from admiration to love, from love to matrimony, in a moment.
vi: The imagination of women is truly quick, in just a moment it leaps from admiration to love, from love to marriage.
tr: Women's imagination is very quick; it jumps from admiration to love, from love to marriage in an instant.
es: A lady's imagination moves very quickly and jumps from admiration to love and from love to marriage in a moment.

en: I knew you would be wishing me joy.”
vi: I know you intend to congratulate me.
tr: I knew you would wish me happiness."
es: I knew you would congratulate me.

en: “Nay, if you are so serious about it, I shall consider the matter as absolutely settled.
vi: - No, if you are serious about this, I will consider it as absolutely settled.
tr: "Since you are so serious, I consider the matter settled.
es: ––If you take it so seriously, I will believe it is already a done deal.

en: You will have a charming mother-in-law, indeed, and of course she will be always at Pemberley with you.”
vi: In fact, you will have a charming mother-in-law, who will of course always come to live at Pemberly with you.
tr: You will have a formidable mother-in-law, by the way; and of course, she will always stay with you at Pemberley."
es: You will have a charming mother-in-law, truly, and needless to say, she will always be at Pemberley with you.

en: He listened to her with perfect indifference, while she chose to entertain herself in this manner; and as his composure convinced her that all was safe, her wit flowed along.
vi: He listened to her with complete indifference, while she took pleasure in speaking in this manner, and as his calm demeanor showed that she was not being stopped, she became even more mischievous.
tr: While Miss Bingley preferred to amuse herself in this way, Mr. Darcy listened with complete indifference; seeing from his expression that there was no danger, the girl let her sarcastic wit run free.
es: He listened to her with perfect indifference, while she continued to enjoy the things she was saying; and seeing, by Darcy's attitude, that everything was safe, she let her wit flow for a long time.

en: CHAPTER VII.
vi: Chapter 7
tr: Chapter VII
es: CHAPTER VII

en: mr BENNET’S property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two thousand a year, which, unfortunately for his daughters, was entailed, in default of heirs male, on a distant relation; and their mother’s fortune, though ample for her situation in life, could but ill supply the deficiency of his.
vi: Mr. Bennet's income consisted almost entirely of two thousand pounds a year. Unfortunately for the daughters, the default heir was a distant male relative. The mother's fortune could not make up for the deficiencies.
tr: Mr. Bennet's entire estate consisted of a property yielding two thousand a year, and, to the misfortune of the daughters, this estate would go to a distant relative due to the absence of a male heir; their mother's income was more than sufficient for her living situation, but it was not enough to cover the household expenses.
es: Mr. Bennet's property consisted almost entirely of an estate of two thousand pounds a year, which, unfortunately for his daughters, was destined, due to the lack of male heirs, to a distant relative; and the fortune of their mother, although ample for her position, could hardly supplement that of her husband.

en: Her father had been an attorney in Meryton, and had left her four thousand pounds.
vi: Her father had practiced law in Meryton and left her four thousand pounds.
tr: Mrs. Bennet's father had practiced law in Meryton and had left her four thousand pounds.
es: Her father had been a lawyer in Meryton and had left her four thousand pounds.

en: She had a sister married to a mr Philips, who had been a clerk to their father and succeeded him in the business, and a brother settled in London in a respectable line of trade.
vi: She has a younger sister who married Mr. Phillips, who worked as a clerk for her father and then continued his career. One of her younger brothers lives in London, works in business, and has a bit of a reputation.
tr: Mrs. Bennet had a sister who was married to a man named Mr. Philips; the man had been a clerk to their father and had taken over the business after his death. Mrs. Bennet also had a brother who was engaged in trade in a reputable area of London.
es: Mrs. Bennet had a sister married to a certain Mr. Phillips who had been employed by her father and had succeeded him in business, and a brother in London who held a respectable position in trade.

en: The village of Longbourn was only one mile from Meryton; a most convenient distance for the young ladies, who were usually tempted thither three or four times a week, to pay their duty to their aunt, and to a milliner’s shop just over the way.
vi: The village of Longburn is only a mile away from Meryton, a convenient distance for young girls who wish to go there three or four times a week to visit their aunt and incidentally stop by the fashion shops.
tr: The village of Longbourn was only a mile away from Meryton; a very convenient distance for the young ladies who felt the urge to visit Meryton three or four times a week to fulfill their duties to their aunts and to stop by a milliner's shop that was right on the way.
es: The village of Longbourn was only a mile from Meryton, a very convenient distance for the young ladies, who were usually tempted to go there three or four times a week to visit their aunt and, incidentally, stop by a millinery shop near her house.

en: The two youngest of the family, Catherine and Lydia, were particularly frequent in these attentions: their minds were more vacant than their sisters’, and when nothing better offered, a walk to Meryton was necessary to amuse their morning hours and furnish conversation for the evening; and, however bare of news the country in general might be, they always contrived to learn some from their aunt.
vi: In particular, the two youngest daughters of the Bennet family, Catherine and Lydia, often made such trips. Their minds were usually less occupied than their older sisters', so when there was nothing better to do, they felt the need to walk to Meryton to enjoy the morning moments and have more topics to talk about in the evening. Even if there was no special news, they always managed to learn something from their aunt.
tr: The family's two youngest daughters, Catherine and Lydia, felt this urge particularly often; their minds were more frivolous than their sisters', and when there was no better offer, a walk to Meryton was necessary to brighten the morning hours and provide material for evening conversation; although the region was generally poor in news, they would find a way to learn something from their aunts.
es: The ones who frequented Meryton the most were the two youngest, Catherine and Lydia, who tended to be more idle than their sisters, and when nothing better was offered, they decided that a little walk to town was necessary to pass the morning well and thus have conversation for the afternoon; because, although news was not usually abundant in the countryside, their aunt always had something to tell.

en: At present, indeed, they were well supplied both with news and happiness by the recent arrival of a militia regiment in the neighbourhood; it was to remain the whole winter, and Meryton was the head-quarters.
vi: At present, they received news about a regiment of militia that had just moved to camp for the entire winter, with Meryton as the headquarters.
tr: In those days, the arrival of a new militia regiment in the area had, of course, given them plenty of news and happiness; the regiment would stay throughout the winter, and Meryton would be their headquarters.
es: At the moment, they were well supplied with gossip and joy at the recent arrival of a military regiment that was going to stay all winter and had its headquarters in Meryton.

en: Their visits to ms Philips were now productive of the most interesting intelligence.
vi: The visits to Mrs. Phillips now generated news of interest.
tr: The visit they paid to Mrs. Philips was now producing the most interesting intelligence.
es: Now the visits to Mrs. Phillips provided the most interesting information.

en: Every day added something to their knowledge of the officers’ names and connections.
vi: Every day they learned more about the names of the officers and their relationships.
tr: Every day, a new piece of information was added to their knowledge about the names and connections of the officers.
es: Each day they added something more to what they already knew about the names and families of the officers.

en: Their lodgings were not long a secret, and at length they began to know the officers themselves.
vi: The location of their camp could not remain a secret for long, so eventually the girls became acquainted with them.
tr: The place where they stayed was no longer a secret; eventually, they even began to recognize the officers themselves.
es: The place where they were staying was no longer a secret and soon they began to meet the officers in person.

en: mr Philips visited them all, and this opened to his nieces a source of felicity unknown before.
vi: Mr. Phillips had visited them all, and this opened up an unprecedented source of joy for the nieces.
tr: Mr. Philips visited all of them, which opened the doors to a source of happiness for his nieces that they had never experienced before.
es: Mr. Phillips knew them all, which was an unexpected source of satisfaction for his nieces.

en: They could talk of nothing but officers; and mr Bingley’s large fortune, the mention of which gave animation to their mother, was worthless in their eyes when opposed to the regimentals of an ensign.
vi: They only talked about the officers. The great fortune of Bingley, which had caused much excitement for the mother upon hearing about it, now became meaningless in the eyes of the young girl.
tr: Now they talked about nothing but the officers; the great fortune of Mr. Bingley, which used to light up their mother's face whenever mentioned, now seemed worthless to them in the presence of military uniforms.
es: He spoke of nothing but officers. Mr. Bingley's great fortune, which his mother so loved to talk about, was no longer worth comparing to the uniform of an ensign.

en: After listening one morning to their effusions on this subject, mr Bennet coolly observed,—
vi: After listening to the ladies chatter all morning, Mr. Bennet coldly remarked:
tr: One morning, after listening to their heated discussions on the matter, Mr. Bennet made a cold observation–
es: After hearing one morning the enthusiasm with which his daughters spoke about the subject, Mr. Bennet observed coldly:

en: “From all that I can collect by your manner of talking, you must be two of the silliest girls in the country.
vi: - According to what I see from the way you two talk, you two are the dumbest girls in the country.
tr: "Judging by the way you speak, you must be the two dumbest girls in the province.
es: ––From everything I can make out from the way you talk, you must be the silliest girls in the whole country.

en: I have suspected it some time, but I am now convinced.”
vi: I had suspected this, but now I believe it's true.
tr: I had been suspecting it for a while, but now I am sure."
es: I had my suspicions sometimes, but now I am convinced.

en: Catherine was disconcerted, and made no answer; but Lydia, with perfect indifference, continued to express her admiration of Captain Carter, and her hope of seeing him in the course of the day, as he was going the next morning to London.
vi: Catherine was confused and did not answer, but Lydia was completely indifferent, continuing to talk about her admiration for Captain Carter, about how she hoped to see him that day, because the next day he would be going to London.
tr: Catherine was bored and did not respond; but Lydia, with all her indifference, continued to express her admiration for Captain Carter, even saying that she hoped to see him during the day as he was going to London the next morning.
es: Catherine was left bewildered and did not reply. Lydia, with complete indifference, continued to express her admiration for Captain Carter and said that she hoped to see him that very day, as he was leaving for London the next morning.

en: “I am astonished, my dear,” said ms Bennet, “that you should be so ready to think your own children silly.
vi: Mrs. Bennet said: - Sir! I am surprised to see that you think your children are foolish.
tr: "I am very surprised, my dear," said Mrs. Bennet, "how can you be so ready to call your own children stupid.
es: ––I am astonished, dear ––said Mrs. Bennet––, at how ready you always are to believe that your daughters are foolish.

en: If I wished to think slightingly of anybody’s children, it should not be of my own, however.”
vi: I can despise other people's children, but I cannot despise my own.
tr: Even if I were to belittle someone else's children, I would not touch my own."
es: If I were to look down on anyone, it would be the daughters of others, not my own.

en: “If my children are silly, I must hope to be always sensible of it.”
vi: - If my children are foolish, I will always sympathize with them.
tr: "If my children are foolish, I always want to be aware of it."
es: ––If my daughters are foolish, the least I can do is acknowledge it.

en: “Yes; but as it happens, they are all of them very clever.”
vi: - Yes, with what has happened, they are all very wise.
tr: "Yes –but you see, they are all very intelligent."
es: ––Yes, but you see, it turns out they are very smart.

en: “This is the only point, I flatter myself, on which we do not agree.
vi: - I am complacent that this is just a point on which we disagree.
tr: "I can proudly say that this is the only topic on which we disagree.
es: ––I presume that is the only point on which we disagree.

en: I had hoped that our sentiments coincided in every particular, but I must so far differ from you as to think our two youngest daughters uncommonly foolish.”
vi: I had expected that our feelings would coincide in everything, but now I must disagree with you when you think that our two little daughters are unusually foolish.
tr: I would have liked our views to align in every detail, but right now I disagree with you on the matter of our two youngest daughters being extraordinarily foolish."
es: I always wished to agree with you on everything, but on this I differ, because our two younger daughters are complete fools.

en: “My dear mr Bennet, you must not expect such girls to have the sense of their father and mother.
vi: - You shouldn't expect your children to have the same awareness as their parents.
tr: "Dear Mr. Bennet, you can't expect these girls to think like their parents.
es: My dear Mr. Bennet, you cannot expect these girls to have as much sense as their parents.

en: When they get to our age, I dare say they will not think about officers any more than we do.
vi: When they are my age, I'm sure they won't think about officers anymore.
tr: When they reach our age, I'm sure they won't think about the officers any more than we do.
es: When they are our age, I would bet that they think about officers as much as we do.

en: I remember the time when I liked a red coat myself very well—and, indeed, so I do still at my heart; and if a smart young colonel, with five or six thousand a year, should want one of my girls, I shall not say nay to him; and I thought Colonel Forster looked very becoming the other night at Sir William’s in his regimentals.”
vi: I still remember a time when I loved the uniform with the red cloak, and in fact, even now I still like it in my heart. If now a young, handsome colonel with five or six thousand pounds a year wanted to marry my daughter, I wouldn't refuse. I think Colonel Foster looked very elegant in his uniform at Sir William's reception that day.
tr: I remember that I once liked a man in a red coat – in fact, I still do; if a bright young colonel earning five or six thousand a year wanted one of my daughters, I wouldn't say no; I think Colonel Forster looked very handsome in his uniform at Sir William's the other night."
es: I remember a time when I was very fond of a red coat, and the truth is that I still carry it in my heart. And if a young colonel with five or six thousand pounds a year wanted one of my daughters, I would not say no. I found Colonel Forster very well the other night at Sir William's house.

en: “Mamma,” cried Lydia, “my aunt says that Colonel Forster and Captain Carter do not go so often to Miss Watson’s as they did when they first came; she sees them now very often standing in Clarke’s library.”
vi: Lydia exclaimed: - Mom, my aunt said that Colonel Foster and Captain Carter don't visit Mrs. Watson's house as often as they did when they first moved in. Now they usually stand in the reading room of the Clark house.
tr: "Anne," Lydia shouted, "my aunt said that Colonel Forster and Captain Carter don't visit the Miss Watsons as often as they used to; now she often sees them hanging out at Clarke's bookstore."
es: ––Mom ––said Lydia, Aunt says that Colonel Forster and Captain Carter don't go to the Watsons' house as much as before. Now she sees them a lot at Clarke's library.

en: ms Bennet was prevented replying by the entrance of the footman with a note for Miss Bennet; it came from Netherfield, and the servant waited for an answer.
vi: While Mrs. Bennet had not yet had time to reply, a servant brought Jane a letter from Netherfield and stood waiting for a response.
tr: Before Mrs. Bennet could respond, a messenger came in and brought a letter for Miss Bennet; the letter was from Netherfield and the servant was waiting for a reply.
es: Mrs. Bennet could not answer as she was interrupted by the entrance of a footman who brought a note for Miss Bennet; it came from Netherfield and the servant awaited a reply.

en: ms Bennet’s eyes sparkled with pleasure, and she was eagerly calling out, while her daughter read,—
vi: Mrs. Bennet's eyes lit up with joy, and she eagerly asked as her daughter was reading:
tr: Mrs. Bennet's eyes sparkled with delight; she eagerly called out while her daughter read the letter–
es: Mrs. Bennet's eyes sparkled with joy and she was impatient for her daughter to finish reading.

en: “Well, Jane, who is it from?
vi: - So Jane, whose letter is it?
tr: "Come on Jane, who is it from?
es: ––Well, Jane, whose is it?

en: What is it about?
vi: What does he say?
tr: What's it about?
es: What is it about?

en: What does he say?
vi: What does he say?
tr: What does it say?
es: What does it say?

en: Well, Jane, make haste and tell us; make haste, my love.”
vi: Jane, read it quickly and tell everyone, hurry up my dear.
tr: Come on Jane, hurry up, tell us, hurry up darling."
es: Hurry up and tell us, hurry up, darling.

en: “It is from Miss Bingley,” said Jane, and then read it aloud.
vi: - That is Miss Bingley's letter. Then she read aloud:
tr: "From Miss Bingley," said Jane, and she read the letter aloud.
es: ––It is from Miss Bingley ––said Jane, and then she read aloud:

en: “My dear friend,
vi: “Dear sister,
tr: "Dear Friend, –
es: My dear friend,

en: “If you are not so compassionate as to dine to-day with Louisa and me, we shall be in danger of hating each other for the rest of our lives; for a whole day’s tête-à-tête between two women can never end without a quarrel.
vi: If you do not make the effort to come visit and join us for dinner tonight with Louisa and me, I fear that we will become estranged for life, because a confrontation between two women cannot end when there is conflict.
tr: "If you do not show mercy and join Louisa and me for dinner tonight, we will be in danger of hating each other for the rest of our lives, because when two women gossip all day, it inevitably ends in a fight.
es: If you have compassion for us, come to dinner today with Louisa and me, otherwise, we will be in danger of hating each other for the rest of our lives, because two women together all day cannot end without fighting.

en: Come as soon as you can on the receipt of this.
vi: Upon receiving this letter, please come immediately.
tr: Come quickly upon receiving this letter.
es: Come as soon as possible after receiving this note.

en: My brother and the gentlemen are to dine with the officers.
vi: My brother and a few others will be dining with the officers.
tr: My brother and the gentlemen will have dinner with the officers.
es: My brother and the other gentlemen will dine with the officers.

en: Yours ever,
vi: Dear,
tr: –Yours,
es: Regards,

en: “Caroline Bingley.”
vi: Caroline Bingley
tr: Caroline Bingley."
es: Caroline Bingley

en: “With the officers!” cried Lydia: “I wonder my aunt did not tell us of that.”
vi: Lydia exclaimed: - For the officers! I wonder why my aunt didn't tell us about this.
tr: "With the officers!" Lydia exclaimed. "I wonder why my aunt didn't tell us about this."
es: ––With the officers! ––exclaimed Lydia––. How strange that Aunt didn't tell us!

en: “Dining out,” said ms Bennet; “that is very unlucky.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet said: - Having dinner at their place, unfortunately.
tr: "He is dining out," said Mrs. Bennet, "this is a great misfortune."
es: ––Dinner out! ––said Mrs. Bennet––. What bad luck!

en: “Can I have the carriage?” said Jane.
vi: Jane asked: - Can I use the carriage?
tr: "Can I take the car?" said Jane.
es: ––Can I take the carriage? ––asked Jane.

en: “No, my dear, you had better go on horseback, because it seems likely to rain; and then you must stay all night.”
vi: - No, my dear, you should ride a horse because it might rain, and then you would have to stay the night.
tr: "No, my dear, it would be better if you go by horse, because it looks like it's going to rain; in that case, you would have to stay all night."
es: ––No, dear; it's better if you go on horseback, because it looks like it's going to rain and that way you'll have to stay the night.

en: “That would be a good scheme,” said Elizabeth, “if you were sure that they would not offer to send her home.”
vi: - It could be a clever scheme, if you're sure they won't volunteer to take you back.
tr: "It would be a good plan," said Elizabeth, "if you were sure they wouldn't try to send him back.""
es: ––It would be a good plan ––said Elizabeth––, if you were sure they wouldn't offer to bring her home.

en: “Oh, but the gentlemen will have mr Bingley’s chaise to go to Meryton; and the Hursts have no horses to theirs.”
vi: - Ah! But you will use Bingley's carriage to go to Meryton, and Mr. and Mrs. Hurst do not have horses.
tr: "Yes, but gentlemen go to Meryton with Mr. Bingley's carriage; the Hursts do not have their own horses."
es: ––Oh, the gentlemen will take Mr. Bingley's landau to Meryton and the Hursts do not have their own horses.

en: “I had much rather go in the coach.”
vi: - Nhung wants to ride a horse-drawn carriage.
tr: "I prefer to go by car.""
es: ––I would prefer to go in the carriage.

en: “But, my dear, your father cannot spare the horses, I am sure.
vi: - But my dear, I believe your father doesn't want you to use the horses.
tr: "But my dear, your father cannot separate the horses, I am sure.
es: ––But dear, your father cannot lend you the horses. I am certain of it.

en: They are wanted in the farm, mr Bennet, are not they?”
vi: We need them to work on the farm, don't we, dear?
tr: They are needed on the farm.
es: They are needed on the farm. Isn't that right, Mr. Bennet?

en: Cheerful prognostics
vi: - I often need them, but I rarely get to use them.
tr: Aren't they, Mr. Bennet?"
es: ––They are needed more on the farm than what I can offer them.

en: “They are wanted in the farm much oftener than I can get them.”
vi: - I often need them, but I rarely get to use them.
tr: "We need them more on the farm.""
es: ––They are needed more on the farm than what I can offer them.

en: “But if you have got them to-day,” said Elizabeth, “my mother’s purpose will be answered.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - But if you use the horses today, mother's purpose will be achieved.
tr: "But if they are already there," said Elizabeth, "my mother's wish will have come true.""
es: ––If you can offer them today ––said Elizabeth––, my mother's wishes will be fulfilled.

en: She did at last extort from her father an acknowledgment that the horses were engaged; Jane was therefore obliged to go on horseback, and her mother attended her to the door with many cheerful prognostics of a bad day.
vi: In the end, she made her father admit that the horses were busy. Therefore, Jane had to ride a horse, and her mother saw her off at the door with many predictions about bad weather.
tr: In the end, she managed to get confirmation from her father that the carriage horses were occupied; as a result, Jane had to go on horseback, and her mother, making cheerful predictions about the weather turning bad, saw her off to the door.
es: In the end, he encouraged the father to admit that the horses were occupied. And, finally, Jane was forced to go on horseback. Her mother accompanied her to the door, very happily predicting a terrible day.

en: Her hopes were answered; Jane had not been gone long before it rained hard.
vi: Her mother's hope came true when it started raining shortly after Jane left.
tr: Her wish came true; Jane had not been gone long when a heavy rain began.
es: Their hopes were fulfilled; Jane had not been gone long when it started to pour rain.

en: Her sisters were uneasy for her, but her mother was delighted.
vi: Her sisters were worried about her, but Mrs. Bennet seemed pleased.
tr: Her sisters worried about her, but her mother was pleased.
es: The sisters were worried about her, but their mother was delighted.

en: The rain continued the whole evening without intermission; Jane certainly could not come back.
vi: The rain continued throughout the evening without stopping, making it clear that Jane could not return home.
tr: The rain continued incessantly all evening; Jane certainly would not be able to return.
es: It didn't stop raining all afternoon; it was obvious that Jane wouldn't be able to return...

en: “This was a lucky idea of mine, indeed!” said ms Bennet, more than once, as if the credit of making it rain were all her own.
vi: And the next day, Mrs. Bennet's joy was multiplied when a servant from Netherfield brought a letter for Elizabeth:
tr: "I really thought this through, I swear!" said Mrs. Bennet, as if making it rain was her own skill.
es: ––Truly, I had a very good idea ––repeated Mrs. Bennet.

en: Till the next morning, however, she was not aware of all the felicity of her contrivance.
vi: And the next day, Mrs. Bennet's joy was multiplied when a servant from Netherfield brought a letter for Elizabeth:
tr: However, she only realized the happy result of her cunning the next morning.
es: However, it was not until the next morning that she knew anything about the result of her timely stratagem.

en: Breakfast was scarcely over when a servant from Netherfield brought the following note for Elizabeth:—
vi: And the next day, Mrs. Bennet's joy was multiplied when a servant from Netherfield brought a letter for Elizabeth:
tr: Just as breakfast was finishing, a servant from Netherfield brought Elizabeth this letter:-
es: She had barely finished breakfast when a servant from Netherfield brought the following note for Elizabeth:

en: “My dearest Lizzie,
vi: “Dear Lizzy,
tr: "Dear Lizzy, –
es: My dear Lizzy:

en: “I find myself very unwell this morning, which, I suppose, is to be imputed to my getting wet through yesterday.
vi: I felt much weaker this morning, I think it might be because I got soaked in the rain all day yesterday.
tr: This morning I feel very sick, probably because I got wet yesterday.
es: I am not feeling very well this morning, which, I suppose, is because I got soaked to the bone yesterday.

en: My kind friends will not hear of my returning home till I am better.
vi: The friends here absolutely won't let me go home until I recover.
tr: My kind-hearted friends are not even mentioning going home until I get better.
es: My kind friends do not want to hear about me going back home until I am better.

en: They insist also on my seeing mr Jones—therefore do not be alarmed if you should hear of his having been to me—and, excepting a sore throat and a headache, there is not much the matter with me.
vi: They also want me to meet Mr. Jones – so don't worry when you hear that he's coming to check on me. Besides a sore throat and headache, I don't have anything else.
tr: They are also insisting that I see Mr. Jones –so if you hear that he is looking after me, don't worry– it's just that my throat is swollen, my head hurts, and I don't have much else.
es: They insist that I see Mr. Jones; therefore, do not be alarmed if you hear that he has come to visit me. I have nothing more than a sore throat and a headache.

en: “Yours, etc.”
vi: My older sister
tr: – Love."
es: Yours always,

en: “Well, my dear,” said mr Bennet, when Elizabeth had read the note aloud, “if your daughter should have a dangerous fit of illness—if she should die—it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of mr Bingley, and under your orders.”
vi: Mr. Bennet said after hearing Elizabeth read the letter: - So if your daughter falls seriously ill, and if anything happens to her, you can console yourself that it was due to pursuing Mr. Bingley under your direction.
tr: "Well, my dear," said Mr. Bennet, when Elizabeth read the letter aloud, "if your daughter catches a dangerous illness and dies, knowing that she died following your orders to pursue Mr. Bingley will bring us all some comfort.""
es: Jane ––Well, my dear ––said Mr. Bennet once Elizabeth had read the note aloud––, if Jane were to contract a dangerous illness or die, it would be a consolation to know that it was all to get Mr. Bingley and under your orders.

en: “Oh, I am not at all afraid of her dying.
vi: - Ah, I am sure it is not as dangerous as you say.
tr: "Oh!
es: ––Oh! I'm not afraid that she will die.

en: People do not die of little trifling colds.
vi: People never die from a common cold.
tr: My dear, don't die. No one dies from a little chill.
es: People don't die from insignificant little colds.

en: She will be taken good care of.
vi: It will be well taken care of.
tr: They will take good care of him.
es: She will have good care.

en: As long as she stays there, it is all very well.
vi: It will be well taken care of.
tr: As long as he stays there, everything will be fine.
es: As long as she is there, everything will go wonderfully.

en: I would go and see her if I could have the carriage.”
vi: I will visit it, if I can use the carriage.
tr: If I can get the car, I will go and see him."
es: I would go see her if I could use the car.

en: Elizabeth, feeling really anxious, determined to go to her, though the carriage was not to be had: and as she was no horsewoman, walking was her only alternative.
vi: Elizabeth felt anxious and decided to visit Jane even though there was no carriage. Since she did not know how to ride a horse, she had no choice but to walk.
tr: Elizabeth, who was genuinely worried, decided to go and see him, but the car was not available; since she didn't know how to ride a horse, her only option was to walk.
es: Elizabeth, who was truly worried, made up her mind to go see her. Since she couldn't have the carriage and wasn't a good rider, walking was her only option.

en: She declared her resolution.
vi: When she expressed her intention, her mother was astonished:
tr: She announced her decision.
es: And she announced her decision.

en: “How can you be so silly,” cried her mother, “as to think of such a thing, in all this dirt!
vi: - How could you be so reckless, with all that dust.
tr: "How can you be so stupid," shouted his mother, "is this the kind of work you undertake in this mud!
es: ––How can you be so foolish? exclaimed her mother––. How can such a thing occur to you? With all the mud there is!

en: You will not be fit to be seen when you get there.”
vi: By the time you get there, you'll be exhausted and your face will be a mess.
tr: When you get to where you're going, you won't be fit to be seen in public."
es: You would arrive looking a mess, you wouldn't be presentable!

en: “I shall be very fit to see Jane—which is all I want.”
vi: - I will still have the strength to check on Jane's condition – that's all I want.
tr: "I will be in a state to see Jane – that's all I want.""
es: ––I would be presentable to see Jane, which is all I desire.

en: “Is this a hint to me, Lizzy,” said her father, “to send for the horses?”
vi: - Lizzy, are you implying that you want Dad to allow you to use the carriage?
tr: "Are you trying to make me listen to nonsense, Lizzy," said her father, "so that I can call for the horses?"
es: ––Is that a hint for me to send for the horses, Lizzy? ––said her father.

en: “No, indeed.
vi: - Actually, no.
tr: "Not at all.
es: ––No, not at all.

en: I do not wish to avoid the walk.
vi: I don't want to avoid having to walk.
tr: I don't complain about walking.
es: I don't mind walking.

en: The distance is nothing, when one has a motive; only three miles.
vi: The distance isn't that far, when one is motivated it's only three miles.
tr: When a person wants something, the distance doesn't matter; it's only three miles.
es: There are no distances when you have a reason. It's only three miles.

en: I shall be back by dinner.”
vi: I'll be home before dinner.
tr: I'll be back for dinner."
es: I'll be back by dinner time.

en: “I admire the activity of your benevolence,” observed Mary, “but every impulse of feeling should be guided by reason; and, in my opinion, exertion should always be in proportion to what is required.”
vi: Mary said: - I admire your compassion, but all emotional impulses need to be guided by reason. In my opinion, you should only act to the necessary extent.
tr: "I admire the energy in your kindness," observed Mary, "but every emotional reaction must be subjected to the test of reason; in my opinion, the reaction shown should be proportional to the need felt.""
es: ––I admire the activity of your benevolence ––observed Mary––; but every impulse of feeling must be guided by reason, and in my opinion, the effort must be proportional to what is intended.

en: “We will go as far as Meryton with you,” said Catherine and Lydia.
vi: Catherine and Lydia expressed their desire to accompany their sister to Meryton.
tr: "We'll come with you as far as Meryton," said Catherine and Lydia.
es: ––We will go with you to Meryton ––said Catherine and Lydia.

en: Elizabeth accepted their company, and the three young ladies set off together.
vi: Elizabeth agreed, and all three set off together.
tr: Elizabeth accepted their company, and the three young ladies set off together.
es: Elizabeth accepted their company and the three young women went out together.

en: “If we make haste,” said Lydia, as they walked along, “perhaps we may see something of Captain Carter, before he goes.”
vi: Lydia said: - If we go quickly, you can meet and chat a bit with Captain Carter before he leaves.
tr: "If we hurry," said Lydia, as they walked, "maybe we can see Captain Carter for a little bit before he leaves."
es: ––If we hurry ––said Lydia as she walked––, maybe we can see Captain Carter before he leaves.

en: In Meryton they parted: the two youngest repaired to the lodgings of one of the officers’ wives, and Elizabeth continued her walk alone, crossing field after field at a quick pace, jumping over stiles and springing over puddles, with impatient activity, and finding herself at last within view of the house, with weary ancles, dirty stockings, and a face glowing with the warmth of exercise.
vi: They parted ways at Meryton, the two younger sisters went to the residential area of the officers' wives, while Elizabeth continued on alone, hurriedly crossing the fields with swift steps, jumping over stiles, and leaping over puddles. Finally, she arrived with weary legs, dirty stockings, and a flushed face from exertion.
tr: They parted ways in Meryton; the younger ones headed to the house of one of the officers' wives, while Elizabeth continued to walk alone, crossing fields with quick steps, leaping over wall steps with impatient energy, and jumping over puddles; finally, with tired ankles, dirty socks, and a face burning from the warmth of the exertion, she found herself in front of the house.
es: In Meryton they parted; the two youngest headed to the home of one of the officers' wives, and Elizabeth continued on her way alone. She crossed field after field at a brisk pace, jumped fences, and navigated puddles impatiently until she finally found herself in front of the house, with soaked ankles, dirty stockings, and a face flushed from the exercise.

en: She was shown into the breakfast parlour, where all but Jane were assembled, and where her appearance created a great deal of surprise.
vi: She was invited into the breakfast room, where everyone was present except Jane. Her appearance caused extreme surprise among everyone.
tr: They took her to the breakfast room; everyone was there except Jane; her arrival caused a great surprise.
es: They took her to the dining room where everyone was gathered except Jane, and where her presence caused great surprise.

en: That she should have walked three miles so early in the day in such dirty weather, and by herself, was almost incredible to ms Hurst and Miss Bingley; and Elizabeth was convinced that they held her in contempt for it.
vi: Mr. Hurst and Miss Bingley could hardly believe that Elizabeth had walked three miles at such an early hour, in muddy weather, and all by herself. Elizabeth believed that they looked down on her.
tr: That she had walked three miles so early, in such bad weather, and alone seemed almost unbelievable to Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley; Elizabeth felt that they looked down on her for it.
es: Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley found it incredible that she had walked three miles alone, so early and in such dreadful weather. Elizabeth was convinced that they looked down on her for it.

en: She was received, however, very politely by them; and in their brother’s manners there was something better than politeness—there was good-humour and kindness.
vi: However, they still treated her very politely, and in the manner of the gentlemen, there was something more than mere politeness.
tr: –Yet they greeted her very politely; their brothers' behavior was better than politeness: there was goodwill and kindness.
es: Nevertheless, they received her with much courtesy, but in the brother's attitude, there was something more than courtesy: there was good humor and kindness.

en: mr Darcy said very little, and mr Hurst nothing at all.
vi: Mr. Darcy spoke very little, and Mr. Hurst almost nothing at all.
tr: –Mr. Darcy spoke very little, Mr. Hurst did not speak at all.
es: Mr. Darcy spoke little and Mr. Hurst nothing at all.

en: The former was divided between admiration of the brilliancy which exercise had given to her complexion and doubt as to the occasion’s justifying her coming so far alone.
vi: Darcy's thoughts were dominated by admiration for the brilliance that the walk had brought to her face, but his mind was filled with doubts about the true reason she had to go so far alone.
tr: Mr. Darcy was torn between admiring the brightness the walk had given her face and doubting whether the situation warranted her coming alone from so far away.
es: The former fluctuated between admiration for the brightness that exercise had given her face and doubt as to whether the occasion justified her having come alone from so far.

en: The latter was thinking only of his breakfast.
vi: Darcy's thoughts were dominated by admiration for the brilliance that the walk had brought to her face, but his mind was filled with doubts about the true reason she had to go so far alone.
tr: Mr. Hurst was only thinking about his breakfast.
es: The latter only thought about his breakfast.

en: Her inquiries after her sister were not very favourably answered.
vi: After inquiring about Jane's condition, but the answer was not very positive, Jane did not sleep well, was having a fever because she was too weak, and was still lying in the bedroom.
tr: The answers she received to her questions about her sister were not encouraging.
es: The questions that Elizabeth asked about her sister were not answered favorably.

en: Miss Bennet had slept ill, and though up, was very feverish, and not well enough to leave her room.
vi: After inquiring about Jane's condition, but the answer was not very positive, Jane did not sleep well, was having a fever because she was too weak, and was still lying in the bedroom.
tr: Miss Bennet had not slept well; she was up but had a high fever and was not well enough to leave her room.
es: Miss Bennet had slept poorly, and although she had gotten up, she had a high fever and was not in a condition to leave her room.

en: Elizabeth was glad to be taken to her immediately; and Jane, who had only been withheld by the fear of giving alarm or inconvenience, from expressing in her note how much she longed for such a visit, was delighted at her entrance.
vi: Elizabeth was delighted to be led into the room to visit her sister. Everyone had hidden Jane's illness for fear of causing panic or trouble, Jane was truly happy to see her step in.
tr: Elizabeth was pleased to be taken to her immediately; Jane, who had not expressed in her letter how much she wanted such a visit because she was afraid of alarming or disturbing her family, was delighted to see her.
es: Elizabeth was glad to be taken to see her immediately; and Jane, who had refrained from expressing in her note how much she desired that visit, for fear of being inconvenient or alarming them, was very happy to see her enter.

en: She was not equal, however, to much conversation; and when Miss Bingley left them together, could attempt little beside expressions of gratitude for the extraordinary kindness she was treated with.
vi: However, she could not talk much. When Miss Bingley stepped outside to let the two sisters talk freely, Jane could do nothing but express her gratitude for the kindness everyone had shown her.
tr: However, she was not in much of a state to talk, and when Miss Bingley left them alone, she could say little more than to express her gratitude for the extraordinary kindness they had shown her.
es: Despite everything, she did not have the spirit for much conversation. When Miss Bingley left them alone, she could only express gratitude for the extraordinary kindness with which she was treated in that house.

en: Elizabeth silently attended her.
vi: Elizabeth silently took care of her sister.
tr: Elizabeth listened to her quietly.
es: Elizabeth attended to her in silence.

en: “The Apothecary came”
vi: When breakfast was over, the host girls played with the two sisters, and Elizabeth began to feel fond of them as she saw their concern and care for Jane.
tr: When breakfast was over, the sisters joined them; seeing how much interest and affection they showed Jane, Elizabeth began to like them.
es: When breakfast was over, the Bingley sisters joined them; and Elizabeth began to find them likable upon seeing the affection and interest they showed for Jane.

en: When breakfast was over, they were joined by the sisters; and Elizabeth began to like them herself, when she saw how much affection and solicitude they showed for Jane.
vi: When breakfast was over, the host girls played with the two sisters, and Elizabeth began to feel fond of them as she saw their concern and care for Jane.
tr: When breakfast was over, the sisters joined them; seeing how much interest and affection they showed Jane, Elizabeth began to like them.
es: When breakfast was over, the Bingley sisters joined them; and Elizabeth began to find them likable upon seeing the affection and interest they showed for Jane.

en: The apothecary came; and having examined his patient, said, as might be supposed, that she had caught a violent cold, and that they must endeavour to get the better of it; advised her to return to bed, and promised her some draughts.
vi: The doctor was also invited to examine Jane, and he stated that she had a severe cold, advising everyone to be practical about the situation, and that Jane needed to rest in bed.
tr: The apothecary arrived; after examining his patient, he said, as expected, that she had caught a severe cold and that they needed to make an effort to overcome it. He advised her to return to bed and promised her some syrup.
es: The doctor came and examined the patient, declaring, as was to be expected, that she had caught a severe cold and that they should do everything possible to take care of her. He recommended that she get back into bed and prescribed some medicines.

en: The advice was followed readily, for the feverish symptoms increased, and her head ached acutely.
vi: The advice was immediately followed, as the fever showed signs of worsening, and on top of that, her head ached terribly.
tr: The advice was immediately followed, as her fever was rising and her head was aching severely.
es: They followed the doctor's instructions to the letter, as the fever had increased and the headache was more severe.

en: Elizabeth did not quit her room for a moment, nor were the other ladies often absent; the gentlemen being out, they had in fact nothing to do elsewhere.
vi: Elizabeth did not want to leave the room, and everyone still came in and out to inquire about her.
tr: Elizabeth did not leave her side for a moment; the other ladies also did not leave her side much: since the gentlemen were outside, they honestly had nothing else to do elsewhere.
es: Elizabeth did not leave the room for a single moment, and the other ladies also did not stay away for long. The gentlemen were outside because they really had nothing to do there.

en: When the clock struck three, Elizabeth felt that she must go, and very unwillingly said so.
vi: When the clock struck three, Elizabeth thought that she needed to leave, although she very much wanted to stay.
tr: When the clock struck three, Elizabeth felt she had to leave and reluctantly said so.
es: When it struck three, Elizabeth realized that she had to leave, and, although very much against her will, she expressed it as such.

en: Miss Bingley offered her the carriage, and she only wanted a little pressing to accept it, when Jane testified such concern at parting with her that Miss Bingley was obliged to convert the offer of the chaise into an invitation to remain at Netherfield for the present.
vi: Miss Bingley suggested that she use the family's carriage. In her heart, Elizabeth hoped that if they just insisted a little, she would agree, and Jane also expressed that she did not want to be separated from her sister. Miss Bingley had to invite Elizabeth to stay at Netherfield for a while, and Elizabeth accepted.
tr: When Miss Bingley offered her the carriage, a little insistence was enough for her to accept, but as Jane was reluctant to part from her at that moment, Miss Bingley had to turn the carriage offer into an invitation to stay at Netherfield for the time being.
es: Miss Bingley offered her the carriage; Elizabeth was only waiting for her to insist a little more to accept it, when Jane expressed her desire to leave with her; therefore, Miss Bingley was obliged to turn the offer of the landau into an invitation for her to stay at Netherfield.

en: Elizabeth most thankfully consented, and a servant was despatched to Longbourn, to acquaint the family with her stay, and bring back a supply of clothes.
vi: Immediately, a servant was sent to Longbourn to deliver the news and bring back some clothes.
tr: Elizabeth accepted gratefully; a servant was sent to Longbourn to inform the family of her stay and to bring back some spare clothes.
es: Elizabeth accepted very gratefully, and they sent a servant to Longbourn to inform the family that she was staying and to send her clothes.

en: CHAPTER VIII.
vi: Chapter 8
tr: Chapter VIII
es: CHAPTER VIII

en: AT five o’clock the two ladies retired to dress, and at half-past six Elizabeth was summoned to dinner.
vi: At five o'clock, Jane and Elizabeth changed clothes to have dinner.
tr: At five o'clock, the two ladies withdrew to dress; at half-past six, Elizabeth was called to dinner.
es: At five o'clock, the ladies retired to dress, and at half-past six, they called Elizabeth to come down for dinner.

en: To the civil inquiries which then poured in, and amongst which she had the pleasure of distinguishing the much superior solicitude of mr Bingley, she could not make a very favourable answer.
vi: Everyone inquired about Jane's health, and Elizabeth noticed that Bingley was genuinely deeply concerned about Jane, but she could not provide a more favorable answer; Jane's condition had not improved at all.
tr: To the polite inquiries that then ensued, among which she could discern with pleasure Mr. Bingley's much closer interest, she could not give a satisfactory answer.
es: She could not respond favorably to the attentive questions they asked her, in which she had the satisfaction of discerning Mr. Bingley's special interest.

en: Jane was by no means better.
vi: Everyone inquired about Jane's health, and Elizabeth noticed that Bingley was genuinely deeply concerned about Jane, but she could not provide a more favorable answer; Jane's condition had not improved at all.
tr: There was no improvement in Jane.
es: Jane had not improved at all; upon hearing this, the sisters repeated three or four times how sorry they were, how awful it was to have a bad cold, and how much they disliked being ill themselves.

en: The sisters, on hearing this, repeated three or four times how much they were grieved, how shocking it was to have a bad cold, and how excessively they disliked being ill themselves; and then thought no more of the matter: and their indifference towards Jane, when not immediately before them, restored Elizabeth to the enjoyment of all her original dislike.
vi: Three or four times, the girls expressed their distress over Jane's illness and mentioned that they felt extremely sad for not being able to help more, and then they no longer paid any attention to the matter. The indifference of the two towards Jane when she was not present made Elizabeth revert to her initial unfavorable impressions of them.
tr: Upon hearing this, the sisters repeatedly expressed how sorry they were, how distressing a severe cold could be, and how much they personally hated being ill, then they forgot about the matter: their indifference to Jane when she was out of sight led Elizabeth to feel her initial displeasure with them once again.
es: After that, they no longer concerned themselves with the matter. Their indifference towards Jane, as soon as she was out of sight, rekindled in Elizabeth the antipathy she had initially felt towards them.

en: Their brother, indeed, was the only one of the party whom she could regard with any complacency.
vi: In fact, Bingley was the only one she had a tolerant idea of.
tr: Her brothers, on the other hand, were the only members of the group who could be thought of with any warmth.
es: In reality, Bingley was the only one in the group whom she viewed with favor.

en: His anxiety for Jane was evident, and his attentions to herself most pleasing; and they prevented her feeling herself so much an intruder as she believed she was considered by the others.
vi: Clearly, he was very worried about Jane. His attitude was very proper, making her feel unintruded upon in her private life unlike others.
tr: His concern for Jane was evident, his attention to herself was gratifying, and these prevented her from feeling like an unwelcome guest as others seemed to see her.
es: His concern for Jane was evident, and the attentions he paid to Elizabeth were what prevented her from feeling like an intruder, which was how the others regarded her.

en: She had very little notice from any but him.
vi: She no longer cared about anyone else but him.
tr: No one else paid much attention to her.
es: Only he seemed to notice her presence.

en: Miss Bingley was engrossed by mr Darcy, her sister scarcely less so; and as for mr Hurst, by whom Elizabeth sat, he was an indolent man, who lived only to eat, drink, and play at cards, who, when he found her prefer a plain dish to a ragout, had nothing to say to her.
vi: Miss Bingley was strongly attracted to Darcy and always stuck close to him. As for Mr. Hurst, sitting next to Elizabeth, he was a lazy person who lived only to eat and play cards, and upon learning that she only liked simple dishes instead of stews, he didn't know what to say to her.
tr: Miss Bingley was captivated by Mr. Darcy, as was her sister; as for Mr. Hurst, who was sitting next to Elizabeth, he was a lazy man who lived only for eating, drinking, and playing cards; upon learning that Elizabeth preferred a plain dish to a French ragout, he never spoke to her again.
es: Miss Bingley was absorbed with Mr. Darcy; her sister, more or less, the same; as for Mr. Hurst, who was seated next to Elizabeth, he was an indolent man who lived only to eat, drink, and play cards. When he learned that Elizabeth preferred a simple dish to a ragout, he had nothing more to talk about with her.

en: When dinner was over, she returned directly to Jane, and Miss Bingley began abusing her as soon as she was out of the room.
vi: When dinner was over, she immediately returned to Jane, and Miss Bingley immediately began to speak ill of her friend.
tr: When the meal was over, he went straight back to Jane, and as soon as he left the room, Miss Bingley started to badmouth him.
es: When dinner was over, Elizabeth immediately returned to Jane. As soon as they left the dining room, Miss Bingley began to criticize her.

en: Her manners were pronounced to be very bad indeed,—a mixture of pride and impertinence: she had no conversation, no style, no taste, no beauty.
vi: Her attitude was truly despicable, a mix of pride and insolence. She remarked that Elizabeth had no conversational skills, no appreciation, and was not beautiful.
tr: She said his behavior was truly awful, a mix of pride and rudeness, and that his conversation was unbearable, lacking style, taste, and charm.
es: Her manners were, indeed, terrible, a mix of pride and impertinence; she had no conversation, no style, no taste, no beauty.

en: ms Hurst thought the same, and added,—
vi: Mrs. Hurst shared the same thoughts and added her own comments:
tr: Mrs. Hurst agreed and immediately added-
es: Mrs. Hurst felt the same and added:

en: “She has nothing, in short, to recommend her, but being an excellent walker.
vi: - In summary, she has nothing worth praising except for her good walking legs.
tr: "In short, the girl has nothing to her name, except for being an amazing walker.
es: ––In summary, the only thing that can be said about her is that she is an excellent walker.

en: I shall never forget her appearance this morning.
vi: I will never forget when she appeared this morning.
tr: I will never forget her state this morning.
es: I will never forget how she appeared this morning.

en: She really looked almost wild.”
vi: She looked really wild.
tr: What wildness that was."
es: She really looked half-wild.

en: “She did indeed, Louisa.
vi: - That's right, Louisa.
tr: "Exactly, Louisa."
es: Indeed, Louisa.

en: I could hardly keep my countenance.
vi: It's hard for you to accept.
tr: "I barely held myself back."
es: When I saw her, I could hardly contain myself.

en: Very nonsensical to come at all!
vi: It's so pointless to come all the way here.
tr: "What do you mean by coming here, for heaven's sake!"
es: What folly to come all the way here!

en: Why must she be scampering about the country, because her sister had a cold?
vi: Why did she have to travel so many miles just because her sister had a cold?
tr: "What does it mean to run around the mountains and fields just because his brother caught a cold?"
es: What need was there for her to run through the fields just because her sister has a cold?

en: Her hair so untidy, so blowzy!”
vi: Her hair was messy and ugly.
tr: "And his hair, how messy, how frizzy!"
es: How she had her hair, so disheveled, so untidy!

en: “Yes, and her petticoat; I hope you saw her petticoat, six inches deep in mud, I am absolutely certain, and the gown which had been let down to hide it not doing its office.”
vi: - Yes, and then there's the petticoat, I wish you could see her petticoat, covered in an inch of mud, with the outer dress let down to cover the mud but failing to do so.
tr: "Yeah, especially her skirt; I hope you've seen her skirt, it's definitely covered in a handspan of mud; and she's let her dress hang down, thinking it will cover the mud.""
es: ––Yes. And the petticoats! If you had seen them! With more than a handspan of mud. And the coat she had put on to cover them, of course, did not fulfill its purpose.

en: “Your picture may be very exact, Louisa,” said Bingley; “but this was all lost upon me.
vi: Bingley said: - You may describe it accurately.
tr: "The picture you painted might be accurate, Louisa," said Bingley; "but these details have escaped my notice.
es: ––Your portrait may be very accurate, Louisa ––said Bingley––, but all of that went unnoticed by me.

en: I thought Miss Elizabeth Bennet looked remarkably well when she came into the room this morning.
vi: But I don't see it that way. I think Miss Elizabeth looked quite nice when she walked in this morning.
tr: This morning, when she entered the room, Miss Elizabeth Bennet looked very beautiful.
es: I think Miss Elizabeth Bennet looked impeccable when she entered the room this morning.

en: Her dirty petticoat quite escaped my notice.”
vi: I didn't notice her petticoat was dirty.
tr: I did not notice her dirty skirt at all."
es: I hardly noticed that her skirts were dirty.

en: “You observed it, mr Darcy, I am sure,” said Miss Bingley; “and I am inclined to think that you would not wish to see your sister make such an exhibition.”
vi: - Mr. Darcy, I am sure you have seen such a situation, so I believe you would never want to see your sister in such a state. – Miss Bingley continued.
tr: "But you must have seen it, Darcy, I'm sure," said Miss Bingley; "you wouldn't like to see your own sister in such a spectacle, would you?"
es: ––I am sure that you did notice, Mr. Darcy ––said Miss Bingley––; and I imagine that you would not like your sister to put on such a display.

en: “Certainly not.”
vi: - Certainly not.
tr: "Of course, he wouldn't go.""
es: ––Of course not.

en: “To walk three miles, or four miles, or five miles, or whatever it is, above her ancles in dirt, and alone, quite alone!
vi: Walking three miles or four miles or any distance, with mud up to your ankles, and going alone!
tr: "Walk three miles, four miles, five miles, however many miles it is, sink into the mud up to your ankles, and do it all alone, by yourself!
es: ––To walk three miles, or four, or five, or however many, with mud up to your ankles and alone, completely alone!

en: what could she mean by it?
vi: What does she mean by that?
tr: What could he mean by this?
es: What could she mean by that?

en: It seems to me to show an abominable sort of conceited independence, a most country-town indifference to decorum.”
vi: To me, it seems like a detestable display of arrogant self-reliance, an indifference to etiquette, characteristic of the most rustic small-town folk.
tr: In my opinion, it’s a lowly kind of self-will, the finest example of peasant uncouthness."
es: To me, that shows an abominable independence and presumption, and an indifference to the decorum typical of country folk.

en: “It shows an affection for her sister that is very pleasing,” said Bingley.
vi: - This shows her concern for her sister, which is very nice. – Bingley defended her.
tr: "It shows his love for his sister; quite a nice thing," said Bingley.
es: ––What it shows is a considerable affection for her sister ––said Bingley.

en: “I am afraid, mr Darcy,” observed Miss Bingley, in a half whisper, “that this adventure has rather affected your admiration of her fine eyes.”
vi: Miss Bingley whispered privately to Darcy: Mr. Darcy, I fear this adventure will affect your admiration for her beautiful eyes.
tr: "I'm afraid, Mr. Darcy," observed Miss Bingley, in a half-whisper, "this adventure has altered your admiration for her beautiful eyes."
es: ––I fear, Mr. Darcy ––observed Miss Bingley in a low voice––, that this adventure may have considerably affected the admiration you felt for her beautiful eyes.

en: “Not at all,” he replied: “they were brightened by the exercise.”
vi: - No, her eyes were radiant because of the trip.
tr: "Not at all," replied Darcy; "her eyes were sparkling from the walk."
es: ––Not at all ––replied Darcy––; the exercise made them even brighter.

en: A short pause followed this speech, and ms Hurst began again,—
vi: After a moment of silence, Mrs. Hurst began again:
tr: This conversation was followed by a brief silence, and Mrs. Hurst began again–
es: This intervention was followed by a brief pause, and Mrs. Hurst began again.

en: “I have an excessive regard for Jane Bennet,—she is really a very sweet girl,—and I wish with all my heart she were well settled.
vi: - I am extremely fond of Jane Bennet; she is a very gentle girl, and with all my sincerity, I wish for her to soon settle down.
tr: "I have great respect for Jane Bennet, she is indeed a very sweet girl; I wholeheartedly wish for her to marry well.
es: ––I hold Jane Bennet in high regard, she is truly a charming girl, and I wish with all my heart that she has much luck.

en: But with such a father and mother, and such low connections, I am afraid there is no chance of it.”
vi: But with such a father and mother, and additionally, low social connections, I fear there is no opportunity for this.
tr: But with such parents, such lowly relatives, I fear she doesn't have much of a chance."
es: But with such parents and relatives of such low class, I fear she will not have many opportunities.

en: “I think I have heard you say that their uncle is an attorney in Meryton?”
vi: - I heard that their uncle practices law in Meryton.
tr: "You must have heard, their brother-in-law is a lawyer in Meryton.""
es: ––I believe I heard you say that his uncle is a lawyer in Meryton.

en: “Yes; and they have another, who lives somewhere near Cheapside.”
vi: - That's right, they have an uncle who lives somewhere near Cheapside.
tr: "Yes, they also have an uncle who lives somewhere near Cheapside."
es: ––Yes, and he has another one who lives somewhere near Cheapside.

en: “That is capital,” added her sister; and they both laughed heartily.
vi: Mrs. Hurst's younger sister interjected: - That's wonderful. Both sisters laughed triumphantly.
tr: "This is amazing," added his sister; they laughed together.
es: ––"Colossal!" added her sister. And the two burst into laughter.

en: “If they had uncles enough to fill all Cheapside,” cried Bingley, “it would not make them one jot less agreeable.”
vi: Bingley exclaimed in surprise: - Even if they had enough uncles or cousins to fill Cheapside, it wouldn't make them any more unpleasant.
tr: "If they had uncles enough to fill all of Cheapside," cried Bingley, "it would not make them one jot less charming.""
es: ––Even if all of Cheapside were full of their uncles ––exclaimed Bingley––, the Bennets would be no less pleasant for it.

en: “But it must very materially lessen their chance of marrying men of any consideration in the world,” replied Darcy.
vi: Darcy replied: - But they will have very little chance of getting a husband with any significant status in society.
tr: "But it greatly reduces her chances of marrying men of any consideration," answered Darcy.
es: ––But it will lessen their chances of marrying men who are of some standing in the world ––replied Darcy.

en: To this speech Bingley made no answer; but his sisters gave it their hearty assent, and indulged their mirth for some time at the expense of their dear friend’s vulgar relations.
vi: Bingley did not reply, but his sisters eagerly agreed and joked for a long time about their friend's humble social connections.
tr: Bingley did not reply to this remark; but his sisters wholeheartedly approved and continued to amuse themselves for a while longer by making fun of their dear friend's uncouth relatives.
es: Bingley made no comment on this observation of Darcy. But his sisters nodded delightedly, and spent some time amusing themselves at the expense of their dear friend's vulgar relatives.

en: With a renewal of tenderness, however, they repaired to her room on leaving the dining-parlour, and sat with her till summoned to coffee.
vi: However, they regained their kindness and gentleness after leaving the dining room, returning to where Jane was lying, and sat with her until they were called for coffee.
tr: Nevertheless, soon they felt a wave of affection and, after leaving the dining room, they went to her room and sat with her until they were called for coffee.
es: However, in an act of renewed kindness, upon leaving the dining room, they went to the sick room and sat with her until they were called for coffee.

en: She was still very poorly, and Elizabeth would not quit her at all, till late in the evening, when she had the comfort of seeing her asleep, and when it appeared to her rather right than pleasant that she should go down stairs herself.
