es: However, Elizabeth was determined not to stay there no matter how much they asked; fearing, on the contrary, to be a nuisance by staying unnecessarily longer, she begged Jane to ask Bingley for the carriage immediately; and, finally, they decided to present their plan to leave Netherfield that very morning and ask to borrow the carriage.

en: The communication excited many professions of concern; and enough was said of wishing them to stay at least till the following day to work on Jane; and till the morrow their going was deferred.
vi: Everyone expressed a desire for them to leave the next day so that Jane could have more time to rest.
tr: The news caused a commotion; it was insisted that they stay at least until the next day to look after Jane; thus, they postponed their departure to the following day.
es: The news caused many expressions of concern; they repeatedly expressed their desire for them to stay at least until the next day, and there was no choice but to delay the departure until then.

en: Miss Bingley was then sorry that she had proposed the delay; for her jealousy and dislike of one sister much exceeded her affection for the other.
vi: The two sisters agreed. And Miss Bingley regretted having made the suggestion to postpone the date, as her jealousy towards Lizzy overshadowed her sympathy for Jane. Mr. Bingley was quite worried about letting the two leave too early, repeatedly persuading Miss Bingley that it was not safe for Jane—that she had not fully recovered.
tr: Then Miss Bingley regretted suggesting the delay, because the jealousy and hatred she felt for one sister surpassed the love she felt for the other.
es: Miss Bingley later regretted having proposed the delay, because the jealousy and antipathy she felt for one of the sisters was far greater than the affection she felt for the other.

en: The master of the house heard with real sorrow that they were to go so soon, and repeatedly tried to persuade Miss Bennet that it would not be safe for her—that she was not enough recovered; but Jane was firm where she felt herself to be right.
vi: But Jane was determined when she believed she was right.
tr: The master of the house was truly saddened to hear that they would leave so soon and often tried to convince Jane that it would not be safe for her to go frequently, that she had not yet recovered enough; but when Jane knew she was right, she was determined.
es: The master of the house was very saddened to learn that they were going to leave so soon, and he persistently tried to convince Jane that it would not be good for her, because she was not yet fully recovered; but Jane was firm when she knew she was acting as she should.

en: To mr Darcy it was welcome intelligence: Elizabeth had been at Netherfield long enough.
vi: For Darcy, this was rather good news – Elizabeth had stayed too long.
tr: Mr. Darcy received the news positively – Elizabeth had stayed at Netherfield long enough.
es: The news seemed good to Darcy. Elizabeth had already been at Netherfield for quite some time.

en: She attracted him more than he liked; and Miss Bingley was uncivil to her and more teasing than usual to himself.
vi: And she attracted him more than he wanted, while Miss Bingley had been impolite to her and teased him more than usual.
tr: She had attracted him more than he could accept – and Miss Bingley was treating Elizabeth poorly, which was also greatly annoying Darcy.
es: She attracted him more than he wanted, and Miss Bingley was rude to her and more annoying to him than ever.

en: He wisely resolved to be particularly careful that no sign of admiration should now escape him—nothing that could elevate her with the hope of influencing his felicity; sensible that, if such an idea had been suggested, his behaviour during the last day must have material weight in confirming or crushing it.
vi: He had wisely resolved that he would not show any signs of affection towards her, and would not create any situation that might lead her to hope she could influence his happiness. Feeling that if this idea were to be revealed, his actions on the last day should be strong enough to either confirm or dispel it.
tr: Darcy was now determined not to show any signs of closeness that might lead Elizabeth to hope that he could affect her happiness; he was aware that even if such an impression had been made, his behavior throughout that last day would have the weight to either confirm or dispel this impression.
es: He resolved to be especially careful not to let any sign of admiration escape him, nor anything that might make Elizabeth believe she had any influence on his happiness. Aware that he might have suggested such an idea, his behavior during the last day had to be decisive in either confirming it or removing it from her mind.

en: Steady to his purpose, he scarcely spoke ten words to her through the whole of Saturday: and though they were at one time left by themselves for half an hour, he adhered most conscientiously to his book, and would not even look at her.
vi: Having decided to pursue his goal, he exchanged only a few words with her throughout Saturday. Even though there were times when they were alone together for half an hour, he focused on reading and did not look at her.
tr: He remained committed to his purpose and did not speak more than ten words to her all Saturday; at one point, they were alone for half an hour, but he did not even lift his head from his book to look at her.
es: Firm in his purpose, he barely spoke ten words to her all Saturday, and despite being left alone for half an hour, he immersed himself in his book and did not even look at her.

en: On Sunday, after morning service, the separation, so agreeable to almost all, took place.
vi: On Sunday, they said goodbye to each other, almost everyone had joy in their hearts.
tr: On Sunday, after the morning prayer, the much-desired departure that almost everyone wanted took place.
es: On Sunday, after the morning religious service, the separation, so pleasant for almost everyone, took place.

en: Miss Bingley’s civility to Elizabeth increased at last very rapidly, as well as her affection for Jane; and when they parted, after assuring the latter of the pleasure it would always give her to see her either at Longbourn or Netherfield, and embracing her most tenderly, she even shook hands with the former.
vi: Miss Bingley quickly treated Elizabeth politely and showed affection towards Jane. She expressed a desire to see Jane again at Longbourn or Netherfield, then gently hugged Jane and shook hands with Elizabeth.
tr: Miss Bingley's kindness towards Elizabeth and her affection for Jane suddenly increased; as they were parting, after saying that she would always be delighted to see Jane at Longbourn or Netherfield and embracing her warmly, she even shook hands with Elizabeth.
es: Miss Bingley's courtesy towards Elizabeth increased rapidly at the last moment, as did her affection for Jane. Upon saying goodbye, after assuring the latter of the pleasure it would always give her to see her both at Longbourn and at Netherfield and giving her a tender hug, she only shook hands with the former.

en: Elizabeth took leave of the whole party in the liveliest spirits.
vi: As for Elizabeth, she felt the most uplifted in spirit.
tr: Elizabeth bid farewell to everyone with great joy.
es: Elizabeth bid farewell to everyone with a more cheerful spirit than ever.

en: They were not welcomed home very cordially by their mother.
vi: Mrs. Bennet did not warmly welcome her two daughters.
tr: Their mother did not welcome them warmly at home.
es: The mother was not very cordial in welcoming them.

en: ms Bennet wondered at their coming, and thought them very wrong to give so much trouble, and was sure Jane would have caught cold again.
vi: She was puzzled to see them return, thinking they had made a wrong decision and believing that it would cause Jane to fall ill again.
tr: Mrs. Bennet was surprised by their arrival and was angry with them for causing so much trouble; she was sure that Jane would catch a cold again.
es: She did not understand why they had returned so soon and told them that they were very wrong to cause her such distress; she was sure that Jane had caught a cold again.

en: But their father, though very laconic in his expressions of pleasure, was really glad to see them; he had felt their importance in the family circle.
vi: But their father, although he only briefly expressed his joy, was genuinely delighted to see them again. He felt that the two daughters truly played a very important role in the family.
tr: –But their father was genuinely happy to see them, even though his expressions of joy were brief and to the point; he had felt the importance of his daughters within the family.
es: But the father, although very laconic in expressing joy, was truly happy to see them. He had realized the importance they had in the family circle.

en: The evening conversation, when they were all assembled, had lost much of its animation, and almost all its sense, by the absence of Jane and Elizabeth.
vi: In their absence, dinner conversations were much less lively and almost devoid of emotion.
tr: When they were together, the evening conversation lost most of its cheerfulness and almost all of its meaning without Jane and Elizabeth.
es: The evening gatherings, when everyone got together, had lost their animation and even their meaning with the absence of Jane and Elizabeth.

en: They found Mary, as usual, deep in the study of thorough bass and human nature; and had some new extracts to admire and some new observations of threadbare morality to listen to.
vi: They noticed that Mary, as usual, was immersing herself in understanding human nature with some old-fashioned moral comments that she wanted everyone to hear.
tr: They found Mary, as usual, immersed in her studies of harmony and human nature; she had gathered admirable new quotes and insightful new observations.
es: They found Mary, as usual, deeply engrossed in the profound study of human nature; they had to admire her new summaries and listen to the observations she had recently made about a very unconvincing morality.

en: Catherine and Lydia had information for them of a different sort.
vi: Catherine and Lydia had information on a different matter; since the previous Wednesday, many things had happened with the regiment, some officers had dined with their uncle, a private had been punished, and there was news that Colonel Foster was going to get married.
tr: However, Catherine and Lydia had different kinds of news to share with them.
es: What Catherine and Lydia had to tell them was very different.

en: Much had been done, and much had been said in the regiment since the preceding Wednesday; several of the officers had dined lately with their uncle; a private had been flogged; and it had actually been hinted that Colonel Forster was going to be married.
vi: Catherine and Lydia had information on a different matter; since the previous Wednesday, many things had happened with the regiment, some officers had dined with their uncle, a private had been punished, and there was news that Colonel Foster was going to get married.
tr: Since the previous Wednesday, much had been done and said in the regiment; a few officers had recently dined with their uncle, a soldier had been whipped, and it was openly talked about that Colonel Forster was going to get married.
es: Many things had been done and said in the regiment since the previous Wednesday; several officers had recently dined with their uncle, a soldier had been flogged, and there was a rumor that Colonel Forster was going to get married.

en: CHAPTER XIII
vi: Chapter 13
tr: Chapter XIII
es: CHAPTER XIII

en: “I hope, my dear,” said mr Bennet to his wife, as they were at breakfast the next morning, “that you have ordered a good dinner to-day, because I have reason to expect an addition to our family party.”
vi: When the whole family was having breakfast together, Mr. Bennet said to his wife: - I hope you will prepare a delicious dinner tonight, as we will have guests visiting.
tr: "I hope, my dear," said Mr. Bennet to his wife, as they were having breakfast the next morning, "that you have ordered a good dinner today, for I have reasons to expect an addition to our family circle."
es: ––I hope, my dear ––Mr. Bennet said to his wife while they were having breakfast the next morning––, that you have prepared a good meal, because I have reason to believe that one more will join us at our table today.

en: “Who do you mean, my dear?
vi: - What do you mean?
tr: "Who do you mean, my dear?
es: ––Who are you referring to, dear?

en: I know of nobody that is coming, I am sure, unless Charlotte Lucas should happen to call in; and I hope my dinners are good enough for her.
vi: I haven't heard anyone will come, except for Charlotte Lucas who might unexpectedly visit.
tr: There is no one coming; perhaps Charlotte Lucas might drop by – I hope my table is good enough for her.
es: I have no news of anyone coming, unless Charlotte Lucas decides to visit us, and I think my meals are good enough for her.

en: I do not believe she often sees such at home.”
vi: But I hope our family's food is good enough to entertain her, I don't think she often gets to enjoy such dishes at home.
tr: She doesn't get to see such things often even in her own home."
es: I don't believe they are better at her house.

en: “The person of whom I speak is a gentleman and a stranger.”
vi: - The person I want to talk about is a strange man.
tr: "The person I mentioned is a man, moreover a foreigner.""
es: ––The person I am talking about is a gentleman and a stranger.

en: ms Bennet’s eyes sparkled.
vi: Mrs. Bennet's eyes lit up:
tr: Mrs. Bennet's eyes sparkled.
es: Mrs. Bennet's eyes sparkled like sparks.

en: “A gentleman and a stranger!
vi: - A strange man?
tr: "A man, and a stranger at that!
es: ––A gentleman and a stranger?

en: It is mr Bingley, I am sure.
vi: I believe you are referring to Mr. Bingley.
tr: It must be Mr. Bingley!
es: It's Mr. Bingley, no doubt.

en: Why, Jane—you never dropped a word of this—you sly thing!
vi: Why, Jane? You never tell me anything!
tr: Oh Jane, why didn't you tell me, you naughty girl!
es: Why do you never say a word about these things, Jane? How sly you are!

en: Well, I am sure I shall be extremely glad to see mr Bingley.
vi: I would certainly be very happy to see him again.
tr: Honestly, I will be very pleased to see Mr. Bingley.
es: Well, I will be very glad to see him.

en: But—good Lord!
vi: But, oh dear, what bad luck.
tr: But –Oh dear!
es: But, my God, what bad luck!

en: how unlucky!
vi: But, oh dear, what bad luck.
tr: What luck!
es: But, my God, what bad luck!

en: there is not a bit of fish to be got to-day.
vi: There's no fish left today!
tr: We have no fish today.
es: Today, it's impossible to get even a bit of fish.

en: Lydia, my love, ring the bell.
vi: Lydia, ring the bell.
tr: Lydia, darling, ring the bell –I need to speak with Hill immediately."
es: Lydia, dear, ring the bell; I need to speak with Hill immediately.

en: I must speak to Hill this moment.”
vi: I need to see Hill right now.
tr: Lydia, darling, ring the bell –I need to speak with Hill immediately."
es: Lydia, dear, ring the bell; I need to speak with Hill immediately.

en: “It is not mr Bingley,” said her husband; “it is a person whom I never saw in the whole course of my life.”
vi: The husband said: - It is not Mr. Bingley. This is someone whom I have never met in my life.
tr: "Not Mr. Bingley," said her husband; "someone I have never seen in my life.""
es: ––It is not Mr. Bingley ––said her husband––; it is a person I have never seen in my life.

en: This roused a general astonishment; and he had the pleasure of being eagerly questioned by his wife and five daughters at once.
vi: He made everyone extremely surprised, and seemed delighted to see his wife and five daughters anxiously asking about this man.
tr: This statement caused general astonishment; Mr. Bennet enjoyed the pleasure of being besieged by his wife and five daughters at the same time.
es: These words aroused general astonishment; and he had the pleasure of being anxiously questioned by his wife and his five daughters at once.

en: After amusing himself some time with their curiosity, he thus explained:—“About a month ago I received this letter, and about a fortnight ago I answered it; for I thought it a case of some delicacy, and requiring early attention.
vi: After amusing himself for a while with his family's curiosity, he calmly explained: - About a month ago, I received this letter, and two weeks ago I replied, because I thought this was a delicate matter, so I needed to pay attention from the beginning.
tr: After amusing himself with their curiosity for a while, he made the explanation– "I received this letter about a month ago; I replied about fifteen days ago, because I thought it was a delicate matter that needed to be handled carefully."
es: After having some fun, piquing their curiosity, he explained to them: ––A month ago I received this letter, and I replied to it about fifteen days ago, because I thought it was a very delicate matter and needed time to reflect.

en: It is from my cousin, mr Collins, who, when I am dead, may turn you all out of this house as soon as he pleases.”
vi: This is a letter from Mr. Collins, who, after I die, can evict everyone from this house if he wants to.
tr: "It is from my nephew Mr. Collins, you know, the man who can throw you all out of this house whenever he wants after I die.""
es: It is from my cousin, Mr. Collins, who, when I die, can throw you out of this house whenever he pleases.

en: “Oh, my dear,” cried his wife, “I cannot bear to hear that mentioned.
vi: The wife exclaimed in horror: - Oh! I can't bear to hear about this.
tr: "Oh my God," cried his wife, "I can't even bear to hear you talk about him.
es: ––Oh, dear! ––lamented his wife––. I can't bear to hear about the subject.

en: Pray do not talk of that odious man.
vi: Please don't say anything about that disgusting fellow.
tr: Please don't mention that disgusting man.
es: Don't mention that hateful man.

en: I do think it is the hardest thing in the world, that your estate should be entailed away from your own children; and I am sure, if I had been you, I should have tried long ago to do something or other about it.”
vi: I think this is the most absurd thing in the world, your property being torn away from our children, and if I were you, I would have done something about it a long time ago.
tr: The most unbearable thing in the world is that his inheritance is mortgaged against his own children; if I were in his place, I would have definitely done something by now, one way or another."
es: It's the worst thing that can happen in the world, that your daughters can't inherit your property. If I were you, I would have done something about it a long time ago.

en: Jane and Elizabeth attempted to explain to her the nature of an entail.
vi: Jane and Elizabeth tried to explain to her the order of inheritance.
tr: They tried to explain to Jane and Elizabeth what an entailment was.
es: Jane and Elizabeth tried to explain to her why the inheritance did not belong to them.

en: They had often attempted it before: but it was a subject on which ms Bennet was beyond the reach of reason; and she continued to rail bitterly against the cruelty of settling an estate away from a family of five daughters, in favour of a man whom nobody cared anything about.
vi: The two had tried to explain many times before, but this was beyond her comprehension. She continued to rail against the cruelty of taking away the property of a family with five daughters to give it to a man who no one cared about.
tr: They had tried before, but it was a subject that Mrs. Bennet could not grasp, and once again she bitterly lamented the cruelty of taking a house away from a family with five daughters and giving it to a man whom no one knew.
es: They had tried many times, but it was a topic that made their mother completely lose her reason; and she continued to complain bitterly about the cruelty of disinheriting a family of five daughters in favor of a man who meant nothing to any of them.

en: “It certainly is a most iniquitous affair,” said mr Bennet; “and nothing can clear mr Collins from the guilt of inheriting Longbourn.
vi: Mr. Bennet admitted: - This is truly an unreasonable issue, nothing can erase Mr. Collins' guilt in inheriting Longbourn.
tr: "Of course, it is an unjust situation," said Mr. Bennet, "and nothing can cover the shame of Mr. Collins inheriting Longbourn.
es: ––Certainly, it is a very unfair matter ––said Mr. Bennet––, and there is nothing that can prove Mr. Collins' guilt for inheriting Longbourn.

en: But if you will listen to his letter, you may, perhaps, be a little softened by his manner of expressing himself.”
vi: But if you are willing to listen to me read this letter, you might feel relieved by the way he expresses himself.
tr: But if you listen to his letter, perhaps his way of expressing himself might soften you."
es: But if you listen to his letter, his way of expressing himself might calm you a bit.

en: “No, that I am sure I shall not: and I think it was very impertinent of him to write to you at all, and very hypocritical.
vi: - No, I will not feel relieved at all. I think he is really insolent to dare to write a letter to you, and hypocritical as well.
tr: "No, I don't want to; I think it's inappropriate, even hypocritical, for him to write to you.
es: ––No, I won't listen to her; and besides, I find it impertinent that she writes to you, and hypocritical.

en: I hate such false friends.
vi: I absolutely hate such deceitful people.
tr: I hate such fake friends.
es: I can't stand those false friends.

en: Why could not he keep on quarrelling with you, as his father did before him?”
vi: Why doesn't he continue the dispute with you like his father did before?
tr: Why doesn't he fight with you like his father does?"
es: Why doesn't she continue litigating with you like her father did?

en: “Why, indeed, he does seem to have had some filial scruples on that head, as you will hear.”
vi: - Oh right, why does he seem to have some hesitation about familial relationships, as you will hear below:
tr: "There seems to be something like a feeling of being adopted; listen.""
es: ––Because it seems to have some pangs of conscience, as you are about to hear:

en: “Hunsford, near Westerham, Kent, 15th October.
vi: "Huntsford, Westerham, Kent" October 15
tr: "Hunsford, near Westerham, Kent, October 15.
es: Hunsford, near Westerham, Kent, October 15.

en: “Dear Sir,
vi: Dear Uncle
tr: Dear Sir,
es: Dear Sir,

en: “The disagreement subsisting between yourself and my late honoured father always gave me much uneasiness; and, since I have had the misfortune to lose him, I have frequently wished to heal the breach: but, for some time, I was kept back by my own doubts, fearing lest it might seem disrespectful to his memory for me to be on good terms with anyone with whom it had always pleased him to be at variance.”—
vi: The long-standing discord between you and my esteemed father has always made me feel uneasy, so since my father's unfortunate passing, I have often wanted to mend this rift. However, for a time I thought it would be disrespectful to my father's memory if I were to have a conciliatory relationship with anyone who had been in conflict with him.
tr: The conflict between you and my late father has always troubled me; since I unfortunately lost my father, I have wanted to mend the disagreement many times; but for a while my doubts held me back, fearing that getting along well with someone he was quarrelsome with might seem disrespectful to his memory.-
es: The ongoing disagreement between you and my recently deceased father has always made me feel somewhat uneasy, and since I had the misfortune of losing him, I have wished to settle the matter. However, for some time, I was held back by doubts, fearing it would be disrespectful to his memory to make amends with someone he was always at odds with, so soon after his death.

en: ‘There, ms Bennet.’—“My mind, however, is now made up on the subject; for, having received ordination at Easter, I have been so fortunate as to be distinguished by the patronage of the Right Honourable Lady Catherine de Bourgh, widow of Sir Lewis de Bourgh, whose bounty and beneficence has preferred me to the valuable rectory of this parish, where it shall be my earnest endeavour to demean myself with grateful respect towards her Ladyship, and be ever ready to perform those rites and ceremonies which are instituted by the Church of England.
vi: Nevertheless, I have now made a decision on this matter because, after being ordained last Easter, I was particularly fortunate to be appointed by the council of Lady Catherine de Bourgh, widow of Sir Lewis de Bourgh, with generosity and kindness, to the precious position of vicar of this parish. Here, I will strive with all my might to act with grateful reverence towards the Lady and be ready to perform the rites of the Church.
tr: [Oh, Mrs. Bennet.] –However, I have made my decision regarding the matter; when I received my ordination certificate at Easter, I was fortunate to be taken under the patronage of the widow of Sir Lewis de Bourgh, the Honorable Lady Catherine de Bourgh; thanks to her generosity and benevolence, I was appointed as the vicar of that village; now, with all my gratitude, I will dedicate myself to the service of Her Ladyship and organize the rites and ceremonies prescribed by the Church of England.
es: But now I have made a decision on the matter, having been ordained at Easter, as I have been fortunate enough to be distinguished with the patronage of the very honorable Lady Catherine de Bourgh, widow of Sir Lewis de Bourgh, whose generosity and beneficence have chosen me to take charge of the esteemed rectory of her parish, where my firmest purpose will be to serve Her Ladyship with gratitude and respect, and to always be ready to perform the rites and ceremonies instituted by the Church of England.

en: As a clergyman, moreover, I feel it my duty to promote and establish the blessing of peace in all families within the reach of my influence; and on these grounds I flatter myself that my present overtures of good-will are highly commendable, and that the circumstance of my being next in the entail of Longbourn estate will be kindly overlooked on your side, and not lead you to reject the offered olive branch.
vi: Furthermore, in my capacity as a clergyman, I feel it is my duty to promote and establish the grace of peace to all families within my sphere of influence. On this basis, I believe that opening my heart is very appropriate, and given my position as the heir apparent to the estate at Longbourn, which will be overlooked by the family, I hope you will not refuse my olive branch.
tr: Additionally, as a clergyman, I aim to protect and strengthen the peace of all the families within my sphere of influence; therefore, I hope you will see this goodwill initiative as quite positive, overlook the fact that I am the first heir to the mortgage on Longbourn estate, and not reject the olive branch I extend.
es: Moreover, as a clergyman, I believe it is my duty to promote and establish the blessing of peace in all the families within my influence; and based on this, I hope that my present intention of goodwill will be well received, and that the fact that I am the heir to Longbourn will be forgotten by you and will not lead you to reject the olive branch I offer.

en: I cannot be otherwise than concerned at being the means of injuring your amiable daughters, and beg leave to apologize for it, as well as to assure you of my readiness to make them every possible amends; but of this hereafter.
vi: I cannot be at ease because I have hurt the dear ladies of the house, and I also wish to apologize for this, as well as to ask you to understand that I am willing to reconcile with them – but I will mention this matter later.
tr: It would distress me to be considered a cause of harm to your dear daughters; with your permission, I want you to know that I am ready to apologize and make amends for this, –but we will discuss this later.
es: I cannot help but be concerned about causing harm to your pleasant daughters, and I beg to be excused for this. I also want to attest to my good disposition to make all possible amends from now on.

en: If you should have no objection to receive me into your house, I propose myself the satisfaction of waiting on you and your family, Monday, November 18th, by four o’clock, and shall probably trespass on your hospitality till the Saturday se’nnight following, which I can do without any inconvenience, as Lady Catherine is far from objecting to my occasional absence on a Sunday, provided that some other clergyman is engaged to do the duty of the day.
vi: If you do not mind welcoming me into your home, I would like to visit the family on Monday, November 10th, at 4 PM. I will impose on the family's hospitality until the following Saturday, and there will be no hindrance to work, as Lady Catherine is willing to allow me to be absent on Sunday, provided another clergyman takes over the duties.
tr: If you have no objection to accepting me into your home, I wish to visit you and your family on Monday, November 18th around four o'clock and possibly seek your hospitality until the following Saturday, as Lady Catherine does not object to my occasional absences provided another clergyman handles the daily duties, bless her.
es: If you do not object to receiving me in your home, I hope to have the satisfaction of visiting you and your family on Monday, November 18th at four o'clock, and I may take advantage of your hospitality until the following Saturday, which I can do without any inconvenience, as Lady Catherine de Bourgh will not object and would not even disapprove of my being absent fortuitously on Sunday, as long as there is another clergyman ready to fulfill the duties of that day.

en: I remain, dear sir, with respectful compliments to your lady and daughters, your well-wisher and friend,
vi: With goodwill and affection, I respectfully send my regards to your wife and the ladies.
tr: –I extend my deepest respects to you and your daughters, sir. Your well-wisher and friend,
es: I send affectionate regards to your wife and daughters, your friend who wishes you all the best,

en: “William Collins.”
vi: William Collins
tr: William Collins."
es: William Collins.

en: “At four o’clock, therefore, we may expect this peace-making gentleman,” said mr Bennet, as he folded up the letter.
vi: Mr. Bennet said, as he folded the letter: - So, at 4 o'clock, we will welcome this peace envoy.
tr: "So we can expect this peace-loving gentleman at four o'clock," said Mr. Bennet, folding the letter.
es: ––Therefore, at four o'clock it is possible that this conciliatory gentleman will appear ––said Mr. Bennet while folding the letter––.

en: “He seems to be a most conscientious and polite young man, upon my word; and, I doubt not, will prove a valuable acquaintance, especially if Lady Catherine should be so indulgent as to let him come to us again.”
vi: It seems that he is a conscientious and courteous person, so I think this will be a good relationship, especially if the Lady allows him to visit again.
tr: "He truly seems like a conscientious and kind young man; I have no doubt he will be a valuable relative, especially if Lady Catherine allows him to visit us again."
es: He seems to be a well-mannered and attentive young man; I have no doubt that his friendship will be valuable to us, especially if Lady Catherine is indulgent enough to allow him to come visit us.

en: “There is some sense in what he says about the girls, however; and, if he is disposed to make them any amends, I shall not be the person to discourage him.”
vi: - There is some meaning when he talks about the girls, and if he is willing to make peace like that, then I will not stop him.
tr: "There is a reasonable tone in his words about the girls; if he wants to make amends with the girls, I won't stand in his way.""
es: ––You see, it seems that what he says about our daughters makes sense. If he is willing to make amends, I won't be the one to discourage him.

en: “Though it is difficult,” said Jane, “to guess in what way he can mean to make us the atonement he thinks our due, the wish is certainly to his credit.”
vi: Jane joined: - Although it is difficult to predict how he will make amends, he earned good points for expressing his intentions.
tr: "It's hard to guess how he intends to make the correction he thinks we deserve," said Jane, "but even this desire earns him points."
es: ––Although it is difficult ––observed Jane–– to guess what he means by that reparation he thinks we deserve, we must give credit to his intentions.

en: Elizabeth was chiefly struck with his extraordinary deference for Lady Catherine, and his kind intention of christening, marrying, and burying his parishioners whenever it were required.
vi: Elizabeth was particularly impressed with his exceptional respect for Lady Catherine, and the good ideas in the rituals of baptism, weddings, and burials for parishioners whenever requested.
tr: Elizabeth was particularly impressed by his extraordinary respect for Lady Catherine and his intention to baptize, marry, and bury the villagers when necessary.
es: Elizabeth was greatly impressed by that extraordinary deference towards Lady Catherine and that earnest intention to baptize, marry, and bury his parishioners whenever necessary.

en: “He must be an oddity, I think,” said she.
vi: She said: - I think he seems strange.
tr: "There must be something strange about the man," he said.
es: ––It must be a bit strange ––he said––.

en: “I cannot make him out.
vi: I can't figure out what kind of person he is.
tr: "I can't understand him.
es: I can't imagine it.

en: There is something very pompous in his style.
vi: He seems somewhat ostentatious, and what did he mean by apologizing for being the heir by order?
tr: –There is something too fancy in his manner.
es: His style is somewhat pompous.

en: And what can he mean by apologizing for being next in the entail?
vi: He seems somewhat ostentatious, and what did he mean by apologizing for being the heir by order?
tr: –What does it mean to apologize for being the first during the inheritance?
es: And what does he mean by apologizing for being the heir of Longbourn?

en: We cannot suppose he would help it, if he could.
vi: I can't expect him to help, even if he could.
tr: –Even if he could, we can't expect him to do anything.
es: I suppose he wouldn't try to avoid it, if he could.

en: Can he be a sensible man, sir?”
vi: Is he a reasonable person, father?
tr: –Do you think he could be a reasonable man, sir?"
es: Dad, could he be a cunning man?

en: “No, my dear; I think not.
vi: - I don't think so.
tr: "No, darling; I don't think so.
es: ––No, dear, I don't think so.

en: I have great hopes of finding him quite the reverse.
vi: I very much hope to meet someone who contradicts my thoughts.
tr: I have high hopes that the opposite is true.
es: I have great hopes that it will be the opposite.

en: There is a mixture of servility and self-importance in his letter which promises well.
vi: His letter seems both humble and arrogant, which says something.
tr: There is something both servile and boastful in his letter, which is quite meaningful.
es: There is a mixture of servility and presumption in his letter that confirms it.

en: I am impatient to see him.”
vi: I am very eager to meet him.
tr: I can't wait to see him."
es: I am eager to see him.

en: “In point of composition,” said Mary, “his letter does not seem defective.
vi: Mary commented: - Regarding the writing style, the letter has no flaws.
tr: "In terms of writing," said Mary, "the letter doesn't seem flawed.
es: ––As for the writing ––said Mary––, your letter doesn't seem to have any flaws.

en: The idea of the olive branch perhaps is not wholly new, yet I think it is well expressed.”
vi: The idea of the olive branch is not new, but I think he expressed it well.
tr: The olive branch idea may not be very new, but I think it is well expressed."
es: The olive branch part isn't very original, but even so, it is well expressed.

en: To Catherine and Lydia neither the letter nor its writer were in any degree interesting.
vi: For Lydia and Catherine, neither the letter nor the letter writer was of any interest.
tr: The letter and its author held no interest for Catherine and Lydia.
es: Catherine and Lydia were not in the least interested in either the letter or its author.

en: It was next to impossible that their cousin should come in a scarlet coat, and it was now some weeks since they had received pleasure from the society of a man in any other colour.
vi: Their cousin could not come in a red coat, and the period during which they were interested in people wearing other colors had passed several weeks ago.
tr: It was almost impossible for their cousins to arrive in a red coat, and they had not enjoyed the presence of a man in any other color for several weeks.
es: It was practically impossible for their cousin to show up in a scarlet coat, and it had been a few weeks since they had felt any fondness for any man dressed in another color.

en: As for their mother, mr Collins’s letter had done away much of her ill-will, and she was preparing to see him with a degree of composure which astonished her husband and daughters.
vi: As for their mother, the letter had somewhat alleviated her aversion; she prepared to meet him with a calmness that surprised both her husband and her daughters.
tr: As for their mother, Mr. Collins' letter had taken away most of her bad thoughts, and she was preparing to receive the man with a calmness that surprised her husband and daughters.
es: As for their mother, Mr. Collins's letter had extinguished her resentment, and she was prepared to receive him with such moderation that it would leave her husband and daughters perplexed.

en: mr Collins was punctual to his time, and was received with great politeness by the whole family.
vi: Mr. Collins arrived on time as promised and was received very politely by the whole family.
tr: Mr. Collins adhered to the given time; he was received very politely by the whole family.
es: Mr. Collins arrived punctually at the announced time and was received with great courtesy by the whole family.

en: mr Bennet indeed said little; but the ladies were ready enough to talk, and mr Collins seemed neither in need of encouragement, nor inclined to be silent himself.
vi: Mr. Bennet spoke very little, but the daughters were always ready to converse; as for Mr. Collins, he neither needed encouragement to speak nor restraint to remain silent.
tr: Mr. Bennet spoke little; but the ladies were quite ready to talk; Mr. Collins, on the other hand, seemed neither to need encouragement nor to have any inclination to sit quietly.
es: Mr. Bennet spoke little, but the ladies were very willing to talk, and Mr. Collins did not seem to need encouragement nor was he fond of silence.

en: He was a tall, heavy-looking young man of five-and-twenty.
vi: He was quite tall and rather heavyset at the age of twenty-five.
tr: He was a twenty-five-year-old man, tall and heavy-looking.
es: He was a man of twenty-five years of age, tall, with a deep gaze, a grave and static air, and ceremonious manners.

en: His air was grave and stately, and his manners were very formal.
vi: His demeanor was serious and formal, complemented by a very proper attitude.
tr: He had a serious and dignified air; his movements were very formal.
es: He was a man of twenty-five years of age, tall, with a deep gaze, a grave and static air, and ceremonious manners.

en: He had not been long seated before he complimented ms Bennet on having so fine a family of daughters, said he had heard much of their beauty, but that, in this instance, fame had fallen short of the truth; and added, that he did not doubt her seeing them all in due time well disposed of in marriage.
vi: Soon after sitting down, he praised Mrs. Bennet for having such a wonderful family with five daughters, and said that he had heard much about them, but in this case, the reputation fell far short of the reality. He added that he was certain that before long, all the daughters would be happily settled.
tr: He had not been seated long before he complimented Mrs. Bennet on her daughters; he said he had heard much about their beauty, but now saw that their reputation fell short of the reality, and added that he had no doubt they would all make good marriages in due time.
es: Shortly after sitting down, he congratulated Mrs. Bennet on having such beautiful daughters; he said he had heard much about their beauty, but that the fame fell short compared to reality; and he added that he did not doubt he would see them all married in due time.

en: This gallantry was not much to the taste of some of his hearers; but ms Bennet, who quarrelled with no compliments, answered most readily,—
vi: Some of the girls did not much like this flattery, but Mrs. Bennet, who enjoyed arguing but lacked for compliments, responded immediately:
tr: This compliment did not quite suit the taste of some of the listeners; but Mrs. Bennet, who thought there was no such thing as a bad compliment, immediately responded.
es: The gallantry was not to the liking of all the listeners; but Mrs. Bennet, who was not one for formalities, replied immediately:

en: “You are very kind, sir, I am sure; and I wish with all my heart it may prove so; for else they will be destitute enough.
vi: - You are truly kind, with all my heart I hope that it will come true, otherwise their fate will be very miserable.
tr: "You are very kind, believe me; I hope it turns out that way, because otherwise they will be left homeless."
es: ––You are very kind, and I sincerely hope that it is as you say, because otherwise the poor ones would be quite helpless, given the strange way things are arranged.

en: Things are settled so oddly.”
vi: Life often creates many strange circumstances.
tr: Things are going very strangely.""
es: ––You are very kind, and I sincerely hope that it is as you say, because otherwise the poor ones would be quite helpless, given the strange way things are arranged.

en: “You allude, perhaps, to the entail of this estate.”
vi: - Maybe she was referring to inheritance by order.
tr: "I suppose you are referring to the mortgage on this property.""
es: ––Are you perhaps referring to the inheritance of this property?

en: “Ah, sir, I do indeed.
vi: - Ah! That's right!
tr: "Ah sir, of course.
es: ––Ah! Indeed, sir.

en: It is a grievous affair to my poor girls, you must confess.
vi: That is the matter that causes me to worry, I have to say so.
tr: You must understand that this is a great torment for my daughters.
es: You cannot deny that it is a very distressing matter for my daughters.

en: Not that I mean to find fault with you, for such things, I know, are all chance in this world.
vi: I do not mean to imply that you are at fault, because I know that such things are merely by chance.
tr: Not that I find fault with you, because I know that these matters are a matter of luck in this world.
es: I do not blame you; you know that in this world these things are just a matter of luck.

en: There is no knowing how estates will go when once they come to be entailed.”
vi: We cannot know where our fortune will go when it is inherited in order.
tr: I don't understand how an inheritance can be mortgaged away."
es: No one has any notion of what will happen with the properties once they have to be inherited.

en: “I am very sensible, madam, of the hardship to my fair cousins, and could say much on the subject, but that I am cautious of appearing forward and precipitate.
vi: - Madam, I deeply sympathize with the situation of your cousins and could say much more about this, only because I do not want to appear too eager and rash.
tr: "I am aware of the difficulty I have created for my dear cousins, madam, and I have much to say on the matter, but I do not wish to appear hasty and rushed.
es: ––I deeply regret the misfortune of your lovely daughters; but I will be cautious, I do not want to rush and seem hasty.

en: But I can assure the young ladies that I come prepared to admire them.
vi: But I can say that you can rest assured, I always care for them with a loving heart.
tr: But I have come ready to admire the young ladies.
es: What I can assure these young ladies is that I have come prepared to admire them.

en: At present I will not say more, but, perhaps, when we are better acquainted——”
vi: At the moment, I cannot say more, but when we get to know each other better…
tr: I will not say more for now, but, perhaps, when we know each other better–"
es: For now, I will say no more, but perhaps, when we get to know each other better...

en: He was interrupted by a summons to dinner; and the girls smiled on each other.
vi: He was interrupted by an invitation to dine, and the girls smiled at each other.
tr: The call to dinner interrupted the conversation; the girls smiled at each other.
es: He was interrupted to be invited to the dining room; and the young ladies smiled at each other.

en: They were not the only objects of mr Collins’s admiration.
vi: The girls were not the only ones he fancied.
tr: Mr. Collins' admiration was not solely directed at them.
es: Not only were they the object of Mr. Collins' admiration: he examined and praised the hall, the dining room, and all the furniture; and the praises he gave to everything would have touched Mrs. Bennet's heart, if it weren't for the fact that she was mortified thinking that Collins saw all of it as his future property.

en: The hall, the dining-room, and all its furniture, were examined and praised; and his commendation of everything would have touched ms Bennet’s heart, but for the mortifying supposition of his viewing it all as his own future property.
vi: He examined and praised the large living room, the dining room, and all the furnishings. His praise of the household items might have touched Mrs. Bennet's heart, but she was tormented by the thought that he was viewing everything as his future inheritance.
tr: The drawing room, the dining room, and all the furniture were examined and praised; Mrs. Bennet's pride would have been flattered by his approval of everything if it weren't for the possibility that he saw it all as his future property.
es: Not only were they the object of Mr. Collins' admiration: he examined and praised the hall, the dining room, and all the furniture; and the praises he gave to everything would have touched Mrs. Bennet's heart, if it weren't for the fact that she was mortified thinking that Collins saw all of it as his future property.

en: The dinner, too, in its turn, was highly admired; and he begged to know to which of his fair cousins the excellence of its cookery was owing.
vi: He also lavishly praised the dinner and asked to know which lady had such excellent culinary skills.
tr: The dinner, in due course, also received its share of admiration; he wanted to know to which lovely cousin he owed thanks for the excellent cooking.
es: He also praised the dinner and begged to be told which of his beautiful cousins was responsible for preparing it.

en: But here he was set right by ms Bennet, who assured him, with some asperity, that they were very well able to keep a good cook, and that her daughters had nothing to do in the kitchen.
vi: But Mrs. Bennet hastily corrected him, somewhat rudely, informing him that the family had their own cook and the girls had nothing to do with the kitchen.
tr: But here Mrs. Bennet interrupted him and said rather sharply that they were well-off enough to hire a good cook, and that her daughters had no business in the kitchen.
es: But here, Mrs. Bennet interrupted him bluntly, telling him that her means allowed her to have a good cook and that her daughters had nothing to do in the kitchen.

en: He begged pardon for having displeased her.
vi: He apologized for offending her.
tr: Mr. Collins apologized for having offended her.
es: He apologized for having bothered her, and she, in a very gentle tone, told him that she was not at all offended.

en: In a softened tone she declared herself not at all offended; but he continued to apologize for about a quarter of an hour.
vi: She gently replied that she was not offended at all, but he continued to apologize for quite some time.
tr: Although Mrs. Bennet explained in a gentle voice that she was not at all offended, the man continued to apologize for a quarter of an hour.
es: But Collins continued apologizing for almost a quarter of an hour.

en: CHAPTER XIV
vi: Chapter 14
tr: Chapter XIV
es: CHAPTER XIV

en: DURING dinner, mr Bennet scarcely spoke at all; but when the servants were withdrawn, he thought it time to have some conversation with his guest, and therefore started a subject in which he expected him to shine, by observing that he seemed very fortunate in his patroness.
vi: Mr. Bennet spoke very little during the meal, but when all the servants had left the dining room, he thought it was time to talk to the guest.
tr: Mr. Bennet did not talk much during the meal; but when the servants withdrew, he thought it was time to converse with his guest and opened a topic in which he hoped he would show himself, saying that he seemed very fortunate in his patroness.
es: Mr. Bennet barely spoke during dinner; but when the servants had already withdrawn, he thought the opportune moment had arrived to converse with his guest. He began with a topic he believed would be to his liking, and told him that he had been very fortunate with his patroness.

en: Lady Catherine de Bourgh’s attention to his wishes, and consideration for his comfort, appeared very remarkable.
vi: So he started with the topic he thought the young man excelled in, by remarking that he had been very fortunate to receive the patronage of the Lady, that Lady Catherine de Bourgh's interest in his work, along with her consideration in making his living arrangements more comfortable, was very unusual.
tr: Lady Catherine de Bourgh's attention to his wishes and care for his comfort was very impressive.
es: Lady Catherine de Bourgh's attention to his wishes and her concern for his well-being were extraordinary.

en: mr Bennet could not have chosen better.
vi: Mr. Bennet could not have chosen a better topic for the young man.
tr: Mr. Bennet could not have chosen a better topic.
es: Mr. Bennet could not have chosen anything better.

en: mr Collins was eloquent in her praise.
vi: For Mr. Collins eloquently praised the Lady.
tr: Mr. Collins could not stop praising the lady.
es: Mr. Collins praised Lady Catherine with great eloquence.

en: The subject elevated him to more than usual solemnity of manner; and with a most important aspect he protested that he had never in his life witnessed such behaviour in a person of rank—such affability and condescension, as he had himself experienced from Lady Catherine.
vi: And the topic elevated his solemn demeanor above the usual level, and with the most important appearance, he stated that he had never met anyone like her in the upper class – the kindness and condescension, as he had observed in Lady Catherine.
tr: As he spoke, he became more and more enthusiastic, speaking with the air of a very important man, "he had never in his life seen such behavior from someone of title – such sensitivity and generosity as Lady Catherine had shown him.
es: The subject elevated the usual solemnity of his manners, and, giving himself much importance, he asserted that he had never seen behavior like hers in a person of her rank, nor such affability and condescension.

en: She had been graciously pleased to approve of both the discourses which he had already had the honour of preaching before her.
vi: She had been pleased to graciously review two of his sermons during her attendance.
tr: She had approved with generous satisfaction both of the sermons he had had the honor of delivering in her presence.
es: She had deigned to give her approval to the two sermons he had already had the honor of delivering in her presence; she had invited him to dine twice at Rosings, and just the previous Saturday had sent for him to complete her quadrille game during the evening.

en: She had also asked him twice to dine at Rosings, and had sent for him only the Saturday before, to make up her pool of quadrille in the evening.
vi: She had also twice invited him to dine at Rosings, and just the previous Saturday had invited him to fill in for a four-person card game in the evening.
tr: She had invited him to dine at Rosings twice, and just last Saturday had sent for him to complete the quartet at the quadrille table in the evening.
es: She had deigned to give her approval to the two sermons he had already had the honor of delivering in her presence; she had invited him to dine twice at Rosings, and just the previous Saturday had sent for him to complete her quadrille game during the evening.

en: Lady Catherine was reckoned proud by many people, he knew, but he had never seen anything but affability in her.
vi: Many people he knew said that Lady Catherine was proud, but he saw nothing in her but affability.
tr: Many people he knew thought Lady Catherine was proud, but he had seen nothing but sensitivity in her.
es: He knew many people who considered Lady Catherine to be proud, but he had never seen in her anything but affability.

en: She had always spoken to him as she would to any other gentleman; she made not the smallest objection to his joining in the society of the neighbourhood, nor to his leaving his parish occasionally for a week or two to visit his relations.
vi: She always spoke to him as she would to any other upper-class person, she never hindered him from socializing with neighboring families, or when he left the parish to visit relatives.
tr: She had always spoken to him as she would to any other gentleman; she had not objected in the slightest to his forming close relationships with the neighbors or to his leaving his parish for a week or two to visit his relatives occasionally.
es: She always spoke to him as she would to any other gentleman; she did not object to his associating with the people of the neighborhood, nor to his leaving the parish for one or two weeks to visit his relatives.

en: She had even condescended to advise him to marry as soon as he could, provided he chose with discretion; and had once paid him a visit in his humble parsonage, where she had perfectly approved all the alterations he had been making, and had even vouchsafed to suggest some herself,—some shelves in the closets upstairs.
vi: She even condescended to advise him to marry as soon as possible, provided he chose carefully, and had several times visited his humble abode, where she was absolutely pleased with all his arrangements, and she even gave him a few suggestions – a few shelves in the room upstairs.
tr: She had even shown her generosity by advising him to marry as soon as possible, provided he made a good choice, and had once visited him in his humble abode, fully approving of all the renovations he was making and even making some suggestions herself – such as adding a few shelves to the small rooms upstairs."
es: She always saw fit to recommend that he marry as soon as possible, provided he chose wisely, and she had visited him at his humble home, where she approved of all the changes he had made, even going so far as to suggest some herself, such as, for example, putting some shelves in the closets of the upstairs rooms.

en: “That is all very proper and civil, I am sure,” said ms Bennet, “and I dare say she is a very agreeable woman.
vi: Mrs. Bennet said: - All these actions are proper and polite, so I am sure she is a very pleasant woman.
tr: "These are very appropriate and polite actions," said Mrs. Bennet, "it is clear that she is a very charming woman.
es: ––All that is very well and very courteous on her part ––commented Mrs. Bennet––. She must be a very pleasant woman.

en: It is a pity that great ladies in general are not more like her.
vi: The unfortunate thing is that there aren't many such ladies.
tr: It is a pity that more grand ladies are not like her.
es: It's a pity that great ladies in general do not resemble her much.

en: Does she live near you, sir?”
vi: Does she live near you?
tr: Does she live near you, sir?"
es: Does she live near you?

en: “The garden in which stands my humble abode is separated only by a lane from Rosings Park, her Ladyship’s residence.”
vi: - The garden outside my modest dwelling is separated from Lady Catherine's Rosings Park estate by only a road.
tr: "My humble abode's garden is separated from the lady's estate, Rosings Park, by only one road.""
es: ––Rosings Park, Her Ladyship's residence, is only separated by a road from the estate where my humble abode is situated.

en: “I think you said she was a widow, sir? has she any family?”
vi: - I think you said she was a widow. Does she have any relatives?
tr: "You said he was dull, didn't you? Does he have a family?"
es: ––I believe you said you were a widow. Do you have family?

en: “She has one only daughter, the heiress of Rosings, and of very extensive property.”
vi: - She has only one daughter, who is the heiress of Rosings and a vast fortune.
tr: "She has an only daughter, the heiress of Rosings and a vast estate.""
es: ––He has only one daughter, the heiress of Rosings and other vast estates.

en: “Ah,” cried ms Bennet, shaking her head, “then she is better off than many girls.
vi: Mrs. Bennet exclaimed, shaking her head:
tr: "Ah!" cried Mrs. Bennet, shaking her head, "so she is better off than most girls.
es: ––Oh! ––sighed Mrs. Bennet, shaking her head––.

en: And what sort of young lady is she?
vi: - Ah!
tr: What kind of young lady is she?
es: She is in a better situation than many other young women. What kind of girl is she?

en: Is she handsome?”
vi: So she is a wealthy person. So what kind of person is she? Does she look beautiful?
tr: Is she beautiful?"
es: Is she pretty?

en: “She is a most charming young lady, indeed.
vi: - Actually, she is the most graceful young woman I have ever met.
tr: "A very elegant young lady indeed.
es: ––She is truly a charming young lady.

en: Lady Catherine herself says that, in point of true beauty, Miss de Bourgh is far superior to the handsomest of her sex; because there is that in her features which marks the young woman of distinguished birth.
vi: Lady Catherine herself said that, in terms of true beauty, Miss de Bourgh surpasses the most beautiful girls, as she has the expressions of a young woman of noble lineage.
tr: Lady Catherine herself says that in terms of true beauty, Miss de Bourgh is far superior to the most beautiful of her peers, because there is something in her face that shows she is a young woman of innate privilege.
es: Lady Catherine herself says that, to be honest, in terms of beauty, she far surpasses the most beautiful of her sex; because there is something in her features that reveals her distinguished birth.

en: She is unfortunately of a sickly constitution, which has prevented her making that progress in many accomplishments which she could not otherwise have failed of, as I am informed by the lady who superintended her education, and who still resides with them.
vi: Unfortunately, her physical condition is too weak, which has hindered her success in many areas; otherwise, she would not fail in any field.
tr: But unfortunately, she is always ill; according to the lady who oversees her education and still stays with them, this prevents her from developing many of her skills, otherwise why would she fall behind.
es: Unfortunately, she is of a sickly constitution, which has prevented her from progressing in certain aspects of her education that, if not for this, would be very remarkable, according to the lady who directed her education and who still lives with them.

en: But she is perfectly amiable, and often condescends to drive by my humble abode in her little phaeton and ponies.”
vi: But she is entirely amiable to everyone, often humbling herself to drive past my modest abode.
tr: But she is extremely amiable; she often shows the kindness of passing by my humble abode with her little phaeton and ponies."
es: But she is very kind and often has the goodness to stop by my humble residence with her little phaeton and her ponies.

en: “Has she been presented?
vi: - Has she been presented at court yet?
tr: "Was it presented?" "I don't remember hearing her name among the ladies in the palace.""
es: ––Has she been introduced to society yet?

en: I do not remember her name among the ladies at court.”
vi: I don't remember ever seeing her name among the women presented at the Court.
tr: "Was it presented?" "I don't remember hearing her name among the ladies in the palace.""
es: I don't remember hearing her name among the ladies of the court.

en: “Her indifferent state of health unhappily prevents her being in town; and by that means, as I told Lady Catherine myself one day, has deprived the British Court of its brightest ornament.
vi: - The sad thing is that her health condition does not allow her to enter the city. I myself told Lady Catherine the other day that this situation deprives the court of a splendid beauty.
tr: "His poor health prevents him from coming to the city; therefore, one day I personally told Lady Catherine that he deprives the English court of its brightest ornament.
es: ––The poor state of his health has unfortunately not allowed him to go to the capital, and because of this, as I once told Lady Catherine, he has deprived the British court of its most radiant ornament.

en: Her Ladyship seemed pleased with the idea; and you may imagine that I am happy on every occasion to offer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable to ladies.
vi: Lady Catherine seemed very pleased with my remark, and you can imagine that I am very delighted at every opportunity to offer subtle compliments that are always accepted by women.
tr: Her Ladyship seemed to like this idea; you can guess that I always gladly express these little delicate compliments that women always find reasonable at every opportunity.
es: Her Ladyship seemed very flattered by this appreciation; and you can understand that I take pleasure in directing, whenever I have the chance, these small and delicate compliments that are usually pleasing to the ladies.

en: I have more than once observed to Lady Catherine, that her charming daughter seemed born to be a duchess; and that the most elevated rank, instead of giving her consequence, would be adorned by her.
vi: More than once, I have remarked to Lady Catherine that her charming daughter seems born to become a duchess, and the title is elevated by her rather than merely providing her with status.
tr: I have told Lady Catherine several times that her beautiful daughter seems to be born to be a duchess, and that even the highest title would be honored by her rather than adding glory to her.
es: More than once I have pointed out to Lady Catherine that her charming daughter seemed born to be a duchess and that the highest rank, instead of giving her importance, would be elevated by her.

en: These are the kind of little things which please her Ladyship, and it is a sort of attention which I conceive myself peculiarly bound to pay.”
vi: These are the little things that please Lady Catherine, and it is the special care that I remind myself to show in response to the favor she has shown me.
tr: –These are the kinds of little things that please Her Ladyship, and I consider it my duty to show such attention."
es: These kinds of little things are what please Her Ladyship and I consider myself especially obliged to have such attentions with her.

en: “You judge very properly,” said mr Bennet; “and it is happy for you that you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy.
vi: Mr. Bennet said: - Your observation is very accurate; you have pleased others through your delicate manner.
tr: "A very sensible thought," said Mr. Bennet, "also, it is nice that you have the ability to make fine compliments.
es: ––You judge very well ––said Mr. Bennet––, and it is fortunate that you have the talent to flatter with delicacy.

en: May I ask whether these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the moment, or are the result of previous study?”
vi: By the way, may I ask whether those gestures stem from the unfolding events, or are they the result of prior study.
tr: I wonder if these sweet words are born at the moment or if they are rehearsed beforehand."
es: May I ask if those pleasant compliments occur to you spontaneously or if they are the result of prior study?

en: “They arise chiefly from what is passing at the time; and though I sometimes amuse myself with suggesting and arranging such little elegant compliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions, I always wish to give them as unstudied an air as possible.”
vi: - Most of it is spontaneous according to the moment, although sometimes I do arrange small compliments depending on the situation. If possible, I always create the appearance of being unprepared.
tr: "They mostly come from things happening at the time; although sometimes I think of and come up with these kinds of delicate compliments that can be adapted to normal situations to keep myself entertained, I always want to say them with an air of spontaneity as much as possible."
es: ––Normally they come to me on the spot, and although sometimes I take the time to meditate and prepare these small and elegant compliments to be able to adapt them to the occasions that arise, I always try to give them a tone that is as unstudied as possible.

en: mr Bennet’s expectations were fully answered.
vi: But what Mr. Bennet had anticipated was satisfactorily answered.
tr: Mr. Bennet's predictions turned out to be entirely correct.
es: Mr. Bennet's assumptions had been confirmed.

en: His cousin was as absurd as he had hoped; and he listened to him with the keenest enjoyment, maintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance, and, except in an occasional glance at Elizabeth, requiring no partner in his pleasure.
vi: He was indeed as ridiculous as Mr. Bennet had thought; he listened to him tell stories with pleasure, maintaining a serious expression, and only seeking sympathy when he glanced over at Elizabeth.
tr: His nephew was as foolish as he had anticipated; he listened to him with intelligent pleasure, maintaining a serious expression on his face and, except for occasionally glancing at Elizabeth, not seeking to share his enjoyment with anyone.
es: His cousin was as absurd as he believed. He listened to him with intense pleasure, maintaining, however, the most perfect composure; and, except for the occasional glance he cast at Elizabeth, no one else needed to share in his joy.

en: By tea-time, however, the dose had been enough, and mr Bennet was glad to take his guest into the drawing-room again, and when tea was over, glad to invite him
vi: At tea time, considering that the amount of amusement had been sufficient, Mr. Bennet cheerfully led the guest back into the drawing room, and after they had finished tea, he invited him to read to the ladies.
tr: Nevertheless, these sufficed for her until tea time; she took her guest back to the sitting room and, when tea was finished, invited him to read to the ladies.
es: However, by tea time he had had enough, and Mr. Bennet had the pleasure of taking his guest back to the drawing room.

en: “Protested
vi: Mr. Collins readily accepted, and a book was handed to him.
tr: Nevertheless, these sufficed for her until tea time; she took her guest back to the sitting room and, when tea was finished, invited him to read to the ladies.
es: When tea was over, he invited him to read something aloud to the ladies.

en: that he never read novels” H. T Feb 94
vi: But when he picked up the book, he apologized and said that he had never read novels – Kitty stared at him, while Lydia exclaimed in astonishment.
tr: Nevertheless, these sufficed for her until tea time; she took her guest back to the sitting room and, when tea was finished, invited him to read to the ladies.
es: When tea was over, he invited him to read something aloud to the ladies.

en: to read aloud to the ladies.
vi: But when he picked up the book, he apologized and said that he had never read novels – Kitty stared at him, while Lydia exclaimed in astonishment.
tr: Nevertheless, these sufficed for her until tea time; she took her guest back to the sitting room and, when tea was finished, invited him to read to the ladies.
es: When tea was over, he invited him to read something aloud to the ladies.

en: mr Collins readily assented, and a book was produced; but on beholding it (for everything announced it to be from a circulating library) he started back, and, begging pardon, protested that he never read novels.
vi: But when he picked up the book, he apologized and said that he had never read novels – Kitty stared at him, while Lydia exclaimed in astonishment.
tr: Mr. Collins immediately accepted; a book was brought, but upon seeing the book (it was evident from every aspect that it had been borrowed from a public library), he recoiled and apologized, saying that he did not read novels.
es: Collins agreed immediately and they brought a book; but as soon as he saw it ––it was immediately noticeable that it was from a circulating library–– he stopped, asked for forgiveness, and said he never read novels.

en: Kitty stared at him, and Lydia exclaimed.
vi: But when he picked up the book, he apologized and said that he had never read novels – Kitty stared at him, while Lydia exclaimed in astonishment.
tr: Kitty stared at him intently, and Lydia let out a cry of astonishment.
es: Kitty looked at him in surprise and Lydia let out an exclamation.

en: Other books were produced, and after some deliberation he chose “Fordyce’s Sermons.”
vi: Several other books were brought to him, and after some consideration, he chose Fordyce's Sermons; Lydia gaped as he opened the book, and before he could read in a solemn, monotonous tone, she interrupted:
tr: Other books were brought, and after some deliberation, he chose Fordyce's Sermons.
es: They brought other volumes and after some hesitation he chose Fordyce's sermons.

en: Lydia gaped as he opened the volume; and before he had, with very monotonous solemnity, read three pages, she interrupted him with,—
vi: Several other books were brought to him, and after some consideration, he chose Fordyce's Sermons; Lydia gaped as he opened the book, and before he could read in a solemn, monotonous tone, she interrupted:
tr: As Mr. Collins opened the book, Lydia yawned, and he had not read more than three pages in a monotonous seriousness before she stopped him-
es: He had barely opened the book when Lydia began to yawn, and before Collins, with monotonous solemnity, had read three pages, the girl interrupted him saying:

en: “Do you know, mamma, that my uncle Philips talks of turning away Richard?
vi: - Mom, do you know, Mr. Phillips intends to fire Richard, and if that happens, the colonel will take him in.
tr: "You know, mom, Aunt Philips is talking about turning Richard away; then Colonel Forster will take him.
es: ––Do you know, Mom, that Uncle Phillips is talking about dismissing Richard?

en: and if he does, Colonel Forster will hire him.
vi: - Mom, do you know, Mr. Phillips intends to fire Richard, and if that happens, the colonel will take him in.
tr: "You know, mom, Aunt Philips is talking about turning Richard away; then Colonel Forster will take him.
es: And if he does, Colonel Forster will hire him.

en: My aunt told me so herself on Saturday.
vi: Aunt told me so.
tr: My aunt said it herself on Saturday.
es: Aunt told me on Saturday.

en: I shall walk to Meryton to-morrow to hear more about it, and to ask when mr Denny comes back from town.”
vi: I will go to Meryton tomorrow to get more details, and also to ask when Danny will return from the city.
tr: Tomorrow I will go to Meryton to learn the rest, and I will also ask when Mr. Denny is returning from the city."
es: I will go to Meryton tomorrow to find out more and to ask when Mr. Denny is coming from the city.

en: Lydia was bid by her two eldest sisters to hold her tongue; but mr Collins, much offended, laid aside his book, and said,—
vi: The two elder sisters demanded that she hold her tongue, but Mr. Collins, feeling deeply offended, put the book aside and began to speak:
tr: Her two older sisters told Lydia to be quiet; but Mr. Collins, who was very offended, put his book aside and said–
es: The two older sisters begged Lydia to be quiet, but Collins, very offended, put down the book and exclaimed:

en: “I have often observed how little young ladies are interested by books of a serious stamp, though written solely for their benefit.
vi: - I often notice that young girls pay little attention to books with distinctive value, even though they are written specifically for them.
tr: "I have often observed that young ladies are not interested in serious books – yet these are written solely for their benefit.
es: ––I have often observed how little young women are interested in books on serious subjects, despite the fact that they were written for their benefit.

en: It amazes me, I confess; for certainly there can be nothing so advantageous to them as instruction.
vi: I must say that I am very surprised, because I believe that this education is very necessary for them.
tr: I must confess, it astonishes me; –because, after all, there is nothing as beneficial as education.
es: I confess that it amazes me, for there can be nothing as advantageous for them as education.

en: But I will no longer importune my young cousin.”
vi: But I do not want to bother the young ladies any further.
tr: But I will not bore my young cousin any longer."
es: But I do not want to keep bothering my little cousin.

en: Then, turning to mr Bennet, he offered himself as his antagonist at backgammon.
vi: Then he turned to Mr. Bennet and suggested they play chess.
tr: Then he turned to Mr. Bennet and offered to be his opponent in backgammon.
es: He approached Mr. Bennet and proposed a game of backgammon.

en: mr Bennet accepted the challenge, observing that he acted very wisely in leaving the girls to their own trifling amusements.
vi: Mr. Bennet agreed, thinking that he had acted wisely by letting the girls amuse themselves with their trivial pursuits.
tr: Mr. Bennet accepted the offer, saying that he was wise to leave his daughters to their own trifling affairs.
es: Mr. Bennet accepted the challenge and found that he was acting very wisely by letting the girls amuse themselves with their frivolities.

en: ms Bennet and her daughters apologized most civilly for Lydia’s interruption, and promised that it should not occur again, if he would resume his book; but mr Collins, after assuring them that he bore his young cousin no ill-will, and should never resent her behaviour as any affront, seated himself at another table with mr Bennet, and prepared for backgammon.
vi: Mrs. Bennet and the older daughters apologized to him in the politest terms for Lydia's interruption. But Mr. Collins reassured them that he did not mind the girl's actions and that he would never feel annoyed by her behavior. Then he sat down with Mr. Bennet at the chess table and prepared for the game.
tr: Mrs. Bennet and her daughters politely apologized for Lydia's interruption and promised it would not happen again if he wished to return to his book; but Mr. Collins, after assuring his young cousin that he was not offended by her action, settled at another table with Mr. Bennet and prepared for backgammon.
es: Mrs. Bennet and her daughters apologized profusely for Lydia's interruption and promised that it would not happen again if he wanted to continue reading. But Collins assured them that he was not angry with his cousin and that he could never interpret what she had done as an offense; and, sitting at another table with Mr. Bennet, he prepared to play backgammon.

en: CHAPTER XV.
vi: Chapter 15
tr: Chapter XV
es: CHAPTER XV

en: mr COLLINS was not a sensible man, and the deficiency of nature had been but little assisted by education or society; the greatest part of his life having been spent under the guidance of an illiterate and miserly father; and though he belonged to one of the universities, he had merely kept the necessary terms without forming at it any useful acquaintance.
vi: Mr. Collins is an insensitive person, and neither education nor communication has helped to compensate for this deficiency. Most of his upbringing was under the tutelage of an uneducated and miserly father. Although he attended university, he only did the bare minimum and failed to form any useful relationships.
tr: Mr. Collins was not a clever man; the flaws in his nature had not benefited from education or environment; most of his life had been spent under the control of an illiterate, miserable father; although he was a university graduate, he had only taken the compulsory courses and had not formed a useful connection with education.
es: Mr. Collins was not an intelligent man, and the deficiencies of his nature had not been helped at all by his education or his social life. He spent most of his life under the authority of an uneducated and miserly father; and although he went to university, he only stayed there for the merely necessary courses and did not acquire any truly useful knowledge.

en: The subjection in which his father had brought him up had given him originally great humility of manner; but it was now a good deal counteracted by the self-conceit of a weak head, living in retirement, and the consequential feelings of early and unexpected prosperity.
vi: The subjugation—imposed on him by his father—initially gave him a humble appearance, now neutralized by the conceit of a dull mind, an isolated life, and a sense of self-satisfaction from early and unexpected success.
tr: The treatment his father subjected him to had given him a great sense of inferiority from the start; but this inferiority was now considerably balanced by the illusions of a weak mind living far from everyone and the feelings provided by early and unexpected prosperity.
es: The subjection with which his father had raised him had initially given him great humility in his character, but this was now counteracted by a vanity obtained thanks to his limited intelligence, his reclusive life, and the feelings inherent to a sudden and unexpected prosperity.

en: A fortunate chance had recommended him to Lady Catherine de Bourgh when the living of Hunsford was vacant; and the respect which he felt for her high rank, and his veneration for her as his patroness, mingling with a very good opinion of himself, of his authority as a clergyman, and his right as a rector, made him altogether a mixture of pride and obsequiousness, self-importance and humility.
vi: A stroke of luck introduced him to Lady Catherine De Bourgh when a preaching position became vacant. His respect for her title and the reverence he holds for her as his patron, combined with his high self-regard, the prestige of being a clergyman, and the rights of a parish rector, have all created in him a blend of pride and obsequiousness, of self-importance and humility.
