tr: A good coincidence had brought Lady Catherine de Bourgh into his life at a time when the Hunsford position was vacant; the respect he felt for the woman's high status, combined with the reverence he felt for her as his patron, and his great appreciation of his authority as a clergyman and his rights as a priest, had made him a man of mixed pride and servility, arrogance and inferiority.
es: A fortunate chance had placed him under the patronage of Lady Catherine de Bourgh when the rectory of Hunsford became vacant, and his respect for the lady's high rank and the veneration she inspired in him for being his patroness, combined with a great self-concept, his authority as a clergyman, and his rights as rector, had turned him into a mixture of pride and servility, of presumption and modesty.

en: Having now a good house and a very sufficient income, he intended to marry; and in seeking a reconciliation with the Longbourn family he had a wife in view, as he meant to choose one of the daughters, if he found them as handsome and amiable as they were represented by common report.
vi: Now with a spacious mansion and sufficient income, he intended to get married. When he planned to reconcile with the family at Longbourn, he aimed to marry one of the daughters, provided they were as beautiful and charming as he had heard.
tr: Now that he had a good house and a very reasonable income, he had decided to marry; while seeking reconciliation with the Longbourn family, he had in mind to find a wife, because he wanted to choose one of the family's daughters, provided he found them as beautiful and charming as they were said to be.
es: Since he now already owned a good house and more than sufficient income, Collins was thinking about getting married. In his reconciliation with the Longbourn family, he sought the possibility of realizing his plan, as he intended to choose one of the daughters, provided they were as beautiful and pleasant as was said.

en: This was his plan of amends—of atonement—for inheriting their father’s estate; and he thought it an excellent one, full of eligibility and suitableness, and excessively generous and disinterested on his own part.
vi: This was his plan for making amends – a way to atone – to inherit Mr. Bennet's estate. He thought this was a wonderful plan, that he was qualified and well-matched, coupled with boundless generosity, and without any self-interest on his part.
tr: This was his plan to compensate – to rectify – inheriting their father's house, and he thought it was a wonderful plan, very clear and convenient, and moreover, extremely generous and selfless.
es: This was his plan of amendment, or reparation, for inheriting the father's properties, a plan that seemed excellent to him, as it was legitimate, very appropriate, and at the same time very generous and selfless on his part.

en: His plan did not vary on seeing them.
vi: After meeting the ladies, his plan remained unchanged.
tr: His plan did not change upon seeing the girls.
es: His plan did not change at all upon seeing them.

en: Miss Bennet’s lovely face confirmed his views, and established all his strictest notions of what was due to seniority; and for the first evening she was his settled choice.
vi: Jane's beautiful face confirmed everyone's rumors and matched the strictest views regarding his status. On the first morning, Jane was his choice.
tr: Miss Bennet's beautiful face confirmed his thoughts, and the requirements of being the eldest grounded his choice on solid foundations; his definite choice on the first evening was Jane.
es: Jane's charming face confirmed his intentions and corroborated all his strict notions about the preference that should be given to the elder daughters; and thus, during the first evening, he definitively decided on her.

en: The next morning, however, made an alteration; for in a quarter of an hour’s tête-à-tête with ms Bennet before breakfast, a conversation beginning with his parsonage-house, and leading naturally to the avowal of his hopes, that a mistress for it might be found at Longbourn, produced from her, amid very complaisant smiles and general encouragement, a caution against the very Jane he had fixed on.
vi: However, the next morning there was an adjustment. While sitting and talking with Mrs. Bennet during breakfast, the conversation started from the parsonage and naturally led to a confession of his hopes that at Longbourn he might find someone who could be the mistress of his estate. Amidst kind smiles and encouragement were hints about Jane, whom he was interested in.
tr: However, the situation changed the next morning; he had a fifteen-minute private conversation with Mrs. Bennet before breakfast; he began by talking about his own home, naturally leading to his hope of finding a lady in Longbourn, and in response, amidst polite smiles and encouraging words, he received a warning about Jane.
es: However, the next morning he had to make an alteration; for before breakfast, he had a quarter-hour conversation with Mrs. Bennet. They began by talking about his parsonage, which naturally led him to confess his hopes of finding in Longbourn the one who was to be its mistress.

en: “As to her younger daughters, she could not take upon her to say—she could not positively answer—but she did not know of any prepossession;—her eldest daughter she must just mention—she felt it incumbent on her to hint, was likely to be very soon engaged.”
vi: But Mrs. Bennet had to mention that she might soon be engaged.
tr: "It was not her place to say anything about her younger daughters – she couldn't say anything definite – but as far as she knew, there was no engagement – as for her eldest daughter, she felt compelled to mention that an engagement was imminent."
es: Amidst complacent smiles and general encouragements, Mrs. Bennet gave him a warning about Jane: "As for the younger daughters, it was not for her to argue; she could not answer positively, though she did not know that anyone had made them proposals; but regarding Jane, she had to warn him, though, after all, it was something that concerned only her, that she might soon be engaged."

en: mr Collins had only to change from Jane to Elizabeth—and it was soon done—done while ms Bennet was stirring the fire.
vi: Mr. Collins simply needed to change from Jane to Elizabeth, and this happened quickly, while Mrs. Bennet was still busy suggesting that Elizabeth was nearly equal to Jane in age and beauty.
tr: Mr. Collins only needed to change his mind from Jane to Elizabeth – and he did – while Mrs. Bennet was stirring the fire.
es: Collins only had to replace Jane with Elizabeth; and, spurred on by Mrs. Bennet, he made the change quickly.

en: Elizabeth, equally next to Jane in birth and beauty, succeeded her of course.
vi: Mr. Collins simply needed to change from Jane to Elizabeth, and this happened quickly, while Mrs. Bennet was still busy suggesting that Elizabeth was nearly equal to Jane in age and beauty.
tr: Elizabeth, who was not inferior to Jane in beauty and virtue, immediately followed her.
es: Elizabeth, who followed Jane in age and beauty, was the new candidate.

en: ms Bennet treasured up the hint, and trusted that she might soon have two daughters married; and the man whom she could not bear to speak of the day before, was now high in her good graces.
vi: Mrs. Bennet paid great attention to this insinuation, and believed that soon her two daughters would be engaged. The young man whom she could not stand to hear about two days ago was now being treated by her as an honored guest.
tr: Mrs. Bennet eagerly seized the opportunity, and soon believed she could marry off her two daughters; the man she couldn't even bear to hear about just yesterday had now become quite favorable in her eyes.
es: Mrs. Bennet took note of it, and she hoped that soon she would have two married daughters. The man she didn't even want to hear about the day before suddenly became the object of her highest esteem.

en: Lydia’s intention of walking to Meryton was not forgotten: every sister except Mary agreed to go with her; and mr Collins was to attend them, at the request of mr Bennet, who was most anxious to get rid of him, and have his library to himself; for thither mr Collins had followed him after breakfast, and there he would continue, nominally engaged with one of the largest folios in the collection, but really talking to mr Bennet, with little cessation, of his house and garden at Hunsford.
vi: Lydia did not forget her intention to go to Meryton; her sisters, except for Mary, all agreed to go with her, and Mr. Collins would accompany them to look after them at Mr. Bennet's request. He only wanted to get rid of the man so he could read in peace, because after breakfast Mr. Collins had been following him around, ostensibly examining the large volumes in the collection, but incessantly talking to him about his house and garden at Huntsford.
tr: Lydia's intention to walk to Meryton was not forgotten; all the girls except Mary agreed to go with her; Mr. Collins would accompany them at the request of Mr. Bennet, who wanted to get rid of him and have the library to himself; the man had followed him to the library after breakfast and, pretending to browse one of the largest volumes in the collection, would once again relentlessly talk about his house and garden in Hunsford, giving Mr. Bennet no respite.
es: Lydia's plan to go to Meryton was still on. All the sisters, except Mary, agreed to go with her. Mr. Collins was going to accompany them at Mr. Bennet's request, who was eager to get rid of his relative and have the library all to himself; for Mr. Collins had followed him there after breakfast and would continue to do so, apparently occupied with one of the largest folios in the collection, though in reality, incessantly talking to Mr. Bennet about his house and garden at Hunsford.

en: Such doings discomposed mr Bennet exceedingly.
vi: This behavior made Mr. Bennet extremely uncomfortable.
tr: Such actions greatly annoyed Mr. Bennet.
es: Such things greatly unsettled him.

en: In his library he had been always sure of leisure and tranquillity; and though prepared, as he told Elizabeth, to meet with folly and conceit in every other room in the house, he was used to be free from them there: his civility, therefore, was most prompt in inviting mr Collins to join his daughters in their walk; and mr Collins, being in fact much better fitted for a walker than a reader, was extremely well pleased to close his large book, and go.
vi: In the reading room, he was always assured of quiet. As he had told Elizabeth, although he had to face folly and conceit elsewhere, in the reading room he was usually free from such annoyances. Therefore, he politely invited Mr. Collins to accompany his daughters. Mr. Collins also preferred going with the ladies to reading, and was very happy to close the thick book and join them.
tr: He always desired absolute comfort and tranquility in his library; as he told Elizabeth, he was prepared to encounter foolishness and pretentiousness in every other room of the house, but he was accustomed to being free from them there; therefore, without losing a moment, he kindly invited Mr. Collins to join his daughters' walk; Mr. Collins, being more inclined to walk than to read, gladly closed the large book and went.
es: The library was the place where he knew he could enjoy his free time in peace. He was willing, as he told Elizabeth, to endure stupidity and conceit in any other room of the house, but in the library, he wanted to be free of all that. So he employed all his courtesy in inviting Collins to accompany his daughters on their walk; and Collins, who was much better at walking than reading, saw the heavens open. He closed the book and left.

en: In pompous nothings on his side, and civil assents on that of his cousins, their time passed till they entered Meryton.
vi: With trivial displays and polite compliments, he accompanied the ladies to Meryton.
tr: He swaggered idly, while his cousins nodded politely, and finally, they arrived in Meryton.
es: And between pompous and insipid phrases on his part, and courteous nods on the part of his cousins, time passed until they reached Meryton.

en: The attention of the younger ones was then no longer to be gained by him.
vi: At this point, the ladies no longer paid attention to him.
tr: By then, he could no longer attract the attention of the young people.
es: From then on, the younger sisters no longer paid him any attention.

en: Their eyes were immediately wandering up the street in quest of the officers, and nothing less than a very smart bonnet, indeed, or a really new muslin in a shop window, could recall them.
vi: Their eyes roamed the streets in search of officers, and only the sight of truly elegant hats or muslin goods could distract them.
tr: The girls' eyes immediately started searching for the officers as they wandered the streets, and nothing could distract them except for a very flashy hat in a shop window or a brand new muslin.
es: They had eyes only for seeking officers in the streets. And unless it was a truly elegant hat or a genuinely new muslin, nothing could distract them.

en: But the attention of every lady was soon caught by a young man, whom they had never seen before, of most gentlemanlike appearance, walking with an officer on the other side of the way.
vi: But a young man appeared and caught the ladies' attention. He had a truly elegant appearance, walking in the opposite direction of an officer.
tr: However, it wasn't long before a young man caught the attention of all the ladies, someone they had never seen before, very gentlemanly in appearance, walking with an officer on the other side of the road.
es: But the attention of all the young ladies was instantly captured by a young man they had not seen before, who had the appearance of being quite the gentleman, and who was walking with an officer on the opposite side of the street.

en: The officer was the very mr Denny concerning whose return from London Lydia came to inquire, and he bowed as they passed.
vi: The officer was Danny, the one who had returned from London that Lydia had mentioned. He bowed his head to greet them as everyone passed by. All the ladies were impressed by his demeanor and wondered who he was. Kitty and Lydia decided to find out who he was.
tr: The officer was Mr. Denny, whom Lydia had come to inquire about whether he had returned from London, and he nodded as they passed by.
es: The officer was Mr. Denny himself, whose return from London Lydia had come to inquire about, and who bowed to greet them as he passed.

en: All were struck with the stranger’s air, all wondered who he could be; and Kitty and Lydia, determined if possible to find out, led the way across the street, under pretence of wanting something in an opposite shop, and fortunately had just gained the pavement, when the two gentlemen, turning back, had reached the same spot.
vi: The two led the way, crossing the street under the pretext of buying something from the shop opposite, and luckily arrived at the curb just as the two young men were returning to the same place.
tr: They were all struck by the stranger's demeanor, all curious about who he might be; Kitty and Lydia pretended to look at something in the shop across the street to find out if possible, and just as they stepped onto the sidewalk, by coincidence, they came face to face with the two gentlemen returning.
es: They were all impressed by the stranger's bearing and wondered who he could be. Kitty and Lydia, determined to find out, crossed the street under the pretext that they wanted to buy something at the shop opposite, reaching the sidewalk so fortunately that, at that very moment, the two gentlemen, on their way back, arrived at exactly the same spot.

en: mr Denny addressed them directly, and entreated permission to introduce his friend, mr Wickham, who had returned with him the day before from town, and, he was happy to say, had accepted a commission in their corps.
vi: Danny greeted them and asked permission to introduce his friend to the ladies, Mr. Wickham, who had returned from the city with him and was also joining the same unit.
tr: Mr. Denny immediately began to speak, asking permission to introduce his friend: Mr. Wickham had come to town with him the previous day and, he was happy to say, had agreed to be an officer in their regiment.
es: Mr. Denny addressed them directly and asked if he might introduce his friend, Mr. Wickham, who had come from London with him the day before and had kindly accepted a position in the Corps.

en: This was exactly as it should be; for the young man wanted only regimentals to make him completely charming.
vi: Just the uniform alone made the young man completely captivating.
tr: This was just as it should be; the young man's only missing element for perfect charm was his uniform.
es: This was the last straw, for belonging to the regiment was the only thing he lacked to complete his charm.

en: His appearance was greatly in his favour: he had all the best parts of beauty, a fine countenance, a good figure, and very pleasing address.
vi: Every aspect of his appearance was splendid; he had a delicate face, a perfect physique, and, in addition, a very charming way of speaking.
tr: Every detail of his demeanor added something to him; everything about him was beautiful: a pleasant face, a well-formed body, and an engaging manner of speaking.
es: His appearance spoke highly in his favor; he was handsome and slender, with very affable manners.

en: The introduction was followed up on his side by a happy readiness of conversation—a readiness at the same time perfectly correct and unassuming; and the whole party were still standing and talking together very agreeably, when the sound of horses drew their notice, and Darcy and Bingley were seen riding down the street.
vi: Right after the introduction, there was a cheerful and naturally fluent conversation that was very proper. They were all chatting when they heard the sound of approaching horses, and they saw Darcy and Bingley riding up.
tr: After the introductions, the young man showed he was eager to talk – but it was a perfectly measured and easy eagerness; the whole group was standing and chatting sweetly when the sound of horses drew their attention, and they saw Darcy and Bingley coming down the street.
es: After the introduction, Mr. Wickham initiated a conversation with great ease, with the utmost correctness and without pretensions. They were all still standing there pleasantly chatting when the sound of horses drew their attention, and they saw Darcy and Bingley, on their mounts, coming down the street.

en: On distinguishing the ladies of the group the two gentlemen came directly towards them, and began the usual civilities.
vi: Upon seeing the ladies, the two men approached and began the usual polite exchanges.
tr: As soon as the two gentlemen recognized the ladies in the group, they came directly to them and displayed their usual politeness.
es: Upon recognizing the young ladies in the group, the two gentlemen approached them and began the customary greetings.

en: Bingley was the principal spokesman, and Miss Bennet the principal object.
vi: Bingley was the main speaker, and Jane the main listener.
tr: Bingley was the main speaker, and Miss Bennet was the main topic.
es: Bingley spoke more than anyone, and Jane was the main subject of his conversation.

en: He was then, he said, on his way to Longbourn on purpose to inquire after her.
vi: He said he was on his way to Longbourn to inquire about her condition.
tr: At that moment, Bingley said, he was also on his way to Longbourn to inquire about her health.
es: At that moment, he said, they were on their way to Longbourn to see how she was; Darcy confirmed this with a nod and was trying not to fix his gaze on Elizabeth when suddenly they were both paralyzed upon seeing the stranger.

en: mr Darcy corroborated it with a bow, and was beginning to determine not to fix his eyes on Elizabeth, when they were suddenly arrested by the sight of the stranger; and Elizabeth happening to see the countenance of both as they looked at each other, was all astonishment at the effect of the meeting.
vi: Darcy confirmed his friend's words with a slight nod, and as he began to resolutely avoid staring at Elizabeth, he noticed the unfamiliar young man. Elizabeth managed to see the expressions on both their faces as they looked at each other, very surprised by the impact of the encounter.
tr: Mr. Darcy nodded to confirm this and was just beginning to struggle not to fix his eyes on Elizabeth when he noticed the stranger's presence and suddenly froze; Elizabeth saw that both their faces froze in astonishment at the encounter as they looked at each other.
es: Elizabeth, who saw both their faces as they looked at each other, was very surprised by the effect the encounter had on them.

en: Both changed colour, one looked white, the other red.
vi: Both changed their complexion, one turning white, the other red.
tr: Both of their colors changed, one turning white, the other red.
es: Both changed color, one turned pale and the other red.

en: mr Wickham, after a few moments, touched his hat—a salutation which mr Darcy just deigned to return.
vi: After a few moments, Wickham touched his hat to greet, and Darcy only awkwardly responded.
tr: Mr. Wickham touched his hat a few seconds later – Darcy barely acknowledged this salute.
es: After a slight hesitation, Wickham raised his hand to his hat, to which Darcy deigned to respond.

en: What could be the meaning of it?
vi: What was that?
tr: What could this mean?
es: What could that mean?

en: It was impossible to imagine; it was impossible not to long to know.
vi: Impossible to think of, impossible not to want to know?
tr: –It was impossible to imagine; it was impossible not to be eager to find out.
es: It was impossible to imagine, but it was also impossible not to feel a great curiosity to know.

en: In another minute mr Bingley, but without seeming to have noticed what passed, took leave and rode on with his friend.
vi: Meanwhile, Bingley seemed unaware of what had happened, bid farewell, and rode off with his friend.
tr: Soon after, Mr. Bingley asked for leave without seeming to pay attention to what was happening and set off with his friend.
es: A moment later, Bingley, who seemed not to have noticed what had happened, said goodbye and continued on with his friend.

en: mr Denny and mr Wickham walked with the young ladies to the door of mr Philips’s house, and then made their bows, in spite of Miss Lydia’s pressing entreaties that they would come in, and even in spite of ms Philips’s throwing up the parlour window, and loudly seconding the invitation.
vi: Mr. Danny and Wickham accompanied the ladies to Mr. Phillips' house, then bowed and took their leave, despite Lydia's pleas for them to come inside.
tr: Mr. Denny and Mr. Wickham walked with the young ladies to the door of Mr. Philips's house, then, despite Miss Lydia's insistent invitations to come inside and even Mrs. Philips raising the parlor window to support the invitation, they bowed and took their leave.
es: Denny and Wickham continued walking with the girls until they reached Mr. Philips' house door, where they made the appropriate bows and left despite Lydia's insistent pleas for them to come in and despite Mrs. Philips opening the vestibule window and leaning out to vocally support the invitation.

en: ms Philips was always glad to see her nieces; and the two eldest, from their recent absence, were particularly welcome; and she was eagerly expressing her surprise at their sudden return home, which, as their own carriage had not fetched them, she should have known nothing about, if she had not happened to see mr Jones’s shopboy in the street, who had told her that they were not to send any more draughts to Netherfield, because the Miss Bennets were come away, when her civility was claimed towards mr Collins by Jane’s introduction of him.
vi: Mrs. Phillips was delighted to see her nieces again. The two older girls, having been away for some time, received a special welcome. She was surprised by their sudden return home. Since they did not use the carriage, she would not have known they had returned if she had not accidentally met the shopkeeper who sold goods to Mr. Jones and informed her.
tr: Mrs. Philips was always pleased to see her nieces; the two eldest girls were especially well received after their recent absence; Mrs. Philips was fervently expressing her surprise at their sudden return, saying that if she hadn't seen Mr. Jones's apprentice in the street, who told her they would no longer be sending syrup to Netherfield because the Miss Bennets had left, she wouldn't have known. At that moment, Jane stepped forward and introduced Mr. Collins, drawing her attention to him.
es: Mrs. Philips was always delighted to see her nieces. The two eldest were especially well received due to their recent absence. She expressed her surprise at their quick return home, of which she would have known nothing, since they did not come back in their own carriage, had it not been for the chance encounter with Dr. Jones's young man, who told her that she no longer needed to send more medicines to Netherfield because the Miss Bennets had left. Then Jane introduced Mr. Collins to whom she dedicated all her attention.

en: She received him with her very best politeness, which he returned with as much more, apologizing for his intrusion, without any previous acquaintance with her, which he could not help flattering himself, however, might be justified by his relationship to the young ladies who introduced him to her notice.
vi: Jane introduced Mr. Collins to her, and she received him with utmost politeness. He responded formally, apologizing for the intrusion as they had not been acquainted before, only through the ladies' introduction.
tr: Mrs. Philips greeted Mr. Collins in the most polite manner, and received the same courtesy in return; Mr. Collins apologized for being a guest without their prior acquaintance, but he believed that his proud connection with the young ladies who brought him there would excuse this situation.
es: She welcomed him with the most exquisite courtesy, to which Collins responded with even more refinement, apologizing for having presented himself at her house without prior notice, although he felt proud that it was the relationship with her nieces that justified such an intrusion.

en: ms Philips was quite awed by such an excess of good breeding; but her contemplation of one stranger was soon put an end to by exclamations and inquiries about the other, of whom, however, she could only tell her nieces what they already knew, that mr Denny had brought him from London, and that he was to have a lieutenant’s commission in the ——shire.
vi: Mrs. Phillips seemed concerned about receiving someone with such excessive politeness.
tr: Mrs. Philips was delighted by such extreme politeness; but her observation of the stranger was soon interrupted by excited questions about another stranger, about whom she could tell her nieces what they already knew, namely that Mr. Denny had brought him from London and that he would be taking the rank of lieutenant in the -------shire regiment.
es: Mrs. Philips was completely overwhelmed by such an excess of good manners. But she soon had to set aside this stranger, due to the exclamations and questions regarding the other. Mrs. Philips could not tell her nieces more than they already knew: that Mr. Denny had brought him from London and that he was going to stay at the county garrison with the rank of lieutenant.

en: She had been watching him the last hour, she said, as he walked up and down the street,—and had mr Wickham appeared, Kitty and Lydia would certainly have continued the occupation; but unluckily no one passed the windows now except a few of the officers, who, in comparison with the stranger, were become “stupid, disagreeable fellows.”
vi: But the welcome was interrupted by inquiries about the stranger, and about him, she only knew what the ladies had already been told.
tr: She said she had been watching him for the past hour, walking up and down the street; if Mr. Wickham had appeared, Kitty and Lydia would certainly have continued to watch, but unfortunately, apart from a few officers who were "stupid, disagreeable fellows" compared to the stranger, no one else was passing by the windows.
es: She added that she had been observing him while he walked down the street; and if Mr. Wickham had appeared then, both Kitty and Lydia would have also approached the window to watch him, but unfortunately, at that moment only a few officers passed by who, compared to the stranger, seemed "stupid and unpleasant fellows."

en: Some of them were to dine with the Philipses the next day, and their aunt promised to make her husband call on mr Wickham, and give him an invitation also, if the family from Longbourn would come in the evening.
vi: She promised to have her husband visit him and invite him for a meal, provided the Bennet family would also come in the evening.
tr: Some of them would be dining with the Philipses the next day; their aunt promised that if the Longbourn family came in the evening, she would send her husband to visit Mr. Wickham and invite him as well.
es: Some of these officers were going to dine the next day with the Philips, and the aunt promised them that she would tell her husband to visit Wickham to invite him too, if the Longbourn family wanted to come in the evening.

en: This was agreed to; and ms Philips protested that they would have a nice comfortable noisy game of lottery tickets, and a little bit of hot supper afterwards.
vi: Everyone agreed, and they all left in high spirits, anticipating the upcoming pleasures.
tr: They agreed; Mrs. Philips said they would play a delightful, easy, and boisterous game of lottery tickets, followed by something hot to eat.
es: Thus it was agreed, and Mrs. Philips offered them to play the lottery and then have a hot dinner.

en: The prospect of such delights was very cheering, and they parted in mutual good spirits.
vi: Everyone agreed, and they all left in high spirits, anticipating the upcoming pleasures.
tr: It was joyful to have such entertainments to look forward to; both parties were in high spirits as they parted.
es: The prospect of such delights was magnificent, and the girls left very happy.

en: mr Collins repeated his apologies in quitting the room, and was assured, with unwearying civility, that they were perfectly needless.
vi: Mr. Collins repeated his apologies, but she reassured him that it was unnecessary.
tr: Mr. Collins repeated his apologies as he left the room and was assured with tireless politeness that there was no need for any apology.
es: Collins apologized again upon leaving, and he was assured that it was unnecessary.

en: As they walked home, Elizabeth related to Jane what she had seen pass between the two gentlemen; but though Jane would have defended either or both, had they appeared to be wrong, she could no more explain such behaviour than her sister.
vi: On the way back, Elizabeth told Jane about Darcy's strange attitude. Although Jane could defend both of them if they had done something wrong, she couldn't explain to her sister the attitude of the two.
tr: While walking home, Elizabeth explained to Jane what had transpired between the two gentlemen; if they seemed to have made a mistake, Jane would have defended one or both of them, but she too could not make more sense of this behavior than her sister.
es: On the way home, Elizabeth told Jane what had happened between the two gentlemen, and although Jane would have defended them if she had noticed anything strange, in this case, like her sister, she could not explain such behavior.

en: mr Collins on his return highly gratified ms Bennet by admiring ms Philips’s manners and politeness.
vi: Mr. Collins made Mrs. Bennet extremely grateful when he praised Mrs. Phillips' attitude and polite manners.
tr: When they returned, Mr. Collins greatly pleased Mrs. Bennet by showering praises on Mrs. Philips's behavior and kindness.
es: Collins praised Mrs. Bennet by commending the manners and education of Mrs. Philips.

en: He protested that, except Lady Catherine and her daughter, he had never seen a more elegant woman; for she had not only received him with the utmost civility, but had even pointedly included him in her invitation for the next evening, although utterly unknown to her before.
vi: He insisted that, except for Lady Catherine and her daughter, he had never met a more elegant woman, for she not only received him with the highest courtesy but also kindly invited him to visit the next evening, despite not having known him before.
tr: He said that, except for Lady Catherine and her daughter, he had never seen a more elegant lady in his life; she had not only received him with tremendous politeness but had also emphatically included him in the invitation for the following evening, even though she had never seen him before.
es: He assured that apart from Lady Catherine and her daughter, he had never seen a more elegant woman, for not only did she receive him with the utmost courtesy, but she also included him in the invitation for the next evening, despite being a complete stranger to her.

en: Something, he supposed, might be attributed to his connection with them, but yet he had never met with so much attention in the whole course of his life.
vi: He could guess that it was due to his connection with the Bennet family, yet he was still very pleased because he had never been so noticed in his life.
tr: Of course, their familial connection might have had some influence, but still, he had never received such attention in his life.
es: Of course, he knew he should attribute it to his relationship with them, but nevertheless, he had never been treated with such kindness in his life.

en: CHAPTER XVI.
vi: Chapter 16
tr: Chapter XVI
es: CHAPTER XVI

en: AS no objection was made to the young people’s engagement with their aunt, and all mr Collins’s scruples of leaving  for a single evening during his visit were most steadily resisted, the coach conveyed him and his five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton; and the girls had the pleasure of hearing, as they entered the drawing-room, that mr Wickham had accepted their uncle’s invitation, and was then in the house.
vi: Because no one objected to the girls gathering at their aunt's house, everyone opposed Mr. Collins' hesitation to leave Mr. and Mrs. Bennet during the visit, the carriage took him and his five cousins to Meryton. When they entered the living room, the girls were delighted to learn that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle's invitation and was currently in the house.
tr: Since there was no objection to the young people's agreement with their aunt, and Mr. Collins's complaints about not wanting to leave Mr. and Mrs. Bennet even for an evening were met with belief, the carriage took him and his five cousins to Meryton at a convenient time; as the girls entered the sitting room, they were delighted to learn that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle's invitation and was currently at home.
es: Since no objection was raised to the young women's commitment to their aunt and Mr. Collins's reservations about not leaving the Bennets for even a single evening during his visit were firmly rejected, at the appropriate time the carriage set off with him and his five cousins towards Meryton. Upon entering the Philips' drawing room, the girls had the satisfaction of learning that Wickham had accepted their uncle's invitation and was in the house.

en: When this information was given, and they had all taken their seats, mr Collins was at leisure to look around him and admire, and he was so much struck with the size and furniture of the apartment, that he declared he might almost have supposed himself in the small summer breakfast parlour at Rosings; a comparison that did not at first convey much gratification; but when ms Philips understood from him what Rosings was, and who was its proprietor, when she had listened to the description of only one of Lady Catherine’s drawing-rooms, and found that the chimney-piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds, she felt all the force of the compliment, and would hardly have resented a comparison with the housekeeper’s room.
vi: When everyone had taken their seats, Mr. Collins gazed around absentmindedly and admired the surroundings, as he was quite impressed with the size and interior of the room, to the extent that he remarked he felt as if he were sitting in the summer dining room at Rosings.
tr: After this information was given and everyone was seated, Mr. Collins began to idly examine the surroundings; he was so impressed by the spaciousness and furnishing of the apartment that he almost declared he could mistake it for the small summer breakfast room at Rosings. Although this comparison did not initially garner much appreciation, once Mrs. Philips learned what Rosings was and who its owner was – upon hearing a description of just one of Lady Catherine's sitting rooms and that just the fireplace had cost eight hundred pounds – she felt the full force of the compliment, to the extent that she would no longer be offended even if it were compared to the servant's quarters.
es: After receiving this information, and when everyone had taken their seats, Collins was able to observe everything at his leisure; the dimensions and the furniture of the room caused him such admiration that he confessed to having believed he was in the summer dining room of Rosings.

en: In describing to her all the grandeur of Lady Catherine and her mansion, with occasional digressions in praise of his own humble abode, and the improvements it was receiving, he was happily employed until the gentlemen joined them; and he found in ms Philips a very attentive listener, whose opinion of his consequence increased with what she heard, and who was resolving to retail it all among her neighbours as soon as she could.
vi: At first, the comparison did not bring joy, but when Mrs. Philips understood where Rosings was and who owned it, when she heard him describe one of Lady Catherine's drawing rooms and learned that just the fireplace had cost eight hundred pounds, she immediately felt the full force of the compliment, and it would not have been bothersome if he had intended to compare it to the housekeeper's room. Until the young men arrived to sit with them, while describing all the splendor of Lady Catherine and her estate, occasionally digressing to praise his own humble Parsonage and its improvements, Mr. Collins found Mrs. Philips to be an attentive listener in conversation. The more she listened, the higher her impression of his status grew, and she intended to recount everything to her neighbors as soon as possible.
tr: She was very happy to describe the splendor of Lady Catherine and her mansion, occasionally praising her own humble abode and the renovations she was undergoing, until the gentlemen joined them; Mrs. Philips was a very attentive listener for her; after hearing these, she found the young man even more important and decided to share this with her neighbors at the first opportunity.
es: This comparison did not arouse any enthusiasm at first; but when Mrs. Philips heard from Collins' lips what Rosings was and who its owner was, when she heard the description of one of Lady Catherine's drawing rooms and learned that just the fireplace had cost eight hundred pounds, she appreciated the full value of that compliment and would hardly have been bothered if he had compared her drawing room to the housekeeper's room at the Bourghs'. Collins amused himself by telling Mrs. Philips all about Lady Catherine's grandeur and her mansion, occasionally mentioning his humble home and the improvements he was making to it, until the gentlemen arrived. Collins found in Mrs. Philips an attentive listener whose good opinion of the rector increased with everything he explained to her, and she was already thinking about telling her neighbors all about it as soon as possible.

en: To the girls, who could not listen to their cousin, and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument, and examine their own indifferent imitations of china on the mantel-piece, the interval of waiting appeared very long.
vi: For the young ladies, unable to hear him speak and with nothing to do but wait, the waiting time seemed excessively long.
tr: The girls, who couldn't listen to their cousins, lamented the lack of a piano, and had nothing to do but examine the fake porcelain they had decorated above the fireplace, found the waiting time very long.
es: To the young ladies, who could not stand their cousin and had nothing else to do but wish for a musical instrument at hand and examine the china imitations on the mantelpiece, the wait was becoming too long.

en: It was over at last, however.
vi: Finally, the young men arrived.
tr: But it finally ended, of course.
es: But finally, the gentlemen appeared.

en: The gentlemen did approach: and when mr Wickham walked into the room, Elizabeth felt that she had neither been seeing him before, nor thinking of him since, with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration.
vi: When Mr. Wickham entered, Elizabeth felt as if she had either never met him before or had not thought of him since then, with a fleeting, inexplicable fondness.
tr: The gentlemen approached; when Mr. Wickham entered the room, Elizabeth felt that she was not at all wrong in her admiration for him when she had seen him before and since then.
es: When Wickham entered the room, Elizabeth noticed that she had neither paid attention to him before nor remembered him afterward with sufficient admiration.

en: The officers of the ——shire were in general a very creditable, gentlemanlike set and the best of them were of the present party; but Mr, Wickham was as far beyond them all in person, countenance, air, and walk, as they were superior to the broad-faced stuffy uncle Philips, breathing port wine, who followed them into the room.
vi: The officers were all reputable, elegant, and the best of them were present here; but Mr. Wickham stood out above all in person, face, manner, and bearing, just as they surpassed Mr. Philips, with his broad face, who at that moment was exhaling the scent of port wine as he followed them into the room.
tr: The officers of the -------shire regiment were generally very reasonable, gentlemanly men, and the best of them were at this party; but Mr. Wickham, with his appearance, face, demeanor, and walk, was far superior to all of them, just as the officers were superior to the broad-faced, dull, wine-breathed Mr. Philips who entered the room after them.
es: The county garrison officers generally enjoyed extraordinary prestige; they were very handsome, and the best of them were now at the present gathering. But Wickham, with his gallantry, his ease, and his graceful walk, was as superior to them as they were to the stout Uncle Philips, who entered the room last, reeking of port wine.

en: “The officers of the ——shire”
vi: Mr. Wickham was the fortunate young man who caught the attention of almost all the ladies, while Elizabeth was the fortunate young woman who got to sit near him.
tr: The officers of the -------shire regiment were generally very reasonable, gentlemanly men, and the best of them were at this party; but Mr. Wickham, with his appearance, face, demeanor, and walk, was far superior to all of them, just as the officers were superior to the broad-faced, dull, wine-breathed Mr. Philips who entered the room after them.
es: Mr. Wickham was the fortunate man to whom almost all female eyes turned; and Elizabeth was the fortunate woman beside whom he decided to take a seat.

en: mr Wickham was the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned, and Elizabeth was the happy woman by whom he finally seated himself; and the agreeable manner in which he immediately fell into conversation, though it was only on its being a wet night, and on the probability of a rainy season, made her feel that the commonest, dullest, most threadbare topic might be rendered interesting by the skill of the speaker.
vi: His relaxed manner when he started a conversation, even if it was about a rainy night and with the potential of a rainy season, made her think that the most ordinary, boring, and old-fashioned topic could become interesting through a person with the gift of gab.
tr: Mr. Wickham was the lucky man who almost every woman's eyes were fixed upon, and Elizabeth soon became the lucky woman when the young man finally came and sat next to her; although he only talked about it being a rainy night and the possibility of a rainy season, the charm with which he started speaking immediately made Elizabeth think that even the most ordinary, most boring, most stale topic could become interesting with the speaker's skill.
es: Wickham initiated the conversation in such a pleasant manner, despite limiting himself to saying that the night was damp and that it would probably rain a lot throughout the season, that Elizabeth realized that the most common, trivial, and worn-out topics can be interesting if said skillfully.

en: With such rivals for the notice of the fair as mr Wickham and the officers, mr Collins seemed to sink into insignificance; to the young ladies he certainly was nothing; but he had still at intervals a kind listener in ms Philips, and was, by her watchfulness, most abundantly supplied with coffee and muffin.
vi: With rivals like Mr. Wickham and the officers, Mr. Collins seemed to sink to a level of insignificance. To the young ladies, he was certainly nothing; but occasionally he had the polite Mrs. Philips to listen to him, and under her care, he was the guest most frequently invited for coffee and cake.
tr: When it came to attracting the attention of the fair sex, with rivals like Mr. Wickham and the officers, Mr. Collins began to sink into insignificance; he was already a nobody to the young ladies; nevertheless, Mrs. Philips occasionally became a good listener to him and, with her attentiveness, did not leave him without coffee and cake.
es: With rivals like Wickham and the other officers monopolizing the ladies' attention, Collins seemed to sink into insignificance. To the young women, he meant nothing. But Mrs. Philips still listened to him from time to time and made sure he never lacked coffee or pastries.

en: When the card tables were placed, he had an opportunity of obliging her, in return, by sitting down to whist.
vi: When the cards were laid out, he had the opportunity to respond to her invitation to join the whist game.
tr: When the game tables were set up, by sitting down to play whist, he also found an opportunity to express his feelings of gratitude towards her.
es: When the gaming tables were arranged, Collins saw an opportunity to return her attentions and sat down to play whist with her.

en: “I know little of the game at present,” said he, “but I shall be glad to improve myself; for in my situation of life——” ms Philips was very thankful for his compliance, but could not wait for his reason.
vi: He said: - I don't know much about this way of playing, but I would be very happy to have the opportunity to learn more, given the circumstances of my life. Mrs. Philips thanked him for indulging her, but could not wait to hear his reason.
tr: "I know very little about the game yet," he said, "but I want to improve myself, because a person in my situation–" Mrs. Philips thanked him for his cooperation but did not want to hear the reason.
es: ––I know little about this game now ––he said to him––, but I would like to learn it better, due to my situation in life. Mrs. Philips thanked him for his condescension, but she could not understand those reasons.

en: mr Wickham did not play at whist, and with ready delight was he received at the other table between Elizabeth and Lydia.
vi: Mr. Wickham did not play whist, but was pleased to sit between Elizabeth and Lydia at the other table.
tr: Mr. Wickham did not play whist and was gladly accepted between Elizabeth and Lydia at the other table.
es: Wickham did not play whist and was received with genuine enthusiasm at the other table, between Elizabeth and Lydia.

en: At first there seemed danger of Lydia’s engrossing him entirely, for she was a most determined talker; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets, she soon grew too much interested in the game, too eager in making bets and exclaiming after prizes, to have attention for anyone in particular.
vi: At first, there was a risk that Lydia would monopolize his time because she talked incessantly, but since she was very fond of playing lottery tickets, she focused more on the game and paid no attention to anyone else.
tr: At first, there was a danger of Lydia overwhelming the man; she was a persistent talker; but since she was also extremely fond of lottery tickets, she soon got caught up in the game, investing money with such great enthusiasm that she couldn't pay attention to anyone else, and demanded her prize with loud cries.
es: At first, it seemed there was a danger that Lydia would completely monopolize him, as she liked to talk incessantly, but since she was also very fond of the lottery, she soon focused all her interest on the game and was too busy betting and exclaiming when prizes were won to be distracted by anything else.

en: Allowing for the common demands of the game, mr Wickham was therefore at leisure to talk to Elizabeth, and she was very willing to hear him, though what she chiefly wished to hear she could not hope to be told, the history of his acquaintance with mr Darcy.
vi: Thus, Mr. Wickham leisurely conversed with Elizabeth. She was willing to listen to him, although the main thing she wanted to hear, which was the reason for his acquaintance with Mr. Darcy, he did not mention.
tr: Thus, Mr. Wickham, adhering to the usual demands of the game, was free to talk to Elizabeth; Elizabeth was very eager to listen to him, but of course, what she most wanted to hear was something else – the story of his acquaintance with Mr. Darcy.
es: As everyone was concentrated on the game, Wickham could dedicate his time to talking with Elizabeth, and she was eager to listen to him, although she had no hope that he would tell her what she most wanted to know, the story of his relationship with Darcy.

en: She dared not even mention that gentleman.
vi: She did not even dare to mention his name.
tr: She didn't even dare to mention it.
es: She did not even dare to mention his name.

en: Her curiosity, however, was unexpectedly relieved.
vi: But soon, her curiosity was satisfied, as Mr. Wickham began the topic.
tr: Nevertheless, her curiosity was unexpectedly satisfied.
es: However, her curiosity was unexpectedly satisfied.

en: mr Wickham began the subject himself.
vi: But soon, her curiosity was satisfied, as Mr. Wickham began the topic.
tr: Mr. Wickham brought up the subject himself.
es: It was Mr. Wickham himself who brought up the subject.

en: He inquired how far Netherfield was from Meryton; and, after receiving her answer, asked in a hesitating manner how long mr Darcy had been staying there.
vi: He asked her how far Netherfield was from Meryton, and after hearing the answer, with a slight hesitation, he asked how long Mr. Darcy had been there. She replied:
tr: He asked how far Netherfield was from Meryton; after receiving Elizabeth's answer, he hesitated and then wanted to know how long Mr. Darcy had been staying there.
es: He asked how far it was from Meryton to Netherfield, and after hearing Elizabeth's response and a few seconds of hesitation, he also wanted to know how long Mr. Darcy had been there.

en: “About a month,” said Elizabeth; and then, unwilling to let the subject drop, added, “he is a man of very large property in Derbyshire, I understand.”
vi: - About a month. Then, not wanting the story to be left unfinished, she added: - I have been informed that he has a large estate in Derbyshire.
tr: "It has been about a month," said Elizabeth; then, to keep the matter from closing, she continued, "As far as I understand, he has a very large estate in Derbyshire."
es: ––About a month ––answered Elizabeth. And with eagerness that the topic wouldn't end there, he added: ––I believe that gentleman owns large estates in Derbyshire.

en: “Yes,” replied Wickham; “his estate there is a noble one.
vi: Wickham replied: - Yes, his real estate is quite substantial.
tr: "Yes," replied Wickham; – "he has a solid estate there.
es: ––Yes ––replied Wickham––, his estate is significant, it provides him with ten thousand pounds annually.

en: A clear ten thousand per annum.
vi: Up to ten thousand a year.
tr: Ten thousand a year clear.
es: ––Yes ––replied Wickham––, his estate is significant, it provides him with ten thousand pounds annually.

en: You could not have met with a person more capable of giving you certain information on that head than myself—for I have been connected with his family, in a particular manner, from my infancy.”
vi: You won't find anyone who can provide as much information about him as I can, because I have had a special relationship with his family since I was a child.
tr: You couldn't have come across anyone who could give you more information on that subject than me – because I have had a special relationship with his family since my childhood."
es: No one better than I could give you authentic information about Mr. Darcy, for I have been particularly connected with his family since my childhood.

en: Elizabeth could not but look surprised.
vi: Elizabeth could not hide her surprise.
tr: Elizabeth couldn't hide the astonishment on her face.
es: Elizabeth couldn't help but show her surprise.

en: “You may well be surprised, Miss Bennet, at such an assertion, after seeing, as you probably might, the very cold manner of our meeting yesterday.
vi: - Elizabeth, you might be very surprised to hear me say this, after you must have noticed the cold attitude between the two of us when we met yesterday.
tr: "After seeing the cold atmosphere in our encounter yesterday, such a statement might certainly surprise you, Miss Bennet.
es: ––It will surprise you what I say, Miss Bennet, after having seen, as you probably did, the coldness of our meeting yesterday.

en: Are you much acquainted with mr Darcy?”
vi: Are you well acquainted with Mr. Darcy?
tr: –Do you know Mr. Darcy well?"
es: Do you know Mr. Darcy well?

en: “As much as I ever wish to be,” cried Elizabeth, warmly.
vi: Elizabeth spoke harshly: - Close enough to the extent that I desire.
tr: "Enough," cried Elizabeth in a warm voice.
es: ––More than I would wish ––replied Elizabeth affectionately––.

en: “I have spent four days in the same house with him, and I think him very disagreeable.”
vi: I spent four days under the same roof with him, and because of that, I think he is a really unpleasant person.
tr: –"I spent four days in the same house with him and I find him quite unpleasant."
es: I have spent four days in the same house as him and I find him very unpleasant.

en: “I have no right to give my opinion,” said Wickham, “as to his being agreeable or otherwise.
vi: Wickham said: - I do not have the right to give my opinion on whether he is pleasant or not.
tr: "I have no right to state my opinion," said Wickham, "I cannot say whether she is charming or not.
es: ––I have no right to say whether he is or isn't disagreeable ––continued Mr. Wickham––.

en: I am not qualified to form one.
vi: I am not qualified to give an opinion.
tr: I am not authorized to give an opinion.
es: I am not the most suitable person for that.

en: I have known him too long and too well to be a fair judge.
vi: I have known him for too long and too well to be impartial in judging him.
tr: I have known her for too long and too well to make a fair judgment.
es: I have known him for too long and too well to be a fair judge.

en: It is impossible for me to be impartial.
vi: I cannot remain unbiased.
tr: It is impossible for me to be impartial.
es: It would be impossible for me to be impartial.

en: But I believe your opinion of him would in general astonish—and, perhaps, you would not express it quite so strongly anywhere else.
vi: But I believe your opinion of him is surprisingly harsh – and perhaps elsewhere you would not speak so harshly.
tr: But I believe that your opinion of her would surprise many people – though perhaps you would not express it so strongly elsewhere.
es: But I believe that the opinion you have of him would surprise anyone, and you might not express it so categorically anywhere else.

en: Here you are in your own family.”
vi: Here, you are with your family.
tr: After all, you are among family here."
es: Here you are among your own.

en: “Upon my word I say no more here than I might say in any house in the neighbourhood, except Netherfield.
vi: - I assure you that here I am not exaggerating what I can say in any other house in the area, except at Netherfield.
tr: "Well, I wouldn't say more about any house in this neighborhood than I would here, except for Netherfield.
es: ––I give you my word that what I say here I would say in any other house in the neighborhood, except in Netherfield.

en: He is not at all liked in Hertfordshire.
vi: No one in Hertfordshire loves him.
tr: No one in Hertfordshire likes it.
es: Darcy has disgusted everyone with his pride.

en: Everybody is disgusted with his pride.
vi: You will not find anyone who speaks well of him.
tr: Everyone hates its pride.
es: Darcy has disgusted everyone with his pride.

en: You will not find him more favourably spoken of by anyone.”
vi: You will not find anyone who speaks well of him.
tr: I don't think you'll hear anyone speaking well of it anywhere."
es: You will not find anyone who speaks well of him.

en: “I cannot pretend to be sorry,” said Wickham, after a short interruption, “that he or that any man should not be estimated beyond their deserts; but with him I believe it does not often happen.
vi: Wickham said: - I cannot pretend to regret that he or any other person should not be overestimated compared to their true worth, but with him, I believe this does not happen often.
tr: "I can't say I'm sorry," said Wickham, after a brief hesitation, "no one should be given more credit than they deserve; but in his case, I suppose that's not happening.
es: ––I cannot pretend that I am sorry ––said Wickham after a brief pause––. I do not feel that he or anyone else should be esteemed solely for their merits, but with Darcy, it usually does not happen that way.

en: The world is blinded by his fortune and consequence, or frightened by his high and imposing manners, and sees him only as he chooses to be seen.”
vi: People are dazzled by his wealth and status, or intimidated by his elevated and dignified demeanor, so they see him the way he wants to be seen.
tr: Anyone who sees him is blinded by his wealth and power, or they are intimidated by his arrogant, oppressive demeanor and see him only as he wants to be seen."
es: People are blinded by his fortune and his importance or fear him for his distinguished and haughty manners, and they see him only as he wishes to be seen.

en: “I should take him, even on my slight acquaintance, to be an ill-tempered man.”
vi: - Even though I don't know him well, I still consider him to be a person with a bad temper.
tr: "Even though I barely know him, I can say that he is a grumpy man."
es: ––Well, despite the little I know him, I consider him a bad person.

en: Wickham only shook his head.
vi: Wickham just shook his head.
tr: Wickham just nodded.
es: Wickham merely nodded his head.

en: “I wonder,” said he, at the next opportunity of speaking, “whether he is likely to be in this country much longer.”
vi: He said: - I wonder how long he will stay here.
tr: "I wonder," he said, when he got the chance to speak again, "if he will stay around here much longer?"
es: Then he added: "I wonder if he plans to stay in this county for long."

en: “I do not at all know; but I heard nothing of his going away when I was at Netherfield.
vi: - I don't know anything, but when I was at Netherfield, I didn't hear anything about him leaving.
tr: "I have no idea; but I didn't hear anything about him leaving while I was at Netherfield.
es: ––I have no idea; but I didn't hear anything about him leaving while he was at Netherfield.

en: I hope your plans in favour of the ——shire will not be affected by his being in the neighbourhood.”
vi: I hope his presence around here won't affect your plans to join the unit here.
tr: I hope your plans for ------shire won't change because of his presence in the area."
es: I hope Darcy's presence won't alter his plans to stay at the county garrison.

en: “Oh no—it is not for me to be driven away by mr Darcy.
vi: - Ah, no – it’s not that I will be shunned by Mr. Darcy.
tr: "No, never! –Mr. Darcy cannot send me away.
es: ––Of course not.

en: If he wishes to avoid seeing me he must go.
vi: If he wants to avoid meeting me, he must leave.
tr: If he wishes to avoid seeing me, he must be the one to go.
es: I will not be the one to leave because of Mr. Darcy, and it always saddens me to see him, but I have only one reason to avoid him and I can proclaim it in front of everyone: a painful regret for his mistreatment and for being the way he is.

en: We are not on friendly terms, and it always gives me pain to meet him, but I have no reason for avoiding him but what I might proclaim to all the world—a sense of very great ill-usage, and most painful regrets at his being what he is.
vi: The two of us are not friends; I always feel uncomfortable when I see him, but I have no reason to avoid him except for what I can publicly declare: a sense of mistreatment, along with the sorrowful regret of seeing him in this situation.
tr: We are not on good terms; seeing him always brings me pain, but I have no reason to avoid him, and I can tell the whole world why – a terrible sense of being wronged and agonizing remorse towards him.
es: I will not be the one to leave because of Mr. Darcy, and it always saddens me to see him, but I have only one reason to avoid him and I can proclaim it in front of everyone: a painful regret for his mistreatment and for being the way he is.

en: His father, Miss Bennet, the late mr Darcy, was one of the best men that ever breathed, and the truest friend I ever had; and I can never be in company with this mr Darcy without being grieved to the soul by a thousand tender recollections.
vi: Miss Bennet, his father passed away, was one of the best men who ever lived on this earth, and also one of my most trusted confidants, so I cannot be close to this Mr. Darcy without my heart aching with a thousand tender memories.
tr: His father, Miss Bennet, the late Mr. Darcy, was one of the kindest men to ever walk the earth and was my truest friend in life; when I see this Mr. Darcy, countless tender memories pierce my heart.
es: His father, Miss Bennet, the late Mr. Darcy, was the best of men and my best friend; I cannot speak with Darcy without my heart breaking with a thousand tender memories.

en: His behaviour to myself has been scandalous; but I verily believe I could forgive him anything and everything, rather than his disappointing the hopes and disgracing the memory of his father.”
vi: His attitude towards me is scandalous, but honestly, I believe that I can forgive him for everything, rather than let him disappoint all hopes and bring shame to his father's spirit.
tr: His behavior towards me is utterly disgraceful; believe me, I can forgive him for everything but never for shattering his father's hopes and tarnishing his memory."
es: His conduct towards me has been improper; but I sincerely confess that I would forgive him everything except that he has frustrated his father's hopes and dishonored his memory.

en: Elizabeth found the interest of the subject increase, and listened with all her heart; but the delicacy of it prevented further inquiry.
vi: Elizabeth felt more interested in the matter and listened with all her heart, but due to delicate reasons, she could not inquire further.
tr: Elizabeth felt that the matter was becoming even more interesting and listened with full attention; but the sensitivity of the subject prevented her from asking questions.
es: Elizabeth found that her interest was increasing and she listened with all her senses, but the delicate nature of the matter prevented her from asking more questions.

en: mr Wickham began to speak on more general topics, Meryton, the neighbourhood, the society, appearing highly pleased with all that he had yet seen, and speaking of the latter, especially, with gentle but very intelligible gallantry.
vi: Mr. Wickham began to talk about more general topics, Meryton, the surrounding area, through social interactions, revealing his appreciation for what he had observed; and with a charming and gentle manner that was very easy to understand, he particularly spoke about social relations.
tr: Mr. Wickham began to talk about more general subjects, Meryton, the surroundings, and the people; he seemed to be very impressed with what he had seen; he spoke of the people in particular with a courteous but very familiar compliment.
es: Wickham began to talk about more general topics: Meryton, the neighborhood, the society; and he seemed extremely pleased with what he already knew, speaking especially of the latter with gentle but understandable gallantry.

en: “It was the prospect of constant society, and good society,” he added, “which was my chief inducement to enter the ——shire.
vi: He added: - It was precisely because I thought of stable social relations and good relationships that I joined the militia.
tr: "The main reason I joined this regiment," he added, "was that it promised a solid community of people, an elite environment.
es: ––The main incentive for my joining the county garrison ––continued Wickham–– was the hope of being in constant contact with society, and people of good society.

en: I know it to be a most respectable, agreeable corps; and my friend Denny tempted me further by his account of their present quarters, and the very great attentions and excellent acquaintance Meryton had procured them.
vi: I know this is the most respectable, most pleasant force, and my friend Denny further encouraged me through the way he spoke about the residential area, along with the utmost care and wonderful relationships in Meryton.
tr: I knew it was a very respectable, reasonable regiment; when my friend Denny described their current headquarters, the close interest Meryton showed them, and the tremendous camaraderie, I was completely captivated.
es: I knew it was a very respected and pleasant Corps, and my friend Denny tempted me further by describing his current residence and the great attentions and excellent friendships he has found in Meryton.

en: Society, I own, is necessary to me.
vi: I confess that I desire social relationships.
tr: The environment is essential for me.
es: I confess that I need a bit of social life.

en: I have been a disappointed man, and my spirits will not bear solitude.
vi: I have been disappointed before, and my temperament cannot endure loneliness.
tr: I am a disappointed man; my soul cannot endure loneliness.
es: I am a disappointed man and my state of mind could not bear solitude.

en: I must have employment and society.
vi: I must have work and relationships.
tr: I need work and friends.
es: I need occupation and company.

en: A military life is not what I was intended for, but circumstances have now made it eligible.
vi: Military life was not something I aimed for before, but circumstances now make me qualified.
tr: I did not aim for a military life, but circumstances led to it.
es: It was not my intention to join military life, but current circumstances made me choose it.

en: The church ought to have been my profession—I was brought up for the church; and I should at this time have been in possession of a most valuable living, had it pleased the gentleman we were speaking of just now.”
vi: The church should have been my professional environment. I was raised for the church; by now I would have had the most valuable life, if the person I just mentioned had accepted,
tr: My profession should have been the church – I was trained for the church and would now have the most valuable church, had the gentleman we mentioned been willing."
es: The Church should have been my profession; I was educated for it and today I would be in possession of a valuable rectory if it had not been for the gentleman I was talking about a moment ago.

en: “Indeed!”
vi: - Really?
tr: "Really?""
es: ––Really?

en: “Yes—the late mr Darcy bequeathed me the next presentation of the best living in his gift.
vi: - Yes: Darcy's late father gave me the highest ecclesiastical income among what he left for me.
tr: "Yes – the late Mr. Darcy bequeathed to me the best parish under his administration, and I was to take charge of it when it became vacant.
es: ––Yes; the late Mr. Darcy had arranged for me to be presented with the best ecclesiastical benefice on his estates.

en: He was my godfather, and excessively attached to me.
vi: He was my godfather, very attached to me.
tr: He was my godfather and was extremely attached to me.
es: He was my godfather and loved me dearly.

en: I cannot do justice to his kindness.
vi: I didn't know how to repay his kindness.
tr: No amount of praise can do justice to his kindness.
es: I can never do justice to his kindness.

en: He meant to provide for me amply, and thought he had done it; but when the living fell, it was given elsewhere.”
vi: He intended to provide me with ample means of living and thought he had accomplished this, but when the income was reduced, I did not receive it.
tr: He wanted to provide me with a good livelihood, and he thought he had; but when the parish became vacant, it was given to someone else."
es: He wanted to leave me well situated, and he believed he had done so; but when the position became vacant, it was granted to someone else.

en: “Good heavens!” cried Elizabeth; “but how could that be?
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed:
tr: "Oh my God!" cried Elizabeth; "but how can this be?
es: ––My God! ––exclaimed Elizabeth––.

en: How could his will be disregarded?
vi: - Oh no! How could this happen? How could people not follow the will?
tr: –How can the will be disregarded?
es: But how could that be? How could they contradict his will?

en: Why did not you seek legal redress?”
vi: Why didn't you seek legal intervention?
tr: –Why didn't you pursue legal action?"
es: Why didn't you seek justice?

en: “There was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to give me no hope from law.
vi: - There is one clause in the will that leaves me with no hope from the law.
tr: "There was something unofficial in the conditions of the will, it didn't give me a chance in the eyes of the law.
es: ––There was so much informality in the terms of the legacy that the law would not have given me any hope.

en: A man of honour could not have doubted the intention, but mr Darcy chose to doubt it—or to treat it as a merely conditional recommendation, and to assert that I had forfeited all claim to it by extravagance, imprudence, in short, anything or nothing.
vi: A man of honor cannot doubt the intention, but Mr. Darcy deliberately doubts, or considers it merely a conditional proposal, and asserts that I have forfeited all rights in it through reckless extravagance, something like that.
tr: An honorable man couldn't doubt the intention here, but Mr. Darcy chose to doubt – or thought it was a conditional recommendation and claimed that I had renounced all my rights, saying I was extravagant, saying I was imprudent – whatever came to his mind.
es: A man of honor would not have doubted the intention of those terms; but Darcy preferred to doubt it or take it as a merely conditional recommendation and asserted that I had lost all my rights due to my extravagance and imprudence; in short, either for one reason or another, the fact is that the rectory became vacant two years ago, just when I was old enough to occupy it, and it was given to someone else; and it is no less true that I cannot blame myself for having done anything to deserve losing it.

en: Certain it is that the living became vacant two years ago, exactly as I was of an age to hold it, and that it was given to another man; and no less certain is it, that I cannot accuse myself of having really done anything to deserve to lose it.
vi: What is certain is that the income was gone two years ago, at the time I came of age to benefit from it. This amount was assigned to someone else. It is also certain that I cannot convict myself of having actually done anything to deserve disinheritance.
tr: That church also became vacant two years ago, just when I was of age to take over, and it was given to someone else, that's certain; but it's also certain that I can't accuse myself of having done anything to deserve losing that church.
es: A man of honor would not have doubted the intention of those terms; but Darcy preferred to doubt it or take it as a merely conditional recommendation and asserted that I had lost all my rights due to my extravagance and imprudence; in short, either for one reason or another, the fact is that the rectory became vacant two years ago, just when I was old enough to occupy it, and it was given to someone else; and it is no less true that I cannot blame myself for having done anything to deserve losing it.

en: I have a warm unguarded temper, and I may perhaps have sometimes spoken my opinion of him, and to him, too freely.
vi: I have a hot temper, cannot restrain myself; perhaps I occasionally said something too loose about him, or to him.
tr: I have a warm, unprotected nature; I may have sometimes spoken freely about my opinions of him, I may have even said something to him.
es: I have a fiery temperament, I am indiscreet, and perhaps I have expressed my opinion about Darcy a few times, and even to him, with excessive frankness.

en: I can recall nothing worse.
vi: I do not remember doing anything worse.
tr: I can't think of anything worse.
es: I do not remember anything else I could be accused of.

en: But the fact is, that we are very different sort of men, and that he hates me.”
vi: But the truth is, we belong to two very different types of people, and he hates me.
tr: But the truth is, we are very different kinds of people and he hates me."
es: But the fact is that we are very different and that he hates me.

en: “This is quite shocking!
vi: - It's terrible!
tr: "I was shocked!
es: ––It's shameful!

en: He deserves to be publicly disgraced.”
vi: He should have been publicly exposed.
tr: –They deserve to be humiliated in front of everyone."
es: He deserves to be discredited in public.

en: “Some time or other he will be—but it shall not be by me.
vi: - One day you will be exposed, but not by me.
tr: "It will eventually happen anyway – but I won't be the one to do it.
es: ––One day or another his time will come, but it won't be me who discredits him.

en: Till I can forget his father, I can never defy or expose him.”
vi: As long as I cannot forget your father, I cannot challenge or accuse you.
tr: I can't confront him until he can forget his father, I can't expose him."
es: As long as I can't forget his father, I will never be able to challenge or unmask him.

en: Elizabeth honoured him for such feelings, and thought him handsomer than ever as he expressed them.
vi: Elizabeth respected him for these thoughts, thinking he looked more handsome when he expressed them.
tr: Elizabeth praised him for these feelings, and thought he looked more handsome than ever while expressing them.
es: Elizabeth honored him for such sentiments and found him more attractive than ever as he expressed them.

en: “But what,” said she, after a pause, “can have been his motive?
vi: After a moment of silence, she said: - But what is his motivation?
tr: "Mom," he said, after a moment's hesitation, "what could be the reason?
es: ––But ––he continued after a pause––, what could be the reason?

en: what can have induced him to behave so cruelly?”
vi: What could make him act so ruthlessly?
tr: –what could have driven him to act so cruelly?"
es: What could have induced him to act with such cruelty?

en: “A thorough, determined dislike of me—a dislike which I cannot but attribute in some measure to jealousy.
vi: - He hates me intensely, and I believe it is due to jealousy.
tr: "A deep, resolute hatred towards me – a hatred that I involuntarily attributed to a certain degree of jealousy.
es: ––A deep and energetic antipathy towards me that I can only attribute to jealousy to a certain extent.

en: Had the late mr Darcy liked me less, his son might have borne with me better; but his father’s uncommon attachment to me irritated him, I believe, very early in life.
vi: If the old man loved me less, his son might have treated me better. But I believe that the unusual attachment between the old man and me made him angry from the very beginning.
tr: The late Mr. Darcy might have treated me better if his father had loved me less: but it seems to me that his father's extraordinary attachment to me disturbed him even as a child.
es: If the late Mr. Darcy had not been so fond of me, his son would have tolerated me better. But the extraordinary affection that his father felt for me irritated him, I believe, from his earliest childhood.

en: He had not a temper to bear the sort of competition in which we stood—the sort of preference which was often given me.”
vi: He did not have enough composure to accept the rivalry between the two of us, to accept the favoritism shown towards me.
tr: He was not of a nature to endure the competition we were in – a competition in which I was always the preferred one."
es: He did not have the character to withstand the kind of rivalry in which we found ourselves, nor the preference that his father often showed me.

en: “I had not thought mr Darcy so bad as this—though I have never liked him, I had not thought so very ill of him—I had supposed him to be despising his fellow-creatures in general, but did not suspect him of descending to such malicious revenge, such injustice, such inhumanity as this!”
vi: - I did not think that Mr. Darcy could be so wicked; although I never liked him, I did not think too badly of him. I guessed that he just generally disliked others, but I did not expect him to stoop to such malicious revenge, such injustice, such inhumanity!
tr: "I never imagined Mr. Darcy could be so bad – although I never liked him, I did not expect him to be this bad. –I thought he generally looked down on people, but I never suspected he could stoop to such heartless vindictiveness, such injustice, such cruelty."
es: He did not have the character to withstand the kind of rivalry in which we found ourselves, nor the preference that his father often showed me.

en: After a few minutes’ reflection, however, she continued, “I do remember his boasting one day, at Netherfield, of the implacability of his resentments, of his having an unforgiving temper.
vi: After a few minutes of thinking, she continued: - Actually, at Netherfield the other day, I remember hearing him boast about his unappeasable irritability and his unwillingness to forgive.
