tr: After thinking for a few minutes, he continued– "I remember, one day at Netherfield, he was boasting that he had an unforgiving nature, that his resentment never passed.
es: ––I remember that one day, in Netherfield, he was boasting about the relentlessness of his feelings and having an unforgiving character.

en: His disposition must be dreadful.”
vi: His temperament is truly dreadful.
tr: He must be a terrible person."
es: His way of being is dreadful.

en: “I will not trust myself on the subject,” replied Wickham; “I can hardly be just to him.”
vi: Wickham replied: - I am not confident enough to talk about this. I find it difficult to be impartial in judging him.
tr: "I cannot trust myself on this matter," replied Wickham; "it is difficult for me to be fair to him."
es: ––I must not speak of this topic, replied Wickham––; I find it difficult to be fair with him.

en: Elizabeth was again deep in thought, and after a time exclaimed, “To treat in such a manner the godson, the friend, the favourite of his father!”
vi: Elizabeth sank deep into thought again, and after a moment she exclaimed: - To treat someone in such a manner, the godson, the friend, the one favored by the father!
tr: Elizabeth once again fell into deep thoughts and after a while couldn't hold herself back: "To treat a godson, a friend, someone his father loved in such a way!"
es: Elizabeth reflected again and after a few moments exclaimed: ––To treat the godson, the friend, the father's favorite in that way!

en: She could have added, “A young man, too, like you, whose very countenance may vouch for your being amiable.”
vi: She could have added: "A young man, like you, with a face that could be called charming," but she only said:
tr: –She was about to add, "and to a young man like you, whose beauty is proof of his goodness," –but she settled for saying, "and to someone who is probably your childhood friend, with whom you have close ties according to what you say!"
es: He could have added: "To a young man, moreover, like you, whose face alone offers ample proof of your kindness."

en: But she contented herself with—“And one, too, who had probably been his own companion from childhood, connected together, as I think you said, in the closest manner.”
vi: - And perhaps also a close companion from his youth, the closest relationship, as he said.
tr: –She was about to add, "and to a young man like you, whose beauty is proof of his goodness," –but she settled for saying, "and to someone who is probably your childhood friend, with whom you have close ties according to what you say!"
es: But he limited himself to saying: ––To a man who was surely the companion of his childhood and with whom, as I believe you have said, he had close ties.

en: “We were born in the same parish, within the same park; the greatest part of our youth was passed together: inmates of the same house, sharing the same amusements, objects of the same parental care.
vi: - We were born in the same parish, in the same garden, living together for most of our childhood; we stayed in the same dormitory, shared the same pleasures, and were cared for by the same parents.
tr: "We were born in the same village, under the same grove; much of our youth was spent together; we were people of the same house, shared the same amusements, and experienced the same parental love.
es: ––We were born in the same parish, on the same estate; we spent most of our youth together, living in the same house, sharing games, and being the object of the same parental care.

en: My father began life in the profession which your uncle, mr Philips, appears to do so much credit to; but he gave up everything to be of use to the late mr Darcy, and devoted all his time to the care of the Pemberley property.
vi: My father started his life with the same profession as your uncle Philips, but he gave it all up to work for Mr. Darcy, dedicating all his time to taking care of the Pemberly estate.
tr: My father started in the same profession that I believe your brother-in-law Mr. Philips is now pursuing with great success – but he left everything to be of service to the late Mr. Darcy and dedicated all his time to managing the Pemberley estate.
es: My father started in the profession in which it seems his uncle, Mr. Philips, has achieved so much prestige; but he left it all to serve Mr. Darcy and dedicated all his time to managing the Pemberley estate.

en: He was most highly esteemed by mr Darcy, a most intimate, confidential friend.
vi: He was greatly respected by Mr. Darcy, and he was also the closest and most trustworthy person in his household.
tr: He was held in high esteem by Mr. Darcy, being his close friend and confidant.
es: Mr. Darcy held him in high esteem and he was his trusted man and closest friend.

en: mr Darcy often acknowledged himself to be under the greatest obligations to my father’s active superintendence; and when, immediately before my father’s death, mr Darcy gave him a voluntary promise of providing for me, I am convinced that he felt it to be as much a debt of gratitude to him as of affection to myself.”
vi: Mr. Darcy often acknowledged that he owed a deep debt of gratitude for my father's diligent care. Just before my father passed away, Mr. Darcy voluntarily promised him that it was both out of a sense of deep debt to him and affection for me.
tr: Mr. Darcy often said himself how much he felt indebted to my father's active management; just before my father's death, when Mr. Darcy voluntarily promised to look after me, I believed it was as much out of gratitude to my father as it was out of affection for me."
es: Mr. Darcy himself often acknowledged that he owed much to my father's active supervision, and when, shortly before he died, Mr. Darcy spontaneously promised to take care of me, I am convinced he did so to repay my father a debt of gratitude as well as out of the affection he had for me.

en: “How strange!” cried Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - How strange!
tr: "How strange!" cried Elizabeth.
es: ––How strange! ––exclaimed Elizabeth––.

en: “How abominable!
vi: How disgusting!
tr: "How abominable!
es: How abominable!

en: I wonder that the very pride of this mr Darcy has not made him just to you.
vi: I wonder if it was pride that made him treat you like that.
tr: –This Mr. Darcy's pride prevented him from being fair to you!
es: It astonishes me that Mr. Darcy's own pride hasn't compelled him to be just with you.

en: If from no better motive, that he should not have been too proud to be dishonest,—for dishonesty I must call it.”
vi: If not for a greater motive, I think he wouldn't have been too proud to become dishonest – because I must call it dishonesty.
tr: –Even if not driven by a better impulse, his pride should not have allowed him to act so basely –because I call what he did base."
es: Because, even if only for that reason, he is too proud not to be honorable; and dishonesty is what I must call what he has done to you.

en: “It is wonderful,” replied Wickham; “for almost all his actions may be traced to pride; and pride has often been his best friend.
vi: Wickham replied: - That is wonderful, because almost all of his actions stem from pride, and pride is often his closest friend.
tr: "Great," answered Wickham, "because almost all of his actions can be attributed to pride; – and pride is often his best friend.
es: It's curious ––answered Wickham––, because almost all of his actions have been guided by pride, which has often been his best advisor.

en: It has connected him nearer with virtue than any other feeling.
vi: It has connected him closer to virtue than any other feeling.
tr: His pride has made him closer to virtue than to other feelings.
es: For him, it is more connected to virtue than any other feeling.

en: But we are none of us consistent; and in his behaviour to me there were stronger impulses even than pride.”
vi: But none of us are consistent; and in his attitude towards me, there are stronger motives than pride.
tr: But none of us are consistent; in his behavior towards me, there were impulses even stronger than pride."
es: But neither of us are consistent; and in his behavior towards me, there were impulses even stronger than pride.

en: “Can such abominable pride as his have ever done him good?”
vi: - Could it be that such disgusting pride has ever helped him do good work?
tr: "I wonder if he ever saw any benefit from such a vile pride?"" "Yes.
es: ––Is it possible that such a detestable pride as his has ever led him to do some good?

en: “Yes; it has often led him to be liberal and generous; to give his money freely, to display hospitality, to assist his tenants, and relieve the poor.
vi: - Yes, of course. Pride often makes him generous and chivalrous – to freely distribute money, to demonstrate hospitality, to support tenants, to help the poor.
tr: That pride often makes him tolerant and generous, –he spends his money lavishly, shows hospitality, supports his tenants, and feeds the poor.
es: ––Yes; it has often led him to be liberal and generous, to give his money freely, to be hospitable, to help his tenants, and to aid the poor.

en: Family pride, and filial pride, for he is very proud of what his father was, have done this.
vi: Pride in his family, pride in filial piety drove these actions, because he is very proud of his father.
tr: It was family pride, and the pride of being a son that did this –because he was very proud of his father.
es: Family pride, his pride as a son, because he is very proud of what his father was, has made him act in this way.

en: Not to appear to disgrace his family, to degenerate from the popular qualities, or lose the influence of the Pemberley House, is a powerful motive.
vi: Not revealing it in a way that would disgrace the family, such as degrading common values, or diminishing the influence of the Pemberley house, all these are strong motivations.
tr: Not doing anything to disgrace his family, not deviating from popular traits, not losing the influence of Pemberley Manor, this is a strong impulse.
es: The desire to show that he did not fall short of his own, that he was no less esteemed than they were, and that he did not diminish the influence of the house of Pemberley, was a powerful motive for him.

en: He has also brotherly pride, which, with some brotherly affection, makes him a very kind and careful guardian of his sister; and you will hear him generally cried up as the most attentive and best of brothers.”
vi: He is also proud of his kinship which, with a certain brotherly love, has made him a very kind and careful guardian of his sister. You could hear people praising him as the most caring and best brother among his siblings.
tr: There is also the pride of being a brother, which, combined with brotherly love, has made him a tender and attentive guardian of his sister; you hear from everyone that he is the most sensitive, the best brother."
es: He also has a brotherly pride which, combined with some fraternal affection, has made him a most kind and solicitous guardian of Miss Darcy, and you will often hear it said that he is considered the most attentive and best of brothers.

en: “What sort of a girl is Miss Darcy?”
vi: - And what kind of person is Miss Darcy?
tr: "What kind of girl is Miss Darcy?""
es: ––What kind of girl is Miss Darcy?

en: He shook his head.
vi: He shook his head:
tr: He nodded his head.
es: Wickham nodded.

en: “I wish I could call her amiable.
vi: -I wish I could say she was charming.
tr: –"I wish I could call her cute.
es: ––I wish I could say she is charming.

en: It gives me pain to speak ill of a Darcy; but she is too much like her brother,—very, very proud.
vi: I feel sad speaking ill of a member of the Darcy family. But she is just like her brother, proud, very proud.
tr: It pains me to speak ill of a Darcy. But she is just like her brother, –very, very proud.
es: It pains me to speak ill of a Darcy. But now she resembles her brother too much, she is very proud.

en: As a child, she was affectionate and pleasing, and extremely fond of me; and I have devoted hours and hours to her amusement.
vi: When she was a child, she was affectionate and pleasant, and she was very fond of me; I spent a lot of time playing with her.
tr: As a child, she was friendly, sweet, and very fond of me; I spent hours entertaining her.
es: As a child, she was very affectionate and accommodating and had great affection for me. Oh, the hours I have spent entertaining her!

en: But she is nothing to me now.
vi: But now, to her, I am nothing.
tr: But now she means nothing to me.
es: But now she is indifferent to me.

en: She is a handsome girl, about fifteen or sixteen, and, I understand, highly accomplished.
vi: She is a pretty girl, about fifteen or sixteen, and as far as I know, she has quite a few talents.
tr: A beautiful girl, fifteen or sixteen years old, and from what I understand, quite talented.
es: She is a beautiful girl of fifteen or sixteen years, I believe very well-educated.

en: Since her father’s death her home has been London, where a lady lives with her, and superintends her education.”
vi: Since her father passed away, she has been living in London, with a lady who stays with her and acts as her governess.
tr: Since her father's death, her home has been in London, where a lady stays with her and oversees her education."
es: Since her father's death, she has been living in London with a governess.

en: After many pauses and many trials of other subjects, Elizabeth could not help reverting once more to the first, and saying,—
vi: After many moments of silence and several attempts to change the subject, Elizabeth couldn't help but return to the original topic. She said:
tr: After many hesitations and trying many other topics, Elizabeth couldn't help but return to the first topic once again:
es: After many pauses and many attempts to talk about other topics, Elizabeth could not help but return to the first subject, and said:

en: “I am astonished at his intimacy with mr Bingley.
vi: - I am surprised by the friendship between Darcy and Mr. Bingley!
tr: "I am surprised at his intimacy with Mr. Bingley!
es: ––What amazes me is his friendship with Mr. Bingley.

en: How can mr Bingley, who seems good-humour itself, and is, I really believe, truly amiable, be in friendship with such a man?
vi: How can Mr. Bingley, who seems quite cheerful and genuinely friendly, as I believe, be friends with someone like Darcy?
tr: How can Mr. Bingley, who seems to be a good-natured and truly charming person, be friends with such a man?
es: How can Mr. Bingley, who is the very embodiment of good humor, and is, I am convinced, truly kind, have anything to do with a man like Mr. Darcy?

en: How can they suit each other?
vi: How can Mr. Bingley, who seems quite cheerful and genuinely friendly, as I believe, be friends with someone like Darcy?
tr: How can they be compatible with each other?
es: How can they get along?

en: Do you know mr Bingley?”
vi: Do you know anything about Mr. Bingley?
tr: –Do you know Mr. Bingley?"
es: Do you know Mr. Bingley?

en: “Not at all.”
vi: - Absolutely not.
tr: "No."
es: ––No, I don't know him.

en: “He is a sweet-tempered, amiable, charming man.
vi: - He is a young man with a gentle, charming, and captivating personality.
tr: "He is a sweet, charming, polite man.
es: ––He is a charming man, kind, with a sweet disposition.

en: He cannot know what mr Darcy is.”
vi: He cannot understand what kind of person Darcy is.
tr: She must not have recognized Mr. Darcy."
es: You must not know what Mr. Darcy is really like.

en: “Probably not; but mr Darcy can please where he chooses.
vi: - It may be so, but Mr. Darcy can please others when he wants to.
tr: "Probably; but Mr. Darcy can be pleasant when he chooses to be.
es: ––Probably not; but Mr. Darcy knows how to please when he feels like it.

en: He does not want abilities.
vi: He is not very likely to.
tr: He is not without talent.
es: He doesn't need to make an effort.

en: He can be a conversible companion if he thinks it worth his while.
vi: He can be a companion to socialize with if he thinks it benefits him.
tr: If he thinks it worth his time, he can be quite engaging.
es: He can be a pleasant conversationalist if he thinks it's worth his while.

en: Among those who are at all his equals in consequence, he is a very different man from what he is to the less prosperous.
vi: Among those of his own status, he becomes a completely different person compared to when he associates with those of lower status.
tr: Among those whose fortunes are equal to his own, he is a very different person than he is among the poor.
es: Among people of his own rank, he is very different from how he is with those of lower status.

en: His pride never deserts him; but with the rich he is liberal-minded, just, sincere, rational, honourable, and, perhaps, agreeable,—allowing something for fortune and figure.”
vi: He is always proud, but with the wealthy, he has a liberal, fair, honest, just, straightforward, and perhaps pleasant demeanor – this is in addition to his wealth and appearance.
tr: His pride never leaves him: but when he is with the wealthy, he is liberal-minded, fair, sincere, sensible, honest, and perhaps even charming – of course, one must give credit where credit is due."
es: Pride never leaves him, but with the wealthy, he adopts a liberal mindset; he is fair, sincere, reasonable, honorable, and perhaps even pleasant, partly due to his fortune and good looks.

en: The whist party soon afterwards breaking up, the players gathered round the other table, and mr Collins took his station between his cousin Elizabeth and ms Philips.
vi: The whist card game table then dispersed, and the card players gathered around another table, with Mr. Collins sitting between Elizabeth and Mrs. Philips.
tr: The whist party ended shortly after; the players gathered around the other table; Mr. Collins took his place between his cousin Elizabeth and Mrs. Philips.
es: Shortly after, the whist game ended and the players gathered around the other table. Collins positioned himself between his cousin Elizabeth and Mrs. Philips.

en: The usual inquiries as to his success were made by the latter.
vi: He lost every point, but when Mrs. Philips expressed concern, he solemnly reassured her that it did not matter at all, that he regarded money as a trivial matter, and asked her not to worry.
tr: Mrs. Philips asked the usual questions about his success.
es: The latter asked him the usual questions about the outcome of the game.

en: It had not been very great; he had lost every point; but when ms Philips began to express her concern thereupon, he assured her, with much earnest gravity, that it was not of the least importance; that he considered the money as a mere trifle, and begged she would not make herself uneasy.
vi: He said:
tr: It had not gone very well; he had lost every point; but when Mrs. Philips began to express her regrets, he said with dignity that it did not matter at all, that he did not value money, and asked her not to feel uncomfortable.
es: It was not much; he had lost all the points. But when Mrs. Philips began to tell him how sorry she was, Collins assured her with the utmost seriousness that it did not matter and that money was the least of his concerns, begging her not to worry about it.

en: “I know very well, madam,” said he, “that when persons sit down to a card table they must take their chance of these things,—and happily I am not in such circumstances as to make five shillings any object.
vi: - Madam, I am well aware that when one sits down at a card table, they must accept the risks involved, and I am fortunate not to be in circumstances where I have to count every penny.
tr: "I know this very well, madam," he said, "when people sit at the gambling table, they try their luck – thankfully, I am not in a position to bet five shillings.
es: ––I know very well, madam ––he said––, that when one sits at a gaming table, one must submit to chance, and fortunately I am not in circumstances to have to worry about five shillings.

en: There are, undoubtedly, many who could not say the same; but, thanks to Lady Catherine de Bourgh, I am removed far beyond the necessity of regarding little matters.”
vi: Surely, many would disagree, but thanks to Lady Catherine de Bourgh, I do not have to worry about such trivial matters.
tr: Undoubtedly, there are many who cannot say the same, but thanks to Lady Catherine de Bourgh, I do not need to concern myself with such small matters."
es: Undoubtedly there are many who cannot say the same, but thanks to Lady Catherine de Bourgh, I am far from having to give importance to such trifles.

en: mr Wickham’s attention was caught; and after observing mr Collins for a few moments, he asked Elizabeth in a low voice whether her relations were very intimately acquainted with the family of De Bourgh.
vi: The remark caught Mr. Wickham's attention. After observing Mr. Collins for a while, he quietly asked Elizabeth about the relationship between Mr. Collins and the De Bourgh family.
tr: Mr. Wickham's eyes fell on Mr. Collins; after watching him for a few seconds, he asked Elizabeth in a low voice if her relative was well acquainted with the de Bourgh family.
es: Wickham caught his attention, and after watching Collins for a few minutes, he quietly asked Elizabeth if her relative was a friend of the Bourgh family.

en: “Lady Catherine de Bourgh,” she replied, “has very lately given him a living.
vi: She replied: - Lady Catherine de Bourgh recently provided him with an ecclesiastical income.
tr: "Lady Catherine de Bourgh," answered Elizabeth, "has recently given him a church.
es: Lady Catherine de Bourgh has recently given him a rectory ––he replied––.

en: I hardly know how mr Collins was first introduced to her notice, but he certainly has not known her long.”
vi: I am not sure how he was first introduced to her, but he certainly hasn't known her for long.
tr: I don't know how Mr. Collins was introduced to her, but it's clear he hasn't known her for long."
es: I don't know very well who introduced them, but he hasn't known her for very long.

en: “You know of course that Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lady Anne Darcy were sisters; consequently that she is aunt to the present mr Darcy.”
vi: - Surely you know that Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lady Anne Darcy are sisters, so she is Mr. Darcy's aunt.
tr: "Of course you must know, Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lady Anne Darcy were sisters; that is, the current Mr. Darcy's aunts.""
es: ––I suppose you know that Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lady Anne Darcy were sisters, and that, consequently, Lady Catherine is the aunt of the current Mr. Darcy.

en: “No, indeed, I did not.
vi: - Actually, I don't know.
tr: "No, I truly didn't know.
es: ––No, no idea; I didn't know anything about Lady Catherine's family.

en: I knew nothing at all of Lady Catherine’s connections.
vi: I don't know anything about Mrs. Catherine's relationships.
tr: –I have no knowledge about Lady Catherine's relatives.
es: ––No, no idea; I didn't know anything about Lady Catherine's family.

en: I never heard of her existence till the day before yesterday.”
vi: I only heard about her the day before yesterday.
tr: Until the day before, I was unaware of their existence."
es: I had no notion of her existence until two days ago.

en: “Her daughter, Miss de Bourgh, will have a very large fortune, and it is believed that she and her cousin will unite the two estates.”
vi: - Your daughter, Miss De Bourgh, will have a very large fortune, and it is believed that she and her cousin, Mr. Darcy, will unite the two estates.
tr: "It is believed that Miss de Bourgh, who will inherit a large fortune, is intended to unite her wealth with that of her cousin.""
es: ––Her daughter, Miss de Bourgh, will inherit a vast fortune, and it is said that she and her cousin will unite the two estates.

en: This information made Elizabeth smile, as she thought of poor Miss Bingley.
vi: This information made Elizabeth smile, as she thought of poor Miss Bingley.
tr: This information made Elizabeth smile, thinking of poor Miss Bingley.
es: This news made Elizabeth smile at the thought of poor Miss Bingley.

en: Vain indeed must be all her attentions, vain and useless her affection for his sister and her praise of himself, if he were already self-destined to another.
vi: All of her attentions would be in vain; her feelings for his sister and her respect for him would also be futile and useless if he had already been designated for someone else. Elizabeth said:
tr: All her interest was in vain, the closeness she showed to his sister and the compliments she paid him were in vain and useless, since he had already chosen another girl.
es: In vain were all her attentions, in vain and useless all her affection for Darcy's sister and all the praises she lavished on him if he was already destined for another.

en: “mr Collins,” said she, “speaks highly both of Lady Catherine and her daughter; but, from some particulars that he has related of her Ladyship, I suspect his gratitude misleads him; and that, in spite of her being his patroness, she is an arrogant, conceited woman.”
vi: - Mr. Collins praised both Lady Catherine and her daughter, but from some details he mentioned about her, I think his appreciation has made him delusional. Although she is his patroness, she is an arrogant, conceited woman.
tr: "Mr. Collins," said Elizabeth, "You speak highly of both Lady Catherine and her daughter; but from some of your words about her ladyship, I think your gratitude has misled you; though she is your patron, she is, in my opinion, an arrogant and conceited woman.""
es: ––Mr. Collins ––said Elizabeth–– speaks very well of Lady Catherine and her daughter; but from some details he has shared about Her Ladyship, I suspect that gratitude blinds him and that, despite being his protector, she is an arrogant and vain woman.

en: “I believe her to be both in a great degree,” replied Wickham; “I have not seen her for many years; but I very well remember that I never liked her, and that her manners were dictatorial and insolent.
vi: Wickham replied: - I believe she possesses both flaws to a severe degree. For many years I did not see her, but I still remember very clearly that I never liked her; I also remember her domineering and arrogant attitude.
tr: "Absolutely so," replied Wickham; "I haven't seen him for years, but I remember that I never liked him; his manner was dictatorial and condescending.
es: ––I believe it is both, and to a high degree ––Wickham replied––. I haven't seen her for many years, but I remember that I never liked her and that her manners were authoritarian and insolent.

en: She has the reputation of being remarkably sensible and clever; but I rather believe she derives part of her abilities from her rank and fortune, part from her authoritative manner, and the rest from the pride of her nephew, who chooses that everyone connected with him should have an understanding of the first class.”
vi: She had a reputation for being reasonable and shrewd, but I believe her abilities were partly due to her status and wealth, partly from her authoritative manner, and the rest from the pride of her nephew, who always wanted those associated with him to have the discernment of the upper class.
tr: He was famous for being very intelligent and clever; but I think he derived his abilities partly from his position and wealth, partly from his authoritative demeanor, and the rest from his nephew's pride; his nephew believes that everyone related to him possesses a first-rate intellect."
es: She has a reputation for being judicious and intelligent; but I get the feeling that part of her qualities derive from her rank and fortune; another part, from her despotism, and the rest, from the pride of her nephew who believes that everyone related to him must possess superior intelligence.

en: Elizabeth allowed that he had given a very rational account of it, and they continued talking together with mutual satisfaction till supper put an end to cards, and gave the rest of the ladies their share of mr Wickham’s attentions.
vi: Elizabeth thought that he had analyzed it reasonably. The two continued to converse with each other harmoniously until the dinner ended the card game and allowed other women to pay attention to him.
tr: Elizabeth acknowledged that she had given a very reasonable explanation of the situation; they continued their conversation happily until the dinner call ended the card game and gave the other ladies a chance to share in Mr. Wickham's kindness.
es: Elizabeth recognized that he had portrayed her very well, and they continued chatting together until dinner ended the game and allowed the other ladies to partake in Wickham's attentions.

en: There could be no conversation in the noise of ms Philips’s supper party, but his manners recommended him to everybody.
vi: During the noisy meal, no one could talk much, but everyone admired his demeanor.
tr: At Mrs. Philips' dinner party, the noise made conversation impossible, but Mr. Wickham's manners won everyone's admiration.
es: A conversation could not be started due to the noise made by Mr. Philips' guests; but his manners charmed everyone.

en: Whatever he said, was said well; and whatever he did, done gracefully.
vi: Everything he said was reasonable; everything he did was elegant.
tr: Whatever he said was well said; whatever he did was done wonderfully.
es: Everything he said was well said and everything he did was well done.

en: Elizabeth went away with her head full of him.
vi: Elizabeth went home with her mind filled only with thoughts of him.
tr: Elizabeth left the place with her mind full of him.
es: Elizabeth was captivated by him.

en: She could think of nothing but of mr Wickham, and of what he had told her, all the way home; but there was not time for her even to mention his name as they went, for neither Lydia nor mr Collins were once silent.
vi: On the way back, she could think of nothing but Mr. Wickham and what he had told her. But she could not even mention his name, because both Lydia and Mr. Collins did not stop talking.
tr: All the way home, she could think of nothing but Mr. Wickham and what he had told her; but she found no time to mention his name, as neither Lydia nor Mr. Collins stopped talking for a moment.
es: On the way back home, she could think of nothing but Mr. Wickham and everything he had told her; but throughout the journey, she was not given a chance to even mention his name, as neither Lydia nor Mr. Collins stopped talking for a second.

en: Lydia talked incessantly of lottery tickets, of the fish she had lost and the fish she had won; and mr Collins, in describing the civility of mr and ms Philips, protesting that he did not in the least regard his losses at whist, enumerating all the dishes at supper, and repeatedly fearing that he crowded his cousins, had more to say than he could well manage before the carriage stopped at Longbourn House.
vi: Lydia chattered on about lottery tickets, about the cards she won and lost. Mr. Collins talked about everything, describing the politeness of Mr. and Mrs. Philips, insisting that he did not care about the money lost at the whist game, naming and praising every dish, repeatedly saying that he took up the cousins' seats, and he still wanted to say more when the carriage stopped at Longbourn.
tr: Lydia kept talking about lottery tickets, the ticket she lost, and the ticket she won; Mr. Collins went on about Mr. and Mrs. Philips' kindness, said he didn't mind his loss at whist in the least, listed all the dishes on the table, repeatedly asked if he had been a bother to his cousins, and when the carriage stopped at Longbourn House, he still hadn't finished telling everything he wanted to say.
es: Lydia kept talking about the lottery, what she had lost, what she had won; and Collins, with praising the hospitality of the Philips, assuring that he didn't mind his losses in whist, listing all the dinner dishes, and constantly repeating that he feared his cousins were cramped because of him, had more to say than he could before the carriage stopped in front of the Longbourn house.

en: CHAPTER XVII.
vi: Chapter 17
tr: Chapter XVII
es: CHAPTER XVII

en: ELIZABETH related to Jane, the next day, what had passed between mr Wickham and herself.
vi: Elizabeth recounted to Jane the things she had discussed with Mr. Wickham, and Jane listened with astonishment and anxiety.
tr: Elizabeth told Jane what had happened between her and Wickham the next day.
es: The next day Elizabeth told Jane everything that she and Wickham had talked about.

en: Jane listened with astonishment and concern: she knew not how to believe that mr Darcy could be so unworthy of mr Bingley’s regard; and yet it was not in her nature to question the veracity of a young man of such amiable appearance as Wickham.
vi: She did not know how to believe that Mr. Darcy was not worthy of Mr. Bingley's esteem. However, her nature could not doubt the sincerity of someone as charming as Mr. Wickham.
tr: Jane listened with astonishment and concern; she did not know how to believe that Mr. Darcy was not as worthy of the esteem Mr. Bingley had shown him; yet, it was not in her nature to question the integrity of someone as pleasant-looking as Wickham.
es: Jane listened with astonishment and interest. She could not believe that Darcy was so unworthy of Bingley's esteem; and yet, she did not dare to doubt the veracity of a man with such an affable appearance as Wickham.

en: The possibility of his having really endured such unkindness was enough to interest all her tender feelings; and nothing therefore remained to be done but to think well of them both, to defend the conduct of each, and throw into the account of accident or mistake whatever could not be otherwise explained.
vi: The fact that he had truly endured such cruel actions was enough to stir tender feelings within her. Therefore, there was nothing left to do but to think well of both men, justify their characters, and consider the possibility of unfortunate circumstances or misunderstandings—anything that could not be explained in any other way.
tr: The possibility that Wickham had truly been subjected to such wrongs was enough to stir her compassionate feelings; therefore, there was nothing left to do but to think well of both, to defend each one's behavior, and in cases that could not be otherwise explained, to suggest an accident or mistake as the explanation.
es: The mere possibility that he had suffered such cruelty was enough to stir her most tender feelings; so she had no choice but to think ill of neither, defend the conduct of both, and attribute to chance or error what otherwise could not be explained.

en: “They have both,” said she, “been deceived, I dare say, in some way or other, of which we can form no idea.
vi: She said: - You could say that both of them were deceived in one way or another – the exact way we do not know.
tr: "Both of them," he said, "were deceived, I think, in a way that we cannot understand.
es: ––I have the impression ––he said–– that both have been let down, they are people, somehow disappointed by something that we cannot guess.

en: Interested people have perhaps misrepresented each to the other.
vi: Perhaps one person misunderstood the other.
tr: The relevant parties might have misrepresented one to the other.
es: Perhaps it was people interested in distorting things who set them against each other.

en: It is, in short, impossible for us to conjecture the causes or circumstances which may have alienated them, without actual blame on either side.”
vi: In short, we cannot speculate on the reasons or circumstances that caused them to drift apart, so we cannot blame either of them.
tr: In short, it is impossible for us to guess the reasons or conditions that alienated them from each other without blaming either side."
es: In any case, we cannot speculate on the causes or circumstances that have separated them without either being at fault.

en: “Very true, indeed; and now, my dear Jane, what have you got to say in behalf of the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business?
vi: - Actually, that's true. Now, Jane, what can you say on behalf of those who might be concerned about the matter?
tr: "Very true indeed; –now dear Jane, what can you say on behalf of the concerned individuals who might have been involved in the matter?
es: ––You are very right; and tell me, my dear Jane: What do you have to say in favor of those interested people who probably had something to do with the matter?

en: Do clear them, too, or we shall be obliged to think ill of somebody.”
vi: We should consider that neither is to blame, otherwise we would have to think badly of someone.
tr: –Let's clear them too, otherwise we will have to sacrifice someone."
es: Defend them too, otherwise we will be forced to speak ill of someone.

en: “Laugh as much as you choose, but you will not laugh me out of my opinion.
vi: - You can laugh freely, but you cannot mock my opinion.
tr: "Laugh as much as you want, but you can't change my mind by laughing.
es: ––Laugh at me all you want, but you won't make me change my mind.

en: My dearest Lizzy, do but consider in what a disgraceful light it places mr Darcy, to be treating his father’s favourite in such a manner,—one whom his father had promised to provide for.
vi: Lizzy, just think about how Mr. Darcy will be disgraced, after having treated so poorly the person whom his father favored, the person his father promised to take care of.
tr: Dear Lizzy, think about how unpleasant it makes Mr. Darcy look to behave this way towards someone her father promised to look after, someone her father cares for.
es: Dear Lizzy, consider what a dishonorable position it places Mr. Darcy in; to treat the favorite of his father this way, someone to whom he had promised a future.

en: It is impossible.
vi: It cannot be, no one with ordinary humanity, no one with any value of character, could do such a thing.
tr: No one with a shred of humanity, no one who values their character even a little, could do this, it's beyond them.
es: It is impossible.

en: No man of common humanity, no man who had any value for his character, could be capable of it.
vi: It cannot be, no one with ordinary humanity, no one with any value of character, could do such a thing.
tr: No one with a shred of humanity, no one who values their character even a little, could do this, it's beyond them.
es: No one even moderately good, who values their conduct at all, is capable of doing it.

en: Can his most intimate friends be so excessively deceived in him?
vi: Could it be that his best friend was so greatly deceived?
tr: Could his closest friends have been so mistaken about him?
es: Is it possible that his closest friends are so deceived about him?

en: Oh no.”
vi: It cannot be!
tr: –no! absolutely not."
es: Oh, no!

en: “I can much more easily believe mr Bingley’s being imposed on than that mr Wickham should invent such a history of himself as he gave me last night; names, facts, everything mentioned without ceremony.
vi: - I can believe that Mr. Bingley was deceived more easily than that Mr. Wickham fabricated the story as he told me last night; the names, the events, everything was mentioned in a natural manner.
tr: "It is much easier for me to believe that Mr. Bingley was misled than to believe that Mr. Wickham fabricated a story about himself as he told me last night; names, facts, everything was told sincerely.
es: ––I believe it is easier for Mr. Bingley's friendship to be imposed than for Mr. Wickham to have invented such a story with names, facts, and to tell it so naturally.

en: If it be not so, let mr Darcy contradict it.
vi: If it were not so, let Mr. Darcy refute it.
tr: If it is not so, let Mr. Darcy object.
es: And if it is not so, let Mr. Darcy be the one to deny it.

en: Besides, there was truth in his looks.”
vi: Moreover, Mr. Darcy's manner somewhat speaks the truth.
tr: Moreover, there was truth in his gaze."
es: Besides, there was sincerity in his eyes.

en: “It is difficult, indeed—it is distressing.
vi: - It's really hard to think, really sad.
tr: "It's hard, really –annoying.
es: ––It's really difficult, it's unfortunate.

en: One does not know what to think.”
vi: People don't know what to think.
tr: You don't know what to think."
es: One doesn't know what to think.

en: “I beg your pardon;—one knows exactly what to think.”
vi: - Sorry, ma'am, people know exactly what to think.
tr: You don't know what to think."
es: ––Excuse me; one knows exactly what to think.

en: But Jane could think with certainty on only one point,—that mr Bingley, if he had been imposed on, would have much to suffer when the affair became public.
vi: But Jane could only be sure of one thing – that Mr. Bingley, if truly deceived, would suffer greatly when the matter became public.
tr: Jane could believe only one thing – Mr. Bingley, if he was truly misled, would suffer greatly when the matter came to light.
es: The two young women were chatting in the garden when they were informed of the arrival of some of the people they were just talking about.

en: The two young ladies were summoned from the shrubbery, where this conversation passed, by the arrival of some of the very persons of whom they had been speaking; mr Bingley and his sisters came to give their personal invitation for the long expected ball at Netherfield, which was fixed for the following Tuesday.
vi: The two ladies were called into the house because there were guests – the very people they had just mentioned. He and his sisters came to deliver invitations for the ball at Netherfield on the following Tuesday.
tr: Two young ladies were called from the shrubbery where this conversation was taking place; some of the people they had been talking about had arrived: Mr. Bingley and his sisters had come in person to extend an invitation for the long-awaited ball at Netherfield; the ball was to be held the following Tuesday.
es: Mr. Bingley and his sisters were coming to personally invite them to the much-anticipated Netherfield ball that had been scheduled for the following Tuesday.

en: The two ladies were delighted to see their dear friend again, called it an age since they had met, and repeatedly asked what she had been doing with herself since their separation.
vi: The two Bingley women were delighted to see their dear friend Jane again, feeling it had been a long time since they last met, and repeatedly asked her what she had been doing for herself since their parting.
tr: The two ladies were delighted to see their dear friends again, –they said it had been ages since they last met, and repeatedly asked what they had been up to since their last meeting.
es: The Bingley sisters were very happy to see their dear friend; it seemed to them that a century had passed since they had been together, and they continually asked her what had happened to her since their separation.

en: To the rest of the family they paid little attention; avoiding ms Bennet as much as possible, saying not much to Elizabeth, and nothing at all to the others.
vi: The two ladies paid little attention to the other family members, avoided Mrs. Bennet if possible, spoke little to Elizabeth, and said nothing to the other girls.
tr: They paid little attention to the other members of the family; they kept as far away from Mrs. Bennet as possible, said very little to Elizabeth, and nothing at all to the others.
es: They paid little attention to the rest of the family; they avoided Mrs. Bennet as much as they could, spoke very little with Elizabeth, and did not even address the others.

en: They were soon gone again, rising from their seats with an activity which took their brother by surprise, and hurrying off as if eager to escape from ms Bennet’s civilities.
vi: The two ladies paid little attention to the other family members, avoided Mrs. Bennet if possible, spoke little to Elizabeth, and said nothing to the other girls.
tr: They soon left, rising from their seats with a speed that caught their brother unprepared, and rushed to the door as if to escape Mrs. Bennet's offerings.
es: They left immediately, rising from their seats with a speed that astonished their brother; they exited so quickly that they seemed eager to escape Mrs. Bennet's attentions.

en: The prospect of the Netherfield ball was extremely agreeable to every female of the family.
vi: Everyone in the family was eagerly looking forward to the ball.
tr: The fact that a ball was to be held at Netherfield made every woman in the family extremely happy.
es: The prospect of the Netherfield ball was extraordinarily appealing to all the female members of the family.

en: ms Bennet chose to consider it as given in compliment to her eldest daughter, and was particularly flattered by receiving the invitation from mr Bingley himself, instead of a ceremonious card.
vi: Mrs. Bennet saw this as an event for her eldest daughter, particularly proud to receive a personal invitation from Mr. Bingley himself, instead of a formal card.
tr: Mrs. Bennet preferred to think that the ball was given as a compliment to her eldest daughter and took particular pride in receiving the invitation personally from Mr. Bingley rather than through a formal card.
es: Mrs. Bennet took it as a compliment to her eldest daughter and felt particularly flattered to have received the invitation from Mr. Bingley in person rather than through a ceremonious card.

en: Jane pictured to herself a happy evening in the society of her two friends, and the attentions of their brother; and Elizabeth thought with pleasure of dancing a great deal with mr Wickham, and of seeing a confirmation of everything in mr Darcy’s look and behaviour.
vi: Jane imagined she would have a happy evening with her two friends, along with the attention of her cousin. Elizabeth thought of the joy of dancing many dances with Mr. Wickham, and seeing everything proven through Mr. Darcy's attitude and gestures.
tr: Jane imagined a happy evening in the company of her two friends and under the attention of their brothers; Elizabeth, in her delight, thought of dancing a lot with Mr. Wickham and seeing everything in Mr. Wickham's gaze and posture confirmed.
es: Jane imagined a happy evening in the company of her two friends and with the attentions of the brother, and Elizabeth thought with delight of dancing the whole time with Mr. Wickham and of seeing the entire story confirmed in Mr. Darcy's looks and behavior.

en: The happiness anticipated by Catherine and Lydia depended less on any single event, or any particular person; for though they each, like Elizabeth, meant to dance half the evening with mr Wickham, he was by no means the only partner who could satisfy them, and a ball was, at any rate, a ball.
vi: The joy that Catherine and Lydia anticipated did not depend much on any particular event or person, for although they liked dancing with Mr. Wickham, they did not focus solely on him, and after all, a ball was just a ball.
tr: The happiness Catherine and Lydia anticipated was not so dependent on a single event or person; although they, like Elizabeth, wanted to dance with Mr. Wickham, Mr. Wickham was not the only partner who could satisfy them, besides, a ball was always a ball.
es: The happiness that Catherine and Lydia anticipated depended less on a single fact or a particular person, because, although both, like Elizabeth, thought of dancing half the night with Wickham, he was by no means the only partner who could satisfy them, and, after all, a ball was a ball.

en: And even Mary could assure her family that she had no disinclination for it.
vi: Even Mary reassured the family that she would not be reluctant to attend.
tr: Even Mary told her family that she did not look unfavorably upon the ball.
es: Even Mary went so far as to assure her family that she did not dislike the idea of going either.

en: “While I can have my mornings to myself,” said she, “it is enough.
vi: She said: - As long as you have your own mornings, that is enough.
tr: "If I reserve my mornings for myself," he said, "that will be enough for me – I suppose missing the occasional evening gathering isn't a great loss.
es: ––As long as I can have the mornings for myself ––he said––, that's enough for me.

en: I think it is no sacrifice to join occasionally in evening engagements.
vi: Occasionally, you can participate in evening parties without feeling forced.
tr: "If I reserve my mornings for myself," he said, "that will be enough for me – I suppose missing the occasional evening gathering isn't a great loss.
es: It doesn't require any sacrifice on my part to occasionally accept evening commitments.

en: Society has claims on us all; and I profess myself one of those who consider intervals of recreation and amusement as desirable for everybody.”
vi: Society has bound everyone, but you are one of those who believe that everyone occasionally desires entertainment and enjoyment that everyone wishes for.
tr: Society has expectations of us as well; I see myself as one of those who believe that breaks given for entertainment and relaxation are beneficial for everyone."
es: We all owe something to society, and I confess that I am one of those who believe that intervals of recreation and relaxation are advisable for everyone.

en: Elizabeth’s spirits were so high on the occasion, that though she did not often speak unnecessarily to mr Collins, she could not help asking him whether he intended to accept mr Bingley’s invitation, and if he did, whether he would think it proper to join in the evening’s amusement; and she was rather surprised to find that he entertained no scruple whatever on that head, and was very far from dreading a rebuke, either from the Archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh, by venturing to dance.
vi: Elizabeth's spirits were so high that, although she did not like conversing with Mr. Collins unless absolutely necessary, she could not help but ask if he intended to accept Mr. Bingley's invitation and, if he did, whether he thought it proper to attend an evening of enjoyment. She was quite surprised to hear him say that his mind harbored no such scruples; he was not afraid of being reprimanded by the Archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh for daring to participate in the dance. He said:
tr: Elizabeth was so delighted at the mention of the ball that, despite usually avoiding conversation with Mr. Collins unless necessary, she couldn't help but ask if he was considering accepting Mr. Bingley's invitation and, if so, whether he found it appropriate to attend the evening festivities. She was surprised to see that he harbored no reservations and was far from fearing any rebuke from the Archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
es: Elizabeth was so excited about the occasion that, despite usually only speaking to Collins when necessary, she couldn't help but ask him if he intended to accept Mr. Bingley's invitation and, if so, whether he thought it appropriate to attend evening parties. Elizabeth was surprised when he replied that he had no objections in this regard and that he did not fear that the archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh would censure him for venturing to the dance.

en: “I am by no means of opinion, I assure you,” said he, “that a ball of this kind, given by a young man of character, to respectable people, can have any evil tendency; and I am so far from objecting to dancing myself, that I shall hope to be honoured with the hands of all my fair cousins in the course of the evening; and I take this opportunity of soliciting yours, Miss Elizabeth, for the two first dances especially; a preference which I trust my cousin Jane will attribute to the right cause, and not to any disrespect for her.”
vi: - I do not intend to view this type of ball, organized by a person of standing for respectable attendees, as potentially having an unhealthy tendency. I do not wish to refuse to participate in the dance, so that I may have the honor of the hands of my beautiful cousins, and I will take this opportunity to request the hand of Miss Elizabeth, especially for the first two dances – a preference which I believe Miss Jane will understand is not due to any lack of respect for her.
tr: "My opinion is," he said, "that a ball given by a man of good character to respectable people cannot harbor ill tendencies; I have no personal objection to dancing, and I even hope to have the honor of holding my lovely cousins' hands throughout the evening; and indeed, while we're on the subject, Miss Elizabeth, I would especially like to request you for the first two dances, –I believe my cousin Jane will understand my preference and will not consider it disrespectful.""
es: ––I assure you that I absolutely do not believe ––he said–– that a ball like this, organized by a man of distinction for respectable people, could have anything wrong with it. I have no objection to dancing and I hope to have the honor of doing so with all my beautiful cousins. I take this opportunity to ask you, specifically you, Miss Elizabeth, for the first two dances, a preference which I trust my cousin Jane will attribute to the proper cause, and not to any disregard for her.

en: Elizabeth felt herself completely taken in.
vi: Elizabeth felt completely awkward.
tr: Elizabeth felt that she was caught badly.
es: Elizabeth was completely disillusioned.

en: She had fully proposed being engaged by Wickham for those very dances; and to have mr Collins instead!—her liveliness had been never worse timed.
vi: She had hoped to dance with Mr. Wickham for the first two dances, but instead, it was Mr. Collins! Never had her lively personality been so poorly scheduled!
tr: She had assumed she would be paired with Mr. Wickham for the dances; now, instead, Mr. Collins! –he couldn't have chosen a worse time to be mischievous.
es: She had intended to dedicate those two very special dances to Mr. Wickham! And now she had to dance them with Mr. Collins! She had chosen the wrong moment to become so happy.

en: There was no help for it, however.
vi: But there was no other way.
tr: However, there was nothing to be done.
es: Well, what could she do?

en: mr Wickham’s happiness and her own was perforce delayed a little longer, and mr Collins’s proposal accepted with as good a grace as she could.
vi: The joy of Mr. Wickham and hers would have to be postponed a bit; she accepted Mr. Collins' invitation with the most cheerful attitude she could muster.
tr: Her happiness with Mr. Wickham was necessarily postponed for a while, and Mr. Collins's proposal was accepted with all the courtesy that could be mustered.
es: She had no choice but to postpone her happiness and Wickham's for a little later and accept Collins' proposal with the best possible attitude.

en: She was not the better pleased with his gallantry, from the idea it suggested of something more.
vi: She was no happier with his flattering manner, thinking it indicated something.
tr: What really bothered her about the man's assertiveness was the underlying idea it expressed.
es: She found no pleasure in his gallantry because there was something more hidden behind it.

en: It now first struck her, that she was selected from among her sisters as worthy of being the mistress of Hunsford Parsonage, and of assisting to form a quadrille table at Rosings, in the absence of more eligible visitors.
vi: Now she suddenly realized that, among her sisters, he had chosen her to be the mistress of the Hunsford Parsonage, and also to fill a seat at the card table at Rossings in the absence of any more qualified guest.
tr: –Now, for the first time, she realized that she had been deemed worthy among her sisters to be the lady of Hunsford Parsonage, to form the quartet at the card table in Rosings when there were no more distinguished guests.
es: For the first time, it occurred to her that she was the chosen one among all her sisters to be the lady of the parsonage at Hunsford and to attend the quadrille parties at Rosings in the absence of more select visitors.

en: The idea soon reached to conviction, as she observed his increasing civilities towards herself, and heard his frequent attempt at a compliment on her wit and vivacity; and though more astonished than gratified herself by this effect of her charms, it was not long before her mother gave her to understand that the probability of their marriage was exceedingly agreeable to her.
vi: The thought gradually turned into conviction as she noticed him becoming increasingly courteous to her, especially when she heard him praise her intelligence and liveliness. Although feeling more surprised than pleased, it wasn't long before her mother hinted that she was very happy about the possibility of a wedding between the two.
tr: The idea quickly turned into belief as she observed the man's increasing interest in her, listened to the compliments he showered on her intelligence and vivacity; although the effect of her charm surprised her more than it honored her, it wasn't long before her mother made it clear that she was quite warm to the possibility of their marriage.
es: This idea soon turned into conviction when she observed Collins' increasing attentions towards her and heard his frequent attempts to praise her wit and vivacity. Although the effect her charms had in this case left her more astonished than pleased, her mother soon made it clear that the possibility of that marriage pleased her excessively.

en: Elizabeth, however, did not choose to take the hint, being well aware that a serious dispute must be the consequence of any reply.
vi: However, Elizabeth did not want to acknowledge the implication, knowing that any response would lead to a heated argument.
tr: However, Elizabeth refused to acknowledge her mother's insinuation because she knew well that her response would result in a serious disagreement.
es: However, Elizabeth preferred to ignore it, because she was sure that any reply would result in a serious argument.

en: mr Collins might never make the offer, and, till he did, it was useless to quarrel about him.
vi: Mr. Collins might never propose, so there was no point in arguing about him at this moment.
tr: Mr. Collins might never make the proposal, and until he did, it was pointless to quarrel over it.
es: Probably Mr. Collins would never make such a proposal, and until he did, it was a waste of time to argue about him.

en: If there had not been a Netherfield ball to prepare for and talk of, the younger Miss Bennets would have been in a pitiable state at this time; for, from the day of the invitation to the day of the ball, there was such a succession of rain as prevented their walking to Meryton once.
vi: If it weren't for the Netherfield ball to prepare for and discuss, the Bennet sisters would surely feel miserable, as the continuous rain from the day they were invited until the ball prevented them from going to Meryton.
tr: If there were no ball to be prepared and talked about at Netherfield, the young Miss Bennets would be in a pitiable state at that time, because the continuous rain from the day of the invitation to the day of the ball prevented them from going to Meryton.
es: If they had not had to make preparations for the Netherfield ball, the younger Bennets would have reached a pitiable state, since from the day of the invitation until the day of the ball, the rain did not stop for a moment, preventing them from going to Meryton even once.

en: No aunt, no officers, no news could be sought after; the very shoe-roses for Netherfield were got by proxy.
vi: Unable to visit their aunt, unable to meet the officers, no new news, they had to substitute with Netherfield.
tr: No aunt, no officers, no news – even the pink shoes for Netherfield were ordered by mail.
es: No aunt, no officers, no gossip to share. Even the rose arrangements for the Netherfield ball had to be made to order.

en: Even Elizabeth might have found some trial of her patience in weather which totally suspended the improvement of her acquaintance with mr Wickham; and nothing less than a dance on Tuesday could have made such a Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday endurable to Kitty and Lydia.
vi: Even Elizabeth felt her patience being tested, as her efforts to strengthen her acquaintance with Mr. Wickham were completely stalled. As for Kitty and Lydia, if it weren't for the ball on Tuesday, there would be nothing else to help them endure Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday.
tr: Even Elizabeth had her patience tested by the weather that prevented her from furthering her acquaintance with Mr. Wickham; such a Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday would have been difficult for Kitty and Lydia if there were no dance on Tuesday.
es: Elizabeth herself saw her patience tested by that bad weather which completely suspended the progress of her friendship with Wickham. Only the Tuesday ball could make a Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday like those bearable for Catherine and Lydia.

en: CHAPTER XVIII.
vi: Chapter 18
tr: Chapter XVIII
es: CHAPTER XVIII

en: TILL Elizabeth entered the drawing-room at Netherfield, and looked in vain for mr Wickham among the cluster of red coats there assembled, a doubt of his being present had never occurred to her.
vi: Elizabeth never doubted that Mr. Wickham would be absent from the ball, until she entered the drawing room at Netherfield and searched for him in vain among the men in red coats.
tr: It had never occurred to Elizabeth that there was any chance of Mr. Wickham not being present until she entered the sitting room at Netherfield and looked in vain among the cluster of redcoats gathered there.
es: Until Elizabeth entered the Netherfield drawing-room and searched in vain among the group of red coats gathered there for Wickham, it did not occur to her that he might not be among the guests.

en: The certainty of meeting him had not been checked by any of those recollections that might not unreasonably have alarmed her.
vi: She had been so sure he would be there, that she did not review her memories for any event that might have alerted her.
tr: The belief that she would encounter him had not been tested by memories that might justifiably have made her uneasy.
es: The certainty of finding him had made her forget what would have rightly alarmed her.

en: She had dressed with more than usual care, and prepared in the highest spirits for the conquest of all that remained unsubdued of his heart, trusting that it was not more than might be won in the course of the evening.
vi: She had dressed more carefully than usual, and prepared with the greatest eagerness to conquer all that remained unconquered in his heart, thinking that it could be achieved in just one evening.
tr: She had dressed with more than usual care, prepared with all her cheerfulness to conquer everything that remained unconquered in the man's heart, confident that there was not much left unconquered throughout the evening.
es: She had groomed herself with more care than usual and was prepared with a very high spirit to conquer whatever remained untamed in her heart, trusting that it was the best reward she could achieve during the evening.

en: But in an instant arose the dreadful suspicion of his being purposely omitted, for mr Darcy’s pleasure, in the Bingleys’ invitation to the officers; and though this was not exactly the case, the absolute fact of his absence was pronounced by his friend mr Denny, to whom Lydia eagerly applied, and who told them that Wickham had been obliged to go to town on business the day before, and was not yet returned; adding, with a significant smile,—
vi: But suddenly, she had the dreadful thought that he had been deliberately excluded from Mr. Bingley's guest list to please Mr. Darcy. Although this was not entirely true, Mr. Denny conveyed the news of his absence when Lydia spoke with him. Denny reported that Wickham had to attend to business in town the day before and had not yet returned. He added, with a suggestive smile:
tr: But for a moment, she was seized by the suspicion that the Bingleys had deliberately omitted the officers from their invitations to please Mr. Darcy; although this was not the case, the fact of his absence was confirmed by his friend Mr. Denny, who, when approached by the curious Lydia, explained that Wickham had been obliged to go to town on business the previous day and had not yet returned, adding with a meaningful smile:
es: But in an instant, the horrible suspicion came over her that Wickham might have been omitted from Bingley's list of invited officers to please Darcy. That was not exactly the case. His absence was definitively confirmed by Mr. Denny, whom Lydia anxiously approached, and who told them that Mr. Wickham had been obliged to go to the capital to resolve some matters the day before and had not yet returned. And with a significant smile, he added:

en: “I do not imagine his business would have called him away just now, if he had not wished to avoid a certain gentleman here.”
vi: - I can't imagine any job that would make him leave at this moment, unless he wants to avoid someone here.
tr: "If she didn't want to avoid a certain gentleman here, she wouldn't care about work or anything else right now.""
es: ––I don't believe those matters would have detained him today, unless he wanted to avoid meeting a certain gentleman here.

en: This part of his intelligence, though unheard by Lydia, was caught by Elizabeth; and, as it assured her that Darcy was not less answerable for Wickham’s absence than if her first surmise had been just, every feeling of displeasure against the former was so sharpened by immediate disappointment, that she could hardly reply with tolerable civility to the polite inquiries which he directly afterwards approached to make.
vi: Although Lydia did not notice, Elizabeth heard it. Though this news reassured her that Darcy was not much involved in Wickham's absence as she had initially suspected, all her resentment towards Darcy grew even more intense due to her disappointment, to the extent that she could not respond with the minimal courtesy to his polite questions.
tr: Although this part of the explanation escaped Lydia's attention, it did not escape Elizabeth's, and even if her initial guess was not correct, it convinced her that the reason for Wickham's absence was Darcy; the coldness she felt towards Darcy hardened so much with her current disappointment that she had difficulty responding with reasonable politeness to Darcy's courteous questions when he approached her shortly after.
es: Lydia did not hear these words, but Elizabeth did; although her initial suspicion had not been true, Darcy was equally responsible for Wickham's absence, her antipathy towards the former was so exacerbated that she could barely respond politely to the kind questions Darcy asked her when he approached her shortly after.

en: Attention, forbearance, patience with Darcy, was injury to Wickham.
vi: She thought that showing interest, tolerance, and patience towards Darcy would hurt Wickham.
tr: Showing interest, patience, and understanding to Darcy meant insulting Wickham.
es: Any attention or tolerance towards Darcy meant an injury to Wickham.

en: She was resolved against any sort of conversation with him, and turned away with a degree of ill-humour which she could not wholly surmount even in speaking to mr Bingley, whose blind partiality provoked her.
vi: She resolved not to speak to Darcy anymore, turning away with a bit of irritation that she could not entirely suppress even when conversing with Mr. Bingley, and was further provoked by his blind partiality.
tr: She was determined not to speak to him in any way and turned her back with a certain petulance; her petulance did not fully subside even while talking to Mr. Bingley; she was also angry with him for not being impartial.
es: She decided not to have any conversation with Darcy and put herself in such a mood that she could not even conceal it when talking to Bingley, as his blind partiality irritated her.

en: But Elizabeth was not formed for ill-humour; and though every prospect of her own was destroyed for the evening, it could not dwell long on her spirits; and, having told all her griefs to Charlotte Lucas, whom she had not seen for a week, she was soon able to make a voluntary transition to the oddities of her cousin, and to point him out to her particular notice.
vi: However, Elizabeth's personality did not hold onto resentment for long. Although all her hopes for the evening had faded away, her spirits gradually became comfortable again. After sharing all her feelings with Charlotte Lucas, whom she had not seen in a week, she soon willingly moved on to the peculiarities of her cousin, telling her friend about him.
tr: Aunt Elizabeth was not made for sulking; although all the dreams she had for the evening were shattered, the sulking did not last long; after pouring out all her sorrows to Charlotte Lucas, whom she hadn't seen for a week, she became willing to transition to her cousin's oddities and pointed her finger at Charlotte.
es: But bad humor was not made for Elizabeth, and despite all her plans for the night being ruined, it soon passed. After telling her sorrows to Charlotte Lucas, whom she hadn't seen for a week, she soon found herself in the mood to tolerate all her cousin's oddities and approached him.

en: The two first dances, however, brought a return of distress: they were dances of mortification.
vi: However, the first two dances brought about sorrow; they were two torturous pieces.
tr: However, the first two dances brought back her boredom; they were no different from a death dance.
es: However, the first two dances brought back her distress; they were like a penance.

en: mr Collins, awkward and solemn, apologizing instead of attending, and often moving wrong without being aware of it, gave her all the shame and misery which a disagreeable partner for a couple of dances can give.
vi: Mr. Collins, clumsy and miserable, apologized instead of attending to her, often stepping out of rhythm without realizing it, bringing her all the shame and misery of an unpleasant dance partner.
tr: Clumsy and solemn Mr. Collins, instead of doing what was necessary, apologized and frequently took wrong steps unknowingly, giving Elizabeth all the embarrassment and discomfort that a terrible partner could give during several dances.
es: Mr. Collins, clumsy and solemn, apologizing instead of keeping to the rhythm, and losing the step without realizing it, gave her all the pity and embarrassment that an unpleasant partner can give in a couple of dances.

en: The moment of her release from him was ecstasy.
vi: She was delighted to be rid of him.
tr: The moment of getting rid of the man was wonderful.
es: Getting rid of him was like reaching ecstasy.

en: She danced next with an officer, and had the refreshment of talking of Wickham, and of hearing that he was universally liked.
vi: She danced the next set with an officer, feeling happy to hear about Wickham and knowing that everyone adored him.
tr: Then she danced with an officer and had the pleasure of hearing everyone speak well of Wickham.
es: Then she had the relief of dancing with an officer with whom she could talk about Mr. Wickham, learning that everyone appreciated him.

en: When those dances were over, she returned to Charlotte Lucas, and was in conversation with her, when she found herself suddenly addressed by mr Darcy, who took her so much by surprise in his application for her hand, that, without knowing what she did, she accepted him.
vi: After the music ended, she returned to Charlotte Lucas. While they were conversing, Mr. Darcy suddenly approached her. He surprised her by asking her to dance. Without thinking, she accepted.
tr: When these dances ended, she turned to Charlotte Lucas; they had just started conversing when suddenly she found Mr. Darcy standing beside her, saying something; she was so caught off guard that when Mr. Darcy asked her to dance, she accepted without realizing it.
es: When this dance ended, she returned to Charlotte Lucas, and they were chatting when she suddenly realized that Mr. Darcy had approached her and was asking for the next dance; she was so surprised that, without knowing what she was doing, she accepted.

en: He walked away again immediately, and she was left to fret over her own want of presence of mind: Charlotte tried to console her.
vi: He immediately turned and walked away; she was left feeling irritated at her own lack of judgment. Charlotte tried to console her.
tr: Mr. Darcy left as quickly as he had come, and Elizabeth was left to lament her foolishness; Charlotte tried to console her.
es: Darcy left immediately, and she, having become very nervous, stayed there wishing to regain her composure. Charlotte tried to console her.

en: “I dare say you will find him very agreeable.”
vi: - I think you will find him very likable.
tr: "I think you will like him/her a lot.""
es: ––Maybe you'll find it charming.

en: “Heaven forbid!
vi: - How miserable!
tr: "God forbid!
es: ––May God forbid it!

en: That would be the greatest misfortune of all!
vi: That would be the most unfortunate thing for everyone!
tr: –It would be the epitome of misfortune!
es: That would be the greatest of all misfortunes.

en: To find a man agreeable whom one is determined to hate!
vi: To see someone you deliberately hate being so likable!
tr: –Liking someone you are determined to hate!
es: To find charming a man who must be hated!

en: Do not wish me such an evil.”
vi: Don't wish me such a malicious thing.
tr: –Don't wish such bad things for me."
es: Do not wish me such ill.

en: When the dancing recommenced, however, and Darcy approached to claim her hand, Charlotte could not help cautioning her, in a whisper, not to be a simpleton, and allow her fancy for Wickham to make her appear unpleasant in the eyes of a man often times his consequence.
vi: However, when the dance music started and Darcy returned to take her hand, Charlotte couldn't help but whisper in her ear not to foolishly dream of Wickham and become unpleasant in the eyes of someone ten times higher in status.
tr: Still, when the dance resumed and Darcy approached to ask her for a dance, Charlotte couldn't help but warn her: she whispered not to act childishly and not to let her fantasies about Wickham make her appear unattractive in the eyes of a man ten times richer.
es: When the dance resumed, Darcy approached her to take her hand, and Charlotte couldn't help but whisper in her ear not to be foolish and not to let her infatuation with Wickham make her appear unpleasant in the eyes of a man who was worth ten times more than him.

en: Elizabeth made no answer, and took her place in the set, amazed at the dignity to which she was arrived in being allowed to stand opposite to mr Darcy, and reading in her neighbours’ looks their equal amazement in beholding it.
vi: Elizabeth did not reply, accepted the dance with him, feeling surprised at how her own dignity had changed to allow her to face Mr. Darcy, and read in the eyes of the other dancing couples an equal surprise at seeing the two of them together.
tr: Elizabeth did not reply and took her place on the dance floor, marveling at the respectability she gained from the chance to stand opposite Mr. Darcy, and saw the same amazement on the faces of their observing neighbors.
es: Elizabeth did not reply. She took her place on the dance floor, astonished by the dignity bestowed upon her by standing face to face with Darcy, reading in the eyes of all her neighbors the same astonishment at witnessing the event.

en: They stood for some time without speaking a word; and she began to imagine that their silence was to last through the two dances, and, at first, was resolved not to break it; till suddenly fancying that it would be the greater punishment to her partner to oblige him to talk, she made some slight observation on the dance.
vi: For a long while, neither of them spoke a word; she began to imagine that their silence would last throughout the two dances. At first, she had no intention of breaking the silence, until she suddenly thought that the heaviest punishment for him would be to make him speak, so she made some idle remarks about the ball.
tr: They stood without speaking for a while; Elizabeth thought their silence would last until the end of the two dances and initially decided not to break it, but then suddenly considered that forcing him to talk would be a greater punishment and made a few observations about the dance.
es: They were silent for a while; Elizabeth began to think that the silence would last until the end of the two dances. At first, she was determined not to break it, when suddenly she thought that the worst punishment for her partner would be to force him to talk, and she made a small remark about the dance.

en: He replied, and was again silent.
vi: He replied, then fell silent again.
tr: Mr. Darcy replied, then fell silent again.
es: Darcy replied and fell silent again.

en: After a pause of some minutes, she addressed him a second time, with—
vi: A moment later, she spoke again for the second time.
tr: After a few minutes of hesitation, Elizabeth spoke to him a second time – "It is now your turn to say something, Mr. Darcy.
es: After a pause of a few minutes, Elizabeth spoke for the second time and said to him:

en: “It is your turn to say something now, mr Darcy.
vi: - Mr. Darcy, it's your turn to say something.
tr: After a few minutes of hesitation, Elizabeth spoke to him a second time – "It is now your turn to say something, Mr. Darcy.
es: ––Now it's your turn to say something, Mr. Darcy.

en: I talked about the dance, and you ought to make some kind of remark on the size of the room, or the number of couples.”
vi: I've talked about the ball, now you must make some remarks about the size of the room, or the number of dancing couples.
tr: I talked about the dance, you could, for instance, say something about the dimensions of the room, or how many couples there are.""
es: I've already talked about the dance, and you should make some comment about the size of the hall and the number of couples.

en: He smiled, and assured her that whatever she wished him to say should be said.
vi: He smiled, assuring her that he would say anything she wanted him to say.
tr: Mr. Darcy smiled and assured her that he would say whatever she wished.
es: He smiled and assured her that he would say everything she wished to hear.

en: “Very well; that reply will do for the present.
vi: - Very good. That answer is sufficient for now.
tr: "Very good. This answer is sufficient for now.
es: ––Very well. That response isn't bad for now.

en: Perhaps, by-and-by, I may observe that private balls are much pleasanter than public ones; but now we may be silent.”
vi: Perhaps gradually I can observe that family dances are more enjoyable than public dances. But now we can be silent.
tr: Maybe in a bit, I'll say that private balls are more pleasant than public balls. But now we must be silent."
es: Maybe little by little I'll be convinced that private dances are more pleasant than public ones; but for now, we can remain silent.

en: “Do you talk by rule, then, while you are dancing?”
vi: - Do you often talk while you are dancing?
tr: "Do you talk about rules while dancing?"
es: ––Do you usually talk while you dance?

en: “Sometimes.
vi: - Sometimes.
tr: "Sometimes.
es: ––Sometimes.

en: One must speak a little, you know.
vi: People need to chat a little, you know.
