tr: A person should talk a little, of course.
es: It's necessary to talk a little, don't you think?

en: It would look odd to be entirely silent for half an hour together; and yet, for the advantage of some, conversation ought to be so arranged as that they may have the trouble of saying as little as possible.”
vi: It does look odd if we stay silent with each other for half an hour, but for some people, it is necessary to arrange the conversation in such a way that they can be bothered to speak as much as possible.
tr: Sitting in silence together for half an hour seems strange; but the conversation should be arranged in such a way that they can speak as little as possible to suit some people."
es: It would be strange to be together for half an hour without saying a word. But out of consideration for some, you have to steer the conversation so that they don't feel compelled to say more than necessary.

en: “Are you consulting your own feelings in the present case, or do you imagine that you are gratifying mine?”
vi: - Are you probing your own feelings in this case, or do you think you are probing mine?
tr: "Are you expressing your own feelings right now, or do you think you are responding to mine?"
es: ––Are you referring to yourself or are you saying it about me?

en: “Both,” replied Elizabeth archly; “for I have always seen a great similarity in the turn of our minds.
vi: Elizabeth replied mischievously: - Both, because I realized there is a similarity in the way both of us shift our thoughts.
tr: "Both," answered Elizabeth mischievously; "I have always seen a great similarity in our ways of thinking.
es: ––For both ––replied Elizabeth coquettishly––, for I have found a great similarity in our ways of being.

en: We are each of an unsocial, taciturn disposition, unwilling to speak, unless we expect to say something that will amaze the whole room, and be handed down to posterity with all the éclat of a proverb.”
vi: Both of us have a difficult temperament, sullen, unwilling to speak, except when we want to say something that surprises the whole room, to be passed down to future generations with all the glory of a proverb.
tr: We are both unsociable, stubborn, we do not like to talk, unless we hope to say something that will enchant the whole room and be passed down to future generations with proverbial grandeur."
es: We are both unsociable, taciturn, and averse to speaking unless we expect to say something that will dazzle everyone present and go down in history with all the brilliance of a proverb.

en: “This is no very striking resemblance of your own character, I am sure,” said he.
vi: - This is not at all like your nature, I am sure of it.
tr: "This is a picture that does not resemble your character at all," said Mr. Darcy.
es: ––I am sure that you are not like that.

en: “How near it may be to mine, I cannot pretend to say.
vi: I dare not say how it aligns with my nature.
tr: "I cannot say how close it is to mine either.
es: As for me, I wouldn't know what to say.

en: You think it a faithful portrait, undoubtedly.”
vi: Surely you think it is a true portrait.
tr: But evidently, you think it is a faithful portrait.""
es: You, without a doubt, believe that you have made a faithful portrait of me.

en: “I must not decide on my own performance.”
vi: - I should not conclude about my nature.
tr: "It is not for me to judge my own skill.""
es: ––I cannot judge my own work.

en: He made no answer; and they were again silent till they had gone down the dance, when he asked her if she and her sisters did not very often walk to Meryton.
vi: He did not answer. The two fell into silence again until near the end of the piece, when he asked her whether she and her sisters often went to Meryton.
tr: Mr. Darcy did not reply, and they did not speak again until the dance was over; then Mr. Darcy asked if they often walked to Meryton with their sisters.
es: He did not answer, and it seemed that they would not open their mouths again until the dance ended, when he asked her if she and her sisters often went to Meryton.

en: She answered in the affirmative; and, unable to resist the temptation, added, “When you met us there the other day, we had just been forming a new acquaintance.”
vi: She said yes and, unable to resist the temptation, added: - When you met us the other day, we had just gotten to know someone new.
tr: Elizabeth said yes, and unable to resist the provocation, added, "When you met us there the other day, we were just making a new acquaintance."
es: Elizabeth answered affirmatively and, unable to resist the temptation, added: ––When you found us the other day, we had just met a new friend.

en: The effect was immediate.
vi: He had an immediate reaction.
tr: The effect of the words was seen immediately.
es: The effect was immediate.

en: A deeper shade of hauteur overspread his features, but he said not a word; and Elizabeth, though blaming herself for her own weakness, could not go on.
vi: A profound arrogance spread across his face, but he did not say a word. Elizabeth, though blaming herself for being too weak, could not continue.
tr: A darker shadow of arrogance spread across his face, but he did not utter a single word; although Elizabeth blamed herself for her weakness, she could not continue the subject.
es: An intense shadow of arrogance darkened Darcy's countenance. But he did not say a word; Elizabeth, though reproaching herself for her weakness, preferred not to continue.

en: At length Darcy spoke, and in a constrained manner said,—
vi: Finally, Darcy spoke, restraining himself:
tr: Finally, Mr. Darcy spoke, and in a tense manner, said, "Mr. Wickham has such charming manners that he quickly makes friends – but I am not sure if he can keep them."
es: Finally, Darcy spoke and said in a forced manner:

en: “mr Wickham is blessed with such happy manners as may insure his making friends; whether he may be equally capable of retaining them, is less certain.”
vi: - Mr. Wickham is fortunate to be endowed with a cheerful demeanor that makes it easy for him to make friends; whether he has the ability to maintain those friendships, I am not sure.
tr: Finally, Mr. Darcy spoke, and in a tense manner, said, "Mr. Wickham has such charming manners that he quickly makes friends – but I am not sure if he can keep them."
es: ––Mr. Wickham is endowed with such pleasant manners that he can certainly make friends easily. What is less certain is that he is equally capable of keeping them.

en: “He has been so unlucky as to lose your friendship,” replied Elizabeth, with emphasis, “and in a manner which he is likely to suffer from all his life.”
vi: Elizabeth replied: - He was unfortunate because he lost his friendship with you. She emphasized further: - And in the way that he might suffer for a lifetime.
tr: "Losing your friendship has been a great misfortune," replied Elizabeth emphatically, "and he will suffer from it for the rest of his life."
es: ––He has had the misfortune of losing his friendship ––said Elizabeth emphatically––, in such a way that he will suffer for it all his life.

en: Darcy made no answer, and seemed desirous of changing the subject.
vi: Darcy did not reply, seemingly wanting to change the subject.
tr: Darcy did not respond; he seemed to want to change the subject.
es: Darcy did not answer and it was noticeable that he was eager to change the subject.

en: At that moment Sir William Lucas appeared close to them, meaning to pass through the set to the other side of the room; but, on perceiving mr Darcy, he stopped, with a bow of superior courtesy, to compliment him on his dancing and his partner.
vi: At that moment, Sir William Lucas appeared near them, but upon seeing Darcy, he bowed with the courtesy of an elder to compliment him on his dance steps and his dance partner.
tr: At that moment, Sir William Lucas appeared nearby; he intended to cross the room from the middle of the dance floor, but upon noticing Mr. Darcy, he stopped and bowed with superior courtesy, complimenting him on the dance and his partner.
es: At that moment, Sir William Lucas was passing near them as he crossed the dance floor with the intention of going to the other end of the hall, and upon seeing Mr. Darcy, he stopped and made a bow with all courtesy to congratulate him on his way of dancing and his partner.

en: “I have been most highly gratified, indeed, my dear sir; such very superior dancing is not often seen.
vi: - I am very pleased, sir. One rarely sees such dancing artistry.
tr: "I am truly very impressed, sir. Such an exceptional dance is rarely seen.
es: ––I am extremely pleased, my esteemed sir, such an excellent way of dancing is not often seen.

en: It is evident that you belong to the first circles.
vi: Obviously, you belong to the upper class.
tr: It is clear that you belong in the front ranks.
es: It is evident that you belong to the most distinguished circles.

en: Allow me to say, however, that your fair partner does not disgrace you: and that I must hope to have this pleasure often repeated, especially when a certain desirable event, my dear Miss Eliza (glancing at her sister and Bingley), shall take place.
vi: However, allow me to say that your beautiful dance partner does not make you ashamed, and I wish to often have such joy, especially when a happy event is about to take place.
tr: But allow me to say, your lovely wife is not inferior to you; I hope for the frequent repetition of this pleasure, dear Miss Eliza, (glancing towards her sister and Bingley) especially when that happy day arrives.
es: Allow me to say, however, that your beautiful partner is in no way inferior to you, and I hope to enjoy this pleasure again, especially when a certain much-desired event, dear Elizabeth (looking at Jane and Bingley), takes place.

en: What congratulations will then flow in!
vi: So many congratulations will pour in!
tr: Then you will see the real congratulations!
es: How many congratulations there will be then!

en: I appeal to mr Darcy;—but let me not interrupt you, sir.
vi: I ask Mr. Darcy not to let me interrupt you, sir.
tr: My request to Mr. Darcy: –but I won't keep you, sir.
es: I appeal to Mr. Darcy. But I do not want to interrupt you, sir.

en: You will not thank me for detaining you from the bewitching converse of that young lady, whose bright eyes are also upbraiding me.”
vi: You will not thank me for pulling you away from the enchanting conversation of this young lady with bright eyes who also seems to blame me.
tr: –If I deprive you of this young lady's conversation, you won't thank me, and her bright eyes are already scolding me.""
es: You will thank me for not depriving you further of the captivating conversation of this young lady whose beautiful eyes are also reproaching me.

en: “Such very superior dancing is not
vi: You will not thank me for pulling you away from the enchanting conversation of this young lady with bright eyes who also seems to blame me.
tr: –If I deprive you of this young lady's conversation, you won't thank me, and her bright eyes are already scolding me.""
es: You will thank me for not depriving you further of the captivating conversation of this young lady whose beautiful eyes are also reproaching me.

en: often seen.”
vi: Darcy did not clearly hear the end of this speech, but Sir William's insinuations seemed to strike him deeply.
tr: Darcy barely heard the second half of these words, but Sir William's insinuation about his friend struck him; with a very serious expression, he turned his eyes to Bingley and Jane, who were dancing together.
es: Darcy barely heard this last part of her speech, but the allusion to his friend seemed to impress him greatly, and with a grave expression, he directed his gaze towards Bingley and Jane who were dancing together.

en: The latter part of this address was scarcely heard by Darcy; but Sir William’s allusion to his friend seemed to strike him forcibly, and his eyes were directed, with a very serious expression, towards Bingley and Jane, who were dancing together.
vi: His eyes, with a very serious expression, turned towards Bingley and Jane, who were dancing together at that moment.
tr: Darcy barely heard the second half of these words, but Sir William's insinuation about his friend struck him; with a very serious expression, he turned his eyes to Bingley and Jane, who were dancing together.
es: Darcy barely heard this last part of her speech, but the allusion to his friend seemed to impress him greatly, and with a grave expression, he directed his gaze towards Bingley and Jane who were dancing together.

en: Recovering himself, however, shortly, he turned to his partner, and said,—
vi: But he quickly regained his composure, turned to his dance partner, and said:
tr: Nevertheless, he quickly composed himself and turned to his companion, saying, "When Sir William interrupted, I forgot what we were talking about."
es: Nevertheless, he quickly recovered and, turning to Elizabeth, said:

en: “Sir William’s interruption has made me forget what we were talking of.”
vi: - Sir William interrupted, making me forget what we were talking about.
tr: Nevertheless, he quickly composed himself and turned to his companion, saying, "When Sir William interrupted, I forgot what we were talking about."
es: ––Sir William's interruption has made me forget what we were talking about.

en: “I do not think we were speaking at all.
vi: - I don't think we are talking about anything at all.
tr: "I don't think we talked.
es: ––I don't think we were talking.

en: Sir William could not have interrupted any two people in the room who had less to say for themselves.
vi: Sir William cannot interrupt two people in this room when they have nothing to say to each other.
tr: Sir William couldn't have found two people who speak less to interrupt.
es: Sir William could not have interrupted another couple in the entire room who had less to say to each other.

en: We have tried two or three subjects already without success, and what we are to talk of next I cannot imagine.”
vi: We have tried two or three topics without success, so I cannot think of what we will talk about next.
tr: We already tried two or three topics, it didn't work; I don't know what we will talk about now."
es: We have already tried two or three topics without success. I have no idea what we can talk about now.

en: “What think you of books?” said he, smiling.
vi: He said, smiling: - What do you think about books? - Books? Oh!
tr: "What do you think about books?" he said, smiling. "Books –No! absolutely not.
es: ––What do you think about books? ––he asked her, smiling. ––The books!

en: “Books—oh no!—I am sure we never read the same, or not with the same feelings.”
vi: No, I'm sure we never read the same kind of books, or read with the same feelings.
tr: –I'm sure we don't read the same books, and I'm also sure we don't read them with the same feelings."
es: Oh, no! I'm sure we never read the same ones or, at least, we don't get the same impressions.

en: “I am sorry you think so; but if that be the case, there can at least be no want of subject.
vi: - It's a pity that you think so, but if that's the case, at least we won't lack topics.
tr: "I am sorry you feel that way; but if that's the case, at least we won't run out of topics.
es: ––I regret that you think that; but if that were the case, anyway, we would not lack a topic.

en: We may compare our different opinions.”
vi: We can compare different viewpoints.
tr: –We can compare our different views."
es: We can compare our various opinions.

en: “No—I cannot talk of books in a ball-room; my head is always full of something else.”
vi: - No, I cannot talk about books in a ballroom; my mind is always filled with other things.
tr: "No – I cannot talk about books in a ballroom; my mind is always filled with other things."
es: ––No, I can't talk about books in a ballroom. My mind is occupied with other things.

en: “The present always occupies you in such scenes—does it?” said he, with a look of doubt.
vi: He asked, with a doubtful look: - The present always preoccupies you in these settings, doesn't it? - Yes, always like that.
tr: "The current you is always preoccupied with such scenes – isn't it?" said Darcy, with a doubtful look.
es: ––In these places, one thinks only of the present, right? ––he said with a doubtful look.

en: “Yes, always,” she replied, without knowing what she said; for her thoughts had wandered far from the subject, as soon afterwards appeared by her suddenly exclaiming, “I remember hearing you once say, mr Darcy, that you hardly ever forgave;—that your resentment, once created, was unappeasable.
vi: She answered without knowing what she was saying, as her thoughts had wandered off the subject, but then suddenly appeared: - Mr. Darcy, I remember the other day, you mentioned that you rarely forgive, and once you are offended, nothing can soothe you.
tr: "Yes, always," answered Elizabeth, not knowing what she was saying; her thoughts had wandered away from the subject; it became apparent a moment later when she suddenly spoke: "I remember you saying once, Mr. Darcy, that you do not forgive easily, that once you are offended, your resentment does not pass.
es: ––Yes, always ––she replied without knowing what she was saying, as her thoughts had wandered elsewhere, as she suddenly demonstrated by exclaiming––: I remember hearing you say once that you rarely forgave; that when you had conceived a resentment, it was impossible for you to appease it.

en: You are very cautious, I suppose, as to its being created?”
vi: I suppose you are very cautious about becoming offended in the first place.
tr: I suppose you are very cautious not to be offended."
es: I suppose, therefore, that you are very cautious in conceiving resentments...

en: “I am,” said he, with a firm voice.
vi: He spoke firmly: - That's right.
tr: "Indeed," said Darcy in a firm voice.
es: ––Indeed ––replied Darcy with a firm voice.

en: “And never allow yourself to be blinded by prejudice?”
vi: - And you never allow yourself to be blinded by prejudice, do you?
tr: "But wouldn't there be times when you let prejudice blind you?""
es: ––And do you never let yourself be blinded by prejudice?

en: “I hope not.”
vi: - I hope so.
tr: "I hope not."
es: ––I hope not.

en: “It is particularly incumbent on those who never change their opinion, to be secure of judging properly at first.”
vi: - Those who never change their opinions must possess this virtue to ensure sound judgment from the very beginning.
tr: "It is especially necessary for those who never change their opinions to arrive at the correct judgment in the first place.""
es: ––Those who never change their opinion must make sure before judging.

en: “May I ask to what these questions tend?”
vi: - May I ask, what are you aiming for?
tr: "May I ask where these questions are leading to?"
es: ––Can I ask you what the intention of these questions is?

en: “Merely to the illustration of your character,” said she, endeavouring to shake off her gravity.
vi: She said, trying to be gentle: - It's just an illustration of your nature.
tr: "I am merely trying to reveal your character," said Elizabeth, trying to shake off the weight on her.
es: ––To know his character, simply ––said Elizabeth, trying to conceal her seriousness––.

en: “I am trying to make it out.”
vi: I'm trying to figure out what that nature is like.
tr: "I am trying to understand."
es: I am trying to decipher it.

en: “And what is your success?”
vi: - And how did she realize it?
tr: "Did you at least understand?"
es: ––And what conclusions have you reached?

en: She shook her head.
vi: She shook her head:
tr: Elizabeth nodded, "I haven't made any progress at all.
es: ––None ––he said, shaking his head––.

en: “I do not get on at all.
vi: - I don't understand anything.
tr: Elizabeth nodded, "I haven't made any progress at all.
es: I've heard such different things about you that I can't make sense of it.

en: I hear such different accounts of you as puzzle me exceedingly.”
vi: I hear different things about you that make me very confused.
tr: I hear such different things about you that it confuses me greatly."
es: I've heard such different things about you that I can't make sense of it.

en: “I can readily believe,” answered he, gravely, “that reports may vary greatly with respect to me; and I could wish, Miss Bennet, that you were not to sketch my character at the present moment, as there is reason to fear that the performance would reflect no credit on either.”
vi: He replied, sternly: - I can readily believe that what people say about me varies greatly. Miss Bennet, I hope you will not hastily sketch out my character at this moment, for there is reason to fear that doing so correctly or incorrectly will not be properly reflected.
tr: "I believe that," Darcy replied seriously, "reports about me can vary greatly; I wish, Miss Bennet, that you would not attempt to sketch my character at this moment, for I have reasons to fear that your effort would not do justice to either side."
es: ––I acknowledge ––he replied gravely–– that opinions about me may vary greatly; and I would wish, Miss Bennet, that you do not sketch my character at this moment, because I have reasons to fear that the result would not reflect the truth.

en: “But if I do not take your likeness now, I may never have another opportunity.”
vi: - But if I don't try to create a portrait of you now, I might never have another chance.
tr: "But if I don't get an idea about you now, I might not have another chance.""
es: ––But if I don't do it now, I might not have another chance.

en: “I would by no means suspend any pleasure of yours,” he coldly replied.
vi: He said coldly: - I have no intention of stopping you if you like it.
tr: "Then I shall not spoil your enjoyment," replied Darcy.
es: ––By no means would I wish to prevent any of your satisfactions ––he replied coldly.

en: She said no more, and they went down the other dance and parted in silence; on each side dissatisfied, though not to an equal degree; for in Darcy’s breast there was a tolerably powerful feeling towards her, which soon procured her pardon, and directed all his anger against another.
vi: She said nothing more. The two continued with another piece of music and then parted in silence. Each felt a sense of resentment, though to different degrees, for within Darcy there was already a strong feeling towards her, allowing him to forgive her and direct all his anger towards someone else.
tr: Elizabeth said nothing more; they finished the other dance and parted in silence; neither was satisfied, though not equally; for there was a rather strong feeling in Darcy's chest towards her, which allowed him to quickly forgive her and direct all his anger towards someone else.
es: Elizabeth did not speak further, and when the dance ended, they parted in silence, both dissatisfied, though to different degrees, for in Darcy's heart there was a powerful feeling of tolerance towards her, which soon led him to forgive her and focus all his anger on another.

en: They had not long separated when Miss Bingley came towards her, and, with an expression of civil disdain, thus accosted her,—
vi: They parted ways not long before Miss Bingley arrived, her face disdainful.
tr: It hadn't been long since they parted when Miss Bingley came towards Elizabeth and, with a measured expression of disdain on her face, harassed her as follows: –"I heard, Miss Eliza, that you are quite fond of George Wickham!
es: It wasn't long after they had parted ways when Miss Bingley approached Elizabeth and, with an expression of both kindness and disdain, said to her:

en: “So, Miss Eliza, I hear you are quite delighted with George Wickham?
vi: - Ah, Miss Eliza, I heard that you are quite fond of George Wickham!
tr: It hadn't been long since they parted when Miss Bingley came towards Elizabeth and, with a measured expression of disdain on her face, harassed her as follows: –"I heard, Miss Eliza, that you are quite fond of George Wickham!
es: ––So, Miss Eliza, you are delighted with Mr. Wickham.

en: Your sister has been talking to me about him, and asking me a thousand questions; and I find that the young man forgot to tell you, among his other communications, that he was the son of old Wickham, the late mr Darcy’s steward.
vi: Your sister has told me about him and asked me a thousand questions. I see that the young man forgot to tell you that he is the son of old Mr. Wickham, the late Mr. Darcy's steward.
tr: Your sister mentioned him to me, she kept asking a thousand questions; I realized that young man forgot to tell you some things, for instance, that he is old Wickham's son, that is, the late Mr. Darcy's steward.
es: I have learned from your sister who has spoken to me about him and asked me a thousand questions. It seems to me that this young man forgot to tell you, among many other things, that he is the son of old Wickham, the last steward of Mr. Darcy.

en: Let me recommend you, however, as a friend, not to give implicit confidence to all his assertions; for, as to mr Darcy’s using him ill, it is perfectly false: for, on the contrary, he has been always remarkably kind to him, though George Wickham has treated mr Darcy in a most infamous manner.
vi: However, as a friend, I advise you not to believe everything he says. The notion that Mr. Darcy treated him poorly is completely wrong, for on the contrary, Mr. Darcy has always been very kind to him, even though George Wickham has treated Mr. Darcy in the most shameful manner.
tr: However, as a friend, my advice to you is not to believe everything he says immediately; as for Mr. Darcy having wronged him, that's a blatant lie; quite the contrary, he has always treated him very well, even though George Wickham has done everything possible to harm him.
es: Let me advise you, as a friend, not to trust too much in everything he tells you, because the idea that Mr. Darcy treated him badly is completely false; on the contrary, he has always been extraordinarily kind to him, although George Wickham has behaved towards Mr. Darcy in the most infamous manner.

en: I do not know the particulars, but I know very well that mr Darcy is not in the least to blame; that he cannot bear to hear George Wickham mentioned; and that though my brother thought he could not well avoid including him in his invitation to the officers, he was excessively glad to find that he had taken himself out of the way.
vi: I do not know the details, but I know very clearly that Mr. Darcy is not to blame at all, and he does not want to hear anyone speak of George Wickham. Although my brother could not help but invite him to the ball, he was very glad to see him voluntarily absent.
tr: I don't know the details, but I do know that Mr. Darcy is not at fault in the slightest, and that he can't even bear to hear George Wickham's name; also, my brother thought he couldn't avoid inviting the officers, but he was very pleased to see him withdraw.
es: I do not know the details, but I know very well that Mr. Darcy is in no way to blame, that he cannot bear to even hear the name of George Wickham, and that, although my brother considered that he could not avoid including him in the list of invited officers, he was greatly relieved to see that he himself had stepped aside.

en: His coming into the country at all is a most insolent thing, indeed, and I wonder how he could presume to do it.
vi: His moving to this area was indeed an insolent act; I wonder how he could have the audacity to do so.
tr: His coming to the countryside is really a great impertinence; I truly wonder how he dared.
es: The mere fact that he has come here to the countryside is a true insolence, and I cannot understand how he dared to do so.

en: I pity you, Miss Eliza, for this discovery of your favourite’s guilt; but really, considering his descent, one could not expect much better.”
vi: I pity you, Eliza, for discovering the wrongdoings of the person you admire, but considering his decline, no one could expect anything better.
tr: I pity you for learning about your favorite's fault in this way, Miss Eliza; but honestly, considering the man's downfall, nothing better could be expected."
es: I pity you, Miss Eliza, for this discovery of the guilt of your favorite; but in reality, considering his origin, nothing better could be expected.

en: “His guilt and his descent appear, by your account, to be the same,” said Elizabeth, angrily; “for I have heard you accuse him of nothing worse than of being the son of mr Darcy’s steward, and of that, I can assure you, he informed me himself.”
vi: Elizabeth angrily: - According to what she said, his wrongdoing and his decline seemed to be one and the same, because I heard her condemn him for nothing worse than being the son of Mr. Darcy's steward, but I inform you that he himself told me about this.
tr: "His crime and his fall seem to be the same as in your story," said Elizabeth angrily; "because I haven't heard you accuse him of anything worse than being Mr. Darcy's steward's son, and rest assured, he himself had already told me as much.""
es: ––His guilt and his origin seem to be the same thing to you ––Elizabeth said angrily––; because the worst thing I have heard you accuse him of is being the son of Mr. Darcy's steward, and I can assure you, he had already informed me of that.

en: “I beg your pardon,” replied Miss Bingley, turning away with a sneer.
vi: I'm sorry for interfering.
tr: "Excuse me," replied Miss Bingley, turning up her nose as she walked away.
es: ––I beg you to excuse me ––replied Miss Bingley, turning away with disdain––.

en: “Excuse my interference; it was kindly meant.”
vi: I only had good intentions.
tr: "Pardon my interference; I said it with good intentions."
es: Forgive my intrusion; it was with the best intention.

en: “Insolent girl!” said Elizabeth to herself.
vi: Miss Bingley turned away, sneering. Elizabeth whispered: "You are the one who is being insolent!
tr: "Arrogant thing!" said Elizabeth to herself.
es: “Insolent!” said Elizabeth to herself.

en: “You are much mistaken if you expect to influence me by such a paltry attack as this.
vi: You are greatly mistaken if you think you can influence me with such vile words.
tr: "If you think you can affect me with such pitiful attacks, you are very mistaken.
es: “You are very mistaken if you think you will influence me with such a petty attack.

en: I see nothing in it but your own wilful ignorance and the malice of mr Darcy.”
vi: I see nothing in this but your deliberate ignorance and Mr. Darcy's malice."
tr: I see nothing in this but your deliberate ignorance and Mr. Darcy's malice."
es: I see nothing in it but your stubborn ignorance and Darcy's malice.”

en: She then sought her eldest sister, who had undertaken to make inquiries on the same subject of Bingley.
vi: Then she went to find her eldest sister; her sister had already inquired Mr. Bingley about the same subject.
tr: Then she looked for her sister; Jane had begun to probe Bingley on the same matter.
es: Then she looked at her older sister who had dared to question Bingley about the same matter.

en: Jane met her with a smile of such sweet complacency, a glow of such happy expression, as sufficiently marked how well she was satisfied with the occurrences of the evening.
vi: Jane met her younger sister with a sweet, satisfied smile, her face glowing with happiness, clearly showing she had enjoyed the evening very much.
tr: She greeted her with such a sweet smile of happiness, such a joyful glow, that it spoke volumes about how pleased she was with what had happened that evening.
es: Jane returned her gaze with such a sweet smile, with an expression of happiness and so much satisfaction that it clearly indicated she was very pleased with what had happened during the evening.

en: Elizabeth instantly read her feelings; and, at that moment, solicitude for Wickham, resentment against his enemies, and everything else, gave way before the hope of Jane’s being in the fairest way for happiness.
vi: Elizabeth immediately understood her sister's feelings.
tr: Elizabeth understood her feelings at that moment, and in that instant, her solidarity with Wickham, her anger towards Wickham's enemies, and everything else faded away in the face of the hope that Jane was on the most beautiful path to happiness.
es: Elizabeth instantly read her feelings; and in a moment all her concern for Wickham, her hatred towards his enemies, and everything else disappeared before the hope that Jane was on the best path to her happiness.

en: “I want to know,” said she, with a countenance no less smiling than her sister’s, “what you have learnt about mr Wickham.
vi: She asked, with a smile as bright as her sister's: - I want to know what you have found out about Mr. Wickham.
tr: "Tell me," she said with a face no less smiling than her sister's, "what did you learn about Mr. Wickham?
es: "I want to know," said Elizabeth as smiling as her sister, "what you have heard about Mr. Wickham."

en: But perhaps you have been too pleasantly engaged to think of any third person, in which case you may be sure of my pardon.”
vi: But perhaps you are too happy to think about a third person, in which case I apologize to you.
tr: But perhaps you were too occupied with happy things to think of a third person; if so, I apologize."
es: "But perhaps you have been too busy with more pleasant things to think about a third person..." "If that has been the case, you can be sure that I forgive you."

en: “No,” replied Jane, “I have not forgotten him; but I have nothing satisfactory to tell you.
vi: Jane replied: - No, I haven't forgotten him, but I have nothing good to say to you about him.
tr: "No," said Jane, "I haven't forgotten him; but there is nothing proper to tell you.
es: ––No ––answered Jane––, I have not forgotten him, but I have nothing pleasant to tell you.

en: mr Bingley does not know the whole of his history, and is quite ignorant of the circumstances which have principally offended mr Darcy; but he will vouch for the good conduct, the probity and honour, of his friend, and is perfectly convinced that mr Wickham has deserved much less attention from mr Darcy than he has received; and I am sorry to say that by his account, as well as his sister’s, mr Wickham is by no means a respectable young man.
vi: Mr. Bingley does not know everything about his past, and he is almost unaware of the circumstances that offended Mr. Darcy, but he can vouch for his friend's good conduct, honesty, and honor. He firmly believes that Mr. Wickham does not deserve Mr. Darcy's attention. I regret to say that, according to him and his sister, Mr. Wickham is not a respectable person.
tr: Mr. Bingley doesn't know the whole story; he also doesn't know what originally angered Mr. Darcy; but he vouches for his friend's moral conduct, honor, and integrity; moreover, he is certain that Mr. Wickham has been treated better than he deserves by Mr. Darcy; I'm sorry to say that from what I've heard from him and his sister, Mr. Wickham is not a very reputable young man.
es: Mr. Bingley does not know the whole story and is unaware of the circumstances that have so offended Mr. Darcy, but he vouches for the good conduct, integrity, and honesty of his friend, and is firmly convinced that Mr. Wickham has received more attention from Mr. Darcy than he deserved; and I regret to say that, according to Mr. Bingley and his sister, Mr. Wickham is far from being a respectable young man.

en: I am afraid he has been very imprudent, and has deserved to lose mr Darcy’s regard.”
vi: I fear that Wickham is too reckless and that Mr. Darcy's dislike of him is justified.
tr: I'm afraid he has behaved too recklessly and deserved to lose Mr. Darcy's trust."
es: I fear he has been imprudent and well deserves to have lost Mr. Darcy's consideration.

en: “mr Bingley does not know mr Wickham himself.”
vi: - Mr. Bingley doesn't know Mr. Wickham?
tr: "Does Mr. Bingley not know Mr. Wickham personally?""
es: ––Does Mr. Bingley not know Mr. Wickham personally?

en: “No; he never saw him till the other morning at Meryton.”
vi: - No; I only met him this morning at Meryton.
tr: "No; she had never seen him before last morning in Meryton.""
es: ––No, I had never seen him before the other day in Meryton.

en: “This account then is what he has received from mr Darcy.
vi: - So, what you know is through Mr. Darcy.
tr: "Then the things they know are what Mr. Darcy taught them.
es: ––So what you know is what Mr. Darcy has told you.

en: I am perfectly satisfied.
vi: I am completely satisfied.
tr: I am quite satisfied.
es: I am satisfied.

en: But what does he say of the living?”
vi: But what did he say about the church income?
tr: So what does he say about the church?"
es: And what does he say about the rectory?

en: “He does not exactly recollect the circumstances, though he has heard them from mr Darcy more than once, but he believes that it was left to him conditionally only.”
vi: - He does not remember anything about this matter, although more than once he has heard from Mr. Darcy, but he believes that this amount was left conditionally for Wickham.
tr: "She has heard from Mr. Darcy a few times but does not remember the events well, yet believes that the church was left to him conditionally."
es: ––He doesn't remember exactly how it was, although he has heard his friend tell it more than once; but he believes it was bequeathed to him only conditionally.

en: “I have not a doubt of mr Bingley’s sincerity,” said Elizabeth warmly, “but you must excuse my not being convinced by assurances only.
vi: Elizabeth said warmly: - I have no doubt about Mr. Bingley's sincerity, but you must forgive me if I am not convinced by his assurances.
tr: "I have no doubt of Mr. Bingley's sincerity," said Elizabeth warmly: "but do not expect me to be convinced merely by suggestions.
es: ––I do not doubt Mr. Bingley's sincerity ––said Elizabeth heatedly––, but forgive me if his assertions do not convince me.

en: mr Bingley’s defence of his friend was a very able one, I dare say; but since he is unacquainted with several parts of the story, and has learnt the rest from that friend himself, I shall venture still to think of both gentlemen as I did before.”
vi: I can acknowledge that Mr. Bingley's defense of his friend has some basis, but since he is unaware of certain parts of the story and only knows the rest through his friend, I still think of Wickham and Darcy as I did before.
tr: It is quite normal for Mr. Bingley to defend his friend; but since he does not know every aspect of the story and has learned the other sides from his friend, I believe I will continue to think the same about both gentlemen as before."
es: He does well to defend his friend; but since he is unaware of some parts of the story and the only thing he knows is what he has been told, I will continue to think of the two gentlemen the same as I did before.

en: She then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each, and on which there could be no difference of sentiment.
vi: Then she changed the conversation to a topic that everyone felt more comfortable with and that did not cause emotional conflict.
tr: Then he moved on to a topic that both would enjoy more and would not disagree on.
es: Having said this, both sisters started another conversation much more pleasant for both of them.

en: Elizabeth listened with delight to the happy though modest hopes which Jane entertained of Bingley’s regard, and said all in her power to heighten her confidence in it.
vi: Elizabeth happily listened to the modest hopes for happiness that Jane harbored about Bingley, and did her best to reinforce her sister's belief.
tr: He listened with pleasure to Jane's happy but modest hopes regarding Bingley's intentions and said everything he could to boost Jane's confidence.
es: Elizabeth listened delightedly to the happy yet modest hopes that Jane harbored regarding Bingley, and she said everything she could to encourage her confidence.

en: On their being joined by mr Bingley himself, Elizabeth withdrew to Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last partner she had scarcely replied, before mr Collins came up to them, and told her with great exultation, that he had just been so fortunate as to make a most important discovery.
vi: When Mr. Bingley arrived, she returned to find Miss Lucas but gave brief answers to her questions about her recent dance partner before Mr. Collins approached. He cheerfully told her that he had just been fortunate to discover something important.
tr: When Mr. Bingley came over, Elizabeth withdrew to Miss Lucas's side; before Miss Lucas could answer whether she liked her last husband, Mr. Collins came over and, in a state of rapture, said he had just made a very important discovery.
es: When Mr. Bingley joined them, Elizabeth withdrew and went to talk with Miss Lucas, who asked her if she had liked her last partner. Elizabeth hardly had time to answer, because Collins presented himself to them, enthusiastically saying that he had been fortunate enough to make a very important discovery.

en: “I have found out,” said he, “by a singular accident, that there is now in the room a near relation to my patroness.
vi: - I happened to learn that there is currently someone in the room who has a close relationship with my benefactor.
tr: "I learned by accident," he said, "that there is a close relative of my boss in the room right now.
es: ––I have learned ––he said––, by a singular chance, that there is in this room a close relative of my benefactress.

en: I happened to overhear the gentleman himself mentioning to the young lady who does the honours of this house the names of his cousin Miss De Bourgh, and of her mother, Lady Catherine.
vi: I accidentally overheard him mentioning the name of this hostess, who is his cousin, Miss De Bourgh, and the name of her mother, Lady Catherine.
tr: I happened to overhear the gentleman personally telling the young lady of the house, Miss de Bourgh, and her mother, Lady Catherine's names.
es: I had the pleasure of hearing the gentleman himself mention to the lady who hosts this house the names of his cousin, Miss de Bourgh, and her mother, Lady Catherine.

en: How wonderfully these sort of things occur!
vi: It is wonderful to know this.
tr: What wonderful things happen in life!
es: How wonderfully these things happen!

en: Who would have thought of my meeting with—perhaps—a nephew of Lady Catherine de Bourgh in this assembly!
vi: Who could have guessed that I would meet Lady Catherine's nephew here!
tr: Who would have thought that I might meet a nephew of Lady Catherine de Bourgh in this gathering!
es: Who would have told me that I would find a nephew of Lady Catherine de Bourgh at this gathering!

en: I am most thankful that the discovery is made in time for me to pay my respects to him, which I am now going to do, and trust he will excuse my not having done it before.
vi: I am very pleased to have learned this just in time to greet him, and I believe he will forgive me for not knowing about this relationship, which can serve as an excuse for my apology.
tr: I am grateful to have learned this in time, so I can go and pay my respects now; I hope they will excuse me for not having gone earlier.
es: I am very glad to have made this discovery in time to pay my respects, which I will do right now.

en: My total ignorance of the connection must plead my apology.”
vi: I am very pleased to have learned this just in time to greet him, and I believe he will forgive me for not knowing about this relationship, which can serve as an excuse for my apology.
tr: My excuse is my ignorance of the relationship."
es: I trust you will forgive me for not having done so earlier, but my total ignorance of this relationship excuses me.

en: “You are not going to introduce yourself to mr Darcy?”
vi: - You don't intend to introduce yourself to Mr. Darcy, do you?
tr: "You will not introduce yourself to Mr. Darcy!""
es: ––Aren't you going to introduce yourself to Mr. Darcy?

en: “Indeed I am.
vi: - Actually, I intended to do so.
tr: "Of course, I will introduce you.
es: ––Of course!

en: I shall entreat his pardon for not having done it earlier.
vi: I will ask for your forgiveness for not doing this sooner.
tr: I will also apologize for not introducing you earlier.
es: I will ask him to excuse me for not having done it earlier.

en: I believe him to be Lady Catherine’s nephew.
vi: I believe you are Lady Catherine's nephew.
tr: I believe you are Lady Catherine's niece.
es: Don't you see that he is Lady Catherine's nephew?

en: It will be in my power to assure him that her Ladyship was quite well yesterday se’nnight.”
vi: I will do my best to assure you that the lady is still in good health.
tr: I will tell her that until last night, her Ladyship was in good health and spirits."
es: I will be able to tell him that Her Ladyship was very well the last time I saw her.

en: Elizabeth tried hard to dissuade him from such a scheme; assuring him that mr Darcy would consider his addressing him without introduction as an impertinent freedom, rather than a compliment to his aunt; that it was not in the least necessary there should be any notice on either side, and that if it were, it must belong to mr Darcy, the superior in consequence, to begin the acquaintance.
vi: Elizabeth tried to persuade him to abandon the idea, making him understand that Mr. Darcy would consider his approaching to start a conversation without an introduction as an improper and presumptuous attitude rather than a friendly inquiry about his aunt; that there was no need for them to recognize each other; that if necessary, Mr. Darcy should be the one to take the initiative to get acquainted due to his higher status.
tr: Elizabeth tried very hard to dissuade him from the plan, saying that she would consider it an impertinent liberty rather than a compliment to her aunt for Mr. Darcy to speak to her without an introduction, that neither party needed such communication, and that even if they did, the right to initiate the acquaintance belonged to Mr. Darcy, who was superior in rank.
es: Elizabeth tried to dissuade him from doing such a thing by assuring him that Mr. Darcy would consider addressing him without a prior introduction as an impertinence and a boldness, rather than a compliment to his aunt; that there was no need to make himself known, and if there were, it would be up to Mr. Darcy, due to the superiority of his rank, to take the initiative.

en: mr Collins listened to her with the determined air of following his own inclination, and when she ceased speaking, replied thus,—
vi: Mr. Collins listened to her with a determined look, still wanting to keep his intention, and when she finished speaking, he replied:
tr: Mr. Collins listened to her with a determined air of knowing better, and when she had finished speaking, he replied: "Dear Miss Elizabeth, I have great respect for your immense judgment in all matters within your understanding; but allow me to say, there is a great difference between the established rules of conduct among worldly men and those governing clergymen; permit me also to express that I see the religious office as equal in sanctity to the highest position in the kingdom – of course, maintaining humble behavior.
es: Collins listened to her, determined to follow his own impulses, and when Elizabeth stopped speaking, he replied:

en: “My dear Miss Elizabeth, I have the highest opinion in the world of your excellent judgment in all matters within the scope of your understanding, but permit me to say that there must be a wide difference between the established forms of ceremony amongst the laity and those which regulate the clergy; for, give me leave to observe that I consider the clerical office as equal in point of dignity with the highest rank in the kingdom—provided that a proper humility of behaviour is at the same time maintained.
vi: - Dear Miss Elizabeth, I have the utmost respect for your excellent judgment on all matters within your understanding, but allow me to say that there is a significant difference between the manners of the secular world and the rituals of the clergy. I must say that I regard the institution of the clergy with the same dignity as the highest titles in the kingdom – provided that proper humility is maintained in conduct.
tr: Mr. Collins listened to her with a determined air of knowing better, and when she had finished speaking, he replied: "Dear Miss Elizabeth, I have great respect for your immense judgment in all matters within your understanding; but allow me to say, there is a great difference between the established rules of conduct among worldly men and those governing clergymen; permit me also to express that I see the religious office as equal in sanctity to the highest position in the kingdom – of course, maintaining humble behavior.
es: ––My dear Miss Elizabeth, I have the highest opinion in the world of your excellent judgment in all kinds of matters, as befits your intelligence; but allow me to tell you that there must be a great difference between the established forms of courtesy for laypeople and those accepted for clergymen; let me warn you that the office of clergyman is, in terms of dignity, equivalent to the highest rank in the kingdom, provided that those who hold it behave with the appropriate humility.

en: You must, therefore, allow me to follow the dictates of my conscience on this occasion, which lead me to perform what I look on as a point of duty.
vi: Therefore, you must allow me to follow the call of my conscience in this situation, so that I may perform what I consider to be a duty.
tr: Therefore, allow me to do what my conscience tells me to do in this situation; my conscience urges me to do what I see as a duty.
es: So allow me to follow the dictates of my conscience which on this occasion lead me to do what I consider a duty.

en: Pardon me for neglecting to profit by your advice, which on every other subject shall be my constant guide, though in the case before us I consider myself more fitted by education and habitual study to decide on what is right than a young lady like yourself;” and with a low bow he left her to attack mr Darcy, whose reception of his advances she eagerly watched, and whose astonishment at being so addressed was very evident.
vi: Forgive me for not taking advantage of your advice, which would be a guiding star for me in other areas, although in the present case, I consider myself to have more understanding than a young lady like you, due to my education and constant learning, to decide what is right. He bent down and then went to meet Mr. Darcy. She eagerly watched how Mr. Darcy greeted him, clearly seeing that Mr. Darcy was very surprised to be approached.
tr: Forgive me for neglecting to take advantage of your advice; in every other matter, your advice will be my guide, but in the present issue, I consider myself more qualified than a young lady like you to decide what is right due to my education and occupation." And with a slight bow, he left her to approach Mr. Darcy; Elizabeth watched with curiosity as Mr. Darcy received him: it was very clear that he was surprised to be approached in such a manner.
es: Excuse me, then, for not following your advice which in all other matters will constantly serve as my guide, but I believe that in this case I am more qualified, due to my education and habitual study, than a young lady like you, to decide what is proper. Collins made a bow and walked away to greet Darcy. Elizabeth did not lose sight of him to see Darcy's reaction, whose astonishment at being approached in such a manner was evident.

en: Her cousin prefaced his speech with a solemn bow, and though she could not hear a word of it, she felt as if hearing it all, and saw in the motion of his lips the words “apology,” “Hunsford,” and “Lady Catherine de Bourgh.”
vi: Her cousin began with a formal bow, though she couldn't hear what he said, she had the impression she heard everything clearly, watching his lips form the words "apology," "Hunsford," and "Lady Catherine de Bourgh."
tr: Her cousin began his speech with a slight bow: although Elizabeth could not hear a single word, she felt as if she heard everything; she saw the words "apology," "Hunsford," and "Lady Catherine de Bourgh" in the movement of his lips.
es: Collins began his speech with a solemn bow, and, although she could not hear him, it was as if she could, for she could read the words "apologies," "Hunsford," and "lady Catherine de Bourgh" on his lips.

en: It vexed her to see him expose himself to such a man.
vi: Her heart fluttered seeing him expose himself to such a person.
tr: It annoyed her to see him make a fool of himself to such a man.
es: It irritated her that he would make a fool of himself in front of a man like Darcy.

en: mr Darcy was eyeing him with unrestrained wonder; and when at last mr Collins allowed him to speak, replied with an air of distant civility.
vi: Mr. Darcy looked at him with undisguised astonishment, and when Mr. Collins finally stopped speaking, he responded with little politeness.
tr: Mr. Darcy was looking at him with boundless astonishment; when Mr. Collins finally allowed him to speak, he replied with an air of distant politeness.
es: Darcy observed him without suppressing his astonishment, and when Collins allowed him to speak, he responded with distant courtesy.

en: mr Collins, however, was not discouraged from speaking again, and mr Darcy’s contempt seemed abundantly increasing with the length of his second speech; and at the end of it he only made him a slight bow, and moved another way: mr Collins then returned to Elizabeth.
vi: However, Mr. Collins was not discouraged and said a few more words, and Mr. Darcy's attitude seemed even more disdainful of what he heard. Finally, Mr. Collins bowed slightly and returned to Elizabeth.
tr: Nevertheless, Mr. Collins's courage to speak again was not broken; the length of the second speech increased Mr. Darcy's disdain, and in the end, he merely gave a slight bow and walked away in the other direction. Mr. Collins turned back to Elizabeth.
es: However, Collins was not discouraged and continued speaking. Darcy's disdain grew with the length of his second speech, and, in the end, he only made a slight bow and went elsewhere. Collins then turned back to Elizabeth.

en: “I have no reason, I assure you,” said he, “to be dissatisfied with my reception.
vi: He said: - I have no reason to be dissatisfied with the audience.
tr: "I assure you," he said, "I have no complaints about the way I was received.
es: ––I assure you ––he said to her–– that I have no reason to be dissatisfied with the reception Mr. Darcy has given me.

en: mr Darcy seemed much pleased with the attention.
vi: Mr. Darcy seemed very pleased with my interest.
tr: Mr. Darcy seemed very pleased with the attention I showed.
es: ––I assure you ––he said to her–– that I have no reason to be dissatisfied with the reception Mr. Darcy has given me.

en: He answered me with the utmost civility, and even paid me the compliment of saying, that he was so well convinced of Lady Catherine’s discernment as to be certain she could never bestow a favour unworthily.
vi: He responded to me very politely, and even complimented me by saying that he had great faith in Lady Catherine's judgment, knowing that she would never bestow favors on someone unworthy.
tr: He gave extremely kind responses and even paid a compliment, saying that he trusted Lady Catherine's decisions so much that he knew she would never do a favor to someone undeserving.
es: My attention has pleased him greatly and he has responded with the utmost politeness, even doing me the honor of stating that he was so convinced of Lady Catherine's good judgment that he took it for granted she would never bestow a favor unless it was deserved.

en: It was really a very handsome thought.
vi: That was a very generous thought.
tr: It was indeed a very nice thought.
es: It was truly a very beautiful phrase.

en: Upon the whole, I am much pleased with him.”
vi: Overall, I am very satisfied with him.
tr: As a result, I was very pleased with him."
es: In short, I am very pleased with him.

en: As Elizabeth had no longer any interest of her own to pursue, she turned her attention almost entirely on her sister and mr Bingley; and the train of agreeable reflections which her observations gave birth to made her perhaps almost as happy as Jane.
vi: Since Elizabeth no longer cared about anything else, she paid close attention to her sister and Mr. Bingley. The sight of the two being close to each other made her feel a joy almost as great as what Jane was experiencing.
tr: When Elizabeth had no business of her own to attend to, she immediately turned all her attention to her sister and Mr. Bingley; the train of thoughts that emerged from her observations made her almost as happy as Jane.
es: Elizabeth, who had no interest whatsoever in continuing to talk with Collins, devoted her attention almost entirely to her sister and Bingley; the multitude of pleasant thoughts that her observations gave rise to made her almost as happy as Jane.

en: She saw her in idea settled in that very house, in all the felicity which a marriage of true affection could bestow; and she felt capable, under such circumstances, of endeavouring even to like Bingley’s two sisters.
vi: She imagined her sister living in this very house with all the happiness that a marriage based on love could bring, and in this context, she thought she could even grow fond of Bingley's two sisters.
tr: She imagined Jane settled in the same house with all the happiness that a true love marriage could bring; and under those circumstances, she felt that she could even try to love Bingley's two sisters.
es: She imagined her settled in that great house with all the happiness that a marriage for true love can provide, and felt so delighted that she even believed that Bingley's two sisters might come to like her.

en: Her mother’s thoughts she plainly saw were bent the same way, and she determined not to venture near her, lest she might hear too much.
vi: She clearly saw that her mother's intentions were aligned with the same feelings, so she decided not to go near her for fear of hearing too much.
tr: She could clearly see that her mother's thoughts were in the same direction and decided not to approach her for fear of hearing too much.
es: It was not difficult for her to guess that her mother's thoughts followed the same path, and she decided not to risk approaching her to avoid hearing her comments.

en: When they sat down to supper, therefore, she considered it a most unlucky perverseness which placed them within one of each other; and deeply was she vexed to find that her mother was talking to that one person (Lady Lucas) freely, openly, and of nothing else but of her expectation that Jane would be soon married to mr Bingley.
vi: Thus, when they sat down to eat, she found the unfortunate circumstance that had placed her and her mother close to each other, and she was very uneasy to see her mother talking comfortably and openly with Lady Lucas, discussing nothing but her expectations of seeing Jane soon married to Mr. Bingley.
tr: When they sat down to dinner, she saw that by a stroke of bad luck she was seated next to her; and her spirits sank even further when she saw her mother freely and openly conversing with Lady Lucas on her other side, constantly talking about how she hoped Jane would soon marry Mr. Bingley. –
es: Unfortunately, at dinner time, they had to sit next to each other. Elizabeth was very upset to see how her mother kept talking to Lady Lucas, freely and openly, about her hope that Jane would soon marry Bingley.

en: It was an animating subject, and ms Bennet seemed incapable of fatigue while enumerating the advantages of the match.
vi: It was a lively topic, and Mrs. Bennet seemed tireless in listing the advantages of the marriage.
tr: It was an exciting topic, and Mrs. Bennet seemed tireless in enumerating the advantages of that union.
es: The topic was captivating, and Mrs. Bennet seemed never to tire of enumerating the advantages of that alliance.

en: His being such a charming young man, and so rich, and living but three miles from them, were the first points of self-gratulation; and then it was such a comfort to think how fond the two sisters were of Jane, and to be certain that they must desire the connection as much as she could do.
vi: The first points she boasted about were a charming, wealthy young man living only three miles away; and then it was truly comforting to see that his two sisters also liked Jane, being sure that they too desired the match as much as she did.
tr: The most significant sources of joy were that the man was so charming, so rich, and lived only three miles away from them; then, seeing how fond Bingley's two sisters were of Jane, and how much they desired the union as much as she did, was a great comfort.
es: Just considering the youth of the groom, his attractiveness, his wealth, and the fact that he lived only three miles from Longbourn, made Mrs. Bennet happy. But in addition, one had to take into account how delighted Bingley's two sisters were with Jane, who would undoubtedly be as pleased with the union as she herself was.

en: It was, moreover, such a promising thing for her younger daughters, as Jane’s marrying so greatly must throw them in the way of other rich men; and, lastly, it was so pleasant at her time of life to be able to consign her single daughters to the care of their sister, that she might not be obliged to go into company more than she liked.
vi: Moreover, this was a promising situation for the younger siblings, as Jane's wedding and such a brother-in-law would bring them closer to other wealthy men, and finally, it was a relief in this stage of her life to be able to entrust the care of her unmarried daughters to their elder sister, so when they went out to socialize, she wouldn't have to follow them more closely than she wished.
tr: Moreover, it was a promising thing for her younger sisters as well, because Jane making such a great marriage would pave the way for them to find wealthy men; and finally, knowing that at her age, she could place her unmarried daughters under their sister's protection and not have to go out into society unless she wanted to was a source of happiness.
es: Moreover, Jane's marriage to someone of such high status was very promising for her younger daughters, who would thus have more opportunities to meet wealthy men. Finally, it was a relief, at her age, to be able to entrust her single daughters to the care of their sister, and not have to accompany them herself except when she felt like it.

en: It was necessary to make this circumstance a matter of pleasure, because on such occasions it is the etiquette; but no one was less likely than ms Bennet to find comfort in staying at home at any period of her life.
vi: In this situation, it was necessary to accept and find joy, due to the social etiquette of such occasions, although she did not feel as comfortable as everyone else being confined indoors at any stage of life.
tr: This situation had to be turned into a source of pleasure because etiquette required it; but no one could enjoy staying at home less than Mrs. Bennet at any period of her life.
es: There was no choice but to take this circumstance as a reason for satisfaction, for in such cases, etiquette demands it; but there was no one who liked staying comfortably at home more at any time in her life.

en: She concluded with many good wishes that Lady Lucas might soon be equally fortunate, though evidently and triumphantly believing there was no chance of it.
vi: She concluded with many good wishes for Lady Lucas to soon be as fortunate as she was, although she confidently believed with a sense of triumph that her friend would have no such luck.
tr: She ended her words with wishes for Lady Lucas to be as fortunate as she was, although she clearly and joyfully believed that this was not possible.
es: She concluded by wishing Lady Lucas that she would soon be as fortunate as she was, though triumphantly thinking that there was not much hope.

en: In vain did Elizabeth endeavour to check the rapidity of her mother’s words, or persuade her to describe her felicity in a less audible whisper; for to her inexpressible vexation she could perceive that the chief of it was overheard by mr Darcy, who sat opposite to them.
vi: Elizabeth tried in vain to curb her mother's incessant chatter or persuade her not to be so loud in expressing her happiness, for in an indescribable agitation, she could see Mr. Darcy, sitting opposite them, had overheard most of the conversation.
tr: Elizabeth tried in vain to control the speed of her mother's words, to persuade her to recount her happiness in a less audible whisper; she was extremely annoyed to see that most of her mother's words were reaching the ears of Mr. Darcy, who was sitting opposite.
es: Elizabeth tried in vain to repress her mother's words and to convince her to express her joy a little more quietly; because, to her greater annoyance, she noticed that Darcy, who was sitting opposite them, was hearing almost everything.

en: Her mother only scolded her for being nonsensical.
vi: Her mother only scolded her for being unreasonable.
tr: Her mother contented herself with scolding her, saying she was being foolish.
es: The only thing her mother did was scold her for being so foolish.

en: “What is mr Darcy to me, pray, that I should be afraid of him?
vi: - What is Mr. Darcy to you that makes you afraid of him?
tr: "What do I care about Mr. Darcy, for heaven's sake, why should I be afraid of him?
es: ––What does Mr. Darcy mean to me? Tell me, why should I be afraid of him?

en: I am sure we owe him no such particular civility as to be obliged to say nothing he may not like to hear.”
vi: You know very well that you don't need to be so polite to him that you dare not say something he might not like to hear.
tr: I'm sure we don't owe him the courtesy of not saying things he wouldn't like to hear."
es: We don't owe him any special attention to feel obliged not to say anything that might upset him.

en: “For heaven’s sake, madam, speak lower.
vi: - Mom, please, I beg you to speak softly.
tr: "Please, mother, speak softly.
es: ––For the love of God, mom, speak more quietly!

en: What advantage can it be to you to offend mr Darcy?
vi: What good does it do to insult Mr. Darcy?
tr: What can offending Mr. Darcy gain you?
es: What do you gain by offending Mr. Darcy?

en: You will never recommend yourself to his friend by so doing.”
vi: His friends will never think well of you if you keep doing that.
tr: –You cannot make him speak well of you to his friend by acting this way."
es: The only thing you'll achieve, if you do, is to look bad in front of his friend.

en: Nothing that she could say, however, had any influence.
vi: However, her words had no effect.
tr: Nothing he said worked.
es: But nothing he said had any effect.

en: Her mother would talk of her views in the same intelligible tone.
vi: The mother still blatantly voiced her opinions.
tr: His mother continued to voice her thoughts in the same audible tone.
es: The mother continued to express her opinion with the same nonchalance.

en: Elizabeth blushed and blushed again with shame and vexation.
vi: Elizabeth kept blushing out of embarrassment and unease.
tr: Elizabeth blushed repeatedly in shame and discomfort.
es: Elizabeth was becoming more and more flushed with embarrassment and displeasure.

en: She could not help frequently glancing her eye at mr Darcy, though every glance convinced her of what she dreaded; for though he was not always looking at her mother, she was convinced that his attention was invariably fixed by her.
vi: She couldn't help but occasionally glance at Mr. Darcy, seeing exactly what she had feared; for although he seldom looked at her, she believed he was still attentively listening.
tr: She often couldn't resist glancing at Mr. Darcy, and each time she realized her worst fear had come true; even if Mr. Darcy wasn't always looking at her mother, Elizabeth felt his attention was constantly fixed on her mother.
es: She couldn't stop looking at Darcy frequently, although each glance convinced her more of what she was fearing. Darcy rarely fixed his eyes on the mother, but Elizabeth had no doubt that his attention was on what was being said.

en: The expression of his face changed gradually from indignant contempt to a composed and steady gravity.
vi: His expression gradually changed from contemptuous indignation to sternness and calmness.
tr: The expression on his face gradually shifted from a haughty disdain to a calm and steady seriousness.
es: The expression on his face gradually shifted from disdain and indignation to an unperturbed seriousness.

en: At length, however, ms Bennet had no more to say; and Lady Lucas, who had been long yawning at the repetition of delights which she saw no likelihood of sharing, was left to the comforts of cold ham and chicken.
vi: In the end, Mrs. Bennet had nothing more to say. Lady Lucas, having yawned at the long-winded accounts of joys she saw no chance of sharing, was left in peace to enjoy the ham and chicken.
tr: Finally, Mrs. Bennet had nothing more to say; Lady Lucas, who had begun to yawn from repeatedly hearing the pleasures that Mrs. Bennet deemed impossible to share, was left with the taste of cold ham and chicken.
es: However, there came a moment when Mrs. Bennet had nothing more to say, and Lady Lucas, who had long been yawning at the repetition of delights in which she saw no possibility of participating, indulged in the pleasures of chicken and ham.

en: Elizabeth now began to revive.
vi: Elizabeth began to recover.
tr: Elizabeth then began to come to her senses.
es: Elizabeth breathed a sigh of relief.

en: But not long was the interval of tranquillity; for when supper was over, singing was talked of, and she had the mortification of seeing Mary, after very little entreaty, preparing to oblige the company.
vi: But the tranquility did not last long, for when the meal ended, a suggestion was made for singing, and she felt tormented seeing Mary, after a little encouragement, preparing to contribute to the entertainment.
tr: However, the silence did not last long; after the meal, there was talk of singing, and she saw that Mary was preparing to respond to the requests after very little insistence.
es: But this interval of tranquility did not last long; after dinner, there was talk of singing, and she had to endure the ordeal of seeing Mary, after very little persuasion, prepare to treat those present with her singing.

en: By many significant looks and silent entreaties did she endeavour to prevent such a proof of complaisance,—but in vain; Mary would not understand them; such an opportunity of exhibiting was delightful to her, and she began her song.
vi: She tried to prevent such indulgence with many suggestive and pleading glances, but to no avail. Mary did not care to understand; such an opportunity to perform was her delight, and she began her song.
tr: She tried to prevent such an indiscretion with meaningful looks and silent pleas, but in vain; Mary did not understand these; she liked the opportunity to show off; she began her song.
es: With significant looks and silent pleas, Elizabeth tried to prevent this display of condescension, but it was useless. Mary could not understand what she meant. Such an opportunity to showcase her talent captivated her, and she began her song.

en: Elizabeth’s eyes were fixed on her, with most painful sensations; and she watched her progress through the several stanzas with an impatience which was very ill rewarded at their close; for Mary, on receiving amongst the thanks of the table the hint of a hope that she might be prevailed on to favour them again, after the pause of half a minute began another.
vi: Elizabeth's eyes were fixed on her sister with the most wretched feelings; and she restlessly watched her through several not very well-received musical passages as they concluded. Upon receiving thanks, Mary also perceived the implied wish for her to sing another song, so she began again.
tr: Elizabeth's eyes were fixed on her in agony, she watched impatiently as Mary progressed through several verses, but as the verses ended, she saw that it was not worth the patience, because when Mary seemed to receive a signal for another song among the table's thanks, she started a new song after a half-minute pause.
es: Elizabeth kept watching her with a painful sensation, observing the progress of the concert with an impatience that was not rewarded in the end, for Mary, upon receiving a slight hint to continue among the expressions of gratitude from her audience, after a minute's pause, began another song.

en: Mary’s powers were by no means fitted for such a display; her voice was weak, and her manner affected.
vi: Mary's talents were not suited for such a style of performance; she had a weak voice and overly affected mannerisms.
tr: Mary's talents were not suited for such a display; her voice was weak, her manner affected.
es: Mary's abilities were not the most suitable for such an exhibition; she had little voice and an affected style.

en: Elizabeth was in agonies.
vi: Elizabeth fell into despair.
tr: Elizabeth was in pain.
es: Elizabeth endured a true agony.

en: She looked at Jane to see how she bore it; but Jane was very composedly talking to Bingley.
vi: She looked over at Jane to see how her sister was enduring it, but Jane was calmly conversing with Bingley.
tr: She looked at Jane to see how she was enduring it; but Jane was calmly talking to Bingley.
es: She looked at Jane to see how she was bearing it, but she was talking calmly with Bingley.

en: She looked at his two sisters, and saw them making signs of derision at each other, and at Darcy, who continued, however, impenetrably grave.
vi: She looked at her two younger sisters, seeing them making mocking gestures at each other. She looked at Darcy, seeing him still stern and reserved.
tr: She looked at her two sisters, saw that they were making signs of disdain to each other; she looked at Darcy, but he maintained his incomprehensibly serious demeanor.
es: She looked at his sisters and saw that they were making mocking gestures to each other, and at Darcy, who remained serious and unperturbed.

en: She looked at her father to entreat his interference, lest Mary should be singing all night.
vi: She glanced at her father to implore him to intervene, lest Mary sing all night.
tr: She looked at her father, hoping he would intervene so that Mary would not sing all night.
es: Finally, she looked at her father, imploring his intervention to prevent Mary from singing all night.

en: He took the hint, and, when Mary had finished her second song, said aloud,—
vi: He understood, and when Mary finished her second song, he spoke loudly:
tr: Her father got the signal, and when Mary finished her second song, he said loudly, "You sang wonderfully, my dear.
es: He took the hint and when Mary finished her second song, he said loudly:

en: “That will do extremely well, child.
vi: - That's good enough, my daughter.
tr: Her father got the signal, and when Mary finished her second song, he said loudly, "You sang wonderfully, my dear.
es: ––Girl, that's enough.

en: You have delighted us long enough.
vi: You have entertained enough.
tr: You have made us all happy enough.
es: You've done very well, you've delighted us quite enough; now let the other young ladies shine.

en: Let the other young ladies have time to exhibit.”
vi: Let the other young ladies have their time to perform.
tr: Let some other young ladies show themselves now."
es: You've done very well, you've delighted us quite enough; now let the other young ladies shine.

en: Mary, though pretending not to hear, was somewhat disconcerted; and Elizabeth, sorry for her, and sorry for her father’s speech, was afraid her anxiety had done no good.
vi: Although pretending not to hear, Mary felt somewhat disappointed. Elizabeth pitied Mary, pitied her father, but feared that worrying would still not help.
tr: Although Mary pretended not to hear, she was a bit upset; Elizabeth, who was worried for her and for her father's words, feared that her concern was in vain.
es: Mary, although she pretended not to hear, was a little disconcerted. Elizabeth felt sorry for her and regretted that her father had said that. She realized that due to her uneasiness, she had not acted well at all.

en: Others of the party were now applied to.
vi: The others were encouraged to show their talents.
tr: Then the other members of the group were consulted.
es: Now it was someone else's turn to sing.

en: “If I,” said mr Collins, “were so fortunate as to be able to sing, I should have great pleasure, I am sure, in obliging the company with an air; for I consider music as a very innocent diversion, and perfectly compatible with the profession of a clergyman.
vi: Mr. Collins said: - If I were fortunate enough to have a good singing voice, I would be very honored to contribute to the enjoyment, as I consider music a healthy pastime and entirely compatible with a clergyman.
tr: "If I were fortunate enough to be able to sing," said Mr. Collins, "I would take great pleasure in entertaining this assembly with a song; I see music as a very innocent occupation, perfectly in harmony with the profession of clergy.
es: ––If I ––said Collins then–– had the good fortune to be apt for singing, I would very much like to entertain the audience with a romance. I consider music to be an innocent distraction and completely compatible with the clerical profession.

en: I do not mean, however, to assert that we can be justified in devoting too much of our time to music, for there are certainly other things to be attended to.
vi: However, I do not mean to say that we have a legitimate reason to spend much time on music, as there are certainly other tasks that need to be done.
tr: –However, I do not say we should devote too much time to music, because there are other things that need attention.
es: By this, I do not mean to say that it is right to devote too much time to music, for there are, of course, other things to attend to.

en: The rector of a parish has much to do.
vi: A pastor managing a parish has many tasks to handle.
tr: A village parson has many duties to attend to.
es: The rector of a parish has a lot of work.

en: In the first place, he must make such an agreement for tithes as may be beneficial to himself and not offensive to his patron.
vi: First and foremost, he must arrange with the higher powers to be effective in his duties without offending his patron.
tr: –For one, he must make a contribution agreement that will be beneficial to himself and not disturb his patron.
es: First of all, he has to make an adjustment of the tithes that is beneficial to him and not burdensome to his patron.

en: He must write his own sermons; and the time that remains will not be too much for his parish duties, and the care and improvement of his dwelling, which he cannot be excused from making as comfortable as possible.
vi: He must write his own sermons, and the remaining time cannot be so extensive that it neglects parish duties. He also has to take care of and improve his living quarters without being condemned for extravagance.
