tr: He must write his own sermons; the remaining time is barely enough for church duties and the maintenance and repair of his home, and it would be inexcusable not to make his home as comfortable as possible.
es: He has to write the sermons, and the time left is never enough for the parish duties and for the care and improvement of his parishioners whose lives he is obliged to make as bearable as possible.

en: And I do not think it of light importance that he should have attentive and conciliatory manners towards everybody, especially towards those to whom he owes his preferment.
vi: I consider it equally important that he must have an attitude of care and reconciliation with everyone, especially those who have elevated him.
tr: Moreover, I find it very important that he should have a careful and conciliatory attitude towards everyone, especially towards those to whom he owes his appointment.
es: And I consider it of great importance that he be attentive and conciliatory with everyone, especially with those to whom he owes his position.

en: I cannot acquit him of that duty; nor could I think well of the man who should omit an occasion of testifying his respect towards anybody connected with the family.”
vi: I cannot exempt him from these duties, just as I cannot think well of someone who has missed the opportunity to show respect to anyone related to the family.
tr: I cannot absolve him from this duty; in fact, let me say, I would not look kindly on him missing an opportunity to show his respect to anyone connected with the family. "
es: I consider this indispensable and cannot hold in good esteem the man who would waste the opportunity to pay his respects to anyone related to the family of his benefactors.

en: And with a bow to mr Darcy, he concluded his speech, which had been spoken so loud as to be heard by half the room.
vi: He leaned towards Mr. Darcy as he concluded his speech, which was delivered loudly enough for half the room to hear clearly.
tr: And he concluded his speech by bowing to Mr. Darcy; he had spoken so loudly that half the room had heard him.
es: And with a bow to Mr. Darcy, he concluded his speech, spoken so loudly that half the room heard it.

en: Many stared—many smiled; but no one looked more amused than mr Bennet himself, while his wife seriously commended mr Collins for having spoken so sensibly, and observed, in a half-whisper to Lady Lucas, that he was a remarkably clever, good kind of young man.
vi: Many people stared at him intently. Many people smiled, but no one appeared as interested as Mr. Bennet, while his wife enthusiastically praised Mr. Collins for his heartfelt words, whispering to Mrs. Lucas that he was a particularly virtuous and wise young man.
tr: –Many people stared –many people smiled; but no one seemed more amused than Mr. Bennet; at that moment his wife was seriously engaged in praising Mr. Collins for making such a meaningful speech: in a half-whisper she was telling Lady Lucas that he was quite an intelligent, well-bred young man.
es: Many stared at him intently, many smiled, but no one was as amused as Mr. Bennet, while his wife seriously praised Collins for having spoken so sensibly, and whispered to Lady Lucas that he was a very good person and extremely clever.

en: To Elizabeth it appeared, that had her family made an agreement to expose themselves as much as they could during the evening, it would have been impossible for them to play their parts with more spirit, or finer success; and happy did she think it for Bingley and her sister that some of the exhibition had escaped his notice, and that his feelings were not of a sort to be much distressed by the folly which he must have witnessed.
vi: For Elizabeth, it seemed as though her family had conspired together to showcase themselves as prominently as possible on this occasion; they could not have played their roles with higher spirits or better results. She thought Mr. Bingley and her sister were truly fortunate that he did not notice some of the performances, and his feelings were not too distressed by the ridiculous actions he had witnessed.
tr: It seemed to Elizabeth as if her entire family had conspired to disgrace themselves throughout the evening; they could not have played their roles more sincerely or with greater success; she was glad for Bingley and her sister that he had missed some of the disgrace; fortunately, Bingley's feelings were not the kind to be troubled by the foolishness he must have witnessed.
es: To Elizabeth, it seemed that if her family had agreed to make themselves as ridiculous as possible that night, they could not have done it better nor achieved such success; and she was very glad that Bingley and his sister had not witnessed most of the spectacle and that Bingley was not the kind of person who cared about or was bothered by the madness he might have witnessed.

en: That his two sisters and mr Darcy, however, should have such an opportunity of ridiculing her relations was bad enough; and she could not determine whether the silent contempt of the gentleman, or the insolent smiles of the ladies, were more intolerable.
vi: However, she found it unfortunate that Mr. Bingley’s sisters and Mr. Darcy had the opportunity to mock her relatives, and she was unsure whether Mr. Darcy's silent arrogance or the sisters' disdainful smiles were more bearable.
tr: However, it was bad enough that her two sisters had found an opportunity to mock Mr. Darcy's relatives, and Elizabeth could not decide whether Mr. Darcy's silent disdain or the two ladies' insolent smiles were more unbearable.
es: It was bad enough that the sisters and Darcy had the opportunity to mock her family; and she did not know what she found more intolerable: Darcy's silent contempt or the ladies' insolent smirks.

en: The rest of the evening brought her little amusement.
vi: She did not feel any joy in the remaining time.
tr: The rest of the evening brought very little amusement.
es: The rest of the night passed for her without the slightest interest.

en: She was teased by mr Collins, who continued most perseveringly by her side; and though he could not prevail with her to dance with him again, put it out of her power to dance with others.
vi: Mr. Collins teased her, persistently clinging to her; and although he could not dance with her again, he found ways to prevent her from dancing with others.
tr: She was weary of Mr. Collins, who stubbornly stood by her side; although he could not persuade her to dance again, he also did not allow her to dance with others.
es: Collins drove her crazy with his insistence on not leaving her side. Although he did not manage to convince her to dance with him again, he prevented her from dancing with others.

en: In vain did she entreat him to stand up with somebody else, and offered to introduce him to any young lady in the room.
vi: She earnestly asked him to dance with someone else and offered to introduce him to any young lady in the room, but he refused.
tr: Elizabeth tried in vain to get rid of him; she even offered to introduce him to one of the young ladies in the room.
es: It was useless for her to beg him to go chat with other people and to offer to introduce him to some young ladies at the party.

en: He assured her that, as to dancing, he was perfectly indifferent to it; that his chief object was, by delicate attentions, to recommend himself to her; and that he should therefore make a point of remaining close to her the whole evening.
vi: He reassured her that he did not like dancing at all, that his main purpose was the delicate attentions he wanted to bestow upon her, and thus he wanted to make his intentions clear by staying close to her for the rest of the time.
tr: The man said that he did not care in the least about dancing, that his main aim was to win her favor by showing delicate attention, and therefore he insisted on staying by her side all evening.
es: Collins assured her that dancing did not matter to him and that his main desire was to make himself agreeable to her with delicate attentions, so he had decided to stay by her side all night.

en: There was no arguing upon such a project.
vi: There was no arguing about this.
tr: There was no arguing with such a project.
es: There was nothing to argue about such a plan.

en: She owed her greatest relief to her friend Miss Lucas, who often joined them, and good-naturedly engaged mr Collins’s conversation to herself.
vi: She felt greatly relieved whenever Miss Lucas came over to them and cheerfully started a conversation with Mr. Collins.
tr: Her friend Miss Lucas often came over to them and meekly took over the task of listening to Mr. Collins' conversation, which allowed Elizabeth to feel somewhat at ease.
es: Her friend Miss Lucas was the only one who consoled her by frequently sitting by her side and diverting Collins' conversation towards her.

en: She was at least free from the offence of mr Darcy’s further notice: though often standing within a very short distance of her, quite disengaged, he never came near enough to speak.
vi: At least she no longer had to endure the annoyance of Mr. Darcy paying her any more attention. Although he often stayed a short distance away, somewhat unburdened, he never came close enough to converse.
tr: At least she did not have to endure the boredom that Mr. Darcy could cause; although he was often very close and standing by himself, he never came close enough to talk.
es: At least in this way she was free of Darcy, who, although sometimes found himself at a short distance from them completely unoccupied, did not approach to speak to them.

en: She felt it to be the probable consequence of her allusions to mr Wickham, and rejoiced in it.
vi: She thought it might be because she had hinted at Mr. Wickham, and she was glad about this.
tr: Elizabeth felt that this might be the result of his implications regarding Mr. Wickham, and she was pleased.
es: Elizabeth attributed it to the result of her allusions to Wickham and was glad of it.

en: The Longbourn party were the last of all the company to depart; and by a manœuvre of ms Bennet had to wait for their carriage a quarter of an hour after everybody else was gone, which gave them time to see how heartily they were wished away by some of the family.
vi: The Longbourn family left the ball last. With Mrs. Bennet's arrangements, they had to wait for their carriage for 15 minutes after everyone else had gone. This gave them enough time to see how warmly some members of the host family bid them farewell.
tr: The Longbourn group was the last to leave; due to Mrs. Bennet's maneuver, they had to wait fifteen minutes after everyone else had left for their carriage, which gave them the opportunity to see how heartily some members of the family wished for their departure.
es: The Longbourn family was the last to leave. Mrs. Bennet managed to make them wait for the carriages for a quarter of an hour after everyone else had left, which allowed them to notice how eager some members of the Bingley family were for them to disappear.

en: ms Hurst and her sister scarcely opened their mouths except to complain of fatigue, and were evidently impatient to have the house to themselves.
vi: Mrs. Hurst and her sister barely spoke except to complain of tiredness, clearly wanting to see the guests off as quickly as possible.
tr: Mrs. Hurst and her sister hardly opened their mouths except to complain of fatigue; it was clear that they wanted the house to themselves.
es: Mrs. Hurst and her sister barely opened their mouths except to complain of fatigue; they were visibly impatient to be alone in the house.

en: They repulsed every attempt of ms Bennet at conversation, and, by so doing, threw a languor over the whole party, which was very little relieved by the long speeches of mr Collins, who was complimenting mr Bingley and his sisters on the elegance of their entertainment, and the hospitality and politeness which had marked their behaviour to their guests.
vi: The two did not want to continue conversing with Mrs. Bennet, despite her attempts to start a conversation, and this created an awkward atmosphere for everyone. Mr. Collins did not help matters by going on at length praising Mr. Bingley and his two sisters for their elegance in manners, as well as their outstanding hospitality and courtesy towards the guests.
tr: They repelled every attempt Mrs. Bennet made to start a conversation, thereby creating a severe silence over the whole group; Mr. Collins' long speeches, full of compliments about the elegance of the entertainment arranged by Mr. Bingley and his sisters, and their hospitality and kindness as a mark of their treatment of their guests, did nothing to ease them.
es: They rejected all of Mrs. Bennet's attempts at conversation and the liveliness dwindled, despite Collins' long speeches congratulating Bingley and his sisters on the elegance of the party and the hospitality and finesse with which they had treated their guests.

en: Darcy said nothing at all.
vi: Darcy said nothing.
tr: Darcy said nothing.
es: Darcy said absolutely nothing.

en: mr Bennet, in equal silence, was enjoying the scene.
vi: Mr. Bennet, also in silence, amused himself by observing the scene around him.
tr: Mr. Bennet, in the same silence, was enjoying the scene.
es: Mr. Bennet, as silent as he, enjoyed the scene.

en: mr Bingley and Jane were standing together a little detached from the rest, and talked only to each other.
vi: Mr. Bingley and Jane stood together, slightly apart from everyone else, speaking only to each other.
tr: Mr. Bingley and Jane stood a little apart from the others, talking only to each other.
es: Bingley and Jane were together and a little apart from the others, talking to each other.

en: Elizabeth preserved as steady a silence as either ms Hurst or Miss Bingley; and even Lydia was too much fatigued to utter more than the occasional exclamation of “Lord, how tired I am!” accompanied by a violent yawn.
vi: Even Lydia was too tired to say anything more than “Oh my, I am so tired!” accompanied by a long yawn.
tr: Elizabeth also maintained her steady silence with Mrs. Hurst or Miss Bingley; even Lydia, except for occasionally exclaiming "My God, how tired I am!" with a violent yawn, was too exhausted to say anything else.
es: Elizabeth maintained the same silence as Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley. Even Lydia was too exhausted to say more than "Good heavens! How tired I am!" amid great yawns.

en: When at length they arose to take leave, ms Bennet was most pressingly civil in her hope of seeing the whole family soon at Longbourn; and addressed herself particularly to mr Bingley, to assure him how happy he would make them, by eating a family dinner with them at any time, without the ceremony of a formal invitation.
vi: Finally, when they bid each other farewell, Mrs. Bennet, with the most constrained politeness, expressed her desire to welcome the entire family to Longbourn, specifically telling Mr. Bingley that everyone would be very happy if he could come for an informal meal with the family at any time, instead of a formal invitation.
tr: When they finally rose to leave, Mrs. Bennet, in her most polite manner, expressed her hope of seeing the entire family at Longbourn as soon as possible. Addressing Mr. Bingley specifically, she mentioned that there was no need for formalities between them and that they would be very happy if he and his family came to dinner without waiting for an invitation.
es: When they finally got up to say goodbye, Mrs. Bennet insisted very courteously on her desire to soon see the whole family at Longbourn. She specifically addressed Bingley to tell him that they would be very honored if one day he came to their house to have lunch with them as a family, without the formality of a formal invitation.

en: Bingley was all grateful pleasure; and he readily engaged for taking the earliest opportunity of waiting on her after his return from London, whither he was obliged to go the next day for a short time.
vi: Bingley cheerfully accepted, willing to take advantage of the earliest opportunity to visit her after he returned from London, as he had to leave the next day for a short period.
tr: Bingley was very pleased and promised to visit them as soon as he returned from London, where he had to go for a short while the next day.
es: Bingley thanked her delightedly and immediately committed to taking the first opportunity that presented itself to visit them upon his return from London, where he had to go the next day, although he would not be long in coming back.

en: ms Bennet was perfectly satisfied; and quitted the house under the delightful persuasion that, allowing for the necessary preparations of settlements, new carriages, and wedding clothes, she should undoubtedly see her daughter settled at Netherfield in the course of three or four months.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was completely satisfied, leaving with the joy that, after preparing for the settlement of living arrangements, new carriages, and wedding dresses, she would surely see her daughter settled at Netherfield within three to four months.
tr: Mrs. Bennet was quite satisfied; if she allowed some time for the necessary preparations, new carriages, and wedding clothes, it was certain that within three or four months she would see her daughter settled at Netherfield; she left the house in this delight.
es: Mrs. Bennet was beside herself with joy and left the house convinced that, accounting for the necessary time for the celebration preparations, purchase of new carriages and wedding dresses, she would see her daughter settled in Netherfield within three or four months.

en: Of having another daughter married to mr Collins she thought with equal certainty, and with considerable, though not equal, pleasure.
vi: Thinking about another daughter marrying Mr. Collins also brought her great joy, though not to the same extent.
tr: She thought with the same conviction and, if not the same, considerable pleasure that another of her daughters would marry Mr. Collins.
es: With the same certainty and with considerable, though not equal, pleasure, she expected to soon have another daughter married to Collins.

en: Elizabeth was the least dear to her of all her children; and though the man and the match were quite good enough for her, the worth of each was eclipsed by mr Bingley and Netherfield.
vi: Among the daughters, she loved Elizabeth the least, although the second suitor and match were good enough for her, the value of Mr. Bingley and Netherfield still surpassed them.
tr: Among her children, she was the least fond of Elizabeth; both the man and the marriage were quite suitable for Elizabeth, but of course, Mr. Bingley and Netherfield were much more valuable than them.
es: Elizabeth was the one she loved the least of all her daughters, and although the suitor and the wedding were more than enough for her, they were overshadowed by Bingley and by Netherfield.

en: CHAPTER XIX.
vi: Chapter 19
tr: Chapter XIX
es: CHAPTER XIX

en: THE next day opened a new scene at Longbourn.
vi: A new scene unfolded at Longbourn the next day.
tr: The next day opened a new scene at Longbourn.
es: The next day, there was another event at Longbourn.

en: mr Collins made his declaration in form.
vi: Mr. Collins had solemnly expressed his intentions.
tr: Mr. Collins formally made his proposal.
es: Collins formally proposed.

en: Having resolved to do it without loss of time, as his leave of absence extended only to the following Saturday, and having no feelings of diffidence to make it distressing to himself even at the moment, he set about it in a very orderly manner, with all the observances which he supposed a regular part of the business.
vi: Having decided not to waste time since he could only take leave until Saturday, and feeling no shyness to be troubled even at this moment, he began in a very orderly manner, adhering to all the formalities of the matter.
tr: Determined not to waste any time since his leave was only until the following Saturday, and feeling no shyness that would turn the matter into a tension for him at that moment, he set to work in a very orderly manner, adhering to all the rules he considered a usual part of the business.
es: He resolved to do it without delay, as his leave was expiring the following Saturday; and having full confidence in his success, he undertook the task methodically and with all the formalities he deemed necessary in such cases.

en: On finding ms Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of the younger girls together, soon after breakfast, he addressed the mother in these words,—
vi: After breakfast, with Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of her sisters present, he spoke to the mother:
tr: When he found Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of the younger girls together immediately after breakfast, he addressed the mother with these words: "Madam, may I hope to obtain your approval if I request the honor of a private audience with your fair daughter Elizabeth this morning?"
es: Shortly after breakfast, he found Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of the younger daughters together, and addressed the mother with these words:

en: “May I hope, madam, for your interest with your fair daughter Elizabeth, when I solicit for the honour of a private audience with her in the course of this morning?”
vi: - Madam, for the love you bear your beautiful daughter Elizabeth, could you grant me the honor of a private conversation with her this morning?
tr: When he found Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of the younger girls together immediately after breakfast, he addressed the mother with these words: "Madam, may I hope to obtain your approval if I request the honor of a private audience with your fair daughter Elizabeth this morning?"
es: ––May I expect, madam, given your interest in your beautiful daughter Elizabeth, that I will be granted the honor of a private interview with her, during the course of this very morning?

en: Before Elizabeth had time for anything but a blush of surprise, ms Bennet instantly answered,—
vi: While Elizabeth had not yet had time to react except to blush, Mrs. Bennet quickly replied:
tr: Elizabeth, her face flushed with astonishment, before she could find an opportunity to say anything, Mrs. Bennet immediately replied, "Oh my God!
es: Before Elizabeth had time to do anything more than blush with surprise, Mrs. Bennet instantly replied:

en: “Oh dear!
vi: - Ah, yes, certainly, I'm sure Lizzy will be very happy.
tr: –Yes –of course.
es: ––Oh, dear!

en: Yes, certainly.
vi: - Ah, yes, certainly, I'm sure Lizzy will be very happy.
tr: –Yes –of course.
es: That was the last thing missing!

en: I am sure Lizzy will be very happy—I am sure she can have no objection.
vi: I'm sure the girl won't refuse.
tr: I am sure Lizzy will be very happy –I am sure she will not object.
es: I'm sure Elizabeth will be delighted and won't have any objections.

en: Come, Kitty, I want you upstairs.”
vi: Come here, Kitty, I want you to go upstairs.
tr: Come, Kitty, I need you upstairs."
es: Come, Kitty, I need you upstairs.

en: And gathering her work together, she was hastening away, when Elizabeth called out,—
vi: As she was hurrying along, Elizabeth called after her:
tr: As she gathered her things and hurried away, Elizabeth called after her,
es: And gathering her work, she hurried to leave them alone. Elizabeth called her, saying:

en: “Dear ma’am, do not go.
vi: - Mom, please don't go.
tr: "Mother, don't go.
es: ––Mom, dear, don't go.

en: I beg you will not go.
vi: I beg you, don't go.
tr: I beg you, don't go.
es: I beg you, don't go.

en: mr Collins must excuse me.
vi: Please forgive me, Mr. Collins.
tr: Mr. Collins must excuse me.
es: Mr. Collins will excuse me; but he has nothing to say to me that everyone can't hear.

en: He can have nothing to say to me that anybody need not hear.
vi: He has nothing to say to me that others don't need to hear.
tr: He cannot have anything to say to me that no one else should hear.
es: Mr. Collins will excuse me; but he has nothing to say to me that everyone can't hear.

en: I am going away myself.”
vi: I'm about to leave as well.
tr: I am going myself."
es: It's me who is leaving.

en: “No, no, nonsense, Lizzy.
vi: - No, no, don't be unreasonable, Lizzy.
tr: "No, no, don't be ridiculous, Lizzy.
es: ––No, don't be silly, Lizzy.

en: I desire you will stay where you are.”
vi: Your mother wants you to sit back down there.
tr: Please stay where you are."
es: Stay where you are.

en: And upon Elizabeth’s seeming really, with vexed and embarrassed looks, about to escape, she added, “Lizzy, I insist upon your staying and hearing mr Collins.”
vi: And when she saw Elizabeth with a frustrated and embarrassed expression as if wanting to hide, she added: - Lizzy, your mother wants you to stay and listen to Mr. Collins.
tr: And when he realized that Elizabeth was indeed about to flee with a troubled and anxious face, he added, "Lizzy, I insist that you sit and listen to Mr. Collins."
es: And seeing that Elizabeth, upset and agitated, was about to leave, he added: ––Lizzy, I order you to stay and listen to Mr. Collins.

en: Elizabeth would not oppose such an injunction; and a moment’s consideration making her also sensible that it would be wisest to get it over as soon and as quietly as possible, she sat down again, and tried to conceal, by incessant employment, the feelings which were divided between distress and diversion.
vi: Elizabeth could not resist this command. A moment of consideration helped her think that the wisest course was to resolve the matter as quickly and smoothly as possible. She sat down, trying to conceal her mixed feelings of distress and distraction.
tr: Elizabeth could not resist such coercion – after a moment's thought, she decided that the wisest course was to get through this quickly and quietly, and she sat down again; she tried to mask her feelings, torn between discomfort and patience, with the work in her hand.
es: Elizabeth could not disobey such a command. For a moment, she reconsidered and thought it wiser to end all of this as soon as possible in peace and tranquility. She sat down again and tried hard to conceal, on one hand, the feeling of discomfort, and on the other, how amusing she found the matter.

en: ms Bennet and Kitty walked off, and as soon as they were gone, mr Collins began,—
vi: Mrs. Bennet and Kitty walked away, and soon after, Mr. Collins began.
tr: Mrs. Bennet and Kitty went outside; as soon as they left, Mr. Collins began to speak.
es: Mrs. Bennet and Kitty left, and then Collins began:

en: “Believe me, my dear Miss Elizabeth, that your modesty, so far from doing you any disservice, rather adds to your other perfections.
vi: - Dear Miss Elizabeth, please believe that your humility so far has not harmed you at all; on the contrary, it complements your perfections.
tr: "Believe me, dear Elizabeth, your modesty, far from doing you any disservice, adds perfection to your perfection.
es: ––Believe me, my dear Miss Elizabeth, that your modesty, instead of harming you, adds to your other perfections.

en: You would have been less amiable in my eyes had there not been this little unwillingness; but allow me to assure you that I have your respected mother’s permission for this address.
vi: In my eyes, you might be less charming if you had not shown such modesty, but I assure you that your esteemed mother has permitted me to converse with you in this manner.
tr: If it were not for this little unwillingness, you would appear less admirable in my eyes; but allow me to assure you, I have obtained your venerable mother's permission for this conversation.
es: I would have found you less adorable if you had not shown that little resistance. But allow me to assure you that your mother has given me permission for this interview.

en: You can hardly doubt the purport of my discourse, however your natural delicacy may lead you to dissemble; my attentions have been too marked to be mistaken.
vi: Surely you do not doubt my intentions, although your innate delicacy might make you ignore them; my feelings are too clear to be mistaken.
tr: You cannot doubt the purpose of my words, but your natural delicacy may cause your mind to be confused; the interest I have shown was too evident to be disregarded.
es: You must already know the object of my discourse; although your natural delicacy leads you to conceal it; my intentions have been too evident to be mistaken.

en: Almost as soon as I entered the house I singled you out as the companion of my future life.
vi: From the moment I entered this house, I chose you as my companion for my future life.
tr: As soon as I entered the house, I chose you as my future life partner.
es: Almost from the moment I set foot in this house, I chose you as the future companion of my life.

en: But before I am run away with by my feelings on this subject, perhaps it will be advisable for me to state my reasons for marrying—and, moreover, for coming into Hertfordshire with the design of selecting a wife, as I certainly did.”
vi: But before I stray too far from the subject due to my emotions in this matter, perhaps I should state the reasons for marriage when I came to Hertfordshire with the intention of finding a wife, for indeed I had this intention.
tr: But before my feelings on the subject take over my senses, it might be appropriate to state my reasons for marriage – indeed, the reason for my coming to Hertfordshire with the intention of choosing a wife."
es: But before expressing my feelings, it might be advisable to explain the reasons I have for marrying, and why I came to Hertfordshire with the idea of finding a wife precisely here.

en: The idea of mr Collins, with all his solemn composure, being run away with by his feelings, made Elizabeth so near laughing that she could not use the short pause he allowed in any attempt to stop him farther, and he continued,—
vi: The idea of Mr. Collins, in all his calm solemnity, about straying from the subject due to his emotions, made Elizabeth almost burst into laughter to the point where she couldn't seize the opportunity when he paused to stop him. He continued.
tr: Looking at his solemn demeanor, the thought that Mr. Collins's feelings could sweep him off his feet almost made Elizabeth laugh; therefore, she couldn't use the brief pause to prevent the man from going further; Mr. Collins continued:–
es: Elizabeth almost burst into laughter at the thought of him expressing his feelings; and she couldn't take advantage of the brief pause he made to prevent him from continuing. Collins continued:

en: “My reasons for marrying are, first, that I think it a right thing for every clergyman in easy circumstances (like myself) to set the example of matrimony in his parish; secondly, that I am convinced it will add very greatly to my happiness; and, thirdly, which perhaps I ought to have mentioned earlier, that it is the particular advice and recommendation of the very noble lady whom I have the honour of calling patroness.
vi: - My reasons for marriage are, first, I think every clergyman, when in favorable circumstances, should set a good example of married life in his parish. Second, I believe that married life will bring me boundless happiness; and third, which I should have mentioned first, due to the advice of the noble lady whom I have the honor to call my patroness.
tr: "My reasons for getting married are as follows; first, I think it is right for a clergyman with comfortable conditions (like myself) to set an example of marriage in his village; second, I believe my happiness will greatly increase; third – and perhaps I should have mentioned this first, it is the special advice and recommendation of that noble lady whom I have the honor to call my patroness.
es: ––The reasons I have for marrying are: first, that the obligation of a clergyman in favorable circumstances like mine is to set an example of marriage in his parish; second, that I am convinced that it will contribute greatly to my happiness; and third, something that perhaps I should have mentioned first, that it is the particular advice and recommendation of the most noble lady whom I have the honor to call my patroness.

en: Twice has she condescended to give me her opinion (unasked too!) on this subject; and it was but the very Saturday night before I left Hunsford,—between our pools at quadrille, while ms Jenkinson was arranging Miss De Bourgh’s footstool,—that she said, ‘mr Collins, you must marry.
vi: Twice she has condescended to give me her opinion on this matter, and only last Saturday before I left Hunsford, she said: “Mr. Collins, you must marry.
tr: She gave me her opinion on this matter twice (unsolicited); it was the Saturday night before I left Hunsford – between the quadrilles, Mrs. Jenkinson was adjusting Miss de Bourgh's footstool, and she said, 'Mr. Collins, you must marry.
es: Twice she has deigned to suggest it to me, even without my hinting at it, and on the very Saturday night before I left Hunsford and during our game of quadrille, while Mrs. Jenkinson was adjusting Miss de Bourgh's chair, she said to me: "Mr. Collins, you must marry.

en: A clergyman like you must marry.
vi: A clergyman like you must marry.
tr: A clergyman like you must marry.
es: A clergyman like you must be married.

en: Choose properly, choose a gentlewoman for my sake, and for your own; let her be an active, useful sort of person, not brought up high, but able to make a small income go a good way.
vi: Choose carefully, select a good woman for me, and for yourself; she must be active and useful, not necessarily high-born but should be capable of managing household finances.
tr: –Make a suitable choice, select a young lady for my sake; for your own sake, she should be lively, useful, not overly pampered, but able to manage a small income.
es: Choose well, choose thinking of me and yourself; make sure she is an active and useful person, not highly educated, but capable of making the most of small incomes.

en: This is my advice.
vi: That is my advice.
tr: That is my advice.
es: This is my advice.

en: Find such a woman as soon as you can, bring her to Hunsford, and I will visit her.’
vi: Find such a woman as soon as possible, bring her to Hunsford, and I will visit her. ”
tr: Find such a woman as soon as possible, bring her to Hunsford, and I will visit.'
es: Find that woman as soon as possible, bring her to Hunsford, and let me see her."

en: Allow me, by the way, to observe, my fair cousin, that I do not reckon the notice and kindness of Lady Catherine de Bourgh as among the least of the advantages in my power to offer.
vi: By the way, my dear, allow me to remark that I consider Lady Catherine de Bourgh's concern and advice among my favorable circumstances.
tr: Meanwhile, my dear cousin, allow me to mention that I do not consider the privilege of being able to present you with Lady Catherine de Bourgh's interest and kindness as the least of my advantages.
es: Allow me, by the way, to say, fair cousin, that I do not consider as the least of the advantages I can offer you, the acquaintance and enjoyment of the kindness of Lady Catherine de Bourgh.

en: You will find her manners beyond anything I can describe; and your wit and vivacity, I think, must be acceptable to her, especially when tempered with the silence and respect which her rank will inevitably excite.
vi: You will find her character far surpasses what I have described; your wit and vivacity will please her, especially when tempered with the silence and respect that her position inevitably commands.
tr: You will find her manners beyond anything I can describe; your intelligence and liveliness, I believe, will be acceptable to her, especially when tempered with the awe her rank will inspire.
es: Her manners will seem to you far above anything I can describe, and your liveliness and wit will seem very acceptable to her, especially when moderated by the discretion and respect that her high rank inevitably imposes.

en: Thus much for my general intention in favour of matrimony; it remains to be told why my views were directed to Longbourn instead of my own neighbourhood, where I assure you there are many amiable young women.
vi: While I have intentions of marriage, I must also explain why I am inclined towards Longbourn rather than the area where I currently reside, which also has many charming young ladies.
tr: That is enough explanation for my intention to consider marriage; now it remains to explain why my thoughts have directed me to Longbourn instead of my own neighborhood; believe me, there are many beautiful young women in my own neighborhood.
es: This is all regarding my general intentions in favor of marriage; I have nothing more to say except the reason why I have directed myself directly to Longbourn instead of seeking in my own locality, where, I assure you, there are many charming young ladies.

en: But the fact is, that being, as I am, to inherit this estate after the death of your honoured father (who, however, may live many years longer), I could not satisfy myself without resolving to choose a wife from among his daughters, that the loss to them might be as little as possible when the melancholy event takes place—which, however, as I have already said, may not be for several years.
vi: I will inherit this estate after your esteemed father passes away, and I would not be at ease if I did not choose one of his daughters as my spouse, so that they would suffer less when that unfortunate event occurs, although, as I have said, it will not happen for many years.
tr: But the truth is, after the death of your esteemed father (may he live long), this estate will pass to me, and I would not feel at ease unless I chose one of his daughters as my wife to lessen the loss they would suffer, which I repeat, may it be long delayed.
es: But it is the case that being as I am the heir of Longbourn upon the death of your honorable father, whom I hope will live many years, I would not be satisfied if I did not choose a wife from among his daughters, to mitigate as much as possible the loss they will suffer upon the occurrence of such a sad event which, as I have already told you, I wish will not happen for many years.

en: This has been my motive, my fair cousin, and I flatter myself it will not sink me in your esteem.
vi: My dear, that is my motivation, which I hope will not make you think less of me.
tr: That was my reason, dear cousin; I believe this will not lower me in your eyes.
es: This has been the reason, fair cousin, and I hope it will not lower me in your esteem.

en: And now nothing remains for me but to assure you in the most animated language of the violence of my affection.
vi: Now, I have nothing more to say except to confirm to you, in the most vivid terms, my ardent affection.
tr: Now it only remains to convince you of the intensity of my feelings in the most colorful language.
es: And now I have only to express to you, in the most emphatic words, the strength of my affection.

en: To fortune I am perfectly indifferent, and shall make no demand of that nature on your father, since I am well aware that it could not be complied with; and that one thousand pounds in the 4 per cents., which will not be yours till after your mother’s decease, is all that you may ever be entitled to.
vi: I am completely indifferent to money, and will not ask your father for anything in this regard because I know well that he cannot provide, and that you will only inherit a sum of one thousand pounds at four percent, which you will only receive after your mother's death.
tr: I have no concern about a dowry; I will not make such a demand from your father, as I am aware it is impossible to meet; the only thing you may have a right to is that thousand-pound bond at 4 percent interest, which will not come to you until after your mother's death.
es: As for your dowry, it is absolutely indifferent to me, and I will not ask your father for anything that I know he cannot fulfill; so you will only have to bring the thousand pounds at four percent that will come to you upon your mother's death.

en: On that head, therefore, I shall be uniformly silent: and you may assure yourself that no ungenerous reproach shall ever pass my lips when we are married.”
vi: Therefore, on this matter, I will remain entirely silent. You can trust that I will not be so narrow-minded as to utter any complaints once we are married.
tr: I will not say a word about this; and rest assured, when we are married, not a single ungenerous complaint will ever escape my lips."
es: But I will not be demanding and you can be assured that no interested reproach will come from my lips once we are married.

en: It was absolutely necessary to interrupt him now.
vi: It was absolutely necessary to interrupt the guy now.
tr: It was now necessary to stop him.
es: It was absolutely necessary to interrupt him immediately.

en: “You are too hasty, sir,” she cried.
vi: She exclaimed: - Sir, you have been too hasty.
tr: "You are in too much of a hurry," cried Elizabeth.
es: ––You are going too fast ––exclaimed Elizabeth––.

en: “You forget that I have made no answer.
vi: You forgot that I have not yet answered.
tr: "You forget that I have not answered.
es: You forget that I have not answered you.

en: Let me do it without further loss of time.
vi: I will answer immediately to avoid wasting more time.
tr: Let me answer without wasting time.
es: Let me do so without further ado.

en: Accept my thanks for the compliment you are paying me.
vi: I thank you for your compliments.
tr: Accept my thanks for your compliments.
es: I appreciate your attention and the honor that your proposal signifies, but I cannot help but decline it.

en: I am very sensible of the honour of your proposals, but it is impossible for me to do otherwise than decline them.”
vi: I am very touched by your proposal, but I can do nothing other than decline.
tr: I appreciate the sincerity of your proposal, but there is nothing I can do except say no."
es: I appreciate your attention and the honor that your proposal signifies, but I cannot help but decline it.

en: “I am not now to learn,” replied mr Collins, with a formal wave of the hand, “that it is usual with young ladies to reject the addresses of the man whom they secretly mean to accept, when he first applies for their favour; and that sometimes the refusal is repeated a second or even a third time.
vi: Mr. Collins replied, with a ceremonious wave of his hand: - Until now, I have always known that when a young man proposes for the first time, young women often refuse while inwardly they are inclined to accept, and that they may refuse two or even three times.
tr: "I do not wish to learn immediately," Mr. Collins replied, waving his hand formally, "it is normal for young ladies to reject the proposal of a man they intend to accept at first; sometimes a second, or even a third refusal may occur.
es: ––I know full well ––replied Collins with a grave gesture of his hand–– that among young women it is very common to reject the proposals of the man whom, deep down, they intend to accept, when he asks for their preference for the first time, and that the refusal is repeated a second or even a third time.

en: I am, therefore, by no means discouraged by what you have just said, and shall hope to lead you to the altar ere long.”
vi: Therefore, I was not discouraged by what you just said, but rather hopeful that I would soon be married to you.
tr: Therefore, your words never discourage me; I hope to soon lead you to the altar.""
es: For this reason, what you have just told me does not discourage me at all, and I hope to lead you to the altar soon.

en: “Upon my word, sir,” cried Elizabeth, “your hope is rather an extraordinary one after my declaration.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - Sir, I must say that your hope is quite unusual after I have explained everything to you.
tr: "Believe me, sir," cried Elizabeth, "it is very strange that you still have hope after my explanation.
es: ––Good heavens, sir! ––exclaimed Elizabeth––. I don't know what hopes you could have left after my response!

en: I do assure you that I am not one of those young ladies (if such young ladies there are) who are so daring as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second time.
vi: Please believe that I am not among those young women who dare to gamble their happiness on the chance of a second proposal.
tr: I assure you, I am not one of those girls who would risk their happiness by expecting a second proposal (if such girls even exist).
es: I assure you that I am not one of those women, if such women even exist, so reckless as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second time.

en: I am perfectly serious in my refusal.
vi: I am entirely serious in my refusal.
tr: I am extremely serious in my refusal.
es: My refusal is very serious.

en: You could not make me happy, and I am convinced that I am the last woman in the world who would make you so.
vi: You cannot bring happiness to me, and I am certain I am not the last woman in this world who could make you happy.
tr: You cannot make me happy, and I am certain that I am the last woman in the world who could make you happy.
es: You could not make me happy, and I am convinced that I am the last woman in the world who could make you happy.

en: Nay, were your friend Lady Catherine to know me, I am persuaded she would find me in every respect ill qualified for the situation.”
vi: No, if Lady Catherine truly understood me, I believe she would see that I do not meet any of her standards.
tr: Moreover, if your friend Lady Catherine knew me, I know she would find me inadequate in every respect."
es: Moreover, if your friend Lady Catherine knew me, I have a feeling she would think that I am, in every respect, the least suitable for you.

en: “Were it certain that Lady Catherine would think so,” said mr Collins, very gravely—“but I cannot imagine that her Ladyship would at all disapprove of you.
vi: Mr. Collins said, very solemnly: - If Lady Catherine truly thinks that way, I cannot imagine that she would completely reject you.
tr: "Even if Lady Catherine is certain to think so," said Mr. Collins seriously, "I don't think she will object to you.
es: ––If it were true that Lady Catherine thought so... ––said Collins with the utmost seriousness–– but I am sure Her Ladyship would approve.

en: And you may be certain that when I have the honour of seeing her again I shall speak in the highest terms of your modesty, economy, and other amiable qualifications.”
vi: And please believe that when I have the honor of meeting her again, I will tell her in the most beautiful words about your humility, household economy skills, along with your other charming virtues.
tr: You can be sure that when I have the honor of seeing her again, I will speak highly of your humility, modesty, and other positive qualities."
es: And believe me ––when I have the honor of seeing her again, I will speak in the most commendatory terms of your modesty, your economy, and your other good qualities.

en: “Indeed, mr Collins, all praise of me will be unnecessary.
vi: - Mr. Collins, in fact, all your praises of me will be unnecessary.
tr: "Believe me, Mr. Collins, it will not be necessary for you to praise me.
es: ––Please, Mr. Collins, all the compliments you give me are unnecessary.

en: You must give me leave to judge for myself, and pay me the compliment of believing what I say.
vi: You should let me judge myself, and respect me by believing what I say.
tr: Allow me to evaluate myself; and please be kind enough to believe what I say.
es: Let me judge for myself and grant me the honor of believing what I say.

en: I wish you very happy and very rich, and by refusing your hand, do all in my power to prevent your being otherwise.
vi: I wish you much happiness and wealth; by refusing you, I have done my best to prevent you from falling into the opposite situation.
tr: I wish you happiness and wealth, and by rejecting your proposal, I have done my utmost to prevent you from being otherwise.
es: I wish you to be very happy and very rich, and by rejecting your hand I am doing everything in my power to ensure it is so.

en: In making me the offer, you must have satisfied the delicacy of your feelings with regard to my family, and may take possession of Longbourn estate whenever it falls, without any self-reproach.
vi: When you proposed to me, you must have satisfied your delicate feelings towards my family, so you can take possession of the Longbourn estate whenever possible without any self-reproach.
tr: By proposing to me, you must have satisfied your kind feelings towards my family; you can take the Longbourn estate without any pangs of conscience when it becomes available.
es: In making me this proposal, you must consider the delicacy of your feelings towards my family satisfied, and when the time comes, you can take possession of the Longbourn inheritance without any pangs of conscience.

en: This matter may be considered, therefore, as finally settled.”
vi: Therefore, this matter can be considered concluded here.
tr: Therefore, this matter should be considered closed."
es: Therefore, let us consider this matter definitively settled.

en: And rising as she thus spoke, she would have quitted the room, had not mr Collins thus addressed her,—
vi: As she spoke, she stood up and might have left the room if Mr. Collins had not continued speaking:
tr: As she said this, she stood up and was leaving the room when Mr. Collins spoke again:
es: While he was finishing saying this, he stood up and was about to leave the room, when Collins insisted again:

en: “When I do myself the honour of speaking to you next on the subject, I shall hope to receive a more favourable answer than you have now given me; though I am far from accusing you of cruelty at present, because I know it to be the established custom of your sex to reject a man on the first application, and, perhaps, you have even now said as much to encourage my suit as would be consistent with the true delicacy of the female character.”
vi: - When I have the honor of discussing this matter with you again, I hope to receive a more satisfactory answer than now; although I have no intention of accusing you of being cruel because I know it is customary for ladies to refuse a man the first time, perhaps; true to the delicacy of women, right now you have the intention of encouraging me to plead.
tr: "I hope that when I have the honor of discussing the matter with you next time, you will give me a more positive answer than you have now; I will not accuse you of cruelty at this moment, because I know it is customary for women to reject men at the first proposal; perhaps even now you have said enough to encourage me within the true delicacy of the female character.""
es: ––The next time I have the honor of speaking to you about this topic again, I hope to receive a more favorable response than the one you have given me now; although I am far from believing that you are cruel to me, for I already know that it is an incorrigible custom of women to reject men the first time they declare themselves, and you may have said all that just to make my request more consistent as befits the true delicacy of the female character.

en: “Really, mr Collins,” cried Elizabeth, with some warmth, “you puzzle me exceedingly.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed, with little gentleness: - Mr. Collins, you have indeed put me in a most awkward position.
tr: "Well, Mr. Collins," cried Elizabeth, beginning to get angry, "you astonish me greatly.
es: ––Really, Mr. Collins ––exclaimed Elizabeth somewhat heatedly–– you confuse me exceedingly.

en: If what I have hitherto said can appear to you in the form of encouragement, I know not how to express my refusal in such a way as may convince you of its being one.”
vi: If anything I have said so far has implied that I encouraged you, then I do not know how to refuse in a way that you would believe to be sincere.
tr: If what I have said so far seems like a promise to you, I don't know how else to say no to convince you."
es: If you interpret everything I have said so far as encouragement, I do not know how to express my repulsion to convince you completely.

en: “You must give me leave to flatter myself, my dear cousin, that your refusal of my addresses are merely words of course.
vi: - My dear, you must allow me to feel gratified that your refusal is merely a matter of course.
tr: "Allow me to give myself some credit, dear cousin; your refusal of my offer is merely in words.
es: ––You must let me presume, my dear cousin, that your rejection has been merely verbal.

en: My reasons for believing it are briefly these:—It does not appear to me that my hand is unworthy your acceptance, or that the establishment I can offer would be any other than highly desirable.
vi: The reasons for my belief are quite simple. There seems to be no indication that I am unworthy of your acceptance, or that my status is insufficient.
tr: Here are my reasons for believing so: –It does not seem to me that I am unworthy of you, and the life I offer is quite attractive.
es: The reasons I have for believing this are as follows: I do not believe that my hand is unworthy of being accepted by you, nor that the position I offer is anything less than highly desirable.

en: My situation in life, my connections with the family of De Bourgh, and my relationship to your own, are circumstances highly in my favour; and you should take it into further consideration that, in spite of your manifold attractions, it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made you.
vi: My circumstances, my connections with the De Bourgh family, and my relationship with your family are all highly advantageous for me; and you should also consider that although you have many charms, it is not certain that you will receive another proposal.
tr: My position in life, my connections with the De Bourgh family, our kinship, all these are in my favor; if you think more thoroughly, despite your many charms, it appears you have not received any other marriage proposals so far.
es: My situation in life, my connection with the Bourgh family, and my kinship with you are important circumstances in my favor. Consider, moreover, that despite your many attractions, it is not certain that you will receive another marriage proposal.

en: Your portion is unhappily so small, that it will in all likelihood undo the effects of your loveliness and amiable qualifications.
vi: Unfortunately, your dowry is too small for your beauty and other amiable qualities to have much effect.
tr: Unfortunately, your income is so small that it surely diminishes the effect of your beauty and charming qualities.
es: Your fortune is so meager that it will unfortunately nullify the effects of your beauty and good qualities.

en: As I must, therefore, conclude that you are not serious in your rejection of me, I shall choose to attribute it to your wish of increasing my love by suspense, according to the usual practice of elegant females.”
vi: Since I must conclude that you are not serious in rejecting me, I can only believe that you wish for my love to grow deeper in suspense, as is often the way with elegant women.
tr: Therefore, I conclude that you are not serious in rejecting me; as a reason for your refusal, I see that, as is customary for polite ladies, you wish to increase my love by making me wait."
es: Therefore, as I cannot deduce from all this that you have sincerely rejected me, I will choose to attribute it to your desire to increase my love with suspense, in accordance with the customary practice among elegant women.

en: “I do assure you, sir, that I have no pretensions whatever to that kind of elegance which consists in tormenting a respectable man.
vi: - Sir, I beg you to believe that I had no intention of acting in such a refined manner when it truly only torments the spirit of a respectable man.
tr: "Believe me, sir, I have no such courtesies as to torture a respectable man.
es: ––I assure you, sir, that I do not find it at all elegant to torment a respectable man.

en: I would rather be paid the compliment of being believed sincere.
vi: Instead, I wish to be praised as a sincere person.
tr: I would be more pleased if my sincerity is believed.
es: I would prefer that you do me the courtesy of believing me.

en: I thank you again and again for the honour you have done me in your proposals, but to accept them is absolutely impossible.
vi: I thank you and thank you again for the honor of your proposal, but I absolutely cannot accept it.
tr: Thank you again and again for the honor you have given me with your offer, but it is impossible for me to accept your offer.
es: I thank you a thousand times for the honor you have done me with your proposal, but it is absolutely impossible for me to accept it.

en: My feelings in every respect forbid it.
vi: My feelings in every aspect forbid this.
tr: My feelings forbid it in every respect.
es: My feelings, in every respect, prevent me from doing so.

en: Can I speak plainer?
vi: Could I possibly be clearer than that?
tr: Could I be more clear?
es: Could I be any clearer?

en: Do not consider me now as an elegant female intending to plague you, but as a rational creature speaking the truth from her heart.”
vi: Now, please do not see me as a refined woman intending to distress you, but merely as a rational being who has spoken the truth from her heart.
tr: Now, think of me not as a polite woman trying to stall you, but as a sensible person speaking the truth from her heart."
es: Do not consider me as an elegant woman who intends to torture you, but as a rational being who speaks from the heart.

en: “You are uniformly charming!” cried he, with an air of awkward gallantry; “and I am persuaded that, when sanctioned by the express authority of both your excellent parents, my proposals will not fail of being acceptable.”
vi: He exclaimed, with a clumsy attempt at flattery: - You are truly charming! I am convinced that when your dear parents agree, my proposal will be accepted.
tr: "You are extremely charming!" exclaimed Mr. Collins, with an air of awkward flirtation; "I believe that my proposal will be accepted once it is clearly approved by both of your parents.""
es: ––She is always charming! ––he exclaimed with coarse gallantry––. I cannot doubt that my proposal will be accepted when it is sanctioned by the authority of her excellent parents.

en: To such perseverance in wilful self-deception Elizabeth would make no reply, and immediately and in silence withdrew; determined, that if he persisted in considering her repeated refusals as flattering encouragement, to apply to her father, whose negative might be uttered in such a manner as must be decisive, and whose behaviour at least could not be mistaken for the affectation and coquetry of an elegant female.
vi: Elizabeth did not respond to such deliberate self-deception and immediately walked away. She had firmly resolved that if the gentleman persisted in interpreting her refusals as encouragements and then felt compelled to appeal to her father, her father's rejection would be unequivocal, and his demeanor would at least not be misinterpreted as the emotional and affected manner of a refined lady.
tr: Faced with such a stubbornness of self-deception, Elizabeth could not find an answer to give and immediately and quietly withdrew; if he insisted on interpreting her no as a promise of hope, she decided to appeal to her father; her father would say no in such a way that it would be understood as final; her father's behavior could not be mistaken for the coquetry or coyness of a polite woman.
es: Given such an effort to deceive himself, Elizabeth did not reply and left immediately without saying a word, determined that, if Collins persisted in considering her repeated refusals as a frivolous system of encouragement, she would turn to her father, whose rejection would be formulated in such a way that it would be unappealable and whose attitude, at least, could not be mistaken for the affectation and coquetry of an elegant lady.

en: CHAPTER XX.
vi: Chapter 20
tr: Chapter XX
es: CHAPTER XX

en: mr COLLINS was not left long to the silent contemplation of his successful love; for ms Bennet, having dawdled about in the vestibule to watch for the end of the conference, no sooner saw Elizabeth open the door and with quick step pass her towards the staircase, than she entered the breakfast-room, and congratulated both him and herself in warm terms on the happy prospect of their nearer connection.
vi: Mr. Collins was not allowed to remain quiet for long to contemplatively appreciate his successful courtship. Mrs. Bennet had been lingering in the hallway to see the conclusion of the conversation, and as soon as she saw Elizabeth open the door and walk out, quickly passing her towards the stairs, she entered the breakfast room and congratulated him and herself with gentle words on the prospect of a closer relationship between them.
tr: Mr. Collins could not remain alone with his dreams of successful love for long; Mrs. Bennet, who had been lingering in the hall waiting for the conversation to end, entered the breakfast room when she saw Elizabeth open the door and pass by her quickly to go up the stairs, and warmly congratulated both Mr. Collins and herself on the possibility of becoming closer relatives.
es: Collins was not left much time to silently ponder the success of his love; because Mrs. Bennet, who had stayed in the hallway waiting for the conversation to end, as soon as she saw Elizabeth open the door and head quickly towards the stairs, entered the dining room and congratulated Collins, rejoicing over the fortunate prospect of the imminent union.

en: mr Collins received and returned these felicitations with equal pleasure, and then proceeded to relate the particulars of their interview, with the result of which he trusted he had every reason to be satisfied, since the refusal which his cousin had steadfastly given him would naturally flow from her bashful modesty and the genuine delicacy of her character.
vi: Mr. Collins received and reciprocated the congratulations with equal joy, then recounted to her the spirit of his exchange with Elizabeth, with the result that he believed he had every reason to be satisfied, as her refusal was merely a natural reaction of the true modesty, shyness, and delicacy in her character.
tr: Mr. Collins accepted these congratulations and responded with equal pleasure; then he proceeded to recount the details of the meeting; he believed he had every reason to be satisfied with the outcome of the conversation, as his cousin's persistent refusal stemmed from her shy modesty and genuine elegance of character.
es: After accepting and returning those congratulations with the same enthusiasm, Collins proceeded to explain the details of the interview, with which he was satisfied, as his cousin's firm refusal could naturally only stem from her shy modesty and the delicacy of her character.

en: This information, however, startled ms Bennet: she would have been glad to be equally satisfied that her daughter had meant to encourage him by protesting against his proposals, but she dared not believe it, and could not help saying so.
vi: However, his words surprised Mrs. Bennet. She should have felt as happy as he did, believing that her daughter's refusal was meant to encourage him further, but she did not dare to believe this and had to speak out.
tr: This information still surprised Mrs. Bennet; –she would have been equally pleased if her daughter had opposed the proposal with the intention of encouraging him, but she did not dare to believe it, and could not help but say that she did not dare.
es: But her news startled Mrs. Bennet. She too would have liked to believe that her daughter had only tried to encourage Collins by rejecting his proposals; but she did not dare to admit it, and thus she conveyed it to Collins.

en: “But depend upon it, mr Collins,” she added, “that Lizzy shall be brought to reason.
vi: - Mr. Collins, but according to this matter, Lizzy needs to be explained.
tr: "But rest assured, Mr. Collins," she added, "Lizzy will come to her senses.
es: ––The important thing ––he added–– is that Lizzy comes to her senses.

en: I will speak to her about it myself directly.
vi: I will speak to her directly.
tr: I will speak to her personally.
es: I will personally talk to her about this matter.

en: She is a very headstrong, foolish girl, and does not know her own interest; but I will make her know it.”
vi: She is a very stubborn and foolish girl who does not see the benefits for her; but I will make her see.
tr: She is a very stubborn, foolish girl who doesn't know her own interest, but I will make sure she understands."
es: She is a very stubborn and crazy girl and doesn't know what's good for her, but I'll make sure she understands.

en: “Pardon me for interrupting you, madam,” cried mr Collins; “but if she is really headstrong and foolish, I know not whether she would altogether be a very desirable wife to a man in my situation, who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state.
vi: - I apologize for interrupting you, but if she truly is stubborn and foolish, I am not sure if she would be an ideal wife for someone in my situation, who seeks happiness in marriage.
tr: "Forgive me for interrupting, madam," cried Mr. Collins; "but if she is truly stubborn and foolish, I am not sure if she would be a reasonable wife for a man like me who naturally seeks happiness in marriage.
es: ––Excuse me for interrupting ––exclaimed Collins––, but if she is indeed stubborn and crazy, I don't know if, all things considered, she is a desirable wife for a man in my situation, who naturally seeks happiness in marriage.

en: If, therefore, she actually persists in rejecting my suit, perhaps it were better not to force her into accepting me, because, if liable to such defects of temper, she could not contribute much to my felicity.”
vi: Therefore, if she genuinely rejects me, it might be better not to force her to accept me, because if she is against it, she cannot bring complete happiness to me.
tr: If she persists in rejecting my proposal, it would be better not to force her to accept me, because if she has such flaws, she would not contribute much to my happiness."
es: Therefore, if she insists on rejecting my proposal, it might be better not to force her to accept me, because if she has those flaws, she wouldn't contribute much to my happiness.

en: “Sir, you quite misunderstand me,” said ms Bennet, alarmed.
vi: Mrs. Bennet said, worried: - Brother, you have misunderstood me.
tr: "Sir, you misunderstood," said Mrs. Bennet, becoming frightened.
es: ––You have misunderstood me ––said Mrs. Bennet alarmed––.

en: “Lizzy is only headstrong in such matters as these.
vi: Lizzy is only stubborn in matters like this.
tr: "Lizzy is only stubborn about matters like this.
es: Lizzy is stubborn only in these matters.

en: In everything else she is as good-natured a girl as ever lived.
vi: In everything else, she is the most obedient.
tr: In every other matter, she is the most good-natured girl in the world.
es: In everything else, she is the most reasonable girl in the world.

en: I will go directly to mr Bennet, and we shall very soon settle it with her, I am sure.”
vi: I will speak directly with her father, we will sort it out with her soon, I am sure of it.
tr: I will go straight to Mr. Bennet and take Elizabeth to settle the matter, I am sure."
es: I will go directly to Mr. Bennet, and I have no doubt that we will soon come to an agreement with her.

en: She would not give him time to reply, but hurrying instantly to her husband, called out, as she entered the library,—
vi: She did not give him time to answer, hurriedly went to find her husband, and exclaimed as she entered the study:
tr: Without giving the man time to respond, she immediately hurried to her husband, calling out as she entered the library, "Oh, Mr. Bennet, you are urgently needed; we are in great distress.
es: Without giving him time to answer, she flew to meet her husband and upon entering the library exclaimed: "Oh, Mr. Bennet!"

en: “Oh, mr Bennet, you are wanted immediately; we are all in an uproar.
vi: - Dear, I need you right now, we are in turmoil.
tr: Without giving the man time to respond, she immediately hurried to her husband, calling out as she entered the library, "Oh, Mr. Bennet, you are urgently needed; we are in great distress.
es: We need you urgently. We are in a predicament.

en: You must come and make Lizzy marry mr Collins, for she vows she will not have him; and if you do not make haste he will change his mind and not have her.”
vi: You must come and advise Lizzy to marry Mr. Collins, because she is determined not to marry him, and if you don't hurry, he will change his mind and won't want to marry her.
tr: You must come and make Lizzy marry Mr. Collins; she is insisting she won't, and if you don't hurry, the man will change his mind about taking her."
es: You must go and convince Elizabeth to marry Collins, for she has sworn she will not and if you don't hurry, Collins will change his mind and won't want her anymore.

en: mr Bennet raised his eyes from his book as she entered, and fixed them on her face with a calm unconcern, which was not in the least altered by her communication.
vi: Mr. Bennet looked up from his book when she entered, gazing at her calmly without any sign of concern and without changing his demeanor as she spoke.
tr: As she entered, Mr. Bennet lifted his eyes from his book and fixed them on his wife's face with a calm indifference that was unaffected by what he heard.
es: When his wife entered, Mr. Bennet lifted his eyes from the book and fixed them on her face with a calm indifference that the news did not alter in the slightest.

en: “I have not the pleasure of understanding you,” said he, when she had finished her speech.
vi: When she finished speaking, he said: - I don't understand what you mean.
tr: "I haven't had the pleasure of understanding you," he said when his wife finished speaking.
es: ––I have not had the pleasure of understanding you ––he said when she finished her tirade––.

en: “Of what are you talking?”
vi: What are you talking about?
tr: "What are you talking about?"
es: What are you talking about?

en: “Of mr Collins and Lizzy.
vi: - The matter of Mr. Collins and Elizabeth.
tr: "From Mr. Collins and Lizzy.
es: ––About Mr. Collins and Lizzy.

en: Lizzy declares she will not have mr Collins, and mr Collins begins to say that he will not have Lizzy.”
vi: Lizzy declared that she would not accept Mr. Collins, and Mr. Collins began to say that he would not want to marry Lizzy.
tr: Lizzy says she doesn't want Mr. Collins, and Mr. Collins is about to say he doesn't want Lizzy."
es: Lizzy says she will not marry Mr. Collins, and Mr. Collins is beginning to say he will not marry Lizzy.

en: “And what am I to do on the occasion?
vi: - What should I do in this situation?
tr: "So what should I do?
es: ––And what am I going to do?

en: It seems a hopeless business.”
vi: It seems like a hopeless matter.
tr: –The situation looks hopeless."
es: It seems to me that there's no solution.

en: “Speak to Lizzy about it yourself.
vi: - You must personally talk to Lizzy.
tr: "You talk to Lizzy.
es: ––Talk to Lizzy.

en: Tell her that you insist upon her marrying him.”
vi: Tell her that you want her to marry Mr. Collins.
tr: Tell her that you insisted on marrying the man."
es: Tell her you want her to marry him.

en: “Let her be called down.
vi: - Call the little one down here.
tr: "Let them come.
es: ––Tell him to come down.

en: She shall hear my opinion.”
vi: It will follow my opinion.
tr: Let them learn my opinion."
es: He will hear my opinion.

en: ms Bennet rang the bell, and Miss Elizabeth was summoned to the library.
vi: Mrs. Bennet rang the bell, and Miss Elizabeth was summoned to the study.
tr: Mrs. Bennet rang the bell; Miss Elizabeth was called to the library.
es: Mrs. Bennet rang the bell and Elizabeth was called to the library.

en: “Come here, child,” cried her father as she appeared.
vi: He called out as she appeared: Come here, my child.
tr: "Come here, my child," said her father when Elizabeth appeared at the door.
es: ––Come, my daughter ––said her father as soon as the young woman entered––.

en: “I have sent for you on an affair of importance.
vi: Your father is calling you because there is something important.
tr: "I called you for an important matter.
es: I have sent for you regarding an important matter.

en: I understand that mr Collins has made you an offer of marriage.
vi: Your father heard that Mr. Collins has proposed to you.
tr: I heard that Mr. Collins has proposed to you.
es: They say that Collins has made you a marriage proposal, is it true?

en: Is it true?”
vi: Is that true?
tr: Is it true?"
es: They say that Collins has made you a marriage proposal, is it true?

en: Elizabeth replied that it was.
vi: Elizabeth answered that it was true:
tr: Elizabeth said it was true.
es: Elizabeth said yes.

en: “Very well—and this offer of marriage you have refused?”
vi: - Very well, and you turned down the proposal, didn't you?
tr: "Alright – did you also reject the marriage proposal?"
es: ––Very well; and they say that you have rejected them.

en: “I have, sir.”
vi: - Yes, father.
tr: "Yes, sir.""
es: ––That's right, Dad.

en: “Very well.
vi: - Very well.
tr: "Alright.
es: ––Well.

en: We now come to the point.
vi: Now let's get to the point.
tr: Now we get to the point.
es: Now let's get to the point.

en: Your mother insists upon your accepting it.
vi: Your mother wants you to agree.
tr: Your mother insists that you accept.
es: Your mother wishes you to accept it.

en: Is it not so, ms Bennet?”
vi: Isn't that right, dear?
tr: Isn't that right, Mrs. Bennet?"
es: Isn't that right, Mrs. Bennet?

en: “Yes, or I will never see her again.”
vi: - That's right, otherwise I would never see its face again.
tr: "Yes, otherwise I won't look at your face again.""
es: Yes, or otherwise I don't want to see her anymore.

en: “An unhappy alternative is before you, Elizabeth.
vi: - So, there is an unfortunate choice before you. Elizabeth.
tr: "You have an unhappy choice before you, Elizabeth.
es: ––You have a sad alternative before you, Elizabeth.

en: From this day you must be a stranger to one of your parents.
vi: From this day forward, you will become a stranger to either your father or your mother.
tr: From this day onward, you must be a stranger to one of your parents.
es: From this day forward, you will have to renounce one of your parents.

en: Your mother will never see you again if you do not marry mr Collins, and I will never see you again if you do.”
vi: Your mother will never see you again if you do not marry Mr. Collins, and your father will never see you again if you do.
tr: Your mother says she will never see you again if you do not marry Mr. Collins, and I will never see you again if you do."
es: Your mother does not want to see you again if you do not marry Collins, and I do not want to see you again if you marry him.

en: Elizabeth could not but smile at such a conclusion of such a beginning; but ms Bennet, who had persuaded herself that her husband regarded the affair as she wished, was excessively disappointed.
vi: Elizabeth could not suppress a smile upon hearing such a conclusion right at the beginning. But Mrs. Bennet was deeply disappointed because she had believed that her husband would agree with her.
tr: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile at such a beginning leading to such an end; but Mrs. Bennet, who believed that her husband would handle the matter as she wished, was very surprised.
es: Elizabeth could not help but smile at such a beginning; but Mrs. Bennet, who was convinced that her husband would advocate for that marriage, was disappointed.

en: “What do you mean, mr Bennet, by talking in this way?
vi: - What do you mean by saying that?
tr: "What do you mean by talking this way, Mr. Bennet?
es: ––What does that way of speaking mean, Mr. Bennet?

en: You promised me to insist upon her marrying him.”
vi: You promised me you would force the girl to marry him.
tr: You promised me that you would insist on her marrying him."
es: You had promised me that you would force her to marry Mr. Collins.

en: “My dear,” replied her husband, “I have two small favours to request.
vi: - Ma'am, I request two small favors from you.
tr: "My dear," replied her husband, "I am asking for two favors.
es: ––My dear ––replied her husband––, I have to ask you for two small favors: first, that you let me use my understanding freely in this matter, and second, that you let me enjoy my library alone as soon as you can.

en: First, that you will allow me the free use of my understanding on the present occasion; and, secondly, of my room.
vi: First: allow me the freedom to use my understanding of the matter, and second: to use the reading room.
tr: First, allow me to use my mind freely on this matter, and then my room.
es: ––My dear ––replied her husband––, I have to ask you for two small favors: first, that you let me use my understanding freely in this matter, and second, that you let me enjoy my library alone as soon as you can.

en: I shall be glad to have the library to myself as soon as may be.”
vi: I would be very happy to continue reading as soon as possible.
tr: The sooner my library is left to me, the happier I will be."
es: ––My dear ––replied her husband––, I have to ask you for two small favors: first, that you let me use my understanding freely in this matter, and second, that you let me enjoy my library alone as soon as you can.

en: Not yet, however, in spite of her disappointment in her husband, did ms Bennet give up the point.
vi: However, despite being disappointed in her husband, she still did not give up her intention.
tr: Even though she was disappointed in her husband, Mrs. Bennet did not give up easily.
es: However, Mrs. Bennet, despite the disappointment she had with her husband, still did not give up.

en: She talked to Elizabeth again and again; coaxed and threatened her by turns.
vi: She spoke with Elizabeth again, alternately advising and threatening her.
tr: She repeatedly talked to Elizabeth; sometimes she tried to flatter her, sometimes she threatened her.
es: She spoke to Elizabeth again and again, flattering and threatening her alternately.

en: She endeavoured to secure Jane in her interest, but Jane, with all possible mildness, declined interfering; and Elizabeth, sometimes with real earnestness, and sometimes with playful gaiety, replied to her attacks.
vi: She wanted Jane to side with her, but Jane refused with all possible gentleness, and Elizabeth responded to her attacks sometimes with genuine seriousness, sometimes with playful banter.
tr: She also tried to get Jane on her side; but Jane, with all her mildness, avoided getting involved; Elizabeth responded to her mother's attacks sometimes with genuine excitement, sometimes with cheerful jesting.
es: She tried to get Jane on her side; but Jane, with all possible gentleness, preferred not to get involved.

en: Though her manner varied, however, her determination never did.
vi: Although her attitude varied, she always remained resolute.
tr: Though her style changed from time to time, her determination did not.
es: Elizabeth, sometimes with true seriousness, and other times jokingly, responded to her attacks; and although her mood changed, her determination remained unshakable.
