en: mr Collins, meanwhile, was meditating in solitude on what had passed.
vi: Meanwhile, Mr. Collins was alone, pondering over what had happened.
tr: Meanwhile, Mr. Collins had fallen into solitary contemplation over what had transpired.
es: Collins, meanwhile, silently pondered everything that had happened.

en: He thought too well of himself to comprehend on what motive his cousin could refuse him; and though his pride was hurt, he suffered in no other way.
vi: He thought too highly of himself to understand what could have motivated his cousin to reject him. Although his pride was wounded, he did not feel any other kind of distress.
tr: He thought too highly of himself to understand why his cousin might reject him; although his pride was wounded, he felt no other pain.
es: He had too high a regard for himself to understand what reasons his cousin might have for rejecting him, and although his pride was wounded, he did not suffer in the least.

en: His regard for her was quite imaginary; and the possibility of her deserving her mother’s reproach prevented his feeling any regret.
vi: His feelings for her were merely the result of much imagination, and her situation of being scolded by her mother prevented any sense of regret in him.
tr: He had a very fanciful interest in Elizabeth; the possibility of deserving his mother's scoldings prevented him from feeling any regret.
es: His interest in his cousin was merely imaginary; the possibility that she might be deserving of her mother's reproaches prevented him from feeling any regret.

en: While the family were in this confusion, Charlotte Lucas came to spend the day with them.
vi: While the family was still bustling, Charlotte Lucas came to visit them.
tr: While the family was in this turmoil, Charlotte Lucas came to spend the day with them.
es: While this confusion reigned in the family, Charlotte Lucas arrived, who was coming to spend the day with them.

en: She was met in the vestibule by Lydia, who, flying to her, cried in a half whisper, “I am glad you are come, for there is such fun here!
vi: In the hall, she met Lydia, who approached her and whispered: - I'm glad to see you, because there's something amusing happening here.
tr: She was met in the hall by Lydia; Lydia threw herself at her and exclaimed in a half-whisper, "I'm glad you came, because there's some strange fun here!
es: She met Lydia in the hall, who ran to her to quietly tell her what was happening. ––I'm glad you came, because there's a commotion here...!

en: What do you think has happened this morning?
vi: Do you know what happened this morning?
tr: –Guess what happened this morning?
es: What do you think happened this morning?

en: mr Collins has made an offer to Lizzy, and she will not have him.”
vi: Mr. Collins proposed to Elizabeth, and she did not accept.
tr: –Mr. Collins proposed to Lizzy, and Lizzy said she didn't want to."
es: Mr. Collins proposed to Elizabeth and she turned him down.

en: “they entered the breakfast room”
vi: While Charlotte did not have time to respond, Kitty went to inform her of the news.
tr: Before Charlotte could respond, Kitty also came over to share the same news; as soon as they entered the breakfast room where Mrs. Bennet was sitting alone, Mrs. Bennet brought up the subject and asked Miss Lucas to take pity on their situation and persuade her friend Lizzy to comply with the wishes of the entire family.
es: Before Charlotte had time to answer, Kitty appeared, coming to give her the same news.

en: Charlotte had hardly time to answer before they were joined by Kitty, who came to tell the same news; and no sooner had they entered the breakfast-room, where ms Bennet was alone, than she likewise began on the subject, calling on Miss Lucas for her compassion, and entreating her to persuade her friend Lizzy to comply with the wishes of her family.
vi: As soon as they entered the breakfast room, where Mrs. Bennet was sitting alone, she also began with the same matter, hoping Miss Lucas would sympathize with her, earnestly asking her to persuade her friend Lizzy to comply with the family's wishes.
tr: Before Charlotte could respond, Kitty also came over to share the same news; as soon as they entered the breakfast room where Mrs. Bennet was sitting alone, Mrs. Bennet brought up the subject and asked Miss Lucas to take pity on their situation and persuade her friend Lizzy to comply with the wishes of the entire family.
es: And as soon as they entered the dining room, where Mrs. Bennet was alone, she also began to talk to her about the matter. She begged her to have compassion and to try to convince Lizzy to yield to the wishes of the whole family.

en: “Pray do, my dear Miss Lucas,” she added, in a melancholy tone; “for nobody is on my side, nobody takes part with me; I am cruelly used, nobody feels for my poor nerves.”
vi: She added, with a sorrowful voice: - Miss Lucas, please help me because no one agrees with me, no one is on my side, I am being treated cruelly, no one sympathizes with my nerves.
tr: "Please speak, my dear Miss Lucas," she added in a sorrowful tone, "no one is on my side, no one supports me, they are being cruel to me, no one considers my nerves."
es: ––I beg you to intercede, dear Charlotte ––he added in a melancholic tone––, since no one is on my side, they treat me cruelly, no one sympathizes with my poor nerves.

en: Charlotte’s reply was spared by the entrance of Jane and Elizabeth.
vi: While Charlotte had not yet had time to respond, Jane and Elizabeth both walked in.
tr: Charlotte's response was interrupted by Jane and Elizabeth's entrance.
es: Charlotte saved herself the response, for at that moment Jane and Elizabeth entered.

en: “Ay, there she comes,” continued ms Bennet, “looking as unconcerned as may be, and caring no more for us than if we were at York, provided she can have her own way.
vi: Mrs. Bennet continued: - Ah, the young lady has arrived, it seems she doesn't care and no longer pays attention to us, as long as she can live her own way.
tr: "Oh, here he comes," continued Mrs. Bennet, "look, he doesn't care at all; as if we were in York and he couldn't see us, doing whatever he pleases.
es: ––There he is ––continued Mrs. Bennet––, as if nothing happened, he doesn't care about us at all, he disengages from everything just to get his way.

en: But I tell you what, Miss Lizzy, if you take it into your head to go on refusing every offer of marriage in this way, you will never get a husband at all—and I am sure I do not know who is to maintain you when your father is dead.
vi: But Miss Lizzy, let me tell you, if you keep stubbornly rejecting every proposal like this, you will never find a husband – and I don't know who will take care of you when your father passes away.
tr: –But let me tell you, Miss Lizzy –if you keep rejecting every suitor like this, you'll never find a husband –who do you think will take care of you when your father dies?
es: I'll tell you one thing: if you get it into your head to keep rejecting all the marriage proposals you receive, you'll end up an old maid; and I don't know who will support you when your father dies.

en: I shall not be able to keep you—and so I warn you.
vi: I will not be able to take care of you – and I warn you about that.
tr: –I certainly won't be able to take care of you –so I'm warning you.
es: I won't be able to, I warn you.

en: I have done with you from this very day.
vi: From today onwards, I will have nothing to do with you anymore.
tr: –From this day forward, I have nothing more to do with you.
es: From today, I'm done with you forever.

en: I told you in the library, you know, that I should never speak to you again, and you will find me as good as my word.
vi: I told you in the reading room, you know, that I will never speak to you again, and you will see that I will do exactly as I said.
tr: –Didn't I tell you in the library that I wouldn't speak to you again, see how I'm keeping my word.
es: I told you in the library that I would never speak to you again; and what I say, I mean.

en: I have no pleasure in talking to undutiful children.
vi: I do not like talking to disobedient children.
tr: I don't speak to ungrateful children.
es: I don't find any pleasure in talking to disobedient daughters.

en: Not that I have much pleasure, indeed, in talking to anybody.
vi: In fact, I do not like talking to anyone.
tr: –If it were up to me, I wouldn't speak to anyone.
es: Nor with anyone.

en: People who suffer as I do from nervous complaints can have no great inclination for talking.
vi: People who are nervous wrecks like me do not like talking at all.
tr: People with nervous complaints like mine are not inclined to talk.
es: People like me who suffer from nerves are not fond of chatting.

en: Nobody can tell what I suffer!
vi: No one can understand how much I suffer.
tr: Only I know what I have suffered.
es: No one knows what I suffer!

en: But it is always so.
vi: But it is always like that.
tr: Only I know what I have suffered.
es: But it's always the same.

en: Those who do not complain are never pitied.”
vi: Those who do not complain are never understood.
tr: They say those who don't express their troubles have no one to pity them."
es: Those who don't complain, no one pities them.

en: Her daughters listened in silence to this effusion, sensible that any attempt to reason with or soothe her would only increase the irritation.
vi: In silence, the girls listened to their mother pouring out, knowing that any attempt to reason with or soothe her would only make her more upset.
tr: The girls listened to this plea in silence, knowing that trying to talk to her or calm her down would only increase her discomfort.
es: The daughters listened in silence to their mother's laments. They knew that if they tried to reason with her or calm her down, they would only succeed in irritating her more.

en: She talked on, therefore, without interruption from any of them till they were joined by mr Collins, who entered with an air more stately than usual, and on perceiving whom, she said to the girls,—
vi: Therefore, she continued without pause until Mr. Collins entered, looking more solemn than ever. As soon as she saw him, she said:
tr: Mrs. Bennet kept complaining, and no one intervened until Mr. Collins came to join them; seeing Mr. Collins enter with an even more pompous air than usual, Mrs. Bennet told the girls, "Now all of you hold your tongues and let me have a little chat with Mr. Collins alone.""
es: So she continued speaking without anyone interrupting her, until Collins entered with a more solemn air than usual. Upon seeing him, Mrs. Bennet said to the girls:

en: “Now, I do insist upon it, that you, all of you, hold your tongues, and let mr Collins and me have a little conversation together.”
vi: - Now, I want all of you to keep quiet so that Mr. Collins and I can have a little conversation.
tr: Mrs. Bennet kept complaining, and no one intervened until Mr. Collins came to join them; seeing Mr. Collins enter with an even more pompous air than usual, Mrs. Bennet told the girls, "Now all of you hold your tongues and let me have a little chat with Mr. Collins alone.""
es: ––Now I ask you to shut your mouths and leave Mr. Collins and me so we can talk for a while.

en: Elizabeth passed quietly out of the room, Jane and Kitty followed, but Lydia stood her ground, determined to hear all she could; and Charlotte, detained first by the civility of mr Collins, whose inquiries after herself and all her family were very minute, and then by a little curiosity, satisfied herself with walking to the window and pretending not to hear.
vi: Elizabeth silently stepped out of the room, Jane and Kitty following behind, but Lydia remained there, determined to hear everything. Charlotte stayed, firstly because Mr. Collins had politely inquired in detail about her and her family, and secondly out of a bit of curiosity, so she moved to the window and pretended not to be listening attentively.
tr: Elizabeth quietly left the room, followed by Jane and Kitty, but Lydia remained in place, determined to hear everything she could; Charlotte stayed there first because of Mr. Collins' interest, who inquired thoroughly about her and her family's well-being, and then out of a little curiosity, she walked to the window and pretended not to hear while satisfying her curiosity.
es: Elizabeth left the room in silence; Jane and Kitty followed her, but Lydia did not move, determined to listen to everything she could. Charlotte, held back by Mr. Collins's courtesy, whose questions about her and her family followed one after another without interruption, and also a bit by curiosity, merely approached the window pretending not to listen.

en: In a doleful voice ms Bennet thus began the projected conversation:—
vi: With a sorrowful voice, she began:
tr: In a distressed voice, Mrs. Bennet began the anticipated conversation: –"Oh, Mr. Collins dear!"
es: In a sad voice, Mrs. Bennet thus began her conversation:

en: “Oh, mr Collins!”
vi: - Oh, Mr. Collins!
tr: "Dear madam," replied Mr. Collins, "let us forever maintain our silence on this matter.
es: ––Oh, Mr. Collins!

en: “My dear madam,” replied he, “let us be for ever silent on this point.
vi: He replied: - Madam, let us remain silent about this matter forever.
tr: "Dear madam," replied Mr. Collins, "let us forever maintain our silence on this matter.
es: ––My dear madam ––he replied––, not another word on this matter.

en: Far be it from me,” he presently continued, in a voice that marked his displeasure, “to resent the behaviour of your daughter.
vi: But he continued, with a dissatisfied tone: - I am not at all disappointed by your daughter's attitude.
tr: It is not my place," he continued immediately after, in a voice that emphasized his displeasure, "to condemn your daughter's behavior.
es: I am very far ––he continued with an accent that denoted his indignation–– from harboring any resentment towards your daughter's attitude.

en: Resignation to inevitable evils is the duty of us all: the peculiar duty of a young man who has been so fortunate as I have been, in early preferment; and, I trust, I am resigned.
vi: We have a duty to endure the unavoidable misfortunes; it is an unusual duty for a young man as fortunate as I am to have achieved success early, and I believe I can endure it.
tr: It is our duty to face unexpected disasters with resignation; it is especially the duty of a young man like myself, who has had the fortune to rise at a young age; and I have indeed resigned myself.
es: It is everyone's duty to resign themselves to inevitable misfortunes; and it is especially a duty for me, who has had the fortune of seeing myself so young in such an elevated position; I trust I will know how to resign myself.

en: Perhaps not the less so from feeling a doubt of my positive happiness had my fair cousin honoured me with her hand; for I have often observed, that resignation is never so perfect as when the blessing denied begins to lose somewhat of its value in our estimation.
vi: Perhaps no less is the doubt about my happiness if your beautiful daughter agreed to marry me; because I often find that we cannot fully endure when a chance, after being rejected, starts to lose a bit of its value in the way we perceive it.
tr: It is not because I doubted the happiness I would feel if my beautiful cousin had granted me the honor of taking my hand; I have often observed that resignation takes on a marvelous quality when the beauty we are deprived of begins to lose its value in our eyes.
es: It may be that my beautiful cousin, by not wanting to honor me with her hand, has not diminished my positive happiness. I have often observed that resignation is never as perfect as when the denied happiness begins to lose some value in our estimation.

en: You will not, I hope, consider me as showing any disrespect to your family, my dear madam, by thus withdrawing my pretensions to your daughter’s favour, without having paid yourself and mr Bennet the compliment of requesting you to interpose your authority in my behalf.
vi: Madam, I hope you will not see me as having a disrespectful attitude towards your family when I withdraw my intentions towards your daughter, when I do not ask you and your husband to use your authority to intervene for me.
tr: I hope you do not think I have disrespected your family by withdrawing my claims regarding your daughter without showing the courtesy of asking you and Mr. Bennet to use your influence in my favor.
es: I hope you do not suppose that I am disrespecting your family, my dear madam, by withdrawing my plans regarding your daughter without asking you and Mr. Bennet to interpose your authority on my behalf.

en: My conduct may, I fear, be objectionable in having accepted my dismission from your daughter’s lips instead of your own; but we are all liable to error.
vi: I am concerned that my manner might be unpleasant when I accept your daughter's refusal instead of yours. But we all can make mistakes.
tr: I fear it may not be pleasant that I accepted the rejection from your daughter rather than from you. But we can all make mistakes.
es: I fear that my conduct, by accepting my rejection from your daughter's lips and not from yours, may be censurable. But we are all capable of making mistakes.

en: I have certainly meant well through the whole affair.
vi: Surely, I have had good intentions throughout this matter.
tr: Throughout the whole matter, I was certainly very well-intentioned.
es: I am sure I have acted with the best intention in this matter.

en: My object has been to secure an amiable companion for myself, with due consideration for the advantage of all your family; and if my manner has been at all reprehensible, I here beg leave to apologize.”
vi: My aim was to seek a charming life partner for myself with all considerations beneficial to your family, and if my attitude was blameworthy, I now ask you to forgive me.
tr: My aim was to find a compassionate life partner for myself while also ensuring the benefit of your entire family; if I have behaved inappropriately, I apologize to you."
es: My objective was to procure myself a kind companion with due consideration to the advantages this would bring to your entire family. If my conduct has been reproachable, I beg you to forgive me.

en: CHAPTER XXI.
vi: Chapter 21
tr: Chapter XXI
es: CHAPTER XXI

en: THE discussion of mr Collins’s offer was now nearly at an end, and Elizabeth had only to suffer from the uncomfortable feelings necessarily attending it, and occasionally from some peevish allusion of her mother.
vi: The debate over Mr. Collins' proposal had now nearly reached its conclusion, and Elizabeth felt miserable due to her discomfort in participating in the discussion, sometimes exacerbated by her mother's irritable insinuations.
tr: The discussion regarding Mr. Collins' proposal was now considered over; Elizabeth only had to endure the boredom that naturally arose from the argument and her mother's occasional irritable scoldings.
es: The discussions about Collins' offer were coming to an end; Elizabeth no longer had to endure more than that uncomfortable feeling, which inevitably derives from such situations, and, from time to time, some pointed allusions from her mother.

en: As for the gentleman himself, his feelings were chiefly expressed, not by embarrassment or dejection, or by trying to avoid her, but by stiffness of manner and resentful silence.
vi: As for the gentleman, his feelings were expressed not so much through confusion or disappointment, or by avoiding her, but through a rigid and silently frustrated demeanor.
tr: As for the gentleman himself, his feelings were expressed not in shame or sorrow or attempts to avoid Elizabeth, but in cold manners and angry silence.
es: As for the gentleman, he did not show himself to be disturbed, nor dejected, nor did he try to avoid Elizabeth, but expressed his feelings with an attitude of rigidity and a resentful silence.

en: He scarcely ever spoke to her; and the assiduous attentions which he had been so sensible of himself were transferred for the rest of the day to Miss Lucas, whose civility in listening to him was a seasonable relief to them all, and especially to her friend.
vi: He spoke very little to her, and subsequently, his diligent attentions were redirected to Miss Lucas. Her polite attentiveness in listening to him relieved everyone, especially her friend.
tr: He hardly spoke to Elizabeth; the determined praises he was well aware of were directed towards Miss Lucas for the rest of the day; Miss Lucas's kindness in listening to him greatly relieved everyone, especially her friend.
es: He hardly spoke to her; and those assiduous attentions so appreciated on his part, he dedicated all day to Miss Lucas who listened to him kindly, providing everyone and especially her friend Elizabeth with great relief.

en: The morrow produced no abatement of ms Bennet’s ill humour or ill health.
vi: The days did not help alleviate Mrs. Bennet's vexation or her poor health.
tr: The next morning brought no relief to Mrs. Bennet's discomfort or illness.
es: The next morning, Mrs. Bennet's bad mood and poor health had not subsided.

en: mr Collins was also in the same state of angry pride.
vi: Mr. Collins shared the same prideful anger.
tr: Mr. Collins was in the same state of angry arrogance.
es: Mr. Collins also suffered from the wound to his pride.

en: Elizabeth had hoped that his resentment might shorten his visit, but his plan did not appear in the least affected by it.
vi: Elizabeth had hoped that his distress would shorten his visit, but this did not affect his plans at all.
tr: Elizabeth had hoped that his anger might shorten his visit, but his plans seemed unaffected in any way.
es: Elizabeth thought that his resentment would shorten his visit; but Mr. Collins's plans did not seem to be altered in the slightest.

en: He was always to have gone on Saturday, and to Saturday he still meant to stay.
vi: He had always intended to leave on Saturday, so he decided to stay until Saturday.
tr: He had kept saying he would leave on Saturday, and he still intended to stay until Saturday.
es: He had initially planned to leave on Saturday and intended to stay until Saturday.

en: After breakfast, the girls walked to Meryton, to inquire if mr Wickham were returned, and to lament over his absence from the Netherfield ball.
vi: After breakfast, the daughters walked to Meryton to see if Mr. Wickham had returned, and also to lament his absence at the Netherfield ball.
tr: After breakfast, the girls walked to Meryton to ask if Mr. Wickham had returned and to lament his absence at the Netherfield ball.
es: After lunch, the girls went to Meryton to find out if Wickham had returned, and to lament his absence at the Netherfield ball.

en: He joined them on their entering the town, and attended them to their aunt’s, where his regret and vexation and the concern of everybody were well talked over.
vi: He met them as they entered the town and accompanied them to their aunt's house. He spoke very eloquently about his regrets, his troubles, and the concern of everyone.
tr: Mr. Wickham joined them as they entered the town and accompanied them to their aunt's house; at home, Mr. Wickham's sorrow and grief, and everyone's curiosity were discussed in detail.
es: They found him upon entering the town and he accompanied them to their aunt's house, where they talked at length about his absence and misfortune and the consternation it had caused everyone.

en: To Elizabeth, however, he voluntarily acknowledged that the necessity of his absence had been self-imposed.
vi: However, with Elizabeth, he was willing to admit that he had felt it necessary to be absent. He said:
tr: –Only, he explained to Elizabeth, it was his own decision not to attend.
es: But in front of Elizabeth, he willingly admitted that his absence had been premeditated.

en: “I found,” said he, “as the time drew near, that I had better not meet mr Darcy;—that to be in the same room, the same party with him for so many hours together, might be more than I could bear, and that scenes might arise unpleasant to more than myself.”
vi: - When that day approached, I thought that I should not meet Mr. Darcy, that being present in the same room, at the same gathering for many hours with him was something I could not endure, while others might also be affected by the discomfort.
tr: "As the time approached," she said, "I felt it would be better not to encounter Mr. Darcy; –being in the same room, in the same company with him for so many hours could be more than I could bear, scenes that could disturb others more than myself might occur."
es: ––As the moment approached ––he said–– it seemed to me that it would be better not to meet Darcy, for being together in a room for so many hours would have been beyond my strength and the situation could have become unpleasant, moreover, for other people.

en: She highly approved his forbearance; and they had leisure for a full discussion of it, and for all the commendations which they civilly bestowed on each other, as Wickham and another officer walked back with them to Longbourn, and during the walk he particularly attended to her.
vi: Accepting his endurance, and the two had leisurely time to discuss this matter in depth, also to compliment each other politely. When Wickham and another officer accompanied the ladies to Longbourn, he paid special attention to her.
tr: Elizabeth regarded the cautious behavior very positively; on the return journey, as Wickham and another officer accompanied them to Longbourn, they found ample time to discuss the matter in detail and exchange numerous compliments; during the walk, Wickham paid her special attention.
es: Elizabeth fully approved of Wickham's conduct and they discussed it extensively, exchanging mutual praises as they headed towards Longbourn, where Wickham and another officer accompanied the young ladies.

en: His accompanying them was a double advantage: she felt all the compliment it offered to herself; and it was most acceptable as an occasion of introducing him to her father and mother.
vi: His accompanying had two advantages: she felt all the affection he had for her, and it was an opportunity for her to introduce him to her father and mother.
tr: Their accompaniment was doubly delightful; firstly, Elizabeth felt that this act was a compliment directed at her, and secondly, it was a good opportunity to introduce Wickham to her parents.
es: During the walk, Wickham devoted himself entirely to Elizabeth, providing her with a double satisfaction: receiving his compliments and having the opportunity to introduce him to her parents.

en: “Walked back with them”
vi: His accompanying had two advantages: she felt all the affection he had for her, and it was an opportunity for her to introduce him to her father and mother.
tr: Immediately after their return, a letter arrived for Miss Bennet; it was from Netherfield and was opened at once.
es: Shortly after arriving, they brought a letter for Jane.

en: Soon after their return, a letter was delivered to Miss Bennet; it came from Netherfield, and was opened immediately.
vi: Not long after they returned, a letter from Netherfield was brought to Miss Bennet: she opened it immediately.
tr: Immediately after their return, a letter arrived for Miss Bennet; it was from Netherfield and was opened at once.
es: It came from Netherfield, and the young woman opened it immediately.

en: The envelope contained a sheet of elegant, little, hot-pressed paper, well covered with a lady’s fair, flowing hand; and Elizabeth saw her sister’s countenance change as she read it, and saw her dwelling intently on some particular passages.
vi: The letter was written on a small, elegant piece of paper, with soft, feminine handwriting. Elizabeth noticed her sister's expression change as she read, and saw her read several passages over and over.
tr: Inside the envelope was a polite, small, high-quality piece of paper, covered with a lady's careful, flowing handwriting; as Elizabeth read the letter, she sensed her sister's face changing and saw her getting stuck at certain points.
es: The envelope contained a very elegant and glossy sheet of paper, covered with the handwriting of a beautiful and agile woman's hand. Elizabeth noticed that her sister's expression changed as she read and that she lingered over certain paragraphs.

en: Jane recollected herself soon; and putting the letter away, tried to join, with her usual cheerfulness, in the general conversation: but Elizabeth felt an anxiety on the subject which drew off her attention even from Wickham; and no sooner had he and his companion taken leave, than a glance from Jane invited her to follow her upstairs.
vi: Jane quickly returned to normal, put away the letter, and tried to join the conversation with her usual cheerfulness, but Elizabeth felt worried, which made her pay less attention even to Mr. Wickham. As soon as he and his friend took their leave, Jane's glance made her follow her sister up the stairs. When they entered her room, Jane took out the letter and said:
tr: Jane soon composed herself, put the letter away, and tried to join the conversation with her usual cheerfulness; but Elizabeth felt a concern that distracted her even from Wickham; as soon as Wickham and his friend left, Jane, with her eyes, called her to follow upstairs.
es: Jane quickly composed herself; she put down the letter and tried to join in the conversation with her usual cheerfulness; but Elizabeth was so curious that she even stopped paying attention to Wickham. And as soon as he and his companion left, Jane invited her with a look to accompany her upstairs. Once in her room, Jane showed her the letter and said:

en: When they had gained their own room, Jane, taking out her letter, said, “This is from Caroline Bingley: what it contains has surprised me a good deal.
vi: - This is a letter from Caroline Bingley; its contents have greatly surprised me.
tr: When they entered their room, Jane took out the letter and said, "It is from Caroline Bingley; what she wrote surprised me a lot.
es: ––It is from Caroline Bingley; its content has surprised me greatly.

en: The whole party have left Netherfield by this time, and are on their way to town; and without any intention of coming back again.
vi: The whole family has now left Netherfield, on their way to the city, with no intention of returning.
tr: They have all left Netherfield and are going to the city –and they have no intention of returning.
es: Everyone in the house has left Netherfield and at this hour they are on their way to the capital, from where they do not plan to return.

en: You shall hear what she says.”
vi: You will hear what she has to say.
tr: Listen to what she says."
es: Listen to what it says.

en: She then read the first sentence aloud, which comprised the information of their having just resolved to follow their brother to town directly, and of their meaning to dine that day in Grosvenor Street, where mr Hurst had a house.
vi: Then she read the letter, the content of which said that they had just decided to follow Mr. Bingley to the city, and would have dinner that evening on Grosvernor Street, where Mr. Hurst had a house.
tr: He read the first sentence aloud; it was announcing that they had immediately decided to go to the city after their siblings and that they planned to have dinner that evening on Grosvenor Street, where Mr. Hurst resided.
es: Jane read aloud the first paragraph where it was stated that they had decided to go to London with her brother and that they intended to eat that same day on Grosvenor Street, where Mr. Hurst had his house.

en: The next was in these words:—“‘I do not pretend to regret anything I shall leave in Hertfordshire except your society, my dearest friend; but we will hope, at some future period, to enjoy many returns of that delightful intercourse we have known, and in the meanwhile may lessen the pain of separation by a very frequent and most unreserved correspondence.
vi: The next section read as follows: "I do not want to pretend to regret anything when leaving Hertfordshire, except for the relationship with you, my dearest friend, but my family hopes that in the future it will be compensated by the friendship between us. For now, the pain of separation can be alleviated by frequent and heartfelt correspondence."
tr: The rest was described with these words: "I don't think I will miss anything I left behind in Hertfordshire except your friendship; but I hope that we will enjoy our pleasant companionship again and again in the future, and in the meantime, we can lessen the pain of separation with frequent and sincere letters.
es: The following was written as follows: "I do not regret leaving Hertfordshire except for you, dearest friend; but I hope to enjoy again later the delightful moments we spent together and in the meantime we can lessen the sorrow of separation with very frequent and effusive letters.

en: I depend on you for that.’”
vi: "I hope you will agree to this."
tr: I trust you on this matter."
es: I count on your correspondence."

en: To these high-flown expressions Elizabeth listened with all the insensibility of distrust; and though the suddenness of their removal surprised her, she saw nothing in it really to lament: it was not to be supposed that their absence from Netherfield would prevent mr Bingley’s being there; and as to the loss of their society, she was persuaded that Jane must soon cease to regard it in the enjoyment of his.
vi: Elizabeth listened to such passionate words with indifference due to suspicion, and although surprised by their sudden departure, she did not find this event tragic. It should not be assumed that their absence from Netherfield would prevent Mr. Bingley from staying. Regarding the loss of their acquaintance, she believed that soon Jane would no longer think about it, and then he would be happy about this. Elizabeth said, after a few moments of thought:
tr: Elizabeth listened to these generous expressions with a calm filled with doubt; although the suddenness of their departure surprised her, she saw nothing to lament in their wake: their absence from Netherfield did not necessarily mean Mr. Bingley would not be there; as for losing their friendship, she believed that Jane should stop thinking about it and focus on Mr. Bingley's companionship.
es: Elizabeth listened to all these grand expressions with impassivity due to the distrust they inspired in her. She was surprised by the haste with which they had left, but in reality, she saw no reason to regret it. It could not be supposed that the fact that they were not in Netherfield would prevent Bingley from coming; and as for the absence of the ladies, she was sure that Jane would console herself with the presence of the brother.

en: “It is unlucky,” said she, after a short pause, “that you should not be able to see your friends before they leave the country.
vi: - The unfortunate thing is that you couldn't meet your friends before they left.
tr: "Bad luck," he said after a brief silence, "it would have been good if you could see your friends before leaving.
es: ––It's a shame ––he said to her after a brief pause–– that you couldn't see your friends before they left.

en: But may we not hope that the period of future happiness, to which Miss Bingley looks forward, may arrive earlier than she is aware, and that the delightful intercourse you have known as friends will be renewed with yet greater satisfaction as sisters?
vi: But can we hope, then, that the happy time Miss Bingley is expecting will come sooner? And the friendship between friends will quickly turn into a sister-in-law relationship?
tr: But can't we hope that the day Miss Bingley is expecting will come sooner than predicted, and that the companionship you enjoyed as friends will be renewed more firmly as sisters?
es: But can't we hope that this "later on" of future happiness that your friend so desires will come sooner than she thinks and that this wonderful relationship you had as friends will be renewed with greater satisfaction as sisters?

en: mr Bingley will not be detained in London by them.”
vi: Mr. Bingley will not be detained by them in London.
tr: They cannot keep Mr. Bingley in London."
es: They are not going to detain Mr. Bingley in London.

en: “Caroline decidedly says that none of the party will return into Hertfordshire this winter.
vi: - Caroline made it clear that no one in the family would return to Herfordshire this winter.
tr: "Caroline insists that no one from the family will return to Hertfordshire this winter.
es: ––Caroline says that decidedly none of them will return to Hertfordshire this winter.

en: I will read it to you.
vi: She will read it to you:
tr: Let me read it to you:–
es: ––Caroline says that decidedly none of them will return to Hertfordshire this winter.

en: “‘When my brother left us yesterday, he imagined that the business which took him to London might be concluded in three or four days; but as we are certain it cannot be so, and at the same time convinced that when Charles gets to town he will be in no hurry to leave it again, we have determined on following him thither, that he may not be obliged to spend his vacant hours in a comfortless hotel.
vi: "When my brother left yesterday, he thought that the job in London might be finished in three or four days, but we couldn't believe it. At the same time, we thought that once Charles was in the city, he wouldn't be in a hurry to leave, so we decided to follow him, so he wouldn't be alone in the uncomfortable hotel room."
tr: " ‘My brother, when leaving us yesterday, thought that the business requiring him to go to London could be handled within three or four days; but now that we know this is not possible, and also believing that Charles will not return once he gets to the city, we decided to follow him so that he wouldn't have to spend his idle hours in an uncomfortable hotel.
es: I will read it to you: «When my brother left us yesterday, he imagined that the matters calling him to London could be handled in three or four days; but as we know that this will not be the case and convinced, at the same time, that when Charles goes to the capital he is in no hurry to return, we have decided to go with him so that he does not have to spend his free hours in a hotel, without any comfort.

en: Many of my acquaintance are already there for the winter: I wish I could hear that you, my dearest friend, had any intention of making one in the crowd, but of that I despair.
vi: "Many of my acquaintances have gone there for the winter; I wish you, my closest friend, could join the crowd, but I'm not sure."
tr: Most of my acquaintances have already come there for the winter; I wish you too, my dear friend, would consider joining us – but I am not hopeful about this.
es: Many of our acquaintances are already there to spend the winter; I would like to know if you, dearest friend, plan to do the same; but I don't think it possible.

en: I sincerely hope your Christmas in Hertfordshire may abound in the gaieties which that season generally brings, and that your beaux will be so numerous as to prevent your feeling the loss of the three of whom we shall deprive you.’
vi: "I sincerely wish you a Merry Christmas in Herfordshire, and you will have many suitors to help you forget the three of us."
tr: With all my heart, I wish that Christmas brings joy to Hertfordshire and to you as it always does, and that your admirers prevent you from feeling the loss of the three friends we have deprived you of.' "
es: I sincerely wish that Christmas in Hertfordshire is bountiful in the joys typical of these festivities, and that your suitors are so numerous that they prevent you from feeling the loss of the three gentlemen we are taking away from you.»

en: “It is evident by this,” added Jane, “that he comes back no more this winter.”
vi: Jane added: - Clearly, he will not return this winter.
tr: "It is clear," added Jane, "that he will not return this winter.""
es: ––Therefore, it is evident ––added Jane–– that Mr. Bingley is not coming back this winter.

en: “It is only evident that Miss Bingley does not mean he should.”
vi: - I only see a clear intention that Miss Bingley implies he should not return.
tr: "The only certain thing is, Miss Bingley is not saying she will return."
es: ––The only thing that is evident is that Miss Bingley is the one who says he is not coming back.

en: “Why will you think so?
vi: - Why do you think that?
tr: "Why do you think that way?
es: ––Why do you believe that?

en: It must be his own doing; he is his own master.
vi: This is something I have to decide for myself. He is the master of his own life.
tr: It should be his decision. The man is his own master.
es: It must be Mr. Bingley's doing:

en: But you do not know all.
vi: But you don't know everything.
tr: But you haven't heard everything yet.
es: It doesn't depend on anyone. But you don't know everything yet.

en: I will read you the passage which particularly hurts me.
vi: I will read to you the part of the letter that broke my heart.
tr: I will read you the part that especially hurt me.
es: I'm going to read you the passage that hurts me the most.

en: I will have no reserves from you.
vi: I won't hide anything from you.
tr: I have nothing to hide from you.
es: I don't want to hide anything from you.

en: ‘mr Darcy is impatient to see his sister; and to confess the truth, we are scarcely less eager to meet her again.
vi: “Mr. Darcy is eager to see his sister again, and to be honest, we are just as impatient to meet her.
tr: " 'Mr. Darcy is eager to see his sister; to be honest, we are no less eager to see her than Mr. Darcy himself.
es: «Mr. Darcy is eager to see his sister, and the truth is that we are no less eager to see her.

en: I really do not think Georgiana Darcy has her equal for beauty, elegance, and accomplishments; and the affection she inspires in Louisa and myself is heightened into something still more interesting from the hope we dare to entertain of her being hereafter our sister.
vi: I truly think no one can compare to Georgiana Darcy in terms of appearance, elegance, and talent, and her affection for Louisa and me has grown into something more, in my bold hope that she will become my sister-in-law.
tr: In my opinion, there is no one who can match Georgiana Darcy in beauty, grace, and talent; the affection she has inspired in Louisa and me has become even more interesting because we hope she will soon become our sister.
es: I believe that Georgina Darcy has no equal in beauty, elegance, and talent, and the affection she inspires in Louisa and me increases with the hope we harbor that she will be our sister in the future.

en: I do not know whether I ever before mentioned to you my feelings on this subject, but I will not leave the country without confiding them, and I trust you will not esteem them unreasonable.
vi: I don't remember if I have mentioned my feelings about this to you before, but I will not leave without confiding in you, and I hope you won't find this too forward.
tr: I don't know if I have mentioned my feelings on this matter to you before; but I will not leave here without opening up to you about my feelings, and I am sure you will find them reasonable.
es: I don't know if I have ever expressed to you my feelings on this matter; but I don't want to leave without confiding it to you, and I imagine you will find it very reasonable.

en: My brother admires her greatly already; he will have frequent opportunity now of seeing her on the most intimate footing; her relations all wish the connection as much as his own; and a sister’s partiality is not misleading me, I think, when I call Charles most capable of engaging any woman’s heart.
vi: My brother is very fond of her, and now he will have many opportunities to see her in the most intimate circumstances. Both her relatives and ours desire this relationship, and I believe that the partiality of a sister does not lead me astray in thinking that Charles has the ability to win the heart of any woman.
tr: My brother already admires her immensely; now he will have the chance to see her often in the closest of settings; her relatives, just like us, desire this union; not because he is my brother, but Charles is someone who could win any woman's heart.
es: My brother already feels great admiration for her, and now he will have frequent opportunities to see her with the greatest intimacy. Georgina's family desires this union as much as we do, and I don't think I am blinded by sisterly passion in believing that Charles is very capable of winning any woman's heart.

en: With all these circumstances to favour an attachment, and nothing to prevent it, am I wrong, my dearest Jane, in indulging the hope of an event which will secure the happiness of so many?’
vi: With all such favorable circumstances for an attachment and nothing to prevent it, dear Jane, am I wrong to expect an event that ensures the happiness of many people?”
tr: When all circumstances are in favor of a relationship, and there is no obstacle, could I be wrong in hoping for an event that will ensure the happiness of many people, dear Jane?'
es: With all these circumstances in favor of this relationship and nothing to prevent it, I cannot be mistaken, dearest Jane, if I hope for the event that would bring happiness to so many people.»

en: What think you of this sentence, my dear Lizzy?” said Jane, as she finished it.
vi: Jane said, when she finished reading: - What do you think about this, Lizzy?
tr: "What do you say to this sentence, dear Lizzy?" said Jane, as she finished the letter.
es: ––What do you think of this paragraph, Lizzy? ––asked Jane after finishing reading––.

en: “Is it not clear enough?
vi: Is the meaning clear enough?
tr: "Isn't it quite clear?
es: Isn't it quite clear?

en: Does it not expressly declare that Caroline neither expects nor wishes me to be her sister; that she is perfectly convinced of her brother’s indifference; and that if she suspects the nature of my feelings for him she means (most kindly!) to put me on my guard.
vi: Does it mean that Caroline neither expects nor hopes that you will become her sister-in-law? That she is certain he is indifferent to you? And if she has guessed your feelings towards him, would she intend to warn you?
tr: Doesn't Caroline plainly say that she neither wants nor hopes for me as her sister-in-law? She is quite certain of her brother's indifference; even if she suspects my feelings for him, she (kindly!) warns me to be cautious.
es: Doesn't it clearly express that Caroline neither expects nor desires that I be her sister, that she is completely convinced of her brother's indifference, and that if she suspects the nature of my feelings towards him, she intends, with all kindness, of course, to warn me?

en: Can there be any other opinion on the subject?”
vi: Do you have any thoughts?
tr: Can there be any other interpretation of this matter?"
es: Can this matter be interpreted in any other way?

en: “Yes, there can; for mine is totally different.
vi: - Yes, because my opinion is completely different.
tr: "Yes, it could be; because mine is completely different.
es: ––Yes, it can be done. I interpret it very differently.

en: Will you hear it?”
vi: Do you want to hear it?
tr: –Will you listen?"
es: Do you want to know how?

en: “Most willingly.”
vi: - Of course, I want to.
tr: "With great enthusiasm."
es: ––Of course.

en: “You shall have it in a few words.
vi: - You can listen briefly.
tr: "I will say it in a few words.
es: ––I will tell you in a few words.

en: Miss Bingley sees that her brother is in love with you and wants him to marry Miss Darcy.
vi: Miss Bingley thought that her brother was in love with you, while she wanted him to marry Miss Darcy.
tr: Miss Bingley sees that her brother is in love with you and wants to marry him to Miss Darcy.
es: Miss Bingley has realized that her brother is in love with you and she wants him to marry Miss Darcy.

en: She follows him to town in the hope of keeping him there, and tries to persuade you that he does not care about you.”
vi: She followed him in hopes of keeping him there, trying to convince you that he didn't care about you.
tr: She is going to the city after him with the intention of keeping him there, and wants to convince you that the man does not care about you."
es: She has gone to the capital after him, hoping to keep him there, and is trying to convince you that Bingley does not care about you at all.

en: Jane shook her head.
vi: Jane shook her head.
tr: Jane nodded her head.
es: Jane shook her head.

en: “Indeed, Jane, you ought to believe me.
vi: - Actually, Jane, you should trust me.
tr: "Truly, Jane, you must believe me.
es: ––That's right, Jane; you must believe me.

en: No one who has ever seen you together can doubt his affection; Miss Bingley, I am sure, cannot: she is not such a simpleton.
vi: No one who has ever seen the two of you together would doubt his feelings for you. I'm sure Miss Bingley doesn't either. She's not foolish.
tr: –No one who has seen you together can doubt his affection. I am sure Miss Bingley cannot doubt it either. She cannot be that foolish.
es: No one who has seen you together can doubt Bingley's affection. His sister doesn't doubt it either, she's not that foolish.

en: Could she have seen half as much love in mr Darcy for herself, she would have ordered her wedding clothes.
vi: If she could recognize that Mr. Darcy loved her even half as much, she would have already ordered her wedding dress.
tr: If she could see that Mr. Darcy was half as in love with her, she would have ordered her wedding dress by now.
es: If she had seen half of that affection in Darcy towards her, she would have already ordered the wedding dress.

en: But the case is this:—we are not rich enough or grand enough for them; and she is the more anxious to get Miss Darcy for her brother, from the notion that when there has been one inter-marriage, she may have less trouble in achieving a second; in which there is certainly some ingenuity, and I dare say it would succeed if Miss de Bourgh were out of the way.
vi: But here's the issue. We are neither wealthy nor have any status for them to look forward to; while her sister keeps trying to pair Miss Darcy with him, with the idea that once there is a marriage between the two families, she could easily secure a second marriage. This calculation is quite clever; I'm sure it could succeed if not for Lady De Bourgh's interference.
tr: But the situation is this: –We are not rich enough or grand enough for them; she wants to marry Miss Darcy to her brother because she thinks that once there is one marriage, achieving a second one will be easier, which she may be partly right about, and she might even succeed if it weren't for the obstacle of Miss de Bourgh.
es: But the thing is this: we are neither rich enough nor distinguished enough for them. If Miss Bingley is so eager to marry Miss Darcy to her brother, it's because it would make it easier for her to marry Darcy himself; which seems a bit naive on her part. But I would dare to believe that she would achieve her desires if Miss de Bourgh were not in the way.

en: But, my dearest Jane, you cannot seriously imagine that, because Miss Bingley tells you her brother greatly admires Miss Darcy, he is in the smallest degree less sensible of your merit than when he took leave of you on Tuesday; or that it will be in her power to persuade him that, instead of being in love with you, he is very much in love with her friend.”
vi: But, dear Jane, you shouldn't seriously imagine that just because Miss Bingley tells you he admires Miss Darcy, he will think less of you than he did when he left on Tuesday, or that she has the ability to persuade him to love her friend instead of you.
tr: But, dear Jane, just because Miss Bingley told you that her brother admires Miss Darcy very much, you cannot believe that Mr. Bingley values your superiority any less than he did at your parting on Tuesday, or that her influence could make him fall in love with her friend instead of you."
es: However, you can't seriously think that just because Miss Bingley tells you that her brother likes Miss Darcy, he is less in love with you than he was on Thursday when he said goodbye; nor that it is possible for his sister to convince him to love Miss Darcy instead of you.

en: “If we thought alike of Miss Bingley,” replied Jane, “your representation of all this might make me quite easy.
vi: Jane replied: - If we had the same thoughts as Miss Bingley, everything you said might help put my mind at ease.
tr: "If we had similar thoughts about Miss Bingley," Jane replied, "these explanations would greatly relieve me.
es: ––If our opinion of Miss Bingley were the same ––replied Jane––, your explanation would reassure me.

en: But I know the foundation is unjust.
vi: But I think that is unfounded.
tr: But I know there is a fundamental mistake.
es: But I know that you are being unfair to her.

en: Caroline is incapable of wilfully deceiving anyone; and all that I can hope in this case is, that she is deceived herself.”
vi: Caroline cannot be capable of deceiving anyone; in this matter, all I can hope is that she has merely deceived herself.
tr: Even Caroline cannot deliberately deceive anyone; in this case, all I can hope for is that she is deceiving herself."
es: Caroline is incapable of deceiving anyone; the only thing I can hope for in this case is that she is deceiving herself.

en: “That is right.
vi: - That's right.
tr: "That's true.
es: ––That's right.

en: You could not have started a more happy idea, since you will not take comfort in mine: believe her to be deceived, by all means.
vi: You can't think of anything better to make you happy, because you can't be happy with my words. Believe that she has deceived herself.
tr: –You couldn't have come up with a better idea, since my idea didn't comfort you. Whatever happens, believe that he is deceiving himself.
es: You couldn't have come up with a better idea, since mine doesn't comfort you. Suppose she's mistaken.

en: You have now done your duty by her, and must fret no longer.”
vi: As for you, it's over with her, you shouldn't be sad anymore.
tr: You have done your duty towards him; don't be sad anymore."
es: That way you'll be in good standing with her and you'll see that you have nothing to worry about.

en: “But, my dear sister, can I be happy, even supposing the best, in accepting a man whose sisters and friends are all wishing him to marry elsewhere?”
vi: - But, my dear, can I be happy, even in the best case, to accept a young man whose siblings and friends all want him to marry someone else?
tr: "But my dear brother, can I be happy even in the best case by accepting a man whom all my sisters and friends wish to marry someone else?""
es: ––But Lizzy, can I be happy, even assuming the best, by accepting a man whose sisters and friends wish him to marry another?

en: “You must decide for yourself,” said Elizabeth; “and if, upon mature deliberation, you find that the misery of disobliging his two sisters is more than equivalent to the happiness of being his wife, I advise you, by all means, to refuse him.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - You must decide for yourself, and if after careful consideration, you find that the distress of displeasing the two sisters outweighs the happiness of being his wife, I advise you by all means to refuse him.
tr: "The decision is up to you," said Elizabeth; "if, after careful consideration, the sorrow of disappointing your two sisters outweighs the happiness of being his wife, then I advise you to reject him.""
es: ––You must decide that for yourself ––said Elizabeth––, if after mature reflection you find that the misfortune of displeasing his sisters is more than equivalent to the happiness of being his wife, I advise you, of course, to reject Bingley. ––What things you say!

en: “How can you talk so?” said Jane, faintly smiling; “you must know, that, though I should be exceedingly grieved at their disapprobation, I could not hesitate.”
vi: Jane smiled softly: - How can you say that? You must know that although I might be very sad because they don't accept me, I cannot hesitate.
tr: "How can you talk like that?" said Jane, with a faint smile. "You know that if they don't approve, I would be very upset, but I wouldn't hesitate for a minute."
es: said Jane with a slight smile––. You must know that although their disapproval would sadden me greatly, I would not hesitate.

en: “I did not think you would; and that being the case, I cannot consider your situation with much compassion.”
vi: - I didn't think you would hesitate, and in such a case, I cannot have compassion for your situation.
tr: "I don't think you deserve it either; if that's the case, your situation isn't that dire.""
es: ––I already figured as much, and being so, I don't think I can sympathize with your situation.

en: “But if he returns no more this winter, my choice will never be required.
vi: - But if he doesn't come back in the winter, you will never have to choose anything at all.
tr: "But if he doesn't come back this winter, I won't need to make a choice.
es: ––But if he doesn't come back all winter, my choice will be useless.

en: A thousand things may arise in six months.”
vi: Thousands of things can happen in six months.
tr: A thousand things can happen in six months!"
es: So many things can happen in six months!

en: The idea of his returning no more Elizabeth treated with the utmost contempt.
vi: The thought that he would not return made Elizabeth utterly contemptuous.
tr: Elizabeth never took seriously the thought of him not returning again.
es: Elizabeth rejected the idea that Bingley would not return; it seemed to her simply a suggestion born of Caroline's self-interested wishes, and she could not suppose for a moment that such wishes, whether expressed openly or covertly, would influence the mind of a man so independent.

en: It appeared to her merely the suggestion of Caroline’s interested wishes; and she could not for a moment suppose that those wishes, however openly or artfully spoken, could influence a young man so totally independent of everyone.
vi: She thought that it seemed merely to be Caroline's self-serving wish; she did not believe that these wishes, whether expressed bluntly or subtly, could influence a man as independent as he was.
tr: She believed that this was merely an implication of Caroline's self-serving wishes, and she did not for a moment think that such wishes, whether expressed openly or subtly, could influence a young man who seemed so independent of everyone.
es: Elizabeth rejected the idea that Bingley would not return; it seemed to her simply a suggestion born of Caroline's self-interested wishes, and she could not suppose for a moment that such wishes, whether expressed openly or covertly, would influence the mind of a man so independent.

en: She represented to her sister, as forcibly as possible, what she felt on the subject, and had soon the pleasure of seeing its happy effect.
vi: She expressed her feelings as strongly as she could, immediately seeing that her sister was very happy.
tr: Elizabeth explained her thoughts on the matter to her sister with all her persuasiveness and soon had the pleasure of seeing the happy effect she had created.
es: He explained to his sister as eloquently as he could his point of view, and soon observed the good effect of his words.

en: Jane’s temper was not desponding; and she was gradually led to hope, though the diffidence of affection sometimes overcame the hope, that Bingley would return to Netherfield, and answer every wish of her heart.
vi: Jane's attitude was not one of discouragement, and she gradually began to hope that Bingley would return to Netherfield and reciprocate her feelings.
tr: Jane's nature was not inclined to remain sorrowful; although occasional doubts of affection hindered her hope, she increasingly believed that Bingley would return to Netherfield and fulfill all the desires of her heart.
es: Jane was by nature an optimist, which gradually led her to hope that Bingley would return to Netherfield and fulfill all the desires of her heart, although doubt occasionally assailed her.

en: They agreed that ms Bennet should only hear of the departure of the family, without being alarmed on the score of the gentleman’s conduct; but even this partial communication gave her a great deal of concern, and she bewailed it as exceedingly unlucky that the ladies should happen to go away just as they were all getting so intimate together.
vi: The two sisters agreed to inform Mrs. Bennet about the family's departure without alarming her about the young man's attitude, but even this news caused her considerable worry, and she lamented her misfortune excessively, as if they were her close relatives.
tr: They decided to only tell Mrs. Bennet about the family's departure, so as not to cause her to panic over the man's behavior; but even this partial information greatly distressed Mrs. Bennet. She kept lamenting that it was a great misfortune for the ladies to leave just when they had gotten so close.
es: They agreed that they would only inform Mrs. Bennet about the family's departure, so she wouldn't be too alarmed; but she was quite alarmed anyway; and lamented the tremendous misfortune that the ladies had left just when they had become so close.

en: After lamenting it, however, at some length, she had the consolation of thinking that mr Bingley would be soon down again, and soon dining at Longbourn; and the conclusion of all was the comfortable declaration, that, though he had been invited only to a family dinner, she would take care to have two full courses.
vi: However, she soon consoled herself with the thought that Mr. Bingley would return shortly and would come to dine at Longbourn. Everyone felt happy, even though they were inviting him to a regular family meal, but she would prepare a lavish feast.
tr: Nevertheless, after her complaints subsided, she soon consoled herself with the thought that Mr. Bingley would be coming very soon and would be dining at Longbourn in the near future; as a result, she cheered up by saying that she would need to prepare a double menu, even though he was only invited to a family dinner.
es: She was very upset about it, but consoled herself by thinking that Bingley would soon return to dine at Longbourn, and ended up declaring that despite having invited him to a family dinner, she would make sure to prepare two first-rate dishes for that day.

en: CHAPTER XXII.
vi: Chapter 22
tr: Chapter XXII
es: CHAPTER XXII

en: THE Bennets were engaged to dine with the Lucases; and again, during the chief of the day, was Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to mr Collins.
vi: The Bennet family was invited to dine with the Lucas family, and once again Miss Charlotte Lucas spent most of the time politely listening to Mr. Collins.
tr: The Bennets had promised to dine with the Lucases; throughout most of the day, Miss Lucas showed kindness by listening to Mr. Collins.
es: The Bennets were invited to dine with the Lucases, and once again Miss Lucas had the kindness to listen to Collins for most of the day.

en: Elizabeth took an opportunity of thanking her.
vi: Elizabeth took the opportunity to express her gratitude to her.
tr: Elizabeth thanked her when she found an opportunity.
es: Elizabeth took the first opportunity to thank her.

en: “It keeps him in good humour,” said she, “and I am more obliged to you than I can express.”
vi: - You have made him happy, thank you very much.
tr: "He is being kept occupied thanks to you," she said, "I am grateful to you for that."
es: ––This puts him in a good mood. I am more grateful to you than you can imagine ––she said to him.

en: Charlotte assured her friend of her satisfaction in being useful, and that it amply repaid her for the little sacrifice of her time.
vi: Charlotte reassured her friend that she was happy to be of help, thinking she had used her time meaningfully.
tr: Charlotte reassured her friend by saying she was happy to be of use and that she had been more than rewarded for spending a little time.
es: Charlotte assured her that she was glad to be able to do something for her, and that it compensated her for the small sacrifice of dedicating her time.

en: This was very amiable; but Charlotte’s kindness extended farther than Elizabeth had any conception of:—its object was nothing less than to secure her from any return of mr Collins’s addresses, by engaging them towards herself.
vi: This was truly sweet, but Charlotte's kindness had gone beyond what Elizabeth imagined – her goal was nothing less than to gain Mr. Collins' attention.
tr: This was very friendly; but Charlotte's kindness went further than Elizabeth thought; –her aim was to draw Mr. Collins' attention to herself, thus sparing Elizabeth from having to reciprocate.
es: It was very kind of her, but Charlotte's kindness went further than Elizabeth could suspect: her goal was none other than to prevent Collins from directing his compliments to her friend again, attracting them to herself instead.

en: Such was Miss Lucas’s scheme; and appearances were so favourable, that when they parted at night, she would have felt almost sure of success if he had not been to leave Hertfordshire so very soon.
vi: That was her intention, and everything appeared so favorable that when they parted that night, she could almost certainly think she had succeeded if he did not have to leave Hertfordshire soon.
tr: This was Miss Lucas's plan, and it seemed to work so well that by the time they parted at night, Miss Lucas would have been almost certain of her success if Mr. Collins were not to leave Hertfordshire so soon.
es: This was Charlotte's plan, and appearances were so favorable to her that upon parting that night, she could almost have taken success for granted, if Collins did not have to leave Hertfordshire so soon.

en: But here she did injustice to the fire and independence of his character; for it led him to escape out of Longbourn House the next morning with admirable slyness, and hasten to Lucas Lodge to throw himself at her feet.
vi: But in this matter, she had not accurately assessed his courage and self-control, for he left Longbourn the next morning, hastily heading to Lucas Lodge to court her.
tr: But at this point, she did not account for Mr. Collins' passionate and independent character; for his character led him to escape from Longbourn House the next morning with admirable secrecy and throw himself at Miss Lucas's feet at Lucas Lodge.
es: But in conceiving this doubt, she did not do justice to Collins' fiery and independent character; the next morning he slipped away from Longbourn with admirable stealth and ran to the Lucas' house to surrender at her feet.

en: He was anxious to avoid the notice of his cousins, from a conviction that, if they saw him depart, they could not fail to conjecture his design, and he was not willing to have the attempt known till its success could be known likewise; for, though feeling almost secure, and with reason, for Charlotte had been tolerably encouraging, he was comparatively diffident since the adventure of Wednesday.
vi: He did not want his cousins to see him, fearing that if they saw him leave, they would immediately guess his intention, which he did not want anyone to know until he was certain of the outcome. He was right to be worried, for although Charlotte had encouraged him to proceed, he lacked confidence after the adventure on Wednesday.
tr: He had taken care not to be seen by his cousins, as he thought they would guess his purpose if they saw him leave, and he did not want his attempt to be known until his success was certain; though he felt almost secure, as he had a right to, because Charlotte had been quite encouraging, but he was relatively shy after Wednesday's adventure.
es: He wanted to conceal his departure from his cousins because if they had seen him, they would have discovered his intention, and he did not want to announce it until he was sure of success; although he felt almost certain of it, for Charlotte had encouraged him enough, but since his adventure on Wednesday, he was a little lacking in confidence.

en: His reception, however, was of the most flattering kind.
vi: However, the way she welcomed him made him truly satisfied.
tr: Nevertheless, he was received in a very flattering manner.
es: Nevertheless, he received a very flattering welcome.

en: Miss Lucas perceived him from an upper window as he walked towards the house, and instantly set out to meet him accidentally in the lane.
vi: As he was approaching the house, Miss Lucas had seen him from an upstairs window, immediately went outside, pretending to meet him by chance on the path.
tr: As he walked towards the house, Miss Lucas saw him from an upstairs window and immediately went out to meet him on the road, pretending it was a coincidence.
es: Miss Lucas saw him arriving from a window, and immediately went out to the path to meet him as if by chance.

en: But little had she dared to hope that so much love and eloquence awaited her there.
vi: But she did not dare hope that so much affection and eloquence awaited her there.
tr: But she could not dare to hope that such a strong love and such beautiful words awaited her there.
es: But little could she imagine how much love and eloquence awaited her.

en: In as short a time as mr Collins’s long speeches would allow, everything was settled between them to the satisfaction of both; and as they entered the house, he earnestly entreated her to name the day that was to make him the happiest of men; and though such a solicitation must be waived for the present, the lady felt no inclination to trifle with his happiness.
vi: In the short period of time that Mr. Collins' lengthy speeches allowed, everything was arranged to the satisfaction of both parties. When the two entered the house, he warmly asked her to set a date that would make him the happiest young man. Although she could not give an answer at that moment, the young lady did not want to downplay his delight.
tr: During the short intervals allowed by Mr. Collins' long speeches, everything between them was settled in a manner satisfactory to both; as they entered the house, Mr. Collins asked her to set the day that would make him the happiest man in the world; although there was no need to rush such a decision, the young lady had no intention of playing with his happiness.
es: In the short span of time left by Collins' endless speeches, everything was arranged between them to mutual satisfaction. Upon entering the house, Collins earnestly begged her to name the day when she would make him the happiest of men; and although such a request had to be postponed for the moment, the lady did not wish to play with his happiness.

en: The stupidity with which he was favoured by nature must guard his courtship from any charm that could make a woman wish for its continuance; and Miss Lucas, who accepted him solely from the pure and disinterested desire of an establishment, cared not how soon that establishment were gained.
vi: His naturally foolish demeanor made his courtship lack the compelling force that women wish to continue. Miss Lucas, having accepted him with pure and selfless intentions regarding the relationship, did not care how quickly the relationship was established.
tr: The foolishness nature had bestowed upon him had protected his courtship style from any charm that might make a woman want it to continue; Miss Lucas, who accepted him out of a pure and selfless desire for marriage, did not mind how quickly that marriage was obtained.
es: The stupidity with which nature had endowed her deprived her courtship of the charms that might incline a woman to prolong it; Miss Lucas, who had accepted him solely out of the pure and selfless desire to marry, did not care how soon this event would take place.

en: Sir William and Lady Lucas were speedily applied to for their consent; and it was bestowed with a most joyful alacrity.
vi: They quickly expressed to Mr. Williams and Lady Lucas, both of whom accepted with the most eager cheerfulness.
tr: Sir William and Lady Lucas were quickly visited to obtain their approval; the approval was given with joyful promptness.
es: They quickly informed Sir William and Lady Lucas to obtain their consent, which was granted with the greatest promptness and joy.

en: mr Collins’s present circumstances made it a most eligible match for their daughter, to whom they could give little fortune; and his prospects of future wealth were exceedingly fair.
vi: Mr. Collins's current situation made him the most eligible match for their daughter, as they could only provide her with a small fortune, and his future prospects were very bright.
tr: Mr. Collins' current circumstances made him a very suitable husband for their daughters, who could not expect much of a dowry; besides, his future prospects of wealth were quite high.
es: Collins' situation made him a very desirable match for their daughter, to whom they could leave only a small fortune, and the prospects of future well-being were too tempting.

en: Lady Lucas began directly to calculate, with more interest than the matter had ever
vi: Lady Lucas began to calculate with unprecedented attention the number of years Mr. Bennet would still live.
tr: Lady Lucas immediately began to calculate how many more years Mr. Bennet might live with more interest than the matter had previously aroused; Sir William also expressed his firm opinion that it would be quite appropriate for both him and his wife to make an appearance at St. James's once Mr. Collins became the owner of the Longbourn estate.
es: Lady Lucas immediately began to calculate with more interest than ever how many more years Mr. Bennet might live, and Sir William expressed his opinion that when Collins became the owner of Longbourn, it would be very convenient for him and his wife to make their appearance at St. James.

en: “So much love and eloquence”
vi: Sir William decided that when Mr. Collins inherited the Longbourn estate, both he and his wife would appear at St. James's Court.
tr: Lady Lucas immediately began to calculate how many more years Mr. Bennet might live with more interest than the matter had previously aroused; Sir William also expressed his firm opinion that it would be quite appropriate for both him and his wife to make an appearance at St. James's once Mr. Collins became the owner of the Longbourn estate.
es: Lady Lucas immediately began to calculate with more interest than ever how many more years Mr. Bennet might live, and Sir William expressed his opinion that when Collins became the owner of Longbourn, it would be very convenient for him and his wife to make their appearance at St. James.

en: excited before, how many years longer mr Bennet was likely to live; and Sir William gave it as his decided opinion, that whenever mr Collins should be in possession of the Longbourn estate, it would be highly expedient that both he and his wife should make their appearance at St. James’s.
vi: Sir William decided that when Mr. Collins inherited the Longbourn estate, both he and his wife would appear at St. James's Court.
tr: Lady Lucas immediately began to calculate how many more years Mr. Bennet might live with more interest than the matter had previously aroused; Sir William also expressed his firm opinion that it would be quite appropriate for both him and his wife to make an appearance at St. James's once Mr. Collins became the owner of the Longbourn estate.
es: Lady Lucas immediately began to calculate with more interest than ever how many more years Mr. Bennet might live, and Sir William expressed his opinion that when Collins became the owner of Longbourn, it would be very convenient for him and his wife to make their appearance at St. James.

en: The whole family in short were properly overjoyed on the occasion.
vi: The whole family seemed delighted.
tr: In short, this event filled the entire family with joy.
es: In short, the whole family rejoiced greatly at the news.

en: The younger girls formed hopes of coming out a year or two sooner than they might otherwise have done; and the boys were relieved from their apprehension of Charlotte’s dying an old maid.
vi: The younger daughters hoped they might come out a year or two sooner than expected, while the sons were relieved that Charlotte would not die an old maid.
tr: The younger girls hoped that they might come out a year or two earlier than would otherwise have been possible; the boys were relieved of the fear that Charlotte would remain unmarried.
es: The younger daughters hoped to be presented in society a year or two earlier than they would have been otherwise due to this circumstance. The sons were relieved of the fear that Charlotte might remain single.

en: Charlotte herself was tolerably composed.
vi: Charlotte herself was quite composed.
tr: Charlotte, however, was more composed.
es: Charlotte was calm.

en: She had gained her point, and had time to consider of it.
vi: She had achieved her goal and had time to think about it.
tr: She had achieved her goal and had had time to consider it.
es: She had won the game and had time to consider it.

en: Her reflections were in general satisfactory.
vi: Her reflections were all satisfactory.
tr: Her thoughts were generally satisfactory.
es: Her reflections were generally satisfactory.

en: mr Collins, to be sure, was neither sensible nor agreeable: his society was irksome, and his attachment to her must be imaginary.
vi: It was evident that Mr. Collins was neither sensible nor agreeable; his manners were awkward, and his attachment to her was imaginary.
tr: Mr. Collins, of course, was neither sensible nor agreeable; his conversation was dreadful; his attachment to her must be imaginary.
es: To tell the truth, Collins was neither intelligent nor pleasant, his company was tedious, and his affection for her must have been imaginary.

en: But still he would be her husband.
vi: But still, he would be her husband.
tr: But still, he would be her husband.
es: But, after all, he would be her husband.

en: Without thinking highly either of men or of matrimony, marriage had always been her object: it was the only honourable provision for well-educated young women of small fortune, and, however uncertain of giving happiness, must be their pleasantest preservative from want.
vi: Not thinking highly of men or matrimony, marriage had always been her objective. It was the most dignified provision for well-educated young women of small fortune; and though uncertain of bringing happiness, it was the most pleasant preservative from want.
tr: Without indulging in great expectations regarding men or the marital bond, she had always aimed for marriage; marriage was the only honorable provision for well-educated young women of small fortune, and though it might not ensure happiness, it must be their most eligible protection against want.
es: Although Charlotte did not have a high opinion of men or marriage, she had always desired it because it was the only honorable position for a well-educated young woman with little fortune, and, although it could not be guaranteed to be a source of happiness, it would always be the most agreeable resource against need.

en: This preservative she had now obtained; and at the age of twenty-seven, without having ever been handsome, she felt all the good luck of it.
