vi: Now that this preservative was secured, and at the age of twenty-seven, without being handsome, she felt fortunate.
tr: She had now secured that protection; at twenty-seven, with no beauty to recommend her, she knew it to be a fortunate chance.
es: This resource was what she had just obtained, for at twenty-seven years of age, never having been pretty, it was a real stroke of luck for her.

en: The least agreeable circumstance in the business was the surprise it must occasion to Elizabeth Bennet, whose friendship she valued beyond that of any other person.
vi: The most uncomfortable feeling was Elizabeth Bennet's surprise, whose friendship she valued more than any other person's.
tr: The most unpleasant part of the affair was the possibility of surprising Elizabeth Bennet, whose friendship she valued more than any other.
es: The least pleasant part of all was the surprise that Elizabeth Bennet would receive, whose friendship she valued more than that of any other person.

en: Elizabeth would wonder, and probably would blame her; and though her resolution was not to be shaken, her feelings must be hurt by such a disapprobation.
vi: Elizabeth might wonder, perhaps reproach her; and though her opinion was resolute, she might feel hurt by her friend's disapproval.
tr: Elizabeth would be astonished and probably would reproach her; her decision would not be altered, but it would hurt her feelings to face such a surprise.
es: Elizabeth would be astonished and probably would not approve; and, although the decision was already made, Elizabeth's disapproval would hurt her greatly.

en: She resolved to give her the information herself; and therefore charged mr Collins, when he returned to Longbourn to dinner, to drop no hint of what had passed before any of the family.
vi: Charlotte decided to inform her friend herself, so when Mr. Collins returned to Longbourn for dinner, she requested him to withhold the news.
tr: She decided to give the news to her herself and enjoined Mr. Collins not to say a word to anyone in the family about what had happened when he returned to Longbourn for dinner.
es: She resolved to tell her herself, so she recommended to Collins, when he returned to Longbourn for dinner, not to say anything about what had happened.

en: A promise of secrecy was of course very dutifully given, but it could not be kept without difficulty; for the curiosity excited by his long absence burst forth in such very direct questions on his return, as required some ingenuity to evade, and he was at the same time exercising great self-denial, for he was longing to publish his prosperous love.
vi: Of course, he promised secrecy, but it was not easy, as everyone was curious about his absence and questioned him directly. He had to be very skillful in evading, while he himself was eager to announce his prosperous love affair.
tr: Of course, the promise of secrecy was given with all his heart, but it would not be easy to keep; the curiosity aroused by his long absence would lead to such direct questions on his return that it would require considerable dexterity to avoid answering; moreover, he was burning with the desire to proclaim his triumphant love, so he had to struggle hard with himself.
es: Naturally, he duly promised to keep the secret; but it was difficult for him, because the curiosity aroused by his long absence burst upon his return in such direct questions that it required great skill to evade them; moreover, it represented a real self-denial for Collins, as he was impatient to proclaim his romantic success to the four winds.

en: As he was to begin his journey too early on the morrow to see any of the family, the ceremony of leave-taking was performed when the ladies moved for the night; and ms Bennet, with great politeness and cordiality, said how happy they should be to see him at Longbourn again, whenever his other engagements might allow him to visit them.
vi: Because he would leave too early the next day to say goodbye to anyone, they had a farewell ceremony that night. With utmost politeness and warmth, Mrs. Bennet said she would be very pleased to welcome him again at Longbourn whenever he had the chance to visit.
tr: Since he would leave so early in the morning that he wouldn't see any of the family, the farewell ceremony was held as the ladies retired for the night; Mrs. Bennet, with great politeness and generosity, said how happy they would be to see him at Longbourn again whenever his duties allowed.
es: The next day he had to leave, but since he had to set off too early to see any member of the family, the farewell ceremony took place when the ladies went to bed. Mrs. Bennet, with great courtesy and warmth, told him that she would be very happy to see him in Longbourn again when his other commitments allowed him to visit them.

en: “My dear madam,” he replied, “this invitation is particularly gratifying, because it is what I have been hoping to receive; and you may be very certain that I shall avail myself of it as soon as possible.”
vi: He replied: - Madam, I am very excited to be invited, as I have always hoped to receive such an invitation, and you can be sure that I will accept it as soon as possible.
tr: "Dear madam," he replied, "this invitation is especially honorable, because I was also expecting it; you can be sure that I will respond to your invitation at the first opportunity.""
es: ––My dear lady ––replied Collins––, I particularly appreciate this invitation because I very much wanted to receive it; rest assured that I will take advantage of it as soon as possible.

en: They were all astonished; and mr Bennet, who could by no means wish for so speedy a return, immediately said,—
vi: The whole family was surprised. They never thought there would be such a quick response. Mr. Bennet immediately said:
tr: They were all surprised; not wanting such a quick turn of events, Mr. Bennet immediately spoke up–
es: Everyone was astonished, and Mr. Bennet, who in no way desired such a quick return, hastened to say:

en: “But is there not danger of Lady Catherine’s disapprobation here, my good sir?
vi: - But will Lady Catherine object, dear?
tr: "But isn't there a danger of offending Lady Catherine here, sir?"
es: ––But, isn't there a danger that Lady Catherine will disapprove this time?

en: You had better neglect your relations than run the risk of offending your patroness.”
vi: Should you forget your own relatives instead of displeasing your benefactor?
tr: "It is better to neglect your relatives than to risk offending your patron.""
es: It is better to be negligent with his relatives than to risk offending his patroness.

en: “My dear sir,” replied mr Collins, “I am particularly obliged to you for this friendly caution, and you may depend upon my not taking so material a step without her Ladyship’s concurrence.”
vi: Mr. Collins replied: - Sir, I am particularly very pleased that you have reminded me so sincerely, and please believe me that I will not do anything without the lady's approval.
tr: "Dear sir," replied Mr. Collins, "I am particularly grateful for this friendly advice; you can be assured that I would not take such an important step without first obtaining permission from her ladyship."
es: ––Dear sir ––replied Collins––, I am very grateful to you for this friendly warning, and you can be assured that I will not take a single step that is not authorized by His Lordship.

en: “You cannot be too much on your guard.
vi: - Anyway, you should be more careful.
tr: "You can never be too careful.
es: ––All precautions are few.

en: Risk anything rather than her displeasure; and if you find it likely to be raised by your coming to us again, which I should think exceedingly probable, stay quietly at home, and be satisfied that we shall take no offence.”
vi: You can afford to lose everything, but you should not offend the lady. I believe you might want to visit us again, but if this matter displeases her, I think you should not come, and please rest assured, we will not hold it against you.
tr: Just don't upset him, and do whatever you want; if you see that coming back to us will be risky, which I think it will be, just stay quietly at home, and be assured that we won't be offended."
es: Risk anything except inconveniencing her, and if you believe that your visits to our house could cause that, which I consider more than possible, stay quietly in yours and console yourself thinking that we will not be offended.

en: “Believe me, my dear sir, my gratitude is warmly excited by such affectionate attention; and, depend upon it, you will speedily receive from me a letter of thanks for this as well as for every other mark of your regard during my stay in Hertfordshire.
vi: - Sir, please believe me, I am deeply grateful for such heartfelt concern, and I will write you a thank-you letter for this concern, as well as for what I received during my stay in Hertfordshire.
tr: "Believe me, dear sir, my gratitude has increased manifold with your kind concern; for this and for all the understanding you have shown during my stay in Hertfordshire, you can be sure that you will receive a thank-you letter from me immediately.
es: ––Believe me, my dear sir, my gratitude increases with your affectionate advice, so I warn you that you will soon receive a letter of thanks for the same and for all the other proofs of consideration that you have given me during my stay in Hertfordshire.

en: As for my fair cousins, though my absence may not be long enough to render it necessary, I shall now take the liberty of wishing them health and happiness, not excepting my cousin Elizabeth.”
vi: As for my lovely cousins, although my absence will not be long and there is no need for many well-wishes, I still wish them health and happiness, including Miss Elizabeth.
tr: As for my lovely cousins, although my absence will not be long enough to necessitate it, I wish them health and happiness, including my cousin Elizabeth."
es: As for my beautiful cousins, although my absence will not be so long as to make it necessary, I will take the liberty of wishing them health and happiness, not excluding my cousin Elizabeth.

en: With proper civilities, the ladies then withdrew; all of them equally surprised to find that he meditated a quick return.
vi: With all due politeness, the women went outside; everyone was surprised to see that he planned to return soon.
tr: After the necessary courtesies, the ladies withdrew; since they thought she would return quickly, they were all equally surprised.
es: After the customary pleasantries, the ladies withdrew. They were all equally surprised to see that he intended to return soon.

en: ms Bennet wished to understand by it that he thought of paying his addresses to one of her younger girls, and Mary might have been prevailed on to accept him.
vi: From this, Mrs. Bennet hoped he would want to get acquainted with one of her young daughters, and Mary in particular might be willing to accept him.
tr: Mrs. Bennet preferred to conclude that she intended to turn to one of her younger daughters; Mary might be persuaded to accept her.
es: Mrs. Bennet wanted to attribute it to his intention of courting one of her younger daughters, so she decided to convince Mary to accept him.

en: She rated his abilities much higher than any of the others: there was a solidity in his reflections which often struck her; and though by no means so clever as herself, she thought that, if encouraged to read and improve himself by such an example as hers, he might become a very agreeable companion.
vi: She had rated him higher than the other girls did. She often had a good impression of his way of thinking, which she considered mature. Although he was not as wise as she was, she thought that if he were encouraged to read more and be as self-improving as she was, he could become a pleasant life partner.
tr: Mary had valued her qualities more than the others; there was a solidity in her thoughts that Mary found interesting, and although she did not consider her as intelligent as herself, she thought she could take her as a model, encourage her to read, improve herself, and become a very reasonable life partner.
es: Indeed, Mary appreciated Collins more than the others; she found a solidity in his reflections that often dazzled her, and although she did not consider him as intelligent as herself, she believed that if he were encouraged to read and to follow an example like hers, he could become a very pleasant companion.

en: But on the following morning every hope of this kind was done away.
vi: But the next morning, all hopes were dashed.
tr: But the next morning, all such hopes vanished.
es: But the next morning, the entire plan fell apart, for Miss Lucas came to visit them just after lunch and in a private conversation with Elizabeth, she recounted the events of the previous day.

en: Miss Lucas called soon after breakfast, and in a private conference with Elizabeth related the event of the day before.
vi: Miss Lucas visited after breakfast, and during a private conversation with Elizabeth, recounted the events of the previous day.
tr: Immediately after breakfast, Miss Lucas called and, while they were sitting alone, told Elizabeth what had happened the previous day.
es: But the next morning, the entire plan fell apart, for Miss Lucas came to visit them just after lunch and in a private conversation with Elizabeth, she recounted the events of the previous day.

en: The possibility of mr Collins’s fancying himself in love with her friend had once occurred to Elizabeth within the last day or two: but that Charlotte could encourage him seemed almost as far from possibility as that she could encourage him herself; and her astonishment was consequently so great as to overcome at first the bounds of decorum, and she could not help crying out,—
vi: The possibility that Mr. Collins might fall for her friend had crossed Elizabeth's mind in the past few days, but the idea that Charlotte could encourage him seemed as unlikely as she herself encouraging him. Therefore, she was so extremely surprised that she forgot all manners and couldn't help but exclaim:
tr: The possibility that Mr. Collins might think himself in love with her friend had crossed Elizabeth's mind in the last few days; but the idea that Charlotte would encourage him seemed as unlikely as her encouraging him herself; thus, the astonishment she felt was so great that it surpassed the bounds of etiquette, and she involuntarily exclaimed–
es: The possibility that Collins might believe himself in love with her friend had already occurred to Elizabeth one or two days before, but that Charlotte would encourage him seemed as impossible as if she herself would do it. Her astonishment, therefore, was so great that it exceeded all bounds of decorum and she could not refrain from shouting at her:

en: “Engaged to mr Collins! my dear Charlotte, impossible!”
vi: - Engaged to Mr. Collins! Dear Charlotte, that cannot be!
tr: "Are you engaged to Mr. Collins! Dear Charlotte, –impossible!"
es: ––Engaged to Mr. Collins! How is that possible, Charlotte?

en: The steady countenance which Miss Lucas had commanded in telling her story gave way to a momentary confusion here on receiving so direct a reproach; though, as it was no more than she expected, she soon regained her composure, and calmly replied,—
vi: The calm expression on Miss Lucas's face as she recounted her story gave way to confusion due to such a straightforward reaction, although it was not unexpected. But she quickly composed herself and replied:
tr: Miss Lucas's calm face while telling her story took on a temporary disheartenment when faced with such a direct reproach; however, it was not more than she had expected, so she quickly recovered and replied calmly–
es: Charlotte had told the story with much serenity, but now she felt momentarily confused for having received such a direct reproach; although it was what she had expected. But she recovered quickly and said calmly:

en: “Why should you be surprised, my dear Eliza?
vi: - Dear Elizabeth, why are you surprised?
tr: "Why are you surprised, dear Eliza?
es: ––What are you surprised about, Elizabeth?

en: Do you think it incredible that mr Collins should be able to procure any woman’s good opinion, because he was not so happy as to succeed with you?”
vi: Do you think it is unbelievable that Mr. Collins could win over another woman because he was not happy after failing to win you?
tr: –Do you think Mr. Collins cannot win any woman's favor just because he couldn't win yours?""
es: Does it seem incredible to you that Mr. Collins was able to gain the esteem of a woman just because he was not fortunate with you?

en: But Elizabeth had now recollected herself; and, making a strong effort for it, was able to assure her, with tolerable firmness, that the prospect of their relationship was highly grateful to her, and that she wished her all imaginable happiness.
vi: But Elizabeth had calmed down, trying her best to reassure her friend that she was very happy to see the prospect of a union between the two, and she wished them all happiness.
tr: But now Elizabeth had composed herself, and with a serious effort, she managed to convincingly assure Miss Lucas that she found their relationship very gratifying and wished her all the happiness imaginable.
es: But, in the meantime, Elizabeth had regained her composure, and with a tremendous effort, she was able to assure him with enough firmness that she was delighted by the idea of their kinship and wished him all the happiness in the world.

en: “I see what you are feeling,” replied Charlotte; “you must be surprised, very much surprised, so lately as mr Collins was wishing to marry you.
vi: Charlotte replied: - I understand what you are thinking. You must be surprised, very surprised to hear that Mr. Collins wants to marry me.
tr: "I understand how you feel," replied Charlotte, "you must be surprised, very surprised – just the other day Mr. Collins wanted to marry you.
es: ––I know how you feel ––replied Charlotte––. You must be surprised, very surprised, considering how little Mr. Collins wanted to marry you.

en: But when you have had time to think it all over, I hope you will be satisfied with what I have done.
vi: But when you have had time to think, I hope you will be satisfied with my decision.
tr: But when you have time to think it all over, I hope you will be as happy with my decision as I am.
es: But when you have had time to think it over, I hope you will understand what I have done.

en: I am not romantic, you know.
vi: I have never been imprudent, you know.
tr: You know I'm not romantic; I never have been.
es: You know I am not romantic.

en: I never was.
vi: I have never been imprudent, you know.
tr: You know I'm not romantic; I never have been.
es: I never have been.

en: I ask only a comfortable home; and, considering mr Collins’s character, connections, and situation in life, I am convinced that my chance of happiness with him is as fair as most people can boast on entering the marriage state.”
vi: I just want a comfortable home; and considering Mr. Collins' character, connections, and social status, I am confident that I will be happy with him, as most people entering into marriage can boast.
tr: All I want is a comfortable home; considering Mr. Collins' character, connections, and life circumstances, I believe my chances of being happy with him are as high as anyone entering into marriage could boast."
es: I seek nothing more than a comfortable home, and considering Collins' character, his connections, and his position, I am convinced that I have as much chance of being happy with him as most people have when they marry.

en: Elizabeth quietly answered “undoubtedly;” and, after an awkward pause, they returned to the rest of the family.
vi: Elizabeth replied gently: - Certainly. After a moment of confusion, both of them went back in with the family.
tr: Elizabeth calmly replied, "Undoubtedly," – and after an awkward silence, they returned to the other members of the family.
es: Elizabeth answered sweetly: ––It is undeniable. And after a somewhat awkward pause, they went to join the rest of the family.

en: Charlotte did not stay much longer; and Elizabeth was then left to reflect on what she had heard.
vi: Charlotte did not stay much longer, and Elizabeth had time to think about what she had heard.
tr: Charlotte did not stay long; Elizabeth was lost in thoughts about what she had heard.
es: Charlotte left immediately, and Elizabeth stayed behind, pondering what she had just heard.

en: It was a long time before she became at all reconciled to the idea of so unsuitable a match.
vi: It took her a while to come to terms with the idea of such an ill-matched marriage.
tr: It took her a long time to come to terms with the idea of such an inappropriate marriage.
es: It took her a long time to come to terms with such a ludicrous marriage.

en: The strangeness of mr Collins’s making two offers of marriage within three days was nothing in comparison of his being now accepted.
vi: That Mr. Collins proposed twice in three days was odd, but even odder was that he was accepted.
tr: The strangeness of Mr. Collins making two marriage proposals within three days was nothing compared to the fact that it had now been accepted.
es: The oddity of Collins having made two marriage proposals in three days was nothing compared to the fact that he had been accepted.

en: She had always felt that Charlotte’s opinion of matrimony was not exactly like her own; but she could not have supposed it possible that, when called into action, she would have sacrificed every better feeling to worldly advantage.
vi: She had always thought Charlotte's views on marriage were exactly like her own, but she could not imagine that when it came to a decision, her friend would sacrifice all feelings to gain worldly advantage.
tr: Elizabeth had always sensed that Charlotte's idea of marriage was quite different from her own, but she could never believe that all good feelings would be sacrificed for worldly comfort when it came to making a decision.
es: She always believed that Charlotte's theories about marriage were not exactly like hers, but she never supposed that in putting them into practice, she would sacrifice her best feelings to worldly matters.

en: Charlotte, the wife of mr Collins, was a most humiliating picture!
vi: Charlotte, the wife of Mr. Collins, was indeed a humiliating image!
tr: Charlotte, the wife of Mr. Collins, what a degrading picture!
es: She always believed that Charlotte's theories about marriage were not exactly like hers, but she never supposed that in putting them into practice, she would sacrifice her best feelings to worldly matters.

en: And to the pang of a friend disgracing herself, and sunk in her esteem, was added the distressing conviction that it was impossible for that friend to be tolerably happy in the lot she had chosen.
vi: In the pain of seeing a friend degrade herself and lose respect, there was also the sorrow from the certain thought that her friend could not be happy with the man she had chosen.
tr: –And to the pain of a friend who had diminished herself and fallen from grace was added the sorrow of knowing that this friend could not be truly happy in the life she had chosen.
es: And to the pain caused by seeing how her friend had discredited herself and lost much of the esteem she had for her, was added the distressing conviction that it would be impossible for her to be happy with the fate she had chosen.

en: CHAPTER XXIII.
vi: Chapter 23
tr: Chapter XXIII
es: CHAPTER XXIII

en: ELIZABETH was sitting with her mother and sisters, reflecting on what she had heard, and doubting whether she was authorized to mention it, when Sir William Lucas himself appeared, sent by his daughter to announce her engagement to the family.
vi: While Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and siblings, thinking about what she had heard and wondering if she was allowed to reveal this matter As it happened, Sir William Lucas appeared, having been sent by his daughter to announce her engagement.
tr: Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters, thinking about what she had heard and trying to decide whether she had the authority to explain it, when Sir William Lucas himself arrived; he had been sent by his daughter to inform the family of her engagement.
es: Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters, pondering over what she had heard and unsure whether to tell it or not, when Sir William Lucas himself appeared, sent by his daughter, to announce the engagement to the family.

en: With many compliments to them, and much self-gratulation on the prospect of a connection between the houses, he unfolded the matter,—to an audience not merely wondering, but incredulous; for ms Bennet, with more perseverance than politeness, protested he must be entirely mistaken; and Lydia, always unguarded and often uncivil, boisterously exclaimed,—
vi: With congratulations for them and greater self-satisfaction about an alliance between the two families, he proclaimed the news. Everyone was not only puzzled but also found it hard to believe. Out of stubbornness rather than politeness, Mrs. Bennet insisted that he must be mistaken. Lydia, always unreserved and seldom polite, exclaimed loudly:
tr: Due to the possibility of kinship between the families, he opened the matter with compliments to them and with pride in himself – to an audience that was not only astonished but also could not believe their ears; so much so that Mrs. Bennet, with an insistence that went beyond politeness, said he must be mistaken; and Lydia, who was always tactless and often behaved rudely, shouted at the top of her lungs–
es: Amid many compliments and congratulating the union of the two houses, he revealed the matter to an audience not only astonished but also incredulous, as Mrs. Bennet, with more obstinacy than courtesy, insisted that he must be completely mistaken, and Lydia, always indiscreet and often ill-mannered, exclaimed boisterously:

en: “Good Lord!
vi: - My God! Mr. Williams, how could you tell such a story?
tr: "My God!
es: ––Holy God!

en: Sir William, how can you tell such a story?
vi: - My God! Mr. Williams, how could you tell such a story?
tr: Sir William, how can you make up such a story?
es: What are you saying, Sir William?

en: Do not you know that mr Collins wants to marry Lizzy?”
vi: Do you know that Mr. Collins wants to marry Lizzy?
tr: Don't you know that Mr. Collins wants to marry Lizzy?"
es: Don't you know that Mr. Collins wants to marry Elizabeth?

en: Nothing less than the complaisance of a courtier could have borne without anger such treatment: but Sir William’s good-breeding carried him through it all; and though he begged leave to be positive as to the truth of his information, he listened to all their impertinence with the most forbearing courtesy.
vi: Only the magnanimity of a nobleman could restrain the anger from such a statement. But Sir William's good education helped him overcome it; and although he confirmed that the news was true, he still listened to all their insolence with the utmost polite forbearance.
tr: Nothing less than courtly politeness could endure this treatment without anger; but Sir William's manners enabled him to withstand it all; he did not consent to confirm the accuracy of the information he provided, but he listened to all their rudeness with very patient nobility.
es: Only the condescension of a courtier could have endured that behavior without getting angry; but Sir William's good manners were above all. He begged to be allowed to guarantee the truth of what he said, but he listened to all those impertinences with the utmost correctness.

en: Elizabeth, feeling it incumbent on her to relieve him from so unpleasant a situation, now put herself forward to confirm his account, by mentioning her prior knowledge of it from Charlotte herself; and endeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of her mother and sisters, by the earnestness of her congratulations to Sir William, in which she was readily joined by Jane, and by making a variety of remarks on the happiness that might be expected from the match, the excellent character of mr Collins, and the convenient distance of Hunsford from London.
vi: Elizabeth thought she needed to help him get out of the uncomfortable situation. She confirmed his words by recounting what she had heard Charlotte announce. She tried to end her mother's and sisters' complaints with warm congratulations to Sir William, which Jane also joined in, and with a few remarks about the happiness the union would bring, the excellent character of Mr. Collins, and the convenient distance between Hunsford and London.
tr: Feeling that it was her duty to rescue the poor man from such an awkward situation, Elizabeth stepped forward and confirmed the news by saying that Charlotte had previously informed her; in an effort to put an end to her mother and sisters' cries of astonishment, she warmly expressed her congratulations to Sir William; Jane immediately joined her and they spoke various words about the happiness promised by the marriage, Mr. Collins' wonderful character, and the proximity of Hunsford to London.
es: Elizabeth felt compelled to help him out of such an awkward situation, and confirmed his words, revealing what she knew from Charlotte herself. She tried to put an end to the exclamations of her mother and sisters warmly congratulating Sir William, in which she was soon seconded by Jane, and commenting on the happiness that could be expected from the event, given Mr. Collins's excellent character and the convenient distance from Hunsford to London.

en: ms Bennet was, in fact, too much overpowered to say a great deal while Sir William remained; but no sooner had he left them than her feelings found a rapid vent.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was too overwhelmed to say much in Sir William's presence; but as soon as he took his leave, she poured out her feelings.
tr: Mrs. Bennet was actually too overwhelmed to say much as long as Sir William was there; but as soon as he left, her emotions quickly poured out.
es: Mrs. Bennet was certainly too overwhelmed to speak much while Sir William remained in the house; but as soon as he left, she quickly vented.

en: In the first place, she persisted in disbelieving the whole of the matter; secondly, she was very sure that mr Collins had been taken in; thirdly, she trusted that they would never be happy together; and, fourthly, that the match might be broken off.
vi: First, she still stubbornly refused to believe the entire affair; second, she was convinced that Mr. Collins had been ensnared; third, she believed that the two would not be happy together; and fourth, the marriage could fall apart.
tr: First, she insisted on not believing the matter in the slightest; then, she decided that Mr. Collins had been deceived; next, she argued that they could never be happy together; finally, she said that the engagement could be broken off.
es: First, she insisted on not believing a word; second, she was sure that Collins had been deceived; third, she trusted that they would never be happy together; and fourth, the wedding would not take place.

en: Two inferences, however, were plainly deduced from the whole: one, that Elizabeth was the real cause of all the mischief; and the other, that she herself had been barbarously used by them all; and on these two points she principally dwelt during the rest of the day.
vi: However, she drew two conclusions: first, Elizabeth was the sole cause of all the turmoil; and second, she herself had been cruelly exploited by them. She carried these two points in her mind throughout the entire day.
tr: In fact, two things emerged from all she said: first, the root cause of all the abomination was Elizabeth; second, everyone had personally treated her, Mrs. Bennet, barbarically: she dwelled on these two points for the rest of the day.
es: However, two things clearly emerged from all this: that Elizabeth was the true cause of all the misfortune, and that she, Mrs. Bennet, had been treated in a barbaric manner by everyone.

en: Nothing could console and nothing appease her.
vi: Nothing could console her and nothing could reason with her.
tr: Nothing could calm her down or console her.
es: The rest of the day was spent ranting, and there was nothing that could console or calm her.

en: Nor did that day wear out her resentment.
vi: Her frustration did not subside in a day.
tr: Her grief did not end when the day ended.
es: The rest of the day was spent ranting, and there was nothing that could console or calm her.

en: A week elapsed before she could see Elizabeth without scolding her: a month passed away before she could speak to Sir William or Lady Lucas without being rude; and many months were gone before she could at all forgive their daughter.
vi: It took a week before she stopped scolding Elizabeth every time she saw her. It took a month before she could speak to Sir William or Mrs. Lucas without rudeness, and many months before she could forgive their daughter.
tr: It took a week for her to look at Elizabeth without scolding, a month to speak to Sir William or Lady Lucas without rudeness, and months to forgive her daughters.
es: A week had to pass before she could see Elizabeth without reprimanding her; a month, before she spoke to Sir William or Lady Lucas without being rude; and much longer, before she forgave Charlotte.

en: mr Bennet’s emotions were much more tranquil on the occasion, and such as he did experience he pronounced to be of a most agreeable sort; for it gratified him, he said, to discover that Charlotte Lucas, whom he had been used to think tolerably sensible, was as foolish as his wife, and more foolish than his daughter!
vi: Mr. Bennet was more composed, as this matter amused him to see Charlotte Lucas, whom he had thought to have quite a bit of judgment, turn out to be as foolish as his wife, and even more foolish than his own daughter!
tr: Mr. Bennet's feelings on the matter were much more subdued; as far as he could see, it was quite a reasonable situation; he said that it pleased him to see that Charlotte Lucas, whom he thought to be a sensible person, was as foolish as his wife and even more foolish than his daughter!
es: Mr. Bennet's mood upon hearing the news was calmer; moreover, he was even pleased, because in this way he could confirm, as he said, that Charlotte Lucas, whom he never considered very smart, was as foolish as his wife, and much more so than his daughter.

en: Jane confessed herself a little surprised at the match: but she said less of her astonishment than of her earnest desire for their happiness; nor could Elizabeth persuade her to consider it as improbable.
vi: In her heart, Jane was somewhat surprised by the marriage, but she spoke more about her wishes for the couple's happiness than about her own surprise; and Elizabeth could not convince her sister that this could not happen.
tr: Jane admitted that she was a bit surprised by the engagement; but she spoke of her sincere wishes for their happiness rather than her astonishment; even Elizabeth could not convince her to find the matter impossible.
es: Jane confessed that she had been surprised; but she spoke less of her astonishment than of her sincere wishes that both would be happy, not even Elizabeth managed to make her see that such happiness was unlikely.

en: Kitty and Lydia were far from envying Miss Lucas, for mr Collins was only a clergyman; and it affected them in no other way than as a piece of news to spread at Meryton.
vi: Kitty and Lydia had nothing to envy Miss Lucas for, as Mr. Collins was merely a clergyman; this marriage only served as gossip material for them in Meryton.
tr: Kitty and Lydia were far from being jealous of Miss Lucas, because Mr. Collins was just a clergyman; the matter only interested them as a morsel of news to spread in Meryton.
es: Catherine and Lydia were far from envying Miss Lucas, for Collins was nothing more than a clergyman and the event held no more interest for them than that of being able to spread it around Meryton.

en: Lady Lucas could not be insensible of triumph on being able to retort on ms Bennet the comfort of having a daughter well married; and she called at Longbourn rather oftener than usual to say how happy she was, though ms Bennet’s sour looks and ill-natured remarks might have been enough to drive happiness away.
vi: Lady Lucas could not avoid feeling a sense of triumph when she retaliated against Mrs. Bennet by having her daughter secure a good marriage. She visited Longbourn more frequently than before to express her joy, even though the bitter looks and nasty remarks should have been strong enough to dispel her happiness.
tr: Lady Lucas did not refrain from savoring the feeling of triumph by rubbing in Mrs. Bennet's face the pleasure of her daughter's good marriage; she visited Longbourn more frequently than ever to say how happy she was, even though Mrs. Bennet's sour looks and grumpy replies were enough to destroy her happiness.
es: Lady Lucas could not resist the joy of being able to get back at Mrs. Bennet by expressing the comfort she felt in having a married daughter; she went to Longbourn more frequently than usual to tell how happy she was, although Mrs. Bennet's unfriendly looks and malicious comments could have ended all that happiness.

en: Between Elizabeth and Charlotte there was a restraint which kept them mutually silent on the subject; and Elizabeth felt persuaded that no real confidence could ever subsist between them again.
vi: Elizabeth and Charlotte showed restraint, causing both to remain silent about the matter; Elizabeth, in particular, realized that they could no longer share intimate thoughts with each other.
tr: There was a tension between Elizabeth and Charlotte that kept both of them silent on the subject; Elizabeth felt that there could never be true trust between them again.
es: Between Elizabeth and Charlotte, there was a barrier that made them remain silent on the subject, and Elizabeth had the impression that true trust would never exist between them again.

en: Her disappointment in Charlotte made her turn with fonder regard to her sister, of whose rectitude and delicacy she was sure her opinion could never be shaken, and for whose happiness she grew daily more anxious, as Bingley had now been gone a week, and nothing was heard of his return.
vi: The disappointment in Charlotte made her turn back to feeling compassion for her sister. Her thoughts on her sister's propriety and sensitivity had not changed; she grew increasingly worried about her sister's happiness, as Mr. Bingley had been gone for a week without any news.
tr: The disappointment regarding Charlotte made her look at her sister with more affection; she was certain that her views on her sister's honesty and taste would never be shaken, and she worried more and more each day for her sister's happiness, as it had been a week since Bingley had left and there was no news of his return.
es: The disappointment she had felt from Charlotte made her turn to her sister with more affection and admiration than ever; her sister's integrity and delicacy guaranteed that her opinion of her would never change, and her happiness concerned her more each day, as it had been a week since Bingley had left and nothing was known about his return.

en: Jane had sent Caroline an early answer to her letter, and was counting the days till she might reasonably hope to hear again.
vi: Jane sent a reply letter to Caroline, waiting each day to receive more news.
tr: Jane had immediately replied to Caroline's letter and was waiting for the time to pass so she could hope to receive another letter.
es: Jane immediately replied to Caroline Bingley's letter, and she was calculating the days it might take to receive the response.

en: The promised letter of thanks from mr Collins arrived on Tuesday, addressed to their father, and written with all the solemnity of gratitude which a twelve-month’s abode in the family might have prompted.
vi: The thank-you letter that Mr. Collins had promised arrived on the third day, signed by his father, expressing gratitude as if he had stayed with them for the past 12 months.
tr: The promised thank-you letter from Mr. Collins arrived on Tuesday; it was addressed to their father and written with a serious gratitude as if he had stayed with the family for twelve months.
es: The promised letter from Collins arrived on Tuesday, addressed to the father and written with all the solemnity of gratitude that only a year of living with the family could have justified.

en: After discharging his conscience on that head, he proceeded to inform them, with many rapturous expressions, of his happiness in having obtained the affection of their amiable neighbour, Miss Lucas, and then explained that it was merely with the view of enjoying her society that he had been so ready to close with their kind wish of seeing him again at Longbourn, whither he hoped to be able to return on Monday fortnight; for Lady Catherine, he added, so heartily approved his marriage, that she wished it to take place as soon as possible, which he trusted would be an unanswerable argument with his amiable Charlotte to name an early day for making him the happiest of men.
vi: After settling his conscience on this matter, with fervent words he continued to write about his happiness at being favored by their charming neighbor, Miss Lucas. He explained that it was only because he wanted to be near her that he would accept their kind wish to see him again at Longbourn. He hoped to return the following Monday, as Lady Catherine had warmly approved the marriage and wished for it to proceed as soon as possible, so he believed his dear Charlotte would agree to set a date so that he could soon become the happiest young man.
tr: Thus, after easing his conscience, he expressed with enthusiastic words the happiness he felt from having won the heart of their dear neighbor Miss Lucas, and then explained that he was ready to accept the kind invitation they had extended to him, solely with the aim of seeing her again, hoping to return the following Monday; Lady Catherine, he continued, had so wholeheartedly approved of his marriage that she wanted it to be completed as soon as possible, and he believed that his dear Charlotte would have no objection to choosing an earlier day to make him the happiest man in the world.
es: After apologizing at the beginning, he proceeded to inform him, with much grandiloquence, of his happiness for having obtained the affection of his charming neighbor Miss Lucas, and then expressed that it was only with the intention of enjoying her company that he had felt so inclined to accede to their kind wishes to see him again in Longbourn, where he hoped to return on Monday in a fortnight; for Lady Catherine, he added, so cordially approved of his marriage that she wished it to be celebrated as soon as possible, something he trusted would be an irrefutable argument for his dear Charlotte to set the day when she would make him the happiest of men.

en: mr Collins’s return into Hertfordshire was no longer a matter of pleasure to ms Bennet.
vi: Mr. Collins's return to Hertfordshire was no longer a joy for Mrs. Bennet.
tr: Mr. Collins's return to Hertfordshire was no longer a source of pleasure for Mrs. Bennet.
es: Mrs. Bennet no longer found Collins's return to Hertfordshire a cause for satisfaction.

en: On the contrary, she was as much disposed to complain of it as her husband.
vi: On the contrary, she constantly complained just like he did.
tr: On the contrary, she began to complain about it like her husband.
es: On the contrary, she deplored it more than her husband: "It was very odd that Collins came to Longbourn instead of going to the Lucas's house; it was very inconvenient and extremely embarrassing.

en: It was very strange that he should come to Longbourn instead of to Lucas Lodge; it was also very inconvenient and exceedingly troublesome.
vi: It was strange, inconvenient, and extremely bothersome that he came to Longbourn instead of Lucas Lodge.
tr: –It was very strange for him to come to Longbourn instead of going to Lucas Lodge; moreover, it was very inappropriate and extremely inconvenient.
es: On the contrary, she deplored it more than her husband: "It was very odd that Collins came to Longbourn instead of going to the Lucas's house; it was very inconvenient and extremely embarrassing.

en: She hated having visitors in the house while her health was so indifferent, and lovers were of all people the most disagreeable.
vi: She hated having guests in the house when her health was not good, and she found that among humanity, those in love were the hardest to endure.
tr: –She hated having a guest at home when her health was so fickle; besides, lovers were the most irritable people in the world.
es: She hated having visitors given her poor health, and engaged couples were the most unbearable beings in the world."

en: Such were the gentle murmurs of ms Bennet, and they gave way only to the greater distress of mr Bingley’s continued absence.
vi: These were her whispered complaints, made even more miserable by Mr. Bingley's prolonged absence.
tr: Thus Mrs. Bennet murmured her complaints, and her grumbling was only subdued by the greater distress caused by Mr. Bingley's prolonged absence.
es: These were Mrs. Bennet's constant murmurs, which only ceased in the face of an even greater distress: Mr. Bingley's long absence.

en: Neither Jane nor Elizabeth were comfortable on this subject.
vi: Both Jane and Elizabeth felt uneasy about this absence.
tr: Neither Jane nor Elizabeth were comfortable about this.
es: Neither Jane nor Elizabeth were calm about this matter.

en: Day after day passed away without bringing any other tidings of him than the report which shortly prevailed in Meryton of his coming no more to Netherfield the whole winter; a report which highly incensed ms Bennet, and which she never failed to contradict as a most scandalous falsehood.
vi: Each day passed without any encouraging news about him, except for the rumor at Netherfields that he would not return throughout the winter. Mrs. Bennet was extremely angry about this news, constantly refuting it as the most malicious falsehood.
tr: Days chased days without bringing any news from him; only a rumor emerged in Meryton that he would not come to Netherfield again throughout the winter; this rumor drove Mrs. Bennet mad, she ranted that such a lie could not be.
es: The days passed without any more news except for what soon spread through Meryton: that the Bingleys would not return for the entire winter. Mrs. Bennet was indignant and did not stop denying it, asserting that it was the most atrocious falsehood one could hear.

en: Even Elizabeth began to fear—not that Bingley was indifferent—but that his sisters would be successful in keeping him away.
vi: Even Elizabeth had begun to fear – not that Mr. Bingley was indifferent – but that his sisters might have succeeded in keeping him away.
tr: Elizabeth even began to fear—not that Bingley was indifferent—but that his sisters would succeed in keeping him away.
es: Even Elizabeth began to fear, not that Bingley had forgotten Jane, but that his sisters might succeed in separating him from her.

en: Unwilling as she was to admit an idea so destructive to Jane’s happiness, and so dishonourable to the stability of her lover, she could not prevent its frequently recurring.
vi: Even though she did not want to accept such a harmful idea for Jane's happiness and such a disgraceful one for her sister's suitor's constancy, the idea still lingered in her mind.
tr: Though she was unwilling to accept the idea, which would be so destructive to Jane's happiness and damaging to her lover's reliability, she could not prevent it from frequently arising.
es: Despite not wanting to admit such a disastrous idea for Jane's happiness and so unworthy of her lover's firmness, Elizabeth could not help but frequently think of it.

en: The united efforts of his two unfeeling sisters, and of his overpowering friend, assisted by the attractions of Miss Darcy and the amusements of London, might be too much, she feared, for the strength of his attachment.
vi: She feared that the unfeeling efforts of the two sisters and the strong-willed friend, along with the charming allure of Miss Darcy and the pleasures of London, might exceed the strength of his affections.
tr: She feared that the combined efforts of Bingley's two unfeeling sisters and his discouraging friend, along with the allure of Miss Darcy and the entertainments of London, might overpower the strength of his attachment.
es: She feared that the combined effort of his heartless sisters and his influential friend, along with the attractions of Miss Darcy and the pleasures of London, could be too many things at once against Bingley's affection.

en: As for Jane, her anxiety under this suspense was, of course, more painful than Elizabeth’s: but whatever she felt she was desirous of concealing; and between herself and Elizabeth, therefore, the subject was never alluded to.
vi: As for Jane, her anxiety in uncertainty was even more painful than the fear in Elizabeth. But no matter what she thought, she still wanted to hide it, so she and Elizabeth never brought up the issue.
tr: When it came to Jane, her fear under this uncertainty was, of course, more painful than Elizabeth's; but she wished to conceal her feelings; therefore, the subject was never touched upon between her and Elizabeth.
es: As for Jane, the anxiety that this doubt caused her was, naturally, more painful than Elizabeth's; but no matter what she felt, she wanted to hide it, and therefore the matter was never mentioned between her and her sister.

en: But as no such delicacy restrained her mother, an hour seldom passed in which she did not talk of Bingley, express her impatience for his arrival, or even require Jane to confess that if he did not come back she should think herself very ill-used.
vi: However, such delicacy could not restrain their mother. Not an hour passed without her mentioning Mr. Bingley, expressing eagerness to see him return, or even forcing Jane to acknowledge that if he did not come back, she should consider herself used.
tr: But since such sensitivity did not affect her mother, not an hour passed without her mentioning Bingley, expressing her impatience for his return, or even pressing Jane to admit that she would feel deceived if he did not come back.
es: Her mother, however, was not restrained by the same delicacy and not an hour passed without her talking about Bingley, expressing her impatience for his arrival or insisting that Jane confess that if he did not return, they would have been treated in the most indecorous manner.

en: It needed all Jane’s steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable tranquillity.
vi: Jane had to muster all her gentle firmness to calmly withstand these attacks.
tr: Jane had to use all her gentleness to remain calm in the face of these attacks.
es: It took all of Jane's gentleness to endure these attacks with tolerable calmness.

en: mr Collins returned most punctually on the Monday fortnight, but his reception at Longbourn was not quite so gracious as it had been on his first introduction.
vi: Mr. Collins returned on Monday as announced, but Longbourn did not welcome him as warmly as the first time.
tr: Mr. Collins returned the next Monday as he had said, but this time he was not received with the same attention at Longbourn as during his first visit.
es: Collins returned promptly on Monday in fifteen days; the reception he received at Longbourn was not as cordial as the first time.

en: He was too happy, however, to need much attention; and, luckily for the others, the business of love-making relieved them from a great deal of his company.
vi: However, he was too delighted to feel the need for much attention, and fortunately for the others, his preoccupations with seeking love spared them from the burden of his close presence.
tr: However, he was too happy to seek much attention; and fortunately for the others, the courtship business largely spared them from having to endure Mr. Collins.
es: But the man was too happy for anything to affect him, and fortunately for everyone, he was so busy with his courtship that they were free of his company for much of the time.

en: The chief of every day was spent by him at Lucas Lodge, and he sometimes returned to Longbourn only in time to make an apology for his absence before the family went to bed.
vi: He spent most of each day at Lucas Lodge; sometimes he returned to Longbourn only to apologize for his absence before the household went to bed.
tr: Mr. Collins spent most of each day at Lucas Lodge and sometimes returned to Longbourn so late that he barely had time to apologize for his absence before the family went to bed.
es: He spent most of the day at the Lucas house, and sometimes returned to Longbourn just in time to excuse his absence before the family went to bed.

en: “Whenever she spoke in a low voice”
vi: He spent most of each day at Lucas Lodge; sometimes he returned to Longbourn only to apologize for his absence before the household went to bed.
tr: Mr. Collins spent most of each day at Lucas Lodge and sometimes returned to Longbourn so late that he barely had time to apologize for his absence before the family went to bed.
es: He spent most of the day at the Lucas house, and sometimes returned to Longbourn just in time to excuse his absence before the family went to bed.

en: ms Bennet was really in a most pitiable state.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was truly in the most pitiable situation.
tr: Mrs Bennet was truly in a pitiable state.
es: Mrs. Bennet was truly in a lamentable state.

en: The very mention of anything concerning the match threw her into an agony of ill-humour, and wherever she went she was sure of hearing it talked of.
vi: Just a mention of the marriage was enough to cause her agony, and wherever she went, she heard talk of it.
tr: Every mention of marriage left her in agony, and wherever she went, she inevitably heard it being talked about.
es: The mere mention of anything concerning the wedding would put her in a bad mood, and wherever she went, she could be sure to hear about the event.

en: The sight of Miss Lucas was odious to her.
vi: She loathed the presence of Miss Lucas, who would inherit the house.
tr: Even seeing Miss Lucas was repulsive to her.
es: Seeing Miss Lucas unsettled her.

en: As her successor in that house, she regarded her with jealous abhorrence.
vi: She loathed the presence of Miss Lucas, who would inherit the house.
tr: She watched her with jealous disgust as her successor in that house.
es: She looked at her with horror and jealousy, imagining her as her successor in that house.

en: Whenever Charlotte came to see them, she concluded her to be anticipating the hour of possession; and whenever she spoke in a low voice to mr Collins, was convinced that they were talking of the Longbourn estate, and resolving to turn herself and her daughters out of the house as soon as mr Bennet was dead.
vi: Whenever Charlotte visited, she thought she was preparing to take over the house; whenever she whispered with Mr. Collins, she believed they were discussing the Longbourn estate, determined to expel her and her daughters from the house as soon as Mr. Bennet passed away.
tr: Whenever Charlotte came to visit them, she was convinced that she was calculating when she would move in; whenever she whispered with Mr. Collins, she believed they were talking about the Longbourn estate and had decided to evict her and her daughters from the house as soon as Mr. Bennet died.
es: Whenever Charlotte came to visit them, Mrs. Bennet concluded that she was anticipating the time of taking possession, and every time she whispered something to Collins, she was convinced they were talking about the inheritance of Longbourn and planning to throw her and her daughters out as soon as Mr. Bennet passed away.

en: She complained bitterly of all this to her husband.
vi: She bitterly complained about this to her husband.
tr: She bitterly complained about all this to her husband.
es: She complained about it bitterly to her husband.

en: “Indeed, mr Bennet,” said she, “it is very hard to think that Charlotte Lucas should ever be mistress of this house, that I should be forced to make way for her, and live to see her take my place in it!”
vi: - Actually, sir, it is hard to believe that Charlotte Lucas would become the mistress of this house, that I would have to give up my place to her, and then live to see her take over my position.
tr: "Really, Mr. Bennet," she was saying, "it's very hard for me to think that Charlotte Lucas will be the mistress of this house; it's very hard for me to think that they will force me to give my home to her, that she will come and take my place!"
es: ––The truth is, Mr. Bennet ––she said to him––, it is very hard to think that Charlotte Lucas will one day be the mistress of this house, and that I will be forced to yield my place to her and live seeing her in my position.

en: “My dear, do not give way to such gloomy thoughts.
vi: - Ma'am, you shouldn't harbor such dark thoughts.
tr: "My dear, don't succumb to such sorrowful thoughts.
es: ––Dear, don't think about sad things.

en: Let us hope for better things.
vi: We should hope for better things.
tr: Let's hope for better things.
es: Let's have hope for better things.

en: Let us flatter ourselves that I may be the survivor.”
vi: We should boast that I might be the one who survives.
tr: For instance, let's do ourselves a favor and think that the one who survives will be me."
es: Let's cheer up with the idea that I can outlive you.

en: This was not very consoling to ms Bennet; and, therefore, instead of making any answer, she went on as before.
vi: This did not appease Mrs. Bennet, so instead of replying, she continued:
tr: These did not comfort Mrs. Bennet; therefore, instead of replying, she continued as she knew best.
es: It was not very comforting, to say the least, for Mrs. Bennet; however, instead of replying, she continued:

en: “I cannot bear to think that they should have all this estate.
vi: - I can't bear the thought that they will take all of this property.
tr: "I can't bear the thought of them taking all this property.
es: ––I can't bear the thought of them becoming the owners of all this property.

en: If it was not for the entail, I should not mind it.”
vi: If it weren't for the inheritance, I wouldn't care at all.
tr: If it weren't for the mortgage, I wouldn't care at all."
es: If it weren't for the inheritance, I wouldn't care.

en: “What should not you mind?”
vi: - She doesn't care about anything?
tr: "Wouldn't it be in his lifetime?"
es: ––What is it that you couldn't care less about?

en: “I should not mind anything at all.”
vi: - I don't care about anything.
tr: "I wouldn't care about anything."
es: ––I wouldn't care about absolutely anything.

en: “Let us be thankful that you are preserved from a state of such insensibility.”
vi: - Grandma, if you are as healthy as that, then we should be happy.
tr: "Then let's be glad that you don't have to be subjected to such insensitivity.""
es: ––Let's give thanks, then, that they save you from such a state of insensitivity.

en: “I never can be thankful, mr Bennet, for anything about the entail.
vi: - I never rejoice over an inheritance.
tr: "I cannot be pleased with anything regarding the mortgage, Mr. Bennet.
es: ––I will never be able to give thanks for anything related to the inheritance.

en: How anyone could have the conscience to entail away an estate from one’s own daughters I cannot understand; and all for the sake of mr Collins, too!
vi: How can a person with a conscience want to inherit and take away the property of their own daughters is something I cannot understand, all because of Mr. Collins.
tr: How can one, in good conscience, leave a house to anyone other than their own daughters, I do not understand; especially to Mr. Collins – Why should he get it and not someone else?"
es: I will never understand how someone can have a clear conscience disinheriting their own daughters. And to top it off, the heir has to be Mr. Collins!

en: Why should he have it more than anybody else?”
vi: Why does he get more than others?
tr: How can one, in good conscience, leave a house to anyone other than their own daughters, I do not understand; especially to Mr. Collins – Why should he get it and not someone else?"
es: Why him, and not anyone else?

en: “I leave it to yourself to determine,” said mr Bennet.
vi: - I will leave it to you to answer.
tr: "The decision is up to you," said Mr. Bennet.
es: ––I leave it to your own consideration.

en: CHAPTER XXIV.
vi: Chapter 24
tr: Second Book Chapter I
es: CHAPTER XXIV

en: MISS BINGLEY’S letter arrived, and put an end to doubt.
vi: Miss Bingley's letter ended all doubts.
tr: Miss Bingley's letter arrived and put an end to the doubt.
es: The letter from Miss Bingley arrived and put an end to all doubts.

en: The very first sentence conveyed the assurance of their being all settled in London for the winter, and concluded with her brother’s regret at not having had time to pay his respects to his friends in Hertfordshire before he left the country.
vi: In the very first sentence, she confirmed that they would stay in London, and the concluding sentence expressed that her brother regretted not having had the time to visit his friends in Hertfordshire before leaving.
tr: The first sentence confirmed that they had settled in London for the winter and ended by saying how sorry her brother was for leaving without finding time to say goodbye to his friends in Hertfordshire.
es: The first sentence already conveyed that everyone had settled in London for the winter, and at the end, it expressed the brother's regret for not having had time, before leaving the countryside, to pay his respects to his friends in Hertfordshire.

en: Hope was over, entirely over; and when Jane could attend to the rest of the letter, she found little, except the professed affection of the writer, that could give her any comfort.
vi: Hope had vanished, completely vanished. When Jane read the rest of the letter, she found little more to comfort her, except for the affection the writer had wished to express.
tr: Hope was gone, completely gone; when Jane could look at the rest of the letter, she found little to comfort her besides the author's supposed affection.
es: There was no hope, it had completely vanished. Jane continued reading, but found few things, aside from the expressions of affection from her author, that could provide her any relief.

en: Miss Darcy’s praise occupied the chief of it.
vi: The letter praised Miss Darcy a lot, about her attractive features.
tr: A large part of the letter was devoted to praising Miss Darcy.
es: The rest of the letter was almost entirely dedicated to praising Miss Darcy.

en: Her many attractions were again dwelt on; and Caroline boasted joyfully of their increasing intimacy, and ventured to predict the accomplishment of the wishes which had been unfolded in her former letter.
vi: Caroline cheerfully talked about the growing bond between the two, predicting that the hopes mentioned in the previous letter might come true.
tr: Again, many virtues were emphasized; Caroline, boasting joyfully of their increasing closeness, ventured to predict that the wishes expressed in her previous letter would come true.
es: It insisted again on her many charms, and Caroline boasted very happily about her growing intimacy with her, venturing to predict the fulfillment of the wishes she had already expressed in the first letter.

en: She wrote also with great pleasure of her brother’s being an inmate of mr Darcy’s house, and mentioned with raptures some plans of the latter with regard to new furniture.
vi: She enthusiastically wrote about her brother becoming close with the Darcy family, excitedly mentioning some issues regarding the interior upgrades in this family.
tr: Once more, she wrote with great pleasure that her brother was staying at Mr. Darcy's house and spoke enthusiastically about Mr. Darcy's plans to buy new furniture.
es: She also joyfully recounted that her brother was close to the Darcy family, and enthusiastically mentioned certain plans of the latter, related to the new furniture.

en: Elizabeth, to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this, heard it in silent indignation.
vi: Elizabeth listened to this in silent disdain.
tr: Jane summarized the letter to Elizabeth shortly after; Elizabeth listened to it in silent fury.
es: Elizabeth, to whom Jane immediately communicated the most important parts of the news, listened in silence and with great indignation.

en: Her heart was divided between concern for her sister and resentment against all others.
vi: Her mind was torn between worry for her sister and resentment towards everyone else.
tr: Her heart was divided between the concern she felt for her sister and the anger she felt towards the others.
es: Her heart wavered between concern for her sister and hatred for everyone else.

en: To Caroline’s assertion of her brother’s being partial to Miss Darcy, she paid no credit.
vi: She did not believe Caroline's words about her brother falling for Miss Darcy.
tr: She did not believe Caroline's claim that her brother was interested in Miss Darcy.
es: She did not believe Caroline's assertion that her brother was interested in Miss Darcy.

en: That he was really fond of Jane, she doubted no more than she had ever done; and much as she had always been disposed to like him, she could not think without anger, hardly without contempt, on that easiness of temper, that want of proper resolution, which now made him the slave of his designing friends, and led him to sacrifice his own happiness to the caprice of their inclinations.
vi: She did not doubt that he genuinely admired Jane. Although she always liked him, she could not help but feel a mix of anger and slight contempt for such an easy-going nature, for the lack of decisiveness that made him a slave to his scheming relatives, causing him to sacrifice his own happiness to please them.
tr: She still did not doubt that Jane genuinely felt close to her; although she had always been inclined to like Mr. Bingley, she could not think of the weakness, that indecisiveness that made him a slave to his meddlesome friends and caused him to sacrifice his own happiness to their spoiled preferences, without feeling anger, even hatred.
es: She never doubted, as she had never doubted before, that Bingley was in love with Jane; but Elizabeth, who had always had so much sympathy for him, could not think without anger, and even without contempt, of that weakness of character and lack of decision that made him a slave to his scheming friends and led him to sacrifice his own happiness to the whims of their desires.

en: Had his own happiness, however, been the only sacrifice, he might have been allowed to sport with it in whatever manner he thought best; but her sister’s was involved in it, as she thought he must be sensible himself.
vi: However, if his happiness was the only sacrifice, he could be allowed to be generous in the way he thought best; but since this involved her sister, she thought he ought to have been more sensitive.
tr: Moreover, if only his own happiness were being sacrificed, no one could object to him doing as he pleased, but her sister's happiness was also at stake, and he needed to consider that.
es: If he were only sacrificing his own happiness, he could play with it as he pleased; but it also involved Jane's happiness, and she thought he should take that into account.

en: It was a subject, in short, on which reflection would be long indulged, and must be unavailing.
vi: This was what troubled her; she could think of nothing else.
tr: In short, the matter was not something that could be resolved by thinking.
es: In the end, it was one of those things that it is useless to break one's head over.

en: She could think of nothing else; and yet, whether Bingley’s regard had really died away, or were suppressed by his friends’ interference; whether he had been aware of Jane’s attachment, or whether it had escaped his observation; whichever were the case, though her opinion of him must be materially affected by the difference, her sister’s situation remained the same, her peace equally wounded.
vi: Yet whether his feelings had faded or were suppressed by the interference of others, whether he could understand that Jane loved him or he did not recognize this affection, in any case—though her opinion of him varied accordingly, her sister's situation remained the same, her own peace was equally disturbed.
tr: Elizabeth could think of nothing else; had Bingley's interest truly waned, or was it suppressed by his friends' interference, was he aware of Jane's attachment or had it escaped his notice; whatever the answer, although her opinion of Bingley would change significantly depending on the answer, her sister's situation remained the same, and her own peace of mind was equally damaged.
es: Elizabeth could think of nothing else; and whether Bingley's interest had truly died, or had been hindered by the interference of his friends; whether Bingley was aware of Jane's affection, or it had gone unnoticed by him; in any case, and although Elizabeth's opinion of Bingley might vary depending on the differences, Jane's situation remained the same and her peace had been disturbed.

en: A day or two passed before Jane had courage to speak of her feelings to Elizabeth; but at last, on ms Bennet’s leaving them together, after a longer irritation than usual about Netherfield and its master, she could not help saying,—
vi: After a few days and only when the Bennet family allowed the two to be alone following a series of frustrations about Netherfield, Jane finally had the courage to confide in Elizabeth.
tr: A few days passed before Jane could find the strength to talk about her feelings to Elizabeth; but finally, after Mrs. Bennet left them alone and following an unusually long discomfort regarding Netherfield and its owner, Jane couldn't hold back and said,
es: A day or two passed before Jane had the courage to confess her feelings to her sister; but finally, in a moment when Mrs. Bennet had left them alone after becoming more irritated than usual with the subject of Netherfield and its owner, the young woman could not resist and exclaimed:

en: “O that my dear mother had more command over herself!
vi: - Ah!
tr: "If only my mother could manage herself a little!
es: ––If my dear mother had more self-control!

en: she can have no idea of the pain she gives me by her continual reflections on him.
vi: The fact that our mother couldn't keep her composure, she doesn't understand that she has caused you so much pain by constantly bringing him up.
tr: She doesn't know how much she hurts me by constantly talking about her.
es: You cannot imagine how much her constant comments about Mr. Bingley hurt me.

en: But I will not repine.
vi: But you won't be upset.
tr: But I won't let it bother me.
es: But I will not be sad.

en: It cannot last long.
vi: It won't last long, you will forget him and we will go back to how we were before.
tr: It won't last long anyway.
es: It cannot last long.

en: He will be forgot, and we shall all be as we were before.”
vi: It won't last long, you will forget him and we will go back to how we were before.
tr: I will forget her and we will all be as we were before."
es: I will forget it and we will all be as we were before.

en: Elizabeth looked at her sister with incredulous solicitude, but said nothing.
vi: Elizabeth looked at her sister with incredible concern, but said nothing.
tr: Elizabeth looked at her sister with a suspicious concern, but said nothing.
es: Elizabeth, solicitous and incredulous, looked at her sister, but said nothing.

en: “You doubt me,” cried Jane, slightly colouring; “indeed, you have no reason.
vi: Jane exclaimed, her face slightly flushed: - I suspect you; in fact, I have no reason to suspect you.
tr: "You don't believe me," cried Jane, her color slightly changing, "but there is no reason for you not to believe.
es: ––Do you doubt it? ––asked Jane, slightly blushing––. You have no reason to.

en: He may live in my memory as the most amiable man of my acquaintance but that is all.
vi: He may reign in your thoughts as the most charming person among those you know, but that's all.
tr: He may live in my memories as the nicest man I have known, but that's all.
es: I will always remember him as the best man I have ever known, that's all.

en: I have nothing either to hope or fear, and nothing to reproach him with.
vi: You have nothing to hope for or worry about, and nothing to blame him for.
tr: I have nothing to hope for or fear, and nothing that requires me to condemn him.
es: I have nothing to hope for nor to fear, and I have nothing to reproach him for.

en: Thank God I have not that pain.
vi: Thank God! You haven't felt such pain.
tr: Thank goodness! I don't suffer that kind of pain.
es: Thank God, I am spared that sorrow.

en: A little time, therefore—I shall certainly try to get the better——”
vi: Just a short time, and you will feel better.
tr: So a little time will be enough. –Of course, I will try to get better."
es: So, in a short time, I will be much better.

en: With a stronger voice she soon added, “I have this comfort immediately, that it has not been more than an error of fancy on my side, and that it has done no harm to anyone but myself.”
vi: Raising her voice, she added: - You have the immediate consolation that all of this is due to your small share of arbitrariness, but this does not harm anyone except yourself.
tr: Immediately after, he added in a stronger voice, "In this respect, I am at ease; from my perspective, it was merely a mistake of imagination, and it harmed no one but myself."
es: In a louder voice, he added afterwards: ––I have the consolation of thinking that it was nothing more than an error of imagination on my part and that it has harmed no one but myself.

en: “My dear Jane,” exclaimed Elizabeth, “you are too good.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - Sister Jane!
tr: "Dear Jane!" cried Elizabeth, "you are so good.
es: ––Dear Jane! ––exclaimed Elizabeth––. You are too good.

en: Your sweetness and disinterestedness are really angelic; I do not know what to say to you.
vi: You are so kind. You are gentle and carefree like an angel. I don't know how to express this to you.
tr: Your sweetness and nobility are truly worthy of angels; I don't know what else to say to you.
es: Your sweetness and selflessness are truly angelic. I don't know what to say to you.

en: I feel as if I had never done you justice, or loved you as you deserve.”
vi: I feel that I have misunderstood you, or have not loved you as you deserve to be loved.
tr: I feel like I have never treated you fairly or loved you as much as you deserve."
es: I feel as if I have never done you justice, or as if I have not loved you as much as you deserve.

en: Miss Bennet eagerly disclaimed all extraordinary merit, and threw back the praise on her sister’s warm affection.
vi: Jane refused to accept any compliments and instead complimented her sister.
tr: Miss Bennet persistently denied all these extraordinary qualities and attributed the praise to her sister's kindness.
es: Jane vehemently denied having any extraordinary merit and rejected her sister's praises, which were only a product of her great affection.

en: “Nay,” said Elizabeth, “this is not fair.
vi: Elizabeth said: - No, that's not fair at all.
tr: "No," said Elizabeth, "this is not fair.
es: ––No ––said Elizabeth––, that is not right.

en: You wish to think all the world respectable, and are hurt if I speak ill of anybody.
vi: You want to think well of everyone and feel hurt if I think badly of someone.
tr: You want to believe that the whole world is moral, and you get hurt when I speak ill of someone.
es: Everyone seems respectable to you and you get offended if I speak ill of someone.

en: I only want to think you perfect, and you set yourself against it.
vi: I just want to think of you as a perfect person, but you have denied it.
tr: I just want to think that you are perfect, and you object to this.
es: You are the only one I find perfect and you don't want me to tell you that either.

en: Do not be afraid of my running into any excess, of my encroaching on your privilege of universal good-will.
vi: Don't worry that I will go astray, or that I will infringe on your privilege of goodwill.
tr: Do not fear my going to extremes, my getting too caught up in your absolute goodwill.
es: Do not fear that I will exceed by appropriating your privilege of universal kindness.

en: You need not.
vi: You don't have to worry.
tr: There is no need.
es: There is no danger.

en: There are few people whom I really love, and still fewer of whom I think well.
vi: The number of people I truly care about is very few; the number of people I think well of is even fewer.
tr: There are very few people I truly love; even fewer people I respect.
es: I truly care for very few people, and I have a good opinion of very few.

en: The more I see of the world the more am I dissatisfied with it; and every day confirms my belief of the inconsistency of all human characters, and of the little dependence that can be placed on the appearance of either merit or sense.
vi: The more I look at the world, the more dissatisfied I feel. Each passing day reinforces my belief in the indomitable nature of human character, and that value or personal consciousness depends on outward appearances.
tr: The more I know the world, the more my discontent grows; every day my belief in the inconsistency of human character and that even those who seem intelligent and sensitive cannot be trusted strengthens.
es: The more I know the world, the more it displeases me, and time confirms my belief in the inconsistency of human character, and in how little one can trust the appearances of goodness or intelligence.

en: I have met with two instances lately: one I will not mention, the other is Charlotte’s marriage.
vi: Later, I encountered two cases; one doesn't need to be mentioned, the other is Charlotte's marriage.
tr: Recently, I have encountered two examples; I will not mention one; the other is Charlotte's marriage.
es: Lately, I have had two examples: one that I do not want to mention, and the other, Charlotte's wedding.

en: It is unaccountable!
vi: It cannot be justified!
tr: It is not understandable!
es: It's incredible!

en: in every view it is unaccountable!”
vi: From every angle, it cannot be justified!
tr: From whichever angle you look, it is not understandable!"
es: No matter how you look at it, it's incredible!

en: “My dear Lizzy, do not give way to such feelings as these.
vi: - Dear Lizzy, you shouldn't be so extreme in your feelings like that, otherwise you won't be happy.
tr: "My dear Lizzy, do not give in to such feelings.
es: ––Dear Lizzy, you must not have those feelings, they will end your happiness.

en: They will ruin your happiness.
vi: - Dear Lizzy, you shouldn't be so extreme in your feelings like that, otherwise you won't be happy.
tr: You will be unhappy.
es: ––Dear Lizzy, you must not have those feelings, they will end your happiness.

en: You do not make allowance enough for difference of situation and temper.
