vi: You haven't tolerated the difference between reality and emotions.
tr: You are not giving enough consideration to the differences in rank and temperament.
es: You do not take into consideration the different situations and the nature of people.

en: Consider mr Collins’s respectability, and Charlotte’s prudent, steady character.
vi: Consider the respectable position of Mr. Collins and the prudent, steadfast character of Charlotte.
tr: Think of Mr. Collins's respectability and Charlotte's sensible, steady character.
es: Keep in mind the respectability of Mr. Collins and the firm and prudent character of Charlotte.

en: Remember that she is one of a large family; that as to fortune it is a most eligible match; and be ready to believe, for everybody’s sake, that she may feel something like regard and esteem for our cousin.”
vi: Think about it; she is the daughter in a large family, materially this is a suitable marriage. For everyone's sake, you should believe that she has some feelings, such as affection and respect for our cousin.
tr: Remember that Charlotte belongs to a large family; she is a financially suitable choice; and, for the good of everyone, you must believe that you can feel some respect and warmth for our cousin."
es: Remember that she belongs to a large family, and as far as fortune is concerned, it is a very desirable marriage. You must believe, for God's sake, that she might feel some affection and esteem for our cousin.

en: “To oblige you, I would try to believe almost anything, but no one else could be benefited by such a belief as this; for were I persuaded that Charlotte had any regard for him, I should only think worse of her understanding than I now do of her heart.
vi: - To please you, I will try to believe almost everything, but no one else benefits from such belief, because I know if Collins loves her, I would despise her understanding even more than I currently disregard her feelings.
tr: "I would try to believe almost anything to please you, but such a belief would benefit no one; if I were convinced that Charlotte respected him, his mind would fall as low in my estimation as his heart.
es: ––To please you, I would try to believe what you say, but no one would benefit, because if I suspected that Charlotte had any interest in Mr. Collins, I would think less of her intelligence than I currently do of her heart.

en: My dear Jane, mr Collins is a conceited, pompous, narrow-minded, silly man: you know he is, as well as I do; and you must feel, as well as I do, that the woman who marries him cannot have a proper way of thinking.
vi: Jane, Collins is an arrogant, ostentatious, narrow-minded, foolish person; you know this as well as I do. You must also think as I do, that any woman who wants to marry him cannot have sound judgment.
tr: Dear Jane, Mr. Collins is a conceited, boastful, selfish, foolish man; you know this as well as I do; you must also be able to guess as well as I can that any woman who marries him must be out of her mind.
es: Dear Jane, Mr. Collins is a conceited, pedantic, stubborn, and foolish man; you know this as well as I do; and you must also know, as I do, that the woman who marries him cannot be in her right mind.

en: You shall not defend her, though it is Charlotte Lucas.
vi: You should not defend anyone, even if it is Charlotte Lucas.
tr: Even if it were Charlotte Lucas, you cannot defend such a woman.
es: Do not defend her just because she is Charlotte Lucas.

en: You shall not, for the sake of one individual, change the meaning of principle and integrity, nor endeavour to persuade yourself or me, that selfishness is prudence, and insensibility of danger security for happiness.”
vi: You should not change the meaning of principles and integrity for the sake of an individual, nor should you try to convince yourself or me that selfishness means prudence, and indifference to danger means the pursuit of happiness.
tr: You are not going to try to change the meaning of principle and honor for the sake of one person, or try to convince yourself or me that selfishness is common sense, or that insensitivity to danger is a guarantee of happiness."
es: For the sake of one person, you should not distort the meaning of principle and integrity, nor try to convince yourself or me that selfishness is prudence or that insensitivity to danger is a guarantee of happiness.

en: “I must think your language too strong in speaking of both,” replied Jane; “and I hope you will be convinced of it, by seeing them happy together.
vi: Jane replied: - I think you have gone too far in your thoughts about the two people; I hope you truly believe me by seeing them live in happiness.
tr: "If you ask me, you are using harsh language when talking about them," Jane replied; "and I hope you will believe it when you see that they are happy together.
es: ––You speak of both with too much harshness ––replied Jane––, and I hope you will admit it when you see that they are happy together.

en: But enough of this.
vi: But that is enough.
tr: But let's leave this aside now.
es: But let's leave this aside.

en: You alluded to something else.
vi: You are alluding to something else.
tr: You mentioned something else.
es: You alluded to something else.

en: You mentioned two instances.
vi: You are talking about two cases.
tr: You spoke of two examples.
es: You mentioned two examples.

en: I cannot misunderstand you, but I entreat you, dear Lizzy, not to pain me by thinking that person to blame, and saying your opinion of him is sunk.
vi: I cannot misunderstand you, but I beg you, dear Lizzy, please do not break my heart by reproaching that person and by thinking lowly of them.
tr: There is no way I can misunderstand you, but I beg you, my dear Lizzy, do not cause me pain by thinking that person is guilty and saying that your impression of him is terrible.
es: I know what it's about, but I beg you, dear Lizzy, not to make me suffer by blaming that person and saying that you have lost the good opinion you had of him.

en: We must not be so ready to fancy ourselves intentionally injured.
vi: We should not dwell on the thought that we are hurt intentionally.
tr: We should not be so ready to see ourselves as people who are intentionally hurt.
es: We should not be so inclined to imagine that we have been intentionally hurt.

en: We must not expect a lively young man to be always so guarded and circumspect.
vi: We cannot expect a young, lively man to always be meticulous and cautious.
tr: We should not expect a cheerful young man to be so careful and cautious at all times.
es: We cannot expect a young and so vital man to always be so circumspect and restrained.

en: It is very often nothing but our own vanity that deceives us.
vi: Very often, it is our own frivolity that has deceived us.
tr: Often it is nothing but our own pride that deceives us.
es: Often what deceives us is only our own vanity.

en: Women fancy admiration means more than it does.”
vi: Women often speculate about love more than its true nature.
tr: Women think admiration means more than it does."
es: We women believe that admiration means more than it actually does.

en: “And men take care that they should.”
vi: - And men want us to be like that.
tr: "Men are also working to make it meaningless.""
es: ––And men make sure that it is so.

en: “If it is designedly done, they cannot be justified; but I have no idea of there being so much design in the world as some persons imagine.”
vi: - If it's true, then this is precisely the reason you can't justify yourself; but you don't know that there are many schemes in this world as some people have imagined.
tr: "If it is done deliberately, it cannot be justified; but I don't think there are as many plans in the world as some people think."
es: ––If they do it deliberately, they have no justification; but it seems to me that there is not as much premeditation in the world as many people imagine.

en: “I am far from attributing any part of mr Bingley’s conduct to design,” said Elizabeth; “but, without scheming to do wrong, or to make others unhappy, there may be error and there may be misery.
vi: Elizabeth said: - I do not attribute any part of Mr. Bingley's attitude to malice, but even without the intention to do harm or cause distress, it can still be a mistake, it can still be painful.
tr: "I do not intend to attribute any part of Mr. Bingley's actions to a plan," said Elizabeth; "but mistakes can be made and sorrow can be caused without the intention of making mistakes or making others unhappy.
es: ––I do not mean to attribute Mr. Bingley's conduct to premeditation; but without intending to do wrong or cause others to suffer, one can make mistakes and do a great deal of harm.

en: Thoughtlessness, want of attention to other people’s feelings, and want of resolution, will do the business.”
vi: Everything could be due to thoughtlessness, or a lack of consideration for others' feelings, or a lack of resolve.
tr: Thoughtlessness, insensitivity to the feelings of others, and indecision can achieve the same result."
es: Inattention, disregard for the feelings of others, and indecision are responsible for that.

en: “And do you impute it to either of those?”
vi: - And you want to blame one of these things, don't you?
tr: "Is this one of the reasons for you?""
es: ––Do you attribute what happened to any of that?

en: “Yes; to the last.
vi: - That's right, for the last thing.
tr: "Yes; the last one.
es: ––Yes, at the end.

en: But if I go on I shall displease you by saying what I think of persons you esteem.
vi: But if you continue, you will upset me by saying what you think about the people I value.
tr: But if I continue, I will upset you by telling you what I think about the people you respect.
es: But if I keep talking, I will upset you by saying what I think of people you hold in high regard.

en: Stop me, whilst you can.”
vi: Please stop me here.
tr: Stop me while you have the chance."
es: It's better if you try to make me stay quiet.

en: “You persist, then, in supposing his sisters influence him?”
vi: - So you still think that his sisters influence him, don't you?
tr: "You still think that his sisters influence him, do you?""
es: Do you still suppose, then, that the sisters influence him?

en: “Yes, in conjunction with his friend.”
vi: - Yes, in collusion with his friend.
tr: "Yes, in partnership with his friend.""
es: ––Yes, along with his friend.

en: “I cannot believe it.
vi: - She couldn't believe it.
tr: "I can't believe this.
es: ––I can't believe it.

en: Why should they try to influence him?
vi: Why did they have to try so hard to influence him?
tr: Why would they want to influence him?
es: Why would he do it?

en: They can only wish his happiness; and if he is attached to me no other woman can secure it.”
vi: They just wanted him to be happy, and if he stayed with her, no woman could be happy with him.
tr: They just want him to be happy; if he's passionate about me, no other woman can make him happy."
es: They can only wish for his happiness; and if he loves me, no other woman will be able to provide it.

en: “Your first position is false.
vi: - Your first argument is incorrect.
tr: "Your first assumption is wrong.
es: Your first assumption is false.

en: They may wish many things besides his happiness: they may wish his increase of wealth and consequence; they may wish him to marry a girl who has all the importance of money, great connections, and pride.”
vi: They may desire many things besides happiness. They may want you to be wealthier, to have more status; they may want you to marry a girl with high financial standing, elite connections, and pride.
tr: They want other things besides happiness; they want their wealth and power to increase; they want to marry a girl with money, important relatives, and ostentation."
es: They may desire many things besides their happiness; they may desire to increase their wealth, with all that it brings; they may desire for you to marry a girl who has all the importance that money, great families, and pride can give.

en: “Beyond a doubt they do wish him to choose Miss Darcy,” replied Jane; “but this may be from better feelings than you are supposing.
vi: Jane replied: - Certainly. They all want you to choose Miss Darcy, but perhaps this is out of goodwill rather than what I guess.
tr: "No doubt, they would prefer Miss Darcy," replied Jane; "but this might be due to better feelings than you think.
es: ––So, you mean that they want me to choose Miss Darcy ––replied Jane––; but perhaps they are driven by better intentions than you think.

en: They have known her much longer than they have known me; no wonder if they love her better.
vi: They have known her for a longer time than they have known you; it's not surprising if they like her more.
tr: They have known her for a longer time than they have known me; it is not surprising that they love her more.
es: They have spent much more time with her than with me, it's logical that they would like her more.

en: But, whatever may be their own wishes, it is very unlikely they should have opposed their brother’s.
vi: But, whatever their intentions might be, there is no reason they would go against your brother's wishes.
tr: But regardless of their own wishes, it is unlikely that they would oppose their brother's desire.
es: But whatever their wishes may be, it is very unlikely that they have opposed their brother's.

en: What sister would think herself at liberty to do it, unless there were something very objectionable?
vi: What sibling would think they have the full right to do so, except if there is something very reprehensible?
tr: Which sister would see herself with this right, if there is nothing much to object to?
es: What sister would believe she has the right to do so, unless there was something very serious to object to?

en: If they believed him attached to me they would not try to part us; if he were so, they could not succeed.
vi: If they still believed that he cared for you, they would not try to separate you; if he truly loved you, they could not succeed.
tr: If they believed he was attached to me, they would not try to separate us; because if he were attached, they would not succeed.
es: If they had seen that he was very interested in me, they would not have tried to separate us; and if he were indeed that interested, all their efforts would be useless.

en: By supposing such an affection, you make everybody acting unnaturally and wrong, and me most unhappy.
vi: When I assume such love, I make everyone's actions seem abnormal and wrong, which makes you the saddest.
tr: By searching for such an intention, you make everyone behave unnaturally and wrongly, and you make me very unhappy.
es: By assuming that he loves me, you only manage to attribute bad behavior and a wrong attitude to everyone and make me suffer even more.

en: Do not distress me by the idea.
vi: Don't make yourself sad with this thought.
tr: Do not upset me with this idea.
es: I am not ashamed of having been wrong, and if I were ashamed, my suffering would be nothing compared to the pain that thinking ill of Bingley or his sisters would cause me.

en: I am not ashamed of having been mistaken—or, at least, it is slight, it is nothing in comparison of what I should feel in thinking ill of him or his sisters.
vi: I'm not ashamed of having been mistaken – or at least this mistake is minor, not comparable to thinking ill of him or his sisters.
tr: I am not ashamed of being mistaken – or whatever, it does not matter, not at all compared to the feelings I would have if I thought badly of him or his sisters.
es: I am not ashamed of having been wrong, and if I were ashamed, my suffering would be nothing compared to the pain that thinking ill of Bingley or his sisters would cause me.

en: Let me take it in the best light, in the light in which it may be understood.”
vi: Let me endure it in the best way, a way that everyone can sympathize with.
tr: Let me see the matter from the best perspective, that is, the one that can be understood."
es: Let me interpret it in the best possible way, in the way that makes it most understandable.

en: Elizabeth could not oppose such a wish; and from this time mr Bingley’s name was scarcely ever mentioned between them.
vi: Elizabeth could not resist such a desire, and from this moment on they rarely mentioned the name Bingley.
tr: Elizabeth could not object to such a request; from that moment on, Mr. Bingley's name was never mentioned between them again.
es: Elizabeth could not oppose such wishes; and from then on, the name of Bingley was seldom mentioned between them.

en: ms Bennet still continued to wonder and repine at his returning no more; and though a day seldom passed in which Elizabeth did not account for it clearly, there seemed little chance of her ever considering it with less perplexity.
vi: Mrs. Bennet continued to worry and fret about him not returning, although there wasn't a day that Elizabeth didn't notice this, it seemed she had little chance to think and be less bewildered.
tr: Mrs. Bennet continued to be amazed and saddened by the fact that he would not be returning anymore; although not a single day passed without Elizabeth explaining the situation, it seemed almost impossible to get Mrs. Bennet to handle the situation more calmly.
es: Mrs. Bennet was still puzzled and murmuring upon seeing that Bingley did not return; and although not a day went by without Elizabeth clearly showing her what was happening, it seemed that the mother could not stop being puzzled.

en: Her daughter endeavoured to convince her of what she did not believe herself, that his attentions to Jane had been merely the effect of a common and transient liking, which ceased when he saw her no more; but though the probability of the statement was admitted at the time, she had the same story to repeat every day.
vi: Her eldest daughter tried to persuade her of something she herself didn't believe, that when he paid attention to her, it was merely the result of ordinary and temporary admiration, which would fade away when he no longer saw her. Although she also recognized that this might be true, she still had only one thing to repeat every day.
tr: Her daughter tried to make her believe something she did not want to believe, that his interest in Jane was nothing more than a normal and temporary liking, and that his interest ceased once he stopped seeing her; however, even if the explanation was accepted as possibly true at the time, she repeated the same story every day.
es: Her daughter tried to convince her of what she herself did not believe, telling her that Bingley's attentions towards Jane had been the result of a common and fleeting whim that ceased once he stopped seeing her; but although Mrs. Bennet did not hesitate to admit that possibility, she could not help but repeat the same story every day.

en: ms Bennet’s best comfort was, that mr Bingley must be down again in the summer.
vi: Mrs. Bennet's only consolation was that Mr. Bingley would return in the summer.
tr: Mrs. Bennet's only consolation was that Mr. Bingley would come there again in the summer.
es: The only thing that consoled her was that Bingley had to return in the summer.

en: mr Bennet treated the matter differently.
vi: Mr. Bennet viewed the matter differently.
tr: Mr. Bennet approached the matter differently.
es: Mr. Bennet saw the matter in a very different light.

en: “So, Lizzy,” said he, one day, “your sister is crossed in love, I find.
vi: One day, he said: - So, Lizzy, I see your sister has encountered a setback in love.
tr: "So, Lizzy," he said one day, "your sister has lost in love.
es: So, Lizzy ––he said one day––, your sister has had a romantic failure.

en: I congratulate her.
vi: I'm glad for her.
tr: I congratulate her.
es: I congratulate her.

en: Next to being married, a girl likes to be crossed in love a little now and then.
vi: Apart from marriage, a young woman likes to occasionally face obstacles in love.
tr: Every girl likes to lose in love once in a while as much as she likes to get married.
es: Before getting married, it's good for a girl to have some failure; it gives her something to think about, and it gives her a certain distinction among her friends.

en: It is something to think of, and gives her a sort of distinction among her companions.
vi: This is something to ponder, making her distinct from others.
tr: It gives her something to think about and a sort of distinction among her friends.
es: Before getting married, it's good for a girl to have some failure; it gives her something to think about, and it gives her a certain distinction among her friends.

en: When is your turn to come?
vi: When will it be your turn?
tr: When is it going to be your turn?
es: And you, when is it your turn?

en: You will hardly bear to be long outdone by Jane.
vi: You can hardly stand for your sister Jane to surpass you.
tr: You can't stand being left behind Jane for too long.
es: You wouldn't want to be less than Jane.

en: Now is your time.
vi: Now it's your turn.
tr: Your time has come.
es: Take advantage now.

en: Here are officers enough at Meryton to disappoint all the young ladies in the country.
vi: There are enough officers in Meryton to disappoint every girl in the area.
tr: There are enough officers in Meryton to disappoint all the women in the country.
es: There are enough officers in Meryton to deceive all the girls in the area.

en: Let Wickham be your man.
vi: Choose Wickham as your man.
tr: Let yours be Wickham.
es: Choose Wickham.

en: He is a pleasant fellow, and would jilt you creditably.”
vi: He is charming and will reliably let you down.
tr: A charming man, he will leave you nicely."
es: He is a pleasant fellow, and he is sure to reject you.

en: “Thank you, sir, but a less agreeable man would satisfy me.
vi: - Thank you, Dad, but a less pleasant person would also make me happy.
tr: "Thank you, sir, but a less charming man will suffice for me."
es: ––Thank you, Dad, but I would be satisfied with a less pleasant man.

en: We must not all expect Jane’s good fortune.”
vi: None of us should rely on luck like Jane.
tr: "We cannot all hope to be as fortunate as Jane.""
es: Not all of us can expect to be as lucky as Jane.

en: “True,” said mr Bennet; “but it is a comfort to think that, whatever of that kind may befall you, you have an affectionate mother who will always make the most of it.”
vi: - That's right, but there's some comfort in thinking that, no matter what happens to you, you still have a loving mother who always knows how to take advantage of the situation.
tr: "True," said Mr. Bennet, "but whatever may come to her, it is comforting to know that she has a loving mother who knows how to make the best of the situation."
es: ––It is true ––said Mr. Bennet––, but it is a comfort to think that, whatever happens, you have a loving mother who will always help you.

en: mr Wickham’s society was of material service in dispelling the gloom which the late perverse occurrences had thrown on many of the Longbourn family.
vi: The relationship with Mr. Wickham had the effect of dispelling any gloom in the Longbourn household.
tr: Mr. Wickham's presence was quite effective in dispelling the sorrow caused by recent misfortunes among many members of the Longbourn family.
es: Wickham's company was of great utility in dispelling the sadness that the recent unfortunate events had caused several members of the Longbourn family.

en: They saw him often, and to his other recommendations was now added that of general unreserve.
vi: They often met with him. Now, additional impressions of him included his unreserved attitude.
tr: They saw him frequently, and now a general frankness was added to his other qualities.
es: They saw him often, and on that occasion, he added to his other virtues that of absolute frankness.

en: The whole of what Elizabeth had already heard, his claims on mr Darcy, and all that he had suffered from him, was now openly acknowledged and publicly canvassed; and everybody was pleased to think how much they had always disliked mr Darcy before they had known anything of the matter.
vi: Everything Elizabeth had heard, the things he told about Darcy, and all that he had to endure because of Darcy, were now openly discussed and acknowledged; everyone was happy to think that they had always had a dislike for Mr. Darcy even before they knew about any issues between the two of them.
tr: The things Elizabeth had already heard, the claims about Mr. Darcy, the sufferings caused by him were now openly spoken of, publicly declared; even before everyone learned everything, she took pleasure in thinking about how much she hated Mr. Darcy.
es: Everything Elizabeth had heard, his complaints against Darcy and the grievances he had inflicted upon him, became public knowledge; everyone delighted in recalling how disagreeable Darcy had always been, even before knowing any of this.

en: Miss Bennet was the only creature who could suppose there might be any extenuating circumstances in the case unknown to the society of Hertfordshire: her mild and steady candour always pleaded for allowances, and urged the possibility of mistakes; but by everybody else mr Darcy was condemned as the worst of men.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was still the only creature who thought that there might be mitigating circumstances in the matter that the people of Hertfordshire were unaware of. Her gentle and steadfast frankness always called for forgiveness and tried to persuade a possibility of misunderstanding – but to everyone else, Mr. Darcy was still condemned as the worst person.
tr: Miss Bennet was the only person who could think that there might be mitigating circumstances in the matter unknown to the people of Hertfordshire; her moderate and steady sincerity always allowed room for tolerance, seeking the possibility of error – but everyone else cursed Mr. Darcy as the most heartless man in the world.
es: Jane was the only one capable of supposing that there might be some mitigating circumstance in this case unknown to the neighbors of Hertfordshire. Her sweet and unwavering candor constantly called for indulgence and proposed the possibility of a mistake; but everyone considered Darcy to be the worst of men.

en: CHAPTER XXV.
vi: Chapter 25
tr: Chapter II
es: CHAPTER XXV

en: AFTER a week spent in professions of love and schemes of felicity, mr Collins was called from his amiable Charlotte by the arrival of Saturday.
vi: After a week of expressing affection and contemplating happiness, Mr. Collins was called back on Sunday.
tr: After a week filled with vows of love and dreams of happiness, Mr. Collins had to part from his dear Charlotte with the arrival of Saturday.
es: After a week spent between promises of love and plans of happiness, Collins had to bid farewell to his beloved Charlotte to arrive on Saturday at Hunsford.

en: The pain of separation, however, might be alleviated on his side by preparations for the reception of his bride, as he had reason to hope, that shortly after his next return into Hertfordshire, the day would be fixed that was to make him the happiest of men.
vi: However, the sadness of parting this time could be alleviated for him by the preparations for welcoming the bride. He had reason to hope that, upon his next return to Hertfordshire, they would set a date for him to become the happiest young man in the world.
tr: But the pain of separation was alleviated for him by the preparations being made for his bride's arrival; he had reasons to hope that the day which would make him the happiest man in the world would be set immediately upon his next return to Hertfordshire.
es: But the sorrow of the separation was alleviated for Collins by the preparations he had to make for the reception of his fiancée; for he had reasons to believe that shortly after his next return to Hertfordshire, the day would be set that would make him the happiest of men.

en: He took leave of his relations at Longbourn with as much solemnity as before; wished his fair cousins health and happiness again, and promised their father another letter of thanks.
vi: He bid farewell to his relatives at Longbourn with the same formal words as before; he wished his lovely cousins health and happiness, and promised Mr. Bennet to send a thank-you letter.
tr: He bade farewell to his relatives at Longbourn with the same solemnity as before; he once again wished his beautiful cousins health and happiness and promised their father a new letter of thanks.
es: He bid farewell to his relatives at Longbourn with the same solemnity as before; once again wished his beautiful cousins health and happiness, and promised the father another letter of gratitude.

en: On the following Monday, ms Bennet had the pleasure of receiving her brother and his wife, who came, as usual, to spend the Christmas at Longbourn.
vi: On the following day, Mrs. Bennet joyfully welcomed her brother and his wife to stay at Longbourn for Christmas.
tr: The following Monday, Mrs. Bennet joyfully welcomed her brother and his wife, who, as usual, had come to spend Christmas at Longbourn.
es: On the following Monday, Mrs. Bennet had the pleasure of receiving her brother and his wife, who came, as usual, to spend Christmas at Longbourn.

en: mr Gardiner was a sensible, gentlemanlike man, greatly superior to his sister, as well by nature as education.
vi: Mr. Gardiner was a sensitive, refined man, surpassing his sister in both character and education.
tr: Mr. Gardiner was a sensible, gentlemanly man; in both nature and education, he was far superior to his sister.
es: Mr. Gardiner was an intelligent and gentlemanly man, far superior to his sister by nature and education.

en: The Netherfield ladies would have had difficulty in believing that a man who lived by trade, and within view of his own warehouses, could have been so well-bred and agreeable.
vi: The ladies of Netherfield might find it hard to believe that someone who made his living through commerce and lived near warehouses could possess such a level of sophistication and pleasant demeanor.
tr: The ladies at Netherfield found it hard to believe that a man who made his living through trade and whose house was within sight of his shop could be so polite and charming.
es: The ladies of Netherfield would have found it difficult to believe that this man, who lived off commerce and was always involved in his warehouse, could be so well-educated and pleasant.

en: ms Gardiner, who was several years younger than ms Bennet and ms Philips, was an amiable, intelligent, elegant woman, and a great favourite with her Longbourn nieces.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner, a few years younger than Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Philips, was a charming, intelligent, and elegant woman, dearly loved by all the young ladies of Longbourn.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner, who was a few years younger than Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Philips, was a pleasant, intelligent, and graceful woman; she was the favorite of all her nieces and nephews at Longbourn.
es: Mrs. Gardiner, much younger than Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Philips, was a charming and elegant woman, adored by her nieces at Longbourn.

en: Between the two eldest and herself especially, there subsisted a very particular regard.
vi: There was a very special affection between the two sisters and Mrs. Gardiner.
tr: She had a particularly special bond with her two eldest nieces.
es: Especially the two eldest, with whom she had a particular friendship.

en: They had frequently been staying with her in town.
vi: They often stayed with her in the city.
tr: When they went to town, they often stayed with her.
es: Elizabeth and Jane had often been to her house in the capital.

en: The first part of ms Gardiner’s business, on her arrival, was to distribute her presents and describe the newest fashions.
vi: The first thing Mrs. Gardiner did upon arrival was to distribute the gifts and describe the new fashion styles.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner's first task upon arrival was to distribute her gifts and discuss the latest fashion trends.
es: The first thing Mrs. Gardiner did upon arriving was to distribute her gifts and describe the new fashions.

en: When this was done, she had a less active part to play.
vi: Once finished, she didn't have much else to do; it was her turn to listen.
tr: After this task was completed, she had a less active role.
es: Once this was done, she ceased to lead the conversation; now it was her turn to listen.

en: It became her turn to listen.
vi: Once finished, she didn't have much else to do; it was her turn to listen.
tr: It was her turn to listen.
es: Once this was done, she ceased to lead the conversation; now it was her turn to listen.

en: ms Bennet had many grievances to relate, and much to complain of.
vi: Mrs. Bennet had many things to complain about.
tr: Mrs. Bennet had a lot of grievances and many complaints to share.
es: Mrs. Bennet had to tell her about her many misfortunes and complaints.

en: They had all been very ill-used since she last saw her sister.
vi: Everyone had been treated poorly since the last time the sisters met.
tr: Since the last time she had seen her aunt, everything had gone wrong for everyone.
es: She had suffered many humiliations since the last time she saw her sister-in-law.

en: Two of her girls had been on the point of marriage, and after all there was nothing in it.
vi: The two daughters had come close to marriage, but in the end, they got nothing.
tr: Two of her daughters had come to the brink of marriage but had remained there.
es: Two of her daughters had been on the verge of getting married, but then everything had come to nothing.

en: “I do not blame Jane,” she continued, “for Jane would have got mr Bingley if she could.
vi: Mrs. Bennet continued: - I do not blame Jane, for Jane would have taken Mr. Bingley if she could.
tr: "I don't blame Jane," she continued, "because if Jane could, she would have won over Mr. Bingley.
es: ––I do not blame Jane, he continued––, because she would have married Mr. Bingley if she could; but Elizabeth...

en: But, Lizzy!
vi: But Lizzy!
tr: But Lizzy!
es: Ah, my sister!

en: Oh, sister!
vi: Oh!
tr: oh, my sister!
es: Ah, my sister!

en: it is very hard to think that she might have been mr Collins’s wife by this time, had not it been for her own perverseness.
vi: It is so distressing to think that she could have been Mr. Collins's wife by now, if she had not been so headstrong.
tr: by now she would have already been Mr. Collins's wife if she hadn't been so perverse.
es: It is very hard to think that at this hour she could be Mrs. Collins if it hadn't been for her stubbornness.

en: He made her an offer in this very room, and she refused him.
vi: He proposed to her right in this room, but she refused.
tr: The man proposed to her in this very room, and she refused.
es: He proposed to her in this very room and she rejected him.

en: The consequence of it is, that Lady Lucas will have a daughter married before I have, and that Longbourn estate is just as much entailed as ever.
vi: As a result, Lady Lucas will have a daughter married before mine, and the Longbourn estate will continue to be inherited as before.
tr: The result is clear, Lady Lucas will be the mother of a married daughter before me; and the Longbourn estate is still mortgaged as ever.
es: As a consequence, Lady Lucas will have a married daughter before I do, and the Longbourn inheritance will pass into their hands.

en: The Lucases are very artful people, indeed, sister.
vi: The Lucases are really very cunning people, my dear.
tr: The Lucases are indeed very clever people, my sister.
es: The Lucases are very shrewd, they always take advantage of what they can.

en: They are all for what they can get.
vi: They want to seize everything they can.
tr: They take whatever they can get.
es: The Lucases are very shrewd, they always take advantage of what they can.

en: I am sorry to say it of them, but so it is.
vi: I regret to speak of them this way, but it is the truth.
tr: I'm sorry to speak about them this way, but it's the truth.
es: I regret having to speak of them in this way but it is the truth.

en: It makes me very nervous and poorly, to be thwarted so in my own family, and to have neighbours who think of themselves before anybody else.
vi: This makes me very anxious and unwell, being thwarted in my own family, and having neighbors who think only of themselves first.
tr: Being pushed around within my own family like this irritates me, it makes me miserable; especially when you have neighbors who think of themselves before anyone else.
es: It makes me very nervous and sick that my own family contradicts me in this way, and to have neighbors who think only of themselves.

en: However, your coming just at this time is the greatest of comforts, and I am very glad to hear what you tell us of long sleeves.”
vi: However, you coming at this moment is a great comfort to me, and I am very glad to hear your opinion.
tr: Nevertheless, your coming at such a time is the greatest consolation; I really enjoyed what you said about the long sleeves."
es: At least having you here at this very moment comforts me greatly; I love what you tell us about the long sleeves.

en: ms Gardiner, to whom the chief of this news had been given before, in the course of Jane and Elizabeth’s correspondence with her, made her sister a slight answer, and, in compassion to her nieces, turned the conversation.
vi: Through Jane and Elizabeth's letters, Mrs. Gardiner had some knowledge of the matter. She only responded briefly, and out of compassion for her nieces, she steered the conversation in a different direction.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner, who had learned the essence of these news during her correspondence with Jane and Elizabeth, responded lightly to her sister-in-law, then, feeling sorry for her nieces, changed the subject.
es: Mrs. Gardiner, who had already heard about the matter through the correspondence she maintained with Jane and Elizabeth, gave a brief response, and out of compassion for her nieces, changed the subject.

en: When alone with Elizabeth afterwards, she spoke more on the subject.
vi: When sitting alone with Elizabeth, she further discussed the matter. She said:
tr: Later, when he was alone with Elizabeth, he talked a little more about this subject.
es: When he was alone later with Elizabeth, he brought up the matter again:

en: “It seems likely to have been a desirable match for Jane,” said she.
vi: - It seems that Jane could have had a desirable marriage.
tr: "It seems like it would have been an ideal marriage for Jane," he said.
es: ––It seems that it would have been a good match for Jane ––he said––.

en: “I am sorry it went off.
vi: Your aunt feels very sad because this did not happen.
tr: "I'm sorry it didn't happen.
es: I regret that it has been ruined.

en: But these things happen so often!
vi: But such things are common!
tr: But such things happen a lot!
es: But these things happen so often!

en: A young man, such as you describe mr Bingley, so easily falls in love with a pretty girl for a few weeks, and, when accident separates them, so easily forgets her, that these sort of inconstancies are very frequent.”
vi: A young man, as you described Mr. Bingley, falls in love with a beautiful girl so easily within a few weeks, and when an incident forces him to be away from her, he forgets her just as easily.
tr: If Mr. Bingley is the kind of man you described, who easily falls in love with a pretty girl for a few weeks and then forgets her just as easily when circumstances separate them, it means he often engages in such infidelity."
es: A young man like Bingley, as you describe him to me, easily falls in love with a pretty girl for a few weeks and, if by chance they part, he forgets her just as easily.

en: “Offended two or three young ladies”
vi: Such inconsistencies happen very often.
tr: If Mr. Bingley is the kind of man you described, who easily falls in love with a pretty girl for a few weeks and then forgets her just as easily when circumstances separate them, it means he often engages in such infidelity."
es: Such inconstancies are very common.

en: “An excellent consolation in its way,” said Elizabeth; “but it will not do for us.
vi: Elizabeth said: - You are very good at comforting, but it doesn't help us.
tr: "A perfect solace on its own," said Elizabeth, "but it doesn't work for us.
es: ––If that had been the case, it would be a great comfort ––said Elizabeth––, but our situation is different.

en: We do not suffer by accident.
vi: We are not suffering because of the incident.
tr: We are not suffering by chance.
es: What happened to us was not by chance.

en: It does not often happen that the interference of friends will persuade a young man of independent fortune to think no more of a girl whom he was violently in love with only a few days before.”
vi: It is not common for close relatives to intervene to persuade a young man with independent means to completely forget a girl he passionately loved just a few days before.
tr: That a friend's intervention convinces a young man with his own income to forget a girl he was passionately in love with just a few days ago, this is not something that happens often."
es: It is not so common for friends to intervene and convince an independent young man to stop thinking about a girl he was madly in love with just a few days before.

en: “But that expression of ‘violently in love’ is so hackneyed, so doubtful, so indefinite, that it gives me very little idea.
vi: - But the phrase "intense love" is too nonsensical, too suspicious, too vague, so there's not much to say about it.
tr: "But this expression 'violently in love' is so clichéd, so doubtful, so vague that it gives me very little idea.
es: ––But that expression, "madly in love," is so overused, so ambiguous and so vague, that it tells me nothing.

en: It is as often applied to feelings which arise only from a half hour’s acquaintance, as to a real, strong attachment.
vi: It usually refers to emotions stemming from interactions lasting half an hour, as well as true love.
tr: It can apply to feelings born from half an hour's acquaintance as well as to real, strong attachments.
es: The same applies to feelings born half an hour after meeting, as to a strong and true affection.

en: Pray, how violent was mr Bingley’s love?”
vi: Try asking yourself, how intense is Mr. Bingley's love?
tr: Please, can you tell me how intense Mr. Bingley's love was?"
es: Explain to me what Mr. Bingley's love was like.

en: “I never saw a more promising inclination; he was growing quite inattentive to other people, and wholly engrossed by her.
vi: - I have never seen such a promising affection. He hardly pays attention to anyone else, completely captivated by my sister.
tr: "I have never seen a more promising interest; gradually, he became oblivious to other people; he was so captivated by Jane.
es: ––I have never seen a more promising attraction. When he was with Jane, he paid no attention to anyone else, he devoted himself entirely to her.

en: Every time they met, it was more decided and remarkable.
vi: Each time they meet, their feelings seem more determined and vivid.
tr: Whenever they met, this became more apparent, more definite.
es: Every time they saw each other, it became more certain and evident.

en: At his own ball he offended two or three young ladies by not asking them to dance; and I spoke to him twice myself without receiving an answer.
vi: At the ball he hosted, he offended two or three young ladies by not inviting them to dance, and I myself spoke to him twice without receiving a response.
tr: At his own ball, he offended several ladies by not asking them to dance; I spoke to him twice, but received no reply.
es: At his own ball, he snubbed two or three young ladies by not asking them to dance, and I spoke to him twice without getting a response.

en: Could there be finer symptoms?
vi: Could there be a clearer sign?
tr: Could there be clearer signs?
es: Could there be clearer symptoms?

en: Is not general incivility the very essence of love?”
vi: Could there be a clearer sign?
tr: Isn't indifference to others the essence of love?"
es: Isn't rudeness to everyone else the very essence of love?

en: “Oh, yes!
vi: - Ah, that's right!
tr: "Ah yes!
es: ––Of that kind of love that I imagine Bingley felt, yes.

en: of that kind of love which I suppose him to have felt.
vi: I do think it's his feelings.
tr: –the kind of love I thought he felt.
es: ––Of that kind of love that I imagine Bingley felt, yes.

en: Poor Jane!
vi: Poor Jane!
tr: Poor Jane!
es: Poor Jane!

en: I am sorry for her, because, with her disposition, she may not get over it immediately.
vi: I feel for her because with her temperament, she can't get over it quickly.
tr: I feel sorry for her; someone of her character cannot get over it quickly.
es: I feel sorry for her, because given her nature, she won't forget so easily.

en: It had better have happened to you, Lizzy; you would have laughed yourself out of it sooner.
vi: This should have happened to you, Lizzy; soon you would be able to joke about such a thing.
tr: I wish it had happened to you, Lizzy; you would laugh it off more quickly.
es: It would have been better if it had happened to you, Lizzy; you would have resigned yourself sooner.

en: But do you think she would be prevailed on to go back with us?
vi: But do you think your sister can overcome herself to return to us?
tr: But do you think we can persuade Jane to come back with us?
es: But, do you think we can convince her to come with us to London?

en: Change of scene might be of service—and perhaps a little relief from home may be as useful as anything.”
vi: A change of scenery, or being away from home for a while, might be beneficial for anything else.
tr: A change of air might help –and perhaps just being away from home would be a relief in itself."
es: A change of air would do her good, and maybe a little rest away from home would be better for her than anything else.

en: Elizabeth was exceedingly pleased with this proposal, and felt persuaded of her sister’s ready acquiescence.
vi: Elizabeth was very pleased with such a proposal, confident that her sister would agree.
tr: Elizabeth was extremely pleased with the offer; she said she believed her sister was more than willing from the start.
es: Elizabeth found this proposition wonderful and did not doubt that her sister would accept it.

en: “I hope,” added ms Gardiner, “that no consideration with regard to this young man will influence her.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner added: - I hope your sister won't be influenced by any thoughts about that young man.
tr: "I hope," added Mrs. Gardiner, "that her concerns about this young man do not affect her.
es: ––I suppose ––he added–– that thinking she might meet that young man won't stop her.

en: We live in so different a part of town, all our connections are so different, and, as you well know, we go out so little, that it is very improbable they should meet at all, unless he really comes to see her.”
vi: As you know, our family lives in a secluded part of the city, and we rarely go out, so it's unlikely that the two of them will meet. Unless he intentionally comes to find your sister.
tr: We live in a very different part of the city, all our associations are very different, and as you know, we seldom go out; so it is almost impossible for them to encounter us, unless the man comes to see her.""
es: We live in opposite parts of the city, all our friends are so different and, as you know, we go out so little, that it's very unlikely to happen, unless he comes expressly to see her.

en: “And that is quite impossible; for he is now in the custody of his friend, and mr Darcy would no more suffer him to call on Jane in such a part of London!
vi: - This is unlikely to happen because he is still being held by his friend, Mr. Darcy will not allow him to meet Jane in that area of London!
tr: "There is no way; because now he is under the watchful eye of his friend; Mr. Darcy cannot tolerate him visiting Jane in such a neighborhood of London!
es: ––And that is impossible, because now he is under the custody of his friend, and Mr. Darcy would not allow him to visit Jane in such a part of London.

en: My dear aunt, how could you think of it?
vi: My dear, how could you come up with such a thing?
tr: My dear aunt, how could such a thing cross your mind?
es: Dear aunt, what do you think?

en: mr Darcy may, perhaps, have heard of such a place as Gracechurch Street, but he would hardly think a month’s ablution enough to cleanse him from its impurities, were he once to enter it; and, depend upon it, mr Bingley never stirs without him.”
vi: Mr. Darcy might have heard of a place like Gracechurch Street, but he should not think that a month of baptism is enough to cleanse all the stains from his person if he comes here, and consequently, Mr. Bingley never acts without him.
tr: Mr. Darcy may have heard of a place called Gracechurch Street, but once he sets foot there, he would think he couldn't rid himself of its grime even if he scrubbed for a month; rest assured, Mr. Bingley won't move an inch without him."
es: Darcy might have heard of a place like Gracechurch Street, but he would believe that not even the ablutions of a whole month would be enough to cleanse him of all its impurities, if he ever deigned to enter that street. And you can be sure that Bingley would not take a step without him.

en: “So much the better.
vi: - Then all the better.
tr: "All the better." "I hope they never meet."
es: ––Much better.

en: I hope they will not meet at all.
vi: She hopes the two of you will never meet again.
tr: "All the better." "I hope they never meet."
es: I hope they never meet.

en: But does not Jane correspond with his sister?
vi: But Jane will correspond with her sister, won't she?
tr: "But isn't Jane corresponding with the man's sister?"
es: But, doesn't Jane write to her sister?

en: She will not be able to help calling.”
vi: She won't be able to resist visiting.
tr: "She can't ignore that.""
es: Then, Miss Bingley will have no excuse not to visit her.

en: “She will drop the acquaintance entirely.”
vi: - My sister will sever all relationships.
tr: "He will end the friendship permanently."
es: ––He will completely break off their friendship.

en: But, in spite of the certainty in which Elizabeth affected to place this point, as well as the still more interesting one of Bingley’s being withheld from seeing Jane, she felt a solicitude on the subject which convinced her, on examination, that she did not consider it entirely hopeless.
vi: But although Elizabeth spoke firmly about this, as well as about Mr. Bingley being detained and unable to visit her sister, she still cared deeply about the matter, leading her to believe that not all hope was lost.
tr: Although Elizabeth seemed very confident when describing this point and the even more intriguing fact that Bingley was being kept from seeing Jane, a doubt about the matter crept into her mind, and upon reflection, it convinced her that the situation was not entirely hopeless.
es: But, despite Elizabeth being so sure about this point, and, what was even more interesting, despite Bingley being prevented from seeing Jane, Mrs. Gardiner was convinced, after examining it well, that there was still hope.

en: It was possible, and sometimes she thought it probable, that his affection might be re-animated, and the influence of his friends successfully combated by the more natural influence of Jane’s attractions.
vi: She thought it very possible that his love would rekindle, and the natural influence of Jane's charm would overcome the influence of those around him.
tr: It was possible, even quite possible, that Bingley's affection could be rekindled and that the influence of his friends could be overcome by the more natural effect of Jane's charm.
es: It was possible, and sometimes she believed even beneficial, that Bingley's affection could be rekindled and fight against the influence of his friends under the more natural influence of Jane's charms.

en: Miss Bennet accepted her aunt’s invitation with pleasure; and the Bingleys were no otherwise in her thoughts at the same time than as she hoped, by Caroline’s not living in the same house with her brother, she might occasionally spend a morning with her, without any danger of seeing him.
vi: Jane happily accepted her aunt's invitation. The Bingley household no longer occupied her thoughts with the idea that she might occasionally spend a morning with Caroline without having to see him, as she did not live in the same house as her brother.
tr: Miss Bennet gladly accepted her sister-in-law's invitation; her only thought about the Bingleys was Caroline; since she did not live in the same house as her brother, she hoped to spend a morning with Caroline now and then without the danger of seeing him.
es: Jane gladly accepted her aunt's invitation, without thinking about the Bingleys, although she hoped that, since Caroline did not live in the same house as her brother, she might spend a morning with her without the danger of encountering him.

en: The Gardiners stayed a week at Longbourn; and what with the Philipses, the Lucases, and the officers, there was not a day without its engagement.
vi: The Gardiners stayed at Longbourn for a week. With the Philipses, the Lucases, and the officers, there was not a day without social engagements.
tr: The Gardiners stayed at Longbourn for a week; with the Philipses, the Lucases, and the officers, not a single day passed without entertainment.
es: The Gardiners stayed in Longbourn for a week; and among the Philipses, the Lucases, and the officers, there was not a day without an engagement.

en: ms Bennet had so carefully provided for the entertainment of her brother and sister, that they did not once sit down to a family dinner.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was so considerate in entertaining her brother and sister-in-law that they had no time to sit down for meals with the family.
tr: Mrs. Bennet tried so hard to ensure her brother and sister-in-law had fun that they couldn't even sit down for a family dinner once.
es: Mrs. Bennet had taken such care to prepare everything so that her brother and sister-in-law would have a good time, that not once could they enjoy a family meal.

en: When the engagement was for home, some of the officers always made part of it, of which officers mr Wickham was sure to be one; and on these occasions ms Gardiner, rendered suspicious by Elizabeth’s warm commendation of him, narrowly observed them both.
vi: When there were social gatherings at the house, the officers were always present, among whom was certainly Mr. Wickham. On these occasions, Mrs. Gardiner noticed Elizabeth's warm demeanor towards him, so she carefully observed the two.
tr: When the entertainment was at home, some officers were always present – Mr. Wickham, of course, was one of them; once, Mrs. Gardiner became suspicious after Elizabeth spoke warmly of him and decided to keep a close watch on the two.
es: When the gathering was at home, there were always some officers present among whom Wickham could not be absent. On these occasions, Mrs. Gardiner, who was curious about the many praises Elizabeth bestowed upon him, observed the two of them closely.

en: Without supposing them, from what she saw, to be very seriously in love, their preference of each other was plain enough to make her a little uneasy; and she resolved to speak to Elizabeth on the subject before she left Hertfordshire, and represent to her the imprudence of encouraging such an attachment.
vi: She did not think they were deeply in love, but felt uneasy seeing them clearly affectionate towards each other. She decided to talk to Elizabeth about this before leaving Hertfordshire, explaining to her the need to be cautious in encouraging such an attachment.
tr: From what she observed, she did not seriously conclude that they were in love, but the obvious interest they showed in each other disturbed her a bit, and before leaving Hertfordshire, she decided to talk to Elizabeth about it and advise her that continuing such a closeness would be unwise.
es: Realizing, from what she saw, that they were not seriously in love; their mutual preference was too evident. She did not feel very at ease, so before leaving Hertfordshire she decided to speak with Elizabeth about the matter, warning her of her imprudence in encouraging that relationship.

en: To ms Gardiner, Wickham had one means of affording pleasure, unconnected with his general powers.
vi: For Mrs. Gardiner, Wickham had a way of enjoying pleasures that had nothing to do with his abilities.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner found Wickham interesting not only because of his general characteristics.
es: Wickham, aside from his qualities, knew how to please Mrs. Gardiner.

en: About ten or a dozen years ago, before her marriage, she had spent a considerable time in that very part of Derbyshire to which he belonged.
vi: About ten years ago, before she got married, she had lived for a long time in Derbyshire, Wickham's hometown.
tr: Ten or twelve years ago, when she was still single, she had spent quite some time in the part of Derbyshire where Wickham was from.
es: Before getting married, ten or twelve years ago, she had spent quite some time in the same part of Derbyshire where Wickham was born.

en: They had, therefore, many acquaintance in common; and, though Wickham had been little there since the death of Darcy’s father, five years before, it was yet in his power to give her fresher intelligence of her former friends than she had been in the way of procuring.
vi: Therefore, she and Wickham had mutual friends. Although Wickham had seldom visited the area since Mr. Darcy's father passed away five years ago, it was through his abilities that she received new information about old acquaintances.
tr: Therefore, they had many mutual acquaintances; although Wickham had not visited there much since Darcy's father died five years ago, Mrs. Gardiner had more recent information about their old friends than he could provide.
es: They therefore had many mutual friends; and although Wickham left shortly after the death of Darcy's father, which occurred five years ago, he could still tell her things about their old friends, more recent than what she knew.

en: ms Gardiner had seen Pemberley, and known the late mr Darcy by character perfectly well.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner had come to Pemberley and knew very well about old Mr. Darcy's character.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner had seen Pemberley and had heard much about the late Mr. Darcy's reputation.
es: Mrs. Gardiner had been to Pemberley and had known the late Mr. Darcy perfectly.

en: Here, consequently, was an inexhaustible subject of discourse.
vi: Therefore, this was a topic for endless conversation.
tr: Here was an inexhaustible topic of conversation.
es: This was, therefore, an inexhaustible topic of conversation.

en: In comparing her recollection of Pemberley with the minute description which Wickham could give, and in bestowing her tribute of praise on the character of its late possessor, she was delighting both him and herself.
vi: When comparing what she remembered about Derbyshire with what Mr. Wickham described in detail, and when praising the character of the late master, both she and he found joy.
tr: Comparing what she remembered of Pemberley with the detailed description given by Wickham, and speaking in praise of the late owner's character, she made both Wickham and herself happy.
es: She compared her memories of Pemberley with the detailed description Wickham gave, and by praising the character of its last owner, they both delighted in it.

en: On being made acquainted with the present mr Darcy’s treatment of him, she tried to remember something of that gentleman’s reputed disposition, when quite a lad, which might agree with it; and was confident, at last, that she recollected having heard mr Fitzwilliam Darcy formerly spoken of as a very proud, ill-natured boy.
vi: Upon learning about how Darcy treated him, she tried to recall something about Darcy's youth that matched his story, and eventually, she remembered hearing Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy talk about a very proud and ill-tempered boy.
tr: Upon hearing what the current Mr. Darcy had done to him, she tried to recall something that would match the reputation of that gentleman in his childhood, and finally she was sure that she remembered hearing Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy described as an excessively proud, mischievous child even then.
es: Upon learning of Darcy's behavior with Wickham, Mrs. Gardiner believed she remembered something of the bad reputation he had when he was still a boy, which fit this case; finally, she confessed that she remembered that even then young Fitzwilliam Darcy was spoken of as a bad and proud boy.

en: CHAPTER XXVI.
vi: Chapter 26
tr: Chapter III
es: CHAPTER XXVI

en: ms GARDINER’S caution to Elizabeth was punctually and kindly given on the first favourable opportunity of speaking to her alone: after honestly telling her what she thought, she thus went on:—
vi: Mrs. Gardiner took the opportunity to speak privately with Elizabeth to gently caution her. After honestly telling her what she thought, she added:
tr: Mrs. Gardiner firmly and kindly warned Elizabeth at the first opportunity they had to speak alone; after sharing her thoughts, she continued: –
es: Mrs. Gardiner gave Elizabeth the aforementioned warning promptly and kindly, at the first opportunity she had to speak with her alone. After having honestly told her what she thought, she added:

en: “You are too sensible a girl, Lizzy, to fall in love merely because you are warned against it; and, therefore, I am not afraid of speaking openly.
vi: - Lizzy, you are mature enough not to fall in love just because you are warned against it. Therefore, I will not hesitate to speak frankly.
tr: "You are a very sensible girl, Lizzy, you won't fall in love with anyone just because you were warned; so I am not afraid to speak openly with you.
es: ––You are a girl too sensible, Lizzy, to fall in love just because you were warned not to; and for that reason, I dare to speak to you openly.

en: Seriously, I would have you be on your guard.
vi: I need to caution you, and I am serious about this.
tr: Seriously, I advise you to protect yourself.
es: Seriously, be careful.

en: Do not involve yourself, or endeavour to involve him, in an affection which the want of fortune would make so very imprudent.
vi: You should not get entangled with him in a relationship where material desires might make love reckless.
tr: Do not enter into or try to force a relationship that would be impossible due to lack of money.
es: Do not commit yourself, nor let him get involved in an affection that the lack of fortune can turn into imprudence.

en: I have nothing to say against him: he is a most interesting young man; and if he had the fortune he ought to have, I should think you could not do better.
vi: I have nothing against him; he is someone worthy of our attention; and if he had the wealth he should have inherited, I could say there would be nothing better for you.
tr: I have nothing against him; he is a very interesting young man; if he had the fortune he deserved, I would say you couldn't do better.
es: I have nothing to say against him; he is a very interesting young man, and if he had the position he should have, he would seem unbeatable to me.

en: But as it is—you must not let your fancy run away with you.
vi: You are sensible, and everyone expects you to use your sense.
tr: But in his current state, you must not let yourself get carried away by dreams.
es: But as things stand, you cannot blind yourself.

en: You have sense, and we all expect you to use it.
vi: You are sensible, and everyone expects you to use your sense.
tr: You have common sense, and we all want to see you use it.
es: You have a lot of sense, and we all expect you to use it.

en: Your father would depend on your resolution and good conduct, I am sure.
vi: I believe your father will rely on your steadfastness and virtue.
tr: Your father trusts your decisions and actions, I am sure.
es: Your father trusts in your firmness and good conduct.

en: You must not disappoint your father.”
vi: You should not disappoint your father.
tr: You must not disappoint your father."
es: Do not disappoint him.

en: “My dear aunt, this is being serious indeed.”
vi: - Auntie, what you said is really serious.
tr: "My dear sister-in-law, this matter is getting very serious.""
es: ––Dear aunt, this is really serious.

en: “Yes, and I hope to engage you to be serious likewise.”
vi: - That's right, and I hope you will be that serious.
tr: "Yes, and I invite you to be serious in the same way."
es: ––Yes, and I hope you take it seriously too.

en: “Well, then, you need not be under any alarm.
vi: - In that case, you shouldn't worry.
tr: "Well then; there's no need for you to worry.
es: ––Well, don't be alarmed.

en: I will take care of myself, and of mr Wickham too.
vi: I know how to take care of myself, and of Mr. Wickham too.
tr: I will take care of myself, and of course, Mr. Wickham too.
es: I will take care of Wickham.

en: He shall not be in love with me, if I can prevent it.”
vi: He wouldn't love me if I could prevent it.
tr: He will not fall in love with me, if I can help it."
es: If I can avoid it, he will not fall in love with me.

en: “Elizabeth, you are not serious now.”
vi: - Elizabeth, now you are being unserious.
tr: "Elizabeth, you are not serious right now.""
es: ––Elizabeth, you can't be serious.

en: “I beg your pardon.
vi: - I'm sorry, aunt.
tr: "Excuse me; I will try again.
es: ––Forgive me.

en: I will try again.
vi: Let me clarify further.
tr: "Excuse me; I will try again.
es: I will try again.

en: At present I am not in love with mr Wickham; no, I certainly am not.
vi: Right now, I don't love Mr. Wickham, I truly don't.
tr: At present, I am not in love with Mr. Wickham; no, not at all.
es: For now, I am not in love with Wickham; it's true, I am not.

en: But he is, beyond all comparison, the most agreeable man I ever saw—and if he becomes really attached to me—I believe it will be better that he should not.
vi: But in every respect, he is the most charming person I have ever met, and if he sincerely loves me, I believe it would be better if he didn't.
tr: But he is the most charming man I have ever seen – if he truly attaches himself to me – I think it would be better if he did not.
es: But he is, without comparison, the most pleasant man I have ever seen; so much so, that I wouldn't mind if he felt attracted to me.

en: I see the imprudence of it.
vi: I feel the need to be cautious.
tr: I can see the impossibility of it.
es: I know it is imprudent.

en: Oh, that abominable mr Darcy!
vi: Oh dear! That dreadful Mr. Darcy!
tr: –Oh! that scoundrel Mr. Darcy! –
es: Oh, that abominable Darcy!

en: My father’s opinion of me does me the greatest honour; and I should be miserable to forfeit it.
vi: My father's opinion of me has given me a great honor, so I would be distressed to lose this honor.
tr: My father's opinion of me honors me; if I lose it, I would be devastated.
es: The opinion my father has of me honors me; and it would grieve me greatly to lose it.

en: My father, however, is partial to mr Wickham.
vi: However, my father is not fair to Mr. Wickham.
tr: My father, meanwhile, likes Mr. Wickham.
es: However, my father is a supporter of Mr. Wickham.

en: In short, my dear aunt, I should be very sorry to be the means of making any of you unhappy; but since we see, every day, that where there is affection young people are seldom withheld, by immediate want of fortune, from entering into engagements with each other, how can I promise to be wiser than so many of my fellow-creatures, if I am tempted, or how am I even to know that it would be wiser to resist?
vi: In short, dear aunt, I would be very sorry to make my loved ones unhappy, but as we see every day, when it comes to matters of love, young people rarely lack material desires, how can I promise to be much wiser than many friends if I am tempted, or how can I know that I must be wise to restrain myself?
tr: In short, my dear aunt, I am very sorry to have made you unhappy; but we see every day that when there is love, young people get engaged without worrying about money; in this situation, how can I promise to be wiser than so many of my peers when I am about to be tempted, or even know that it would be wise to resist?
es: In short, dear aunt, I would be very sorry to make any of you suffer; but when we see daily that young people, if they are in love, usually disregard the lack of fortune when committing, how could I promise to be wiser than so many of my peers if I found myself tempted? Or how would I know that I would act wisely if I resist?

en: All that I can promise you, therefore, is not to be in a hurry.
vi: Therefore, I can only promise not to be hasty.
tr: Therefore, all I can promise you is not to rush.
es: So the only thing I can promise you is that I will not rush.

en: I will not be in a hurry to believe myself his first object.
vi: I will not hastily believe in his initial intentions.
tr: I will not be in a hurry to believe that I am his first choice.
es: I will not hasten to believe that I am the woman of his dreams.

en: When I am in company with him, I will not be wishing.
vi: When I meet him, I will not have any expectations.
tr: I will not be eager when I am with him.
es: When I am by his side, I will not show him that I like him.

en: In short, I will do my best.”
vi: In short, I will do everything possible.
tr: In short, I will do my best."
es: In other words, I will behave as best as I can.

en: “Perhaps it will be as well if you discourage his coming here so very often.
vi: - It might also be a good idea if you advise him not to come here often.
tr: "Maybe you can also prevent him from coming here so often.
es: ––Maybe you would achieve it, if you try to make sure he doesn't come here so often.

en: At least you should not remind your mother of inviting him.”
vi: At the very least, you shouldn't remind your mother to invite him.
tr: At least you won't remind your mother to invite him."
es: At the very least, you shouldn't remind your mother to invite him.

en: “As I did the other day,” said Elizabeth, with a conscious smile; “very true, it will be wise in me to refrain from that.
vi: Elizabeth gave a conscious smile. - As I reminded you that day. That's right, you should be wise and not do this.
tr: "Like I did the other day," said Elizabeth with a meaningful smile: "very true, I should give it up."
es: ––As I did the other day ––replied Elizabeth with a malicious smile––. It's true, it would be the most appropriate.

en: But do not imagine that he is always here so often.
vi: But you shouldn't think he always comes here.
tr: But don't think it happens that often.
es: But don't go imagining that he comes so often.

en: It is on your account that he has been so frequently invited this week.
vi: You noticed that this week he has often been invited.
tr: This week, thanks to you, I've been invited so frequently.
es: If we've invited him so much this week, it's because you were here.

en: You know my mother’s ideas as to the necessity of constant company for her friends.
vi: You know, my mother's idea is to always have her loved ones close by.
tr: You know my mother always wants company.
es: You know my mother's obsession with having her guests constantly accompanied.

en: But really, and upon my honour, I will try to do what I think to be wisest; and now I hope you are satisfied.”
vi: But honestly, I swear on my honor that I will try to do what I believe is the wisest. And now, I think you are reassured.
tr: But really, I give you my word, I will do what seems most sensible to me; now I hope you are satisfied.""
es: But truly, I give you my word that I will always try to do what I believe is most sensible. I hope you are happier now.

en: Her aunt assured her that she was; and Elizabeth, having thanked her for the kindness of her hints, they parted,—a wonderful instance of advice being given on such a point without being resented.
vi: Aunt reassured her niece that she was satisfied, and Elizabeth thanked her for her kind advice. The two parted ways, after a situation where advice was accepted without causing offense..
tr: Her sister-in-law said she was satisfied, and after Elizabeth thanked her for her courtesy in the warnings, they parted ways; an unusual example of giving advice on such a matter without causing offense.
es: Her aunt assured her that she was; Elizabeth thanked her for her kind warnings, and they left. Their conversation had been an admirable example of how to give advice without causing resentment.

en: mr Collins returned into Hertfordshire soon after it had been quitted by the Gardiners and Jane; but, as he took up his abode with the Lucases, his arrival was no great inconvenience to ms Bennet.
vi: Mr. Collins returned to Hertfordshire shortly after Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner and Jane left, but since he stayed at the Lucas house, his presence did not bother Mrs. Bennet much.
tr: Right after Jane left with the Gardiners, Mr. Collins returned to Hertfordshire; but since he stayed with the Lucases, his arrival did not cause much inconvenience for Mrs. Bennet.
es: Shortly after the Gardiners and Jane had left, Collins returned to Hertfordshire; but since he went to the Lucas house, Mrs. Bennet was not bothered by his arrival.

en: His marriage was now fast approaching; and she was at length so far resigned as to think it inevitable, and even repeatedly to say, in an ill-natured tone, that she “wished they might be happy.”
vi: His marriage was being hastily arranged, and in the end, she had to accept the inevitable, even though she often said in a displeased tone that she "hoped the two could be happy."
tr: His marriage was now rapidly approaching; Mrs. Bennet had finally been forced to accept that this matter was inevitable, and even repeatedly said, in a malicious tone, "I hope they can be happy."
es: The wedding was approaching, and Mrs. Bennet had resigned herself so much that she already considered it inevitable and even repeated, albeit in a bad mood, that she wished them to be happy.

en: Thursday was to be the wedding-day, and on Wednesday Miss Lucas paid her farewell visit; and when she rose to take leave, Elizabeth, ashamed of her mother’s ungracious and reluctant good wishes, and sincerely affected herself, accompanied her out of the room.
vi: The wedding was to be held on Thursday, and on Wednesday Miss Lucas came to say goodbye. As she stood up to leave, embarrassed by her mother's reluctant well-wishes, Elizabeth escorted her out of the room.
tr: The wedding was to be on Thursday; on Wednesday, Miss Lucas came for a farewell visit; when she rose to leave, Elizabeth, embarrassed by her mother's sour-faced, reluctant good wishes and sincerely moved on her own behalf, accompanied her out of the room.
es: The wedding was to be held on Thursday, and on Wednesday Miss Lucas came to make her farewell visit. When the young woman got up to leave, Elizabeth, sincerely moved and embarrassed by her mother's inattentive attitude and feigned good wishes, left the room with her and accompanied her to the door.

en: As they went down stairs together, Charlotte said,—
vi: As the two walked down the stairs, Charlotte said:
tr: As they descended the stairs together, Charlotte said–
es: As they were going down the stairs, Charlotte said:

en: “I shall depend on hearing from you very often, Eliza.”
vi: - Eliza, I hope you will keep in touch with me often.
tr: "I believe I will hear from you often, Eliza."
es: ––I trust that I will hear from you very often, Eliza.

en: “That you certainly shall.”
vi: - This is definitely doable.
tr: "Of course you will get it.""
es: ––You will have them.

en: “And I have another favour to ask.
vi: - And she also asked for another job.
tr: "I have one more request.
es: ––And I want to ask you another favor.

en: Will you come and see me?”
vi: Can you come visit her?
tr: Would you come and see me?"
es: Will you come to see me?

en: “We shall often meet, I hope, in Hertfordshire.”
vi: - I think we will often meet each other, in Hertfordshire.
tr: "I hope we often meet in Hertfordshire.""
es: ––We will see each other often in Hertfordshire, I hope.

en: “I am not likely to leave Kent for some time.
vi: - It is possible that for a while, I will not leave Kent.
tr: "It doesn't seem possible for me to leave Kent for a while.
es: ––It seems to me that I won't be able to leave Kent for a while.

en: Promise me, therefore, to come to Hunsford.”
vi: Therefore, please promise to visit me in Hunsford.
tr: So promise to come to Hunsford."
es: Therefore, promise me to come to Hunsford.

en: Elizabeth could not refuse, though she foresaw little pleasure in the visit.
vi: Elizabeth could not refuse, although she foresaw no pleasure in the visit.
tr: Elizabeth did not like the idea of the visit, but she could not say no.
es: Despite how little she liked the visit, Elizabeth could not refuse Charlotte's invitation.

en: “My father and Maria are to come to me in March,” added Charlotte, “and I hope you will consent to be of the party.
vi: Charlotte added: - Your father and Maria will visit you in March, at that time I hope you will agree to go with them.
tr: "My father and Maria will come to visit me in March," added Charlotte, "I hope you will join them as well.
es: ––My father and María will come to see me in March ––––added Charlotte–– and I would like you to accompany them.

en: Indeed, Eliza, you will be as welcome to me as either of them.”
vi: Eliza, in fact, I wish to welcome you just as much as I look forward to seeing those two again.
tr: Honestly, Eliza, your arrival would make me as happy as theirs."
es: I assure you, Eliza, that you will be as well received as they are.

en: The wedding took place: the bride and bridegroom set off for Kent from the church door, and everybody had as much to say or to hear on the subject as usual.
vi: The wedding ceremony was held. The bride and groom left the church to go to Kent, and everyone had something to say or listen to as usual.
tr: The marriage was solemnized: the bride and groom left the church and set off towards Kent; as always, there was much to tell or listen to about the event.
es: The wedding took place; the groom and the bride departed for Kent from the church door, and everyone had some comment to make or hear on the matter, as usual.

en: Elizabeth soon heard from her friend, and their correspondence was as regular and frequent as it ever had been: that it should be equally unreserved was impossible.
vi: Soon, Elizabeth received news from her friend, the two still corresponded regularly as before.
tr: Elizabeth soon received news from her friend; they were corresponding as frequently and regularly as before, but it was impossible for it to be as intimate.
es: Elizabeth soon received a letter from her friend, and their correspondence was as regular and frequent as ever.

en: Elizabeth could never address her without feeling that all the comfort of intimacy was over; and, though determined not to slacken as a correspondent, it was for the sake of what had been rather than what was.
vi: Every time she wrote to her, Elizabeth couldn't help but think that the comfortable friendliness was gone. Although she still wanted to keep in touch, it was because of their past rather than the present.
