tr: Elizabeth couldn't write to her without feeling that all sense of closeness had ended, and although she was determined not to neglect writing letters, she was writing them for the sake of past things, not present ones.
es: But no longer as frank.

en: Charlotte’s first letters were received with a good deal of eagerness: there could not but be curiosity to know how she would speak of her new home, how she would like Lady Catherine, and how happy she would dare pronounce herself to be; though, when the letters were read, Elizabeth felt that Charlotte expressed herself on every point exactly as she might have foreseen.
vi: She eagerly received Charlotte's first letters. Of course, there was the curious thought of wanting to know how she spoke about her new home, how she liked Lady Catherine, how she confidently claimed to be happy, even though Elizabeth felt Charlotte described everything exactly as Elizabeth had predicted.
tr: Charlotte's first letters were received with considerable excitement; there was natural curiosity about how she would describe her new home, whether she liked Lady Catherine, and if she was happy; however, when the letters were read, Elizabeth felt that Charlotte expressed herself exactly as she had expected in every way.
es: It was impossible for Elizabeth to address Charlotte without noticing that all her former confidence had disappeared, and although she did not want to interrupt the correspondence, she did so more for what their friendship had been than for what it actually was now. Charlotte’s first letters were received with much impatience; she was very curious to see what she would say about her new home, to know if she would have liked Lady Catherine and to what extent she would dare to confess that she was happy. But upon reading those letters, Elizabeth observed that Charlotte expressed herself exactly as she had anticipated.

en: She wrote cheerfully, seemed surrounded with comforts, and mentioned nothing which she could not praise.
vi: Charlotte's words in the letters were cheerful, seemingly wrapped in comfort, without touching on things she couldn't praise.
tr: She wrote cheerfully, seemed comfortable, and mentioned nothing that she couldn't praise.
es: She wrote cheerfully, seemed to be surrounded by comforts, and did not mention anything that was not worthy of praise.

en: The house, furniture, neighbourhood, and roads, were all to her taste, and Lady Catherine’s behaviour was most friendly and obliging.
vi: The house, the interior, the neighbors, the roads, all were to her liking, and Lady Catherine was very friendly and accommodating.
tr: The house, the furniture, the neighborhood, the roads, all were to her liking, and Lady Catherine's demeanor was extremely friendly and kind.
es: The house, the furniture, the neighborhood, and the roads, everything was to her liking, and Lady Catherine could not be more sociable and attentive.

en: It was mr Collins’s picture of Hunsford and Rosings rationally softened; and Elizabeth perceived that she must wait for her own visit there, to know the rest.
vi: This was Mr. Collins' image of Hunsford and Rosings toned down to some extent, and Elizabeth felt she would have to wait until she visited them to know the other details.
tr: The picture Mr. Collins painted of Hunsford and Rosings was only smartly softened; Elizabeth realized she would have to wait for her own visit to learn the rest.
es: It was the same portrait of Hunsford and Rosings that Mr. Collins had made, although reasonably mitigated. Elizabeth understood that she would have to wait for her own visit to learn the rest.

en: Jane had already written a few lines to her sister, to announce their safe arrival in London; and when she wrote again, Elizabeth hoped it would be in her power to say something of the Bingleys.
vi: Jane wrote a few lines to inform that she had arrived in London safely. Elizabeth hoped that her sister's next letter would tell something about the Bingley household.
tr: Jane had already informed her sister with a few lines that they had arrived safely in London; she believed that when she wrote again, she would be able to say something about the Bingleys.
es: Jane had already sent a few lines to her sister announcing her happy arrival in London; and when she wrote to her again, Elizabeth hoped that she would be able to tell her something about the Bingleys.

en: Her impatience for this second letter was as well rewarded as impatience generally is.
vi: Jane's impatience for the second letter was compensated, as she had been living in the city for a week without seeing or hearing from Caroline.
tr: His impatience for this second letter, like every impatience, received its reward.
es: Her impatience for this second letter received the usual reward for all impatience: Jane had been in the capital for a week without having seen or heard anything from Caroline.

en: Jane had been a week in town, without either seeing or hearing from Caroline.
vi: Jane's impatience for the second letter was compensated, as she had been living in the city for a week without seeing or hearing from Caroline.
tr: Jane had been in the city for a week and had neither seen Caroline nor heard from her.
es: Her impatience for this second letter received the usual reward for all impatience: Jane had been in the capital for a week without having seen or heard anything from Caroline.

en: She accounted for it, however, by supposing that her last letter to her friend from Longbourn had by some accident been lost.
vi: However, she explained that the last letter to her friend might have been lost.
tr: But she attributed this to the possibility that the last letter she wrote to her friend from Longbourn had been accidentally lost.
es: However, she explained it by assuming that the last letter she sent to her friend from Longbourn must have been lost.

en: “My aunt,” she continued, “is going to-morrow into that part of the town, and I shall take the opportunity of calling in Grosvenor Street.”
vi: She continued writing that her aunt would be going to the area they were residing in the next day, and she would have the opportunity to visit Grosvenor Street.
tr: "My sister-in-law," he continued, "is going to that part of the city tomorrow; I will also have the opportunity to stop by Grosvenor Street."
es: “My aunt,” he continued, “will go to that part of the city tomorrow, and I will have the opportunity to visit Caroline on Grosvenor Street.”

en: She wrote again when the visit was paid, and she had seen Miss Bingley.
vi: She wrote the letter after the visit.
tr: After the visit, he wrote again; he had seen Miss Bingley.
es: After the mentioned visit, in which she saw Miss Bingley, Jane wrote again: "Caroline was not in a good mood, but she was very happy to see me and reproached me for not notifying her of my arrival in London.

en: “I did not think Caroline in spirits,” were her words, “but she was very glad to see me, and reproached me for giving her no notice of my coming to London.
vi: “I didn't think Caroline was a sentimental person, but she was very happy to see me again and scolded me for not letting her know sooner that I had arrived in London.
tr: "I found Caroline unwell," he wrote, "but she was very happy to see me; she was upset that I hadn't informed her of my arrival in London.
es: After the mentioned visit, in which she saw Miss Bingley, Jane wrote again: "Caroline was not in a good mood, but she was very happy to see me and reproached me for not notifying her of my arrival in London.

en: I was right, therefore; my last letter had never reached her.
vi: Therefore, I guessed correctly that my recent letter did not reach her.
tr: So I was right; my last letter did not reach her.
es: Therefore, I was right: she had not received my letter.

en: I inquired after their brother, of course.
vi: Of course, I inquired about her brother.
tr: Of course, I asked about her siblings.
es: Naturally, I asked her about her brother.

en: He was well, but so much engaged with mr Darcy that they scarcely ever saw him.
vi: He is still the same, but very busy with Mr. Darcy, so they rarely see him.
tr: They are well, but she is so occupied with Mr. Darcy that they rarely see her.
es: She told me he was well, but that he is so busy with Mr. Darcy that she barely sees him.

en: I found that Miss Darcy was expected to dinner: I wish I could see her.
vi: I saw that they were waiting for Miss Darcy to have dinner. I hope to meet her.
tr: I learned that Miss Darcy is expected for dinner. I wish I could see her.
es: They were expecting Miss Darcy for lunch by chance; I would like to see her.

en: My visit was not long, as Caroline and ms Hurst were going out.
vi: I couldn't stay long because Caroline and Mrs. Hurst were about to go out.
tr: I couldn't stay long; Caroline and Mrs. Hurst were about to go out.
es: My visit was not long, as Caroline and Mrs. Hurst had to go out.

en: I dare say I shall soon see them here.”
vi: I believe it won't be long before I see them here again.”
tr: I think I will see them here soon."
es: I suppose they will come to see me soon."

en: Elizabeth shook her head over this letter.
vi: Elizabeth shook her head as she read the letter.
tr: Elizabeth read the letter, shaking her head.
es: Elizabeth shook her head as she read the letter.

en: It convinced her that accident only could discover to mr Bingley her sister’s being in town.
vi: It convinced her that only a chance opportunity could let Mr. Bingley know that her sister was currently in the city.
tr: So, Mr. Bingley could only have learned that his sister was in town by chance.
es: She saw clearly that only by chance could Bingley discover that Jane was in London.

en: Four weeks passed away, and Jane saw nothing of him.
vi: Four weeks passed, Jane did not see him at all.
tr: Four weeks passed and Jane did not see Mr. Bingley.
es: Four weeks passed without Jane knowing anything about him.

en: She endeavoured to persuade herself that she did not regret it; but she could no longer be blind to Miss Bingley’s inattention.
vi: She told herself she had nothing to be upset about regarding this, but she couldn't help but notice Miss Bingley's indifference.
tr: She tried to convince herself that she was not upset about this; but she could no longer ignore Miss Bingley's indifference.
es: She tried to convince herself that she did not regret it; but what she could no longer be blind to was Miss Bingley's indifference.

en: After waiting at home every morning for a fortnight, and inventing every evening a fresh excuse for her, the visitor did at last appear; but the shortness of her stay, and, yet more, the alteration of her manner, would allow Jane to deceive herself no longer.
vi: After expecting every morning for two weeks, and every evening thinking of all sorts of reasons to excuse her friend, she finally came. But the brief visit and, moreover, her friend's changed attitude, made it impossible for Jane to deceive herself any longer.
tr: After waiting at home every morning for fifteen days, and making excuses for him every evening, the visitor finally appeared; but his short stay, moreover the change in his demeanor, did not allow Jane to deceive herself any longer.
es: After waiting for her at home every morning for fifteen days and inventing an excuse for her every afternoon, she finally received her visit; but the brevity of it and, moreover, her strange attitude did not allow Jane to continue deceiving herself.

en: The letter which she wrote on this occasion to her sister will prove what she felt:—
vi: She wrote to Elizabeth about this:
tr: The letter she wrote to her sister about this will show how she felt.
es: The letter she then wrote to her sister demonstrated what she felt:

en: “My dearest Lizzy will, I am sure, be incapable of triumphing in her better judgment, at my expense, when I confess myself to have been entirely deceived in Miss Bingley’s regard for me.
vi: “My dear Lizzy, you must be proud of having outshone me in judgment, as I admit I was completely deceived by Miss Bingley.
tr: "I am sure, my dear Lizzy, that Miss Bingley will not derive any pleasure from being proven right in her judgments against me when I admit to myself that I was entirely mistaken about her regard for me.
es: I am sure, my dearest Lizzy, that you will be unable to boast at my expense about your good judgment when I confess that I have been completely disillusioned with Miss Bingley's affection.

en: But, my dear sister, though the event has proved you right, do not think me obstinate if I still assert that, considering what her behaviour was, my confidence was as natural as your suspicion.
vi: But, my dear, although the event proves you right, do not think me stubborn if I say that my trust in him was as natural as your suspicion.
tr: But, my dear sister, although events have proven you right, I hope you do not think me stubborn if I continue to say that, considering Miss Bingley's behavior, my confidence was as natural as your doubt.
es: Anyway, although the facts have proven you right, do not think me obstinate if I still assert that, given her behavior towards me, my trust was as natural as your suspicions.

en: I do not at all comprehend her reason for wishing to be intimate with me; but, if the same circumstances were to happen again, I am sure I should be deceived again.
vi: I do not understand her reasons for being so friendly with me, but if similar situations arise, I am sure I will be deceived again.
tr: I cannot understand why she wanted to be close to me; but if the same things were to happen again, I am sure I would be deceived once more.
es: Despite everything, I cannot understand why she wanted to be my friend; but if things were to happen again, I have no doubt that I would be deceived once more.

en: Caroline did not return my visit till yesterday; and not a note, not a line, did I receive in the meantime.
vi: It was only yesterday that Caroline visited me in return, and she had not written a single word to me before that.
tr: Caroline only returned my visit yesterday; during the intervening time, I received neither a note nor a single line from her.
es: Caroline did not return my visit until yesterday, and in the meantime, I did not receive a single note or line from her.

en: When she did come, it was very evident that she had no pleasure in it; she made a slight, formal apology for not calling before, said not a word of wishing to see me again, and was, in every respect, so altered a creature, that when she went away I was perfectly resolved to continue the acquaintance no longer.
vi: When she came, it was clear she took no pleasure in the visit. She offered a superficial, solemn apology for not visiting sooner, without expressing any desire to see me again. Her demeanor had changed so completely that when she left, I resolved not to continue the acquaintance.
tr: When she did come, it was clear she did not enjoy it; she made a light, formal apology for not having called earlier, said nothing about wanting to see me again, and in every way was so changed that I resolved not to continue our acquaintance after she left.
es: When she came, it was quite clear that it was against her will; she gave a slight, merely formal excuse for not having come earlier; she did not say a word about when we would see each other again and was so upset that, when she left, I firmly decided to put an end to our relationship.

en: I pity, though I cannot help blaming, her.
vi: I pity her, though I cannot help but blame her.
tr: I pity her, but I cannot help blaming her.
es: I feel sorry, although I cannot help but blame her.

en: She was very wrong in singling me out as she did; I can safely say, that every advance to intimacy began on her side.
vi: She was entirely mistaken in targeting me. I can rightly say that all the beginnings of our acquaintance were initiated by her.
tr: She made a great mistake in singling me out; I can safely say that all the advances came from her.
es: She was wrong to choose me as a friend. But I can safely say that it was she who took the first step to become close to me.

en: But I pity her, because she must feel that she has been acting wrong, and because I am very sure that anxiety for her brother is the cause of it.
vi: But I pity her, for she must realize she was wrong, and I am convinced that the reason for this is her concern for her brother.
tr: But I pity her, because she must feel she has acted wrongly, and I am sure it is her concern for her brother that is the cause.
es: Anyway, I pity her because she must understand that she has behaved very badly, and because I am sure that her concern for her brother was the cause of everything.

en: I need not explain myself farther; and though we know this anxiety to be quite needless, yet if she feels it, it will easily account for her behaviour to me; and so deservedly dear as he is to his sister, whatever anxiety she may feel on his behalf is natural and amiable.
vi: I need not explain further; although we all know there is no need for such anxiety, if she is worried, it easily explains her attitude towards me. Any concern for her brother is natural and endearing, as he deserves such care from his sister.
tr: I need not explain myself further; we know that this concern is entirely unnecessary, but if she is worried, it easily explains her behavior towards me; since she is justly so fond of her brother, any concern on his behalf is natural and reasonable.
es: And although we know that this concern is unnecessary, the fact of feeling it justifies her attitude towards me, and since he fully deserves his sister's adoration, all the anxiety he inspires in her is natural and appreciable.

en: I cannot but wonder, however, at her having any such fears now, because if he had at all cared about me, we must have met long, long ago.
vi: However, she still worried about her fear, because if he still cared about her, he could have met her many days ago.
tr: However, I cannot help being surprised that she should feel such fears now, because if Mr. Bingley cared about me, we would have met a very, very long time ago.
es: But I cannot help but wonder why she continues to have these fears, for if he had been interested in me, we would have seen each other a long time ago.

en: He knows of my being in town, I am certain, from something she said herself; and yet it would seem, by her manner of talking, as if she wanted to persuade herself that he is really partial to Miss Darcy.
vi: From her sister's words, she was certain that he knew she was currently residing in the city. Yet, from the way she talked, it seemed he truly leaned towards Miss Darcy.
tr: He knows I am in town, I gathered that from something Miss Bingley said; yet it was evident from the way she spoke that she wanted to convince herself that Mr. Bingley really admired Miss Darcy.
es: He knows that I am in the city; I deduce this from something she herself said; and still, it seemed, by her way of speaking, that she needed to convince herself that Bingley is really interested in Miss Darcy.

en: I cannot understand it.
vi: She couldn't understand this.
tr: I cannot understand it.
es: I do not understand it.

en: If I were not afraid of judging harshly, I should be almost tempted to say, that there is a strong appearance of duplicity in all this.
vi: If she didn't fear being judged harshly, she could clearly say there was an ambivalent attitude in everything.
tr: If I were not afraid of making a harsh judgment, I would say there is a strong appearance of duplicity in all this.
es: If I did not fear judging harshly, I would almost say that there is more to this than meets the eye.

en: I will endeavour to banish every painful thought, and think only of what will make me happy, your affection, and the invariable kindness of my dear uncle and aunt.
vi: But she would try to dispel all sorrowful thoughts, only thinking about things that made her happy, about her sister's love, about the kindness of their uncle and aunt.
tr: But I will try to keep every painful thought at bay and think only of what will make me happy, your love, the unfailing kindness of my dear uncle and aunt.
es: But I will try to dispel all these painful thoughts and think only of what makes me happy: your affection and the unalterable kindness of our dear uncles.

en: Let me hear from you very soon.
vi: Write to me soon.
tr: I wish to hear from you as soon as possible.
es: Write to me soon.

en: Miss Bingley said something of his never returning to Netherfield again, of giving up the house, but not with any certainty.
vi: Miss Bingley mentioned something about him never returning to Netherfield, about giving up the house, but it is not certain.
tr: Miss Bingley said something about not returning to Netherfield and leaving the house, but she was not definite.
es: Miss Bingley spoke of never returning to Netherfield and of getting rid of the house, but not with much certainty.

en: We had better not mention it.
vi: It is better not to mention this matter.
tr: It is best not to speak of it.
es: It is better not to mention these things.

en: I am extremely glad that you have such pleasant accounts from our friends at Hunsford.
vi: I am very glad to know that you are on good terms with our friends at Hunsford.
tr: I am very glad to hear that you have received pleasant news from our friends at Hunsford.
es: I am very glad that you have had such good news from our friends in Hunsford.

en: Pray go to see them, with Sir William and Maria.
vi: Go visit them, with Sir William and Maria.
tr: Please go and see them, with Sir William and Maria.
es: Please go to see them with Sir William and Maria.

en: I am sure you will be very comfortable there.
vi: I believe you will feel comfortable there.
tr: I am sure you will be very comfortable there.
es: I am sure you will be well there.

en: “Yours, etc.”
vi: My older sister
tr: –With love."
es: Yours,

en: This letter gave Elizabeth some pain; but her spirits returned, as she considered that Jane would no longer be duped, by the sister at least.
vi: Elizabeth felt somewhat pained when reading the letter, but she calmed herself with the thought that Jane would no longer be deceived, at least by the sister.
tr: This letter upset Elizabeth a little; but at least she felt better thinking that Jane could no longer be deceived by that sister.
es: Jane Elizabeth felt a bit sorry about this letter, but she regained her spirits by thinking that at least she would no longer be fooled by Miss Bingley.

en: All expectation from the brother was now absolutely over.
vi: All expectations from the brother had completely vanished.
tr: Expectations regarding the brother were now definitely over.
es: All hope regarding the brother had completely vanished.

en: She would not even wish for any renewal of his attentions.
vi: She did not even hope to rekindle his affections.
tr: She didn't even want his interest to revive.
es: She didn't even wish for their relationship to be renewed.

en: His character sunk on every review of it; and, as a punishment for him, as well as a possible advantage to Jane, she seriously hoped he might really soon marry mr Darcy’s sister, as, by Wickham’s account, she would make him abundantly regret what he had thrown away.
vi: His character had diminished in every respect. She sincerely hoped he would marry Miss Darcy, as a punishment for him and a benefit for Jane, because according to Mr. Wickham, she would make him deeply regret what he had thrown away.
tr: With every examination, his character became a little more unpleasant; punishing him and giving Jane a possible advantage, she seriously hoped that he would soon truly marry Mr. Darcy's sister, because according to Wickham, the girl was the kind who would make him regret the things he had thrown away a thousand times over.
es: Every time she thought of him, his character disappointed her more. And as a punishment for him and for Jane's benefit, Elizabeth wished he would marry Mr. Darcy's sister as soon as possible, for, according to what Wickham said, she would make him regret greatly what he had scorned.

en: ms Gardiner about this time reminded Elizabeth of her promise concerning that gentleman, and required information; and Elizabeth had such to send as might rather give contentment to her aunt than to herself.
vi: Around this time, Mrs. Gardiner reminded Elizabeth of her promise to interact with that young man, and inquired about the news. Elizabeth had to comply to put her aunt at ease.
tr: Around the same days, Mrs. Gardiner reminded Elizabeth of her promise regarding that gentleman and asked for information; Elizabeth had such information that would please her aunt more than herself.
es: Meanwhile, Mrs. Gardiner reminded Elizabeth of her promise regarding Wickham and wanted to know how things were going. Elizabeth's news was more favorable for her aunt than for herself.

en: His apparent partiality had subsided, his attentions were over, he was the admirer of some one else.
vi: He no longer paid exclusive attention to her; his attentions were gone, he was fond of someone else.
tr: Wickham's evident admiration had passed, his interest had ended; he was now infatuated with someone else.
es: Wickham's apparent interest had disappeared, as had his attentions. Now it was another whom he admired.

en: Elizabeth was watchful enough to see it all, but she could see it and write of it without material pain.
vi: Elizabeth observed carefully so she knew everything, but she could look and write about it without feeling sorrow.
tr: Elizabeth was perceptive enough to see it all, but she could see and write about it without feeling significant pain.
es: Elizabeth was observant enough to notice everything, but she saw it and wrote about it without much sorrow.

en: Her heart had been but slightly touched, and her vanity was satisfied with believing that she would have been his only choice, had fortune permitted it.
vi: Her heart had only slightly fluttered; her vanity was satisfied with the thought that she could have been his only choice, if circumstances had allowed.
tr: She wasn't very hurt; her pride was satisfied when she believed that she would be his only choice if his financial situation allowed it.
es: It had not made much of an impression on her heart, and her vanity was satisfied with believing that she would have been his favorite if her fortune had allowed it.

en: The sudden acquisition of ten thousand pounds was the most remarkable charm of the young lady to whom he was now rendering himself agreeable; but Elizabeth, less clear-sighted perhaps in this case than in Charlotte’s, did not quarrel with him for his wish of independence.
vi: The fact that he unexpectedly received ten thousand pounds was the most attractive thing about the girl he was pursuing. But Elizabeth, perhaps in this case not as farsighted as Charlotte, did not argue with him about his desire for independence.
tr: The most striking charm of the young lady he was now trying to impress was that she had suddenly come into possession of ten thousand pounds; but perhaps because Elizabeth, who showed more understanding to Wickham than she did to Charlotte, wanted to be free, she did not quarrel with him.
es: The sudden acquisition of ten thousand pounds was the most notable charm of the young woman to whom Wickham now paid his attention. But Elizabeth, perhaps less perceptive in this case than in Charlotte's, did not blame him for his desire for independence.

en: Nothing, on the contrary, could be more natural; and, while able to suppose that it cost him a few struggles to relinquish her, she was ready to allow it a wise and desirable measure for both, and could very sincerely wish him happy.
vi: On the contrary, nothing could be more natural. While guessing that he had to go through some mental struggle to part from her, she was ready to wish him happiness.
tr: On the contrary, nothing could be more natural; while she guessed that Wickham had to struggle a bit to leave her, she was ready to accept that it was a wise and suitable solution for both of them and sincerely wished him happiness.
es: On the contrary, it seemed the most natural thing in the world to her, and as she presumed it cost him some effort to give her up, she was willing to consider it the wisest and most desirable measure for both, and could sincerely wish him much happiness.

en: All this was acknowledged to ms Gardiner; and, after relating the circumstances, she thus went on:—“I am now convinced, my dear aunt, that I have never been much in love; for had I really experienced that pure and elevating passion, I should at present detest his very name, and wish him all manner of evil.
vi: She explained everything to Mrs. Gardiner, and continued: “Dear aunt, now I am sure that I have never been in love, because if I had truly experienced that pure and noble feeling, I would now detest even his name and wish all sorts of ill upon him.
tr: All this was told to Mrs. Gardiner; after recounting the events, Elizabeth continued: – "Now I believe, my dear aunt, that I was not too much in love; for if I had experienced that pure and intoxicating passion, I would now be cursing his name and wishing him ill.
es: She communicated all this to Mrs. Gardiner; and after recounting all the details, she added: "I am convinced, dear aunt, that I have never been truly in love, for if I had really felt that pure and elevated passion of love, I would detest even his name and wish him the greatest misfortunes.

en: But my feelings are not only cordial towards him, they are even impartial towards Miss King.
vi: But my feelings towards him are not only kind but also indifferent towards Miss King.
tr: But I have good feelings towards him, and I am indifferent to Miss King.
es: But not only do I still appreciate him, I do not feel any aversion towards Miss King.

en: I cannot find out that I hate her at all, or that I am in the least unwilling to think her a very good sort of girl.
vi: I do not hate her at all, and I am willing to acknowledge that she is a good example of a fine young lady.
tr: I don't even feel like hating him or refusing to think that she is a very good girl.
es: I do not hate her, I do not want to believe she is a bad girl.

en: There can be no love in all this.
vi: There could not have been any love in this matter.
tr: There can be no love in all this.
es: This cannot be love.

en: My watchfulness has been effectual; and though I should certainly be a more interesting object to all my acquaintance, were I distractedly in love with him, I cannot say that I regret my comparative insignificance.
vi: My vigilance has paid off. Although I would certainly become the subject of everyone's attention if I foolishly fell in love with him, I do not regret becoming unimportant.
tr: Being alert has helped me; if I were madly in love with him, I would certainly be a more interesting person to all my acquaintances, but I can't say that I regret my relative insignificance.
es: My precautions have been effective; and although my friends would worry much more about me if I were madly in love with him, I cannot say that I regret my relative insignificance.

en: Importance may sometimes be purchased too dearly.
vi: Sometimes one can pay a high price to become important.
tr: Importance can sometimes be bought at a very high price.
es: Importance is sometimes paid for too dearly.

en: Kitty and Lydia take his defection much more to heart than I do.
vi: Kitty and Lydia are more concerned than I am about his distancing himself from me.
tr: Kitty and Lydia are much more troubled by this betrayal than I am.
es: Kitty and Lydia take Wickham's betrayal more to heart than I do.

en: They are young in the ways of the world, and not yet open to the mortifying conviction that handsome young men must have something to live on as well as the plain.”
vi: They are still young, not yet ready to accept the embarrassing reality that handsome young men must have something to rely on to live.”
tr: They are still young in the ways of the world; they are not yet open to believing that handsome young men can be as concerned with making a living as ordinary men."
es: They are still too young to see the reality of the world and to acquire the humiliating conviction that handsome men must have something to live on, just like the ugly ones."

en: CHAPTER XXVII.
vi: Chapter 27
tr: Chapter IV
es: CHAPTER XXVII/h3>

en: WITH no greater events than these in the Longbourn family, and otherwise diversified by little beyond the walks to Meryton, sometimes dirty and sometimes cold, did January and February pass away.
vi: February and March passed without any events of greater importance at Longbourn, with little variation through visits to Meryton, sometimes muddy, sometimes cold.
tr: The months of January and February passed for the Longbourn family without any events of greater significance, or without much color aside from occasional walks to Meryton, sometimes in the mud, sometimes in the cold.
es: Without any significant events in the Longbourn family, and with no more variation than walks to Meryton, sometimes muddy and sometimes cold, the months of January and February passed.

en: March was to take Elizabeth to Hunsford.
vi: In March, Elizabeth visited Huntsford.
tr: In March, Elizabeth was to go to Hunsford.
es: March was the month in which Elizabeth would go to Hunsford.

en: She had not at first thought very seriously of going thither; but Charlotte, she soon found, was depending on the plan, and she gradually learned to consider it herself with greater pleasure as well as greater certainty.
vi: At first, she had no serious intention of going there, but she learned that Charlotte was eagerly awaiting her, and she gradually thought of the trip with joy and more determination.
tr: Initially, she was not very serious about going; but soon she realized that Charlotte valued the plan, and gradually she learned to think about it with both greater pleasure and greater determination.
es: At first, she did not seriously think of going. But she saw that Charlotte took it for granted, and little by little she became pleasantly accustomed to the idea until she decided to go.

en: Absence had increased her desire of seeing Charlotte again, and weakened her disgust of mr Collins.
vi: Their absence had made her eager to see Charlotte again and less resentful of Mr. Collins.
tr: In their absence, her desire to see Charlotte again had increased, and her displeasure towards Mr. Collins had diminished.
es: With the absence, her desire to see Charlotte had increased and her aversion to Collins had diminished.

en: There was novelty in the scheme; and as, with such a mother and such uncompanionable sisters, home could not be faultless, a little change was not unwelcome for its own sake.
vi: There was a bit of novelty in the plan, for with such a mother and sisters who could not be close, the family setting inevitably became unpleasant, so a little change of scenery was good for her.
tr: Life demanded novelty; a home with such a mother and such unbearable sisters could not be considered perfect; a small change, even for her own sake, would not be bad at all.
es: The project involved a certain novelty, and since with such a mother and such unbearable sisters, her home was not a very pleasant place, she could not disregard this change of scenery.

en: The journey would, moreover, give her a peep at Jane; and, in short, as the time drew near, she would have been very sorry for any delay.
vi: The trip could also give her a brief insight into Jane's situation. As the day of departure approached, she would have regretted any delay.
tr: Moreover, the journey would give her the opportunity to see Jane; in short, as the time approached, she began to worry that there might be a delay or something.
es: The trip also provided her with the pleasure of going to give Jane a hug; so much so that when the date approached, she would have regretted having to postpone it.

en: Everything, however, went on smoothly, and was finally settled according to Charlotte’s first sketch.
vi: However, everything went smoothly, finally arranged according to Charlotte's outline.
tr: But everything went smoothly and was arranged according to Charlotte's initial plan.
es: But everything went smoothly and the trip was carried out according to Charlotte's plans.

en: She was to accompany Sir William and his second daughter.
vi: She would accompany Sir William and his second daughter.
tr: Sir William would accompany her along with his second daughter.
es: Elizabeth would accompany Sir William and his second daughter.

en: The improvement of spending a night in London was added in time, and the plan became as perfect as plan could be.
vi: They decided to spend the night in London, and thus the plan became perfect.
tr: The plan became perfect with the addition of the idea of spending the night in London.
es: And to top it off, they decided to spend a night in London; the plan was so perfect that nothing more could be asked for.

en: The only pain was in leaving her father, who would certainly miss her, and who, when it came to the point, so little liked her going, that he told her to write to him, and almost promised to answer her letter.
vi: The only thing that worried her was having to leave her father, who would surely miss her, had asked her to write letters home and almost promised to reply, even though he didn't want to see her go.
tr: Her only sorrow was parting from her father; her father would miss her very much, so when the time came, he was not very supportive of her leaving, told her to write to him, and almost promised to reply to her letter.
es: The only thing that saddened Elizabeth was parting from her father, because she knew he would miss her, and when the time came to leave, he became so sad that he asked his daughter to write to him and even promised to reply to her letter.

en: The farewell between herself and mr Wickham was perfectly friendly; on his side even more.
vi: Both she and Mr. Wickham showed the utmost friendliness when they parted; even he appeared more friendly.
tr: The farewell with Mr. Wickham was quite amicable, especially from Wickham's perspective.
es: The farewell between Wickham and Elizabeth was very cordial, even more so on Wickham's part.

en: His present pursuit could not make him forget that Elizabeth had been the first to excite and to deserve his attention, the first to listen and to pity, the first to be admired; and in his manner of bidding her adieu, wishing her every enjoyment, reminding her of what she was to expect in Lady Catherine de Bourgh, and trusting their opinion of her—their opinion of everybody—would always coincide, there was a solicitude, an interest, which she felt must ever attach her to him with a most sincere regard; and she parted from him convinced, that, whether married or single, he must always be her model of the amiable and pleasing.
vi: The affection he currently pursued could not make him forget that Elizabeth had been the first to awaken feelings in him and deserved those feelings, the first to listen to him and pity him, the first to be admired by him. In the way he bid her farewell, when he wished her all happiness, reminded her of what Lady Catherine de Bourgh was like, and when he believed that their opinions of this lady – their opinions of everyone – always coincided, there was a desire, a concern that she felt must always bind her to him with the sincerest respect. Then she bid him farewell, believing that whether he was married or still single, he would always be to her the epitome of a charming person.
tr: His current objective had not allowed him to forget that Elizabeth was the first woman to catch his interest and deserve it, the first to listen and sympathize, the first to be admired; there was a closeness, an interest in his manner while saying goodbye, wishing her good times, reminding her what to expect from Lady Catherine de Bourgh, and saying that he believed they would be in agreement about her – about everyone – and because of this, Elizabeth felt she would remain forever sincerely attached to Wickham; when she parted from him, whether married or single, she believed he would always be the model of a charming and delightful man for her.
es: Although at that moment he was occupied with other things, he could not forget that she was the first to excite and deserve his attention, the first to listen to him and sympathize with him, and the first to please him. And in his manner of saying goodbye, wishing her well, reminding her of what Lady Catherine de Bourgh seemed like to him, and repeating that his opinions about her and everyone else would always coincide, there was such solicitude and interest that Elizabeth felt filled with the most sincere affection towards him and left convinced that she would always consider Wickham, single or married, as a model of sympathy and simplicity.

en: Her fellow-travellers the next day were not of a kind to make her think him less agreeable.
vi: Her companions were not the kind of people who made her think he was less pleasant.
tr: The passengers accompanying him the next day were not the type to make Wickham fall out of favor.
es: Her travel companions for the next day were not the most suitable for Elizabeth to remember Wickham with less displeasure.

en: Sir William Lucas, and his daughter Maria, a good-humoured girl, but as empty-headed as himself, had nothing to say that could be worth hearing, and were listened to with about as much delight as the rattle of the chaise.
vi: Sir William Lucas and his daughter Maria, a cheerful girl but as empty-headed as her father, had nothing worth listening to. She listened to them with as much interest as she would to the clattering of a horse-drawn carriage.
tr: Sir William Lucas and his daughter Maria, a polite but as empty-headed girl as her father, did not have anything worth listening to; listening to them was no more enjoyable than listening to the creaking of the carriage.
es: Sir William and his daughter Maria, a cheerful girl but as empty-headed as her father, said nothing worth listening to; so hearing them was the same for Elizabeth as hearing the rattling of the carriage.

en: Elizabeth loved absurdities, but she had known Sir William’s too long.
vi: Elizabeth enjoyed hearing nonsense, but she had known Sir William for too long.
tr: Elizabeth liked oddities, but she had known Sir William's for too long.
es: Elizabeth was amused by the nonsense, but she had known Sir William for too long and he could tell her nothing new about the wonders of his presentation at court and his title of "Sir," and his courtesies were as stale as his news.

en: He could tell her nothing new of the wonders of his presentation and knighthood; and his civilities were worn out, like his information.
vi: He could no longer tell her anything new about his audience with the king or his knighthood, and his politeness was running thin with his repetitive stories.
tr: He could not tell her anything new about the wonders of his presentation at court and his knighthood; his polite manners, like his stories, had worn out.
es: Elizabeth was amused by the nonsense, but she had known Sir William for too long and he could tell her nothing new about the wonders of his presentation at court and his title of "Sir," and his courtesies were as stale as his news.

en: It was a journey of only twenty-four miles, and they began it so early as to be in Gracechurch Street by noon.
vi: The trip was only twenty-four miles, and the three of them set out early to reach Gracechurch Street by noon.
tr: It was a twenty-four-mile journey; they set out early and arrived at Gracechurch Street by noon.
es: The journey was only twenty-four miles, and they set out so early that by noon they were already on Gracechurch Street.

en: As they drove to mr Gardiner’s door, Jane was at a drawing-room window watching their arrival: when they entered the passage, she was there to welcome them, and Elizabeth, looking earnestly in her face, was pleased to see it healthful and lovely as ever.
vi: As they entered Mrs. Gardiner's house, Jane was in the drawing-room watching them come in, and she stepped out to greet them. Elizabeth looked intently and was delighted to see that her sister was still as healthy and pretty as ever.
tr: As they approached Mr. Gardiner's door, Jane was at the sitting room window, waiting for their arrival; when they entered the courtyard, she came down to greet them; Elizabeth, who looked eagerly at her face, was happy to see her looking as healthy and charming as ever.
es: As they approached the Gardiners' door, Jane was at the sitting room window watching their arrival; when they entered the hall, she was already there to welcome them. Elizabeth examined her anxiously and was pleased to find her as healthy and charming as ever.

en: On the stairs were a troop of little boys and girls, whose eagerness for their cousin’s appearance would not allow them to wait in the drawing-room, and whose shyness, as they had not seen her for a twelvemonth, prevented their coming lower.
vi: On the stairs was a group of children, eager to meet their cousin but not allowed into the drawing-room, and too shy to approach because they hadn't seen her in twelve months.
tr: There was a group of girls and boys on the stairs; their curiosity to see their cousins had not allowed them to wait in the sitting room, and their shyness, having not seen her for twelve months, had not allowed them to come down.
es: On the stairs, there was a throng of boys and girls too impatient to see their cousin to wait for her in the sitting room, but their shyness kept them from fully descending and going to meet her, as it had been more than a year since they last saw her.

en: All was joy and kindness.
vi: Everyone was cheerful and kind.
tr: Everything was cheerful and sweet.
es: Everything was joy and attentions.

en: The day passed most pleasantly away; the morning in bustle and shopping, and the evening at one of the theatres.
vi: They enjoyed each other's company all day; during the day they bustled around and went shopping, and in the evening they went to see a musical.
tr: Most of the day passed pleasantly; bustling and shopping in the morning, theater in the evening.
es: The day passed pleasantly; in the afternoon, they strolled around and visited the shops, and in the evening, they went to a theater.

en: Elizabeth then contrived to sit by her aunt.
vi: Then Elizabeth managed to sit with her aunt. The first topic of conversation between the aunt and niece was the elder sister.
tr: Elizabeth made an adjustment and sat down next to her aunt.
es: Elizabeth then managed to sit next to her aunt.

en: Their first subject was her sister; and she was more grieved than astonished to hear, in reply to her minute inquiries, that though Jane always struggled to support her spirits, there were periods of dejection.
vi: Elizabeth felt more sorrow than surprise after inquiring thoroughly and hearing that Jane had periods of despondency despite always struggling mentally to lift herself up.
tr: Their first topic was her sister; as detailed questions were answered, she felt more pain than surprise upon hearing that Jane always struggled to be cheerful but also went through periods of depression.
es: The first topic of conversation was Jane; after hearing the answers to the detailed questions she asked about her sister, Elizabeth was more saddened than surprised to learn that Jane, although always striving to keep her spirits high, was going through moments of great despondency.

en: It was reasonable, however, to hope that they would not continue long.
vi: However, there was reason to hope that this condition would not last long.
tr: Fortunately, it was possible to hope that it wouldn't last long.
es: Nevertheless, it was reasonable to expect that they would not last long.

en: ms Gardiner gave her the particulars also of Miss Bingley’s visit in Gracechurch Street, and repeated conversations occurring at different times between Jane and herself, which proved that the former had, from her heart, given up the acquaintance.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner also mentioned Miss Bingley's visit, recounting the things the two ladies discussed, showing that Jane sincerely wanted to abandon the relationship.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner also gave her the details of Miss Bingley's visit to Gracechurch Street and repeated the details of the conversations that took place between her and Jane at different times; it was understood that Miss Bingley had ended the friendship from her own perspective.
es: Mrs. Gardiner also told her details of Miss Bingley's visit to Gracechurch, and repeated some conversations she had later with Jane that showed the latter had ended their friendship.

en: ms Gardiner then rallied her niece on Wickham’s desertion, and complimented her on bearing it so well.
vi: Then Mrs. Gardiner inquired of her niece about Mr. Wickham's departure from her, praising her for enduring it very well.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner then pressed her niece about Wickham's misconduct and congratulated her for enduring it so well.
es: Mrs. Gardiner consoled her niece for Wickham's betrayal and congratulated her on how well she had taken it.

en: “But, my dear Elizabeth,” she added, “what sort of girl is Miss King?
vi: She added: - But, Elizabeth dear, what kind of person is Miss King?
tr: "But, dear Elizabeth," he added, "what kind of girl is Miss King?
es: ––But tell me, dear Elizabeth ––he added––, what kind of girl is Miss King?

en: I should be sorry to think our friend mercenary.”
vi: You would regret it if you thought she was opportunistic.
tr: It is sad to think that our friend is a gold-digger."
es: I would be very sorry to think that our friend is a fortune hunter.

en: “Pray, my dear aunt, what is the difference in matrimonial affairs, between the mercenary and the prudent motive?
vi: - Aunt, could you please explain the difference between opportunism and prudence in matters of marriage?
tr: "Please tell me, dear aunt, what is the difference between being greedy and being prudent in matters of marriage?
es: ––Let's see, dear aunt, what is the difference in matrimonial matters between selfish motives and prudent ones?

en: Where does discretion end, and avarice begin?
vi: Where does prudence begin and where does greed end?
tr: Where do emotions end and greed begin?
es: Where does discretion end and greed begin?

en: Last Christmas you were afraid of his marrying me, because it would be imprudent; and now, because he is trying to get a girl with only ten thousand pounds, you want to find out that he is mercenary.”
vi: Last Christmas, you were afraid I would marry him because it would be reckless, but now because he wants to marry a girl with only ten thousand pounds, you want to think he is greedy.
tr: Last Christmas you were afraid of him marrying me because you thought it would be foolish; but now you want to think he is greedy just because he is trying to win a girl who only has ten thousand pounds."
es: Last Christmas you feared he would marry me because it would have been imprudent, and now because he is seeking a young woman with only ten thousand pounds of income, you assume he is a fortune hunter.

en: “If you will only tell me what sort of girl Miss King is, I shall know what to think.”
vi: - If you just tell me what kind of person she is, I will know what to think.
tr: "If you tell me what kind of girl Miss King is, I will decide what to think."
es: ––Just tell me what kind of person Miss King is, and I will be able to form a judgment.

en: “She is a very good kind of girl, I believe.
vi: - I believe she is a very good girl.
tr: "She is a very good girl, in my opinion.
es: ––I think she is a good girl.

en: I know no harm of her.”
vi: I don't think badly of her.
tr: I haven't seen any harm from her."
es: I haven't heard anything bad about her.

en: “But he paid her not the smallest attention till her grandfather’s death made her mistress of this fortune?”
vi: - But he didn't pay any attention to her, not until she inherited that sum of money.
tr: "But he never showed any interest in the girl until he inherited this fortune after his grandfather's death.""
es: ––But he didn't pay her the slightest attention until her grandfather's death made her the owner of that fortune...

en: “No—why should he?
vi: - That's right, but why did you have to pay attention to her first?
tr: "No –why should he show it?
es: ––Of course, why would he do it?

en: If it were not allowable for him to gain my affections, because I had no money, what occasion could there be for making love to a girl whom he did not care about, and who was equally poor?”
vi: If he is not allowed to win your affection because you have no money, what chance does he have to confess his feelings to a girl he doesn't care about and who is also poor?
tr: If he doesn't care about winning my heart because I have no money, what sense does it make for him to court a girl who is equally penniless?"
es: If he couldn't afford to win me over because I had no money, what reason would he have to court a girl who meant nothing to him and was as poor as I was?

en: “But there seems indelicacy in directing his attentions towards her so soon after this event.”
vi: - But it seems he lacked tact when he paid attention to her right after she inherited.
tr: "But there's something crude about immediately turning his attention to her right after this incident."
es: ––But it seems improper for him to direct his attentions to her so soon after that event.

en: “A man in distressed circumstances has not time for all those elegant decorums which other people may observe.
vi: - A young man in distressing circumstances does not have time for all the formalities that others might adhere to.
tr: "A man in distress does not have the time to devote to all those elegant customs that others might observe."
es: ––A man who is in a bad situation does not have time, like others, to observe those elegant delicacies.

en: If she does not object to it, why should we?”
vi: If she does not oppose, why should we oppose?
tr: If the girl does not object, why should we?"
es: Besides, if she does not reproach him, why should we reproach him?

en: “Her not objecting does not justify him.
vi: - Her lack of resistance cannot justify him.
tr: "The girl's lack of objection does not justify the man.
es: ––The fact that she doesn't care doesn't justify Wickham.

en: It only shows her being deficient in something herself—sense or feeling.”
vi: It only shows that she lacks either awareness or feelings.
tr: It only shows a deficiency within the girl herself – either emotion or sensitivity."
es: It only shows that this young lady lacks sense or sensitivity.

en: “Well,” cried Elizabeth, “have it as you choose.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - Alright, it's up to you to think.
tr: "Well," cried Elizabeth, "say whatever you like.
es: ––Well ––exclaimed Elizabeth––, as you wish.

en: He shall be mercenary, and she shall be foolish.”
vi: He is greedy, and she is foolish.
tr: Let the man be greedy, and the girl be foolish."
es: Let's say he is a fortune hunter and she is a fool.

en: “No, Lizzy, that is what I do not choose.
vi: - No, Lizzy, it's not up to you to think whatever you want.
tr: "No, Lizzy, that's not what I meant.
es: ––No, Elizabeth, that's what I don't want.

en: I should be sorry, you know, to think ill of a young man who has lived so long in Derbyshire.”
vi: You know, I feel sad thinking badly about a young man who has lived in Derbyshire for a long time.
tr: It would truly upset me to think badly of a young man who has lived in Derbyshire for so long."
es: You know it would hurt me to think badly of a young man who lived so long in Derbyshire.

en: “Oh, if that is all, I have a very poor opinion of young men who live in Derbyshire; and their intimate friends who live in Hertfordshire are not much better.
vi: - Oh dear! If that's all, I have a very poor opinion of the young men living in Derbyshire, and their friends in Hertfordshire are no better.
tr: "Oh! If that's the issue, I have no regard for the young men living in Derbyshire; their close friends living in Hertfordshire are no better.
es: ––Ah! Well, if that's the case, I have a very poor opinion of the young men who live in Derbyshire, whose close friends, who live in Hertfordshire, are not much better.

en: I am sick of them all.
vi: I'm fed up with all of them.
tr: I'm tired of all of them.
es: I'm fed up with all of them.

en: Thank heaven!
vi: Thank God!
tr: Thank God!
es: Thank God, tomorrow I'm going to a place where I'll meet a man who has no pleasant qualities, who has neither manners nor the ability to be likable.

en: I am going to-morrow where I shall find a man who has not one agreeable quality, who has neither manners nor sense to recommend him.
vi: Tomorrow I will go to a place where I can find a man who has no agreeable qualities, no dignity, or sense worth mentioning.
tr: Tomorrow, I'm going to a place where I'll meet a man who has not a single charming aspect, neither inside nor out.
es: Thank God, tomorrow I'm going to a place where I'll meet a man who has no pleasant qualities, who has neither manners nor the ability to be likable.

en: Stupid men are the only ones worth knowing, after all.”
vi: After all, only fools are worth getting to know.
tr: In my opinion, foolish men are the only ones worth knowing."
es: After all, stupid men are the only ones worth knowing.

en: “Take care, Lizzy; that speech savours strongly of disappointment.”
vi: - Be careful, Lizzy, such words clearly show disappointment.
tr: "Oh dear, Lizzy; there's a strong sense of disappointment in this conversation."
es: ––Watch out, Lizzy! Those words sound too much like disappointment.

en: Before they were separated by the conclusion of the play, she had the unexpected happiness of an invitation to accompany her uncle and aunt in a tour of pleasure which they proposed taking in the summer.
vi: Before they parted ways with a playful concluding remark, she had the unexpected pleasure of being invited to join her uncle and aunt on their summer trip.
tr: Before parting ways at the end of the game, with unexpected joy, they received an invitation to accompany their uncle and aunt on the trip they were planning to take in the summer.
es: Before parting ways after finishing the work, Elizabeth had the unexpected joy of being invited by her uncles to accompany them on a trip they were planning to take in the summer.

en: “We have not quite determined how far it shall carry us,” said ms Gardiner; “but perhaps, to the Lakes.”
vi: Mrs. Gardiner said: - Aunt and uncle haven't decided how far they will go, but they might go to the Lake District.
tr: "We haven't decided exactly how far we will go yet," said Mrs. Gardiner, "perhaps we might go as far as the Lake District."
es: ––We still don't know how far we will go ––said Mrs. Gardiner––, but we might reach the Lakes.

en: No scheme could have been more agreeable to Elizabeth, and her acceptance of the invitation was most ready and grateful.
vi: No other plan could make Elizabeth as happy.
tr: No offer could be more appealing to Elizabeth; she accepted the invitation immediately and gratefully.
es: No other project could be as pleasing to Elizabeth. She accepted the invitation instantly, extremely grateful.

en: “My dear, dear aunt,” she rapturously cried, “what delight!
vi: She exclaimed enthusiastically: - My dear aunt, that's wonderful!
tr: "My dear, beloved aunt," she exclaimed with enthusiasm, "what joy!
es: ––Dear, dearest aunt, she exclaimed enthusiastically––, what a delight!, what happiness!

en: what felicity!
vi: So exciting!
tr: what happiness!
es: ––Dear, dearest aunt, she exclaimed enthusiastically––, what a delight!, what happiness!

en: You give me fresh life and vigour.
vi: You give me joy and new vitality!
tr: You have given me new life and energy.
es: You make me come alive again, this gives me strength.

en: Adieu to disappointment and spleen.
vi: Farewell to all disappointment and melancholy.
tr: Goodbye to disappointment and sorrow.
es: Goodbye to disappointment and resentment!

en: What are men to rocks and mountains?
vi: Compared to rocks and mountains, what are men?
tr: What are men compared to mountains and rocks?
es: What are men compared to rocks and mountains?

en: Oh, what hours of transport we shall spend!
vi: Oh my! I have so much time to explore!
tr: Oh! just think of the hours we will spend on the roads!
es: Oh, what hours of escape we will have!

en: And when we do return, it shall not be like other travellers, without being able to give one accurate idea of anything.
vi: And when we return, we won't be like other tourists who can't give accurate opinions about anything.
tr: When we return, we will not be like other travelers; we will be able to describe everything in detail.
es: And when we return, we will not be like those travelers who are unable to give an accurate idea of anything.

en: We will know where we have gone—we will recollect what we have seen.
vi: We will know where we have been, we will remember what we have seen.
tr: We will know where we went – we will remember what we saw.
es: We will know where we have gone, and we will remember what we have seen.

en: Lakes, mountains, and rivers, shall not be jumbled together in our imaginations; nor, when we attempt to describe any particular scene, will we begin quarrelling about its relative situation.
vi: The rivers, lakes, and mountains will not be jumbled in our imagination; and when we try to describe a certain scene, we won't have to argue about its related circumstances.
tr: Lakes, mountains, rivers will not get mixed up in our minds; when we try to describe a particular scene, we will not start arguing about what was near and what was far.
es: The lakes, the rivers, and the mountains will not be confused in our memory, nor will we argue about their relative positions when we want to describe a specific landscape.

en: Let our first effusions be less insupportable than those of the generality of travellers.”
vi: Let our initial overflowing emotions be more pleasant than the general feelings of other tourists...
tr: Even our hastily told stories will be more convincing than most travelers' accounts."
es: Let our first outpourings not be like those of most travelers!

en: CHAPTER XXVIII.
vi: Chapter 28
tr: Chapter V
es: CHAPTER XXVIII

en: EVERY object in the next day’s journey was new and interesting to Elizabeth; and her spirits were in a state of enjoyment; for she had seen her sister looking so well as to banish all fear for her health, and the prospect of her northern tour was a constant source of delight.
vi: Everything on the next day's journey was new and exciting for Elizabeth. Her spirits were high because she had seen her sister in good health and had no worries, and the prospect of the trip to the North was a source of endless joy.
tr: Everything Elizabeth saw on the journey the next day was new and interesting to her; she was in a cheerful mood because she had seen her sister well enough to dispel all her fears about her health, and the possibility of taking a northern tour was a constant source of joy for her.
es: The next day everything was new and interesting for Elizabeth. She was determined to have a good time and was very cheerful, as she had found her sister in very good health, and all the fears she had about her health had vanished. Moreover, the prospect of a trip to the North was for her a constant source of joy.

en: When they left the high road for the lane to Hunsford, every eye was in search of the Parsonage, and every turning expected to bring it in view.
vi: When they turned off the main road to go to Huntsford, every eye was searching for the Parsonage, which everyone thought could be seen after every turn, with the boundary of Rosings Park on one side.
tr: When they left the main road and turned onto the Hunsford road, all eyes began to search for the Parsonage, expecting it to appear after every bend.
es: When they left the main road to enter the Hunsford path, everyone's eyes searched for the parsonage and at every turn they thought they were going to see it.

en: The paling of Rosings park was their boundary on one side.
vi: When they turned off the main road to go to Huntsford, every eye was searching for the Parsonage, which everyone thought could be seen after every turn, with the boundary of Rosings Park on one side.
tr: The fence of Rosings Park marked their boundaries on one side.
es: On one side of the path ran the fence of the Rosings estate.

en: Elizabeth smiled at the recollection of all that she had heard of its inhabitants.
vi: Elizabeth smiled as she recalled what she had heard about the inhabitants of this place.
tr: Elizabeth smiled as she remembered all that she had heard about the inhabitants of the estate.
es: Elizabeth smiled as she remembered everything she had heard about its inhabitants.

en: At length the Parsonage was discernible.
vi: Finally, the Parish Priest's Residence appeared.
tr: Finally, the lodgings were chosen.
es: At last, they caught sight of the parsonage.

en: The garden sloping to the road, the house standing in it, the green pales and the laurel hedge, everything declared they were arriving.
vi: The garden sloped down to the road, the house lay within the fence and hedge, everything indicated they had reached their destination.
tr: The garden sloping towards the road, the house within it, the green posts, the laurel bushes, everything announced their arrival.
es: The garden that extended to the road, the house that stood in the middle, the green palisade, and the laurel hedge indicated that they had arrived.

en: mr Collins and Charlotte appeared at the door, and the carriage stopped at the small gate, which led by a short gravel walk to the house, amidst the nods and smiles of the whole party.
vi: Mr. Collins and Charlotte appeared at the doorway, and the carriage stopped before a small gate leading to a short gravel path, amidst nods and smiles from the group.
tr: Mr. Collins and Charlotte appeared at the door; the carriage stopped at a small gate; a short gravel path led up from the gate to the house; everyone's satisfaction was evident on their faces.
es: Collins and Charlotte appeared at the door, and the carriage stopped at a small entrance that led to the house through a gravel path, amidst general greetings and smiles.

en: In a moment they were all out of the chaise, rejoicing at the sight of each other.
vi: In a moment, the three of them got off the carriage, happy to see each other again.
tr: Soon they all got out of the carriage, looking at each other with joy.
es: In a moment, everyone got down from the landau, mutually rejoicing at seeing each other.

en: ms Collins welcomed her friend with the liveliest pleasure, and Elizabeth was more and more satisfied with coming, when she found herself so affectionately received.
vi: Mrs. Collins welcomed her friend with the liveliest joy, and Elizabeth grew increasingly pleased with the visit as the couple treated her with great affection.
tr: Mrs. Collins greeted her friend with enthusiastic delight; seeing how warmly she was welcomed, Elizabeth was even more pleased to have come.
es: Mrs. Collins welcomed her friend with the sincerest pleasure, and Elizabeth, being received with such affection, was increasingly glad she had come.

en: She saw instantly that her cousin’s manners were not altered by his marriage: his formal civility was just what it had been; and he detained her some minutes at the gate to hear and satisfy his inquiries after all her family.
vi: She immediately noticed that her cousin's manner had not changed after marriage. His formal politeness remained the same, and he kept her for a few minutes by the gate to inquire about her family.
tr: She immediately noticed that her cousin's behavior had not changed after marriage; his formal politeness was just as it had been, and he detained Elizabeth at the door for a few minutes, inquiring about the health of each member of her family.
es: She immediately observed that her cousin's manners had not changed with marriage; his rigid courtesy was exactly the same as before, and he kept her at the door for several minutes to ask questions about the entire family.

en: They were then, with no other delay than his pointing out the neatness of the entrance, taken into the house; and as soon as they were in the parlour, he welcomed them a second time, with ostentatious formality, to his humble abode, and punctually repeated all his wife’s offers of refreshment.
vi: After showing the three guests the intricate details of the entrance, he invited them in, and as soon as they reached the hall, with deliberately ostentatious words, he once again welcomed them to his humble abode and reiterated his wife's invitation for refreshments.
tr: Then, without any delay except to draw their attention to the neatness of the entrance, they were taken inside; as soon as they entered the parlor, he welcomed them to his humble abode with grand formality for the second time, and repeated all of his wife's offers of refreshments verbatim.
es: Without further delay than Collins's remarks to his guests about the neatness of the entrance, they entered the house. Once in the hall, Collins, with bombastic formality, welcomed them to his humble abode for the second time, repeating point by point his wife's offer to serve them a refreshment.

en: Elizabeth was prepared to see him in his glory; and she could not help fancying that in displaying the good proportion of the room, its aspect, and its furniture, he addressed himself particularly to her, as if wishing to make her feel what she had lost in refusing him.
vi: Elizabeth had prepared herself to meet him again in his glory; she couldn't help but imagine that in the display of most of the room, its layout, and its furnishings, he particularly wanted to speak to her privately, as if wanting her to think about how much she had lost by refusing him.
tr: Elizabeth was prepared to see him display his triumph; while drawing attention to the dimensions, atmosphere, and furniture of the room, she couldn't help but think that it was specifically addressing her: as if it wanted to make her feel what she had lost by rejecting him.
es: Elizabeth was prepared to see him now in his environment, and she couldn't help but think that by showing them the good proportions of the room, its appearance, and its furnishings, Collins was addressing her specifically, as if he wanted to make her feel what she had lost by rejecting him.

en: But though everything seemed neat and comfortable, she was not able to gratify him by any sigh of repentance; and rather looked with wonder at her friend, that she could have so cheerful an air with such a companion.
vi: But although everything was neat and comfortable, she could not satisfy him with a single sigh expressing regret. Instead, she looked at her friend and wondered about such cheerfulness, with such a husband.
tr: However, although everything appeared to be in place and comfortable, Elizabeth couldn't detect any sign of regret that would please her; on the contrary, she looked at her friend with some amazement for being able to capture such a cheerful atmosphere with such a life partner.
es: But although everything seemed bright and comfortable, Elizabeth could not gratify him with any sign of regret; rather, she marveled that her friend could appear so cheerful with such a companion.

en: When mr Collins said anything of which his wife might reasonably be ashamed, which certainly was not seldom, she involuntarily turned her eye on Charlotte.
vi: When Mr. Collins said something that might embarrass his wife, she involuntarily turned to look at Charlotte.
tr: Whenever Mr. Collins said something that his wife might be embarrassed by, which was evidently not infrequent, Elizabeth couldn't help but fix her eyes on Charlotte.
es: When Collins said something that must have embarrassed his wife, which happened quite often, Elizabeth involuntarily turned her eyes towards Charlotte.

en: Once or twice she could discern a faint blush; but in general Charlotte wisely did not hear.
vi: A couple of times she could detect a faint blush, but usually, Charlotte wisely ignored it as if she hadn't heard.
tr: Once or twice she thought she detected a slight blush; but Charlotte was wise, mostly pretending not to hear.
es: Once or twice she could see that Charlotte blushed slightly; but, for the most part, Charlotte pretended not to hear him.

en: After sitting long enough to admire every article of furniture in the room, from the sideboard to the fender, to give an account of their journey, and of all that had happened in London, mr Collins invited them to take a stroll in the garden, which was large and well laid out, and to the cultivation of which he attended himself.
vi: After everyone had had time to admire the furnishings in the room, recount their journey and the events in London, Mr. Collins invited everyone to take a walk in the garden, which was quite large and meticulously arranged, tended by his own hands.
tr: After sitting long enough to admire every piece of furniture in the room, from the display cabinet to the fireplace grate, and to recount their travels and what had happened in London, Mr. Collins invited them for a walk in the garden; the garden was large, well-arranged, and he personally took care of its maintenance.
es: After sitting for a while, long enough to admire each and every piece of furniture, from the sideboard to the fireplace grate, and to recount the journey and everything that had happened in London, Mr. Collins invited them to take a walk in the garden, which was large and well laid out and which he personally took care of.

en: To work in his garden was one of his most respectable pleasures; and Elizabeth admired the command of countenance with which Charlotte talked of the healthfulness of the exercise, and owned she encouraged it as much as possible.
vi: Gardening was one of his respectable pleasures, and Elizabeth admired Charlotte's composed expression when her friend spoke about the health benefits of gardening; Elizabeth thought her friend intended to encourage this as much as possible.
tr: Working in his garden was one of his most esteemed pleasures; Elizabeth admired Charlotte's ability to control her facial expressions while she spoke about the benefits of exercise and her great encouragement in this matter.
es: Working in the garden was one of his most respected pleasures; Elizabeth admired the seriousness with which Charlotte spoke of how healthy it was for Collins and confessed that she herself encouraged him to do it whenever possible.

en: Here, leading the way through every walk and cross walk, and scarcely allowing them an interval to utter the praises he asked for, every view was pointed out with a minuteness which left beauty entirely behind.
vi: He led the three companions around, rarely giving them time to express any praise, pointing out every trivial detail, leaving the beauty completely behind.
tr: Falling ahead of them on every path, without giving them a second to utter the praises he expected, he pointed out the details of the scenery with a speed that made them forget every beauty.
es: Guiding them through all the paths and corners and barely giving them time to express the praises he demanded, he pointed out all the views with a meticulousness that far exceeded their beauty.

en: He could number the fields in every direction, and could tell how many trees there were in the most distant clump.
vi: He could count the garden plots on every side and tell how many trees were in the farthest grove.
tr: He could count the fields in every direction and tell how many trees were in the most distant grove.
es: He enumerated the fields that could be seen in all directions and said how many trees were in each one.

en: But of all the views which his garden, or which the country or the kingdom could boast, none were to be compared with the prospect of Rosings, afforded by an opening in the trees that bordered the park nearly opposite the front of his house.
vi: But for all the beauty that his garden, or the entire region, or even the entire kingdom, could boast, nothing compared to the view of the Rosings estate, seen through a gap in the foliage surrounding the garden near the front of the Parsonage.
tr: But among all the landscapes that his garden, or the country, or the kingdom could boast of, Rosings was incomparable, as seen through the clearing among the trees surrounding the grove facing the front of his house.
es: But of all the views that his garden, or the countryside, or the entire kingdom could boast of, there was none that could compare to that of Rosings, which was revealed through a clearing in the trees that bordered the estate on the side opposite to the front of his house.

en: It was a handsome modern building, well situated on rising ground.
vi: This was a magnificent, modern mansion, situated on a small elevated piece of land.
tr: It was a beautiful, modern building; built on a rising ground.
es: The mansion was pretty, modern, and very well situated, on an elevation of the land.

en: From his garden, mr Collins would have led them round his two meadows; but the ladies, not having shoes to encounter the remains of a white frost, turned back; and while Sir William accompanied him, Charlotte took her sister and friend over the house, extremely well pleased, probably, to have the opportunity of showing it without her husband’s help.
vi: From his garden, Mr. Collins wanted to take them to his two meadows, but the women were not wearing suitable shoes, so they turned back. While Sir William followed him, Charlotte led her sister and friend back, perhaps very happy to have the opportunity to introduce the residence without needing her husband's accompaniment.
tr: After the garden, Mr. Collins was going to show them his two lawns, but the ladies turned back as their shoes were not suitable for the remnants of frost on the ground; while Sir William accompanied him, Charlotte took her sister and friend back to the house, seemingly very delighted to have the opportunity to show the house without her husband's help.
es: From the garden, Collins would have liked to take them to tour his two meadows, but the ladies were not properly shod to walk on the still frozen grass and they declined. Sir William was the only one who accompanied him. Charlotte returned to the house with her sister and Elizabeth, probably extremely happy to be able to show it to them without her husband's help.

en: It was rather small, but well built and convenient; and everything was fitted up and arranged with a neatness and consistency, of which Elizabeth gave Charlotte all the credit.
vi: The residence was quite small, but it was built in a complete and convenient manner. Everything was arranged and equipped in an orderly and consistent way that Elizabeth attributed to Charlotte's efforts.
tr: It was a small house, but well-built and functional; everything was matched with a care and harmony that Elizabeth attributed to Charlotte.
es: It was small but well laid out, everything was arranged with order and cleanliness, a merit that Elizabeth attributed to Charlotte.

en: When mr Collins could be forgotten, there was really a great air of comfort throughout, and by Charlotte’s evident enjoyment of it, Elizabeth supposed he must be often forgotten.
