vi: When they could forget about Mr. Collins, there was clearly a comfortable atmosphere prevailing, and from Charlotte's cheerful demeanor, Elizabeth guessed that he was often forgotten.
tr: When Mr. Collins was forgotten, there was an air of great comfort everywhere and Charlotte's enjoyment of it; Elizabeth thought that the man must often be forgotten.
es: When one could forget Collins, the house had a more pleasant atmosphere; and from her friend's evident satisfaction, Elizabeth thought she should forget him more often.

en: She had already learnt that Lady Catherine was still in the country.
vi: She had heard that Lady Catherine was still staying in the area.
tr: He had previously learned that Lady Catherine was still in the countryside.
es: They had already told him that Lady Catherine was still in the country.

en: It was spoken of again while they were at dinner, when mr Collins joining in, observed,—
vi: They talked more about this at the dinner table, when Mr. Collins added his comments:
tr: This was mentioned again at dinner; Mr. Collins joined the conversation and said-
es: She was mentioned again while they were dining, and Collins, joining the conversation, said:

en: “Yes, Miss Elizabeth, you will have the honour of seeing Lady Catherine de Bourgh on the ensuing Sunday at church, and I need not say you will be delighted with her.
vi: - Yes, Miss Elizabeth, you will have the honor of meeting Lady Catherine de Bourgh next Sunday at church, and I need not say that you will be very pleased with this opportunity.
tr: "Yes, Miss Elizabeth, you will have the honor of seeing Lady Catherine de Bourgh in church next Sunday; I don't even need to tell you that you will be delighted with her.
es: ––Yes, Elizabeth; you will have the honor of seeing Lady Catherine de Bourgh next Sunday at church, and I don't need to tell you how much you will enjoy it.

en: She is all affability and condescension, and I doubt not but you will be honoured with some portion of her notice when service is over.
vi: She is full of grace and sociable with those of lower status, and I am sure you will have the honor of being noticed by her a little when the service ends.
tr: She is a paragon of kindness and magnanimity; I have no doubt that you will receive a certain amount of her attention once the service is over.
es: She is all affability and condescension, and I have no doubt that she will honor you by speaking to you as soon as the service is over.

en: I have scarcely any hesitation in saying that she will include you and my sister Maria in every invitation with which she honours us during your stay here.
vi: I am certain that during your stay here, the Lady will invite you and my sister Maria to attend every gathering organized for us.
tr: I can say without hesitation that during your stay here, she will include you and my sister-in-law Maria in every invitation she honors us with.
es: I also almost have no doubt that you and my sister-in-law Maria will be included in all the invitations with which she honors us during your stay here.

en: Her behaviour to my dear Charlotte is charming.
vi: Her attitude towards my dear Charlotte is truly captivating.
tr: Her behavior towards my dear Charlotte is simply charming.
es: Her attitude towards my dear Charlotte is most kind.

en: We dine at Rosings twice every week, and are never allowed to walk home.
vi: We dine at her house twice a week, and we are never allowed to walk back.
tr: We dine at Rosings twice a week and are not allowed to walk home.
es: We dine at Rosings twice a week and she never allows us to walk back.

en: Her Ladyship’s carriage is regularly ordered for us.
vi: The Lady's carriage is often called for us to use.
tr: Her ladyship's carriage is regularly called for us.
es: She always requests her carriage to take us, or rather, one of her carriages, because she has several.

en: I should say, one of her Ladyship’s carriages, for she has several.”
vi: I must say, one of the carriages, because the Lady has several.
tr: One of her carriages, I should say, because she has several."
es: She always requests her carriage to take us, or rather, one of her carriages, because she has several.

en: “Lady Catherine is a very respectable, sensible woman, indeed,” added Charlotte, “and a most attentive neighbour.”
vi: Charlotte added: - Madam is truly a very respectable person, who knows right from wrong, and is the most considerate neighbor.
tr: "Lady Catherine is indeed a very respectable, understanding woman," added Charlotte, "and a very considerate neighbor."
es: ––Lady Catherine is really a very respectable and affectionate lady ––added Charlotte––, and a very attentive neighbor.

en: “Very true, my dear, that is exactly what I say.
vi: - That's right, my dear, this is exactly what I said.
tr: "That's right, my dear, I say the same thing.
es: ––Very true, dear; it is exactly what I say: she is a woman who can never be considered with enough deference.

en: She is the sort of woman whom one cannot regard with too much deference.”
vi: She is the kind of woman whom people respect no matter what.
tr: She is such a woman that no matter how much respect you show, it is never enough."
es: ––Very true, dear; it is exactly what I say: she is a woman who can never be considered with enough deference.

en: The evening was spent chiefly in talking over Hertfordshire news, and telling again what had been already written; and when it closed, Elizabeth, in the solitude of her chamber, had to meditate upon Charlotte’s degree of contentment, to understand her address in guiding, and composure in bearing with, her husband, and to acknowledge that it was all done very well.
vi: In the evening, they sat together mainly talking about the news in Hertfordshire and recounting what they had exchanged through letters. When they finished, Elizabeth sat alone in the room designated for her, contemplating Charlotte's contented appearance, to understand more about the cleverness in guiding and enduring her husband, and to acknowledge that her friend had behaved well in all matters.
tr: The evening mostly passed by talking about Hertfordshire news and recounting things that had already been written; when the evening ended, Elizabeth, in the solitude of her room, had to reflect on how content Charlotte was with her life, understand her ability to guide and endure her husband, and accept that everything was going quite well.
es: During the evening, there was almost constant talk about Hertfordshire, and what had already been said in writing was repeated. Upon retiring, Elizabeth, in the solitude of her room, reflected on Charlotte's well-being and her skill and discretion in making the best of and enduring her husband, acknowledging that she did it very well.

en: She had also to anticipate how her visit would pass, the quiet tenour of their usual employments, the vexatious interruptions of mr Collins, and the gaieties of their intercourse with Rosings.
vi: Previously, she had anticipated what this trip would be like, with the daily routines, the annoying interjections of Mr. Collins, and their enthusiasm in their relationship with Rosings.
tr: She also had to anticipate how her visit would go, the calm flow of her daily activities, Mr. Collins' tedious interventions, and the amusements in their interactions with Rosings.
es: She also thought about how her visit would go, what they would do, the tedious interruptions from Collins, and how much she would enjoy dealing with the Rosings family.

en: A lively imagination soon settled it all.
vi: A rich imagination soon delineated everything.
tr: A vivid imagination soon resolved everything.
es: Her vivid imagination planned it all at once.

en: About the middle of the next day, as she was in her room getting ready for a walk, a sudden noise below seemed to speak the whole house in confusion; and, after listening a moment, she heard somebody running upstairs in a violent hurry, and calling loudly after her.
vi: In the middle of the next day, as she was preparing to go out for a walk, a sudden noise seemed to throw the entire house into chaos. After listening for a moment, she heard the hurried footsteps of someone running up the stairs and loudly calling her name.
tr: By the middle of the next day, while preparing for a walk in his room, a sudden noise from downstairs seemed to turn the whole house upside down; after listening for a moment, he heard someone running up the stairs in a wild rush and shouting at him.
es: The next day, around noon, she was in her room getting ready to go out for a walk, when she heard a sudden noise downstairs that seemed to throw the whole house into confusion. She listened for a moment and noticed that someone was hurriedly coming up the stairs and calling out to her loudly.

en: She opened the door, and met Maria in the landing-place, who, breathless with agitation, cried out,—
vi: She opened the door and met Maria on the stairs, who breathlessly exclaimed:
tr: He opened the door and saw Maria on the landing; out of breath from excitement, she was shouting-
es: She opened the door and in the hallway she found María, very agitated and out of breath, who exclaimed:

en: “In Conversation with the ladies”
vi: She opened the door and met Maria on the stairs, who breathlessly exclaimed:
tr: He opened the door and saw Maria on the landing; out of breath from excitement, she was shouting-
es: She opened the door and in the hallway she found María, very agitated and out of breath, who exclaimed:

en: “Oh, my dear Eliza!
vi: - Hey, Eliza!
tr: "Ah dear Eliza!
es: ––Oh, dear Elizabeth!

en: pray make haste and come into the dining-room, for there is such a sight to be seen!
vi: Please hurry to the dining room, because there's something you need to see!
tr: Please hurry, come to the dining room, there's a sight to see!
es: Hurry up, come down to the dining room and you'll see!

en: I will not tell you what it is.
vi: I won't tell you what it is.
tr: I won't tell you what it is.
es: I can't tell you what it is.

en: Make haste, and come down this moment.”
vi: Quickly, please come down right away.
tr: Hurry up, come down immediately."
es: Run, come at once!

en: Elizabeth asked questions in vain; Maria would tell her nothing more; and down they ran into the dining-room which fronted the lane, in quest of this wonder; it was two ladies, stopping in a low phaeton at the garden gate.
vi: Elizabeth asked but there was no answer; Maria refused to say anything more. They ran down to the dining room to look out onto the street. Two women arrived in a four-wheeled carriage, stopping in front of the garden gate, Elizabeth exclaimed:
tr: Elizabeth asked questions in vain; Maria was not going to say anything else; they ran together down to the dining room; the dining room faced the road, and the marvel they were pursuing was right in front of them! Two ladies were standing in a low carriage at the garden gate.
es: Elizabeth asked in vain what was happening. Maria did not want to tell her more; both went to the dining room, whose windows faced the road, to see the marvel. This consisted simply of two ladies who were standing at the garden gate in a low phaeton.

en: “And is this all?” cried Elizabeth.
vi: - Is that all?
tr: "Is that all?" cried Elizabeth.
es: ––And is that all? ––exclaimed Elizabeth––.

en: “I expected at least that the pigs were got into the garden, and here is nothing but Lady Catherine and her daughter!”
vi: I thought at least a few pigs had run into the garden, but here there are only Lady Catherine and her daughter!
tr: "I had at least hoped that the pigs had gotten into the garden, but there's nothing here except Lady Catherine and her daughter!"
es: I was at least expecting the pigs to have invaded the garden, and all I see is Lady Catherine and her daughter!

en: “La! my dear,” said Maria, quite shocked at the mistake, “it is not Lady Catherine.
vi: Maria was quite surprised by the mistake:
tr: "Oh, my dear," said Maria, bewildered by the mistake, "this is not Lady Catherine.
es: ––Oh, dear! ––replied María, extremely surprised by the mistake––. It is not Lady Catherine.

en: The old lady is ms Jenkinson, who lives with them.
vi: - No, ma'am. That is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them.
tr: The elderly lady is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them; the other one is Miss de Bourgh.
es: The older one is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them.

en: The other is Miss De Bourgh.
vi: The other one is Miss De Bourgh.
tr: The elderly lady is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them; the other one is Miss de Bourgh.
es: The other one is Miss de Bourgh.

en: Only look at her.
vi: Look at her.
tr: Look at her.
es: Look at her closely.

en: She is quite a little creature.
vi: She is quite small.
tr: What a cute thing.
es: She is a little creature.

en: Who would have thought she could be so thin and small!”
vi: Who could think she is so thin and small.
tr: Who would have thought she was so slim and small!"
es: Who would have believed she was so small and so thin!

en: “She is abominably rude to keep Charlotte out of doors in all this wind.
vi: - She was indeed rude to make Charlotte go outside in this wind.
tr: "It's very rude to keep Charlotte outside in this wind.
es: ––It is rude to have Charlotte at the door with the wind blowing like this.

en: Why does she not come in?”
vi: Why doesn't she come inside? - Ah!
tr: Why isn't she coming inside?"
es: Why doesn't that young lady come in?

en: “Oh, Charlotte says she hardly ever does.
vi: Charlotte says she rarely agrees to come inside.
tr: "Charlotte says she rarely comes in.
es: ––Charlotte says she almost never does it.

en: It is the greatest of favours when Miss De Bourgh comes in.”
vi: If Miss De Bourgh agrees, it is the greatest favor.
tr: Miss de Bourgh's entrance is the greatest compliment."
es: It would be the greatest of favors if Miss de Bourgh were to enter the house.

en: “I like her appearance,” said Elizabeth, struck with other ideas.
vi: Elizabeth said: - She likes her figure. Suddenly, Elizabeth had a new thought.
tr: "I liked his appearance," said Elizabeth, her mind occupied with other thoughts.
es: ––I like her appearance ––said Elizabeth, thinking about other things––.

en: “She looks sickly and cross.
vi: "She looks weak and irritable.
tr: "He looks sick and irritable.
es: She looks sick and ill-tempered.

en: Yes, she will do for him very well.
vi: Yes, she will suit him.
tr: Yes, it will do him good.
es: Yes, she is the right woman for him, she suits him well.

en: She will make him a very proper wife.”
vi: She will be a very fitting wife for him."
tr: She would make a very suitable wife for him."
es: Yes, she is the right woman for him, she suits him well.

en: mr Collins and Charlotte were both standing at the gate in conversation with the ladies; and Sir William, to Elizabeth’s high diversion, was stationed in the doorway, in earnest contemplation of the greatness before him, and constantly bowing whenever Miss De Bourgh looked that way.
vi: Mr. Collins and Charlotte are standing by the gate talking to two women. Sir William is standing by the door frame, which distracts Elizabeth. He is solemnly observing the scene before him and always bows whenever Miss De Bourgh looks his way.
tr: Mr. Collins and Charlotte were standing at the door, talking to the ladies; Sir William, in a manner that would surprise Elizabeth, was positioned in front of the door, eagerly watching the noble person before him, and every time Miss de Bourgh looked that way, he kept bowing his head in greeting.
es: Collins and his wife were conversing with the two ladies at the garden gate, and Elizabeth was greatly amused watching Sir William at the entrance door, absorbed in the contemplation of the grandeur before him and bowing every time Miss de Bourgh glanced in his direction.

en: At length there was nothing more to be said; the ladies drove on, and the others returned into the house.
vi: In the end, they had nothing left to say. The two women drove away, and the others went into the house.
tr: Finally, there was nothing left to say; the ladies continued on their way, and the others returned home.
es: Once the conversation ended, the ladies continued on their way, and the others entered the house.

en: mr Collins no sooner saw the two girls than he began to congratulate them on their good fortune, which Charlotte explained by letting them know that the whole party was asked to dine at Rosings the next day.
vi: As soon as he saw the two ladies, Mr. Collins hurriedly congratulated them both, and Charlotte explained that everyone was invited to dinner at Rosings the next day.
tr: As soon as Mr. Collins saw the two girls, he began to congratulate them on their fortune, and Charlotte explained what the fortune was: the whole group had been invited to dinner at Rosings the next day.
es: Collins, as soon as he saw the two girls, congratulated them on their good fortune.

en: “Lady Catherine, said she, you have given me a treasure.”
vi: As soon as he saw the two ladies, Mr. Collins hurriedly congratulated them both, and Charlotte explained that everyone was invited to dinner at Rosings the next day.
tr: As soon as Mr. Collins saw the two girls, he began to congratulate them on their fortune, and Charlotte explained what the fortune was: the whole group had been invited to dinner at Rosings the next day.
es: This good fortune, as Charlotte clarified, was that they were all invited to dine at Rosings the next day.

en: CHAPTER XXIX.
vi: Chapter 29
tr: Chapter VI
es: CHAPTER XXIX

en: mr COLLINS’S triumph, in consequence of this invitation, was complete.
vi: The triumph of Mr. Collins after they received such an invitation was complete.
tr: With this invitation, Mr. Collins' success was complete.
es: Collins's satisfaction with this invitation was complete.

en: The power of displaying the grandeur of his patroness to his wondering visitors, and of letting them see her civility towards himself and his wife, was exactly what he had wished for; and that an opportunity of doing it should be given so soon was such an instance of Lady Catherine’s condescension as he knew not how to admire enough.
vi: The opportunity to present to the guests, who were astonished, the influence of his patroness and her courteous attitude towards him and his wife, was exactly what he had hoped for. Such an opportunity came quite quickly, demonstrating the Lady's affability towards her subordinates, which he did not know how to admire adequately.
tr: The opportunity to showcase his patroness's splendor to curious guests and to have them witness the kindness shown to him and his wife was exactly what he desired; that this opportunity was given so quickly was such a rare example of Lady Catherine's generosity that no amount of gratitude would be sufficient.
es: There was nothing that delighted him more than being able to showcase the grandeur of his patroness to his admired guests and to make them see the courtesy with which this lady treated him and his wife; and the fact that he was given an opportunity to do so so soon was an example of Lady Catherine's condescension that he wouldn't know how to thank.

en: “I confess,” said he, “that I should not have been at all surprised by her Ladyship’s asking us on Sunday to drink tea and spend the evening at Rosings.
vi: He said: - I must confess that I should not have been surprised by Lady Catherine inviting us this Sunday for tea and dinner at Rosings.
tr: "I must confess," he said, "I wouldn't have been surprised if her ladyship had invited us to Rosings for tea and to spend Sunday evening together.
es: ––I confess ––he said–– that I would not have been surprised if His Lordship had invited us on Sunday to have tea and spend the afternoon at Rosings.

en: I rather expected, from my knowledge of her affability, that it would happen.
vi: Given what I know about Lady Catherine's kindness, this was bound to happen.
tr: Knowing how humble she is, I was expecting this.
es: In fact, I was expecting it, because I know his affability.

en: But who could have foreseen such an attention as this?
vi: But who could have anticipated such kindness?
tr: But who would have thought that we would be invited to dine there immediately after your arrival, and all of us at that!"
es: But who could have imagined such an attention as this?

en: Who could have imagined that we should receive an invitation to dine there (an invitation, moreover, including the whole party) so immediately after your arrival?”
vi: Who could have imagined that we would receive a dinner invitation as soon as you arrived!
tr: But who would have thought that we would be invited to dine there immediately after your arrival, and all of us at that!"
es: Who could have imagined that we would receive an invitation to dinner; an invitation, moreover, extended to everyone in the house, so very shortly after you arrived?

en: “I am the less surprised at what has happened,” replied Sir William, “from that knowledge of what the manners of the great really are, which my situation in life has allowed me to acquire.
vi: Sir William replied: - I am less surprised by what happened, as the circumstances of my life have helped me understand the true nature of the upper class.
tr: "I wasn't that surprised," replied Sir William, "if you ask why, it's because I know the manners of great people, my position in life has allowed me to acquire that style.
es: ––I am not surprised ––replied Sir William––, because my position in life has allowed me to know the true nature of the great.

en: About the court, such instances of elegant breeding are not uncommon.”
vi: Speaking of the court, such cases of refined upbringing are not uncommon.
tr: Such refinements are not uncommon in the court circles."
es: In the court, such examples of elegant manners are very common.

en: Scarcely anything was talked of the whole day or next morning but their visit to Rosings.
vi: All that day and the next morning, they hardly talked about anything other than the upcoming visit to Rosings.
tr: All day and the next morning, little was talked about other than the visit to Rosings.
es: All day long and the following morning, hardly anything else was talked about except the visit to Rosings.

en: mr Collins was carefully instructing them in what they were to expect, that the sight of such rooms, so many servants, and so splendid a dinner, might not wholly overpower them.
vi: Mr. Collins carefully instructed the three guests on what they would encounter, so that the grandeur of the rooms, the numerous servants, and the splendid dinner would not overwhelm them.
tr: Mr. Collins was carefully warning them about what to expect, so that the sight of such rooms, so many servants, and such a magnificent table would not completely overwhelm them.
es: Collins carefully instructed them on what they were going to see, so that the sight of those rooms, so many servants, and such splendid food would not leave them open-mouthed.

en: When the ladies were separating for the toilette, he said to Elizabeth,—
vi: He spoke privately to Elizabeth:
tr: While the ladies withdrew to dress, Elizabeth was told-
es: When the ladies went to get dressed, he said to Elizabeth:

en: “Do not make yourself uneasy, my dear cousin, about your apparel.
vi: - My dear sister. You should not be anxious about your appearance.
tr: "Do not feel uncomfortable about your attire, dear cousin.
es: ––Do not worry about your attire, dear cousin.

en: Lady Catherine is far from requiring that elegance of dress in us which becomes herself and daughter.
vi: The lady does not require us to dress elegantly, so both she and her daughter dress plainly.
tr: Lady Catherine does not expect us to wear dresses that match her and her daughter's elegance.
es: Lady Catherine is far from demanding from us the elegance in dressing that befits her and her daughter.

en: I would advise you merely to put on whatever of your clothes is superior to the rest—there is no occasion for anything more.
vi: I suggest that you simply wear the outfit that looks better than the others, nothing more.
tr: My advice is to wear whichever of your clothes is superior to the others – nothing more is needed.
es: I would only like to advise you to wear the best outfit you have; there is no need for more.

en: Lady Catherine will not think the worse of you for being simply dressed.
vi: Lady Catherine will not think ill of you if you dress simply.
tr: Lady Catherine will not think ill of you for being plainly dressed.
es: Lady Catherine will not think ill of you for being dressed simply.

en: She likes to have the distinction of rank preserved.”
vi: She wants everyone to maintain the distinctiveness of their own class.
tr: She likes to maintain the difference in status."
es: She likes to be reserved the distinction due to her rank.

en: While they were dressing, he came two or three times to their different doors, to recommend their being quick, as Lady Catherine very much objected to be kept waiting for her dinner.
vi: While they were getting ready, he went to each room two or three times to urge them to hurry, as the Lady greatly disliked having to wait for her dinner.
tr: While they were getting dressed, he came to their door several times, urging them to hurry, saying that Lady Catherine did not like to be kept waiting for dinner.
es: While they were getting dressed, Collins went two or three times to knock on the various doors, to recommend that they hurry up, as Lady Catherine was very uncomfortable having to wait to eat.

en: Such formidable accounts of her Ladyship, and her manner of living, quite frightened Maria Lucas, who had been little used to company; and she looked forward to her introduction at Rosings with as much apprehension as her father had done to his presentation at St. James’s.
vi: Maria Lucas was horrified by such dreadful details about the Lady and her way of life. Unaccustomed to socializing, she prepared for the party at Rosings with as much anxiety as her father had when he was knighted at St. James's Palace.
tr: Such grand pronouncements about Her Ladyship and her way of life intimidated Maria Lucas, who was not accustomed to such crowds, and she began to await her introduction at Rosings with the same anxiety as she had awaited her father's introduction at St. James's.
es: Such formidable reports about Her Ladyship and her way of living had intimidated Maria Lucas, who was not used to social life, and awaited her entrance into Rosings with the same apprehension that her father had experienced when being presented at St. James.

en: As the weather was fine, they had a pleasant walk of about half a mile across the park.
vi: Because of the good weather, they leisurely walked about half a mile, through a grove of trees.
tr: Because the weather was nice, they took a pleasant half-mile walk in the grove.
es: Since the weather was good, the half-mile walk through the Rosings estate was very pleasant.

en: Every park has its beauty and its prospects; and Elizabeth saw much to be pleased with, though she could not be in such raptures as mr Collins expected the scene to inspire, and was but slightly affected by his enumeration of the windows in front of the house, and his relation of what the glazing altogether had originally cost Sir Lewis de Bourgh.
vi: Each garden had its own unique beauty and distinctive panorama. Elizabeth enjoyed the scenery, though she did not show the excitement that Mr. Collins hoped the view would evoke in her. She absentmindedly listened to him talk about the number of windows on the mansion's facade and the cost of polishing that Sir Lewis De Bourgh had to incur.
tr: Each grove has its own beauty and characteristics; Elizabeth saw many things she liked, but she still did not feel as much enthusiasm as Mr. Collins hoped the scene would inspire, nor was she very impressed by his counting the windows on the front facade of the house and telling her how much the glass had originally cost Sir Lewis de Bourgh.
es: All estates have their beauty and views, and Elizabeth was delighted with everything she saw, although she did not show the enthusiasm that Collins expected, and listened with little interest to his enumeration of the windows on the facade, and the account of what the stained glass had cost Sir Lewis de Bourgh.

en: When they ascended the steps to the hall, Maria’s alarm was every moment increasing, and even Sir William did not look perfectly calm.
vi: As they ascended the steps leading to the vestibule, Maria became increasingly alarmed, and even Sir William could not remain completely calm.
tr: As they ascended the stairs, Maria's anxiety increased with each passing moment; even Sir William did not appear very calm.
es: As they ascended the staircase leading to the lobby, María's excitement was increasing, and even Sir William was not entirely at ease.

en: Elizabeth’s courage did not fail her.
vi: Elizabeth's courageous temperament did not abandon her.
tr: Elizabeth's courage did not fail her.
es: Elizabeth, on the other hand, did not lack courage.

en: She had heard nothing of Lady Catherine that spoke her awful from any extraordinary talents or miraculous virtue, and the mere stateliness of money and rank she thought she could witness without trepidation.
vi: She had not heard anything about Lady Catherine that suggested extraordinary talents or miraculous virtues. As for the grandeur stemming from wealth and status, she thought she could witness it without fear.
tr: She had not heard Lady Catherine praised for extraordinary talents or miraculous virtues, and she thought she could observe the usual splendor of money and rank without feeling intimidated.
es: She had not heard anything about Lady Catherine that made her believe she possessed any extraordinary talents or miraculous virtues, and she knew that the mere majesty of money and lineage would not make her lose her composure.

en: From the entrance hall, of which mr Collins pointed out, with a rapturous air, the fine proportion and finished ornaments, they followed the servants through an antechamber to the room where Lady Catherine, her daughter, and ms Jenkinson were sitting.
vi: From the foyer, where Mr. Collins enthusiastically pointed out the harmonious proportions and decorative patterns, they followed the servant through the antechamber and then entered a room where Lady Catherine, her daughter, and Mrs. Jenkinson were seated.
tr: They followed the servants from the entrance hall, which Mr. Collins, in a state of rapture, pointed out for its vast dimensions and perfect adornments, through a waiting room, and entered the room where Lady Catherine, her daughter, and Mrs. Jenkinson were seated.
es: From the entrance hall, whose harmonious proportions and delicate ornamentation Collins enthusiastically pointed out, the servants led them, through an antechamber, to the room where Lady Catherine, her daughter, and Mrs. Jenkinson were.

en: Her Ladyship, with great condescension, arose to receive them; and as ms Collins had settled it with her husband that the office of introduction should be hers, it was performed in a proper manner, without any of those apologies and thanks which he would have thought necessary.
vi: The lady, with a formally humble demeanor, stood up to greet them. Since Mrs. Collins had agreed with her husband that the introductions should be entirely her responsibility, she carried them out in the proper manner, without the apologies and thanks that her husband might have thought necessary.
tr: Her Ladyship rose with great condescension to receive them; Mrs. Collins, having previously arranged with her husband that the duty of introduction should fall to her, performed the introduction accordingly, without any of the apologies and thanks the man might have deemed necessary.
es: Her Ladyship rose with great kindness to receive them. And as Mrs. Collins had agreed with her husband that she would make the introductions, they took place normally, without the excuses or expressions of gratitude that he would have deemed necessary.

en: In spite of having been at St. James’s, Sir William was so completely awed by the grandeur surrounding him, that he had but just courage enough to make a very low bow, and take his seat without saying a word; and his daughter, frightened almost out of her senses, sat on the edge of her chair, not knowing which way to look.
vi: Although present at St. James's Palace, Sir William still felt completely awed by the magnificent surroundings, to the point where he only had the courage to bow very low and then sit down without being able to say a word. His daughter, terrified to the extent of almost losing all her senses, sat on the edge of her seat, not knowing which way to turn.
tr: Although he had previously been to St. James, Sir William was so astonished by the surrounding splendor that he could only muster the courage to bow deeply and sit down without uttering a word; his daughter, almost fainting from fear, sat on the edge of her seat, not knowing where to look.
es: Despite having been to St. James, Sir William was so overwhelmed by the grandeur surrounding him that he barely had the courage to make a deep bow and sat down without saying a word. His daughter, frightened and beside herself, also sat on the edge of a chair, not knowing where to look.

en: Elizabeth found herself quite equal to the scene, and could observe the three ladies before her composedly.
vi: Elizabeth felt herself quite at ease with the setting, able to calmly observe the three women in front of her.
tr: Elizabeth felt quite at ease and was able to calmly observe the three ladies in front of her.
es: Elizabeth was as usual, and was able to calmly observe the three ladies in front of her.

en: Lady Catherine was a tall, large woman, with strongly-marked features, which might once have been handsome.
vi: Lady Catherine was tall and large, with strong features that might have once been beautiful.
tr: –Lady Catherine was a tall, large woman with stern features that might have been beautiful once.
es: Lady Catherine was a very tall and stout woman, with extremely pronounced features that must have been beautiful in her youth.

en: Her air was not conciliating, nor was her manner of receiving them such as to make her visitors forget their inferior rank.
vi: Her manner and gestures of greeting did not aim to win affection, such as helping the guests forget their lower status.
tr: Her demeanor was not conciliatory, and the way she received them did not make her visitors forget their lower status.
es: She had an air of sufficiency, and her manner of receiving them was not the most appropriate to make her guests forget their inferior rank.

en: She was not rendered formidable by silence: but whatever she said was spoken in so authoritative a tone as marked her self-importance, and brought mr Wickham immediately to Elizabeth’s mind; and, from the observation of the day altogether, she believed Lady Catherine to be exactly what he had represented.
vi: When silent, she did not seem terrifying, but every word she spoke carried an authoritative tone as if to assert her position. She immediately reminded Elizabeth of Mr. Wickham, and from what she had observed, Elizabeth believed she was exactly the type of person he had described.
tr: When silent, she was not intimidating; but she spoke in such an authoritative voice that demonstrated her self-importance, which immediately reminded Elizabeth of Mr. Wickham; after observing her all day, Elizabeth concluded that Lady Catherine was exactly as he had described.
es: When she was silent, she was not at all terrible; but when she spoke, she did so in such an authoritative tone that her importance became overwhelming. Elizabeth remembered Wickham, and her observations during the evening confirmed that Lady Catherine was exactly as he had described her.

en: When, after examining the mother, in whose countenance and deportment she soon found some resemblance of mr Darcy, she turned her eyes on the daughter, she could almost have joined in Maria’s astonishment at her being so thin and so small.
vi: After examining the mother, whose face and gestures vaguely resembled Mr. Darcy, she turned to look at the daughter. She found Maria's surprise understandable, as the girl was too slender and too short.
tr: After examining the mother, in whom she immediately found a resemblance to Mr. Darcy in her face and posture, and then turning her eyes to the girl, she seemed to share Maria's astonishment at finding her so thin and petite.
es: After examining the mother, in whose countenance and behavior he immediately found a certain resemblance to Darcy, he turned his eyes towards the daughter, and was almost as astonished as Maria to see her so thin and so small.

en: There was neither in figure nor face any likeness between the ladies.
vi: The mother and daughter bore no resemblance to each other in terms of stature or face.
tr: There was neither stature nor facial similarity among the ladies.
es: Both her figure and her face had nothing to do with her mother.

en: Miss de Bourgh was pale and sickly: her features, though not plain, were insignificant; and she spoke very little, except in a low voice, to ms Jenkinson, in whose appearance there was nothing remarkable, and who was entirely engaged in listening to what she said, and placing a screen in the proper direction before her eyes.
vi: Miss De Bourgh had a pale, sickly complexion; her features were unremarkable, though not unattractive. She spoke very little except when addressing Mrs. Jenkinson, in a soft voice. The latter had nothing distinctive in appearance, paying attention only to what Miss De Bourgh said.
tr: Miss de Bourgh looked pale and sickly; her facial features, if not ordinary, were expressionless; she spoke very little and in a low voice only to Mrs. Jenkinson; there was nothing remarkable about Mrs. Jenkinson's appearance, and she was entirely occupied with listening to her and aligning the screen so that the light from the fireplace would not hurt her eyes.
es: Miss de Bourgh was pale and sickly; her features, although not ugly, were insignificant; she spoke little and only whispered to Mrs. Jenkinson, whose appearance was unremarkable and who did nothing but listen to what the girl said to her and place a screen in the right direction to protect her eyes from the sun.

en: After sitting a few minutes, they were all sent to one of the windows to admire the view, mr Collins attending them to point out its beauties, and Lady Catherine kindly informing them that it was much better worth looking at in the summer.
vi: After sitting for a few minutes, they were led to a window to enjoy the view. Mr. Collins followed to point out the beauties, and Lady Catherine politely mentioned that the scenery was more beautiful in the summer.
tr: After sitting for a few minutes, they were all sent to the window to enjoy the view; Mr. Collins accompanied them to point out the beauties of the scenery, and Lady Catherine remarked that it should really be seen in the summer.
es: After sitting for a few minutes, they were taken to one of the windows to admire the view; Mr. Collins accompanied them to properly point out its beauty, and Lady Catherine kindly informed them that in summer the view was much better.

en: The dinner was exceedingly handsome, and there were all the servants, and all the articles of plate which mr Collins had promised; and, as he had likewise foretold, he took his seat at the bottom of the table, by her Ladyship’s desire, and looked as if he felt that life could furnish nothing greater.
vi: The dinner was exceedingly sumptuous. All the servants and every piece of glassware and dishware that Mr. Collins had mentioned were present. As he had been forewarned, he sat down at the end of the table; according to the Lady's wishes, and acting as if nothing in life could be greater for him, he carved the food, eating and praising with all his quick words.
tr: The meal was extremely delightful, and all those servants and all that tableware Mr. Collins had promised were there; as he had mentioned beforehand, he took his place at the other end of the table at the behest of her ladyship, and he looked like someone who thought life could offer no more.
es: The dinner was excellent, and all the servants and the silverware that Collins had promised were brought out; and just as he had predicted, he took a seat at the head of the table at Her Ladyship's request, making it seem as if life had nothing more important to offer him.

en: He carved and ate and praised with delighted alacrity; and every dish was commended first by him, and then by Sir William, who was now enough recovered to echo whatever his son-in-law said, in a manner which Elizabeth wondered Lady Catherine could bear.
vi: Every dish was praised, first through his words, then through Sir William's, who had recovered enough to echo every word his son-in-law said, in a manner that made Elizabeth wonder if Lady Catherine could endure it.
tr: He cut up his food, ate, and praised it with delightful care; each dish was complimented separately, first by him, then by Sir William; Sir William had by then recovered enough to repeat everything his son-in-law said, in a manner that Elizabeth could not understand how Lady Catherine could endure.
es: He carved, ate, and praised everything with delight and alacrity. Each dish was first praised by him and then by Sir William, who had recovered enough to echo everything his son-in-law said, so much so that Elizabeth couldn't understand how Lady Catherine could tolerate them.

en: But Lady Catherine seemed gratified by their excessive admiration, and gave most gracious smiles, especially when any dish on the table proved a novelty to them.
vi: But Lady Catherine seemed pleased with the excessive praise, smiling very graciously, especially when there was a dish that was new to them.
tr: But Lady Catherine seemed to take pleasure in their excessive admiration and distributed generous smiles, especially when a dish appeared that they seemed not to have tasted before.
es: But Lady Catherine seemed pleased with such excessive admiration and smiled kindly, especially when a dish was new to them.

en: The party did not supply much conversation.
vi: They did not converse much with each other.
tr: The company was not very talkative.
es: The others said almost nothing.

en: Elizabeth was ready to speak whenever there was an opening, but she was seated between Charlotte and Miss de Bourgh—the former of whom was engaged in listening to Lady Catherine, and the latter said not a word to her all the dinnertime.
vi: Elizabeth was ready to respond whenever spoken to, but she sat between Charlotte and Miss De Bourgh – the former only focused on listening to Lady Catherine, and the latter did not say a word throughout the meal.
tr: Elizabeth was ready to speak whenever she found a gap, but she was seated between Charlotte and Miss de Bourgh – the former was busy listening to Lady Catherine, and the latter did not say a single word to her throughout the meal.
es: Elizabeth was ready to speak as soon as she was given the opportunity; but she was seated between Charlotte and Miss de Bourgh, and the former was busy listening to Lady Catherine, while the latter did not open her mouth throughout the meal.

en: ms Jenkinson was chiefly employed in watching how little Miss de Bourgh ate, pressing her to try some other dish and fearing she was indisposed.
vi: Mrs. Jenkinson primarily concerned herself with overseeing Miss De Bourgh's eating, urging her to try various dishes; worried she wasn't eating well.
tr: Mrs. Jenkinson was mostly occupied with observing how little Miss de Bourgh ate, insisting she try another dish, and fearing she had no appetite.
es: Miss Jenkinson's main occupation was to watch over the little that Miss de Bourgh ate, insistently asking her to take another dish, fearing all the time that she was unwell.

en: Maria thought speaking out of the question, and the gentlemen did nothing but eat and admire.
vi: Maria could not say anything; the men only ate and praised.
tr: Maria thought that conversation was out of the question, while the gentleman did nothing but eat and admire.
es: Maria thought it best not to speak, and the gentlemen did nothing but eat and praise.

en: When the ladies returned to the drawing-room, there was little to be done but to hear Lady Catherine talk, which she did without any intermission till coffee came in, delivering her opinion on every subject in so decisive a manner as proved that she was not used to have her judgment controverted.
vi: When the women returned to the living room, they did nothing more than listen to Lady Catherine speak. She spoke incessantly until the servants brought out the coffee. She gave her opinion on every subject with a decisive manner as if to demonstrate that she was not accustomed to being contradicted.
tr: When the ladies returned to the sitting room, there was little to do but listen to Lady Catherine's conversation; she talked incessantly until the coffee arrived, expressing her opinions on every subject with such a definitive manner that it was clear she was not accustomed to having her judgments questioned.
es: When the ladies returned to the drawing room, they had nothing else to do but listen to Lady Catherine, who spoke without interruption until coffee was served, expressing her opinion on all kinds of matters in such a decided manner that it was clear she was not used to being contradicted.

en: She inquired into Charlotte’s domestic concerns familiarly and minutely, and gave her a great deal of advice as to the management of them all; told her how everything ought to be regulated in so small a family as hers, and instructed her as to the care of her cows and her poultry.
vi: She inquired knowledgeably and meticulously about the concerns in Charlotte's family life, giving her much advice on managing everything; she told her how to coordinate everything in a small household; she instructed her on how to take care of her cattle and poultry.
tr: She closely and meticulously inquired into Charlotte's household affairs and gave her plenty of advice on how to manage everything; she explained how everything should be organized in a small family like hers, and gave lessons on the care of her cows and chickens.
es: She questioned Charlotte minutely and with great familiarity about her domestic affairs, giving her a multitude of advice; she told her that everything should be very well organized in a family as small as hers, and instructed her even in the care of the cows and chickens.

en: Elizabeth found that nothing was beneath this great lady’s attention which could furnish her with an occasion for dictating to others.
vi: Elizabeth noticed that nothing escaped her attention, giving her the opportunity to impose her opinions on others.
tr: Elizabeth noticed that nothing was beneath this grand lady's interest, as long as it provided her with the opportunity to give instructions to others.
es: Elizabeth saw that there was nothing under the attention of this great lady that did not offer her the opportunity to dictate orders to others.

en: In the intervals of her discourse with ms Collins, she addressed a variety of questions to Maria and Elizabeth, but especially to the latter, of whose connections she knew the least, and who, she observed to ms Collins, was a very genteel, pretty kind of girl.
vi: Between conversations with Mrs. Collins, Lady Catherine asked many questions of Maria and Elizabeth, especially Elizabeth. She knew the least about Elizabeth and remarked to Mrs. Collins that Elizabeth was a gentle and pretty young woman.
tr: In the midst of her conversation with Mrs. Collins, she directed various questions to Maria and Elizabeth, but especially to Elizabeth; she did not know her relatives and told Mrs. Collins that she was a very elegant and beautiful girl.
es: In the intervals of her discourse to Mrs. Collins, she directed several questions to Maria and Elizabeth, but especially to the latter, about whose family she knew nothing, and who, as she told Mrs. Collins, seemed to her a very gentle and pretty girl.

en: She asked her at different times how many sisters she had, whether they were older or younger than herself, whether any of them were likely to be married, whether they were handsome, where they had been educated, what carriage her father kept, and what had been her mother’s maiden name?
vi: She asked her many questions, how many sisters she had, if any were about to get married, whether they were beautiful, how educated they were, what kind of carriage her father had, and what her mother's maiden name was.
tr: At different times, she asked Elizabeth how many sisters she had, whether they were older or younger than her, whether any of them were likely to get married, whether they were beautiful, where they were educated, what kind of carriages her father had, and her mother's maiden name.
es: She asked her, on various occasions, how many sisters she had, whether they were older or younger than her, if any of them were about to be married, if they were pretty, where they had been educated, what kind of carriage her father had, and what her mother's maiden name had been.

en: Elizabeth felt all the impertinence of her questions, but answered them very composedly.
vi: Elizabeth found all her questions irrelevant but calmly answered them.
tr: –Elizabeth, though she felt the impertinence of her questions, answered quite calmly.
es: Elizabeth noticed the impertinence of her questions, but answered all of them with composure.

en: Lady Catherine then observed,—
vi: Then Lady Catherine remarked:
tr: –Lady Catherine then made this observation,
es: Lady Catherine then observed:

en: “Your father’s estate is entailed on mr Collins, I think?
vi: - Her father's estate is to be inherited by Mr. Collins in order, as I heard.
tr: "Your father's estate is mortgaged to Mr. Collins, I believe.
es: ––I understand that your father's property is to be inherited by Mr. Collins.

en: For your sake,” turning to Charlotte, “I am glad of it; but otherwise I see no occasion for entailing estates from the female line.
vi: Then she turned to Charlotte: - I am happy for you, but on the other hand, I do not see the opportunity to pass on the inheritance through the female line.
tr: From your perspective," he turned to Charlotte, "this is fortunate; but in fact, mortgaging the estate to anyone other than the daughters is not acceptable.
es: I congratulate you ––he said, turning to Charlotte––; but I see no reason to bequeath the possessions outside the female line.

en: It was not thought necessary in Sir Lewis de Bourgh’s family.
vi: In the family of Mr. Lewis De Bourgh, this is considered unnecessary.
tr: –In Sir Lewis de Bourgh's family, this has not been deemed necessary.
es: In Sir Lewis de Bourgh's family, it was not done that way.

en: Do you play and sing, Miss Bennet?”
vi: Do you pursue music and vocal arts, Miss Bennet?
tr: Do you know how to play the piano, sing, Miss Bennet?"
es: Do you play and sing, Miss Bennet?

en: “A little.”
vi: - Just a little.
tr: "A little." "Ah!
es: ––A little. ––Ah!

en: “Oh then—some time or other we shall be happy to hear you.
vi: - Ah! Then at some point, we would be delighted to hear you perform.
tr: Then we would be happy to listen to you sometime.
es: Then we will have the pleasure of hearing you at some point.

en: Our instrument is a capital one, probably superior to —— you shall try it some day.
vi: Our musical instruments are of good quality, even better. You should try them someday.
tr: Our piano is one of the best, probably better than yours– You should try it one day.
es: Our piano is excellent, probably better than... One day you will try it.

en: Do your sisters play and sing?”
vi: Do your sisters study these arts as well?
tr: Do your siblings also play and sing?"
es: And your sisters, do they play and sing as well?

en: “One of them does.”
vi: - There is a person.
tr: "One of them."
es: ––One of them, yes.

en: “Why did not you all learn?
vi: - Why don't all of you study?
tr: "Why didn't all of you learn?
es: ––And why not all of them?

en: You ought all to have learned.
vi: All of you need to study.
tr: –All of you should have learned.
es: All of them should have learned.

en: The Miss Webbs all play, and their father has not so good an income as yours.
vi: The Webb sisters all study, while their father doesn't have as much income as your father.
tr: All the Webblers know, and their father's income isn't as good as yours.
es: The Misses Webb all play, and their parents are not as rich as yours.

en: Do you draw?”
vi: Do you study painting?
tr: –Will you draw a picture?"
es: Do you draw?

en: “No, not at all.”
vi: - No, no one is studying.
tr: "No, never."
es: ––No, nothing.

en: “What, none of you?”
vi: - What, no one?
tr: "What do you mean, none of you?""
es: ––How? None of you?

en: “Not one.”
vi: - No one.
tr: "None of us."
es: ––None.

en: “That is very strange.
vi: - That's really strange.
tr: "This is very strange.
es: ––It's very strange.

en: But I suppose you had no opportunity.
vi: But I guess you girls didn't have the chance.
tr: But you probably haven't had the opportunity.
es: I suppose they haven't had the opportunity.

en: Your mother should have taken you to town every spring for the benefit of masters.”
vi: Your mother should have taken you to the city every spring to study with renowned artists.
tr: Your mother should have taken you to the city every spring to benefit from the teachers."
es: Their mother must have taken them to the city every spring to have good teachers.

en: “My mother would have no objection, but my father hates London.”
vi: - Our mother surely wouldn't object, but our father hates London.
tr: "My mother wouldn't object, but my father hates London."
es: ––My mother wouldn't have objected, but my father hates London.

en: “Has your governess left you?”
vi: - Has your tutor quit already?
tr: "Did your governess leave you?"
es: ––And is your governess still with you?

en: “We never had any governess.”
vi: - We have never had a tutor.
tr: "We never had a governess."
es: ––We have never had a governess.

en: “No governess!
vi: - No governess!
tr: "Not at all!
es: ––They have never had a governess!

en: How was that possible?
vi: How can that be?
tr: How is that possible?
es: How is that possible?

en: Five daughters brought up at home without a governess!
vi: Five daughters brought up in the house without a governess!
tr: Raising five girls at home without a governess!
es: Five daughters educated at home without a governess!

en: I never heard of such a thing.
vi: I have never heard of such a thing.
tr: I've never heard of such a thing.
es: I've never seen anything like it.

en: Your mother must have been quite a slave to your education.”
vi: Your mother must have been a slave to your education.
tr: Your mother must have worked like a slave for your education."
es: Their mother must have been a true slave to their education.

en: Elizabeth could hardly help smiling, as she assured her that had not been the case.
vi: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile as she explained that it wasn't like that.
tr: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile as she said that wasn't the case.
es: Elizabeth could hardly suppress a smile as she assured him that it had not been so.

en: “Then who taught you?
vi: - Then, who teaches you?
tr: "So, who educated you?
es: ––So, who educated them?

en: who attended to you?
vi: Who takes care of you?
tr: Who looked after you?
es: Who took care of them?

en: Without a governess, you must have been neglected.”
vi: Without a tutor, you must have been neglected.
tr: You must have been neglected without a governess."
es: Without a governess, they must have been neglected.

en: “Compared with some families, I believe we were; but such of us as wished to learn never wanted the means.
vi: - Compared to other families, I believe we were neglected, but if we wanted to learn, we were not lacking in resources.
tr: "According to some families, I'm sure we were privileged; but those of us who wanted to learn were never deprived of the necessary means.
es: ––In comparison with some families, I'm not saying otherwise; but for those of us who wanted to learn, we never lacked the means.

en: We were always encouraged to read, and had all the masters that were necessary.
vi: We were always encouraged to read books, and had tutors for all subjects when necessary.
tr: We were always encouraged to read and had all the necessary teachers.
es: We were always encouraged to read, and we had all the teachers we needed.

en: Those who chose to be idle certainly might.”
vi: Those who wanted leisure could have leisure.
tr: But those who chose idleness were also free to choose it."
es: It is true that those who preferred to be idle, could be.

en: “Ay, no doubt: but that is what a governess will prevent; and if I had known your mother, I should have advised her most strenuously to engage one.
vi: - Ah, that's right, but a tutor can prevent this. If I had known your mother, I could have urgently advised her to have a tutor.
tr: "Yes, undoubtedly; but that is precisely what a governess is for; if I knew your mother, I would insistently advise her to hire one.
es: ––Yes, I don't doubt it! And that is what a governess can prevent, and if I had known your mother, I would have insisted with all my might that she take one.

en: I always say that nothing is to be done in education without steady and regular instruction, and nobody but a governess can give it.
vi: I always say that nothing can be achieved in education without long-term and regular teaching, and only a tutor can accomplish this.
tr: I always say, nothing can be achieved in education without continuous and regular lessons, and only a governess can provide those lessons.
es: I always maintain that in matters of education, nothing is achieved without solid and orderly instruction, and only a governess can provide that.

en: It is wonderful how many families I have been the means of supplying in that way.
vi: It's quite wonderful to think about how many families I've had the opportunity to assist in this way.
tr: You would be amazed if you knew how many families' needs I have met in this regard.
es: You should see the number of families I have guided in this regard!

en: I am always glad to get a young person well placed out.
vi: I'm always delighted to support a young person to achieve a good position.
tr: I am always pleased to place a young person in a good position.
es: I love to see girls well-placed.

en: Four nieces of ms Jenkinson are most delightfully situated through my means; and it was but the other day that I recommended another young person, who was merely accidentally mentioned to me, and the family are quite delighted with her.
vi: Four of Mrs. Jenkinson's nephews have been arranged in the best manner through my means. Just recently, I recommended a young person who was only mentioned to me by someone else, and the family is very happy with her.
tr: Thanks to me, Mrs. Jenkinson's four nieces have secured very good positions; just the other day, I recommended another young girl who was mentioned to me by chance, and the family was very pleased with her.
es: Four nieces of Mrs. Jenkinson were very well placed thanks to me, and just the other day I recommended another young woman whom I heard about by chance, and the family is very happy with her.

en: ms Collins, did I tell you of Lady Metcalfe’s calling yesterday to thank me?
vi: Mrs. Collins, did I tell you about Lady Metcalfe visiting me yesterday to thank me?
tr: Mrs. Collins, did I tell you that Lady Metcalfe came to thank me yesterday?
es: Mrs. Collins, did I tell you that Lady Metcalfe was here yesterday to thank me?

en: She finds Miss Pope a treasure.
vi: She considers Miss Pope a treasure.
tr: Miss Pope was a treasure for her.
es: She assures that Miss Pope is a treasure.

en: ‘Lady Catherine,’ said she, ‘you have given me a treasure.’
vi: She said: “Lady Catherine, you have given me a treasure.”
tr: 'Lady Catherine,' she said, 'you have given me a treasure.'
es: “Lady Catherine,” she said to me, “you have given me a treasure.”

en: Are any of your younger sisters out, Miss Bennet?”
vi: Miss Bennet, have any of your sisters ever been out in society?
tr: Have your younger sisters been presented to society, Miss Bennet?"
es: Have any of your younger sisters been presented to society yet, Miss Bennet?

en: “Yes, ma’am, all.”
vi: - Yes, Madam, all of it.
tr: "Yes, sir, all of them."
es: ––Yes, ma'am, all of them.

en: “All!
vi: - All of them!
tr: "All of you!
es: ––All of them! How!

en: What, all five out at once?
vi: What, all five girls at once?
tr: –All five of you at once?
es: All five at once?

en: Very odd!
vi: How strange!
tr: Very strange!
es: How strange!

en: And you only the second.
vi: And you are only the second child in the family.
tr: –Moreover, you are only the second one.
es: And you are only the second.

en: The younger ones out before the elder are married!
vi: The younger sisters are socializing before the eldest gets married!
tr: –The younger ones are coming out before the older ones get married!
es: The younger ones presented in society before the older ones get married!

en: Your younger sisters must be very young?”
vi: Your younger sisters must be very young?!
tr: –Are your siblings very young?"
es: Your sisters must be very young...

en: “Yes, my youngest is not sixteen.
vi: - Yes, the youngest one is not yet sixteen.
tr: "Yes, our youngest is not even sixteen.
es: ––Yes; the youngest is not yet sixteen years old.

en: Perhaps she is full young to be much in company.
vi: Perhaps she is still too young to socialize widely.
tr: Maybe too young to be among too many people.
es: Perhaps she is too young to have been introduced to society.

en: But really, ma’am, I think it would be very hard upon younger sisters that they should not have their share of society and amusement, because the elder may not have the means or inclination to marry early.
vi: But, madam, I truly think it is too harsh for the younger sisters if they are not allowed to socialize and enjoy themselves just because the eldest sister is not yet in a position or does not intend to marry soon.
tr: But really, sir, it would be very sad if the young ones were deprived of gatherings and entertainments just because the elders do not have the means or desire to marry early.
es: But in reality, madam, I believe it would be very unfair for the younger sisters to be unable to enjoy society and its amenities, just because the older ones do not have the means or desire to marry soon.

en: The last born has as good a right to the pleasures of youth as the first.
vi: I believe the youngest child also has the right to enjoy the pleasures of youth like the eldest.
tr: The youngest has as much right to enjoy the pleasures of youth as the firstborn.
es: The youngest daughter has as much right to the pleasures of youth as the first.

en: And to be kept back on such a motive!
vi: And being so restrained, I think it is difficult to foster sisterly bonds or develop the subtlety of the soul.
tr: To be kept closed for such a reason!
es: Delaying them for that reason, I believe, would not be the most appropriate way to foster fraternal affection and delicacy of thought.

en: I think it would not be very likely to promote sisterly affection or delicacy of mind.”
vi: And being so restrained, I think it is difficult to foster sisterly bonds or develop the subtlety of the soul.
tr: I don't think it would be very helpful in developing a sense of brotherhood or understanding."
es: ––"Goodness!" ––said His Lordship––.

en: “Upon my word,” said her Ladyship, “you give your opinion very decidedly for so young a person.
vi: - You have quite a decisive opinion for someone young.
tr: "Honestly," said the lady, "you express your opinions very decisively for someone so young.
es: For being so young, you express your opinions very decisively.

en: Pray, what is your age?”
vi: May I ask, how old are you?
tr: For God's sake, how old are you?"
es: Tell me, how old are you?

en: “With three younger sisters grown up,” replied Elizabeth, smiling, “your Ladyship can hardly expect me to own it.”
vi: Elizabeth smiled: - With three younger sisters who have grown up, Madam can hardly expect me to reveal my age publicly.
tr: "Since my three younger sisters are grown," replied Elizabeth with a smile, "I suppose her ladyship cannot expect me to state my age."
es: ––With three grown-up sisters behind me ––replied Elizabeth, smiling––, Your Lordship cannot expect me to confess it.

en: Lady Catherine seemed quite astonished at not receiving a direct answer; and Elizabeth suspected herself to be the first creature who had ever dared to trifle with so much dignified impertinence.
vi: Lady Catherine seemed quite surprised not to receive a direct answer, and Elizabeth guessed she was the first creature to dare to disregard such an intrusion into personal matters!
tr: Lady Catherine seemed very surprised not to receive a direct answer; Elizabeth suspected that she was the first person to dare to take such dignified impudence lightly.
es: Lady Catherine was astonished not to have received a direct response; and Elizabeth suspected that she was the first person who had dared to mock such majestic impertinence.

en: “You cannot be more than twenty, I am sure,—therefore you need not conceal your age.”
vi: - I'm sure you're not yet twenty, so you don't need to hide your age.
tr: "You can't be more than twenty, I'm sure, –so there's no need to hide your age."
es: ––You can't be more than twenty, I'm sure; so you don't need to hide your age.

en: “I am not one-and-twenty.”
vi: - I am not yet twenty-one.
tr: "I haven't turned twenty-one yet.""
es: ––I haven't turned twenty-one yet.

en: When the gentlemen had joined them, and tea was over, the card tables were placed.
vi: When they joined the group and had finished their tea, they set up the card tables.
tr: When the gentlemen joined them, and the tea was finished, the game tables were set up.
es: When the gentlemen entered and finished having tea, the game tables were set up.

en: Lady Catherine, Sir William, and mr and ms Collins sat down to quadrille; and as Miss De Bourgh chose to play at cassino, the two girls had the honour of assisting ms Jenkinson to make up her party.
vi: Lady Charlotte, Sir William, and Mr. and Mrs. Collins sat down to play a four-person card game. Since Miss De Bourgh wanted to play a different game, the two young ladies had the honor of forming a table with Mrs. Jenkinson.
tr: Lady Catherine, Sir William, and Mr. and Mrs. Collins sat down to quadrille; since Miss de Bourgh preferred to play cassino, the two girls supported Mr. Jenkinson to form a group with her.
es: Lady Catherine, Sir William, and the Collinses sat down to play a game of quadrille, and as Miss de Bourgh preferred to play casino, Elizabeth and Maria had the honor of helping Mrs. Jenkinson complete her table, which was supremely boring.

en: Their table was superlatively stupid.
vi: This group was extremely dull.
tr: The tables were extraordinarily dull.
es: Lady Catherine, Sir William, and the Collinses sat down to play a game of quadrille, and as Miss de Bourgh preferred to play casino, Elizabeth and Maria had the honor of helping Mrs. Jenkinson complete her table, which was supremely boring.

en: Scarcely a syllable was uttered that did not relate to the game, except when ms Jenkinson expressed her fears of Miss De Bourgh’s being too hot or too cold, or having too much or too little light.
vi: Hardly a word was spoken that did not pertain to the game, except when Mrs. Jenkinson expressed concern that Miss De Bourgh might be too hot or too cold, or that there was too much or too little light.
tr: Not a single syllable unrelated to the game came out of anyone's mouth; only Mrs. Jenkinson expressed her concerns about whether Miss de Bourgh was too hot or too cold, whether her clothing was too thick or too thin.
es: Hardly a syllable was uttered that did not pertain to the game, except when Mrs. Jenkinson expressed her fears that Miss de Bourgh might be too hot or too cold, too much light or too little.

en: A great deal more passed at the other table.
vi: The other table had more going on.
tr: More was happening at the other table.
es: The other table was much more lively.

en: Lady Catherine was generally speaking—stating the mistakes of the three others, or relating some anecdote of herself.
vi: Lady Catherine talked more – pointing out the faults of the other three, or recounting some anecdotes about herself.
tr: Lady Catherine was generally speaking – pointing out the mistakes of the other three people or telling an anecdote about herself.
es: Lady Catherine almost never stopped talking, highlighting the mistakes of her fellow players or recounting some anecdote about herself.

en: mr Collins was employed in agreeing to everything her Ladyship said, thanking her for every fish he won, and apologizing if he thought he won too many.
vi: Mr. Collins agreed with everything Lady Catherine said, thanked her whenever he scored points, and apologized when he thought he was winning too much.
tr: Mr. Collins was busy approving everything her ladyship said, thanking her for every chip he won, and apologizing if he thought he had won too much.
es: Collins did nothing but affirm everything Her Ladyship said, thanking her every time he won and apologizing when he thought his winnings were excessive.

en: Sir William did not say much.
vi: Sir William did not say much.
tr: Sir William did not say much.
es: Sir William did not say much.

en: He was storing his memory with anecdotes and noble names.
vi: His mind was busy remembering the anecdotes and the names of the aristocratic figures.
tr: He was storing anecdotes and noble names in his memory.
es: He devoted himself to recalling in his memory all those anecdotes and so many illustrious names.

en: When Lady Catherine and her daughter had played as long as they chose, the tables were broken up, the carriage was offered to ms Collins, gratefully accepted, and immediately ordered.
vi: When Lady Catherine and her daughter decided it was enough, they put away the card tables, Mrs. Collins was offered the carriage and she gladly accepted.
tr: After Lady Catherine and her daughter played until they were bored, the tables were cleared, a carriage was offered to Mrs. Collins, the offer was gratefully accepted, and the carriage was immediately ordered.
es: When Lady Catherine and her daughter grew tired of playing, the tables were cleared, and they offered the carriage to Mrs. Collins, who accepted it very gratefully, and immediately gave orders to bring it.

en: The party then gathered round the fire to hear Lady Catherine determine what weather they were to have on the morrow.
vi: Then the whole group sat around the fireplace to hear Lady Catherine decide what the weather would be like the next day.
tr: Then the group gathered around the fire to listen to Lady Catherine decide what the weather would be like the next day.
es: The gathering then congregated by the fire to hear Lady Catherine predict what the weather would be like the next day.

en: From these instructions they were summoned by the arrival of the coach; and with many speeches of thankfulness on mr Collins’s side, and as many bows on Sir William’s, they departed.
vi: Then they were informed that the carriage had arrived, with many expressions of gratitude from Mr. Collins along with many bows from Sir William, they bid each other farewell.
tr: With the arrival of the carriage, they bid farewell to these observations; they departed with Mr. Collins's numerous expressions of gratitude and Sir William's endless salutations.
es: At that moment, they were informed that the carriage was at the door, and with many bows from Sir William and many expressions of gratitude from Mr. Collins, they took their leave.

en: As soon as they had driven from the door, Elizabeth was called on by her cousin to give her opinion of all that she had seen at Rosings, which, for Charlotte’s sake, she made more favourable than it really was.
vi: As soon as they left, Mr. Collins asked Elizabeth about her impressions of Rosings. To please Charlotte, she made more favorable comments than she truly felt.
tr: As soon as the carriage left the door, Elizabeth was invited by her cousin to comment on what they had seen at Rosings; for Charlotte's sake, Elizabeth made a more favorable comment than she actually felt.
es: As soon as they left the hallway behind, Mr. Collins invited Elizabeth to express her opinion on what she had seen at Rosings, to which she agreed, only for Charlotte's sake, exaggerating it more than she felt.

en: But her commendation, though costing her some trouble, could by no means satisfy mr Collins, and he was very soon obliged to take her Ladyship’s praise into his own hands.
vi: But her words of praise, though they made her somewhat uncomfortable, still could not satisfy Mr. Collins, so he had to add more of his own to further extol Lady Catherine.
tr: But the praises she struggled so hard to fabricate did not satisfy Mr. Collins in any way, and soon Mr. Collins had to take the task of praising her ladyship into his own hands.
es: But no matter how hard she tried, her praise did not satisfy Mr. Collins, who soon found himself obliged to take on the task of praising Her Ladyship himself.

en: CHAPTER XXX.
vi: Chapter 30
tr: Chapter VII
es: CHAPTER XXX

en: SIR WILLIAM stayed only a week at Hunsford; but his visit was long enough to convince him of his daughter’s being most comfortably settled, and of her possessing such a husband and such a neighbour as were not often met with.
vi: Sir William stayed in Huntsford for only a week, but it was enough for him to believe that his daughter was settled in the most satisfactory manner, that she had a husband and neighbors that were not easy to find.
tr: Sir William stayed in Hunsford for only a week, but his visit was long enough to convince him that his daughter had made an extraordinary marriage, and that she had a rare husband and neighbor.
es: Sir William spent no more than a week in Hunsford, but it was enough to convince him that his daughter was very well situated and that a husband like that and a neighborhood like that were not often found.

en: While Sir William was with them, mr Collins devoted his mornings to driving him out in his gig, and showing him the country: but when he went away, the whole family returned to their usual employments, and Elizabeth was thankful to find that they did not see more of her cousin by the alteration; for the chief of the time between breakfast and dinner was now passed by him either at work in the garden, or in reading and writing, and looking out of window in his own book room, which fronted the road.
vi: While Sir William was staying there, Mr. Collins spent every morning driving him out into the countryside. When he left, the whole family returned to their usual routine.
tr: While Sir William was with them, Mr. Collins devoted his mornings to taking him around the countryside in his one-horse carriage; but after he left, the whole family returned to their usual routines; Elizabeth was glad that she did not have to see her cousin more often due to the change; Mr. Collins spent most of the time between breakfast and dinner either working in the garden or reading and writing, or watching the outside from the window of his reading room facing the front road.
es: While he was there, Collins dedicated the morning to taking him around in his carriage to show him the countryside; but as soon as he left, the family returned to their usual occupations. Elizabeth was grateful that with the change in routine, she no longer had to see her cousin so frequently, as most of the time between lunch and dinner, Collins spent working in the garden, reading, writing, or looking out the window of his study, which faced the road.

en: The room in which the ladies sat was backwards.
vi: Elizabeth was pleased to see that they seldom saw him, for in the time between breakfast and dinner, he was either working in the garden or reading and writing, sitting in his own study at the front of the house looking out the window, while the women's gathering room was at the back of the house.
tr: The room where the ladies sat was at the back.
es: The room where the ladies usually stayed faced the back of the house.

en: Elizabeth at first had rather wondered that Charlotte should not prefer the dining parlour for common use; it was a better sized room, and had a pleasanter aspect: but she soon saw that her friend had an excellent reason for what she did, for mr Collins would undoubtedly have been much less in his own apartment had they sat in one equally lively; and she gave Charlotte credit for the arrangement.
vi: At first, Catherine was puzzled that Charlotte did not want to use the dining room for everyone to gather in, as it was quite spacious and had a better view, but soon she saw that her friend had a very good reason, for if they used the large room, Mr. Collins would seldom be in his own study.
tr: Elizabeth was initially surprised that Charlotte had not chosen the dining room for everyday use; it was a larger room and had a more pleasant view; but she soon saw that her friend had an excellent reason for doing so, because if they sat in an equally beautiful room, Mr. Collins would undoubtedly spend less time in his own room; Elizabeth appreciated Charlotte for this arrangement.
es: At first, it surprised Elizabeth that Charlotte did not prefer to be in the dining room, which was a larger and more pleasant-looking room. But soon she saw that her friend had excellent reasons for acting this way, as Collins would have undoubtedly spent less time in his room if they had enjoyed one as large as his. And Elizabeth approved of Charlotte's attitude.

en: From the drawing-room they could distinguish nothing in the lane, and were indebted to mr Collins for the knowledge of what carriages went along, and how often especially Miss De Bourgh drove by in her phaeton, which he never failed coming to inform them of, though it happened almost every day.
vi: From the living room, they couldn't distinguish anything on the road, and they remembered Mr. Collins telling them what kind of carriage was passing by, especially how often Miss De Bourgh would come by in her four-wheeled carriage, which he always informed them of in advance even though she came almost every day.
tr: While they were in the living room, they were unaware of what was happening on the road; they could only learn which cars passed by thanks to Mr. Collins, who would promptly inform them of Miss de Bourgh's every passing, even though she passed almost every day.
es: From the living room, they couldn't see the road, so it was always Collins who informed them about the passing cars and especially about how often Miss de Bourgh crossed in her phaeton, something he never failed to report even though it happened almost every day.

en: She not unfrequently stopped at the Parsonage, and had a few minutes’ conversation with Charlotte, but was scarcely ever prevailed on to get out.
vi: She often stopped in front of the Parsonage and chatted for a few minutes with Charlotte but almost never stepped out of the carriage.
