tr: Occasionally, he would stop at the lodge and talk to Charlotte for a few minutes, but he was reluctant to get out of the car.
es: Miss de Bourgh usually stopped at the house to chat with Charlotte for a few minutes, but it was difficult to convince her to get out of the carriage.

en: Very few days passed in which mr Collins did not walk to Rosings, and not many in which his wife did not think it necessary to go likewise; and till Elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings to be disposed of, she could not understand the sacrifice of so many hours.
vi: There were very few days when Mr. Collins did not go to Rosings, and there were also many days when his wife thought it unnecessary to do so. Elizabeth could not understand the need to sacrifice so much time until she remembered that there might be other family activities that needed to be excluded.
tr: Few days passed without Mr. Collins walking to Rosings, and his wife also deemed it necessary to go as well; Elizabeth did not understand the sacrifice of so many hours until she realized there might be other church parishes to be distributed.
es: Few days passed without Collins taking a walk to Rosings, and his wife often felt it her duty to do the same; Elizabeth, until she remembered that there might be other families willing to do the same, did not understand the sacrifice of so many hours.

en: Now and then they were honoured with a call from her Ladyship, and nothing escaped her observation that was passing in the room during these visits.
vi: Occasionally, they had the honor of being visited by the Lady, and nothing that happened during these visits escaped her observation.
tr: Occasionally, they were honored by a visit from her ladyship; during these visits, nothing that happened in the room escaped her notice.
es: From time to time, he honored them with a visit, during which nothing that happened in the drawing room escaped his notice.

en: She examined into their employments, looked at their work, and advised them to do it differently; found fault with the arrangement of the furniture, or detected the housemaid in negligence; and if she accepted any refreshment, seemed to do it only for the sake of finding out that ms Collins’s joints of meat were too large for her family.
vi: She would scrutinize the couple's lifestyle, look into their work and advise them to do it differently, criticize the arrangement of the furniture, or notice the servants' negligence. If she accepted to have refreshments, it seemed she did so only to find out that Mrs. Collins's portions of meat were too large for the family.
tr: She examined their occupations, looked at the work they produced, and advised them to do it differently; she found fault with the arrangement of the furniture or detected the servant's neglect; if she accepted to eat or drink something, it seemed she did so only to see that Mrs. Collins's meat allowance was too much for her family.
es: Indeed, he paid attention to what they were doing, looked at their work and advised them to do it differently, found faults in the arrangement of the furniture or discovered negligence in the maid; if he accepted any refreshment, it seemed he did so only to point out that the meat portions were too large for them.

en: Elizabeth soon perceived, that though this great lady was not in the commission of the peace for the county, she was a most active magistrate in her own parish, the minutest concerns of which were carried to her by mr Collins; and whenever any of the cottagers were disposed to be quarrelsome, discontented, or too poor, she sallied forth into the village to settle their differences, silence their complaints, and scold them into harmony and plenty.
vi: Elizabeth soon learned that, although this Lady did not hold any civil office for the local county, she was the most active magistrate in her parish, and every minor issue was reported to her by Mr. Collins. When the local residents quarreled with each other, expressed dissatisfaction, or fell into distress, she would come to resolve the disagreements, quell the complaints, and reprimand them to bring them into a state of harmony and prosperity.
tr: Elizabeth soon realized that although this great lady was not a member of the provincial peace committee, she was very active as a judge in her own village; Mr. Collins would bring her detailed reports, and whenever one of the villagers fought, got into trouble, or became very poor, she would immediately go to the village, resolve disputes, silence complaints, and give them a scolding while calling for unity and solidarity.
es: Elizabeth soon realized that although the peace of the county was not entrusted to that great lady, she was an active magistrate in her own parish, whose details were communicated to her by Collins.

en: “he never failed to inform them”
vi: They were invited to dine at Rosings about twice a week.
tr: Elizabeth soon realized that although this great lady was not a member of the provincial peace committee, she was very active as a judge in her own village; Mr. Collins would bring her detailed reports, and whenever one of the villagers fought, got into trouble, or became very poor, she would immediately go to the village, resolve disputes, silence complaints, and give them a scolding while calling for unity and solidarity.
es: Whenever any of the villagers were about to cause trouble or felt discontented or helpless, Lady Catherine would personally go to the required place to settle the differences and reprimand them, restoring harmony or ensuring abundance.

en: The entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week; and, allowing for the loss of Sir William, and there being only one card-table in the evening, every such entertainment was the counterpart of the first.
vi: After Mr. William had left and there was only one card table, each dining opportunity was no longer as enjoyable as the first evening.
tr: The evening entertainment at Rosings was repeated twice a week; since Sir William's place was vacant and only one game table was set up throughout the evening, each of these entertainments was a copy of the first.
es: The invitation to dine at Rosings was repeated a couple of times a week, and since Sir William's departure, as there was only one game table during the evening, the entertainment was always the same.

en: Their other engagements were few, as the style of living of the neighbourhood in general was beyond the Collinses’ reach.
vi: They had little chance to interact with anyone else, as the lifestyle of the neighbors did not suit the Collins family.
tr: They had very few other occupations, as the lifestyle of the neighborhood generally exceeded Mr. Collins' means.
es: They did not have many other commitments, because the lifestyle of the rest of the neighbors was below that of the Collinses.

en: This, however, was no evil to Elizabeth, and upon the whole she spent her time comfortably enough: there were half hours of pleasant conversation with Charlotte, and the weather was so fine for the time of year, that she had often great enjoyment out of doors.
vi: This did not bother Elizabeth. During this time, she felt quite comfortable. She had half-hour conversations with Charlotte each time. The weather was very pleasant for this time of year, so she often enjoyed being outdoors.
tr: Nevertheless, Elizabeth was not bothered by this and mostly spent her time quite pleasantly; there were sweet half-hour conversations with Charlotte, and the weather was so beautiful for that time of year that she often spent cheerful hours outdoors.
es: Elizabeth did not mind; she was comfortable with it, spending long periods chatting pleasantly with Charlotte; and since the weather was wonderful, despite the time of year, she amused herself by going out for walks.

en: Her favourite walk, and where she frequently went while the others were calling on Lady Catherine, was along the open grove which edged that side of the park, where there was a nice sheltered path, which no one seemed to value but herself, and where she felt beyond the reach of Lady Catherine’s curiosity.
vi: The path she liked to walk the most, especially when others were invited to Rosings, was the shaded trail along the garden fence that seemed to be favored only by her, where she felt she could escape Lady Catherine's prying eyes.
tr: When the others went to visit Lady Catherine, she often went for a walk; she had a favorite route; there was a sheltered, beautiful path along the open plain adjacent to that side of the grove that seemed to matter to no one else, and here she felt herself in a place where Lady Catherine's curiosity could not reach.
es: Her favorite walk, which she often took while the others visited Lady Catherine, was the avenue that bordered one side of the estate where there was a very beautiful and sheltered path that no one but her seemed to appreciate, and on which she was out of Lady Catherine's curious reach.

en: In this quiet way the first fortnight of her visit soon passed away.
vi: The first two weeks of Elizabeth's visit passed in this manner.
tr: The first fifteen days of her visit passed quickly in this tranquility.
es: With this tranquility, the first fortnight of her stay in Hunsford quickly passed.

en: Easter was approaching, and the week preceding it was to bring an addition to the family at Rosings, which in so small a circle must be important.
vi: Easter was approaching, and a week before that, a notable person was expected to visit the Rosings family, which, in such a small household, would be a significant event.
tr: Easter was approaching, and the week before it, there would be a new addition to the family at Rosings, which must have been significant for such a small circle.
es: Easter was approaching, and the week before it was going to bring an addition to the family at Rosings, which, in such a small circle, had to be very important.

en: Elizabeth had heard, soon after her arrival, that mr Darcy was expected there in the course of a few weeks; and though there were not many of her acquaintance whom she did not prefer, his coming would furnish one comparatively new to look at in their Rosings parties, and she might be amused in seeing how hopeless Miss Bingley’s designs on him were, by his behaviour to his cousin, for whom he was evidently destined by Lady Catherine, who talked of his coming with the greatest satisfaction, spoke of him in terms of the highest admiration, and seemed almost angry to find that he had already been frequently seen by Miss Lucas and herself.
vi: Elizabeth had heard that Mr. Darcy would be coming. Although there were few people she did not like, his presence would add a new subject for observation within the Rosings family. She might be interested in seeing how Miss Bingley's schemes regarding him would become futile, by examining his attitude towards his cousin, as it was clear that Lady Catherine had decided his fate with her. She had announced his imminent arrival with great satisfaction, speaking of him in terms of admiration, and seemed almost angry upon learning that Miss Lucas and Elizabeth herself had often met him.
tr: Elizabeth had heard shortly after her arrival that Mr. Darcy was expected to come there within a few weeks; although there were few acquaintances she liked less, his arrival would have added someone relatively new to the parties at Rosings; moreover, by observing his behavior towards her cousin, she could amuse herself by seeing how hopeless Miss Bingley's plans regarding him were; Lady Catherine was clearly considering him for her daughter; she spoke of his arrival with great joy, praised him endlessly, and was almost furious when she learned that Miss Lucas and Elizabeth had already seen him many times.
es: Shortly after her arrival, Elizabeth heard that Darcy was going to arrive in a few weeks, and although she would have preferred any other of his acquaintances, the truth was that his presence could bring a bit of variety to the evenings at Rosings and that she could amuse herself by seeing the little foundation of Miss Bingley's hopes while observing Darcy's attitude towards Miss de Bourgh, to whom Lady Catherine evidently intended him. Her Ladyship spoke of his coming with enormous satisfaction, and of him, in terms of the highest admiration; and it seemed to bother her that Miss Lucas and Elizabeth had already seen him frequently before.

en: His arrival was soon known at the Parsonage; for mr Collins was walking the whole morning within view of the lodges opening into Hunsford Lane, in order to have
vi: Not long after, the entire Parish House knew about his impending visit, because Mr. Collins had spent the entire morning walking around Huntsford spreading the news.
tr: Mr. Darcy's arrival at the parsonage was immediately noticed, because Mr. Collins had spent the entire morning walking within the view of the outbuildings that opened onto Hunsford Road in order to detect the exact moment of his arrival, and after bowing as the carriage turned into the Grove, he had rushed back to the house with the great news.
es: Their arrival was known immediately, for Collins had been strolling all morning with his eyes fixed on the pavilions at the entrance to the Hunsford road; as soon as he saw the carriage enter the estate, he made his corresponding bow, and ran home to deliver the grand news.

en: “The gentlemen accompanied him.”
vi: Not long after, the entire Parish House knew about his impending visit, because Mr. Collins had spent the entire morning walking around Huntsford spreading the news.
tr: Mr. Darcy's arrival at the parsonage was immediately noticed, because Mr. Collins had spent the entire morning walking within the view of the outbuildings that opened onto Hunsford Road in order to detect the exact moment of his arrival, and after bowing as the carriage turned into the Grove, he had rushed back to the house with the great news.
es: Their arrival was known immediately, for Collins had been strolling all morning with his eyes fixed on the pavilions at the entrance to the Hunsford road; as soon as he saw the carriage enter the estate, he made his corresponding bow, and ran home to deliver the grand news.

en: the earliest assurance of it; and, after making his bow as the carriage turned into the park, hurried home with the great intelligence.
vi: After bowing at Rosings Park, he hurried home with the most important news.
tr: Mr. Darcy's arrival at the parsonage was immediately noticed, because Mr. Collins had spent the entire morning walking within the view of the outbuildings that opened onto Hunsford Road in order to detect the exact moment of his arrival, and after bowing as the carriage turned into the Grove, he had rushed back to the house with the great news.
es: Their arrival was known immediately, for Collins had been strolling all morning with his eyes fixed on the pavilions at the entrance to the Hunsford road; as soon as he saw the carriage enter the estate, he made his corresponding bow, and ran home to deliver the grand news.

en: On the following morning he hastened to Rosings to pay his respects.
vi: The next morning, he rushed to Rosings to pay his respects.
tr: The next morning, he hurried to Rosings to pay his respects.
es: The next morning he flew to Rosings to pay his respects.

en: There were two nephews of Lady Catherine to require them, for mr Darcy had brought with him a Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of his uncle, Lord ——; and, to the great surprise of all the party, when mr Collins returned, the gentlemen accompanied him.
vi: He needed to greet Lady Catherine's two nephews, as Mr. Darcy had brought along a Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of his uncle. When Mr. Collins returned, the two men followed him.
tr: Lady Catherine had two nephews who commanded respect; Mr. Darcy had brought along Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of his uncle Lord --------, and as Mr. Collins returned home, the two gentlemen accompanied him, causing great astonishment to everyone.
es: But there was someone else to whom he had to present them, for there he found two of Lady Catherine's nephews. Darcy had come with Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of his uncle Lord; and to the great surprise of the whole house, when Collins returned, both gentlemen accompanied him.

en: Charlotte had seen them from her husband’s room, crossing the road, and immediately running into the other, told the girls what an honour they might expect, adding,—
vi: From her husband's room, Charlotte saw them crossing the road. She quickly ran in to inform the women and added:
tr: Charlotte had seen them from her husband's room, crossing the road; she immediately ran to the other room to tell the girls what an honor awaited them, and added–
es: Charlotte saw them from her husband's room as they crossed the path, and rushed to the other room to inform the two girls of the great honor that awaited them, and added:

en: “I may thank you, Eliza, for this piece of civility.
vi: - She thanks Eliza for this courteous action.
tr: "I owe you thanks, Eliza, for this kind gesture.
es: ––Elizabeth, it is you whom I must thank for this display of courtesy.

en: mr Darcy would never have come so soon to wait upon me.”
vi: Mr. Darcy would never have visited her so quickly.
tr: Mr. Darcy would not have come to visit me so quickly."
es: Mr. Darcy would not have come to visit me so soon.

en: Elizabeth had scarcely time to disclaim all right to the compliment before their approach was announced by the door-bell, and shortly afterwards the three gentlemen entered the room.
vi: Elizabeth had barely had time to decline the praise before the doorbell announced their arrival, and a moment later, three people entered the room.
tr: Before Elizabeth could say that she did not deserve this compliment at all, the doorbell announced their arrival, and shortly after, three gentlemen entered the room.
es: Elizabeth barely had time to deny her right to such a compliment, for immediately the bell rang announcing the arrival of the two gentlemen, who shortly after entered the room.

en: Colonel Fitzwilliam, who led the way, was about thirty, not handsome, but in person and address most truly the gentleman.
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam led the way. He was about thirty, not handsome, but his demeanor and speech indicated he was a gentleman.
tr: Leading the way, Colonel Fitzwilliam was in his thirties, unpretentious, but a true gentleman in both his actions and speech.
es: Colonel Fitzwilliam was ahead; he was about thirty years old, not handsome, but in his manner and person, he distinguished himself as a gentleman.

en: mr Darcy looked just as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, paid his compliments, with his usual reserve, to ms Collins; and whatever might be his feelings towards her friend, met her with every appearance of composure.
vi: Mr. Darcy looked the same as when he was in Hertfordshire. He greeted Mrs. Collins with his usual reserve. No matter what feelings he had for her friend, he remained composed.
tr: Mr. Darcy looked just as he had in Hertfordshire – with his usual reserved demeanor, he complimented Mrs. Collins and, regardless of what he felt towards his friend, looked at her with perfect composure.
es: Darcy was the same as in Hertfordshire; he greeted Mrs. Collins with his usual reserve, and whatever his feelings towards Elizabeth were, he greeted her with apparent impassivity.

en: Elizabeth merely courtesied to him, without saying a word.
vi: Elizabeth merely inclined her head to him, without saying a word.
tr: Elizabeth greeted with a mere bend of her knees, without uttering a single word.
es: Elizabeth merely bowed without saying a word.

en: Colonel Fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly, with the readiness and ease of a well-bred man, and talked very pleasantly; but his cousin, after having addressed a slight observation on the house and garden to ms Collins, sat for some time without speaking to anybody.
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam started the conversation directly with the fluency and ease of a well-educated person, speaking very pleasantly. But his cousin, after making a few remarks to Mrs. Collins about the house and garden, did not say another word to anyone.
tr: Colonel Fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly with the energy and ease of a well-bred man and spoke sweetly; but his cousin, after expressing a slight observation to Mrs. Collins about the house and garden, sat for a while without speaking to anyone.
es: Colonel Fitzwilliam took part in the conversation with the ease and fluency of a well-educated man, he was very pleasant; but his cousin, after making a few brief remarks to Mrs. Collins about the garden and the house, sat for a long time without speaking to anyone.

en: At length, however, his civility was so far awakened as to inquire of Elizabeth after the health of her family.
vi: However, after a while, his politeness awakened, prompting him to inquire Elizabeth about the health of her family members.
tr: Yet, in the end, his politeness prevailed, and he asked Elizabeth about her family's health.
es: Finally, however, his courtesy extended to asking Elizabeth how her family was.

en: She answered him in the usual way; and, after a moment’s pause, added,—
vi: She answered him in the usual manner, and after a moment, added:
tr: Elizabeth answered in the usual manner and, after a moment's pause, said–
es: She replied in the usual terms, and after a moment of silence, added:

en: “My eldest sister has been in town these three months.
vi: - My eldest sister has been living in the city for three months now.
tr: "My brother has been in the city for three months.
es: ––My older sister has spent these three months in London.

en: Have you never happened to see her there?”
vi: Have you met her?
tr: Haven't you ever run into him there?"
es: Haven't you seen her by any chance?

en: She was perfectly sensible that he never had: but she wished to see whether he would betray any consciousness of what had passed between the Bingleys and Jane; and she thought he looked a little confused as he answered that he had never been so fortunate as to meet Miss Bennet.
vi: She had the impression that he had indeed met her, but she wanted to see if he would reveal any knowledge about what had happened between the Bingleys and Jane. She thought he seemed a bit confused when he replied that he had not had the good fortune to meet Miss Bennet again.
tr: Elizabeth knew very well that she had not met them, but she wanted to see if she would reveal that she knew what had transpired between the Bingleys and Jane, and she thought she seemed a bit surprised while answering that she had not had the chance to see Miss Bennet.
es: He knew perfectly well that he had not seen her, but he wanted to see if any gesture would betray him and reveal that he was aware of what had happened between the Bingleys and Jane; and it seemed to him that he was a bit embarrassed when he replied that he had never had the luck to meet Miss Bennet.

en: The subject was pursued no further, and the gentlemen soon afterwards went away.
vi: No one said anything more about the matter, and shortly after, the gentlemen took their leave.
tr: The subject was not prolonged; the gentlemen left shortly after.
es: Nothing more was said about the matter, and shortly after, the gentlemen left.

en: CHAPTER XXXI.
vi: Chapter 31
tr: Chapter VIII
es: CHAPTER XXXI

en: COLONEL FITZWILLIAM’S manners were very much admired at the Parsonage, and the ladies all felt that he must add considerably to the pleasure of their engagements at Rosings.
vi: Everyone in the Parsonage admired Colonel Fitzwilliam's demeanor, and the women in particular thought he would make the gatherings at Rosings more enjoyable.
tr: Colonel Fitzwilliam's behavior was much appreciated at the parsonage; all the ladies felt that he would add pleasure to their activities at Rosings.
es: Colonel Fitzwilliam was highly praised and all the ladies considered that his presence would be an additional charm to the gatherings at Rosings.

en: It was some days, however, before they received any invitation thither, for while there were visitors in the house they could not be necessary; and it was not till Easter-day, almost a week after the gentlemen’s arrival, that they were honoured by such an attention, and then they were merely asked on leaving church to come there in the evening.
vi: However, they were only invited over for Easter because there were many other guests, and they were asked to come only in the evening after attending church services.
tr: However, it took a few days for them to receive any invitation from there – because when there were guests at the house, they were not needed; they did not receive such attention until Easter day, that is, a week after the gentlemen's arrival; even then, they were only asked to come in the evening as they were leaving the church.
es: But a few days passed without receiving any invitation, as if, having guests in the house, the Collinses were no longer needed. Until Easter day, a week after the arrival of the two gentlemen, they were not honored with such attention and even then, upon leaving the church, they were advised not to go until the very late afternoon.

en: For the last week they had seen very little of either Lady Catherine or her daughter.
vi: During this week, they rarely saw Lady Catherine or her daughter.
tr: They had seen very little of Lady Catherine or her daughter during the past week.
es: During the previous week, they saw very little of Lady Catherine and her daughter.

en: Colonel Fitzwilliam had called at the Parsonage more than once during the time, but mr Darcy they had only seen at church.
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam visited the Parsonage a couple of times, but they only saw Mr. Darcy at church.
tr: The Colonel had come to the parsonage several times during that period, but they had only seen Mr. Darcy at church.
es: Colonel Fitzwilliam visited the Collins' house more than once, but they only saw Darcy at church.

en: The invitation was accepted, of course, and at a proper hour they joined the party in Lady Catherine’s drawing-room.
vi: Mrs. Catherine received them in the living room.
tr: The invitation was, of course, accepted; at a suitable hour, they joined the group in Lady Catherine's drawing room.
es: The invitation, naturally, was accepted, and at the appropriate time, the Collinses presented themselves in Lady Catherine's drawing room.

en: Her Ladyship received them civilly, but it was plain that their company was by no means so acceptable as when she could get nobody else; and she was, in fact, almost engrossed by her nephews, speaking to them, especially to Darcy, much more than to any other person in the room.
vi: Her attitude remained polite, but it was clear that she only accepted their presence when she couldn't invite anyone else. In fact, she almost exclusively focused on her two nephews; she conversed with them, especially with Mr. Darcy, more than with anyone else.
tr: Her Ladyship received them politely, but it was clear that their presence was not as welcome as when she could find no one else; indeed, she was almost enraptured with her nephews and spoke to them, especially Darcy, more than to anyone else in the room.
es: Her Ladyship received them attentively, but it was quite clear that their company was no longer as pleasing to her as when she was alone; indeed, she was focused on her nephews and spoke with them, especially with Darcy–– much more than with any other person in the room.

en: Colonel Fitzwilliam seemed really glad to see them: anything was a welcome relief to him at Rosings; and ms Collins’s pretty friend had, moreover, caught his fancy very much.
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam seemed pleased to meet the family of his host; whatever the case, he was warmly welcomed at Rosings. The beautiful friend of Mrs. Collins particularly caught his attention.
tr: Colonel Fitzwilliam seemed genuinely pleased to see them; everything at Rosings was a pleasant diversion for him, and Mrs. Collins' beautiful friend had quite caught his interest.
es: Colonel Fitzwilliam seemed genuinely pleased to see them; in Rosings, anything seemed like a relief to him, and besides, Mrs. Collins's pretty friend had captivated him.

en: He now seated himself by her, and talked so agreeably of Kent and Hertfordshire, of travelling and staying at home, of new books and music, that Elizabeth had never been half so well entertained in that room before; and they conversed with so much spirit and flow as to draw the attention of Lady Catherine herself, as well as of mr Darcy.
vi: Now he was sitting next to her, engaging in pleasant conversation about Kent and Hertfordshire, about traveling and staying at home, about new books and music, to the extent that Elizabeth had never felt so entertained. The two of them chatted so animatedly and cheerfully together that even Lady Catherine took notice, as did Mr. Darcy.
tr: He sat next to her and spoke so sweetly about Kent and Hertfordshire, about traveling and staying at home, about new books and music, that Elizabeth had never enjoyed herself half as much in that room before; they conversed so cheerfully and fluently that they even attracted the attention of both Lady Catherine and Mr. Darcy.
es: He sat next to Elizabeth and they chatted so pleasantly about Kent and Hertfordshire, their travels and the time spent at home, new books and music, that Elizabeth had never enjoyed herself so much in that parlor; they spoke with such ease and animation that they attracted the attention of Lady Catherine and Darcy.

en: His eyes had been soon and repeatedly turned towards them with a look of curiosity; and that her Ladyship, after a while, shared the feeling, was more openly acknowledged, for she did not scruple to call out,—
vi: His eyes frequently turned towards the two with curiosity. The lady shared the same sentiment and did not hesitate to exclaim:
tr: Mr. Darcy's eyes soon and repeatedly turned to them with a curious gaze; Her Ladyship, after a while, also openly expressed her shared sentiment by calling out to them without any hesitation–
es: The latter had already looked at them several times with curiosity. Her Ladyship soon shared the same sentiment, and it was clearly seen, for she did not hesitate to ask:

en: “What is that you are saying, Fitzwilliam?
vi: - What are you talking about, Fitzwilliam?
tr: "What are you talking about, Fitzwilliam?
es: ––What are you saying, Fitzwilliam?

en: What is it you are talking of?
vi: - What are you talking about, Fitzwilliam?
tr: What are you saying like that?
es: What are you talking about?

en: What are you telling Miss Bennet?
vi: What are you telling Miss Bennet?
tr: What are you telling Miss Bennet?
es: What are you telling Miss Bennet?

en: Let me hear what it is.”
vi: Let me hear it too.
tr: Tell me, I want to listen too."
es: Let me hear it.

en: “We were talking of music, madam,” said he, when no longer able to avoid a reply.
vi: He said, when he could no longer avoid it: - We are talking about music, aunt.
tr: "We are talking about music, madam," said Fitzwilliam, when he could no longer avoid answering.
es: ––We are talking about music, madam ––declared the colonel when he saw that he couldn't avoid the response.

en: “Of music!
vi: - About music?
tr: "From music!
es: ––About music!

en: Then pray speak aloud.
vi: Then you should speak up.
tr: In that case, please speak loudly.
es: Well, do me the favor of speaking loudly.

en: It is of all subjects my delight.
vi: Among the arts, my favorite is music.
tr: It is my favorite subject.
es: Of all the topics of conversation, it is the one I enjoy the most.

en: I must have my share in the conversation, if you are speaking of music.
vi: I must join the conversation if you are talking about music.
tr: If you are talking about music, I should have my share of the conversation too.
es: I must take part in the conversation if you are talking about music.

en: There are few people in England, I suppose, who have more true enjoyment of music than myself, or a better natural taste.
vi: I don't think there are many people in England who appreciate music more than I do, or have a higher taste for it than I do.
tr: In England, there are few as keen music listeners as myself, even fewer with as natural a taste, in my opinion.
es: I believe there are few people in England more fond of music than I am or who possess better natural taste.

en: If I had ever learnt, I should have been a great proficient.
vi: If I had the opportunity to study, I could master it.
tr: If I had learned, I would have been a great artist.
es: If I had studied, I would have become a great disciple.

en: And so would Anne, if her health had allowed her to apply.
vi: And so could Ann, if her health permitted.
tr: Oh look, Anne too, if her health had allowed her to work.
es: The same would happen to Anne if her health permitted it; I am sure she would have played delightfully.

en: I am confident that she would have performed delightfully.
vi: I believe she could perform wonderfully.
tr: I'm sure she would have done extraordinarily well.
es: The same would happen to Anne if her health permitted it; I am sure she would have played delightfully.

en: How does Georgiana get on, Darcy?”
vi: What about Georgiana, Darcy?
tr: How is Georgiana doing, Darcy?"
es: How is Georgiana, Darcy?

en: mr Darcy spoke with affectionate praise of his sister’s proficiency.
vi: Mr. Darcy lovingly praised his sister's proficiency.
tr: Mr. Darcy spoke with emotional praise about his sister's talent.
es: Darcy made a cordial compliment about how advanced his sister was.

en: “I am very glad to hear such a good account of her,” said Lady Catherine; “and pray tell her from me, that she cannot expect to excel, if she does not practise a great deal.”
vi: Lady Catherine said: - Auntie is very happy to hear you talk about her, and please convey Auntie's message to her that she cannot become outstanding if she does not practice a lot.
tr: "I am very glad to hear that," said Lady Catherine; "please tell her that she will never succeed unless she practices a great deal.""
es: ––I am very glad that you give me such good news ––said Lady Catherine––, and I beg you to tell her on my behalf that if she does not practice a lot, she will not improve at all.

en: “I assure you, madam,” he replied, “that she does not need such advice.
vi: He replied: - Xin Di believes that she did not wait until she received such advice.
tr: "Rest assured, madam," replied Mr. Darcy, "he has no need of such advice.
es: ––I assure you that he doesn't need to be warned.

en: She practises very constantly.”
vi: She practiced continuously.
tr: He practices constantly."
es: He practices constantly.

en: “So much the better.
vi: - That's good. No amount of practice is ever enough.
tr: "The more, the better.
es: ––Better.

en: It cannot be done too much; and when I next write to her, I shall charge her not to neglect it on any account.
vi: When I write to her, I will insist that she must not be distracted for any reason.
tr: There is no end to it; when I write to her again, I will urge her never to neglect this matter.
es: That is never too much; and the next time I write to her, I will make sure she does not neglect it.

en: I often tell young ladies, that no excellence in music is to be acquired without constant practice.
vi: I often tell young girls that to excel in music, they must practice regularly.
tr: I often tell young ladies that perfection in music is not achieved without constant practice.
es: I often tell young ladies that in music, nothing is achieved without constant practice.

en: I have told Miss Bennet several times, that she will never play really well, unless she practises more; and though ms Collins has no instrument, she is very welcome, as I have often told her, to come to Rosings every day, and play on the pianoforte in ms Jenkinson’s room.
vi: I have often told Miss Bennet several times that she can never play well unless she practices more. Even though Mrs. Collins does not have a piano, I often tell her that we are ready to let her practice at Rosings and use the piano in Mrs. Jenkinson's room.
tr: I have also told Miss Bennet several times that she will never play really well unless she practices more; Mrs. Collins does not have a piano, but how many times have I told her that she can easily come to Rosings every day and play the piano in Mrs. Jenkinson's room.
es: I have often told Miss Bennet that she will never play truly well if she does not practice more; and although Mrs. Collins does not have a piano, Miss Bennet will be very welcome, as I have often told her, if she comes to Rosings every day to play the piano in Mrs. Jenkinson's room.

en: She would be in nobody’s way, you know, in that part of the house.”
vi: You know, in that room, she won't disturb anyone.
tr: It wouldn't interfere with anyone, after all, it's on that side of the house."
es: In that part of the house, she will not bother anyone.

en: mr Darcy looked a little ashamed of his aunt’s ill-breeding, and made no answer.
vi: Mr. Darcy seemed a bit embarrassed by his aunt's demeanor but did not reply.
tr: Mr. Darcy was a bit embarrassed by his aunt's rudeness and did not respond.
es: Darcy seemed a little embarrassed by his aunt's rudeness, and did not reply.

en: When coffee was over, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth of having promised to play to him; and she sat down directly to the instrument.
vi: When they had finished their coffee, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth of her promise to play the piano for him, and she sat down in front of the instrument.
tr: When the coffee was finished, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth of her promise to play the piano for him; Elizabeth sat down at the piano immediately.
es: When they finished their coffee, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth that she had promised to play, and the young woman immediately sat down at the piano.

en: He drew a chair near her.
vi: He pulled a chair over to sit beside her.
tr: Fitzwilliam also pulled up a chair next to her.
es: The colonel placed his chair beside her.

en: Lady Catherine listened to half a song, and then talked, as before, to her other nephew; till the latter walked away from her, and moving with his usual deliberation towards the pianoforte, stationed himself so as to command a full view of the fair performer’s countenance.
vi: Lady Catherine listened to half the piece, then resumed her conversation with Mr. Darcy as before; until he disengaged himself from her, walking with his usual leisurely gait towards the piano.
tr: Lady Catherine listened to half a song, then, as before, talked to her other nephew; until her nephew moved away from her and, with his usual determination, approached the piano and positioned himself where he could fully see the beautiful pianist's face.
es: Lady Catherine listened to half of the song and then continued talking, as before, to her other nephew, until Darcy left her and, cautiously approaching the piano, positioned himself so that he could see the face of the beautiful performer.

en: Elizabeth saw what he was doing, and at the first convenient pause turned to him with an arch smile, and said,—
vi: He positioned himself where he could observe Elizabeth's entire face. She noticed, and during the pause between two pieces, said:
tr: Elizabeth saw what he was doing and, at the first suitable pause, turned to him with a mocking smile and said–
es: Elizabeth noticed what he was doing and at the first opportune pause turned to him with a broad smile and said:

en: “You mean to frighten me, mr Darcy, by coming in all this state to hear me.
vi: - Mr. Darcy, are you trying to overwhelm me by standing here listening to me play?
tr: "Are you trying to frighten me by coming to listen to me in this state, Mr. Darcy?
es: ––Do you intend to frighten me by coming to listen to me with such seriousness?

en: But I will not be alarmed, though your sister does play so well.
vi: I will not worry about the fact that your sister indeed plays music well.
tr: But I will not be alarmed because your sister plays so well.
es: I am not scared, even though your sister plays so well.

en: There is a stubbornness about me that never can bear to be frightened at the will of others.
vi: I have a stubborn nature that never fears the will of others.
tr: I have a stubbornness that does not accept being intimidated by others.
es: There is a kind of stubbornness in me that never allows anyone to intimidate me.

en: My courage always rises with every attempt to intimidate me.”
vi: I always gain more courage with each threat.
tr: Any attempt to frighten me only increases my courage."
es: On the contrary, my courage grows when someone tries to intimidate me.

en: “I shall not say that you are mistaken,” he replied, “because you could not really believe me to entertain any design of alarming you; and I have had the pleasure of your acquaintance long enough to know, that you find great enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which, in fact, are not your own.”
vi: He replied: - I don't want to say you're mistaken, because I can't believe that I have any intention of intimidating you. I have had the pleasure of knowing you for a long time, so I understand that you occasionally find it amusing to express thoughts that are not really yours.
tr: "I will not say that you are mistaken," replied Mr. Darcy, "because you cannot really believe that I plan to frighten you; I have known you long enough to know that you take great pleasure in occasionally adopting views that are not actually your own."
es: ––I will not tell you that you are mistaken ––replied Darcy–– because you do not sincerely believe that I had any intention of alarming you; and I have had the pleasure of knowing you well enough to know that you sometimes take pleasure in holding opinions that are not actually yours.

en: Elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture of herself, and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam, “Your cousin will give you a very pretty notion of me, and teach you not to believe a word I say.
vi: Elizabeth laughed joyfully at the description of herself, and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam: - Your cousin will show you a very beautiful side of me, and teach you clearly not to believe my words.
tr: Elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam, "Your cousin will give you a very pleasant idea of me and will advise you not to believe a single word I say.
es: Elizabeth laughed openly at that description of herself, and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam: ––Your cousin aims to give you a poor impression of me by teaching you not to believe a word I say.

en: I am particularly unlucky in meeting with a person so well able to expose my real character, in a part of the world where I had hoped to pass myself off with some degree of credit.
vi: I am unfortunate to encounter someone who can clearly reveal my true self, in a part of the world where I hoped to be judged favorably.
tr: It is truly unfortunate that in a place where I hoped to make myself a little liked, I have encountered someone who reveals my true character so well.
es: It dismays me to encounter someone so eager to uncover my true nature in a place where I had hoped to pass for better than I am.

en: Indeed, mr Darcy, it is very ungenerous in you to mention all that you knew to my disadvantage in Hertfordshire—and, give me leave to say, very impolitic too—for it is provoking me to retaliate, and such things may come out as will shock your relations to hear.”
vi: Mr. Darcy, you lack generosity when you say you know all about me in Hertfordshire, allow me to say, you were also too rude, for you provoked me to retaliate, and if this happens, your relatives will be shocked to hear what I say.
tr: Indeed, Mr. Darcy, it is very cruel of you to speak of everything you learned against me in Hertfordshire – and allow me to say, very imprudent – because it provokes me to take revenge; things that could shock your relatives might come to light."
es: Really, Mr. Darcy, it is very ungenerous of you to reveal the bad things you learned about me in Hertfordshire, and allow me to say that it is also very indiscreet, for this might lead me to retaliate and bring to light things that would scandalize your relatives.

en: “I am not afraid of you,” said he, smilingly.
vi: He smiled: - I'm not afraid of you.
tr: "I am not afraid of you," said Mr. Darcy, smiling.
es: ––I'm not––afraid ––he said, smiling.

en: “Pray let me hear what you have to accuse him of,” cried Colonel Fitzwilliam.
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam exclaimed: - Please let me hear what you accuse him of.
tr: "Please tell me what you are accusing him of," cried Colonel Fitzwilliam.
es: ––Tell me, please, what you accuse him of ––exclaimed Colonel Fitzwilliam––.

en: “I should like to know how he behaves among strangers.”
vi: I need to know how he treats others.
tr: "I want to know how he behaves among strangers."
es: I would like to know how he behaves among strangers.

en: “You shall hear, then—but prepare for something very dreadful.
vi: - Then you will listen, but be prepared to hear something dreadful.
tr: "Listen then –but prepare yourself for something very dreadful.
es: ––I will tell you, but prepare yourself to hear something very dreadful.

en: The first time of my ever seeing him in Hertfordshire, you must know, was at a ball—and at this ball, what do you think he did?
vi: The first time I met him was in Hertfordshire, you know, at a ball, and at this ball, do you know what he did?
tr: When I first saw him in Hertfordshire, we were at a ball –and guess what he did at this ball?
es: You must know that the first time I saw him was at a ball, and at that ball, what do you think he did?

en: He danced only four dances!
vi: He only danced four dances!
tr: He danced only four times!
es: Well, he only danced four pieces, despite the scarcity of gentlemen, and more than one lady was left sitting for lack of a partner.

en: I am sorry to pain you, but so it was.
vi: Sorry to break your heart, but that's the truth.
tr: I apologize for upsetting you –but that's how it was.
es: Well, he only danced four pieces, despite the scarcity of gentlemen, and more than one lady was left sitting for lack of a partner.

en: He danced only four dances, though gentlemen were scarce; and, to my certain knowledge, more than one young lady was sitting down in want of a partner.
vi: He only danced four dances, even though young men were scarce, and I know for a fact that there was a young girl who had to sit out because there were not enough dance partners.
tr: Only four dances, despite the lack of men; and I know very well that many ladies were left sitting due to the absence of partners.
es: Well, he only danced four pieces, despite the scarcity of gentlemen, and more than one lady was left sitting for lack of a partner.

en: mr Darcy, you cannot deny the fact.”
vi: Mr. Darcy, you cannot deny the fact.
tr: Mr. Darcy, you cannot deny what you did."
es: Mr. Darcy, you cannot deny it.

en: “I had not at that time the honour of knowing any lady in the assembly beyond my own party.”
vi: - At that time, I did not have the honor of knowing any lady outside of my group.
tr: "At that time, I had not had the honor of meeting any lady outside of my own group."
es: ––I did not have the honor of knowing any of the ladies at the gathering, except for those who accompanied me.

en: “True; and nobody can ever be introduced in a ball-room.
vi: - That's right, and no one has ever been introduced at a ball.
tr: "That's right; no one can meet anyone at the ball anyway.
es: ––True, and at a ball there is never a chance to be introduced...

en: Well, Colonel Fitzwilliam, what do I play next?
vi: So, Colonel Fitzwilliam, what should I play next?
tr: So, Colonel Fitzwilliam, what shall I play now?
es: Well, Colonel Fitzwilliam, what shall I play now?

en: My fingers wait your orders.”
vi: My fingers are awaiting your command.
tr: My fingers are awaiting your orders."
es: My fingers are awaiting your orders.

en: “Perhaps,” said Darcy, “I should have judged better had I sought an introduction, but I am ill-qualified to recommend myself to strangers.”
vi: Darcy said: - Perhaps I should consider more carefully if I seek an introduction, but I am not qualified to introduce myself to strangers.
tr: "Perhaps," said Darcy, "I would behave differently if I sought the opportunity to meet; but I am inept at introducing myself to strangers."
es: ––Perhaps you would have judged me better ––added Darcy–– if I had requested an introduction. But I am not good at making myself known to strangers.

en: “Shall we ask your cousin the reason of this?” said Elizabeth, still addressing Colonel Fitzwilliam.
vi: Elizabeth still spoke directly to Colonel Fitzwilliam: - Should we ask your cousin about the reason for this?
tr: "Shall we ask your cousin the reason for this?" said Elizabeth, still addressing Colonel Fitzwilliam.
es: ––Let's ask his cousin why he is like that ––said Elizabeth, addressing no one but Colonel Fitzwilliam––.

en: “Shall we ask him why a man of sense and education, and who has lived in the world, is ill-qualified to recommend himself to strangers?”
vi: Should we ask how a conscious and educated person, who has lived in this social class, could be unfit to introduce to strangers?
tr: "Why would an intelligent, educated man, someone who has seen the world, be inept at introducing himself to strangers, shall we ask?"
es: Shall we ask him how it is possible that a talented and well-educated man, who has lived in high society, is not capable of attending to strangers?

en: “I can answer your question,” said Fitzwilliam, “without applying to him.
vi: Fitzwilliam said: - I can answer your question without needing him.
tr: "I can answer your question," said Fitzwilliam, "there is no need for you to consult him.
es: ––I can answer this question myself ––replied Fitzwilliam–– without asking Darcy.

en: It is because he will not give himself the trouble.”
vi: It's just because he isn't diligent.
tr: Because it won't cause any trouble."
es: That's because he doesn't want to bother.

en: “I certainly have not the talent which some people possess,” said Darcy, “of conversing easily with those I have never seen before.
vi: Darcy said: - I certainly don't have the talent that some people possess, to easily converse with someone they've never met before.
tr: "I don't have the talent that some people possess," said Darcy, "the ability to comfortably talk to people I haven't met before.
es: ––I acknowledge ––said Darcy–– that I do not have the ability that others possess to converse easily with people I have never seen.

en: I cannot catch their tone of conversation, or appear interested in their concerns, as I often see done.”
vi: I can't join in their conversations or show interest in their issues, as I often see them do.
tr: I can't catch the tone of their conversations like others do, I can't seem to show interest in the things they talk about."
es: I cannot engage in those conversations and pretend to be interested in their affairs as is customary.

en: “My fingers,” said Elizabeth, “do not move over this instrument in the masterly manner which I see so many women’s do.
vi: Elizabeth said:
tr: "My fingers," said Elizabeth, "do not skillfully glide over this instrument like the fingers of many women.
es: ––My fingers ––replied Elizabeth–– do not move over this instrument in the masterful way I have seen other women's fingers move; they do not have the same strength or agility, and they cannot produce the same impression.

en: They have not the same force or rapidity, and do not produce the same expression.
vi: - My fingers are not as skillful on this instrument as many other girls', because they lack the same strength or dexterity, and do not express the same emotions.
tr: They do not have the same strength, the same speed, nor do they create the same expression.
es: ––My fingers ––replied Elizabeth–– do not move over this instrument in the masterful way I have seen other women's fingers move; they do not have the same strength or agility, and they cannot produce the same impression.

en: But then I have always supposed it to be my own fault—because I would not take the trouble of practising.
vi: But then I always considered it my fault – because I did not practice diligently.
tr: But I always thought that this was my own fault – because I did not endure the trouble of practicing.
es: But I have always believed it was my fault, for not wanting to take the trouble to do exercises.

en: It is not that I do not believe my fingers as capable as any other woman’s of superior execution.”
vi: It's not that I don't believe my fingers have the same potential as any woman who plays better than me.
tr: Not because I believed that my fingers could not possess the superior skill like another woman's fingers."
es: Not because my fingers are not capable, like those of any other woman, of playing perfectly.

en: Darcy smiled and said, “You are perfectly right.
vi: Darcy smiled: - You are absolutely right.
tr: Darcy smiled and said, "You are very right.
es: Darcy smiled and said to her: ––You are absolutely right.

en: You have employed your time much better.
vi: You have used your time much more beneficially.
tr: You have used your time much better.
es: You have used your time much better.

en: No one admitted to the privilege of hearing you can think anything wanting.
vi: No one who has the privilege of hearing you play can think there is any weakness.
tr: No one who has had the privilege of listening to you can find any fault.
es: No one who has the privilege of listening to you will be able to find fault.

en: We neither of us perform to strangers.”
vi: Neither of us performs for strangers.
tr: We both do not play for strangers."
es: None of us perform in front of strangers.

en: Here they were interrupted by Lady Catherine, who called out to know what they were talking of.
vi: They were interrupted by Lady Catherine, who called out to ask what they were talking about.
tr: Lady Catherine interrupted here: she called out and asked what they were talking about.
es: Lady Catherine interrupted them by asking what they were talking about.

en: Elizabeth immediately began playing again.
vi: Elizabeth immediately began to play music.
tr: Elizabeth immediately started to play.
es: Elizabeth began to play again.

en: Lady Catherine approached, and, after listening for a few minutes, said to Darcy,—
vi: Lady Catherine approached, and after listening for a while, said to Mr. Darcy:
tr: Lady Catherine approached, and after listening for a few minutes, she said to Darcy–
es: Lady Catherine approached and after listening to her for a few minutes, said to Darcy:

en: “Miss Bennet would not play at all amiss if she practised more, and could have the advantage of a London master.
vi: - Miss Bennet's performance was flawless, if she practices more and gets a teacher in London.
tr: "If Miss practiced more and could benefit from a teacher from London, she would never play incorrectly.
es: ––Miss Bennet would not play badly if she practiced more and had enjoyed the advantages of a good teacher from London.

en: She has a very good notion of fingering, though her taste is not equal to Anne’s.
vi: Her playing is quite skillful, although her taste is not as refined as Ann's.
tr: Her finger technique is very good, but of course, her taste is not as refined as Anne's.
es: She knows what it is to play the keys, although her taste is not like Anne's.

en: Anne would have been a delightful performer, had her health allowed her to learn.”
vi: Ann could perform wonderfully if her health allowed her to practice.
tr: Anne would have been an extraordinary pianist if her health had allowed her to learn."
es: Anne would have been a wonderful pianist if her health had allowed her to learn.

en: Elizabeth looked at Darcy, to see how cordially he assented to his cousin’s praise: but neither at that moment nor at any other could she discern any symptom of love; and from the whole of his behaviour to Miss De Bourgh she derived this comfort for Miss Bingley, that he might have been just as likely to marry her, had she been his relation.
vi: Elizabeth looked at Darcy to see how he would respond to his aunt's praise of his cousin, but at that moment and at any other time, she did not detect any sign of affection. From the way he treated Miss De Bourgh, she felt reassured about her sister that Mr. Bingley could have married her if she had been related to him.
tr: Elizabeth looked at Darcy to see how he would react to the praise about his cousin; but neither at that moment nor at any other time did she see any sign of affection; from his overall behavior towards Miss de Bourgh, Elizabeth drew this consolation on behalf of Miss Bingley: he could have married her too, if she had been his relative.
es: Elizabeth looked at Darcy to observe his cordial assent to the praise given to his cousin, but neither then nor at any other time did she discover any sign of love; and from his attitude towards Miss de Bourgh, Elizabeth deduced something consoling in favor of Miss Bingley: that Darcy would have married her if she had belonged to his family.

en: Lady Catherine continued her remarks on Elizabeth’s performance, mixing with them many instructions on execution and taste.
vi: Lady Catherine continued to comment on Elizabeth's level of performance, mixing in advice on how to perform and appreciate music.
tr: Lady Catherine continued to express her opinions about Elizabeth's performance, adding lessons of practice and taste to her remarks.
es: Lady Catherine continued making observations about Elizabeth's manner of playing, mixed with numerous instructions on execution and taste.

en: Elizabeth received them with all the forbearance of civility; and at the request of the gentlemen remained at the instrument till her Ladyship’s carriage was ready to take them all home.
vi: Elizabeth accepted it with all the patience that politeness demanded, and at the request of the gentlemen, she remained at the piano until the carriage was ready to take them home.
tr: Elizabeth received these words with all the fortitude of politeness and continued to play the piano at the gentlemen's request until her ladyship's carriage was ready to take them home.
es: Elizabeth endured them with all the patience that courtesy demands, and at the gentlemen's request, she continued playing until Her Ladyship's carriage was ready and took everyone home.

en: CHAPTER XXXII.
vi: Chapter 32
tr: Chapter IX
es: CHAPTER XXXII

en: ELIZABETH was sitting by herself the next morning, and writing to Jane, while ms Collins and Maria were gone on business into the village, when she was startled by a ring at the door, the certain signal of a visitor.
vi: The next morning, while sitting alone writing a letter to Jane as Mrs. Collins and Maria had business in the village, Elizabeth was surprised to hear the doorbell signaling a visitor.
tr: Elizabeth was sitting alone the next morning, writing a letter to Jane; Mrs. Collins and Maria had gone to the village on an errand; at one point, Elizabeth was startled by the ringing of the doorbell, clearly indicating a visitor.
es: The next morning, Elizabeth was alone writing to Jane, while Mrs. Collins and Maria had gone shopping in town, when she was startled by the ringing of the doorbell, an unmistakable sign of a visitor.

en: As she had heard no carriage, she thought it not unlikely to be Lady Catherine; and under that apprehension was putting away her half-finished letter, that she might escape all impertinent questions, when the door opened, and to her very great surprise mr Darcy, and mr Darcy only, entered the room.
vi: Since she did not hear a carriage, she thought it could not be Lady Catherine. She set the unfinished letter aside. When the door opened, she was surprised to see Mr. Darcy, and only Mr. Darcy, walk in.
tr: Since she did not hear the sound of a carriage, she thought it might be Lady Catherine and, with that thought, she was putting away her half-finished letter to avoid being subjected to impertinent questions when the door opened and, leaving Elizabeth in great astonishment, Mr. Darcy entered, and it was only Mr. Darcy.
es: Although she had not heard any carriage, she thought it might be Lady Catherine, and hurried to hide the half-written letter to avoid impertinent questions. But to her great surprise, the door opened, and Mr. Darcy entered the room. Darcy alone.

en: He seemed astonished too on finding her alone, and apologized for his intrusion, by letting her know that he had understood all the ladies to be within.
vi: He also showed surprise to see her alone, and apologized for being abrupt, saying he had assumed all women would be at home.
tr: He also seemed surprised to find Elizabeth alone and apologized for his unannounced visit, saying that he thought all the ladies were at home.
es: He seemed surprised to find her alone and apologized for his intrusion, saying that he believed all the ladies were in the house.

en: They then sat down, and when her inquiries after Rosings were made, seemed in danger of sinking into total silence.
vi: Then the two sat down, and when she asked him about Rosings, it seemed there was a risk they would lapse into silence.
tr: Then they sat down; after Elizabeth's questions about Rosings were asked, the danger of falling into silence arose.
es: They both sat down and, after the obligatory questions about Rosings, it seemed they were going to remain silent.

en: It was absolutely necessary, therefore, to think of something; and in this emergency recollecting when she had seen him last in Hertfordshire, and feeling curious to know what he would say on the subject of their hasty departure, she observed,—
vi: Therefore, needing to think of something else, in this urgent moment she recalled the last time she met him in Hertfordshire, and wondered what he thought about their hasty departure. She remarked:
tr: So it was necessary to think of something, and in this urgent situation, she began to speak, recalling the last time she saw him in Hertfordshire and wondering what he would say about their hasty departure–
es: Therefore, it was absolutely necessary to think of something, and Elizabeth, faced with this necessity, recalled the last time they had seen each other in Hertfordshire and felt curious to see what he would say about his hasty departure.

en: “How very suddenly you all quitted Netherfield last November, mr Darcy!
vi: - All of you left Netherfield quite suddenly, Mr. Darcy!
tr: "How suddenly you left Netherfield last November, Mr. Darcy!
es: ––How suddenly you left Netherfield last November, Mr. Darcy!

en: It must have been a most agreeable surprise to mr Bingley to see you all after him so soon; for, if I recollect right, he went but the day before.
vi: Mr. Bingley must have been pleasantly surprised to see you again so soon, because if I am not mistaken, he only left the day before.
tr: Mr. Bingley must have been very surprised and pleased to see you all come right after him; if I remember correctly, he had left the day before.
es: ––she said––. It must have been a very pleasant surprise for Mr. Bingley to see you so soon by his side, because, if I remember correctly, he had left a day earlier.

en: He and his sisters were well, I hope, when you left London?”
vi: I hope he and his sisters were well when you left London.
tr: I hope both he and his sisters were in good health when you left London."
es: I suppose both he and his sisters were well when you left London.

en: “Perfectly so, I thank you.”
vi: - Everything is normal, thank you.
tr: "They were very good, thank you."
es: ––Perfectly. Thank you.

en: She found that she was to receive no other answer; and, after a short pause, added,—
vi: She saw that she would not have any other answer, so after a moment, she continued:
tr: Elizabeth realized she could not get another answer, and after a short silence, she continued–
es: Elizabeth warned that she was not going to answer him anymore and, after a brief silence, added:

en: “I think I have understood that mr Bingley has not much idea of ever returning to Netherfield again?”
vi: - I have been informed that Mr. Bingley has no intention of returning to Netherfield, is that correct?
tr: "I think they said Mr. Bingley would not return to Netherfield again."
es: ––I understand that Mr. Bingley does not intend to return to Netherfield.

en: “I have never heard him say so; but it is probable that he may spend very little of his time there in future.
vi: - I have never heard him say that, but maybe in the future, he will live less in that place.
tr: "I didn't hear him say such a thing; but it is likely that he won't stay there for long in the future.
es: ––I have never heard him say such a thing; but it is likely that he will not spend much time there in the future.

en: He has many friends, and he is at a time of life when friends and engagements are continually increasing.”
vi: He has many friends, he is in a phase where friends and gatherings are continuously increasing.
tr: He has many friends, and he is at an age where both his friendships and relationships are constantly increasing."
es: He has many friends and is at a stage in life where friends and commitments continuously increase.

en: “If he means to be but little at Netherfield, it would be better for the neighbourhood that he should give up the place entirely, for then we might possibly get a settled family there.
vi: - If he intends to rarely stay at Netherfield, it might be better for the neighbors if he returns the house entirely, because then we could have a family permanently settled there.
tr: "If he does not intend to stay long at Netherfield, it would be better for the neighborhood if he left it altogether, because then a family could settle there.
es: ––If you intend to stay for a short time at Netherfield, it would be better for the neighborhood if you left it completely, and thus possibly another family could settle there.

en: But, perhaps, mr Bingley did not take the house so much for the convenience of the neighbourhood as for his own, and we must expect him to keep or quit it on the same principle.”
vi: But perhaps Mr. Bingley uses the house not for the convenience of the neighbors but for his own convenience, and we think he will keep or return the house based on that same principle.
tr: But perhaps Mr. Bingley has rented the house not for the benefit of the neighborhood, but for himself; and he will probably keep it or leave it for the same reason."
es: But perhaps Mr. Bingley has taken the house not so much for the convenience of the neighborhood as for his own, and it is to be hoped that he will keep it or leave it based on that same principle.

en: “I should not be surprised,” said Darcy, “if he were to give it up as soon as any eligible purchase offers.”
vi: - I wouldn't be surprised if he returns as soon as someone comes to rent.
tr: "If he leaves as soon as a place to buy comes up," said Darcy, "I wouldn't be surprised."
es: ––It wouldn't surprise me ––added Darcy–– if he got rid of it as soon as he was offered an acceptable purchase.

en: Elizabeth made no answer.
vi: Elizabeth did not answer.
tr: Elizabeth did not respond.
es: Elizabeth did not answer.

en: She was afraid of talking longer of his friend; and, having nothing else to say, was now determined to leave the trouble of finding a subject to him.
vi: She did not want to talk much about his friend. Since there was nothing else to discuss, she decided to let him choose the topic.
tr: She was afraid to talk more about her friend; since she had nothing else to say, she decided to leave the trouble of finding a new topic to him.
es: She feared speaking too much about her friend, and since she had nothing else to say, she decided to let Darcy find another topic of conversation. He understood it and said immediately:

en: He took the hint and soon began with, “This seems a very comfortable house.
vi: I understand the idea, starting: - This house seems very comfortable.
tr: Darcy received the signal and soon began to speak, "This place looks like a very comfortable home.
es: ––This house seems very comfortable.

en: Lady Catherine, I believe, did a great deal to it when mr Collins first came to Hunsford.”
vi: I think Lady Catherine had contributed a lot here before Mr. Collins first came to Huntsford.
tr: When Mr. Collins first came to Hunsford, I believe Lady Catherine did a lot here."
es: I believe Lady Catherine improved it a lot when Mr. Collins first came to Hunsford.

en: “I believe she did—and I am sure she could not have bestowed her kindness on a more grateful object.”
vi: - I think that's right, I believe you cannot bestow a favor in a more precious way.
tr: "He must have done it – he couldn't have shown his kindness better for someone who knows how to thank better.""
es: ––It seems so, and I am sure that he could not have given a better proof of his kindness.

en: “mr Collins appears very fortunate in his choice of a wife.”
vi: - Mr. Collins seems to be fortunate in choosing his wife.
tr: "Mr. Collins seems very fortunate in his choice of wife.""
es: ––Mr. Collins seems to have been very fortunate in the choice of his wife.

en: “Yes, indeed; his friends may well rejoice in his having met with one of the very few sensible women who would have accepted him, or have made him happy if they had.
vi: - Yes, that's right. His relatives will be very happy to see him meet one of the rare women who is very knowledgeable and accepts him, or brings him happiness once they accept him.
tr: "Indeed it is so; her friends may rejoice that she has met one of the rare, sensible women who can accept her, even make her happy.
es: ––That's right. His friends can rejoice that he found one of the few intelligent women who would have accepted him or who would have made him happy after accepting him.

en: My friend has an excellent understanding—though I am not certain that I consider her marrying mr Collins as the wisest thing she ever did.
vi: My friend has an excellent understanding – although I am not sure she made the wisest decision in agreeing to marry Mr. Collins.
tr: My friend has a flawless intellect –though I am not sure marrying Mr. Collins was the wisest thing she has ever done.
es: My friend is very sensible, although her marriage to Collins seems to me the least sensible of her actions.

en: She seems perfectly happy, however; and, in a prudential light, it is certainly a very good match for her.”
vi: However, she seems completely happy, and from a cautious perspective, she has a very suitable marriage.
tr: Nevertheless, she seems quite happy; and from a common-sense perspective, he is a rather suitable match for her."
es: However, she seems completely happy: from a prudent point of view, this was a good match for her.

en: “It must be very agreeable to her to be settled within so easy a distance of her own family and friends.”
vi: - It's quite a relief that she has stabilized her life within a very convenient distance from her family and friends.
tr: "He liked settling in a place so close to his family and friends."
es: ––It must be very pleasant for Mrs. Collins to live so close to her family and friends.

en: “An easy distance do you call it?
vi: - Do you think this is a very convenient distance?
tr: "Are you saying it's close to here?"
es: ––Do you call that a short distance?

en: It is nearly fifty miles.”
vi: It's nearly fifty miles.
tr: "It's almost fifty miles.""
es: It's about fifty miles.

en: “And what is fifty miles of good road?
vi: - And what if the fifty miles are good roads?
tr: "Once the road is good, what is fifty miles?
es: ––And what are fifty miles of good road?

en: Little more than half a day’s journey.
vi: It would only take a little more than half a day.
tr: A little more than half a day's journey, that's all.
es: Just over half a day's journey.

en: Yes, I call it a very easy distance.”
vi: Yes, I think this is a very convenient distance.
tr: Yes, I think it's very close."
es: Yes, I call that a short distance.

en: “I should never have considered the distance as one of the advantages of the match,” cried Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - I have never considered distance to be an advantage in marriage.
tr: "I wouldn't really consider proximity as one of the advantages of marriage," exclaimed Elizabeth.
es: ––I would never have considered that distance was one of the advantages of the match, exclaimed Elizabeth, and it would never have occurred to me that Mrs. Collins lived close to her family.

en: “I should never have said ms Collins was settled near her family.”
vi: I have never said that Mrs. Collins has settled near her family.
tr: "I wouldn't say Mrs. Collins settled close to her family."
es: ––I would never have considered that distance was one of the advantages of the match, exclaimed Elizabeth, and it would never have occurred to me that Mrs. Collins lived close to her family.

en: “It is a proof of your own attachment to Hertfordshire.
vi: - This is evidence of your attachment to Herfordshire.
tr: "This is proof of your attachment to Hertfordshire.
es: ––That shows the attachment you have to Hertfordshire.

en: Anything beyond the very neighbourhood of Longbourn, I suppose, would appear far.”
vi: I suppose any place outside of Longbourn seems distant.
tr: Everywhere else seems evidently distant to you except the vicinity of Longbourn."
es: Everything beyond Longbourn must already seem far away to you.

en: As he spoke there was a sort of smile, which Elizabeth fancied she understood; he must be supposing her to be thinking of Jane and Netherfield, and she blushed as she answered,—
vi: When he spoke, it seemed he smiled slightly, and Elizabeth thought she understood his implication. He must have guessed she was thinking about Jane and Netherfield, and her face flushed as she replied:
tr: While Darcy was speaking, there was a kind of smile on his face, and Elizabeth thought she understood it; she must have assumed he was thinking of Netherfield with Jane; her face turned red as she replied–
es: While speaking, he smiled in a way that Elizabeth thought she could interpret: Darcy must have assumed she was thinking about Jane and Netherfield; and she replied somewhat blushing:

en: “I do not mean to say that a woman may not be settled too near her family.
vi: - I do not mean to say that a woman should not settle too close to her family.
tr: "I do not mean to say that a woman may not settle too near her family.
es: ––I don't mean to say that a woman cannot live far from her family.

en: The far and the near must be relative, and depend on many varying circumstances.
vi: Far or near is only relative, depending on various circumstances.
tr: Distance and nearness are relative; they depend on many varying circumstances.
es: Far and near are relative things and depend on very different circumstances.

en: Where there is fortune to make the expense of travelling unimportant, distance becomes no evil.
vi: When conditions make travel costs not an issue, distance means nothing.
tr: When there is fortune to make the expenses of traveling unimportant, distance becomes no evil.
es: If one has the fortune not to worry about travel expenses, the distance is the least of it.

en: But that is not the case here.
vi: But that is not the case here.
tr: But that is not the case here.
es: But this is not the case.

en: mr and ms Collins have a comfortable income, but not such a one as will allow of frequent journeys—and I am persuaded my friend would not call herself near her family under less than half the present distance.”
vi: Mr. and Mrs. Collins have a comfortable income, but still not enough to travel frequently – and I believe my friend would not consider herself close to her family even if the distance were halved.
tr: Mr. and Mrs. Collins have a comfortable income, but not enough to allow for frequent journeys – I think my friend would not consider herself near her family unless she lived at half that distance."
es: The Collinses do not live in straitened circumstances, but they are not so wealthy as to afford frequent travel; I am sure my friend would not say she lives close to her family unless she were at half this distance.

en: mr Darcy drew his chair a little towards her, and said, “You cannot have a right to such very strong local attachment.
vi: Mr. Darcy pulled the chair he was sitting on a little closer to her and said: - You cannot be so attached to your place like that.
tr: Mr. Darcy pulled his chair a little towards her and said, "You do not have the right to such strong attachment to your country."
es: Darcy moved his seat a little closer to Elizabeth's and said: ––You have no right to be so attached to your residence.

en: You cannot have been always at Longbourn.”
vi: You cannot live with Longbourn forever.
tr: "You cannot always live in Longbourn.""
es: You will not always be in Longbourn.

en: Elizabeth looked surprised.
vi: Elizabeth was surprised.
tr: Elizabeth seemed surprised.
es: Elizabeth seemed to be surprised, and the gentleman thought he should change the conversation.

en: The gentleman experienced some change of feeling; he drew back his chair, took a newspaper from the table, and, glancing over it, said, in a colder voice,—
vi: The young man felt some change in his feelings. He pulled the chair back, picked up a newspaper from the table, and glanced through it, speaking in a cold voice:
tr: Mr. Darcy changed his mind; he pulled back his chair, took the newspaper from the table, and, looking over the top of the newspaper, said in a cold voice–
es: He put his chair back where it was, took a newspaper from the table, and glancing over it, asked coldly:

en: “Are you pleased with Kent?”
vi: - Do you like Kent?
tr: "Did you like the city?"
es: ––Do you like Kent?

en: A short dialogue on the subject of the country ensued, on either side calm and concise—and soon put an end to by the entrance of Charlotte and her sister, just returned from their walk.
vi: A short conversation followed on the topic of the countryside, with each side calm and proper, until Charlotte and her sister walked in after a stroll.
tr: A brief discussion about the region followed, with both sides being calm and measured – it was soon interrupted by the entrance of Charlotte and her sister returning from their walk.
es: This was followed by a short dialogue on the subject of the countryside, concise and moderate on both sides, which soon ended, as Charlotte and her sister entered, having just returned from their walk.

en: The tête-à-tête surprised them.
vi: They were surprised to see the two facing each other.
tr: They were surprised to see the two of them alone.
es: The tête-à-tête left them stunned.

en: mr Darcy related the mistake which had occasioned his intruding on Miss Bennet, and, after sitting a few minutes longer, without saying much to anybody, went away.
vi: Mr. Darcy recounted how he had been mistaken and abrupt with Miss Bennet, and after sitting for a few more minutes without much conversation with anyone, he took his leave.
tr: Mr. Darcy explained to Miss Bennet the mistake that caused him to be an uninvited guest, and after sitting for a few more minutes without saying much to anyone, he left.
