es: Darcy explained the misunderstanding that had led to his visit to the house; he remained seated for a few more minutes, not talking much to anyone, and then left.

en: “Accompanied by their aunt”
vi: Mr. Darcy recounted how he had been mistaken and abrupt with Miss Bennet, and after sitting for a few more minutes without much conversation with anyone, he took his leave.
tr: Mr. Darcy explained to Miss Bennet the mistake that caused him to be an uninvited guest, and after sitting for a few more minutes without saying much to anyone, he left.
es: ––What does this mean?

en: “What can be the meaning of this?” said Charlotte, as soon as he was gone.
vi: Charlotte said right after he walked away: - What does that mean?
tr: "What could this mean?" said Charlotte, as soon as she left.
es: ––asked Charlotte as soon as he left––.

en: “My dear Eliza, he must be in love with you, or he would never have called on us in this familiar way.”
vi: Dear Eliza, he has fallen in love with you; otherwise, he would never visit you so intimately like this!
tr: "My dear Eliza, he must be in love with you, otherwise he would never come to us so unceremoniously."
es: Dear Elizabeth, he must be in love with you, for otherwise, he would never have come to see us with such familiarity.

en: But when Elizabeth told of his silence, it did not seem very likely, even to Charlotte’s wishes, to be the case; and, after various conjectures, they could at last only suppose his visit to proceed from the difficulty of finding anything to do, which was the more probable from the time of year.
vi: But when Elizabeth spoke of his silence, everyone felt it didn't seem to be the case, even Charlotte had a wish. After speculating on everything, they finally thought he visited just because he had nothing else to do, and that might be true for this time of year.
tr: When Elizabeth mentioned Miss Darcy's silence, it became clear, despite Charlotte's wishes, that the situation was not quite as she had hoped; after various speculations, they finally assumed that her visit stemmed from the difficulty of finding something to do, which was very possible for that time of year.
es: But when Elizabeth recounted how quiet he had been, it didn't seem very likely, despite Charlotte's good wishes; and after several conjectures, they limited themselves to supposing that his visit had been due to the difficulty of finding something to do, which was very natural at that time of year.

en: All field sports were over.
vi: All outdoor sports had ended.
tr: All outdoor sports had ended.
es: All the sports had ended.

en: Within doors there was Lady Catherine, books, and a billiard table, but gentlemen cannot be always within doors; and in the nearness of the Parsonage, or the pleasantness of the walk to it, or of the people who lived in it, the two cousins found a temptation from this period of walking thither almost every day.
vi: Inside was Lady Catherine, books, billiards table, but the young men couldn't be confined within four walls forever. Next door was the Parsonage, either the pleasure of walking there or because of the people living there, the two cousins found pleasure in walking there almost every day.
tr: Inside, there were only Lady Catherine, books, and a billiard table, but men cannot stay indoors all the time; soon, the parsonage, or the walk there, or the pleasantness of the people there, enticed the two cousins to walk there almost every day thereafter.
es: At Lady Catherine's house, there were books and a billiard table, but the gentlemen were frustrated by always being cooped up indoors, and whether it was because the Collins' residence was so close, or because the walk was pleasant, or because of the people who lived there, the two cousins felt tempted to visit them every day.

en: They called at various times of the morning, sometimes separately, sometimes together, and now and then accompanied by their aunt.
vi: The two came at different morning hours, sometimes separately, sometimes together, occasionally with their aunt.
tr: In the mornings, at different times, sometimes separately, sometimes together, they visited, and sometimes their aunt accompanied them.
es: They would show up at different times in the morning, sometimes separately and other times together, and occasionally accompanied by their aunt.

en: It was plain to them all that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he had pleasure in their society, a persuasion which of course recommended him still more; and Elizabeth was reminded by her own satisfaction in being with him, as well as by his evident admiration, of her former favourite, George Wickham; and though, in comparing them, she saw there was less captivating softness in Colonel Fitzwilliam’s manners, she believed he might have the best informed mind.
vi: Everyone clearly saw that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he enjoyed their company; this thought made them like him even more. Elizabeth felt comfortable near him as well as seeing him like her, seeing him like Mr. George Wickham whom she once admired; and though in comparing the two, she found Colonel Fitzwilliam's gentle manners less captivating, she believed he might have higher knowledge.
tr: Everyone understood that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he enjoyed their conversation, which made them like him even more; Elizabeth, thinking about the pleasure she took in his company, especially the admiration he showed her, was reminded of her former favorite, George Wickham; comparing the two, she found that Colonel Fitzwilliam's manners had less of a heart-winning softness, but she decided he was better educated.
es: It was evident that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he felt comfortable with them, which naturally made him even more pleasant. The pleasure Elizabeth derived from his company and Fitzwilliam's evident admiration for her made her remember her first favorite, George Wickham. Comparing them, Elizabeth found that the Colonel's manners were less attractive and sweet than Wickham's, but Fitzwilliam seemed to her to be a more cultured man.

en: But why mr Darcy came so often to the Parsonage it was more difficult to understand.
vi: But why Mr. Darcy often went to the Parsonage was more difficult to understand.
tr: It was hard to understand why Mr. Darcy came to the lodge so often.
es: But understanding why Darcy came to the house so often was more difficult.

en: It could not be for society, as he frequently sat there ten minutes together without opening his lips; and when he did speak, it seemed the effect of necessity rather than of choice—a sacrifice to propriety, not a pleasure to himself.
vi: It was not due to a fondness for socializing, as he would often sit for a full ten minutes without saying a word, and when he did speak, it seemed more out of necessity than spontaneity – a sacrifice to propriety rather than personal inclination.
tr: It couldn't be for friendship, because he would come, sit for ten minutes, and leave without opening his mouth; and when he did speak, it seemed out of necessity rather than desire – not for pleasure, but to avoid rudeness.
es: It couldn't be to seek company, as he would sit for ten minutes without opening his mouth, and when he spoke, it seemed more out of obligation than pleasure, as if it were a sacrifice rather than a delight.

en: He seldom appeared really animated.
vi: He was rarely lively.
tr: He rarely appeared cheerful.
es: He was rarely truly animated.

en: ms Collins knew not what to make of him.
vi: Mrs. Collins could not discern his character.
tr: Mrs. Collins didn't know what to make of it.
es: Mrs. Collins didn't know what to think of him.

en: Colonel Fitzwilliam’s occasionally laughing at his stupidity proved that he was generally different, which her own knowledge of him could not have told her; and as she would have liked to believe this change the effect of love, and the object of that love her friend Eliza, she set herself seriously to work to find it out: she watched him whenever they were at Rosings, and whenever he came to Hunsford; but without much success.
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam sometimes joked about his peculiar manners, suggesting he was different, but Mrs. Collins could not make anything of it. When she wanted to believe that this change was due to love, the object of this love, her friend Eliza, would sit solemnly alone for him to observe. She watched him whenever they visited Rosings and whenever he came to Huntsford, but she could not understand his feelings.
tr: Colonel Fitzwilliam's occasional amusement at his absent-mindedness indicated that he was normally a different person, otherwise, she didn't know Mr. Darcy well enough to decide for herself; she seriously dedicated herself to finding out, because she liked to believe that this change was due to the effect of love, and that the object of his affection was her friend Elizabeth. She observed him every time they went to Rosings or whenever he came to Hunsford, but she didn't achieve much success.
es: Since Colonel Fitzwilliam sometimes laughed at Darcy's foolishness, Charlotte understood that he must not always be like that, something her limited acquaintance with the gentleman would not have allowed her to guess; and as she wished to believe that this change was the work of love and that the object of that love was Elizabeth, she set out to discover it. When they were at Rosings and whenever Darcy came to her house, Charlotte observed him attentively, but she couldn't make anything of it.

en: He certainly looked at her friend a great deal, but the expression of that look was disputable.
vi: It was evident that he often looked at her friend, but the expression in his gaze was unfathomable.
tr: He looked at her friend a lot, but the expression of that gaze was debatable.
es: It was true that he looked at her friend a lot, but the expression of those looks was ambiguous.

en: It was an earnest, steadfast gaze, but she often doubted whether there were much admiration in it, and sometimes it seemed nothing but absence of mind.
vi: It was a serious, intent look; but she often wondered if there was any affection in it, and sometimes she saw nothing but indifference.
tr: It was a determined, steady gaze, but she wasn't sure if it contained much admiration and sometimes it just seemed like absent-mindedness.
es: It was a fixed and deep gaze, but Charlotte sometimes doubted that it was enthusiastic, and at times it simply seemed that he was distracted.

en: She had once or twice suggested to Elizabeth the possibility of his being partial to her, but Elizabeth always laughed at the idea; and ms Collins did not think it right to press the subject, from the danger of raising expectations which might only end in disappointment; for in her opinion it admitted not of a doubt, that all her friend’s dislike would vanish, if she could suppose him to be in her power.
vi: A few times, she let Elizabeth know that there was a possibility his feelings were leaning towards her, but Elizabeth always laughed off the idea. Mrs. Collins thought it best not to say more about this matter, as there was a risk of creating false hopes that would end in despair.
tr: Once or twice, she mentioned to Elizabeth the possibility that Mr. Darcy might be in love with her, but every time Elizabeth laughed it off, Mrs. Collins decided it was not right to insist on the matter too much, as there was a danger of raising hopes that could only end in disappointment, because it seemed to her that the moment her friend believed Mr. Darcy was in love with her, all her coldness towards him would disappear.
es: Two or three times he told Elizabeth that he might be in love with her, but Elizabeth would laugh, and Mrs. Collins thought it more prudent not to insist on it to avoid the danger of fostering impossible hopes, for she had no doubt that all of Elizabeth's aversion to Darcy would dissipate with the belief that he loved her.

en: In her kind schemes for Elizabeth, she sometimes planned her marrying Colonel Fitzwilliam.
vi: With good intentions for Elizabeth, sometimes she intended to help her marry Colonel Fitzwilliam.
tr: While making sweet plans for Elizabeth, he sometimes imagined her marrying Colonel Fitzwilliam.
es: In the good and affectionate plans that Charlotte made regarding Elizabeth, sometimes marrying her to Colonel Fitzwilliam was included.

en: He was, beyond comparison, the pleasantest man: he certainly admired her, and his situation in life was most eligible; but, to counterbalance these advantages, mr Darcy had considerable patronage in the church, and his cousin could have none at all.
vi: Obviously, he was the most amiable person, certainly liked her, and was fully qualified; but in return, with these advantages, Mr. Darcy had considerable patronage from the church, while his cousin had none.
tr: He was a more charming man than anyone else; he was clearly enamored with Elizabeth; his means were extremely ample; however, despite these advantages, Mr. Darcy was also a significant patron of the church, whereas his cousin had no connection to the church.
es: He was, without comparison, the most pleasant of all. He felt genuine admiration for Elizabeth and his position was excellent. But Darcy had considerable patronage in the Church, and his cousin had none.

en: “On looking up.”
vi: Obviously, he was the most amiable person, certainly liked her, and was fully qualified; but in return, with these advantages, Mr. Darcy had considerable patronage from the church, while his cousin had none.
tr: He was a more charming man than anyone else; he was clearly enamored with Elizabeth; his means were extremely ample; however, despite these advantages, Mr. Darcy was also a significant patron of the church, whereas his cousin had no connection to the church.
es: CHAPTER XXXIII

en: CHAPTER XXXIII.
vi: Chapter 33
tr: Chapter X
es: CHAPTER XXXIII

en: MORE than once did Elizabeth, in her ramble within the park, unexpectedly meet mr Darcy.
vi: A couple of times while wandering in the garden, Elizabeth happened to meet Mr. Darcy.
tr: While Elizabeth was walking around, she unexpectedly encountered Mr. Darcy several times.
es: During her walks through the grove within the estate, Elizabeth had more than once unexpectedly encountered Darcy.

en: She felt all the perverseness of the mischance that should bring him where no one else was brought; and, to prevent its ever happening again, took care to inform him, at first, that it was a favourite haunt of hers.
vi: She felt that unfortunate irony had led him to a place where no one else bothered to go. To prevent this from happening again, she informed him in advance that this path was her favorite.
tr: –She felt all the discomfort of the unfortunate coincidence that brought him to a place where no one else came, and to prevent it from happening again, she immediately told him that it was her favorite refuge.
es: The first time, she was not at all pleased that bad luck had brought him precisely to a place where no one else usually went, and to prevent it from happening again, she was careful to indicate that it was her favorite spot.

en: How it could occur a second time, therefore, was very odd!
vi: How this happened a second time was truly strange!
tr: –However, it was very strange for this to happen a second time!
es: Consequently, it was rare for the encounter to happen again, and yet, it occurred even a third time.

en: Yet it did, and even the third.
vi: Nevertheless, it happened, and it happened a third time.
tr: –But it did, and in fact, it happened once more after that.
es: Consequently, it was rare for the encounter to happen again, and yet, it occurred even a third time.

en: It seemed like wilful ill-nature, or a voluntary penance; for on these occasions it was not merely a few formal inquiries and an awkward pause and then away, but he actually thought it necessary to turn back and walk with her.
vi: It seemed like a deliberate bad habit, or a voluntary act of remorse, because on these occasions, it wasn't just a few customary greetings and a moment of awkwardness before moving on, but rather he turned back to walk with her.
tr: It was actually no different from a deliberate mischief or a voluntary ordeal, because in these situations, it wasn't just about asking a few formal questions, awkwardly hesitating, and then leaving; on the contrary, Mr. Darcy found it really necessary to turn back and walk with her.
es: It seemed as if he did it with intentional malice or as a penance, because it wasn't just limited to the usual questions or a simple and annoying stop; Darcy would turn back and walk with her.

en: He never said a great deal, nor did she give herself the trouble of talking or of listening much; but it struck her in the course of their third rencounter that he was asking some odd unconnected questions—about her pleasure in being at Hunsford, her love of solitary walks, and her opinion of mr and ms Collins’s happiness; and that in speaking of Rosings, and her not perfectly understanding the house, he seemed to expect that whenever she came into Kent again she would be staying there too.
vi: He never said much, and she didn't bother to talk or listen much either, but she noticed during the third walk that he asked strange questions, unrelated to the conversation – about her impressions of staying at Huntsford, her thoughts on walking alone, her opinion on the happiness of Mr. and Mrs. Collins. When talking about Rosings, her lack of understanding about this residence, it seemed he intended that whenever she came to Kent, she would also stay there.
tr: He didn't talk much; Elizabeth also didn't bother to talk or listen to him much; but during their third encounter, she was intrigued by some odd, unrelated questions he asked –whether she liked being in Hunsford, her solitary walks, her views on Mr. and Mrs. Collins' happiness; then, when Elizabeth mentioned Rosings and that she didn't know the house well, Mr. Darcy spoke as if he hoped she would stay there during her next visit to Kent.
es: He never talked much nor bothered her by making her talk or listen too much.

en: His words seemed to imply it.
vi: His words carried this implication.
tr: His words implied this.
es: But at the third encounter, Elizabeth was astonished by the oddity of the questions he asked: if she liked being in Hunsford, if she enjoyed solitary walks, and what her opinion was of the happiness of the Collins' marriage; but the strangest thing was that when talking about Rosings and her limited knowledge of the house, it seemed that he assumed that, upon returning to Kent, Elizabeth would also reside there.

en: Could he have Colonel Fitzwilliam in his thoughts?
vi: Could he be thinking of Colonel Fitzwilliam in his thoughts?
tr: Could he have been thinking of Colonel Fitzwilliam?
es: Was he thinking about Colonel Fitzwilliam?

en: She supposed, if he meant anything, he must mean an allusion to what might arise in that quarter.
vi: She guessed, if he had any intention, he must be hinting at the possibility of it happening that way.
tr: Elizabeth thought that if he meant anything, he might be hinting in that direction.
es: The young woman thought that if he meant anything, it had to be an allusion in that direction.

en: It distressed her a little, and she was quite glad to find herself at the gate in the pales opposite the Parsonage.
vi: This made her a bit uncomfortable, and she was glad to see that she had reached the gate of the garden opposite the Parsonage.
tr: This bothered her a bit, and she was glad when she found herself at the gate of the fence opposite the lodge.
es: This unsettled her a bit, and she was glad to find herself at the gate of the fence that was right in front of the Collins' house.

en: She was engaged one day, as she walked, in re-perusing Jane’s last letter, and dwelling on some passages which proved that Jane had not written in spirits, when, instead of being again surprised by mr Darcy, she saw, on looking up, that Colonel Fitzwilliam was meeting her.
vi: One day, while she was walking and pondering over Jane's latest letter, preoccupied with some passages that indicated Jane had not written with a calm mind, instead of being surprised once again by Mr. Darcy, she looked up and saw Colonel Fitzwilliam approaching.
tr: One day, while walking and rereading Jane's last letter, her mind got stuck on a part that showed Jane wrote without cheer, and instead of being surprised by Mr. Darcy again, she looked up and saw Colonel Fitzwilliam coming towards her.
es: One day, while walking, she was rereading Jane's last letter and focusing on a passage that denoted the sadness with which it had been written, when, instead of running into Darcy again, she looked up and found herself face to face with Colonel Fitzwilliam.

en: Putting away the letter immediately, and forcing a smile, she said,—
vi: She quickly hid the letter and tried to smile:
tr: She immediately put the letter away and, with difficulty smiling, said–
es: She quickly hid the letter and, feigning a smile, said:

en: “I did not know before that you ever walked this way.”
vi: - I didn't know beforehand that you also liked walking along this path.
tr: "I didn't know you were walking this path."
es: ––I never knew until now that you walked this path.

en: “I have been making the tour of the park,” he replied, “as I generally do every year, and intended to close it with a call at the Parsonage.
vi: He replied: - I am making a round around the campus as per my annual habit, intending to conclude with a visit to the Parish Priest's Residence.
tr: "I was walking through the grove," answered Colonel Fitzwilliam, "I do it every year; I was going to end the walk by stopping by the lodge.
es: ––I have been making the full round of the estate ––replied the colonel––, something I usually do every year. And I was thinking of finishing it with a visit to the parish priest's house.

en: Are you going much farther?”
vi: Are you going any further?
tr: Are you going any further?"
es: Are you going to continue walking?

en: “No, I should have turned in a moment.”
vi: - No, I intend to come back a little later.
tr: "No, I was about to leave too."
es: ––No; I was going to return.

en: And accordingly she did turn, and they walked towards the Parsonage together.
vi: Accordingly, she turned back, and the two of them walked together towards the Parish House.
tr: She turned around; they started walking towards the lodging together.
es: Indeed, he turned around and together they headed towards the parish house.

en: “Do you certainly leave Kent on Saturday?” said she.
vi: She asked: - Are you sure you intend to leave Kent on Saturday?
tr: "Are you really leaving Kent on Saturday?" said Elizabeth.
es: ––Are you definitely leaving Kent on Saturday? ––asked Elizabeth.

en: “Yes—if Darcy does not put it off again.
vi: - Yes, if Darcy doesn't postpone it again.
tr: "Yes – if Darcy doesn't postpone again.
es: ––Yes, if Darcy doesn't postpone the trip again.

en: But I am at his disposal.
vi: But I depend on him.
tr: But I am subject to him.
es: I am at his disposal; he arranges things as he sees fit.

en: He arranges the business just as he pleases.”
vi: He arranges his work as he pleases.
tr: He arranges things as he pleases."
es: ––And if he does not like things, at least he takes great pleasure in being able to arrange them as he pleases.

en: “And if not able to please himself in the arrangement, he has at least great pleasure in the power of choice.
vi: - If he doesn't get things arranged to his liking, at least he will like having the right to decide.
tr: "If she is not pleased with the arrangement, at least she can be satisfied with having had the choice.
es: ––And if he does not like things, at least he takes great pleasure in being able to arrange them as he pleases.

en: I do not know anybody who seems more to enjoy the power of doing what he likes than mr Darcy.”
vi: I have never known anyone who likes having the right to do as they please more than Mr. Darcy.
tr: I have never seen anyone who loves having the power to do as they wish more than Mr. Darcy."
es: I do not know anyone who seems to enjoy the power to do what he wants more than Mr. Darcy.

en: “He likes to have his own way very well,” replied Colonel Fitzwilliam.
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam replied: - He likes to do things his own way.
tr: "He loves to do as he pleases," answered Colonel Fitzwilliam.
es: ––He likes to have his own way, replied Colonel Fitzwilliam––.

en: “But so we all do.
vi: But we all do.
tr: "But of course, we all do.
es: But we all like that.

en: It is only that he has better means of having it than many others, because he is rich, and many others are poor.
vi: It's just that he has more means than others because he is rich, and many others are poor.
tr: He just has more means to do so, because he is rich and many others are poor.
es: It's just that he has more means to do it than many others, because he is rich and others are poor.

en: I speak feelingly.
vi: I'm speaking emotionally.
tr: I am speaking of myself.
es: I say what I feel.

en: A younger son, you know, must be inured to self-denial and dependence.”
vi: A young man must learn to get used to self-restraint and dependence.
tr: Being the younger son, I am accustomed to sacrifice and dependency."
es: You know that younger children have to get used to dependency and give up many things.

en: “In my opinion, the younger son of an earl can know very little of either.
vi: - In my opinion, the young son of an Earl might know very little about many things.
tr: "I don't think the younger son of a count knows either of them very well.
es: ––I believe that the youngest son of a count doesn't have it as bad as you say.

en: Now, seriously, what have you ever known of self-denial and dependence?
vi: Now, seriously, what do you know about self-restraint and dependence?
tr: Seriously, do you know what sacrifice and dependency are?
es: Let's see, honestly, what do you know about renunciations and dependencies?

en: When have you been prevented by want of money from going wherever you chose or procuring anything you had a fancy for?”
vi: Have you ever been unable to go where you wanted or buy what you liked because of a lack of money?
tr: When has a lack of money ever stopped you from going wherever you wanted or buying something you desired?"
es: When have you been deprived, due to lack of money, of going where you wanted or getting something you fancied?

en: “These are home questions—and perhaps I cannot say that I have experienced many hardships of that nature.
vi: - These are questions about family matters – and perhaps I have never experienced such hardships.
tr: "These are valid questions –perhaps I can't say I've faced too much difficulty of that kind.
es: ––Those are insignificant matters, and perhaps I can acknowledge that I haven't suffered many deprivations of that nature.

en: But in matters of greater weight, I may suffer from the want of money.
vi: But in more significant matters, I might still be lacking money.
tr: But I might face financial difficulties in more important matters.
es: But in matters of greater importance, I am subject to a lack of money.

en: Younger sons cannot marry where they like.”
vi: Young men cannot just marry whoever they want.
tr: Young sons cannot marry the person they want."
es: The younger children cannot marry whenever they please.

en: “Unless where they like women of fortune, which I think they very often do.”
vi: - Unless they like to marry wealthy women, and I think they often do.
tr: "If they don't want wealthy women, of course; I suppose they do this very often.""
es: ––Unless they like rich women, which I think happens often.

en: “Our habits of expense make us too dependent, and there are not many in my rank of life who can afford to marry without some attention to money.”
vi: - Our spending habits make us too dependent; not many people in my social class can get married without worrying about money.
tr: "Our spending habits make us quite dependent; there aren't many people in my position in life who can afford to get married without giving some importance to money."
es: ––Our habit of spending makes us too dependent, and there are not many of my rank who marry without paying a little attention to money.

en: “Is this,” thought Elizabeth, “meant for me?” and she coloured at the idea; but, recovering herself, said in a lively tone, “And pray, what is the usual price of an earl’s younger son?
vi: Elizabeth thought, "Is this remark aimed at me?" and she blushed at the idea. But she composed herself and cheerfully said: - Could you please tell me, what is the usual price for a young son of an Earl?
tr: "I wonder," thought Elizabeth, "is he referring to me with this?" and the thought made her blush; but, pulling herself together, she said in a cheerful voice, "For God's sake, can you tell me, what is the usual price for the younger son of an earl?
es: "Could this be referring to me?" thought Elizabeth, blushing. But recovering, she replied in a jovial tone: ––And tell me, what is the usual price for the younger son of an earl?

en: Unless the elder brother is very sickly, I suppose you would not ask above fifty thousand pounds.”
vi: Unless your cousin is ill, I guess you wouldn't ask for more than fifty thousand pounds.
tr: If his elder brother is not very ill, surely you wouldn't ask for more than fifty thousand pounds."
es: Unless the elder brother is very ill, you wouldn't ask for more than fifty thousand pounds...

en: He answered her in the same style, and the subject dropped.
vi: He replied to her in a joking manner, and they stopped there.
tr: He responded in the same manner, and the matter was dropped.
es: He responded in the same tone and the topic was exhausted.

en: To interrupt a silence which might make him fancy her affected with what had passed, she soon afterwards said,—
vi: To break the silence that might make him think she was affected by the recent words, she said:
tr: Elizabeth immediately said the following to avoid a silence that might suggest she was affected by the conversation–
es: To prevent a silence that might make the colonel think that what was said had affected her, Elizabeth spoke shortly after:

en: “I imagine your cousin brought you down with him chiefly for the sake of having somebody at his disposal.
vi: - I imagine your cousin brought you here mainly to have someone to boss around.
tr: "I think your cousin brought you along to have someone at his command.
es: ––I imagine that his cousin brought him along mainly to have someone at his disposal.

en: I wonder he does not marry, to secure a lasting convenience of that kind.
vi: I think he doesn't want to get married in order to enjoy this kind of freedom for a long time.
tr: I'm surprised he hasn't married to have this kind of comfort all the time.
es: It surprises me that he doesn't get married, as that way he would have someone constantly subject to him.

en: But, perhaps, his sister does as well for the present; and, as she is under his sole care, he may do what he likes with her.”
vi: But, perhaps his sister feels the same way, and since she is under his protection, he can do whatever he wants with her.
tr: But maybe for now his sister is enough; since he is her guardian, he can manage her as he wishes."
es: Although it may be that his sister suffices for that, for the moment, since as she is under his exclusive custody, he must be able to command her as he pleases.

en: “No,” said Colonel Fitzwilliam, “that is an advantage which he must divide with me.
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam replied: - No, this is an advantage that he has to share with me.
tr: "No," said Colonel Fitzwilliam, "this is a privilege that should be shared with me.
es: ––No ––said Colonel Fitzwilliam––, that advantage must be shared with me.

en: I am joined with him in the guardianship of Miss Darcy.”
vi: I, along with him, protect Miss Darcy.
tr: I am a partner with him in Miss Darcy's guardianship."
es: I am entrusted, along with him, with the guardianship of his sister.

en: “Are you, indeed?
vi: - Really?
tr: "Is that really so?
es: ––Really?

en: And pray what sort of a guardian do you make?
vi: And may I ask, how do you protect her?
tr: God knows what kind of saints you have become?
es: And tell me, what kind of tutelage do you provide?

en: Does your charge give you much trouble?
vi: Does she cause you any trouble?
tr: Does the young lady upset you a lot?
es: Does it keep you very busy?

en: Young ladies of her age are sometimes a little difficult to manage; and if she has the true Darcy spirit, she may like to have her own way.”
vi: Young ladies at her age can sometimes be difficult to manage, so if she truly has the Darcy temperament, she might want to do things her own way.
tr: It is a bit difficult to manage young girls at that age; especially if she has the true Darcy spirit, she may want to do as she pleases."
es: Girls of her age can sometimes be a bit difficult to manage, and if she has the same character as Mr. Darcy, she must also like to have her own way.

en: As she spoke, she observed him looking at her earnestly; and the manner in which he immediately asked her why she supposed Miss Darcy likely to give them any uneasiness, convinced her that she had somehow or other got pretty near the truth.
vi: When she spoke, she noticed that he was watching her intently, and the way he immediately asked her how she guessed that Miss Darcy might cause trouble for them made her think that somehow she had come close to the truth.
tr: Elizabeth noticed that Colonel Fitzwilliam was looking at her with curiosity while she was speaking, and the way he immediately asked her why Miss Darcy might upset them convinced Elizabeth that she was quite close to the truth from one angle.
es: While she was speaking, Elizabeth noticed that the colonel was looking at her very seriously, and the way he immediately asked how she supposed Miss Darcy could cause them any trouble convinced Elizabeth that, to some extent, she had come close to the truth.

en: She directly replied,—
vi: She answered frankly:
tr: He immediately replied,
es: The young woman answered his question directly:

en: “You need not be frightened.
vi: - You don't need to worry.
tr: "You don't need to be afraid.
es: ––Don't be alarmed.

en: I never heard any harm of her; and I dare say she is one of the most tractable creatures in the world.
vi: I have never heard anyone speak ill of her, and I am even certain that she is one of the most manageable creatures in the world.
tr: I haven't heard anything bad about him; in fact, I think he is one of the most charming people in the world.
es: I've never heard anything bad about her and I would almost assure you that she is one of the best creatures in the world.

en: She is a very great favourite with some ladies of my acquaintance, ms Hurst and Miss Bingley.
vi: Many women I know, such as Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley, are very fond of her.
tr: He is a favorite of some ladies I know, Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley.
es: She is the favorite of certain ladies I know: Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley.

en: I think I have heard you say that you know them.”
vi: I think I heard that you know them.
tr: If I'm not mistaken, you mentioned that you know them."
es: I believe you told me that you also knew them.

en: “I know them a little.
vi: - I am somewhat acquainted with them.
tr: "I know him a little.
es: ––Something, yes.

en: Their brother is a pleasant, gentlemanlike man—he is a great friend of Darcy’s.”
vi: Their younger brother is a pleasant person – he is close friends with Mr. Darcy.
tr: His brothers are pleasant gentlemen – Darcy's close friend."
es: Her brother is a very pleasant gentleman, an intimate friend of Darcy.

en: “Oh yes,” said Elizabeth drily—“mr Darcy is uncommonly kind to mr Bingley, and takes a prodigious deal of care of him.”
vi: Elizabeth is dry: - Ah! Yes. Mr. Darcy is unusually kind to Mr. Bingley and takes great care of him.
tr: "Indeed," said Elizabeth in a dry tone – "Mr. Darcy is extremely kind to Mr. Bingley; he looks after him as if he were his child."
es: ––Oh, yes! ––said Elizabeth dryly––. Mr. Darcy is incredibly kind to Mr. Bingley and takes care of him in an extraordinary way.

en: “Care of him!
vi: - Take care of him!
tr: "He looks out for him, right!
es: ––Does he take care of him?

en: Yes, I really believe Darcy does take care of him in those points where he most wants care.
vi: Yes, I believe that Darcy truly takes care of him in the matters he needs the most attention.
tr: Yes, I think Darcy looks out for him when needed.
es: Yes, really, I think he takes care of him precisely in what requires the most care.

en: From something that he told me in our journey hither, I have reason to think Bingley very much indebted to him.
vi: According to what Darcy told me during this trip, I have reason to believe that Bingley owes him a lot.
tr: From something he told me on the way here, I got the impression that Bingley owes him.
es: From something he told me when we were coming here, I presume that Bingley owes him a lot.

en: But I ought to beg his pardon, for I have no right to suppose that Bingley was the person meant.
vi: But I must apologize to him, for I should not assume that Bingley is the subject.
tr: But forgive me, I have no right to think that the person in question is Bingley.
es: But I must ask you to forgive me, because I have no right to assume that Bingley was the person Darcy was referring to.

en: It was all conjecture.”
vi: It is all conjecture.
tr: It's all my assumption."
es: They are just conjectures.

en: “What is it you mean?”
vi: - What do you mean?
tr: "What do you mean?"
es: ––What does it mean?

en: “It is a circumstance which Darcy of course could not wish to be generally known, because if it were to get round to the lady’s family it would be an unpleasant thing.”
vi: - This is a situation that Darcy naturally does not want everyone to know about, because if Lady's family finds out, it will be unpleasant.
tr: "A situation Darcy doesn't want to spread around; if it reaches the lady's family, it would be very unpleasant."
es: ––It is something that Darcy would not want to be disclosed, for if it reached the ears of the lady's family, it would be very unpleasant.

en: “You may depend upon my not mentioning it.”
vi: - You can trust me not to reveal it.
tr: "You can be sure that I won't tell anyone.""
es: Don't worry, I won't disclose it.

en: “And remember that I have not much reason for supposing it to be Bingley.
vi: - You should remember that I have little reason to guess that it was Mr. Bingley.
tr: "But remember, I have little reason to believe it was Bingley.
es: ––Keep in mind that I lack evidence to suppose that it is Bingley.

en: What he told me was merely this: that he congratulated himself on having lately saved a friend from the inconveniences of a most imprudent marriage, but without mentioning names or any other particulars; and I only suspected it to be Bingley from believing him the kind of young man to get into a scrape of that sort, and from knowing them to have been together the whole of last summer.”
vi: What Darcy told me was simply this: he praised himself for having saved a friend from the troubles of a reckless marriage, but Darcy did not specify the name of the person or any other details. I only suspected it was Bingley because I believe Bingley is the type of young man who would behave foolishly like that, and because I know the two have been close throughout the past summer.
tr: All he told me was that he recently congratulated himself for saving a friend from making an unwise marriage, without giving any names or details. I only suspected it was Bingley because he is the kind of man who would be influenced in that way, and also because I knew they were together all last summer."
es: What Darcy told me is that he was glad to have recently saved a friend from a very imprudent marriage; but he did not mention names or details, and I suspected that the friend was Bingley only because he seems to me a young man very suitable for such a case, and because I know they were together all summer.

en: “Did mr Darcy give you his reasons for this interference?”
vi: - Did Mr. Darcy tell you any reason why he wanted to get involved like that?
tr: "Did Mr. Darcy tell you the reasons for his intervention?"
es: ––Did Mr. Darcy tell you the reasons he had for interfering in the matter?

en: “I understood that there were some very strong objections against the lady.”
vi: - I think the girl faced a lot of strong opposition.
tr: "There were some very strong objections against the lady.""
es: ––I understood that there were some significant objections against the young lady.

en: “And what arts did he use to separate them?”
vi: - And what technique did he use to separate the two people?
tr: "So, what skills did he use to separate them?""
es: ––And what tricks did he use to separate them?

en: “He did not talk to me of his own arts,” said Fitzwilliam, smiling.
vi: Fitzwilliam smiled: - He didn't tell me about his techniques.
tr: "He didn't tell me about his own skills," said Fitzwilliam, smiling.
es: ––He didn't speak of his tricks ––said Fitzwilliam, smiling––.

en: “He only told me what I have now told you.”
vi: I told you everything he told me.
tr: "He only told me what I told you."
es: He only told me what I just told you.

en: Elizabeth made no answer, and walked on, her heart swelling with indignation.
vi: Elizabeth did not reply, continued walking, her mind filled with indignation.
tr: Elizabeth did not answer; she continued walking, her heart swelling with anger.
es: Elizabeth made no comment and continued walking with her heart swollen with indignation.

en: After watching her a little, Fitzwilliam asked her why she was so thoughtful.
vi: Watching her for a moment, Fitzwilliam asked why she seemed pensive.
tr: After watching her for a while, Fitzwilliam asked why she was so pensive.
es: After observing her for a bit, Fitzwilliam asked her why she was so thoughtful.

en: “I am thinking of what you have been telling me,” said she.
vi: She said: - I am thinking about what you told me.
tr: "I am thinking about what you told me," said Elizabeth.
es: ––I am thinking about what you have told me ––Elizabeth replied––.

en: “Your cousin’s conduct does not suit my feelings.
vi: Your cousin's behavior does not align with my feelings.
tr: "Your cousin's behavior does not align with my feelings.
es: Your cousin's behavior does not seem right to me at all.

en: Why was he to be the judge?”
vi: Why does he want to be a judge?
tr: Why would he be a judge?"
es: Why did he have to be the judge?

en: “You are rather disposed to call his interference officious?”
vi: - Do you mean that his interference is a nuisance?
tr: "It seems you found his intervention meddlesome."
es: ––Does that mean your intervention was indiscreet?

en: “I do not see what right mr Darcy had to decide on the propriety of his friend’s inclination; or why, upon his own judgment alone, he was to determine and direct in what manner that friend was to be happy.
vi: - I think Mr. Darcy has no right to judge whether his friend's feelings are right or wrong, or why he should determine and dictate how his friend should find happiness based solely on his own judgment.
tr: "What right does Mr. Darcy have to decide whether his friend's wish is appropriate, or how does he determine and direct what will make his friend happy, I don't understand."
es: ––I don't see what right Mr. Darcy has to decide on his friend's inclination and why he should be the one to direct and determine, in his judgment, how his friend should be happy.

en: But,” she continued, recollecting herself, “as we know none of the particulars, it is not fair to condemn him.
vi: She continued, calming down: - But, since we don't know any details, condemning him is unfair.
tr: "But," he continued, collecting himself, "it would not be fair to condemn him as we do not know the details.
es: But ––he continued, composing himself––, not knowing the details, it is not right to criticize him.

en: It is not to be supposed that there was much affection in the case.”
vi: We cannot assume that there are many emotions involved in this case.
tr: Clearly, there was no significant affection involved."
es: One must believe that love had little to do with this case.

en: “That is not an unnatural surmise,” said Fitzwilliam; “but it is lessening the honour of my cousin’s triumph very sadly.”
vi: Fitzwilliam said: - This is not a forced guess, but it sadly diminishes the glory of my cousin's victory.
tr: "This is not an incorrect assumption," said Fitzwilliam, "but it sadly diminishes the grandeur of my cousin's triumph."
es: It is to be supposed ––said Fitzwilliam––, but that very sadly diminishes my cousin's triumph.

en: This was spoken jestingly, but it appeared to her so just a picture of mr Darcy, that she would not trust herself with an answer; and, therefore, abruptly changing the conversation, talked on indifferent matters till they reached the Parsonage.
vi: He was only joking, but to her, that was exactly the image of Mr. Darcy. She thought it best not to respond, so she suddenly switched to other topics until they arrived at the Parsonage.
tr: This remark was made in jest, but it seemed to Elizabeth such an accurate depiction of Darcy that she did not dare to respond; consequently, she immediately changed the subject and talked about trivial matters until they reached the parsonage.
es: He said this last part in jest, but to Elizabeth, it seemed such an accurate portrayal of Darcy that she thought it useless to respond. She changed the subject and began talking about trivial matters until they arrived at the house.

en: There, shut into her own room, as soon as their visitor left them, she could think without interruption of all that she had heard.
vi: Right after the guest said goodbye, locking herself in her room, she could think without interruption about everything she had heard.
tr: At the parsonage, as soon as the guest left, she shut herself in her room and thought long and hard about everything she had heard.
es: As soon as the colonel left, Elizabeth locked herself in her room and thought without interruption about everything she had heard.

en: It was not to be supposed that any other people could be meant than those with whom she was connected.
vi: It couldn't be said that he was referring to anyone other than those she knew.
tr: She thought it could not have been referring to anyone other than the people she knew.
es: There was no supposing that the colonel was referring to anyone other than Jane and Bingley.

en: There could not exist in the world two men over whom mr Darcy could have such boundless influence.
vi: In this world, there couldn't be two people who had such a great influence on Mr. Darcy.
tr: There could not be a second man in the world whom Darcy could so thoroughly influence.
es: There could not exist two men over whom Darcy exercised such unlimited influence.

en: That he had been concerned in the measures taken to separate mr Bingley and Jane, she had never doubted; but she had always attributed to Miss Bingley the principal design and arrangement of them.
vi: She never doubted that Darcy was involved in measures to separate Mr. Bingley and Jane, but she always thought that Miss Bingley was the main instigator.
tr: She had no doubt that he had been involved in measures to separate Mr. Bingley and Jane; but she had always attributed the main plan and execution to Miss Bingley.
es: She had never doubted that Darcy had been involved in the measures taken to separate Bingley and Jane; but she had always attributed the plan and the main role to Miss Bingley.

en: If his own vanity, however, did not mislead him, he was the cause—his pride and caprice were the cause—of all that Jane had suffered, and still continued to suffer.
vi: However, if his vanity didn't lead him astray, then he himself was the cause, his pride and impulsiveness were the reasons why Jane had suffered and continued to suffer.
tr: If Mr. Bingley's own pride did not guide him, then the reason for all Jane's suffering, which she still continued to endure, was him, his pride and arrogance.
es: However, if her own vanity did not blind her, he was the culprit; his pride and his whim were the cause of all that Jane had suffered and continued to suffer.

en: He had ruined for a while every hope of happiness for the most affectionate, generous heart in the world; and no one could say how lasting an evil he might have inflicted.
vi: He had extinguished all hopes of happiness for the most earnest and generous heart, and no one could say how much more harm he would cause.
tr: He had temporarily shattered all hope of happiness in the most loving, most generous heart in the world; moreover, no one could yet know how lasting the damage was.
es: Because of him, all hope of happiness had disappeared from the kindest and most generous heart in the world, and no one could calculate all the harm he had done.

en: “There were some very strong objections against the lady,” were Colonel Fitzwilliam’s words; and these strong objections probably were, her having one uncle who was a country attorney, and another who was in business in London.
vi: “The girl faces strong opposition” were the words of Colonel Fitzwilliam, and this strong opposition might come from her uncle who is a lawyer in the countryside and another uncle in London.
tr: "There were some very strong objections against the lady," these were the words of Colonel Fitzwilliam, and those strong objections were probably that her uncle was a country lawyer and her other uncle was a tradesman in London.
es: Colonel Fitzwilliam had said that "there were some serious objections against the young lady." And those objections would surely be having an uncle who was a country lawyer and another who was a merchant in London...

en: “To Jane herself,” she exclaimed, “there could be no possibility of objection,—all loveliness and goodness as she is!
vi: She thought, with Jane, there could be no issue of opposition. She is everything that is lovely and gentle!
tr: "Jane herself," he cried, "could never have objected. She is a monument of beauty and goodness!
es: “Against Jane,” thought Elizabeth, “there was no possible objection. She is the embodiment of charm and kindness!

en: Her understanding excellent, her mind improved, and her manners captivating.
vi: She has excellent understanding, an open mind, and graceful manners that captivate people.
tr: Her intelligence is so flawless, her spirit so mature, her manners so graceful.
es: Her intelligence is excellent; her talent, unparalleled; her manners, captivating.

en: Neither could anything be urged against my father, who, though with some peculiarities, has abilities which mr Darcy himself need not disdain, and respectability which he will probably never reach.”
vi: There is also nothing to criticize about her father, because although he is a bit eccentric, he has qualities that Mr. Darcy cannot disdain, and a respectable position that he cannot attain.
tr: Nothing can be said against my father either; yes, he has his peculiarities, but he has talents that Mr. Darcy cannot scorn and a honesty he probably will never possess."
es: There was nothing to object to about her father either, who, despite his eccentricities, possessed qualities that even Darcy would not disdain and a respectability that perhaps Darcy would never attain.”

en: When she thought of her mother, indeed, her confidence gave way a little; but she would not allow that any objections there had material weight with mr Darcy, whose pride, she was convinced, would receive a deeper wound from the want of importance in his friend’s connections than from their want of sense; and she was quite decided, at last, that he had been partly governed by this worst kind of pride, and partly by the wish of retaining mr Bingley for his sister.
vi: When she thought of the mother, she felt a bit less confident, but she did not think any opposition here would carry weight with Mr. Darcy. She believed that his pride would be more severely wounded by his friend's lack of social standing than by their lack of awareness. Finally, she was convinced that he was partly influenced by his worst kind of pride, and partly by his desire to keep Mr. Bingley for his own sister.
tr: Thinking of her mother, of course, shook her confidence a little, but she did not believe that even the objections at that point would have a significant effect on Mr. Darcy; it seemed to Elizabeth that Mr. Darcy's pride had been most deeply wounded by the insignificance of his friend's relatives, not their impropriety; in the end, she concluded that he acted out of this worst kind of pride on one hand, and on the other hand, the desire to keep Mr. Bingley for his own sister.
es: When she thought of her mother, her confidence wavered a bit; but she did not admit that Darcy could have any serious objection to her, for she was sure that his pride–– valued the lack of rank in his friend's potential relatives more than their lack of sense. In short, one had to think that he was driven partly by the most stubborn pride and partly by his desire to keep Bingley for his sister.

en: The agitation and tears which the subject occasioned brought on a headache; and it grew so much worse towards the evening that, added to her unwillingness to see mr Darcy, it determined her not to attend her cousins to Rosings, where they were engaged to drink tea.
vi: The emotional turmoil and tears gave her a headache, and by the evening the symptoms had worsened to the point that she did not want to go to Rosings for the tea party, compounded by her reluctance to see Mr. Darcy.
tr: The excitement and tears caused by the issue brought on a headache; the pain worsened so much by the evening that, combined with her reluctance to see Mr. Darcy, it prevented her from accompanying her cousins to the tea invitation at Rosings.
es: The agitation and tears gave Elizabeth a headache that worsened in the afternoon, and adding her ailment to her desire not to see Darcy, she decided not to accompany her cousins to Rosings, where they were invited for tea.

en: ms Collins, seeing that she was really unwell, did not press her to go, and as much as possible prevented her husband from pressing her; but mr Collins could not conceal his apprehension of Lady Catherine’s being rather displeased by her staying at home.
vi: Mrs. Collins saw that she was indeed unwell and did not insist, trying to stop her husband from pressing her, but Mr. Collins could not hide his concern that Lady Catherine might be displeased.
tr: Seeing that she was truly unwell, Mrs. Collins did not insist on her going, and did her best to prevent her husband from insisting as well, but Mr. Collins did not hide his fear that Lady Catherine would not be pleased to hear this.
es: Mrs. Collins, seeing that she was truly unwell, did not insist, and did everything possible to prevent her husband from doing so; but Collins could not hide his fear that Lady Catherine would take offense at Elizabeth's absence.

en: CHAPTER XXXIV.
vi: Chapter 34
tr: Chapter XI
es: CHAPTER XXXIV

en: WHEN they were gone, Elizabeth, as if intending to exasperate herself as much as possible against mr Darcy, chose for her employment the examination of all the letters which Jane had written to her since her being in Kent.
vi: When they had gone, as if wanting to vent her anger on Mr. Darcy, Elizabeth took out and reviewed all the letters Jane had sent her since she went to visit in Kent.
tr: When they left, Elizabeth, as if wanting to make herself even angrier with Mr. Darcy, began to examine all the letters Jane had written to her since she came to Kent.
es: When everyone had left, Elizabeth, as if she intended to further exasperate herself against Darcy, set about reviewing all the letters she had received from Jane since she had been in Kent.

en: They contained no actual complaint, nor was there any revival of past occurrences, or any communication of present suffering.
vi: The letters contained no complaints, no recounting of past events or current suffering.
tr: There was no specific complaint in the letters; past events were not remembered, nor was there any mention of present suffering.
es: They contained no lamentations nor anything that indicated she remembered the past or that she suffered because of it; but overall, and almost in every line, there was a lack of the joy that used to characterize Jane's style, a joy that, as was natural in such a calm and affectionate character, had almost never been eclipsed.

en: But in all, and in almost every line of each, there was a want of that cheerfulness which had been used to characterize her style, and which, proceeding from the serenity of a mind at ease with itself, and kindly disposed towards everyone, had been scarcely ever clouded.
vi: But she noticed that every letter, and almost every line, was less cheerful, whereas her sister's writing was usually cheerful and truly calm, making it hard to disguise this change in tone.
tr: But in all of them, and in almost every line of them, there was a lack of that cheerfulness which had so far hardly ever been dimmed, coming from the tranquility of a spirit at peace with itself and kind to everyone, which was a typical feature of her style.
es: They contained no lamentations nor anything that indicated she remembered the past or that she suffered because of it; but overall, and almost in every line, there was a lack of the joy that used to characterize Jane's style, a joy that, as was natural in such a calm and affectionate character, had almost never been eclipsed.

en: Elizabeth noticed every sentence conveying the idea of uneasiness, with an attention which it had hardly received on the first perusal.
vi: Elizabeth noticed that every phrase carried a sense of discomfort, which would not be noticed upon a first, cursory reading.
tr: When Elizabeth read them more carefully than she had the first time, she noticed that every sentence carried a sense of discomfort.
es: Elizabeth focused on all the phrases revealing unease, with an attention she had not given them in the first reading.

en: mr Darcy’s shameful boast of what misery he had been able to inflict gave her a keener sense of her sister’s sufferings.
vi: Mr. Darcy's shameful boast about how he could inflict harm helped her clearly feel her sister's suffering.
tr: Mr. Darcy's arrogant boasting about the sorrow he had caused made her feel her sister's pains more acutely.
es: Darcy's shameful boast about the harm he had caused made her feel her sister's suffering more keenly.

en: It was some consolation to think that his visit to Rosings was to end on the day after the next, and a still greater that in less than a fortnight she should herself be with Jane again, and enabled to contribute to the recovery of her spirits, by all that affection could do.
vi: She found some comfort in thinking that his visit to Rosings would end in two days. A greater comfort was that within two weeks she would see Jane again, when she could help her sister recover her spirits with all the love she could muster.
tr: The thought that Mr. Darcy's visit to Rosings would end the next day gave her some relief; the thought that in less than fifteen days she would be with Jane again, and with all her love would help restore her cheerfulness, gave her even more comfort.
es: It consoled her a little to think that in two days she would be back by Jane's side and could help her regain her spirits with the care that only affection can provide.

en: She could not think of Darcy’s leaving Kent without remembering that his cousin was to go with him; but Colonel Fitzwilliam had made it clear that he had no intentions at all, and, agreeable as he was, she did not mean to be unhappy about him.
vi: She could not think of Mr. Darcy leaving Kent without remembering that his cousin would also be leaving with him. But Colonel Fitzwilliam had clearly shown no romantic interest in her, and although he was amiable, she would have no reason to be sad about his departure.
tr: She could not imagine Darcy leaving Kent without remembering that his cousin would be going with him; but Colonel Fitzwilliam had made it clear that he had no intentions regarding her, and although he was a pleasant man, Elizabeth had no intention of being unhappy because of him.
es: She could not think of Darcy's departure without remembering that his cousin was leaving with him; but Colonel Fitzwilliam had made it clear that he could not think of her.

en: While settling this point, she was suddenly roused by the sound of the door-bell; and her spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its being Colonel Fitzwilliam himself, who had once before called late in the evening, and might now come to inquire particularly after her.
vi: While she had already made up her mind, she suddenly heard the doorbell ring, and her spirits were somewhat agitated at the thought that it might be Colonel Fitzwilliam, as he had once visited in the evening and might be coming to inquire about her.
tr: While sorting out this point in her mind, she was suddenly startled by the doorbell; the thought that it might be Colonel Fitzwilliam made her heart race; Colonel Fitzwilliam had called once in the afternoon and might have come now out of special concern for her.
es: While she was contemplating all this, she was startled by the doorbell, and she hoped it might be Colonel Fitzwilliam himself, who had once visited them in the afternoon and might be coming to ask how she was.

en: But this idea was soon banished, and her spirits were very differently affected, when, to her utter amazement, she saw mr Darcy walk into the room.
vi: But this thought quickly vanished, and her spirits were agitated in a different way. She was utterly surprised to see Mr. Darcy walk in.
tr: But this thought quickly passed, and her heart came under a different influence: she saw with astonishment that Mr. Darcy had entered the room.
es: But she soon dismissed that idea and continued with her thoughts when, to her complete surprise, she saw Darcy enter the room.

en: In a hurried manner he immediately began an inquiry after her health, imputing his visit to a wish of hearing that she were better.
vi: He hurriedly inquired about her health and expressed his wish to visit in hopes of knowing whether she had gotten any better.
tr: Mr. Darcy, with an unhurried demeanor, immediately inquired about her health, attributing his visit to a desire to hear that she was feeling better.
es: He immediately began to inquire, very hastily, about her health, attributing his visit to a desire to know that she was feeling better.

en: She answered him with cold civility.
vi: She responded in a politely cold manner.
tr: Elizabeth responded to him with cold politeness.
es: She replied courteously but coldly.

en: He sat down for a few moments, and then getting up walked about the room.
vi: He sat for a moment, then stood up and walked around the room.
tr: Mr. Darcy sat for a few seconds, then got up and began to walk around the room.
es: She replied courteously but coldly.

en: Elizabeth was surprised, but said not a word.
vi: Elizabeth was surprised, but did not say a word.
tr: Elizabeth was surprised, but said not a word.
es: Elizabeth was astonished but did not say a word.

en: After a silence of several minutes, he came towards her in an agitated manner, and thus began:—
vi: After a few minutes of silence, he approached her in an agitated manner, and then began:
tr: After a few minutes of silence, he approached her excitedly and began to speak,
es: After several minutes of silence, he approached her and, very agitated, declared:

en: “In vain have I struggled.
vi: - I have struggled, but to no avail.
tr: "I have struggled in vain.
es: ––I have fought in vain.

en: It will not do.
vi: There is nothing that can be done. I cannot do anything at all.
tr: It will not work.
es: I can't go on any longer.

en: My feelings will not be repressed.
vi: I cannot control my emotions.
tr: My feelings cannot be repressed.
es: I am incapable of containing my feelings.

en: You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love you.”
vi: You must allow me to tell you how deeply I have admired and loved you.
tr: Allow me to tell you how passionately I admire and love you."
es: Allow me to tell you that I admire you and love you passionately.

en: Elizabeth’s astonishment was beyond expression.
vi: No words could describe Elizabeth's astonishment.
tr: Elizabeth's astonishment was indescribable.
es: Elizabeth's astonishment was inexpressible.

en: She stared, coloured, doubted, and was silent.
vi: She stared, face flushed, doubtful and silent.
tr: Her eyes widened, her face turned red, she became doubtful and fell silent.
es: She blushed, stood staring at him, indecisive and mute.

en: This he considered sufficient encouragement, and the avowal of all that he felt and had long felt for her immediately followed.
vi: He considered this enough encouragement to continue expressing what had caused his feelings for her to blossom for a long time.
tr: Mr. Darcy took this as a sign of hope; immediately afterward, he began to confess all his feelings for her, feelings he had harbored for a long time.
es: He interpreted it as a favorable sign and continued expressing to her all that he had felt for her for a long time.

en: He spoke well; but there were feelings besides those of the heart to be detailed, and he was not more eloquent on the subject of tenderness than of pride.
vi: He spoke coherently but with emotions beyond those of the heart that needed to be meticulously expressed, and on the subject of emotions, he was no more fluent than on the subject of pride.
tr: He spoke beautifully, but there were other emotions to express alongside the feelings of the heart; he was not more passionate when speaking of love than when speaking of pride.
es: He explained himself well, but he had to talk not only about his love, and he was no more eloquent on the subject of tenderness than on that of pride.

en: His sense of her inferiority, of its being a degradation, of the family obstacles which judgment had always opposed to inclination, were dwelt on with a warmth which seemed due to the consequence he was wounding, but was very unlikely to recommend his suit.
vi: His awareness of her lower status – of the loss of dignity – and of the obstacles in the family that always opposed such feelings, was passionately presented by him; the passion seemed to stem more from being hurt than from the purpose of proposing.
tr: His thoughts on Elizabeth's lower status, the disgrace it brought, the family obstacles in the way, and how his mind had always opposed it were conveyed with a warmth that seemed more injurious to his own family position than likely to benefit his marriage proposal.
es: Elizabeth's inferiority, the degradation it meant for him, the family obstacles that good judgment had always made him prioritize over esteem. He spoke of these things with an ardor that reflected how much they hurt him, but all of it was not the most suitable to support his request.

en: In spite of her deeply-rooted dislike, she could not be insensible to the compliment of such a man’s affection, and though her intentions did not vary for an instant, she was at first sorry for the pain he was to receive; till roused to resentment by his subsequent language, she lost all compassion in anger.
vi: Although she harbored deep resentment, she couldn't remain indifferent when a man confessed his feelings in such a manner, and although her intentions never wavered, at first she regretted that he would suffer, until, offended by his subsequent words, in a fit of anger she lost all compassion.
tr: Despite the deep coldness she felt, Elizabeth couldn't remain indifferent to the pleasure of having won the love of such a man; although her intention had not changed for even a moment, she pitied him for the pain he was about to endure; but then, feeling disturbed by the language he used, all her pity vanished in anger.
es: Despite all the deeply rooted antipathy she had for him, Elizabeth could not remain indifferent to the manifestations of affection from a man like Darcy, and although her opinion did not change in the slightest, she was initially saddened by the disappointment he was going to experience; but the language he used afterward was so insulting that all compassion turned into anger.

en: She tried, however, to compose herself to answer him with patience, when he should have done.
vi: However, she tried to remain calm so she could patiently respond to him when he finished.
tr: Nevertheless, she tried to compose herself to be able to respond to him patiently when he finished speaking.
es: However, she tried to reply calmly when he finished speaking.

en: He concluded with representing to her the strength of that attachment which in spite of all his endeavours he had found impossible to conquer; and with expressing his hope that it would now be rewarded by her acceptance of his hand.
vi: He concluded by confessing to her the intense feelings he couldn't subdue despite numerous efforts, and he expressed hope that she might now reciprocate his affection.
tr: Mr. Darcy, despite all his efforts, concluded his speech by expressing the strength of the love he couldn't manage to forget, and his hope that his love would be reciprocated and his proposal accepted.
es: He concluded by assuring her of the firmness of his love which, despite all his efforts, he had not been able to overcome, and hoping that it would be rewarded with the acceptance of his hand.

en: As he said this she could easily see that he had no doubt of a favourable answer.
vi: As he said this, she could easily see that he was confident he would receive a satisfactory response.
tr: As he said these things, Elizabeth could easily see that he had no doubt he would receive a positive response.
es: By his manner of speaking, Elizabeth noticed that Darcy did not doubt that her response would be favorable.

en: He spoke of apprehension and anxiety, but his countenance expressed real security.
vi: He spoke of anxiety, but his face radiated genuine confidence.
tr: He spoke of anxiety and concern, but his face expressed genuine confidence.
es: He spoke of fears and anxiety, but his appearance revealed absolute certainty.

en: Such a circumstance could only exasperate farther; and when he ceased the colour rose into her cheeks and she said,—
vi: Such a situation only made her angrier, so when he stopped, her face flushed, and she said:
tr: This sight only increased her anger; when Mr. Darcy finished his words, Elizabeth, with her cheeks flushed, said,
es: This exasperated her even more, and when he finished, she replied with cheeks flushed with anger:

en: “In such cases as this, it is, I believe, the established mode to express a sense of obligation for the sentiments avowed, however unequally they may be returned.
vi: - I believe that in cases like this, the usual manner is to express appreciation for the sentiments that have been disclosed, even if the response is not reciprocal.
tr: "In situations like this, I believe it is customary to express a sense of obligation in response to confessed feelings, even if they cannot be reciprocated to the same extent.
es: ––In these cases, I believe it is customary to express some gratitude for the feelings expressed, even if they cannot be equally reciprocated.

en: It is natural that obligation should be felt, and if I could feel gratitude, I would now thank you.
vi: It is naturally necessary to be appreciative, and if my feelings were such, I could thank you now.
tr: It is natural to feel obligated; if I could feel gratitude, I would thank you now.
es: It is natural to feel this obligation, and if I felt gratitude, I would thank you.

en: But I cannot—I have never desired your good opinion, and you have certainly bestowed it most unwillingly.
vi: But I cannot thank you – I have never desired your affection, and you have bestowed it in the most reluctant manner.
tr: But I cannot – I never desired your kind feelings, and you expressed them quite reluctantly anyway.
es: But I cannot; I have never coveted your regard, and you have granted it very much against your will.

en: I am sorry to have occasioned pain to anyone.
vi: I am sorry if I have caused anyone any pain.
tr: I would not want to cause anyone pain.
es: I regret having hurt someone, but it was unconsciously, and I hope that hurt lasts a short time.

en: It has been most unconsciously done, however, and I hope will be of short duration.
vi: However, this was not intentional, and I hope it will pass quickly.
tr: It was something done thoughtlessly, and I hope it passes soon.
es: I regret having hurt someone, but it was unconsciously, and I hope that hurt lasts a short time.

en: The feelings which you tell me have long prevented the acknowledgment of your regard can have little difficulty in overcoming it after this explanation.”
vi: The emotions that, as you said, have long prevented you from acknowledging your feelings, can also be soothed without much difficulty after this explanation.
tr: The thoughts you said prevented you from accepting your feelings for a long time will not have much difficulty overcoming your feelings after this explanation."
es: The same feelings that, as you say, prevented you from revealing your intentions to me for so long will easily overcome that suffering.

en: mr Darcy, who was leaning against the mantel-piece with his eyes fixed on her face, seemed to catch her words with no less resentment than surprise.
vi: Mr. Darcy, standing by the fireplace with his eyes fixed intently on her face, seemed to receive her words with irritation rather than surprise.
tr: Mr. Darcy, who was leaning against the fireplace with his eyes fixed on Elizabeth's face, seemed to meet her words with as much confusion as distress.
es: Darcy, who was leaning against the mantelpiece with his eyes fixed on Elizabeth's face, seemed to receive her words with as much resentment as surprise.

en: His complexion became pale with anger, and the disturbance of his mind was visible in every feature.
vi: His face turned pale with anger, the turmoil in his mind clearly reflected in his every expression.
tr: His face paled with anger; it was evident in every line of his face that his mind was troubled.
es: His complexion paled with rage and all his features showed the disturbance of his mind.

en: He was struggling for the appearance of composure, and would not open his lips till he believed himself to have attained it.
vi: He was striving to appear calm, not wanting to speak until he had regained his composure.
tr: He struggled to control his appearance and did not open his mouth until he believed he had succeeded.
es: He struggled to maintain his composure and would not open his lips until he believed he had achieved it.

en: The pause was to Elizabeth’s feelings dreadful.
vi: The moment of silence made Elizabeth feel utterly bored.
tr: The silence was terrifying to Elizabeth.
es: This silence was terrible for Elizabeth.

en: At length, in a voice of forced calmness, he said,—
vi: Finally, in a voice that he tried to keep gentle, he said:
tr: Finally, Mr. Darcy said with forced calmness,
es: Finally, forcing his voice to appear calm, he said:

en: “And this is all the reply which I am to have the honour of expecting!
vi: - And here is the answer I have been honored to await!
tr: "The answer you granted is just this, clearly!
es: ––And is this the only response I will have the honor of expecting?

en: I might, perhaps, wish to be informed why, with so little endeavour at civility, I am thus rejected.
vi: Perhaps I want to know the reason why I was rejected with so little effort at courtesy like that.
tr: Maybe I'll have the chance to learn why I was rejected with such limited courtesy.
es: Perhaps I should ask why I am being rejected with such scant courtesy.

en: But it is of small importance.”
vi: But this matter is not very important.
tr: But it's not that important."
es: But it doesn't matter in the slightest.

en: “I might as well inquire,” replied she, “why, with so evident a design of offending and insulting me, you chose to tell me that you liked me against your will, against your reason, and even against your character?
vi: She replied: - And I also want to ask why, with such a clear intention to insult and humiliate me, you want to tell me that you go against your will, against your reason, even against your nature, to love me?
tr: "I might ask you this," replied Elizabeth, "why do you tell me that you love me against your will, your reason, and even your character, with such a clear sense of insult?
es: ––I could also ask, replied Elizabeth–– why, with such an evident purpose of offending and insulting me, you tell me that you like me against your will, against your better judgment, and even against your nature.

en: Was not this some excuse for incivility, if I was uncivil?
vi: Is this an excuse for being rude, if I have been rude?
tr: If I have acted rudely, isn't that a sufficient reason to behave rudely?
es: Isn't this an excuse for my lack of courtesy, if indeed I have committed it?

en: But I have other provocations.
vi: But I have other provocations.
tr: But I have other reasons as well.
es: But, moreover, I have received other provocations, you know that very well.

en: You know I have.
vi: You know that very well.
tr: You know I do.
es: But, moreover, I have received other provocations, you know that very well.

en: Had not my own feelings decided against you, had they been indifferent, or had they even been favourable, do you think that any consideration would tempt me to accept the man who has been the means of ruining, perhaps for ever, the happiness of a most beloved sister?”
vi: If my feelings were not opposed to you, if I had different feelings, or even favorable feelings, do you think that any consideration would lead me to accept a person who intended to destroy, perhaps for the rest of their life, the happiness of the sister I love the most?
tr: Do you think I would accept the man who perhaps forever ruined the happiness of my dearest sister, for any reason, if my feelings towards you were not negative, if they were indifferent, or even if they were positive?"
es: Even if my feelings had not been contrary to yours, even if they had been indifferent or even favorable, do you think there would be anything that could tempt me to accept the man who has been responsible for ruining, perhaps forever, the happiness of a very dear sister?

en: As she pronounced these words, mr Darcy changed colour; but the emotion was short, and he listened without attempting to interrupt her while she continued,—
vi: When she spoke these words, Mr. Darcy's complexion changed, but only momentarily. He listened to her without attempting to interrupt, while she continued:
tr: Upon hearing this, Mr. Darcy's color changed; but his discomfort quickly passed, and he listened to Elizabeth, who continued speaking, without intervening.
es: Upon hearing these words, Darcy changed color; but the shock was fleeting and he continued listening without any intention of interrupting her.

en: “I have every reason in the world to think ill of you.
vi: - I have every reason in the world to think ill of you.
tr: "I have every reason to think badly of you.
