es: ––I have every reason in the world to have a poor opinion of you ––continued Elizabeth––.

en: No motive can excuse the unjust and ungenerous part you acted there.
vi: No motivation can justify the unfair and narrow-minded role you have displayed here.
tr: No explanation can excuse the unfair and cruel role you played there.
es: There is nothing that can excuse your unjust and vile conduct.

en: You dare not, you cannot deny that you have been the principal, if not the only means of dividing them from each other, of exposing one to the censure of the world for caprice and instability, the other to its derision for disappointed hopes, and involving them both in misery of the acutest kind.”
vi: You dare not deny, you cannot deny, that you are the key person, if not the only one, who has in the cruelest way separated two people, exposing one to the world's criticism for being fickle and inconsistent, exposing the other to public ridicule for shattered aspirations, and causing both to suffer.
tr: Even if you were not alone in separating them, you cannot deny that you played the leading role, you made one fall from grace by calling them spoiled and unstable, and you made the other a subject of ridicule for having false hopes, forcing both into severe misery."
es: You will not dare to deny that you were the main, if not the only, cause of the separation between Mr. Bingley and my sister, exposing one to the censure of people for being capricious and fickle, and the other to ridicule for her failed hopes, plunging both into the greatest misfortune.

en: She paused, and saw with no slight indignation that he was listening with an air which proved him wholly unmoved by any feeling of remorse.
vi: She stopped and saw, along with the initial resentment, that he was listening with an expression that showed he had no intention of regretting.
tr: She saw that he was listening with an air that showed he felt not the slightest bit of remorse, and she became angry again.
es: She paused and saw, indignantly, that Darcy was listening to her with an air that indicated he was not at all moved by any kind of remorse.

en: He even looked at her with a smile of affected incredulity.
vi: He even looked at her with a smile that expressed skepticism in his emotions.
tr: Mr. Darcy, on the contrary, was looking at her with a smile of feigned disbelief.
es: He even looked at her with a smile of petulant disbelief.

en: “Can you deny that you have done it?” she repeated.
vi: She repeated: - Can you deny that you did that?
tr: "Can you deny what you have done?" he repeated.
es: ––Can you deny that you have done this? ––she repeated.

en: With assumed tranquillity he then replied, “I have no wish of denying that I did everything in my power to separate my friend from your sister, or that I rejoice in my success.
vi: He replied, seeming calm: - I do not intend to deny that I did everything within my power to separate my friend from her sister, or deny that I was pleased to have succeeded.
tr: Then Mr. Darcy replied with a feigned calmness, "I will not deny that I did everything in my power to separate my friend from your sister, and that I am pleased with my success.
es: Pretending to be calm, Darcy replied: ––I must not deny that I did everything in my power to separate my friend from his sister, nor that I am glad of the result.

en: Towards him I have been kinder than towards myself.”
vi: I was kinder to him than to myself.
tr: I was more careful with my friend than I was with myself."
es: I have been kinder to him than to myself.

en: Elizabeth disdained the appearance of noticing this civil reflection, but its meaning did not escape, nor was it likely to conciliate her.
vi: Elizabeth despised the outward appearance of this manner of polite criticism, but she still grasped its essential meaning and did not wish to conform to it.
tr: Elizabeth could not bring herself to appear to have noticed this kind-hearted thought, but its meaning did not escape her; besides, it was impossible to appease her.
es: Elizabeth disdained to appear as if she noticed that subtle reflection, but its meaning did not escape her, and she could not reconcile it.

en: “But it is not merely this affair,” she continued, “on which my dislike is founded.
vi: She continued: - But it is not just this matter that makes me hate you.
tr: "But the reason I dislike you is not just this matter," he continued; "my opinion of you was formed long before this.
es: ––But my antipathy is not only based on this ––continued Elizabeth.

en: Long before it had taken place, my opinion of you was decided.
vi: Long before this, I already had thoughts about you in such a manner.
tr: "But the reason I dislike you is not just this matter," he continued; "my opinion of you was formed long before this.
es: My opinion of you was formed long before this matter took place.

en: Your character was unfolded in the recital which I received many months ago from mr Wickham.
vi: Many months ago, Mr. Wickham told me about your true nature.
tr: The story I heard from Mr. Wickham months ago revealed your character clearly.
es: Your character was revealed by a story Mr. Wickham told me a few months ago.

en: On this subject, what can you have to say?
vi: Regarding this matter, what can you say?
tr: What do you have to say about this?
es: What can you say to this?

en: In what imaginary act of friendship can you here defend yourself?
vi: How can you defend yourself by imagining a friendly act?
tr: With what imaginary act of friendship can you defend yourself?
es: With what fictitious act of friendship can you defend yourself now?

en: or under what misrepresentation can you here impose upon others?”
vi: Or how do you wish to distort the truth for others to hear?
tr: Or with what unfounded words can you deceive others?"
es: With what falsehood can you justify your dominance over others in this case?

en: “You take an eager interest in that gentleman’s concerns,” said Darcy, in a less tranquil tone, and with a heightened colour.
vi: Darcy said in a less amiable tone, his face reddening further:
tr: "You are quite interested in those brain matters," said Darcy in a less calm tone of voice, his color deepening further.
es: ––You are very keenly interested in what affects that gentleman ––said Darcy in a less calm tone, his face flushed.

en: “Who that knows what his misfortunes have been can help feeling an interest in him?”
vi: - She has been too concerned about his problems. - If you know about his misfortunes, who wouldn't care?
tr: "No one who hears about the misfortune he suffered can remain indifferent to him."
es: ––Who, knowing the hardships he has endured, can avoid feeling interest in him?

en: “His misfortunes!” repeated Darcy, contemptuously,—“yes, his misfortunes have been great indeed.”
vi: Darcy scorned: - His misfortunes! Yes, his misfortunes are truly great.
tr: "Misfortune!" repeated Darcy with disdain; "yes, she has indeed encountered great misfortune."
es: ––"The hardships he has endured!" exclaimed Darcy disdainfully––. "Yes, truly, immense hardships..." ––It's your fault!

en: “And of your infliction,” cried Elizabeth, with energy; “You have reduced him to his present state of poverty—comparative poverty.
vi: Elizabeth shouted loudly: - And you caused it. You have driven him into his current state of misery, misery in a relative sense.
tr: "You are the reason," cried Elizabeth excitedly. "You pushed him into this poverty, relatively speaking, into poverty.
es: ––exclaimed Elizabeth energetically––. You reduced him to his current relative poverty.

en: You have withheld the advantages which you must know to have been designed for him.
vi: You have taken hold of all the rights that you should have known were arranged for him.
tr: You deprived him of the opportunities you knew he left for.
es: You denied him the future that, as you well know, was destined for him.

en: You have deprived the best years of his life of that independence which was no less his due than his desert.
vi: You have taken away the best years of his life, the independent life that he should have enjoyed.
tr: You took away the best years of his life, the chance for the freedom he deserved.
es: In the best years of his life, you deprived him of an independence to which he not only had a right but also deserved.

en: You have done all this!
vi: You did all these things!
tr: You did all this!
es: You did all this!

en: and yet you can treat the mention of his misfortunes with contempt and ridicule.”
vi: And on top of that, you scorn and mock when people mention his misfortunes.
tr: And now you mock his misfortune."
es: And you are still capable of ridiculing and mocking his sorrows...

en: “And this,” cried Darcy, as he walked with quick steps across the room, “is your opinion of me!
vi: Darcy exclaimed, as he paced quickly around the room:
tr: "So, this is it," cried Darcy as he paced the room briskly, "so this is what you think of me!
es: ––And that is –– shouted Darcy as he paced the room like a whirlwind –– the opinion you have of me!

en: This is the estimation in which you hold me!
vi: - So that's what you think of me! That's how you judge me!
tr: So this is how you see me!
es: This is the esteem in which you hold me!

en: I thank you for explaining it so fully.
vi: Thank you for explaining it thoroughly.
tr: Thank you for explaining it so thoroughly.
es: I thank you for explaining it to me so openly.

en: My faults, according to this calculation, are heavy indeed!
vi: According to that reasoning, my faults are indeed severe!
tr: According to this account, my faults are indeed great!
es: My faults, according to your calculation, are truly enormous.

en: But, perhaps,” added he, stopping in his walk, and turning towards her, “these offences might have been overlooked, had not your pride been hurt by my honest confession of the scruples that had long prevented my forming any serious design.
vi: He stopped walking and turned to look at her: - But perhaps these faults would have been overlooked if her pride had not been hurt by my sincere confession of the long-standing hesitations that had prevented me from having serious intentions.
tr: Perhaps," he added, turning towards her, "these insults could have been overlooked, but your pride was wounded because I honestly confessed the concerns that have long prevented me from making a serious attempt.
es: But perhaps ––he added, stopping and turning towards her–– these offenses would have been overlooked if I had not wounded your pride with my honest confession of the reservations that for a long time prevented me from making a decision.

en: These bitter accusations might have been suppressed, had I, with greater policy, concealed my struggles, and flattered you into the belief of my being impelled by unqualified, unalloyed inclination; by reason, by reflection, by everything.
vi: These bitter accusations would have been restrained if I had tried harder to conceal the struggles within my soul, to make her complacently believe that I had been driven by unburdened, pure emotions; by reason, by recollection, by everything.
tr: If I had concealed my struggle with a finer strategy, flattering your pride with reason, logic, and everything, making you believe I was a captive of an indescribable, pure passion, these bitter accusations might have been dismissed.
es: I would have spared myself these bitter accusations if I had been more skillful and had hidden my struggle, flattering you by making you believe that I had taken this step driven by reason, by reflection, by an unconditional and pure inclination, by whatever.

en: But disguise of every sort is my abhorrence.
vi: But I hate concealing anything.
tr: But I despise every kind of falsehood.
es: But I abhor all kinds of deceit and I am not ashamed of the feelings I have expressed, they were natural and just.

en: Nor am I ashamed of the feelings I related.
vi: And I am not ashamed of the feelings I have confessed.
tr: Moreover, I am not ashamed of the feelings I have expressed.
es: But I abhor all kinds of deceit and I am not ashamed of the feelings I have expressed, they were natural and just.

en: They were natural and just.
vi: These feelings are natural and legitimate.
tr: Because they are natural and justified feelings.
es: But I abhor all kinds of deceit and I am not ashamed of the feelings I have expressed, they were natural and just.

en: Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your connections?—to congratulate myself on the hope of relations whose condition in life is so decidedly beneath my own?”
vi: Could she expect me to be happy in a lower position in relation to her? To expect me to congratulate myself on the hopes of relatives who are entirely lower in status than I am?
tr: Can you expect me to take pleasure in the low status of your relatives? Should I congratulate myself for having kin whose positions in life are so far below mine?"
es: How could you suppose that I would be pleased by the inferiority of your family and that I would congratulate myself on the prospect of having relatives whose condition is so far below mine?

en: Elizabeth felt herself growing more angry every moment; yet she tried to the utmost to speak with composure when she said,—
vi: Elizabeth felt increasingly angry, but she tried her best to remain calm as she said:
tr: Elizabeth felt herself becoming even angrier; nevertheless, she made a great effort to control herself while speaking:
es: Elizabeth's irritation grew with each passing moment; even so, she tried with all her might to speak calmly when she said:

en: “You are mistaken, mr Darcy, if you suppose that the mode of your declaration affected me in any other way than as it spared me the concern which I might have felt in refusing you, had you behaved in a more gentlemanlike manner.”
vi: - You were mistaken, Mr. Darcy, if you thought that the manner of your proposal would affect me in any way other than one: I might have felt concern for you when I rejected you, had you behaved in a more gentlemanly manner.
tr: "If you think that making your proposal in another manner would have affected me, you are mistaken, Mr. Darcy; by not behaving more gentlemanly, you have only spared me from worrying whether you were hurt because I rejected you."
es: ––You are mistaken, Mr. Darcy, if you suppose that what affected me was your manner of proposing; if you imagine that you would have spared me the unpleasant task of rejecting you had you behaved in a more gentlemanlike manner.

en: She saw him start at this; but he said nothing, and she continued,—
vi: She saw him seem to startle, but he remained silent. She continued:
tr: She saw that Darcy flinched at these words but did not respond, and she continued,
es: Elizabeth realized that she was about to be interrupted, but she said nothing and continued:

en: “You could not have made me the offer of your hand in any possible way that would have tempted me to accept it.”
vi: - You cannot confess your feelings to me in any other way to try to make me accept you.
tr: "There was no way to make me accept the hand you extended.""
es: ––You could not have offered me your hand in any way that would have tempted me to accept it.

en: Again his astonishment was obvious; and he looked at her with an expression of mingled incredulity and mortification.
vi: Once again, it was clear that he was stunned. He looked at her with a face that was both incredulous and embarrassed.
tr: Once again, his astonishment was evident; he was looking at her with a mixture of disbelief and humiliation.
es: Once again, his astonishment was obvious.

en: She went on,—
vi: She continued:
tr: Elizabeth continued.
es: He looked at her with an expression of disbelief and humiliation at the same time, and she continued speaking:

en: “From the very beginning, from the first moment, I may almost say, of my acquaintance with you, your manners impressing me with the fullest belief of your arrogance, your conceit, and your selfish disdain of the feelings of others, were such as to form that groundwork of disapprobation, on which succeeding events have built so immovable a dislike; and I had not known you a month before I felt that you were the last man in the world whom I could ever be prevailed on to marry.”
vi: - Right from the beginning, it can almost be said that from the moment I first met him, his attitude made an impression on me that allowed me to clearly understand his arrogance, his haughtiness, and his despicable selfishness towards the feelings of others, to the point that this was the basis for my rejection of him. Then, subsequent events only made me hate him even more intensely, and in less than a month of knowing him, I thought he was the last person on earth I would want to marry.
tr: "From the very beginning, almost from the first moment I saw you, your demeanor convinced me that you were an arrogant, conceited person who selfishly disregarded the feelings of others. That is how my anger towards you was born, and it turned into a severe discontent with subsequent events; it hadn't even been a month since I got to know you when I felt that even if you were the last man on earth, no force could persuade me to marry you.""
es: ––From the beginning, almost from the first moment I met him, his manners convinced me of his arrogance, his vanity, and his selfish disdain for the feelings of others; they disgusted me so much that they gave rise to the disapproval that subsequent events turned into firm dislike; and it wasn't even a month since I had known him when I realized that you would be the last man on earth I could marry.

en: “You have said quite enough, madam.
vi: - You have said enough.
tr: "You have spoken enough, madam.
es: ––You have said enough, miss.

en: I perfectly comprehend your feelings, and have now only to be ashamed of what my own have been.
vi: I completely understand your feelings, now I only feel ashamed of my previous thoughts.
tr: I understand your feelings very well; now I must only be ashamed of my own feelings.
es: I perfectly understand your feelings and I can only be ashamed of my own.

en: Forgive me for having taken up so much of your time, and accept my best wishes for your health and happiness.”
vi: Forgive me for taking up so much of your time, and please accept my best wishes for your health and happiness.
tr: Forgive me for taking up so much of your time and accept my wishes for health and happiness."
es: Forgive me for having made you waste so much time, and accept my best wishes for your health and happiness.

en: And with these words he hastily left the room, and Elizabeth heard him the next moment open the front door and quit the house.
vi: He hurriedly stepped out of the room, and in a moment, Elizabeth heard him open the door and go outside.
tr: And with these words, he hurriedly left the room; shortly after, Elizabeth heard him open the front door and leave the house.
es: Having said this, he hurriedly left the room, and Elizabeth immediately heard him open the front door and leave the house.

en: The tumult of her mind was now painfully great.
vi: Her mind was now in turmoil and intense pain.
tr: The storm in her mind had increased to a painful extent.
es: The confusion of her mind made her suffer intensely.

en: She knew not how to support herself, and, from actual weakness, sat down and cried for half an hour.
vi: She did not know how to pull herself together; in her weakness, she sat down and cried for half an hour.
tr: She didn't know how to stand and, in complete exhaustion, sat down and cried for half an hour.
es: She could not stand and had to sit down because her legs were giving way. She cried for half an hour.

en: Her astonishment, as she reflected on what had passed, was increased by every review of it.
vi: The more she thought back on each past event, the more astonished she became.
tr: As she thought about what had happened, every image increased her astonishment.
es: Her astonishment at recalling what had happened grew more and more.

en: That she should receive an offer of marriage from mr Darcy!
vi: She had heard a proposal from Mr. Darcy!
tr: To receive a marriage proposal from Mr. Darcy!
es: Having received a marriage proposal from Darcy, who had been in love with her for so many months, and so in love that he wanted to marry her despite all the objections that had led him to prevent his friend from marrying Jane, and which should have applied equally in his own case, was incredible.

en: that he should have been in love with her for so many months!
vi: He had loved her for many months!
tr: for him to be in love with her for so many months!
es: Having received a marriage proposal from Darcy, who had been in love with her for so many months, and so in love that he wanted to marry her despite all the objections that had led him to prevent his friend from marrying Jane, and which should have applied equally in his own case, was incredible.

en: so much in love as to wish to marry her in spite of all the objections which had made him prevent his friend’s marrying her sister, and which must appear at least with equal force in his own case, was almost incredible!
vi: He had loved her so passionately that he wanted to marry her despite all the opposition that had led him to prevent his friend from marrying her sister! And the opposition was just as strong in his own case. It was almost unbelievable!
tr: for him to want to marry her despite all the obstacles that led him to prevent his friend from marrying her sister, obstacles that were equally valid for his own situation, it was unbelievable!
es: Having received a marriage proposal from Darcy, who had been in love with her for so many months, and so in love that he wanted to marry her despite all the objections that had led him to prevent his friend from marrying Jane, and which should have applied equally in his own case, was incredible.

en: it was gratifying to have inspired unconsciously so strong an affection.
vi: It was exhilarating to have unconsciously sparked such a passionate love.
tr: To have unknowingly inspired such a strong love was an honor.
es: She was pleased to have inspired such a vehement affection.

en: But his pride, his abominable pride, his shameless avowal of what he had done with respect to Jane, his unpardonable assurance in acknowledging, though he could not justify it, and the unfeeling manner which he had mentioned mr Wickham, his cruelty towards whom he had not attempted to deny, soon overcame the pity which the consideration of his attachment had for a moment excited.
vi: But his pride – his despicable pride, his shameless admission of how he treated Jane – his unforgivable confidence even if he could not justify it, and his indifference when he mentioned Mr. Wickham – his cruel actions towards him which he did not bother to deny, all exceeded her compassion when she thought of his feelings.
tr: But Darcy's pride, that disgusting pride, his shameless confession of what he did regarding Jane, his unforgivable arrogance in accepting it even though he couldn't justify himself, and his callous demeanor when speaking of Mr. Wickham, the cruelty he did not deny towards him, soon destroyed the feeling of pity that thinking about his love had momentarily created.
es: But the pride, his abominable pride, his shameless confession of what he had done to Jane, his unforgivable brazenness in admitting it without even trying to excuse himself, and the insensitivity with which he had spoken of Wickham despite not denying his cruelty towards him, soon prevailed over the compassion she had felt when thinking about his love.

en: She continued in very agitating reflections till the sound of Lady Catherine’s carriage made her feel how unequal she was to encounter Charlotte’s observation, and hurried her away to her room.
vi: She continued to reminisce in her agitated thoughts until the sound of Lady Catherine's carriage made her think she could not hide from Charlotte's watchful eyes, and hurriedly ran back to her room.
tr: He continued with the thoughts that shook his heart until he realized, with the noise of Lady Catherine's carriage, that he was in no state to face Charlotte and hurried to his room.
es: She remained immersed in her agitated thoughts until the noise of Lady Catherine's carriage made her realize that she was not in a condition to meet Charlotte, and she ran up to her room.

en: “Hearing herself called.”
vi: She continued to reminisce in her agitated thoughts until the sound of Lady Catherine's carriage made her think she could not hide from Charlotte's watchful eyes, and hurriedly ran back to her room.
tr: He continued with the thoughts that shook his heart until he realized, with the noise of Lady Catherine's carriage, that he was in no state to face Charlotte and hurried to his room.
es: She remained immersed in her agitated thoughts until the noise of Lady Catherine's carriage made her realize that she was not in a condition to meet Charlotte, and she ran up to her room.

en: CHAPTER XXXV.
vi: Chapter 35
tr: Chapter XII
es: CHAPTER XXXV

en: ELIZABETH awoke the next morning to the same thoughts and meditations which had at length closed her eyes.
vi: Elizabeth woke up the next morning with the same thoughts and reflections as when she had fallen asleep.
tr: The next morning, Elizabeth woke up with the same feelings and thoughts she had when she last closed her eyes.
es: Elizabeth woke up the next morning with the same thoughts and reflections she had fallen asleep with.

en: She could not yet recover from the surprise of what had happened: it was impossible to think of anything else; and, totally indisposed for employment, she resolved soon after breakfast to indulge herself in air and exercise.
vi: She had not yet recovered from the astonishment of what had happened; she could not think of anything else. Unable to accomplish anything, after breakfast, she decided to get some fresh air and exercise.
tr: She had not yet recovered from the impact of what had happened; it was impossible to think of anything else; she also did not feel like engaging in any activity, so she decided to entertain herself by taking a walk in the open air right after breakfast.
es: She couldn't recover from the surprise of what had happened; it was impossible for her to think of anything else. Unable to do anything, as soon as she had breakfast, she decided to go out to get some fresh air and exercise.

en: She was proceeding directly to her favourite walk, when the recollection of mr Darcy’s sometimes coming there stopped her, and instead of entering the park, she turned up the lane which led her farther from the turnpike road.
vi: She went straight to the path she loved, where memories of Mr. Darcy occasionally stopped her, and instead of entering the garden, she turned onto the path that led her further away from the main road.
tr: She was heading straight to her favorite path when she remembered that Mr. Darcy sometimes came there, so she stopped and, instead of entering the grove, went up the path and moved away from the main road.
es: She was heading directly towards her favorite walk when she remembered that Darcy sometimes went there; she stopped and instead of entering the estate, she took another path in the opposite direction to the street where the toll gate was, which was still bordered by the Rosings' fence, and soon passed by one of the gates that gave access to the estate.

en: The park paling was still the boundary on one side, and she soon passed one of the gates into the ground.
vi: The garden fence still marked the boundary on one side, and soon she passed through one of the gates leading to the open field.
tr: The grove fences still marked a boundary on one side; shortly after, she passed through one of the gates and entered the field.
es: She was heading directly towards her favorite walk when she remembered that Darcy sometimes went there; she stopped and instead of entering the estate, she took another path in the opposite direction to the street where the toll gate was, which was still bordered by the Rosings' fence, and soon passed by one of the gates that gave access to the estate.

en: After walking two or three times along that part of the lane, she was tempted, by the pleasantness of the morning, to stop at the gates and look into the park.
vi: After having walked two or three times along this section of the trail, the pleasant morning weather made her stop in front of the gates and linger in the garden.
tr: After walking along that part of the path two or three times, he felt the urge to stop at the door and watch the grove, captivated by the beauty of the morning.
es: After walking up and down that part of the road two or three times, he felt the temptation, given how delightful the morning was, to stop at the gates and gaze at the estate.

en: The five weeks which she had now passed in Kent had made a great difference in the country, and every day was adding to the verdure of the early trees.
vi: The five weeks she had spent in Kent had changed the scenery significantly, with the trees becoming greener each day.
tr: The five weeks he had spent in the city had changed many things in nature; each new day was increasing the greenness of the blossoming trees.
es: The five weeks he had spent in Kent had greatly transformed the countryside, and each day the early trees grew greener.

en: She was on the point of continuing her walk, when she caught a glimpse of a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park: he was moving that way; and fearful of its being mr Darcy, she was directly retreating.
vi: She was about to continue walking when she caught a glimpse of a young man in the bushes along the edge of the garden; he was walking towards her. Fearing it was Mr. Darcy, she turned back.
tr: As he was about to continue his walk, he caught sight of a man in the wooded area along the edge of the grove; the man was coming towards him; fearing it might be Mr. Darcy, he immediately turned back.
es: He was about to continue his walk when he glimpsed a gentleman in the avenue bordering the estate; the gentleman was walking towards her, and Elizabeth, fearing it was Darcy, instantly retreated.

en: But the person who advanced was now near enough to see her, and stepping forward with eagerness, pronounced her name.
vi: But the man had come close enough to recognize her, quickly approached, and called her name.
tr: But the approaching man was now close enough to see him and excitedly rushed forward, calling out his name.
es: But the person advancing was already close enough to see her; he continued walking quickly and called her name.

en: She had turned away; but on hearing herself called, though in a voice which proved it to be mr Darcy, she moved again towards the gate.
vi: She had turned away, but upon hearing her name, even in Mr. Darcy's voice, she turned back towards the gate.
tr: Elizabeth had turned the other way, but upon hearing herself being called, she continued walking towards the door, even though she recognized Mr. Darcy's voice.
es: She had turned, but upon hearing that voice in which she recognized Darcy, she continued towards the gate.

en: He had by that time reached it also; and, holding out a letter, which she instinctively took, said, with a look of haughty composure, “I have been walking in the grove some time, in the hope of meeting you.
vi: At that moment, he also reached the gate, handed her a letter which she reflexively accepted, and spoke with an arrogant demeanor: - I took a walk through some bushes hoping to meet you.
tr: Mr. Darcy caught up with her at the door and handed her a letter, and as Elizabeth instinctively took the letter, he said with a haughty solemnity, "I was walking in the grove hoping to meet you.
es: The gentleman caught up with her and, showing her a letter which she instinctively took, said to her with a haughty look: ––I have been strolling through the promenade for a while hoping to find you.

en: Will you do me the honour of reading that letter?” and then, with a slight bow, turned again into the plantation, and was soon out of sight.
vi: Could you do me the honor of reading this letter? And then, gently bowing his head in greeting, he walked towards the plantation; before long, he disappeared.
tr: Would you be so kind as to read this letter?" –Then he bowed slightly, turned, disappeared among the trees, and was out of sight.
es: Will you grant me the honor of reading this letter? And then, with a slight inclination, he headed back towards the plantations and soon disappeared from sight.

en: With no expectation of pleasure, but with the strongest curiosity, Elizabeth opened the letter, and to her still increasing wonder, perceived an envelope containing two sheets of letter paper, written quite through, in a very close hand.
vi: Not expecting any joy but with the greatest curiosity, Elizabeth opened the letter, and with increasing bewilderment, she found that the envelope contained two sheets of densely written paper.
tr: Without any expectation of satisfaction, but with a strong curiosity, Elizabeth opened the letter and saw with increasing astonishment that the envelope contained two sheets of letter paper filled with cramped handwriting.
es: Without expecting any pleasure, but with great curiosity, Elizabeth opened the letter, and her astonishment grew as she saw that the envelope contained two sheets completely written in very tight handwriting.

en: The envelope itself was likewise full.
vi: Even the envelope itself was quite thick.
tr: –The envelope itself was also similarly filled.
es: Even the envelope was written on.

en: Pursuing her way along the lane, she then began it.
vi: As she walked along the path, she began to read.
tr: –She began to read the letter as she walked along the path.
es: Continuing her walk along the path, she began to read it.

en: It was dated from Rosings, at eight o’clock in the morning, and was as follows:—
vi: The letter was dated from Rosings, at eight o'clock in the morning, and read as follows:
tr: It was written at eight o'clock in the morning at Rosings, and it said: –
es: It was dated at Rosings at eight in the morning and said the following:

en: “Be not alarmed, madam, on receiving this letter, by the apprehension of its containing any repetition of those sentiments, or renewal of those offers, which were last night so disgusting to you.
vi: “Dear Miss, you should not panic upon receiving this letter for fear that it reiterates the sentiments or pleads once more, all of which disgusted you last night.
tr: "When you receive this letter, Madam, do not be alarmed thinking that he repeated the confessions that were so repulsive to you last night or renewed those proposals.
es: Do not be alarmed, miss, upon receiving this letter, nor believe that I am going to repeat my feelings or renew the propositions that bothered you so much last night.

en: I write without any intention of paining you, or humbling myself, by dwelling on wishes, which, for the happiness of both, cannot be too soon forgotten; and the effort which the formation and the perusal of this letter must occasion, should have been spared, had not my character required it to be written and read.
vi: I write without the intention of causing you sorrow, nor with the intent of humbling myself by clinging to an unforgettably early desire, a desire for happiness for both of us. There would be no need to make the effort to write and read this letter if it were not necessary to express and understand my character.
tr: I am not writing with the intention of causing you pain by dwelling on wishes that should be forgotten as soon as possible for the happiness of both of us, nor to demean myself; my respectability required that this letter be written and read, but it would not be worth the effort to write or read it.
es: I write with no intention of distressing you nor of humiliating myself by insisting on desires that, for the happiness of both, cannot be forgotten so easily; the effort of writing and reading this letter could have been avoided if my nature did not compel me to write it and you to read it.

en: You must, therefore, pardon the freedom with which I demand your attention; your feelings, I know, will bestow it unwillingly, but I demand it of your justice.
vi: Therefore, you should forgive me for presumptuously demanding your attention. I know your sentiments will pay attention reluctantly, but I demand your attention due to your fair attitude.
tr: Therefore, you must excuse my audacity in seeking your attention; I know your feelings will reluctantly respond to my request, but I make this appeal relying on your sense of justice.
es: Therefore, forgive me for taking the liberty of requesting your attention; although I know you will grant it reluctantly, I ask for it in fairness.

en: “Two offences of a very different nature, and by no means of equal magnitude, you last night laid to my charge.
vi: "Last night you accused me of two charges of entirely different nature and unequal magnitude.
tr: "Last night, you accused me of two evils of very different natures and varying degrees of importance.
es: Yesterday you accused me of two offenses of very different nature and magnitude.

en: The first mentioned was, that, regardless of the sentiments of either, I had detached mr Bingley from your sister,—and the other, that I had, in defiance of various claims, in defiance of honour and humanity, ruined the immediate prosperity and blasted the prospects of mr Wickham.
vi: The first charge is that, regardless of the feelings of each party, I separated Mr. Bingley from your sister; the other charge is that I ruined Mr. Wickham's immediate prosperity and shattered all his prospects, in defiance of all appeals, in defiance of honor and humanity.
tr: The first was that I separated Mr. Bingley from your sister without regard for either of their feelings, and the second was that I hindered Mr. Wickham's prosperity and darkened his future by rejecting various claims, disregarding honor and humanity.
es: The first was having separated Mr. Bingley from his sister, without consideration for the feelings of either; and the other, that despite certain rights and ignoring honor and humanity, I ruined Mr. Wickham's immediate prosperity and destroyed his future.

en: Wilfully and wantonly to have thrown off the companion of my youth, the acknowledged favourite of my father, a young man who had scarcely any other dependence than on our patronage, and who had been brought up to expect its exertion, would be a depravity, to which the separation of two young persons whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks, could bear no comparison.
vi: Deliberately and obstinately denying the friend of my youth, whom my father loved, a young man who had no other refuge than our patronage, who was raised to fend for himself. This is an unparalleled vile act, separating two young men whose affection could blossom in just a few weeks.
tr: –To deliberately and irresponsibly cast aside a childhood friend, known to be my father's favorite, who had no means of subsistence outside our protection and was raised to expect to benefit from our patronage, would have been a deprivation incomparable to the separation of children with only a few weeks of shared feelings.
es: To have abandoned ruthlessly and intentionally the companion of my youth and my father's favorite, a young man who had almost no other future than that of our rectory and who had been educated for its practice, would be a depravity that could not be compared to the separation of two young people whose affection had been the result of only a few weeks.

en: But from the severity of that blame which was last night so liberally bestowed, respecting each circumstance, I shall hope to be in future secured, when the following account of my actions and their motives has been read.
vi: “But from the severe condemnation declared so liberally last evening, for each case, I hope in the future you will believe me, if you read through the explanations below about my behavior and motivations.
tr: –But when the following explanation of my actions and reasons is read, I hope to be spared from the severity of the accusations so unreservedly directed at me last night in both matters.
es: But I hope you will withdraw the severe censure you so openly directed at me last night, when you have read the following account of my actions regarding these two circumstances and their motives.

en: If, in the explanation of them which is due to myself, I am under the necessity of relating feelings which may be offensive to yours, I can only say that I am sorry.
vi: If while explaining, I mention feelings that might upset you, I can only ask for your forgiveness.
tr: –If I feel compelled to explain emotions that may seem repulsive to you while doing so, I can only apologize for it.
es: If in the explanation that I cannot help but give, I am forced to express feelings that offend you, I can only say that I regret it.

en: The necessity must be obeyed, and further apology would be absurd.
vi: But I need to mention them, and if further apologies are unreasonable.
tr: –I must comply with this obligation –to apologize further would be absurd.
es: One must submit to necessity and any apology would be absurd.

en: I had not been long in Hertfordshire before I saw, in common with others, that Bingley preferred your elder sister to any other young woman in the country.
vi: “When I first came to reside at Netherfield, like everyone else, I noticed that Mr. Bingley had more affection for your eldest sister than for any other young woman in the area.
tr: –It wasn't long after I arrived in Hertfordshire that I, like others, saw that Bingley preferred your sister over all the other girls in the countryside.
es: It wasn't long after I arrived in Hertfordshire that I noticed, like everyone else, that Mr. Bingley favored your eldest sister much more than any of the other young ladies in the locality; but until the night of the Netherfield ball, I did not see that his affection was formal.

en: But it was not till the evening of the dance at Netherfield that I had any apprehension of his feeling a serious attachment.
vi: But it was only at the Netherfield ball that I realized the seriousness of his feelings.
tr: But it wasn't until the dance evening at Netherfield that I realized he had serious attachment.
es: It wasn't long after I arrived in Hertfordshire that I noticed, like everyone else, that Mr. Bingley favored your eldest sister much more than any of the other young ladies in the locality; but until the night of the Netherfield ball, I did not see that his affection was formal.

en: I had often seen him in love before.
vi: I have often seen him in love before.
tr: –I had seen him in love many times before.
es: I had seen him in love several times before.

en: At that ball, while I had the honour of dancing with you, I was first made acquainted, by Sir William Lucas’s accidental information, that Bingley’s attentions to your sister had given rise to a general expectation of their marriage.
vi: At that ball, while I had the honor of dancing with you, for the first time through Sir William Lucas, I learned that Mr. Bingley's attentions to your sister had raised hopes of a marriage between the two.
tr: –At that ball, while I was dancing with you, a casual remark by Sir William Lucas made me realize for the first time that Bingley's interest in your sister had created expectations of marriage in everyone.
es: At that ball, while I had the honor of dancing with you, I learned for the first time, through a casual remark from Sir William Lucas, that Bingley's attentions towards your sister had given rise to hopes of marriage; he spoke of it as a settled matter with only the date to be fixed.

en: He spoke of it as a certain event, of which the time alone could be undecided.
vi: He spoke of it as if it were a certainty, with only the date and time yet to be determined.
tr: Sir William spoke of it as if it were a certain event, with only the date left to be determined.
es: At that ball, while I had the honor of dancing with you, I learned for the first time, through a casual remark from Sir William Lucas, that Bingley's attentions towards your sister had given rise to hopes of marriage; he spoke of it as a settled matter with only the date to be fixed.

en: From that moment I observed my friend’s behaviour attentively; and I could then perceive that his partiality for Miss Bennet was beyond what I had ever witnessed in him.
vi: “From that moment, I paid close attention to my friend's behavior, and noticed that Bingley's feelings towards your sister exceeded anything I had ever witnessed in him.
tr: From that moment, I observed my friend's actions carefully; and it was only then that I understood his attachment to Miss Bennet was beyond what I had seen before.
es: From that moment, I carefully observed my friend's behavior and noticed that his inclination towards Miss Bennet was greater than any he had felt before.

en: Your sister I also watched.
vi: I also observed your sister.
tr: I also watched your sister.
es: I also studied your sister.

en: Her look and manners were open, cheerful, and engaging as ever, but without any symptom of peculiar regard; and I remained convinced, from the evening’s scrutiny, that though she received his attentions with pleasure, she did not invite them by any participation of sentiment.
vi: Her demeanor and gestures remained open, cheerful, and graceful as always, but there was no particular sign of affection, and after a thorough examination that evening, I believed that although she was happy to be noticed by him, she did not invite his attention by revealing any sentiments.
tr: –Her demeanor was as open, cheerful, and charming as ever, but there were no signs of special interest; from my observations that evening, I concluded that while Miss Bennet accepted Bingley's interest with pleasure, she did not invite it with any shared feelings.
es: Her appearance and manners were as frank, cheerful, and attractive as ever, but they did not reveal any particular regard. My observations that evening left me convinced that, despite the pleasure with which she received my friend's attentions, she did not reciprocate his feelings.

en: If you have not been mistaken here, I must have been in an error.
vi: If you are not mistaken here, I could be mistaken.
tr: –If you are not mistaken on this point, then I was wrong.
es: If you were not mistaken about this, then I must have been in error.

en: Your superior knowledge of your sister must make the latter probable.
vi: You understand her better than I do, so I could be mistaken.
tr: Your better knowledge of your sister strengthens the second possibility.
es: Since you know your sister better, it is more likely the latter; and if so, if driven by that error I have caused her suffering, your resentment is not unfounded.

en: If it be so, if I have been misled by such error to inflict pain on her, your resentment has not been unreasonable.
vi: If that is the case, if I am mistaken, and it causes her distress, you have every right to be angry.
tr: –If so, if I made a mistake that caused her pain, your resentment would not be unjust.
es: Since you know your sister better, it is more likely the latter; and if so, if driven by that error I have caused her suffering, your resentment is not unfounded.

en: But I shall not scruple to assert, that the serenity of your sister’s countenance and air was such as might have given the most acute observer a conviction that, however amiable her temper, her heart was not likely to be easily touched.
vi: But I do not hesitate to assert that, regardless of how amiable her disposition may be, her feelings are not easily swayed, judging by the calmness in her expression and demeanor that a sensitive observer can detect.
tr: But I will say without hesitation that the seriousness in your sister's face and demeanor was such that even the most careful observer would think she was someone who, while friendly, was not easily accessible to the heart.
es: But I do not hesitate to assert that your sister's appearance and demeanor could have given even the most astute observer the assurance that, despite her affectionate nature, her heart did not seem to have been affected.

en: That I was desirous of believing her indifferent is certain; but I will venture to say that my investigations and decisions are not usually influenced by my hopes or fears.
vi: I sincerely want to believe that she is indifferent, but I must boldly add that my hopes or fears do not usually influence my understanding and decisions.
tr: –It is true that I wanted to believe in her indifference, –but I can say that my investigations and decisions are generally not influenced by my hopes or fears.
es: It is true that I wished to believe in her indifference, but I assure you that my studies and conclusions are not usually influenced by my hopes or fears.

en: I did not believe her to be indifferent because I wished it; I believed it on impartial conviction, as truly as I wished it in reason.
vi: It is not that I believe she is indifferent because I wish it so. I believe this based on impartial observation; as truly as if I had reason to wish otherwise.
tr: –I did not believe in your sister's indifference because I wanted it to be so; –I believed it with impartial conviction, and with the same sincerity.
es: I did not believe her indifferent because it suited me to believe so; I believed it with absolute impartiality.

en: My objections to the marriage were not merely those which I last night acknowledged to have required the utmost force of passion to put aside in my own case; the want of connection could not be so great an evil to my friend as to me.
vi: I oppose the marriage not merely for the sake of opposition, and last night I realized that it would take the strongest emotions to set aside these objections, in my case; if lacking, the relationship would not be bad for him but very bad for me.
tr: –My objections to the marriage were not the matters I confessed last night could be overcome by a great passion on my part; the issue of relatives was not as great an obstacle for my friend as it was for me.
es: My objections to that marriage were not exactly those I acknowledged last night could only be overcome by the force of passion, as in my own case; the disparity in rank would not be as serious for my friend as it would be for me; but there were other obstacles that, despite existing in both my friend's case and mine, I would have tried to forget since they did not affect me directly.

en: But there were other causes of repugnance; causes which, though still existing, and existing to an equal degree in both instances, I had myself endeavoured to forget, because they were not immediately before me.
vi: “But the aversion has other causes that I myself want to forget because they are not apparent to me, although they still exist, and exist to the same degree in both Mr. Bingley's and my cases.
tr: –But there were other annoying circumstances; –although they still exist, and even if they exist to the same extent for both of us, they are not constantly in front of me, so I personally try to forget them.
es: My objections to that marriage were not exactly those I acknowledged last night could only be overcome by the force of passion, as in my own case; the disparity in rank would not be as serious for my friend as it would be for me; but there were other obstacles that, despite existing in both my friend's case and mine, I would have tried to forget since they did not affect me directly.

en: These causes must be stated, though briefly.
vi: I need to briefly mention these causes, though succinctly.
tr: –These reasons also need to be briefly mentioned.
es: I must say what they were, though I will do so briefly.

en: The situation of your mother’s family, though objectionable, was nothing in comparison of that total want of propriety so frequently, so almost uniformly betrayed by herself, by your three younger sisters, and occasionally even by your father:—pardon me,—it pains me to offend you.
vi: Your family's circumstances, although uncomfortable, are insignificant compared to the material desires often manifested through your mother, your three younger sisters, and sometimes even your father. I apologize to you, I feel pained if I offend you.
tr: –The situation of your mother's family, though repulsive, is insignificant compared to the absolute vulgarity almost always displayed by her, your three younger sisters, and even occasionally your father. –Forgive me. –It pains me to offend you.
es: The position of your mother's family, though questionable, was nothing compared to the absolute impropriety so often, almost constantly, displayed by that lady, by her three younger sisters, and occasionally even by her father.

en: But amidst your concern for the defects of your nearest relations, and your displeasure at this representation of them, let it give you consolation to consider that to have conducted yourselves so as to avoid any share of the like censure is praise no less generally bestowed on you and your eldest sister than it is honourable to the sense and disposition of both.
vi: But when you and your sister show hesitation about the shortcomings of your relatives and displeasure at the manifestation of these shortcomings, please take comfort in knowing that your attitudes have avoided the criticism that others have faced, and have even earned you much praise, as well as making both your awareness and temperament worthy of respect.
tr: However, despite the discomfort you feel because of the faults of your closest relatives and the displeasure you will feel at their being described in this way, you may find consolation in knowing that the praise of your and your sister's intelligence and sensitivity, which prevents you from sharing in a similar judgment, is frequently expressed as you deserve.
es: Forgive me, it pains me to offend you; but amid the concerns about the faults of your closest relatives and your displeasure at my mentioning them, take comfort in knowing that the fact that both you and your sister conduct yourselves in such a way that no similar reproaches can be made against you, elevates you even more in the esteem you deserve.

en: I will only say, farther, that from what passed that evening my opinion of all parties was confirmed, and every inducement heightened, which could have led me before to preserve my friend from what I esteemed a most unhappy connection.
vi: “I can only add that, from what happened that evening, my opinion of everyone was determined, and I was further compelled to act to protect my friend from an unhappy marriage.
tr: –Lastly, I must say that what happened that evening confirmed my views on everyone and strengthened my desire to protect my friend from a connection I found very unpleasant without further delay.
es: I will only say that what happened that night confirmed all my suspicions and increased the reasons that might have already prompted me to preserve my friend from what I considered an unfortunate union.

en: He left Netherfield for London on the day following, as you, I am certain, remember, with the design of soon returning.
vi: As you may recall, I am sure, the next day he left Netherfield for London with the intention of returning soon.
tr: –The next day, as you surely know, he went to London from Netherfield, intending to return soon.
es: Bingley left for London the next day, as you will recall, with the intention of returning very soon.

en: The part which I acted is now to be explained.
vi: Now I will explain my actions.
tr: –Now it's time to explain the role I played.
es: Now it remains to explain my involvement in the matter.

en: His sisters’ uneasiness had been equally excited with my own: our coincidence of feeling was soon discovered; and, alike sensible that no time was to be lost in detaching their brother, we shortly resolved on joining him directly in London.
vi: Both his sister and I were concerned, and soon we both realized this coincidence, both of us were aware that no time should be wasted in separating him, so we decided to go to London with him.
tr: –His sisters' discomfort was no less than mine; we soon realized we shared the same thought; and believing that we should not waste time in separating their brother, we immediately decided to go to London to join him.
es: The displeasure of his sisters had also intensified, and we soon discovered that we agreed in our assessments. We saw that there was no time to lose if we wanted to separate Bingley from his sister, and we decided to go with him to London.

en: We accordingly went—and there I readily engaged in the office of pointing out to my friend the certain evils of such a choice.
vi: There, I tried my best to point out to my friend the disadvantages of such a choice.
tr: –We went –there I began to explain to my friend the certain disadvantages of such a choice.
es: We moved there, and immediately I set about making my friend understand the dangers of his choice.

en: I described and enforced them earnestly.
vi: I tried to persuade him earnestly.
tr: –I did not just describe them, I proved them.
es: I listed and described them to him with diligence.

en: But however this remonstrance might have staggered or delayed his determination, I do not suppose that it would ultimately have prevented the marriage, had it not been seconded by the assurance, which I hesitated not in giving, of your sister’s indifference.
vi: But even if this reproach might have caused him to hesitate or delay his decision, I do not believe it would have prevented the marriage, if not for your sister's indifferent attitude.
tr: –This intervention could have accelerated or delayed his decision, but in my opinion, it would not have prevented the marriage in the end if I had not mentioned your sister's indifference, which I did without hesitation.
es: But, although this might have caused his determination to waver or be postponed, I do not believe it would have ultimately prevented the marriage, except for the conviction I managed to instill in him of his sister's indifference.

en: He had before believed her to return his affection with sincere, if not with equal, regard.
vi: Previously, he believed that she would reciprocate his feelings with sincere interest, if not equally.
tr: Until then, he believed he had received sincere reciprocation of feelings, if not to the same extent as his own.
es: Until then, Bingley had believed that she reciprocated his affection with sincere, though not equal, interest.

en: But Bingley has great natural modesty, with a stronger dependence on my judgment than on his own.
vi: But Bingley is inherently shy, and he relied on my judgment more than his own.
tr: –But Bingley has a tremendous natural humility; he trusts my judgments more than his own.
es: But Bingley possesses great natural modesty and, moreover, genuinely believes that my sagacity is greater than his.

en: To convince him, therefore, that he had deceived himself was no very difficult point.
vi: Therefore, convincing him that he had deceived himself was easy.
tr: –It was not difficult to convince him that he was deceiving himself.
es: Even so, it was not easy to convince him that he had been mistaken.

en: To persuade him against returning into Hertfordshire, when that conviction had been given, was scarcely the work of a moment.
vi: Once I had made him believe it, urging him not to return to Hertfordshire was not difficult.
tr: After giving him this belief, persuading him not to return to Hertfordshire was a moment's work.
es: Once convinced, making him decide not to return to Hertfordshire was a matter of an instant.

en: I cannot blame myself for having done thus much.
vi: “I cannot blame myself for having acted to such an extent.
tr: –I cannot blame myself for what I did.
es: I see nothing in all this that is reprehensible against me.

en: There is but one part of my conduct, in the whole affair, on which I do not reflect with satisfaction; it is that I condescended to adopt the measures of art so far as to conceal from him your sister’s being in town.
vi: In the entire matter, there is only one action of mine that I am dissatisfied with when I recall it, and that is that I lowered myself to use the art of concealing from you the fact that your sister was in town at that time.
tr: There is one aspect of my behavior in the whole matter that I do not like to remember; that is, I stooped so low as to scheme to keep from him the fact that your sister was in town.
es: One thing alone in all I did seems reproachable to me: having agreed to take the necessary measures to keep Bingley unaware of his sister's presence in the city.

en: I knew it myself, as it was known to Miss Bingley; but her brother is even yet ignorant of it.
vi: I knew this information, Miss Bingley knew it too, but Mr. Bingley did not know at all.
tr: I knew, Miss Bingley knew, but her brother still does not know.
es: I knew she was in London, and Miss Bingley knew it too; but my friend has not found out yet.

en: That they might have met without ill consequence is, perhaps, probable; but his regard did not appear to me enough extinguished for him to see her without some danger.
vi: It is possible that the two might meet without any harmful consequences, but I deemed that his feelings had not yet been entirely extinguished, so there was still a disadvantage in their meeting.
tr: –It is possible that they could have met without bad consequences; –but it seemed to me that his feelings had not yet faded enough for him to see her safely.
es: Perhaps if they had met, nothing would have happened; but it did not seem to me that his affection had extinguished enough for him to see her again without any danger.

en: Perhaps this concealment, this disguise, was beneath me.
vi: Perhaps this concealment and disguise went against my nature.
tr: –Perhaps these secretive, devious actions did not suit me.
es: Maybe this concealment is unworthy of me, but I believed it my duty to do so.

en: It is done, however, and it was done for the best.
vi: However, I did it, and did it in the hope of achieving the best outcome.
tr: –But I did it once, and I did it with good intentions.
es: Maybe this concealment is unworthy of me, but I believed it my duty to do so.

en: On this subject I have nothing more to say, no other apology to offer.
vi: On this matter, I have nothing more to say, no further apologies to offer.
tr: –I have nothing more to say on this matter, no other excuse to offer.
es: I have nothing more to say on this matter nor any further apology to offer.

en: If I have wounded your sister’s feelings, it was unknowingly done; and though the motives which governed me may to you very naturally appear insufficient, I have not yet learnt to condemn them.
vi: If I have caused your sister any pain, it was beyond my intention; and although the motives that guided me may not seem sufficient justification to you, I do not know how to condemn these motives.
tr: If I hurt your sister's feelings, it was unknowingly; the reasons that guided me may naturally seem insufficient to you, but I have not yet learned to reject them.
es: If I have hurt his sister's feelings, it has been unintentionally, and although my motives may seem insufficient to her, I do not find them so condemnable.

en: —With respect to that other, more weighty accusation, of having injured mr Wickham, I can only refute it by laying before you the whole of his connection with my family.
vi: “Regarding the heavier accusation, that I have harmed Mr. Wickham, I can only refute it by explaining to you all the relations he has had with my family.
tr: –As for the more serious accusation, the accusation that I harmed Mr. Wickham, I can refute it by revealing his entire connection with my family.
es: Regarding the other more important accusation of having wronged Mr. Wickham, I can only counter it by explaining in detail the relationship of that gentleman with my family.

en: Of what he has particularly accused me I am ignorant; but of the truth of what I shall relate I can summon more than one witness of undoubted veracity.
vi: He particularly accuses me of ignorance, but according to the truth I will present, I can call upon witnesses whose honesty is beyond dispute.
tr: I do not know exactly what he accuses me of; but I can present more than one witness whose reliability is beyond doubt regarding the truth of what I will tell.
es: I am unaware of what he may have specifically accused me of, but there is more than one reliable witness who can corroborate the truth of what I am about to tell you.

en: mr Wickham is the son of a very respectable man, who had for many years the management of all the Pemberley estates, and whose good conduct in the discharge of his trust naturally inclined my father to be of service to him; and on George Wickham, who was his godson, his kindness was therefore liberally bestowed.
vi: Mr. Wickham is the son of a very respectable man, who for many years managed all the estates at Pemberley, and due to his virtue in his work, he was highly trusted, so naturally my father helped him. As for George Wickham, my father was very kind to him, as he was practically his adopted son.
tr: Mr. Wickham is the son of a very respectable man who managed all the Pemberley estates; his father's good conduct in his duties naturally inspired my father with a desire to be beneficial to him, and he showed his affection for his godson George Wickham with all his generosity.
es: Mr. Wickham is the son of a most respectable man who was in charge of managing all the Pemberley estates for many years, and whose excellent conduct inclined my father to favor him, as was natural; my father's affection was therefore generously manifested in George Wickham, who was his godson.

en: My father supported him at school, and afterwards at Cambridge; most important assistance, as his own father, always poor from the extravagance of his wife, would have been unable to give him a gentleman’s education.
vi: My father supported his education up to Cambridge University. This support was even more important because his father was poor due to his wife's extravagant lifestyle and could not afford to educate him properly.
tr: My father supported him at school, and later at Cambridge –significantly, because his own father, condemned to poverty by his wife's extravagance, was not in a position to provide him with a gentleman's education.
es: He funded his education at a school and then at Cambridge, for his father, constantly impoverished by his wife's extravagances, would not have been able to give him a gentleman's education.

en: My father was not only fond of this young man’s society, whose manners were always engaging, he had also the highest opinion of him, and hoping the church would be his profession, intended to provide for him in it.
vi: My father not only cherished his always engaging company but also held him in high regard, hoping he would have a career in the church, so he intended to support him in this direction.
tr: My father not only valued the friendship of this young man, who always had pleasant manners, but also held high hopes for him and decided to provide him with a means of livelihood by hoping he would choose the church as his profession.
es: My father not only enjoyed the boy's company, who was always very charming, but also formed the highest opinion of him and believed that the Church could be his profession, so he sought to provide him with the means for it.

en: As for myself, it is many, many years since I first began to think of him in a very different manner.
vi: As for me, it was only after many, many years that I began to think of him differently.
tr: For my part, I began to think differently about him years, long years ago.
es: I, on the other hand, began to have a very different opinion of Wickham many years ago.

en: The vicious propensities, the want of principle, which he was careful to guard from the knowledge of his best friend, could not escape the observation of a young man of nearly the same age with himself, and who had opportunities of seeing him in unguarded moments, which mr Darcy could not have.
vi: The lowly talents and lack of principles that he carefully concealed from his closest friend could not escape the observation of someone nearly his age, who had opportunities to see him in unguarded moments.
tr: He was careful to hide his immoral tendencies and indecency from his closest friend, but these did not escape the notice of a young man almost the same age as him, who had the opportunity to catch him in unguarded moments, unlike Mr. Darcy.
es: The propensity for vices and the lack of principles that he took care to hide from his best friend could not escape the observation of a boy almost his age who had the chance to catch him in moments of carelessness that Mr. Darcy did not see.

en: Here again I shall give you pain—to what degree you only can tell.
vi: Here, once again, I am causing you pain, to what extent only you can know.
tr: Here I will upset you again –only you can know how much.
es: Now I will have to sadden you again to a degree that only you can calculate, but whatever feelings Mr. Wickham may have awakened in you, this suspicion will not prevent me from unmasking him; on the contrary, it will be an additional incentive for me.

en: But whatever may be the sentiments which mr Wickham has created, a suspicion of their nature shall not prevent me from unfolding his real character.
vi: But whatever feelings Mr. Wickham has stirred in you, the doubt about the nature of these feelings cannot prevent me from exposing his true character.
tr: But whatever feelings Mr. Wickham has aroused, my doubts about their nature will not prevent me from revealing his true face.
es: Now I will have to sadden you again to a degree that only you can calculate, but whatever feelings Mr. Wickham may have awakened in you, this suspicion will not prevent me from unmasking him; on the contrary, it will be an additional incentive for me.

en: It adds even another motive.
vi: “I have another motivation as well.
tr: There is another reason.
es: Now I will have to sadden you again to a degree that only you can calculate, but whatever feelings Mr. Wickham may have awakened in you, this suspicion will not prevent me from unmasking him; on the contrary, it will be an additional incentive for me.

en: My excellent father died about five years ago; and his attachment to mr Wickham was to the last so steady, that in his will he particularly recommended it to me to promote his advancement in the best manner that his profession might allow, and if he took orders, desired that a valuable family living might be his as soon as it became vacant.
vi: My father passed away about five years ago, and his affection for him remained so steadfast that in his will, which he specifically conveyed to me, it was stated that he would support the advancement that his profession allowed, and if he took holy orders, he would be given a substantial allowance from the family.
tr: My kind-hearted father died five years ago; his attachment to Mr. Wickham continued until the end; so much so that in his will, he specifically instructed me to assist him in advancing in his profession as much as possible, and if he qualified for the clergy, to give him a valuable family living as soon as it became vacant.
es: My excellent father died five years ago, and his affection for Mr. Wickham remained so constant until the end that in his will he recommended that I support him in the best way that his profession would allow; if he were ordained a priest, my father wished for him to be granted a benefice capable of supporting a family, at the first vacancy.

en: There was also a legacy of one thousand pounds.
vi: There was also a legacy of one thousand pounds.
tr: There was also a sum of one thousand pounds.
es: He also bequeathed him a thousand pounds.

en: His own father did not long survive mine; and within half a year from these events mr Wickham wrote to inform me that, having finally resolved against taking orders, he hoped I should not think it unreasonable for him to expect some more immediate pecuniary advantage, in lieu of the preferment, by which he could not be benefited.
vi: His father passed away shortly after mine, within a year, and Mr. Wickham wrote to inform me that he had finally decided not to take holy orders, and he hoped I could consider providing him with financial assistance immediately rather than waiting until he was appointed.
tr: His father did not outlive mine by much; six months after these events, Mr. Wickham wrote to me saying he had decided to give up his religious education, and hoped I would not find it inappropriate to expect some financial assistance instead of a church appointment that would be of no use to him.
es: Wickham's father did not survive mine by much. And half a year after his death, the young Wickham wrote to me informing me that he had finally resolved not to be ordained, and that, in exchange for the benefice he was not to enjoy, he hoped I would give him some more immediate pecuniary advantage.

en: He had some intention, he added, of studying the law, and I must be aware that the interest of one thousand pounds would be a very insufficient support therein.
vi: He added that he intended to study law, and I had to admit that one thousand pounds would not be sufficient for him.
tr: He also added that he intended to study law; he assumed I would understand that the interest on a thousand pounds would not be enough to support him there.
es: He added that he intended to pursue a career in law, and that I should understand that the interest on a thousand pounds could not suffice for that.

en: I rather wished than believed him to be sincere; but, at any rate, was perfectly ready to accede to his proposal.
vi: I wished, rather than believed, that he was sincere. But in any case, I was willing to comply with his request.
tr: Although I did not believe he was sincere, I wished he were; but in any case, I was ready to accept his proposal.
es: More than believing him sincere, I wished he were; but in any case, I agreed to his proposal.

en: I knew that mr Wickham ought not to be a clergyman.
vi: I knew that Mr. Wickham should not become a clergyman.
tr: I knew Mr. Wickham should not be a clergyman.
es: I knew that Mr. Wickham was not suited to be a clergyman; so I arranged the matter.

en: The business was therefore soon settled.
vi: Therefore, the matter was settled shortly thereafter.
tr: The matter was quickly settled.
es: I knew that Mr. Wickham was not suited to be a clergyman; so I arranged the matter.

en: He resigned all claim to assistance in the church, were it possible that he could ever be in a situation to receive it, and accepted in return three thousand pounds.
vi: He declared that he would renounce any future claims to church support that he might be entitled to, and instead, he received three thousand pounds.
tr: He renounced all financial rights he could have received from the church and accepted three thousand pounds in return.
es: He renounced all claims to assistance regarding the clerical profession, even if he might find himself in a position to adopt it, and accepted three thousand pounds.

en: All connection between us seemed now dissolved.
vi: All relations between us now seem to be dissolved.
tr: Thus, all relations between us seemed to be over.
es: Everything seemed settled between us.

en: I thought too ill of him to invite him to Pemberley, or admit his society in town.
vi: I thought so little of him that I did not want to invite him to Pemberley, nor associate with him in the city.
tr: My thoughts about him were so negative that I neither invited him to Pemberley nor allowed him to appear to me in town.
es: I had too poor an opinion of him to invite him to Pemberley or admit his company in the capital.

en: In town, I believe, he chiefly lived, but his studying the law was a mere pretence; and being now free from all restraint, his life was a life of idleness and dissipation.
vi: I believe he lives mainly in the city, but studying law was just an excuse, and now free from all restraints, he lives idly and extravagantly.
tr: I believe he mostly lived in town, but the study of law was merely a lie; once free of all obstacles, his life became one of complete idleness and vagabondage.
es: I believe he lived mostly in London, but his law studies were nothing but a pretext, and as there was nothing to hold him, he freely indulged in idleness and dissipation.

en: For about three years I heard little of him; but on the decease of the incumbent of the living which had been designed for him, he applied to me again by letter for the presentation.
vi: "For about three years, I heard little news about him, but when the allowance he received ran out, he wrote to me asking for more.
tr: For three years, I heard little from him; but upon the death of the clergyman intended for him, he again approached me for the letter of appointment.
es: I knew almost nothing of him for three years, but upon the death of the holder of the rectory that had been intended for him, he sent me a letter asking me to grant it to him.

en: His circumstances, he assured me, and I had no difficulty in believing it, were exceedingly bad.
vi: He persuaded me, and I had no difficulty believing him that he was in need.
tr: He wanted me to believe he was in very bad condition, which I found easy to believe.
es: He told me, and it was not difficult for me to believe, that he was in very poor circumstances, opined that the law career was not profitable, and was completely decided to be ordained if I granted him the rectory in question, something he did not doubt I would do, as he knew I had no one else to occupy it and on the other hand, I could not forget the wishes of my venerable father.

en: He had found the law a most unprofitable study, and was now absolutely resolved on being ordained, if I would present him to the living in question—of which he trusted there could be little doubt, as he was well assured that I had no other person to provide for, and I could not have forgotten my revered father’s intentions.
vi: He found studying law to be unprofitable; now he was determined to be ordained, if I would transfer the remaining part of the allowance to him. He believed he was entitled to this because he knew I did not need to support anyone else, and I surely could not forget my grandfather's intentions.
tr: He had seen that law was a non-lucrative profession and had now definitely decided to take the clergy, provided I gave him the said living –he had no doubt about it, and besides, who else did I have to look after, and I could not have forgotten my dear father's intention.
es: He told me, and it was not difficult for me to believe, that he was in very poor circumstances, opined that the law career was not profitable, and was completely decided to be ordained if I granted him the rectory in question, something he did not doubt I would do, as he knew I had no one else to occupy it and on the other hand, I could not forget the wishes of my venerable father.

en: You will hardly blame me for refusing to comply with this entreaty, or for resisting every repetition of it.
vi: You cannot blame me for refusing his plea, or for rejecting all subsequent repeated requests.
