tr: You cannot blame me for refusing this attempt or resisting its repetition.
es: I believe you cannot blame me for having refused to comply with this demand and preventing it from being repeated.

en: His resentment was in proportion to the distress of his circumstances—and he was doubtless as violent in his abuse of me to others as in his reproaches to myself.
vi: His resentment was as intense as his material deprivation, and surely he spoke ill of me to others as fiercely as he reproached me.
tr: His resentment was proportional to the harshness of his circumstances –his complaints to others were as intense as the insults he directed at me.
es: Wickham's resentment was proportional to the calamitousness of his circumstances, and he undoubtedly spoke of me to people with the same violence with which he directly insulted me.

en: After this period, every appearance of acquaintance was dropped.
vi: “After this period, all outward appearances of the relationship between the two of us were discarded.
tr: After this period, all signs of acquaintance were abandoned.
es: After this, all relations between him and me were broken off.

en: How he lived, I know not.
vi: I do not know how he managed to live.
tr: I do not know how he lived.
es: I do not know how he lived.

en: But last summer he was again most painfully obtruded on my notice.
vi: But last summer, he again forced me to pay painful attention to him.
tr: But last summer, he entered my life again in a very painful way.
es: But last summer I received very unpleasant news about him.

en: I must now mention a circumstance which I would wish to forget myself, and which no obligation less than the present should induce me to unfold to any human being.
vi: Now I must mention an event that I myself wish to forget, only because I am now compelled to reveal it.
tr: I must now speak of an event I wish I could forget and which no force other than the current matter would compel me to reveal to anyone.
es: I have to tell you something now that I myself would like to forget and that no other circumstance than the present one could induce me to reveal to any human being.

en: Having said thus much, I feel no doubt of your secrecy.
vi: In such a lengthy manner, I think I can trust you to keep this matter confidential.
tr: I am telling you this because I have no doubt you know how to keep a secret.
es: I have no doubt that you will keep my secret.

en: My sister, who is more than ten years my junior, was left to the guardianship of my mother’s nephew, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and myself.
vi: My sister Georgiana, who is more than ten years younger than I, was entrusted to the guardianship of my mother's nephew, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and myself.
tr: My sister, who is at least ten years younger than me, was left under the guardianship of my mother's nephew, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and myself.
es: My sister, who is ten years younger than I am, was left under the guardianship of my mother's nephew, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and myself.

en: About a year ago, she was taken from school, and an establishment formed for her in London; and last summer she went with the lady who presided over it to Ramsgate; and thither also went mr Wickham, undoubtedly by design; for there proved to have been a prior acquaintance between him and ms Younge, in whose character we were most unhappily deceived; and by her connivance and aid he so far recommended himself to Georgiana, whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of his kindness to her as a child, that she was persuaded to believe herself in love and to consent to an elopement.
vi: About a year ago, she left school, a residence was established for her in London, and she, along with the manager of this residence, went to Ramsgate, from where she sought out Mr. Wickham. Surely this was premeditated, as he and Mrs. Younge had known each other previously. She deceived us sadly; through her collusion and assistance, he courted Georgiana. My sister's tender heart was strongly impressed by his kindness to a child, to the point that she was persuaded she loved him and agreed to elope with him.
tr: About a year ago, she was taken from school and a house was opened for her in London; last summer, she went to Ramsgate with the lady managing the house; Mr. Wickham also went there, undoubtedly with intent; for it turned out he had a prior acquaintance with Mrs. Younge, which we had been quite mistaken about her character; with her arrangement and assistance, he managed to ingratiate himself with Georgiana; my sister, whose sensitive heart had been filled with affectionate memories of him since childhood, was convinced she was in love with him and agreed to elope with him.
es: About a year ago, she left school and settled in London. Last summer, she went with her governess to Ramsgate, where Mr. Wickham also went expressly, with complete certainty, for we later learned that Mrs. Younge and he had been in contact. We had, unfortunately, been deceived about the character of the governess. With her complicity and help, Wickham set about seducing Georgiana, whose affectionate heart was strongly impressed by his attentions; she was only a child and, believing herself to be in love, consented to elope.

en: She was then but fifteen, which must be her excuse; and after stating her imprudence, I am happy to add, that I owed the knowledge of it to herself.
vi: At that time, she was only fifteen, so this was an excuse to run away, and after mentioning her imprudence, I am pleased to add that I learned of this through her.
tr: She was only fifteen at the time; this must be her excuse; after expressing her imprudence, I am also pleased to add that I learned of the matter from her.
es: She was then only fifteen years old, which serves as an excuse. After confessing her imprudence, I have the satisfaction of adding that I learned of that plan from her herself.

en: I joined them unexpectedly a day or two before the intended elopement; and then Georgiana, unable to support the idea of grieving and offending a brother whom she almost looked up to as a father, acknowledged the whole to me.
vi: I met the two of them one or two days before they planned to elope. Georgiana, not wanting to cause her brother, whom she also viewed as a father, distress and offense, confessed everything to me.
tr: A few days before the planned elopement, I unexpectedly joined them; at that time, Georgiana could no longer bear the idea of subjecting a brother she saw as a father to such distress and insult, and she told me everything as it was.
es: I went to Ramsgate and surprised them a day or two before the planned elopement, and then Georgiana, unable to distress and offend her brother whom she almost loved as a father, told me everything.

en: You may imagine what I felt and how I acted.
vi: You can imagine what I thought and how I acted.
tr: You can imagine what I felt and how I acted.
es: You can imagine how I felt and how I acted.

en: Regard for my sister’s credit and feelings prevented any public exposure; but I wrote to mr Wickham, who left the place immediately, and ms Younge was of course removed from her charge.
vi: For the sake of my sister's dignity and feelings, I kept the matter confidential, but I wrote to Mr. Wickham, and of course, Mrs. Younge was dismissed.
tr: My concern for my sister's reputation and feelings prevented the matter from becoming public; but my writing to Mr. Wickham and his immediate departure were simultaneous; Mrs. Younge was, of course, dismissed from her position.
es: Out of consideration for my sister's honor and feelings, I did not make a public scandal, but I wrote to Mr. Wickham, who left immediately. Mrs. Younge, naturally, was dismissed on the spot.

en: mr Wickham’s chief object was unquestionably my sister’s fortune, which is thirty thousand pounds; but I cannot help supposing that the hope of revenging himself on me was a strong inducement.
vi: Surely Mr. Wickham's aim was my sister's fortune, about thirty thousand pounds, but I cannot help but guess that a desire for revenge against me was also a strong motivating factor.
tr: Mr. Wickham's main goal was undoubtedly my sister's thirty thousand-pound fortune; on the other hand, I cannot help but think that the hope of taking revenge on me was also a strong motivating factor.
es: Mr. Wickham's main objective was undoubtedly my sister's fortune, which amounts to thirty thousand pounds, but I cannot help but suspect that his desire for revenge against me was also part of his purpose.

en: His revenge would have been complete indeed.
vi: Indeed, his revenge could have been complete.
tr: Mr. Wickham's main goal was undoubtedly my sister's thirty thousand-pound fortune; on the other hand, I cannot help but think that the hope of taking revenge on me was also a strong motivating factor.
es: It really would have been a complete revenge.

en: This, madam, is a faithful narrative of every event in which we have been concerned together; and if you do not absolutely reject it as false, you will, I hope, acquit me henceforth of cruelty towards mr Wickham.
vi: "Miss, I have recounted every event truthfully that pertains to both of us. If you do not dismiss the story as falsehood, I hope you will retract your accusation of my cruel treatment towards Mr. Wickham.
tr: This, madam, is an honest explanation of every event between us; if you do not reject it as a lie, I hope you will retract the accusation that I have been cruel to Mr. Wickham.
es: This is, miss, the faithful narration of what happened between him and me; and if you do not reject it as absolutely false, I hope that henceforth you will withdraw the accusation of having behaved cruelly towards Mr. Wickham.

en: I know not in what manner, under what form of falsehood, he has imposed on you; but his success is not perhaps to be wondered at, ignorant as you previously were of everything concerning either.
vi: I am not sure how he has influenced you, with what deceitful words, but it is likely that he has succeeded.
tr: I do not know what style or lies he used to influence you; but perhaps his success should not be surprising, as you had no prior knowledge of these matters.
es: I do not know in what way or with what falsehood he has deceived you; but it is not surprising that he has succeeded, for you were unaware of all these matters.

en: Detection could not be in your power, and suspicion certainly not in your inclination.
vi: Previously, you knew nothing of these matters, you had no means to investigate, and certainly, you had no inclination to doubt.
tr: You could not have learned these things yourself; doubting them was naturally not in your nature.
es: It was impossible for you to find them out and you were not inclined to suspect them.

en: You may possibly wonder why all this was not told you last night.
vi: You may wonder why I did not recount all these events last night.
tr: You may wonder why all this was not told to you last night.
es: You may wonder why I did not tell you everything last night, but at that time I was not in control of myself and did not know what I could or should reveal to you.

en: But I was not then master enough of myself to know what could or ought to be revealed.
vi: But at that time, I could not maintain the composure to know what could or should be said.
tr: But at that time, I was not in a state to decide how much could be explained.
es: You may wonder why I did not tell you everything last night, but at that time I was not in control of myself and did not know what I could or should reveal to you.

en: For the truth of everything here related, I can appeal more particularly to the testimony of Colonel Fitzwilliam, who, from our near relationship and constant intimacy, and still more as one of the executors of my father’s will, has been unavoidably acquainted with every particular of these transactions.
vi: Regarding the truth behind what I have recounted here, I can call upon Colonel Fitzwilliam as a witness. As he is closely related and lives in proximity to us, still being an executor of my father's will, he could not help but be well aware of all the details.
tr: Regarding the truth of everything told here, I can particularly recommend the testimony of Colonel Fitzwilliam; due to our close relationship and constant confidences, and as one of the executors of my father's will, he has inevitably been involved in every detail of these transactions.
es: Regarding the truth of everything I have narrated to you, I can appeal to the testimony of Colonel Fitzwilliam, who, due to our close relationship and constant interaction, and even more so for being one of the executors of my father's will, has had to become fully aware of everything that has happened.

en: If your abhorrence of me should make my assertions valueless, you cannot be prevented by the same cause from confiding in my cousin; and that there may be the possibility of consulting him, I shall endeavour to find some opportunity of putting this letter in your hands in the course of the morning.
vi: If you despise me so bitterly that all my explanations are worthless, you can still confide in my cousin, and since you may have the opportunity to seek his opinion, I have endeavored to find a chance to deliver this letter to you this morning.
tr: If your contempt for me makes my explanations worthless, there is no reason to prevent you from consulting my cousin; I will try to find an opportunity to give you this letter this morning so that you can consult him.
es: If the hatred you feel towards me invalidates my assertions, you may consult with my cousin, against whom you will have no reason for distrust; and to make this possible, I will try to find the opportunity to get this letter into your hands this very morning.

en: I will only add, God bless you.
vi: “I only have one more thing to say: may God bless you.”
tr: All I can wish is, may God protect you.
es: I only have to add: May God bless you.

en: “Fitzwilliam Darcy.”
vi: Fitzwilliam Darcy
tr: FITZWILLIAM DARCY"
es: Fitzwilliam Darcy.

en: CHAPTER XXXVI.
vi: Chapter 36
tr: Chapter XIII
es: CHAPTER XXXVI

en: ELIZABETH, when mr Darcy gave her the letter, did not expect it to contain a renewal of his offers, she had formed no expectation at all of its contents.
vi: When Mr. Darcy handed her the letter, Elizabeth had not expected him to propose to her again, nor could she anticipate its contents.
tr: When Mr. Darcy gave her the letter, although Elizabeth did not expect it to reiterate his marriage proposal, she had no idea what it might be about.
es: Elizabeth did not expect, when Darcy gave her the letter, that he would repeat his proposal in it, but she had no idea what it might contain.

en: But such as they were, it may be well supposed how eagerly she went through them, and what a contrariety of emotion they excited.
vi: But she eagerly read it, and the letter caused conflicting emotions within her.
tr: But given what it explained, it is easy to imagine how eagerly she read the letter and the complex emotions she experienced.
es: Upon discovering it, one can well imagine how quickly she read it and what conflicting emotions it aroused in her.

en: Her feelings as she read were scarcely to be defined.
vi: She could not clearly define her thoughts as she read through the letter.
tr: What she felt while reading is indescribable.
es: It would have been difficult to define her feelings.

en: With amazement did she first understand that he believed any apology to be in his power; and steadfastly was she persuaded, that he could have no explanation to give, which a just sense of shame would not conceal.
vi: At first, she was surprised to understand that he believed he had the ability to apologize to her, and she remained firmly convinced that he had no explanation that could justify his shameful behavior.
tr: First, she saw with astonishment that Mr. Darcy believed he could somehow manage to apologize; whereas Elizabeth firmly believed that there was no explanation Mr. Darcy could give without blushing from shame.
es: At first, she believed with astonishment that Darcy would want to apologize as best he could, but she immediately became firmly convinced that he could not offer any explanation that the most basic sense of dignity would not advise concealing.

en: With a strong prejudice against everything he might say, she began his account of what had happened at Netherfield.
vi: With a strong prejudice against everything he might say, she began with the explanation of what had happened at Netherfield.
tr: With a strong prejudice against everything he might say, she began reading his words about what happened at Netherfield.
es: With great prejudice against everything he might say, she began to read his account of what had happened at Netherfield.

en: She read with an eagerness which hardly left her power of comprehension; and from impatience of knowing what the next sentence might bring, was incapable of attending to the sense of the one before her eyes.
vi: She eagerly read, but in her impatience to know what the next sentence said, she could not clearly grasp what she was reading.
tr: She read with an excitement that did not leave her mind at ease, and due to her impatience to learn what the next sentence might bring, she could not manage to pay attention to the meaning of the sentence before her.
es: Her eyes skimmed the paper with such anxiety that she barely had time to comprehend, and her impatience to know what the next sentence said prevented her from understanding the meaning of the one she was reading.

en: His belief of her sister’s insensibility she instantly resolved to be false; and his account of the real, the worst objections to the match, made her too angry to have any wish of doing him justice.
vi: She immediately assumed that his belief in her sister's indifference was wrong, and his explanation of the strong objections made her too angry to consider him impartially.
tr: She immediately dismissed Mr. Darcy's belief in her sister's indifference as wrong; the most real, the worst objections against the marriage angered her so much that she could not remain impartial.
es: She instantly assumed that Darcy's belief in her sister's indifference was false, and the worst objections he raised to that marriage angered her too much to be able to do him justice.

en: He expressed no regret for what he had done which satisfied her; his style was not penitent, but haughty.
vi: He did not show any regret for what he had done; his manner was not repentant but arrogant.
tr: She found it understandable that he said he did not regret what he had done; there was no remorse in his tone, there was arrogance.
es: She was pleased that he expressed no regret for what he had done; his style revealed no contrition, but arrogance.

en: It was all pride and insolence.
vi: It was all pride and insolence.
tr: From beginning to end, it was proud and disrespectful.
es: In his lines, she saw nothing but pride and insolence.

en: But when this subject was succeeded by his account of mr Wickham—when she read, with somewhat clearer attention, a relation of events which, if true, must overthrow every cherished opinion of his worth, and which bore so alarming an affinity to his own history of himself—her feelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition.
vi: But when he mentioned Mr. Wickham, as she read more attentively, the events, if true, would surely dispel all her good feelings about his worth. Her feelings became more painful and harder to define.
tr: But when the explanation regarding Mr. Wickham followed this subject, if it were true, it should have shattered every good thought she had about Mr. Wickham, and as she read the explanation of events that bore a very disturbing similarity to the story he had told with a bit more clear attention, she felt an even more intense and indescribable pain.
es: But when she came to the part concerning Wickham, she read with greater attention.

en: Astonishment, apprehension, and even horror, oppressed her.
vi: She was extremely surprised, worried, even horrified.
tr: She was left in astonishment, anxiety, even horror.
es: Faced with that account of events which, if true, would destroy all her good opinion of the young man, and which bore an alarming similarity to what Wickham himself had told her, her feelings became even more distressing and harder to define; confusion, suspicion, and even horror overwhelmed her.

en: She wished to discredit it entirely, repeatedly exclaiming, “This must be false!
vi: She wanted to reject everything, constantly shouting: "This is not right!
tr: She wanted to oppose it all, repeatedly cried out, "Lies!
es: She wanted to deny it all and repeatedly exclaimed: "That must be false, it can't be true!

en: This cannot be!
vi: It can't be like this!
tr: It cannot be true!
es: It must be the greatest of lies!"

en: This must be the grossest falsehood!
vi: This is nonsense!"
tr: It cannot be true!
es: It must be the greatest of lies!"

en: ”—and when she had gone through the whole letter, though scarcely knowing anything of the last page or two, put it hastily away, protesting that she would not regard it, that she would never look in it again.
vi: And when she had finished reading the letter, though she remembered nothing of the last one or two pages, she hurriedly folded the letter, convinced that she should not believe it, that she would never read it again.
tr: The utmost of lies!" – when she finished reading the letter, although she understood very little from the last one or two pages, she hastily folded and put it away, saying she would not believe what was written and would not look at it again.
es: She finished reading the letter, and without having taken in the last one or two pages, she quickly put it away, complaining to herself that she would not look at it again, that she did not want to know anything about it.

en: In this perturbed state of mind, with thoughts that could rest on nothing, she walked on; but it would not do: in half a minute the letter was unfolded again; and collecting herself as well as she could, she again began the mortifying perusal of all that related to Wickham, and commanded herself so far as to examine the meaning of every sentence.
vi: In such a state of mental turmoil, with intentions not knowing where to cling, she continued to walk. But she could not control herself, opened the letter again, trying to calm herself in her distressed state, and read everything about Wickham again, examining the meaning in each sentence.
tr: In this shaken state of mind, he continued to walk with scattered thoughts; but it didn't work; half a minute later, the letter was opened again; he tried to collect himself as best as he could and began to read all those things about Wickham again in shame, forcing himself to examine the meaning of each sentence.
es: In such a state of perturbation, assaulted by a thousand confused thoughts, she continued walking; but it was of no use; after half a minute she took out the letter again and, overcoming herself as best she could, began once more the mortifying reading of what referred to Wickham, mastering herself enough to examine the meaning of each phrase.

en: The account of his connection with the Pemberley family was exactly what he had related himself; and the kindness of the late mr Darcy, though she had not before known its extent, agreed equally well with his own words.
vi: The letter's account of Mr. Wickham's relationship with the Pemberly family was just as he had told. The kindness of the late Mr. Darcy was also as he had said, though she had not known it well before.
tr: The connection with the Pemberley family was exactly as he had described; although he did not know the extent of it until then, the kindness of the late Mr. Darcy matched his own words exactly.
es: His relationship with the Pemberley family was exactly as he had said, and the kindness of the old Mr. Darcy, although Elizabeth had not known until now how far it had gone, also coincided with what Wickham himself had indicated.

en: So far each recital confirmed the other; but when she came to the will, the difference was great.
vi: Up to this point, everything matched, but when she read the part about the will, there was a significant difference.
tr: Up to that point, both statements corroborated each other: but when it came to the will, the difference was significant.
es: Therefore, one account confirmed the other, but when it came to the matter of the will, it was very different.

en: What Wickham had said of the living was fresh in her memory; and as she recalled his very words, it was impossible not to feel that there was gross duplicity on one side or the other, and, for a few moments, she flattered herself that her wishes did not err.
vi: She still remembered the allowance that Wickham mentioned, and when pondering each word he said, she couldn't help but think that either one or the other had behaved deceitfully, and for a moment she was proud that she had not been mistaken.
tr: What Wickham had said about the church was still fresh in his memory; remembering his words, it was impossible not to feel that there was a heavy lie on one side or the other; for a few minutes, he complimented himself by saying that his instincts would not mislead him.
es: Everything he had said about his ecclesiastical benefice was fresh in the young woman's memory, and recalling his words, she had to acknowledge that there was double intention on one side or the other, and for a few moments she believed that her wishes were not deceiving her.

en: But when she read and re-read, with the closest attention, the particulars immediately following of Wickham’s resigning all pretensions to the living, of his receiving in lieu so considerable a sum as three thousand pounds, again was she forced to hesitate.
vi: But as she continued to read, then carefully reread, the subsequent details about Wickham renouncing all claims to the support, instead accepting a sum of three thousand pounds, made her uneasy.
tr: But upon closer reading, upon re-reading, the details behind Wickham's relinquishment of all claims to the church and instead receiving a substantial sum of three thousand pounds made him hesitate again.
es: But when she read and reread everything that had happened after Wickham had refused the rectory, in exchange for which he had received a sum as considerable as three thousand pounds, she could not help but doubt again.

en: She put down the letter, weighed every circumstance with what she meant to be impartiality—deliberated on the probability of each statement—but with little success.
vi: She put the letter down, considering every situation she thought was fair – cautious about the assumptions in each sentence – but she could not reach a conclusion.
tr: He put the letter aside, trying to weigh every possibility in his mind impartially – he pondered and considered the likelihood of every word, but he was unsuccessful.
es: She folded the letter and weighed all the circumstances with her supposed impartiality, meditating on the probabilities of sincerity of each account, but she made no progress; from both sides she found nothing but assertions.

en: On both sides it was only assertion.
vi: Each side was adamant about what they said.
tr: Both statements were merely claims.
es: She folded the letter and weighed all the circumstances with her supposed impartiality, meditating on the probabilities of sincerity of each account, but she made no progress; from both sides she found nothing but assertions.

en: Again she read on.
vi: She read on.
tr: He read it again.
es: She began to read again, but each line proved more clearly that the matter, which she had not believed could be explained in any way other than as an infamy to the detriment of Darcy's conduct, could be exposed in such a way that left Darcy completely free of blame.

en: But every line proved more clearly that the affair, which she had believed it impossible that any contrivance could so represent as to render mr Darcy’s conduct in it less than infamous, was capable of a turn which must make him entirely blameless throughout the whole.
vi: But each line showed more clearly that the matter, which she had believed no scheme could present in such a way as to make Mr. Darcy appear not too bad, had taken a step or made him completely innocent.
tr: But each line more clearly revealed that although he did not believe the matter had been falsified to make Mr. Darcy's behavior appear vile, it was also open to an interpretation that would show him completely innocent from the beginning to the end of the story.
es: She began to read again, but each line proved more clearly that the matter, which she had not believed could be explained in any way other than as an infamy to the detriment of Darcy's conduct, could be exposed in such a way that left Darcy completely free of blame.

en: The extravagance and general profligacy which he scrupled not to lay to mr Wickham’s charge exceedingly shocked her; the more so, as she could bring no proof of its injustice.
vi: The extravagance and liberality that he had unhesitatingly accused Mr. Wickham of shocked her, even more so because she saw no evidence of any injustice.
tr: The accusation of excess and general immorality that he did not hesitate to direct at Mr. Wickham shook him deeply; it shook him even more as he could not find any evidence to disprove the accusation.
es: The vices and prodigality that Darcy did not hesitate to attribute to Wickham outraged her excessively, all the more so because she had no evidence to refute Darcy's testimony.

en: She had never heard of him before his entrance into the ——shire militia, in which he had engaged at the persuasion of the young man, who, on meeting him accidentally in town, had there renewed a slight acquaintance.
vi: She had never heard of Mr. Wickham before he joined the military at the persuasion of her young brother, who had rekindled a superficial acquaintance upon meeting him again in the city.
tr: He had heard nothing about him before he joined the -------shire Regiment; he had joined this regiment on the recommendation of a young man he had met by chance in the city and quickly renewed his friendship with.
es: Elizabeth had never heard of Wickham before his joining the county garrison, which had been prompted by his casual encounter in London with a young man she only knew superficially.

en: Of his former way of life, nothing had been known in Hertfordshire but what he told
vi: No one in Hertfordshire knew anything about his previous life except for what he himself had said.
tr: Nothing was known about his previous lifestyle except for what he had told in Hertfordshire.
es: Of his former life, nothing was known in Hertfordshire except what he himself had told.

en: “Meeting accidentally in Town”
vi: No one in Hertfordshire knew anything about his previous life except for what he himself had said.
tr: Nothing was known about his previous lifestyle except for what he had told in Hertfordshire.
es: Of his former life, nothing was known in Hertfordshire except what he himself had told.

en: himself.
vi: No one in Hertfordshire knew anything about his previous life except for what he himself had said.
tr: If he had learned something about his true character, he would not have felt the desire to investigate.
es: Of his former life, nothing was known in Hertfordshire except what he himself had told.

en: As to his real character, had information been in her power, she had never felt a wish of inquiring.
vi: She never wanted to inquire about his true character.
tr: If he had learned something about his true character, he would not have felt the desire to investigate.
es: As for his true character, despite Elizabeth having the opportunity to analyze it, she never felt the desire to do so; his appearance, voice, and manners instantly endowed him with all virtues.

en: His countenance, voice, and manner, had established him at once in the possession of every virtue.
vi: His face, voice, and gestures all immediately confirmed every virtue of his.
tr: Thanks to his face, voice, and demeanor, he had immediately established himself as a very virtuous person.
es: As for his true character, despite Elizabeth having the opportunity to analyze it, she never felt the desire to do so; his appearance, voice, and manners instantly endowed him with all virtues.

en: She tried to recollect some instance of goodness, some distinguished trait of integrity or benevolence, that might rescue him from the attacks of mr Darcy; or at least, by the predominance of virtue, atone for those casual errors, under which she would endeavour to class what mr Darcy had described as the idleness and vice of many years’ continuance.
vi: She tried to recall a few virtues, a few unique traits of integrity or benevolence that could help defend him against Mr. Darcy's accusations, or at least could excuse the common faults, as she thought, that Mr. Darcy had described as laziness and long-standing vices.
tr: Elizabeth tried to remember an example of goodness, a sign of evident honesty or humanity that could save him from Mr. Darcy's attacks or at least help classify the faults Mr. Darcy described as long-standing idleness and wickedness as mere ordinary mistakes through his inherent morality, but she could not recall anything more tangible than the general positive opinion in the village and the reputation his sociability had earned him among his fellow soldiers.
es: She tried to recall some noble trait, some special gesture of integrity or kindness that could shield him from Darcy's attacks, or at least that the predominance of good qualities would compensate for those casual errors, which was how she insisted on labeling what Darcy branded as laziness and immorality ingrained in him from the beginning.

en: But no such recollection befriended her.
vi: But she could not remember anything like that.
tr: Elizabeth tried to remember an example of goodness, a sign of evident honesty or humanity that could save him from Mr. Darcy's attacks or at least help classify the faults Mr. Darcy described as long-standing idleness and wickedness as mere ordinary mistakes through his inherent morality, but she could not recall anything more tangible than the general positive opinion in the village and the reputation his sociability had earned him among his fellow soldiers.
es: She imagined Wickham in front of her and remembered him with all the charm of his demeanor, but apart from the general approval he enjoyed in the locality and the consideration he had gained among his comrades for his sympathy, Elizabeth could find nothing more in his favor.

en: She could see him instantly before her, in every charm of air and address, but she could remember no more substantial good than the general approbation of the neighbourhood, and the regard which his social powers had gained him in the mess.
vi: She could see him right before her, every manner and word captivating, but she could not recall any substantial point of his virtues, except for the approval of neighbors and the affection due to his social skills among the guests.
tr: Elizabeth tried to remember an example of goodness, a sign of evident honesty or humanity that could save him from Mr. Darcy's attacks or at least help classify the faults Mr. Darcy described as long-standing idleness and wickedness as mere ordinary mistakes through his inherent morality, but she could not recall anything more tangible than the general positive opinion in the village and the reputation his sociability had earned him among his fellow soldiers.
es: She imagined Wickham in front of her and remembered him with all the charm of his demeanor, but apart from the general approval he enjoyed in the locality and the consideration he had gained among his comrades for his sympathy, Elizabeth could find nothing more in his favor.

en: After pausing on this point a considerable while, she once more continued to read.
vi: After a moment of pondering this point, she continued reading.
tr: After dwelling on this point for a while, she continued reading once again.
es: After having reflected for a long time on this point, she resumed reading.

en: But, alas!
vi: But, alas!
tr: But alas!
es: But what followed about the adventure with Miss Darcy was partly confirmed by the conversation Elizabeth had had the previous morning with Colonel Fitzwilliam; and, at the end of the letter, Darcy appealed, to prove the truth of everything, to the colonel himself, whose involvement in all his cousin's affairs Elizabeth knew in advance, and whose veracity she had no reason to doubt.

en: the story which followed, of his designs on Miss Darcy, received some confirmation from what had passed between Colonel Fitzwilliam and herself only the morning before; and at last she was referred for the truth of every particular to Colonel Fitzwilliam himself—from whom she had previously received the information of his near concern in all his cousin’s affairs and whose character she had no reason to question.
vi: The subsequent story about his intentions towards Miss Darcy, partially confirmed by the conversation she had with Colonel Fitzwilliam the previous morning, and finally substantiated in every detail by Colonel Fitzwilliam himself – who had informed her of his concerns about his cousin's actions, a man whose integrity she had no reason to doubt.
tr: The next story described his plans regarding Miss Darcy and was somewhat confirmed by the conversations she had had with Colonel Fitzwilliam earlier that morning; in the end, every detail was referred to Colonel Fitzwilliam for verification, from whom she had already learned about his close interest in all his cousin's affairs and had no reason to question his character.
es: But what followed about the adventure with Miss Darcy was partly confirmed by the conversation Elizabeth had had the previous morning with Colonel Fitzwilliam; and, at the end of the letter, Darcy appealed, to prove the truth of everything, to the colonel himself, whose involvement in all his cousin's affairs Elizabeth knew in advance, and whose veracity she had no reason to doubt.

en: At one time she had almost resolved on applying to him, but the idea was checked by the awkwardness of the application, and at length wholly banished by the conviction that mr Darcy would never have hazarded such a proposal, if he had not been well assured of his cousin’s corroboration.
vi: For a moment she decided she would ask him about it, but the intention wavered because she felt awkward bringing it up. Ultimately, she dismissed the idea altogether, convinced that Mr. Darcy would never risk making such a proposal unless he was certain his cousin would corroborate his account.
tr: At one point, she almost decided to consult him but realized it would seem odd and gave up; in the end, she dismissed the idea entirely, thinking that Mr. Darcy would not risk making such an offer unless he was quite sure of his cousin's cooperation.
es: She was about to turn to him, but restrained herself at the thought of how awkward it would be to take that step; dismissing it in the end, convinced that Darcy would never have risked proposing it without being absolutely certain that his cousin would corroborate his statements.

en: She perfectly remembered everything that had passed in conversation between Wickham and herself in their first evening at mr Philips’s.
vi: She clearly remembered everything that was exchanged between Wickham and her on the evening they first met at Mr. Phillips' house.
tr: Mr. Philips remembered everything that was said during his conversations with Wickham very well.
es: She perfectly remembered everything Wickham told her when they first spoke at Mr. Philips' house; many of his expressions were still entirely in her memory.

en: Many of his expressions were still fresh in her memory.
vi: Many of his words were still vividly imprinted in her memory.
tr: Most of his words remained fresh in his memory.
es: She perfectly remembered everything Wickham told her when they first spoke at Mr. Philips' house; many of his expressions were still entirely in her memory.

en: She was now struck with the impropriety of such communications to a stranger, and wondered it had escaped her before.
vi: Now she was startled to think that speaking in such a manner to a stranger was improper, and she wondered why she hadn't realized this before.
tr: Now, he was disturbed by the impropriety of making such revelations to a stranger and was amazed that he had overlooked this until now.
es: Now she realized the impropriety of such confidences to a stranger and was amazed that she had not noticed it before.

en: She saw the indelicacy of putting himself forward as he had done, and the inconsistency of his professions with his conduct.
vi: She thought he lacked tact when presenting himself in that way, and his statements and actions were inconsistent.
tr: He saw the indiscretion in revealing oneself in such a manner and that his words did not align with his actions.
es: She saw the lack of delicacy involved in exposing oneself in that way, and the inconsistency of his statements with his behavior.

en: She remembered that he had boasted of having no fear of seeing mr Darcy—that mr Darcy might leave the country, but that he should stand his ground; yet he had avoided the Netherfield ball the very next week.
vi: She remembered that he had boasted that he was not afraid to meet Mr. Darcy, that Mr. Darcy could leave but he would stay; yet, he had avoided the ball at Netherfield the following week.
tr: He recalled Wickham boasting that he was not afraid of seeing Mr. Darcy – that Mr. Darcy could leave the village if he wanted, but he would not budge from his place, yet he avoided the ball at Netherfield the following week.
es: She remembered that he boasted of not fearing to see Darcy and that Darcy would have to leave, but that he would not move, which did not prevent him from evading the Netherfield ball the following week.

en: She remembered, also, that till the Netherfield family had quitted the country, he had told his story to no one but herself; but that after their removal, it had been everywhere discussed; that he had then no reserves, no scruples in sinking mr Darcy’s character, though he had assured her that respect for the father would always prevent his exposing the son.
vi: She also remembered that, until the Netherfield family left, he had only told his story to her and no one else, but after they left, the story was discussed everywhere. She thought he had not hesitated at all, not even for a moment, to seek to undermine Mr. Darcy's character, even though he had reassured her that out of respect for the late gentleman, he would never expose the son.
tr: He remembered that Wickham did not tell his story to anyone else until the family at Netherfield left the village, but after they were gone, the story was talked about everywhere, and despite saying that his respect for his father would not allow him to disgrace his son in public, he ceaselessly criticized Mr. Darcy.
es: She also remembered that until the Netherfield family had left the county, he told his story only to her, but after their departure, the said story spread from mouth to mouth, and Wickham had no scruples about ruining Darcy's reputation, despite previously assuring Elizabeth that respect for the father would always prevent him from offending the son.

en: How differently did everything now appear in which he was concerned!
vi: Everything related to him has now changed!
tr: How different everything related to Wickham seemed now!
es: How different everything related to Wickham seemed to her now!

en: His attentions to Miss King were now the consequence of views solely and hatefully mercenary; and the mediocrity of her fortune proved no longer the moderation of his wishes, but his eagerness to grasp at anything.
vi: His attention to Miss King is now merely a consequence of pure greed and a desire for revenge, and her meager fortune indicates that his aspirations are no longer moderate but driven by a keen eagerness to seize anything.
tr: His interest in Miss King was now only the result of his low and selfish inclinations; the modesty of the girl's fortune no longer proved the ordinariness of Wickham's desires, but his desire to cling to whatever he could find.
es: His attentions towards Miss King were now solely and exclusively the consequence of his odious fortune-hunting prospects, and the mediocrity of the young lady's fortune was no longer proof of the moderation of his ambitions, but rather his eagerness to cling to anything.

en: His behaviour to herself could now have had no tolerable motive: he had either been deceived with regard to her fortune, or had been gratifying his vanity by encouraging the preference which she believed she had most incautiously shown.
vi: His attitude towards her now cannot be motivated by anything acceptable; either he is disappointed by her poor fortune, or his vanity has been satisfied after he aroused the affection that she believed she had shown imprudently.
tr: There was now no understandable reason for his behavior towards Elizabeth; either he was mistaken about her wealth, or he was feeding his own vanity by encouraging the intimacy he believed Elizabeth had shown so imprudently.
es: His attitude towards Elizabeth could no longer have an acceptable motive: either he had been mistaken at first about her wealth, or he had tried to flatter his own vanity by nurturing the preference she had unwittingly shown him. All the efforts she made to defend him were progressively weakening.

en: Every lingering struggle in his favour grew fainter and fainter; and in further justification of mr Darcy, she could not but allow that mr Bingley, when questioned by Jane, had long ago asserted his blamelessness in the affair;—that, proud and repulsive as were his manners, she had never, in the whole course of their acquaintance—an acquaintance which had latterly brought them much together, and given her a sort of intimacy with his ways—seen anything that betrayed him to be unprincipled or unjust—anything that spoke him of irreligious or immoral habits;—that among his own connections he was esteemed and valued;—that even Wickham had allowed him merit as a brother, and that she had often heard him speak so affectionately of his sister as to prove him capable of some amiable feeling;—that had his actions been what Wickham represented them, so gross a violation of everything right could hardly have been concealed from the world; and that friendship between a person capable of it and such an amiable man as mr Bingley was incomprehensible.
vi: All ideas of justifying him are gradually fading away. Through Mr. Darcy's explanation, she had to accept that Mr. Bingley, when asked by Jane, had long believed he was not at fault in the matter. She realized that, throughout the time Mr. Darcy and she had a relationship that eventually brought them closer and allowed her to know his lifestyle well, although he was proud and unpleasant, she had never seen anything that indicated he lacked principles or fairness. Anything that indicated irreligious or immoral habits. In his social interactions, he was respected and highly regarded – even Wickham had considered him a brother; she had often heard him speak affectionately about his sister; all of which indicated he had some amiable sentiments. If his actions were as Wickham described, a blatant violation of all that is right could hardly be concealed from anyone, and the friendship between a person capable of forming bonds and someone as charming as Mr. Bingley; all of it was incomprehensible.
tr: As her last efforts to defend him weakened and further justified Mr. Darcy, she couldn't help but agree with Mr. Bingley's assertion of his innocence in response to Jane's question long ago; although his behavior was so proud and repulsive, throughout their acquaintance, which had recently brought them together frequently and made her familiar with his manner, she had never seen anything that revealed him to be unprincipled or unjust – nothing that suggested he had impious or immoral habits. He was respected and complimented among their acquaintances – even Wickham had admitted he was valuable as a brother, and Elizabeth had often witnessed him speaking of his sister with great affection, so much so that she thought he was capable of feeling closeness in his own way. If his actions were as Wickham described, such a grave disregard for everything right would be hard to hide from the world; a friendship between a person capable of this and a man as extremely kind-hearted as Mr. Bingley would be inconceivable.
es: And to further justify Darcy, she could not help but recognize that Bingley, when questioned by Jane, had long ago proclaimed Darcy's innocence in that matter; that no matter how proud and repellent he was, never, in the entire course of their relationship ––a relationship that had recently brought them much closer, allowing her to know his character more deeply––, had she seen him do anything ignoble or unjust, nothing for which he could be accused of being irreligious or immoral; that among his friends he was appreciated and loved, and even Wickham himself had acknowledged that he was a good brother. She had also heard him speak of his sister with such affection that it demonstrated he had good feelings. If he had been as Wickham painted him, capable of such a violation of all rights, it would have been difficult for no one to know, and the friendship between such a being and a man as amiable as Bingley would have been incomprehensible.

en: She grew absolutely ashamed of herself.
vi: She felt completely ashamed of herself.
tr: In the end, she was terribly ashamed of herself.
es: She came to be ashamed of herself.

en: Of neither Darcy nor Wickham could she think, without feeling that she had been blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd.
vi: She could not think of Darcy or Wickham without the idea that she had been blind, prejudiced, unjust, foolish.
tr: –She couldn't think of Darcy or Wickham without feeling blind, biased, prejudiced, and ridiculous.
es: She could not think of Darcy or Wickham without acknowledging that she had been biased, absurd, blind, and full of prejudice.

en: “How despicably have I acted!” she cried.
vi: She exclaimed: "I have acted in such a despicable manner!
tr: "I acted disgracefully!" he shouted.
es: “How despicably I have acted,” she thought, “I, who prided myself on my discernment!”

en: “I, who have prided myself on my discernment!
vi: I have been proud of my own awareness!
tr: –"I, who used to take pride in my intuition!
es: “How despicably I have acted,” she thought, “I, who prided myself on my discernment!”

en: I, who have valued myself on my abilities!
vi: I have overestimated my own abilities!
tr: –I, who used to admire my talents!
es: “I, who have boasted of my talent, who have scorned my sister’s generous candor, and have flattered my vanity with useless or blameworthy suspicions!”

en: who have often disdained the generous candour of my sister, and gratified my vanity in useless or blameless distrust.
vi: I have looked down on my sister's genuine and generous nature, satisfying my own vanity with useless or condemnable suspicion.
tr: I would belittle my sister's boundless goodwill, and in a shameful and meaningless skepticism, I would constantly admire myself.
es: “I, who have boasted of my talent, who have scorned my sister’s generous candor, and have flattered my vanity with useless or blameworthy suspicions!”

en: How humiliating is this discovery!
vi: How shameful it is to have realized this!
tr: –How humiliating it is to realize this!
es: “How humiliating all this is, but how I deserve this humiliation!”

en: Yet, how just a humiliation!
vi: Indeed, it is only shame!
tr: –How utterly humiliating!
es: “How humiliating all this is, but how I deserve this humiliation!”

en: Had I been in love, I could not have been more wretchedly blind.
vi: If I had known love, I could not have been so miserably blind!
tr: –If I had been in love, I couldn't have been in a more wretched blindness than this.
es: If I had been in love with Wickham, I would not have acted with such lamentable blindness.

en: But vanity, not love, has been my folly.
vi: But vanity, not love, has always been my folly.
tr: But my foolish mistake was not love, it was pride.
es: But vanity, not love, has been my folly.

en: Pleased with the preference of one, and offended by the neglect of the other, on the very beginning of our acquaintance, I have courted prepossession and ignorance, and driven reason away where either were concerned.
vi: Moved by one person's kindness and offended by another's indifference, from the very beginning of my acquaintance with him, I have been full of prejudices, foolishness, always rejecting all reason.
tr: As soon as we met, I liked being someone's choice, and I was offended by being neglected by the other; I acted prejudiced and ignorantly about both, setting reason aside.
es: Pleased with the preference of one and offended by the disdain of the other, I have from the beginning given myself up to presumption and ignorance, avoiding reason whenever it concerned either of them.

en: Till this moment, I never knew myself.”
vi: From the start until now, I have never truly recognized my own self."
tr: It turns out I didn't know myself until this moment."
es: Until this moment, I did not know myself.”

en: From herself to Jane, from Jane to Bingley, her thoughts were in a line which soon brought to her recollection that mr Darcy’s explanation there had appeared very insufficient; and she read it again.
vi: From herself to Jane, from Jane to Bingley, her thoughts all converged to remind her that what Mr. Darcy explained here seemed to lack many things, so she read the letter again.
tr: From herself to Jane – from Jane to Bingley, her thoughts progressed in a line and soon brought to mind that Mr. Darcy's explanation there seemed quite inadequate; she read the letter once more.
es: From herself to Jane and from Jane to Bingley, her thoughts traveled a path that soon led her to remember that the explanation Darcy had given about their matter had seemed very insufficient to her, and she read it again.

en: Widely different was the effect of a second perusal.
vi: This time the effect was very different – how could she dismiss his words in one situation, while believing them in another?
tr: The effect of the second reading was very different.
es: The effect of this second reading was very different.

en: How could she deny that credit to his assertions, in one instance, which she had been obliged to give in the other?
vi: This time the effect was very different – how could she dismiss his words in one situation, while believing them in another?
tr: –How could she accept part of his explanations as true while rejecting the other part?
es: How could she not give credit to what Darcy said about one of the points, if she had been forced to give it to him on the other?

en: He declared himself to have been totally unsuspicious of her sister’s attachment; and she could not help remembering what Charlotte’s opinion had always been.
vi: He said he knew nothing of her sister's feelings, while she could not forget the remark about her sister that Charlotte still held in her mind.
tr: –He had said that he never considered the possibility that her sister was interested; –Elizabeth couldn't help but recall Charlotte's opinion.
es: Darcy declared that he had always suspected that Jane felt no love for Bingley, and Elizabeth remembered what Charlotte's opinion had been.

en: Neither could she deny the justice of his description of Jane.
vi: Nor could she dismiss his description of Jane.
tr: –She couldn't deny that his observations about Jane were also correct.
es: Nor could she dispute the accuracy of his description of Jane; Elizabeth knew that her sister's feelings, though fervent, had been little expressed; and that the constant complacency in her air and manners often did not go hand in hand with great sensitivity.

en: She felt that Jane’s feelings, though fervent, were little displayed, and that there was a constant complacency in her air and manner, not often united with great sensibility.
vi: She thought that her sister expressed very little emotion even though her feelings were deep, and that her sister's attitude and gestures always exuded a sense of self-satisfaction, not well aligned with extreme sensitivity.
tr: – Elizabeth felt that Jane's feelings, even if passionate, were seldom displayed, that there was a constant contentment in her demeanor and manner rarely accompanied by great sensitivity.
es: Nor could she dispute the accuracy of his description of Jane; Elizabeth knew that her sister's feelings, though fervent, had been little expressed; and that the constant complacency in her air and manners often did not go hand in hand with great sensitivity.

en: When she came to that part of the letter in which her family were mentioned, in tones of such mortifying, yet merited, reproach, her sense of shame was severe.
vi: When she read the part about her family, with its reproachful but justified tone, she felt even more ashamed.
tr: When the letter reached his family with such a humiliating but justified reproach, he felt intense shame.
es: When she reached the part of the letter where Darcy mentioned her family in terms of such humiliating yet deserved reproaches, Elizabeth felt truly ashamed.

en: The justice of the charge struck her too forcibly for denial; and the circumstances to which he particularly alluded, as having passed at the Netherfield ball, and as confirming all his first disapprobation, could not have made a stronger impression on his mind than on hers.
vi: The impartial comment struck her consciousness so heavily that she could not deny it. The situations he specifically alluded to, such as what happened at the Netherfield ball, seemed to confirm everything he disapproved of, leaving a stronger impression on her mind than on his.
tr: The justification of the accusation shook him so severely that he could not object; the events at the Netherfield ball, which Darcy particularly mentioned and which confirmed all his initial suspicions, could not have been more strongly imprinted in his mind than they were in Elizabeth's.
es: The justice of his accusations seemed too evident for her to deny, and the circumstances he particularly alluded to as having occurred at the Netherfield ball could not have impressed him more than they had embarrassed her.

en: The compliment to herself and her sister was not unfelt.
vi: She did not overlook his praise for her and her sister.
tr: The compliments directed at her and her sister were not ignored.
es: The praise that Darcy bestowed upon her and her sister did not go unnoticed.

en: It soothed, but it could not console her for the contempt which had been thus self-attracted by the rest of her family; and as she considered that Jane’s disappointment had, in fact, been the work of her nearest relations, and reflected how materially the credit of both must be hurt by such impropriety of conduct, she felt depressed beyond anything she had ever known before.
vi: This helped her feel soothed, but it could not console her for the disdain towards the rest of the family. When she considered that Jane had been disappointed solely because of the attitude of their dearest relatives, and when she thought about how the reputation of those two had been harmed by such improper conduct, she felt a sorrow she had never experienced before.
tr: The compliments soothed the pain of the disgrace caused by her other family members, but they couldn't erase it; –while thinking that Jane's disappointment was actually the work of her closest relatives and how such vulgarity must have greatly damaged the dignity of both, she felt a distress heavier than anything she had ever experienced before.
es: It flattered her, but she could not console herself for the disdain it implied for the rest of the family; and upon considering that Jane's troubles had actually been caused by their own family, and reflecting on how the reputation of both would suffer due to such improper conduct, she felt a despondency she had never known before.

en: After wandering along the lane for two hours, giving way to every variety of thought, reconsidering events, determining probabilities, and reconciling herself, as well as she could, to a change so sudden and so important, fatigue, and a recollection of her long absence, made her at length return home; and she entered the house with the wish of appearing cheerful as usual, and the resolution of repressing such reflections as must make her unfit for conversation.
vi: After wandering along the path for two hours, indulging in every thought, reviewing events, determining possibilities, and trying to reconcile herself with the sudden and significant upheaval, fatigue and the sudden realization that she had been absent for quite a while made her turn back. She entered the house with the desire to appear cheerful as usual, and the firm intention to suppress the thoughts that made it difficult for her to converse with anyone.
tr: After walking on the path for two hours, getting caught up in all sorts of thoughts, reconsidering events, determining possibilities, and reconciling as best as he could with such a sudden and significant change, the fatigue and his long absence made him head home; he entered the house with the desire to appear cheerful as usual and with the decision to suppress thoughts that might cause him to become silent in the presence of others.
es: After walking for two hours along the road, turning over the diversity of her thoughts, reconsidering the events, determining possibilities, and gradually getting used to such a sudden and significant change, fatigue and the memory of how long she had been away made her return to the house. She entered with the intention of feigning her usual cheerfulness and resolved to suppress the thoughts that besieged her, as otherwise, she would not be able to maintain any conversation.

en: She was immediately told, that the two gentlemen from Rosings had each called during her absence; mr Darcy, only for a few minutes, to take leave, but that Colonel Fitzwilliam had been sitting with them at least an hour, hoping for her return, and almost resolving to walk after her till she could be found.
vi: She was informed that the two gentlemen from Rosings had visited while she was away. Mr. Darcy stayed only a few minutes, but Colonel Fitzwilliam had sat down for at least an hour, hoping she would return in time, almost wanting to go find her.
tr: As soon as she entered, they told her that while she was out, two gentlemen from Rosings had called separately; Mr. Darcy had stopped by for just a few minutes to say goodbye, but Colonel Fitzwilliam had sat with them for at least an hour in the hope of Elizabeth's return, and had even attempted to walk after her to find her.
es: They told her that the two gentlemen from Rosings had been there during her absence; Darcy only for a brief moment, to say goodbye; but that Colonel Fitzwilliam had stayed for at least an hour, to see if she arrived and almost ready to go in search of her.

en: Elizabeth could but just affect concern in missing him; she really rejoiced at it.
vi: Elizabeth could only feel concerned that she would miss him; in fact, she was happy about it.
tr: Elizabeth pretended to be sorry she had missed him, but inwardly she was glad.
es: Elizabeth was hardly affected by the colonel's departure; in fact, she was glad.

en: Colonel Fitzwilliam was no longer an object.
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam was no longer the subject, she could only think about the letter.
tr: Colonel Fitzwilliam no longer interested her.
es: Elizabeth was hardly affected by the colonel's departure; in fact, she was glad.

en: She could think only of her letter.
vi: Colonel Fitzwilliam was no longer the subject, she could only think about the letter.
tr: Now she could think of nothing but the letter in her hand.
es: She could only think about Darcy's letter.

en: CHAPTER XXXVII.
vi: Chapter 37
tr: Chapter XIV
es: CHAPTER XXXVII

en: THE two gentlemen left Rosings the next morning; and mr Collins having been in waiting near the lodges, to make them his parting obeisance, was able to bring home the pleasing intelligence of their appearing in very good health, and in as tolerable spirits as could be expected, after the melancholy scene so lately gone through at Rosings.
vi: The two young men left Rosings the next morning. After arriving at the place where the two were staying to bid farewell, Mr. Collins returned and happily reported to everyone that they were still in good health and in as good spirits as could be expected after the recent sorrowful events at Rosings.
tr: The two gentlemen left Rosings the next morning; Mr. Collins, who was waiting near the outbuildings to bid them farewell, came back to the house with this pleasant news: both of them appeared to be in very good health, and despite the sad scene that had just occurred at Rosings, they were in quite good spirits.
es: Both gentlemen left Rosings the next morning. Collins was waiting near the entrance gates to bid them farewell, and brought home the pleasant news that they seemed to be well and in a passable mood, as was to be expected after the melancholy scene that must have taken place at Rosings.

en: To Rosings he then hastened to console Lady Catherine and her daughter; and on his return brought back, with great satisfaction, a message from her Ladyship, importing that she felt herself so dull as to make her very desirous of having them all to dine with her.
vi: Then he hurried to Rosings to comfort Lady Catherine and her daughter. When he returned, with a look of complete satisfaction, he conveyed Lady Catherine's message that she felt quite lonely and was very eager to invite everyone to dinner.
tr: Then he hurried to Rosings to console Lady Catherine and her daughter; upon his return, he brought a message from Lady Catherine with great satisfaction; she felt so sorrowful that she wanted to see them all at dinner with her.
es: Collins then hurried to Rosings to console Lady Catherine and her daughter, and upon returning, he brought with great satisfaction a message from Her Ladyship, who was very sad and wished for everyone to dine with her.

en: Elizabeth could not see Lady Catherine without recollecting that, had she chosen it, she might by this time have been presented to her as her future niece; nor could she think, without a smile, of what her Ladyship’s indignation would have been.
vi: Elizabeth could not meet Lady Catherine without the thought that, if she wished, this time she could come to see her as her future niece-in-law. And she could not avoid the thought, with a smile, of her indignant reaction.
tr: Elizabeth could not look at Lady Catherine without thinking that she might have already been presented to her as her future niece; nor could she think, without smiling, of how her ladyship's anger would be.
es: Elizabeth could not see Lady Catherine without remembering that, if she had wanted, she would have been introduced to her as her future niece; nor could she think, without smiling, about how indignant she would have been.

en: “What would she have said?
vi: She found it amusing to ask herself: “What would she say?
tr: "What would she say?
es: What would she have said? What would she have done?

en: how would she have behaved?” were the questions with which she amused herself.
vi: How would she behave?”
tr: –how would she behave?" she amused herself with these questions.
es: It amused her to wonder about all these things.

en: Their first subject was the diminution of the Rosings’ party.
vi: Their first topic was the event that the two people had missed.
tr: The first topic was the reduced group at Rosings.
es: The first thing that was discussed was the decline suffered in the gatherings at Rosings.

en: “I assure you, I feel it exceedingly,” said Lady Catherine; “I believe nobody feels the loss of friends so much as I do.
vi: Lady Catherine said: - I hope you understand that I feel very deeply. I believe that no one feels the separation from loved ones as I do.
tr: –"Believe me, I feel it immensely," said Lady Catherine; "I'm sure no one feels the loss of their friends as much as I do.
es: ––I assure you that I am very sorry ––said Lady Catherine––; I believe that no one laments the loss of friends as much as I do.

en: But I am particularly attached to these young men; and know them to be so much attached to me!
vi: But I am particularly attached to these two young men, and I know they are also attached to me!
tr: But I am particularly fond of these young men; I know they are equally fond of me!
es: But, moreover, I love those boys so much and they love me so much!

en: They were excessively sorry to go!
vi: They are infinitely sad to say goodbye.
tr: –How sorry they were to leave!
es: They were very sad when they left, as always when we part.

en: But so they always are.
vi: But they have always been like that.
tr: They always are.
es: They were very sad when they left, as always when we part.

en: The dear Colonel rallied his spirits tolerably till just at last; but Darcy seemed to feel it most acutely—more, I think, than last year.
vi: The Colonel tried to stay cheerful until the last moment, but Darcy seemed somewhat sadder; I think he is sadder than last year.
tr: Dear Colonel kept his spirits up until the last moment; but Darcy seemed very upset, even more than last year, it seemed.
es: The colonel remained firm until the end, but Darcy's sorrow was much more acute, more than last year, in my opinion.

en: His attachment to Rosings certainly increases.”
vi: Surely he has felt more attached to Rosings.
tr: His attachment to Rosings is clearly growing."
es: I do not doubt that his affection for Rosings is increasing.

en: mr Collins had a compliment and an allusion to throw in here, which were kindly smiled on by the mother and daughter.
vi: Mr. Collins offered words of praise and added a hint, causing the mother and daughter to smile gently.
tr: Mr. Collins made a compliment here and also hinted at something, receiving a polite smile from both the mother and the daughter.
es: Collins had a compliment and an allusion to the matter, which mother and daughter received with a kind smile.

en: Lady Catherine observed, after dinner, that Miss Bennet seemed out of spirits; and immediately accounting for it herself, by supposing that she did not like to go home again so soon, she added,—
vi: After the meal, Lady Catherine remarked that Miss Bennet seemed depressed, and immediately assumed that she did not want to return home too early. She added:
tr: Lady Catherine said that Miss Bennet looked unwell after dinner, and then immediately stated the reason; because she did not want to return home so quickly; and continued,
es: After the meal, Lady Catherine observed that Miss Bennet seemed to be low in spirits. She immediately explained it in her own way, assuming that the idea of returning so soon to her parents' house did not appeal to her, and said:

en: “But if that is the case, you must write to your mother to beg that you may stay a little longer.
vi: - If that's true, you must immediately write a letter to your mother asking her to allow you to stay a little longer.
tr: "But if that's the case, write to your mother and ask for permission to stay a bit longer.
es: ––If that is the case, write to your mother to ask her to let you stay a little longer.

en: ms Collins will be very glad of your company, I am sure.”
vi: I am sure Mrs. Collins will be very happy to have your company.
tr: Mrs. Collins would be very happy for you to stay, I think."
es: I'm sure Mrs. Collins will be happy to have you by her side.

en: “I am much obliged to your Ladyship for your kind invitation,” replied Elizabeth; “but it is not in my power to accept it.
vi: Elizabeth replied: - I greatly appreciate the Lady's kind invitation, but I cannot accept.
tr: "I am grateful to Her Ladyship for the kind invitation," replied Elizabeth, "but it is not possible for me to accept it.
es: ––I greatly appreciate Your Lordship's kind invitation ––replied Elizabeth––, but I cannot accept it.

en: I must be in town next Saturday.”
vi: I have to return to the city next Saturday.
tr: –I must be in the city next Saturday."
es: I have to be in London next Saturday.

en: “Why, at that rate, you will have been here only six weeks.
vi: - That way, you will only be able to stay here for six weeks.
tr: "But if that's the case, you will have only stayed here for six weeks.
es: ––What! Then you have only been here for six weeks.

en: I expected you to stay two months.
vi: I had hoped you could stay for two months.
tr: I was expecting you to stay for two months.
es: I expected you to stay for two months; I told Mrs. Collins so before you arrived.

en: I told ms Collins so before you came.
vi: I told Mrs. Collins that before you came here.
tr: That's what I told Mrs. Collins before you arrived.
es: I expected you to stay for two months; I told Mrs. Collins so before you arrived.

en: There can be no occasion for your going so soon.
vi: There can't be anything that makes you leave in such a hurry.
tr: There can be no reason for you to leave so soon.
es: There is no reason for you to leave so soon.

en: ms Bennet could certainly spare you for another fortnight.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet will surely allow you to stay for another two weeks.
tr: Mrs. Bennet can certainly give you another fifteen days."
es: Mrs. Bennet will not mind if you stay another fortnight.

en: “But my father cannot.
vi: - But my father does not allow it.
tr: "But my father can't give it.
es: ––But my father, yes; he wrote to me last week asking me to come back soon.

en: He wrote last week to hurry my return.”
vi: Last week he wrote me a letter, telling me I must return in time.
tr: – Last week, he wrote and told me to return quickly."
es: ––But my father, yes; he wrote to me last week asking me to come back soon.

en: “Dawson”
vi: - Ah!
tr: "Oh, come on!
es: ––If your mother can do without you, your father will be able to as well.

en: “Oh, your father, of course, may spare you, if your mother can.
vi: Your father will certainly allow you, if your mother has already agreed.
tr: If your mother allows it, your father will definitely allow it too.
es: ––If your mother can do without you, your father will be able to as well.

en: Daughters are never of so much consequence to a father.
vi: Daughters are never important to fathers.
tr: –Girls are not that important to fathers.
es: Daughters are never as necessary to fathers as they are to mothers.

en: And if you will stay another month complete, it will be in my power to take one of you as far as London, for I am going there early in June, for a week; and as Dawson does not object to the barouche-box, there will be very good room for one of you—and, indeed, if the weather should happen to be cool, I should not object to taking you both, as you are neither of you large.”
vi: If you stay for a whole month, I will have the opportunity to take you all the way to London, because I will be going there in June and staying for a week. If Dawson agrees, one of you will have a comfortable room. In fact, if the weather turns cold, I wouldn't mind taking both of you, since you are both quite petite.
tr: If you stay for another month, I'll take one of you to London; I'm going at the beginning of June; since Dawson didn't object to the big car, there will be plenty of room for one of you –and if the weather is cool, I wouldn't say no to taking both of you, after all, neither of you are fat."
es: And if you would like to stay here another month, I could take you to London, because I have to go there at the beginning of June for a week; and since Danson won't mind traveling on the coachman's seat, there will be room for one of you, and if the weather is cool, I wouldn't mind taking both of you, as neither of you is stout.

en: “You are all kindness, madam; but I believe we must abide by our original plan.”
vi: - Madam, you are really kind, but we have to follow the planned schedule.
tr: "You are very kind, Madam; but it would be best to stick to our plan."
es: You are very kind, ma'am; but I believe we will have no choice but to do what we had originally planned.

en: Lady Catherine seemed resigned.
vi: Lady Catherine seemed to have to accept it.
tr: Lady Catherine seemed to be giving up.
es: Lady Catherine seemed to resign herself.

en: “ms Collins, you must send a servant with them.
vi: - Mrs. Collins, you must send a servant to accompany the two girls.
tr: "Mrs. Collins, you must give them a servant.
es: ––Mrs. Collins, you will have to send a servant with them.

en: You know I always speak my mind, and I cannot bear the idea of two young women travelling post by themselves.
vi: You know, I always speak my mind, and I cannot bear the thought of just two young girls going together.
tr: You know, I always say what's on my mind; I can't bear the thought of two young ladies traveling alone in a hired carriage.
es: You know that I always say what I feel, and I cannot bear the idea of two young ladies traveling alone in the coach.

en: It is highly improper.
vi: That is not proper at all.
tr: It's very improper.
es: It is not proper.

en: You must contrive to send somebody.
vi: I do not like to see this at all.
tr: Find someone, send them.
es: Find a way to have someone accompany them.

en: I have the greatest dislike in the world to that sort of thing.
vi: I do not like to see this at all.
tr: This is the kind of thing I detest the most in the world.
es: There is nothing I dislike as much as that.

en: Young women should always be properly guarded and attended, according to their situation in life.
vi: Young women should always have someone to protect and care for them, depending on their circumstances.
tr: –Young ladies should always have a companion, a protector, according to their status.
es: Young ladies must always be guarded and attended to according to their position.

en: When my niece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last summer, I made a point of her having two men-servants go with her.
vi: When my niece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last year, I pointed out that two servants should go with her.
tr: When my niece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last summer, I insisted on having two footmen with her.
es: When my niece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last summer, I insisted that two male servants go with them; otherwise, it would be improper for Miss Darcy, the daughter of Mr. Darcy of Pemberley and Lady Anne.

en: Miss Darcy, the daughter of mr Darcy of Pemberley, and Lady Anne, could not have appeared with propriety in a different manner.
vi: Miss Darcy, the daughter of Mr. Darcy of Pemberly, and Lady Ann cannot go out properly in any other way.
tr: –Miss Darcy, the daughter of Mr. Darcy of Pemberley and Lady Anne, could not appear otherwise, it would be unbecoming.
es: When my niece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last summer, I insisted that two male servants go with them; otherwise, it would be improper for Miss Darcy, the daughter of Mr. Darcy of Pemberley and Lady Anne.

en: I am excessively attentive to all those things.
vi: I am very attentive to this matter.
tr: –I pay extreme attention to such matters.
