es: I am very careful about these things.

en: You must send John with the young ladies, ms Collins.
vi: Mrs. Collins, you need to send John with the girls.
tr: You must send John with the young ladies, Mrs. Collins.
es: Send John with the young ladies, Mrs. Collins.

en: I am glad it occurred to me to mention it; for it would really be discreditable to you to let them go alone.”
vi: I am glad to remember to remind you of this, for you will lose your reputation if you let the two girls go alone.
tr: I'm glad it occurred to me to say it; if you had sent them alone, you would have done something truly unforgivable."
es: I am glad it occurred to me, for it would be disgraceful for you to send them alone.

en: “My uncle is to send a servant for us.”
vi: - My uncle will send a servant to pick us up.
tr: "My uncle will send a servant for us.""
es: ––My uncle will send us a servant.

en: “Oh!
vi: - Ah!
tr: "Ha, your uncle!
es: ––Ah!

en: Your uncle!
vi: Your uncle!
tr: "Ha, your uncle!
es: An uncle of yours!

en: He keeps a man-servant, does he?
vi: He has a male servant, doesn't he?
tr: –He has a child, does he?
es: So you have a servant?

en: I am very glad you have somebody who thinks of those things.
vi: I am very pleased that you ladies have thought of this.
tr: –I'm glad you have a relative who thinks about these kinds of things.
es: I'm glad you have someone who thinks about these things.

en: Where shall you change horses?
vi: Where will you change horses?
tr: Where will you change the horses?
es: Where will you change horses?

en: Oh, Bromley, of course.
vi: Ah, Bromley, of course.
tr: –Ah, Bromley of course.
es: Oh! In Bromley, of course.

en: If you mention my name at the Bell, you will be attended to.”
vi: If you mention my name at Bell, they will take care of you.
tr: –If you give my name at the Bell Inn, they will serve you well."
es: If you mention my name at "The Bell," they will take good care of you.

en: Lady Catherine had many other questions to ask respecting their journey; and as she did not answer them all herself attention was necessary—which Elizabeth believed to be lucky for her; or, with a mind so occupied, she might have forgotten where she was.
vi: Mrs. Catherine asked many more questions about the journey of the two ladies, and since Elizabeth could not answer all the questions herself, she had to pay attention, and she found herself fortunate. Because, with a mind full of worries, she almost forgot where she was.
tr: Lady Catherine had many more questions to ask about her travels, and it was necessary to pay attention because she did not answer all the questions herself, which pleased Elizabeth, otherwise, she might forget where she was while her mind was so occupied.
es: Lady Catherine had many other questions to ask about the trip, and since not all of them were answered by her, Elizabeth had to pay attention to her; it was fortunate, for otherwise, with her head so occupied, she would have forgotten where she was.

en: Reflection must be reserved for solitary hours: whenever she was alone, she gave way to it as the greatest relief; and not a day went by without a solitary walk, in which she might indulge in all the delight of unpleasant recollections.
vi: Thoughts should be reserved for solitary moments; whenever she was alone, she considered this the best solace. Every day she had a solitary walk, during which she could indulge in the pleasure of not-so-pleasant recollections.
tr: Reflection should be reserved for solitary hours; whenever she was alone, she gave herself up to thought with great relief; not a single day passed without her taking a solitary walk and indulging in all the pleasure of her troubling memories.
es: She had to reserve her meditations for her solitary hours; when she was alone, she indulged in them as her greatest relief; not a day passed without her going for a walk to immerse herself in the delight of her unpleasant memories.

en: mr Darcy’s letter she was in a fair way of soon knowing by heart.
vi: Before long, she had memorized Mr. Darcy's letter.
tr: At this rate, she would memorize Mr. Darcy's letter.
es: She almost knew Darcy's letter by heart.

en: She studied every sentence; and her feelings towards its writer were at times widely different.
vi: She pondered over each sentence, and her feelings towards the writer changed greatly over time.
tr: She examined every sentence; her feelings towards the author of the letter frequently changed.
es: She studied its phrases one by one, and her feelings towards its author were sometimes extremely conflicted.

en: When she remembered the style of his address, she was still full of indignation: but when she considered how unjustly she had condemned and upbraided him, her anger was turned against herself; and his disappointed feelings became the object of compassion.
vi: When she recalled his manner of speaking, she was still full of indignation. But when she thought of how unjustly she had condemned and scolded him, she was angry at herself; his feelings became an object of her compassion.
tr: When she remembered the writing style, she was still filled with anger; but when she thought about how unjustly she had accused and condemned him, her anger turned towards herself; she began to pity Mr. Darcy for his unrequited feelings.
es: When she focused on the tone in which he addressed her, she was filled with indignation, but when she considered how unjustly she had condemned and vilified him, her anger turned against herself and she pitied Darcy's disillusionment.

en: His attachment excited gratitude, his general character respect: but she could not approve him; nor could she for a moment repent her refusal, or feel the slightest inclination ever to see him again.
vi: She was glad that he loved her; she respected his character, but could not accept him; and at no time did she regret rejecting him, nor did she have any fleeting desire to see him again.
tr: The man's interest evoked gratitude, his character respect; yet Elizabeth still could not accept him, she did not even regret rejecting him for a moment; she did not even feel like seeing him again.
es: His love for her stirred her gratitude, and his general demeanor, her respect; but she could not accept him and never for a moment regretted having rejected him nor felt the slightest desire to see him again.

en: In her own past behaviour, there was a constant source of vexation and regret: and in the unhappy defects of her family, a subject of yet heavier chagrin.
vi: In her past behavior, there were always sources of annoyance and regret; and the shortcomings of her family were a matter that caused her even more distress.
tr: Within her past behaviors, there was a constant source of distress and regret, and in the sad mistakes of her family, an even heavier subject of unhappiness.
es: The way she had behaved filled her with constant shame and regret, and the unfortunate flaws of her family caused her horrible discomfort.

en: They were hopeless of remedy.
vi: She felt hopeless to remedy it.
tr: Their situation was hopeless.
es: There was no remedy.

en: Her father, contented with laughing at them, would never exert himself to restrain the wild giddiness of his youngest daughters; and her mother, with manners so far from right herself, was entirely insensible of the evil.
vi: Her father only wanted to joke and never restrained the frivolity of the young daughters. Her mother, with attitudes that were still improper, was completely insensitive to the harm.
tr: Their father, who consoled himself by laughing at them, did not make any effort to restrain the wild recklessness of his younger daughters; their mother, with actions far from propriety, was unaware of the vulgarity at hand.
es: Her father merely mocked her younger sisters, but never attempted to curb their impetuous recklessness; and her mother, whose manners were so far from any decorum, was completely insensitive to the danger.

en: Elizabeth had frequently united with Jane in an endeavour to check the imprudence of Catherine and Lydia; but while they were supported by their mother’s indulgence, what chance could there be of improvement?
vi: Elizabeth often tried with Jane to control the impulsiveness of Catherine and Lydia, but while their mother indulged them, what chance was there for the two to improve?
tr: Elizabeth often joined hands with Jane, trying to control the instability of Catherine and Lydia; but how could they possibly improve as long as they were supported by their mother's obsession?
es: Elizabeth had often conspired with Jane to curb Catherine and Lydia's imprudence, but as long as they had their mother's indulgence, what hope was there that they would be corrected?

en: Catherine, weak-spirited, irritable, and completely under Lydia’s guidance, had been always affronted by their advice; and Lydia, self-willed and careless, would scarcely give them a hearing.
vi: Catherine, with her weak and irritable nature, always being led by Lydia, was always displeased with her sisters' advice. Lydia, with her self-willed and careless disposition, rarely listened to them.
tr: Weak-willed, uneasy, and having taken Lydia as her complete role model, Catherine was offended by their advice; ambitious and indifferent Lydia did not even hear them.
es: Catherine, weak and irritable in character and absolutely submissive to Lydia's direction, had always rebelled against their warnings; and Lydia, capricious and carefree, paid them no heed.

en: They were ignorant, idle, and vain.
vi: Both were foolish, lazy, and empty-headed.
tr: They were ignorant, idle, and headstrong.
es: Both were ignorant, lazy, and vain.

en: While there was an officer in Meryton, they would flirt with him; and while Meryton was within a walk of Longbourn, they would be going there for ever.
vi: As long as there were officers in Meryton, the two would continue to flirt with them; as long as Meryton was just a walk away from Longbourn, they would always go there.
tr: As long as there were officers in Meryton, they would flirt with them; as long as Meryton was within walking distance of Longbourn, they would go there forever.
es: As long as there was an officer in Meryton, they would flirt with him, and as long as Meryton was so close to Longbourn, nothing could prevent them from going there all their lives.

en: Anxiety on Jane’s behalf was another prevailing concern; and mr Darcy’s explanation, by restoring Bingley to all her former good opinion, heightened the sense of what Jane had lost.
vi: Another concern was worrying about Jane. Mr. Darcy's explanation, by restoring Bingley to her good graces, made her understand what Jane had lost.
tr: Another source of her unhappiness was the worry she felt for Jane; Mr. Darcy's explanation had revived all her former positive opinions about Bingley, making her feel the magnitude of Jane's loss even more.
es: The anxiety for Jane's fate was another of her predominant concerns. Darcy's explanation, by restoring Bingley to the good opinion she previously had of him, made her better realize what Jane had lost.

en: His affection was proved to have been sincere, and his conduct cleared of all blame, unless any could attach to the implicitness of his confidence in his friend.
vi: His feelings were proven to be sincere, his behavior showed nothing to criticize, except that he might be faulted for relying too much on his friend's opinion.
tr: Bingley's love had proven to be genuine, his behavior free from blame, unless one finds fault in his unquestioning trust in his friend.
es: Bingley's affection was sincere and his conduct had been impeccable, except for his blind trust in his friend.

en: How grievous then was the thought that, of a situation so desirable in every respect, so replete with advantage, so promising for happiness, Jane had been deprived, by the folly and indecorum of her own family!
vi: She felt even more compassion when she thought that, with a situation favorable in every way, full of advantages, full of promises of happiness, Jane was deprived of it all, just because her own family had been too foolish and impolite!
tr: How painful it was that Jane, in every way so perfect, so satisfying, so promising of happiness, had lost such a match due to her own family's foolishness and lack of manners!
es: How sad, then, it was to think that Jane had been deprived of such a desirable position in every sense, so full of advantages and so promising in happiness, due to the folly and lack of decorum of her own family!

en: When to these recollections was added the development of Wickham’s character, it may be easily believed that the happy spirits which had seldom been depressed before were now so much affected as to make it almost impossible for her to appear tolerably cheerful.
vi: When Wickham's true nature was added to this recollection, the previously seldom suppressed happy sentiments were now so heavily affected that she could hardly even pretend to be relatively cheerful.
tr: When the emergence of Wickham's character was added to these thoughts, it can easily be believed that it made it impossible for her to appear even somewhat cheerful, whereas she had previously rarely been in a dark mood.
es: When to all this was added the discovery of Wickham's true personality, it was easily understood that Elizabeth's jovial spirit, which had rarely felt depressed, had now declined to such an extent that it was almost impossible for her to feign even a little joy.

en: Their engagements at Rosings were as frequent during the last week of her stay as they had been at first.
vi: The social gatherings at Rosings remained frequent during the last week of her stay, just as frequent as during the first week.
tr: During the last week of her visit, the invitations at Rosings were as frequent as they were in the first week.
es: Invitations to Rosings were as frequent during the last week of their stay in Hunsford as they were at the beginning.

en: The very last evening was spent there; and her Ladyship again inquired minutely into the particulars of their journey, gave them directions as to the best method of packing, and was so urgent on the necessity of placing gowns in the only right way, that Maria thought herself obliged, on her return, to undo all the work of the morning, and pack her trunk afresh.
vi: On the evening of the last day, they went to the Lady's residence, where she once again inquired thoroughly about the two girls' journey and gave instructions on how to arrange their luggage. She spoke urgently about the necessity of arranging evening dresses in the only way she deemed correct, to the extent that Maria thought she would unpack all her luggage to rearrange it upon returning.
tr: The last evening was also spent there; Her Ladyship once again inquired in detail about their travels, gave instructions on the best methods for packing, and insisted so much on the only correct way to arrange clothes that Maria felt compelled to undo all her work from the morning and repack her trunk from scratch when they returned home.
es: The last evening was spent there, and Her Ladyship once again asked meticulous questions about the details of the trip, gave them instructions on the best way to pack the trunks, and insisted so much on the necessity of arranging the dresses in the only way she deemed proper, that when they returned to the house, Maria felt obliged to undo all her morning's work and had to repack.

en: When they parted, Lady Catherine, with great condescension, wished them a good journey, and invited them to come to Hunsford again next year; and Miss de Bourgh exerted herself so far as to courtesy and hold out her hand to both.
vi: When they bid farewell, Lady Catherine, with extreme humility, wished the two ladies a pleasant journey and invited them to visit Huntsford again the following year. As for Miss De Bourgh, she merely nodded and shook hands with the two ladies.
tr: When they parted, Lady Catherine deigned to wish them a good journey and invited them to come to Hunsford again next year; Miss de Bourgh also made an effort to curtsy and extended her hand to both of them.
es: When they left, Lady Catherine deigned to wish them a pleasant journey and invited them to return to Hunsford the following year. Miss de Bourgh extended her effort to the courtesy of shaking hands with both of them.

en: CHAPTER XXXVIII.
vi: Chapter 38
tr: Chapter XV
es: CHAPTER XXXVIII

en: ON Saturday morning Elizabeth and mr Collins met for breakfast a few minutes before the others appeared; and he took the opportunity of paying the parting civilities which he deemed indispensably necessary.
vi: On Saturday morning, Elizabeth and Mr. Collins met for a few minutes before the others appeared, and he took the opportunity to express a few polite words of farewell that he thought were very necessary. He said:
tr: On Saturday morning, Elizabeth and Mr. Collins met at breakfast a few minutes before the others arrived; Mr. Collins seized the opportunity to say the polite words he deemed absolutely necessary for a farewell.
es: On Saturday morning, Elizabeth and Collins met at breakfast a few minutes before the others appeared; and he took the opportunity to offer her the farewell compliments he considered absolutely necessary.

en: “I know not, Miss Elizabeth,” said he, “whether ms Collins has yet expressed her sense of your kindness in coming to us; but I am very certain you will not leave the house without receiving her thanks for it.
vi: - Miss Elizabeth, I am not sure if Mrs. Collins has expressed her feelings about your kind visit to us, but I am certain she will thank you when you leave.
tr: "I don't know, Miss Elizabeth," he said, "perhaps Mrs. Collins has not yet expressed her own feelings about the kindness you have shown by coming to us, but I am quite sure that you will not leave this house without receiving her thanks.
es: ––I am unaware, Miss Elizabeth ––he said––, whether Mrs. Collins has expressed to you how grateful she is for your kindness in coming; but I am sure she will do so before you leave this house.

en: The favour of your company has been much felt, I assure you.
vi: Please believe that we are very touched by your group's visit to us.
tr: Rest assured, the happiness your presence has brought is deeply felt.
es: We have greatly appreciated the favor of your company.

en: We know how little there is to tempt anyone to our humble abode.
vi: We think our humble abode has nothing attractive to visitors.
tr: We know that there is very little in our humble abode to make it appealing to people.
es: We know how unappealing it can be for anyone to come to our humble abode.

en: Our plain manner of living, our small rooms, and few domestics, and the little we see of the world, must make Hunsford extremely dull to a young lady like yourself; but I hope you will believe us grateful for the condescension, and that we have done everything in our power to prevent you spending your time unpleasantly.”
vi: Our simple way of living, the small rooms, few servants; and since we seldom go out to explore the outside world, all of this surely makes Huntsford completely boring for a young lady like you. But I hope you will believe that we have been very happy to humble ourselves, and we have done everything we can to make your time here pleasant.
tr: Our simple life, small rooms, few servants, and limited means must make Hunsford extremely dull for a young lady like yourself; but we hope you will believe that we are grateful for your condescension in coming, and that we have done everything in our power to prevent you from being bored during your stay here."
es: Our simple way of living, our small rooms, our few servants, and our isolation must make Hunsford an extremely dreary place for a young lady like yourself. But I hope you believe in our gratitude for your condescension and that we have done everything within our power to prevent you from being bored.

en: Elizabeth was eager with her thanks and assurances of happiness.
vi: Elizabeth eagerly responded with thanks and reassured him that she was satisfied.
tr: Elizabeth thanked eagerly, wanting them to be sure that she was happy.
es: Elizabeth thanked her effusively and said she was very happy.

en: She had spent six weeks with great enjoyment; and the pleasure of being with Charlotte, and the kind attention she had received, must make her feel the obliged.
vi: She had spent six weeks in happiness and was pleased to have Charlotte's company; the attentions given to her made her very appreciative.
tr: She had spent six weeks with great pleasure; the joy of being with Charlotte, and the close attention shown to her, made her the one who should be truly grateful.
es: She had spent six very happy weeks; and the pleasure of being with Charlotte and the kind attentions she had received had left her very satisfied.

en: mr Collins was gratified; and with a more smiling solemnity replied,—
vi: Mr. Collins was delighted, and with a more solemn yet cheerful demeanor, he replied:
tr: Mr. Collins was very pleased and replied with a more smiling solemnity,
es: Collins celebrated it solemnly, but with a more smiling demeanor, he replied:

en: “It gives me the greatest pleasure to hear that you have passed your time not disagreeably.
vi: - I am very pleased to hear that your stay here has not been too unpleasant.
tr: "I am very glad to hear that you did not spend your time badly.
es: ––It gives me the greatest pleasure to know that you have spent your time pleasantly.

en: We have certainly done our best; and most fortunately having it in our power to introduce you to very superior society, and from our connection with Rosings, the frequent means of varying the humble home scene, I think we may flatter ourselves that your Hunsford visit cannot have been entirely irksome.
vi: We certainly did our best; fortunately, we had the circumstances to introduce you to a very distinguished society, and from our relationship with Rosings, which provides a change of atmosphere compared to our humble home, I think we can be satisfied that your visit to Huntsford was not too dull.
tr: Of course, we did our best; fortunately, we were also able to introduce you to very high-ranking individuals; I think we can take some pride in our connection with Rosings, which often brings liveliness to our humble home atmosphere, if your visit to Hunsford was not entirely dull.
es: Everything that could be done has indeed been done; we have had the supreme luck of being able to introduce you to the highest society, and the frequent means of varying the humble domestic scene that our relations with Rosings have facilitated, allow us to hope that your visit has been pleasant.

en: Our situation with regard to Lady Catherine’s family is, indeed, the sort of extraordinary advantage and blessing which few can boast.
vi: Our circumstances in relation to Lady Catherine's family are indeed an exceptional advantage and fortune that few possess.
tr: Our situation with Lady Catherine's family is indeed a very exceptional privilege, an honor that very few people can attain.
es: Our dealings with Lady Catherine's family are truly an extraordinary advantage and a blessing that few can boast of.

en: You see on what a footing we are.
vi: You have seen what our status is like.
tr: You see what friends we have.
es: You have seen the situation we are in at Rosings, how many times we have been invited there.

en: You see how continually we are engaged there.
vi: You have seen how frequently we interact with them.
tr: You see how we are constantly invited.
es: You have seen the situation we are in at Rosings, how many times we have been invited there.

en: In truth, I must acknowledge, that, with all the disadvantages of this humble parsonage, I should not think anyone abiding in it an object of compassion, while they are sharers of our intimacy at Rosings.”
vi: Honestly, I must admit that, with the disadvantages of the humble Parsonage here, I did not dare to think that anyone would be kind enough to come to this place, while on the contrary, they are eager to share in our private moments at Rosings.
tr: In fact, I must confess that despite all the flaws of this modest parsonage, no one living in it would be pitiable as long as they share our closeness with Rosings."
es: I must sincerely acknowledge that, with all the disadvantages of this humble parsonage, no one who comes here can pity themselves as long as they can share our intimacy with the Bourgh family.

en: Words were insufficient for the elevation of his feelings; and he was obliged to walk about the room, while Elizabeth tried to unite civility and truth in a few short sentences.
vi: Words could never suffice to elevate his ideas, so he had to pace around the room while Elizabeth tried to blend politeness and truth into a few short sentences.
tr: Words failed in the face of the intensity of his emotions; he had to pace around the room; meanwhile, Elizabeth was trying to politely condense the truth into a few short sentences.
es: Words were insufficient to express the elevation of his feelings, and he found himself compelled to pace the room, while Elizabeth tried to combine truth with courtesy in brief phrases.

en: “You may, in fact, carry a very favourable report of us into Hertfordshire, my dear cousin.
vi: He continued: - My dear cousin, in fact, you can tell Herfordshire all the favorable things about us.
tr: "Of course, you can take a very favorable report about us back to Hertfordshire, my dear cousin.
es: ––So, then, you will be able to bring good news from us to Hertfordshire, dear cousin.

en: I flatter myself, at least, that you will be able to do so.
vi: I take pride in the fact that at least you can do this.
tr: At least being able to do that would make me proud.
es: At least this is my hope.

en: Lady Catherine’s great attentions to ms Collins you have been a daily witness of; and altogether I trust it does not appear that your friend has drawn an unfortunate—but on this point it will be as well to be silent.
vi: Every day you have witnessed Lady Catherine paying special attention to Mrs. Collins, and generally, I believe your friend does not seem to be without troubles, but we should remain silent about this.
tr: You have witnessed day by day the great kindness Lady Catherine has shown to Mrs. Collins; finally, I hope your friend is not so unfortunate a – but anyway, it is best to remain silent on this matter.
es: You have been a daily witness to Lady Catherine's great attentions towards Mrs. Collins, and I trust it has not seemed to you that your friend is unhappy. But regarding this point, it is better that I remain silent.

en: Only let me assure you, my dear Miss Elizabeth, that I can from my heart most cordially wish you equal felicity in marriage.
vi: My dear Elizabeth, I just want to assure you that deep down I sincerely wish you the utmost happiness in marriage.
tr: Just believe, dear Miss Elizabeth, that I sincerely and wholeheartedly wish you such a happy marriage.
es: Allow me only to assure you, dear Miss Elizabeth, that I wholeheartedly wish you the same happiness in your marriage.

en: My dear Charlotte and I have but one mind and one way of thinking.
vi: My beloved Charlotte and I share the same sentiments and thoughts.
tr: My dear Charlotte and I have become of one mind and one soul.
es: My dear Charlotte and I have but one will and one way of thinking.

en: There is in everything a most remarkable resemblance of character and ideas between us.
vi: In everything, we are extraordinarily compatible with each other in both character and feelings.
tr: There is a magnificent similarity of feeling and thought between us in everything.
es: There exist between us very notable similarities of character and ideas; we seem made for each other.

en: We seem to have been designed for each other.”
vi: It seems as if we were born to live for each other.
tr: It is as if we were made for each other."
es: There exist between us very notable similarities of character and ideas; we seem made for each other.

en: Elizabeth could safely say that it was a great happiness where that was the case, and with equal sincerity could add, that she firmly believed and rejoiced in his domestic comforts.
vi: Elizabeth said moderately that it was a great happiness in such a situation, with the same sincere tone, she added that she firmly believed and was glad about the comforts in his family.
tr: Elizabeth could easily say that this situation was a great happiness; with the same sincerity, she managed to add that she wholeheartedly believed in and rejoiced in her familial peace.
es: Elizabeth could truly say that it was a great joy that it was so, and with the same sincerity, she added that she firmly believed it and was glad for her domestic well-being; however, she did not regret that the description of it was interrupted by the arrival of the lady in question.

en: She was not sorry, however, to have the recital of them interrupted by the entrance of the lady from whom they sprang.
vi: However, she did not regret seeing the account of these comforts interrupted because the person they were talking about stepped in.
tr: However, she was not at all sorry that their conversation was interrupted by the entrance of the lady they were talking about.
es: Elizabeth could truly say that it was a great joy that it was so, and with the same sincerity, she added that she firmly believed it and was glad for her domestic well-being; however, she did not regret that the description of it was interrupted by the arrival of the lady in question.

en: Poor Charlotte!
vi: Poor Charlotte!
tr: Poor Charlotte!
es: Poor Charlotte!

en: it was melancholy to leave her to such society!
vi: It was indeed sad to let her live among such people!
tr: –how sad it was to leave her to such a life!
es: It was sad to leave her in such company!

en: But she had chosen it with her eyes open; and though evidently regretting that her visitors were to go, she did not seem to ask for compassion.
vi: But she had chosen this with a clear intention, and obviously, she was sad because the guests were about to leave, as if she did not want anyone to pity her.
tr: –But she had chosen this herself, knowingly; she was obviously sorry to see her guests leave, but she did not have an air of expecting pity.
es: But she had chosen it consciously. It was clear that she was pained by the departure of her guests, but she did not seem to want to be pitied.

en: Her home and her housekeeping, her parish and her poultry, and all their dependent concerns, had not yet lost their charms.
vi: Her house and her housekeeping, her parish and her flock of chickens, and all their dependent relationships, had not yet lost their charm.
tr: Her house and household chores, her church and chickens, and all the concerns related to these had not yet lost their charm.
es: Her home and domestic chores, her parish, her chicken coop, and all the other associated tasks had not yet lost their charm for her.

en: At length the chaise arrived, the trunks were fastened on, the parcels placed within, and it was pronounced to be ready.
vi: Finally, the carriage arrived, the luggage was securely tied to the vehicle, the packages were loaded in the middle, and then it was announced that everything was ready.
tr: Finally, the car arrived, the crates were tied, the packages were placed inside, and it was announced that it was ready to move.
es: Finally, the stagecoach arrived; the trunks were loaded, the packages were arranged, and they were informed that everything was ready.

en: After an affectionate parting between the friends, Elizabeth was attended to the carriage by mr Collins; and as they walked down the garden, he was commissioning her with his best respects to all her family, not forgetting his thanks for the kindness he had received at Longbourn in the winter, and his compliments to mr and ms Gardiner, though unknown.
vi: After heartfelt goodbyes, Mr. Collins escorted Elizabeth to the carriage. As they passed through the flower garden, he sent his most respectful regards to her family, not forgetting to thank them for the kindness he received during the winter at Longbourn, and extended his greetings to Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, even though he had not yet met them.
tr: After an emotional farewell among friends, Mr. Collins escorted Elizabeth to the car; as they walked down the garden, Mr. Collins was asking her to convey his deepest respects to her family, his thanks for the hospitality he received at Longbourn during the winter, and his regards to Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, even though he did not know them.
es: The two friends said their affectionate goodbyes, and Collins accompanied Elizabeth to the carriage. As they crossed the garden, he asked her to convey his warm regards to the entire family and to repeat his gratitude for the kindnesses they had shown him during his stay in Longbourn last winter, and he urged her to also greet the Gardiners even though he did not know them. He helped her into the carriage and, after her, Maria.

en: He then handed her in, Maria followed, and the door was on the point of being closed, when he suddenly reminded them, with some consternation, that they had hitherto forgotten to leave any message for the ladies of Rosings.
vi: Then he helped Elizabeth into the carriage, with Maria following behind, and just as the door was about to close, he suddenly, with some anxiety, reminded the two ladies that they had forgotten to send their regards to the women at Rosings.
tr: Then he took her hand and helped her get in, Maria followed her, and just as the door was about to close, he suddenly remembered with a certain concern that they had forgotten to leave a message for the ladies at Rosings.
es: Just as he was about to close the doors, Collins, distressed, reminded them that they had forgotten to ask him to convey something to the ladies of Rosings.

en: “They had forgotten to leave any message”
vi: He added:
tr: Then he took her hand and helped her get in, Maria followed her, and just as the door was about to close, he suddenly remembered with a certain concern that they had forgotten to leave a message for the ladies at Rosings.
es: Just as he was about to close the doors, Collins, distressed, reminded them that they had forgotten to ask him to convey something to the ladies of Rosings.

en: “But,” he added, “you will of course wish to have your humble respects delivered to them, with your grateful thanks for their kindness to you while you have been here.”
vi: - But of course, she will send them humble respects to thank them for their kindness during her time here.
tr: "But," he added, "of course you would like your deepest respects and your heartfelt thanks for the kindness they have shown during your stay here to be conveyed to them."
es: ––But ––he added–– surely they would want us to convey their humble respects along with their gratitude for your kindness towards them.

en: Elizabeth made no objection: the door was then allowed to be shut, and the carriage drove off.
vi: Elizabeth agreed, then the door closed, and the car drove away.
tr: Elizabeth did not object; –then the door was allowed to close and the carriage set off.
es: Elizabeth did not object; the door closed and the carriage departed.

en: “Good gracious!” cried Maria, after a few minutes’ silence, “it seems but a day or two since we first came!
vi: Maria exclaimed, after a few moments of silence: - My goodness! It seems like we've only been here for a few days!
tr: "Oh my God!" cried Maria after a few minutes of silence, "it feels like we just arrived a day or two ago!
es: ––My God! ––exclaimed María after a few minutes of silence––.

en: and yet how many things have happened!”
vi: And yet so many things have happened!
tr: –but so much has happened!"
es: It seems like it was just yesterday when we arrived and yet, so many things have happened!

en: “A great many indeed,” said her companion, with a sigh.
vi: Elizabeth sighed: - Indeed, many things have happened.
tr: "A lot has really happened," said his travel companion with a sigh.
es: ––Many, it's true ––replied her companion with a sigh.

en: “We have dined nine times at Rosings, besides drinking tea there twice!
vi: - We have dined at Rosings nine times, besides having tea twice!
tr: "We had dinner at Rosings nine times, and we also had tea three times!
es: ––We have dined at Rosings nine times, and we have had tea there twice.

en: How much I shall have to tell!”
vi: I will have so many stories to tell.
tr: –I have so much to tell!"
es: How much I have to tell!

en: Elizabeth privately added, “And how much I shall have to conceal!”
vi: In her heart, Elizabeth added: "And you will have so many more things to keep secret."
tr: "I also have so many things to hide," said Elizabeth to herself.
es: Elizabeth added to herself: "And I, how many things I have to keep to myself!"

en: Their journey was performed without much conversation, or any alarm; and within four hours of their leaving Hunsford they reached mr Gardiner’s house, where they were to remain a few days.
vi: The two ladies spoke little to each other during the trip. Within four hours, they arrived at Mr. Gardiner's house, where they stayed for a few days.
tr: They didn't talk much along the way; there were no mishaps either; four hours after leaving Hunsford, they reached Mr. Gardiner's house; they would stay there for a few days.
es: The journey passed without much conversation and without any incident, and four hours after leaving Hunsford, they arrived at the Gardiners' house, where they were going to spend a few days.

en: Jane looked well, and Elizabeth had little opportunity of studying her spirits, amidst the various engagements which the kindness of her aunt had reserved for them.
vi: Jane appeared to be in good health, but amidst the gatherings that their aunt organized for them, Elizabeth had little opportunity to understand her sister's feelings.
tr: Jane looked well; Elizabeth did not find time to examine her among the various entertainments her aunt had prepared for them.
es: Jane looked very well, and Elizabeth hardly had a chance to examine her state of mind, as her aunt had prepared countless invitations for them.

en: But Jane was to go home with her, and at Longbourn there would be leisure enough for observation.
vi: However, Jane would return home with her, and at Longbourn, there would be plenty of time to observe.
tr: But Jane would also be returning home with her, and there would be plenty of free time to observe at Longbourn.
es: But Jane was going to return to Longbourn with her sister, and once there, there would be plenty of time to observe her.

en: It was not without an effort, meanwhile, that she could wait even for Longbourn, before she told her sister of mr Darcy’s proposals.
vi: But while waiting, with a little effort, Elizabeth told her sister about Mr. Darcy's proposal.
tr: Meanwhile, even waiting for Longbourn to tell her sister about Mr. Darcy's proposal required a considerable effort.
es: Elizabeth barely managed to restrain herself from telling her until then about Darcy's proposals.

en: To know that she had the power of revealing what would so exceedingly astonish Jane, and must, at the same time, so highly gratify whatever of her own vanity she had not yet been able to reason away, was such a temptation to openness as nothing could have conquered, but the state of indecision in which she remained as to the extent of what she should communicate, and her fear, if she once entered on the subject, of being hurried into repeating something of Bingley, which might only grieve her sister further.
vi: Knowing that she had the ability to reveal something that would astonish Jane greatly, while simultaneously making her pleased with her own frivolity which she could not yet explain – this was what prompted her to confide in her sister, except for the hesitation about how much to reveal and her fear of acting rashly like Bingley, which would cause her sister further distress.
tr: Knowing that she had the power to reveal something that would astonish Jane to such a degree and at the same time flatter the pride she had not yet managed to rid herself of, tempted her so much that she could only resist this temptation thanks to her indecision about how much to reveal and the fear that if she started to tell, she might inadvertently repeat something about Bingley that could cause her sister even more pain.
es: What a surprise she was going to get, and how gratifying it would be for the vanity that Elizabeth still could not master! It was such a strong temptation that she would not have been able to resist it if it were not for the indecision she found herself in, the extent of what she had to communicate, and the fear that if she started talking, she would be forced to mention Bingley, which would only succeed in making her sister even sadder.

en: CHAPTER XXXIX.
vi: Chapter 39
tr: Chapter XVI
es: CHAPTER XXXIX

en: IT was the second week in May, in which the three young ladies set out together from Gracechurch Street for the town of ——, in Hertfordshire; and, as they drew near the appointed inn where mr Bennet’s carriage was to meet them, they quickly perceived, in token of the coachman’s punctuality, both Kitty and Lydia looking out of a dining-room upstairs.
vi: In the second week of May, three young girls traveled together from Gracechurch Street to Hertfordshire. As they approached an inn that served as a meeting point where Mr. Bennet's carriage would pick them up, they saw Kitty and Lydia looking down from the dining room upstairs.
tr: In the second week of May, three young ladies set out from Gracechurch Street towards the town of ------- in Hertfordshire; as they approached the inn where Mr. Bennet's carriage was to meet them, thanks to the punctuality of the coachman, they caught sight of Kitty and Lydia looking out from one of the upper-floor dining rooms.
es: In the second week of May, the three girls set off together from Gracechurch Street, heading towards the town of X, in Hertfordshire. Upon arriving near the inn where Mr. Bennet's carriage was supposed to wait for them, they immediately saw, as proof of the coachman's punctuality, Catherine and Lydia who were on the lookout in the upper floor dining room.

en: These two girls had been above an hour in the place, happily employed in visiting an opposite milliner, watching the sentinel on guard, and dressing a salad and cucumber.
vi: The two had arrived more than an hour earlier, delighting in shopping at a hat store, watching the guards on duty, and enjoying a vinegar-dressed salad.
tr: These two girls had been there for over an hour, had paid a pleasant visit to a draper across the street, watched the soldiers on guard, and made a curly lettuce and cucumber salad.
es: They had spent almost an hour at the place happily occupied with visiting the hat shop across the street, watching the guard on duty, and preparing a cucumber salad.

en: After welcoming their sisters, they triumphantly displayed a table set out with such cold meat as an inn larder usually affords, exclaiming, “Is not this nice?
vi: After the greetings, the two girls proudly presented a table already set with cold food, exclaiming, "Looks delicious, doesn't it?"
tr: After welcoming their sisters, they proudly showed the table prepared with cold meat that a pantry could offer; "isn't it nice?
es: After welcoming their sisters, they triumphantly showed them a table set with all the cold cuts that can normally be found in the pantry of an inn and exclaimed:

en: is not this an agreeable surprise?”
vi: "Aren't you surprised and delighted?"
tr: isn't it a lovely surprise?" they exclaimed.
es: ––Isn't it wonderful? Isn't it a pleasant surprise?

en: “And we mean to treat you all,” added Lydia; “but you must lend us the money, for we have just spent ours at the shop out there.”
vi: Lydia added. - We will treat you, but you have to lend us money because we spent all our money at the shop over there.
tr: "We are thinking of treating you all to a feast," Lydia added; "but you must lend us some money, because we spent all our money in this shop."
es: ––We want to invite all of you ––added Lydia––; but you will have to lend us the money, because we just spent ours in the store out there.

en: Then showing her purchases,—“Look here, I have bought this bonnet.
vi: Then she showed some items: - Look here, I bought this hat.
tr: Then she showed what she had bought: "Look, I bought this bonnet.
es: And, showing her purchases, she added: ––Look at the hat I bought.

en: I do not think it is very pretty; but I thought I might as well buy it as not.
vi: I think it's not very pretty, but it's better to buy it than not.
tr: It's not very nice, but I bought it just for the sake of it.
es: I don't think it's very pretty, but I thought it was the same to buy it or not; I'll take it apart as soon as we get home and see if I can improve it a bit.

en: I shall pull it to pieces as soon as I get home, and see if I can make it up any better.”
vi: I'll fix it when I get home, to see if it looks better.
tr: When I get home, I'll take it apart to see if I can make something out of it."
es: I don't think it's very pretty, but I thought it was the same to buy it or not; I'll take it apart as soon as we get home and see if I can improve it a bit.

en: And when her sisters abused it as ugly, she added, with perfect unconcern, “Oh, but there were two or three much uglier in the shop; and when I have bought some prettier-coloured satin to trim it with fresh, I think it will be very tolerable.
vi: When the older sisters had words of criticism, she indifferently continued: - Ah! But there are a few that are much worse. When I bought some satin fabric to make the trim, I thought it looked okay.
tr: When her sisters called it ugly, she nonchalantly added, "There were only two or three hats in the shop uglier than this one; if I take a more nicely colored satin and decorate it again, it will be quite good.
es: The sisters found him very ugly, but Lydia, not giving it any importance, replied: ––Well, there were two or three much uglier ones in the shop. And when I buy a satin of a prettier color, I'll fix it up and I think it won't look too bad at all.

en: Besides, it will not much signify what one wears this summer, after the ——shire have left Meryton, and they are going in a fortnight.”
vi: Moreover, it won't matter this summer, after the militia unit leaves Meryton, they will be gone in two weeks.
tr: Anyway, what people wear this summer is not that important, the --------shire regiment has left Meryton, they are leaving within fifteen days."
es: Besides, it hardly matters what we wear this summer, because the county garrison is leaving Meryton in fifteen days.

en: “Are they, indeed?” cried Elizabeth, with the greatest satisfaction.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed, in utmost satisfaction: - Are they really going to go?
tr: "Really?" cried Elizabeth, with great satisfaction.
es: ––Really? ––exclaimed Elizabeth very satisfied.

en: “They are going to be encamped near Brighton; and I do so want papa to take us all there for the summer!
vi: - They will camp near Brington; I really want papa to take all of us there this summer!
tr: "They are going to camp near Brighton; I want my father to take all of us there so much this summer!
es: ––They are going to camp near Brighton. Let's see if Dad takes us there this summer.

en: It would be such a delicious scheme, and I dare say would hardly cost anything at all.
vi: It will be a wonderful plan, and I am sure it won't cost much.
tr: What a fun plan it would be; and it’s not even a major expense.
es: It would be a great plan and would cost very little.

en: Mamma would like to go, too, of all things!
vi: Mother will also want to go for any reason.
tr: My mother would want to go the most!
es: Mom wants to go more than anything else.

en: Only think what a miserable summer else we shall have!”
vi: Elizabeth thought: "Indeed, this will be a wonderful plan, making everyone happy at once."
tr: Otherwise, just imagine what a boring summer we will have!"
es: Imagine, otherwise, what a sad summer awaits us!

en: “Yes,” thought Elizabeth; “that would be a delightful scheme, indeed, and completely do for us at once.
vi: Elizabeth thought: "Indeed, this will be a wonderful plan, making everyone happy at once."
tr: "Yes," thought Elizabeth, "this would indeed be an amusing plan, we would all be ruined at once.
es: “Yes,” thought Elizabeth, “it would be a truly splendid plan and very fitting for us.

en: Good Heaven!
vi: Elizabeth thought: "Indeed, this will be a wonderful plan, making everyone happy at once."
tr: Oh my God!
es: That’s all we would need.

en: Brighton and a whole campful of soldiers, to us, who have been overset already by one poor regiment of militia, and the monthly balls of Meryton!”
vi: My God! Brington, adding a military camp to those already shaken by a miserable regiment and the monthly balls at Meryton."
tr: Brighton, a whole camp full of soldiers and us, already a scattered poor militia regiment because of Meryton's monthly balls."
es: Brighton and a whole camp of soldiers, with how disrupted we already are by a mere regiment and the monthly Meryton balls.”

en: “Now I have got some news for you,” said Lydia, as they sat down to table.
vi: Lydia said, as the sisters sat down at the dining table: - Now I have some news for you all.
tr: "Now I have news for you," said Lydia, as they sat down at the table.
es: ––I have some news to share with you ––said Lydia as they sat down at the table—.

en: “What do you think?
vi: Try to guess!
tr: "Guess what!
es: What do you think?

en: It is excellent news, capital news, and about a certain person that we all like.”
vi: This is extremely good news, important news, related to a person we all cherish.
tr: Wonderful news, extraordinary news, and it's about someone we all love."
es: It's the most sensational thing you can imagine; something very important about a certain person we all like.

en: Jane and Elizabeth looked at each other, and the waiter was told that he need not stay.
vi: Jane and Elizabeth looked at each other, the waiter had been told not to attend to them closely.
tr: Jane and Elizabeth looked at each other; they told the waiter he didn't need to stay.
es: Jane and Elizabeth looked at each other and told the servant that they no longer needed him.

en: Lydia laughed, and said,—
vi: Lydia laughed, and said:
tr: Lydia laughed and said,
es: Lydia laughed and said:

en: “Ay, that is just like your formality and discretion.
vi: - Ah, both sisters are still serious and cautious.
tr: "Ah, your formality and tight-lipped nature, don't you see.
es: ––Ah! That reveals your formality and discretion.

en: You thought the waiter must not hear, as if he cared!
vi: The two sisters think it’s not necessary to let the servant know, as if he really wants to know!
tr: You didn't want the waiter to hear, as if he cared!
es: Do you think the servant was going to listen? As if he cared!

en: I dare say he often hears worse things said than I am going to say.
vi: I think surely he often hears worse news than what I’m about to reveal.
tr: He probably hears worse things than what I'm about to tell you.
es: I would bet he often hears things much worse than what I'm going to tell you.

en: But he is an ugly fellow!
vi: But he is so ugly!
tr: But what an ugly fellow!
es: But he's a very ugly fellow; I'm glad he's gone; I've never seen such a long chin.

en: I am glad he is gone.
vi: I’m glad he’s gone.
tr: Good thing he left.
es: But he's a very ugly fellow; I'm glad he's gone; I've never seen such a long chin.

en: I never saw such a long chin in my life.
vi: In my life, I’ve never seen anyone with such a long chin.
tr: I've never seen such a long chin in my life.
es: But he's a very ugly fellow; I'm glad he's gone; I've never seen such a long chin.

en: Well, but now for my news: it is about dear Wickham; too good for the waiter, is not it?
vi: Alright, now here’s the news I want to announce; it’s about Mr. Wickham, too good for him, isn’t it?
tr: Anyway, let's get to my news: about dear Wickham; too good for the waiter, isn't it?
es: Well, now let's get to the news; it concerns our dear Wickham; it's too good for the servant, isn't it?

en: There is no danger of Wickham’s marrying Mary King—there’s for you!
vi: There’s no danger of Wickham marrying Miss Mary King. He’s yours!
tr: There's no danger of Wickham marrying Mary King. How's that for news!
es: There's no danger of Wickham marrying Mary King.

en: She is gone down to her uncle at Liverpool; gone to stay.
vi: She has gone with her uncle to Liverpool and will stay there permanently.
tr: The girl has gone to her uncle in Liverpool; she's gone to stay.
es: We'll keep it to ourselves. Mary King has gone to Liverpool, to her aunt's house, and she won't be coming back.

en: Wickham is safe.”
vi: Wickham is safe.
tr: Wickham is safe now."
es: Wickham is safe!

en: “And Mary King is safe!” added Elizabeth; “safe from a connection imprudent as to fortune.”
vi: Elizabeth added: - And Mary King is safe! Safe from a reckless marriage in terms of fortune.
tr: "Mary King is safe!" added Elizabeth; "she has escaped a financially imprudent marriage.""
es: ––And Mary King is safe too ––added Elizabeth––, safe from an imprudent marriage for her happiness.

en: “She is a great fool for going away, if she liked him.”
vi: - She was foolish to leave if she liked him.
tr: "Leaving was a big mistake if he loved her.""
es: ––Well, she’s quite foolish for leaving if she loves him.

en: “But I hope there is no strong attachment on either side,” said Jane.
vi: Jane said: - But she hopes that neither side remains attached.
tr: "But I guess there isn't a strong commitment on either side," said Jane.
es: ––But I suppose there wouldn't be much love between them ––said Jane.

en: “I am sure there is not on his.
vi: - I'm sure he doesn't have any attachment.
tr: "I'm sure he's not in Wickham.
es: ––As for him, I'm sure he doesn't; Mary never mattered to him at all.

en: I will answer for it, he never cared three straws about her.
vi: You can answer about this, that he doesn't care about her.
tr: I don't think he cared about the girl at all.
es: ––As for him, I'm sure he doesn't; Mary never mattered to him at all.

en: Who could about such a nasty little freckled thing?”
vi: Who would care about such a freckled and ugly person!
tr: Who would care about such a pesky, freckled, insignificant girl?"
es: Who could be interested in something so disgusting and so full of freckles?

en: Elizabeth was shocked to think that, however incapable of such coarseness of expression herself, the coarseness of the sentiment was little other than her own breast had formerly harboured and fancied liberal!
vi: Elizabeth was shocked to think that, although she did not have the ability to express such rudeness, the rudeness in her feelings in this way was no different than if her breasts were freely exposed!
tr: Elizabeth was stunned, and although she could not bring herself to use such coarse expressions, she thought about how she had once harbored such coarse feelings in her own heart and had found them reasonable!
es: Elizabeth was scandalized to think that, although she was incapable of expressing such vulgarity, the sentiment was not very different from what she herself had once harbored and admitted as liberal.

en: As soon as all had ate, and the elder ones paid, the carriage was ordered; and, after some contrivance, the whole party, with all their boxes, workbags, and parcels, and the unwelcome addition of Kitty’s and Lydia’s purchases, were seated in it.
vi: After they had finished eating and the older sisters had paid, they called the driver and loaded all the luggage, boxes, bags, along with the items Kitty and Lydia had bought that no one liked.
tr: After everyone finished their meal and the sisters paid the bill, the car was summoned; after a bit of effort, they all settled into the car along with all the boxes, craft bags, and packages, and the annoying addition of Kitty and Lydia's shopping.
es: As soon as they had eaten and the older ones had paid, they called for the carriage and, after organizing themselves a bit, all the girls, with their boxes, their work bags, their packages, and the poorly received addition of Catherine and Lydia's purchases, settled into the vehicle.

en: “How nicely we are crammed in!” cried Lydia.
vi: Lydia exclaimed:
tr: "How nicely we fit!" cried Lydia.
es: ––How tightly packed we are! ––exclaimed Lydia––.

en: “I am glad I brought my bonnet, if it is only for the fun of having another band-box!
vi: - How wonderful it is to stack them up! I'm glad I bought the hat, not just because I got an extra box!
tr: "I'm so glad I brought my bonnet, it's worth it just for the box!
es: I'm glad I bought the hat, if only for the pleasure of having another hatbox!

en: Well, now let us be quite comfortable and snug, and talk and laugh all the way home.
vi: Now let's be comfortable and cozy, feel free to chat and laugh along the way back.
tr: Now let's make ourselves comfortable, talk and laugh all the way home.
es: Well, let's get comfortable and chat and laugh all the way home.

en: And in the first place, let us hear what has happened to you all since you went away.
vi: First of all, please tell me what has happened since you left home.
tr: Tell me what happened since you left.
es: First, let's hear what has happened to you since you left.

en: Have you seen any pleasant men?
vi: Did you meet any nice gentlemen?
tr: Did you see any handsome men?
es: Have you met any interesting men?

en: Have you had any flirting?
vi: Did anyone try to court you?
tr: Did you have any flirtations?
es: Have you had any flirts?

en: I was in great hopes that one of you would have got a husband before you came back.
vi: I had hoped one of you would have a husband before returning.
tr: I was saying that at least one of you wouldn't return without finding a husband.
es: I had high hopes that one of you would catch a husband before coming back.

en: Jane will be quite an old maid soon, I declare.
vi: I can say that Jane will soon become an old maid.
tr: Jane will soon be left on the shelf.
es: Jane is soon going to get old.

en: She is almost three-and-twenty!
vi: She's almost twenty-three.
tr: She's almost twenty-three!
es: She is almost twenty-three years old!

en: Lord!
vi: Goodness, I would be so ashamed if I didn't get married before twenty-three!
tr: God, how embarrassed I would be if I weren't married before twenty-three!
es: Lord, how ashamed I would be if I didn't get married before twenty-three...!

en: how ashamed I should be of not being married before three-and-twenty!
vi: Goodness, I would be so ashamed if I didn't get married before twenty-three!
tr: God, how embarrassed I would be if I weren't married before twenty-three!
es: Lord, how ashamed I would be if I didn't get married before twenty-three...!

en: My aunt Philips wants you so to get husbands you can’t think.
vi: Aunt Phillips really wants you to get married, you don't know that.
tr: You can't imagine how much Aunt Philips wants us to find husbands.
es: You can't imagine how much Aunt Philips wants you to get married.

en: She says Lizzy had better have taken mr Collins; but I do not think there would have been any fun in it.
vi: She said Lizzy should have married Mr. Collins, but I think that wouldn't have been any good.
tr: She says Lizzy should have accepted Mr. Collins; but I think that wouldn't have been fun.
es: She says Lizzy would have done better to accept Collins; but I think it would have been very boring.

en: Lord!
vi: She said Lizzy should have married Mr. Collins, but I think that wouldn't have been any good.
tr: God!
es: Lord, how I would love to get married before you!

en: how I should like to be married before any of you!
vi: Oh, I wish I could get married before you all, then I could accompany you to all the balls.
tr: How I wish to get married before you; then I would play matchmaker for you at all the balls.
es: Lord, how I would love to get married before you!

en: and then I would chaperon you about to all the balls.
vi: Oh, I wish I could get married before you all, then I could accompany you to all the balls.
tr: How I wish to get married before you; then I would play matchmaker for you at all the balls.
es: Then I would be the one to accompany you to the balls.

en: Dear me!
vi: Goodness!
tr: Honestly, we had such fun at Colonel Forster's the other day!
es: How much fun we had the other day at the Forsters'!

en: we had such a good piece of fun the other day at Colonel Forster’s!
vi: The other day we had such a fun time at Colonel Forster's house.
tr: Honestly, we had such fun at Colonel Forster's the other day!
es: How much fun we had the other day at the Forsters'!

en: Kitty and me were to spend the day there, and ms Forster promised to have a little dance in the evening; (by-the-bye, ms Forster and me are such friends!) and so she asked the two Harringtons to come: but Harriet was ill, and so Pen was forced to come by herself; and then, what do you think we did?
vi: Kitty and I planned to visit for a day, and Mrs. Forster promised to hold a dance in the evening, so she invited the Harrington sisters, but Harriet was sick and Pen had to go alone. And then, guess what we did?
tr: Kitty and I were going to spend the day there, and Mrs. Forster promised a little dance in the evening; (by the way, we became close friends with Mrs. Forster!) then she invited the Harringtons, but Harriet was sick, so Pen had to come alone; and guess what we did?
es: Catherine and I went to spend the day there, and Mrs. Forster promised us she would give a small dance in the evening. Since Mrs. Forster and I are such good friends! So she invited the Harringtons, but since Harriet was sick, Pen had to come alone; and then, what do you think we did?

en: We dressed up Chamberlayne in woman’s clothes, on purpose to pass for a lady,—only think what fun!
vi: We dressed Chamberlayne in women's clothes, to disguise him as a girl – just for fun.
tr: We dressed Chamberlayne in women's clothes and passed him off as a maid – imagine how much fun we had!
es: We dressed Chamberlayne as a woman so he could pass as a lady. Can you imagine the laughter?

en: Not a soul knew of it, but Colonel and ms Forster, and Kitty and me, except my aunt, for we were forced to borrow one of her gowns; and you cannot imagine how well he looked!
vi: No one else knew except Mr. and Mrs. Forster, Kitty and I, and the aunt, because we had to borrow her dress, you can't imagine how much he looked like a girl!
tr: Only Colonel and Mrs. Forster, Kitty and I, and my aunt knew about it; we told my aunt to borrow her dress; you can't imagine how great it was!
es: Nobody knew, only the colonel, Mrs. Forster, Catherine, and I, apart from my aunt, because we had to borrow one of her dresses; you can't imagine how well he looked.

en: When Denny, and Wickham, and Pratt, and two or three more of the men came in, they did not know him in the least.
vi: When Denny, Wickham, and Pratt along with a few other guys walked in, they had no idea it was him.
tr: Denny, Wickham, Pratt, and a few others came, and they didn't recognize him.
es: When Denny, Wickham, Pratt, and two or three other gentlemen arrived, they didn't recognize him at all.

en: Lord!
vi: Oh my, I laughed so hard!
tr: God!
es: Oh, how I laughed!

en: how I laughed!
vi: Oh my, I laughed so hard!
tr: How I laughed!
es: Oh, how I laughed!

en: and so did ms Forster.
vi: So did Mrs. Forster.
tr: Mrs. Forster laughed so much too.
es: And how Mrs. Forster laughed!

en: I thought I should have died.
vi: I thought I might faint.
tr: I was dying of laughter.
es: I thought I was going to die of laughter.

en: And that made the men suspect something, and then they soon found out what was the matter.”
vi: And that made the guys suspicious, and soon they found out the truth.
tr: The men got suspicious because of this, and then they figured it out anyway."
es: And then, that made them suspect something and they soon discovered the joke.

en: With such kind of histories of their parties and good jokes did Lydia, assisted by Kitty’s hints and additions, endeavour to amuse her companions all the way to Longbourn.
vi: With the stories about the ball and such jokes, along with Kitty's embellishments, Lydia tried to entertain her sisters all the way back to Longbourn.
tr: By recounting the stories of their parties and sweet jokes, Lydia, with Kitty's help and additions, tried to entertain their companions all the way to Longbourn.
es: With similar stories of parties and jokes, Lydia tried, with the help of Catherine's directions, to entertain her sisters and Maria all the way until they reached Longbourn.

en: Elizabeth listened as little as she could, but there was no escaping the frequent mention of Wickham’s name.
vi: Elizabeth wanted to hear as little as possible, but she could not avoid hearing Wickham's name.
tr: Elizabeth listened as little as possible, but she couldn't help noticing Wickham's name being mentioned frequently.
es: Elizabeth tried to listen to her as little as possible, but the frequent allusions to Wickham did not escape her.

en: Their reception at home was most kind.
vi: They were warmly welcomed at home.
tr: They were warmly welcomed at home.
es: At home, they were received with all the affection.

en: ms Bennet rejoiced to see Jane in undiminished beauty; and more than once during dinner did mr Bennet say voluntarily to Elizabeth,——
vi: Mrs. Bennet was delighted to see that Jane was still as beautiful as before. More than once during dinner, Mr. Bennet said to Elizabeth:
tr: Mrs. Bennet was very happy to see that Jane's beauty was still intact; during the meal, Mr. Bennet said to Elizabeth several times, "I'm glad you're back, Lizzy," with affection.
es: Mrs. Bennet rejoiced to see Jane as beautiful as ever, and Mr. Bennet, during the meal, more than once said to Elizabeth with all his heart:

en: “I am glad you are come back, Lizzy.”
vi: - Dad is happy to see you back, Lizzy.
tr: Mrs. Bennet was very happy to see that Jane's beauty was still intact; during the meal, Mr. Bennet said to Elizabeth several times, "I'm glad you're back, Lizzy," with affection.
es: ––I'm glad you're back, Lizzy.

en: Their party in the dining-room was large, for almost all the Lucases came to meet Maria and hear the news; and various were the subjects which occupied them: Lady Lucas was inquiring of Maria, across the table, after the welfare and poultry of her eldest daughter; ms Bennet was doubly engaged, on one hand collecting an account of the present fashions from Jane, who sat some way below her, and on the other, retailing them all to the younger Miss Lucases; and Lydia, in a voice rather louder than any other person’s, was enumerating the various pleasures of the morning to anybody who would hear her.
vi: The gathering in the dining room had many people, as most of the Lucas household came to meet Maria and hear her news, asking about everything. Lady Lucas asked Maria about her health and the chickens of her eldest daughter. Mrs. Bennet was doubly busy, on one hand asking Jane about the current fashion, and on the other talking to the Lucas sister. Lydia, with a voice that drowned out everyone else, recounted her morning amusements to anyone who would listen.
tr: There was a large crowd in the dining room; almost all the Lucases had come to welcome Maria and hear the news; everyone was occupied with a different matter; Lady Lucas was asking Maria about her eldest daughter's well-being and her chickens from across the table; Mrs. Bennet was engaged in two tasks at once, receiving the latest fashion news from Jane, who was sitting a little further away, and relaying this information to the younger Lucas girls; Lydia, in a voice louder than anyone else's, was recounting her morning's amusements to the room, for anyone who cared to listen.
es: The gathering in the dining room was large, as most of the Lucases had come to pick up Maria and hear the news. Many things were discussed. Lady Lucas was questioning Maria from across the table about the well-being and the pen of her eldest daughter; Mrs. Bennet was doubly occupied in finding out about the London fashions that her daughter Jane was explaining to her on one side, and in conveying the information to the younger Lucases on the other. Lydia, shouting louder than anyone, detailed what they had enjoyed that morning to all who would listen.

en: “Oh, Mary,” said she, “I wish you had gone with us, for we had such fun!
vi: - Hey! Maria, I wish you were with us, it was so much fun!
tr: "Ah, Mary," he was saying, "I wish you had come with us, we had so much fun!
es: ––Oh, Mary! ––he exclaimed––. How much I would have liked you to come with us! We had so much fun!

en: as we went along Kitty and me drew up all the blinds, and pretended there was nobody in the coach; and I should have gone so all the way, if Kitty had not been sick; and when we got to the George, I do think we behaved very handsomely, for we treated the other three with the nicest cold luncheon in the world, and if you would have gone, we would have treated you too.
vi: On the way, Kitty and I pulled down all the curtains, pretending there was no one on the bus. I could go the whole way like that, but Kitty felt uncomfortable. When we got to George, I think we behaved well, because we treated your dad to the best ham in the world; if you leave and come back, we will treat you the same way.
tr: On the way, Kitty and I opened all the curtains, pretending there was no one else in the car; if Kitty hadn't gotten nauseous, I would have gone the whole way like that; when we arrived at George's inn, I think we acted very chic and offered these three people the best cold dishes in the world, if you had come, we would have offered them to you too.
es: When Catherine and I were alone, we closed all the windows to make it look like the car was empty, and we would have gone like that the whole way if Catherine hadn't gotten sick. When we arrived at the "George" we were so generous! We treated the three of us to the most amazing appetizer in the world, and if you had come, we would have invited you too.

en: And then when we came away it was such fun!
vi: And it was really fun when everyone was on the bus.
tr: Our return was just as fun!
es: And what a blast on the way back!

en: I thought we never should have got into the coach.
vi: I thought all of us sisters couldn't fit on the bus.
tr: I thought we would never get into the car.
es: I thought we wouldn't fit in the car.

en: I was ready to die of laughter.
vi: I laughed so hard I almost died.
tr: I was laughing so hard I almost died.
es: I almost died laughing.

en: And then we were so merry all the way home!
vi: And then all of us sisters were happy on the way back.
tr: And such joy on the way back!
es: And the whole way we had a great time; we talked and laughed so loudly that we could have been heard ten miles away.

en: we talked and laughed so loud, that anybody might have heard us ten miles off!”
vi: We talked so loudly that everyone could hear us from ten miles away!
tr: What a laugh, they must have heard us from miles away."
es: And the whole way we had a great time; we talked and laughed so loudly that we could have been heard ten miles away.

en: To this, Mary very gravely replied, “Far be it from me, my dear sister, to depreciate such pleasures.
vi: Mary replied, solemnly:
tr: Mary answered this seriously, "Oh, keep it away from me, sister, such pleasures are not for me."
es: Mary replied gravely: ––Far be it from me, dear sister, to disdain those pleasures.

en: They would doubtless be congenial with the generality of female minds.
vi: - She does not underestimate such pleasures, which are clearly in line with the temperament of women.
tr: Most women like such things.
es: They are undoubtedly suitable for the majority of women.

en: But I confess they would have no charms for me.
vi: But to be honest, she does not crave these pleasures.
tr: But they are not attractive to me at all.
es: But I confess that they do not amuse me at all; I would have preferred a book a thousand times over.

en: I should infinitely prefer a book.”
vi: She definitely prefers reading books.
tr: I prefer to read books."
es: But I confess that they do not amuse me at all; I would have preferred a book a thousand times over.

en: But of this answer Lydia heard not a word.
vi: But Lydia did not want to hear a word of the reply.
tr: Aunt Lydia did not hear a single word of this answer.
es: But Lydia did not hear a word of her remark.

en: She seldom listened to anybody for more than half a minute, and never attended to Mary at all.
vi: She rarely listened to anyone for more than half a minute, and never wanted to hear Mary.
tr: She rarely listened to anyone for more than half a minute, and she didn't even listen to Mary for that long.
es: She rarely listened to anyone for more than half a minute, and she never paid any attention to Mary.

en: In the afternoon Lydia was urgent with the rest of the girls to walk to Meryton, and see how everybody went on; but Elizabeth steadily opposed the scheme.
vi: In the afternoon, Lydia eagerly joined the other girls to go to Meryton and see what everyone was doing, but Elizabeth stubbornly resisted.
tr: In the afternoon, Lydia insisted on walking to Meryton with the other girls to see what everyone was up to; but Elizabeth stubbornly opposed the plan.
es: In the afternoon, Lydia insisted that they all go to Meryton to see how everyone was; but Elizabeth vehemently opposed.

en: It should not be said, that the Miss Bennets could not be at home half a day before they were in pursuit of the officers.
vi: It should not be said that the Bennet girls could not stay at home for half a day without chasing after the officers.
tr: It should not be said that the Miss Bennets were chasing after officers without even spending half a day at home.
es: She did not want it to be said that the Bennet ladies could not stay at home for half a day without running after the officers.

en: There was another reason, too, for her opposition.
vi: She resisted for another reason.
tr: There was another reason for her opposition.
es: She had another reason for opposing: she feared seeing Wickham again, something she wanted to avoid at all costs.

en: She dreaded seeing Wickham again, and was resolved to avoid it as long as possible.
vi: She was fed up with seeing Wickham again and was determined to avoid this for as long as possible.
tr: The thought of seeing Wickham again was terrifying to her, and she was determined to avoid it as much as possible.
es: She had another reason for opposing: she feared seeing Wickham again, something she wanted to avoid at all costs.

en: The comfort to her, of the regiment’s approaching removal, was indeed beyond expression.
vi: The consolation for her, that the regiment would be moving, was truly hard to describe.
tr: The proximity of the regiment's departure gave her an indescribable comfort.
es: The satisfaction she felt at the regiment's departure was beyond what could be expressed.

en: In a fortnight they were to go, and once gone, she hoped there could be nothing more to plague her on his account.
vi: They would depart in two weeks, and after they were gone, she hoped there would be nothing left to trouble her about him.
tr: They would be gone within fifteen days; and once they were gone, she hoped she would no longer be troubled because of Wickham.
es: In fifteen days they would no longer be there, and she hoped that this way she would be rid of Wickham forever.

en: She had not been many hours at home, before she found that the Brighton scheme, of which Lydia had given them a hint at the inn, was under frequent discussion between her parents.
vi: Just a few hours after arriving home, she realized that her parents often discussed the plan about Brington that Lydia had mentioned at the inn.
tr: She had not been home for long when she saw that the Brighton plan Lydia had mentioned at the inn was a frequent topic of discussion between her mother and father.
es: She hadn't been home for many hours when she realized that the Brighton plan Lydia had informed them about at the inn was often discussed by her parents.

en: Elizabeth saw directly that her father had not the smallest intention of yielding; but his answers were at the same time so vague and equivocal, that her mother, though often disheartened, had never yet despaired of succeeding at last.
vi: Elizabeth immediately saw that her father did not want to comply, but his answers were both vague and ambiguous; while her mother was not worried about failure, even though she often felt discouraged.
tr: She immediately understood that her father had no intention of going; but his responses were so vague and evasive that, although her mother often lost hope, she had not yet lost her belief that she would eventually succeed.
es: Elizabeth understood that Mr. Bennet had no intention of giving in, but his replies were so vague and equivocal that her mother, although sometimes discouraged, did not lose hope of eventually getting her way.

en: CHAPTER XL.
vi: Chapter 40
tr: Chapter XVII
es: CHAPTER XL

en: ELIZABETH’S impatience to acquaint Jane with what had happened could no longer be overcome; and at length resolving to suppress every particular in which her sister was concerned, and preparing her to be surprised, she related to her the next morning the chief of the scene between mr Darcy and herself.
vi: Jane no longer wanted to satisfy Elizabeth's eagerness to know about what had happened. Eventually, Elizabeth did not mention her sister's situation. The next morning, she wanted to surprise her sister; she recounted what had happened between Mr. Darcy and herself.
tr: Elizabeth could no longer resist the impatience she felt to tell Jane what had happened; finally, deciding to withhold the details concerning her sister and asking her to be prepared for a surprise, she recounted to her the majority of what had transpired between her and Mr. Darcy the next morning.
es: Elizabeth could no longer contain her impatience to tell Jane everything that had happened. Finally, she decided to omit everything related to her sister, and after preparing her for the surprise, she recounted the most important parts of her scene with Darcy the next morning.

en: Miss Bennet’s astonishment was soon lessened by the strong sisterly partiality which made any admiration of Elizabeth appear perfectly natural; and all surprise was shortly lost in other feelings.
vi: Miss Bennet's surprise did not last long due to the sisterly affection that made her admire her sister's natural composure, then she sank into other thoughts.
tr: Miss Bennet's astonishment did not last long, as she found it quite natural that Elizabeth should be admired, due to her strong sisterly partiality; indeed, soon there was no astonishment left at all.
es: The great affection that Jane felt for Elizabeth diminished her astonishment, for anything that was admiration for her seemed perfectly natural. Her feelings were different.

en: She was sorry that mr Darcy should have delivered his sentiments in a manner so little suited to recommend them; but still more was she grieved for the unhappiness which her sister’s refusal must have given him.
