vi: She regretted that Mr. Darcy had proposed in an inappropriate manner, but she was even more saddened by his misfortune of being rejected by her sister. She said:
tr: She was upset that Mr. Darcy had expressed his feelings in a rather ungracious manner; but she was more upset by the unhappiness that her sister's rejection must have caused him.
es: It hurt her that Darcy had expressed himself in such a way that was so little suitable to make himself agreeable, but it pained her even more to think of the unhappiness that her sister's refusal would have caused him.

en: “His being so sure of succeeding was wrong,” said she, “and certainly ought not to have appeared; but consider how much it must increase his disappointment.”
vi: - He made a mistake by being too confident that he would succeed, he shouldn't have expressed it in that way, but I think this only makes him more disappointed.
tr: "It was a mistake to be so sure it would be accepted," he said, "it shouldn't have looked that way; but just think, how much it must have increased his disappointment."
es: ––It was a mistake to be so sure of success ––he said–– and of course he shouldn't have given himself away; but just imagine how much he must regret it and how bad he must feel now!

en: “Indeed,” replied Elizabeth, “I am heartily sorry for him; but he has other feelings which will probably soon drive away his regard for me.
vi: Elizabeth replied: - That's right, I pity him, but you have other thoughts that might dispel your feelings for me.
tr: "Of course," replied Elizabeth, "I really feel sorry for him; but he has other feelings that will extinguish his interest in me.
es: ––It is true ––replied Elizabeth––, I truly feel sorry for him; but his pride is so great that it won't take long for him to forget me.

en: You do not blame me, however, for refusing him?”
vi: However, you don't blame me for rejecting him, do you?
tr: Still, you don't blame me for rejecting him, do you?"
es: Do you think it was wrong for me to reject him?

en: “Blame you!
vi: - Blame you?
tr: "Blame you!
es: ––Do I mind?

en: Oh, no.”
vi: Oh, no.
tr: No, not at all."
es: Not at all.

en: “But you blame me for having spoken so warmly of Wickham?”
vi: - But you blame me for speaking so warmly about Wickham.
tr: "But you blame me for speaking so sympathetically about Wickham."
es: ––But you must not have liked that I spoke to him with such emphasis about Wickham.

en: “No—I do not know that you were wrong in saying what you did.”
vi: - No. Based on what you told me about your reaction, I don't think you were wrong.
tr: "No – I don't know if I made a mistake by saying them."
es: ––I don't know if you did wrong by speaking to him the way you did.

en: “But you will know it, when I have told you what happened the very next day.”
vi: - But you will think, after I tell you about the next day.
tr: "But you will know when I tell you what happened the next day.""
es: ––Well, you will know when I have told you what happened the next day.

en: She then spoke of the letter, repeating the whole of its contents as far as they concerned George Wickham.
vi: Then she recounted the letter, repeating even the part about George Wickham.
tr: Then she spoke about the letter, repeating all the parts concerning George Wickham.
es: Then Elizabeth spoke to her about the letter, repeating all its contents as far as they related to George Wickham.

en: What a stroke was this for poor Jane, who would willingly have gone through the world without believing that so much wickedness existed in the whole race of mankind as was here collected in one individual!
vi: It was indeed a shock for poor Jane! She was always willing to endure all the ups and downs of life without believing that all the malice of humanity could be gathered in one individual.
tr: These were a great blow to poor Jane! She could have spent her whole life believing that such baseness did not exist in any one person among the entire human race.
es: It was a hard blow for poor Jane. She would have traveled around the world without suspecting that such perversity could exist in all of humanity as was contained in that single individual.

en: Nor was Darcy’s vindication, though grateful to her feelings, capable of consoling her for such discovery.
vi: Even Darcy's explanation could not console her for this discovery, though her mind was somewhat eased.
tr: Even though Darcy's exoneration pleased her, it could not lessen the pain of such a discovery.
es: Not even Darcy's justification, however pleasing it was to her, was enough to console her from such a revelation.

en: Most earnestly did she labour to prove the probability of error, and seek to clear one, without involving the other.
vi: She was eager to prove the possibility of a mistake and wanted to exonerate one person without affecting another.
tr: She searched with all her might for the possibility of a mistake and tried to find one innocent without implicating the other.
es: She tried with all her might to maintain that there could be some mistake, attempting to defend one without incriminating the other.

en: “This will not do,” said Elizabeth; “you never will be able to make both of them good for anything.
vi: Elizabeth said: - It can't be done. You can never make both people good at anything.
tr: "It's no use," said Elizabeth. "You can't do a good thing with both of them at the same time.
es: ––It will be of no use to you ––Elizabeth told him––; you will never be able to say that both are good.

en: Take your choice, but you must be satisfied with only one.
vi: You should choose, but you should be content with just one person.
tr: Make your choice, but you must be content with just one.
es: Choose as you wish; but either you stay with one or the other.

en: There is but such a quantity of merit between them; just enough to make one good sort of man; and of late it has been shifting about pretty much.
vi: There is only one value between them that is enough to help one person become good, and recently, this value has been transferred back and forth quite a lot.
tr: Even if you take all their virtues, it would only be enough to make one good man; besides, he has been changing sides a lot lately.
es: Between the two, they do not gather more than just enough merits for one decent man. We have already deceived ourselves enough lately.

en: For my part, I am inclined to believe it all mr Darcy’s, but you shall do as you choose.”
vi: As for me, I can trust Mr. Darcy completely, but it's up to you to decide.
tr: For my part, I am inclined to believe Mr. Darcy, but you must make your own choice."
es: For my part, I am inclined to believe everything Darcy says; you will see what you decide.

en: It was some time, however, before a smile could be extorted from Jane.
vi: However, it took Jane a while before she could muster a smile.
tr: It still took some time for Jane to be able to smile.
es: It took a long time before Jane could smile.

en: “I do not know when I have been more shocked,” said she.
vi: She said: - I have never been so shocked like this.
tr: "I don't remember being more surprised," she said.
es: ––I don't know what has surprised me more ––she said at last––.

en: “Wickham so very bad!
vi: Wickham is really terrible!
tr: "Wickham being so bad!
es: That Wickham is so wicked!

en: It is almost past belief.
vi: It's almost unbelievable.
tr: It's an incredible thing.
es: It's almost unbelievable.

en: And poor mr Darcy!
vi: Poor Mr. Darcy!
tr: Poor Mr. Darcy!
es: And poor Darcy!

en: dear Lizzy, only consider what he must have suffered.
vi: Lizzy, just thinking about how much he has suffered.
tr: Imagine the agony he must have endured, my dear Lizzy.
es: Dear Elizabeth, just think of what he must have suffered.

en: Such a disappointment!
vi: It must be so disappointing for him to know that you thought badly of him!
tr: Such a disappointment!
es: What a disappointment!

en: and with the knowledge of your ill opinion too!
vi: It must be so disappointing for him to know that you thought badly of him!
tr: and knowing your negative opinions as well!
es: And on top of that, confessing the bad opinion you had of him!

en: and having to relate such a thing of his sister!
vi: To have to recount the story of his sister like that!
tr: To have to tell such a thing about his sister!
es: And having to tell such things about his sister!

en: It is really too distressing, I am sure you must feel it so.”
vi: It’s truly painful! I am sure you feel the same way.
tr: It's truly very distressing. I'm sure you feel the same way."
es: It is truly dreadful. Don't you think so?

en: “Oh no, my regret and compassion are all done away by seeing you so full of both.
vi: - Oh, no! When I see you carrying heavy regret and pity, I no longer feel regret and pity.
tr: "No, no! My chances of regret or pity are disappearing, while you have both in abundance.
es: ––Oh, no! All my sorrow and compassion have left me upon seeing that you feel them for both.

en: I know you will do him such ample justice, that I am growing every moment more unconcerned and indifferent.
vi: I know you will judge him fairly, so I worry less.
tr: I know you will treat him quite fairly, so I am becoming more indifferent, more detached by the minute.
es: I know that as long as you do justice, it is enough. I know I can become more and more unconcerned and indifferent.

en: Your profusion makes me saving; and if you lament over him much longer, my heart will be as light as a feather.”
vi: Your heavy heart makes mine lighter. If you lament for him more, my heart will be as light as a feather.
tr: Your generosity makes me frugal; if you complain about him a little more, my heart will feel as light as a feather."
es: Your abundance of lamentations saves me. And if you continue to pity him for a long time, my heart will become as insensitive as a rock.

en: “Poor Wickham!
vi: - Poor Wickham!
tr: "Poor Wickham; goodness radiates from his face!
es: ––Poor Wickham!

en: there is such an expression of goodness in his countenance!
vi: His face shows a kind expression.
tr: "Poor Wickham; goodness radiates from his face!
es: He seems so good, so frank!

en: such an openness and gentleness in his manner.”
vi: His gestures are all open and graceful.
tr: His manners are so charming, so kind.""
es: ––Yes, it's true; there must have been a misdirection in the education of these two young men; one took all the kindness and the other all the good appearances.

en: “There certainly was some great mismanagement in the education of those two young men.
vi: - There is certainly some trouble in the educational foundation of you two.
tr: "It is clear that a great mistake was made in the education of these two young men.
es: ––Yes, it's true; there must have been a misdirection in the education of these two young men; one took all the kindness and the other all the good appearances.

en: One has got all the goodness, and the other all the appearance of it.”
vi: One person absorbs all the good things; the other only shows all the good things on the surface.
tr: Goodness is in one of them, and in the appearance of the other."
es: ––Yes, it's true; there must have been a misdirection in the education of these two young men; one took all the kindness and the other all the good appearances.

en: “I never thought mr Darcy so deficient in the appearance of it as you used to do.”
vi: - I never thought Mr. Darcy was as lacking in appearance as you often think.
tr: "I never thought there was any goodness in Mr. Darcy's appearance, unlike you."
es: ––I never considered that Darcy's appearances were as bad as you said.

en: “And yet I meant to be uncommonly clever in taking so decided a dislike to him, without any reason.
vi: - And yet, previously you had determined to appear extraordinarily wise by hating me without any reason at all.
tr: "Still, I thought I was being incredibly smart by feeling an unfounded coldness towards him.
es: ––Well, you see, I thought I was very clever when I found him so unpleasant for no reason at all.

en: It is such a spur to one’s genius, such an opening for wit, to have a dislike of that kind.
vi: This is the natural instinct of a human being, the act of opening a keen mind to have such hatred in this way.
tr: This kind of coldness stimulates one's genius, opens up one's intellect.
es: Feeling that kind of antipathy is like a stimulus for intelligence, it's like a sign of wit.

en: One may be continually abusive without saying anything just; but one cannot be always laughing at a man without now and then stumbling on something witty.”
vi: People can continue to insult without bothering to say anything fair, but they cannot keep mocking someone without occasionally touching on something witty.
tr: A person can continuously harass someone without saying a single justified word; but a person cannot laugh at someone forever without occasionally saying something clever."
es: You can keep talking badly about someone without ever saying anything accurate; but it's impossible to always laugh at a person without hitting the mark at least once.

en: “Lizzy, when you first read that letter, I am sure you could not treat the matter as you do now.”
vi: - Lizzy, I'm sure that when you first read the letter, you didn't think about the matter as you do now.
tr: "Lizzy, I'm sure you couldn't evaluate the matter the same way when you first read that letter as you do now.""
es: ––I am sure, Elizabeth, that when you first read Darcy's letter, you did not think so.

en: “Indeed, I could not.
vi: - Actually, at that time, I couldn't think about anything.
tr: "Of course not.
es: ––I wouldn't have been able to, it's true.

en: I was uncomfortable enough, I was very uncomfortable—I may say unhappy.
vi: I was too disturbed. I was very disturbed, you could say I was miserable.
tr: I am very disturbed. I can say I am quite disturbed, even unhappy.
es: I was so upset, or rather, so sad.

en: And with no one to speak to of what I felt, no Jane to comfort me, and say that I had not been so very weak, and vain, and nonsensical, as I knew I had!
vi: And there was no one to talk to about what I was thinking, no Jane to comfort me and tell me that I had never been so weak, empty, and unreasonable!
tr: There is no one to talk to about what I feel, no Jane to comfort me and tell me that I am not acting as weak, brainless, and heartless as I think!
es: And the worst part of all was that I had no one to confide my sorrow in. To have no one to talk to about what I felt, no Jane to console me and tell me that I hadn't been as fragile, as vain, and as foolish as I thought I was!

en: Oh, how I wanted you!”
vi: Oh! I needed you so much!
tr: Oh! how I have missed you!"
es: How much I missed you!

en: “How unfortunate that you should have used such very strong expressions in speaking of Wickham to mr Darcy, for now they do appear wholly undeserved.”
vi: - It is truly regrettable that you used such strong expressions when speaking to Mr. Darcy about Wickham, as neither of them is entirely deserving of such praise or criticism.
tr: "It was unfortunate that you used such strong expressions when talking to Mr. Darcy about Wickham; now it turns out he didn't deserve it at all.""
es: ––To have attacked Darcy in that way to defend Wickham, and now to think that he didn't deserve it!

en: “Certainly.
vi: - Certainly so.
tr: "Absolutely.
es: ––It's true; but she was embittered by the prejudices she had been nurturing.

en: But the misfortune of speaking with bitterness is a most natural consequence of the prejudices I had been encouraging.
vi: But the bitter way of speaking is the most inevitable consequence of the prejudices you keep pursuing.
tr: But the misfortune of speaking harsh words is the natural result of the prejudices I have nurtured within me.
es: ––It's true; but she was embittered by the prejudices she had been nurturing.

en: There is one point on which I want your advice.
vi: There is one thing I need your advice on.
tr: There is a point where I need your advice.
es: I need you to advise me on something.

en: I want to be told whether I ought, or ought not, to make our acquaintance in general understand Wickham’s character.”
vi: I want you to tell me whether or not I should inform the people we know so that they understand Wickham's true nature.
tr: You need to tell me whether I should or should not speak about Wickham's character to others."
es: Should I or should I not disclose what I have learned about Wickham?

en: Miss Bennet paused a little, and then replied, “Surely there can be no occasion for exposing him so dreadfully.
vi: Ms. Bennet hesitated for a moment, then replied: - There's certainly no chance to expose him in such a terrible way.
tr: After a moment's hesitation, Miss Bennet replied, "There is no reason to disgrace the poor man in front of everyone."
es: Jane meditated for a while and then said: ––I don't think there's any reason to put him in such a bad light.

en: What is your own opinion?”
vi: What do you think?
tr: "What is your opinion?""
es: What do you think?

en: “That it ought not to be attempted.
vi: - I think you shouldn't.
tr: "I think it is best not to do it.
es: ––That you are right.

en: mr Darcy has not authorized me to make his communication public.
vi: Mr. Darcy hasn't given me permission to tell the world about what he said.
tr: Mr. Darcy did not allow me to explain what he had told me.
es: Darcy has not authorized me to disclose what he has revealed to me.

en: On the contrary, every particular relative to his sister was meant to be kept as much as possible to myself; and if I endeavour to undeceive people as to the rest of his conduct, who will believe me?
vi: Moreover, all details concerning his sister need to be kept confidential. If I try to tell everyone about other matters, who will believe me?
tr: On the contrary, he instructed me to keep every detail about his sister to myself as much as possible; if I try to correct people's misconceptions about his other behaviors, who would believe me?
es: On the contrary, he has made it clear that I must keep the matter of his sister as confidential as possible. And, on the other hand, even if I wanted to open people's eyes to his conduct in other matters, who would believe me?

en: The general prejudice against mr Darcy is so violent, that it would be the death of half the good people in Meryton, to attempt to place him in an amiable light.
vi: The prejudices against Mr. Darcy are so intense that if he were portrayed in a good light, half the people in Meryton would faint.
tr: The prejudice against Mr. Darcy is so strong that to make him appear likable, one would have to kill half the people in Meryton.
es: The prejudice against Darcy is so strong that half of the good people of Meryton would rather die than have to put him on a pedestal.

en: I am not equal to it.
vi: The prejudices against Mr. Darcy are so intense that if he were portrayed in a good light, half the people in Meryton would faint.
tr: I can't manage that much.
es: I am not suited for that.

en: Wickham will soon be gone; and, therefore, it will not signify to anybody here what he really is.
vi: Wickham will soon leave, so no one will care to know what kind of person he really is.
tr: Wickham will be leaving soon; therefore, his true nature will not mean anything to anyone.
es: Wickham will leave soon, and it is better that I keep quiet.

en: Some time hence it will be all found out, and then we may laugh at their stupidity in not knowing it before.
vi: After some time, people will find out, and then we can mock them for being ignorant and not recognizing it earlier.
tr: One day in the future, it will be known, and then we will laugh at their foolishness for not having learned it earlier.
es: In some time, everything will be discovered and then we can laugh at people's foolishness for not having known it earlier.

en: At present I will say nothing about it.”
vi: Right now, I don't want to say anything about this matter.
tr: For now, I will not say anything about it."
es: For now, I will say nothing.

en: “You are quite right.
vi: - I think you're absolutely right.
tr: "You are absolutely right.
es: ––It seems very good to me.

en: To have his errors made public might ruin him for ever.
vi: If we expose all his mistakes, we could ruin his entire life.
tr: Revealing his flaws could ruin his life.
es: If you spread his defects, you could ruin him forever.

en: He is now, perhaps, sorry for what he has done, and anxious to re-establish a character.
vi: Maybe now he's regretting what he did and wants to rebuild himself.
tr: Maybe he regrets what he has done and is trying to become a better person again.
es: Maybe he regrets what he did and wants to make amends.

en: We must not make him desperate.”
vi: We shouldn't make him lose hope.
tr: Let's not crush his hopes."
es: We should not push him to despair.

en: The tumult of Elizabeth’s mind was allayed by this conversation.
vi: Elizabeth's troubled mind returned to peace thanks to this conversation.
tr: The storm within Elizabeth calmed with this conversation.
es: The tumult in Elizabeth's mind was calmed by this conversation.

en: She had got rid of two of the secrets which had weighed on her for a fortnight, and was certain of a willing listener in Jane, whenever she might wish to talk again of either.
vi: She had confided two deep secrets that had weighed heavily on her mind for the past two weeks, certain that Jane would be willing to listen, even if she might not want to discuss the matter again.
tr: She had rid herself of two of the secrets that had burdened her for fifteen days, and she knew that Jane would be a willing listener if she ever wanted to talk about them again.
es: She had unburdened herself of one of the two secrets that had weighed on her soul for fifteen days, and she knew that Jane would always listen willingly whenever she wanted to talk about it.

en: But there was still something lurking behind, of which prudence forbade the disclosure.
vi: But there was still something lingering in the background that her cautious nature prevented her from revealing.
tr: But there was still something lurking in the background, something that common sense did not allow to be explained.
es: But she still concealed something that prudence prevented her from revealing.

en: She dared not relate the other half of mr Darcy’s letter, nor explain to her sister how sincerely she had been valued by his friend.
vi: She did not dare to mention the other half of Mr. Darcy's letter, nor did she dare to explain how honestly his friend had judged her sister.
tr: She did not dare to tell the other half of Mr. Darcy's letter, to explain to her sister how sincerely her friend was valued by him.
es: She did not dare to disclose to her sister the other half of Darcy's letter, nor to tell her how sincerely she had been loved by his friend.

en: Here was knowledge in which no one could partake; and she was sensible that nothing less than a perfect understanding between the parties could justify her in throwing off this last encumbrance of mystery.
vi: This was a sentiment that no one could share; she realized that only perfect empathy between the two sides could dispel this mysterious burden.
tr: This was knowledge that no one could share, and Elizabeth knew that it would not be right to rid herself of this final burden of secrecy without complete mutual understanding between the two parties.
es: It was a secret of hers that she could share with no one, and she knew that only an agreement between Jane and Bingley would justify her confession.

en: “And then,” said she, “if that very improbable event should ever take place, I shall merely be able to tell what Bingley may tell in a much more agreeable manner himself.
vi: She told herself, "And then, if this unlikely situation were to actually occur, I would just have to say that Bingley could have spoken in a gentler manner.
tr: "Then," she thought, "if this impossible situation happens, I will tell what Bingley himself could explain much more pleasantly.
es: «And even then ––she told herself–– I could only tell her what Bingley himself deemed appropriate to share.

en: The liberty of communication cannot be mine till it has lost all its value!”
vi: I cannot divulge everything until the moment of revelation has lost all significance!”
tr: I cannot have the right to tell it until this information loses all its value."
es: I will not have the freedom to reveal this secret until it has lost all its value.»

en: She was now, on being settled at home, at leisure to observe the real state of her sister’s spirits.
vi: Now she had time to observe the true state of her sister's spirit.
tr: Now that she had settled at home, she had time to observe her sister's true state of mind.
es: Since she was at home all day, she had the opportunity to study her sister's true state of mind.

en: Jane was not happy.
vi: Jane was not happy.
tr: Jane was not happy.
es: Jane was not happy; she still tenderly loved Bingley.

en: She still cherished a very tender affection for Bingley.
vi: Her sister still harbored very tender feelings for Mr. Bingley.
tr: She still harbored a deep affection for Bingley.
es: Jane was not happy; she still tenderly loved Bingley.

en: Having never even fancied herself in love before, her regard had all the warmth of first attachment, and from her age and disposition, greater steadiness than first attachments often boast; and so fervently did she value his remembrance, and prefer him to every other man, that all her good sense, and all her attention to the feelings of her friends, were requisite to check the indulgence of those regrets which must have been injurious to her own health and their tranquillity.
vi: Previously, she had never thought that she knew love, but her mind was now filled with the warmth of first love. Due to her age and status, she was calmer than in other first loves. She cherished and respected her memories of him and leaned towards him more than anyone else, to the extent that all her good sense and all her care for the feelings of her loved ones were necessary to prevent her from indulging in regrets that were not beneficial to her health and peace of mind.
tr: Since she had never imagined herself in love before, her feelings carried all the warmth of a first attachment, and, due to her age and temperament, with a greater solidity than first attachments usually possess; she valued Bingley's memory so passionately and regarded him as superior to everyone else that, if she did not use all her sensitivity and attention to avoid hurting her friends, it would be easy for her to succumb to these sorrows, compromising her own health and the peace of those around her.
es: She had never been in love before, and her affection had all the fire of a first love, but her age and character gave it a firmness that first loves usually lack. She could think of nothing but Bingley, and it required all her good sense and attention to her family to moderate those memories that could ruin her health and the tranquility of those around her.

en: “Well, Lizzy,” said ms Bennet, one day, “what is your opinion now of this sad business of Jane’s?
vi: One day, Mrs. Bennet asked: - So, Lizzy, what do you now think about Jane's miserable situation?
tr: "Well, Lizzy," said Mrs. Bennet one day, "what do you say now about Jane's sad business?
es: ––Well, Elizabeth ––said Mrs. Bennet one day––, tell me now what your opinion is on the sad matter of Jane.

en: For my part, I am determined never to speak of it again to anybody.
vi: As for me, I have decided never to speak of this matter to anyone again.
tr: As for myself, I am determined never to speak of it to anyone again.
es: I am determined not to speak of it again.

en: I told my sister Philips so the other day.
vi: I told your Aunt Phillips so the other day.
tr: I told my sister Philips so the other day.
es: That's what I told my sister Philips the other day.

en: But I cannot find out that Jane saw anything of him in London.
vi: But I cannot know if Jane has met him at all in London.
tr: But how is it that Jane never sees him in London, I do not understand.
es: But I can't believe that Jane hasn't seen Bingley in London.

en: Well, he is a very undeserving young man—and I do not suppose there is the least chance in the world of her ever getting him now.
vi: He is a young man of no worth at all. And I think there is now no chance for Jane to marry him.
tr: Well, he turned out to be a worthless man – surely now there is no chance of her marrying him.
es: Really, he is heartless and I don't think there's the slightest chance of her succeeding.

en: There is no talk of his coming to Netherfield again in the summer; and I have inquired of everybody, too, who is likely to know.”
vi: No one has mentioned anything about him returning to Netherfield this summer; I have also inquired from everyone who might know about him.
tr: There is no talk of him coming to Netherfield in the summer either; I asked everyone who might know."
es: There's no talk of him returning to Netherfield this summer, and I've asked everyone who might be informed.

en: “I am determined never to speak of it again”
vi: No one has mentioned anything about him returning to Netherfield this summer; I have also inquired from everyone who might know about him.
tr: "I don't think he will live at Netherfield again.""
es: ––I don't think he will return to Netherfield anymore.

en: “I do not believe that he will ever live at Netherfield any more.”
vi: - I don't think he will live at Netherfield anymore.
tr: "I don't think he will live at Netherfield again.""
es: ––I don't think he will return to Netherfield anymore.

en: “Oh, well!
vi: - Oh, is that so!
tr: "It's up to him."
es: ––Very well.

en: it is just as he chooses.
vi: It's up to him to decide.
tr: "Oh, as if anyone wants him to come."
es: It's better this way. There's no need.

en: Nobody wants him to come; though I shall always say that he used my daughter extremely ill; and, if I was her, I would not have put up with it.
vi: No one wants him to come back. Although mother always says that he treated her daughter badly, if she were Jane, she wouldn't have to endure it.
tr: "I always say he treats my daughter badly, but if I were in my daughter's place, I couldn't bear it."
es: Although I will always say that he has behaved terribly with my daughter, and if I were her, I wouldn't have tolerated it.

en: Well, my comfort is, I am sure Jane will die of a broken heart, and then he will be sorry for what he has done.”
vi: Mother finds comfort in believing that if Jane were to die of heartbreak, he would regret what he had done.
tr: "My only consolation is that Jane will die of a broken heart, and then the man will suffer for what he has done.""
es: My only consolation is that Jane will die of a broken heart and then Bingley will regret what he has done.

en: But as Elizabeth could not receive comfort from any such expectation she made no answer.
vi: But since Elizabeth did not feel comforted by such a prospect, she did not reply.
tr: Elizabeth, unable to find solace in such an expectation, did not respond.
es: But Elizabeth, who could not console herself with those hopes, remained silent.

en: “Well, Lizzy,” continued her mother, soon afterwards, “and so the Collinses live very comfortable, do they?
vi: The mother continued: - Hey, Lizzy, and then the Collins family lives very comfortably, right?
tr: "Well, Lizzy," her mother continued shortly after, "the Collinses live quite comfortably, don't they?
es: ––Tell me ––continued the mother––, the Collins live very well, don't they?

en: Well, well, I only hope it will last.
vi: Alright, alright, I just hope the couple continues to be like that.
tr: Well, I hope they live long.
es: Well, well, I hope it lasts a long time for them.

en: And what sort of table do they keep?
vi: And how is their dining table?
tr: How is their table?
es: And how do they eat?

en: Charlotte is an excellent manager, I dare say.
vi: I'm sure Charlotte is an excellent housekeeper.
tr: Charlotte understands household management well, I think.
es: I'm sure Charlotte is an excellent manager.

en: If she is half as sharp as her mother, she is saving enough.
vi: If she is only half as thrifty as her mother, she could save enough money.
tr: If she is half as frugal as her mother, she will save quite a bit.
es: If she is half as sharp as her mother, she will save a lot.

en: There is nothing extravagant in their housekeeping, I dare say.”
vi: I'm sure there is nothing wasteful in the management of their household.
tr: I don't think they ever go to excess in their home."
es: I don't think they indulge much.

en: “No, nothing at all.”
vi: - No, no waste at all.
tr: "No, not at all.""
es: ––No, not at all.

en: “A great deal of good management, depend upon it.
vi: - Management must be very skillful.
tr: "He is very frugal, very, trust my word.
es: ––Good administration depends on it.

en: Yes, yes.
vi: Yes, that's right.
tr: Truly.
es: Yes, yes; they will be very careful not to squander their salary.

en: They will take care not to outrun their income.
vi: They will be careful not to spend more than their income.
tr: They are careful to spend only as much as they earn.
es: Yes, yes; they will be very careful not to squander their salary.

en: They will never be distressed for money.
vi: They will never be short of money.
tr: That's why they never have money troubles.
es: They will never have money troubles.

en: Well, much good may it do them!
vi: Ah, so many good things for them!
tr: Well, may God accept it!
es: Good for them!

en: And so, I suppose, they often talk of having Longbourn when your father is dead.
vi: And so, I guess the two often talk about taking over Longbourn when your father passes away.
tr: Then, I think, they often talk about inheriting Longbourn when your father dies.
es: And I imagine they often talk about acquiring Longbourn when your father dies, and that they already consider it theirs as soon as that happens.

en: They look upon it quite as their own, I dare say, whenever that happens.”
vi: I'm sure they consider it theirs once that happens.
tr: They see this place as their own property, I suppose, eventually."
es: And I imagine they often talk about acquiring Longbourn when your father dies, and that they already consider it theirs as soon as that happens.

en: “It was a subject which they could not mention before me.”
vi: - They don't talk about this in front of the child.
tr: "This was a topic they couldn't talk about in front of me."
es: ––They never mentioned this topic in front of me.

en: “No; it would have been strange if they had.
vi: - That's right. If they say so, it is indeed strange.
tr: "Indeed. It would be strange if they talked.
es: ––Of course, it wouldn't have been appropriate; but I have no doubt that they talk about it many times among themselves.

en: But I make no doubt they often talk of it between themselves.
vi: But I no longer have any doubts. They often talk about that with each other.
tr: But I have no doubt, they often talk about this among themselves.
es: ––Of course, it wouldn't have been appropriate; but I have no doubt that they talk about it many times among themselves.

en: Well, if they can be easy with an estate that is not lawfully their own, so much the better.
vi: Well, if they can feel comfortable with a property that is not legally theirs, then that's fine.
tr: Well, if they will feel at ease by settling in a house that doesn't legally belong to them, it's their choice.
es: Well, if they are content with a possession that legally isn't theirs, that's their problem.

en: I should be ashamed of having one that was only entailed on me.”
vi: I would be ashamed to have a property that I only inherited by order.
tr: If such an inheritance were to come to me, I would be ashamed to claim it."
es: It would embarrass me.

en: CHAPTER XLI.
vi: Chapter 41
tr: Chapter XVIII
es: CHAPTER XLI

en: THE first week of their return was soon gone.
vi: They have been back home for two weeks.
tr: The first week of their return passed quickly.
es: The first week of the return passed quickly, and they entered the second, which was the last week of the regiment's stay in Meryton.

en: The second began.
vi: They have been back home for two weeks.
tr: The second one began.
es: The first week of the return passed quickly, and they entered the second, which was the last week of the regiment's stay in Meryton.

en: It was the last of the regiment’s stay in Meryton, and all the young ladies in the neighbourhood were drooping apace.
vi: This is the last week the regiment will stay in Meryton.
tr: It was the last week the regiment would spend in Meryton, and all the young ladies in the vicinity were swooning.
es: The first week of the return passed quickly, and they entered the second, which was the last week of the regiment's stay in Meryton.

en: The dejection was almost universal.
vi: All the young girls were downcast; all were disheartened.
tr: Sorrow had enveloped almost everyone.
es: The young women of the locality languished; the sadness was almost general.

en: The elder Miss Bennets alone were still able to eat, drink, and sleep, and pursue the usual course of their employments.
vi: Only the two eldest Bennet daughters could eat, sleep, and continue their daily routines.
tr: Only the elder Miss Bennets were still able to eat, drink, sleep, and continue their daily activities.
es: Only the elder Bennet daughters were capable of eating, drinking, and sleeping as if nothing was happening.

en: Very frequently were they reproached for this insensibility by Kitty and Lydia, whose own misery was extreme, and who could not comprehend such hard-heartedness in any of the family.
vi: Very often, Kitty and Lydia reproached them for their indifferent attitude. The two younger girls felt too miserable to understand such stony-heartedness within the family. They often bitterly exclaimed:
tr: They were often scolded by Kitty and Lydia for this insensitivity; those two were in deep mourning and could not accept such heartlessness in the family.
es: Catherine and Lydia often reproached them for their insensitivity. They were very dejected and could not understand such hardness of heart in members of their own family.

en: “Good Heaven!
vi: - Good heavens!
tr: "For God's sake!
es: ––My God!

en: What is to become of us?
vi: What will become of us?
tr: What will happen to us!"
es: What is going to become of us? What are we going to do?

en: What are we to do?” would they often exclaim in the bitterness of woe.
vi: What will we do?
tr: "What will we do!" they often lamented in a bitter voice.
es: ––they exclaimed desolately––.

en: “How can you be smiling so, Lizzy?”
vi: How can you still smile like that, Lizzy?
tr: "How can you smile like that, Lizzy?"
es: How can you smile like that, Elizabeth?

en: Their affectionate mother shared all their grief; she remembered what she had herself endured on a similar occasion five-and-twenty years ago.
vi: The loving mother shared their pain. She remembered that she had gone through a similar situation twenty years ago. She said:
tr: Their loving mothers shared in all their pain; she too remembered facing a similar situation, twenty-five years ago.
es: Her loving mother shared her sorrow and remembered what she herself had suffered on a similar occasion twenty-five years ago.

en: “I am sure,” said she, “I cried for two days together when Colonel Miller’s regiment went away.
vi: - I'm sure I will cry for two days with you when Colonel Millar's regiment leaves.
tr: "Believe me," she said, "when Colonel Millar's regiment left, I cried for exactly two days.
es: ––I remember ––he said–– that I cried for two days straight when Colonel Miller's regiment left, I thought my heart was going to break.

en: I thought I should have broke my heart.”
vi: I think my heart might break. - I am sure my heart will be broken.
tr: I thought I was done for."
es: ––I remember ––he said–– that I cried for two days straight when Colonel Miller's regiment left, I thought my heart was going to break.

en: “I am sure I shall break mine,” said Lydia.
vi: She remarked:
tr: "But I am really exhausted," said Lydia.
es: ––Mine will also fall to pieces ––said Lydia.

en: “If one could but go to Brighton!” observed ms Bennet.
vi: - I just wish I could go to Brington!
tr: "Oh, if only we could go to Brighton!" said Mrs. Bennet.
es: ––If only we could go to Brighton! ––sighed Mrs. Bennet.

en: “Oh yes!—if one could but go to Brighton!
vi: - Ah, really, I wish I could go to Brington!
tr: "Ah yes! –If only we could go to Brighton!
es: ––Oh, yes! If only we could go to Brighton!

en: But papa is so disagreeable.”
vi: But papa is too difficult!
tr: But my father is so stubborn."
es: But father is so unaccommodating!

en: “A little sea-bathing would set me up for ever.”
vi: - Swimming in the sea a little is enough for you forever.
tr: "Going to the sea used to make me feel so good."
es: ––A few sea baths would make me feel like new.

en: “And my aunt Philips is sure it would do me a great deal of good,” added Kitty.
vi: Kitty added: - And Aunt Phillips will certainly be able to help you a lot.
tr: "Aunt Philips says it will be especially good for me," added Kitty.
es: ––And Aunt Philips says they would do me a lot of good too ––added Catherine.

en: Such were the kind of lamentations resounding perpetually through Longbourn House.
vi: This is the kind of lamentation that always echoes in the Longbourn house.
tr: Such pleas echoed incessantly in the Longbourn estate.
es: These lamentations continually echoed in the Longbourn house.

en: Elizabeth tried to be diverted by them; but all sense of pleasure was lost in shame.
vi: Elizabeth tried to make this a diversion, but all feelings of joy vanished in shame.
tr: Elizabeth tried to distract herself with them; but all sense of pleasure vanished in shame.
es: Elizabeth tried to keep herself isolated, but she could not avoid the shame.

en: She felt anew the justice of mr Darcy’s objections; and never had she before been so much disposed to pardon his interference in the views of his friend.
vi: Once again, she felt that Mr. Darcy's opposition was justified, and never before had she felt such a desire to forgive his interference in his friend's views.
tr: She felt the validity of Mr. Darcy's objections once again; never before had she been so inclined to forgive his interference in his friend's opinions.
es: She once again recognized the justice of Darcy's observations, and she had never felt so willing to forgive him for opposing his friend's plans.

en: But the gloom of Lydia’s prospect was shortly cleared away; for she received an invitation from ms Forster, the wife of the colonel of the regiment, to accompany her to Brighton.
vi: But the gloom in Lydia's prospects was dispelled, for she received an invitation from Mrs. Forster, the wife of the Colonel in the regiment, to accompany her to Brington.
tr: But Lydia's sorrow was soon alleviated; she received an invitation from Mrs. Forster, the wife of the regiment's Colonel, to accompany her to Brighton.
es: But Lydia's melancholy did not take long to dissipate, for she received an invitation from Mrs. Forster, the wife of the regiment's colonel, to accompany her to Brighton.

en: This invaluable friend was a very young woman, and very lately married.
vi: This dear friend was a very young woman, and had only recently been married.
tr: This dear friend was a very young woman, newly married.
es: This invaluable friend of Lydia was very young and had recently married.

en: A resemblance in good-humour and good spirits had recommended her and Lydia to each other, and out of their three months’ acquaintance they had been intimate two.
vi: A similar sense of humor and high spirits had brought the two women together, and in three months of acquaintance, they had become close in two months.
tr: The similarity in their temperaments and their fondness for amusement had drawn her and Lydia close to each other, and during their three months of acquaintance, Lydia had become like a member of the family.
es: Since both were equally cheerful and lively, they got along perfectly and within three months of meeting, they were already close friends.

en: The rapture of Lydia on this occasion, her adoration of ms Forster, the delight of ms Bennet, and the mortification of Kitty, are scarcely to be described.
vi: Lydia's delight, her affection for Mrs. Forster, Mrs. Bennet's cheerfulness, and Kitty's humiliation were all difficult to describe.
tr: The joy Lydia felt in this situation, the love she felt for Mrs. Forster, Mrs. Bennet's satisfaction, and Kitty's sorrow were indescribable.
es: Lydia's enthusiasm and the adoration she felt for Mrs. Forster, Mrs. Bennet's satisfaction, and Catherine's mortification were almost indescribable.

en: Wholly inattentive to her sister’s feelings, Lydia flew about the house in restless ecstasy, calling for everyone’s congratulations, and laughing and talking with more violence than ever; whilst the luckless Kitty continued in the parlour repining at her fate in terms as unreasonable as her accent was peevish.
vi: Completely oblivious to her sister's feelings, Lydia wandered around the house in a state of ecstatic restlessness, calling on everyone to congratulate her, chattering away, while the unfortunate Kitty expressed her irritation in nonsensical words. She said to her sisters:
tr: Lydia, who was completely indifferent to her sister's feelings, ran around the house in a state of ecstasy, wanting everyone to congratulate her, laughed louder than ever, and spoke; meanwhile, the unfortunate Kitty continued to grumble about her fate in the living room with a grumpy voice and equally unreasonable expressions.
es: Without the slightest concern for her sister's displeasure, Lydia ran around the house completely ecstatic, asking everyone to congratulate her, laughing and talking more energetically than ever, while poor Catherine remained in the living room lamenting her bad luck in unreasonable terms and in a foul mood.

en: “I cannot see why ms Forster should not ask me as well as Lydia,” said she, “though I am not her particular friend.
vi: - I can't understand why Mrs. Forster invited Lydia and not me. Even though I'm not a special friend of hers, I still have the right to be invited just as much as she does.
tr: "I may not be a close friend," she said, "but I don't understand why Mrs. Forster doesn't invite me instead of Lydia.
es: ––I don't see why Mrs. Forster doesn't invite me as well ––she said––, even though Lydia is her particular friend.

en: I have just as much right to be asked as she has, and more too, for I am two years older.”
vi: Even more so, because I am two years older than she is.
tr: I have as much right to be invited as she does, even more; I am two years older."
es: I have the same right as she does to be invited, and even more so, because I am older.

en: In vain did Elizabeth attempt to make her reasonable, and Jane to make her resigned.
vi: Elizabeth could not make her understand more, and Jane could not make her resign.
tr: Elizabeth tried to persuade Jane to be reasonable and give up, but it was in vain.
es: In vain did Elizabeth try to make her see reason, and in vain did Jane try to make her resign herself.

en: As for Elizabeth herself, this invitation was so far from exciting in her the same feelings as in her mother and Lydia, that she considered it as the death-warrant of all possibility of common sense for the latter; and detestable as such a step must make her, were it known, she could not help secretly advising her father not to let her go.
vi: As for Elizabeth, this invitation did not excite her as much as it did her mother and Lydia, to the extent that she saw it as a death sentence for any possibility of Lydia having a conscience. She made a decision that might be despised if not kept secret; she could not help but advise her father not to let Lydia go.
tr: As for Elizabeth herself, this invitation did not evoke the same feelings in her as it did in her mother and Lydia; she saw the invitation as the death knell for any chance of her sister behaving sensibly; knowing that learning of the trip would put her in a difficult position, Elizabeth couldn't help but secretly speak to her father to prevent her from going.
es: The happy invitation awakened in Elizabeth feelings quite different from those of Lydia and her mother; she clearly understood that there was no longer any hope that Mrs. Bennet would show any sign of common sense. She could not help but ask her father not to let Lydia go to Brighton, as such a step could have dire consequences.

en: She represented to him all the improprieties of Lydia’s general behaviour, the little advantage she could derive from the friendship of such a woman as ms Forster, and the probability of her being yet more imprudent with such a companion at Brighton, where the temptations must be greater than at home.
vi: She presented to him all of Lydia's improper behavior, the unbeneficial relationship with Mrs. Forster, the possibility that Lydia would become even more reckless with such a companion at Brington, where the temptations might be stronger than near home.
tr: She explained to her father all the impropriety of Lydia's general behavior, that a woman like Mrs. Forster would be of no benefit to her, and that in a place full of traps like Brighton, she was likely to get even more out of control with such a friend.
es: She pointed out to him Lydia's unsuitability, the few advantages her friendship with Mrs. Forster could bring, and the danger that, with such company, Lydia's imprudence in Brighton, where temptations would be greater, would be redoubled.

en: He heard her attentively, and then said,—
vi: He listened to her attentively, then said:
tr: After listening to her carefully, her father said,
es: Mr. Bennet listened attentively to his daughter and said to her:

en: “Lydia will never be easy till she has exposed herself in some public place or other, and we can never expect her to do it with so little expense or inconvenience to her family as under the present circumstances.”
vi: - Lydia will never be at peace until she can socialize in public or somewhere else. And we can never expect her to socialize in such a way with less expense or trouble for the family under the current circumstances.
tr: "Lydia will not be at ease until she has shown herself to the public in one community or another; and we cannot expect her to do this with so little expense or inconvenience to her family.""
es: ––Lydia will not be at ease until she makes a fool of herself in public at one place or another, and we can never expect her to do it with so little expense and sacrifice to her family as on this occasion.

en: “If you were aware,” said Elizabeth, “of the very great disadvantage to us all, which must arise from the public notice of Lydia’s unguarded and imprudent manner, nay, which has already arisen from it, I am sure you would judge differently in the affair.”
vi: Elizabeth said: - If father knew about the severe disadvantages for all of us when people notice Lydia's lack of tact and recklessness, which they already have, I think he would consider the matter differently.
tr: "If you knew the discomfort Lydia's imprudent and careless appearance to the public would cause us all," said Elizabeth, "or even the discomfort it has already caused; I am sure you would then evaluate the matter differently.""
es: ––If you knew ––replied Elizabeth–– the great harm that the indiscreet and improper behavior of Lydia can bring upon all of us, and the harm it has already caused us, I am sure you would think very differently.

en: “Already arisen!” repeated mr Bennet.
vi: - Noticed?!
tr: "Already created, ha!" repeated Mr. Bennet.
es: ––"It has already caused us trouble!" ––exclaimed Mr. Bennet––.

en: “What! has she frightened away some of your lovers?
vi: What, has she already driven away a few of your suitors?
tr: "What, did she scare away her suitors?
es: "Has it scared away any of your suitors?

en: Poor little Lizzy!
vi: Poor Lizzy!
tr: Poor Lizzy!
es: Poor Lizzy!"

en: But do not be cast down.
vi: But don't be discouraged.
tr: Don't worry.
es: "But don't be distressed."

en: Such squeamish youths as cannot bear to be connected with a little absurdity are not worth a regret.
vi: Any young people who are so restless that they can't bear to engage with a bit of absurdity aren't worth our regret.
tr: It's not worth feeling sorry for young men who can't stand being related to a few oddballs.
es: "Those delicate young men who cannot endure such nonsense are not worth it."

en: Come, let me see the list of the pitiful fellows who have been kept aloof by Lydia’s folly.”
vi: Come here, let me see the list of those poor boys who have been kept away by that crazy Lydia.
tr: Come on, count the poor souls scared away by Lydia's foolishness."
es: "Come, tell me who are the finicky suitors that Lydia's madness has driven away."

en: “Indeed, you are mistaken.
vi: - Actually, father was mistaken.
tr: "You are truly mistaken.
es: ––You don't understand me.

en: I have no such injuries to resent.
vi: I don't feel hurt or upset.
tr: I don't have those kinds of wounds that you worry about.
es: I'm not complaining about that.

en: It is not of peculiar, but of general evils, which I am now complaining.
vi: I am complaining about bad habits in general, not any specific bad habit.
tr: I'm not afraid of any specific thing, but rather of general dangers.
es: I'm not denouncing specific dangers, but general ones.

en: Our importance, our respectability in the world, must be affected by the wild volatility, the assurance and disdain of all restraint which mark Lydia’s character.
vi: The status of our family and the respect others have for us will certainly be affected by the impulsiveness, decisiveness, and disregard for all restraint, which are Lydia's characteristics.
tr: Because of Lydia's character trait of wild variability, her tendency to break all rules and disregard them, our importance and respect in the world will be damaged.
es: Our prestige and our respectability in front of people will be harmed by Lydia's extreme frivolity, disdain, and recklessness.

en: Excuse me,—for I must speak plainly.
vi: Sorry, father, for speaking frankly.
tr: Forgive me – because I must speak openly.
es: Forgive me, but I have to speak to you clearly.

en: If you, my dear father, will not take the trouble of checking her exuberant spirits, and of teaching her that her present pursuits are not to be the business of her life, she will soon be beyond the reach of amendment.
vi: Dear father, if you do not take the trouble to control her exuberant temperament and if you do not teach her that she should not make her current pursuits of pleasure her daily life's work, she will soon be beyond correction.
tr: If you, dear father, do not take the trouble to curb her rebellious spirit and teach her that she cannot spend her life chasing such fantasies, she will soon become uncontrollable.
es: If you, dear father, do not take the trouble to curb her euphoria, to teach her that she should not devote her life to her current pastimes, soon it will be too late for her to amend.

en: Her character will be fixed; and she will, at sixteen, be the most determined flirt that ever made herself and her family ridiculous;—a flirt, too, in the worst and meanest degree of flirtation; without any attraction beyond youth and a tolerable person; and, from the ignorance and emptiness of her mind, wholly unable to ward off any portion of that universal contempt which her rage for admiration will excite.
vi: Her character will become fixed; then at sixteen, she will become so wanton that she herself and the whole family will be a laughingstock. A girl who indulges in the worst and most base kind of wantonness, with nothing to attract people except youth, and a person barely tolerable. With a foolish and empty mind, she cannot withstand contempt while she herself desires to be admired.
tr: Her character will settle, and at sixteen, she will become a complete disgrace to herself and her family. And a disgrace of the worst, most vulgar kind; someone who has no charm beyond her youth and physique; due to her ignorance and stupidity, while she struggles to be admired, she will not be able to prevent everyone from despising her.
es: Her character will be set, and at sixteen she will be an incorrigible flirt who will not only make a fool of herself but also of her entire family; a flirt, moreover, in the worst and most insignificant degree of flirtation, with no more attraction than her youth and her average physical traits; ignorant and empty-headed, incapable of noticing the slightest bit of the general contempt that her desire to be admired will provoke.

en: In this danger Kitty is also comprehended.
vi: In this danger, Kitty is also a concern.
tr: This danger applies to Kitty as well.
es: Catherine is in the same danger, because she will go where Lydia leads her; vain, ignorant, lazy, and absolutely uncontrollable.

en: She will follow wherever Lydia leads.
vi: She will imitate all of Lydia's bad habits.
tr: Wherever Lydia goes, she follows.
es: Catherine is in the same danger, because she will go where Lydia leads her; vain, ignorant, lazy, and absolutely uncontrollable.

en: Vain, ignorant, idle, and absolutely uncontrolled!
vi: Oh, father, can you think that they will not be criticized and despised everywhere they are known, and that their sisters will not be humiliated by association?
tr: Foolish, ignorant, idle, and completely uncontrolled! Oh!
es: Catherine is in the same danger, because she will go where Lydia leads her; vain, ignorant, lazy, and absolutely uncontrollable.

en: Oh, my dear father, can you suppose it possible that they will not be censured and despised wherever they are known, and that their sisters will not be often involved in the disgrace?”
vi: Oh, father, can you think that they will not be criticized and despised everywhere they are known, and that their sisters will not be humiliated by association?
tr: Dear father, don't you see that they will be condemned and scorned wherever they are known, and their sisters will also share in this shame?"
es: Father, can you believe that they will not be criticized and despised wherever they go, and that they will not drag the other sisters into their disgrace?

en: mr Bennet saw that her whole heart was in the subject; and, affectionately taking her hand, said, in reply,—
vi: Mr. Bennet saw that she was deeply invested in the matter, and affectionately took her hand, he said:
tr: Mr. Bennet understood that Elizabeth was speaking with all her heart; he lovingly took her hand and replied,
es: Mr. Bennet realized that Elizabeth was speaking from the heart. He took her hand affectionately and replied:

en: “Do not make yourself uneasy, my love.
vi: - Don't let yourself be anxious, my dear.
tr: "Don't be upset, my dear.
es: ––Don't be troubled, my love.

en: Wherever you and Jane are known, you must be respected and valued; and you will not appear to less advantage for having a couple of—or I may say, three—very silly sisters.
vi: Everywhere people know you and Jane, you both will be respected and appreciated, and you won't seem disadvantaged if you have two – or three – foolish siblings.
tr: Wherever you and Jane are known, you will be met with respect and love; having one or two, how should I say, quite foolish sisters does not diminish your worth.
es: You and Jane will always be respected and loved everywhere, and you won't seem less advantaged for having two or perhaps three very foolish sisters.

en: We shall have no peace at Longbourn if Lydia does not go to Brighton.
vi: We won't be able to have peace at Longbourn if Lydia doesn't go to Brington.
tr: If Lydia does not go to Brighton, we will not see peace at Longbourn.
es: There will be no peace in Longbourn if Lydia does not go to Brighton.

en: Let her go, then.
vi: Let her go.
tr: Therefore, let her go.
es: Let her go.

en: Colonel Forster is a sensible man, and will keep her out of any real mischief; and she is luckily too poor to be an object of prey to anybody.
vi: Colonel Forster is a sensible person and will help her avoid all sorts of trouble, and fortunately, she is too poor to be prey for anyone.
tr: Colonel Forster is a reasonable man, he will not allow her to get into serious trouble; fortunately, she is too poor to be preyed upon by anyone.
es: Colonel Forster is a sensible man and will watch over her. And she is fortunately too poor to be the target of anyone's predation.

en: At Brighton she will be of less importance even as a common flirt than she has been here.
vi: In Brington, she will become less playful than she is here.
tr: As an ordinary floozy in Brighton, she will be less significant than she is here.
es: Her flirtation will be of less importance in Brighton than here, as the officers will find more attractive women there.

en: The officers will find women better worth their notice.
vi: The officers there will find women more worthy of their attention.
tr: The officers will find more useful women.
es: Her flirtation will be of less importance in Brighton than here, as the officers will find more attractive women there.

en: Let us hope, therefore, that her being there may teach her her own insignificance.
vi: Therefore, we should believe that the girl will learn a lesson about her own insignificance.
tr: So let us hope that going there teaches her her own insignificance.
es: So it will serve to make her understand her own insignificance.

en: At any rate, she cannot grow many degrees worse, without authorizing us to lock her up for the rest of her life.”
vi: Anyway, she can't become any worse, unless she wants me to confine her to the house for the rest of her life.
tr: After all, she cannot go worse than she is now, otherwise it would mean we have to keep her locked up for the rest of her life."
es: In any case, she can't get much worse, and if she does, we would then have sufficient reason to lock her up for the rest of her life.

en: With this answer Elizabeth was forced to be content; but her own opinion continued the same, and she left him disappointed and sorry.
vi: With this answer, Elizabeth was forced to be satisfied, but she still held onto her opinion in disappointment and frustration.
tr: Elizabeth was forced to find solace in this answer; but her own view remained the same, and she left her father's side feeling disappointed and sad.
es: Elizabeth had to be content with this answer; but her opinion remained the same, and she parted from her father sorrowful and disappointed.

en: It was not in her nature, however, to increase her vexations by dwelling on them.
vi: However, she did not have the temperament to remain upset forever over the matter.
tr: Nevertheless, she did not have the habit of increasing her troubles by dwelling on them.
es: But her character prevented her from increasing her troubles by dwelling on them.

en: She was confident of having performed her duty; and to fret over unavoidable evils, or augment them by anxiety, was no part of her disposition.
vi: She was content that she had fulfilled her duty, and did not have the tendency to stay upset over unpleasant matters, which were inevitable, and thus cause herself more worry.
tr: She was confident that she had done her duty; it was not in her nature to worry about inevitable disasters or to magnify them with anxiety.
es: She believed she had fulfilled her duty and was not willing to consume herself thinking about inevitable evils or to increase them with her anxiety.

en: Had Lydia and her mother known the substance of her conference with her father, their indignation would hardly have found expression in their united volubility.
vi: If Lydia and her mother knew about the conversation she had with her father, their outrage would be difficult to put into words given their quick tempers.
tr: If her mother and Lydia knew the subject of the conversation she had with her father, they would join forces and say everything they could out of anger.
es: If Lydia or her mother had known what Elizabeth had been talking about with her father, their indignation would have known no bounds.

en: In Lydia’s imagination, a visit to Brighton comprised every possibility of earthly happiness.
vi: In Lydia's imagination, a trip to Brington encompassed every possibility of earthly happiness.
tr: In Lydia's imagination, the trip to Brighton encompassed every possibility of earthly happiness.
es: A visit to Brighton was for Lydia the epitome of earthly happiness.

en: She saw, with the creative eye of fancy, the streets of that gay bathing-place covered with officers.
vi: With a fanciful eye, she envisioned streets crowded with officers, and herself as the object of attention for dozens of strange young men.
tr: She saw the streets of the cheerful seaside resort, filled with officers, through the creative eye of dreams.
es: With her enormous imagination, she saw the streets of that cheerful coastal town teeming with officers; she saw herself attracting the gazes of dozens and dozens of them whom she had yet to meet.

en: She saw herself the object of attention to tens and to scores of them at present unknown.
vi: With a fanciful eye, she envisioned streets crowded with officers, and herself as the object of attention for dozens of strange young men.
tr: She saw herself as an object of attention for dozens, even scores, of men she had yet to meet.
es: With her enormous imagination, she saw the streets of that cheerful coastal town teeming with officers; she saw herself attracting the gazes of dozens and dozens of them whom she had yet to meet.

en: She saw all the glories of the camp: its tents stretched forth in beauteous uniformity of lines, crowded with the young and the gay, and dazzling with scarlet; and, to complete the view, she saw herself seated beneath a tent, tenderly flirting with at least six officers at once.
vi: She saw all the glory of the barracks; the rows of tents neatly lined up, bustling with young and lively men in bright red; and to complete the scene, she even saw herself sitting under a tent, playfully flirting with at least six officers at once.
tr: She envisioned all the splendor of the military camp; rows of tents stretched out beautifully, filled with young and cheerful men in dazzling red; and to complete the scene, she saw herself sitting under a canopy, playfully flirting with at least six officers.
es: She imagined herself in the middle of the camp, with its tents laid out in the beautiful uniformity of their lines, filled with cheerful and dazzling young men in their crimson uniforms; and to complete the picture, she imagined herself sitting next to one of those tents and tenderly flirting with no fewer than six officers at once.

en: “Tenderly flirting”
vi: She saw all the glory of the barracks; the rows of tents neatly lined up, bustling with young and lively men in bright red; and to complete the scene, she even saw herself sitting under a tent, playfully flirting with at least six officers at once.
tr: She envisioned all the splendor of the military camp; rows of tents stretched out beautifully, filled with young and cheerful men in dazzling red; and to complete the scene, she saw herself sitting under a canopy, playfully flirting with at least six officers.
es: She imagined herself in the middle of the camp, with its tents laid out in the beautiful uniformity of their lines, filled with cheerful and dazzling young men in their crimson uniforms; and to complete the picture, she imagined herself sitting next to one of those tents and tenderly flirting with no fewer than six officers at once.

en: Had she known that her sister sought to tear her from such prospects and such realities as these, what would have been her sensations?
vi: If you knew that your sister had tried to pull you out of such visions and realities, what would you think?
tr: What would his reaction be if he knew that his sister was trying to separate him from these opportunities and these realities?
es: If she had known that her sister intended to take away all those dreams, all those realities, what would have happened?

en: They could have been understood only by her mother, who might have felt nearly the same.
vi: Only your mother could understand these thoughts, because she had the same feelings.
tr: Only his mother could understand this, because she might have felt more or less the same things.
es: Only her mother would have been able to understand it, as she almost felt the same as her.

en: Lydia’s going to Brighton was all that consoled her for the melancholy conviction of her husband’s never intending to go there himself.
vi: Lydia going to Brington was the only comfort for her melancholy, as her husband never intended to go there.
tr: Lydia going to Brighton was her mother's only consolation against the sorrow caused by her husband's reluctance to go.
es: Lydia's trip to Brighton was the only thing that consoled her from her melancholic conviction that she would never manage to take her husband there.

en: But they were entirely ignorant of what had passed; and their raptures continued, with little intermission, to the very day of Lydia’s leaving home.
vi: But they knew nothing about what had happened, remaining eager until the day of departure.
tr: But they were completely unaware of what had happened; their joy continued uninterrupted until the day Lydia left the house.
es: But neither of them suspected what had happened, and their enthusiasm continued until the very day Lydia left home.

en: Elizabeth was now to see mr Wickham for the last time.
vi: Elizabeth is now preparing to meet Mr. Wickham for the last time.
tr: Elizabeth was now going to see Mr. Wickham for the last time.
es: Elizabeth was now going to see Wickham for the last time.

en: Having been frequently in company with him since her return, agitation was pretty well over; the agitations of former partiality entirely so.
vi: Since her return, she had met him frequently, and the agitation in her mind had greatly diminished; the agitation from her initial feelings had completely disappeared.
tr: Since she had been in his company frequently since his return, her excitement had considerably diminished; the excitement caused by their former intimacy had entirely vanished.
es: She had often been in his company since she returned from Hunsford, and her agitation had greatly subsided; her former interest in him had completely vanished.

en: She had even learnt to detect, in the very gentleness which had first delighted her, an affectation and a sameness to disgust and weary.
vi: She had realized that, in the same gentle demeanor that had once delighted her, there was now a sense of absurdity and something akin to disgust and weariness.
tr: She had even learned to detect a tiresome, wearisome falseness and sameness in the politeness that had once pleased her so much.
es: She had learned to discern in that kindness which initially attracted her a certain affectation that now repelled her.

en: In his present behaviour to herself, moreover, she had a fresh source of displeasure; for the inclination he soon testified of renewing those attentions which had marked the early part of their acquaintance could only serve, after what had since passed, to provoke her.
vi: Moreover, in his current manner towards her, she had additional reasons for dissatisfaction because he seemed to want to rekindle their old feelings as if nothing had happened, which only made her more infuriated after all that had transpired.
tr: Moreover, she found a new source of dissatisfaction in Wickham's current behavior towards her because his attempt to restore the intimacy that had characterized the first part of their relationship, after all that had happened in between, only served to irritate Elizabeth.
es: Moreover, Wickham's attitude towards her had just displeased her, as the young man showed a desire to renew his courtship, and after all that had happened, Elizabeth could not help but feel indignant.

en: She lost all concern for him in finding herself thus selected as the object of such idle and frivolous gallantry; and while she steadily repressed it, could not but feel the reproof contained in his believing, that however long, and for whatever cause, his attentions had been withdrawn, her vanity would be gratified, and her preference secured, at any time, by their renewal.
vi: She lost all interest in him when she saw herself being chosen as an object for such pointless and frivolous flirtation. While she rebuffed him, she had the impression that he was still confident that no matter how long he had neglected her and for whatever reason, he could satisfy her vanity and could win her back at any time.
tr: Seeing herself chosen as the object of such idle and spurious flirtation, she had lost all interest in him; while resolutely resisting Wickham's advances, she could not help but feel the condescension underlying his belief that he would flatter her pride and win her heart by rekindling an interest she had long since and for known reasons ceased to have.
es: She firmly restrained his vain and frivolous attentions, while still feeling the offense implied by Wickham's belief that no matter how long he had neglected her and whatever the cause of his neglect, he would flatter and win her over again just by seeking her out once more.

en: On the very last day of the regiment’s remaining in Meryton, he dined, with others of the officers, at Longbourn; and so little was Elizabeth disposed to part from him in good-humour, that, on his making some inquiry as to the manner in which her time had passed at Hunsford, she mentioned Colonel Fitzwilliam’s and mr Darcy’s having both spent three weeks at Rosings, and asked him if he were acquainted with the former.
vi: On the last day of the Meryton regiment, he attended a dinner with other officers at Longbourn. Elizabeth was not at all prepared to bid him farewell cheerfully, so much so that when he asked about her stay in Hentsford, she mentioned that both Colonel Fitzwilliam and Mr. Darcy would be staying at Rosings for three weeks, and asked if he was acquainted with the colonel.
tr: On the last day of the regiment's stay in Meryton, Wickham dined at Longbourn with other officers; Elizabeth was so reluctant to part on bad terms with him that when Wickham asked how she had spent her time in Hunsford, she mentioned that Colonel Fitzwilliam and Mr. Darcy had spent three weeks at Rosings and asked if he had met the former.
es: On the last day of the regiment's stay in Meryton, Wickham dined at Longbourn with other officers. Elizabeth was so unwilling to endure him that when Wickham asked her how she had spent her time in Hunsford, she replied that Colonel Fitzwilliam and Darcy had spent three weeks in Rosings, and she wanted to know if he knew the former.

en: He looked surprised, displeased, alarmed; but, with a moment’s recollection, and a returning smile, replied, that he had formerly seen him often; and, after observing that he was a very gentlemanlike man, asked her how she had liked him.
vi: He showed a look of surprise, dissatisfaction, and worry, but quickly calmed himself, and with a smile, replied that he often met the Colonel; and after noting that he was a refined person, he asked her what she thought of him.
tr: Wickham appeared surprised, bored, and flustered; but after a moment's thought, his smile returned, and he replied that he had often seen him before; after stating that he was a very gentlemanly man, he asked Elizabeth whether she liked him.
es: Wickham seemed surprised, upset, and alarmed; but he quickly recovered and with a smile replied that he used to see him often. He said that he was quite a gentleman and asked if she had liked him.

en: Her answer was warmly in his favour.
vi: Her answer warmed his heart.
tr: Elizabeth's response was very positive.
es: Elizabeth responded enthusiastically that she had.

en: With an air of indifference, he soon afterwards added, “How long did you say that he was at Rosings?”
vi: With a cold demeanor, he then asked: - How long did she tell him to stay at Rosings?
tr: Wickham added shortly after, in an indifferent manner, "How long did you say he stayed at Rosings?"
es: But then Wickham added, with an indifferent air: ––How long did you say the colonel was at Rosings?

en: “Nearly three weeks.”
vi: - Nearly three weeks.
tr: "About three weeks."
es: ––About three weeks.

en: “And you saw him frequently?”
vi: - And do you meet him often?
tr: "Did you see him often?"
es: ––And did you see him often?

en: “Yes, almost every day.”
vi: - Yes, almost every day.
tr: "Yes, almost every day.""
es: Almost every day.

en: “His manners are very different from his cousin’s.”
vi: - His character is completely different from his cousin's.
tr: "His/her behavior is different from his/her cousin's."
es: ––He is very different from his cousin.

en: “Yes, very different; but I think mr Darcy improves on acquaintance.”
vi: - Yes, very different. But I think Mr. Darcy has learned to communicate better.
tr: "Yes, very much. But I think Mr. Darcy becomes more likable as you get to know him."
es: ––Yes, indeed. But I think Mr. Darcy improves a lot upon acquaintance.

en: “Indeed!” cried Wickham, with a look which did not escape her.
vi: Wickham exclaimed with an expression that did not escape her observation: - Really?
tr: "What do you say!" cried Wickham, with a look that did not escape Elizabeth's notice.
es: ––Wow! ––exclaimed Wickham with a look that did not go unnoticed by Elizabeth––. In what?

en: “And pray may I ask—” but checking himself, he added, in a gayer tone, “Is it in address that he improves?
vi: But he calmed down and added: - May I ask, does he communicate better through spoken words?
tr: "Well, may I ask?" but collecting himself, he added in a more cheerful voice, "Did you like the way of speaking?
es: ––but, restraining himself, he continued in a more jovial tone––:

en: Has he deigned to add aught of civility to his ordinary style?
vi: Or does he just want to add more politeness to his usual manner?
tr: Does he condescend to add other things to his usual manner?
es: In manners? Has he deigned to behave more correctly than usual?

en: for I dare not hope,” he continued, in a lower and more serious tone, “that he is improved in essentials.”
vi: He continued in a lower and more solemn tone: - Because I do not dare to hope that he has changed his essential nature.
tr: because," he continued in a lower and more serious voice, "I don't think you would like him at heart."
es: Because I cannot believe ––he continued in a lower and more serious voice–– that he has improved in the essential.

en: “Oh, no!” said Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth said: - Ah, no.
tr: "No, no!" said Elizabeth.
es: ––Oh, no!

en: “In essentials, I believe, he is very much what he ever was.”
vi: I believe that in his essential qualities, he is still much the same as before.
tr: "I think he is what he is at his core.""
es: In essence, he is still the same as always.

en: While she spoke, Wickham looked as if scarcely knowing whether to rejoice over her words or to distrust their meaning.
vi: While she spoke, Wickham seemed unsure whether to be pleased by her words or to distrust their meaning.
tr: While Elizabeth was speaking, Wickham could not decide whether to be pleased by her words or to doubt their meaning.
