es: Wickham did not know whether to be pleased with her words or to distrust their meaning.

en: There was a something in her countenance which made him listen with an apprehensive and anxious attention, while she added,—
vi: There was something in her expression that made him listen with anxious attention as she continued:
tr: There was something in Elizabeth's face that compelled him to listen with an uneasy and anxious attention as she said the following words,
es: There was something in Elizabeth's demeanor that made him listen with anxious attention and suspicion to what she said next:

en: “When I said that he improved on acquaintance, I did not mean that either his mind or manners were in a state of improvement; but that, from knowing him better, his disposition was better understood.”
vi: - When I said he communicated better, I didn't mean that his speech or gestures had improved. I just meant that, if we knew more about him, we could understand him better.
tr: "When I said 'he becomes more pleasant as you get to know him,' I didn't mean that his thoughts or behaviors undergo a pleasant change, but rather that as you get to know him better, his temperament is better understood."
es: ––By saying that he benefits from the interaction, I do not mean to imply that his character or manners have improved, but rather that by getting to know him better, it is easier to understand his attitude.

en: Wickham’s alarm now appeared in a heightened complexion and agitated look; for a few minutes he was silent; till, shaking off his embarrassment, he turned to her again, and said in the gentlest of accents,—
vi: The worried look on Wickham's face now seemed to have added confusion. For a few minutes, he remained silent until he shook off all confusion, then turned back to her and spoke very gently:
tr: Wickham's agitation now appeared with a tense face and an excited look; he was silent for a few minutes; finally, shaking off his discomfort, he turned to her again and said in a very gentle voice,
es: Wickham's alarm then betrayed itself through his blush and the agitation in his gaze; he remained silent for a few moments until he managed to overcome his embarrassment and, addressing Elizabeth again, said in the kindest tone:

en: “You, who so well know my feelings towards mr Darcy, will readily comprehend how sincerely I must rejoice that he is wise enough to assume even the appearance of what is right.
vi: - Since you have understood very well my feelings about Mr. Darcy, you must understand how sincerely happy I was when he was wise enough to create a proper appearance.
tr: "You, who know well my feelings towards Mr. Darcy, can imagine how sincerely I am glad that he is wise enough to assume the appearance of truthfulness, even if only in form.
es: ––You, who know so well my resentment against Mr. Darcy, will understand how sincerely I must rejoice that he is astute enough to at least assume an outward correction.

en: His pride, in that direction, may be of service, if not to himself, to many others, for it must deter him from such foul misconduct as I have suffered by.
vi: In this way, his pride will be beneficial if not to him then to others, as it will prevent him from committing the vile acts that caused me so much misery.
tr: His pride can be beneficial in that respect, if not to himself, then to many others; thus preventing the wrongs done to me from being inflicted on others.
es: With that system, his pride can be useful, if not to him; to many others, for it will keep him away from the bad behavior of which I was a victim.

en: I only fear that the sort of cautiousness to which you, I imagine, have been alluding, is merely adopted on his visits to his aunt, of whose good opinion and judgment he stands much in awe.
vi: I only fear that he adopts a cautious attitude, which I guess you have observed, only when he visits his aunt, whose opinions and judgments he greatly respects.
tr: My only fear is that the prudence you mentioned only manifests during his visits to his aunt; he cares greatly about how she perceives him.
es: But I very much fear that the kind of prudence to which you seem to allude is employed only during his visits to his aunt, as it does not suit him to misbehave in her presence.

en: His fear of her has always operated, I know, when they were together; and a good deal is to be imputed to his wish of forwarding the match with Miss de Bourgh, which I am certain he has very much at heart.”
vi: I know he is always afraid of her when they are together, largely because of his intention to marry Miss De Bourgh, whom I am sure he is very fond of.
tr: I know that he is always afraid of her when they are together; and considerable weight should also be given to his desire to expedite his marriage to Miss de Bourgh, which I am sure is always on his mind."
es: I know very well that he has always cared about appearances in front of her with the desire to bring to fruition his marriage with Miss de Bourgh, in which he puts all his effort.

en: Elizabeth could not repress a smile at this, but she answered only by a slight inclination of the head.
vi: Elizabeth couldn't suppress a smile when she heard this, but she only responded with a slight nod.
tr: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile when she heard these words, but she only responded with a slight nod of her head.
es: Elizabeth couldn't suppress a smile upon hearing this; but she only responded with a slight nod of her head.

en: She saw that he wanted to engage her on the old subject of his grievances, and she was in no humour to indulge him.
vi: She sensed that he wanted to bring her back to the old topic of his complaints, but she no longer had the inclination to follow his lead.
tr: She realized that Wickham wanted to draw her back to the old topic, to his sufferings, but she was not in a state to comply now.
es: She noticed that Wickham was about to return to the old topic of his misfortunes, and she was not in the mood to allow it.

en: The rest of the evening passed with the appearance, on his side, of usual cheerfulness, but with no further attempt to distinguish Elizabeth; and they parted at last with mutual civility, and possibly a mutual desire of never meeting again.
vi: Throughout the rest of the evening, outwardly he tried to maintain his usual cheerful demeanor, but he no longer wanted to pay attention to her amidst the crowd. Finally, the two politely parted ways, perhaps both wishing never to see each other again.
tr: The rest of the evening passed with Wickham's usual appearance of cheerfulness; he made no further attempt towards Elizabeth; eventually, they parted with mutual politeness and possibly a desire never to meet again.
es: For the rest of the evening, Wickham pretended his usual cheerfulness, but he no longer attempted to court Elizabeth. In the end, they parted with mutual courtesy and also probably with the mutual desire never to see each other again.

en: When the party broke up, Lydia returned with ms Forster to Meryton, from whence they were to set out early the next morning.
vi: When everyone had left, Lydia went with Mrs. Forster to Meryton, from where they would set off the next morning.
tr: As the meeting dispersed, Lydia went to Meryton with Mrs. Forster; they would set off from there early the next morning.
es: When the gathering ended, Lydia went to Meryton with Mrs. Forster, from where they were to depart early the next morning.

en: The separation between her and her family was rather noisy than pathetic.
vi: The farewell between her and the family was more noisy than touching.
tr: Her farewell with the family was not sorrowful but noisy.
es: Her farewell to the family was more noisy than pathetic.

en: Kitty was the only one who shed tears; but she did weep from vexation and envy.
vi: Only Kitty shed tears, but it was out of displeasure and jealousy.
tr: Only Kitty shed tears; the reason for her crying was boredom and jealousy.
es: Catherine was the only one who cried, although out of humiliation and envy.

en: ms Bennet was diffuse in her good wishes for the felicity of her daughter, and impressive in her injunctions that she would not miss the opportunity of enjoying herself as much as possible,—advice which there was every reason to believe would be attended to; and, in the clamorous happiness of Lydia herself in bidding farewell, the more gentle adieus of her sisters were uttered without being heard.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was lengthy in her blessings for her fortunate daughter, impressing upon her through her instructions that she should not miss any opportunity to enjoy herself as much as possible. In the noisy delight, Lydia bid farewell, unable to hear the gentle goodbyes of her sisters.
tr: Mrs. Bennet wished her daughter plenty of happiness and sternly advised her not to miss any opportunity to have fun; it was evident that this advice would be followed; amidst Lydia's boisterous happiness while bidding farewell, the more polite farewell words of her sisters went unheard.
es: Mrs. Bennet wished her daughter to have as much fun as possible, advice that the girl was willing to follow to the letter. And her clamor upon leaving was so loud that she didn't even hear the gentle goodbyes from her sisters.

en: CHAPTER XLII.
vi: Chapter 42
tr: Chapter XIX
es: CHAPTER XLII

en: HAD Elizabeth’s opinion been all drawn from her own family, she could not have formed a very pleasing picture of conjugal felicity or domestic comfort.
vi: If Elizabeth's thoughts were all derived from her family, she could not have formed a very favorable impression of married life or a harmonious family.
tr: If Elizabeth's views had come from her family, she might not have been able to paint a very pleasant picture of a happy marriage or a comfortable home life.
es: If Elizabeth's opinion were derived from what she saw in her own family, she could not have formed a very pleasant idea of marital happiness and domestic well-being.

en: Her father, captivated by youth and beauty, and that appearance of good-humour which youth and beauty generally give, had married a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in their marriage put an end to all real affection for her.
vi: Her father, attracted by youth, beauty, and the outward cheerfulness that youth and beauty bring, had married a woman of weak understanding and narrow mind, and from the very beginning of the marriage, he had lost all real affection for her.
tr: Her father, captivated by youth and beauty, and the cheerful appearance that youth and beauty generally bring, had married a woman who was lacking in both sense and manners, and had lost all real affection for her soon after their marriage began.
es: Her father, captivated by youth and beauty, and the apparent illusion and joy that both entail, had married a woman whose weak understanding and petty spirit had put an end to all affection at the very beginning of their marriage.

en: Respect, esteem, and confidence had vanished for ever; and all his views of domestic happiness were overthrown.
vi: Respect, esteem, and confidence had vanished forever; all his views of domestic happiness were overthrown.
tr: Respect, reverence, and trust had vanished forever; all hopes for family happiness were shattered.
es: Respect, esteem, and trust had vanished forever; and all of Mr. Bennet's prospects of happiness within the home had collapsed.

en: But mr Bennet was not of a disposition to seek comfort for the disappointment which his own imprudence had brought on in any of those pleasures which too often console the unfortunate for their folly or their vice.
vi: But Mr. Bennet was not of a disposition to seek comfort for his disappointment in his own imprudence, so he did not resort to those pleasures which might have soothed the unfortunate who had acted foolishly or wickedly.
tr: But Mr. Bennet was not the kind of man to seek solace in the pleasures that other unfortunate people, who had acted foolishly or wickedly, might resort to in their disappointment caused by their own imprudence.
es: But he was not one of those men who seek comfort for the effects of their own imprudence in the pleasures that often console those who have become unhappy through their follies and vices.

en: He was fond of the country and of books; and from these tastes had arisen his principal enjoyments.
vi: He loved the countryside and books, and found enjoyment in them.
tr: He was fond of the countryside and books; his main enjoyment came from these pleasures.
es: He loved the countryside and books, and they constituted the source of his main joys.

en: To his wife he was very little otherwise indebted than as her ignorance and folly had contributed to his amusement.
vi: As for his wife, he owed her little gratitude except for the amusement her folly and nonsense provided him.
tr: He owed very little to his wife, except for the amusement her ignorance and foolishness provided him.
es: From his wife, he owed nothing more than the laughter that her ignorance and folly provided him from time to time.

en: This is not the sort of happiness which a man would in general wish to owe to his wife; but where other powers of entertainment are wanting, the true philosopher will derive benefit from such as are given.
vi: This was not the sort of happiness that makes a man grateful to his wife, but when he had no ability to indulge in other diversions, the true philosopher must derive benefit from whatever is available.
tr: This is not usually the kind of happiness a man wishes to owe to his wife; but when there are no other means of distraction, a true philosopher makes do with what he has.
es: That is not the kind of happiness a man would wish to owe to his wife; but in the absence of... The good philosopher only takes benefit from where it exists.

en: Elizabeth, however, had never been blind to the impropriety of her father’s behaviour as a husband.
vi: However, Elizabeth had never ignored his improper behaviors as a husband.
tr: However, Elizabeth had never been blind to her father's inappropriate behavior as a husband.
es: Elizabeth, nevertheless, had never ceased to recognize the impropriety of her father's conduct as a husband.

en: She had always seen it with pain; but respecting his abilities, and grateful for his affectionate treatment of herself, she endeavoured to forget what she could not overlook, and to banish from her thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation and decorum which, in exposing his wife to the contempt of her own children, was so highly reprehensible.
vi: She was always distressed to see him like that, but out of respect for his abilities and happiness at being cherished by him, she tried to forget what she could not overlook and pushed out of her mind the sad actions when he showed irresponsibility or lacked the spirit of marital decorum by exposing his wife to the contempt of their children.
tr: She had always watched these with pain; but because she respected her father's abilities and was grateful for the love he showed her, she tried not to think about the extremely unpleasant act of constantly violating the duties and decorum of marriage, such as belittling his wife at every opportunity in front of their children.
es: She had always observed it with sorrow, but she respected his talent and was grateful for his affection, so she tried to forget what she could not ignore and to put out of her mind his continuous breach of marital duties and the decorum that, by exposing his wife to the contempt of her own daughters, was so exceedingly reprehensible.

en: But she had never felt so strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend the children of so unsuitable a marriage, nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising from so ill-judged a direction of talents—talents which, rightly used, might at least have preserved the respectability of his daughters, even if incapable of enlarging the mind of his wife.
vi: But she had never deeply felt the disadvantages for the daughters in such a discordant marriage, nor had she ever recognized the harms of misusing talents – talents that, if properly harnessed, could at least earn the daughters respect from others, if not broaden the mind of their mother.
tr: But never had she felt so strongly the troubles that children of such an incompatible marriage had to endure; never had she understood so well the harm caused by talents directed at the wrong targets – talents that, if used correctly, could at least have preserved her daughters' dignity, even if they failed to improve her wife's mind.
es: But she had never felt as she did then the harm that a discordant marriage can cause to the children, nor had she ever so clearly realized the dangers inherent in the misdirection of talent, talent that, if well employed, although it might not have been enough to enhance his wife's intelligence, could at least have preserved the respectability of the daughters.

en: When Elizabeth had rejoiced over Wickham’s departure, she found little other cause for satisfaction in the loss of the regiment.
vi: While Elizabeth was glad that Wickham would be leaving, she saw no other reason to be satisfied with the loss of the militia regiment.
tr: While Elizabeth Wickham was happy to be gone, she couldn't find any other consoling aspect in losing the regiment.
es: While it is true that Elizabeth was glad of Wickham's absence, it cannot be said that she rejoiced at the regiment's departure.

en: Their parties abroad were less varied than before; and at home she had a mother and sister, whose constant repinings at the dulness of everything around them threw a real gloom over their domestic circle; and, though Kitty might in time regain her natural degree of sense, since the disturbers of her brain were removed, her other sister, from whose disposition greater evil might be apprehended, was likely to be hardened in all her folly and assurance, by a situation of such double danger as a watering-place and a camp.
vi: Social gatherings at other people's houses became more monotonous than before; and at home, she had a mother and a sister who were always irritable because everything around them had become boring, creating a gloomy atmosphere in the family. Although Kitty gradually regained her natural sense because those who disturbed her mind were absent, the other sister, whom everyone feared would encounter worse, might plunge deeper into her foolish self-confidence.
tr: The parties outside were duller than before; at home, her mother and sister, who constantly complained about the monotony of everything around them, cast a gloom over their family life; with the things that troubled her mind now distant, Kitty might eventually regain her former common sense, but her other sister, from whom greater mischief could be expected, seemed likely to harden all her foolishness and stubbornness in a situation that involved the double danger of the seaside and the military camp.
es: Her outings were less frequent than before, and the constant complaints of her mother and sister about the boredom they had fallen into saddened the house. And although Catherine might have regained the common sense lost with the departure of those who caused her disturbance, her other sister, from whose behavior all calamities could be expected, was in danger of affirming her madness and brazenness, for being near a beach and a camp, her situation was doubly threatening.

en: Upon the whole, therefore, she found, what has been sometimes found before, that an event to which she had looked forward with impatient desire, did not, in taking place, bring all the satisfaction she had promised herself.
vi: Thus, as before, she thought that an event she eagerly awaited, when it happened, did not satisfy her as she had hoped.
tr: In the end, as she had seen a few times before, she realized that an event she had been waiting for with impatient anticipation did not bring the joy Elizabeth had promised her when it finally happened.
es: In short, she now saw what she had already realized at other times, that an eagerly awaited event could not, upon happening, bring her all the satisfaction that was to be expected.

en: It was consequently necessary to name some other period for the commencement of actual felicity; to have some other point on which her wishes and hopes might be fixed, and by again enjoying the pleasure of anticipation, console herself for the present, and prepare for another disappointment.
vi: As a result, it was necessary to identify another time period to truly begin to be happy. There needed to be a milestone to which all wishes and hopes could be connected. Through this, feeling pleasure in anticipation, comforting her for the present, and preparing for another disappointment.
tr: Another date would have to be set for true happiness to begin, another turning point where her wishes and hopes could be realized; and once again, she would console herself for the time being with the pleasure of anticipation, and prepare for another disappointment.
es: It was necessary, therefore, to open another period for the beginning of her happiness, to set another goal for the achievement of her desires and hopes, which by cheering her with another anticipated pleasure, would console her for the present and prepare her for another disappointment.

en: Her tour to the Lakes was now the object of her happiest thoughts: it was her best consolation for all the uncomfortable hours which the discontentedness of her mother and Kitty made inevitable; and could she have included Jane in the scheme, every part of it would have been perfect.
vi: Her trip to the Lake District had now become a happy thought. This was the best consolation for the frustrating moments caused by her mother and Kitty. If Jane could join in this plan, everything would become wonderful.
tr: The trip to the Lake District now formed her happiest thoughts; it was her strongest consolation against all those distressing hours made inevitable by her mother and Kitty; if she could include Jane in the plan, everything would be perfect.
es: Her trip to the Lakes became the object of her happiest thoughts and constituted her best refuge in the unpleasant hours that her mother's and Catherine's discontent made inevitable. And if she could have included Jane in the plan, everything would have been perfect.

en: “But it is fortunate,” thought she, “that I have something to wish for.
vi: She thought: "It's fortunate that I still have something to wish for.
tr: "But luckily," she thought, "I have something to wish for.
es: ––"It's a stroke of luck," he thought, "to have something to desire.

en: Were the whole arrangement complete, my disappointment would be certain.
vi: If everything had been arranged perfectly, I would surely be disappointed.
tr: If all the arrangements had been made, I would certainly be disappointed.
es: If everything were complete, there would undoubtedly be something that would disappoint me.

en: But here, by carrying with me one ceaseless source of regret in my sister’s absence, I may reasonably hope to have all my expectations of pleasure realized.
vi: But here, by harboring an endless source of regret while my sister is absent, I can hope that all my wishes will come true.
tr: But here, while my sister is not around, I can carry a continuous source of sorrow with me and hope for all my joy expectations to come true.
es: But now, carrying with me that source of longing which will be Jane's absence, I can reasonably think that all my expectations of pleasure will be fulfilled.

en: A scheme of which every part promises delight can never be successful; and general disappointment is only warded off by the defence of some little peculiar vexation.”
vi: A plan in which everything promises to bring joy never succeeds; one can only avoid disappointment by making excuses for a few peculiar inconveniences."
tr: A plan that promises pleasure in every part can never succeed; the only way to prevent a great disappointment is to defend a small inconvenience."
es: A plan that in all its parts promises happiness never turns out well; and you can't avoid some mishap if you don't have a small setback."

en: When Lydia went away she promised to write very often and very minutely to her mother and Kitty; but her letters were always long expected, and always very short.
vi: When Lydia left, she promised to write letters regularly and in great detail to her mother and Kitty; but her letters were always delayed and always very short.
tr: Lydia had promised her mother and Kitty that she would write to them often and at length; but her letters always arrived very late and were always very short.
es: Lydia, upon leaving, promised to write very often and in great detail to her mother and Catherine, but her letters were always long overdue and all were brief.

en: Those to her mother contained little else than that they were just returned from the library, where such and such officers had attended them, and where she had seen such beautiful ornaments as made her quite wild; that she had a new gown, or a new parasol, which she would have described more fully, but was obliged to leave off in a violent hurry, as ms Forster called her, and they were going to the camp; and from her correspondence with her sister there was still less to be learnt, for her letters to Kitty, though rather longer, were much too full of lines under the words to be made public.
vi: The letters to her mother said little more than that they had just returned from the library with some officers who were doting on them, about the shops where they saw jewelry that captivated them; that she had just bought a new maxi dress, or a new umbrella that she should have described in detail, but had to hastily end because Mrs. Forster was calling, and they were preparing to go to the barracks. Communication with her sister provided even less news, the letters to Kitty, though longer, contained too many things that could not be shared with others.
tr: The letters she wrote to her mother contained little more than the fact that they had just returned from the bookstore, that such and such officers had accompanied them there, that she had seen some trinkets that had taken her breath away, or that she had bought a new dress or a new umbrella that she would describe in detail but couldn't because Mrs. Forster had called and they were about to go to the camp; –even less could be learned from the letters she wrote to her sister –because although the letters to Kitty were somewhat longer, they were filled with underlined sentences not to be told to anyone else.
es: The ones addressed to her mother said little more than that they had just returned from the reading room where they had been greeted by such and such officers, that the decoration of the room was so beautiful that it had taken her breath away, that she had a new dress or a new parasol that she would describe more extensively, but that she couldn't because Mrs. Forster was waiting for her to go to the camp together... From the correspondence addressed to her sister, even less could be known, for her letters to Catherine, although long, had many underlined lines that could not be made public.

en: After the first fortnight or three weeks of her absence, health, good-humour, and cheerfulness began to reappear at Longbourn.
vi: After Lydia had been gone for two or three weeks, a cheerful atmosphere returned to Longbourn.
tr: After the first two or three weeks of his absence, health, cheerfulness, and liveliness returned to Longbourn.
es: After the two or three weeks of Lydia's absence, health and good humor began to reign in Longbourn.

en: Everything wore a happier aspect.
vi: Everything brought a more uplifting spirit.
tr: Everything took on a happier appearance.
es: Everything looked better.

en: The families who had been in town for the winter came back again, and summer finery and summer engagements arose.
vi: Families who had gone to the city during the winter returned, and springtime interactions began again.
tr: Families who had gone to the city for the winter returned, and summer clothes and summer invitations emerged.
es: Families who had spent the winter in the capital were returning, and the summer festivities and invitations were reemerging.

en: ms Bennet was restored to her usual querulous serenity; and by the middle of June Kitty was so much recovered as to be able to enter Meryton without tears,—an event of such happy promise as to make Elizabeth hope, that by the following Christmas she might be so tolerably reasonable as not to mention an officer above once a day, unless, by some cruel and malicious arrangement at the War Office, another regiment should be quartered in Meryton.
vi: Mrs. Bennet reverted to her usual quiet grumbling. By mid-June, Kitty had calmed down enough to go to Meryton without shedding tears; an event promising much good, leading Elizabeth to hope that by the next Christmas season, her younger sister might become sensible enough not to mention an officer more than once a day, unless, through the malicious arrangements of the defense department, another regiment was stationed in Meryton.
tr: Mrs. Bennet resumed her usual fretful solemnity; by mid-June, Kitty had recovered enough to go to Meryton without shedding tears – which was such a happy event in Elizabeth's eyes that she hoped Kitty might normalize to the point of not mentioning an officer's name more than once a day until the next Christmas, provided, of course, that the war office did not cruelly and ominously decide to station a new regiment in Meryton.
es: Mrs. Bennet recovered from her complaining state, and by mid-June, Catherine was already consoled enough to enter Meryton without tears. This fact was so promising that Elizabeth believed that by the next Christmas, Catherine would be so reasonable that she wouldn't mention an officer even once a day, unless by some cruel and malicious order of the War Office, a new regiment was quartered in Meryton.

en: The time fixed for the beginning of their northern tour was now fast approaching; and a fortnight only was wanting of it, when a letter arrived from ms Gardiner, which at once delayed its commencement and curtailed its extent.
vi: The time to start the Northern excursion is approaching quickly. With only two weeks left, a letter from Mrs. Gardiner arrives, causing the trip to be postponed and the journey to be shortened.
tr: The start date of the northern travels was rapidly approaching; only fifteen days were left when a letter from Mrs. Gardiner both postponed the start date of the trip and narrowed its scope.
es: The appointed time for the excursion to the North was already approaching; only two weeks were left, when a letter was received from Mrs. Gardiner postponing the date of the trip and, at the same time, shortening its duration.

en: mr Gardiner would be prevented by business from setting out till a fortnight later in July, and must be in London again within a month; and as that left too short a period for them to go so far, and see so much as they had proposed, or at least to see it with the leisure and comfort they had built on, they were obliged to give up the Lakes, and substitute a more contracted tour; and, according to the present plan, were to go no farther northward than Derbyshire.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner is busy with work until July and has to go to London for a month. The time is not sufficient for them to travel far to see much, or at least to see leisurely and comfortably as planned. They are forced to cancel the trip to the Lake District, replacing it with a closer itinerary. According to the new plan, they will only go as far as Derbyshire.
tr: Mr. Gardiner's work would not allow him to leave until mid-July, and he had to be back in London within a month; this left them so little time that they would not be able to go as far as they wanted or visit every place they wished, or at least not comfortably; therefore, they had to give up the Lake District and settle for a more limited tour; according to the current plan, they would not go further north than Derbyshire.
es: Mr. Gardiner's business prevented him from leaving until two weeks after the beginning of July, and he had to be back in London within a month; and since this reduced the time too much to go so far and see all the things they had planned, or to see them with enough rest and comfort, there was no choice but to give up the Lakes and think of a more limited excursion, in view of which they would not go beyond Derbyshire.

en: In that county there was enough to be seen to occupy the chief of their three weeks; and to ms Gardiner it had a peculiarly strong attraction.
vi: This region has enough variety for them to explore over three weeks and is particularly appealing to Mrs. Gardiner.
tr: There were enough places to visit and see in that county to keep them occupied for three weeks; it was particularly appealing to Mrs. Gardiner.
es: In that region, there were enough things worth seeing to fill most of the time they had available, and, moreover, Mrs. Gardiner felt a very special attraction for Derbyshire.

en: The town where she had formerly passed some years of her life, and where they were now to spend a few days, was probably as great an object of her curiosity as all the celebrated beauties of Matlock, Chatsworth, Dovedale, or the Peak.
vi: The town where she lived for a few years before, and where they plan to stay for a few days, is of special interest to her.
tr: The city where she had spent a few years of her life in the past and where she would now stay for a few days was probably as much of a curiosity for her as famous places like Matlock, Chatsworth, Dovedale, or the Peak.
es: The town where she had spent several years of her life might be as interesting to her as all the famous beauties of Matlock, Chatsworth, Dovedale, or the Peak.

en: Elizabeth was excessively disappointed: she had set her heart on seeing the Lakes; and still thought there might have been time enough.
vi: Elizabeth was very disappointed; she had hoped to visit the Lake District and thought there might still be enough time.
tr: Elizabeth was greatly disappointed; she had very much wanted to see the Lake District; yet she thought there might still be time.
es: Elizabeth felt very disappointed; she was very excited about going to the Lakes, and she believed there would have been plenty of time for it.

en: But it was her business to be satisfied—and certainly her temper to be happy; and all was soon right again.
vi: But her nature was easily contented with what she had, so she was willing to accept the new circumstances.
tr: But her task was to be content – of course, her inclination was also to be happy; soon everything was fine.
es: But, in any case, she should be satisfied, they would surely have a good time, and it didn't take long for her to come to terms with it.

en: With the mention of Derbyshire, there were many ideas connected.
vi: Many thoughts are evoked by the name Derbyshire.
tr: The mention of Derbyshire brought many ideas to mind.
es: For Elizabeth, the name of Derbyshire was connected to many other things.

en: It was impossible for her to see the word without thinking of Pemberley and its owner.
vi: She could not visit the area without thinking of Pemberley estate and its owner.
tr: It was impossible to see that word without thinking of Pemberley and its owner.
es: It made her think of Pemberley and its owner.

en: “But surely,” said she, “I may enter his county with impunity, and rob it of a few petrified spars, without his perceiving me.”
vi: She told herself, "But surely I can enter the region where he resides with a peaceful mind and bring back some mineral crystals without his knowledge."
tr: "What if," she said, "I secretly enter his homeland and steal a few florid stones without being seen by him."
es: "But," she said to herself, "I can enter his county with impunity and steal a few stones without him noticing."

en: The period of expectation was now doubled.
vi: The waiting time has now doubled, four weeks before the uncle and aunt arrive.
tr: The waiting period had now doubled.
es: The wait then felt doubly long to her.

en: Four weeks were to pass away before her uncle and aunt’s arrival.
vi: The waiting time has now doubled, four weeks before the uncle and aunt arrive.
tr: Four more weeks would pass before her uncle and aunt arrived.
es: There were four weeks left until her uncles arrived.

en: But they did pass away, and mr and ms Gardiner, with their four children, did at length appear at Longbourn.
vi: The waiting time has now doubled, four weeks before the uncle and aunt arrive.
tr: But it passed; finally, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner appeared at Longbourn with their four children.
es: But, finally, the time passed and Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner arrived in Longbourn with their four children.

en: The children, two girls of six and eight years old, and two younger boys, were to be left under the particular care of their cousin Jane, who was the general favourite, and whose steady sense and sweetness of temper exactly adapted her for attending to them in every way—teaching them, playing with them, and loving them.
vi: The children, including two girls aged six and eight and two younger boys, were entrusted to Jane's care. The children adored Jane, and with her calm and sweet nature, she proved to be suitable for taking care of them, teaching them, playing with them, and loving them.
tr: The children, two girls aged six and eight and two younger boys, were to be entrusted specifically to their cousin Jane; Jane was their favorite cousin, and with her calm speech and affectionate behavior, she was able to look after them in every way – educating them, entertaining them, and loving them.
es: The children ––two little girls aged six and eight respectively, and two younger boys–– were to be under the special care of their cousin Jane, the favorite of all, whose sweet and calm temperament was ideal for teaching them, playing with them, and loving them.

en: The Gardiners stayed only one night at Longbourn, and set off the next morning with Elizabeth in pursuit of novelty and amusement.
vi: Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner stayed at Longbourn for only one night, then set off the next day with Elizabeth to seek new and delightful experiences.
tr: The Gardiners stayed at Longbourn for only one night and set out the next morning with Elizabeth in search of novelty and amusement.
es: The Gardiners slept at Longbourn that night and the next morning they set off with Elizabeth in search of news and amusement.

en: One enjoyment was certain—that of suitableness as companions; a suitableness which comprehended health and temper to bear inconveniences—cheerfulness to enhance every pleasure—and affection and intelligence, which might supply it among themselves if there were disappointments abroad.
vi: Surely the three of them would find much enjoyment, as they had suitable companions; the harmony in both body and mind to endure any inconveniences, the optimism to fully appreciate every pleasure, along with the love and intelligence to cope with any disappointments when away from home.
tr: There was a certain pleasure – they were well-suited as travel companions; both mentally and physically capable of enduring hardships – they had a cheerfulness that would enhance every happiness, and a love and intelligence that would compensate for any possible disappointments in their journey.
es: They had assured pleasure: the three of them were excellent travel companions, which meant they had the health and character to endure inconveniences, the cheerfulness to enhance all kinds of happiness, and the affection and intelligence to overcome any setbacks.

en: It is not the object of this work to give a description of Derbyshire, nor of any of the remarkable places through which their route thither lay—Oxford, Blenheim, Warwick, Kenilworth, Birmingham, etc., are sufficiently known.
vi: No need to describe Derbyshire or the famous places along the way in detail, just focus on a small region of Derbyshire.
tr: Describing Derbyshire or the notable places along the way is not the purpose of this book; Oxford, Blenheim, Warwick, Kenilworth, and Birmingham are well known enough.
es: We are not going to describe Derbyshire here, nor any of the notable places they passed through: Oxford, Blenheim, Warwick, Kenilworth, Birmingham, and all the others, are well known.

en: A small part of Derbyshire is all the present concern.
vi: No need to describe Derbyshire or the famous places along the way in detail, just focus on a small region of Derbyshire.
tr: Now, we are only concerned with a small part of Derbyshire.
es: We will only refer to a small part of Derbyshire.

en: To the little town of Lambton, the scene of ms Gardiner’s former residence, and where she had lately learned that some acquaintance still remained, they bent their steps, after having seen all the principal wonders of the country; and within five miles of Lambton, Elizabeth found, from her aunt, that Pemberley was situated.
vi: When they arrived at the small town of Lambton, where Mrs. Gardiner used to reside and where she recently learned that some acquaintances still remained, they turned onto another road, and after traveling five miles, Mrs. Gardiner informed Elizabeth that they had reached Pemberley.
tr: After seeing the main wonders of the countryside, they turned their steps towards the small town of Lambton, where Mrs. Gardiner used to live and recently learned that a few of her acquaintances still resided; Elizabeth learned from her aunt that Pemberley was located about five miles from Lambton.
es: Towards the small town of Lambton, the scene of Mrs. Gardiner's youth, where she had recently learned that some acquaintances still resided, the travelers directed their steps after having seen the main wonders of the region. Elizabeth learned from her aunt that Pemberley was about five miles from Lambton.

en: It was not in their direct road; nor more than a mile or two out of it.
vi: It was not directly on their route, but no more than one or two miles off the road.
tr: It was not directly on their way, but it was not more than a mile or two off the road either.
es: It was not on their way, but they only had to deviate one or two miles to visit it.

en: In talking over their route the evening before, ms Gardiner expressed an inclination to see the place again.
vi: On the previous evening, while discussing the next day's journey, Mrs. Gardiner had expressed a desire to visit this place again.
tr: While discussing their route the previous evening, Mrs. Gardiner mentioned that she wanted to see the place again.
es: While discussing their route the previous evening, Mrs. Gardiner expressed a desire to see Pemberley again.

en: mr Gardiner declared his willingness, and Elizabeth was applied to for her approbation.
vi: Mr. Gardiner agreed, and Elizabeth was consulted. Mrs. Gardiner said:
tr: Mr. Gardiner also expressed his desire, so they turned to Elizabeth for approval.
es: Mr. Gardiner did not object and sought Elizabeth's approval.

en: “My love, should not you like to see a place of which you have heard so much?” said her aunt.
vi: - Child, do you want to go see the place you've heard so much about?
tr: "Sweetie, wouldn't you like to see a place you've heard so much about?" said her aunt.
es: ––Dear ––her aunt said to her––, wouldn’t you like to see a place you’ve heard so much about and that is connected with so many of your acquaintances?

en: “A place, too, with which so many of your acquaintance are connected.
vi: The place where a few people you know are.
tr: "A place with connections to many of your friends, moreover.
es: ––Dear ––her aunt said to her––, wouldn’t you like to see a place you’ve heard so much about and that is connected with so many of your acquaintances?

en: Wickham passed all his youth there, you know.”
vi: Wickham lived here when he was a child, you know.
tr: Wickham spent all his youth there."
es: You know that Wickham spent all his youth there.

en: Elizabeth was distressed.
vi: Elizabeth felt sorrowful.
tr: Elizabeth was bored.
es: Elizabeth was distressed.

en: She felt that she had no business at Pemberley, and was obliged to assume a disinclination for seeing it.
vi: She thought she had nothing to do with Pemberley, wanting to appear uninterested in going there.
tr: She felt that she had no business at Pemberley; she was inwardly inclined to object to seeing the place.
es: She felt that she had nothing to do at Pemberley and was forced to say that she was not interested.

en: She must own that she was tired of great houses: after going over so many, she really had no pleasure in fine carpets or satin curtains.
vi: She stated that she was too tired of looking at large houses; after having seen so many of them, she no longer found any pleasure in seeing beautiful carpets or satin curtains.
tr: She had to admit that she was tired of large houses; she had seen so many that she no longer truly enjoyed silk carpets or satin curtains.
es: She had to confess that she was tired of large houses, after having seen so many; and that she found no pleasure in seeing exquisite carpets and satin curtains.

en: ms Gardiner abused her stupidity.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner criticized her ignorance:
tr: Mrs. Gardiner was annoyed by the indifference.
es: Mrs. Gardiner censured her foolishness.

en: “If it were merely a fine house richly furnished,” said she, “I should not care about it myself; but the grounds are delightful.
vi: - If there were only elaborately decorated houses, I wouldn't bother going there; but this land is truly wonderful.
tr: "If it were just a beautifully furnished house," she said, "I wouldn't care; but the land is magnificent.
es: ––If it were just a richly furnished house ––he said–– I wouldn't be interested either; but the estate is a marvel.

en: They have some of the finest woods in the country.”
vi: It has the most beautiful forests in the country.
tr: Some of the finest woods in the area are there."
es: It contains one of the most beautiful forests in the country.

en: Elizabeth said no more; but her mind could not acquiesce.
vi: Elizabeth said nothing more, but inwardly she did not agree.
tr: Elizabeth did not object any further – but it wasn't coming from her heart.
es: Elizabeth did not speak any more, but she no longer had any peace of mind.

en: The possibility of meeting mr Darcy, while viewing the place, instantly occurred.
vi: The possibility of meeting Mr. Darcy again upon going there immediately came to her mind.
tr: As she was walking around, the possibility of encountering Mr. Darcy suddenly crossed her mind.
es: The possibility of encountering Darcy while visiting Pemberley instantly crossed her mind.

en: It would be dreadful!
vi: How dreadful!
tr: It would be dreadful!
es: It would be horrible!

en: She blushed at the very idea; and thought it would be better to speak openly to her aunt, than to run such a risk.
vi: She blushed at the thought, considering that she should speak frankly to her aunt rather than take the risk. But her aunt objected.
tr: The mere thought of it was enough to make her blush; she thought it would be better to speak openly with her aunt rather than face such a danger.
es: Just thinking about it made her blush, and she thought it would be better to speak clearly to her aunt than to expose herself to such a risk.

en: But against this there were objections; and she finally resolved that it could be the last resource, if her private inquiries as to the absence of the family were unfavourably answered.
vi: In the end, she would decide after discreetly inquiring about the family's absence.
tr: But there were obstacles to this as well; finally, she decided that this would be the last resort, in case a secret investigation about whether the family was there or not yielded an unpleasant result.
es: But this decision had its drawbacks, and she resolved that she would only adopt it if her inquiries about the absence of the property owner's family were negative.

en: Accordingly, when she retired at night, she asked the chambermaid whether Pemberley were not a very fine place, what was the name of its proprietor, and, with no little alarm, whether the family were down for the summer?
vi: In that manner, in the evening, she asked the chambermaid whether the Pemberley estate was worth visiting, who the owner was, and she calmly inquired whether the owner had arrived to enjoy the summer yet. The chambermaid replied that he had not.
tr: Accordingly, when she retired to her room at night, she asked the servant whether Pemberley was a beautiful place, who its owner was, and, quite anxiously, whether the family was at the summer house.
es: Consequently, upon retiring that night, she asked the maid if Pemberley was a very beautiful place, what the name of its owner was, and finally, with no small amount of concern, if the family was spending the summer there.

en: A most welcome negative followed the last question; and her alarms being now removed, she was at leisure to feel a great deal of curiosity to see the house herself; and when the subject was revived the next morning, and she was again applied to, could readily answer, and with a proper air of indifference, that she had not really any dislike to the scheme.
vi: Now with nothing to worry about, she was curious to see the house. When asked for her opinion again the next morning, she calmly replied that she actually had no objections to the couple's plan.
tr: The answer to the last question was a very reassuring no – with her anxiety thus relieved, she had the opportunity to feel a great curiosity to see the house; when the subject was brought up again the next morning and she was asked, her answer was ready; she said, with a very indifferent air, that she had no objection to the plan.
es: The negative response to this last question was the most welcome in the world. With her anxiety now gone, she felt great curiosity even about the house itself, and when the plan was proposed again the next morning and she was consulted, she instantly replied, with an evident air of indifference, that she did not dislike the idea.

en: To Pemberley, therefore, they were to go.
vi: Therefore, the three people set off for Pemberley.
tr: So, they were going to Pemberley. Third Book
es: Therefore, they set out for Pemberley.

en: CHAPTER XLIII.
vi: End of episode 2 Chapter 43
tr: Chapter I
es: CHAPTER XLIII

en: ELIZABETH, as they drove along, watched for the first appearance of Pemberley Woods with some perturbation; and when at length they turned in at the lodge, her spirits were in a high flutter.
vi: On the way, Elizabeth anxiously watched the Pemberley garden come into view, but as they entered the estate, her spirits lifted again.
tr: Elizabeth watched the first glimpses of Pemberley Woods from the carriage with some unease; by the time they entered through the lodge, she was quite discomposed.
es: Elizabeth glimpsed the woods of Pemberley with some unease, and when they finally arrived at the gate, her heart was beating strongly.

en: The park was very large, and contained great variety of ground.
vi: The garden was really spacious and varied.
tr: The grove was very large; the terrain was filled with various elevations.
es: The estate was enormous and comprised a great variety of lands.

en: They entered it in one of its lowest points, and drove for some time through a beautiful wood stretching over a wide extent.
vi: They entered through one of the low areas, then drove a long way along a lush forest.
tr: They entered the grove from one of its lowest points and proceeded for a while through a beautiful forest that stretched far to both sides.
es: They entered through one of the lowest points and strolled for a long time through a beautiful forest that extended over its wide surface.

en: Elizabeth’s mind was too full for conversation, but she saw and admired every remarkable spot and point of view.
vi: Elizabeth's mind was too busy for conversation, but she observed every scene and angle.
tr: Elizabeth's mind was too full to speak, but she saw and admired every remarkable detail and view.
es: Elizabeth's mind was too busy to converse; but she observed and admired all the notable spots and all the views.

en: They gradually ascended for half a mile, and then found themselves at the top of a considerable eminence, where the wood ceased, and the eye was instantly caught by Pemberley House, situated on the opposite side of the valley, into which the road with some abruptness wound.
vi: They walked half a mile up a gentle slope, then reached a high ground where the woodland ended, and they immediately saw Pemberley House, situated on the opposite side of the valley, with the road suddenly turning into it.
tr: They climbed about half a mile up the slope, then found themselves on a rather high hill; the forest had ended, and in an instant, her eyes were caught by Pemberley Manor; the Manor rose on the opposite side of a valley into which the road suddenly wound down.
es: For half a mile, they climbed a slope that led them to a considerable hill where the forest broke off and from where they immediately saw Pemberley House, situated on the other side of the valley through which a somewhat steep path wound.

en: It was a large, handsome stone building, standing well on rising ground, and backed by a ridge of high woody hills; and in front a stream of some natural importance was swelled into greater, but without any artificial appearance.
vi: It was a large, grand building, built of stone, standing prominently on high ground, backed by a range of hills covered with woods.
tr: It was a large, beautiful stone building; set on the slope, backed by the ridges of high wooded hills; –in front, a river of natural significance swelled, but without creating an artificial appearance, it joined a larger river.
es: It was a stone building, spacious and beautiful, well situated on a knoll that stood out in front of a chain of high, forest-covered hills, and it had in front a rather copious stream that ran increasingly powerful, completely natural and wild.

en: Its banks were neither formal nor falsely adorned.
vi: In front was a stream that widened out but did not appear artificial; the banks were not in straight lines but did not seem overly embellished.
tr: The banks of the river were neither formal nor artificially adorned.
es: Its banks were neither regular nor falsely adorned with gardening works.

en: Elizabeth was delighted.
vi: Elizabeth enjoyed the view.
tr: Elizabeth was delighted.
es: Elizabeth was amazed.

en: She had never seen a place for which nature had done more, or where natural beauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste.
vi: She had never seen a place so favored by nature, or one where natural beauty was so little marred by coarse taste.
tr: She had never seen a place where nature had been more generous or where natural beauty had been less marred by tastelessness in her life.
es: She had never seen a place more favored by nature or where natural beauty was less marred by poor taste.

en: They were all of them warm in their admiration; and at that moment she felt that to be mistress of Pemberley might be something!
vi: All three felt a warmth in their hearts as they admired it, and at that moment she thought that being the mistress of this estate must be something indeed!
tr: They all stood in awe; and at that moment, Elizabeth felt that being the mistress of Pemberley might mean something!
es: Everyone was full of admiration, and Elizabeth then understood what it might mean to be the mistress of Pemberley.

en: They descended the hill, crossed the bridge, and drove to the door; and, while examining the nearer aspect of the house, all her apprehension of meeting its owner returned.
vi: They went down the hillside, crossed a bridge, and drove the carriage through the gate. While observing the mansion up close, all her worries about meeting the owner returned to her mind.
tr: They went down the slope, crossed the bridge, and arrived at the door; while Elizabeth was examining the house more closely, the possibility of encountering its owner again crossed her mind.
es: They went down the hill, crossed a bridge, and continued to the door. While they examined the appearance of the house up close, Elizabeth again feared encountering the owner.

en: She dreaded lest the chambermaid had been mistaken.
vi: She feared that the butler might be mistaken.
tr: She was seized by the fear that the servant might have been mistaken.
es: What if the maid had been mistaken?

en: On applying to see the place, they were admitted into the hall; and Elizabeth, as they waited for the housekeeper, had leisure to wonder at her being where she was.
vi: They asked for permission and were invited into the hall. While waiting for the steward, Elizabeth idly thought about her presence there.
tr: When they knocked on the door to see the house, they were taken into the hall; while waiting for the steward to come, Elizabeth was surprised to find herself there.
es: After asking for permission to see the mansion, they were led into the vestibule. While they waited for the housekeeper, Elizabeth had time to marvel at finding herself in such a place.

en: The housekeeper came; a respectable looking elderly woman, much less fine, and more civil, than she had any notion of finding her.
vi: The housekeeper came, a respectable-looking, elderly woman, somewhat coarse but more polite than she had thought.
tr: The housekeeper arrived; she was an elderly woman with a dignified appearance, less ornate but more elegant than Elizabeth had imagined.
es: The housekeeper was an elderly woman, of respectable appearance, much less stiff and much more courteous than Elizabeth had imagined.

en: They followed her into the dining-parlour.
vi: They followed her into the dining room.
tr: Following her, they entered the dining room.
es: She led them to the dining room.

en: It was a large, well-proportioned room, handsomely fitted up.
vi: It was a spacious, well-proportioned room, decorated with elegance.
tr: It was a large, well-proportioned, beautifully furnished room.
es: It was a well-proportioned and elegantly furnished room.

en: Elizabeth, after slightly surveying it, went to a window to enjoy its prospect.
vi: After a brief glance around, Elizabeth walked to a window to admire the view outside.
tr: After briefly examining the room, Elizabeth went to the window to see the view.
es: Elizabeth glanced at it briefly and went to one of the windows to take in the view.

en: The hill, crowned with wood, from which they had descended, receiving increased abruptness from the distance, was a beautiful object.
vi: The hill covered by the canopy of trees where they had descended was suddenly interrupted by a steep slope, creating a magnificent landscape.
tr: The hill they had descended was crowned with forest, appearing even more steep and magnificent from a distance.
es: The hill crowned with forest they had descended, from a distance, appeared more abrupt and more beautiful.

en: Every disposition of the ground was good; and she looked on the whole scene, the river, the trees scattered on its banks, and the winding of the valley, as far as she could trace it, with delight.
vi: Everything on the ground was harmoniously arranged; and she delighted in the panoramic view, the river, the scattered trees along its banks, and the winding valley stretching as far as the eye could see.
tr: The garden was well-kept; Elizabeth looked with pleasure at the entire view, the river, the scattered trees along its banks, and the valley rising in winding curves.
es: The entire layout of the land was good; she looked at the landscape with delight: the stream, the trees along the banks, and the curve of the valley as far as the eye could see.

en: As they passed into other rooms, these objects were taking different positions; but from every window there were beauties to be seen.
vi: As they passed through other rooms, these scenes shifted position, but each window revealed its own unique beauty.
tr: As they moved to the other rooms, these views took on different perspectives; but there was beauty to be seen from every window.
es: As they moved to other rooms, the landscape appeared from different angles, but magnificent views could be seen from all the windows.

en: The rooms were lofty and handsome, and their furniture suitable to the fortune of their proprietor; but Elizabeth saw, with admiration of his taste, that it was neither gaudy nor uselessly fine,—with less of splendour, and more real elegance, than the furniture of Rosings.
vi: The rooms were all high and spacious, with elegant furnishings befitting the wealth of the owner; but Elizabeth admired his taste, as there was nothing gaudy or excessively meticulous; less opulent yet more refined than the furnishings in the Rosings estate.
tr: The rooms were grand and beautiful; the furniture was fitting for the owner's wealth; but Elizabeth, admiring the owner's taste, saw that they were neither gaudy nor unnecessarily simple; they had a more genuine elegance than the furniture at Rosings.
es: The rooms were tall and beautiful, and their furnishings were in harmony with the fortune of their owner. Elizabeth noted, admiring his taste, that there was nothing flashy or tacky and that there was less pomp but more elegance than at Rosings.

en: “And of this place,” thought she, “I might have been mistress!
vi: She thought: "I could be the mistress of this place!
tr: "And I," she thought, "could have been the mistress of this place!
es: "And to think," she said to herself, "that I could have been the mistress of all this!

en: With these rooms I might have now been familiarly acquainted!
vi: Now I can start getting familiar with these rooms.
tr: I could have known these rooms very well by now!
es: These rooms could now be mine!

en: Instead of viewing them as a stranger, I might have rejoiced in them as my own, and welcomed to them as visitors my uncle and aunt.
vi: Instead of looking at everything like a stranger, I can delight in seeing it as mine, and I can welcome my uncle and aunt as if they were two close relatives visiting."
tr: Instead of looking at them as a stranger, I could have enjoyed them as mine and could have invited my uncle and aunt as guests.
es: Instead of visiting them as a stranger, I could enjoy them and receive my uncles here!

en: But, no,” recollecting herself, “that could never be; my uncle and aunt would have been lost to me; I should not have been allowed to invite them.”
vi: She calmed herself: "But no, it can never be like that; my uncle and aunt will never know what happened to me; I shouldn't invite them."
tr: –But no," –she pulled herself together, – "it wouldn't be like that: I would have lost my uncle and aunt: I wouldn't have been allowed to invite them."
es: But no," she replied, recovering herself, "it would not have been possible, I would have had to give up my uncles; I would not have been allowed to invite them."

en: This was a lucky recollection—it saved her from something like regret.
vi: This is a fortunate calmness – it helps her escape from something almost like regret.
tr: This was a fortunate recollection – it prevented him from feeling something like regret.
es: This revived her and saved her from something akin to regret.

en: She longed to inquire of the housekeeper whether her master were really absent, but had not courage for it.
vi: She very much wanted to ask the housekeeper whether the master was truly absent or not, but she did not have the courage.
tr: The butler wanted to ask if the landlord was really traveling, but he didn't dare.
es: He wanted to find out from the housekeeper if his master was truly absent, but he lacked the courage.

en: At length, however, the question was asked by her uncle; and she turned away with alarm, while ms Reynolds replied, that he was; adding, “But we expect him to-morrow, with a large party of friends.”
vi: However, eventually her uncle asked, and she turned away in panic, while Mrs. Reynolds replied that he was away, and added: "But we are preparing to welcome him back tomorrow, with a large group of his friends."
tr: Still, in the end, his uncle asked the question; while Elizabeth turned away in fear, Mrs. Reynolds said he was traveling and added, "but we expect him to come tomorrow, many of his friends will also come."
es: Finally, it was his uncle who asked the question, and Elizabeth turned frightened when Mrs. Reynolds said yes, adding: ––But we expect him tomorrow. He is going to come with many friends.

en: How rejoiced was Elizabeth that their own journey had not by any circumstance been delayed a day!
vi: Elizabeth was delighted to feel that their trip had not been delayed by a day!
tr: How glad Elizabeth was that their own travels were not delayed by a day for any reason!
es: Elizabeth was glad that her trip had not been postponed by a day for any reason.

en: Her aunt now called her to look at a picture.
vi: Aunt now called her to see a painting.
tr: Her aunt called her to look at a picture at that moment.
es: Her aunt called her to see a painting.

en: She approached, and saw the likeness of mr Wickham, suspended, amongst several other miniatures, over the mantel-piece.
vi: She approached and saw Wickham's portrait hanging above the fireplace, among other miniatures.
tr: When Elizabeth approached, she saw Mr. Wickham's likeness among several miniatures above the fireplace.
es: Elizabeth approached and saw a portrait of Wickham above the mantelpiece among other miniatures.

en: Her aunt asked her, smilingly, how she liked it.
vi: Aunt smiled and asked her what she thought.
tr: Her aunt asked with a smile how she found it.
es: Her aunt asked her with a smile what she thought of it.

en: The housekeeper came forward, and told them it was the picture of a young gentleman, the son of her late master’s steward, who had been brought up by him at his own expense.
vi: The housekeeper stepped forward and informed them that it was a picture of the old gentleman's adopted son, who had been supported by him, and added: "He has joined the army, but I fear he has become too wayward."
tr: The housekeeper approached and said that the picture belonged to the son of her late master's steward, and that the young man had been raised by her master.
es: The housekeeper came to tell them that he was a young son of the last steward of her lord, educated by him at his own expense.

en: “He is now gone into the army,” she added; “but I am afraid he has turned out very wild.”
vi: The housekeeper stepped forward and informed them that it was a picture of the old gentleman's adopted son, who had been supported by him, and added: "He has joined the army, but I fear he has become too wayward."
tr: –"He is in the army now," she added, "but I'm afraid he has become quite a rascal."
es: ––Now he has joined the army ––––he added–– and I think he is a lost cause.

en: ms Gardiner looked at her niece with a smile, but Elizabeth could not return it.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner looked at her and smiled, but she could not respond.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner smiled at her niece, but Elizabeth could not respond.
es: Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece with a smile, but Elizabeth remained very serious.

en: “And that,” said ms Reynolds, pointing to another of the miniatures, “is my master—and very like him.
vi: Mrs. Reynolds pointed to another miniature painting and said: - And here is my boss, he looks a lot like him.
tr: "This one," said Mrs. Reynolds, pointing to another miniature, "is my master – it resembles him greatly.
es: ––And this one ––said Mrs. Reynolds, pointing to another of the miniatures–– is my master, and it is very similar.

en: It was drawn at the same time as the other—about eight years ago.”
vi: The painting was made around the same time as the other one, about eight years ago.
tr: It was drawn at the same time as the other one – about eight years ago."
es: It was painted at the same time as the other one, about eight years ago.

en: “I have heard much of your master’s fine person,” said ms Gardiner, looking at the picture; “it is a handsome face.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner looked at the painting and said: - I have heard much about your master's good nature; this is a beautiful portrait.
tr: "I have heard much praise of your master," said Mrs. Gardiner, looking at the picture; "a handsome face.
es: ––I have heard much about your master's distinction ––replied Mrs. Gardiner, gazing at the portrait––, he is handsome.

en: But, Lizzy, you can tell us whether it is like or not.”
vi: But, Lizzy, can you tell me if the portrait resembles him in real life?
tr: But Lizzy, you can tell us whether it resembles him or not."
es: Elizabeth, tell me if it is a good likeness or not.

en: ms Reynolds’ respect for Elizabeth seemed to increase on this intimation of her knowing her master.
vi: Mrs. Reynolds seemed to have more respect for Elizabeth upon hearing that she was acquainted with her master.
tr: Mrs. Reynolds's respect for Elizabeth seemed to increase upon the implication that she knew her master.
es: Mrs. Reynolds's respect for Elizabeth seemed to increase upon seeing that she knew her master –– "Does the young lady know Mr. Darcy?"

en: “Does that young lady know mr Darcy?”
vi: - Does the young lady here know Mr. Darcy?
tr: "Does this young lady know Mr. Darcy?""
es: Mrs. Reynolds's respect for Elizabeth seemed to increase upon seeing that she knew her master –– "Does the young lady know Mr. Darcy?"

en: Elizabeth coloured, and said, “A little.”
vi: Elizabeth blushed: - I know a little bit.
tr: Elizabeth blushed; "A little," she said.
es: Elizabeth blushed and replied: ––A little.

en: “And do not you think him a very handsome gentleman, ma’am?”
vi: - And you must think he is a really handsome man, right?
tr: "Don't you think he is a very handsome gentleman, madam?"
es: ––And doesn't the young lady think he is a very handsome gentleman?

en: “Yes, very handsome.”
vi: - Yes, very handsome.
tr: "Yes, very handsome.""
es: ––Yes, very handsome.

en: “I am sure I know none so handsome; but in the gallery upstairs you will see a finer, larger picture of him than this.
vi: - I am sure I have never seen anyone as handsome, but in the room upstairs you will see a more beautiful painting, larger than this one.
tr: "I am sure I have never seen someone so handsome; but in the gallery upstairs, you will see a bigger and more beautiful portrait of him.
es: ––I would swear he is the most handsome I have seen; but in the gallery upstairs you will see a better and larger portrait of him.

en: This room was my late master’s favourite room, and these miniatures are just as they used to be then.
vi: This room was the old man's favorite; these miniature paintings are still arranged just as they were in the old days.
tr: This room was my late master's favorite room; these miniatures are exactly as he left them.
es: This room was the favorite of my previous master, and these miniatures are just as they were during his lifetime.

en: He was very fond of them.”
vi: The old man was very fond of these paintings.
tr: He was very fond of them."
es: He liked them very much.

en: This accounted to Elizabeth for mr Wickham’s being among them.
vi: This explains to Elizabeth why Mr. Wickham's portrait is hung here.
tr: This explained to Elizabeth why Wickham's portrait was there.
es: Elizabeth then explained to herself why Wickham's was among them.

en: ms Reynolds then directed their attention to one of Miss Darcy, drawn when she was only eight years old.
vi: Then Mrs. Reynolds pointed to a portrait of Miss Darcy, painted when she was only eight years old.
tr: Mrs. Reynolds then drew their attention to a picture of Miss Darcy that had been drawn when she was eight years old.
es: Mrs. Reynolds then showed them a portrait of Miss Darcy, painted when she was only eight years old.

en: “And is Miss Darcy as handsome as her brother?” said mr Gardiner.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner asked: - And Miss Darcy is as beautiful as her brother, isn't she?
tr: "Is Miss Darcy as beautiful as her brother?" said Mr. Gardiner.
es: ––And is Miss Darcy as handsome as her brother?

en: “Oh, yes—the handsomest young lady that ever was seen; and so accomplished!
vi: - Ah! Yes – a young lady, beautiful beyond compare, and very talented too.
tr: "Ah yes – the most beautiful young lady ever; and so talented too!
es: ––Oh, yes! She is the most beautiful young woman ever seen! And so diligent!

en: She plays and sings all day long.
vi: She sings and performs all day long.
tr: –She plays and sings all day long.
es: She plays and sings all day long.

en: In the next room is a new instrument just come down for her—a present from my master: she comes here to-morrow with him.”
vi: In the next room, there is a new piano that was just delivered for her – a gift from my master; she will come here with him.
tr: There is a new piano that just arrived for her in the next room – a gift from my master; the young lady is coming with it tomorrow."
es: In the next room, there is a new piano that was just brought to her, a gift from my master. She will also arrive tomorrow with him.

en: mr Gardiner, whose manners were easy and pleasant, encouraged her communicativeness by his questions and remarks: ms Reynolds, either from pride or attachment, had evidently great pleasure in talking of her master and his sister.
vi: With very natural gestures and easily creating goodwill through a few questions and comments, Mr. Gardiner encouraged her to speak more. Mrs. Reynolds, out of pride or hospitality, was clearly very happy to have the opportunity to talk about her master and his sister.
tr: Mr. Gardiner, who was in a relaxed and pleasant manner, increased the woman's talkativeness with his questions and observations; Mrs. Reynolds, either out of pride or loyalty, clearly took great pleasure in talking about her master and his sister.
es: Mr. Gardiner, with kindness and skill, was drawing her out, and Mrs. Reynolds, out of pride and affection, evidently took pleasure in talking about her master and his sister.

en: “Is your master much at Pemberley in the course of the year?”
vi: - Does your master stay at Pemberley often throughout the year?
tr: "Does your master stay at Pemberley much throughout the year?""
es: ––Does your master come to Pemberley very often throughout the year?

en: “Not so much as I could wish, sir: but I dare say he may spend half his time here; and Miss Darcy is always down for the summer months.”
vi: - Not as often as I would like, sir; but I can say that he is here half of the time, and Miss Darcy is always here during the summer months.
tr: "Not as much as I would like, sir; but I can say that he spends half the year here; Miss Darcy is always here during the summer months."
es: ––Not as much as I would like, sir; but I would say he spends half of his time here; Miss Darcy is always here during the summer months.

en: “Except,” thought Elizabeth, “when she goes to Ramsgate.”
vi: Elizabeth thought: "Except when she went to Ramsgate."
tr: "Of course," thought Elizabeth, "except for the times he went to Ramsgate."
es: “Except ––thought Elizabeth–– when she goes to Ramsgate.”

en: “If your master would marry, you might see more of him.”
vi: - When your husband gets married, you will surely see him more often.
tr: "If your master gets married, you can see him more often.""
es: ––If your master got married, you would see him more.

en: “Yes, sir; but I do not know when that will be.
vi: - Yes, Sir, but I am not sure when that will happen.
tr: "Yes, sir; but I don't know when he will get married.
es: ––Yes, sir; but I don't know when it will be.

en: I do not know who is good enough for him.”
vi: I am not sure who could be worthy of him.
tr: I don't know anyone worthy of him."
es: I don't know if there will be anyone who deserves it.

en: mr and ms Gardiner smiled.
vi: Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner smiled.
tr: Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner smiled.
es: Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner smiled.

en: Elizabeth could not help saying, “It is very much to his credit, I am sure, that you should think so.”
vi: Elizabeth couldn't help but exclaim: - She must think that way because of his true worth as a person.
tr: Elizabeth couldn't help but say, "You say that because you value him.""
es: Elizabeth couldn't help but say: ––If that is what you believe, it speaks highly of Mr. Darcy.

en: “I say no more than the truth, and what everybody will say that knows him,” replied the other.
vi: - I am only speaking the truth and what everyone knows well about him.
tr: "I am telling the truth; everyone who knows him would say the same," replied the other.
es: ––I am only telling the truth and what anyone who knows him would say ––replied Mrs. Reynolds.

en: Elizabeth thought this was going pretty far; and she listened with increasing astonishment as the housekeeper added, “I have never had a cross word from him in my life, and I have known him ever since he was four years old.”
vi: Elizabeth thought the matter was going quite far, and she listened in surprise as the housekeeper added: - In my life, I have never heard him say anything harsh, and I have known him since he was four.
tr: Elizabeth thought things had gone too far; she listened to the steward's words with increasing astonishment, "In my life, I have never heard a single harsh word from his mouth, and I have known him since he was four years old."
es: Elizabeth thought that things were going too far, and listened with growing astonishment to what the housekeeper continued to say. ––Never in his life did he have a word of anger with me. And I have known him since he was four years old.

en: This was praise of all others most extraordinary, most opposite to her ideas.
vi: This is an unusual praise compared to other praises, completely contrary to her opinion.
tr: This praise was the most unusual of all, the one most contrary to Elizabeth's thoughts.
es: It was a more important compliment than all the others and more opposed to what Elizabeth thought of Darcy.

en: That he was not a good-tempered man had been her firmest opinion.
vi: She always firmly believed that he was not a calm person.
tr: She was absolutely convinced that he was not a charming man.
es: She always firmly believed that he was a man of bad character.

en: Her keenest attention was awakened: she longed to hear more; and was grateful to her uncle for saying,—
vi: Her attention was further aroused, and she was delighted to hear her uncle say:
tr: All her attention was aroused; she wanted to hear more and felt grateful to her uncle when she heard his words,
es: With keen curiosity, she waited to keep hearing what the housekeeper was saying, when her uncle observed:

en: “There are very few people of whom so much can be said.
vi: - Very few people are praised that much.
tr: "Very few people can be spoken of in such a way.
es: ––There are few people about whom that can be said.

en: You are lucky in having such a master.”
vi: She is fortunate to have such a boss.
tr: You are lucky to have such a master."
es: It is a stroke of luck for you to have such a gentleman.

en: “Yes, sir, I know I am.
vi: - Yes, Sir, I know I am lucky.
tr: "Yes, sir, I know that I am lucky.
es: ––Yes, sir; it is a stroke of luck.

en: If I were to go through the world, I could not meet with a better.
vi: If I traveled around the world, I would not be able to meet anyone better than him.
tr: I couldn't find a better one even if I traveled the world.
