es: Even if you traveled around the world, you wouldn't find a better one.

en: But I have always observed, that they who are good-natured when children, are good-natured when they grow up; and he was always the sweetest tempered, most generous-hearted boy in the world.”
vi: But I always see one thing: a person who has a good nature as a child will have a good nature when they grow up; and he has always been the gentlest child, with the most generous heart in the world.
tr: But I have always seen that those who are well-behaved as children remain well-behaved when they grow up; and he was the sweetest-natured, most soft-hearted child in the world."
es: I've always noticed that those who are kind as children, remain so as adults. And Mr. Darcy was the sweetest and most generous child on earth.

en: Elizabeth almost stared at her.
vi: Elizabeth almost stared at her.
tr: Elizabeth stared at the woman.
es: Elizabeth stared intently at the old woman: "Could that be Darcy?" she thought.

en: “Can this be mr Darcy?” thought she.
vi: She thought: "Could Mr. Darcy really be like that!"
tr: –"Could this be Mr. Darcy!" she thought.
es: Elizabeth stared intently at the old woman: "Could that be Darcy?" she thought.

en: “His father was an excellent man,” said ms Gardiner.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner said: - The old man is a very good person.
tr: "Her father was a wonderful man," said Mrs. Gardiner.
es: ––I believe his father was an excellent person ––added Mrs. Gardiner.

en: “Yes, ma’am, that he was indeed; and his son will be just like him—just as affable to the poor.”
vi: - Yes, that's right, ma'am; and his son will be like him – also kind to the poor.
tr: "Yes ma'am, it was like that; his son will be just like him – a friend to the poor and needy like him.""
es: ––Yes, ma'am; yes, he was, and his son is exactly like him, just as good with the poor.

en: Elizabeth listened, wondered, doubted, and was impatient for more.
vi: Elizabeth listened, wondering, doubting, eager to hear more.
tr: Elizabeth listened, was astonished, doubted, and was impatient for it to continue.
es: Elizabeth listened, marveled, doubted, and wished to know more.

en: ms Reynolds could interest her on no other point.
vi: Mrs. Reynolds could not get her to pay attention to anything else.
tr: Mrs. Reynolds could not draw her attention to another subject.
es: Mrs. Reynolds could not capture her attention with anything else.

en: She related the subjects of the pictures, the dimensions of the rooms, and the price of the furniture in vain.
vi: She talked about the paintings, the size of the rooms, the cost of the furnishings, but Elizabeth did not pay attention.
tr: She touched on topics such as the pictures, the dimensions of the room, and the prices of the furniture, but it was in vain.
es: It was useless for her to explain the subject of the paintings, the dimensions of the rooms, and the value of the furniture.

en: mr Gardiner, highly amused by the kind of family prejudice, to which he attributed her excessive commendation of her master, soon led again to the subject; and she dwelt with energy on his many merits, as they proceeded together up the great staircase.
vi: Mr. Gardiner was very amused by the prejudiced attitude stemming from family affection, which he thought was the reason for the enthusiastic praises. He drew her back to the old topic, and she eagerly spoke about the virtues of her master as they walked up the stairs together.
tr: Mr. Gardiner, attributing the woman's excessive praise of her master to family pride, was quite amused and soon returned to the subject; as they all went up the grand staircase together, the woman began enumerating her master's virtues again.
es: Mr. Gardiner, very amused at what he assumed was family prejudice inspiring the old lady's lavish praises of her master, soon insisted on his questions, and as they ascended the grand staircase, Mrs. Reynolds continued extolling Darcy's many merits.

en: “He is the best landlord, and the best master,” said she, “that ever lived.
vi: She said:
tr: "Of all time," he said, "he is the best landlord and the best master.
es: ––He is the best lord and the best master that could exist; he is not like the reckless young men of today who think only of themselves.

en: Not like the wild young men now-a-days, who think of nothing but themselves.
vi: - He is the best landlord and the best householder, unlike the young men these days who only think of themselves and don't care about anyone else.
tr: He is unlike today's wild young men who think of nothing but themselves.
es: ––He is the best lord and the best master that could exist; he is not like the reckless young men of today who think only of themselves.

en: There is not one of his tenants or servants but what will give him a good name.
vi: There isn't a tenant or servant who doesn't speak well of him.
tr: There is not a single tenant or servant who would not speak well of him.
es: There is not a single one of his tenants and servants who does not praise him.

en: Some people call him proud; but I am sure I never saw anything of it.
vi: Some people say he is proud, but I have never seen that.
tr: Some call him proud, but I am sure I have not seen a trace of it.
es: Some say he is proud, but I have never noticed it.

en: To my fancy, it is only because he does not rattle away like other young men.”
vi: I think it's just because he doesn't boast like the young men.
tr: In my opinion, they say so because he does not make a fuss like other young men."
es: I suppose they find him proud because he is not boisterous like the others.

en: “In what an amiable light does this place him!” thought Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth thought, "How endearing this makes him!"
tr: "How charming these words make him appear!" thought Elizabeth.
es: "What a good place this puts everything in," thought Elizabeth.

en: “This fine account of him,” whispered her aunt as they walked, “is not quite consistent with his behaviour to our poor friend.”
vi: The aunt whispered, as they walked together: - Such words of praise about his virtues are not consistent with your attitude towards our poor friend.
tr: "This description," whispered her aunt as they walked, "doesn't quite match the way she behaves towards our poor friend."
es: ––Such delicate praise ––whispered her aunt as they continued touring the house–– does not align with what he did to our poor friend.

en: “Perhaps we might be deceived.”
vi: - Maybe we have been deceived.
tr: "Maybe we were wrong."
es: ––Maybe we are wrong.

en: “That is not very likely; our authority was too good.”
vi: - It's hard to be like that; our source is very reliable.
tr: "Sanmam; our source was reliable.""
es: ––It’s not likely; we know it from a very reliable source.

en: On reaching the spacious lobby above, they were shown into a very pretty sitting-room, lately fitted up with greater elegance and lightness than the apartments below; and were informed that it was but just done to give pleasure to Miss Darcy, who had taken a liking to the room, when last at Pemberley.
vi: As they walked up the hallway on the upper floor, they were led into a reception room, which was decorated more elegantly and gracefully than the rooms below. The housekeeper introduced it as a room that had just been completed specifically for Miss Darcy, as she had taken a liking to it during her last stay here.
tr: When they reached the spacious lobby on the upper floor, they were taken to a very pleasant sitting room furnished in a more elegant and lighter style than the apartments below; it was said that the room was newly built to please Miss Darcy, who liked the room when she last came to Pemberley.
es: In the wide corridor upstairs, they were shown a lovely room recently decorated with greater elegance and a lighter tone than the lower rooms, and they were told that all of it had been done to please Miss Darcy, who had taken a liking to that room the last time she was at Pemberley.

en: “He is certainly a good brother,” said Elizabeth, as she walked towards one of the windows.
vi: Elizabeth said, as she walked to a window: - He is definitely a good brother.
tr: "It is clear that he is a good brother," said Elizabeth, walking towards one of the windows.
es: ––He is really a good brother ––said Elizabeth, turning to one of the windows.

en: ms Reynolds anticipated Miss Darcy’s delight, when she should enter the room.
vi: Mrs. Reynolds thinks Miss Darcy will like this room when she arrives here.
tr: Mrs. Reynolds could see how pleased Miss Darcy would be when she entered the room.
es: Mrs. Reynolds said that Miss Darcy would be delighted when she saw that room.

en: “And this is always the way with him,” she added.
vi: She added: - He has always been like that.
tr: "The master is always like this," she added. –
es: ––And it's always like that ––he added––, he goes out of his way to please his sister.

en: “Whatever can give his sister any pleasure, is sure to be done in a moment.
vi: Anything that can make her happy can be done immediately.
tr: "If there is something that will please his sister, it is done at that moment.
es: ––And it's always like that ––he added––, he goes out of his way to please his sister.

en: There is nothing he would not do for her.”
vi: If it's for her, there's nothing he would refuse.
tr: There is nothing he wouldn't do for her."
es: There is nothing he wouldn't do for her.

en: The picture gallery, and two or three of the principal bed-rooms, were all that remained to be shown.
vi: They were taken to see the gallery and a few of the main bedrooms.
tr: There remained the picture gallery to be shown and a few main bedrooms.
es: There was nothing left to see but the picture gallery and two or three of the main bedrooms.

en: In the former were many good paintings: but Elizabeth knew nothing of the art; and from such as had been already visible below, she had willingly turned to look at some drawings of Miss Darcy’s, in crayons, whose subjects were usually more interesting, and also more intelligible.
vi: The gallery had beautiful paintings, but Elizabeth knew nothing about art; and from what she had seen downstairs, she wanted to see the portraits of Miss Darcy, drawn in pastels, which were subjects she found more interesting and easier to understand.
tr: There were many beautiful paintings in the gallery; but Elizabeth did not understand paintings; she left the pictures she saw below and turned her attention to Miss Darcy's pencil sketches, which had more interesting subjects and were more comprehensible.
es: In the first, there were several good paintings, but Elizabeth knew nothing about art, and among the objects of that nature she had already seen downstairs, she only looked at a few pastel drawings by Miss Darcy, which were of more interest and more intelligible to her.

en: In the gallery there were many family portraits, but they could have little to fix the attention of a stranger.
vi: The gallery had many family portraits, but nothing that drew the attention of visitors.
tr: There were many family portraits in the gallery, but they had no aspects that might be interesting to a stranger.
es: In the gallery, there were also several family portraits, but it was not easy for them to attract the attention of a stranger.

en: Elizabeth walked on in quest of the only face whose features would be known to her.
vi: Elizabeth walked around searching for the one face she knew.
tr: Elizabeth continued to walk, searching for the one face she would recognize.
es: Elizabeth went through them looking for the only portrait whose features she could recognize.

en: At last it arrested her—and she beheld a striking resemblance of mr Darcy, with such a smile over the face, as she remembered to have sometimes seen, when he looked at her.
vi: Finally, she stopped in front of Mr. Darcy's portrait, with a smile on his face that she remembered seeing a few times when he looked at her.
tr: Finally, that face stopped her – and she saw a striking resemblance to Mr. Darcy, with the smile she remembered seeing occasionally when she looked at him.
es: Upon reaching it, she stopped, noting its surprising accuracy. Darcy's face had that same smile that Elizabeth had seen when he looked at her.

en: She stood several minutes before the picture, in earnest contemplation, and returned to it again before they quitted the gallery.
vi: She stood for a few minutes before the portrait, gazing intently, and looked back once more before they left the gallery.
tr: She stood in front of it for a few minutes, examining the painting with curiosity, and before leaving the gallery, she turned to look at it once more.
es: She remained in front of the painting for several minutes, in the most attentive contemplation, and even looked at it again before leaving the gallery.

en: ms Reynolds informed them, that it had been taken in his father’s lifetime.
vi: Mrs. Reynolds mentioned that the painting was done during the old master's lifetime.
tr: Mrs. Reynolds said the painting was done during his father's lifetime.
es: Mrs. Reynolds informed her that it had been done during Darcy's father's lifetime.

en: There was certainly at this moment, in Elizabeth’s mind, a more gentle sensation towards the original than she had ever felt in the height of their acquaintance.
vi: At this moment, a gentle feeling seeped into Elizabeth's consciousness, gentler than her thoughts when they were at their best with each other.
tr: There was a feeling within Elizabeth during their relationship that was much warmer than what she had felt towards him before.
es: Elizabeth felt at that moment a much greater inclination for the original than she had felt at the height of their relationship.

en: The commendation bestowed on him by ms Reynolds was of no trifling nature.
vi: Mrs. Reynolds's praise was not a trivial matter.
tr: The praises Mrs. Reynolds showered upon him were by no means ordinary.
es: Mrs. Reynolds' praises were no small matter.

en: What praise is more valuable than the praise of an intelligent servant?
vi: What praise could be more valuable than that of an intelligent servant?
tr: What praise is more valuable than that of an intelligent servant?
es: What praise can be more valuable than that of an intelligent servant?

en: As a brother, a landlord, a master, she considered how many people’s happiness were in his guardianship!
vi: She thought of how many people were made happy under his protection, as a brother, a landlord, a master of the house!
tr: As a brother, a landlord, a master, how many people's happiness was under his protection!
es: How many people had their happiness placed in Darcy's hands as a brother, a proprietor, and a lord!

en: How much of pleasure or pain it was in his power to bestow!
vi: How much joy or sorrow he had the power to bestow!
tr: –How much power he had to bring joy or sorrow!
es: How much pleasure and how much pain could he bestow!

en: How much of good or evil must be done by him!
vi: How many good or bad things he could do!
tr: –How much good or evil he could do!
es: How much harm and how much good could he do!

en: Every idea that had been brought forward by the housekeeper was favourable to his character; and as she stood before the canvas, on which he was represented, and fixed his eyes upon herself, she thought of his regard with a deeper sentiment of gratitude than it had ever raised before: she remembered its warmth, and softened its impropriety of expression.
vi: Every opinion the housekeeper expressed spoke well of his character, and as she stood before his portrait, with him gazing intently at her, she thought of his feelings with the deepest gratitude she had ever felt; she recalled the warmth of these feelings, realizing that his way of expressing them was not as improper as she had previously thought.
tr: Every word the steward spoke elevated his character; as Elizabeth stood before the portrait with her eyes fixed upon it, she looked at the image with a deeper sense of gratitude than ever before; she remembered the warmth of that image, softened the flaw in its expression.
es: Everything said by the housekeeper exalted him. Standing before the canvas on which he was portrayed, it seemed to Elizabeth that his eyes were looking at her, and she thought of his esteem for her with a much deeper gratitude than she had felt before; Elizabeth recalled the strength and warmth of his words and mitigated her lack of decorum.

en: When all of the house that was open to general inspection had been seen, they returned down stairs; and, taking leave of the housekeeper, were consigned over to the gardener, who met them at the hall door.
vi: After having toured all the places they were allowed to visit, the three of them went back downstairs, bid farewell to the housekeeper, and were introduced to the gardener who had come to the foyer to meet them.
tr: After they had seen every part of the house that was open to visitors, they went back downstairs; they bid farewell to the steward, and at the hall door, the gardener took over from him.
es: They had already seen everything that was shown to the public in the house; they went downstairs and said goodbye to the housekeeper, who entrusted them to a gardener waiting at the vestibule door.

en: As they walked across the lawn towards the river, Elizabeth turned back to look again; her uncle and aunt stopped also; and while the former was conjecturing as to the date of the building, the owner of it himself suddenly came forward from the road which led behind it to the stables.
vi: As they walked across the lawn towards the river, Elizabeth looked back; her uncle and aunt also stopped, and while they were speculating about the time the mansion was built, its owner suddenly came up from the path leading to the stables.
tr: As they walked from the meadow towards the river, Elizabeth turned around to look again; her uncle and aunt also stopped; while Elizabeth was trying to determine the construction date of the house, the owner of the house suddenly appeared in front of them from the road winding from the back of the house to the stables.
es: When they were crossing the meadow on their way to the stream, Elizabeth turned to look at the house again. Her uncles stopped as well, and while Mr. Gardiner was speculating about the age of the building, its owner suddenly came out from behind the house on the path leading to the stables.

en: They were within twenty yards of each other; and so abrupt was his appearance, that it was impossible to avoid his sight.
vi: They stood about twenty yards apart, his appearance was so sudden that she couldn't avoid him.
tr: They were twenty steps apart from each other; his appearance had been so sudden that it was impossible not to see him.
es: They were less than twenty yards away, and their appearance was so sudden that it was impossible to prevent them from being seen.

en: Their eyes instantly met, and the cheeks of each were overspread with the deepest blush.
vi: Their eyes met, and both of their cheeks flushed.
tr: Their eyes met instantly; both of their cheeks were covered in a deep blush.
es: Elizabeth and Darcy's eyes met instantly, and their faces were covered with intense blushes.

en: He absolutely started, and for a moment seemed immovable from surprise; but shortly recovering himself, advanced towards the party, and spoke to Elizabeth, if not in terms of perfect composure, at least of perfect civility.
vi: He was extremely surprised, for a moment seemingly motionless with astonishment. But he quickly regained his composure, stepped forward and greeted Elizabeth with words that were not entirely calm, but at least very polite.
tr: Darcy was stunned and couldn't move for a moment out of shock; but soon he composed himself, advanced towards the visitors, and spoke to Elizabeth with perfect politeness, if not perfect calmness.
es: He stopped short and for a moment remained motionless with surprise; he quickly recovered and, stepping forward towards the visitors, spoke to Elizabeth, if not in terms of perfect composure, at least with absolute courtesy.

en: She had instinctively turned away; but stopping on his approach, received his compliments with an embarrassment impossible to be overcome.
vi: She instinctively turned her face away, but stopped when he approached, accepting his greeting with an uncontainable confusion.
tr: Elizabeth instinctively turned the other way; but when she saw him approaching, she stopped and accepted his compliments with an insurmountable discomfort.
es: She had turned instinctively, but as he approached, he stopped and received her compliments with embarrassment.

en: Had his first appearance, or his resemblance to the picture they had just been examining, been insufficient to assure the other two that they now saw mr Darcy, the gardener’s expression of surprise, on beholding his master, must immediately have told it.
vi: If his appearance or the portrait of him they had just seen were not enough for her uncle and aunt to recognize him, the gardener's surprise upon seeing the master of the house immediately said it all.
tr: If his initial appearance, or his resemblance to the portrait they were examining, had not been enough to convince the other two that it was Mr. Darcy they were seeing, the gardener's expression of astonishment upon seeing his master would have immediately confirmed it.
es: If Darcy's appearance at first sight or his resemblance to the portraits they had just been viewing had been insufficient to reveal to Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner that they had Darcy himself before them, the gardener's astonishment at encountering his master would have left no room for doubt.

en: They stood a little aloof while he was talking to their niece, who, astonished and confused, scarcely dared lift her eyes to his face, and knew not what answer she returned to his civil inquiries after her family.
vi: The uncle and aunt stood a little distance away as he spoke with their niece, while she was too stunned and awkward to look directly at him, not knowing how to respond when he politely inquired about her family's health.
tr: While Mr. Darcy spoke with his nephews, the two of them stood a little aside; the nephews were astonished, dazed, and did not even dare to lift their eyes to look at his face, unsure of how to respond to his polite inquiries about their family's health.
es: They waited at a certain distance while their niece spoke with him. Elizabeth, astonished and confused, hardly dared to raise her eyes to Darcy and did not know how to answer the questions he asked about her family.

en: Amazed at the alteration of his manner since they last parted, every sentence that he uttered was increasing her embarrassment; and every idea of the impropriety of her being found there recurring to her mind, the few minutes in which they continued together were some of the most uncomfortable of her life.
vi: She was also surprised by his changed demeanor compared to the last time they met, which only added to her confusion with every word he uttered. All thoughts about her sudden visit returned to her mind; and the few minutes they continued to converse were the most uncomfortable moments of her life.
tr: As she marveled at how differently he behaved compared to the last time they parted, every sentence he uttered increased her discomfort a bit more; the inappropriateness of her presence repeatedly came to mind, making the few minutes they stood face to face some of the most tense moments of her life.
es: Surprised by the change in manners since they had last parted, each phrase he uttered increased her embarrassment, and as she thought about how improper it was to have met him there, the few moments they were together were the most uneasy of her life.

en: Nor did he seem much more at ease; when he spoke, his accent had none of its usual sedateness; and he repeated his inquiries as to the time of her having left Longbourn, and of her stay in Derbyshire, so often, and in so hurried a way, as plainly spoke the distraction of his thoughts.
vi: He did not seem natural either. When he spoke, his tone lacked its usual calmness; and he repeated questions about when they had left Longbourn and about her stay in Derbyshire, stammering, clearly showing he was distracted.
tr: On the other hand, Mr. Darcy did not seem very comfortable either; there was no trace of his usual calmness in his voice as he spoke; he repeatedly, frequently, and hurriedly asked when she had left Longbourn and how long she would stay in Derbyshire, making it clear that his mind was confused.
es: Darcy did not seem more in control of himself than she was; his tone lacked the usual calm, and he kept asking her when she had left Longbourn and how long she had been in Derbyshire, with such disorder and haste that his agitation was clearly evident.

en: At length, every idea seemed to fail him; and after standing a few moments without saying a word, he suddenly recollected himself, and took leave.
vi: In the end, he couldn't focus on any idea; and, after standing there for a moment speechless, he suddenly calmed down, then took his leave of them.
tr: In the end, it seemed as if no thought was enough for him; after standing silently for a few minutes, he suddenly pulled himself together and said goodbye.
es: At last, it seemed that he no longer knew what to say; he remained silent for a few moments, suddenly composed himself, and said goodbye.

en: The others then joined her, and expressed their admiration of his figure; but Elizabeth heard not a word, and, wholly engrossed by her own feelings, followed them in silence.
vi: Her uncle and aunt went on to praise his appearance; but Elizabeth did not hear a word. Completely absorbed in her own thoughts, she walked on with the couple.
tr: Then the others came to her and expressed how much they admired Mr. Darcy; but Elizabeth did not hear a single word and followed them silently, surrounded by her own feelings.
es: The Gardiners met with Elizabeth and praised Darcy's good appearance; but she heard nothing; absorbed in her thoughts, she followed them in silence.

en: She was overpowered by shame and vexation.
vi: Shame and vexation filled her heart.
tr: She was exhausted from shame and distress.
es: She was overwhelmed by shame and frustration.

en: Her coming there was the most unfortunate, the most ill-judged thing in the world!
vi: Her coming here was truly unfortunate, the most ill-considered act of her life!
tr: Coming there was the most unfortunate, most foolish thing she had ever done!
es: How had it occurred to her to go there? It had been the most unfortunate and foolish decision in the world!

en: How strange must it appear to him!
vi: How strange he must find it!
tr: How strange she must have appeared to him!
es: How strange it must seem to Darcy!

en: In what a disgraceful light might it not strike so vain a man!
vi: A vain man like him would see her as humiliated!
tr: Such a thing would seem so unbecoming to such a proud man!
es: How was a man ––so vain!–– to interpret that?

en: It might seem as if she had purposely thrown herself in his way again!
vi: It seemed as if once again she had deliberately brought herself right in front of him!
tr: It would look as if she had deliberately thrown herself in his way!
es: Her visit to Pemberley would seem deliberately made to seek him out.

en: Oh!
vi: Oh!
tr: Why had she come, why?
es: Why had she gone?

en: why did she come?
vi: Why did she come here?
tr: Why had she come, why?
es: Why had she gone?

en: or, why did he thus come a day before he was expected?
vi: And why did he return a day early?
tr: And why had Mr. Darcy arrived a day earlier than expected?
es: And he, why had he come a day earlier?

en: Had they been only ten minutes sooner, they should have been beyond the reach of his discrimination; for it was plain that he was that moment arrived, that moment alighted from his horse or his carriage.
vi: If the three of them had left ten minutes earlier, they could have avoided him, for it was evident that at that moment he was arriving, either dismounting from his horse or stepping out of his carriage.
tr: If they had left ten minutes earlier, he wouldn't have even noticed them, because it was clear he had just arrived, just dismounted from his horse or carriage.
es: If they themselves had arrived at Pemberley just ten minutes earlier, they would not have met, for it was evident that Darcy had just arrived, that at that moment he was getting off the horse or the carriage.

en: She blushed again and again over the perverseness of the meeting.
vi: She blushed and blushed again over the wretched encounter.
tr: She blushed repeatedly at the thought of the awkward encounter.
es: Elizabeth could not stop feeling ashamed of their unfortunate encounter.

en: And his behaviour, so strikingly altered,—what could it mean?
vi: And his demeanor, completely changed, what did it mean?
tr: And his so changed behavior – what to make of that?
es: And Darcy's behavior, so remarkably changed, what could it mean?

en: That he should even speak to her was amazing!—but to speak with such civility, to inquire after her family!
vi: That he still wanted to converse with her was surprising enough, but to speak with such politeness, and even inquire about her family!
tr: It was a miracle that he even spoke to her! – especially speaking so kindly and inquiring about her family's health!
es: It was surprising that he had spoken to her, but even more so that he did it with such finesse and asked about her family.

en: Never in her life had she seen his manners so little dignified, never had he spoken with such gentleness as on this unexpected meeting.
vi: Never had she seen his manner so unpretentious, never had he spoken so gently as in this unexpected meeting.
tr: She had never seen him behave so humbly, never heard him speak so delicately as he did in that unexpected encounter.
es: She had never seen such simplicity in his manners nor had she ever heard him express himself with such gentleness.

en: What a contrast did it offer to his last address in Rosings Park, when he put his letter into her hand!
vi: It was indeed a stark contrast to his behavior at Rosings, when he handed her his letter.
tr: How different it was from their last conversation at Rosings Park, especially when he handed her that letter!
es: What a contrast to the last time he approached her at the Rosings estate to hand her the letter!

en: She knew not what to think, or how to account for it.
vi: She did not know what to think or how to interpret it.
tr: She did not know what to think, how to explain it.
es: Elizabeth did not know what to think or how to judge all this.

en: They had now entered a beautiful walk by the side of the water, and every step was bringing forward a nobler fall of ground, or a finer reach of the woods to which they were approaching: but it was some time before Elizabeth was sensible of any of it; and, though she answered mechanically to the repeated appeals of her uncle and aunt, and seemed to direct her eyes to such objects as they pointed out, she distinguished no part of the scene.
vi: They had walked onto the path along the riverbank, each step bringing a more elegant scene or a more beautiful stretch of forest; but only after a while did Elizabeth realize this. Although she mechanically responded to every comment from her uncle and aunt and tried to direct her gaze to where they pointed, she could not distinguish the scenes around her.
tr: They had now entered a beautiful road by the water; each step revealed a larger slope or a small extension of the forest they were approaching; but it took Elizabeth some time to see these; she was so busy answering her uncle and aunt's incessant questions, turning her eyes to the places they pointed out, that she could not distinguish any part of the scene.
es: Meanwhile, they had entered a beautiful path parallel to the stream, and with each step, a more beautiful slope of the terrain or a more impressive view of the forests they were approaching appeared before them. But some time passed before Elizabeth realized all of this, and although she mechanically responded to her uncles' repeated questions and seemed to direct her gaze to the objects they pointed out, she did not distinguish any part of the landscape.

en: Her thoughts were all fixed on that one spot of Pemberley House, whichever it might be, where mr Darcy then was.
vi: All her thoughts were directed to a place within the Pemberley estate, any place where Mr. Darcy might be present.
tr: Her thoughts were fixed on that single point of Pemberley Manor, the point where Mr. Darcy was at that moment.
es: Her thoughts could not be diverted from the site of Pemberley mansion, wherever it might be, where Darcy must be.

en: She longed to know what at that moment was passing in his mind; in what manner he thought of her, and whether, in defiance of everything, she was still dear to him.
vi: She wanted to know what he was thinking at that moment, and whether she still held any affection in his mind, even though she still felt defiant.
tr: She wanted to know what was going through his mind at that moment, what he thought of her, and whether she still mattered to him despite everything.
es: She longed to know what was going through his mind at that moment, what he thought of her, and if he still loved her.

en: Perhaps he had been civil only because he felt himself at ease; yet there had been that in his voice, which was not like ease.
vi: Perhaps he had been polite to her just because he felt comfortable, yet there was something in his voice that showed her he was not calm.
tr: Perhaps he had been kind just because he felt comfortable; but still, there was that thing in his voice, that thing that was not like comfort.
es: It might be that his courtesy was merely because he had already forgotten her; but there was something in his voice that denoted unease.

en: Whether he had felt more of pain or of pleasure in seeing her, she could not tell, but he certainly had not seen her with composure.
vi: She could not guess whether he was distressed or pleased to see her again, but surely he had not maintained his composure when he saw her.
tr: She did not know whether he felt pain or joy at seeing Elizabeth, but she knew he could not remain calm when he saw her.
es: She could not guess whether Darcy felt pleasure or regret at seeing her; but the truth is that he seemed bewildered.

en: At length, however, the remarks of her companions on her absence of mind roused her, and she felt the necessity of appearing more like herself.
vi: However, in the end, her uncle and aunt's remarks about her absent-mindedness awakened her mind, and she thought she needed to return to herself.
tr: Nevertheless, in the end, the words of his friends woke him from his reverie; he felt he needed to appear more present.
es: The observations of her companions about her lack of attention woke her up and made her realize that she needed to appear calm.

en: They entered the woods, and, bidding adieu to the river for a while, ascended some of the higher grounds; whence, in spots where the opening of the trees gave the eye power to wander, were many charming views of the valley, the opposite hills, with the long range of woods overspreading many, and occasionally part of the stream.
vi: They entered the forest and bid farewell to the river, climbing up a slope to a place where the sparse canopy opened up to reveal a mesmerizing view of the valley, with hills facing a long stretch of tree-covered land, and glimpses of the water appearing intermittently.
tr: They entered the forest, bidding farewell to the river for a while; they descended several slopes; at points where the clearings among the trees allowed the eye to wander, they caught magnificent views of the valley, the opposite hills, the distant forests covering many hills, and occasionally a part of the river.
es: They penetrated the forest and, moving away from the stream for a while, climbed to one of the highest points, from which, through the clearings of the trees, one could extend the view and appreciate magnificent panoramas of the valley and the opposite hills covered with woodland, and parts of the stream could also be seen.

en: mr Gardiner expressed a wish of going round the whole park, but feared it might be beyond a walk.
vi: The uncle expressed a desire to walk around the entire garden, but was concerned about the long distance.
tr: Mr. Gardiner said he wanted to explore the entire grove, but he feared it might not be possible to do so on foot.
es: Mr. Gardiner would have liked to tour the entire estate, but he feared the walk would be too long.

en: With a triumphant smile, they were told, that it was ten miles round.
vi: The gardener proudly informed them that the path was ten miles long.
tr: With a triumphant smile, they were told that the grove was ten miles in diameter.
es: With a triumphant smile, the gardener told them that the estate was ten miles long, so they decided not to take the planned tour and headed back down to a slope with trees leaning over the water at one of the narrowest points of the stream.

en: It settled the matter; and they pursued the accustomed circuit; which brought them again, after some time, in a descent among hanging woods, to the edge of the water, and one of its narrowest parts.
vi: So he dismissed the idea, and they followed the familiar path, and after descending under the drooping foliage, they reencountered the riverbank where the water was at its narrowest.
tr: This settled the matter; they followed the usual path, which after a while led them down a slope through drooping trees to the water's edge, at one of its narrowest points.
es: With a triumphant smile, the gardener told them that the estate was ten miles long, so they decided not to take the planned tour and headed back down to a slope with trees leaning over the water at one of the narrowest points of the stream.

en: They crossed it by a simple bridge, in character with the general air of the scene: it was a spot less adorned than any they had yet visited; and the valley, here contracted into a glen, allowed room only for the stream, and a narrow walk amidst the rough coppice-wood which bordered it.
vi: They crossed a rustic bridge that blended harmoniously with the surrounding scenery. This was the least maintained area compared to the places they had passed through. The valley here narrowed, leaving just enough space for the river to flow through, and the path also narrowed between the low bushes on either side.
tr: They crossed a simple bridge made in a style suitable to the atmosphere of the surroundings; it was a less adorned place than the areas they had previously explored; here the valley narrowed, allowing space only for the river and a narrow path winding through the bushes along the river.
es: They crossed it by a simple bridge in harmony with the general aspect of the landscape. That spot was the least adorned with artifices of all they had seen. The valley, turned into a glen here, left only space for the stream and a narrow path in the middle of the rustic grove that bordered it.

en: Elizabeth longed to explore its windings; but when they had crossed the bridge, and perceived their distance from the house, ms Gardiner, who was not a great walker, could go no farther, and thought only of returning to the carriage as quickly as possible.
vi: Elizabeth wanted to explore along the trail, but they realized they had gone quite far, and Mrs. Gardiner, due to her frail health, could not go any further and wished to return to the carriage as quickly as possible.
tr: Elizabeth wanted to follow the path; but when they crossed the bridge and realized how far they were from the house, Mrs. Gardiner, who was not a vigorous walker, could go no further and was eager to return to the carriage as soon as possible.
es: Elizabeth wanted to explore its twists and turns, but as soon as they crossed the bridge and could appreciate how far they were from the house, Mrs. Gardiner, who was not fond of walking, did not want to go any further and only thought of returning to the carriage as soon as possible.

en: Her niece was, therefore, obliged to submit, and they took their way towards the house on the opposite side of the river, in the nearest direction; but their progress was slow, for mr Gardiner, though seldom able to indulge the taste, was very fond of fishing, and was so much engaged in watching the occasional appearance of some trout in the water, and talking to the man about them, that he advanced but little.
vi: Her niece had to comply with her. They followed the riverbank back to the mansion by the shortest route. But they could not move quickly because Mr. Gardiner, who was very fond of fishing despite having few opportunities, was captivated by the occasional appearance of trout on the water's surface, and as he walked slowly, he conversed with the gardener.
tr: Her niece had to agree, and they walked towards the house by a shortcut on the opposite side of the river; they moved slowly because, although Mr. Gardiner could not spare the time, he was very keen on fishing and would get absorbed in watching a trout in the water, talking about trout, and hardly walking at all.
es: Her niece was forced to yield, and they began the return to the house on the opposite side of the stream and by the shortest path. But they walked very slowly because Mr. Gardiner was fond of fishing, although he seldom had the chance to indulge in it, and he was distracted every so often by watching for the appearance of a trout and commenting on it with the gardener.

en: Whilst wandering on in this slow manner, they were again surprised, and Elizabeth’s astonishment was quite equal to what it had been at first, by the sight of mr Darcy approaching them, and at no great distance.
vi: While they were leisurely like this, once again the three were surprised, and Elizabeth was as astonished as the last time, when they saw Mr. Darcy approaching.
tr: As they walked at this slow pace, something else surprised them; seeing Mr. Darcy approaching them and not far away at all, Elizabeth was once again as astonished as before.
es: As they continued their slow march, they were surprised again; and this time Elizabeth's astonishment was as great as before when she saw Darcy heading towards them and at a short distance.

en: The walk being here less sheltered than on the other side, allowed them to see him before they met.
vi: This area had fewer trees than the opposite bank, so they saw him before they met.
tr: Because the path on that side of the river was less sheltered than the one on the opposite side, they could see him before coming face to face with him.
es: Since the path was not as hidden as the one on the other side, they saw each other from afar.

en: Elizabeth, however astonished, was at least more prepared for an interview than before, and resolved to appear and to speak with calmness, if he really intended to meet them.
vi: Though surprised, Elizabeth was somewhat more prepared than before to respond to him, intending to remain calm if indeed he wanted to meet them.
tr: Although Elizabeth was surprised, she was at least more prepared to speak than before and decided to appear and speak calmly if Mr. Darcy indeed intended to talk to them.
es: Therefore, Elizabeth was more prepared and resolved to show calmness in her appearance and words if Darcy indeed intended to approach them.

en: For a few moments, indeed, she felt that he would probably strike into some other path.
vi: For a moment, she thought he seemed to want to take a different path.
tr: For a few minutes, she really thought he would take another path.
es: There was a moment when she firmly believed that Darcy was going to take another path, and her conviction lasted while a bend in the path hid him, but after passing the bend, Darcy appeared before them.

en: The idea lasted while a turning in the walk concealed him from their view; the turning past, he was immediately before them.
vi: He disappeared around a bend, then suddenly appeared before them.
tr: As a bend in the path hid him from view, they continued, then the bend was passed, and they found him right in front of them.
es: There was a moment when she firmly believed that Darcy was going to take another path, and her conviction lasted while a bend in the path hid him, but after passing the bend, Darcy appeared before them.

en: With a glance she saw that he had lost none of his recent civility; and, to imitate his politeness, she began as they met to admire the beauty of the place; but she had not got beyond the words “delightful,” and “charming,” when some unlucky recollections obtruded, and she fancied that praise of Pemberley from her might be mischievously construed.
vi: With just a glance, she saw that he maintained the same courteous demeanor as before, and to mimic his manner, when they faced each other, she began to praise the scenery there. But before she could say more than "beautiful" or "charming," she remembered something, and she imagined that he might misunderstand her praise of Pemberley.
tr: At a glance, Elizabeth saw that he had not lost his previous courtesy; and to reciprocate his politeness, as they came face to face, she began to express how much she admired the beauty of the surroundings, but she could not get beyond the words "magnificent" and "extraordinary" when some unfortunate memories intervened, and she thought that praising Pemberley might be misunderstood.
es: At the first glance, she noticed that he was as courteous as a moment ago, and to imitate his good manners, she began to admire the beauty of the place; but she had barely said "delightful" and "charming" when she thought that praising Pemberley might be misinterpreted.

en: Her colour changed, and she said no more.
vi: She blushed deeply and said nothing more.
tr: She blushed and fell silent.
es: She changed color and said no more.

en: ms Gardiner was standing a little behind; and on her pausing, he asked her if she would do him the honour of introducing him to her friends.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner stood behind her. When she stopped speaking, he asked if she could grant him the honor of being introduced to her companions.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner was standing a little behind; when Elizabeth paused, Mr. Darcy asked her to introduce him to her friends.
es: Mrs. Gardiner was coming a little behind, and Darcy took advantage of Elizabeth's silence to ask her to do him the honor of introducing him to her friends.

en: This was a stroke of civility for which she was quite unprepared; and she could hardly suppress a smile at his being now seeking the acquaintance of some of those very people, against whom his pride had revolted, in his offer to herself.
vi: This was a courtesy that completely surprised her, and she could hardly conceal a smile when she saw that he wanted to be acquainted with the very people who had stirred his pride.
tr: This was a gesture of courtesy for which Elizabeth was quite unprepared, and she could barely suppress a smile when she saw that he now wanted to be introduced to the same people whom his pride had previously rejected.
es: Elizabeth was not prepared for this gesture of courtesy, and she could not help but smile at seeing that he intended to meet one of those people against whom his pride had rebelled when he declared himself to her.

en: “What will be his surprise,” thought she, “when he knows who they are!
vi: She thought, "How surprised he will be when he knows who they are!"
tr: "How surprised he will be," she thought, "when he finds out who they are!
es: "What will his surprise be," she thought, "when he finds out who they are?

en: He takes them now for people of fashion.”
vi: He must think they are people of high society.
tr: He thinks they are from high society."
es: He imagines they are people of high rank."

en: The introduction, however, was immediately made; and as she named their relationship to herself, she stole a sly look at him, to see how he bore it; and was not without the expectation of his decamping as fast as he could from such disgraceful companions.
vi: However, she still introduced the two sides to each other. When she informed him about the relationship between the two people and herself, she cunningly watched his reaction, thinking he would flee as quickly as possible to avoid associating with such lowly individuals.
tr: However, the introduction was made immediately; while Elizabeth was explaining their kinship, she cast a furtive glance at Mr. Darcy's face to see how he would react; she did not entirely expect him to quickly distance himself from such lowly friends.
es: He made the introduction promptly and, upon mentioning the relationship, quickly glanced at Darcy to see his reaction, hoping he would hastily flee from such company.

en: That he was surprised by the connection was evident: he sustained it, however, with fortitude: and, so far from going away, turned back with them, and entered into conversation with mr Gardiner.
vi: Clearly, his face showed surprise, but he stubbornly suppressed it; instead of walking away, he turned to look at them and started a conversation with Mr. Gardiner.
tr: Mr. Darcy was clearly surprised by the kinship; nevertheless, he endured this information with composure, and instead of walking away, he turned to the other side with them and began conversing with Mr. Gardiner.
es: It was evident that Darcy was surprised, but he composed himself and instead of continuing on his way, he turned back with all of them and began conversing with Mr. Gardiner.

en: Elizabeth could not but be pleased, could not but triumph.
vi: Elizabeth couldn't help but feel a sense of satisfaction, a sense of victory.
tr: Elizabeth felt joy, she felt the intoxication of victory.
es: Elizabeth couldn't help but feel satisfied and triumphant.

en: It was consoling that he should know she had some relations for whom there was no need to blush.
vi: She found comfort in the fact that he should know she had relationships she was not ashamed of.
tr: It was reassuring to have relatives who were not disgraceful, and for Mr. Darcy to know this.
es: It was comforting that Darcy knew she had relatives of whom there was no need to be ashamed.

en: She listened most attentively to all that passed between them, and gloried in every expression, every sentence of her uncle, which marked his intelligence, his taste, or his good manners.
vi: She attentively listened to their exchange, delighted with every word her uncle spoke that demonstrated his intelligence, his taste, or his gentle demeanor.
tr: She listened to the conversation between them with great attention and took pride in every expression, every sentence of her uncle; he was showing himself to be an intelligent, tasteful, and cultured man.
es: She listened attentively to what they were saying and took pride in her uncle's phrases and remarks that demonstrated his intelligence, good taste, and excellent manners.

en: The conversation soon turned upon fishing; and she heard mr Darcy invite him, with the greatest civility, to fish there as often as he chose, while he continued in the neighbourhood, offering at the same time to supply him with fishing tackle, and pointing out those parts of the stream where there was usually most sport.
vi: The conversation shifted to the topic of fishing, and she heard Mr. Darcy, with utmost politeness, invite him to fish there whenever he wished, offering to lend him his fishing gear and pointing out the best spots.
tr: The conversation quickly turned to fishing; he heard that Mr. Darcy had very kindly invited him to fish as often as he wished while he was in the area, had also offered to give him fishing tackle, and had shown him the spots in the river where the catch was most abundant.
es: The conversation soon turned to fishing, and Elizabeth heard Darcy inviting her uncle to go fishing there whenever he wanted while they were in the neighboring town, even offering to provide him with gear and pointing out the best spots on the river for fishing.

en: ms Gardiner, who was walking arm in arm with Elizabeth, gave her a look expressive of her wonder.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner, walking hand in hand with Elizabeth, looked at her with astonishment.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner, walking arm in arm with Elizabeth, gave her a look of astonishment.
es: Mrs. Gardiner, who was walking arm in arm with Elizabeth, looked at her with an expression of disbelief.

en: Elizabeth said nothing, but it gratified her exceedingly; the compliment must be all for herself.
vi: Elizabeth said nothing, but felt extremely pleased; all good thoughts were for her.
tr: Elizabeth said nothing, but she was extremely proud of the situation; the compliment must have been entirely directed at her.
es: Elizabeth said nothing, but she was extremely pleased; Darcy's attentions must surely be directed at her.

en: Her astonishment, however, was extreme; and continually was she repeating, “Why is he so altered?
vi: However, she was utterly astonished, and kept wondering: "Why has he changed so much?
tr: Nevertheless, her astonishment was very great, and she kept repeating to herself, "Why has he changed so much?
es: Her astonishment, however, was extraordinary and she couldn't stop repeating to herself: "Why is he so changed?

en: From what can it proceed?
vi: Where did this come from?
tr: What can be inferred from this?
es: Her astonishment, however, was extraordinary and she couldn't stop repeating to herself: "Why is he so changed?

en: It cannot be for me, it cannot be for my sake that his manners are thus softened.
vi: It can't be because of me, it can't be for me that his attitude has become so gentle.
tr: The softening of his actions cannot be for me, it cannot be for my sake.
es: It can't be because of me, it can't be for my sake that his manners have softened so much.

en: My reproofs at Hunsford could not work such a change as this.
vi: My scolding him at Huntsford couldn't have made him change this much.
tr: My words at Hunsford cannot have caused such a change.
es: My reproaches in Hunsford cannot have effected such a transformation.

en: It is impossible that he should still love me.”
vi: There's no way he still loves me."
tr: It is impossible that he still loves me."
es: It's impossible that he still loves me."

en: After walking some time in this way, the two ladies in front, the two gentlemen behind, on resuming their places, after descending to the brink of the river for the better inspection of some curious water-plant, there chanced to be a little alteration.
vi: After having walked such a distance, with two women in front and two men behind, and as they went down near the riverbank to observe some strange aquatic plant, they wanted to make a slight change.
tr: Two ladies in front, two gentlemen behind, after walking this way for a while, there was a small change in the situation after descending to the riverbank to better examine a strange water plant.
es: After walking for a while in this manner, the two ladies in front and the two gentlemen behind, upon resuming their path after descending to the riverbank to get a better look at a curious aquatic plant, there was a change of pairs.

en: It originated in ms Gardiner, who, fatigued by the exercise of the morning, found Elizabeth’s arm inadequate to her support, and consequently preferred her husband’s.
vi: This was because Mrs. Gardiner, tired from the long distance, saw that Elizabeth could not support her, so she wanted to lean on her husband.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner, tired from the morning walk, did not get enough support from Elizabeth's arm and eventually preferred her husband's arm.
es: This was initiated by Mrs. Gardiner, who, fatigued by the day's exertions, found Elizabeth's arm too weak to support her and therefore preferred her husband's arm.

en: mr
vi: Mr. Darcy took Mrs. Gardiner's place, and they walked together.
tr: Mr. Darcy took his place beside his niece and they walked together.
es: This was initiated by Mrs. Gardiner, who, fatigued by the day's exertions, found Elizabeth's arm too weak to support her and therefore preferred her husband's arm.

en: Darcy took her place by her niece, and they walked on together.
vi: Mr. Darcy took Mrs. Gardiner's place, and they walked together.
tr: Mr. Darcy took his place beside his niece and they walked together.
es: Darcy then positioned himself beside the niece, and they continued their walk in this way.

en: After a short silence the lady first spoke.
vi: After a moment of silence, Elizabeth began to speak.
tr: After a short silence, Elizabeth spoke first.
es: After a short silence, Elizabeth spoke.

en: She wished him to know that she had been assured of his absence before she came to the place, and accordingly began by observing, that his arrival had been very unexpected—“for your housekeeper,” she added, “informed us that you would certainly not be here till to-morrow; and, indeed, before we left Bakewell, we understood that you were not immediately expected in the country.”
vi: She wanted him to understand clearly that she had heard he was absent before she came here, so she remarked that his return was completely unexpected. She continued: - Because your housekeeper assured us that you would definitely return tomorrow; and in fact, before we left Bakewell, we were informed that you would not return soon.
tr: She wanted him to know that she was sure he wasn't there before they arrived and said his arrival was very sudden – "your steward," she added, "said you wouldn't come before tomorrow; we even learned before leaving Bakewell that you wouldn't come to the village nearby."
es: She wanted to let him know that before going to Pemberley, she had made sure that he was not there and that their arrival was completely unexpected. ––Your housekeeper ––he added–– informed us that you wouldn't arrive until tomorrow; and even before leaving Bakewell, we were told that you would be delayed in returning to Derbyshire.

en: He acknowledged the truth of it all; and said that business with his steward had occasioned his coming forward a few hours before the rest of the party with whom he had been travelling.
vi: He accepted that she was sincere, because he had little work with the butler so he had to return earlier than his friends. He continued:
tr: Mr. Darcy confirmed these were true; he said his business with the steward caused him to arrive a few hours earlier than the rest of the group they traveled with.
es: Darcy acknowledged that it was so, but some matters he had to resolve with his steward had forced him to go ahead of his companions.

en: “They will join me early to-morrow,” he continued, “and among them are some who will claim an acquaintance with you,—mr Bingley and his sisters.”
vi: - They will come here tomorrow morning, among them are a few people you know – Mr. Bingley and his sisters.
tr: "They will join me early tomorrow," he continued, "and among them are those who know you, –Mr. Bingley and his sisters."
es: ––Tomorrow morning ––he continued–– they will all meet with me. Among them are your acquaintances who will wish to see you; Mr. Bingley and his sisters.

en: Elizabeth answered only by a slight bow.
vi: Elizabeth only responded with a slight nod.
tr: Elizabeth merely nodded slightly in response.
es: Elizabeth did nothing more than a slight nod of her head.

en: Her thoughts were instantly driven back to the time when mr Bingley’s name had been last mentioned between them; and if she might judge from his complexion, his mind was not very differently engaged.
vi: Her thoughts flashed back to the time, that day, when the two of them mentioned Mr. Bingley's name, and if she guessed correctly from his expression, he was having the same thought.
tr: Her thoughts suddenly returned to the last time Mr. Bingley's name was mentioned among them; from what she could tell from his face, Mr. Darcy's mind was not occupied with anything very different.
es: She instantly remembered the last time Bingley's name had been mentioned between them, and judging by Darcy's expression, he must have been thinking the same thing.

en: “There is also one other person in the party,” he continued after a pause, “who more particularly wishes to be known to you.
vi: He continued after a moment of silence: - There is someone else in the group who wants to get to know you.
tr: "There is one more person in the group," he continued after pausing, "who particularly wants to meet you.
es: ––A person who has a special desire to meet you is also coming with his friends ––he continued after a pause––.

en: Will you allow me, or do I ask too much, to introduce my sister to your acquaintance during your stay at Lambton?”
vi: Would it be possible for you to allow me, if I am not asking too much, to introduce my sister to you during your stay in Lambton?
tr: –While staying in Lambton, would you allow me to introduce my sister to you, or am I asking too much?"
es: Will you allow me, or is it asking too much, to introduce my sister to you while you are in Lambton?

en: The surprise of such an application was great indeed; it was too great for her to know in what manner she acceded to it.
vi: She was surprised again, to the point that she did not know how to respond affirmatively.
tr: The astonishment caused by this request was great; he felt a tremendous desire to know how he had attained this privilege.
es: Elizabeth was left speechless.

en: She immediately felt that whatever desire Miss Darcy might have of being acquainted with her, must be the work of her brother, and without looking farther, it was satisfactory; it was gratifying to know that his resentment had not made him think really ill of her.
vi: She immediately thought that any desire of Miss Darcy to get acquainted with her must have been orchestrated by her brother. It was quite encouraging to know that although he was upset with her, he did not actually think ill of her.
tr: He immediately sensed that Miss Darcy's desire to meet him must have been the result of her brother's words, and without looking further, he found this explanation sufficient; it was pleasing to see that his resentment had not led him to think ill of Elizabeth.
es: She could not imagine how Miss Darcy could intend such a thing; but she immediately understood that this desire was her brother's doing, and without drawing any further conclusions, it seemed very flattering to her. It was pleasant to know that Darcy did not hold a grudge against her.

en: They now walked on in silence; each of them deep in thought.
vi: Two people walked in silence, each immersed in their own thoughts.
tr: Now they were walking silently, each deep in thought.
es: They continued walking in silence, both deeply absorbed in their thoughts.

en: Elizabeth was not comfortable; that was impossible; but she was flattered and pleased.
vi: Elizabeth was uncomfortable, as it could not be otherwise, but she felt smug and pleased.
tr: Elizabeth was not comfortable; it was impossible; but her pride was flattered, she was happy.
es: Elizabeth could not be calm, but she felt flattered and pleased.

en: His wish of introducing his sister to her was a compliment of the highest kind.
vi: His intention to introduce his sister to her was the best thing he could offer her.
tr: The desire to introduce his sister to her was the highest form of compliment.
es: Darcy's intention to introduce her to his sister was an exceptional kindness.

en: They soon outstripped the others; and when they had reached the carriage, mr and ms Gardiner were half a quarter of a mile behind.
vi: They walked faster than the other two, and by the time they reached the carriage, the couple was still a quarter of a mile away.
tr: They quickly left the others behind; by the time they reached the carriage, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were a quarter mile behind.
es: Soon they left the others behind, and when they reached the carriage, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were half a quarter of a mile away from them.

en: He then asked her to walk into the house—but she declared herself not tired, and they stood together on the lawn.
vi: Then he invited her into the house, but she said she did not feel tired, and they stood together on the lawn.
tr: Then Mr. Darcy invited her to the house – but Elizabeth, saying she was not tired, declined the offer; they stood together on the lawn.
es: Darcy then invited her to come into the house, but Elizabeth declared that she was not tired and they waited together on the lawn.

en: At such a time much might have been said, and silence was very awkward.
vi: At this moment, many things could have been said, while silence caused awkwardness.
tr: Much could have been said at such a time, and the silence was very strange.
es: In that moment they could have talked about many things, the silence was awkward.

en: She wanted to talk, but there seemed an embargo on every subject.
vi: She wanted to speak, but seemed unable to find a topic.
tr: Elizabeth wanted to speak, but it was as if every topic was forbidden.
es: She wanted to speak but her mind was blank and all the topics that came to her seemed to be off-limits.

en: At last she recollected that she had been travelling, and they talked of Matlock and Dovedale with great perseverance.
vi: Finally, she remembered that she was on a tour, so they ended up talking about the sights.
tr: Finally, she remembered that they were traveling; with great effort, they talked about Matlock and Dove Dale.
es: Finally, she remembered her trip and spoke about Matlock and Dove Dale with great perseverance.

en: Yet time and her aunt moved slowly—and her patience and her ideas were nearly worn out before the tête-à-tête was over.
vi: However, time and her aunt moved slowly, and her patience and ideas were nearly exhausted before the encounter ended.
tr: But both time and her aunt were progressing slowly – her patience and ideas were nearly exhausted when their tête-à-tête ended.
es: Time passed, her aunt walked very slowly, and Elizabeth's patience and ideas were running out before the tête-à-tête ended.

en: On mr and ms Gardiner’s coming up they were all pressed to go into the house and take some refreshment; but this was declined, and they parted on each side with the utmost politeness.
vi: When Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner arrived, he earnestly invited the three of them into the house for refreshments, but they declined. They parted with utmost politeness.
tr: Upon the arrival of Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, they were all invited to the house for some refreshments, but this offer was declined; both parties bid farewell very politely.
es: When Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner arrived, Darcy invited them all to come into the house and have some refreshments; but they excused themselves and parted with the utmost courtesy.

en: mr Darcy handed the ladies into the carriage; and when it drove off, Elizabeth saw him walking slowly towards the house.
vi: Mr. Darcy helped the two women into the carriage; and as it rolled away, Elizabeth saw him walking slowly back into the house.
tr: Mr. Darcy helped the ladies into the carriage, and as it moved away, Elizabeth saw him walking slowly back towards the house.
es: Darcy accompanied them to the carriage, and when it started moving, Elizabeth saw him walking slowly back towards the house.

en: The observations of her uncle and aunt now began; and each of them pronounced him to be infinitely superior to anything they had expected.
vi: Uncle and aunt now began their comments; each said that he was certainly much better than they had initially thought.
tr: Then her uncle and aunt's observations began; both said they found her far superior to what they had expected.
es: Then the uncles began their comments; both declared that Darcy was superior to anything that could be imagined.

en: “He is perfectly well-behaved, polite, and unassuming,” said her uncle.
vi: Uncle said: - He is truly a modest, polite, and unpretentious person.
tr: "Extremely polite, kind, humble," said her uncle.
es: ––Her education is perfect and her elegance and simplicity are admirable ––said her uncle.

en: “There is something a little stately in him, to be sure,” replied her aunt; “but it is confined to his air, and is not unbecoming.
vi: The aunt replied: - There is certainly something dignified about him, but it is in a form that is not excessive.
tr: "Of course, there's a slightly pretentious side to her," replied her aunt, "but it's just about her demeanor and it doesn't look bad on her, to be honest.
es: ––There is a bit of arrogance in him ––added the aunt, but only in his demeanor, and it doesn't look bad on him.

en: I can now say with the housekeeper, that though some people may call him proud, I have seen nothing of it.”
vi: Now I agree with the housekeeper that although some people may think he is proud, I don't see it at all.
tr: Now I agree with the steward, some call her proud but I haven't seen a trace of it."
es: I can say, like the housekeeper, that although he is labeled as proud, it is not noticeable at all.

en: “I was never more surprised than by his behaviour to us.
vi: - I have never been so surprised by his manner.
tr: "What surprised me the most was his behavior towards us.
es: ––His attitude towards us has left me astonished.

en: It was more than civil; it was really attentive; and there was no necessity for such attention.
vi: More than politeness, it was attentiveness; such concern was unnecessary.
tr: There was more than just politeness; he was genuinely interested, which was more attention than necessary.
es: He has been more than courteous, he has been frankly attentive and nothing obliged him to be so.

en: His acquaintance with Elizabeth was very trifling.”
vi: He and Elizabeth were only very casually acquainted.
tr: He had a superficial acquaintance with Elizabeth."
es: His friendship with Elizabeth was very superficial.

en: “To be sure, Lizzy,” said her aunt, “he is not so handsome as Wickham; or rather he has not Wickham’s countenance, for his features are perfectly good.
vi: Auntie said: - Lizzy, it's true that I am not as handsome as Wickham; or in other words, I don't have Wickham's face, because my figure is perfect.
tr: "Indeed, Lizzy," said her aunt, "he is not as handsome as Wickham; or rather, he lacks Wickham's charm, otherwise his features are perfect.
es: ––Of course, he is not as handsome as Wickham ––replied the aunt––; or rather, he is not as well-built, but his features are perfect.

en: But how came you to tell us that he was so disagreeable?”
vi: But why do you say that he is very unpleasant?
tr: But what made you tell us he was such a disagreeable person?"
es: How could you tell us he was so unpleasant, Lizzy?

en: Elizabeth excused herself as well as she could: said that she had liked him better when they met in Kent than before, and that she had never seen him so pleasant as this morning.
vi: Elizabeth tried to justify herself; she said that she liked him more when they met in Kent than before; and that she had never found him as pleasant as this morning.
tr: Elizabeth tried her best to excuse herself; she said that she liked him more than before when they met in Kent, and that he had never seemed as charming as he did that morning.
es: Elizabeth apologized as best she could; she said that upon seeing him in Kent, she had liked him more than before and had never found him as agreeable as that morning.

en: “But perhaps he may be a little whimsical in his civilities,” replied her uncle.
vi: Uncle answered: - But perhaps he has a somewhat erratic nature when it comes to politeness.
tr: "But maybe his politeness is a bit of a coincidence," his uncle replied.
es: ––He might be a bit whimsical in his courtesy ––replied the uncle––; those very haughty gentlemen tend to be like that.

en: “Your great men often are; and therefore I shall not take him at his word about fishing, as he might change his mind another day, and warn me off his grounds.”
vi: All of your friends are like that, so you wouldn't truly believe his invitation to go fishing, because one day he might change his mind and forbid you from coming near.
tr: "Great men are like that; so I won't take his words about fishing seriously, because he might forget what he said and fire me the day after tomorrow."
es: That's why I won't take his word regarding the fishing, in case he changes his mind another day and throws me off the estate.

en: Elizabeth felt that they had entirely mistaken his character, but said nothing.
vi: Elizabeth thought the couple were completely mistaken about his character, but she remained silent.
tr: She felt that they were completely wrong about Elizabeth's character, but she said nothing.
es: Elizabeth realized that they were completely wrong about her character, but she said nothing.

en: “From what we have seen of him,” continued ms Gardiner, “I really should not have thought that he could have behaved in so cruel a way by anybody as he has done by poor Wickham.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner continued: - From what we see, honestly, you shouldn't have thought he could behave cruelly towards anyone, as Wickham said.
tr: "As far as we can see," continued Mrs. Gardiner, "I can't imagine anyone treating poor Wickham as cruelly as he did.
es: ––After having seen him now, I would never have believed that he could behave as badly as he did with Wickham ––continued Mrs. Gardiner––, he doesn't seem heartless.

en: He has not an ill-natured look.
vi: He doesn't look like a bad person.
tr: He doesn't have the appearance of a bad-hearted person.
es: On the contrary, he has a very pleasant expression when he speaks.

en: On the contrary, there is something pleasing about his mouth when he speaks.
vi: On the contrary, there is something pleasant in his words.
tr: On the contrary, when he speaks, a pleasant air emanates from his words.
es: On the contrary, he has a very pleasant expression when he speaks.

en: And there is something of dignity in his countenance, that would not give one an unfavourable idea of his heart.
vi: And there is a certain dignity in his face that does not indicate he has a bad heart.
tr: There is such nobility in his face that one cannot think there could be evil in his heart.
es: And there is also a dignity in his face that would make no one think he doesn't have a good heart.

en: But, to be sure, the good lady who showed us the house did give him a most flaming character!
vi: But surely the lady who took us to see the house spoke very highly of him!
tr: But of course, the lovely woman showing us the house exaggerated him a lot!
es: But, to tell the truth, the good woman who showed us the house exaggerated his character a bit.

en: I could hardly help laughing aloud sometimes.
vi: At times, you almost couldn't help but laugh.
tr: At one point, I held myself back from laughing.
es: There were times when I almost burst out laughing.

en: But he is a liberal master, I suppose, and that, in the eye of a servant, comprehends every virtue.”
vi: But I think he is a generous master, and this, in the eyes of a servant, is enough to encompass all virtues.
tr: But he must be a generous master for his servant to think he possesses every virtue."
es: The thing is, he must be a very generous master and that, in the eyes of a servant, equals all virtues.

en: Elizabeth here felt herself called on to say something in vindication of his behaviour to Wickham; and, therefore, gave them to understand, in as guarded a manner as she could, that by what she had heard from his relations in Kent, his actions were capable of a very different construction; and that his character was by no means so faulty, nor Wickham’s so amiable, as they had been considered in Hertfordshire.
vi: Elizabeth felt the need to say something to vindicate his attitude towards Wickham. In the most cautious words possible, she explained to them that from what she had heard from his relatives in Kent, his actions could be explained differently, that his character was not as flawed as they thought, and that Wickham was not as amiable as the people in Hertfordshire believed.
tr: Elizabeth felt the need to say something corrective about her behavior towards Wickham and, as limited as possible, told them that, according to what she had heard from relatives in Kent, his actions were open to a very different interpretation, his character was not at all flawed, and on the other hand, Wickham was not as good as they thought in Hertfordshire.
es: Upon hearing this, Elizabeth believed she should say something in defense of Darcy's conduct with Wickham. With all the care she could muster, she tried to hint that, based on what she had heard from her relatives in Kent, his actions could be interpreted very differently, and that neither his character was as bad nor Wickham's as good as had been believed in Hertfordshire.

en: In confirmation of this, she related the particulars of all the pecuniary transactions in which they had been connected, without actually naming her authority, but stating it to be such as might be relied on.
vi: To confirm this, she recounted all the details of the strange relations between the two young men without specifying who said what, only indicating that these events could be trusted.
tr: To confirm this, without specifying the source but stating that it was reliable, she explained all the details of the financial transactions that concerned them all.
es: To confirm what she had said, she recounted the details of all the financial transactions that had taken place between them, without mentioning how she had come to know them, but asserting that it was strictly true.

en: ms Gardiner was surprised and concerned: but as they were now approaching the scene of her former pleasures, every idea gave way to the charm of recollection; and she was too much engaged in pointing out to her husband all the interesting spots in its environs, to think of anything else.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner felt surprised and concerned, but when she arrived at the scene she had enjoyed in the past, all thoughts gave way to enchanting memories, and she was too busy pointing out interesting spots in the area to her husband to think of anything else.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner was surprised and worried; but as they approached the places of her old happy days, these thoughts gave way to the charm of memories; she became so engrossed in pointing out the interesting places in the vicinity to her husband that she couldn't think of anything else.
es: Mrs. Gardiner was surprised and curious about the topic, but as they were approaching the scene of her former pleasures, she yielded to the charm of her memories and only pointed out to her husband all the interesting places and their surroundings.

en: Fatigued as she had been by the morning’s walk, they had no sooner dined than she set off again in quest of her former acquaintance, and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of an intercourse renewed after many years’ discontinuance.
vi: Although tired from the morning walk, after dinner she visited old acquaintances, and she was pleased with the relationships rekindled after many years of interruption.
tr: Although she was tired from the morning walk, she immediately set out to search for old acquaintances as soon as the meal was over; the evening passed in the pleasure of a relationship renewed after a long separation.
es: Despite being tired from the morning walk, as soon as they had dinner, they went out in search of old acquaintances, and the evening passed with the satisfaction of relationships renewed after many years of interruption.
