en: The occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave Elizabeth much attention for any of these new friends; and she could do nothing but think, and think with wonder, of mr Darcy’s civility, and, above all, of his wishing her to be acquainted with his sister.
vi: The events of the day occupied Elizabeth's mind entirely, so she could do nothing but think, and think with amazement, about Mr. Darcy's courteous behavior, especially about his desire for her to become acquainted with his sister.
tr: The events of that day were so intriguing to Elizabeth that she could not focus on these new friends; she could not stop thinking about Mr. Darcy's politeness and, most of all, his desire to introduce her to his sister, and she was astonished by it.
es: The events of that day had been too overwhelming for Elizabeth to pay much attention to any of those new friends, and she could only think with admiration of Darcy's kindnesses, and especially of his desire for her to meet his sister.

en: CHAPTER XLIV.
vi: Chapter 44
tr: Chapter II
es: CHAPTER XLIV

en: ELIZABETH had settled it that mr Darcy would bring his sister to visit her the very day after her reaching Pemberley; and was, consequently, resolved not to be out of sight of the inn the whole of that morning.
vi: Elizabeth guessed that Mr. Darcy would bring his sister to visit her on the very day she arrived at Pemberley, so she planned not to stray far from the inn that entire morning.
tr: Elizabeth had arranged for Mr. Darcy to bring his sister to visit the day after they arrived at Pemberley; therefore, she decided not to leave the inn's vicinity throughout the morning.
es: Elizabeth had calculated that Darcy would bring his sister to visit her the day after their arrival at Pemberley, and consequently, she resolved not to lose sight of the inn all that morning.

en: But her conclusion was false; for on the very morning after their own arrival at Lambton these visitors came.
vi: But she was mistaken, for the very morning after they arrived in Lambton, their two guests came.
tr: But her assumption was wrong; because these visitors came the morning after they themselves arrived in Lambton.
es: But she was mistaken, for she received the visit the very day they arrived.

en: They had been walking about the place with some of their new friends, and were just returned to the inn to dress themselves for dining with the same family, when the sound of a carriage drew them to a window, and they saw a gentleman and lady in a curricle driving up the street.
vi: The three had strolled around the area with a few new friends; just as they returned to the inn to change clothes for a meal with these friends' family, they heard the sound of a carriage, and through the window, they saw a man and a woman driving a two-wheeled carriage along the road.
tr: They were touring the surroundings with some of their new friends; they had returned to the inn to change their clothes to go dine with the same family when they heard the sound of a carriage and went to the window; they saw a gentleman and a lady coming up the street in an open carriage.
es: The Gardiners and Elizabeth had been walking around the town with some of their new friends, and were returning at that moment to the inn to dress and go to lunch with them, when the noise of a carriage made them look out the window and they saw a gentleman and a young lady in a cabriolet coming up the street.

en: Elizabeth, immediately recognizing the livery, guessed what it meant, and imparted no small degree of surprise to her relations, by acquainting them with the honour which she expected.
vi: Immediately, Elizabeth recognized the noble attire, expressing her surprise to her uncle and aunt about the honor their guests were bestowing upon her.
tr: Elizabeth immediately recognized the coachman's uniform, guessed its meaning, and surprised her relatives just as much by announcing the expected visit.
es: Elizabeth instantly recognized the livery of the footmen, guessed what it meant, and left her uncles astonished by informing them of the honor that awaited them.

en: Her uncle and aunt were all amazement; and the embarrassment of her manner as she spoke, joined to the circumstance itself, and many of the circumstances of the preceding day, opened to them a new idea on the business.
vi: The uncle and aunt were equally astonished. The awkwardness when she spoke to them, combined with the current situation and many past situations, led them to a new thought.
tr: Her uncle and aunt were astonished; their discomfort in their movements while speaking, combined with the situation itself and the events of the previous day, sparked a new idea about the matter in their minds.
es: They were frightened; that visit, Elizabeth's bewilderment, and the circumstances of the previous day made them form a new idea of the matter.

en: Nothing had ever suggested it before, but they now felt that there was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such a quarter than by supposing a partiality for their niece.
vi: Nothing had been said about this before, but now they thought there was no other way to explain such attentions from the upper class, except for the affection they had for their niece.
tr: Nothing had suggested this possibility before, but now they felt that the only explanation for such attention from such a place could be an interest in their niece.
es: There had been nothing to suggest it before, but now they realized that there was no other way to explain Darcy's attentions than by supposing him interested in their niece.

en: While these newly-born notions were passing in their heads, the perturbation of Elizabeth’s feelings was every moment increasing.
vi: While these ideas passed through their minds, Elizabeth's state of anxiety grew higher and higher.
tr: As these new thoughts passed through their minds, the confusion of Elizabeth's feelings increased every moment.
es: While they were thinking about all this, Elizabeth's agitation increased by the moment.

en: She was quite amazed at her own discomposure; but, amongst other causes of disquiet, she dreaded lest the partiality of the brother should have said too much in her favour; and, more than commonly anxious to please, she naturally suspected that every power of pleasing would fail her.
vi: She found it strange that she was losing her composure, but among the reasons for her agitation, she feared that his feelings for her might have spoken too highly of her to his sister. More than the anxiety of wanting to please, she feared that she no longer had the ability to please anyone at all.
tr: She was surprised at her own agitation; but among other reasons for discomfort, she most feared that the brother had praised her too much; she wanted to appear pleasing, but she was afraid that nothing she did would be enough to achieve that.
es: She was alarmed by her own bewilderment, and among the other causes of her unease was the idea that Darcy, in his enthusiasm, might have spoken of her to his sister with too much praise. She wanted to please more than ever, but suspected that she would not be able to achieve it.

en: She retreated from the window, fearful of being seen; and as she walked up and down the room, endeavouring to compose herself, saw such looks of inquiring surprise in her uncle and aunt as made everything worse.
vi: She stepped away from the window, afraid of being seen; and as she paced back and forth in the room trying to stay calm, she saw the surprised looks of her uncle and aunt, which made her even more agitated.
tr: He pulled back from the window, afraid of being seen; while trying to compose himself, he saw the bewildered looks filled with questions from his uncle and aunt, and his task became even more difficult.
es: She withdrew from the window for fear of being seen, and, while pacing back and forth in the room, the questioning looks from her uncles made her even more nervous.

en: Miss Darcy and her brother appeared, and this formidable introduction took place.
vi: Miss Darcy and her brother appeared, and the introduction – the dreadful introduction in her mind – took place.
tr: Miss Darcy and her brother arrived, and the intimidating introduction took place.
es: Finally, Miss Darcy and her brother appeared, and the grand introduction took place.

en: With astonishment did Elizabeth see that her new acquaintance was at least as much embarrassed as herself.
vi: Elizabeth was surprised to notice that the younger sister was just as flustered as she was.
tr: Elizabeth was surprised to see that her new acquaintance was at least as uncomfortable as she was.
es: Elizabeth noticed with astonishment that her new acquaintance was at least as disturbed as she was.

en: Since her being at Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was exceedingly proud; but the observation of a very few minutes convinced her that she was only exceedingly shy.
vi: Since arriving in Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was extremely proud, but after only a few minutes of observation, Elizabeth was convinced that she was merely excessively shy.
tr: Since coming to Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was extremely proud; but a few minutes of observation convinced her that she was extremely shy.
es: Since arriving in Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was extremely proud, but after observing her for a few minutes, she was convinced that she was only extremely shy.

en: She found it difficult to obtain even a word from her beyond a monosyllable.
vi: The younger sister could hardly complete a sentence, only uttering a few short words.
tr: It was difficult to get a single word out of her, except for monosyllables.
es: She could hardly get a word out of her, except for a few monosyllables.

en: Miss Darcy was tall, and on a larger scale than Elizabeth; and, though little more than sixteen, her figure was formed, and her appearance womanly and graceful.
vi: Miss Darcy is tall and somewhat larger than Elizabeth. Although she is just over sixteen, she already has the figure of a graceful and mature woman.
tr: Miss Darcy was tall, larger than Elizabeth; although she was only sixteen, she had matured well; her appearance was feminine and graceful.
es: Miss Darcy was taller than Elizabeth and, although she was only sixteen years old, her body was already developed and her appearance was very feminine and graceful.

en: She was less handsome than her brother, but there was sense and good-humour in her face, and her manners were perfectly unassuming and gentle.
vi: She is not as handsome as her brother, but her face shows a sense of propriety and cheerfulness, and her demeanor is entirely gentle and unpretentious.
tr: She was not as beautiful as her brother, but there was sensitivity and kindness in her face; her manners were modest and polite.
es: She was not as beautiful as her brother, but her face revealed intelligence and good character, and her manners were very simple and gentle.

en: Elizabeth, who had expected to find in her as acute and unembarrassed an observer as ever mr Darcy had been, was much relieved by discerning such different feelings.
vi: Previously, Elizabeth had thought she might be someone with keen and sharp observational skills, but now she felt relieved to realize the opposite.
tr: Elizabeth, who expected to find in her as sharp and bold an observer as Mr. Darcy, was quite relieved to distinguish such different feelings.
es: Elizabeth, who had feared that she might be as sharp and outgoing an observer as Darcy, felt great relief to see how different she was.

en: They had not been long together before Darcy told her that Bingley was also coming to wait on her; and she had barely time to express her satisfaction, and prepare for such a visitor, when Bingley’s quick step was heard on the stairs, and in a moment he entered the room.
vi: They only managed to exchange a few words when Darcy informed her that Bingley was also coming to visit her. Before she had time to express her joy and prepare for the new guest, she heard footsteps coming up the stairs, and then he entered.
tr: It hadn't been long since they had come together when Darcy told her that Bingley would also be visiting her; and before Elizabeth could express her pleasure and prepare herself for such a visitor, Bingley's quick steps were heard on the stairs, and in a moment he entered the room.
es: They had been conversing for only a short while when Darcy told Elizabeth that Bingley would also be coming to visit her, and she had barely had time to express her satisfaction and prepare to receive him when they heard Bingley's hurried steps on the stairs, and he immediately entered the room.

en: All Elizabeth’s anger against him had been long done away; but had she still felt any, it could hardly have stood its ground against the unaffected cordiality with which he expressed himself on seeing her again.
vi: All of Elizabeth's anger towards him had long since dissipated, but now, even if any remnants remained, they completely vanished due to his friendly and unpretentious demeanor when he met her again.
tr: Elizabeth's anger towards him had long passed; but if any remained, it vanished in the face of Bingley's humble closeness as he expressed how delighted he was to see her again.
es: All of Elizabeth's indignation against him had long since disappeared, but if any resentment had remained, she could not have resisted the frank cordiality that Bingley showed her upon seeing her again.

en: He inquired in a friendly, though general, way, after her family, and looked and spoke with the same good-humoured ease that he had ever done.
vi: He inquired warmly, though generally, about her family's health, looking and speaking with the same natural and cheerful manner as before.
tr: In a friendly but impartial manner, he inquired about her family's health and moved and spoke with his usual cheerful ease.
es: He inquired about her family in a caring, albeit general, manner, and behaved and spoke with his usual good humor.

en: To mr and ms Gardiner he was scarcely a less interesting personage than to herself.
vi: For Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, Mr. Bingley was a character worth paying attention to just as much as their niece.
tr: He was just as interesting to Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner.
es: The Gardiners welcomed Bingley with the same interest as Elizabeth.

en: They had long wished to see him.
vi: They had long wanted to meet him.
tr: They had wanted to see him for some time.
es: They had long wanted to meet him.

en: The whole party before them, indeed, excited a lively attention.
vi: In fact, the entire group of guests before them had sparked lively attention.
tr: The entire group in front of them was exciting.
es: In truth, all those present inspired the liveliest curiosity in them.

en: The suspicions which had just arisen of mr Darcy and their niece, directed their observation towards each with an earnest, though guarded, inquiry; and they soon drew from those inquiries the full conviction that one of them at least knew what it was to love.
vi: Their suspicions about Mr. Darcy and their niece directed their attention to each guest with eager yet cautious inquiries, and soon from these inquiries, they were convinced that at least one of the two knew what love was.
tr: The doubts they had just heard about Mr. Darcy and his nieces directed their attention to the two with curious but covert scrutiny; soon they concluded from their observation that at least one of them knew what love was.
es: The suspicions they had just conceived about Darcy and his niece led them to focus their attention on them, examining them closely, though discreetly, and very soon they realized that at least one of them was very much in love.

en: Of the lady’s sensations they remained a little in doubt; but that the gentleman was overflowing with admiration was evident enough.
vi: They had doubts about their niece's feelings, but it was clear to them that the other was overflowing with affection.
tr: They had little doubt about the girl's feelings; but the boy was evidently burning with admiration.
es: Elizabeth's feelings were somewhat doubtful, but it was evident that Darcy was overflowing with admiration in every way.

en: Elizabeth, on her side, had much to do.
vi: As for Elizabeth, she had many things to do.
tr: Elizabeth had a lot to do on her own behalf.
es: Elizabeth, for her part, had a lot to do.

en: She wanted to ascertain the feelings of each of her visitors, she wanted to compose her own, and to make herself agreeable to all; and in the latter object, where she feared most to fail, she was most sure of success, for those to whom she endeavoured to give pleasure were pre-possessed in her favour.
vi: She wanted to understand the thoughts of each guest, she wanted to remain calm, and she wanted to appear pleasant to everyone. Regarding the last task, which she feared failing the most, she was confident she would succeed, because everyone she wanted to please had a favorable opinion of her.
tr: She wanted to be sure of the feelings of each of her guests, to calm her own mood, and to make herself appear charming to everyone; the chance of success for her second goal, which she feared she would fail at most, was certain because the people she was trying to please were already on her side.
es: She had to guess the feelings of each of her visitors and at the same time had to contain her own and make herself pleasant to everyone. It is true that the last part, which was what scared her the most, was what she could achieve most confidently, as the interested parties were already very predisposed in her favor.

en: Bingley was ready, Georgiana was eager, and Darcy determined, to be pleased.
vi: Bingley was willing, Georgiana was eager, and Darcy was intentionally pleased.
tr: Bingley was ready, Georgiana was willing, and Darcy was determined to be pleased.
es: Bingley was ready, Georgiana desired it, and Darcy was completely decided.

en: “To make herself agreeable to all”
vi: When she met Mr. Bingley again, her thoughts naturally turned to her sister, and she was eager to know what was on his mind.
tr: Upon seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally turned to her sister; oh, how she wished she knew if his thoughts were directed to the same place!
es: Upon seeing Bingley, Elizabeth's thoughts naturally flew to her sister, and she diligently observed whether any of his thoughts were going in the same direction.

en: In seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally flew to her sister; and oh!
vi: When she met Mr. Bingley again, her thoughts naturally turned to her sister, and she was eager to know what was on his mind.
tr: Upon seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally turned to her sister; oh, how she wished she knew if his thoughts were directed to the same place!
es: Upon seeing Bingley, Elizabeth's thoughts naturally flew to her sister, and she diligently observed whether any of his thoughts were going in the same direction.

en: how ardently did she long to know whether any of his were directed in a like manner.
vi: When she met Mr. Bingley again, her thoughts naturally turned to her sister, and she was eager to know what was on his mind.
tr: Upon seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally turned to her sister; oh, how she wished she knew if his thoughts were directed to the same place!
es: Upon seeing Bingley, Elizabeth's thoughts naturally flew to her sister, and she diligently observed whether any of his thoughts were going in the same direction.

en: Sometimes she could fancy that he talked less than on former occasions, and once or twice pleased herself with the notion that, as he looked at her, he was trying to trace a resemblance.
vi: Sometimes she imagined that he was less talkative than in previous encounters, and occasionally she was pleased to notice that when he looked at her, he was searching for similarities between the two sisters.
tr: Sometimes it seemed to her that Bingley spoke less than he used to; indeed, once or twice she was delighted by the thought that he was trying to find traces of resemblance while looking at her.
es: She deluded herself into thinking that he spoke less than on other occasions, and once or twice she took pleasure in the idea that, when he looked at her, Bingley was trying to find a resemblance.

en: But, though this might be imaginary, she could not be deceived as to his behaviour to Miss Darcy, who had been set up as a rival to Jane.
vi: But, although this might have been mere imagination, she could not be deceived by his attitude towards Miss Darcy, who had been presented as Jane's rival.
tr: These could be mere figments of her imagination, but she could not be mistaken about his behavior towards Miss Darcy, who was set up as a rival to Jane.
es: But, even if all that were just her fantasies, she could not be mistaken about his behavior towards Miss Darcy, who had been spoken of as Jane's presumed rival.

en: No look appeared on either side that spoke particular regard.
vi: Neither of them showed any signs of affection.
tr: Neither party's looks indicated any special interest.
es: She did not notice a single glance from either of them that could justify the hopes of Bingley's sister.

en: Nothing occurred between them that could justify the hopes of his sister.
vi: Nothing occurred between the two that could justify Miss Darcy's hopes.
tr: There was nothing between them that could justify her sisters' hopes.
es: She did not notice a single glance from either of them that could justify the hopes of Bingley's sister.

en: On this point she was soon satisfied; and two or three little circumstances occurred ere they parted, which, in her anxious interpretation, denoted a recollection of Jane, not untinctured by tenderness, and a wish of saying more that might lead to the mention of her, had he dared.
vi: She felt immediately satisfied on this point, and there were a few small incidents before they parted, which, in her eager interpretation, indicated that he had fleeting recollections of Jane, marked by a gentle demeanor and a desire to inquire further about something that might lead to mentioning Jane, if he dared.
tr: She was quickly satisfied on this point; indeed, before their departure, there were a few small incidents which, according to Elizabeth's eager interpretation, showed that he remembered Jane and wanted to say something more that could lead to her being mentioned, but did not dare to.
es: Regarding this matter, she was completely satisfied. Before they left, she still noticed from two or three small details that Bingley remembered Jane tenderly and seemed to want to say something more but did not dare.

en: He observed to her, at a moment when the others were talking together, and in a tone which had something of real regret, that it “was a very long time since he had had the pleasure of seeing her;” and, before she could reply, he added, “It is above eight months.
vi: While the others were conversing, he spoke to her in a voice tinged with regret, saying that it had been a long time since he last saw Jane, and before she could respond, he added that it had been over eight months since the 26th of October when they danced together at Netherfield.
tr: At a moment when the others were talking among themselves, he said to Elizabeth in a voice filled with genuine regret, "It has been a very long time since I had the pleasure of seeing her;" and before Elizabeth could respond, he added, "It has been over eight months.
es: At a moment when the others were conversing, he said it in a sorrowful tone: ––How long it has been since I had the pleasure of seeing you! And, before Elizabeth had time to respond, he added: ––About eight months ago.

en: We have not met since the 26th of November, when we were all dancing together at Netherfield.”
vi: While the others were conversing, he spoke to her in a voice tinged with regret, saying that it had been a long time since he last saw Jane, and before she could respond, he added that it had been over eight months since the 26th of October when they danced together at Netherfield.
tr: We have not met since the 26th of November, the day we danced at Netherfield."
es: We hadn't seen each other since the twenty-sixth of November when we all danced together at Netherfield.

en: Elizabeth was pleased to find his memory so exact; and he afterwards took occasion to ask her, when unattended to by any of the rest, whether all her sisters were at Longbourn.
vi: Elizabeth was pleased to see that his memory was so accurate, and then taking advantage of the opportunity when no one was standing next to them, he asked her if all her sisters were at Longbourn.
tr: Elizabeth was pleased to see that her memory was so strong; later, finding an opportunity when the others were not around, she asked if all her sisters were at Longbourn.
es: Elizabeth was glad to see that her memory did not fail her. Then, taking advantage of the others being distracted, she asked him if all his sisters were at Longbourn.

en: There was not much in the question, nor in the preceding remark; but there was a look and a manner which gave them meaning.
vi: The question was not much, just like the previous one, but with an attitude and gesture that conveyed some meaning.
tr: There was nothing much in the question, nor in the answer that came, but there was a look and a manner that gave them meaning.
es: Neither the question nor the previous memory were important, but Bingley's look and gesture were very significant.

en: It was not often that she could turn her eyes on mr Darcy himself; but whenever she did catch a glimpse she saw an expression of general complaisance, and in all that he said, she heard an accent so far removed from hauteur or disdain of his companions, as convinced her that the improvement of manners which she had yesterday witnessed, however temporary its existence might prove, had at least outlived one day.
vi: She did not often look at Mr. Darcy, but whenever she glanced at him, she always noticed a kind demeanor, and in every word he spoke, she detected a tone that no longer seemed arrogant or disdainful. This convinced her that the improvement in his character, which she had noticed before, had lasted for more than just two days.
tr: She could not often turn her eyes towards Mr. Darcy; but whenever she did catch a glimpse of him, she saw a general expression of politeness, and in everything he said, she heard a tone of voice that was far removed from arrogance or disdain towards his companions, which convinced her that the improvement in his behavior she had witnessed yesterday, even if temporary, had lasted for more than just a day.
es: Elizabeth did not look at Darcy very often; but when she did, she saw in him an expression of contentment and in what he said she perceived a tone that erased all disdain or haughtiness towards his companions, and convinced her that the improvement in his character that she had witnessed the previous day, even if fleeting, had lasted, at least, until now.

en: When she saw him thus seeking the acquaintance, and courting the good opinion of people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a disgrace; when she saw him thus civil, not only to herself, but to the very relations whom he had openly disdained, and recollected their last lively scene in Hunsford Parsonage, the difference, the change was so great, and struck so forcibly on her mind, that she could hardly restrain her astonishment from being visible.
vi: When she saw him wanting to get acquainted and win the approval of people he had not wanted to associate with a few months ago, when she saw him being polite not only to her but also to those he had previously openly scorned, and recalled the vivid scene at the Huntsford Parsonage; the differences, the changes were so great, striking her consciousness so strongly, that she could hardly contain her expression of astonishment.
tr: Seeing him seek opportunities to meet people he would have been ashamed to encounter a few months ago, and trying to win their approval, and observing him being courteous not only to her but also to the relatives he had previously openly scorned, and recalling the last lively scenes at the parsonage in Hunsford, the difference and change seemed so great and made such a strong impression on her mind that she could not help but show her astonishment.
es: Seeing him trying to be sociable, seeking the good opinion of those present, with whom having any dealings a few months ago would have meant disgrace for him; seeing him so courteous, not only with her, but with the very relatives he had despised, and remembering the violent scene at the parsonage in Hunsford, the difference, the change was so great, that she could barely prevent her astonishment from becoming visible.

en: Never, even in the company of his dear friends at Netherfield, or his dignified relations at Rosings, had she seen him so desirous to please, so free from self-consequence or unbending reserve, as now, when no importance could result from the success of his endeavours, and when even the acquaintance of those to whom his attentions were addressed, would draw down the ridicule and censure of the ladies both of Netherfield and Rosings.
vi: Never, even when he was among his close friends at Netherfield, or his noble relatives at Rosings, had she seen him so eager to please others, so devoid of arrogance, or as comfortable as he was now, while gaining no significant benefit from this attitude, even though this interaction would cause the ladies at Netherfield and Rosings to mock and criticize him.
tr: She had never seen him so eager to be liked, whether among his dear friends at Netherfield or his noble relatives at Rosings, and so far removed from self-importance or pretentiousness, even though his efforts would bring him no benefit and his acquaintance with the people he was showing kindness to would lead to the mockery and disapproval of the ladies at Netherfield and Rosings.
es: Never, neither in the company of his dear friends at Netherfield, nor in that of his haughty relatives at Rosings, had she found him so eager to please, so devoid of self-importance or reserve, as now when no vanity could be gained from the success of his endeavor, and when dealing with those he showered with attentions would have been censured and ridiculed by the ladies of Netherfield and Rosings.

en: Their visitors stayed with them above half an hour; and when they arose to depart, mr Darcy called on his sister to join him in expressing their wish of seeing mr and ms Gardiner, and Miss Bennet, to dinner at Pemberley, before they left the country.
vi: The three people stayed for just over half an hour. When they stood up to say goodbye, Mr. Darcy asked his sister to join him in inviting Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner and Miss Bennet to dine at Pemberley before their departure.
tr: The guests stayed with them for more than half an hour; when they got up to leave, Mr. Darcy turned to his sister and asked her to join him in expressing the desire to see Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner and Miss Bennet again for dinner at Pemberley before they left the area.
es: The visit lasted about half an hour, and when they stood up to say goodbye, Darcy asked his sister to support the invitation to the Gardiners and Miss Bennet, so that they would come to dine at Pemberley before leaving the area.

en: Miss Darcy, though with a diffidence which marked her little in the habit of giving invitations, readily obeyed.
vi: Miss Darcy readily obeyed, though with a lack of confidence in extending the invitation, due to her nature.
tr: Miss Darcy, though shyly indicating her lack of habit in making invitations, complied with the request.
es: Miss Darcy, although with a shyness that revealed her little habit of making invitations, obeyed immediately.

en: ms Gardiner looked at her niece, desirous of knowing how she, whom the invitation most concerned, felt disposed as to its acceptance, but Elizabeth had turned away her head.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece, as she was the main subject of the invitation, to see how she would respond, but Elizabeth had turned away.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece to see if she, the person most concerned with the invitation, was inclined to accept, but Elizabeth had turned her head away.
es: Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece to see how she, to whom the invitation was directed, would receive it; but Elizabeth had turned her head away.

en: Presuming, however, that this studied avoidance spoke rather a momentary embarrassment than any dislike of the proposal, and seeing in her husband, who was fond of society, a perfect willingness to accept it, she ventured to engage for her attendance, and the day after the next was fixed on.
vi: However, she guessed that this was due to shyness rather than a desire to refuse; and seeing that her husband enjoyed socializing, she suggested that her niece accept, and they arranged to meet two days later.
tr: However, assuming that this eager avoidance indicated momentary discomfort rather than displeasure with the offer, and seeing in her husband a complete willingness to accept, she accepted the invitation; the next day was agreed upon.
es: She presumed, however, that her studied evasion meant more a momentary confusion than displeasure at the proposition, and seeing her husband, who was very fond of social life, eager to accept, she ventured to accept on behalf of the three; and the date was set for two days later.

en: Bingley expressed great pleasure in the certainty of seeing Elizabeth again, having still a great deal to say to her, and many inquiries to make after all their Hertfordshire friends.
vi: Bingley expressed genuine joy at the prospect of seeing Elizabeth again, as he still had many things he wanted to discuss with her and many questions to ask about his friends at Netherfield.
tr: Bingley said that he was very happy to see Elizabeth again, that he still had much to tell her and many questions to ask about their friends in Hertfordshire.
es: Bingley expressed his delight at knowing he would see Elizabeth again, as he still had many things to tell her and many questions to ask about all the friends in Hertfordshire.

en: Elizabeth, construing all this into a wish of hearing her speak of her sister, was pleased; and on this account, as well as some others, found herself, when their visitors left them, capable of considering the last half hour with some satisfaction, though while it was passing the enjoyment of it had been little.
vi: Elizabeth was pleased, thinking he wanted to hear her talk about her sister. When the guests had left, Elizabeth reflected on the recent events and felt satisfied.
tr: Elizabeth, attributing all this to his desire to hear news about her sister, was pleased; therefore, and for some other reasons as well, she found that she could think back on the last half hour with a certain satisfaction after the guests had left, even though it had not seemed very enjoyable at the time.
es: Elizabeth believed she understood that he wished to hear her speak of her sister, and she was very pleased. This and some other details of the visit left her inclined, as soon as their friends had left, to recall it with pleasure, even though she had felt a bit uncomfortable during the visit.

en: Eager to be alone, and fearful of inquiries or hints from her uncle and aunt, she stayed with them only long enough to hear their favourable opinion of Bingley, and then hurried away to dress.
vi: Desiring privacy and wary of her uncle and aunt's questions or insinuations, she lingered only a moment to hear them praise Bingley, then excused herself to go change her clothes.
tr: She wanted to be alone, fearing questions or insinuations from her uncle and aunt, and stayed with them just long enough to learn their positive opinions about Bingley, then hurriedly went to change her clothes.
es: Eager to be alone and fearful of her uncles' questions or suppositions, she stayed with them just long enough to hear their favorable comments about Bingley, and then hurried to get dressed.

en: But she had no reason to fear mr and ms Gardiner’s curiosity; it was not their wish to force her communication.
vi: But she had no reason to fear Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner's curiosity; they did not want to press her to disclose anything.
tr: However, there was no reason for Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner to fear their curiosity; they did not intend to force her to talk.
es: But she was very wrong to fear the curiosity of the Gardiners, who had no intention of making her talk.

en: It was evident that she was much better acquainted with mr Darcy than they had before any idea of; it was evident that he was very much in love with her.
vi: They clearly saw that she was more acquainted with Mr. Darcy than they had thought; and it was also evident that he loved her deeply.
tr: It was clear that Elizabeth knew Mr. Darcy much better than they had previously realized; it was also clear that Mr. Darcy was deeply in love with her.
es: It was evident that her relationship with Darcy was much more serious than they had believed, and it was clearer than water that he was deeply in love with her.

en: They saw much to interest, but nothing to justify inquiry.
vi: They had noticed many things worthy of their attention, but there was nothing that needed to be asked.
tr: They were seeing interesting things, but there was no need to ask questions.
es: They had seen many things that interested them, but they did not justify their inquiry.

en: Of mr Darcy it was now a matter of anxiety to think well; and, as far as their acquaintance reached, there was no fault to find.
vi: Regarding Mr. Darcy, this is a matter of concern that requires her to think clearly. According to the acquaintance they have just established, the couple did not find anything lacking.
tr: Thinking well of Mr. Darcy was now a matter of concern; throughout their acquaintance, they had seen no fault in him.
es: The important thing now was that Darcy was a good boy. As far as they could have appreciated, he had no faults.

en: They could not be untouched by his politeness; and had they drawn his character from their own feelings and his servant’s report, without any reference to any other account, the circle in Hertfordshire to which he was known would not have recognized it for mr Darcy.
vi: They could not be indifferent to his courteous demeanor, and if they judged him based on their feelings combined with the housekeeper's affection but disregarded other opinions, those who knew him in Hertfordshire would not recognize this as Mr. Darcy.
tr: It was impossible not to be impressed by his politeness; if they had drawn his character from their own feelings and the words of his servant without resorting to anyone else's expression, the Hertfordshire community who knew him could not recognize this Mr. Darcy.
es: His kindnesses had moved them, and if they had had to describe his character according to their own opinion and according to the reports of their maid, disregarding any other reference, they would have done so in such a way that the Hertfordshire circle who knew him would not have recognized him.

en: There was now an interest, however, in believing the housekeeper; and they soon became sensible that the authority of a servant, who had known him since he was four years old, and whose own manners indicated respectability, was not to be hastily rejected.
vi: However, now is the time to consider whether to trust the housekeeper or not. They realized that it would not be wise to hastily dismiss the opinion of a respectable servant who had known him since he was four.
tr: However, there was also meaning in believing the steward; they realized that the testimony of a servant who had known him since he was four years old and whose own behavior exuded respectability could not be easily disregarded.
es: They now wished to give credit to the housekeeper and soon agreed that the testimony of a maid who had known him since he was four years old and who seemed so respectable, could not be questioned.

en: Neither had anything occurred in the intelligence of their Lambton friends that could materially lessen its weight.
vi: They also did not hear their friends in Lambton speak ill of him.
tr: There was nothing known by their friends in Lambton that could significantly lessen the weight of this.
es: On the other hand, there was nothing in what his friends from Lambton said that could diminish the weight of that testimony.

en: They had nothing to accuse him of but pride; pride he probably had, and if not, it would certainly be imputed by the inhabitants of a small market town where the family did not visit.
vi: These people had nothing to accuse him of except pride. Perhaps he is proud, or it could be that those living in a small town who are less acquainted with him said so.
tr: They could not accuse him of anything other than pride; he was probably proud, but even if he were not, the residents of a small market town that the family did not visit would somehow attach that label to him.
es: They accused him of nothing more than pride; proud he may have been, but even if he had not been, the inhabitants of that small commercial town, where the Pemberley family never went, would have attributed the label to him just the same.

en: It was acknowledged, however, that he was a liberal man, and did much good among the poor.
vi: However, they acknowledged that he was a generous person who had done many good deeds for the poor.
tr: On the other hand, it was accepted that he was a generous man, and that he did much good for the poor and needy.
es: But they said he was very generous and did a lot of good among the poor.

en: With respect to Wickham, the travellers soon found that he was not held there in much estimation; for though the chief of his concerns with the son of his patron were imperfectly understood, it was yet a well-known fact that, on his quitting Derbyshire, he had left many debts behind him, which mr Darcy afterwards discharged.
vi: As for Wickham, the couple did not think highly of him. Although they did not fully understand what he complained about regarding the son of the patron who took care of him, they knew one thing for sure: when he left Derbyshire, he left behind many debts that Mr. Darcy had to settle afterward.
tr: As for Wickham, the travelers learned that he was not held in high regard there; although most of his troubles, particularly those involving his master's son, were not well known, it was a well-known fact that he had left behind a considerable amount of debt when he departed from Derbyshire, and that these debts were later paid off by Mr. Darcy.
es: As for Wickham, the travelers soon saw that he was not held in high regard there; the main details of his relationship with his master's son were unknown, but it was well known that upon leaving Derbyshire he had left behind a multitude of debts that Darcy had paid.

en: As for Elizabeth, her thoughts were at Pemberley this evening more than the last; and the evening, though as it passed it seemed long, was not long enough to determine her feelings towards one in that mansion; and she lay awake two whole hours, endeavouring to make them out.
vi: As for Elizabeth, her thoughts about Pemberley tonight were even more complicated than the day before. Although the evening seemed to pass slowly, it was not slow enough for her to determine her feelings for a certain resident of that estate, and she lay awake for two hours trying to find an answer.
tr: Elizabeth's thoughts this evening were even more focused on Pemberley than the previous evening; the evening hours seemed long as they passed, but not long enough for her to understand her feelings for someone at that estate; she lay awake for two hours trying to make sense of her emotions.
es: Elizabeth thought about Pemberley that night even more than the previous one. It seemed very long to her, but not long enough to determine her feelings towards one of the inhabitants of the mansion. After going to bed, she stayed awake for two hours trying to decipher them.

en: She certainly did not hate him.
vi: Surely, she did not hate him.
tr: Of course, she did not hate him.
es: She did not hate him, no; the hatred had vanished long ago, and for almost all that time she had been ashamed of having felt a dislike towards that person that could bear such a name.

en: No; hatred had vanished long ago, and she had almost as long been ashamed of ever feeling a dislike against him, that could be so called.
vi: No, the thought of hatred had long vanished, and for a long time, she had felt ashamed of having harbored such thoughts, one might say.
tr: No; the hatred had passed long ago, and Elizabeth had almost been ashamed of the coldness she had felt towards him since then.
es: She did not hate him, no; the hatred had vanished long ago, and for almost all that time she had been ashamed of having felt a dislike towards that person that could bear such a name.

en: The respect created by the conviction of his valuable qualities, though at first unwillingly admitted, had for some time ceased to be repugnant to her feelings; and it was now heightened into somewhat of a friendlier nature by the testimony so highly in his favour, and bringing forward his disposition in so amiable a light, which yesterday had produced.
vi: The respect born from her belief in his noble qualities, although initially she did not want to admit it, no longer conflicted with her feelings. Now, that respect had grown to a more intimate level, through her good opinions of him, making him more likable, as past events had shown.
tr: The respect that his superior qualities had aroused, though initially accepted reluctantly, had for some time ceased to be repulsive to her; moreover, thanks to the praise spoken about him, he now appeared in a more friendly light, and his character was shown in a very charming light that had emerged yesterday.
es: The respect due to his valuable qualities, although admitted at first against her will, had contributed to the cessation of the hostility of her feelings, and these had evolved into affectionate ones in light of the significant testimony in his favor that she had heard and the good disposition he himself had shown the previous day.

en: But above all, above respect and esteem, there was a motive within her of good-will which could not be overlooked.
vi: But above all, above respect and affection, there was in her a driving force of goodwill that could not be ignored. It was emotion.
tr: But more than anything, more than respect and trust, there was a feeling of goodwill within Elizabeth that she could not ignore.
es: But above all that, above respect and esteem, Elizabeth felt another impulse of benevolence towards Darcy that could not be overlooked.

en: It was gratitude;—gratitude, not merely for having once loved her, but for loving her still well enough to forgive all the petulance and acrimony of her manner in rejecting him, and all the unjust accusations accompanying her rejection.
vi: Emotion not just because someone loved her, but because he loved her so deeply that he forgave all her impulsiveness and sharpness when rejecting his proposal, and forgave all the unjust accusations that followed the rejection.
tr: It was gratitude. –Not just gratitude for once loving him, but gratitude for loving him enough to forgive all the rudeness and irritability in her manner of rejecting him, and all the unjust accusations that accompanied them.
es: It was gratitude; gratitude not only for having loved her, but for still loving her enough to forget all the petulance and sharpness of her rejection and all the unjust accusations that accompanied it.

en: He who, she had been persuaded, would avoid her as his greatest enemy, seemed, on this accidental meeting, most eager to preserve the acquaintance; and without any indelicate display of regard, or any peculiarity of manner, where their two selves only were concerned, was soliciting the good opinion of her friends, and bent on making her known to his sister.
vi: She had thought he would avoid her like the worst enemy; but when he unexpectedly met her again, he seemed to want to maintain a relationship with her. Without any lack of tact or odd gestures, he had won the good opinion of her relatives and even wanted his sister to become acquainted with her.
tr: When she should have seen him as her greatest enemy and avoided him, he had shown willingness to maintain their friendship when they met by chance, had tried to win the hearts of her friends without the discourtesy of limiting his attention to her, and had decided to introduce her to his sister.
es: He, who should consider her ––so Elizabeth supposed–– as his greatest enemy, upon meeting her by chance seemed eager to maintain her friendship, and without any display of indelicacy or affectation in his manner, in a matter that only concerned the two of them, sought the good opinion of her friends and decided to introduce her to his sister.

en: Such a change in a man of so much pride excited not only astonishment but gratitude—for to love, ardent love, it must be attributed; and, as such, its impression on her was of a sort to be encouraged, as by no means unpleasing, though it could not be exactly defined.
vi: Such a change in a very proud man not only astonished her but also moved her – for this was due to love, deep love. Therefore, the impression within her was something that should be encouraged, certainly not unpleasant, though it could not be clearly defined.
tr: Such a change in a man so proud not only aroused astonishment but also gratitude –for it must have been because of love, passionate love; thus, the effect on Elizabeth was not irritating but rather of a kind that sought encouragement, though it was not clear exactly what it was.
es: Such a change in a man so proud not only had to inspire astonishment, but also gratitude, for it had to be attributed to love, to a passionate love. But, although this impression was encouraging and very contrary to dislike, she could not define it precisely.

en: She respected, she esteemed, she was grateful to him, she felt a real interest in his welfare; and she only wanted to know how far she wished that welfare to depend upon herself, and how far it would be for the happiness of both that she should employ the power, which her fancy told her she still possessed, of bringing on the renewal of his addresses.
vi: She respected him, liked him, was moved by him. She genuinely cared about his happiness. She only wanted to know how much she desired that his happiness depended on her and how much she would use her abilities for the happiness of both. She thought she still had the ability to lead him to propose to her again.
tr: She felt respect, appreciation, and gratitude towards him, and sincerely wished for his well-being; she just wanted to know to what extent she wished that well-being to be tied to herself, Elizabeth, and to what extent her imagination, which still told her she had the power, would take their happiness if he used the power to renew his proposal.
es: She respected him, esteemed him, was grateful to him, and earnestly wished for his happiness. She only needed to know to what extent she wished that happiness to depend on her, and to what extent it would result in the happiness of both if she used the power she imagined she still possessed to induce him to renew his proposal.

en: It had been settled in the evening, between the aunt and niece, that such a striking civility as Miss Darcy’s, in coming to them on the very day of her arrival at Pemberley—for she had reached it only to a late breakfast—ought to be imitated, though it could not be equalled, by some exertion of politeness on their side; and, consequently, that it would be highly expedient to wait on her at Pemberley the following morning.
vi: In the evening, the aunt and the niece agreed that according to the standards of etiquette on their part, they needed to return the visit to Miss Darcy, who had been extremely courteous when she visited them immediately upon returning to Pemberley, even though their return visit could not be equivalent. They decided they needed to visit her at Pemberley the next morning.
tr: The aunt and the niece decided that evening that it was necessary to respond to Miss Darcy's tremendous kindness, that is, the kindness she showed by getting up to visit them on the day she arrived at Pemberley, even though she arrived at breakfast time, with a response that, even if not as exquisite, should be close to it; as a result, they agreed that it would be very appropriate to visit her at Pemberley the next morning.
es: In the afternoon, the aunt and niece agreed that such an extraordinary attention as the visit from Miss Darcy on the very day of her arrival at Pemberley—where she had arrived shortly after breakfast—should be reciprocated, if not with something equivalent, at least with some special courtesy.

en: They were, therefore, to go.
vi: Thus, the aunt and niece went together.
tr: They would go, that is.
es: Therefore, they decided to visit her at Pemberley the next morning.

en: Elizabeth was pleased; though when she asked herself the reason, she had very little to say in reply.
vi: Elizabeth felt happy, though when she silently asked herself the reason for her happiness, she could not provide much of an answer.
tr: –Elizabeth was happy, but when she asked herself why she was happy, she couldn't find much of an answer.
es: Elizabeth felt happy, although when she asked herself why, she couldn't find an answer.

en: mr Gardiner left them soon after breakfast.
vi: Mr. Gardiner left after breakfast.
tr: Mr. Gardiner left them immediately after breakfast.
es: After breakfast, Mr. Gardiner left them.

en: The fishing scheme had been renewed the day before, and a positive engagement made of his meeting some of the gentlemen at Pemberley by noon.
vi: The day before, he had once again been invited to go fishing and had agreed to meet some people at Pemberley in the afternoon.
tr: The invitation to go fishing had been repeated the previous day, and it was arranged to meet a few gentlemen at Pemberley around noon.
es: The offer to go fishing had been renewed the previous day, and he had been assured that one of the gentlemen from Pemberley would accompany him at noon.

en: CHAPTER XLV.
vi: Chapter 45
tr: Chapter III
es: CHAPTER XLV

en: CONVINCED as Elizabeth now was that Miss Bingley’s dislike of her had originated in jealousy, she could not help feeling how very unwelcome her appearance at Pemberley must be to her, and was curious to know with how much civility on that lady’s side the acquaintance would now be renewed.
vi: Elizabeth was now convinced that Miss Bingley disliked her purely out of jealousy. She wondered how Miss Bingley would receive her at Pemberley, curious to know how this young woman would treat her once her relationship with Mr. Darcy was rekindled.
tr: Elizabeth, now thoroughly convinced that Miss Bingley's dislike for her stemmed from jealousy, couldn't help but think about how uncomfortable it must be for her to appear at Pemberley; indeed, she wondered how much courtesy that lady would show while renewing their acquaintance.
es: Elizabeth was now convinced that Miss Bingley's antipathy towards her stemmed from jealousy. She understood, therefore, how unpleasant it must be for her to see her appear at Pemberley and wondered with curiosity how much courtesy she would muster to resume their relations.

en: On reaching the house, they were shown through the hall into the saloon, whose northern aspect rendered it delightful for summer.
vi: When they arrived at the mansion, the two were led through the foyer to enter the great hall, which opened to the north and looked beautiful in the summer.
tr: When they arrived at the house, they were taken from the hall to the living room; its north-facing aspect made the living room a pleasant place for summer.
es: Upon arriving at the house, they crossed the vestibule and entered the living room, whose northward orientation made it delightful in summer.

en: Its windows, opening to the ground, admitted a most refreshing view of the high woody hills behind the house, and of the beautiful oaks and Spanish chestnuts which were scattered over the intermediate lawn.
vi: The windows extended to the ground, revealing a refreshing view of the forest-covered hills behind the mansion, with oaks and chestnuts scattered across the adjacent lawn.
tr: The windows opening to the garden displayed the refreshing view of the high wooded hills behind the house and the magnificent oak and chestnut trees rising in the grassy area just in front.
es: The wide-open windows offered a refreshing view of the tall, forested hills behind the building, and of the beautiful oaks and chestnut trees of Spain scattered across the meadow that stretched out in front of the house.

en: In this room they were received by Miss Darcy, who was sitting there with ms Hurst and Miss Bingley, and the lady with whom she lived in London.
vi: They were received by Miss Darcy; she was sitting with Mrs. Hunts and Miss Bingley, along with a lady who lived with her in London.
tr: They were greeted in this room by Miss Darcy; Miss Darcy was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst, Miss Bingley, and a lady from London.
es: In that room, they were received by Miss Darcy, who was waiting for them along with Mrs. Hurst, Miss Bingley, and her companion.

en: Georgiana’s reception of them was very civil, but attended with all that embarrassment which, though proceeding from shyness and the fear of doing wrong, would easily give to those who felt themselves inferior the belief of her being proud and reserved.
vi: Georgiana was very polite in receiving the two, but with a confused manner due to shyness and the fear of making mistakes, which could make someone of lower class mistakenly think that she was proud and fastidious.
tr: Georgiana greeted them very politely; but there was no lack of that discomfort stemming from shyness and the fear of making mistakes, which could make those who felt inferior to her think she was proud and distant.
es: Georgiana's welcome was very courteous, but dominated by that shyness due to her timidity and the fear of doing things wrong, which had given her a reputation of being proud and reserved among her inferiors.

en: ms Gardiner and her niece, however, did her justice, and pitied her.
vi: However, Mrs. Gardiner and Elizabeth thought rightly of her, feeling sorry for her.
tr: Nevertheless, Mrs. Gardiner and her niece gave her credit and felt sorry for her.
es: But Mrs. Gardiner and her niece understood and sympathized with her.

en: By ms Hurst and Miss Bingley they were noticed only by a courtesy; and on their being seated, a pause, awkward as such pauses must always be, succeeded for a few moments.
vi: Mrs. Hunts and Miss Bingley only inclined their heads to greet them.
tr: Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley greeted them only with a slight bend of the knee; once seated, there was a silence, the kind of awkward silence that can occur in such a situation, and it lasted for a few minutes.
es: Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley made a simple bow and sat down. An extremely awkward silence ensued, lasting for a few moments.

en: It was first broken by ms Annesley, a genteel, agreeable-looking woman, whose endeavour to introduce some kind of discourse proved her to be more truly well-bred than either of the others; and between her and ms Gardiner, with occasional help from Elizabeth, the conversation was carried on.
vi: After everyone sat down, there was an awkward moment, broken by Mrs. Annesley. She was a gentle, pleasant woman; when she wanted to start a conversation, she demonstrated that she was truly better educated than the others. The conversation took place between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with Elizabeth occasionally joining in.
tr: The first to break the silence was Mrs. Annesley; she appeared to be a kind and amiable woman, and her attempt to start a conversation showed that she was better bred than the other two; the conversation continued between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with occasional help from Elizabeth.
es: It was interrupted by Mrs. Annesley, a kind and pleasant person who, in attempting to break the ice, showed better manners than any of the other ladies. The conversation continued between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with some contributions from Elizabeth.

en: Miss Darcy looked as if she wished for courage enough to join in it; and sometimes did venture a short sentence, when there was least danger of its being heard.
vi: It seemed that Miss Darcy needed to muster enough courage to contribute, and she occasionally added a short sentence when there was the least risk of being overheard by others.
tr: Miss Darcy seemed to be gathering the courage to join the conversation and sometimes dared to say a brief word when the risk of being heard was at its lowest.
es: Miss Darcy seemed to wish she had the confidence to take part in the conversation, and occasionally ventured a short sentence when there was the least danger of being overheard.

en: Elizabeth soon saw that she was herself closely watched by Miss Bingley, and that she could not speak a word, especially to Miss Darcy, without calling her attention.
vi: Elizabeth immediately realized that Miss Bingley was observing her closely.
tr: Elizabeth soon realized that she was under the close watch of Miss Bingley and that she couldn't speak a single word to Miss Darcy without drawing her attention.
es: Elizabeth immediately realized that Miss Bingley was closely watching her and that she couldn't say a word, especially to Miss Darcy, without the other sharpening her ears.

en: This observation would not have prevented her from trying to talk to the latter, had they not been seated at an inconvenient distance; but she was not sorry to be spared the necessity of saying much: her own thoughts were employing her.
vi: This would not have prevented her from joining the conversation if she were not in an inconvenient position, but she did not regret having to speak less.
tr: This observation did not prevent her from trying to talk to her, but there was an inconvenient distance between their seats; however, she was not upset as she was relieved from the obligation of much conversation. Her thoughts were already occupying her.
es: However, her tenacious observation would not have prevented her from speaking with Georgiana if they hadn't been so distant from each other; but she was not distressed by not being able to speak much, as it allowed her to think more freely.

en: She expected every moment that some of the gentlemen would enter the room: she wished, she feared, that the master of the house might be amongst them; and whether she wished or feared it most, she could scarcely determine.
vi: She was preoccupied with the thought that at any moment some gentlemen would enter the room. She both wished for and feared the presence of the master of the estate among them, and she could not discern whether she wished or feared it more.
tr: She was expecting some of the gentlemen to enter the room at any moment. She wanted the master of the house to be among them, feared he would be, and couldn't decide whether she wanted it or feared it.
es: She both wished for and feared the arrival of the master of the house, and she could hardly clarify whether she feared it more than she desired it.

en: After sitting in this manner a quarter of an hour, without hearing Miss Bingley’s voice, Elizabeth was roused by receiving from her a cold inquiry after the health of her family.
vi: After sitting for a while without hearing Miss Bingley, Elizabeth heard her coldly inquiring about her family's health.
tr: After sitting for a quarter of an hour in this manner without hearing Miss Bingley's voice, Elizabeth was startled when a cold question about her family's health came from her.
es: After being like this for a quarter of an hour without hearing Miss Bingley's voice, Elizabeth blushed when the latter asked her how her family was.

en: She answered with equal indifference and brevity, and the other said no more.
vi: She responded with the same coldness and brevity, and Miss Bingley said nothing more.
tr: She replied with the same indifference and brevity, and the other said nothing more.
es: She replied with the same indifference and brevity, and the other said nothing more.

en: The next variation which their visit afforded was produced by the entrance of servants with cold meat, cake, and a variety of all the finest fruits in season; but this did not take place till after many a significant look and smile from ms Annesley to Miss Darcy had been given, to remind her of her post.
vi: The servants brought in cold meats, pastries, and some of the finest seasonal fruits; this was only after Mrs. Annesley had repeatedly glanced and smiled at Miss Darcy to remind her of her position.
tr: The second movement during the visit occurred with the entrance of the servants; they brought cold cuts, cake, and various seasonal fruits; but for this movement to happen, Mrs. Annesley had to make numerous gestures to Miss Darcy to remind her of her duty.
es: The first variety of the visit consisted of the appearance of some servants who brought cold cuts, pastries, and some of the best fruits of the season, but this happened after many significant looks from Mrs. Annesley to Georgiana to remind her of her duties.

en: There was now employment for the whole party; for though they could not all talk, they could all eat; and the beautiful pyramids of grapes, nectarines, and peaches, soon collected them round the table.
vi: Now they had something to do, for if they could not talk, they could eat, and they gathered around the table adorned with fresh grapes, tangerines, and peaches.
tr: Now there was something for everyone to occupy themselves with; they couldn't all talk, but they could all eat; seeing the grapes, nectarines, and peaches arranged in marvelous pyramids, they soon gathered around the table.
es: This distracted the gathering, for, although not all the ladies could talk, at least all could eat. The beautiful pyramids of grapes, apricots, and peaches immediately gathered them around the table.

en: While thus engaged, Elizabeth had a fair opportunity of deciding whether she most feared or wished for the appearance of mr Darcy, by the feelings which prevailed on his entering the room; and then, though but a moment before she had believed her wishes to predominate, she began to regret that he came.
vi: At that moment, Elizabeth had the opportunity to determine whether she wished for or feared Mr. Darcy's appearance more, through the emotions that arose within her as he entered. Just a moment ago, she believed she wished for it more, but now she began to regret that he had come.
tr: In the midst of this occupation, was Elizabeth afraid of Mr. Darcy's arrival, or did she want him to come? She had the opportunity to truly decide when Mr. Darcy entered the room; then, she began to feel upset that he had come, even though she thought she wanted it just a minute before.
es: While they were engaged in this, Elizabeth began to ponder whether she feared or desired Darcy's arrival due to the effect his presence would have on her; and although a moment before she believed she rather desired it, she now began to think the opposite.

en: He had been some time with mr Gardiner, who, with two or three other gentlemen from the house, was engaged by the river; and had left him only on learning that the ladies of the family intended a visit to Georgiana that morning.
vi: He was standing by the river with Mr. Gardiner and a few of his friends when he was informed that there were guests.
tr: Mr. Darcy had been with Mr. Gardiner for a while; Mr. Gardiner was busy at the river with a few gentlemen who were guests at the house, and Mr. Darcy had only left him alone upon learning that the ladies of the family were planning to visit Georgiana that morning.
es: Darcy had been with Mr. Gardiner, who was fishing in the river with two or three other gentlemen, but upon learning that the ladies of his family planned to visit Georgiana that very morning, he went home.

en: No sooner did he appear, than Elizabeth wisely resolved to be perfectly easy and unembarrassed;—a resolution the more necessary to be made, but perhaps not the more easily kept, because she saw that the suspicions of the whole party were awakened against them, and that there was scarcely an eye which did not watch his behaviour when he first came into the room.
vi: As soon as he appeared, Elizabeth wisely resolved that she needed to appear completely at ease and not flustered. Thinking it was easy but doing it could be difficult, because when he entered, she felt all the curiosity was focused on the two of them, with every eye keenly observing his demeanor.
tr: As soon as she entered the room, Elizabeth decided to appear quite at ease and natural – a necessary decision but perhaps not so easy to adhere to, because she saw that the suspicions of everyone in the room were aroused against the two of them and that there was not a single eye that did not follow Mr. Darcy's behavior when he first entered.
es: Upon seeing him enter, Elizabeth resolved to appear as natural as possible, a necessary but difficult task, as she was aware that the entire gathering was focused on them, and as soon as Darcy arrived, all eyes turned to examine him.

en: In no countenance was attentive curiosity so strongly marked as in Miss Bingley’s, in spite of the smiles which overspread her face whenever she spoke to one of its objects; for jealousy had not yet made her desperate, and her attentions to mr Darcy were by no means over.
vi: Miss Bingley's face showed the most attentive curiosity although she always smiled when talking, because jealousy had not yet made her desperate, she had not ceased to pay attention to Mr. Darcy.
tr: No one else's face bore such a strongly fixed look of attentive curiosity as Miss Bingley's, even though her face lit up with smiles while speaking to one of the two people who aroused her curiosity; jealousy had not yet exhausted all her hopes, and she had not given up showing interest in Mr. Darcy.
es: But no face showed curiosity as strongly as Miss Bingley's, despite the smiles she lavished while speaking with anyone; however, her jealousy had not reached the point of making her desist from her attentions to Darcy––.

en: Miss Darcy, on her brother’s entrance, exerted herself much more to talk; and Elizabeth saw that he was anxious for his sister and herself to get acquainted, and forwarded, as much as possible, every attempt at conversation on either side.
vi: When she saw her brother enter, Miss Darcy spoke more, and Elizabeth noticed that he wanted her and his sister to become more acquainted, so he tried to draw the two into the conversation.
tr: Miss Darcy forced herself to talk more upon her brother's arrival; Elizabeth saw that Mr. Darcy wanted his sister and herself to become closer and that he supported every attempt at conversation from both sides as much as he could.
es: Georgiana, as soon as her brother entered, made more effort to speak, and Elizabeth understood that Darcy wanted the two to become close, for which he encouraged all attempts at conversation from both sides.

en: Miss Bingley saw all this likewise; and, in the imprudence of anger, took the first opportunity of saying, with sneering civility,—
vi: Miss Bingley also knew this, and in a rash moment of anger, she seized the first opportunity to speak, with a polite mocking tone:
tr: Miss Bingley also saw all this and, in the carelessness of her anger, said with a contemptuous interest at the first opportunity,
es: Miss Bingley also noticed this and with the imprudence typical of her anger, seized the first opportunity to say with mocking finesse:

en: “Pray, Miss Eliza, are not the ——shire militia removed from Meryton?
vi: - Miss Elizabeth, has the militia regiment moved away from Meryton?
tr: "May I ask, Miss Eliza, hasn't the -------shire regiment withdrawn from Meryton?
es: ––Tell me, Miss Elizabeth, is it true that the Meryton garrison has been relocated?

en: They must be a great loss to your family.”
vi: This must be a great loss for your family.
tr: It must have been a great loss for your family."
es: It must have been a great loss for your family.

en: In Darcy’s presence she dared not mention Wickham’s name: but Elizabeth instantly comprehended that he was uppermost in her thoughts; and the various recollections connected with him gave her a moment’s distress; but, exerting herself vigorously to repel the ill-natured attack, she presently answered the question in a tolerably disengaged tone.
vi: In front of Darcy, she did not dare to mention Wickham by name, but Elizabeth immediately understood that he was present in her thoughts, and Elizabeth felt a moment of pain when memories of him were mentioned. However, she tried to counter the attack with ill intent, answering the question by distancing herself from the issue.
tr: She did not dare to mention Wickham's name in Darcy's presence; but Elizabeth immediately understood that he was on her mind; various memories related to Wickham briefly troubled her, but she gathered her attention to fend off that malicious attack and answered the question in a very indifferent tone.
es: In Darcy's presence, she did not dare to utter Wickham's name, but Elizabeth guessed that he had that name in his thoughts; the various memories it evoked distressed her for a moment, but she composed herself with fortitude to repel that brazen attack and answered the question in a nonchalant tone.

en: While she spoke, an involuntary glance showed her Darcy with a heightened complexion, earnestly looking at her, and his sister overcome with confusion, and unable to lift up her eyes.
vi: While she spoke, she inadvertently glanced at her brother Darcy and saw his tense, worried face looking at her; meanwhile, her sister showed a confused expression, unable to lift her eyes.
tr: While speaking, she glanced at Darcy for a moment and saw a serious expression on his face, persistently looking at her, and his sister, unable to lift her eyes, sinking into distress.
es: In doing so, an involuntary glance made her see Darcy, with his face flushed, watching her intently, and his sister completely confused and unable to lift her eyes.

en: Had Miss Bingley known what pain she was then giving her beloved friend, she undoubtedly would have refrained from the hint; but she had merely intended to discompose Elizabeth, by bringing forward the idea of a man to whom she believed her partial, to make her betray a sensibility which might injure her in Darcy’s opinion, and, perhaps, to remind the latter of all the follies and absurdities by which some part of her family were connected with that corps.
vi: If Miss Bingley understood the pain she had caused her dear friend Darcy, she certainly would not have implied such things. She only wanted to embarrass Elizabeth to force her opponent to reveal emotions that could harm Darcy's feelings, perhaps to remind him of the recklessness and impropriety associated with some members of Elizabeth's family involved with the regiment.
tr: If Miss Bingley had known how much she was hurting her dear friend at that moment, she undoubtedly would not have made such an insinuation, but she only wanted to upset Elizabeth by mentioning a man she believed she was close to, revealing a sensitivity that could lower him in Darcy's eyes, and perhaps reminding Darcy of all the foolishness and ridiculousness of some of her family members associating with soldiers.
es: If Miss Bingley could have suspected how much it pained her beloved, she would undoubtedly have refrained; but she had only tried to unsettle Elizabeth by bringing up something related to a man for whom she had been partial, and to provoke her into some misstep that would harm her in Darcy's eyes and, incidentally, remind him of the absurdities and follies of the Bennet family.

en: Not a syllable had ever reached her of Miss Darcy’s meditated elopement.
vi: She knew nothing about Miss Darcy's intention to elope with her lover.
tr: Miss Darcy had not heard a single word about the planned elopement.
es: She did not know a word about Miss Darcy's elopement, as it had been kept strictly secret, and Elizabeth was the only person to whom it had been revealed.

en: To no creature had it been revealed, where secrecy was possible, except to Elizabeth; and from all Bingley’s connections her brother was particularly anxious to conceal it, from that very wish which Elizabeth had long ago attributed to him, of their becoming hereafter her own.
vi: The news was not disclosed to anyone except Elizabeth, and Darcy particularly kept it secret from all of Bingley's connections. This stemmed from the very wish that Elizabeth previously thought was his, that the relationships between the two young men would also become her relationships.
tr: This had been kept as secret as possible from everyone, except Elizabeth; her brother especially wanted to keep it from all of Bingley's relatives due to the same wish Elizabeth had long ago attributed to him, namely the wish for Bingley's relatives to be his relatives.
es: Darcy wanted to conceal it from all of Bingley's relatives for that same desire, which Elizabeth had attributed to him for so long, of becoming part of their family.

en: He had certainly formed such a plan; and without meaning that it should affect his endeavour to separate him from Miss Bennet, it is probable that it might add something to his lively concern for the welfare of his friend.
vi: He certainly had such a plan, and while he had no intention of separating Bingley and Miss Bennet, the plan might have caused him to worry about his friend's happiness.
tr: Of course, he had made such a plan; although it might not have had an effect on his effort to separate Bingley from Miss Bennet, it could have contributed to his concern for his friend's well-being.
es: Darcy, in fact, had this purpose, and although it was not for this reason that he sought to separate his friend from Jane, it is likely that it added to his keen interest in Bingley's happiness.

en: Elizabeth’s collected behaviour, however, soon quieted his emotion; and as Miss Bingley, vexed and disappointed, dared not approach nearer to Wickham, Georgiana also recovered in time, though not enough to be able to speak any more.
vi: However, Elizabeth's calm reaction reassured him, and when Miss Bingley, frustrated and disappointed, no longer dared to imply anything about Wickham, Georgiana also calmed down, though not enough to say anything further.
tr: Elizabeth quickly calmed her excitement with her careful demeanor; Georgiana, who was disappointed and bored, gradually recovered as Miss Bingley did not dare to approach Wickham any further, but of course, she could not speak to anyone for a while.
es: But Elizabeth's attitude reassured him. Miss Bingley, humiliated and disappointed, did not dare to allude to anything related to Wickham again. Georgiana began to recover, but she remained definitively silent, not daring to face her brother's gaze.

en: Her brother, whose eye she feared to meet, scarcely recollected her interest in the affair; and the very circumstance which had been designed to turn his thoughts from Elizabeth, seemed to have fixed them on her more and more cheerfully.
