vi: Her brother no longer remembered much about his sister's affair, and the very circumstances created to distract him from Elizabeth made him pay even more attention to Elizabeth, and he became even more cheerful.
tr: Her brother, whose eyes she was afraid to meet, did not seem to remember her involvement in the matter; the words designed to distract his mind from Elizabeth seemed to fix his mind on Elizabeth even more and with more joy.
es: Darcy did not dwell on what had happened, but instead of putting Elizabeth out of his mind, Miss Bingley's insinuation seemed to excite his passion even more.

en: Their visit did not continue long after the question and answer above mentioned; and while mr Darcy was attending them to their carriage, Miss Bingley was venting her feelings in criticisms on Elizabeth’s person, behaviour, and dress.
vi: The two people did not stay seated for much longer. While Mr. Darcy escorted them to their carriage, Miss Bingley vented her anger through comments about Elizabeth's character, manners, and attire.
tr: After the question-and-answer session described above, their visit did not last long; while Mr. Darcy accompanied them to their carriage, Miss Bingley was venting by criticizing Elizabeth's personality, behavior, and attire.
es: After the aforementioned question and answer, the visit did not last much longer, and while Darcy accompanied the ladies to the carriage, Miss Bingley vented by criticizing Elizabeth's behavior and attire.

en: But Georgiana would not join her.
vi: But Georgiana did not join her.
tr: But Georgiana did not join her.
es: But Georgiana paid her no mind.

en: Her brother’s recommendation was enough to insure her favour: his judgment could not err; and he had spoken in such terms of Elizabeth, as to leave Georgiana without the power of finding her otherwise than lovely and amiable.
vi: Her brother's opinion was enough for her to follow: she believed her brother's judgment was infallible, and he had spoken so many good things about Elizabeth that she could see nothing but beauty and charm in her.
tr: Her brother's admiration was enough to win her heart: her brother could not be mistaken; he had spoken of Elizabeth in such terms that Georgiana had no choice but to find her beautiful and amiable.
es: Her brother's interest in Miss Bennet was more than enough to ensure her approval; his judgment was infallible, and he had spoken of Elizabeth in such terms that Georgiana had to find her amiable and attractive.

en: When Darcy returned to the saloon, Miss Bingley could not help repeating to him some part of what she had been saying to his sister.
vi: When Mr. Darcy returned, Miss Bingley couldn't help but repeat some of the things she had said to his sister:
tr: When Darcy returned to the drawing room, Miss Bingley could not help but share some of what she had been telling her sister with him as well.
es: When Darcy returned to the drawing room, Miss Bingley could not contain herself and had to repeat some of what she had already said to her sister:

en: “How very ill Eliza Bennet looks this morning, mr Darcy,” she cried: “I never in my life saw anyone so much altered as she is since the winter.
vi: - Mr. Darcy, Eliza Bennet looked so ugly this morning. In my life, I have never seen anyone change so much since last winter.
tr: "Eliza Bennet looks so ill this morning, Mr. Darcy," she exclaimed; "how much she has changed since winter; I have never seen anyone change so much in my life.
es: ––How poorly Elizabeth Bennet looked, Mr. Darcy! ––she exclaimed––. How changed I found her since the winter!

en: She is grown so brown and coarse!
vi: She has become so dark and coarse!
tr: She has become brown and coarse!
es: How tanned and unrefined she has become!

en: Louisa and I were agreeing that we should not have known her again.”
vi: Louisa and I have agreed that we do not want to see her anymore.
tr: Louisa and I were saying that we should not see her again."
es: Neither Louisa nor I would have recognized her.

en: However little mr Darcy might have liked such an address, he contented himself with coolly replying, that he perceived no other alteration than her being rather tanned,—no miraculous consequence of travelling in the summer.
vi: Although Mr. Darcy might not be very fond of such words, he still coldly replied that he saw no change except for her tanned skin – which was not the result of a miracle when one travels during the summer. Miss Bingley added:
tr: Although Mr. Darcy did not like such a conversation, he contented himself with answering coldly: he had not seen any change except that she was a little tanned, –it was not a miracle for a person to get tanned when traveling in the summer.
es: The remark amused Darcy very little, but he restrained himself and replied coldly that he had noticed no other change than being tanned by the sun, which was very natural when traveling in summer.

en: “For my own part,” she rejoined, “I must confess that I never could see any beauty in her.
vi: - As for me, I must admit that I have never seen any beauty in her.
tr: "Speaking for myself," continued Miss Bingley, "I must confess that I have not seen any beauty in her.
es: ––For my part ––continued Miss Bingley, I confess that she has never seemed pretty to me.

en: Her face is too thin; her complexion has no brilliancy; and her features are not at all handsome.
vi: Her face is too thin, her complexion is not bright, and her figure is not elegant.
tr: Her face is too thin; her skin lacks brightness; and her features are not delicate at all.
es: Her face is too thin, her complexion is dull, and her features are not at all attractive; her nose has no character and there is nothing remarkable about its lines; she has passable teeth, but they are nothing out of the ordinary, and as for her much-praised eyes, I do not see anything extraordinary about them, they look in a penetrating and stern way that is very unpleasant; and in her whole demeanor, in short, there is so much pretension and a lack of good taste that it is intolerable.

en: Her nose wants character; there is nothing marked in its lines.
vi: Her nose needs more character, there is nothing remarkable about it.
tr: There is no character in her nose; the lines of her nose are not even noticeable.
es: Her face is too thin, her complexion is dull, and her features are not at all attractive; her nose has no character and there is nothing remarkable about its lines; she has passable teeth, but they are nothing out of the ordinary, and as for her much-praised eyes, I do not see anything extraordinary about them, they look in a penetrating and stern way that is very unpleasant; and in her whole demeanor, in short, there is so much pretension and a lack of good taste that it is intolerable.

en: Her teeth are tolerable, but not out of the common way; and as for her eyes, which have sometimes been called so fine, I never could perceive anything extraordinary in them.
vi: Her teeth look decent, but they are just ordinary, and as for her eyes, which some people occasionally claim are beautiful, I have never found anything special about them.
tr: Her teeth are not bad, but just average; as for her eyes, it has been said occasionally that they are beautiful, but in my opinion, there is nothing extraordinary about them.
es: Her face is too thin, her complexion is dull, and her features are not at all attractive; her nose has no character and there is nothing remarkable about its lines; she has passable teeth, but they are nothing out of the ordinary, and as for her much-praised eyes, I do not see anything extraordinary about them, they look in a penetrating and stern way that is very unpleasant; and in her whole demeanor, in short, there is so much pretension and a lack of good taste that it is intolerable.

en: They have a sharp, shrewish look, which I do not like at all; and in her air altogether, there is a self-sufficiency without fashion, which is intolerable.”
vi: Her eyes have a sharp, harsh look that I do not like at all. And in her entire demeanor, there is a self-satisfaction that is not polite and is unacceptable.
tr: She has a harsh, irritable look that I do not like at all; overall, there is a careless arrogance in her demeanor that I find unbearable."
es: Her face is too thin, her complexion is dull, and her features are not at all attractive; her nose has no character and there is nothing remarkable about its lines; she has passable teeth, but they are nothing out of the ordinary, and as for her much-praised eyes, I do not see anything extraordinary about them, they look in a penetrating and stern way that is very unpleasant; and in her whole demeanor, in short, there is so much pretension and a lack of good taste that it is intolerable.

en: Persuaded as Miss Bingley was that Darcy admired Elizabeth, this was not the best method of recommending herself; but angry people are not always wise; and in seeing him at last look somewhat nettled, she had all the success she expected.
vi: When Miss Bingley believed that Mr. Darcy was fond of Elizabeth, this was not the best way to elevate herself. But angry people are not always rational, and seeing that he seemed irritated, she thought she had succeeded.
tr: Miss Bingley had believed that Darcy admired Elizabeth, but she had not chosen a good way to ingratiate herself; however, angry people are not always smart; in the end, when Darcy appeared a bit bored, she achieved all the success she had hoped for.
es: Knowing as Miss Bingley did that Darcy admired Elizabeth, this was not at all the best way to please him, but irritated people do not usually act wisely; and seeing that she was provoking him, she achieved the success she expected.

en: He was resolutely silent, however; and, from a determination of making him speak, she continued,—
vi: But he remained resolutely silent, and wanting him to speak, she continued:
tr: However, Darcy remained tightly silent; Miss Bingley, determined to make him talk, continued,
es: However, he remained silent, but Miss Bingley was determined to make him speak and continued:

en: “I remember, when we first knew her in Hertfordshire, how amazed we all were to find that she was a reputed beauty; and I particularly recollect your saying one night, after they had been dining at Netherfield, ‘She a beauty!
vi: - I still remember, when we first met her in Hertfordshire, we were surprised to see that she was beautiful.
tr: "I remember how surprised we all were when we first met her in Hertfordshire and found out she was a famous beauty; especially that one night after dinner at Netherfield, when you said, 'If she is a beauty, we might as well call her mother a scholar.'
es: ––I remember that the first time we saw her in Hertfordshire, we were surprised that she had a reputation for being beautiful; and I especially remember that one night when they had dined at Netherfield, you said: "If she is a beauty, her mother is a genius!"

en: I should as soon call her mother a wit.’
vi: I particularly remember one day after they had dinner at Netherfield, you said, "Her, beautiful! – I think her mother was quite witty.”
tr: "I remember how surprised we all were when we first met her in Hertfordshire and found out she was a famous beauty; especially that one night after dinner at Netherfield, when you said, 'If she is a beauty, we might as well call her mother a scholar.'
es: ––I remember that the first time we saw her in Hertfordshire, we were surprised that she had a reputation for being beautiful; and I especially remember that one night when they had dined at Netherfield, you said: "If she is a beauty, her mother is a genius!"

en: But afterwards she seemed to improve on you, and I believe you thought her rather pretty at one time.”
vi: But after that, she seemed somewhat better to you, so I believe at some point you thought she was quite pretty.
tr: But later on, she seemed to have an effect on you, and if I'm not mistaken, at one point you found her beautiful."
es: But afterwards, it seemed that you started to like her, and I believe you came to consider her pretty at some point.

en: “Yes,” replied Darcy, who could contain himself no longer, “but that was only when I first knew her; for it is many months since I have considered her as one of the handsomest women of my acquaintance.”
vi: Darcy replied, when he could no longer hold back: - Yes, but that was only when I first got to know her, and for many months afterwards I considered her the most beautiful among the people I knew.
tr: "Yes," answered Darcy; he could no longer contain himself; "but that was only when I first met her, because for months I have thought she is one of the most beautiful women I have ever known."
es: ––Yes ––replied Darcy, unable to contain himself any longer––, but that was when I first started to get to know her, because for many months now I have considered her one of the most beautiful women I have ever seen.

en: He then went away, and Miss Bingley was left to all the satisfaction of having forced him to say what gave no one any pain but herself.
vi: Then he walked away, leaving Miss Bingley sitting with the satisfaction of having forced him to speak, but what he said only caused her pain.
tr: Then he left, and Miss Bingley was left with the full satisfaction of having forced him to say something that caused pain to no one but herself.
es: Having said this, he left, and Miss Bingley was very pleased to have forced him to say what only hurt her.

en: ms Gardiner and Elizabeth talked of all that had occurred during their visit, as they returned, except what had particularly interested them both.
vi: Upon returning, Mrs. Gardiner and Elizabeth conversed about the events of their visit, except for the points each was most interested in.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner and Elizabeth talked about what happened during their visit on the way back, but they did not mention the thing that particularly interested both of them.
es: On the way back from Lambton, Mrs. Gardiner and Elizabeth discussed everything that had happened during the visit, except for what interested them both the most.

en: The looks and behaviour of everybody they had seen were discussed, except of the person who had mostly engaged their attention.
vi: They discussed the demeanor and gestures of everyone they had met, except for the person they paid the most attention to.
tr: They talked about the appearance and behavior of everyone they saw, but they did not mention the person they paid the most attention to.
es: They talked about the appearance and behavior of everyone, without mentioning the person to whom they had paid the most attention.

en: They talked of his sister, his friends, his house, his fruit, of everything but himself; yet Elizabeth was longing to know what ms Gardiner thought of him, and ms Gardiner would have been highly gratified by her niece’s beginning the subject.
vi: They talked about his sister, his friends, his estate, the fruits, everything, except about him; but Elizabeth was very eager to know what Mrs. Gardiner thought of him, while Mrs. Gardiner would have been very pleased if her niece had broached the subject.
tr: They talked about his sister, his friends, his house, his fruits, in short, everything about him except himself; yet Elizabeth wanted to know what Mrs. Gardiner thought about him, and Mrs. Gardiner was impatient for her niece to bring up the subject.
es: They spoke about his sister, his friends, his house, his fruits, everything except for him, despite Elizabeth's desire to know what Mrs. Gardiner thought of Darcy, and how much Mrs. Gardiner would have been pleased if her niece had brought up the subject.

en: Chapter XLVI.
vi: Chapter 46
tr: Chapter IV
es: CHAPTER XLVI

en: ELIZABETH had been a good deal disappointed in not finding a letter from Jane on their first arrival at Lambton; and this disappointment had been renewed on each of the mornings that had now been spent there; but on the third her repining was over, and her sister justified, by the receipt of two letters from her at once, on one of which was marked that it had been mis-sent elsewhere.
vi: Elizabeth was very disappointed when she arrived in Lambton and did not see a letter from Jane, and even more disappointed the next day. But on the third day, she was no longer upset, her sister was vindicated when two letters arrived at the same time, one of which had been misdirected somewhere.
tr: Elizabeth was very surprised when she saw that no letter had arrived from Jane upon their first arrival at Lambton; this surprise grew with each morning they spent there; but on the third morning, her concern dissipated; her sister was proven right by receiving two letters from her at the same time; one of the letters had been marked as incorrectly addressed.
es: Upon arriving at Lambton, Elizabeth was displeased not to find a letter from Jane; the displeasure was renewed every morning, but on the third day, she received two letters at once, one of which contained a note saying that it had been misplaced and sent to another location, which did not surprise Elizabeth, because Jane had addressed it very poorly.

en: Elizabeth was not surprised at it, as Jane had written the direction remarkably ill.
vi: Elizabeth was not surprised by this, as her sister had written the address unclearly.
tr: Elizabeth was not surprised by this, as Jane had written the address very illegibly.
es: Upon arriving at Lambton, Elizabeth was displeased not to find a letter from Jane; the displeasure was renewed every morning, but on the third day, she received two letters at once, one of which contained a note saying that it had been misplaced and sent to another location, which did not surprise Elizabeth, because Jane had addressed it very poorly.

en: They had just been preparing to walk as the letters came in; and her uncle and aunt, leaving her to enjoy them in quiet, set off by themselves.
vi: They were ready to go for a walk when she received two letters. Her uncle and aunt went ahead to give her some privacy.
tr: They were just about to go for a walk when the letters arrived; her uncle and aunt went for a walk on their own to let her enjoy the letters in silence.
es: At the moment the two letters arrived, they were about to go for a walk, and to let her enjoy them quietly, her uncles went off alone.

en: The one mis-sent must be first attended to; it had been written five days ago.
vi: She needed to read the misdelivered letter that was written five days ago first.
tr: The wrongly sent letter had to be read first; it had been written five days earlier.
es: Elizabeth first read the lost letter, which was five days late.

en: The beginning contained an account of all their little parties and engagements, with such news as the country afforded; but the latter half, which was dated a day later, and written in evident agitation, gave more important intelligence.
vi: At the beginning, the letter talked about small interactions and some other news, but the latter part, dated the next day, seemed to be written in a disturbed state of mind, conveying more important news:
tr: The introduction described their small parties and invitations, giving news from the village; but the second letter, dated the next day, was written in a semi-urgent manner and contained more important information.
es: At first, it recounted the small gatherings and invitations, and gave the few news that the countryside allowed; but the last half, dated a day later and written with evident agitation, said much more important things:

en: It was to this effect:—
vi: At the beginning, the letter talked about small interactions and some other news, but the latter part, dated the next day, seemed to be written in a disturbed state of mind, conveying more important news:
tr: It said:
es: At first, it recounted the small gatherings and invitations, and gave the few news that the countryside allowed; but the last half, dated a day later and written with evident agitation, said much more important things:

en: “Since writing the above, dearest Lizzy, something has occurred of a most unexpected and serious nature; but I am afraid of alarming you—be assured that we are all well.
vi: “Dear Lizzy, since writing the above, an unexpected and serious matter has occurred, but I fear you will worry – rest assured that our whole family is healthy.
tr: "After writing the above, my dear Lizzy, something unexpected and serious happened, but I am afraid of alarming you – believe me, we are all well.
es: After having written the above, dearest Elizabeth, something very serious and unexpected has occurred; but do not be alarmed, we are all well.

en: What I have to say relates to poor Lydia.
vi: The matter I am about to tell you concerns Lydia.
tr: What I have to tell you is about poor Lydia.
es: What I am going to tell you concerns poor Lydia.

en: An express came at twelve last night, just as we were all gone to bed, from Colonel Forster, to inform us that she was gone off to Scotland with one of his officers; to own the truth, with Wickham!
vi: An urgent message arrived at midnight last night, informing us that she has eloped to Scotland with an officer: to be precise, Wickham!
tr: Last night at twelve, just as we were going to bed, a courier came from Colonel Forster; he reported that Lydia had gone to Scotland with one of the officers; you understand, with Wickham!
es: Last night at eleven, when we were going to bed, an express arrived sent by Colonel Forster to inform us that our sister had eloped to Scotland with one of the officers; to be blunt: with Wickham.

en: Imagine our surprise.
vi: Imagine the astonishment of the household.
tr: – Imagine how surprised we were.
es: Imagine our surprise.

en: To Kitty, however, it does not seem so wholly unexpected.
vi: However, for Kitty, this was not entirely unexpected.
tr: However, Kitty did not seem so surprised.
es: However, Catherine did not find it surprising at all.

en: I am very, very sorry.
vi: I am sad, very sad.
tr: I am very, very sorry.
es: I am very sad.

en: So imprudent a match on both sides!
vi: Both are reckless.
tr: Such an imprudent union for both sides! –
es: What imprudence on the part of both!

en: But I am willing to hope the best, and that his character has been misunderstood.
vi: But I want to hope for the best, that his character has been misunderstood.
tr: But I prefer to hope for the best and think that we have misunderstood Wickham's character.
es: But I want to hope for the best and that Wickham is not as bad as believed, that he is merely frivolous and indiscreet; for what he has done ––let us be glad of it–– does not indicate a bad heart.

en: Thoughtless and indiscreet I can easily believe him, but this step (and let us rejoice over it) marks nothing bad at heart.
vi: I can easily believe he lacks judgment and discretion, but that there is nothing bad in his soul.
tr: I can easily believe that he is thoughtless and irresponsible, but this step (I think we should be glad) shows that there is no malice in him.
es: But I want to hope for the best and that Wickham is not as bad as believed, that he is merely frivolous and indiscreet; for what he has done ––let us be glad of it–– does not indicate a bad heart.

en: His choice is disinterested at least, for he must know my father can give her nothing.
vi: At least he has no intention of taking advantage of her, for he must know that father has nothing to leave her.
tr: At least he has not made a mercenary choice, because he knows that my father can give Lydia nothing.
es: His choice, after all, is disinterested, because he knows that our father cannot give Lydia anything.

en: Our poor mother is sadly grieved.
vi: Our poor mother is very distressed.
tr: Our poor mother is very distressed.
es: Our poor mother is dismayed.

en: My father bears it better.
vi: Father is bearing it better.
tr: My father is bearing it better.
es: Father is taking it better.

en: How thankful am I, that we never let them know what has been said against him; we must forget it ourselves.
vi: I am very glad that we never let them know what people have been saying about him; we should forget these matters.
tr: I am so glad we did not tell them what was said about Wickham; we must forget these things ourselves too.
es: How right we were not to tell them what we knew about Wickham! We ourselves must forget it.

en: They were off Saturday night about twelve, as is conjectured, but were not missed till yesterday morning at eight.
vi: The two people left around 12 o'clock on Saturday night, it is guessed, but it wasn't until 8 o'clock yesterday morning that people found out.
tr: They left around twelve on Saturday night, presumably, but it was not noticed until eight the next morning.
es: It is supposed that they eloped on Saturday at about twelve, but they were not missed until yesterday at eight in the morning.

en: The express was sent off directly.
vi: An urgent letter was sent immediately.
tr: A courier was sent immediately.
es: They immediately sent the express.

en: My dear Lizzy, they must have passed within ten miles of us.
vi: Dear Lizzy, they must have passed by our house about ten miles away.
tr: My dear Lizzy, they must have passed within ten miles of us.
es: Dear Elizabeth, they must have passed less than ten miles from you!

en: Colonel Forster gives us reason to expect him here soon.
vi: Colonel Forster announced the reason to come to the house.
tr: According to Colonel Forster, we may see him here soon.
es: Colonel Forster says he will come at once.

en: Lydia left a few lines for his wife, informing her of their intention.
vi: Lydia left a few lines for his wife, informing her of her intentions.
tr: Lydia left a few lines for his wife, explaining her intention.
es: Lydia left a few lines written for Mrs. Forster informing her of her intentions.

en: I must conclude, for I cannot be long from my poor mother.
vi: I have to end the letter here, because I don't want to be away from mother for long.
tr: I must stop now, because I cannot leave my mother for long.
es: I have to finish, for I cannot extend myself because of my poor mother.

en: I am afraid you will not be able to make it out, but I hardly know what I have written.”
vi: I'm worried you won't understand the whole story, but I don't even know what I've written.”
tr: I fear you will not be able to read my writing, but I am not aware of what I am writing myself."
es: I fear you will not understand what is written, for I do not even know what I have put.

en: Without allowing herself time for consideration, and scarcely knowing what she felt, Elizabeth, on finishing this letter, instantly seized the other, and opening it with the utmost impatience, read as follows: it had been written a day later than the conclusion of the first.
vi: Not allowing herself time to think and not knowing what she was thinking, after finishing the first letter, Elizabeth hastily opened the second letter to read, which was written one day after the previous letter.
tr: Without giving herself time to think and without knowing what she felt, Elizabeth immediately grabbed the other letter as soon as she finished this one; she opened it impatiently and read: it was written one day after the first letter.
es: Without taking time to reflect and barely knowing what she felt after finishing the reading of this letter, Elizabeth impatiently opened the other one and read the following, written a day later:

en: “By this time, my dearest sister, you have received my hurried letter; I wish this may be more intelligible, but though not confined for time, my head is so bewildered that I cannot answer for being coherent.
vi: “My dear, at this moment you have received the previous letter I wrote in haste. I hope this letter is clearer, but my mind is still confused so perhaps it is still not coherent.
tr: "By now, my dear brother, you must have received my hastily written letter; I hope this one is more legible, but although I am not pressed for time, my mind is so unsettled that I may not be able to be coherent.
es: By this time, dearest sister, you will have received my hurried letter. I hope this one is more intelligible; but, although I have time, my head is so bewildered that I cannot be coherent.

en: Dearest Lizzy, I hardly know what I would write, but I have bad news for you, and it cannot be delayed.
vi: Dearest Lizzy, I don't know what to write, but I have bad news for you, which cannot be delayed.
tr: Dear Lizzy, I don't know what to write, but I have bad news for you, and it cannot be delayed.
es: Dear Eliza, I would rather not write to you, but I have bad news to give you and I cannot delay it.

en: Imprudent as a marriage between mr Wickham and our poor Lydia would be, we are now anxious to be assured it has taken place, for there is but too much reason to fear they are not gone to Scotland.
vi: Although the marriage between Wickham and the poor girl is imprudent, the family is anxious to hear that they have married, as there are many reasons to fear they did not go to Scotland.
tr: While the idea of a marriage between Mr. Wickham and our poor Lydia was considered imprudent, now we are anxious to be assured that they are married, because there are many reasons to fear that they did not go to Scotland.
es: However imprudent the marriage of Wickham and our poor Lydia may be, we are anxious to know that it has already taken place, for there are ample reasons to fear that they have not gone to Scotland.

en: Colonel Forster came yesterday, having left Brighton the day before, not many hours after the express.
vi: Colonel Forster came to the house yesterday, after leaving Brington the day before, a few hours after the urgent news.
tr: Colonel Forster arrived yesterday; he had set out from Brighton the day before, just a few hours after the courier.
es: Colonel Forster arrived yesterday; he left Brighton a few hours after the couple themselves.

en: Though Lydia’s short letter to ms F. gave them to understand that they were going to Gretna Green, something was dropped by Denny expressing his belief that W. never intended to go there, or to marry Lydia at all, which was repeated to Colonel F., who, instantly taking the alarm, set off from B., intending to trace their route.
vi: Although Lydia's letter to Mrs. F. stated that the two intended to go to Gretna Green. Denny has reason to believe that W. never intended to go there, nor to marry Lydia at all. Colonel F. immediately sent out a notice upon hearing this news, then left B. to trace their route.
tr: According to the note Lydia wrote to Mrs. F., they were going to Gretna Green, but in the meantime, Denny said that he did not believe W. intended to go there or to marry Lydia; when this was conveyed to Colonel Forster, he immediately became alarmed and set out from B. to follow them.
es: Although Lydia's letter to Mrs. Forster implied that they were going to Gretna Green, Denny said that he was aware and that Wickham never intended to go there nor to marry Lydia; upon learning this, Colonel Forster became alarmed and immediately left Brighton with the idea of catching up with them.

en: He did trace them easily to Clapham, but no farther; for on entering that place, they removed into a hackney-coach, and dismissed the chaise that brought them from Epsom.
vi: He tracked them to Clapham but lost the trail, as the two traveled there by a small carriage and then switched to a hired carriage.
tr: He tracked them easily as far as Clapham but could go no further; for there they had hired a carriage and dismissed the one that had brought them from Epsom.
es: He indeed followed their trail easily to Clapham, but could not continue further, because upon reaching that point they took a hired carriage, leaving the post chaise that had brought them from Epsom.

en: All that is known after this is, that they were seen to continue the London road.
vi: From there, they only know that the two were seen continuing on the road to London.
tr: After that, all that is known is that they continued on the road to London.
es: And nothing more is known except that they were seen taking the road to London.

en: I know not what to think.
vi: I don't know what to think.
tr: I don't know what to think.
es: I do not know what to think.

en: After making every possible inquiry on that side London, Colonel F. came on into Hertfordshire, anxiously renewing them at all the turnpikes, and at the inns in Barnet and Hatfield, but without any success,—no such people had been seen to pass through.
vi: After inquiring everywhere on that side of London, Colonel F. went to Hertfordshire, continuing to inquire at the turnings, at the inns in Barnet and Hatfield, but could not find them, no one had seen such a pair pass through.
tr: After making every possible inquiry on that side of London, Colonel F. came to Hertfordshire, searched for them at the toll gates and in Barnet and Hatfield, but to no avail, as no one had seen such persons pass through.
es: After making all possible inquiries from there to London, Colonel Forster came to Hertfordshire to repeat them at all the toll gates and inns in Barnet and Hatfield, but without any result; no one has seen those persons there.

en: With the kindest concern he came on to Longbourn, and broke his apprehensions to us in a manner most creditable to his heart.
vi: He was kind enough to visit the house, providing the news in the most reliable way from his heart.
tr: He came to Longbourn in distress and told us what he had learned in sorrow.
es: With the greatest regret, he arrived at Longbourn to inform us of everything, in a manner that does him honor.

en: I am sincerely grieved for him and ms F.; but no one can throw any blame on them.
vi: I also feel sorry for Mr. and Mrs. F. but no one can blame them.
tr: I am truly sorry for him and Mrs. F., but no one can blame them.
es: I am truly sorry for him and his wife; no one can reproach them.

en: Our distress, my dear Lizzy, is very great.
vi: Dear Lizzy, the family is in great distress.
tr: Our distress, dear Lizzy, is immense.
es: Our grief is very great.

en: My father and mother believe the worst, but I cannot think so ill of him.
vi: Both parents are thinking the worst, but she cannot think ill of her father.
tr: My father and mother believe the worst, but I cannot think so ill of W. Instead of carrying out their first plan, they may have found it more suitable for various reasons to marry secretly in town; even if Lydia, in her position, had such intentions, which is impossible, can I think Lydia would disregard everything?
es: Father and mother expect the worst, but I cannot believe that Wickham is so wicked.

en: Many circumstances might make it more eligible for them to be married privately in town than to pursue their first plan; and even if he could form such a design against a young woman of Lydia’s connections, which is not likely, can I suppose her so lost to everything?
vi: Many situations suggest that the two might marry discreetly in the city rather than pursue their original intention, and even if he had such intentions towards a young girl of a lower class like Lydia, unlikely as it may be, would the girl lose much?
tr: My father and mother believe the worst, but I cannot think so ill of W. Instead of carrying out their first plan, they may have found it more suitable for various reasons to marry secretly in town; even if Lydia, in her position, had such intentions, which is impossible, can I think Lydia would disregard everything?
es: Many circumstances may have driven them to marry secretly in the capital instead of following their first plan; and even in the case that he had plotted the ruin of a girl from a good family like Lydia, which is not likely, should I believe her so lost?

en: Impossible!
vi: It cannot be.
tr: –Impossible.
es: Impossible.

en: I grieve to find, however, that Colonel F. is not disposed to depend upon their marriage: he shook his head when I expressed my hopes, and said he feared W. was not a man to be trusted.
vi: However, she is saddened to see that Colonel F. does not believe in the marriage; he shook his head when she expressed such a hope, and said he feared W. is not a trustworthy person.
tr: On the other hand, Colonel F.'s inclination not to believe they are married greatly distresses me; when I expressed my hopes, he shook his head and said he feared W. was not a trustworthy man.
es: It dismays me, however, to see that Colonel Forster does not trust that they have married; when I expressed my hopes to him, he shook his head and expressed his fear that Wickham is not to be trusted.

en: My poor mother is really ill, and keeps her room.
vi: The poor mother was really sick and stayed in her room.
tr: My poor mother is ill, confined to her room.
es: My poor mother is truly ill and does not leave her room.

en: Could she exert herself, it would be better, but this is not to be expected; and as to my father, I never in my life saw him so affected.
vi: It would be better if she had more willpower, but one shouldn't count on that. As for the father, she had never seen him so emotional.
tr: It would be good for her to show herself, but we cannot expect it; as for my father, I have never seen him so upset in my life.
es: As for my father, I have never seen him so affected.

en: Poor Kitty has anger for having concealed their attachment; but as it was a matter of confidence, one cannot wonder.
vi: The parents were angry with poor little Kitty for hiding the matter between the two, but this is a private issue that we cannot question.
tr: Poor Kitty is blamed by everyone for keeping their companionship a secret; but what could she do, things told in confidence.
es: Poor Catherine is desperate for having concealed Lydia and Wickham's romance, but it is not surprising that the girls confided in each other.

en: I am truly glad, dearest Lizzy, that you have been spared something of these distressing scenes; but now, as the first shock is over, shall I own that I long for your return?
vi: Dear Lizzy, I am truly happy to see you avoid these painful scenes, but now that the initial shock has passed, can I hope for your return?
tr: I am truly glad, dear Lizzy, that you are not here to witness these distressing scenes; but now that we have passed the initial shock, may I confess that I wish for your return?
es: Dearest Lizzy, I am sincerely glad that you have been spared these painful scenes. But now that the first blow has passed, I confess that I long for your return.

en: I am not so selfish, however, as to press for it, if inconvenient.
vi: However, I am not so selfish as to compel you, if it is not convenient.
tr: However, if it is not convenient, I am not selfish enough to insist.
es: I am not selfish, however, to the extent of asking you to come back if you cannot.

en: Adieu!
vi: Goodbye.
tr: Goodbye.
es: Goodbye.

en: I take up my pen again to do, what I have just told you I would not; but circumstances are such, that I cannot help earnestly begging you all to come here as soon as possible.
vi: You are picking up the pen to do what you just wrote above that you wouldn't do, because circumstances compel you to earnestly call for you to return as soon as possible.
tr: I have taken up my pen again to do what I just said I would not, but the circumstances are such that I cannot help it, I beg you all to come here as soon as possible.
es: I take up the pen again to do what I just told you I would not do, but the circumstances are such that I cannot help but implore the three of you to come as soon as possible.

en: I know my dear uncle and aunt so well, that I am not afraid of requesting it, though I have still something more to ask of the former.
vi: I understand uncle and aunt's nature well, so I am not afraid to make such a request, although I have other matters to ask of him.
tr: Knowing my dear uncle and aunt well, I am not hesitant to make this request, but there is one more thing I ask of them.
es: I know our dear uncles so well that I do not doubt they will agree. I also have another request to make of our uncle.

en: My father is going to London with Colonel Forster instantly, to try to discover her.
vi: Father will go to London immediately with Colonel Forster to try to find the girl.
tr: My father is going to London immediately with Colonel Forster to search for them.
es: My father is going to London with Colonel Forster to see if they can find her.

en: What he means to do, I am sure I know not; but his excessive distress will not allow him to pursue any measure in the best and safest way, and Colonel Forster is obliged to be at Brighton again to-morrow evening.
vi: I don't know exactly what father intends to do, but he is too distressed to act carefully, while Colonel Forster is obliged to return to Brighton tomorrow night.
tr: I do not know what he intends to do; but his extreme distress will not allow him to conduct any business properly and safely; Colonel Forster must return to Brighton by tomorrow evening.
es: I do not know what they plan to do, but he is so dejected that he will not be able to take the best and most expeditious measures, and Colonel Forster has no choice but to be in Brighton by tomorrow night.

en: In such an exigence my uncle’s advice and assistance would be everything in the world; he will immediately comprehend what I must feel, and I rely upon his goodness.”
vi: In this urgent matter, your opinion and support will be very helpful; he will immediately understand what I mean, and I am relying on his goodwill.
tr: In such an urgent situation, my uncle's advice and assistance would be most beneficial; he will immediately understand what I feel; I rely on his compassion."
es: In this situation, our uncle's advice and assistance would be of great help. He will understand this; I count on his kindness.

en: “Oh! where, where is my uncle?” cried Elizabeth, darting from her seat as she finished the letter, in eagerness to follow him, without losing a moment of the time so precious; but as she reached the door, it was opened by a servant, and mr Darcy appeared.
vi: As soon as she finished reading the letter, Elizabeth exclaimed: "Oh! Where is my uncle, where is my uncle?", then ran outside, but when she reached the door, a servant opened it, and Mr. Darcy appeared.
tr: "Uncle, where is my uncle?" cried Elizabeth, leaping up from her seat like an arrow to follow him after finishing the letter, so as not to waste any precious time; but just as she reached the door, it was opened by a servant and Mr. Darcy appeared.
es: ––Where, where is my uncle? ––exclaimed Elizabeth, rising from the chair as soon as she finished reading and determined not to lose a single moment; but as she reached the door, a servant opened it and Darcy entered. Elizabeth's pale countenance and urgency alarmed him.

en: Her pale face and impetuous manner made him start, and before he could recover himself enough to speak, she, in whose mind every idea was superseded by Lydia’s situation, hastily exclaimed, “I beg your pardon, but I must leave you.
vi: Her pale face and frantic demeanor stunned him, and before he could regain his composure, she hurriedly said: - I'm sorry, but I have to go.
tr: Elizabeth's pale face and anxious demeanor surprised him; before she could gather herself enough to speak, Elizabeth, with Lydia's situation foremost in her mind, hastily exclaimed, "I beg your pardon, but I must leave you.
es: Before he could recover enough to speak to her, Elizabeth, who could think of nothing but Lydia's situation, exclaimed hastily:

en: I must find mr Gardiner this moment on business that cannot be delayed; I have not an instant to lose.”
vi: I have to go find Mr. Gardiner now, because there's something that can't be delayed, I can't waste any time.
tr: I need to find Mr. Gardiner immediately, it's an urgent matter; I can't afford to lose a moment."
es: ––Excuse me, but I have to leave you; I need to speak with Mr. Gardiner immediately about a matter that cannot be delayed; there is no time to lose.

en: “Good God! what is the matter?” cried he, with more feeling than politeness; then recollecting himself, “I will not detain you a minute; but let me, or let the servant, go after mr and ms Gardiner.
vi: - My God! What happened? Then he calmed himself down: - I do not wish to detain you for a moment, but please allow me, or let a servant go find Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner.
tr: "My God! What is the matter?" cried Darcy, more in excitement than politeness; then composing himself, "I won't keep you for even a moment, but let me call them, or let the servant call them.
es: ––My God! What is this about? ––he asked with more feeling than courtesy; then, recovering himself, he said––: I don't want to detain you for even a minute; but allow me to be the one to go in search of Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner or send a servant.

en: You are not well enough; you cannot go yourself.”
vi: You are not well – you cannot go by yourself.
tr: You are not well; you cannot go by yourself."
es: You cannot go in those conditions.

en: Elizabeth hesitated; but her knees trembled under her, and she felt how little would be gained by her attempting to pursue them.
vi: Elizabeth hesitated, but her knees were trembling, and she thought it would be more disadvantageous if she went by herself.
tr: Elizabeth hesitated, but her knees were trembling, and she felt how futile it would be to try to follow them.
es: Elizabeth hesitated; but her knees were trembling and she realized that she would gain nothing by trying to catch up with them.

en: Calling back the servant, therefore, she commissioned him, though in so breathless an accent as made her almost unintelligible, to fetch his master and mistress home instantly.
vi: She called a servant over, with a breathless voice that was almost unintelligible, asking him to immediately find the couple.
tr: Upon this, she called back the servant and told him, in a voice almost unintelligible from breathlessness, to bring his master and mistress home immediately.
es: Consequently, she called the servant and instructed him to bring her masters without delay, although she gave the order in such a faint voice that she was barely heard.

en: On his quitting the room, she sat down, unable to support herself, and looking so miserably ill, that it was impossible for Darcy to leave her, or to refrain from saying, in a tone of gentleness and commiseration, “Let me call your maid.
vi: Then she sat down, unable to stand on her own, and her appearance was so miserable that Darcy couldn't leave her, nor could he stop himself from asking about her, gently and sympathetically: - Let me call your servant.
tr: When the servant left the room, Elizabeth sat down; she couldn't stand; she looked so terribly ill that it was impossible for Darcy to leave her; in a gentle and warm voice, he said, "Shall I call your maid?
es: When the servant left the room, Elizabeth collapsed into a chair, unable to support herself. She looked so distraught that Darcy could not leave her without saying in an affectionate and compassionate tone: ––I am going to call your maid.

en: Is there nothing you could take to give you present relief?
vi: Do you want anything to help you calm down?
tr: Is there any medicine you can take, something to ease you?
es: What could you take to feel better?

en: A glass of wine; shall I get you one?
vi: How about some wine, shall I get you a glass?
tr: –How about some wine –shall I bring you some wine?
es: A glass of wine? I am going to bring it to you.

en: You are very ill.”
vi: You look very weak.
tr: –You look very ill," he said.
es: You are sick.

en: “No, I thank you,” she replied, endeavouring to recover herself.
vi: She replied, trying to center herself: - No, thank you.
tr: "No, thank you;" replied Elizabeth, trying to pull herself together.
es: ––No, thank you ––replied Elizabeth, trying to calm herself––.

en: “There is nothing the matter with me.
vi: I have nothing to worry about. I still feel fine.
tr: "There is nothing wrong with me.
es: It's nothing of mine. I am fine.

en: I am quite well, I am only distressed by some dreadful news which I have just received from Longbourn.”
vi: I am just saddened by the news I received from Longbourn.
tr: I am perfectly fine. I am just distressed by some terrible news I have just received from Longbourn."
es: The only thing that happens to me is that I am devastated by a horrible news I just received from Longbourn.

en: She burst into tears as she alluded to it, and for a few minutes could not speak another word.
vi: She sobbed when she alluded to it, and for a few minutes couldn't say another word.
tr: When she mentioned the issue, she burst into tears and couldn't say a word for several minutes.
es: Upon saying this, she burst into tears and was unable to speak for a few minutes.

en: Darcy, in wretched suspense, could only say something indistinctly of his
vi: In miserable tension, Darcy could only utter something incoherent about his concern, then silently watched her with compassion.
tr: Darcy, filled with anxious curiosity, could barely express his concern and watched her in a silence full of pity.
es: Darcy, distressed and in suspense, said nothing more than a few vague remarks about his interest in her, and then watched her in silence.

en: “I have not an instant to lose”
vi: In miserable tension, Darcy could only utter something incoherent about his concern, then silently watched her with compassion.
tr: Darcy, filled with anxious curiosity, could barely express his concern and watched her in a silence full of pity.
es: Darcy, distressed and in suspense, said nothing more than a few vague remarks about his interest in her, and then watched her in silence.

en: concern, and observe her in compassionate silence.
vi: In miserable tension, Darcy could only utter something incoherent about his concern, then silently watched her with compassion.
tr: Darcy, filled with anxious curiosity, could barely express his concern and watched her in a silence full of pity.
es: Darcy, distressed and in suspense, said nothing more than a few vague remarks about his interest in her, and then watched her in silence.

en: At length she spoke again.
vi: Finally, she said:
tr: Finally, Elizabeth spoke again.
es: Finally, Elizabeth continued:

en: “I have just had a letter from Jane, with such dreadful news.
vi: - I just received a letter from Jane, with a dreadful piece of news.
tr: "I just received a letter from Jane, bringing terrible news.
es: ––I have had a letter from Jane, and she gives me some dreadful news that cannot be concealed from anyone.

en: It cannot be concealed from anyone.
vi: This news cannot be hidden from anyone.
tr: It's not something that can be hidden from anyone.
es: ––I have had a letter from Jane, and she gives me some dreadful news that cannot be concealed from anyone.

en: My youngest sister has left all her friends—has eloped; has thrown herself into the power of—of mr Wickham.
vi: My youngest sister has left the family… has run away… has fallen under the influence of… of Mr. Wickham.
tr: My youngest sister has abandoned all her friends – she has run away; she has thrown herself into the hands of that – that – Mr. Wickham.
es: My younger sister has abandoned us, she has eloped, she has given herself to... Wickham.

en: They are gone off together from Brighton.
vi: They eloped from Brighton together.
tr: They have eloped from Brighton together.
es: The two have escaped from Brighton.

en: You know him too well to doubt the rest.
vi: You know him too well to guess the rest.
tr: You know him well enough to have no doubt about the rest.
es: You know Wickham too well to understand what that means.

en: She has no money, no connections, nothing that can tempt him to—she is lost for ever.”
vi: She has no money, no acquaintances, nothing to attract him… she will be gone forever.
tr: My sister has no money, no relatives, nothing to make him marry her – the poor girl is ruined forever."
es: Lydia has no money nor anything that could have tempted him... She is lost forever.

en: Darcy was fixed in astonishment.
vi: Darcy was stunned into silence.
tr: Darcy was frozen in place with astonishment.
es: Darcy stood motionless in astonishment.

en: “When I consider,” she added, in a yet more agitated voice, “that I might have prevented it!
vi: She added, her voice trembling: - When I think that I could have prevented this!...
tr: "To think that I could have prevented it!"
es: ––When I think ––added Elizabeth even more agitatedly–– that I could have prevented it!

en: I who knew what he was.
vi: I knew about his character.
tr: Elizabeth continued in an even more excited voice, "I knew who he was.
es: I who knew who Wickham was!

en: Had I but explained some part of it only—some part of what I learnt, to my own family!
vi: If I had just explained a part… a part of what I knew, to my family!
tr: If I had explained even a part of it to my family – even a part of what I knew!
es: If I had explained to my family just a part, something of what I knew about him!

en: Had his character been known, this could not have happened.
vi: If everyone knew about his character, this couldn't have happened.
tr: If they had known his character, none of this would have happened.
es: If they had known him, this would not have happened.

en: But it is all, all too late now.”
vi: But now it’s too late.
tr: But now it's too late, too late for everything."
es: But now it is too late for everything.

en: “I am grieved, indeed,” cried Darcy: “grieved—shocked.
vi: Darcy exclaimed: - I am very sad, truly sad... I am shocked.
tr: "I'm very sorry, truly," cried Darcy; "I'm sorry – I'm shocked.
es: ––I am horrified ––exclaimed Darcy––.

en: But is it certain, absolutely certain?”
vi: But is this news correct, is it absolutely correct?
tr: But is it certain?"
es: But is it true, absolutely true?

en: “Oh, yes!
vi: - Correct.
tr: "Ah yes!
es: ––Unfortunately!

en: They left Brighton together on Sunday night, and were traced almost to London, but not beyond: they are certainly not gone to Scotland.”
vi: They left Brighton on Sunday night, were tracked to London, then disappeared. They certainly did not go to Scotland.
tr: –They went to Brighton together on Sunday night; they were tracked as far as London, but no further; clearly, they did not go to Scotland."
es: They left Brighton on Sunday night and their tracks have been followed up to near London, but no further; it is certain that they have not gone to Scotland.

en: “And what has been done, what has been attempted, to recover her?”
vi: - And what have people done to find her?
tr: "So, what did they do to find it?""
es: ––And what has been done, what have they tried to do to find her?

en: “My father has gone to London, and Jane has written to beg my uncle’s immediate assistance, and we shall be off, I hope, in half an hour.
vi: - My father has gone to London. Jane wrote a letter asking my uncle for help, while I hoped we could set off within half an hour.
tr: "My father has gone to London; Jane also wrote a letter asking for my uncle's help; we will leave within half an hour, I hope.
es: ––My father has gone to London and Jane writes requesting my uncle's immediate help; I hope we will leave within half an hour.

en: But nothing can be done; I know very well that nothing can be done.
vi: But nothing could be done, I knew very well that nothing could be done.
tr: But there is nothing to be done; I know, there isn't.
es: But nothing can be done, I know nothing can be done.

en: How is such a man to be worked on?
vi: How to find them?
tr: How can such a man be persuaded?
es: How to convince such a man?

en: How are they even to be discovered?
vi: How to find them?
tr: How will we find them?
es: How to discover them?

en: I have not the smallest hope.
vi: I had no hope.
tr: I have no hope.
es: I have not the slightest hope.

en: It is every way horrible!”
vi: Everything was too terrible.
tr: It's dreadful in every way!"
es: Any way you look at it, it is horrible.

en: Darcy shook his head in silent acquiescence.
vi: Darcy shook his head in acknowledgment. She continued:
tr: Darcy nodded in silent approval.
es: Darcy nodded silently.

en: “When my eyes were opened to his real character, oh! had I known what I ought, what I dared to do!
vi: - When I opened my eyes and realized his true nature... Oh! I wish I had known what to do, dared to do!
tr: "When I saw his true face. –Ah! If only I knew what I should do, what I could dare!
es: ––Oh, if only when I opened my eyes and saw who Wickham was, I had done what I should have!

en: But I knew not—I was afraid of doing too much.
vi: But I didn't know... I was afraid of acting too harshly.
tr: I didn't know –I was afraid to move forward.
es: But I didn't dare, I feared I would go too far.

en: Wretched, wretched mistake!”
vi: Oh, the misery, it's all my fault!
tr: What a miserable mistake I made!"
es: What an unfortunate mistake!

en: Darcy made no answer.
vi: Darcy did not reply.
tr: Darcy did not respond.
es: Darcy did not respond.

en: He seemed scarcely to hear her, and was walking up and down the room in earnest meditation; his brow contracted, his air gloomy.
vi: It seemed he did not hear everything she said, he was pacing thoughtfully; his eyebrows furrowed, his expression sorrowful.
tr: He seemed not to hear Elizabeth; he was pacing up and down the room in deep thought, his brows furrowed, his expression gloomy.
es: It seemed as if he didn't even hear her; he paced back and forth in the room, absorbed in his thoughts, with a frown and a somber air.

en: Elizabeth soon observed, and instantly understood it.
vi: Before long, Elizabeth noticed and understood immediately.
tr: Elizabeth saw this shortly and immediately understood it.
es: Elizabeth watched him, and in an instant, she understood everything.

en: Her power was sinking; everything must sink under such a proof of family weakness, such an assurance of the deepest disgrace.
vi: Her position was being overshadowed, everything would be overshadowed by the manifestation of a lowly family, an unmistakable sign of utmost humiliation.
tr: Her influence over Darcy was ending; in the face of such proof of family weakness, in the face of such deep shame, everything would be over.
es: The attraction he felt for her had ended; everything had ended before that proof of her family's unworthiness and the certainty of such profound misfortune.

en: She could neither wonder nor condemn; but the belief of his self-conquest brought nothing consolatory to her bosom, afforded no palliation of her distress.
vi: She could neither wonder nor condemn, but her belief in his love brought no comfort to her heart and could not soothe her sorrow.
tr: She could neither be surprised nor angry; the belief that Darcy would distance himself despite his feelings did not console her, did not alleviate her distress.
es: She neither found it strange nor could she blame him. But the belief that Darcy had recovered did not console her pain nor lessen her despair.

en: It was, on the contrary, exactly calculated to make her understand her own wishes; and never had she so honestly felt that she could have loved him, as now, when all love must be vain.
vi: On the contrary, this belief was calculated to help her understand her own desires, and never had she truly thought she could love him as much as she did now, when all love had become hopeless.
tr: On the contrary, everything seemed calculated to make her understand her own desires; she had never felt as deeply as she did now that she could love Darcy, as much as she did in that moment when love seemed so empty.
es: On the contrary, it made the young woman realize her own feelings, and never had she felt so sincerely as at that moment that she could have loved him, when all love was already impossible.

en: But self, though it would intrude, could not engross her.
vi: But even though personal matters intertwined, they could not occupy all her mind.
tr: But even though her own troubles intervened, they could not completely occupy her.
es: But not even this consideration managed to distract her.

en: Lydia—the humiliation, the misery she was bringing on them all—soon swallowed up every private care; and covering her face with her handkerchief, Elizabeth was soon lost to everything else; and, after a pause of several minutes, was only recalled to a sense of her situation by the voice of her companion, who, in a manner which, though it spoke compassion, spoke likewise restraint, said,—
vi: Lydia – the disgrace, the torment that her sister had brought upon the entire family, overshadowed all personal worries. Burying her face in her handkerchief, Elizabeth forgot everything else. After a while, she could only return to reality thanks to Darcy's voice, empathetic yet controlled.
tr: The disgrace and shame that Lydia brought upon her entire family soon erased her personal worries; Elizabeth covered her face with a handkerchief and soon forgot everything else; after a few minutes of silence, her friend's voice brought her back to the present moment, with a kind but measured tone saying: "I fear you have wanted me to leave for some time now; I have no excuse for my continued presence here other than my genuine but futile concern.
es: She could not take Lydia, nor the humiliation and misfortune that had befallen them all, out of her mind. She covered her face with a handkerchief and forgot everything else. After several minutes of silence, she heard Darcy's voice, compassionate yet reserved, saying to her:

en: “I am afraid you have been long desiring my absence, nor have I anything to plead in excuse of my stay, but real, though unavailing concern.
vi: - I fear you do not want my presence here, and I have nothing to ask to stay except for sincere concern, but it is of no help.
tr: The disgrace and shame that Lydia brought upon her entire family soon erased her personal worries; Elizabeth covered her face with a handkerchief and soon forgot everything else; after a few minutes of silence, her friend's voice brought her back to the present moment, with a kind but measured tone saying: "I fear you have wanted me to leave for some time now; I have no excuse for my continued presence here other than my genuine but futile concern.
es: ––I am afraid you want me to leave, and there is nothing that excuses my presence; but I have been moved by a genuine, though useless, interest.

en: Would to Heaven that anything could be either said or done on my part, that might offer consolation to such distress!
vi: I wish I could say or do something to help comfort you.
tr: I wish there was something I could do or say to alleviate your distress.
es: I wish I could say or do something to console you in such misfortune!

en: But I will not torment you with vain wishes, which may seem purposely to ask for your thanks.
vi: But I do not want to trouble you with vain hopes that seem to be spoken only to seek your thanks.
tr: –But I will not burden you with empty wishes that might seem like I am expecting your gratitude.
es: But I do not want to torment you with vain wishes that would seem to be expressed only so that you would thank me.

en: This unfortunate affair will, I fear, prevent my sister’s having the pleasure of seeing you at Pemberley to-day.”
vi: I fear with this unfortunate matter, my sister cannot have the honor of receiving you at Pemberley today.
tr: This unfortunate matter, I fear, will deprive my sister of the pleasure of seeing you at Pemberley today."
es: I believe this unfortunate matter is going to deprive my sister of the pleasure of seeing you today at Pemberley.

en: “Oh, yes!
vi: - Ah yes.
tr: "Ah yes.
es: ––Oh, yes!

en: Be so kind as to apologize for us to Miss Darcy.
vi: Please kindly apologize to Miss Darcy on our behalf, saying that an urgent matter calls us back immediately.
tr: Please convey my apologies to Miss Darcy.
es: Please excuse us to Miss Darcy.

en: Say that urgent business calls us home immediately.
vi: Please kindly apologize to Miss Darcy on our behalf, saying that an urgent matter calls us back immediately.
tr: Tell her that an urgent matter requires us to return home immediately.
es: Tell her that urgent matters call us home without delay.

en: Conceal the unhappy truth as long as it is possible.
vi: Please keep this unfortunate matter confidential for as long as possible.
tr: Please conceal the distressing truth as much as possible.
es: Hide the sad truth from her, although I know it won't be very easy for you.

en: I know it cannot be long.”
vi: I don't think it will be long.
tr: –Now, as far as it goes."
es: Hide the sad truth from her, although I know it won't be very easy for you.

en: He readily assured her of his secrecy, again expressed his sorrow for her distress, wished it a happier conclusion than there was at present reason to hope, and, leaving his compliments for her relations, with only one serious parting look, went away.
vi: He eagerly promised her that he would keep it a secret. Then he expressed his sympathy for her sorrow, hoping for a better outcome than the current reason for hope, and sent his regards to her relatives. Then, with just a solemn farewell glance, he left.
tr: Darcy assured her that he would keep it a secret – he repeated how sorry he was for her distress, wished for a happier ending than currently seemed possible, left his regards to her relatives, and with one serious, parting glance, he left.
es: Darcy promised to be discreet, expressed his sympathy once again for the misfortune, wished that the matter would not end as badly as could be expected, and, asking him to send his regards to his relatives, took his leave with just a serious look.

en: As he quitted the room, Elizabeth felt how improbable it was that they should ever see each other again on such terms of cordiality as had marked their several meetings in Derbyshire; and as she threw a retrospective glance over the whole of their acquaintance, so full of contradictions and varieties, sighed at the perverseness of those feelings which would now have promoted its continuance, and would formerly have rejoiced in its termination.
vi: When he stepped out of the room, Elizabeth thought it was unlikely that he and she would meet again with the same friendliness as in their encounters in Derbyshire. When reflecting on the entire relationship between the two, full of conflicts and upheavals, she sighed for the tangled emotions that now should have been strengthened for the relationship to endure, whereas before she would have been glad if the relationship had ended.
tr: As she left the room, Elizabeth felt how impossible it was for them to see each other again with the same warmth that had enveloped their few meetings in Derbyshire; looking back at the entirety of their relationship, filled with contrasts and changes, she now felt sorrow as she realized that the feelings which would now desire the continuation of the relationship had replaced the feelings that were once satisfied with its end.
es: When Darcy left the room, Elizabeth realized how unlikely it was that they would see each other again with the cordiality that had characterized their encounters in Derbyshire. She recalled the history of her relations with Darcy, so full of contradictions and changes, and appreciated the perversity of the feelings that now made her wish those relations to continue, when before they had made her glad that they had ended.

en: If gratitude and esteem are good foundations of affection, Elizabeth’s change of sentiment will be neither improbable nor faulty.
vi: If gratitude and esteem are good foundations for love, the change in Elizabeth's feelings is neither improbable nor faulty.
tr: If gratitude and respect are the solid foundations of love, then Elizabeth's change of feelings would be neither impossible nor wrong.
es: If gratitude or esteem are good bases for affection, the transformation of Elizabeth's feelings will not seem improbable or condemnable.

en: But if otherwise, if the regard springing from such sources is unreasonable or unnatural, in comparison of what is so often described as arising on a first interview with its object, and even before two words have been exchanged, nothing can be said in her defence, except that she had given somewhat of a trial to the latter method, in her partiality for Wickham, and that its ill success might, perhaps, authorize her to seek the other less interesting mode of attachment.
vi: But if not, if the affection arising from these sources is not justifiable, or not natural compared to what is commonly called the initial stage, nothing can excuse her, except perhaps her feelings for Wickham, and also except perhaps the failure that might allow her to seek another way.
tr: But if the opposite is true, if the admiration arising from these sources remains irrational or unnatural compared to what is said to arise at first sight and even without a word being exchanged, then, except for the fact that her interest in Wickham was tested by the subsequent method and its failure justified her beginning to follow another, less interesting attachment, nothing can be said to defend Elizabeth.
es: But if it is not so, if the interest that arises from this is less natural and reasonable than that which springs spontaneously, as often described, from the first meeting and before having exchanged two words with the object of said interest, only one thing can be said in Elizabeth's defense: that she tried this system with Wickham and the bad results it gave her perhaps authorized her to lean towards the other method, even if it was less passionate.

en: Be that as it may, she saw him go with regret; and in this early example of what Lydia’s infamy must produce, found additional anguish as she reflected on that wretched business.
vi: In any case, she regretted seeing him leave; and in the first instance of the consequences of Lydia's disgrace, she was even more distressed when recalling this unfortunate event.
tr: Even so, she saw his departure with sadness; and in this first instance of the disgrace brought by Lydia's notoriety, Elizabeth found a separate source of pain while contemplating that miserable incident.
es: Be that as it may, she saw Darcy leave with great sorrow, and this first example of the misfortunes that Lydia's infamy could cause increased the anguish she felt when thinking about that disastrous matter.

en: Never since reading Jane’s second letter had she entertained a hope of Wickham’s meaning to marry her.
vi: Since reading Jane's second letter, she had never hoped that Wickham would marry her sister.
tr: Since reading Jane's second letter, she had never hoped that Wickham intended to marry Lydia.
es: As soon as she read Jane's second letter, she did not believe that Wickham intended to marry Lydia.

en: No one but Jane, she thought, could flatter herself with such an expectation.
vi: She thought no one, except Jane, could be complacent with such a hope.
tr: No one but Jane, she thought, could entertain such an expectation.
es: No one but Jane could have had that hope.

en: Surprise was the least of all her feelings on this development.
vi: In her feelings about this matter, surprise held the smallest place.
tr: The least she felt in this development was surprise.
es: Surprise was the last of her feelings.

en: While the contents of the first letter remained on her mind, she was all surprise, all astonishment, that Wickham should marry a girl whom it was impossible he could marry for money; and how Lydia could ever have attached him had appeared incomprehensible.
vi: When she remembered the contents of the first letter, she was completely astonished—completely stunned that Wickham would want to marry a girl without money; and how Lydia could have captivated him was something she could not understand.
tr: As long as the content of the first letter remained in her mind, she was in a state of astonishment – astonishment at Wickham marrying a girl he couldn't marry for money; how Lydia could have become attached to him seemed incomprehensible.
es: Upon reading the first letter, she was astonished that Wickham would marry a girl who was not a good match and did not understand how Lydia could have attracted him.

en: But now it was all too natural.
vi: But now, everything seemed natural.
tr: But now it all seemed quite natural.
es: But now she saw everything clearly.

en: For such an attachment as this, she might have sufficient charms; and though she did not suppose Lydia to be deliberately engaging in an elopement, without the intention of marriage, she had no difficulty in believing that neither her virtue nor her understanding would preserve her from falling an easy prey.
vi: With such an affair, Lydia had enough charm, and although she did not think her sister had intentionally wanted to elope without intending to marry, it was not difficult for her to believe that neither her sister's virtue nor understanding could protect her from becoming an easy prey.
tr: Lydia might have had enough charm for such an attachment; although she did not think Lydia had deliberately run away without the thought of marriage, she found it easy to believe that neither a sense of honor nor understanding would be enough to prevent her from becoming an easy prey.
es: Lydia was pretty, and although she did not suppose she had committed to eloping without any intention of marriage, Elizabeth knew that neither her virtue nor her good judgment could preserve her from falling as an easy prey.

en: She had never perceived, while the regiment was in Hertfordshire, that Lydia had any partiality for him; but she was convinced that Lydia had wanted only encouragement to attach herself to anybody.
vi: When the regiment was still stationed in Hertfordshire, she never realized that Lydia had any feelings for him, but she believed that Lydia only needed a little encouragement to fall in love with anyone.
tr: While Alay was in Hertfordshire, he had never noticed that Lydia was interested in him, but he knew that Lydia only needed a face to feel attached to anyone.
es: While the regiment was in Hertfordshire, she never noticed that Lydia was attracted to Wickham; but she was convinced that she only needed a little attention to fall in love with anyone.

en: Sometimes one officer, sometimes another, had been her favourite, as their attentions raised them in her opinion.
vi: Sometimes an officer, sometimes another person was liked by Lydia just because of their attentions.
tr: At one time, she was the favorite of one officer, at another time, the favorite of another officer, depending on the attention she received from them.
es: She liked one officer as soon as another, depending on the attention they paid her.

en: Her affections had been continually fluctuating, but never without an object.
vi: Her sister's affections were always fluctuating, but there was never a lack of an object.
tr: Her feelings were constantly in a state of fluctuation but never had any specific targets.
es: She had always flitted about, without any fixed object.

en: The mischief of neglect and mistaken indulgence towards such a girl—oh!
vi: The disaster of neglect and misguided indulgence of a daughter.
tr: The harm done to such a girl by neglect and indulgence.
es: How they were now paying for the neglect and indulgence with which they had raised that girl!

en: how acutely did she now feel it!
vi: Oh! Now she understood it deeply!
tr: –How sharply she felt it now!
es: How they were now paying for the neglect and indulgence with which they had raised that girl!

en: She was wild to be at home—to hear, to see, to be upon the spot to share with Jane in the cares that must now fall wholly upon her, in a family so deranged; a father absent, a mother incapable of exertion, and requiring constant attendance; and though almost persuaded that nothing could be done for Lydia, her uncle’s interference seemed of the utmost importance, and till he entered the room the misery of her impatience was severe.
vi: She was anxious to return home, to listen, to see, to be present at the place, to share with Jane all the care that her sister now had to bear alone, in a family that was in disarray. The father was absent, the mother could not get up and needed constant care, although she believed there was hardly anything she could do for Lydia, the support of the uncle would be extremely important, she continued to suffer from impatience waiting for the uncle to return.
tr: She was writhing to be at home –now to hear, see, and share all the worries that had entirely fallen on Jane's shoulders, in such a scattered family, no father, a mother incapable of showing herself and constantly in need of care; although she almost believed that nothing could be done for Lydia, her uncle's intervention seemed of vital importance; the pain of her impatience was quite intense until her uncle entered the room.
es: She couldn't wait to be home to see, hear, and be there, and to share with Jane the care that such a troubled family required, with the father absent and the mother incapable of any effort and needing constant attention. Although she was almost convinced that nothing could be done for Lydia, her uncle's help seemed of utmost importance to her, so until she saw him enter the room, she endured the torment of an impatient wait.

en: mr and ms Gardiner had hurried back in alarm, supposing, by the servant’s account, that their niece was taken suddenly ill; but satisfying them instantly on that head, she eagerly communicated the cause of their summons, reading the two letters aloud, and dwelling on the postscript of the last with trembling energy.
vi: Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner returned in worry, thinking that their niece had fallen ill suddenly, as the servant had informed them, but were immediately reassured about this matter. She immediately explained the reason she had sent for them, trembling as she read the two letters to them.
tr: Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner had returned in a hurry, assuming from the servant's statement that their niece had suddenly fallen ill; –but she reassured them on that account and explained the reason for their urgent summons, reading both letters aloud with trembling energy and emphasizing the note in the second one.
es: Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner returned hurriedly and alarmed, believing, from what the servant had told them, that their niece had suddenly fallen ill. Elizabeth reassured them on this point and immediately informed them of the reason for her call by reading them the two letters and insisting on the postscript with trembling energy.

en: Though Lydia had never been a favourite with them, mr and ms Gardiner could not but be deeply affected.
vi: Although Lydia was never the niece they particularly cherished, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were still deeply moved. It was not only Lydia, but everyone involved.
tr: –Although Lydia was not their favorite niece, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner couldn't help but feel deep sorrow.
es: Although Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner had never been very fond of Lydia, the news deeply affected them. The misfortune affected not only Lydia but everyone.

en: Not Lydia only, but all were concerned in it; and after the first exclamations of surprise and horror, mr Gardiner readily promised every assistance in his power.
vi: After a few expressions of surprise and horror, Mr. Gardiner eagerly promised to help in any way he could.
tr: The matter concerned not just Lydia, but everyone; after the initial cries of shock and horror, Mr. Gardiner promised to do all he could to help.
