es: After the initial exclamations of surprise and horror, Mr. Gardiner offered all the help he could.

en: Elizabeth, though expecting no less, thanked him with tears of gratitude; and all three being actuated by one spirit, everything relating to their journey was speedily settled.
vi: After a few expressions of surprise and horror, Mr. Gardiner eagerly promised to help in any way he could.
tr: –Elizabeth thanked him with tears of gratitude, although she expected no less; since all three were in the same state of mind, all the travel details were quickly settled.
es: Elizabeth expected no less and thanked them with tears in her eyes.

en: They were to be off as soon as possible.
vi: They would return as soon as possible.
tr: They would set out at the first opportunity.
es: Moved by the same spirit, the three of them quickly arranged everything for the trip.

en: “But what is to be done about Pemberley?” cried ms Gardiner.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner exclaimed: - But what will we do with Pemberley?
tr: "But what about Pemberley?" cried Mrs. Gardiner.
es: ––And what shall we do about Pemberley? ––asked Mrs. Gardiner––.

en: “John told us mr Darcy was here when you sent for us;—was it so?”
vi: John said that Mr. Darcy came here when you sent him to call your uncle and aunt. Is that correct?
tr: "When John called us, he said Mr. Darcy was here; –was he here?"
es: John has told us that Mr. Darcy was here when you sent him to fetch us. Is it true?

en: “Yes; and I told him we should not be able to keep our engagement.
vi: - Yes; I told Mr. Darcy that we would not be able to keep our promise.
tr: "Yes; I told him that we wouldn't be able to keep our promise.
es: ––Yes; I told him that we were not in a position to fulfill our commitment.

en: That is all settled.”
vi: This matter has been settled.
tr: Everything is settled."
es: That's already been settled.

en: “What is all settled?” repeated the other, as she ran into her room to prepare.
vi: The aunt repeated, as she ran into the room to prepare: "This matter has been arranged."
tr: "Everything is taken care of," repeated the other, darting to their room to get ready.
es: ––That's already been settled ––repeated Mrs. Gardiner as she ran to the other room to get ready–.

en: “And are they upon such terms as for her to disclose the real truth?
vi: And I don't know how close the two of you are for the niece to reveal the truth!
tr: "I wonder if they are close enough to reveal the truth!
es: Are they on such close terms as to have revealed the truth to him?

en: Oh, that I knew how it was!”
vi: Oh, if only I had known what the situation was like!”
tr: Oh, I wish I knew!"
es: How I would love to find out what has happened!

en: But wishes were vain; or, at best, could serve only to amuse her in the hurry and confusion of the following hour.
vi: But all wishes were futile, or at least only helped her feel better in the rush and confusion of the next hour.
tr: It was not a time for wishes; or if there were any, they would only serve to distract her in the rush and hurry of the next hour.
es: But her curiosity was useless. At most, it served to entertain her in the rush and confusion of the next hour.

en: Had Elizabeth been at leisure to be idle, she would have remained certain that all employment was impossible to one so wretched as herself; but she had her share of business as well as her aunt, and amongst the rest there were notes to be written to all their friends at Lambton, with false excuses for their sudden departure.
vi: If Elizabeth had been at leisure, she would have been convinced that she could not accomplish anything while in such distress; but she had as much to do as her aunt, including writing letters to inform everyone in Lambton, with a fabricated reason for their sudden departure.
tr: If Elizabeth had the chance to be idle, she would believe that it was impossible for someone as miserable as herself to engage in any activity, but she had as much work to do as her aunt; it fell to her to write notes to all their friends in Lambton, making up false excuses for their sudden departure.
es: If Elizabeth could have stayed idle, she would have believed that someone as miserable as she was incapable of any work, but she was as busy as her aunt and, to top it off, she had to write cards to all the friends in Lambton to explain their sudden departure with false excuses.

en: An hour, however, saw the whole completed; and mr Gardiner, meanwhile, having settled his account at the inn, nothing remained to be done but to go; and Elizabeth, after all the misery of the morning, found herself, in a shorter space of time than she could have supposed, seated in the carriage, and on the road to Longbourn.
vi: However, within an hour, everything was settled. After a miserable morning, Elizabeth found that she could return to Longbourn sooner than she had thought.
tr: Yet within an hour, all the work was completed; in the meantime, Mr. Gardiner settled the inn's account and there was nothing left to do but leave. After all the morning's misery, Elizabeth found herself settled in the carriage and on the way to Longbourn sooner than she had expected.
es: Everything was dispatched within an hour. Meanwhile, Mr. Gardiner settled the inn's bill, and all that was left was to depart. After the sadness of the morning, Elizabeth found herself, in less time than she had supposed, seated in the carriage and heading towards Longbourn.

en: CHAPTER XLVII.
vi: Chapter 47
tr: Chapter V
es: CHAPTER XLII

en: “I HAVE been thinking it over again, Elizabeth,” said her uncle, as they drove from the town; “and really, upon serious consideration, I am much more inclined than I was to judge as your eldest sister does of the matter.
vi: When they drove out of town, the uncle said to her: - Elizabeth, you have thought over the matter, and after serious consideration, now you can truly be ready to judge the matter better, just as your sister has judged.
tr: "I keep thinking about it, Elizabeth," said her uncle, as they moved away from the town; "and the more I think, the more inclined I am to view the matter as your sister does.
es: I've been thinking about it again, Elizabeth," her uncle said to her as they were leaving the city, "and finally, after serious consideration, I feel inclined to adopt your elder sister's opinion.

en: It appears to me so very unlikely that any young man should form such a design against a girl who is by no means unprotected or friendless, and who was actually staying in his Colonel’s family, that I am strongly inclined to hope the best.
vi: You think there is no reason why a young man would intend to marry a girl with no guaranteed fortune and no friends, while she is actually staying with his colonel's family.
tr: It seems highly unlikely to me that a young man would make such a plan against a girl who is not unprotected, not without guardians, and who is a guest of his colonel's family; so much so that I am inclined to hope for the best outcome.
es: It seems unlikely to me that Wickham would want to harm a girl who is not without protection or friends and who was living with the Forster family.

en: Could he expect that her friends would not step forward?
vi: Can he rely on his friends to help him?
tr: Can this young man expect that the girl's relatives will not emerge?
es: He wouldn't assume that the girl's friends would stand idly by, nor that he would be readmitted to the regiment after such a grave offense to his colonel.

en: Could he expect to be noticed again by the regiment, after such an affront to Colonel Forster?
vi: After confronting Colonel Forster, does he think he will be reprimanded by the regiment?
tr: Can he expect to be accepted into the regiment after such an insult to Colonel Forster?
es: He wouldn't assume that the girl's friends would stand idly by, nor that he would be readmitted to the regiment after such a grave offense to his colonel.

en: His temptation is not adequate to the risk.”
vi: His actions are not worth taking such risks.
tr: The reasons do not outweigh the risks."
es: The temptation is not proportional to the risk.

en: “Do you really think so?” cried Elizabeth, brightening up for a moment.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed, her face momentarily lighting up with joy: - Do you really believe that?
tr: "Do you really think so?" cried Elizabeth, coming to life for a moment.
es: ––Do you really believe that? ––asked Elizabeth, brightening up for a moment.

en: “Upon my word,” said ms Gardiner, “I begin to be of your uncle’s opinion.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner said: - Honestly, I am beginning to think like your uncle.
tr: "Absolutely," said Mrs. Gardiner, "I am beginning to think like your uncle.
es: ––I am also beginning to share your uncle's opinion ––said Mrs. Gardiner––.

en: It is really too great a violation of decency, honour, and interest, for him to be guilty of it.
vi: This is too grave an error in terms of propriety, honor, and rights, not deserving of him being accused.
tr: He cannot risk being guilty of such a great abuse in so many matters of decorum, honor, and profession.
es: It is too great a violation of decency, honor, and self-interest to have acted so lightly.

en: I cannot think so very ill of Wickham.
vi: I cannot believe Wickham could be that bad.
tr: I cannot think so badly of Wickham.
es: I cannot admit that Wickham is so foolish.

en: Can you, yourself, Lizzie, so wholly give him up, as to believe him capable of it?”
vi: Lizzy, you yourself, can you believe he is capable of doing such a thing?
tr: Have you, yourself, Lizzy, lost hope in him enough to think he could do this?"
es: And you yourself, Elizabeth, do you hold him in such low regard to believe him capable of such madness?

en: “Not perhaps of neglecting his own interest.
vi: - Perhaps he won't overlook your rights, but I believe he can overlook everything else.
tr: "Maybe not to the extent of thinking he neglected his own interests.
es: ––I don't believe he's capable of forgetting his own convenience, but he is capable of forgetting everything that doesn't pertain to it.

en: But of every other neglect I can believe him capable.
vi: - Perhaps he won't overlook your rights, but I believe he can overlook everything else.
tr: But I expect every other kind of neglect from him.
es: ––I don't believe he's capable of forgetting his own convenience, but he is capable of forgetting everything that doesn't pertain to it.

en: If, indeed, it should be so!
vi: But why didn't they go to Scotland if that's the case?
tr: What if it is so!
es: I wish it were as you say!

en: But I dare not hope it.
vi: But why didn't they go to Scotland if that's the case?
tr: I hope it isn't.
es: I don't dare to hope for it.

en: Why should they not go on to Scotland, if that had been the case?”
vi: But why didn't they go to Scotland if that's the case?
tr: Then why didn't they go to Scotland?"
es: And if not, why haven't they gone to Scotland?

en: “In the first place,” replied mr Gardiner, “there is no absolute proof that they are not gone to Scotland.”
vi: Mr. Gardiner replied: - First of all, there is no conclusive evidence that they did not go to Scotland.
tr: "For one thing," replied Mr. Gardiner, "there is no definite proof that they did not go to Scotland."
es: ––First of all ––replied Mr. Gardiner––, there is no evidence that they haven't gone.

en: “Oh, but their removing from the chaise into a hackney coach is such a presumption!
vi: - Ah! But the fact that they switched from a horse-drawn carriage to a rented vehicle allows us to infer that.
tr: "But that means they switched to the city car!
es: ––What better proof than having left the post chaise and taken a hired carriage?

en: And, besides, no traces of them were to be found on the Barnet road.”
vi: And furthermore, no trace of the two was found along Barnet Street.
tr: Besides, no traces of them were found on Barnet Road."
es: Besides, they did not go through the Barnet road.

en: “Well, then,—supposing them to be in London—they may be there, though for the purpose of concealment, for no more exceptionable purpose.
vi: - Alright, then suppose they are in London. They might be there for the purpose of hiding, not for any other exceptional reason.
tr: "Alright – let's assume they are in London. They might be there to hide, but there can't be any other exceptional reason.
es: ––Well, suppose they are in London. They may have done it only for the purpose of hiding.

en: It is not likely that money should be very abundant on either side; and it might strike them that they could be more economically, though less expeditiously, married in London, than in Scotland.”
vi: Each person might not have much money, and they think they can get married more cheaply, though slowly, in London than in Scotland.
tr: It's unlikely that both sides are swimming in money; they might have thought that getting married in London would be more economical, if not more urgent, than in Scotland."
es: It is not likely that either of them has plenty of money, and they might have thought it would be cheaper to get married in London than in Scotland, even if it is more difficult for them.

en: “But why all this secrecy?
vi: - But why keep it a secret?
tr: "But why this secrecy?
es: ––But why the secrecy?

en: Why any fear of detection?
vi: Why be afraid of being discovered?
tr: Why are they afraid of being found?
es: ––But why the secrecy?

en: Why must their marriage be private?
vi: Why must the marriage be kept secret?
tr: Why must their marriage be secret?
es: Why do they have to marry in secret?

en: Oh, no, no—this is not likely.
vi: Oh, no, no, it makes no sense.
tr: Oh! No, no, it's not possible.
es: You know from Jane that Wickham's closest friend assures that he never thought of marrying Lydia.

en: His most particular friend, you see by Jane’s account, was persuaded of his never intending to marry her.
vi: His closest friend, according to Jane, believes that he never had any intention of marrying.
tr: From what Jane told us, we saw that his closest friend says he has no intention of marrying her.
es: You know from Jane that Wickham's closest friend assures that he never thought of marrying Lydia.

en: Wickham will never marry a woman without some money.
vi: Wickham would never marry someone without money.
tr: Wickham would never marry a woman without money.
es: Wickham will never marry a woman who doesn't have money, because he can't afford the expenses of a marriage.

en: He cannot afford it.
vi: He does not have the financial means to do so.
tr: His means do not allow it.
es: Wickham will never marry a woman who doesn't have money, because he can't afford the expenses of a marriage.

en: And what claims has Lydia, what attractions has she beyond youth, health, and good humour, that could make him for her sake forego every chance of benefiting himself by marrying well?
vi: And what does Lydia have, what attractive qualities beyond youth, health, and cheerfulness, that could make him give up every opportunity for a wealthy marriage?
tr: But what does Lydia have, besides youth, health, and cheerfulness, that would make him ruin his chance of a good marriage for her sake?
es: And what merits does Lydia have, what attractions, aside from her health, her youth, and her good humor, for Wickham to give up the possibility of making a good match for her?

en: As to what restraint the apprehensions of disgrace in the corps might throw on a dishonourable elopement with her, I am not able to judge; for I know nothing of the effects that such a step might produce.
vi: As for his fear of being despised by the army for eloping in disgrace, I cannot judge, because I do not know the consequences of this situation.
tr: I don't know how the fear of losing reputation in the army could prevent him from eloping so disgracefully with Lydia; because I know nothing about the consequences of such a step.
es: I can't accurately assess to what extent a dishonorable elopement will harm him in the Corps, as I am unaware of the measures taken in such cases, but as for your other objections, it seems difficult for them to hold up.

en: But as to your other objection, I am afraid it will hardly hold good.
vi: As for your argument, I fear it has no basis.
tr: But as for your other objection, I'm not sure it will work.
es: I can't accurately assess to what extent a dishonorable elopement will harm him in the Corps, as I am unaware of the measures taken in such cases, but as for your other objections, it seems difficult for them to hold up.

en: Lydia has no brothers to step forward; and he might imagine, from my father’s behaviour, from his indolence and the little attention he has ever seemed to give to what was going forward in his family, that he would do as little and think as little about it, as any father could do, in such a matter.”
vi: Lydia has no brothers to hope for help from, and from my father's attitude, his laziness, and his lack of attention to what is happening in the family, one could think that he would do as little as possible and think as little as possible about this matter, like any other father.
tr: Lydia has no brothers to come forward; and Wickham might have concluded from my father's behavior, his laziness, and his apparent indifference to what happens in his family, that he would not trouble himself like any other father would in such a matter."
es: Lydia has no brothers to intervene; and given my father's character, his indolence, and the little attention he has always paid to his family, Wickham might have believed he wouldn't take it too seriously.

en: “But can you think that Lydia is so lost to everything but love of him, as to consent to live with him on any other terms than marriage?”
vi: - But can you think that Lydia would lose so much except for your love, that she would be willing to live with you in any way other than marriage?
tr: "But can you imagine that Lydia is so blindly in love that she would agree to live a life outside of marriage, not seeing anything else?"
es: ––But how do you suppose that Lydia is so inconsiderate about everything except loving him, that she would agree to live with him in any other way than as his legitimate wife?

en: “It does seem, and it is most shocking, indeed,” replied Elizabeth, with tears in her eyes, “that a sister’s sense of decency and virtue in such a point should admit of doubt.
vi: Elizabeth replied, her eyes filled with tears: - It seems, and this is the most astonishing thing, that the conscience of an elder sister regarding propriety and morality should consider herself doubtful.
tr: "It appears, quite bitterly," replied Elizabeth, with tears in her eyes, "that one must accept that a sister's sense of virtue and honor is questionable at such a point.
es: ––It seems so ––replied Elizabeth with her eyes full of tears––, and it is dreadful to have to doubt the decency and virtue of a sister.

en: But, really, I know not what to say.
vi: But, truly, I don't know what to say.
tr: But I really don't know what to say.
es: But in reality, I don't know what to say.

en: Perhaps I am not doing her justice.
vi: Perhaps I am not being fair to my sister.
tr: Perhaps I am not being fair to her.
es: Perhaps I judge her wrongly, but she is very young, she has never been accustomed to thinking about serious matters, and for the last half year, or rather for an entire year, she has done nothing but chase after diversions and vanity.

en: But she is very young: she has never been taught to think on serious subjects; and for the last half year, nay, for a twelvemonth, she has been given up to nothing but amusement and vanity.
vi: But she is still too young; she has never been taught how to think about serious matters; for the past six months, no, for the past twelve months, she has cared for nothing but fun and frivolity.
tr: But she is very young; she was not taught to think about serious matters; for the last six months, even a year, she has been encouraged in nothing but pleasure and display.
es: Perhaps I judge her wrongly, but she is very young, she has never been accustomed to thinking about serious matters, and for the last half year, or rather for an entire year, she has done nothing but chase after diversions and vanity.

en: She has been allowed to dispose of her time in the most idle and frivolous manner, and to adopt any opinions that came in her way.
vi: She has been allowed to spend her time in the laziest and most frivolous manner, and to follow every opinion she has picked up.
tr: She was allowed to spend her time in the most idle and superficial manner, adopting every idea that came her way.
es: She has been allowed to indulge in idleness and frivolity and to do nothing but what she fancied.

en: Since the ——shire were first quartered in Meryton, nothing but love, flirtation, and officers, have been in her head.
vi: Since the regiment arrived at Meryton, her mind has been filled with love, amusement, and the officers.
tr: Since the --------shire regiment settled in Meryton, nothing has occupied her mind but love, flirtation, and officers.
es: Since the county garrison was quartered in Meryton, she has thought of nothing but love, flirting, and the officers.

en: She has been doing everything in her power, by thinking and talking on the subject, to give greater—what shall I call it?—susceptibility to her feelings; which are naturally lively enough.
vi: She has done everything in her power to think and talk about this subject, to create – what should I call it? To create a sensitivity in her mind, a mind naturally quite lively.
tr: She did everything she could to, how shall I say, further inflame her already lively feelings by thinking and talking about this subject.
es: She did everything she could to excite, how should I put it?, the susceptibility of her feelings, which are already quite lively by nature.

en: And we all know that Wickham has every charm of person and address that can captivate a woman.”
vi: And we all know Wickham has all the appearances and words to captivate a woman.
tr: And we all know that Wickham's appearance and speech possess every charm to captivate a woman."
es: And we all know that Wickham possesses in his person and manners all the charms that can captivate a woman.

en: “But you see that Jane,” said her aunt, “does not think so ill of Wickham, as to believe him capable of the attempt.”
vi: Auntie said: - But don't you see that Jane doesn't think too badly of Wickham, so she doesn't believe he is capable of doing such a thing? - Does
tr: "But you see," said her aunt, "she doesn't think so badly of Jane Wickham, she doesn't believe she would attempt such a thing."
es: ––But you see ––insisted her aunt–– that your sister does not believe Wickham capable of such an offense.

en: “Of whom does Jane ever think ill?
vi: Jane think ill of anyone?
tr: "Who would Jane think badly of?
es: ––Jane never believes anything bad about anyone.

en: And who is there, whatever might be their former conduct, that she would believe capable of such an attempt, till it were proved against them?
vi: And does she believe that anyone is capable, regardless of their character, until there is proof?
tr: No matter what his past behavior was, who does she believe could attempt such a thing, until events prove otherwise?
es: Much less when it comes to something like this, until it has been proven to her.

en: But Jane knows, as well as I do, what Wickham really is.
vi: But like you, Jane knows what Wickham's true nature is.
tr: But Jane knows as well as I do what Wickham really is.
es: But Jane knows as well as I do who Wickham is.

en: We both know that he has been profligate in every sense of the word; that he has neither integrity nor honour; that he is as false and deceitful as he is insinuating.”
vi: We both know he has been dissolute in every sense of the word. He has no integrity or honor. He likes deceit and deception.
tr: We both know that he is a bad person in every sense of the word. That he knows neither honor nor integrity. That he is as deceitful as he is a liar and a fraud."
es: We both know that he is a libertine in every sense of the word, lacking integrity and honor, and that he is as false and deceitful as he is attractive.

en: “And do you really know all this?” cried ms Gardiner, whose curiosity as to the mode of her intelligence was all alive.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner exclaimed, surprised at how she gathered information: - And you really know all these things??
tr: "Do you really know all this?" cried Mrs. Gardiner; her curiosity about where this information came from was thoroughly aroused.
es: ––Are you sure? ––asked Mrs. Gardiner, who was burning with the desire to know the source of her niece's information.

en: “I do, indeed,” replied Elizabeth, colouring.
vi: Elizabeth blushed: - I really know.
tr: "Of course I know," replied Elizabeth, blushing.
es: ––Absolutely sure ––replied Elizabeth, blushing––.

en: “I told you the other day of his infamous behaviour to mr Darcy; and you, yourself, when last at Longbourn, heard in what manner he spoke of the man who had behaved with such forbearance and liberality towards him.
vi: The other day I told my aunt about his scandalous behavior towards Mr. Darcy; it was my aunt who, during her last visit to Longbourn, heard him speak about Mr. Darcy, who had treated him with tolerance and generosity.
tr: "The other day I told you about the villainy he did to Mr. Darcy; you yourself heard how he spoke about the man who treated him so patiently and generously when he last came to Longbourn.
es: I already told you the other day about his infamous behavior towards Mr. Darcy, and you yourself heard the last time in Longbourn how he spoke about the man who has treated him with such indulgence and generosity.

en: And there are other circumstances which I am not at liberty—which it is not worth while to relate; but his lies about the whole Pemberley family are endless.
vi: And there are other instances that I cannot... instances not worth mentioning; but he has continuously lied about the Pemberley family.
tr: There are also other incidents that I am not authorized to tell – I mean, not worth mentioning; but his lies about the entire Pemberley family are countless.
es: And there is yet another circumstance that I am not authorized... that is not worth mentioning. The truth is that his lies about the Pemberley family are endless.

en: From what he said of Miss Darcy, I was thoroughly prepared to see a proud, reserved, disagreeable girl.
vi: From what he said about Miss Darcy, I thought she was a proud, fastidious, and unpleasant girl.
tr: From what he said about Miss Darcy, I was prepared to see a proud, cold, unpleasant girl.
es: From what he had told us about Miss Darcy, I believed she would be a haughty, reserved, and unpleasant girl.

en: Yet he knew to the contrary himself.
vi: Yet he knew the opposite was true.
tr: But he knew very well that the opposite was true.
es: However, he knew that she was quite the opposite.

en: He must know that she was as amiable and unpretending as we have found her.”
vi: He must have known that she is as sweet and humble as we have seen.
tr: He knew that she was a pleasant and unassuming girl, as we found her to be."
es: He must know very well, as we have observed, how affectionate and simple she is.

en: “But does Lydia know nothing of this?
vi: - But Lydia didn't know anything at all?
tr: "But doesn't Lydia know these things?"
es: ––And Lydia isn't aware of any of this?

en: can she be ignorant of what you and Jane seem so well to understand?”
vi: Could it be that she doesn't know what you and Jane seem to understand so well?
tr: "How could she not know the things that you and Jane seem to know so well?""
es: How does she not know what Jane and you know?

en: “Oh, yes!—that, that is the worst of all.
vi: - Yes, exactly like that! And this is the worst part.
tr: "Ah yes! –and that's the worst part of it anyway.
es: ––You are right.

en: Till I was in Kent, and saw so much both of mr Darcy and his relation Colonel Fitzwilliam, I was ignorant of the truth myself.
vi: I myself was not clear about the truth until I went to Kent and met Mr. Darcy and his cousin, Colonel Fitzwilliam.
tr: Until I went to Kent and got to know Mr. Darcy and his cousin Colonel Fitzwilliam well, I didn't know the truth either.
es: Until I was in Kent and met Mr. Darcy and his cousin Colonel Fitzwilliam, I did not know either.

en: And when I returned home the ——shire was to leave Meryton in a week or fortnight’s time.
vi: When I returned home, the regiment was preparing to leave Meryton in a week or two.
tr: When I returned home, the --------shire regiment was about to leave within a week or two.
es: When I arrived home, the county garrison was set to leave Meryton within three weeks, so neither Jane, whom I informed of everything, nor I thought it necessary to disclose it; because what use would it be to ruin the good opinion they had of him in Hertfordshire?

en: As that was the case, neither Jane, to whom I related the whole, nor I, thought it necessary to make our knowledge public; for of what use could it apparently be to anyone, that the good opinion, which all the neighbourhood had of him, should then be overthrown?
vi: Because of this, both Jane and I thought it unnecessary to make it public, as what good would it do to disrupt everyone's positive impression of him?
tr: Given the situation, neither Jane nor I felt it necessary to explain these things to everyone; because what good would it do to shatter the positive opinions the whole community had of him?
es: When I arrived home, the county garrison was set to leave Meryton within three weeks, so neither Jane, whom I informed of everything, nor I thought it necessary to disclose it; because what use would it be to ruin the good opinion they had of him in Hertfordshire?

en: And even when it was settled that Lydia should go with ms Forster, the necessity of opening her eyes to his character never occurred to me.
vi: And even when the family agreed to let Lydia go with Mrs. Forster, I never thought it necessary to enlighten her about his character.
tr: Even when it was decided that Lydia would go with Mrs. Forster, it didn't occur to me to warn her about his true nature.
es: And when it was decided that Lydia would go with the Forsters to Brighton, it never occurred to me to reveal Wickham's true character to her, as it never crossed my mind that she would be in any danger of that kind.

en: That she could be in any danger from the deception never entered my head.
vi: I never suspected she could be deceived.
tr: I never considered the possibility that she could be in danger of being deceived.
es: And when it was decided that Lydia would go with the Forsters to Brighton, it never occurred to me to reveal Wickham's true character to her, as it never crossed my mind that she would be in any danger of that kind.

en: That such a consequence as this should ensue, you may easily believe was far enough from my thoughts.”
vi: I did not foresee such consequences, while you could have easily thought of them.
tr: Believe me, the thought of such an outcome never even crossed my mind."
es: You can understand that I was far from suspecting that such disastrous consequences would ensue.

en: “When they all removed to Brighton, therefore, you had no reason, I suppose, to believe them fond of each other?”
vi: - So, you think there's no reason for you to believe that when they went to Brighton, they had feelings for each other, right?
tr: "When they all went to Brighton together, there was no reason for you to think that they were interested in each other."
es: ––When they moved the garrison to Brighton, did you have any idea that there was something between them?

en: “Not the slightest.
vi: - I don't see any reason at all.
tr: "There was no reason at all.
es: ––Not the slightest bit.

en: I can remember no symptom of affection on either side; and had anything of the kind been perceptible, you must be aware that ours is not a family on which it could be thrown away.
vi: I don't remember seeing any signs of affection between the two.
tr: I saw no sign of any intimacy on either side; you know that if I had sensed the slightest thing, our family is not one to overlook such matters.
es: I don't remember noticing any sign of affection from either one of them. If there had been anything, my family is certainly sharp enough to have noticed it!

en: When first he entered the corps, she was ready enough to admire him; but so we all were.
vi: When he first joined the militia, she already liked him, but so did all of us.
tr: When Wickham first joined the regiment, Lydia was quite ready to admire him; but so were we all.
es: When Wickham joined the Corps, Lydia liked him a lot, but no more than the rest of us did.

en: Every girl in or near Meryton was out of her senses about him for the first two months: but he never distinguished her by any particular attention; and, consequently, after a moderate period of extravagant and wild admiration, her fancy for him gave way, and others of the regiment, who treated her with more distinction, again became her favourites.”
vi: Every girl in Meryton and around there was infatuated with him for the first two months, but he never treated her with any special attention. Therefore, after the phase of crazy infatuation, she no longer liked him, and since others in the regiment treated her more specially, she liked them more.
tr: Every girl in Meryton and the surrounding area was crazy about him for the first two months; but he showed no special interest in Lydia; eventually, after a brief period of exaggerated and wild admiration, she stopped dreaming about Wickham and began to occupy herself with other officers who paid her more attention." -------------------------------
es: All the girls in Meryton and the surrounding areas went crazy over him during the first two months, but he never paid Lydia any special attention, so after a period of extravagant and unrestrained admiration, she forgot about him and turned her attention to other officers who paid her more attention.

en: It may be easily believed, that however little of novelty could be added to their fears, hopes, and conjectures, on this interesting subject by its repeated discussion, no other could detain them from it long, during the whole of the journey.
vi: Even though there wasn't much new to add to the worries, hopes, and speculations, no one could dismiss these thoughts for long throughout the journey.
tr: Although it could easily be anticipated that nothing new could be added by repeatedly talking about their fears, hopes, and wishes on this important matter, no other topic could distract them from it for long throughout the entire journey.
es: Although few new things could be added to their fears, hopes, and conjectures about such an interesting matter, the travelers debated it throughout the entire journey.

en: From Elizabeth’s thoughts it was never absent.
vi: Elizabeth's mind was always preoccupied.
tr: It never left Elizabeth's thoughts.
es: Elizabeth could not think of anything else.

en: Fixed there by the keenest of all anguish, self-reproach, she could find no interval of ease or forgetfulness.
vi: Tormented by all the distress and self-blame, she never felt comfortable or temporarily forgot the incident.
tr: It had firmly settled there with all its torment and pangs of conscience, not allowing her a moment's peace or forgetfulness.
es: The sharpest of all agonies, self-reproach, prevented her from finding the slightest interval of relief or forgetfulness.

en: They travelled as expeditiously as possible; and sleeping one night on the road, reached Longbourn by dinnertime the next day.
vi: The three people moved as quickly as possible, and after spending the night on the road, they arrived back at Longbourn by dinner time the next day.
tr: They traveled as fast as they could; they slept on the road one night and reached Longbourn the next day at mealtime.
es: They walked as quickly as they could, spent the night at an inn, and arrived at Longbourn the next day at lunchtime.

en: It was a comfort to Elizabeth to consider that Jane could not have been wearied by long expectations.
vi: Elizabeth was reassured that Jane must not have been anxious due to the long wait.
tr: It comforted Elizabeth to think that Jane had not kept her eyes on the road for a long time.
es: Elizabeth's only consolation was that she would not have kept Jane waiting too long.

en: The little Gardiners, attracted by the sight of a chaise, were standing on the steps of the house, as they entered the paddock; and when the carriage drove up to the door, the joyful surprise that lighted up their faces and displayed itself over their whole bodies, in a variety of capers and frisks, was the first pleasing earnest of their welcome.
vi: The Gardiner children were standing on the doorstep when they drove in, and as the car reached the threshold, the children's faces lit up, jumping excitedly to greet them.
tr: When they saw the car, the little Gardiners, who had eagerly climbed the steps as the car entered the lawn, were waiting; as the car approached the door, the joyful astonishment that lit up their faces and spread through their entire bodies, making them jump and bounce, was the first sign of the excitement caused by their arrival.
es: The little Gardiners, drawn by the sight of a carriage, stood on the steps of the house as it made its way up the driveway. When the carriage stopped at the door, the joyful surprise that shone on their faces and made them jump around was the prelude to their welcome.

en: Elizabeth jumped out; and after giving each of them a hasty kiss, hurried into the vestibule, where Jane, who came running downstairs from her mother’s apartment, immediately met her.
vi: Elizabeth jumped down from the carriage, quickly kissed each child, and ran into the front hall while Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were busy with their children and Jane was running down the stairs from their parents' room.
tr: Elizabeth rushed outside; after hastily kissing each one, she darted to the hall; Jane came running out of her mother's room and immediately greeted her.
es: Elizabeth gave each one a kiss and ran to the hall, where she met Jane who was hurrying down from their mother's room.

en: Elizabeth, as she affectionately embraced her, whilst tears filled the eyes of both, lost not a moment in asking whether anything had been heard of the fugitives.
vi: Elizabeth affectionately hugged her sister, tears streaming down but not wasting a moment. She asked if there was any news of the two who had run away.
tr: As Elizabeth embraced him with love, while tears filled both of their eyes, she asked without losing a moment if there was any news about the fugitives.
es: They embraced warmly, with eyes full of tears, and Elizabeth asked without wasting a second if there had been any news of the fugitives.

en: “Not yet,” replied Jane.
vi: Jane replied: - Not yet.
tr: "Not yet," Jane replied.
es: ––Not yet ––replied Jane––, but now that our dear uncle has arrived, I hope everything goes well.

en: “But now that my dear uncle is come, I hope everything will be well.”
vi: But now that you are here, I hope everything will be fine.
tr: "But now that my uncle is here, I hope everything will be alright.""
es: ––Not yet ––replied Jane––, but now that our dear uncle has arrived, I hope everything goes well.

en: “Is my father in town?”
vi: - Has Dad gone to the city?
tr: "Is my father in the city?"
es: ––Is Dad in the capital?

en: “Yes, he went on Tuesday, as I wrote you word.”
vi: - Yes, he left on Tuesday as you mentioned in the letter.
tr: "Yes, he went on Tuesday, while I was writing you a letter."
es: ––Yes, he left on Tuesday, as I wrote to you.

en: “And have you heard from him often?”
vi: - And have you heard from Dad often?
tr: "Have you heard from him often?""
es: ––And what news have you had of him?

en: “We have heard only once.
vi: - The family only received news once.
tr: "I received it once.
es: ––Few.

en: He wrote me a few lines on Wednesday, to say that he had arrived in safety, and to give me his directions, which I particularly begged him to do.
vi: Dad wrote a few lines to my sister on Wednesday, saying that he had arrived safely.
tr: He wrote a few lines on Wednesday, saying he arrived safely, and gave his address, which I had specifically requested.
es: On Wednesday, he sent me a few lines saying that he had arrived safely and giving me his address, as I had asked him to.

en: He merely added, that he should not write again, till he had something of importance to mention.”
vi: He only added that he would not send any more letters unless there was important news.
tr: He said he wouldn't write again unless he had something important to say."
es: He only added that he wouldn't write again until he had something important to tell us.

en: “And my mother—how is she?
vi: - And mother, how is she?
tr: "And my mother – How is she?
es: ––And mom, how is she?

en: How are you all?”
vi: How is the whole family?
tr: How are you all?"
es: How are all of you?

en: “My mother is tolerably well, I trust; though her spirits are greatly shaken.
vi: - Mother is enduring quite well, I believe; although her spirit is in crisis.
tr: "My mother is doing fairly well; her morale is very low though.
es: ––Mom is fine, as far as I can see, although very downcast.

en: She is upstairs, and will have great satisfaction in seeing you all.
vi: She is lying upstairs, and will be very happy to see everyone again.
tr: She is upstairs; she will be happy to see you.
es: She is upstairs and will have great satisfaction in seeing you all.

en: She does not yet leave her dressing-room.
vi: She is lying upstairs, and will be very happy to see everyone again.
tr: She hasn't come out of her room yet.
es: She still hasn't left her room.

en: Mary and Kitty, thank Heaven! are quite well.”
vi: Mary and Kitty, thank God, are both normal.
tr: Mary and Kitty, thank goodness, are very well."
es: Mary and Catherine are perfectly well, thank God.

en: “But you—how are you?” cried Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - But what about you, how are you?
tr: "Well, you – How are you?" cried Elizabeth.
es: ––And you, how are you feeling? ––asked Elizabeth––.

en: “You look pale.
vi: You look pale.
tr: "You look pale.
es: You look pale.

en: How much you must have gone through!”
vi: You've had to go through so much suffering?
tr: Who knows what you've been through!"
es: You must have gone through so much!

en: Her sister, however, assured her of her being perfectly well; and their conversation, which had been passing while mr and ms Gardiner were engaged with their children, was now put an end to by the approach of the whole party.
vi: But the older sister reassured that she was completely healthy, their conversation was interrupted when the uncle and aunt entered.
tr: However, her sister assured her that she was quite well; the conversation that was taking place among them ended as Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were occupied with their children and all approached together.
es: But Jane assured her that she was very well. Meanwhile, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, who had been busy with their children, arrived and put an end to the conversation between the two sisters.

en: Jane ran to her uncle and aunt, and welcomed and thanked them both, with alternate smiles and tears.
vi: Jane ran to them, greeted and thanked them with smiles mixed with tears.
tr: Jane ran to her uncle and aunt, greeted them, and oscillating between tears and smiles, thanked them both.
es: Jane ran to her aunt and uncle and welcomed and thanked them with tears and smiles.

en: When they were all in the drawing-room, the questions which Elizabeth had already asked were of course repeated by the others, and they soon found that Jane had no intelligence to give.
vi: When everyone had entered the living room, the couple repeated the same questions as Elizabeth, and found that Jane had no news.
tr: When they gathered in the living room, the questions Elizabeth asked were naturally repeated by the others, and they saw that Jane had no news to share.
es: Once gathered in the living room, the questions asked by Elizabeth were repeated by the others, and they saw that poor Jane had no new information.

en: The sanguine hope of good, however, which the benevolence of her heart suggested, had not yet deserted her; she still expected that it would all end well, and that every morning would bring some letter, either from Lydia or her father, to explain their proceedings, and, perhaps, announce the marriage.
vi: However, the optimistic hope from her gentle heart remained; she still hoped that everything would end well, and each morning she expected to receive a letter, either from Lydia or from her father, to explain what the two had done and perhaps to announce a wedding.
tr: Nevertheless, the hope inspired by the innocence in her heart had not yet abandoned her; she still hoped that everything would end well, that every morning would bring a letter either from Lydia or her father explaining what had happened and perhaps announcing the marriage.
es: But her ardent confidence that everything would end well had not abandoned her; she still hoped that one of these mornings a letter from Lydia or her father would arrive explaining the events and perhaps announcing the marriage.

en: ms Bennet, to whose apartment they all repaired, after a few minutes’ conversation together, received them exactly as might be expected; with tears and lamentations of regret, invectives against the villainous conduct of Wickham, and complaints of her own sufferings and ill-usage; blaming everybody but the person to whose ill-judging indulgence the errors of her daughter must be principally owing.
vi: After a few minutes of conversation, they went together to Mrs. Bennet's room. She received them in the manner they had anticipated, with tears and lamentations, insults to Wickham's character, and complaints about the suffering and mistreatment she was enduring. She blamed everyone while the less knowledgeable had indulged the faults of the daughter who should have blamed herself.
tr: After talking privately for a few minutes, they went up to Mrs. Bennet's room, where she received them exactly as expected: with tears of regret and pleas, curses directed at Wickham's vile behavior, complaints about her own suffering and misfortune, and blaming everyone except the one responsible for the neglect that was the main cause of her daughter's mistakes.
es: Mrs. Bennet, to whose room they all went up after their brief conversation, received them as expected: with tears and lamentations, reproaches against Wickham's villainous conduct, and complaints about her own sufferings, blaming everyone except the one who, due to her tolerance and poor judgment, was mainly responsible for her daughter's mistakes.

en: “If I had been able,” said she, “to carry my point in going to Brighton with all my family, this would not have happened: but poor dear Lydia had nobody to take care of her.
vi: She said: - If everyone had listened to my opinion and all gone to Brighton, this wouldn't have happened; but poor little Lydia had no one to look after her.
tr: "If only I could," she said, "if I had carried out my plan to go to Brighton with my whole family, none of this would have happened; but there was no one to keep an eye on poor Lydia.
es: ––If I had been able ––he said–– to carry out my plan of going to Brighton with my whole family, this would not have happened; but poor Lydia had no one to look after her.

en: Why did the Forsters ever let her go out of their sight?
vi: Why didn't the Forsters take care of her?
tr: Why did the Forsters take their eyes off her?
es: The Forsters should not have lost sight of her.

en: I am sure there was some great neglect or other on their side, for she is not the kind of girl to do such a thing, if she had been well looked after.
vi: I'm sure they were negligent or something, because the girl wouldn't have done such a thing if she had been properly cared for.
tr: I think they must have been greatly negligent in some way or another, otherwise Lydia is not the kind of girl to do such a thing; they did not keep a good eye on her, that's why this happened.
es: If they had watched her closely, she would not have done such a thing, Lydia is not that kind of girl.

en: I always thought they were very unfit to have the charge of her; but I was over-ruled, as I always am.
vi: I've always thought they weren't capable of looking after the girl, but no one ever listens to me, as always.
tr: I always knew they were not capable of taking responsibility for her, but who listens to me, when did they ever listen anyway.
es: I always knew that the Forsters were very unsuitable to take care of her, but no one listened to me, as always.

en: Poor, dear child!
vi: Poor little girl!
tr: Oh, my poor girl!
es: My poor girl!

en: And now here’s mr Bennet gone away, and I know he will fight Wickham, wherever he meets him, and then he will be killed, and what is to become of us all?
vi: And now Mr. Bennet is away, I know he will confront Wickham wherever he meets him, and then he will be killed, and what will become of all of us?
tr: Now Mr. Bennet has gone; I know he will fight Wickham when he sees him, then he will be killed, and what will happen to us then?
es: And now Bennet has gone and I suppose he will challenge Wickham wherever he finds him, and since he will die in the duel, what will become of us?

en: The Collinses will turn us out, before he is cold in his grave; and if you are not kind to us, brother, I do not know what we shall do.”
vi: The Collinses will throw us out before his grave is even green, dear brother, if you are not kind to us, I don't know how we will survive.
tr: The Collinses will throw us out of the house before his body is even cold in the grave; if you don't reach out to us, brother, God knows what will become of us."
es: The Collins will throw us out of here before he is cold in his grave, and if you, my brother, do not assist us, I don't know what we will do.

en: They all exclaimed against such terrific ideas; and mr Gardiner, after general assurances of his affection for her and all her family, told her that he meant to be in London the very next day, and would assist mr Bennet in every endeavour for recovering Lydia.
vi: They all refuted such terrible opinions; Mr. Gardiner reassured her about his feelings for her and for her entire family, then he told her he planned to go to London the next day, and would try to help Mr. Bennet in every way to find Lydia.
tr: They all objected to such pessimistic thoughts in unison; after Mr. Gardiner expressed how fond he was of her and her entire family, he mentioned that he was considering going to London the next day and would assist Mr. Bennet in every way to find Lydia.
es: Everyone protested against such terrifying ideas. Mr. Gardiner assured her that they would not lack his support and said that he planned to be in London the next day to help Mr. Bennet with all his efforts to find Lydia.

en: “Do not give way to useless alarm,” added he: “though it is right to be prepared for the worst, there is no occasion to look on it as certain.
vi: He added: - Please don't panic as it won't do any good; although we should prepare for the worst-case scenario, we shouldn't think that it will definitely happen like that.
tr: "Don't panic unnecessarily," he added, "it's right to be prepared for the worst, but there's no point in seeing it as a done deal.
es: ––Do not alarm yourselves needlessly ––he added––; although it is good to prepare for the worst, it should not be taken for granted.

en: It is not quite a week since they left Brighton.
vi: The two people left Brighton less than a week ago.
tr: It hasn't even been a week since they left Brighton.
es: It has not even been a week since they left Brighton.

en: In a few days more, we may gain some news of them; and till we know that they are not married, and have no design of marrying, do not let us give the matter over as lost.
vi: In the next few days, we hope to receive some news about them, and since we don't know if they have married or intend to marry, we shouldn't think that all is lost.
tr: Let's wait a few more days, we'll hear from them; until we learn that they haven't married and aren't planning to marry, let's not consider the matter lost.
es: In a few more days we will find out something; and until we know that they are not married and have no intentions of being so, let us not consider the matter lost.

en: As soon as I get to town, I shall go to my brother, and make him come home with me to Gracechurch Street, and then we may consult together as to what is to be done.”
vi: When I get to the city, I will immediately go see my brother and invite him to go with me to Gracechurch Street, then we will discuss together what to do.
tr: As soon as I get to the city, I'll find my uncle, take him to Gracechurch Street, to our house; then we'll sit down and discuss what we should do."
es: As soon as I arrive in London, I will pick up my brother and take him to Gracechurch Street; together we will deliberate on what needs to be done.

en: “Oh, my dear brother,” replied ms Bennet, “that is exactly what I could most wish for.
vi: Mrs. Bennet replied: - Oh! My dear brother, this is exactly what I long for.
tr: "Ah my dear brother," replied Mrs. Bennet, "I was just saying the same thing.
es: ––Oh, my dear brother! exclaimed Mrs. Bennet––, that is precisely my greatest wish.

en: And now do, when you get to town, find them out, wherever they may be; and if they are not married already, make them marry.
vi: And please, when you get to the city and find them, wherever they may be, if they are not yet married, help advise them to get married.
tr: When you go to the city, find them, wherever they are; if they haven't married, make them marry.
es: When you get to London, find them wherever they are, and if they are not married, make them get married.

en: And as for wedding clothes, do not let them wait for that, but tell Lydia she shall have as much money as she chooses to buy them, after they are married.
vi: Regarding the wedding dress, tell them not to wait, but please tell Lydia she will have the money she wants to shop after the wedding.
tr: They shouldn't wait for wedding dresses or anything; tell Lydia to just get married first, and then we can buy whatever dress she wants, no matter the cost.
es: Do not allow them to delay the wedding for the bridal gown, tell Lydia that she will have all the money she wants to buy it afterwards.

en: And, above all things, keep mr Bennet from fighting.
vi: Above all, keep Mr. Bennet away from any conflicts.
tr: But most importantly, don't involve Mr. Bennet in any fights.
es: And above all, prevent Bennet from dueling with Wickham.

en: Tell him what a dreadful state I am in—that I am frightened out of my wits; and have such tremblings, such flutterings all over me, such spasms in my side, and pains in my head, and such beatings at my heart, that I can get no rest by night nor by day.
vi: Tell him about my miserable state – that I am so terrified I can't think straight, I am trembling, speaking incoherently, having spasms on both sides, headaches, rapid heartbeat, to the point that I cannot rest day or night.
tr: Tell him how terribly I am, –say that I've lost my mind from fear, that I'm trembling, having convulsions, suffering from chest pains, headaches, my heart is pounding, and I'm in such a state that I have neither night nor day.
es: Tell him the horrible state I am in: shattered, distraught, with such trembling and agitation, such convulsions in my side, such headaches and such palpitations that I cannot rest either day or night.

en: And tell my dear Lydia not to give any directions about her clothes till she has seen me, for she does not know which are the best warehouses.
vi: Please tell Lydia not to rush into buying clothes before seeing me again, as she doesn't know where to buy at a cheap price.
tr: Also tell my sweet Lydia not to get into the matter of clothes until she sees me because she doesn't know which shop is good.
es: And tell my dear Lydia not to order her dresses until she has seen me, for she does not know which are the best stores.

en: Oh, brother, how kind you are!
vi: Oh, my dear brother, you are so kind!
tr: Oh brother, how kind you are!
es: Oh, brother! How good you are!

en: I know you will contrive it all.”
vi: I know you will take care of everything.
tr: You can handle all of this."
es: I know you will sort everything out.

en: But mr Gardiner, though he assured her again of his earnest endeavours in the cause, could not avoid recommending moderation to her, as well in her hopes as her fears; and after talking with her in this manner till dinner was on table, they left her to vent all her feelings on the housekeeper, who attended in the absence of her daughters.
vi: But Mr. Gardiner, despite reassuring three more times that he would try, still wanted to advise her to remain calm in both hope and fear. They tried to console her in this way until dinner time, then they left her to pour out all her thoughts to the housekeeper who came to take care of her while the daughters had their meal.
tr: Although Mr. Gardiner expressed that he would do his best for that purpose, he could not refrain from advising him to be moderate in both his fears and hopes; after talking to him in this way until dinner was served, they left his side so that he could vent all his emotions to the butler who had taken over his daughter's duties in her absence.
es: Mr. Gardiner repeated to her that he would do everything he could and advised her to moderate her hopes and fears. He conversed with her in this manner until the meal was on the table, and left her to vent with the housekeeper who assisted her in the absence of her daughters.

en: Though her brother and sister were persuaded that there was no real occasion for such a seclusion from the family, they did not attempt to oppose it; for they knew that she had not prudence enough to hold her tongue before the servants, while they waited at table, and judged it better that one only of the household, and the one whom they could most trust, should comprehend all her fears and solicitude on the subject.
vi: Even though the younger brother and sister-in-law believed there was no reason to isolate her from the family like that, they did not object because they knew she was not careful enough to keep her mouth shut with the servants when they served at the table. So it was better to have only one servant, the most trusted one, who knew about all her tears and worries regarding the matter.
tr: His brother and sister-in-law thought there was no reason to hide it from the family, but they did not try to oppose it either, because they knew he did not have the common sense to hold his tongue in front of the servants while waiting at the table, and they decided that it would be appropriate for just one person among the servants, the one they trusted the most, to witness his fears and concerns about the matter.
es: Although his brother and sister-in-law were convinced that there was no reason for him not to come down to eat, they did not dare ask him to sit with them at the table, because they feared his imprudence in front of the servants and thought it preferable that only one of them, the one they could trust the most, should learn of his troubles.

en: In the dining-room they were soon joined by Mary and Kitty, who had been too busily engaged in their separate apartments to make their appearance before.
vi: Mary and Kitty came to dine together after being busy in their respective rooms, one occupied with books, the other preoccupied with makeup.
tr: Mary and Kitty, who had been too busy to appear earlier in their own rooms, joined them in the dining room.
es: In the dining room appeared Mary and Catherine, who had been too busy in their rooms to show up earlier.

en: One came from her books, and the other from her toilette.
vi: Mary and Kitty came to dine together after being busy in their respective rooms, one occupied with books, the other preoccupied with makeup.
tr: One came from her books, the other from her dressing table.
es: One had just put down her books and the other her vanity.

en: The faces of both, however, were tolerably calm; and no change was visible in either, except that the loss of her favourite sister, or the anger which she had herself incurred in the business, had given something more of fretfulness than usual to the accents of Kitty.
vi: However, both appeared quite calm, with no noticeable changes, except that Kitty seemed more irritable than usual, due to the loss of her beloved younger sibling and the anger she had caused within the family.
tr: Both of their faces were quite calm; apart from the loss of their beloved sister or the unusual annoyance in Kitty's manner of speaking caused by the anger she had gathered because of it, there was no visible change.
es: But both were very calm and did not seem upset. Only the latter had a more irate tone than usual, whether due to the loss of the favorite sister or the anger of not finding herself in her place.

en: As for Mary, she was mistress enough of herself to whisper to Elizabeth, with a countenance of grave reflection, soon after they were seated at table,—
vi: As for Mary, she had matured enough to whisper to Elizabeth with a serious expression.
tr: As for Mary, she was composed enough to whisper to Elizabeth with a face full of serious thought right after sitting at the table,
es: Shortly after sitting at the table, Mary, very sure of herself, whispered to Elizabeth with an air of gravity in her reflection:

en: “This is a most unfortunate affair, and will probably be much talked of.
vi: - This is the most unfortunate event, and it will probably be talked about the most.
tr: "A very unfortunate situation; it will probably be talked about a lot.
es: It is a very unfortunate matter and will probably be much talked about; but we must overcome the wave of malice and pour the balm of fraternal comfort over our wounded hearts.

en: But we must stem the tide of malice, and pour into the wounded bosoms of each other the balm of sisterly consolation.”
vi: But we must strive to overcome malice, and pour into each wounded heart the comfort of sisterly love.
tr: But we must stop the winds of evil and apply the balm of brotherhood's consolation to each other's wounded chests."
es: It is a very unfortunate matter and will probably be much talked about; but we must overcome the wave of malice and pour the balm of fraternal comfort over our wounded hearts.

en: Then perceiving in Elizabeth no inclination of replying, she added, “Unhappy as the event must be for Lydia, we may draw from it this useful lesson:—that loss of virtue in a female is irretrievable, that one false step involves her in endless ruin, that her reputation is no less brittle than it is beautiful, and that she cannot be too much guarded in her behaviour towards the undeserving of the other sex.”
vi: Then, noticing that Elizabeth had no intention of replying, she added: - Although the event was unfortunate for Lydia, we can draw a useful lesson from it, which is: a single misstep can cause immense ruin, reputation is as fragile as beauty, and maintaining propriety in one's attitude towards ordinary boys cannot be overemphasized.
tr: Then, seeing that Elizabeth had no intention of replying, he added, "Although it is a grievous incident for Lydia, we must derive a useful lesson from it; a woman's loss of honor is irreparable – a single misstep can darken a woman's world – a woman's virtue is as beautiful as it is fragile – her behavior towards the worthless members of the opposite sex can never be too cautious.""
es: Upon arriving here, he noticed that Elizabeth did not feel like answering, and added: ––Although it may be a misfortune for Lydia, for us it can be a valuable lesson: the loss of virtue in a woman is irreparable; a single misstep carries within it the final ruin; her reputation is no less fragile than her beauty, and she can never be cautious enough in her behavior towards the indignities of the other sex.

en: Elizabeth lifted up her eyes in amazement, but was too much oppressed to make any reply.
vi: Elizabeth looked up in astonishment, but her mind was too heavy for her to respond.
tr: Elizabeth raised her eyes in astonishment, but she was too distressed to respond.
es: Elizabeth, astonished, raised her eyes, but she was too distressed to respond.

en: Mary, however, continued to console herself with such kind of moral extractions from the evil before them.
vi: However, Mary continued to console herself with quotes from books on ethics.
tr: Nevertheless, Mary continued to occupy herself with making such moral inferences from the disaster ahead of them.
es: Mary continued consoling herself with moral lessons of the sort drawn from the misfortune before them.

en: In the afternoon, the two elder Miss Bennets were able to be for half an hour by themselves; and Elizabeth instantly availed herself of the opportunity of making any inquiries which Jane was equally eager to satisfy.
vi: In the afternoon, the two eldest Bennet sisters had some time to sit alone together, and Elizabeth immediately inquired about many things, with Jane willing to respond amidst lamentations about the dreadful consequences of the affair.
tr: In the afternoon, the two eldest Miss Bennets managed to stay alone together for about half an hour; Elizabeth seized the opportunity and immediately asked many questions, and Jane answered with equal eagerness.
es: In the afternoon, the two eldest Bennet daughters were able to be alone for half an hour, and Elizabeth immediately took the opportunity to ask some questions that Jane was equally eager to answer.

en: After joining in general lamentations over the dreadful sequel of this event, which Elizabeth considered as all but certain, and Miss Bennet could not assert to be wholly impossible, the former continued the subject by saying, “But tell me all and everything about it which I have not already heard.
vi: Elizabeth asked:
tr: According to Elizabeth, the only certain thing about this event was the dreadful conclusion that Miss Bennet could not quite deny as impossible. After lamenting over it together, Elizabeth continued: "Tell me everything about this that I haven't heard yet, one by one.
es: After lamenting together about the terrible consequences of the event, which Elizabeth took for granted and the other could not assure were impossible, the former said:

en: Give me further particulars.
vi: - But please tell me all the details that I haven't heard yet.
tr: Give me more details.
es: Tell me everything I don't know. Give me more details.

en: What did Colonel Forster say?
vi: What did Colonel Forster say?
tr: What did Colonel Forster say?
es: What did Colonel Forster say?

en: Had they no apprehension of anything before the elopement took place?
vi: Did they notice any signs before the two ran away?
tr: Didn't they notice anything before they ran away?
es: Didn't he have any suspicion about the escape?

en: They must have seen them together for ever.”
vi: They must have seen the two of them always together?
tr: They must have seen the two of them together all the time."
es: They must have always seen them together.

en: “Colonel Forster did own that he had often suspected some partiality, especially on Lydia’s side, but nothing to give him any alarm.
vi: - Colonel Forster said he suspected the two had feelings for each other, especially on Lydia's part, but didn't see anything to worry about.
tr: "Colonel Forster admitted that he often suspected from close proximity, especially regarding Lydia, but nothing had happened to alarm him.
es: ––Colonel Forster confessed that he once noticed some interest, especially on Lydia's part, but he saw nothing that alarmed him.

en: I am so grieved for him.
vi: She felt sorry for him.
tr: I felt very sorry for him.
es: I feel sorry for him.

en: His behaviour was attentive and kind to the utmost.
vi: His attitude was very attentive and kind.
tr: He behaved extremely close and concerned.
es: He was most attentive and kind.

en: He was coming to us, in order to assure us of his concern, before he had any idea of their not being gone to Scotland: when that apprehension first got abroad, it hastened his journey.”
vi: He was coming here to express his concerns before he knew they weren't going to Scotland. As soon as he got the news, he hurried on his way.
tr: He was coming to us to make sure of his interest before the idea that they hadn't gone to Scotland occurred to him, and that idea hastened his journey."
es: He was planning to come see us before knowing they hadn't gone to Scotland, and when it was presumed they were in London, he hastened his trip.

en: “And was Denny convinced that Wickham would not marry?
vi: - And does Danny firmly believe that Wickham will refuse to get married?
tr: "So, you believe that Denny will not marry Wickham?
es: ––And Denny, was he convinced that Wickham would not get married?

en: Did he know of their intending to go off?
vi: Does he know anything about the two eloping?
tr: Did he know that they were planning to elope?
es: Did he know they were going to elope?

en: Had Colonel Forster seen Denny himself?”
vi: Did Colonel Forster meet Danny?
tr: Did Colonel Forster see Denny himself?"
es: Has Colonel Forster seen Denny?

en: “Yes; but when questioned by him, Denny denied knowing anything of their plan, and would not give his real opinion about it.
vi: - Yes, but when he was questioned by him, he said he didn't know anything about their plan and didn't give any opinion on the matter.
tr: "Yes; but when questioned, Denny denied knowing about the plans and did not reveal his true opinion on the matter.
es: ––Yes, but when he was questioned, Denny said he wasn't aware of anything and refused to give his true opinion on the matter.

en: He did not repeat his persuasion of their not marrying, and from that I am inclined to hope he might have been misunderstood before.”
vi: He didn't repeat what he believed, that they wouldn't get married, and from this, she hoped he had previously misunderstood.
tr: He did not repeat that he thought they would not marry – from this, I hope that he might have been previously misunderstood."
es: He didn't repeat his conviction that they wouldn't get married, and that's why I think he might have misunderstood it.

en: “And till Colonel Forster came himself, not one of you entertained a doubt, I suppose, of their being really married?”
vi: - Do you think that before Colonel Forster came here, no one in the family suspected that they would actually get married, right?
tr: "Until Colonel Forster came in person, none of you really doubted that they would get married, did you?"
es: ––I suppose that until Colonel Forster came, no one in the house doubted that they were married.

en: “How was it possible that such an idea should enter our brains?
vi: - How could such a thought have entered our minds!
tr: "But how could such a thing even cross our minds!
es: ––How could such a thing occur to us?

en: I felt a little uneasy—a little fearful of my sister’s happiness with him in marriage, because I knew that his conduct had not been always quite right.
vi: She felt a little worried – a little fearful about the happiness of the girl in her marriage with him, because she knew his character was not always proper.
tr: I was a bit uneasy – I was slightly afraid that she would marry him and be unhappy, because I knew that the man's behavior was not always proper.
es: I felt sad because I know it is difficult for my sister to be happy marrying Wickham due to his terrible background.

en: My father and mother knew nothing of that; they only felt how imprudent a match it must be.
vi: Both father and mother knew nothing about this; they only thought that the marriage was too hasty.
tr: My parents didn't know this; they just thought it was an imprudent marriage.
es: Our parents knew nothing of this, but they realized the imprudence of such a wedding.

en: Kitty then owned, with a very natural triumph on knowing more than the rest of us, that in Lydia’s last letter she had prepared her for such a step.
vi: Then, with the pride of knowing more than others, Kitty revealed that in Lydia's last letter, the girl had prepared her sister for this matter.
tr: Then Kitty, with the rightful pride of knowing more than us, confessed in Lydia's last letter that she was preparing to take such a step.
es: Then Catherine confessed, very satisfied to know more than us, that Lydia's last letter already hinted at what they were plotting.

en: She had known, it seems, of their being in love with each other many weeks.”
vi: It seemed that Kitty had known for weeks that they had feelings for each other.
tr: Apparently, she knew they had been in love for weeks."
es: It seems that she said they had been in love for a few weeks.

en: “But not before they went to Brighton?”
vi: - But not from before they went to Brighton, right?
tr: "Not until I go to Brighton.""
es: ––But not before going to Brighton.

en: “No, I believe not.”
vi: - That's right.
tr: "No, I don't think so."
es: ––I don't think so.

en: “And did Colonel Forster appear to think ill of Wickham himself?
vi: - And it seems that Colonel Forster himself had a poor opinion of Wickham, didn't he?
tr: "Was Colonel Forster blaming Wickham?
es: ––And Colonel Forster, does he have a bad opinion of Wickham?

en: Does he know his real character?”
vi: Did he know Wickham's true nature?
tr: Does he know his true character?"
es: Does he know what he is really like?

en: “I must confess that he did not speak so well of Wickham as he formerly did.
vi: - You must admit that he doesn't speak about Wickham as favorably as he did before.
tr: "I must admit that I do not speak as well of Wickham as I used to.
es: ––I must confess that he did not speak as well of him as before.

en: He believed him to be imprudent and extravagant; and since this sad affair has taken place, it is said that he left Meryton greatly in debt: but I hope this may be false.”
vi: Since this unfortunate incident occurred, it is said that he has many debts in Meryton, but I hope this is not true.
tr: He is believed to be indifferent and frivolous. It is said that he left a lot of debt when he departed from Meryton since that unfortunate incident, but I hope it is not true."
es: He considers him imprudent and a spendthrift. And it is said that he has left great debts in Meryton, but I hope it is not true.

en: “Oh, Jane, had we been less secret, had we told what we knew of him, this could not have happened!”
vi: - Oh, Jane, if we hadn't been so secretive, if we had told everyone what we knew about him, this wouldn't have happened!
tr: "Ah Jane, if we had kept fewer secrets and told you what we knew about you, none of this might have happened."
es: ––Oh, Jane! If we hadn't been so reserved and had said what we knew about Wickham, this wouldn't have happened.

en: “Perhaps it would have been better,” replied her sister.
vi: - Maybe it would be better.
tr: "Maybe it would have been better," her sister replied.
es: ––Maybe it would have been better ––replied her sister––, but it is not fair to publish a person's past mistakes, ignoring whether they have corrected them.

en: “But to expose the former faults of any person, without knowing what their present feelings were, seemed unjustifiable.”
vi: But exposing someone's past mistakes without knowing their current state of mind seems unfair.
tr: "But it might seem unjust to reveal a person's past mistakes without knowing their current feelings.
es: ––Maybe it would have been better ––replied her sister––, but it is not fair to publish a person's past mistakes, ignoring whether they have corrected them.

en: “We acted with the best intentions.”
vi: We acted with the best intentions.
tr: We acted with good intentions."
es: We acted in good faith.

en: “Could Colonel Forster repeat the particulars of Lydia’s note to his wife?”
vi: - Did Colonel Forster mention anything about the contents of Lydia's letter to his wife?
tr: "Did Colonel Forster explain the details of the letter he wrote to Lydia's wife?""
es: ––Did Colonel Forster repeat the details of the note that Lydia left for his wife?

en: “He brought it with him for us to see.”
vi: - You brought that letter here for the household to read.
tr: "He brought it along so we could see.""
es: ––He brought it with him to show it to us.

en: Jane then took it from her pocket-book, and gave it to Elizabeth.
vi: Then Jane took out the letter and handed it to Elizabeth.
tr: Jane took the letter out of her notebook and gave it to Elizabeth.
es: Jane took it out of her purse and gave it to Elizabeth.

en: These were the contents:—
vi: The content of the letter was as follows:
tr: The content of the letter was as follows:
es: This was its content:

en: “My dear Harriet,
vi: "Dear Harriet,
tr: "Dear Harriet,
es: Dear Harriet,

en: “You will laugh when you know where I am gone, and I cannot help laughing myself at your surprise to-morrow morning, as soon as I am missed.
vi: You will laugh when you know that I am about to leave, and I cannot help but laugh when I think of your surprise tomorrow morning, right after I am absent.
tr: When you learn that I have gone, you will laugh; I cannot help but laugh myself when I think of how surprised you will be when you cannot find me tomorrow.
es: You will laugh when you find out where I have gone, and I can't stop laughing myself thinking about the fright you will get tomorrow when you don't find me.

en: I am going to Gretna Green, and if you cannot guess with who, I shall think you a simpleton, for there is but one man in the world I love, and he is an angel.
vi: I intend to go to Gretna Green, and if you cannot guess who I am going with, I will think you are foolish, because there is only one person in the world whom I love, he is an angel.
tr: I am going to Gretna Green; if you cannot guess with whom, I will call you a fool, because there is only one man in the world that I love, and he is an angel.
es: I'm going to Gretna Green, and if you don't guess with whom, I will think you're a fool, because he is the only man I love in the world, so I don't think I'm doing anything foolish by going with him.

en: I should never be happy without him, so think it no harm to be off.
vi: I will never be happy without him, so please do not worry about me.
tr: I can never be happy without him, so I see no harm in going.
es: I'm going to Gretna Green, and if you don't guess with whom, I will think you're a fool, because he is the only man I love in the world, so I don't think I'm doing anything foolish by going with him.

en: You need not send them word at Longbourn of my going, if you do not like it, for it will make the surprise the greater when I write to them, and sign my name Lydia Wickham.
vi: If you do not accept my departure, please do not inform Longbourn about this, because I want to give them a bigger surprise when I write to them and sign as Lydia Wickham.
tr: You need not inform those at Longbourn of my departure, if you do not wish to, because the surprise will be greater when I write to them and sign my name as Lydia Wickham.
es: If you don't want to, don't tell my family, as it will be a bigger surprise when I write to them and sign as Lydia Wickham.

en: What a good joke it will be!
