vi: What a joke!
tr: What a delightful joke it will be!
es: It will be a great joke!

en: I can hardly write for laughing.
vi: I will probably laugh so hard that I cannot write.
tr: I cannot write for laughing.
es: I can hardly write from laughing.

en: Pray make my excuses to Pratt for not keeping my engagement, and dancing with him to-night.
vi: Please apologize to Mr. Pratt for me, tell him I will be very happy to dance with him at the first ball I see him again.
tr: Please make up something for Pratt on my behalf, as I cannot go to the dance with him tonight.
es: I beg you to excuse me with Pratt for not fulfilling my commitment to dance with him tonight; tell him I hope he will forgive me when he knows everything, and also that I will gladly dance with him at the first ball we meet.

en: Tell him I hope he will excuse me when he knows all, and tell him I will dance with him at the next ball we meet with great pleasure.
vi: Please apologize to Mr. Pratt for me, tell him I will be very happy to dance with him at the first ball I see him again.
tr: Say that I hope he will forgive me when he learns everything, and also say that I will dance with him with great pleasure at the first ball when we meet again.
es: I beg you to excuse me with Pratt for not fulfilling my commitment to dance with him tonight; tell him I hope he will forgive me when he knows everything, and also that I will gladly dance with him at the first ball we meet.

en: I shall send for my clothes when I get to Longbourn; but I wish you would tell Sally to mend a great slit in my worked muslin gown before they are packed up.
vi: I will ask for my clothes to be sent to me when I get to Longbourn; but please tell Sally to mend the tear in the muslin dress before sending it.
tr: When I go to Longbourn, I will send for my clothes; but I wish you would tell Sally to mend the large tear in my embroidered muslin dress before it is packed.
es: I will send for my dresses when I go to Longbourn, but tell Sally to fix the cut of the muslin dress from home before you pack it.

en: Good-bye.
vi: Goodbye.
tr: Goodbye.
es: Goodbye.

en: Give my love to Colonel Forster.
vi: Please send my regards to Colonel Forster, I hope you will drink to my journey.
tr: Give my love to Colonel Forster; I hope you will raise a glass to wish us a good journey.
es: Give my regards to Colonel Forster.

en: I hope you will drink to our good journey.
vi: Please send my regards to Colonel Forster, I hope you will drink to my journey.
tr: Give my love to Colonel Forster; I hope you will raise a glass to wish us a good journey.
es: I hope you will toast to our happy journey.

en: “Your affectionate friend,
vi: Grandma's little friend.
tr: Your friend who loves you,
es: Affectionate greetings from your friend,

en: “Lydia Bennet.”
vi: Lydia Bennet
tr: Lydia Bennet."
es: Lydia Bennet

en: “Oh, thoughtless, thoughtless Lydia!” cried Elizabeth when she had finished it.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed after reading the letter: - Oh! Foolish, that foolish Lydia!
tr: "Oh, foolish, foolish Lydia!" cried Elizabeth as she finished the letter.
es: ––Oh, Lydia, how thoughtless! How thoughtless! ––exclaimed Elizabeth after finishing reading––.

en: “What a letter is this, to be written at such a moment!
vi: What kind of letter is this, written at this time.
tr: What a letter, to be written at such a time.
es: What a letter to be written at such a moment!

en: But at least it shows that she was serious in the object of her journey.
vi: But at least it shows that she was serious about the purpose of the trip.
tr: But at least it shows she was serious about the journey.
es: But at least it seems she was serious about the purpose of her trip; we don't know what Wickham might have led her into, but Lydia's intention wasn't so infamous.

en: Whatever he might afterwards persuade her to, it was not on her side a scheme of infamy.
vi: Even if he later persuaded her in some other way, for her part, it was not a disgraceful intention.
tr: Whatever Wickham convinced her of later, Lydia did not have an immoral plan in mind.
es: But at least it seems she was serious about the purpose of her trip; we don't know what Wickham might have led her into, but Lydia's intention wasn't so infamous.

en: My poor father!
vi: Poor father!
tr: Poor father!
es: Poor father of mine!

en: how he must have felt it!”
vi: I wonder what he was thinking!
tr: Who knows how terrible he must feel!"
es: How much he must have felt it!

en: “I never saw anyone so shocked.
vi: - She had never seen anyone so shocked.
tr: "I have never seen anyone so shaken in my life.
es: ––I have never seen anyone so overwhelmed.

en: He could not speak a word for full ten minutes.
vi: After reading the letter, he couldn't speak for a long time.
tr: He couldn't say a single word for ten whole minutes.
es: He couldn't say a word for ten minutes.

en: My mother was taken ill immediately, and the whole house in such confusion!”
vi: Mother fell ill immediately, and the whole family was in confusion.
tr: My mother immediately fainted, and the whole house was in chaos in an instant!"
es: Mom got sick immediately. There was such confusion throughout the whole house!

en: “Oh, Jane,” cried Elizabeth, “was there a servant belonging to it who did not know the whole story before the end of the day?”
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - Oh! Jane, did any of the servants know about this matter right after the first day?
tr: "Ah Jane," cried Elizabeth, "there is not a single servant left at home who hasn't learned the whole story by evening."
es: ––Was there any servant who didn't find out about the whole story before the day ended?

en: “I do not know: I hope there was.
vi: - I'm not sure, I hope no one knows.
tr: "I don't know. –I hope there is some left.
es: ––I don't know, I think not.

en: But to be guarded at such a time is very difficult.
vi: But during that time, it was very difficult to keep it a secret.
tr: –But it's very difficult to be cautious in such times.
es: But it was very difficult to be cautious in those moments.

en: My mother was in hysterics; and though I endeavoured to give her every assistance in my power, I am afraid I did not do so much as I might have done.
vi: My mother was in a panic, and although I tried to take care of her as best as I could, I'm afraid I didn't do as much as I wanted!
tr: My mother had a nervous breakdown, and although I tried to help her in every way I could, I'm afraid I didn't do everything I could!
es: Mom became hysterical and although I assisted her as best as I could, I don't know if I did what I should have.

en: But the horror of what might possibly happen almost took from me my faculties.”
vi: But just thinking about the terrible things that could happen made me lose all my spirit.
tr: But the horror of thinking about the worst possibilities also left me powerless."
es: The horror of what had happened almost made me lose consciousness.

en: “Your attendance upon her has been too much for you.
vi: - Taking care of mom has already been too much for you.
tr: "Taking care of her must have been very hard on you.
es: ––You have sacrificed too much for mom; you don't look well.

en: You do not look well.
vi: You don't look well.
tr: You don't look well.
es: ––You have sacrificed too much for mom; you don't look well.

en: Oh that I had been with you!
vi: Oh!
tr: I wish I could have been there; you carried all the worry and fatigue alone."
es: I wish I had been by your side!

en: you have had every care and anxiety upon yourself alone.”
vi: If I had been with you then, I could have shared all the hardships and worries with you.
tr: I wish I could have been there; you carried all the worry and fatigue alone."
es: That way you could have taken care of yourself.

en: “Mary and Kitty have been very kind, and would have shared in every fatigue, I am sure, but I did not think it right for either of them.
vi: - Mary and Kitty are very good and I believe they can share, but I don't want them to.
tr: "Mary and Kitty were very understanding; they would share every fatigue, I'm sure, but I thought it wouldn't be right for them.
es: ––Mary and Catherine behaved very well and I have no doubt they would have helped me, but I did not think it convenient for either of them; Catherine is weak and delicate, and Mary studies so much that her hours of rest should not be interrupted.

en: Kitty is slight and delicate, and Mary studies so much that her hours of repose should not be broken in on.
vi: Kitty is somewhat weak and sensitive, while Mary has to study a lot, so I don't want her rest time to be interrupted.
tr: Kitty is weak and delicate, and Mary reads too much, I didn't want their rest hours to be interrupted.
es: ––Mary and Catherine behaved very well and I have no doubt they would have helped me, but I did not think it convenient for either of them; Catherine is weak and delicate, and Mary studies so much that her hours of rest should not be interrupted.

en: My aunt Philips came to Longbourn on Tuesday, after my father went away; and was so good as to stay till Thursday with me.
vi: Aunt Philips came to our house on Tuesday, after father had left, and kindly offered to stay with me until Thursday.
tr: After my father left, on Tuesday my Aunt Philips came to Longbourn; bless her, she stayed with me until Thursday.
es: Aunt Philips came to Longbourn on Tuesday, after father left, and she was so kind that she stayed with me until Thursday.

en: She was of great use and comfort to us all, and Lady Lucas has been very kind: she walked here on Wednesday morning to condole with us, and offered her services, or any of her daughters, if they could be of use to us.”
vi: She has helped a lot and has been a valuable source of comfort for us. Lady Lucas is also very kind; she walked here on Wednesday morning to comfort everyone and expressed her willingness to send one of her daughters to help if we need.
tr: She was very helpful, she relieved us all a lot; Lady Lucas was also very kind, she walked here on Wednesday morning to comfort us, offering her and her daughters' help, in case there was anything they could do."
es: She helped and encouraged us all a lot. Lady Lucas was also very kind: she came on Friday morning to offer her condolences and her services in any way possible, and to send any of her daughters if we thought they could be useful to us.

en: “She had better have stayed at home,” cried Elizabeth: “perhaps she meant well, but, under such a misfortune as this, one cannot see too little of one’s neighbours.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed: - You shouldn't have come; maybe you had good intentions, but in such unfortunate circumstances, one cannot think too highly of neighbors.
tr: "I wish she had stayed at home," cried Elizabeth; "she may have good intentions, but in the face of such misfortune, the less one sees their neighbors, the better.
es: ––It would have been better if he had stayed at home ––said Elizabeth––; his intentions may have been good, but in misfortunes like this, one should avoid neighbors.

en: Assistance is impossible; condolence, insufferable.
vi: Support is impossible; consolation is unbearable.
tr: Helping is impossible, comforting is unbearable.
es: They cannot help us and their condolences are offensive.

en: Let them triumph over us at a distance, and be satisfied.”
vi: Let them triumph from afar, and be satisfied.
tr: Let them enjoy and be satisfied from afar."
es: Let them take pleasure in criticizing us from a distance!

en: She then proceeded to inquire into the measures which her father had intended to pursue, while in town, for the recovery of his daughter.
vi: Then she inquired about the measures that the father intended to take, when in London, to find his daughter.
tr: Afterwards, he asked what kind of methods his father intended to follow in the city to find his daughter.
es: He then asked what measures his father planned to take in the capital in order to find his daughter.

en: “He meant, I believe,” replied Jane, “to go to Epsom, the place where they last changed horses, see the postilions, and try if anything could be made out from them.
vi: Jane replied: - She thinks he intends to go to Epsom, where the two exchanged horses, observe the route, and try to track from there.
tr: "I think his intention," Jane replied, "was to go to Epsom; they last changed horses there; he was going to see the drivers, to see if he could learn anything from them.
es: ––I think he intended to go to Epsom ––replied Jane––, which is where they last changed horses; he will talk to the postilions and see what he can find out from them.

en: His principal object must be to discover the number of the hackney coach which took them from Clapham.
vi: His main purpose is to find the whereabouts of the small carriage that took them to Clapham.
tr: His main goal was to find out the number of the carriage that brought them from Clapham.
es: His main goal is to discover the number of the rental carriage they left Clapham with; which had come from London with a passenger; and since my father thinks that the fact a gentleman and a lady change carriages might be noticed, he wants to make inquiries in Clapham.

en: It had come with a fare from London; and as he thought the circumstance of a gentleman and lady’s removing from one carriage into another might be remarked, he meant to make inquiries at Clapham.
vi: It carried a passenger from London, because he thinks the case of a young man and a girl getting off this carriage and then getting on another might attract attention, so he intends to inquire at Clapham.
tr: They had come from London with a passenger fare, and my father thought a lady and a gentleman changing carriages might have drawn attention, so he was going to investigate in Clapham.
es: His main goal is to discover the number of the rental carriage they left Clapham with; which had come from London with a passenger; and since my father thinks that the fact a gentleman and a lady change carriages might be noticed, he wants to make inquiries in Clapham.

en: If he could anyhow discover at what house the coachman had before set down his fare, he determined to make inquiries there, and hoped it might not be impossible to find out the stand and number of the coach.
vi: If he can find the address where the carriage dropped off the passenger, he will inquire there, hoping to find the whereabouts of the carriage.
tr: If he could find out in front of which house the driver dropped off the passengers, he would investigate there; he hoped it wouldn't be impossible to find the carriage's stand and number.
es: If he could discover the house where the coachman dropped off the traveler, it wouldn't be difficult to find out what type of carriage it was and the number.

en: I do not know of any other designs that he had formed; but he was in such a hurry to be gone, and his spirits so greatly discomposed, that I had difficulty in finding out even so much as this.”
vi: She is not sure what else he will do, because he left too hurriedly and was too agitated, so finding out this much was already very difficult.
tr: I don't know what else he had in mind: but he was in such a hurry and so upset when he left that I could barely learn this much."
es: I don't know what other plans he had; but he was in such a hurry to leave and was so distraught that this is all I could get out of him.

en: CHAPTER XLVIII.
vi: Chapter 48
tr: Chapter VI
es: CHAPTER XLVIII

en: THE whole party were in hopes of a letter from mr Bennet the next morning, but the post came in without bringing a single line from him.
vi: The whole family was expecting a letter from Mr. Bennet the next morning, but the postman arrived without bringing a single line from him.
tr: The next morning, they all expected to receive a letter from Mr. Bennet; the mail arrived, but it did not bring a single line from him.
es: Everyone expected a letter from Mr. Bennet the next morning; but the mail arrived and did not bring a single line from him.

en: His family knew him to be, on all common occasions, a most negligent and dilatory correspondent; but at such a time they had hoped for exertion.
vi: The entire family knew he was forgetful or lazy about correspondence in ordinary circumstances, but in this case, they hoped he would quickly send news home.
tr: The family knew that he was normally a negligent and lazy letter writer, but they hoped he would make some effort at such a time.
es: His family knew that he was not very fond of writing, but on this occasion, they believed he could well make an exception.

en: They were forced to conclude, that he had no pleasing intelligence to send; but even of that they would have been glad to be certain.
vi: Therefore, they concluded that he had no exciting news to write, but even about this, they still wanted to be sure.
tr: They concluded that he had no good news to send, but they would have preferred to be certain even of that.
es: They were, therefore, forced to assume that there was no good news; but even in that case, they preferred to have certainty.

en: mr Gardiner had waited only for the letters before he set off.
vi: Mr. Gardiner only waited for the postman before setting off.
tr: Mr. Gardiner had only waited for the letters before setting off.
es: Mr. Gardiner waited only for the mail to arrive and then left.

en: When he was gone, they were certain at least of receiving constant information of what was going on; and their uncle promised, at parting, to prevail on mr Bennet to return to Longbourn as soon as he could, to the great consolation of his sister, who considered it as the only security for her husband’s not being killed in a duel.
vi: When he had gone, they felt certain they would at least receive regular news about what was happening. Their uncle had promised to persuade Mr. Bennet to return to Longbourn as soon as possible. Mrs. Bennet felt much more at ease, as she believed this was the only way to save her husband from death in a fatal duel.
tr: When he left, they knew at least they would receive regular updates about what was happening; their uncle, upon leaving, promised to persuade Mr. Bennet to return to Longbourn as soon as possible, which greatly relieved his sister, who saw this as the only way to ensure her husband wouldn't die in the duel.
es: When he left, everyone remained confident that this way, at least they would have constant information about what was happening. Mr. Gardiner promised them he would persuade Mr. Bennet to return to Longbourn as soon as possible for the comfort of his wife, who considered his return as the only guarantee that he would not die in the duel.

en: ms Gardiner and the children were to remain in Hertfordshire a few days longer, as the former thought her presence might be serviceable to her nieces.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner and her children stayed in Hertfordshire for a few more days, thinking that her presence might help the nieces.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner was going to stay in Hertfordshire for a few more days with the children, thinking that her presence might be beneficial to her nieces.
es: Mrs. Gardiner and her children would remain in Hertfordshire a few more days, as she believed her presence would be useful to her nieces.

en: She shared in their attendance on ms Bennet, and was a great comfort to them in their hours of freedom.
vi: She took turns taking care of Mrs. Bennet and helping the nieces feel comfortable during their free hours.
tr: While keeping an eye on Mrs. Bennet, she shared the burden of her nieces and greatly relieved them during their free hours.
es: She helped them take care of Mrs. Bennet and provided great relief during their free hours.

en: Their other aunt also visited them frequently, and always, as she said, with the design of cheering and heartening them up—though, as she never came without reporting some fresh instance of Wickham’s extravagance or irregularity, she seldom went away without leaving them more dispirited than she found them.
vi: The other aunt also visited them frequently and always, as she said, with the purpose of boosting their spirits. However, each time she came, she would recount additional instances of Wickham's extravagance or irregularities, so whenever she left, she often made them feel even more disheartened.
tr: Their aunt also frequently visited them; according to her, she always came with the intention of cheering them up and encouraging them, but each time she brought some fresh news about Wickham's roguishness or mischief, leaving them more disheartened than she found them.
es: Their other aunt visited them often with the intention, as she said, of encouraging them; but since she always recounted some new example of Wickham's extravagance and lack of scruples, she rarely left without making them even more disheartened.

en: All Meryton seemed striving to blacken the man who, but three months before, had been almost an angel of light.
vi: Everyone in Meryton seemed to despise the man who was almost an angel to them just three months ago.
tr: It seemed like all of Meryton was scrambling to defame the man, who just three months ago was regarded as an angel.
es: The entire town of Meryton was bent on discrediting the man who only three months earlier had been regarded as an angel of light.

en: He was declared to be in debt to every tradesman in the place, and his intrigues, all honoured with the title of seduction, had been extended into every tradesman’s family.
vi: They gossiped that he owed every merchant here; and his shady actions, all under the guise of charming women, extended to every family of the merchants.
tr: It was said that he owed money to every tradesman in town, and his attempts, honored with the title of seduction, had extended to every tradesman's family.
es: It was said that he owed money to every shop in the city, and his intrigues, honored with the name of seductions, extended to all the families of the merchants.

en: Everybody declared that he was the wickedest young man in the world; and everybody began to find out that they had always distrusted the appearance of his goodness.
vi: Each person considered him the most depraved young man in the world, and each began to realize that they had never truly believed in his handsome appearance before.
tr: Everyone was saying he was the vilest man in the world, and everyone was beginning to realize that they had never trusted his appearance anyway.
es: Everyone claimed that he was the most wicked young man in the world, and they began to say that they had always distrusted his apparent goodness.

en: Elizabeth, though she did not credit above half of what was said, believed enough to make her former assurance of her sister’s ruin still more certain; and even Jane, who believed still less of it, became almost hopeless, more especially as the time was now come, when, if they had gone to Scotland, which she had never before entirely despaired of, they must in all probability have gained some news of them.
vi: Although she believed less than half of what was said about him, Elizabeth still believed he would ruin her sister's life. Even Jane, who believed the rumors even less, felt almost hopeless, especially since if the two had gone to Scotland, this was the time they should have received news of them, and she still hoped the two had gone to Scotland to get married.
tr: Even though Elizabeth did not believe more than half of what was said, she believed enough to further strengthen her conviction that her sister was ruined; even Jane, who believed even less of it, almost fell into despair, especially since the time had come when they should have heard from them if they had gone to Scotland, something she had never completely given up hope on before.
es: Elizabeth, despite not believing even half of what was being whispered, believed enough to reinforce her prior belief in her sister's ruin, and even Jane began to lose hope, especially when the time came that, had they gone to Scotland, news of them would have already been received.

en: mr Gardiner left Longbourn on Sunday; on Tuesday, his wife received a letter from him: it told them, that on his arrival he had immediately found out his brother, and persuaded him to come to Gracechurch Street.
vi: Mr. Gardiner left Longbourn on Sunday. On Tuesday, his wife received a letter from him, stating that he had immediately found Mr. Bennet and persuaded him to go to Gracechurch Street.
tr: Mr. Gardiner left Longbourn on Sunday; on Tuesday, his wife received a letter from him, saying that he had found his brother-in-law as soon as he arrived and had persuaded him to come to Gracechurch Street.
es: Mr. Gardiner left Longbourn on Sunday and on Tuesday his wife received a letter from him.

en: That mr Bennet had been to Epsom and Clapham, before his arrival, but without gaining any satisfactory information; and that he was now determined to inquire at all the principal hotels in town, as mr Bennet thought it possible they might have gone to one of them, on their first coming to London, before they procured lodgings.
vi: The letter also mentioned that Mr. Bennet had gone to Epsom and Clapham but had not obtained any satisfactory information; and that Mr. Bennet was currently inquiring at all the main hotels in the city, thinking they might have stayed at one of those places during their initial time in London before finding a residence.
tr: Mr. Bennet had gone to Epsom and Clapham before his arrival but had not obtained any satisfactory information; he was now determined to search the principal hotels in the city, as Mr. Bennet thought they might have stayed at a hotel before renting an apartment upon arriving in London.
es: He told her that upon his arrival he had immediately gone in search of his brother-in-law and had taken him to Gracechurch Street; that Mr. Bennet had been to Epsom and Clapham, but without any results, and that he now wanted to inquire at all the main inns in the city, as he believed it possible that they might have lodged in one of them upon their arrival in London, before securing other accommodations.

en: mr Gardiner himself did not expect any success from this measure; but as his brother was eager in it, he meant to assist him in pursuing it.
vi: Mr. Gardiner did not believe they could find the two people this way, but he still assisted Mr. Bennet.
tr: Mr. Gardiner did not expect success from this endeavor on his own behalf, but he intended to help his brother-in-law because he was eager.
es: Mr. Gardiner thought this attempt was futile, but since his brother-in-law was determined to carry it out, he would help him.

en: He added, that mr Bennet seemed wholly disinclined at present to leave London, and promised to write again very soon.
vi: He added that Mr. Bennet seemed completely unwilling to leave London and promised to write again as soon as possible.
tr: He also added that Mr. Bennet did not seem inclined to leave London at the moment and promised to write again very soon.
es: He added that Mr. Bennet refused to leave London, and promised to write soon.

en: There was also a postscript to this effect:—
vi: He also wrote an additional note at the bottom of the letter:
tr: A note was also appended to the letter.
es: In a postscript, he said the following:

en: “I have written to Colonel Forster to desire him to find out, if possible, from some of the young man’s intimates in the regiment, whether Wickham has any relations or connections who would be likely to know in what part of the town he has now concealed himself.
vi: "I have written to Colonel Forster to ask him, if possible, to inquire among his friends in the regiment about any relatives or acquaintances who might know where he is hiding.
tr: "I wrote to Colonel Forster and asked him to find out, if possible, whether there are any relatives or close friends in the regiment who might know where Wickham is hiding in the city.
es: I have written to Colonel Forster, begging him to find out from the friends of the regiment if Wickham has any relatives or connections who might know where in the city he will be hiding.

en: If there were anyone that one could apply to, with a probability of gaining such a clue as that, it might be of essential consequence.
vi: If there is such a person who provides information, they could help us a lot.
tr: If there are such people who can be approached and provide a clue in this direction, it could be very useful.
es: If there were anyone to whom we could turn with any probability of obtaining that clue, it would advance us greatly.

en: At present we have nothing to guide us.
vi: At the moment, the two of us have no leads to guide the search.
tr: We still have nothing to guide us.
es: For now, there is nothing to guide us.

en: Colonel Forster will, I dare say, do everything in his power to satisfy us on this head.
vi: I am sure Colonel Forster will do everything within his power to help us.
tr: I believe Colonel Forster will do his utmost to satisfy us on this matter.
es: I do not doubt that Colonel Forster will do everything in his power to please us, but perhaps Elizabeth can tell us better than anyone if Wickham has any relatives.

en: But, on second thoughts, perhaps Lizzy could tell us what relations he has now living better than any other person.”
vi: However, I think perhaps Lizzy might be able to tell us more about his acquaintances than anyone else."
tr: But, I think, maybe Lizzy can tell us better than anyone else which relatives he has alive."
es: I do not doubt that Colonel Forster will do everything in his power to please us, but perhaps Elizabeth can tell us better than anyone if Wickham has any relatives.

en: Elizabeth was at no loss to understand from whence this deference for her authority proceeded; but it was not in her power to give any information of so satisfactory a nature as the compliment deserved.
vi: Elizabeth was not surprised to understand why they thought she could help in such a way, but she had no satisfactory information.
tr: Elizabeth was not surprised when she understood the reason her knowledge was sought; but she was not able to provide the information that the compliment deserved.
es: Elizabeth understood the reason for this allusion, but she could not respond to it.

en: She had never heard of his having had any relations, except a father and mother, both of whom had been dead many years.
vi: She had never heard him mention his relatives, except for his father and mother; both had passed away many years ago.
tr: He had not heard of any relatives other than his father and mother, both of whom had died years ago.
es: She had never heard if she had any relatives apart from her father and mother, who had died many years ago.

en: It was possible, however, that some of his companions in the ——shire might be able to give more information; and though she was not very sanguine in expecting it, the application was a something to look forward to.
vi: However, some of his friends in the militia might have some additional information, and although she did not have much hope in this, she thought it was still worth a try.
tr: However, it was possible that some of his friends in the --------shire regiment could provide more information; he did not expect anything to come of it, but he was still curious about the response he would receive.
es: But it was possible that one of her companions might be able to provide better information, and although she was not optimistic, she considered it wise to ask.

en: Every day at Longbourn was now a day of anxiety; but the most anxious part of each was when the post was expected.
vi: Each day at Longbourn now is a day of anxiety, but the most anxious time is the hour when the mail arrives.
tr: Every day at Longbourn was now a day of anxiety; but the most anxious part of each day was the time when the mail was expected.
es: In Longbourn, the days passed with great anxiety, anxiety that grew with the arrival of the mail.

en: The arrival of letters was the first grand object of every morning’s impatience.
vi: They are all restless waiting for the mail to be delivered.
tr: The arrival of letters was the first great object of impatience every morning.
es: Every morning they awaited the letters with impatience.

en: Through letters, whatever of good or bad was to be told would be communicated; and every succeeding day was expected to bring some news of importance.
vi: Through the letters, they will learn news whether good or bad, and each following day brings hope for new important news.
tr: Whatever good or bad there was to be told was conveyed through letters, and each succeeding day was expected to bring important news.
es: By letter, they would learn of the good or bad progress of the matter, and each day they believed they would receive some important news.

en: But before they heard again from mr Gardiner, a letter arrived for their father, from a different quarter, from mr Collins; which, as Jane had received directions to open all that came for him in his absence, she accordingly read; and Elizabeth, who knew what curiosities his letters always were, looked over her, and read it likewise.
vi: But before they received further news from Mr. Gardiner, a letter was sent to the father from Mr. Collins. Jane had been instructed by her father to open his letters when he was away, so she read it, and Elizabeth, out of curiosity, read it with her.
tr: However, before they could hear back from Mr. Gardiner, a letter arrived from Mr. Collins to their father; since Jane had been instructed to open everything that came in her absence, she read the letter; knowing how peculiar his letters always were, Elizabeth read it over her sister's shoulder.
es: But before they heard again from Mr. Gardiner, a letter arrived from Hunsford for Mr. Bennet from his cousin Collins. Since Jane had been instructed to read everything received in her father's absence, she opened the letter. Elizabeth, who knew what Collins's letters were like, also read over her sister's shoulder.

en: It was as follows:—
vi: "Sir,
tr: It said:
es: It read as follows:

en: “My dear Sir,
vi: "Sir,
tr: "Dear Sir,
es: "My dear sir,

en: “I feel myself called upon, by our relationship, and my situation in life, to condole with you on the grievous affliction you are now suffering under, of which we were yesterday informed by a letter from Hertfordshire.
vi: Due to the relationship between us and my position in society, I feel compelled to send you my condolences for the suffering you are enduring, which we were informed of yesterday through a letter sent from Hertfordshire.
tr: Due to our relationship and my position in life, I consider it my duty to console you in light of the grievous incident you are currently suffering from; we became aware of the incident through a letter that arrived from Hertfordshire yesterday.
es: Our kinship and my situation in life compel me to offer you my condolences for the grave affliction you are enduring, of which we were informed by a letter from Hertfordshire.

en: Be assured, my dear sir, that ms Collins and myself sincerely sympathize with you, and all your respectable family, in your present distress, which must be of the bitterest kind, because proceeding from a cause which no time can remove.
vi: Sir, please believe that Mrs. Collins and I sincerely sympathize with you and your esteemed family for the sorrow that must now be of the most bitter kind, as it stems from a cause that time cannot erase.
tr: Rest assured, dear sir, that Mrs. Collins and I sincerely share in the sorrow of you and your esteemed family during this difficult time; your pain must be heart-wrenching, as it stems from a cause that time cannot erase.
es: Do not doubt that both Mrs. Collins and I share in the sorrow with you and your respectable family in this present calamity, which must be very bitter, as time cannot erase it.

en: No arguments shall be wanting on my part, that can alleviate so severe a misfortune; or that may comfort you, under a circumstance that must be, of all others, most afflicting to a parent’s mind.
vi: No words from me can alleviate such severe misfortune; nor can they console you, given the situation that everyone perceives as most distressing for the spirit of a parent.
tr: I am ready to do anything that might alleviate such a severe misfortune or comfort you in the face of a situation that would trouble a father's mind more than anything else.
es: There will be no lack of arguments on my part to alleviate such a tremendous misfortune or to serve as consolation in circumstances that must be more painful for a father than for anyone else.

en: The death of your daughter would have been a blessing in comparison of this.
vi: Your daughter's death might have been a blessing compared to this circumstance.
tr: The death of your daughter would pale in comparison.
es: The death of a daughter would have been a blessing compared to this.

en: And it is the more to be lamented, because there is reason to suppose, as my dear Charlotte informs me, that this licentiousness of behaviour in your
vi: And there is further cause for lamentation, as Charlotte informs me, there is reason to believe that your daughter's waywardness is due to erroneous indulgence, although, to console you and Mrs. Bennet, I believe it is due to her inherently bad nature, otherwise she would not have committed such a grave offense at such a young age.
tr: Moreover, it is even more distressing because, according to what my dear Charlotte has told me, this behavior in your daughter has resulted from being excessively spoiled; but at the same time, to console you and Mrs. Bennet, I think it must also be due to her own naturally bad disposition, otherwise she could not have committed such a grave moral offense at such a young age.
es: And it is more lamentable because there are reasons to suppose, according to my dear Charlotte, that this licentious behavior of your daughter stems from a deplorable excess of indulgence; although at the same time, for your and your wife's consolation, I am inclined to think that it must have been due to a perverse nature, for otherwise she would not have committed such an atrocity at such a young age.

en: “To whom I have related the affair”
vi: And there is further cause for lamentation, as Charlotte informs me, there is reason to believe that your daughter's waywardness is due to erroneous indulgence, although, to console you and Mrs. Bennet, I believe it is due to her inherently bad nature, otherwise she would not have committed such a grave offense at such a young age.
tr: Moreover, it is even more distressing because, according to what my dear Charlotte has told me, this behavior in your daughter has resulted from being excessively spoiled; but at the same time, to console you and Mrs. Bennet, I think it must also be due to her own naturally bad disposition, otherwise she could not have committed such a grave moral offense at such a young age.
es: And it is more lamentable because there are reasons to suppose, according to my dear Charlotte, that this licentious behavior of your daughter stems from a deplorable excess of indulgence; although at the same time, for your and your wife's consolation, I am inclined to think that it must have been due to a perverse nature, for otherwise she would not have committed such an atrocity at such a young age.

en: daughter has proceeded from a faulty degree of indulgence; though, at the same time, for the consolation of yourself and ms Bennet, I am inclined to think that her own disposition must be naturally bad, or she could not be guilty of such an enormity, at so early an age.
vi: And there is further cause for lamentation, as Charlotte informs me, there is reason to believe that your daughter's waywardness is due to erroneous indulgence, although, to console you and Mrs. Bennet, I believe it is due to her inherently bad nature, otherwise she would not have committed such a grave offense at such a young age.
tr: Moreover, it is even more distressing because, according to what my dear Charlotte has told me, this behavior in your daughter has resulted from being excessively spoiled; but at the same time, to console you and Mrs. Bennet, I think it must also be due to her own naturally bad disposition, otherwise she could not have committed such a grave moral offense at such a young age.
es: And it is more lamentable because there are reasons to suppose, according to my dear Charlotte, that this licentious behavior of your daughter stems from a deplorable excess of indulgence; although at the same time, for your and your wife's consolation, I am inclined to think that it must have been due to a perverse nature, for otherwise she would not have committed such an atrocity at such a young age.

en: Howsoever that may be, you are grievously to be pitied; in which opinion I am not only joined by ms Collins, but likewise by Lady Catherine and her daughter, to whom I have related the affair.
vi: No matter what, he deserves to be pitied in his suffering, and not only does Mrs. Collins agree with this, but also Lady Catherine and her daughter, who were informed by me about the incident.
tr: Either way, your situation is pitiable, and not only Mrs. Collins but also Lady Catherine and her daughter, to whom I have explained the matter, share this view.
es: In any case, you are deserving of compassion, an opinion shared not only by Mrs. Collins but also by Lady Catherine and her daughter, to whom I have related the matter.

en: They agree with me in apprehending that this false step in one daughter will be injurious to the fortunes of all the others: for who, as Lady Catherine herself condescendingly says, will connect themselves with such a family?
vi: They agree with me in the concern that the misconduct of one daughter will harm the fortunes of everyone else, for those who will be associated with such a family, as Lady Catherine herself condescendingly remarked.
tr: They also agree with me in this regard, that a single misstep by one daughter will negatively affect the prospects of all the others, because, as Lady Catherine herself condescended to say, who would want to be related to such a family.
es: They agree with me that this misstep by your daughter will be detrimental to the fortunes of the others; because, as Lady Catherine herself kindly says, who will want to ally themselves with such a family?

en: And this consideration leads me, moreover, to reflect, with augmented satisfaction, on a certain event of last November; for had it been otherwise, I must have been involved in all your sorrow and disgrace.
vi: And this thought makes me all the more glad to recall an event last November, because if it had turned out differently, I would have been involved in all his troubles and disgrace.
tr: This observation leads me to reflect with increasing satisfaction on a certain event that occurred last November, because otherwise, I would have had to share in all your sorrow and shame.
es: This consideration moves me to recall with the greatest satisfaction a certain event from last November, for had things not gone as they did, I would now be involved in all your sadness and misfortune.

en: Let me advise you, then, my dear sir, to console yourself as much as possible, to throw off your unworthy child from your affection for ever, and leave her to reap the fruits of her own heinous offence.
vi: So, sir, I ask you to try to console yourself by completely casting out the unworthy daughter from your affections, leaving her to bear the consequences of her heinous wrongdoing.
tr: Therefore, let me offer you this advice, dear sir: to console yourself as much as possible, erase your worthless child from your life forever, and let her reap what she has sown with her treacherous immorality.
es: Allow me, then, to advise you, dear sir, to resign yourself as much as possible and to remove your unworthy daughter from your heart forever, and let her reap the fruits of her abominable offense.

en: “I am, dear sir,” etc., etc.
vi: Respectfully yours
tr: Yours sincerely, etc. etc."
es: Allow me, then, to advise you, dear sir, to resign yourself as much as possible and to remove your unworthy daughter from your heart forever, and let her reap the fruits of her abominable offense.

en: mr Gardiner did not write again, till he had received an answer from Colonel Forster; and then he had nothing of a pleasant nature to send.
vi: Mr. Gardiner did not send any more letters until he received a reply from Colonel Forster, and then he had no bright news.
tr: Mr. Gardiner did not write again until he received a reply from Colonel Forster; and the news he had to give then was not pleasant.
es: Mr. Gardiner did not write again until he had received a reply from Colonel Forster, but he could not say anything good.

en: It was not known that Wickham had a single relation with whom he kept up any connection, and it was certain that he had no near one living.
vi: They could not find any relative of Wickham who kept in touch with him, and it was certain that he did not live near any living relatives.
tr: Wickham was known to have no relatives with whom he maintained a relationship; it was certain that he had no living close kin.
es: It was not known that Wickham had any relationship with any relatives, and it was assured that he had none close.

en: His former acquaintance had been numerous; but since he had been in the militia, it did not appear that he was on terms of particular friendship with any of them.
vi: They could not find any relative of Wickham who kept in touch with him, and it was certain that he did not live near any living relatives.
tr: He had many old acquaintances, but since he had joined the army, he did not seem to have maintained friendships with any of them.
es: He had formerly had many friends, but since his entry into the army, he seemed to have distanced himself from everyone.

en: There was no one, therefore, who could be pointed out as likely to give any news of him.
vi: Therefore, there was no one to provide information about him.
tr: Therefore, there was no one who could be pointed to as able to provide news about him.
es: There was, therefore, no one capable of providing news of his whereabouts.

en: And in the wretched state of his own finances, there was a very powerful motive for secrecy, in addition to his fear of discovery by Lydia’s relations; for it had just transpired that he had left gaming debts behind him to a very considerable amount.
vi: And in his messy financial state, there was an additional strong incentive for him to hide his whereabouts besides the fear of Lydia’s relatives finding him, as it was discovered that he had left behind large gambling debts.
tr: Moreover, in addition to the fear of being found by Lydia's relatives, he had strong reasons for secrecy due to the wretchedness of his financial situation, as it had recently come to light that he had left behind a significant amount of gambling debt.
es: There was a powerful reason for him to hide, which added to the fear of being discovered by Lydia's family, and it was that he had left behind a large amount of gambling debts.

en: Colonel Forster believed that more than a thousand pounds would be necessary to clear his expenses at Brighton.
vi: Colonel Forster believed that it would take a thousand pounds to settle his expenses in Brighton.
tr: Colonel Forster estimated that it would take over a thousand pounds to clear his debts in Brighton.
es: Colonel Forster believed that more than a thousand pounds would be necessary to clear his accounts in Brighton.

en: He owed a good deal in the town, but his debts of honour were still more formidable.
vi: He owed a lot in the city, but his debts of honor were even higher.
tr: He also had many debts in town, but his debts of honor were more alarming.
es: He owed much in the city, but his debts of honor were even higher.

en: mr Gardiner did not attempt to conceal these particulars from the Longbourn family; Jane heard them with horror.
vi: Mr. Gardiner did not want to hide these details from the Longbourn family. Jane heard the news with a sense of horror.
tr: Mr. Gardiner did not try to hide these details from the Longbourn family; Jane learned them with horror.
es: Mr. Gardiner did not dare to hide these details from the Longbourn family. Jane was horrified:

en: “A gamester!” she cried.
vi: She exclaimed: “A scoundrel!
tr: "A gambler!" she exclaimed. "This is something new.
es: ––A player!

en: “This is wholly unexpected; I had not an idea of it.”
vi: This is completely unexpected. I had no idea at all.”
tr: I had no idea."
es: I didn't expect that. I couldn't imagine it!

en: mr Gardiner added, in his letter, that they might expect to see their father at home on the following day, which was Saturday.
vi: Mr. Gardiner added in the letter that their father might return the next day, Saturday.
tr: Mr. Gardiner added in his letter that they could expect to see their father at home the next day, which was Saturday.
es: Mr. Gardiner added in his letter that Mr. Bennet was going to return to Longbourn the next day, which was Saturday.

en: Rendered spiritless by the ill success of all their endeavours, he had yielded to his brother-in-law’s entreaty that he would return to his family and leave it to him to do whatever occasion might suggest to be advisable for continuing their pursuit.
vi: Disappointed that all efforts had been unsuccessful, their father had agreed with his brother-in-law's suggestion that he should return to the family and leave everything to his brother-in-law to continue the search, depending on the situation.
tr: The poor man, disheartened by the failure of his efforts, had acquiesced to his brother-in-law's suggestion to return to his family and leave to him what could be done to continue the search based on developments.
es: Discouraged by the failure of his inquiries, he had yielded to his brother-in-law's insistence to return home and let him handle things while the circumstances were not more favorable for joint action.

en: When ms Bennet was told of this, she did not express so much satisfaction as her children expected, considering what her anxiety for his life had been before.
vi: When Mrs. Bennet was informed, she did not appear as pleased as her children, even though she had been worried about his safety.
tr: When this was told to Mrs. Bennet, she did not seem as pleased as her children had expected, especially considering the worry she felt about him dying.
es: When they told Mrs. Bennet, she did not show the satisfaction that her daughters expected given her concerns for her husband's life.

en: “What! is he coming home, and without poor Lydia?” she cried.
vi: She exclaimed: - What is this, he returned without poor Lydia!
tr: "No, he is coming home, and without Lydia!" he cried.
es: ––He is coming home without poor Lydia? she exclaimed––.

en: “Sure he will not leave London before he has found them.
vi: He shouldn't leave London without finding the two of them.
tr: "He cannot leave London without finding them.
es: I cannot believe he is leaving London without having found them.

en: Who is to fight Wickham, and make him marry her, if he comes away?”
vi: Who will deal with Wickham and force him to marry the girl if he comes back?
tr: If he comes, who will fight Wickham, who will force him to marry?"
es: Who will challenge Wickham and make him marry, if Bennet returns?

en: As ms Gardiner began to wish to be at home, it was settled that she and her children should go to London at the same time that mr Bennet came from it.
vi: Because Mrs. Gardiner expressed a desire to return home, everyone agreed that she and her children should set off at the same time Mr. Bennet returned.
tr: When Mrs. Gardiner started to feel the desire to go home, it was decided that she would go to London with the children while Mr. Bennet was on his way.
es: Since Mrs. Gardiner was already eager to be at home, it was agreed that she would go to London with the children, taking advantage of Mr. Bennet's return.

en: The coach, therefore, took them the first stage of their journey, and brought its master back to Longbourn.
vi: In this way, the carriage would take her away and bring the master back to Longbourn.
tr: Upon this, the carriage took them to the meeting point and brought its owner back to Longbourn.
es: Consequently, the Longbourn carriage took them to the first stage of their journey and brought Mr. Bennet back.

en: ms Gardiner went away in all the perplexity about Elizabeth and her Derbyshire friend, that had attended her from that part of the world.
vi: Mrs. Gardiner went home with all sorts of puzzling thoughts about Elizabeth and her Derbyshire friend, who had intentionally sought her out.
tr: Mrs. Gardiner went to Elizabeth still as confused as ever about her friend from Derbyshire.
es: Mrs. Gardiner left still perplexed at the thought of the chance encounter between Elizabeth and her friend from Derbyshire in that place.

en: His name had never been voluntarily mentioned before them by her niece; and the kind of half-expectation which ms Gardiner had formed, of their being followed by a letter from him, had ended in nothing.
vi: Her niece had not mentioned him, and although Mrs. Gardiner had been expecting a letter from him, they had received nothing.
tr: His name had never been voluntarily mentioned in front of her by her nieces; the half-expectation that arose in Mrs. Gardiner was that she would write a letter after them, but it did not happen.
es: Elizabeth had refrained from mentioning his name, and that sort of semi-hope that her aunt had nurtured of receiving a letter from him upon arriving at Longbourn had come to nothing.

en: Elizabeth had received none since her return, that could come from Pemberley.
vi: Since returning home, Elizabeth had not received any letters from Pemberley.
tr: Since Elizabeth arrived, she had not received a letter that might have come from Pemberley.
es: Since their arrival, Elizabeth had not received any letter from Pemberley.

en: The present unhappy state of the family rendered any other excuse for the lowness of her spirits unnecessary; nothing, therefore, could be fairly conjectured from that,—though Elizabeth, who was by this time tolerably well acquainted with her own feelings, was perfectly aware that, had she known nothing of Darcy, she could have borne the dread of Lydia’s infamy somewhat better.
vi: The current unfortunate state of the family makes any explanation for her mental decline unnecessary, so no one can speculate about this, although Elizabeth, now aware of her own feelings, believes that if she knew nothing about Mr. Darcy, she would have endured Lydia's disgrace better.
tr: The family's current unhappy state made it unnecessary to seek other excuses for Elizabeth's low spirits; therefore, nothing definitive could be concluded from that matter. However, Elizabeth, who had understood her own feelings very well until then, was aware that if she had not known Darcy, she would have been able to endure the pain caused by Lydia's scandal better.
es: The unfortunate state of the entire family made any other excuse unnecessary to explain Elizabeth's dejection; nothing, therefore, could be conjectured about it, although Elizabeth, who by then knew where she stood regarding her feelings, was aware that, if not for Darcy, she would have better endured her fears about Lydia's disgrace.

en: It would have spared her, she thought, one sleepless night out of two.
vi: She thought this might help her avoid one or two sleepless nights.
tr: It would have prevented her from staying awake until morning, she thought.
es: She would have spared herself one or two sleepless nights.

en: When mr Bennet arrived, he had all the appearance of his usual philosophic composure.
vi: When Mr. Bennet returned home, he had his usual calm demeanor.
tr: Mr. Bennet, when he arrived, was in his usual philosophical calmness.
es: Mr. Bennet arrived with his usual philosophical demeanor.

en: He said as little as he had ever been in the habit of saying; made no mention of the business that had taken him away; and it was some time before his daughters had courage to speak of it.
vi: He was as taciturn as ever, not mentioning the matter that had caused him to leave, and it was only after some time that his daughters had the courage to ask him about it.
tr: He spoke little, as was his custom; he did not mention the business that had taken him there, and it took some time for his daughters to muster the courage to talk about it.
es: He spoke little, as always; he said nothing about the reason that had prompted his return, and some time passed before his daughters had the courage to speak on the subject.

en: It was not till the afternoon, when he joined them at tea, that Elizabeth ventured to introduce the subject; and then, on her briefly expressing her sorrow for what he must have endured, he replied, “Say nothing of that.
vi: In the afternoon, when he had tea with his children, Elizabeth started the conversation, and then, when she expressed concern about his endurance, he replied: - Don't say anything about this.
tr: In the end, she joined them for afternoon tea, and only then did Elizabeth dare to broach the subject; then, upon expressing her regrets about what he must have gone through, he said, "Don't talk about it.
es: In the afternoon, when she met with them at tea time, Elizabeth ventured to touch on the matter; she briefly expressed her sorrow for what her father must have suffered, and he replied:

en: Who should suffer but myself?
vi: Who suffers if not Dad?
tr: If I don't suffer, who will?
es: ––Let it be. Who else would suffer but me?

en: It has been my own doing, and I ought to feel it.”
vi: This is caused by Dad, he has to feel that.
tr: It happened because of me, I must bear the punishment."
es: It was my fault and it's only right that I pay for it.

en: “You must not be too severe upon yourself,” replied Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth replied: - Dad shouldn't be too hard on himself.
tr: "You must not be so hard on yourself," replied Elizabeth.
es: ––Don't be so hard on yourself, replied Elizabeth.

en: “You may well warn me against such an evil.
vi: - You can warn your father about such disasters.
tr: "Of course, you can warn me against such a mistake.
es: ––There are no considerations that matter in such great evils.

en: Human nature is so prone to fall into it!
vi: Human nature is easily susceptible to them!
tr: Human nature is so prone to making mistakes!
es: Human nature is too prone to resort to them.

en: No, Lizzy, let me once in my life feel how much I have been to blame.
vi: No, Lizzy, at least once in my life, let me feel guilty on my own; I am not afraid of this feeling.
tr: No, Lizzy, let me feel how guilty I am for once in my life.
es: No, Lizzy; let me realize once in my life how badly I have acted.

en: I am not afraid of being overpowered by the impression.
vi: No, Lizzy, at least once in my life, let me feel guilty on my own; I am not afraid of this feeling.
tr: I'm not afraid of succumbing to this feeling.
es: I'm not going to die from the shock; it will pass quite soon.

en: It will pass away soon enough.”
vi: It will soon pass.
tr: It will pass soon."
es: I'm not going to die from the shock; it will pass quite soon.

en: “Do you suppose them to be in London?”
vi: - Dad, do you think the two people are currently in London?
tr: "Do you think they are in London?"
es: ––Do you think they are in London?

en: “Yes; where else can they be so well concealed?”
vi: - Yes, can they hide so discreetly anywhere else?
tr: "Yes; where else could they hide so well?""
es: ––Yes; where else could they be so well hidden?

en: “And Lydia used to want to go to London,” added Kitty.
vi: Kitty added: - And Lydia had once expressed a desire to go to London.
tr: "Lydia always wanted to go to London," added Kitty.
es: ––And Lydia always wanted so much to go to London!

en: “She is happy, then,” said her father, drily; “and her residence there will probably be of some duration.”
vi: The father replied, with difficulty: - Then it will be happy, and its place to live there will probably be long-lasting.
tr: "He must be happy then," said his father in a dry voice; "he will probably stay there for a while."
es: ––added Catherine. ––Then he must be happy ––said his father coldly–– and he won't leave there for a long time.

en: Then, after a short silence, he continued, “Lizzy, I bear you no ill-will for being justified in your advice to me last May, which, considering the event, shows some greatness of mind.”
vi: After a moment of silence, he continued: - Lizzy, I don't have any bad thoughts about you because you were right when you advised me last May. With this incident, your advice shows that your thinking is quite good.
tr: Then, after a brief silence, he continued, "Lizzy, I am not angry with you for being right in the advice you gave me last May; upon reflection, it shows how wise you are."
es: After a short silence, he continued: Lizzy, don't hold a grudge against me for not having followed your advice last May; what happened shows that you were right.

en: They were interrupted by Miss Bennet, who came to fetch her mother’s tea.
vi: They were interrupted by Miss Bennet, who came to get some tea for her mother.
tr: Their conversation was interrupted when Miss Bennet came to get her mother's tea.
es: At that moment, they were interrupted by Jane, who came to get the tea for her mother. ––"Look how nice!" exclaimed Mr. Bennet.

en: “This is a parade,” cried he, “which does one good; it gives such an elegance to misfortune!
vi: He exclaimed: - This is a parade, it's fine, creating such an elegant character for unfortunate fate.
tr: "These antics," cried Mr. Bennet, "do one good; they add a touch of elegance to disaster!
es: "That lends a certain elegance to misfortune!"

en: Another day I will do the same; I will sit in my library, in my nightcap and powdering gown, and give as much trouble as I can,—or perhaps I may defer it till Kitty runs away.”
vi: One day, Dad will do the same; he will sit in the reading room, wearing a warm hat and pajamas, and cause more trouble, or perhaps he will wait until Kitty runs away from home.
tr: Tomorrow I shall do the same; I will sit in my library, wear my nightgown and powdering apron, and lament with all my might – or better yet, I'll postpone it until Kitty runs away."
es: "Another day I will do the same: I will stay in the library with my nightcap and dressing gown and give you all the trouble I can, or perhaps I will leave it for when Catherine runs away..."

en: “I am not going to run away, papa,” said Kitty, fretfully.
vi: Kitty said, miserably: - I will not run away from home, papa.
tr: "I won't run away, father," said Kitty, anxiously; "if I go to Brighton, I will behave more properly than Lydia."
es: ––I'm not going to run away, Dad! ––shouted Catherine furiously––.

en: “If I should ever go to Brighton, I would behave better than Lydia.”
vi: If I do go to Brighton, I will behave better than Lydia.
tr: "I won't run away, father," said Kitty, anxiously; "if I go to Brighton, I will behave more properly than Lydia."
es: If I had gone to Brighton, I would have behaved better than Lydia.

en: “You go to Brighton!
vi: - You're going to Brighton!
tr: "Go to Brighton!
es: ––You to Brighton!

en: I would not trust you so near it as Eastbourne, for fifty pounds!
vi: I wouldn't dare let you near East Bourn, even if I were to bet fifty pounds!
tr: –Even if they gave you fifty pounds, I wouldn't trust you to go as far as East Bourne!
es: I wouldn't trust you even if you were just going to the corner!

en: No, Kitty, I have at least learnt to be cautious, and you will feel the effects of it.
vi: No, Kitty, I've finally learned to be cautious, and you will see the consequences of this.
tr: No, Kitty, I've finally learned to be cautious, and you will feel the effects of this.
es: No, Catherine. I've finally learned to be cautious, and you will regret it.

en: No officer is ever to enter my house again, nor even to pass through the village.
vi: No officer is allowed to step into this house anymore, not even to pass through the village.
tr: No officer will ever enter my house again, or even pass through the village.
es: No officer will enter this house again, even if just passing through.

en: Balls will be absolutely prohibited, unless you stand up with one of your sisters.
vi: All dances are forbidden, except for you to dance with one of your sisters.
tr: Balls will be strictly forbidden; never without one of your sisters accompanying you.
es: Dances will be absolutely prohibited unless one of your sisters accompanies you, and you will never go out even to the door of the house without proving that you have spent ten minutes of the day in a reasonable manner.

en: And you are never to stir out of doors, till you can prove that you have spent ten minutes of every day in a rational manner.”
vi: And you will never step outside the door unless you can prove that you have been of good character for ten minutes each day.
tr: You can't step outside without proving you've spent ten minutes of each day sensibly."
es: Dances will be absolutely prohibited unless one of your sisters accompanies you, and you will never go out even to the door of the house without proving that you have spent ten minutes of the day in a reasonable manner.

en: Kitty, who took all these threats in a serious light, began to cry.
vi: Kitty thought all these warnings were serious. She began to cry. The father said:
tr: Kitty, who took all these threats seriously, started to cry.
es: Catherine took all these threats seriously and began to cry.

en: “Well, well,” said he, “do not make yourself unhappy.
vi: - Alright, alright, don't pretend to be miserable.
tr: "Come on, come on," said Mr. Bennet, "don't worry.
es: ––Well, well ––said Mr. Bennet––, don't get upset.

en: If you are a good girl for the next ten years, I will take you to a review at the end of them.”
vi: If in the next ten years you prove that you are a good girl, I will reconsider for you.
tr: If you behave for the next ten years, then I'll take you to the parade."
es: If you are a good girl for the next ten years, as soon as they pass, I will take you to see a parade.

en: CHAPTER XLIX.
vi: Chapter 49
tr: Chapter VII
es: CHAPTER XLIX

en: TWO days after mr Bennet’s return, as Jane and Elizabeth were walking together in the shrubbery behind the house, they saw the housekeeper coming towards them, and concluding that she came to call them to their mother, went forward to meet her; but instead of the expected summons, when they approached her, she said to Miss Bennet, “I beg your pardon, madam, for interrupting you, but I was in hopes you might have got some good news from town, so I took the liberty of coming to ask.”
vi: Two days after Mr. Bennet returned, when Jane and Elizabeth were walking together behind the house, they saw a maid coming towards them, and thinking she was calling them to see their mother, they approached her. But she said to Miss Bennet: - I'm sorry for interrupting, but I hope you have good news from the city, so I took the liberty to come and ask.
tr: Two days after Mr. Bennet's return, while Jane and Elizabeth were walking in the shrubbery behind the house, they saw the housekeeper coming towards them; thinking she was coming to call them to their mother's side, they went to meet her; but, as they approached her, instead of the expected summons, she said to Miss Bennet, "I beg your pardon, madam, for disturbing you, but I took the liberty of coming to ask, hoping you might have received good news from town.""
es: Two days after Mr. Bennet's return, while Jane and Elizabeth were walking together through the shrubbery behind the house, they saw the housekeeper coming towards them. They thought she was coming to call them on behalf of their mother and ran to meet her; but the woman said to Jane: Excuse me for interrupting you, miss; but I assumed you might have some good news from the capital and therefore took the liberty of coming to ask you about it.

en: “What do you mean, Hill?
vi: - What are you saying, Hill?
tr: "What do you mean, Hill?
es: ––What do you say, Hill?

en: We have heard nothing from town.”
vi: We haven't heard anything from the city.
tr: We haven't heard from the city."
es: I haven't heard anything.

en: “Dear madam,” cried ms Hill, in great astonishment, “don’t you know there is an express come for master from mr Gardiner?
vi: Mrs. Hill exclaimed, astonished: - Miss, don't you know? You have an urgent letter sent by Mr. Gardiner to the master.
tr: "Dear madam," cried Mrs. Hill in great astonishment, "don't you know that a courier has come for the gentleman from Mr. Gardiner?
es: ––Dear miss! ––exclaimed Mrs. Hill with great astonishment––. Do you not know that a messenger has arrived for the master, sent by Mr. Gardiner?

en: He has been here this half hour, and master has had a letter.”
vi: The letter arrived half an hour ago.
tr: The man has been here for half an hour, and the gentleman has received a letter."
es: He has been here for half an hour and the master has received a letter.

en: Away ran the girls, too eager to get in to have time for speech.
vi: The two girls dashed off, too eager to say anything more.
tr: The girls ran, hurrying to find time to talk.
es: The two girls rushed towards the house, too anxious to continue their conversation.

en: They ran through the vestibule into the breakfast-room; from thence to the library;—their father was in neither; and they were on the point of seeking him upstairs with their mother, when they were met by the butler, who said,—
vi: They ran through the front hall into the breakfast room and through the reading room, but they couldn't find their father, and they were about to run up the stairs when they encountered the butler. He said:
tr: They ran through the hall to the breakfast room, and from there to the library; their father was not in either place; they were about to look for him upstairs with their mother when they encountered the servant.
es: They went from the hall to the dining room and from there to the library, but their father was not in any of those places; they were about to check if he was upstairs with their mother when they ran into the butler who told them:

en: “If you are looking for my master, ma’am, he is walking towards the little copse.”
vi: - If you two are looking for the boss, he is heading towards the orchard.
tr: "If you are looking for the gentleman, madam, he is walking towards the small grove," said the servant.
es: ––If you are looking for my master, ladies, you will find him strolling through the grove.

en: Upon this information, they instantly passed through the hall once more, and ran across the lawn after their father, who was deliberately pursuing his way towards a small wood on one side of the paddock.
vi: They immediately ran back through the hall and across the lawn, seeing their father heading towards the small grove.
tr: Upon receiving this information, they ran once more through the hall and across the lawn towards their father; their father was walking determinedly towards the small forest on one side of the meadow.
es: Jane and Elizabeth crossed the hall again and, crossing the lawn, ran after their father who was heading towards a small grove beside the fence.

en: Jane, who was not so light, nor so much in the habit of running as Elizabeth, soon lagged behind, while her sister, panting for breath, came up with him, and eagerly cried out,—
vi: Jane lacked endurance and gradually fell behind, while Elizabeth ran to their father, gasping for breath:
tr: Jane, who was lighter and not accustomed to running, soon fell behind, while her sister, out of breath, approached her father and asked curiously,
es: Jane, who was neither as light nor had the habit of running like Elizabeth, fell behind, while her sister arrived breathlessly to their father and exclaimed:

en: “Oh, papa, what news?
vi: - Hey, dad, any news?
tr: "Dad, is there news?
es: ––What news is there, Dad?

en: what news?
vi: What news?
tr: is there news?
es: What news is there?

en: have you heard from my uncle?”
vi: Did you receive a letter from your son?
tr: did you get news from my uncle?"
es: Have you heard anything about my uncle?

en: “Yes, I have had a letter from him by express.”
vi: - Yes, Dad received the urgent letter. - Ah, what does the letter say?
tr: "Yes, I received a letter by courier.""
es: ––Yes, he has sent me a letter by a messenger.

en: “Well, and what news does it bring—good or bad?”
vi: Good or bad?
tr: "So, what's the news? Is it good or bad?""
es: ––And what news do you bring, good or bad?

en: “What is there of good to be expected?” said he, taking the letter from his pocket; “but perhaps you would like to read it.”
vi: The father took the letter out of his pocket: - What good news could there be to expect? But maybe you still want to read it.
tr: "Is there something good to expect?" said his father, taking the letter out of his pocket; "but maybe you would like to read it."
es: ––What good can be expected? ––said the father, taking the letter out of his pocket––. Here, read it if you want.

en: Elizabeth impatiently caught it from his hand.
vi: Elizabeth hurriedly snatched the letter from his hand.
tr: Elizabeth impatiently took the letter from her hand.
es: Elizabeth grabbed the letter impatiently.

en: Jane now came up.
vi: By this time, Jane had arrived.
tr: At that moment, Jane also arrived.
es: Jane arrived then.

en: “Read it aloud,” said their father, “for I hardly know myself what it is about.”
vi: The father said: - Read it out loud, because I don't quite understand what the letter is trying to say.
tr: "Read it out loud," said his father, "I didn't fully understand what it is either."
es: ––Read it aloud ––Mr. Bennet requested––, because I still don't know what it's about.

en: “Gracechurch Street, Monday, August 2.
vi: "Gracechurch Street, Monday" August 2
tr: "Gracechurch street, Monday, August 2.
es: Gracechurch Street, Monday, August 2.

en: “My dear Brother,
vi: Dear brother,
tr: Dear Brother,
es: My dear brother,

en: “At last I am able to send you some tidings of my niece, and such as, upon the whole, I hope will give you satisfaction.
vi: Finally, I can send you some news about my niece, and in general, I hope this news will make you happy.
tr: Finally, I can give you some news about my nephew that I hope will be pleasing to you.
es: At last, I can send you news about my niece, and such news, overall, that I hope will satisfy you.

en: Soon after you left me on Saturday, I was fortunate enough to find out in what part of London they were.
vi: After you left on Saturday, I was fortunate to find out where the two of them were staying in London.
tr: Right after you left on Saturday, luck smiled upon me and I found out where they are in London.
es: Shortly after you left on Saturday, I was fortunate enough to find out where in London they were.

en: The particulars I reserve till we meet.
vi: I will tell you the details when we meet again.
tr: I'm saving the details for our meeting.
es: I will reserve the details for when we see each other; suffice it to know that they have been discovered; I have seen both of them.

en: It is enough to know they are discovered: I have seen them both——”
vi: Just know that I have met the two of them."
tr: Knowing where they are is enough; I saw both of them–"
es: I will reserve the details for when we see each other; suffice it to know that they have been discovered; I have seen both of them.

en: “But perhaps you would like to read it”
vi: Jane exclaimed:
tr: Knowing where they are is enough; I saw both of them–"
es: Then it is what I have always hoped for, exclaimed Jane––.

en: “Then it is as I always hoped,” cried Jane: “they are married!”
vi: - That's right, just as you hoped, they got married.
tr: "Then, as I have always hoped," cried Jane; "they are married!"
es: They are married!

en: Elizabeth read on: “I have seen them both.
vi: Elizabeth continued reading: “I have met both of them.
tr: Elizabeth continued reading; "I saw both of them.
es: Elizabeth continued reading:

en: They are not married, nor can I find there was any intention of being so; but if you are willing to perform the engagements which I have ventured to make on your side, I hope it will not be long before they are.
vi: They are not married to each other; I do not see that they have such intentions, but if you approve of the arrangements that I have made on your behalf, I hope they will soon be married to each other.
tr: They are not married, and I have not seen any intention of them getting married; but if you agree to fulfill the commitments I am willing to make on your behalf, I hope it won't take long for them to marry.
es: They are not married nor do I believe they intend to be, but if you want to fulfill the commitments I have taken the liberty to make in your name, it won't be long before they are.

en: All that is required of you is, to assure to your daughter, by settlement, her equal share of the five thousand pounds, secured among your children after the decease of yourself and my sister; and, moreover, to enter into an engagement of allowing her, during your life, one hundred pounds per annum.
vi: All that is required of you is to assure your daughter an inheritance of five thousand pounds after you and your wife have passed away, and furthermore, during your lifetime, to provide her with an allowance of one hundred pounds per year.
tr: All that is expected from you is to guarantee your daughter her share of the five thousand pounds that will go to your children after your and my sister's death through a marriage settlement, and also to commit to giving your daughter a hundred pounds a year as long as you live.
es: All you have to do is secure for your daughter, as a dowry, her equal share of the five thousand pounds that your daughters will receive upon your death and that of your wife, and promise to give her one hundred pounds annually while you live.

en: These are conditions which, considering everything, I had no hesitation in complying with, as far as I thought myself privileged, for you.
vi: In all respects, these are conditions that I do not hesitate to agree to on your behalf, if you permit.
tr: All things considered, I did not hesitate to accept these terms on your behalf, as I saw myself authorized to do so.
es: These are the conditions that, upon careful consideration, I have not hesitated to accept on your behalf, as I believed I was authorized to do so.

en: I shall send this by express, that no time may be lost in bringing me your answer.
vi: I am sending this letter urgently to avoid any delay in receiving your response.
tr: I am sending this letter by courier, so we don't waste time until your response reaches me.
es: I am sending you this by special messenger, as there is no time to lose for you to give me a response.

en: You will easily comprehend, from these particulars, that mr Wickham’s circumstances are not so hopeless as they are generally believed to be.
vi: From these circumstances, you can easily see that Mr. Wickham's situation is not as desperate as we thought.
tr: From these details, you can easily deduce that Mr. Wickham's situation is not as hopeless as everyone thinks.
es: You will easily understand from all the details that Mr. Wickham's situation is not as desperate as has been believed.
