en: The world has been deceived in that respect; and I am happy to say, there will be some little money, even when all his debts are discharged, to settle on my niece, in addition to her own fortune.
vi: People have been mistaken about this, and I am pleased to say that he still has a little money, even after settling his debts, to provide for my niece, in addition to her own property.
tr: People were mistaken in this regard; and I am happy to say that even after all his debts are paid, my nephew will have a little money left in addition to his own.
es: People have been mistaken, and I am pleased to affirm that after all debts are paid, there will still be some money left to endow my niece as an addition to her own fortune.

en: If, as I conclude will be the case, you send me full powers to act in your name throughout the whole of this business, I will immediately give directions to Haggerston for preparing a proper settlement.
vi: If I deem it necessary in this case, and you grant me full authority to act on your behalf throughout this matter, I will immediately instruct Haggerton to prepare the payment.
tr: If you give me full authority to act on your behalf until the end of this matter as I thought, I will immediately instruct Haggerston to prepare a suitable agreement.
es: If, as I hope, you send me full powers to act on your behalf in this matter, I will immediately instruct Haggerston to draft the appropriate document.

en: There will not be the smallest occasion for your coming to town again; therefore stay quietly at Longbourn, and depend on my diligence and care.
vi: There is no reason for you to return to the city, but rather to remain calmly at Longbourn and let me handle everything for you.
tr: There will be no reason for you to come to the city again; so, sit quietly in Longbourn and trust in my diligence and attention.
es: There is no need for you to return to the capital; therefore, stay calm in Longbourn and trust in my diligence and care.

en: Send back your answer as soon as you can, and be careful to write explicitly.
vi: Please give me your response as soon as possible, and write down everything clearly.
tr: Send your response as quickly as possible and make sure to write clearly.
es: Answer me as soon as possible and try to write clearly.

en: We have judged it best that my niece should be married from this house, of which I hope you will approve.
vi: I think it is best that my niece's wedding takes place from my house, and I hope you will agree to this.
tr: We have decided that the best solution would be for my nephew to marry from this house, I hope you agree.
es: We have thought it best for my niece to leave my house to get married, which I have no doubt you will approve.

en: She comes to us to-day.
vi: She will arrive here today.
tr: He is coming to us today.
es: She is coming today.

en: I shall write again as soon as anything more is determined on.
vi: I will write to you again as soon as further arrangements are made.
tr: If anything else is finalized, I will write again.
es: I will write to you again as soon as there is any news.

en: Yours, etc.
vi: Respectfully. Edw.
tr: Edw.
es: Yours,

en: “Edw. Gardiner.”
vi: Gardiner
tr: Gardiner
es: E. Gardiner.

en: “Is it possible?” cried Elizabeth, when she had finished.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed, when she finished reading the letter:
tr: "Is it possible!" cried Elizabeth, when she finished the letter.
es: ––Is it possible? ––exclaimed Elizabeth upon finishing the letter––.

en: “Can it be possible that he will marry her?”
vi: - Is that even possible! Could he really agree to marry that girl?
tr: "Could it be possible for him to marry Lydia?"
es: Could it be possible that he will marry her?

en: “Wickham is not so undeserving, then, as we have thought him,” said her sister.
vi: The older sister said: - Then Wickham is not as bad as we thought.
tr: "So Wickham isn't as terrible as we thought," said her sister.
es: ––Then Wickham is not as despicable as we thought ––observed Jane––.

en: “My dear father, I congratulate you.”
vi: Dear father, I congratulate you.
tr: "Father, I congratulate you."
es: Dear father, I congratulate you.

en: “And have you answered the letter?” said Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth replied: - And has Dad replied to this letter yet?
tr: "Did you reply to the letter?" said Elizabeth.
es: ––Have you already answered the letter?

en: “No; but it must be done soon.”
vi: - Not yet, but you must answer immediately.
tr: "No, but it should be given immediately."
es: ––No, but it must be done immediately.

en: Most earnestly did she then entreat him to lose no more time before he wrote.
vi: Elizabeth earnestly implored her father not to waste much time.
tr: He pleaded with his father with all his might to write without wasting any time.
es: Elizabeth vehemently begged him not to delay it.

en: “Oh! my dear father,” she cried, “come back and write immediately.
vi: She exclaimed: - Oh, dear father, go back inside and write a reply immediately.
tr: "Ah dear father," she cried, "come back and write immediately.
es: ––Dear Dad, come home and start writing immediately.

en: Consider how important every moment is in such a case.”
vi: Father, consider how crucial this moment is in this situation.
tr: Don't forget how important every moment is."
es: Think about how important the minutes are at this moment.

en: “Let me write for you,” said Jane, “if you dislike the trouble yourself.”
vi: Jane said: - Let me write it for you, Dad, if you don't want the hassle.
tr: "Let me write it for you," said Jane, "if you don't want to bother."
es: ––Let me write for you ––said Jane––, if you don't want to bother.

en: “I dislike it very much,” he replied; “but it must be done.”
vi: He replied: - Dad doesn't want to at all, but he will have to write.
tr: "I don't want to get into trouble," his father replied; "but it must be written."
es: ––It bothers me a lot ––he replied––, but there's no other choice.

en: And so saying, he turned back with them, and walked towards the house.
vi: Then he turned back and walked home.
tr: Saying this, he returned with them and walked towards the house.
es: And he returned with them to the house.

en: “And—may I ask?” said Elizabeth; “but the terms, I suppose, must be complied with.”
vi: Elizabeth asked: - And may I ask this question? I think we have to agree to the conditions.
tr: "May I ask?" said Elizabeth, "the conditions must be met, right?"
es: ––I suppose you will accept, added Elizabeth.

en: “Complied with!
vi: - Agreed!
tr: "Conditions!
es: ––Accept!

en: I am only ashamed of his asking so little.”
vi: Dad just feels ashamed because he demands too little.
tr: I'm ashamed for wanting so little."
es: I'm embarrassed that you ask for so little!

en: “And they must marry!
vi: - And they have to get married!
tr: "They need to get married!
es: ––They must get married!

en: Yet he is such a man.”
vi: Yet he truly is a person!
tr: He's that kind of man!"
es: Even though he is the way he is.

en: “Yes, yes, they must marry.
vi: - Yes, yes, they must get married.
tr: "Yes, yes, they need to get married.
es: ––Yes, yes, they must get married.

en: There is nothing else to be done.
vi: There is no other way.
tr: There is no other choice.
es: There is no other option.

en: But there are two things that I want very much to know:—one is, how much money your uncle has laid down to bring it about; and the other, how I am ever to pay him.”
vi: But there are two things I really want to know: the first thing is, how much money did your uncle spend to arrange this, and the second thing is, how can I repay him.
tr: But there are two things I really want to know: –one, how much money your uncle spent to uncover these, and the other, how I will repay him this money."
es: But there are two points I want to clarify: first, how much money your uncle has advanced to resolve this, and second, how I am going to pay him back.

en: “Money! my uncle!” cried Jane, “what do you mean, sir?”
vi: Jane exclaimed: - Money! Your uncle! What do you mean, Dad?
tr: "Money! To my uncle!" Jane shouted, "what do you mean, sir?"
es: ––Money, my uncle? ––asked Jane––. What do you mean?

en: “I mean that no man in his proper senses would marry Lydia on so slight a temptation as one hundred a year during my life, and fifty after I am gone.”
vi: - Dad means that no one, like him, would want to marry Lydia just because he is tempted by one hundred pounds a year while Dad is still alive, and five thousand pounds after that.
tr: "What I mean is that no one in their right mind would marry Lydia for a flimsy reason like a hundred pounds a year while I'm alive, and fifty pounds a year after I'm gone."
es: ––I say that no man in his right mind would marry Lydia for such a slight temptation as one hundred pounds annually during my life and fifty when I die.

en: “That is very true,” said Elizabeth; “though it had not occurred to me before.
vi: Elizabeth said: - That's right, although I didn't think of this.
tr: "This is very true," said Elizabeth; "it hadn't occurred to me before.
es: ––It is very true ––said Elizabeth––; it hadn't occurred to me.

en: His debts to be discharged, and something still to remain!
vi: All his debts have been paid off, and there's even a little money left!
tr: The debts will be paid off, and there will be something left over!
es: Paid off his debts and still something left!

en: Oh, it must be my uncle’s doings!
vi: Oh, this is arranged by your son!
tr: Oh! It must be my uncle's doing!
es: That must be my uncle's doing.

en: Generous, good man, I am afraid he has distressed himself.
vi: A generous, kind person, I'm afraid he has to suffer losses.
tr: What a generous, kind-hearted man; I fear he has put himself in difficulty.
es: What a good and generous man!

en: A small sum could not do all this.”
vi: A small amount of money can't do all this.
tr: These things couldn't have been done with little money."
es: I fear he is in trouble, for with a small amount, you can't do all that.

en: “No,” said her father.
vi: - That's right.
tr: "No," said her father, "I would say Wickham is a fool if he accepts the girl for less than ten thousand pounds.
es: ––No ––said Mr. Bennet––, Wickham is a fool if he accepts Lydia for less than ten thousand pounds.

en: “Wickham’s a fool if he takes her with a farthing less than ten thousand pounds: I should be sorry to think so ill of him, in the very beginning of our relationship.”
vi: Wickham is a fool if he agrees to marry the girl for less than ten thousand pounds. Father regrets having to think badly of him when his relationship with the family has just begun.
tr: It would upset me to think so badly of him at the beginning of our relationship."
es: I would regret judging him so poorly when we are about to become relatives.

en: “Ten thousand pounds!
vi: - Ten thousand pounds!
tr: "Ten thousand pounds!
es: ––Ten thousand pounds!

en: Heaven forbid!
vi: My God!
tr: God forbid!
es: God forbid!

en: How is half such a sum to be repaid?”
vi: How can one repay even half of such an amount?
tr: How can even half of such an amount be paid?"
es: When could we ever pay half of that amount?

en: mr Bennet made no answer; and each of them, deep in thought, continued silent till they reached the house.
vi: Mr. Bennet did not reply, and each person, lost in their own thoughts, walked back home.
tr: Mr. Bennet did not reply; each walked in silence, deep in thought, all the way home.
es: Mr. Bennet did not reply, and, absorbed in their thoughts, they continued in silence until they reached the house.

en: Their father then went to the library to write, and the girls walked into the breakfast-room.
vi: The father went into the study to write a reply letter, while the two girls went into the breakfast room.
tr: Their father went to the library to write, and the girls went to the breakfast room.
es: The father went into the library to write, and the girls went to the dining room.

en: “And they are really to be married!” cried Elizabeth, as soon as they were by themselves.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed, when only the two sisters were left alone: - And they are really going to get married!
tr: "So they are really going to get married!" cried Elizabeth when they were alone.
es: ––Are they really going to get married? ––exclaimed Elizabeth as soon as they were alone––.

en: “How strange this is!
vi: How strange!
tr: "How strange!
es: How strange!

en: and for this we are to be thankful.
vi: And we will be happy about this.
tr: Moreover, we have to be grateful for this.
es: And we shall have to give thanks yet.

en: That they should marry, small as is their chance of happiness, and wretched as is his character, we are forced to rejoice!
vi: We must be happy because they are getting married, no matter how slim their chances of happiness are, no matter how bad his character is.
tr: We have to be happy that they are getting married, even though their chances of happiness are low and the man's character is vile!
es: Despite the slim chances of happiness in that marriage and Wickham's perfidy, we will still have to rejoice.

en: Oh, Lydia!”
vi: Oh, Lydia!
tr: Oh, Lydia!"
es: Oh, Lydia!

en: “I comfort myself with thinking,” replied Jane, “that he certainly would not marry Lydia, if he had not a real regard for her.
vi: Jane replied: - She took comfort in thinking that he certainly wouldn't marry Lydia if he didn't truly love the girl.
tr: "This is how I comfort myself," replied Lydia, "if he didn't really feel close, he would never have married Lydia."
es: ––I console myself by thinking ––replied Jane–– that he surely wouldn't marry Lydia if he didn't love her.

en: Though our kind uncle has done something towards clearing him, I cannot believe that ten thousand pounds, or anything like it, has been advanced.
vi: Although our kind uncle did something to untangle things for him, she didn't believe ten thousand pounds, or something like that, had been spent.
tr: "Even if our kind-hearted uncle did something to clear his debts, I can't believe that ten thousand pounds or something similar has been paid."
es: Although our kind uncle may have done something to save him, I can't believe he advanced ten thousand pounds or anything like that.

en: He has children of his own, and may have more.
vi: Our uncle had children, and could have more.
tr: "He has his own children, and there could be more."
es: He has children and may have more.

en: How could he spare half ten thousand pounds?”
vi: How could he possibly spend even half of the ten thousand pounds?
tr: "How could he set aside even half of ten thousand pounds?""
es: He wouldn't be able to save even half of that amount.

en: “If we are ever able to learn what Wickham’s debts have been,” said Elizabeth, “and how much is settled on his side on our sister, we shall exactly know what mr Gardiner has done for them, because Wickham has not sixpence of his own.
vi: Elizabeth said: - If we can find out about Wickham's debts and how much the payment is, we can know exactly how much Mr. Gardiner had to spend, because Wickham doesn't have a penny to his name.
tr: "If we can find out how much debt Wickham has," said Elizabeth, "and how much was settled on his behalf by our uncle, we will know exactly what Mr. Gardiner has done for them, because Wickham doesn't have a penny to his name.
es: ––If we could find out how much Wickham's debts amount to ––said Elizabeth–– and what dowry Uncle Gardiner is giving our sister, we would know exactly what he has done for them, since Wickham doesn't have a single shilling.

en: The kindness of my uncle and aunt can never be requited.
vi: We can never repay the kindness of our uncle and aunt adequately.
tr: My uncle and aunt's kindness can never be repaid.
es: We will never be able to repay Uncle's kindness.

en: Their taking her home, and affording her their personal protection and countenance, is such a sacrifice to her advantage as years of gratitude cannot enough acknowledge.
vi: The fact that they took Lydia into their home and cared for her is a huge sacrifice that many years of gratitude cannot fully acknowledge.
tr: Taking him into their home, giving him personal protection and support are such great sacrifices that years of thanks would not suffice.
es: Taking her into his home and placing her under his personal care and protection is a sacrifice we can never thank him enough for.

en: By this time she is actually with them!
vi: At this moment, the girl is already at their house!
tr: He is really with them right now!
es: He must be with them now.

en: If such goodness does not make her miserable now, she will never deserve to be happy!
vi: If this kindness does not make her feel remorseful now, she will never deserve happiness!
tr: If such kindness doesn't make him feel terrible now, he will never deserve to be happy!
es: If such kindness doesn't make her feel miserable, she will never deserve to be happy.

en: What a meeting for her, when she first sees my aunt!”
vi: I wonder how the meeting will go when she first sees our aunt!
tr: How surprised he must have been when he first saw my aunt!"
es: What a shame for her to face our aunt!

en: “We must endeavour to forget all that has passed on either side,” said Jane: “I hope and trust they will yet be happy.
vi: Jane said: - We must try to forget what happened to both sides. I hope and believe that the two of you will be happy.
tr: "We must try to forget what happened on both sides," said Jane: "Still, I believe and trust that they will be happy.
es: ––We must all try to forget what happened ––said Jane––: I hope they will still be happy.

en: His consenting to marry her is a proof, I will believe, that he is come to a right way of thinking.
vi: I think his willingness to marry the girl is proof that he has thought things through properly.
tr: Her agreeing to marry is, in my opinion, proof that she has started to think correctly.
es: In my view, the fact that Wickham has agreed to marry is proof that he has taken the right path.

en: Their mutual affection will steady them; and I flatter myself they will settle so quietly, and live in so rational a manner, as may in time make their past imprudence forgotten.”
vi: The love between the two of them will help them stay steadfast, and I am satisfied to see them settling into a quiet and proper life; over time, their past impulsiveness will be overlooked.
tr: Their mutual love will put them in order; my belief is that they will settle down calmly and lead a sensible life, and time will make them forget their past mistakes."
es: Their mutual affection will make them settle down, and I trust it will make them so reasonable that, in time, they will make us forget their past imprudence:

en: “Their conduct has been such,” replied Elizabeth, “as neither you, nor I, nor anybody, can ever forget.
vi: Elizabeth replied: - Their behavior was so terrible that you, or I, or anyone else, cannot forget it.
tr: "Your actions," replied Elizabeth, "can neither be forgotten by you, nor by me, nor by anyone else.
es: ––They have behaved in such a way ––replied Elizabeth–– that neither you, nor I, nor anyone will ever be able to forget it.

en: It is useless to talk of it.”
vi: There is no use in talking about this.
tr: It is useless to talk about it."
es: It's useless to talk about it.

en: It now occurred to the girls that their mother was in all likelihood perfectly ignorant of what had happened.
vi: Now the two sisters realized that their mother still didn't know anything about what had happened.
tr: Then the girls realized that their mother was unaware of what had happened.
es: It then occurred to the girls that their mother was completely unaware of all this.

en: They went to the library, therefore, and asked their father whether he would not wish them to make it known to her.
vi: They went to the study and asked their father if he wanted them to inform their mother.
tr: So they went to the library and asked their father if he wanted to tell their mother about the development.
es: They went to the library and asked their father if he wanted them to tell her.

en: He was writing, and, without raising his head, coolly replied,—
vi: The father, busy writing, did not look up and only replied:
tr: Their father was writing and answered coldly without lifting his head,
es: Mr. Bennet was writing and, without raising his head, replied coldly:

en: “Just as you please.”
vi: - Up to you.
tr: "As you wish."
es: ––As you wish.

en: “May we take my uncle’s letter to read to her?”
vi: - Can we read your letter to mom?
tr: "Can we take my uncle's letter and read it to him?""
es: ––Can we show him Uncle Gardiner's letter?

en: “Take whatever you like, and get away.”
vi: - Do anything you want, and go outside.
tr: "Take whatever you want and leave.""
es: ––Teach him whatever you want and leave.

en: Elizabeth took the letter from his writing-table, and they went upstairs together.
vi: Elizabeth took the letter placed on her father's writing desk, and they went upstairs together.
tr: Elizabeth took the letter from the writing desk and they went upstairs together.
es: Elizabeth picked up the letter from the desk and the two sisters went up to their mother's room.

en: Mary and Kitty were both with ms Bennet: one communication would, therefore, do for all.
vi: Both Mary and Kitty were sitting in Mrs. Bennet's room, so it was only necessary to inform everyone once.
tr: Mary and Kitty were with Mrs. Bennet: telling it once would be enough for everyone.
es: Mary and Catherine were with Mrs. Bennet, and therefore, they had to find out as well.

en: After a slight preparation for good news, the letter was read aloud.
vi: Jane opened the letter to read.
tr: After a brief preparation for the good news, the letter was read aloud.
es: After a slight preparation for the good news, the letter was read aloud.

en: ms Bennet could hardly contain herself.
vi: Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself.
tr: Mrs. Bennet could barely contain herself.
es: Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself, and as soon as Jane reached Mr. Gardiner's hopes that Lydia would soon be married, her joy burst forth, and every subsequent phrase increased it.

en: As soon as Jane had read mr Gardiner’s hope of Lydia’s being soon married, her joy burst forth, and every following sentence added to its exuberance.
vi: As soon as Jane read the part where Mr. Gardiner hoped Lydia would soon be married, she burst into joy, and each subsequent sentence added to her happiness.
tr: As soon as Jane read Mr. Gardiner's hope that Lydia would soon be married, her joy overflowed, and every subsequent sentence added to her happiness.
es: Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself, and as soon as Jane reached Mr. Gardiner's hopes that Lydia would soon be married, her joy burst forth, and every subsequent phrase increased it.

en: She was now in an irritation as violent from delight as she had ever been fidgety from alarm and vexation.
vi: As soon as Jane read the part where Mr. Gardiner hoped Lydia would soon be married, she burst into joy, and each subsequent sentence added to her happiness.
tr: As much as she had been distressed by fear and anxiety, she was now intensely excited by pleasure.
es: The jubilation now produced an exaltation in her that anguish and sorrow had not caused.

en: To know that her daughter would be married was enough.
vi: Knowing that her daughter would be married – that was all she needed.
tr: Knowing that her daughter would soon be married was enough.
es: The main thing was that her daughter would get married; the fear that she might not be happy did not concern her in the least, nor did it humiliate her to think of her bad behavior.

en: She was disturbed by no fear for her felicity, nor humbled by any remembrance of her misconduct.
vi: She did not worry whether her daughter would be happy, nor did she feel ashamed recalling her daughter's misdeeds.
tr: She no longer feared for her daughter's happiness, nor did recalling her daughter's mistakes dampen her spirits.
es: The main thing was that her daughter would get married; the fear that she might not be happy did not concern her in the least, nor did it humiliate her to think of her bad behavior.

en: “My dear, dear Lydia!” she cried: “this is delightful indeed!
vi: She exclaimed: - Oh my dear Lydia, my beloved daughter! This is such wonderful news!
tr: "Ah my dearest Lydia!" she exclaimed: "What delightful news!
es: ––My dear, my beloved Lydia! ––he exclaimed––. It's wonderful!

en: She will be married!
vi: My little girl is getting married!
tr: –She is going to get married!
es: She will get married!

en: I shall see her again!
vi: I will see her again!
tr: –I will see her again!
es: I will see her again!

en: She will be married at sixteen!
vi: She will be married at sixteen!
tr: –She will get married at sixteen!
es: Married at sixteen!

en: My good, kind brother!
vi: And my kind, good brother!
tr: –Oh my kind-hearted sister!
es: Oh, how good and loving you are, my brother!

en: I knew how it would be—I knew he would manage everything.
vi: I knew how this would turn out – I knew he would take care of everything.
tr: –I knew it would be like this –I knew you would sort everything out.
es: I knew it would be like this, that everything would be sorted out!

en: How I long to see her!
vi: I am so eager to see my little girl again!
tr: How I long to see my daughter!
es: How eager I am to see her, and also dear Wickham!

en: and to see dear Wickham too!
vi: And to see dear Wickham too!
tr: And dear Wickham too!
es: How eager I am to see her, and also dear Wickham!

en: But the clothes, the wedding clothes!
vi: But what about the outfits, the wedding outfits!
tr: But the clothes, the wedding clothes!
es: But, what about the dresses? And the wedding dress?

en: I will write to my sister Gardiner about them directly.
vi: I will write to Mrs. Gardiner about this.
tr: I must urgently write to my Aunt Gardiner about this.
es: I will write to my sister-in-law about that right now.

en: Lizzy, my dear, run down to your father, and ask him how much he will give her.
vi: Lizzy, run down and find your father, ask him how much he will give your sister.
tr: Lizzy, my dear, run to your father immediately, ask him how much he will give Lydia.
es: Lizzy, my dear, run to see your father and ask him how much he is going to give.

en: Stay, stay, I will go myself.
vi: Stay, stay here, I will go ask him.
tr: Wait, wait, I'll go myself.
es: Wait, wait, I will go myself.

en: Ring the bell, Kitty, for Hill.
vi: Kitty, ring the bell for Mrs. Hill.
tr: Ring the bell, Kitty, let Hill come.
es: Ring the bell, Catherine, so Hill can come.

en: I will put on my things in a moment.
vi: I will change my outfit.
tr: Let me get dressed at once.
es: I will get dressed in a moment.

en: My dear, dear Lydia!
vi: Lydia, my dear!
tr: Oh my dearest Lydia!
es: My dear, my Lydia of my soul!

en: How merry we shall be together when we meet!”
vi: How happy we will all be to see each other again!
tr: –How happy we will all be when we are together!"
es: How happy we will both be when we see each other!

en: Her eldest daughter endeavoured to give some relief to the violence of these transports, by leading her thoughts to the obligations which mr Gardiner’s behaviour laid them all under.
vi: The eldest daughter tried to curb her mother's intense pleasure by directing her thoughts to the family's gratitude for Mr. Gardiner's kindness.
tr: The eldest daughter tried to somewhat reduce the intensity of these outbursts by drawing attention to Mr. Gardiner's behavior and the obligations it imposed on everyone.
es: The older sister tried to moderate the violence of her excitement a little and to make her mother think about the obligations that Mr. Gardiner's behavior imposed on all of them.

en: “For we must attribute this happy conclusion,” she added, “in a great measure to his kindness.
vi: She added: - We need to acknowledge that the good outcome is largely due to his kindness.
tr: "We owe this happy outcome," he added, "largely to his kindness.
es: ––Well, we must attribute this happy outcome, he added–– to his generosity.

en: We are persuaded that he has pledged himself to assist mr Wickham with money.”
vi: We are certain he promised to support Mr. Wickham financially.
tr: We believe he put himself forward by providing financial assistance to Mr. Wickham."
es: We are convinced that he has helped Wickham with his money.

en: “Well,” cried her mother, “it is all very right; who should do it but her own uncle?
vi: The mother exclaimed: - Ah, that's great! If it's not you, who else would do this?
tr: "Oh," cried her mother, "what's the big deal; isn't he her uncle, of course he will do it!
es: ––Well ––exclaimed the mother––, it is very natural. Who else would have done it, but your uncle?

en: If he had not had a family of his own, I and my children must have had all his money, you know; and it is the first time we have ever had anything from him except a few presents.
vi: Do you know, if he didn't have a family, your mother and you would receive all his money, and this is the first time our family has received anything from him, not counting a few gifts before.
tr: If he didn't have his own family, all his money would have gone to my children; besides, this is the first time we're seeing something from him, except for a few gifts.
es: If he hadn't had children, we would have inherited his fortune, you know, and this is the first time he has done something for us, apart from a few gifts.

en: Well!
vi: Ah, I feel so happy.
tr: Honestly, I'm quite happy.
es: How happy I am!

en: I am so happy.
vi: Ah, I feel so happy.
tr: Honestly, I'm quite happy.
es: How happy I am!

en: In a short time, I shall have a daughter married.
vi: Soon, I will have a daughter getting married.
tr: Very soon, I will have a married daughter.
es: Soon I will have a married daughter: Mrs. Wickham!

en: ms Wickham!
vi: Mrs. Wickham!
tr: Mrs. Wickham!
es: Soon I will have a married daughter: Mrs. Wickham!

en: How well it sounds!
vi: Sounds delightful.
tr: How nice it sounds.
es: How well that sounds!

en: And she was only sixteen last June.
vi: And she's only just turned sixteen. Last June.
tr: And she just turned sixteen last June.
es: And she just turned sixteen last June.

en: My dear Jane, I am in such a flutter, that I am sure I can’t write; so I will dictate, and you write for me.
vi: Jane, I'm too excited to write; I'll dictate and you write for me.
tr: Jane dear, I'm so flustered that I can't write; I'll tell you, and you write.
es: Dear Jane, I am so excited that I won't be able to write; so I will dictate and you will write for me.

en: We will settle with your father about the money afterwards; but the things should be ordered immediately.”
vi: Later we will discuss money matters with your father; but we should order the necessary items right away.
tr: We'll sort out the money issue with your father later; right now there are things that need to be ordered urgently."
es: Then we will determine with your father what to do about the money, but the other things must be arranged right now.

en: She was then proceeding to all the particulars of calico, muslin, and cambric, and would shortly have dictated some very plentiful orders, had not Jane, though with some difficulty, persuaded her to wait till her father was at leisure to be consulted.
vi: Then she went into detail about the fabric samples for making clothes, and might have read a long list of items to buy if Jane hadn't persuaded her, though with some difficulty, that she should wait to consult her father.
tr: Then she started listing the details of linen, muslin, and calico, and was about to write down a full order when Jane, with difficulty, managed to convince her to wait for a suitable time to consult her father.
es: She was about to deal with all the particulars about silks, muslins, and batistes, and would have immediately given some orders if Jane had not convinced her, though with some difficulty, that she should first consult her husband.

en: One day’s delay, she observed, would be of small importance; and her mother was too happy to be quite so obstinate as usual.
vi: Jane said that a delay of one day wouldn't matter, and her mother, being so overjoyed, was not as stubborn as usual.
tr: One day's delay wouldn't matter, she said; her mother was too happy to be stubborn as usual.
es: She made her understand that a day's delay would not have the slightest importance, and Mrs. Bennet was too happy to be as obstinate as always.

en: Other schemes, too, came into her head.
vi: Other plans began to creep into her mind. She said:
tr: Other plans also came to her mind.
es: Besides, other plans had already occurred to her:

en: “I will go to Meryton,” said she, “as soon as I am dressed, and tell the good, good news to my sister Philips.
vi: - I will go to Meryton as soon as I finish getting ready, to inform your Aunt Philips of the good news.
tr: "I am going to Meryton," she said, "as soon as I am dressed; I will give my sister Philips the good news.
es: ––I will go to Meryton as soon as I get dressed, to share such excellent news with my sister Philips.

en: And as I come back, I can call on Lady Lucas and ms Long.
vi: And on the way back, I will stop by Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long.
tr: On my way back, I will call on Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long.
es: And on the way back I can visit Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long.

en: Kitty, run down and order the carriage.
vi: Kitty, run down and tell them to prepare the carriage.
tr: Kitty, go down and order the carriage.
es: Catherine, run downstairs and call for the carriage!

en: An airing would do me a great deal of good, I am sure.
vi: I think a little fresh air will do me good.
tr: A little fresh air will do me a lot of good, I am sure.
es: I am sure that getting some fresh air will do me good.

en: Girls, can I do anything for you in Meryton?
vi: Children, do you want me to buy anything in Meryton?
tr: Girls, can I do anything for you in Meryton?
es: Girls, do you need anything from Meryton?

en: Oh! here comes Hill.
vi: Oh, look! Mrs. Hill has arrived.
tr: Oh, here comes Hill.
es: Oh, here comes Hill.

en: My dear Hill, have you heard the good news?
vi: Mrs. Hill, have you heard the good news?
tr: Dear Hill, have you heard the good news?
es: Dear Hill, have you heard the good news yet?

en: Miss Lydia is going to be married; and you shall all have a bowl of punch to make merry at her wedding.”
vi: Miss Lydia is getting married, and you will get to drink to your heart's content to celebrate her wedding day.
tr: Miss Lydia is getting married, and you will make a bowl of punch and celebrate at the wedding."
es: Miss Lydia is going to get married, and to toast her wedding, you will have some punch.

en: ms Hill began instantly to express her joy.
vi: Mrs. Hill immediately expressed her joy.
tr: Mrs. Hill immediately began to express her joy.
es: Mrs. Hill expressed her satisfaction and gave her congratulations to everyone.

en: Elizabeth received her congratulations amongst the rest, and then, sick of this folly, took refuge in her own room, that she might think with freedom.
vi: Elizabeth, along with the others, also received her congratulations, and then, weary of this lively affair, she returned to her room so she could think freely.
tr: Elizabeth accepted her congratulations among the others, then, overwhelmed by this foolishness, she retreated to her room to think comfortably.
es: Elizabeth, dizzy from all the madness, took refuge in her room to freely indulge her thoughts.

en: Poor Lydia’s situation must, at best, be bad enough; but that it was no worse, she had need to be thankful.
vi: The plight of poor little Lydia was bad, to put it mildly, but it couldn't get any worse, she should be glad.
tr: Even at best, poor Lydia's situation must have been quite bad; but she should be grateful that it wasn't worse.
es: The situation of poor Lydia was to be, even in the best case, quite bad; but that was not the worst; she had to be grateful, for although looking to the future her sister could not expect any reasonable happiness or any prosperity in the world, looking back, to what only two hours earlier Elizabeth had feared so much, it could not be denied that she had still been lucky.

en: She felt it so; and though, in looking forward, neither rational happiness, nor worldly prosperity could be justly expected for her sister, in looking back to what they had feared, only two hours ago, she felt all the advantages of what they had gained.
vi: She felt this, although when thinking about the future, she couldn't expect her sister to be moderately happy or materially well-off; when thinking about what they had feared just two hours ago, she felt all the advantages they had just gained.
tr: She felt this way; looking ahead, neither a sensible happiness nor worldly prosperity could be hoped for her sister; but looking back, she felt all the goodness of what they had obtained compared to the things they had feared just two hours ago.
es: The situation of poor Lydia was to be, even in the best case, quite bad; but that was not the worst; she had to be grateful, for although looking to the future her sister could not expect any reasonable happiness or any prosperity in the world, looking back, to what only two hours earlier Elizabeth had feared so much, it could not be denied that she had still been lucky.

en: CHAPTER L.
vi: Chapter 50
tr: Chapter VIII
es: CHAPTER L

en: mr BENNET had very often wished, before this period of his life, that, instead of spending his whole income, he had laid by an annual sum, for the better provision of his children, and of his wife, if she survived him.
vi: In the past, Mr. Bennet had often wished that instead of spending all his income, he would save a portion each year to later provide for his children and his wife, should she outlive him.
tr: Mr. Bennet, before this period of his life, often wanted to set aside a sum of money each year to ensure a better life for his children and wife after his death, instead of spending all his income.
es: Previously, Mr. Bennet had often wanted to save a certain annual amount to improve the fortune of his daughters and his wife, if she survived him, instead of spending all his income.

en: He now wished it more than ever.
vi: Now he wished for this more than ever.
tr: He now wished he had done this more than ever.
es: And now he regretted not having done so.

en: Had he done his duty in that respect, Lydia need not have been indebted to her uncle for whatever of honour or credit could now be purchased for her.
vi: If he had fulfilled his duty in this way, Lydia would not have to be indebted to her uncle for having to buy any honor or reputation for her.
tr: Had he fulfilled this duty, Lydia would not be indebted to her uncle for the respectability or credibility that could now be bought for her.
es: This would have prevented Lydia from indebting herself to her uncle for everything he now had to do for her, both in terms of honor and money.

en: The satisfaction of prevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be her husband might then have rested in its proper place.
vi: Thus, the satisfaction of having persuaded one of the most worthless men in England to marry his daughter might have been rightly placed.
tr: The satisfaction of having persuaded one of the most worthless young men in England to be her husband could then be felt in the right place.
es: Moreover, he could have had the pleasure of tempting any of the brightest young men in Great Britain to marry her.

en: He was seriously concerned that a cause of so little advantage to anyone should be forwarded at the sole expense of his brother-in-law; and he was determined, if possible, to find out the extent of his assistance, and to discharge the obligation as soon as he could.
vi: He seriously worried about his brother-in-law having to bear the costs, and he intended, if possible, to find out the amount his brother-in-law had supported, so that he could repay the debt as soon as possible.
tr: He was seriously upset that the entire cost of such a purpose, which was of little benefit to anyone, had fallen on his brother-in-law; if possible, he was determined to find out the amount of his help and to settle the debt at the first opportunity.
es: He was seriously dismayed that for a matter which offered so few advantages for anyone, his brother-in-law had to make so many sacrifices, and he wanted to find out the amount of his donation in order to repay him when possible.

en: When first mr Bennet had married, economy was held to be perfectly useless; for, of course, they were to have a son.
vi: When Mr. Bennet had just gotten married, the couple did not need to think about frugality because, of course, they would have a son, they believed so.
tr: When Mr. Bennet first got married, saving money seemed utterly unnecessary; because surely they would have a son.
es: In the early days of Mr. Bennet's marriage, it was considered that there was no need for economy, as it was assumed that a male heir would be born and that he would inherit the estate upon reaching the appropriate age, thus ensuring the widow and daughters would be provided for.

en: This son was to join in cutting off the entail, as soon as he should be of age, and the widow and younger children would by that means be provided for.
vi: This son would inherit the estate as soon as he came of age, and the widowed mother and the sisters would be provided for from this inheritance.
tr: This son, as soon as he came of age, would remove the mortgage, and his widow and younger children would not suffer from financial difficulties thanks to him.
es: In the early days of Mr. Bennet's marriage, it was considered that there was no need for economy, as it was assumed that a male heir would be born and that he would inherit the estate upon reaching the appropriate age, thus ensuring the widow and daughters would be provided for.

en: Five daughters successively entered the world, but yet the son was to come; and ms Bennet, for many years after Lydia’s birth, had been certain that he would.
vi: The five daughters were born one after another without a son, while Mrs. Bennet, many years after giving birth to Lydia, still believed she would have a son.
tr: Five daughters came into the world one after another, but still no son; Mrs. Bennet was confident that a son would come even years after Lydia was born.
es: But five daughters were born in succession, and the male heir did not appear. Years after Lydia's birth, Mrs. Bennet still believed that the heir would come, but eventually, she gave up hope.

en: This event had at last been despaired of, but it was then too late to be saving.
vi: Eventually, this became hopeless, but it was too late to save up.
tr: When hope was finally lost for this event, it was too late to start saving.
es: Now it was too late to save: Mrs. Bennet had no aptitude for economy, and her husband's love of independence was the only thing that prevented them from overspending.

en: ms Bennet had no turn for economy; and her husband’s love of independence had alone prevented their exceeding their income.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was not frugal and her husband liked to be free and easy, so for this reason alone they could not prevent overspending their income.
tr: Mrs. Bennet had no understanding of saving, and it was only thanks to her husband's love of independence that they managed not to spend more than they earned.
es: Now it was too late to save: Mrs. Bennet had no aptitude for economy, and her husband's love of independence was the only thing that prevented them from overspending.

en: Five thousand pounds was settled by marriage articles on ms Bennet and the children.
vi: The marriage terms specified a sum of five thousand pounds for Mrs. Bennet and the children.
tr: As per the conditions of the marriage, five thousand pounds were allocated to Mrs. Bennet and the children.
es: In the marriage settlements, five thousand pounds were secured for Mrs. Bennet and her daughters; but the distribution depended on the will of the parents.

en: But in what proportions it should be divided amongst the latter depended on the will of the parents.
vi: But how this sum would be divided depended on the will of both Mr. and Mrs. Bennet.
tr: But the proportion of how the money would be divided among the children was to be decided by the parents.
es: In the marriage settlements, five thousand pounds were secured for Mrs. Bennet and her daughters; but the distribution depended on the will of the parents.

en: This was one point, with regard to Lydia at least, which was now to be settled, and mr Bennet could have no hesitation in acceding to the proposal before him.
vi: Now it was necessary to settle the inheritance finances, at least for Lydia, and Mr. Bennet did not hesitate to meet the immediate demands placed before him.
tr: Now, at least regarding Lydia, this point needed to be resolved, and Mr. Bennet could not hesitate to accept the proposal before him.
es: Finally, this point was to be decided concerning Lydia, and Mr. Bennet did not hesitate to agree to the proposal.

en: In terms of grateful acknowledgment for the kindness of his brother, though expressed most concisely, he then delivered on paper his perfect approbation of all that was done, and his willingness to fulfil the engagements that had been made for him.
vi: Accompanied by sincere words of gratitude for his brother-in-law's kindness, though concisely expressed, he wrote down his complete approval of all the arrangements made, confirming that he would meet the demands placed upon him.
tr: In terms of appreciating his brother-in-law's kindness, he acknowledged on paper, albeit briefly, that he fully approved of everything that had been done and agreed to fulfill the commitments made on his behalf.
es: In terms of gratitude for his brother-in-law's kindness, though expressed very concisely, he entrusted to paper his approval of everything done and his desire to fulfill the commitments made in his name.

en: He had never before supposed that, could Wickham be prevailed on to marry his daughter, it would be done with so little inconvenience to himself as by the present arrangement.
vi: Previously, he had never thought that persuading Wickham to marry his daughter would be so inexpensive for him under the current arrangement.
tr: It had never occurred to him before that if Wickham could be persuaded to marry his daughter, it could be done without causing him any inconvenience, as stated in the agreement before him.
es: He would never have believed that Wickham would consent to marry Lydia at the cost of so few inconveniences as those resulting from that arrangement.

en: He would scarcely be ten pounds a year the loser, by the hundred that was to be paid them; for, what with her board and pocket allowance, and the continual presents in money which passed to her through her mother’s hands, Lydia’s expenses had been very little within that sum.
vi: By providing an annual allowance of one hundred pounds for his daughter, he would only spend about ten pounds a year, because with the living expenses and pocket money plus the amounts given by her mother, all the costs for his daughter were now almost equal to that allowance.
tr: The hundred pounds to be paid to them would either cost him ten pounds a year or not; because with her food, drink, pocket money, and the constant financial support from her mother, Lydia's expenses would only just be covered by that amount.
es: Ten pounds annually was the most he was going to lose by giving the hundred he had to give them, for between the fixed ordinary expenses, the loose money he gave Lydia, and the continuous cash gifts her mother made to her, little less than that amount was spent on Lydia.

en: That it would be done with such trifling exertion on his side, too, was another very welcome surprise; for his chief wish at present was to have as little trouble in the business as possible.
vi: He was also pleased to see that he didn't have to put much effort into such arrangements, as his main desire now was to be disturbed as little as possible.
tr: The fact that the matter was resolved with such an insignificant effort from his perspective was another pleasant surprise; his current main goal was to cause as few problems as possible in the matter.
es: Another thing that pleasantly surprised him was that everything was done with such insignificant trouble for him, as his main desire was always to be left alone.

en: When the first transports of rage which had produced his activity in seeking her were over, he naturally returned to all his former indolence.
vi: When the initial fierce words that prompted him to search for his daughter had subsided, he naturally reverted to his lazy habits.
tr: After the initial fits of anger that led him to go searching for him subsided, he naturally returned to his old occupations.
es: After the initial burst of anger that motivated him to seek out his daughter, he returned, as expected, to his usual indolence.

en: His letter was soon despatched; for though dilatory in undertaking business, he was quick in its execution.
vi: The letter was quickly sent, because although he was slow to start a task, he often finished it swiftly.
tr: The letter was sent immediately; although he was slow to start the task, he was quick to finish it.
es: He quickly dispatched the letter, though he took a long time to start things, he was quick to execute them.

en: He begged to know further particulars of what he was indebted to his brother; but was too angry with Lydia to send any message to her.
vi: In the letter, he earnestly wanted to know how much he owed his brother-in-law, but he was too angry with Lydia to write anything to her.
tr: He also wanted to know in detail what he owed his brother-in-law; but he was so angry with Lydia that he did not send her any message.
es: In the letter, he asked for more details about what he owed his brother-in-law, but he was too resentful towards Lydia to send her any message.

en: The good news quickly spread through the house; and with proportionate speed through the neighbourhood.
vi: The good news spread quickly within the house, and just as quickly in the surrounding area.
tr: The good news spread quickly at home; it spread around just as fast.
es: The good news spread quickly throughout the house and, with proportional promptness, through the neighborhood.

en: It was borne in the latter with decent philosophy.
vi: The neighbors added a bit of serious philosophy.
tr: The people around received the news reasonably.
es: It is true that it would have caused more talk if Lydia Bennet had come to town, and it would have been even better if they had confined her to some distant farm; but there was already enough to gossip about regarding her marriage, and the well-intentioned wishes for her happiness that the spiteful old women of Meryton had previously expressed lost only a little of their liveliness in this change of circumstances, for with such a husband Lydia's misfortune was considered certain.

en: To be sure, it would have been more for the advantage of conversation, had Miss Lydia Bennet come upon the town; or, as the happiest alternative, been secluded from the world in some distant farm-house.
vi: Conversations would certainly be more interesting if Lydia Bennet had fallen into the mire of society, or in a more favorable way, if she were isolated from the public, confined in a remote rustic house.
tr: Of course, the gossip would have been more enjoyable if Miss Lydia Bennet had fallen into the city streets, or better yet, retreated to a distant farmhouse.
es: It is true that it would have caused more talk if Lydia Bennet had come to town, and it would have been even better if they had confined her to some distant farm; but there was already enough to gossip about regarding her marriage, and the well-intentioned wishes for her happiness that the spiteful old women of Meryton had previously expressed lost only a little of their liveliness in this change of circumstances, for with such a husband Lydia's misfortune was considered certain.

en: But there was much to be talked of, in marrying her; and the good-natured wishes for her well-doing, which had proceeded before from all the spiteful old ladies in Meryton, lost but little of their spirit in this change of circumstances, because with such a husband her misery was considered certain.
vi: But there was still much to discuss about her wedding; and the kind wishes for her well-being, which every spiteful old lady in Meryton had previously expressed, remained similar in this changed circumstance, as people thought that with such a husband, she would surely suffer.
tr: But she was getting married, and there was still much to talk about; all the old ladies in Meryton who had previously wished her well did not lose any of their enthusiasm when the situation changed, because they knew that with such a husband, that girl would never reform.
es: It is true that it would have caused more talk if Lydia Bennet had come to town, and it would have been even better if they had confined her to some distant farm; but there was already enough to gossip about regarding her marriage, and the well-intentioned wishes for her happiness that the spiteful old women of Meryton had previously expressed lost only a little of their liveliness in this change of circumstances, for with such a husband Lydia's misfortune was considered certain.

en: It was a fortnight since ms Bennet had been down stairs, but on this happy day she again took her seat at the head of her table, and in spirits oppressively high.
vi: It has been two weeks since Mrs. Bennet recovered from her illness and came downstairs to join the household, but on this happy day, she was once again sitting at the head of the dining table, her spirits suddenly uplifted.
tr: It had been fifteen days since Mrs. Bennet had set foot on the ground floor, but on this happy day, she took her place at the head of the table once again, with a cheerfulness that would drive everyone crazy.
es: It had been fifteen days since Mrs. Bennet had come down from her rooms, but in order to celebrate such joyous events, she once again took her radiant place at the head of the table.

en: No sentiment of shame gave a damp to her triumph.
vi: There was no thought of shame to dampen her triumphant feelings.
tr: No sense of shame could tarnish her victory in the slightest.
es: In her triumph, there was not the slightest feeling of shame.

en: The marriage of a daughter, which had been the first object of her wishes since Jane was sixteen, was now on the point of accomplishment, and her thoughts and her words ran wholly on those attendants of elegant nuptials, fine muslins, new carriages, and servants.
vi: Having a daughter get married was one of her earliest wishes since Jane turned sixteen, and now it was about to come true. Her thoughts and words always revolved around grand wedding ceremonies, fine fabrics, new carriages, and servants.
tr: Since Jane had turned sixteen, her greatest dream had been to marry off one of her daughters, and now she was on the verge of achieving it; all her thoughts and conversations revolved around elegant weddings, high-quality muslins, new carriages, and servants.
es: The marriage of a daughter, which had been her main desire since Jane turned sixteen, was now about to take place. She thought and spoke of nothing but elegant weddings, fine muslins, new servants, and new carriages.

en: She was busily searching through the neighbourhood for a proper situation for her daughter; and, without knowing or considering what their income might be, rejected many as deficient in size and importance.
vi: She was busily searching the area for a house for her daughter, and without considering the family's income, she had rejected many houses of moderate size and appearance.
tr: She was looking for a suitable house in the vicinity for her daughter, turning her nose up at many because their size and location were not adequate, without knowing or caring what their income would be.
es: She was very busy looking for a suitable house for the couple in the neighborhood, and without knowing or considering what their income would be, she rejected many for lack of space or luxury.

en: “Haye Park might do,” said she, “if the Gouldings would quit it, or the great house at Stoke, if the drawing-room were larger; but Ashworth is too far off.
vi: She said: - Haye-Park would be acceptable if the Gouldings would move, or the big house at Stoke would do if the drawing-room were larger, but Ashworth is too far away!
tr: "It could be Haye-Park," he said, "if the Gouldings leave it; the large house at Stoke could also work, if the sitting room were larger; but Ashworth is too far!
es: ––Haye Park ––he said–– would do very well if the Gouldings would let it; or the house at Stoke, if the drawing-room were larger; but Asworth is too far away!

en: I could not bear to have her ten miles from me; and as for Purvis Lodge, the attics are dreadful.”
vi: I could not bear it if it lived ten miles away from me, and Purvis Lodge with its upper floor is dreadfully dull.
tr: I can't bear it being more than ten miles away from me; as for Purvis Lodge, its attic is terrible."
es: I could not bear to have her live ten miles away. As for Purvis Lodge, the attics are dreadful.

en: Her husband allowed her to talk on without interruption while the servants remained.
vi: The husband let his wife speak without interruption when there were servants around.
tr: He allowed her to speak without interference while the servants were there.
es: Her husband let her speak without interrupting her while the servants were present. But when they left, he said to her:

en: But when they had withdrawn, he said to her, “ms Bennet, before you take any, or all of these houses, for your son and daughter, let us come to a right understanding.
vi: But when they withdrew, he said to her: - Mrs. Bennet, before you choose any house, or all the houses for your son-in-law and daughter, we need to understand each other properly.
tr: When the servants withdrew, he said to her, "Mrs. Bennet, before you take any of these houses, or all of them, for your son or daughter, let us come to an agreement on one matter.
es: ––Mrs. Bennet, before taking any of those houses or all of them for your daughter, let's make things clear.

en: Into one house in this neighbourhood they shall never have admittance.
vi: They will never set foot in a house in this area.
tr: They shall never enter a single house in this neighborhood.
es: There is a house in this neighborhood where they will never be admitted.

en: I will not encourage the imprudence of either, by receiving them at Longbourn.”
vi: I will not encourage the recklessness of the others by receiving them at Longbourn.
tr: I will not reward their immorality by accepting them at Longbourn."
es: I will not encourage the impudence of either of them by receiving them at Longbourn.

en: A long dispute followed this declaration; but mr Bennet was firm: it soon led to another; and ms Bennet found, with amazement and horror, that her husband would not advance a guinea to buy clothes for his daughter.
vi: Two people argued with each other after his statement, but Mr. Bennet remained steadfast, and soon the argument shifted to another topic. Mrs. Bennet felt surprised and horrified to learn that her husband would not spend a penny on clothing for his daughter.
tr: This statement was followed by a long dispute; but Mr. Bennet was resolute: another dispute ensued; Mrs. Bennet learned with astonishment and horror that her husband would not give a single penny for their daughter's dress.
es: This declaration was followed by a long dispute, but Mr. Bennet remained firm. The discussion moved from this point to another, and Mrs. Bennet watched with astonishment and horror as her husband refused to advance even a guinea to buy their daughter’s wedding dress.

en: He protested that she should receive from him no mark of affection whatever on the occasion.
vi: He also declared that on the wedding day, he would not show any sign of affection towards his daughter.
tr: Mr. Bennet said he would not show the slightest sign of affection regarding the wedding.
es: He assured that she would not receive any proof of affection from him regarding that matter.

en: ms Bennet could hardly comprehend it.
vi: Mrs. Bennet could hardly understand.
tr: Mrs. Bennet could not comprehend these things.
es: Mrs. Bennet could not comprehend it; it was beyond the possibilities of her imagination that her husband's resentment could reach the point of denying their daughter a privilege without which her marriage would scarcely seem valid.

en: That his anger could be carried to such a point of inconceivable resentment as to refuse his daughter a privilege, without which her marriage would scarcely seem valid, exceeded all that she could believe possible.
vi: She could not comprehend how his anger could lead to such unimaginable resentment, to the point of not wanting to grant his daughter a favor, making the wedding seem hardly legitimate.
tr: His refusal to do such a kindness for his daughter would take the wedding out of the realm of weddings; it was inconceivable that his anger had reached such an unimaginable point of resentment.
es: Mrs. Bennet could not comprehend it; it was beyond the possibilities of her imagination that her husband's resentment could reach the point of denying their daughter a privilege without which her marriage would scarcely seem valid.

en: She was more alive to the disgrace, which her want of new clothes must reflect on her daughter’s nuptials, than to any sense of shame at her eloping and living with Wickham a fortnight before they took place.
vi: She was more worried that her daughter would be humiliated by the lack of new clothes at the wedding than feeling ashamed of her running away and living with Wickham, just two weeks before the wedding was to take place.
tr: Mrs. Bennet cared less about the shame of her daughter eloping and living with Wickham just fifteen days ago than she did about the new dresslessness staining the wedding.
es: She was more sensitive to the misfortune of her daughter not having a wedding dress to wear than to the shame of her having eloped and lived with Wickham for fifteen days before the wedding took place.

en: Elizabeth was now most heartily sorry that she had, from the distress of the moment, been led to make mr Darcy acquainted with their fears for her sister; for since her marriage would so shortly give the proper termination to the elopement, they might hope to conceal its unfavourable beginning from all those who were not immediately on the spot.
vi: Elizabeth now regretted that in a moment of sorrow she had revealed to Mr. Darcy the family's fears regarding her youngest sister; for with her sister's wedding bringing a proper conclusion to the elopement, the family could hope to conceal the initial scandal from those living far away.
tr: Elizabeth was now very upset for having given in to the despair of the moment and told Mr. Darcy about the fears they had for his sister; they could hope to conceal the distressing beginning from everyone who was not present at that moment, as the matter of the elopement would soon be properly resolved.
es: Elizabeth regretted more than ever having informed Darcy, driven by the pain of the moment, of her sister's action, for since the wedding was going to cover the scandal of the elopement, it was to be assumed that the ungrateful preliminaries would be hidden from all those who could be unaware of them.

en: She had no fear of its spreading farther, through his means.
vi: She was not afraid that Mr. Darcy would spread the news of the incident further.
tr: He did not fear that the situation would spread further through Mr. Darcy.
es: He did not fear Darcy's indiscretion; few people inspired more confidence in him than Darcy; but it mortified him that he knew his sister's weakness.

en: There were few people on whose secrecy she would have more confidently depended; but at the same time there was no one whose knowledge of a sister’s frailty would have mortified her so much.
vi: There were few people she could trust more regarding discretion; but at the same time, there was no one else whose knowledge of her sister's susceptibility would cause her such humiliation.
tr: There were very few people whose confidentiality he could trust more than him; but at the same time, no one else's knowledge of his sister's weakness could upset him more.
es: He did not fear Darcy's indiscretion; few people inspired more confidence in him than Darcy; but it mortified him that he knew his sister's weakness.

en: Not, however, from any fear of disadvantage from it individually to herself; for at any rate there seemed a gulf impassable between them.
vi: However, this was not a fear of personal disadvantage, as there was already an insurmountable chasm between them.
tr: Not because he would be personally harmed by it; because, in any case, there seemed to be an insurmountable chasm between them.
es: And not out of fear that it would cause her any harm, because the chasm that seemed to separate them was insurmountable anyway.

en: Had Lydia’s marriage been concluded on the most honourable terms, it was not to be supposed that mr Darcy would connect himself with a family, where to every other objection would now be added an alliance and relationship of the nearest kind with the man whom he so justly scorned.
vi: Even if Lydia's wedding were conducted with the utmost honor, it was not to be thought that Mr. Darcy would wish to associate with her family, as there was an additional obstacle: his justified disdain for a person he had rightly despised.
tr: Even if Lydia's marriage had been handled in the most respectable manner, it was unimaginable that Mr. Darcy would want to be related to a family that added the closest and most intimate relationship with a man he rightfully despised to its other negative aspects.
es: Even if Lydia's marriage had been arranged in the most honorable way, it could not be supposed that Darcy would want to ally himself with a family that, to all its other drawbacks, would now add the most intimate connection with the man whom Darcy so justly despised.

en: From such a connection she could not wonder that he should shrink.
vi: From such a relationship, she had no doubt that he would withdraw.
tr: There was nothing surprising in wanting to stay away from such a kinship.
es: In the face of such a thing, it was natural for Darcy to retreat.

en: The wish of procuring her regard, which she had assured herself of his feeling in Derbyshire, could not in rational expectation survive such a blow as this.
vi: The desire to win her affection, as she had clearly seen in Derbyshire, could not survive such a disaster.
tr: She had felt that she was trying to win his favor in Derbyshire, but after such a blow, no one in their right mind could expect her to continue.
es: The desire to win Elizabeth's affection, which she had sensed in him in Derbyshire, could not survive such a blow.

en: She was humbled, she was grieved; she repented, though she hardly knew of what.
vi: She felt inferior, she felt sorrowful, she felt regretful, although she was not sure about what.
tr: Elizabeth was humiliated, she was suffering; she was repenting, though she didn't know for what.
es: Elizabeth felt humiliated, saddened, and filled with vague remorse.

en: She became jealous of his esteem, when she could no longer hope to be benefited by it.
vi: She envied his respectable status, when she no longer had any hope of benefiting from it.
tr: She was jealous of his love, even though she could no longer hope to feel it.
es: She longed for his affection when she could no longer hope to obtain it.

en: She wanted to hear of him, when there seemed the least chance of gaining intelligence.
vi: She wanted to receive news of him, when it seemed there was the least chance of hearing from him.
tr: She wanted to hear from him, even though there was no way to reach him.
es: She wanted to hear from him when there was not the slightest chance of receiving news from him.

en: She was convinced that she could have been happy with him, when it was no longer likely they should meet.
vi: She believed she could be happy with him when they might never meet again.
tr: She believed she could be happy with him, even though it now seemed impossible for them to be together.
es: She was convinced that she could have been happy with him, when it was likely that they would not see each other again.

en: What a triumph for him, as she often thought, could he know that the proposals which she had proudly spurned only four months ago would now have been gladly and gratefully received!
vi: She often thought, it would indeed be a victory for him if he knew that now she could accept the feelings she had proudly rejected just four months ago!
tr: How victorious he would have been, he often thought, if only he had known that the offers he had proudly rejected just four months ago would now be accepted with such great joy and gratitude!
es: "What a triumph for him," she thought, "if he knew that the proposals I so proudly rejected just four months ago, I would now gladly accept."

en: He was as generous, she doubted not, as the most generous of his sex.
vi: She still believed he had the most generous nature of any man.
tr: There was no doubt that he was a noble man, and one of the noblest at that.
es: He did not doubt that he was as generous as anyone, but as long as he lived, that had to be a triumph for him.

en: But while he was mortal, there must be a triumph.
vi: But because he was only human, he could still feel intoxicated by the triumph.
tr: But at the same time, he was human and could feel a sense of victory.
es: He did not doubt that he was as generous as anyone, but as long as he lived, that had to be a triumph for him.

en: She began now to comprehend that he was exactly the man who, in disposition and talents, would most suit her.
vi: Now she began to realize that he was the person most suited to her, in terms of temperament and talent.
tr: Now she was beginning to realize that he was the most suitable man for her, with his personality and abilities.
es: Then she began to understand that Darcy was exactly, by his way of being and his talent, the man who would have suited her best.

en: His understanding and temper, though unlike her own, would have answered all her wishes.
vi: His understanding and character, although different from hers, met all her desires.
tr: Even though his mind and nature were not similar to hers, he fulfilled all her wishes.
es: Darcy's understanding and character, although not similar to hers, would have fulfilled all her desires.

en: It was an union that must have been to the advantage of both: by her ease and liveliness, his mind might have been softened, his manners improved; and from his judgment, information, and knowledge of the world, she must have received benefit of greater importance.
vi: This was a mutually beneficial combination: through her simplicity and liveliness, his character could become more gentle, his behavior more measured; while from his maturity and knowledge, she could learn many more important things.
tr: This was a relationship that would make both of them happy; Elizabeth's ease and liveliness could soften his character and improve his behavior; his judgment, knowledge, and experience would teach Elizabeth more important things.
es: Their union would have been advantageous for both: with her ease and liveliness, his temperament would have softened and his manners would have improved. And the judgment, culture, and knowledge of the world that he possessed would have brought her significant benefits.

en: But no such happy marriage could now teach the admiring multitude what connubial felicity really was.
vi: But such a happy marriage cannot teach people what true marital happiness really is.
tr: But such a happy marriage would not be able to teach the crowd around them what true marital happiness really was.
es: But that ideal marriage could no longer teach the admiring crowds what conjugal happiness was; the union that was about to take place in Elizabeth's family was very different and excluded the possibility of the former.

en: An union of a different tendency, and precluding the possibility of the other, was soon to be formed in their family.
vi: The combination of one distinct personality, and the rejection of the other personality, will soon occur in their family.
tr: A union of a different nature, which would eliminate the possibility of the other within their families, was about to be established.
es: But that ideal marriage could no longer teach the admiring crowds what conjugal happiness was; the union that was about to take place in Elizabeth's family was very different and excluded the possibility of the former.

en: How Wickham and Lydia were to be supported in tolerable independence she could not imagine.
vi: She could not imagine how Wickham and Lydia would manage to support themselves even relatively independently.
tr: Wickham could not imagine how Lydia and he would manage to live more or less independently.
es: They could not imagine how Wickham and Lydia would manage to live with a passable independence; but it was not difficult to conjecture how unstable the happiness of a couple united solely because their passions were stronger than their virtue would be.

en: But how little of permanent happiness could belong to a couple who were only brought together because their passions were stronger than their virtue, she could easily conjecture.
vi: But she could easily guess how short-lived their happiness would be for a couple brought together by infatuation rather than by virtue.
tr: However, he could easily predict how little lasting happiness could be possible in the life of a couple who came together only because their passions were stronger than their virtues.
es: They could not imagine how Wickham and Lydia would manage to live with a passable independence; but it was not difficult to conjecture how unstable the happiness of a couple united solely because their passions were stronger than their virtue would be.

en: mr Gardiner soon wrote again to his brother.
vi: Mr. Gardiner had written another letter to his brother-in-law.
tr: ------------------------ Mr. Gardiner soon wrote back to his brother-in-law.
es: Mr. Gardiner soon wrote back to his brother-in-law.

en: To mr Bennet’s acknowledgments he briefly replied, with assurances of his eagerness to promote the welfare of any of his family; and concluded with entreaties that the subject might never be mentioned to him again.
vi: With Mr. Bennet's words of thanks, he only replied briefly to affirm his earnest desire to bring happiness to any member of the family and asked Mr. Bennet not to mention gratitude anymore.
tr: He briefly acknowledged Mr. Bennet's thanks, expressed his readiness to ensure the well-being of every member of the family, and concluded by requesting that the matter not be mentioned to him again.
es: He briefly responded to Mr. Bennet's gratitude by saying that his greatest wish was to contribute to the well-being of the entire family and concluded by asking that the matter not be discussed any further.

en: The principal purport of his letter was to inform them, that mr Wickham had resolved on quitting the militia.
vi: The purpose of his letter was to inform the family that Mr. Wickham had decided to resign from the militia.
tr: The main purpose of his letter was to inform them that Wickham had decided to leave the Militia.
es: The main purpose of the letter was to inform him that Wickham had decided to leave the regiment.

en: “It was greatly my wish that he should do so,” he added, “as soon as his marriage was fixed on.
vi: He added: "I earnestly hope that he should proceed with this matter as soon as he has decided on the wedding.
tr: "Once the marriage is finalized," he added, "I wanted him to do so as well.
es: He was very eager for him to do it ––he added when we finalized the marriage; and I believe you will agree with me that his departure from that Corps is highly beneficial both for him and for my niece.

en: And I think you will agree with me, in considering a removal from that corps as highly advisable, both on his account and my niece’s.
vi: And I think you will agree with me that this is the right thing to do, considering his circumstances and my niece's.
tr: I believe you will agree that it would be beneficial for both him and my niece to leave the regiment.
es: He was very eager for him to do it ––he added when we finalized the marriage; and I believe you will agree with me that his departure from that Corps is highly beneficial both for him and for my niece.

en: It is mr Wickham’s intention to go into the Regulars; and, among his former friends, there are still some who are able and willing to assist him in the army.
vi: Mr. Wickham intends to join the regular army, among his old friends there are still some who are capable and willing to help him enlist.
tr: Mr. Wickham's intention is to enlist in the regular army; there are still some of his old friends who are willing and able to support him in the army.
es: Mr. Wickham's intention is to join the regular Army, and among his old friends, there are those who can and want to help him achieve it.

en: He has the promise of an ensigncy in General——’s regiment, now quartered in the north.
vi: He has been promised assistance by an officer in a regiment currently stationed in the North.
tr: He has been promised a corporal position in the unit of General ---------, who is currently stationed in the North.
es: He has been promised the rank of ensign in General X's regiment, currently stationed in the North.

en: It is an advantage to have it so far from this part of the kingdom.
vi: There is an advantage to him serving in a unit stationed so far away, I hope that when they live with others, they will become more cautious, in a place where each person still retains some good qualities.
tr: Being so far from this part of the kingdom is also an advantage.
es: It is much better for him to move away from this part of the kingdom.

en: He promises fairly; and I hope among different people, where they may each have a character to preserve, they will both be more prudent.
vi: There is an advantage to him serving in a unit stationed so far away, I hope that when they live with others, they will become more cautious, in a place where each person still retains some good qualities.
tr: He promises reasonably; I hope they will act more prudently among different people where they can present themselves as new individuals.
es: He firmly promises, and I hope it will be so, that being among other people before whom they should not discredit themselves, the two will be more prudent.

en: I have written to Colonel Forster, to inform him of our present arrangements, and to request that he will satisfy the various creditors of mr Wickham in and near Brighton with assurances of speedy payment, for which I have pledged myself.
vi: I have written to Colonel Forster to inform him of our arrangements, and I have asked him to notify Mr. Wickham's creditors in Brighton and the surrounding area that the debts will be paid promptly, as I have committed myself.
