tr: I wrote a letter to Colonel Forster informing him of our agreement, asking him to reassure Mr. Wickham's creditors in and around Brighton by promising quick payment under my personal guarantee.
es: I have written to Colonel Forster informing him of our arrangements and requesting that he tell Mr. Wickham's various creditors in Brighton and its surroundings that they will be paid immediately under my responsibility.

en: And will you give yourself the trouble of carrying similar assurances to his creditors in Meryton, of whom I shall subjoin a list, according to his information?
vi: And please kindly inform his creditors in Meryton similarly, I enclose a list provided by him.
tr: I also ask you to kindly give the same assurance to the creditors in Meryton; I will send you the list according to the information he provided me.
es: Would you mind taking the trouble to give the same assurances to the creditors in Meryton, of whom I am sending you a list according to what Mr. Wickham has indicated to me?

en: He has given in all his debts; I hope at least he has not deceived us.
vi: He has declared all his debts; I hope at least he is not deceiving us.
tr: He listed all his debts; I hope at least he has not deceived us.
es: He has confessed all his debts to us and I hope that at least in this he has not deceived us.

en: Haggerston has our directions, and all will be completed in a week.
vi: Haggerston has received my instructions, and everything will be settled within a week.
tr: Haggerston has received our instructions; everything will be settled within a week.
es: Haggerston already has instructions and within a week everything will be ready.

en: They will then join his regiment, unless they are first invited to Longbourn; and I understand from ms Gardiner that my niece is very desirous of seeing you all before she leaves the south.
vi: Then the two will go to live with the regiment, except when they are invited to Longbourn. As I have learned from Mrs. Gardiner, my niece is very eager to see the whole family again before leaving the South.
tr: Then they will join their unit, unless they are invited to Longbourn beforehand; from what Mrs. Gardiner has told me, my niece is very eager to see you all before she leaves the South.
es: Then Mr. Wickham will join his regiment, unless he is first invited to go to Longbourn, for my wife tells me that Lydia is very eager to see you all before leaving the South.

en: She is well, and begs to be dutifully remembered to you and her mother.
vi: She is well and hopes you will kindly think of her.
tr: She is well; she sends her love to you and your mother.
es: She is very well and humbly asks you and her mother to remember her.

en: —Yours, etc.
vi: Respectfully yours
tr: She is well; she sends her love to you and your mother.
es: Yours,

en: “E. Gardiner.”
vi: E. Gardiner
tr: E. Gardiner."
es: E. Gardiner.

en: mr Bennet and his daughters saw all the advantages of Wickham’s removal from the ——shire, as clearly as mr Gardiner could do.
vi: Just like Mr. Gardiner, Mr. Bennet and his daughters clearly saw all the advantages when Mr. Wickham requested to leave the militia.
tr: Mr. Bennet and his daughters found Wickham's departure from the ---------shire regiment to be as favorable as Mr. Gardiner did.
es: Mr. Bennet and his daughters understood the advantages of Wickham leaving the county garrison as clearly as Mr. Gardiner; but Mrs. Bennet was not as satisfied as they were.

en: But ms Bennet was not so well pleased with it.
vi: But Mrs. Bennet was not very pleased.
tr: But Mrs. Bennet was not as pleased about it.
es: Mr. Bennet and his daughters understood the advantages of Wickham leaving the county garrison as clearly as Mr. Gardiner; but Mrs. Bennet was not as satisfied as they were.

en: Lydia’s being settled in the north, just when she had expected most pleasure and pride in her company, for she had by no means given up her plan of their residing in Hertfordshire, was a severe disappointment; and, besides, it was such a pity that Lydia should be taken from a regiment where she was acquainted with everybody, and had so many favourites.
vi: She was deeply disappointed to see Lydia having to settle in the North, just when she wished to have her close in happiness and pride. She had not yet given up the idea of having the two stay in Hertfordshire, and moreover, it was rather pitiful for Lydia to be separated from the militia regiment where she knew everyone and where she was fond of many people.
tr: Just when she was about to take great pleasure and pride in his presence, Lydia's move to the North was a heavy disappointment for her, because she had not yet given up on the plan of them living in Hertfordshire, and it was truly a pity that Lydia had to leave a regiment where she knew everyone and had many loved ones.
es: She was very displeased that Lydia was to settle in the North precisely when she had been looking forward with pleasure and pride to enjoying her company, for she had not given up her illusion that Lydia would reside in Hertfordshire. And besides, it was a pity that Lydia would be separated from a regiment where everyone knew her and where she had so many admirers.

en: “She is so fond of ms Forster,” said she, “it will be quite shocking to send her away!
vi: She said: - The little girl loves Mrs. Forster very much; it would be a shock if she had to be sent away!
tr: "She is very fond of Mrs. Forster," he said, "sending her away will be a complete shock!
es: ––She is so fond of Mrs. Forster that it will be very hard for her to leave her.

en: And there are several of the young men, too, that she likes very much.
vi: And there are a few young men that she is also very fond of.
tr: Besides, there are plenty of young people she likes very much there.
es: And, besides, there are several boys she likes.

en: The officers may not be so pleasant in General——’s regiment.”
vi: The officers in the new regiment might not be as pleasant.
tr: It is impossible for the officers in General ---------'s unit to be so pleasant."
es: It may be that the officers of General X's regiment are not as nice.

en: His daughter’s request, for such it might be considered, of being admitted into her family again, before she set off for the north, received at first an absolute negative.
vi: Lydia's plea to be accepted back into the family before she went to the North initially met with a completely negative reaction.
tr: The request of her daughter to be accepted back into the family before going North, because she seemed to have made such a request, was initially met with absolute opposition.
es: The plea ––for such it had to be considered from his daughter to be readmitted into the family before departing for the North was at first roundly denied; but Jane and Elizabeth, for the sake of their sister's feelings and future, wished that she would notify her parents of her marriage in person, and insisted with such interest, gentleness, and sweetness that Mr. Bennet agreed to receive her and her husband at Longbourn after the wedding, that they convinced him.

en: But Jane and Elizabeth, who agreed in wishing, for the sake of their sister’s feelings and consequence, that she should be noticed on her marriage by her parents, urged him so earnestly, yet so rationally and so mildly, to receive her and her husband at Longbourn, as soon as they were married, that he was prevailed on to think as they thought, and act as they wished.
vi: But Jane and Elizabeth thought about their sister's feelings and position. The two sisters earnestly pleaded with their father, both reasonably and emotionally, to accept the couple at Longbourn after their marriage. They hoped their father would think as they did and act as they wished.
tr: But for the sake of their sisters' feelings and reputation, Jane and Elizabeth, who accepted the request for her marriage to be recognized by their mother and father, so persistently but so wisely and moderately pressured Mr. Bennet to accept Lydia and her husband at Longbourn as soon as they got married that he was finally convinced to think like them and act as they wished.
es: The plea ––for such it had to be considered from his daughter to be readmitted into the family before departing for the North was at first roundly denied; but Jane and Elizabeth, for the sake of their sister's feelings and future, wished that she would notify her parents of her marriage in person, and insisted with such interest, gentleness, and sweetness that Mr. Bennet agreed to receive her and her husband at Longbourn after the wedding, that they convinced him.

en: And their mother had the satisfaction of knowing, that she should be able to show her married daughter in the neighbourhood, before she was banished to the north.
vi: Their mother would be satisfied if she had the chance to show her neighbors that her daughter was married before she was sent to the North.
tr: Thus, their mother was also pleased, thinking she could show her daughter around before she was exiled to the North.
es: Thus, Mrs. Bennet had the satisfaction of knowing that they could present their married daughter to the neighborhood before she was banished to the North.

en: When mr Bennet wrote again to his brother, therefore, he sent his permission for them to come; and it was settled, that, as soon as the ceremony was over, they should proceed to Longbourn.
vi: Therefore, Mr. Bennet wrote to his brother-in-law that he allowed the couple to come, agreeing that immediately after the wedding, they should go straight to Longbourn.
tr: When Mr. Bennet wrote to his brother-in-law again, he thus allowed them to come; it was decided that they would proceed to Longbourn immediately after the ceremony.
es: Consequently, when Mr. Bennet wrote back to his brother-in-law, he gave permission for the couple to come, and it was determined that after the ceremony they would leave for Longbourn.

en: Elizabeth was surprised, however, that Wickham should consent to such a scheme; and, had she consulted only her own inclination, any meeting with him would have been the last object of her wishes.
vi: However, Elizabeth was surprised to learn that Wickham agreed to this plan. If she only considered her own feelings, she did not want to see him at all.
tr: However, Elizabeth was surprised that Wickham consented to such a plan; if it were up to her, encountering Wickham would be the last thing she would want in life.
es: Elizabeth complained that Wickham accepted this plan, and if she had been guided only by her own desires, Wickham would be the last person she would want to meet.

en: CHAPTER LI.
vi: Chapter 51
tr: Chapter IX
es: CHAPTER LI

en: THEIR sister’s wedding-day arrived; and Jane and Elizabeth felt for her probably more than she felt for herself.
vi: The wedding day of their younger sister had arrived, and perhaps Jane and Elizabeth felt more for their sister than she felt for herself.
tr: The wedding day of their sisters arrived; Jane and Elizabeth were probably more anxious on her behalf than she was herself.
es: The day of Lydia's wedding arrived, and Jane and Elizabeth were probably more interested in it than she was herself.

en: The carriage was sent to meet them at——, and they were to return in it by dinnertime.
vi: The family sent a carriage to pick them up, and the two would arrive home by dinner time.
tr: A carriage was sent to meet them at ----------; they would have returned by mealtime.
es: The carriage was sent to fetch them from X, and it would return with them at lunchtime.

en: Their arrival was dreaded by the elder Miss Bennets—and Jane more especially, who gave Lydia the feelings which would have attended herself, had she been the culprit, and was wretched in the thought of what her sister must endure.
vi: The two older sisters, especially Jane, were terrified for their younger sister about the return journey of the two. Jane thought of Lydia through the emotions she attributed to herself, as if she were the guilty one, and thus she sorrowfully contemplated what her sister would have to endure.
tr: The elder Miss Bennets were gripped by the fear of their arrival; especially Jane, who was distressed thinking about what her sister had to endure, as she felt the emotions Lydia would have if she had been the one to make the mistake.
es: Jane and Elizabeth dreaded their arrival, especially Jane, who attributed to Lydia the same feelings that would have overwhelmed her if she had been the guilty one, and she tormented herself thinking about what Lydia must be suffering.

en: They came.
vi: Two people have arrived.
tr: They arrived.
es: They arrived.

en: The family were assembled in the breakfast-room to receive them.
vi: The whole family gathered in the breakfast room to welcome them.
tr: The family gathered in the breakfast room to greet them.
es: The family was gathered in the sitting room waiting for them.

en: Smiles decked the face of ms Bennet, as the carriage drove up to the door; her husband looked impenetrably grave; her daughters, alarmed, anxious, uneasy.
vi: Smiles adorned Mrs. Bennet's face as the carriage pulled up to the doorstep; her husband bore a serious expression, revealing nothing of his thoughts; the daughters, on the other hand, were anxious, restless, and uneasy.
tr: As the car approached the door, Mrs. Bennet's face lit up with smiles; her husband appeared impenetrably serious; their daughters were anxious, worried, and tense.
es: A smile adorned Mrs. Bennet's face when the carriage stopped in front of the door; her husband was impenetrably serious, and her daughters were alarmed, anxious, and restless.

en: Lydia’s voice was heard in the vestibule; the door was thrown open, and she ran into the room.
vi: The whole family heard Lydia's voice from the hall; the door was wide open, and she ran in.
tr: Lydia's voice was heard in the hallway; the door opened quickly and she ran into the room.
es: The voice of Lydia was heard in the hall; the door opened and the newlywed entered the room.

en: Her mother stepped forwards, embraced her, and welcomed her with rapture; gave her hand with an affectionate smile to Wickham, who followed his lady; and wished them both joy, with an alacrity which showed no doubt of their happiness.
vi: Her mother stepped forward, embraced her, excitedly welcoming her. She extended her hand to Wickham with a tender smile and wished them both happiness, in a lively tone that showed she believed they were happy.
tr: Her mother stepped forward, embraced her, and greeted her warmly; with a loving smile, she gave her hand to Wickham, who was following his wife, and with an enthusiasm that left no doubt about their happiness, she wished them both eternal bliss.
es: Her mother stood up, hugged her, and enthusiastically welcomed her, extending her hand to Wickham who followed his wife, wishing them both the greatest happiness, with a promptness that demonstrated her conviction that they would undoubtedly be happy.

en: Their reception from mr Bennet, to whom they then turned, was not quite so cordial.
vi: The two turned towards Mr. Bennet, but his reception was not as warm as the mother's.
tr: Then they turned to Mr. Bennet; the reception they received from him was not very friendly.
es: The reception of Mr. Bennet, to whom they then turned, was no longer so cordial.

en: His countenance rather gained in austerity; and he scarcely opened his lips.
vi: His face showed a stern expression, and he scarcely parted his lips.
tr: A cold expression settled on his face, and he hardly opened his mouth.
es: He reaffirmed his seriousness and barely opened his lips.

en: The easy assurance of the young couple, indeed, was enough to provoke him.
vi: In fact, their confident demeanor was enough to provoke him.
tr: The carefree ease of the young couple was enough to provoke him.
es: The tranquility of the young couple was really enough to provoke him.

en: Elizabeth was disgusted, and even Miss Bennet was shocked.
vi: Elizabeth felt disdain, even Miss Bennet was shocked.
tr: Elizabeth was disgusted; even Miss Bennet was shaken.
es: Elizabeth was embarrassed and even Jane was scandalized.

en: Lydia was Lydia still; untamed, unabashed, wild, noisy, and fearless.
vi: Lydia was still the same old Lydia; unruly, shameless, reckless, loud, and fearless.
tr: Lydia was still Lydia; mischievous, shameless, wild, boisterous, and fearless.
es: Lydia remained Lydia: untamed, shameless, foolish, loud, and daring.

en: She turned from sister to sister, demanding their congratulations; and when at length they all sat down, looked eagerly round the room, took notice of some little alteration in it, and observed, with a laugh, that it was a great while since she had been there.
vi: She looked from one sister to another, hoping they would congratulate her. When finally everyone sat down, she glanced around the room, noting a few small changes, and laughed loudly as she remarked that she had been away from this place for quite a while.
tr: She turned from one sister to another, demanding their congratulations; finally, when they all sat together, she looked around the room curiously, noticed a few changes, and laughingly said that a lot of time had passed since she was last there.
es: She went from sister to sister asking them to congratulate her, and when they all finally sat down, she looked eagerly around the room, noticing that there had been a small change, and, bursting into laughter, said that it had been a long time since she had been there.

en: Wickham was not at all more distressed than herself; but his manners were always so pleasing, that, had his character and his marriage been exactly what they ought, his smiles and his easy address, while he claimed their relationship, would have delighted them all.
vi: Wickham did not appear more distressed than she did. On the contrary, his demeanor was always pleasant, so much so that if his character and his wedding were as the family wished, his smiles and easy conversation when confirming their relationship would have pleased them.
tr: Wickham was not more troublesome than before, but his actions were so pleasant at every moment that if his personality and marriage were as they wished, his smile and easy conversation while expecting intimacy would give them all pleasure.
es: Wickham did not seem less pleased than she was; but his manners remained so pleasant that if his behavior and his marriage had been as they should, his smiles and his easy gestures in claiming the recognition of his kinship from his sisters-in-law would have charmed them all.

en: Elizabeth had not before believed him quite equal to such assurance; but she sat down, resolving within herself to draw no limits in future to the impudence of an impudent man.
vi: Elizabeth did not think he could be so brazen; but she sat down, resolute in her heart to never accept any shameless actions from a shameless person in the future.
tr: Elizabeth had not previously believed that he could possess such confidence; but she sat down, resolving within herself that in the future she would set no limits to the shamelessness of a shameless man.
es: Elizabeth never believed he was capable of such impudence, but she sat determined not to set limits henceforth to the shamelessness of a shameless person.

en: She blushed, and Jane blushed; but the cheeks of the two who caused their confusion suffered no variation of colour.
vi: She blushed, Jane blushed; but the cheeks of the two, though embarrassed in different ways, were equally red.
tr: Her face turned red, Jane's face turned red, but the color on the cheeks of the two people who upset them did not even flicker.
es: Both Jane and she were blushing, but the cheeks of those who caused their embarrassment remained unchanged.

en: There was no want of discourse.
vi: No one wants her to perform lengthy speeches.
tr: There was no lack of conversation.
es: The conversation was not lacking.

en: The bride and her mother could neither of them talk fast enough; and Wickham, who happened to sit near Elizabeth, began inquiring after his acquaintance in that neighbourhood, with a good-humoured ease, which she felt very unable to equal in her replies.
vi: The bride and the mother could not speak any faster. Wickham unintentionally sat close to Elizabeth, starting to inquire about the people he knew in the area with a cheerful and relaxed attitude, which she could not match in her responses.
tr: Both the bride and her mother kept talking; Wickham, who was sitting close to Elizabeth, began to ask about acquaintances in the area with a cheerful ease; Elizabeth felt that she was having quite a hard time responding in the same manner.
es: The bride and the mother talked without pause, and Wickham, who sat next to Elizabeth, began to ask about their acquaintances in the neighborhood with a cheerfulness and good humor that she could not have matched in her responses.

en: They seemed each of them to have the happiest memories in the world.
vi: It seemed as if everyone had the best memories in the world.
tr: Both seemed to possess the happiest memories in the world.
es: Both Lydia and Wickham seemed to have wonderful memories.

en: Nothing of the past was recollected with pain; and Lydia led voluntarily to subjects which her sisters would not have alluded to for the world.
vi: Nothing was recalled in sorrow; and Lydia herself steered the conversation to the incident that the older sisters did not want to mention to the public. Lydia exclaimed:
tr: Nothing from the past was remembered with pain; Lydia willingly brought up topics that her sisters would never want to be mentioned in the world.
es: They remembered everything from the past without any regret, and she willingly spoke of things that her sisters would not have mentioned for anything in the world.

en: “Only think of its being three months,” she cried, “since I went away: it seems but a fortnight, I declare; and yet there have been things enough happened in the time.
vi: - Just thinking about the past three months since you left, it feels like it's only been two weeks, yet so much has happened.
tr: "Just imagine," he exclaimed, "it’s only been three months since I left; yet it feels like fifteen days to me; but so much has happened in that time.
es: ––It's already been three months since I left! ––she exclaimed––. And it seems like it was only fifteen days ago! And yet, how many things have happened!

en: Good gracious!
vi: My God!
tr: Oh my God!
es: My God!

en: when I went away, I am sure I had no more idea of being married till I came back again!
vi: When you left, you had no thoughts of marriage until you returned!
tr: When I left, the idea of getting married never crossed my mind until I returned!
es: When I left, I had no idea that when I returned I would be married; although I thought it would be hilarious if that were the case.

en: though I thought it would be very good fun if I was.”
vi: Although I would be really happy if that’s truly what you thought.
tr: Still, I thought that if I got married, it would be a lot of fun."
es: When I left, I had no idea that when I returned I would be married; although I thought it would be hilarious if that were the case.

en: Her father lifted up his eyes, Jane was distressed, Elizabeth looked expressively at Lydia; but she, who never heard nor saw anything of which she chose to be insensible, gaily continued,—
vi: The father raised his eyes. Jane felt uneasy. Elizabeth looked at Lydia meaningfully, but her sister, who never listened to or looked at anything she didn't like, cheerfully continued:
tr: Her father raised his eyes. Jane was bored, overwhelmed.
es: Her father raised his eyes; Jane was distressed; Elizabeth looked at Lydia significantly, but she, who never saw or heard what did not interest her, continued cheerfully:

en: “Oh, mamma, do the people hereabouts know I am married to-day?
vi: - Oh, Ma-man! Do the people around here know that I got married today?
tr: Elizabeth looked meaningfully at Lydia; but Lydia, who preferred to be oblivious to the things she chose to ignore, continued cheerfully, "Oh, mother, do people know I got married today?
es: ––Mom, do the people around here know that I got married?

en: I was afraid they might not; and we overtook William Goulding in his curricle, so I was determined he should know it, and so I let down the side glass next to him, and took off my glove and let my hand just rest upon the window frame, so that he might see the ring, and then I bowed and smiled like anything.”
vi: I fear they don't, so when we passed by William Goulding's carriage, I lowered the window, took off my glove, and placed my hand on the window sill so he could see the wedding ring, then I bowed my head and smiled.
tr: I was afraid they might not know; we caught up with William Goulding on the road, in his carriage, I wanted him to see and find out, so I lowered the window on his side, took off my glove, and placed my hand on the window sill so he could see my ring, then I bowed my head and smiled calmly."
es: I was afraid they didn't, and that's why, when we passed William Goulding's carriage, I wanted him to find out; I lowered the window on his side, took off my glove, and rested my hand on the window frame so he could see the ring. Then I greeted him and smiled as if nothing had happened.

en: Elizabeth could bear it no longer.
vi: Elizabeth could not endure it any longer.
tr: Elizabeth couldn't bear it any longer.
es: Elizabeth couldn't take it anymore.

en: She got up and ran out of the room; and returned no more, till she heard them passing through the hall to the dining-parlour.
vi: She stood up, ran out of the room, and did not return until she heard them going to the dining room.
tr: She got up, ran out of the room, and didn't return until she heard them passing through the corridor to the dining room.
es: She got up and went to her room and didn't come down until she heard them passing through the hall towards the dining room.

en: She then joined them soon enough to see Lydia, with anxious parade, walk up to her mother’s right hand, and hear her say to her eldest sister,—
vi: She arrived just in time to see Lydia, with the intention of showing off, walk to her mother's right side and say to her eldest sister: - Ah!
tr: Then she immediately went inside and, pretending to be worried, approached her mother on the right side and heard Lydia say to her eldest sister, "Well Jane, I'm taking your place now, your turn has passed, because I'm now a married woman.""
es: She arrived in time to see Lydia, strutting, taking her place at the table on their mother's right side and saying to her older sister:

en: “Ah, Jane, I take your place now, and you must go lower, because I am a married woman.”
vi: Sister Jane, I now take your place and you have to move down, because now I am a married woman.
tr: Then she immediately went inside and, pretending to be worried, approached her mother on the right side and heard Lydia say to her eldest sister, "Well Jane, I'm taking your place now, your turn has passed, because I'm now a married woman.""
es: ––Jane, now it is my turn to take your place. You move to second place, because I am a married woman.

en: It was not to be supposed that time would give Lydia that embarrassment from which she had been so wholly free at first.
vi: Do not assume that time would make Lydia embarrassed, so at first she was completely at ease.
tr: It was inconceivable that time would give Lydia a sense of shame that she initially lacked.
es: It was not to be supposed that time would give Lydia that composure which she had always lacked.

en: Her ease and good spirits increased.
vi: She became even more comfortable and cheerful.
tr: Her comfort and cheerfulness increased.
es: Her peace of mind and her ease were increasing.

en: She longed to see ms Philips, the Lucases, and all their other neighbours, and to hear herself called “ms Wickham” by each of them; and in the meantime she went after dinner to show her ring and boast of being married to ms Hill and the two housemaids.
vi: She expressed a desire to see Mrs. Philips, the Lucas family, and all the other neighbors, to hear each of them call her "Mrs. Wickham," and in the meantime, she showed Mrs. Hill and two other servants her ring and boasted to them that she was married.
tr: She wanted to see Mrs. Philips, the Lucases, and all the other neighbors, to hear each of them call her "Mrs. Wickham"; meanwhile, after dinner, she went to show her ring and boast about being married to Mrs. Hill and the two servants.
es: She was eager to see Mrs. Philips, the Lucases, and all the other neighbors, to hear them call her "Mrs. Wickham." Meanwhile, after lunch, she went to show her wedding ring to Mrs. Hill and the two maids to boast about being married.

en: “Well, mamma,” said she, when they were all returned to the breakfast-room, “and what do you think of my husband?
vi: When they returned to the breakfast room, she said to her mother: - Hey, ma-man, what do you think about my husband?
tr: "Honestly, mom," she said, as they all returned to the breakfast room, "what do you think about my husband?
es: ––Well, Mom ––she said when everyone returned to the sitting room––, what do you think of my husband?

en: Is not he a charming man?
vi: Is he a likable person?
tr: Isn't he a charming man?
es: Isn't he charming?

en: I am sure my sisters must all envy me.
vi: I am sure my sisters are all jealous of me.
tr: I'm sure all my sisters are jealous of me.
es: I'm sure all my sisters envy me; I only wish they have half the luck I do.

en: I only hope they may have half my good luck.
vi: I just wish they had half the luck I have.
tr: I hope they are at least half as lucky as I am.
es: I'm sure all my sisters envy me; I only wish they have half the luck I do.

en: They must all go to Brighton.
vi: The sisters should go to Brighton.
tr: They should all go to Brighton.
es: They should go to Brighton; it's an ideal place to find a husband.

en: That is the place to get husbands.
vi: This is the place to find a husband.
tr: That's the place to find a husband.
es: They should go to Brighton; it's an ideal place to find a husband.

en: What a pity it is, mamma, we did not all go!”
vi: Ma-man, it's a pity that we all didn't go together.
tr: It's a pity, mom, that we didn't all go together."
es: What a pity we all didn't go!

en: “Very true; and if I had my will we should.
vi: - That's right, and if mother had the authority, all of us would have gone together.
tr: "You are absolutely right; if they listened to me, we would have gone.
es: ––It's true. If I were in charge, we would have gone.

en: But, my dear Lydia, I don’t at all like your going such a way off.
vi: But dear Lydia, mother doesn't want you to go so far away.
tr: But my dear Lydia, I don't like you going so far away.
es: Lydia, my dear, I don't like it at all that you are going so far away.

en: Must it be so?”
vi: Is it necessary to go that far?
tr: Is it necessary?"
es: Does it have to be this way?

en: “Oh, Lord!
vi: - Oh, my God, I have to go – it's nothing.
tr: "Oh my God!
es: ––Oh, Lord!

en: yes; there is nothing in that.
vi: - Oh, my God, I have to go – it's nothing.
tr: yes; –there's nothing wrong with that.
es: Yes, there is no other choice.

en: I shall like it of all things.
vi: I will be happy with everything.
tr: I like it.
es: But I will like it a lot.

en: You and papa, and my sisters, must come down and see us.
vi: Mom and dad and the sisters should come visit us.
tr: You, my father, my sisters will come and see me.
es: You, dad, and my sisters have to come see us.

en: We shall be at Newcastle all the winter, and I dare say there will be some balls, and I will take care to get good partners for them all.”
vi: We will spend the winter in Newcastle; I dare say there will be some balls, and I will find dance partners for everyone.
tr: We will be in Newcastle all winter; I'm sure there will be balls, I will make sure to find good partners for all of them."
es: We will be in Newcastle all winter, and there will surely be some dances; I will try to get good partners for everyone.

en: “I should like it beyond anything!” said her mother.
vi: The mother said: - Mom would like that more than anything else.
tr: "I want it more than anything!" said her mother.
es: ––That's what I would like the most! ––sighed her mother.

en: “And then when you go away, you may leave one or two of my sisters behind you; and I dare say I shall get husbands for them before the winter is over.”
vi: Elizabeth said:
tr: "And then, when you leave, you can leave a couple of my sisters with me; I'm sure I'll find them husbands before the winter ends.""
es: ––And when you return, let one or two of my sisters stay with us, and I am sure I will have found them a husband before the winter is over:

en: “I thank you for my share of the favour,” said Elizabeth; “but I do not particularly like your way of getting husbands.”
vi: - I appreciate your good intentions, but I particularly dislike the way you are looking for a husband for me.
tr: "Thanks, I'll pass," said Elizabeth; "I don't quite like your way of finding a husband."
es: ––I appreciate the intention ––replied Elizabeth––, but I don't quite like, to say the least, your way of getting a husband.

en: Their visitors were not to remain above ten days with them.
vi: The two people stayed for no more than ten days.
tr: The guests would not stay with them for more than ten days.
es: The guests were going to stay at Longbourn for only ten days.

en: mr Wickham had received his commission before he left London, and he was to join his regiment at the end of a fortnight.
vi: Mr. Wickham had completed the enlistment procedures before he left London, and he needed to report to the regiment within two weeks.
tr: Mr. Wickham had received his assignment before leaving London and would join his unit in fifteen days.
es: Wickham had received his assignment before leaving London and had to join his regiment within a fortnight.

en: No one but ms Bennet regretted that their stay would be so short; and she made the most of the time by visiting about with her daughter, and having very frequent parties at home.
vi: Except for Mrs. Bennet, no one expressed regret that the two stayed for such a short time. She made the most of the time by taking her daughter to visit various people and often organizing gatherings at home.
tr: No one but Mrs. Bennet was upset that they would stay so briefly; Mrs. Bennet made good use of the time, visiting friends and acquaintances with her daughter, and frequently hosting parties at home.
es: Nobody, except Mrs. Bennet, felt that their stay was too short. Most of the time was spent making visits accompanied by her daughter and organizing parties at the house.

en: These parties were acceptable to all; to avoid a family circle was even more desirable to such as did think than such as did not.
vi: Everyone accepted these gatherings at home; the thought of avoiding family reunions was better than not thinking at all.
tr: These parties seemed reasonable to everyone; in fact, those troubled by family matters enjoyed escaping the family atmosphere more than those who were not troubled.
es: The parties were pleasant for everyone; avoiding the family circle was even more desirable for those who thought than for those who did not think.

en: Wickham’s affection for Lydia was just what Elizabeth had expected to find it; not equal to Lydia’s for him.
vi: The feelings of Wickham towards Lydia were exactly as Elizabeth had thought: not as strong as Lydia's feelings for him.
tr: Wickham's interest in Lydia was exactly as Elizabeth had predicted; it was not equal to the interest Lydia showed him.
es: Wickham's affection for Lydia was exactly as Elizabeth had imagined it, and very different from Lydia's affection for him.

en: She had scarcely needed her present observation to be satisfied, from the reason of things, that their elopement had been brought on by the strength of her love rather than by his; and she would have wondered why, without violently caring for her, he chose to elope with her at all, had she not felt certain that his flight was rendered necessary by distress of circumstances; and if that were the case, he was not the young man to resist an opportunity of having a companion.
vi: According to her own reasoning, she did not need to observe much to understand that the elopement was more due to her sister's love than his. She could have wondered why, if he did not love her sister much, he wanted to elope with her. This was simply because she believed that he surely needed to do so due to his dire circumstances, and if that were the case, he was not a young man who would pass up the opportunity to find himself a companion.
tr: It did not need to be confirmed that their elopement stemmed from the strength of Lydia's love rather than Wickham's; even though he did not have a strong desire for Lydia, he might have wondered why he agreed to run away with her if he were not sure that the hopelessness of his circumstances necessitated it; and even in that situation, he was not a man who could resist the opportunity to have a companion by his side.
es: Elizabeth needed only to observe her sister a little to realize that the elopement had been driven more by Lydia's love for him than by his love for her. She would have been surprised that Wickham had eloped with a woman towards whom he felt no special attraction, if she had not been certain that his dire situation had forced that action upon him, and he was not the kind of man, in such a case, to pass up the opportunity of having a companion.

en: Lydia was exceedingly fond of him.
vi: Lydia loved him dearly.
tr: Lydia was extremely fond of him.
es: Lydia was crazy about him; her "dear Wickham" was always on her lips, he was the most perfect man in the world and everything he did was well done.

en: He was her dear Wickham on every occasion; no one was to be put in competition with him.
vi: In every circumstance, he was always her beloved Mr. Wickham; no one could take him away from her.
tr: He was her dear Wickham in every situation; no one could compare to him.
es: Lydia was crazy about him; her "dear Wickham" was always on her lips, he was the most perfect man in the world and everything he did was well done.

en: He did everything best in the world; and she was sure he would kill more birds on the first of September than anybody else in the country.
vi: He was everything good in the world, and she was certain that on the first day of September, he would shoot more birds than anyone else in the country.
tr: He did everything in the world better than anyone else; Lydia was sure he would kill more birds than anyone else in the village one September.
es: She assured that at the beginning of September Wickham would kill more birds than anyone in the region.

en: One morning, soon after their arrival, as she was sitting with her two elder sisters, she said to Elizabeth,—
vi: One morning, not long after the two arrived, while Lydia was sitting and talking with her two older sisters, she said to Elizabeth:
tr: Shortly after their arrival, one morning while sitting with her two sisters, Elizabeth said,
es: One morning, shortly after her arrival, while she was sitting with her older sisters, Lydia said to Elizabeth:

en: “Lizzy, I never gave you an account of my wedding, I believe.
vi: - Lizzy, you have never told me about your wedding.
tr: "Lizzy, I don't think I told you about my wedding.
es: ––I don't think I've told you yet how my wedding was.

en: You were not by, when I told mamma, and the others, all about it.
vi: When you talk to mom and others, I am not comfortable with it.
tr: You weren't there when I was telling my mom and others.
es: You weren't there when I explained it to mom and the others.

en: Are not you curious to hear how it was managed?”
vi: Do you wonder how the event was organized?
tr: Aren't you curious about how it was?"
es: Aren't you interested in knowing?

en: “No, really,” replied Elizabeth; “I think there cannot be too little said on the subject.”
vi: Elizabeth replied: - She is not exactly puzzled.
tr: "I do not believe it," replied Elizabeth; "the less we know, the better.""
es: ––Really, no ––replied Elizabeth––; you shouldn't talk much about that matter.

en: “La!
vi: She thinks that talking about the incident could go on forever.
tr: "Oh my God!
es: ––Oh, how strange you are!

en: You are so strange!
vi: - There, you are so strange!
tr: You are so strange!"
es: ––Oh, how strange you are!

en: But I must tell you how it went off.
vi: But I need to tell you.
tr: "But I will tell you anyway."
es: But I want to tell you about it.

en: We were married, you know, at St. Clement’s, because Wickham’s lodgings were in that parish.
vi: You know, we got married at St. Clement's Church because Wickham resided in that parish.
tr: "As you know, we got married at St. Clement's because Wickham's house was in that neighborhood."
es: You already know that we got married in San Clemente because Wickham's lodging belonged to that parish.

en: And it was settled that we should all be there by eleven o’clock.
vi: And we decided to go there at eleven o'clock.
tr: "It was decided that everyone would be there by eleven o'clock."
es: We had agreed to all be there at eleven.

en: My uncle and aunt and I were to go together; and the others were to meet us at the church.
vi: My uncle, aunt, and I will go together, while the others will meet us at the church.
tr: "My uncle, aunt, and I were going to go together; the others would meet us at the church."
es: My uncles and I had to go together and meet the others at the church.

en: “Well, Monday morning came, and I was in such a fuss!
vi: And well, Monday morning came, I was so nervous!
tr: "Honestly, when Monday morning came, I panicked so much!"
es: Well, Monday morning arrived and I was beside myself. You know?

en: I was so afraid, you know, that something would happen to put it off, and then I should have gone quite distracted.
vi: You know, I was very afraid that something might happen to cancel the wedding, and then I would be in a mess.
tr: "I was so scared that something would come up and prevent it, and I would go crazy again."
es: I was so afraid that something would happen to ruin everything, I would have gone crazy!

en: And there was my aunt, all the time I was dressing, preaching and talking away just as if she was reading a sermon.
vi: And with my aunt here, I was getting dressed, she was pleading and talking incessantly as if she were preaching.
tr: "Especially my aunt, while I was getting dressed, she kept preaching, talking continuously like she was reciting a prayer."
es: While I was getting dressed, my aunt kept preaching to me non-stop as if she were reading me a sermon.

en: However, I did not hear above one word in ten, for I was thinking, you may suppose, of my dear Wickham.
vi: However, I could only catch bits and pieces, because I was thinking about, you can guess, my dear Wickham.
tr: "But I could only hear one out of ten of her words, because, you understand, my mind was on my dear Wickham."
es: But I didn't hear even a tenth of her words because, as you can imagine, I was thinking about my dear Wickham, and whether he would wear his blue suit for the wedding.

en: I longed to know whether he would be married in his blue coat.
vi: I wanted to know if he would wear the blue coat for the wedding ceremony or not.
tr: "I was wondering if he would wear his blue jacket at the wedding."
es: But I didn't hear even a tenth of her words because, as you can imagine, I was thinking about my dear Wickham, and whether he would wear his blue suit for the wedding.

en: “Well, and so we breakfasted at ten as usual: I thought it would never be over; for, by the bye, you are to understand that my uncle and aunt were horrid unpleasant all the time I was with them.
vi: "Ah, and then everyone had breakfast at ten o'clock as usual; I thought the meal would never end, because, by the way, you will know, my uncle and aunt are terribly unpleasant whenever they are near me.
tr: "Then, as usual, we had breakfast at ten; I thought it would never end because, you know, my uncle and aunt were terribly unpleasant while I was there.
es: "Well, we had breakfast at ten, as usual." "I thought it would never end, because you should know that my uncles were extremely annoying with me the whole time I spent with them."

en: If you’ll believe me, I did not once put my foot out of doors, though I was there a fortnight.
vi: If you can believe me, I haven't stepped out the door in the entire two weeks I've been here.
tr: Believe it or not, I didn't even step outside the door, even though I stayed there for fifteen days.
es: "Believe me, I didn't set foot outside the house in fifteen days; no parties, no excursions, nothing!"

en: Not one party, or scheme, or anything!
vi: No gatherings, plans, or anything.
tr: No parties, no plans, nothing.
es: "Believe me, I didn't set foot outside the house in fifteen days; no parties, no excursions, nothing!"

en: To be sure, London was rather thin, but, however, the Little Theatre was open.
vi: London is actually quite dull, but there is a theater performing.
tr: Although London was also dull, at least the Little Theater was open.
es: "The truth is that London wasn't very lively; but the Little Theatre was open."

en: “Well, and so, just as the carriage came to the door, my uncle was called away upon business to that horrid man mr Stone.
vi: Ah, and when a carriage came to the doorstep, my uncle was called away to do some work for that annoying Mr. Stone.
tr: Oh, just as the car was pulling up to the door, didn't that awful man, Mr. Stone, call my uncle for work.
es: "As soon as the car arrived at the door, my uncle had to attend to that horrible Mr. Stone for some matter."

en: And then, you know, when once they get together, there is no end of it.
vi: And then, you know, whenever the two meet, they can't seem to part.
tr: You know, when those two get together, it never ends.
es: "And you know that as soon as they meet, it takes a long time."

en: Well, I was so frightened I did not know what to do, for my uncle was to give me away; and if we were beyond the hour we could not be married all day.
vi: Ah, I was so worried that I didn't know what to do, because my uncle was supposed to take me to the wedding, and if we were late, we couldn't get married.
tr: I was so scared I didn't know what to do because my uncle was supposed to give me away; moreover, if we missed the time, we couldn't get married all day.
es: "Well, I was so scared that I didn't know what to do, because my uncle was going to be the best man, and if we arrived late, we wouldn't be able to get married that day."

en: But, luckily, he came back again in ten minutes’ time, and then we all set out.
vi: But, fortunately, ten minutes later he returned, and then everyone went together.
tr: But luckily, he came back in ten minutes, and we all set off together.
es: "But fortunately, my uncle was ready in two minutes and we left for the church."

en: However, I recollected afterwards, that if he had been prevented going, the wedding need not be put off, for mr Darcy might have done as well.”
vi: However, I later remembered, if my uncle couldn't go, there was no need to postpone the wedding, because Mr. Darcy could help."
tr: But then it occurred to me that even if he couldn't come, the wedding wouldn't have to be postponed because Mr. Darcy could also perform his duties."
es: "But then I remembered that if Uncle Gardiner hadn't been able to go to the wedding, it wouldn't have been canceled anyway, because Mr. Darcy could have taken his place."

en: “mr Darcy!” repeated Elizabeth, in utter amazement.
vi: Elizabeth repeated, astonished: - Mr. Darcy!
tr: "Mr. Darcy!" repeated Elizabeth, in horror.
es: Mr. Darcy! ––repeated Elizabeth in complete astonishment.

en: “Oh, yes!
vi: - Ah, that's right!
tr: "Oh yes!
es: Of course!

en: he was to come there with Wickham, you know.
vi: He will come with Wickham, you know.
tr: –he was going to come with Wickham.
es: He was accompanying Wickham, you know.

en: But, gracious me!
vi: But poor me!
tr: Oh my God!
es: But alas, I had forgotten!

en: I quite forgot!
vi: I forgot!
tr: I completely forgot!
es: But alas, I had forgotten!

en: I ought not to have said a word about it.
vi: I shouldn't have said a word about this.
tr: I wasn't supposed to mention this.
es: I shouldn't have said it.

en: I promised them so faithfully!
vi: I had sincerely promised them.
tr: I had given them my word of honor!
es: I promised faithfully.

en: What will Wickham say?
vi: What will Wickham say?
tr: What will Wickham say now?
es: What will Wickham say?

en: It was to be such a secret!”
vi: This is a secret!
tr: It was supposed to remain a secret!"
es: It was a secret!

en: “If it was to be a secret,” said Jane, “say not another word on the subject.
vi: Jane said: - If it's a secret, don't say anything more.
tr: "If it was meant to remain a secret," said Jane, "don't say another word.
es: ––If it was a secret ––said Jane–– don't say another word.

en: You may depend upon my seeking no further.”
vi: The two of us won't want to know more.
tr: You can be sure that I don't want to hear anything else."
es: I don't want to know.

en: “Oh, certainly,” said Elizabeth, though burning with curiosity; “we will ask you no questions.”
vi: Elizabeth said, though restless with curiosity: - Ah, that's right, you two won't ask anything.
tr: "Oh, of course," said Elizabeth, even though she was burning with curiosity; "we won't ask you any questions."
es: ––Naturally ––added Elizabeth, even though she was dying of curiosity––, we won't ask you anything.

en: “Thank you,” said Lydia; “for if you did, I should certainly tell you all, and then Wickham would be so angry.”
vi: Lydia said: - Thank you both, because if you had asked, I would have certainly told you everything, and then Wickham would have been furious.
tr: "Thank you," said Lydia, "because if you had asked, I would have told you everything, and Wickham would have blushed."
es: ––Thank you ––said Lydia––, because if you asked me, I would tell you everything and Wickham would get angry.

en: On such encouragement to ask, Elizabeth was forced to put it out of her power, by running away.
vi: With such encouragement to ask questions, Elizabeth was forced to avoid it by running away.
tr: Upon such an invitation to ask a question, Elizabeth ran outside and had to restrain herself.
es: With such an incentive to coax him, Elizabeth refrained from doing so and to avoid the temptation, she left.

en: But to live in ignorance on such a point was impossible; or at least it was impossible not to try for information.
vi: But she found it difficult to live without knowing about such matters, or at least difficult not to want to find out.
tr: However, it was impossible to live without knowing something about such a point; or at least, it was impossible not to try to gain information.
es: But ignoring that was impossible or, at the very least, it was impossible not to try to find out.

en: mr Darcy had been at her sister’s wedding.
vi: Mr. Darcy had attended her sister’s wedding.
tr: Mr. Darcy had attended his sister's wedding.
es: Darcy had attended Lydia's wedding.

en: It was exactly a scene, and exactly among people, where he had apparently least to do, and least temptation to go.
vi: Clearly, it was precisely such a setting and precisely such people that he did not want to attend and did not want to meet.
tr: This was a scene and a group of people in which he had the least interest and the least desire to go.
es: Both the event and its protagonists seemed precisely the least likely for Darcy to get involved with them.

en: Conjectures as to the meaning of it, rapid and wild, hurried into her brain; but she was satisfied with none.
vi: Speculations about the meaning of this arose wildly in her mind, but she was not satisfied with any of them.
tr: Quick and frantic guesses about its meaning swarmed his mind, but none were satisfactory.
es: Quick and confused conjectures about what that meant crossed her mind, but none seemed acceptable to her.

en: Those that best pleased her, as placing his conduct in the noblest light, seemed most improbable.
vi: The speculation that pleased her the most, placing him in the highest regard, seemed impossible to be true.
tr: The ones he liked the most, that is, those which placed his behavior in the noblest light, seemed the most impossible.
es: The ones that pleased her the most, because they exalted Darcy, were apparently improbable.

en: She could not bear such suspense; and hastily seizing a sheet of paper, wrote a short letter to her aunt, to request an explanation of what Lydia had dropped, if it were compatible with the secrecy which had been intended.
vi: She could not bear such intense thoughts, so she hurriedly grabbed a piece of paper and wrote a short letter to her aunt to ask her to explain the matter Lydia had just brought up, to see if this matched the secretive nature they had identified.
tr: He could not bear this tension; he hastily took paper and pen and wrote a short letter to his aunt, asking for an explanation about the things Lydia had not mentioned, if the situation allowed for confidentiality.
es: She could not bear such uncertainty, so she hurried and grabbed a sheet of paper to write a brief letter to her aunt asking her to clarify what Lydia had let slip, if it was compatible with the secrecy of the matter.

en: “You may readily comprehend,” she added, “what my curiosity must be to know how a person unconnected with any of us, and, comparatively speaking, a stranger to our family, should have been amongst you at such a time.
vi: She added: "You can immediately understand my eagerness to know how someone who has no relation to anyone in our family, a stranger to the family, could attend such a ceremony."
tr: "As you might imagine," he added, "I was extremely curious to see someone among you who has no ties to any of us, a stranger to our family (relatively speaking, I mean) at such a moment.
es: "You will understand," he added, "that I need to know why a person who has nothing to do with us and who, properly speaking, is a stranger to our family, was with you at that moment."

en: Pray write instantly, and let me understand it—unless it is, for very cogent reasons, to remain in the secrecy which Lydia seems to think necessary; and then I must endeavour to be satisfied with ignorance.”
vi: "Please write back to me immediately and help me understand – except for the reason that Lydia thinks it necessary to keep it secret, after which I will be at ease and not want to know anything more."
tr: Please write immediately so that I can understand – of course, if Lydia does not need to maintain secrecy for very credible reasons; in that case, I will have to try to live without knowing."
es: "I beg you to reply by return mail and explain it to me, unless there are powerful reasons that impose the secrecy Lydia mentions, in which case I will have to try to resign myself to ignorance."

en: “Not that I shall, though,” she added to herself, and she finished the letter; “and, my dear aunt, if you do not tell me in an honourable manner, I shall certainly be reduced to tricks and stratagems to find it out.”
vi: She thought, upon finishing the letter: "Although you won't feel at ease, dear aunt, if you don't let me know in an honorable manner, I will certainly resort to tricks to find out."
tr: "But it won't be necessary, of course," he added to himself, as he finished the letter; "and, my dear aunt, if you don't explain it to me clearly, I will have no choice but to resort to some tricks to find out.""
es: “But I will not do it,” she said to herself upon finishing the letter; “and dear aunt, if you do not tell me, I will be forced to resort to tricks and stratagems to find out.”

en: Jane’s delicate sense of honour would not allow her to speak to Elizabeth privately of what Lydia had let fall; Elizabeth was glad of it:—till it appeared whether her inquiries would receive any satisfaction, she had rather be without a confidante.
vi: Jane's delicate and honorable nature did not allow her to speak privately with Elizabeth about what Lydia had revealed. Elizabeth was pleased about this – until her inquiries were satisfactorily answered, she had to endure the situation without a confidant.
tr: Jane's delicate sense of honor would not allow her to secretly discuss with Elizabeth what Lydia had let slip; Elizabeth was pleased with this; she preferred to be without a confidante until her questions were answered.
es: Jane's delicate sense of honor prevented her from speaking alone with Elizabeth about what had slipped out to Lydia. Elizabeth was glad, although in this way, if her inquiries were successful, she would not be able to have a confidant.

en: CHAPTER LII.
vi: Chapter 52
tr: Chapter X
es: CHAPTER LII

en: ELIZABETH had the satisfaction of receiving an answer to her letter as soon as she possibly could.
vi: Elizabeth was pleased to receive a reply to her letter as quickly as she had hoped.
tr: Elizabeth received a reply to her letter as quickly as possible.
es: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of receiving an immediate response to her letter.

en: She was no sooner in possession of it, than hurrying into the little copse, where she was least likely to be interrupted, she sat down on one of the benches, and prepared to be happy; for the length of the letter convinced her that it did not contain a denial.
vi: As soon as she received the letter, she hurried to a grove in the garden where she was least likely to be disturbed, sat on a bench, and prepared for the pleasure, as the letter looked quite long, indicating that there was no secrecy being kept from her.
tr: As soon as the letter reached her hands, she hurried to the small grove, the place where she would be least disturbed, sat on one of the benches, and prepared to be happy; because the letter was too long to be dismissive.
es: She ran with it to the grove, where there was less chance of being disturbed, sat on a bench, and prepared to be happy, as the length of the letter convinced her that it did not contain a refusal.

en: “Gracechurch Street, Sept. 6.
vi: "Gracechurch Street, September 6,
tr: "Gracechurch Street, September 6"
es: Gracechurch Street, September 8.

en: “My dear Niece,
vi: My dear niece/nephew,
tr: Dear Nephew,
es: My dear niece: I have just received your letter and I am going to dedicate the whole morning to answering it, as I believe that in a few words I will not be able to tell you all that I have to share with you.

en: “I have just received your letter, and shall devote this whole morning to answering it, as I foresee that a little writing will not comprise what I have to tell you.
vi: Auntie just received your letter, and she spent the entire morning writing a reply, because she anticipated that if she wrote briefly, it wouldn't be enough to convey everything she wants to say to you.
tr: I just received your letter; since I anticipate that a short writing will not suffice to explain everything I need to tell you, I will dedicate the entire morning to replying.
es: My dear niece: I have just received your letter and I am going to dedicate the whole morning to answering it, as I believe that in a few words I will not be able to tell you all that I have to share with you.

en: I must confess myself surprised by your application; I did not expect it from you.
vi: I must say that Auntie was surprised when she received your request; she didn't think such a request would come from you.
tr: I must confess that I am surprised by your request; I did not expect this from you.
es: I must confess that your question surprised me, as I did not expect it from you.

en: Don’t think me angry, however, for I only mean to let you know, that I had not imagined such inquiries to be necessary on your side.
vi: However, don't think that Auntie is upset, because she just wants you to understand that she thinks you don't need to inquire in such a manner.
tr: Do not think that I am angry, but I want you to know that I did not think you would need to ask such questions.
es: Do not be upset, I only wish you to know that I did not think such clarifications were necessary on your part.

en: If you do not choose to understand me, forgive my impertinence.
vi: If you don't want to understand Auntie, she apologizes for digressing.
tr: If you are having difficulty understanding me, please excuse my intervention.
es: If you do not want to understand me, forgive my impertinence.

en: Your uncle is as much surprised as I am; and nothing but the belief of your being a party concerned would have allowed him to act as he has done.
vi: Your uncle was just as surprised as Auntie. He did those things only because he thought you were involved.
tr: Your uncle was as surprised as I was – he would never have acted this way if he believed you were aware of the matter.
es: Your uncle is as surprised as I am, and only because of the belief that you are an interested party has he allowed himself to act as he has.

en: But if you are really innocent and ignorant, I must be more explicit.
vi: But if you are truly unaware and innocent, Auntie needs to clarify further.
tr: But if you are truly unaware, then I must be more explicit.
es: But in case you are indeed innocent and know nothing at all, I will have to be more explicit.

en: On the very day of my coming home from Longbourn, your uncle had a most unexpected visitor.
vi: "On the very day you returned home from Longbourn, your uncle received an unexpected guest.
tr: The day I returned home from Longbourn, your uncle received an unexpected visitor.
es: The same day I arrived from Longbourn, your uncle had a very unexpected visit.

en: mr Darcy called, and was shut up with him several hours.
vi: Mr. Darcy came to visit, and the two talked for many hours.
tr: Mr. Darcy came, and they locked themselves in a room for several hours.
es: Mr. Darcy came and was locked up with him for several hours.

en: It was all over before I arrived; so my curiosity was not so dreadfully racked as yours seems to have been.
vi: By the time you arrived, they had finished; therefore, your curiosity was not as tormenting as mine.
tr: Everything was over before I arrived; therefore, my curiosity was not as agonizing as yours.
es: When I returned, everything was already settled; so my curiosity did not suffer as much as yours.

en: He came to tell mr Gardiner that he had found out where your sister and mr Wickham were, and that he had seen and talked with them both—Wickham repeatedly, Lydia once.
vi: Mr. Darcy came to inform Mr. Gardiner that he had found the place where your sister and Mr. Wickham were hiding, and he had met and talked with both of them, several times with Wickham, and once with Lydia.
tr: Mr. Darcy came to tell Mr. Gardiner that he had found out where your sister and Mr. Wickham were, had seen them, had spoken with Wickham frequently, and with Lydia once.
es: Darcy came to tell Gardiner that he had discovered the hiding place of Wickham and your sister, and that he had seen and spoken to both of them: to Wickham several times, to your sister only once.

en: From what I can collect, he left Derbyshire only one day after ourselves, and came to town with the resolution of hunting for them.
vi: If I remember correctly, he left Derbyshire just one day after we returned, and went to the city with the determination to find them.
tr: As far as I can understand, he left Derbyshire a day after us and came to the city with the aim of finding them.
es: From what I can deduce, Darcy left Derbyshire the day after we did and came to London with the idea of finding them.

en: The motive professed was his conviction of its being owing to himself that Wickham’s worthlessness had not been so well known as to make it impossible for any young woman of character to love or confide in him.
vi: He explained that his motivation in this was because he thought that due to him, not many people were aware of Wickham's true character, otherwise he could have prevented respectable young women from mistakenly falling in love with him.
tr: The reason for his action was that he felt responsible for the fact that Wickham's villainy was not sufficiently known; if it were known, it would be impossible for well-bred girls to love or trust him.
es: The reason he gave is that he felt guilty for not having made Wickham's infamy sufficiently known to prevent a decent girl from loving or trusting him.

en: He generously imputed the whole to his mistaken pride, and confessed that he had before thought it beneath him to lay his private actions open to the world.
vi: Mr. Darcy blamed his misplaced pride for the entire affair, confessing that he previously thought it beneath him to expose the private actions of the other man to everyone.
tr: He found all the blame in his own faulty pride; he admitted that he did not consider it appropriate to reveal private matters to the public.
es: He generously attributed it all to his blind pride, saying that he had previously deemed it unworthy of him to publish his private affairs.

en: His character was to speak for itself.
vi: Therefore, he felt it was his duty to act and try to rectify the mistake he had caused.
tr: He found all the blame in his own faulty pride; he admitted that he did not consider it appropriate to reveal private matters to the public.
es: His conduct would speak for him.

en: He called it, therefore, his duty to step forward, and endeavour to remedy an evil which had been brought on by himself.
vi: Therefore, he felt it was his duty to act and try to rectify the mistake he had caused.
tr: Therefore, he felt it his duty to come forward and make an effort to remedy a wrong he had caused.
es: Therefore, he believed it his duty to intervene and remedy a wrong that he himself had caused.

en: If he had another motive, I am sure it would never disgrace him.
vi: If Mr. Darcy had any other motivation, I think it would not cause him any shame.
tr: If there is another reason, I am sure it is not one that would embarrass him.
es: If he had another motive, I am sure it was not dishonorable...

en: He had been some days in town before he was able to discover them; but he had something to direct his search, which was more than we had; and the consciousness of this was another reason for his resolving to follow us.
vi: “He came to the city and within just a few days found two people, because he had some clues that we didn't have, and his awareness of this was another reason why he was determined to help you search.
tr: He spent a few days in the city until he found them; unlike us, he knew where to direct his search; knowing this was another reason he decided to follow us.
es: He had spent several days in the capital without being able to find them, but he had a lead that could guide him and that was more important than all of ours and that, moreover, was another reason that prompted him to come see us.

en: There is a lady, it seems, a ms Younge, who was some time ago governess to Miss Darcy, and was dismissed from her charge on some cause of disapprobation, though he did not say what.
vi: It seems there was a woman, Mrs. Younge, who was previously a governess for Miss Darcy, but was later dismissed for some reason that Mr. Darcy did not disclose.
tr: It appears there is a lady, someone named Mrs. Younge, who was Miss Darcy's governess for a while; he did not say exactly what happened, but she was dismissed for some reason.
es: It seems that there is a lady, a certain Mrs. Younge, who some time ago was Miss Darcy's governess, and had to be dismissed from her position for some reprehensible reason that he did not tell us.

en: She then took a large house in Edward Street, and has since maintained herself by letting lodgings.
vi: She moved to a large house on Edward Street, and since then has been living by renting out rooms.
tr: The lady then rented a large house on Edward Street and has been making a living by renting rooms since then.
es: Upon leaving the Darcy family, Mrs. Younge took a large house on Edwards Street and since then made a living by renting out rooms.

en: This ms Younge was, he knew, intimately acquainted with Wickham; and he went to her for intelligence of him, as soon as he got to town.
vi: Mr. Darcy knew this woman was close to Wickham, so as soon as he arrived in the city, he went to find her to inquire.
tr: He knew that Mrs. Younge was well acquainted with Wickham and went to her for information as soon as he arrived in the city.
es: Darcy knew that this Mrs. Younge had close ties with Wickham, and he went to her for news of him as soon as he arrived in the capital.

en: But it was two or three days before he could get from her what he wanted.
vi: But it took one or two days for her to give him any information.
tr: But it took two or three days to get what he wanted from her.
es: But two or three days went by without being able to obtain from that lady what he needed.

en: She would not betray her trust, I suppose, without bribery and corruption, for she really did know where her friend was to be found.
vi: I think this woman didn't want to betray Wickham's trust unless there was money involved, because she really knew where her friend was staying.
tr: Apparently, he had to bribe her to betray Wickham because she really knew where her friend was.
es: I suppose she did not want to speak until she was bribed, for, in reality, she knew from the beginning where her friend was.

en: Wickham, indeed, had gone to her on their first arrival in London; and had she been able to receive them into her house, they would have taken up their abode with her.
vi: In fact, Wickham went to find her as soon as the two of them arrived in London, and if she had the means to accommodate them, they would have stayed at her place.
tr: Wickham had actually gone to her first when he came to London; if she could have accommodated him, they would have stayed with her.
es: Wickham, in fact, went to her upon his arrival in London, and if there had been room in her house, he would have stayed there.

en: At length, however, our kind friend procured the wished-for direction.
vi: However, in the end, our kind friend Mr. Darcy managed to get the information.
tr: But in the end, our kind-hearted friend got the address he wanted.
es: But, finally, our good friend obtained the address he was looking for.

en: They were in —— Street.
vi: However, in the end, our kind friend Mr. Darcy managed to get the information.
tr: They were on ------- street.
es: They were on X Street.

en: He saw Wickham, and afterwards insisted on seeing Lydia.
vi: He went to meet Wickham, and then insisted on meeting Lydia.
tr: He saw Wickham and then insisted on seeing Lydia.
es: He saw Wickham and then wanted to see Lydia.

en: His first object with her, he acknowledged, had been to persuade her to quit her present disgraceful situation, and return to her friends as soon as they could be prevailed on to receive her, offering his assistance as far as it would go.
vi: Mr. Darcy said his purpose was to persuade her to get out of the disgraceful situation, to return to her family as soon as they showed willingness to take her back and support her.
tr: His initial aim regarding Lydia was to persuade her to end that disgraceful situation and return to her relatives, as soon as they were willing to accept her, and he offered to help as much as he could to achieve this.
es: He confessed to us that his first intention was to convince her to leave that unfortunate situation and return to her family's bosom if it could be arranged for them to receive her, and he offered his help in everything within his reach.

en: But he found Lydia absolutely resolved on remaining where she was.
vi: But he found Lydia determined to stay where they were hiding.
tr: But he saw that Lydia was determined to stay where she was.
es: But he found Lydia absolutely determined to stay as she was.

en: She cared for none of her friends; she wanted no help of his; she would not hear of leaving Wickham.
vi: She didn't care about her family, she didn't want him to help her, she didn't want to hear about leaving Wickham.
tr: She did not care about her relatives, did not want his help, and would not even hear of leaving Wickham.
es: She did not care a bit about her family and rejected Darcy's help; she did not want to hear about leaving Wickham; she was convinced that they would marry someday and did not care when.

en: She was sure they should be married some time or other, and it did not much signify when.
vi: She was convinced that she and Wickham would get married someday, but didn't specify when that would be.
tr: At some point, she was sure they would marry, and the timing did not matter much.
es: She did not care a bit about her family and rejected Darcy's help; she did not want to hear about leaving Wickham; she was convinced that they would marry someday and did not care when.

en: Since such were her feelings, it only remained, he thought, to secure and expedite a marriage, which, in his very first conversation with Wickham, he easily learnt had never been his design.
vi: "Mr. Darcy thought that given her feelings, the only thing left to do was to expedite the wedding, although in his first conversation with Wickham, Mr. Darcy clearly saw that this was never in his intentions.
tr: Given her feelings, he thought the only thing left was to secure and hasten the marriage; in his first conversation with Wickham, he easily learned that he had no such intention.
es: In view of this, Darcy thought that the only thing to do was to facilitate and secure the marriage; in his first dialogue with Wickham, he saw that marriage was not in his plans.

en: He confessed himself obliged to leave the regiment on account of some debts of honour which were very pressing; and scrupled not to lay all the ill consequences of Lydia’s flight on her own folly alone.
vi: Wickham only talked about resigning from the militia due to pressing debts of honor, without considering the negative consequences of Lydia's elopement, which were solely due to her own foolishness.
tr: Wickham himself admitted that he had to leave the regiment due to some urgent gambling debts; he did not hesitate to attribute all the bad consequences of Lydia's elopement solely to her foolishness.
es: Wickham confessed that he had been forced to leave the regiment due to certain pressing debts of honor; he had no scruples in blaming Lydia's madness for all the unfortunate consequences of the elopement.

en: He meant to resign his commission immediately; and as to his future situation, he could conjecture very little about it.
vi: He intended to resign as an officer immediately, and as for his future, he had no concrete plans.
tr: He intended to leave the regiment immediately; he had no clear idea of what he would do in the future.
es: He said he would immediately resign from his position, and as for the future, he did not know what would become of him; he had to go somewhere, but he did not know where and admitted that he did not have a penny to his name.

en: He must go somewhere, but he did not know where, and he knew he should have nothing to live on.
vi: He had to go somewhere but did not know where, and he was well aware that he had no income to live on.
tr: He had to go somewhere, but he did not know where; he also did not know how he would make a living.
es: He said he would immediately resign from his position, and as for the future, he did not know what would become of him; he had to go somewhere, but he did not know where and admitted that he did not have a penny to his name.

en: mr Darcy asked why he did not marry your sister at once.
vi: Mr. Darcy asked him why he did not marry your sister right away.
tr: Mr. Darcy asked him why he did not marry your sister immediately.
es: Mr. Darcy asked him why he had not married your sister on the spot.

en: Though mr Bennet was not imagined to be very rich, he would have been able to do something for him, and his situation must have been benefited by marriage.
vi: Although no one thought Mr. Bennet was wealthy, he could still do something for him, and his situation would improve thanks to the marriage.
tr: Although Mr. Bennet was not very wealthy, he could do something for him, and his situation could improve through marriage.
es: Although Mr. Bennet might not be very wealthy, he could do something for him and his situation would improve with the marriage.

en: But he found, in reply to this question, that Wickham still cherished the hope of more effectually making his fortune by marriage, in some other country.
vi: But from Wickham's response, Mr. Darcy realized that he still harbored hopes of securing a better fortune through marriage elsewhere.
tr: But in response to this question, Mr. Darcy learned that Wickham still held out hope of making a more substantial fortune through marriage in another region.
es: But from Wickham's response, Darcy understood that he still harbored the hope of securing a more solid fortune by marrying another girl in some other country; nevertheless, given the circumstances he was in, he did not seem very averse to the temptation of obtaining an immediate solution.

en: Under such circumstances, however, he was not likely to be proof against the temptation of immediate relief.
vi: However, given the circumstances, he still wanted to quickly escape his current difficulties.
tr: However, it was not easy for him to resist the temptation of immediate relief.
es: But from Wickham's response, Darcy understood that he still harbored the hope of securing a more solid fortune by marrying another girl in some other country; nevertheless, given the circumstances he was in, he did not seem very averse to the temptation of obtaining an immediate solution.

en: They met several times, for there was much to be discussed.
vi: The two met several times as there were many matters to discuss.
tr: They met several times because there was much to discuss.
es: They met repeatedly because there were many things to discuss.

en: Wickham, of course, wanted more than he could get; but at length was reduced to be reasonable.
vi: Of course, Wickham wanted more than what he could receive, but in the end, the two reached a reasonable agreement.
tr: Of course, Wickham wanted more than he could get, but eventually, he agreed to a reasonable amount.
es: Wickham, of course, needed much more than could be given to him, but in the end, he agreed to be reasonable.

en: Everything being settled between them, mr Darcy’s next step was to make your uncle acquainted with it, and he first called in Gracechurch Street the evening before I came home.
vi: "Everything was agreed upon by the two of them. Next, Mr. Darcy intended to explain his plan clearly to your uncle, and he went to Gracechurch Street one evening before your aunt returned home.
tr: Once everything was settled between them, Mr. Darcy's next step was to inform your uncle of the situation; he visited Gracechurch Street the evening before my first arrival.
es: When everything was agreed upon between them, the first thing Mr. Darcy did was inform your uncle, for which he came to Gracechurch Street for the first time, the afternoon before my arrival.

en: But mr Gardiner could not be seen; and mr Darcy found, on further inquiry, that your father was still with him, but would quit town the next morning.
