vi: But he did not meet Mr. Gardiner, and upon further inquiry, Mr. Darcy found out that your father was with him, but would be leaving the city the next morning.
tr: But Mr. Gardiner was not around; after doing some more research, Mr. Darcy learned that your father was with him but would leave the city the next day.
es: But he could not see Gardiner. Darcy found out that your father was still at our house, but that he was going to leave the next day.

en: He did not judge your father to be a person whom he could so properly consult as your uncle, and therefore readily postponed seeing him till after the departure of the former.
vi: He thought your father was not someone he could consult as effectively as your uncle, so he waited until your father left before meeting your uncle.
tr: Thinking he could not speak as comfortably with your father as with your uncle, he postponed the meeting until your father left.
es: He did not believe that your father was a more suitable person than your uncle to handle the matter, and then postponed his visit until your father had left.

en: He did not leave his name, and till the next day it was only known that a gentleman had called on business.
vi: He did not leave his name, so until the next day, everyone only knew that a gentleman wanted to discuss business matters.
tr: He did not leave his name; until the next day, all that was known was that a gentleman had called on business.
es: He did not leave his name, and the next day we only knew that a gentleman had come on a business matter.

en: On Saturday he came again.
vi: He returned on Saturday.
tr: He came again on Saturday.
es: He returned on Saturday.

en: Your father was gone, your uncle at home, and, as I said before, they had a great deal of talk together.
vi: By then, your father had left, your uncle was at home, and as your aunt mentioned above, they talked for a long time.
tr: Your father was gone, your uncle was home, and as I said, they talked extensively in private.
es: Your father had left and your uncle was at home. As I said before, the two of them talked for a long time.

en: They met again on Sunday, and then I saw him too.
vi: They met again on Sunday; that was when your aunt also met him.
tr: They met again on Sunday, and that was when I saw him.
es: On Sunday they met again and then I saw him too.

en: It was not all settled before Monday: as soon as it was, the express was sent off to Longbourn.
vi: It wasn't until Monday that they agreed on everything, and immediately after, your uncle sent an urgent letter to Longbourn.
tr: Everything was settled by Monday: a courier was immediately sent to Longbourn.
es: It wasn't until Monday that everything was decided, and then it was when the messenger was sent to Longbourn.

en: But our visitor was very obstinate.
vi: “But Mr. Darcy is very stubborn, Lizzy, I think this stubbornness is truly a flaw of Mr. Darcy.
tr: But our guest was very stubborn.
es: But our visitor was very stubborn; I assure you, Elizabeth, that stubbornness is the true flaw in his character.

en: I fancy, Lizzy, that obstinacy is the real defect of his character, after all.
vi: “But Mr. Darcy is very stubborn, Lizzy, I think this stubbornness is truly a flaw of Mr. Darcy.
tr: It seems to me, my dear Lizzy, that stubbornness is his true character flaw.
es: But our visitor was very stubborn; I assure you, Elizabeth, that stubbornness is the true flaw in his character.

en: He has been accused of many faults at different times; but this is the true one.
vi: At different times, he must have been condemned for different faults, but this is the real flaw.
tr: He has been found to have many faults at different times; but this is the real flaw.
es: He has been accused of many faults on various occasions, but that is the only true one.

en: Nothing was to be done that he did not do himself; though I am sure (and I do not speak it to be thanked, therefore say nothing about it) your uncle would most readily have settled the whole.
vi: Nothing can be done unless he takes charge himself, although I am sure your uncle is willing to take care of everything.
tr: He did not allow anything to be done that he did not do himself; yet I am sure (I am not saying this to expect thanks, so do not say anything) your uncle would have wholeheartedly handled the entire matter.
es: He wanted to do everything on his own, despite the fact that your uncle ––and I don't say this for you to thank me, so I beg you not to speak of it–– would have arranged everything instantly.

en: They battled it together for a long time, which was more than either the gentleman or lady concerned in it deserved.
vi: They kept arguing with each other for a long time, longer than two young people deserve to be concerned about.
tr: They struggled over this for a long time, much more than the gentleman or lady involved deserved.
es: They argued for a long time, much longer than the gentleman and the young lady in question deserved.

en: But at last your uncle was forced to yield, and instead of being allowed to be of use to his niece, was forced to put up with only having the probable credit of it, which went sorely against the grain; and I really believe your letter this morning gave him great pleasure, because it required an explanation that would rob him of his borrowed feathers, and give the praise where it was due.
vi: But in the end, your uncle was forced to yield, and instead of being allowed to act to help his niece, he only received credit for the arrangement. This goes against his nature, and I truly think your letter made him infinitely happy; this explanatory letter helped him remove the false mask of gratitude and place the benefactor in his rightful position.
tr: But in the end, your uncle had to agree; he had to be content with the probable reputation of being truly helpful to his niece rather than actually being so, which he could not bear at all; therefore, I believe your letter this morning pleased him greatly because it asked for an explanation that would free your uncle from his borrowed crown and return the praise to where it belonged.
es: But in the end, your uncle was forced to yield, and instead of allowing him to be useful to his niece, he reduced him to merely appearing to be so, much to your uncle's displeasure. So I imagine that your letter this morning has given him great pleasure by providing the opportunity to confess the truth and relinquish the credit that belongs to another.

en: But, Lizzy, this must go no further than yourself, or Jane at most.
vi: But, Lizzy, you should not reveal this to anyone, at most only to Jane.
tr: However, my dear Lizzy, no one should know about this except you and perhaps Jane.
es: But I beg you not to disclose this and, at most, only tell Jane.

en: You know pretty well, I suppose, what has been done for the young people.
vi: I think you already know quite well how they arranged things for the two young people.
tr: I believe you know very well what was done for the young couple.
es: I imagine you know what has been done for those young people.

en: His debts are to be paid, amounting, I believe, to considerably more than a thousand pounds, another thousand in addition to her own settled upon her, and his commission purchased.
vi: I believe the amount of money to cover his debts was more than a thousand pounds, plus another thousand pounds for her in addition to what she received from her family, and the cost for him to join the army.
tr: Wickham's debts, which I believe exceed a thousand pounds, will be paid, and another thousand will be added to Lydia's own money in her name, and Wickham's rank in the army will be purchased.
es: The debts of Wickham, which amount, I believe, to much more than a thousand pounds, have been paid; another thousand has been set aside to increase Lydia's dowry, and he has been secured a job.

en: The reason why all this was to be done by him alone, was such as I have given above.
vi: The reason why Mr. Darcy wanted to do all this, I mentioned above.
tr: All this was done solely by him for the reason I mentioned above.
es: According to Darcy, the reasons for doing all this are solely the ones I mentioned before: because of his discretion, it was not known who Wickham was, and he was received and regarded in a way he did not deserve.

en: It was owing to him, to his reserve and want of proper consideration, that Wickham’s character had been so misunderstood, and consequently that he had been received and noticed as he was.
vi: Mr. Darcy thinks that because of him, due to his reserve and lack of prudent judgment, others did not understand Wickham's character, hence the incident occurred.
tr: It was Mr. Darcy's fault, negligence, and thoughtlessness that Wickham's character was so misunderstood and consequently accepted by society.
es: According to Darcy, the reasons for doing all this are solely the ones I mentioned before: because of his discretion, it was not known who Wickham was, and he was received and regarded in a way he did not deserve.

en: Perhaps there was some truth in this; though I doubt whether his reserve, or anybody’s reserve can be answerable for the event.
vi: There may be some truth in this, but I am not sure whether to blame his reserve or the reserve of anyone else.
tr: There may be some truth in this; but I doubt that the reason was his or anyone else's negligence.
es: There may be some truth in this, although I do not doubt that neither Darcy's discretion nor anyone else's has anything to do with the matter.

en: But in spite of all this fine talking, my dear Lizzy, you may rest perfectly assured that your uncle would never have yielded, if we had not given him credit for another interest in the affair.
vi: “But despite having such a clever way of speaking, my dear Lizzy, you can rest assured that your uncle would never have conceded if he and your aunt did not believe that Mr. Darcy had another interest in arranging this matter.
tr: Nevertheless, despite all these fine words, my dear Lizzy, rest assured, your uncle would not have agreed if he did not think there was another reason related to this matter.
es: But despite his nice words, my dear Elizabeth, you can be sure that your uncle would never have yielded had he not believed himself moved by another interest.

en: When all this was resolved on, he returned again to his friends, who were still staying at Pemberley; but it was agreed that he should be in London once more when the wedding took place, and all money matters were then to receive the last finish.
vi: Once they had agreed on everything, he returned to his friends who were still staying at Pemberley, but they agreed that he would return to London once more on the wedding day, at which time all the financial matters would be settled.
tr: When all this was decided, Mr. Darcy returned to his friends still staying at Pemberley; but it was agreed that he would come to London once more for the wedding; all financial matters would be finalized then.
es: When everything was resolved, Mr. Darcy returned to his friends who were still at Pemberley, but he promised to return to London for the wedding and to settle the financial arrangements.

en: I believe I have now told you everything.
vi: "I think I have now told you everything clearly.
tr: I believe I have now told you everything.
es: I think I have already told you everything.

en: It is a relation which you tell me is to give you great surprise; I hope at least it will not afford you any displeasure.
vi: The relationship you mentioned to me will surprise and delight you; I hope at least it does not bother you.
tr: You said this explanation would surprise you greatly; I hope at least it will not upset you.
es: If what you say is true, this story will surprise you greatly, but I imagine it will not displease you.

en: Lydia came to us, and Wickham had constant admission to the house.
vi: Lydia is staying with us, and Wickham often visits.
tr: Lydia came to us; Wickham was allowed to come and go as he pleased.
es: Lydia came to the house and Wickham had constant access to her.

en: He was exactly what he had been when I knew him in Hertfordshire; but I would not tell you how little I was satisfied with her behaviour while she stayed with us, if I had not perceived, by Jane’s letter last Wednesday, that her conduct on coming home was exactly of a piece with it, and therefore what I now tell you can give you no fresh pain.
vi: He is still the same person I understood him to be in Hertfordshire. As for Lydia, I wouldn't want to tell you that I am not very pleased with her attitude if I hadn't realized, through Jane's letter last Wednesday, that her behavior when visiting home would be the same, so now saying it won't cause you any more pain.
tr: Wickham was just as he was when we knew him in Hertfordshire; I was not going to tell you how repulsive I found Lydia's behavior while she stayed with us, but from Jane's letter last Wednesday, I understand that her behavior when she arrived home was the same; so what I will now tell you will not cause you new pain.
es: He was the same as I knew him in Hertfordshire, but I wouldn't tell you how much Lydia's behavior during her stay in our house displeased me, if it weren't for Jane's letter on Wednesday that made me understand that upon arriving at Longbourn she behaved exactly the same, so it shouldn't surprise you what I am now telling.

en: I talked to her repeatedly in the most serious manner, representing to her the wickedness of what she had done, and all the unhappiness she had brought on her family.
vi: I often speak to her in the most serious manner, showing her all the harm her actions have caused and all the suffering she has brought to the family.
tr: I spoke to Lydia very seriously and repeatedly, explaining the immorality of what she had done and how much she had made her family unhappy.
es: I spoke to her many times with all seriousness, making her see the misfortune she had brought upon her family, but if she heard me it would be by chance, because I am convinced that she didn't even listen to me.

en: If she heard me, it was by good luck, for I am sure she did not listen.
vi: If she happens to hear what I say, it is by luck, because I am certain she does not listen.
tr: If she heard me, it was by chance, because I am sure she did not listen.
es: I spoke to her many times with all seriousness, making her see the misfortune she had brought upon her family, but if she heard me it would be by chance, because I am convinced that she didn't even listen to me.

en: I was sometimes quite provoked; but then I recollected my dear Elizabeth and Jane, and for their sakes had patience with her.
vi: Sometimes I get annoyed, but I think of dear Jane and Elizabeth, and for their sake, I try to endure her.
tr: Sometimes I felt like I was losing control, but then I remembered my dear Elizabeth and Jane and showed patience for their sake.
es: There were times when she irritated me; but I remembered my dear Elizabeth and Jane and clothed myself with patience.

en: mr Darcy was punctual in his return, and, as Lydia imformed you, attended the wedding.
vi: “Mr. Darcy returned as promised, and as Lydia informed you, he attended the wedding.
tr: Mr. Darcy returned without delay and, as Lydia told you, attended the wedding.
es: Mr. Darcy returned punctually and, as Lydia told you, attended the wedding.

en: He dined with us the next day, and was to leave town again on Wednesday or Thursday.
vi: The next day, he dined with the family, and he will leave the city on Wednesday or Thursday.
tr: He had dinner with us the next day; he was to leave the city again on Wednesday or Thursday.
es: He dined with us the next day. He was planning to leave London on Wednesday or Thursday.

en: Will you be very angry with me, my dear Lizzy, if I take this opportunity of saying (what I was never bold enough to say before) how much I like him?
vi: My dear, you may be very angry with me if I take this opportunity to say that I am very fond of him.
tr: If I take this opportunity to tell you how much I admire him (I had not found the courage to say this before), will you be angry with me, my dear Lizzy?
es: Will you be angry with me, dear Lizzy, if I take this opportunity to tell you what I never would have dared to say before, which is how much I like Darcy?

en: His behaviour to us has, in every respect, been as pleasing as when we were in Derbyshire.
vi: In every aspect, his demeanor is as pleasant as when we were in Derbyshire.
tr: His behavior towards us was as pleasant in every way as it was in Derbyshire.
es: His conduct with us has been as pleasant in every way as when we were in Derbyshire.

en: His understanding and opinions all please me; he wants nothing but a little more liveliness, and that, if he marry prudently, his wife may teach him.
vi: All his knowledge and opinions please me; he only lacks a bit of liveliness, but his wife could influence him in this regard, if he chooses his spouse carefully.
tr: I like his intelligence and opinions; all he needs is a bit more liveliness, which, if he makes a wise marriage, his wife can teach him.
es: His intelligence, his opinions, everything pleases me. He only lacks a bit of liveliness, and if he marries wisely, his wife will teach him that.

en: I thought him very sly; he hardly ever mentioned your name.
vi: I think he is quite reserved – he almost never mentions your name.
tr: I found him very tight-lipped; – he hardly mentioned your name.
es: It seems to me that he conceals it very well; he hardly mentioned your name.

en: But slyness seems the fashion.
vi: But discretion seems to be a fashionable trait.
tr: But being tight-lipped must be in fashion these days.
es: But it seems that concealment is in fashion.

en: Pray forgive me, if I have been very presuming, or at least do not punish me so far as to exclude me from P. I shall never be quite happy till I have been all round the park.
vi: Forgive me if I have any undue thoughts, or at least do not punish me by forbidding me from coming to P. I will never be satisfied until I have the opportunity to take a full tour around the garden.
tr: If I have been building castles in the air, please forgive me, or at least do not punish me so severely as to ban me from Pemberley. I will never be happy until I thoroughly explore the grove.
es: I beg you to forgive me if I have been too suspicious, or at least do not punish me to the point of excluding me from Pemberley. I will not be completely happy until I have taken a full tour of the estate.

en: A low phaeton with a nice little pair of ponies would be the very thing.
vi: A four-wheeled carriage with a pair of small horses is sufficient.
tr: A small carriage with a pair of beautiful ponies will suffice and more.
es: A low phaeton with a good pair of ponies would be ideal.

en: But I must write no more.
vi: But I cannot write any more.
tr: But I cannot continue any longer.
es: I can't write to you anymore.

en: The children have been wanting me this half hour.
vi: My children have been clamoring for me for half an hour now.
tr: The children have been calling me for half an hour.
es: The children have been calling me for half an hour.

en: “Yours, very sincerely,
vi: Your aunt,
tr: With my love,
es: Yours affectionately,

en: “M. Gardiner.”
vi: M. Gardiner
tr: M. Gardiner."
es: M. Gardiner

en: The contents of this letter threw Elizabeth into a flutter of spirits, in which it was difficult to determine whether pleasure or pain bore the greatest share.
vi: The content of the letter caused Elizabeth's mind to be agitated with chaotic thoughts, in which it was difficult to discern whether joy or pain was more dominant.
tr: This letter's content threw Elizabeth into a tumultuous state of mind; it was difficult to decide whether joy or sorrow had the greater share.
es: The content of this letter left Elizabeth in a state of shock where it was impossible to determine whether pleasure or pain took the greater part.

en: The vague and unsettled suspicions which uncertainty had produced, of what mr Darcy might have been doing to forward her sister’s match—which she had feared to encourage, as an exertion of goodness too great to be probable, and at the same time dreaded to be just, from the pain of obligation—were proved beyond their greatest extent to be true!
vi: She had vague and confused speculations because she was unsure of what Mr. Darcy could have done with her sister's spouse, while she feared encouraging him to do something too good to be true. And at the same time, she dreaded having to be fair and then painfully thinking he had not done so. Now the speculations about the good deed had become too real!
tr: The disturbing doubts caused by not being sure of all the actions Mr. Darcy might have taken to hasten his sister's marriage, which Elizabeth feared to believe because they were impossibly kind, and at the same time was horrified by the obligation they implied, all turned out to be true in the end!
es: The vague suspicions she had conceived in her uncertainty about Darcy's role in her sister's wedding, without daring to entertain them because they implied acts of kindness too great to be possible, and fearing they were true because of the humiliation that gratitude would impose, were thus confirmed.

en: He had followed them purposely to town, he had taken on himself all the trouble and mortification attendant on such a research; in which supplication had been necessary to a woman whom he must abominate and despise, and where he was reduced to meet, frequently meet, reason with, persuade, and finally bribe the man whom he always most wished to avoid, and whose very name it was punishment to him to pronounce.
vi: He had determined to track down the two people in the city, he had endured all difficulties and hardships in such a search, then had to plead with a woman he hated and despised terribly. He had to humble himself to meet a person he only wanted to avoid and whose name he did not want to mention, then had to meet this person repeatedly, reason with them, advise them, and finally spend money to bribe them.
tr: He had deliberately followed them to the city, endured all the trouble and distress such an investigation could bring; he had to persuade a woman he despised, face, meet frequently, talk to, convince, and finally bribe a man he most wanted to avoid and couldn't even bear to hear the name of.
es: Darcy had gone after them expressly, had assumed all the trouble and mortification inherent in that search, implored a woman he must detest and was forced to deal with frequently, to persuade and ultimately bribe the man he most wished to avoid and whose very name horrified him to pronounce.

en: He had done all this for a girl whom he could neither regard nor esteem.
vi: He had done all these things for a young girl he neither loved nor respected.
tr: He had done all this for a girl he wouldn't even consider a person.
es: He had done it all to save a girl who must mean nothing to him and for whom he could feel no esteem.

en: Her heart did whisper that he had done it for her.
vi: Her heart whispered to her that he did all these things for her.
tr: His heart told him he did it for Elizabeth.
es: Elizabeth's heart told her he had done it for her, but other considerations repressed this hope and she soon realized she was flattering her vanity by explaining the fact in this way, for Darcy could not feel any affection for a woman who had rejected him and, if he did, he would not be able to overcome such a natural feeling as that of being related to Wickham.

en: But it was a hope shortly checked by other considerations; and she soon felt that even her vanity was insufficient, when required to depend on his affection for her, for a woman who had already refused him, as able to overcome a sentiment so natural as abhorrence against relationship with Wickham.
vi: But her hope was suppressed by other thoughts. She immediately thought that her vanity was still not enough to expect his feelings for her, for a woman who had once rejected him, now wanting him to overcome the natural disdain for a connection with Wickham.
tr: But this hope was immediately tested by other concerns; soon, when Elizabeth felt the need to trust in Darcy's love for her, a woman who had once rejected him, even his pride couldn't make him believe that this love could overcome a natural feeling like the disgust of being related to Wickham.
es: Elizabeth's heart told her he had done it for her, but other considerations repressed this hope and she soon realized she was flattering her vanity by explaining the fact in this way, for Darcy could not feel any affection for a woman who had rejected him and, if he did, he would not be able to overcome such a natural feeling as that of being related to Wickham.

en: Brother-in-law of Wickham!
vi: Wickham's brother-in-law!
tr: Wickham's brother-in-law!
es: Darcy, Wickham's brother-in-law!

en: Every kind of pride must revolt from the connection.
vi: Every form of pride must oppose such a relationship.
tr: Such a relationship would provoke every sense of pride.
es: The most basic pride had to rebel against that bond.

en: He had, to be sure, done much.
vi: Surely he had helped a great deal.
tr: Of course, he had done a lot.
es: It was true that Darcy had done so much that Elizabeth was confused, but he gave a very plausible reason.

en: She was ashamed to think how much.
vi: She felt ashamed when she thought of how much he had helped.
tr: Elizabeth felt ashamed when she thought of how much he had done.
es: It was not unreasonable to think that Darcy believed he had acted wrongly; he was generous and had the means to demonstrate it, and although Elizabeth resisted admitting that she had been the main motive, it was possible to suppose that a remnant of interest in her had contributed to his efforts in a matter that compromised his peace of mind.

en: But he had given a reason for his interference, which asked no extraordinary stretch of belief.
vi: But he had spoken about the reason for his intervention, and it was easy to see that this reason was legitimate.
tr: But he had given a reason for his intervention that was not so hard to believe.
es: It was not unreasonable to think that Darcy believed he had acted wrongly; he was generous and had the means to demonstrate it, and although Elizabeth resisted admitting that she had been the main motive, it was possible to suppose that a remnant of interest in her had contributed to his efforts in a matter that compromised his peace of mind.

en: It was reasonable that he should feel he had been wrong; he had liberality, and he had the means of exercising it; and though she would not place herself as his principal inducement, she could perhaps believe, that remaining partiality for her might assist his endeavours in a cause where her peace of mind must be materially concerned.
vi: It was right that he believed he had been wrong; he had every right to act and every condition to act. Although she did not consider herself the main reason for his actions, perhaps she could believe that the remaining affection he had for her had supported his purpose to help her achieve peace of mind.
tr: It was understandable for him to feel guilty; he was generous and had the means to be generous; Elizabeth did not see herself as Darcy's main reason, but she could believe that perhaps a lingering feeling of affection might have helped him strive for a goal that also concerned her peace of mind.
es: It was not unreasonable to think that Darcy believed he had acted wrongly; he was generous and had the means to demonstrate it, and although Elizabeth resisted admitting that she had been the main motive, it was possible to suppose that a remnant of interest in her had contributed to his efforts in a matter that compromised his peace of mind.

en: It was painful, exceedingly painful, to know that they were under obligations to a person who could never receive a return.
vi: It was painful, exceedingly painful, to know that those efforts were for someone who did not hope for any reciprocation.
tr: It was understandable for him to feel guilty; he was generous and had the means to be generous; Elizabeth did not see herself as Darcy's main reason, but she could believe that perhaps a lingering feeling of affection might have helped him strive for a goal that also concerned her peace of mind.
es: It was very painful to be so indebted to a person to whom they could never repay what he had done.

en: They owed the restoration of Lydia, her character, everything to him.
vi: Her family owed him for Lydia's restoration, for Lydia's dignity, for everything.
tr: They owed everything, including Lydia's regained respectability, to him.
es: They owed him Lydia's salvation and reputation.

en: Oh, how heartily did she grieve over every ungracious sensation she had ever encouraged, every saucy speech she had ever directed towards him!
vi: Oh! She was deeply grieved when she thought of every unkind thought she had harbored, every harsh word she had spoken to him.
tr: Oh! how she suffered for every ungrateful feeling she had harbored towards him, for every harsh word she had directed at him!
es: How much Elizabeth was hurt by her ingratitude and the insolent words she had addressed to him!

en: For herself she was humbled; but she was proud of him,—proud that in a cause of compassion and honour he had been able to get the better of himself.
vi: She felt ashamed for herself, but proud of him. Proud that in that goal of affection and honor, he had surpassed himself.
tr: For her part, she had learned her lesson; but she was proud of him. She was proud that he had managed to overcome himself for the sake of compassion and honor.
es: She was ashamed of herself, but proud of him, proud that he had behaved so compassionately and nobly.

en: She read over her aunt’s commendation of him again and again.
vi: She read and reread the part where her aunt praised him.
tr: She read over and over the parts where her aunt praised him.
es: She read over and over again the praises her aunt bestowed on him, and although they did not seem sufficient, they pleased her.

en: It was hardly enough; but it pleased her.
vi: Not much, but enough to make her happy.
tr: It wasn't enough, but it pleased her.
es: She read over and over again the praises her aunt bestowed on him, and although they did not seem sufficient, they pleased her.

en: She was even sensible of some pleasure, though mixed with regret, on finding how steadfastly both she and her uncle had been persuaded that affection and confidence subsisted between mr Darcy and herself.
vi: She also felt joy, though mixed with regret, when she saw that both her aunt and uncle firmly believed that there was always genuine affection and trust between her and Darcy.
tr: When she saw how wholeheartedly her aunt and uncle believed in the love and affection between her and Mr. Darcy, she realized that she felt a certain pleasure, mixed with regret.
es: It gave her great pleasure, though it also saddened her to think that her uncles believed that affection and trust still existed between Darcy and her.

en: She was roused from her seat and her reflections, by someone’s approach; and, before she could strike into another path, she was overtaken by Wickham.
vi: Someone came over, causing her to stand up and interrupting her train of thought. She intended to move to another place, but Wickham blocked her way.
tr: When she heard someone approaching, she got up from where she was sitting, shaking off her thoughts; before she could move to another path, Wickham caught up with her.
es: She rose from her seat and came out of her meditation upon noticing someone approaching; and before she could reach another path, Wickham accosted her.

en: “I am afraid I interrupt your solitary ramble, my dear sister?” said he, as he joined her.
vi: He said, as he approached her: - Dear sister, I fear I have intruded upon your solitary walk, haven't I?
tr: "I'm afraid I'm interrupting your walk, dear sister," he said as he came up to her.
es: ––I fear I am interrupting your solitary walk, dear sister ––he said as he walked up to her side.

en: “You certainly do,” she replied with a smile; “but it does not follow that the interruption must be unwelcome.”
vi: She replied with a smile: - That's right, but it doesn't mean that I welcome any further intrusion into my privacy.
tr: "Of course you are interrupting," replied Elizabeth, "but that doesn't mean you are being bothersome."
es: ––That's right, indeed ––he replied with a smile––, but it doesn't mean that the interruption bothers me.

en: “I should be sorry, indeed, if it were.
vi: - If that's the case, I sincerely apologize.
tr: "If that were the case, I would be truly sad.
es: ––I would feel bad bothering you.

en: We were always good friends, and now we are better.”
vi: We have always been good friends, and now even more so.
tr: We have always been good friends, and now we are even closer."
es: We have always been good friends. And now we are something more.

en: “True.
vi: - Yes.
tr: "Correct.
es: ––True.

en: Are the others coming out?”
vi: Did anyone else leave the house?
tr: Are the others coming too?"
es: And the others, have they left?

en: “I do not know.
vi: - I don't know.
tr: "I don't know.
es: ––I don't know.

en: ms Bennet and Lydia are going in the carriage to Meryton.
vi: Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are getting into the carriage to go to Meryton.
tr: Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are going to Meryton by carriage.
es: Mrs. Bennet and Lydia have gone by carriage to Meryton.

en: And so, my dear sister, I find, from our uncle and aunt, that you have actually seen Pemberley.”
vi: Dear sister, I heard your uncle and aunt say you went to see Pemberley.
tr: In the meantime, my dear sister, from what I have learned from our uncle and aunt, you have indeed seen Pemberley."
es: My dear sister, your uncles have told me that you have been to Pemberley.

en: She replied in the affirmative.
vi: She accepted.
tr: Elizabeth said she saw it.
es: Elizabeth answered affirmatively.

en: “I almost envy you the pleasure, and yet I believe it would be too much for me, or else I could take it in my way to Newcastle.
vi: - I am envious of you, but I believe this is too much for me; otherwise, I could have dropped by on my way to Newcastle.
tr: "I can't say I wasn't envious of his privilege, but still, I think it would have been too much for me, otherwise I would have passed through there on my way to Newcastle.
es: ––I envy you that pleasure, and if it were possible, I would pass by there on my way to Newcastle.

en: And you saw the old housekeeper, I suppose?
vi: I guess you have met the old housekeeper, haven't you?
tr: You must have seen the old butler, right?
es: I suppose you would have seen the old housekeeper.

en: Poor Reynolds, she was always very fond of me.
vi: Poor Reynolds, she always loved me.
tr: Poor Reynolds, he was always very fond of me.
es: Poor Mrs. Reynolds! How much she loved me!

en: But of course she did not mention my name to you.”
vi: But of course, she didn't mention my name when talking to you.
tr: But of course, he wouldn't have mentioned me to you."
es: But I imagine she wouldn't have mentioned me in front of you.

en: “Yes, she did.”
vi: - Actually, she did mention it.
tr: "He mentioned it."
es: ––Yes, he mentioned you.

en: “And what did she say?”
vi: - And what did she say?
tr: "So, what did he say?""
es: ––And what did he say?

en: “That you were gone into the army, and she was afraid had—not turned out well.
vi: - She said you had joined the military, and she feared it had not... not gone very well.
tr: "He fears that you joined the army because things are not going well.
es: ––That you had joined the army and that you were getting into trouble.

en: At such a distance as that, you know, things are strangely misrepresented.”
vi: With such a distance, you know, many things get misinterpreted.
tr: You know, from afar, news is often strangely misrepresented."
es: You know that at such a distance things get distorted.

en: “Certainly,” he replied, biting his lips.
vi: He replied, biting his lip: - That's right.
tr: "Of course," she replied, biting her lips.
es: ––Sure ––he replied, biting his lips.

en: Elizabeth hoped she had silenced him; but he soon afterwards said,—
vi: Elizabeth hoped she had shut the guy up, but he continued:
tr: Elizabeth hoped she had silenced him, but Wickham continued shortly after,
es: Elizabeth thought she had silenced him, but Wickham immediately said:

en: “I was surprised to see Darcy in town last month.
vi: - I was surprised to meet Darcy again in the city this month.
tr: "I was surprised to see Darcy in the city last month.
es: I was surprised to see Darcy last month in the capital.

en: We passed each other several times.
vi: We ran into each other a few times.
tr: We passed by each other a few times.
es: We met several times.

en: I wonder what he can be doing there.”
vi: I wondered what he was doing there.
tr: I wondered what he might be doing there."
es: I would like to know what he was doing in London.

en: “Perhaps preparing for his marriage with Miss de Bourgh,” said Elizabeth.
vi: - Maybe he is preparing for Miss De Bourgh's wedding.
tr: "Maybe he is preparing for a marriage with Miss de Bourgh," said Elizabeth.
es: ––He might be preparing for his marriage to Miss de Bourgh ––said Elizabeth––.

en: “It must be something particular to take him there at this time of year.”
vi: There must be something special that requires him to go to the city at this time of year.
tr: "There must be a special reason for him to go there at this time of the year."
es: It must be something special for him to be in London at this time of year.

en: “Undoubtedly.
vi: - Certainly.
tr: "Undoubtedly.
es: ––Undoubtedly.

en: Did you see him while you were at Lambton?
vi: Did you meet him at Lambton?
tr: Did you see him while you were at Lambton?
es: Did you see him when you were in Lambton?

en: I thought I understood from the Gardiners that you had.”
vi: I heard from the Gardiners that you did.
tr: From what I understand from the Gardiners, you did."
es: I think the Gardiners told me that you did.

en: “Yes; he introduced us to his sister.”
vi: - Yes, he introduced us to his sister.
tr: "Yes; he introduced us to his sister.""
es: ––Indeed; he introduced us to his sister.

en: “And do you like her?”
vi: - And do you like her?
tr: "So, did you like him?"
es: ––And did you like it?

en: “Very much.”
vi: - Very fond.
tr: "Very much so."
es: ––A lot.

en: “I have heard, indeed, that she is uncommonly improved within this year or two.
vi: - Actually, I heard that she has gotten better in the past one or two years.
tr: "Indeed, I heard that he has made extraordinary progress in the last couple of years.
es: ––It is true that I have heard that in the last two years she has improved extraordinarily.

en: When I last saw her, she was not very promising.
vi: When I last met her, she didn't seem to have much promise.
tr: When I last saw him, he didn't seem very promising.
es: The last time I saw her, she didn't promise much.

en: I am very glad you liked her.
vi: I'm very glad to know you like her.
tr: I'm very glad that you like him.
es: I'm glad you liked her.

en: I hope she will turn out well.”
vi: I hope she will become a really good person. - I'm sure she will be like that.
tr: I hope he continues to improve."
es: I hope she does well. ––He will do well.

en: “I dare say she will; she has got over the most trying age.”
vi: She has gone through the most difficult age.
tr: "I'm sure he will improve; he has overcome the most difficult period.""
es: He has already passed the most difficult age.

en: “Did you go by the village of Kympton?”
vi: - Do you pass by the village of Kympton?
tr: "Did you go to the village of Kympton?"
es: ––Did you pass through the town of Kimpton?

en: “I do not recollect that we did.”
vi: - I don't remember us passing through.
tr: "I don't remember."
es: ––I don't remember.

en: “I mention it because it is the living which I ought to have had.
vi: - I mention this region because it is the parish that I was supposed to take charge of.
tr: "I am talking about it because that is the church I should have taken.
es: ––I tell you, because that is the rectory that I should have had.

en: A most delightful place!
vi: A truly beautiful area!
tr: A marvelous place!
es: It's a delightful place!

en: Excellent parsonage-house!
vi: The Parish Priest's Residence is wonderful!
tr: –A perfect parsonage!
es: And what an excellent parsonage it has!

en: It would have suited me in every respect.”
vi: It suits me in every way.
tr: In every way, it suited me very well."
es: It would have suited me from every point of view.

en: “How should you have liked making sermons?”
vi: - If you were a clergyman, would you enjoy preaching?
tr: "Would you like to give a sermon?"
es: ––Would you have liked to compose sermons?

en: “Exceedingly well.
vi: - I liked it a lot.
tr: "Indeed, how so.
es: ––Very much.

en: I should have considered it as part of my duty, and the exertion would soon have been nothing.
vi: I should have considered this as part of my duty, and soon it would have meant nothing to me.
tr: I would consider it part of my duty, and the fatigue would quickly pass.
es: I would have taken it as part of my duties and soon it would have cost me no effort.

en: One ought not to repine; but, to be sure, it would have been such a thing for me!
vi: One should not be troubled..., but surely, this should have been meant for me!
tr: One should not complain; –but of course, it would be something important for me!
es: I cannot complain, but there is no doubt that it would have been the best for me.

en: The quiet, the retirement of such a life, would have answered all my ideas of happiness!
vi: A peaceful, secluded setting for such a life would have matched my idea of happiness.
tr: The tranquility and silence of such a life would answer all my dreams of happiness!
es: The quiet and the retreat of such a life would have fulfilled all my desires.

en: But it was not to be.
vi: But it was not to be.
tr: But it didn't happen.
es: But it could not be!

en: Did you ever hear Darcy mention the circumstance when you were in Kent?”
vi: Did you ever hear Darcy mention this situation when you were in Kent?
tr: Did you ever hear Darcy mention the matter while in Kent?"
es: Did you hear Darcy mention that topic when you were in Kent?

en: “I have heard from authority, which I thought as good, that it was left you conditionally only, and at the will of the present patron.”
vi: - I heard from a knowledgeable person, whom I believe to be correct, that there are conditions set for you regarding this matter, depending on the person in charge of the property.
tr: "I heard it from an authoritative source, which is equally acceptable to me, that it was left to you conditionally, dependent on the current owner's will."
es: ––I learned from reliable sources that the parish was bequeathed to you only conditionally and at the will of the current master of Pemberley.

en: “You have!
vi: - She has heard.
tr: "Is that so?
es: ––Did he tell you that?

en: Yes, there was something in that; I told you so from the first, you may remember.”
vi: Yes, there are conditions set for that matter; I have told you about it, you probably remember.
tr: Yes, there was something like that; I told you right from the beginning, you remember."
es: Yes, there was something like that; that's how I told you the first time, do you remember?

en: “I did hear, too, that there was a time when sermon-making was not so palatable to you as it seems to be at present; that you actually declared your resolution of never taking orders, and that the business had been compromised accordingly.”
vi: - I heard that, at one time, you didn't like preaching as you do now, that in fact, you had declared you never wanted to be ordained, and all arrangements were made accordingly.
tr: "I have also heard that there was a time when preaching did not bring you as much joy as it does now, and you had clearly stated that you decided not to take your clerical appointment, and the matter was settled accordingly."
es: ––I also heard that there was a time when composing sermons did not seem as pleasant to you as it does now, that you then declared your intention never to be ordained, and that the matter was settled in accordance with your wishes.

en: “You did!
vi: - She has heard!
tr: "Is that so!
es: ––Yes, it's true.

en: and it was not wholly without foundation.
vi: And it's not without foundation.
tr: It's not entirely baseless.
es: ––Yes, it's true.

en: You may remember what I told you on that point, when first we talked of it.”
vi: You may remember I told you about this when we first talked about the case.
tr: You remember what I told you about that when we first talked."
es: You must remember what I told you about that when we talked about it the first time.

en: They were now almost at the door of the house, for she had walked fast to get rid of him; and unwilling, for her sister’s sake, to provoke him, she only said in reply, with a good-humoured smile,—
vi: They approached the main door of the house, as she had walked quickly in hopes of getting rid of him. Thinking of her sister, she didn't want to anger him. She only replied, with a slightly wry smile:
tr: They were now almost at the door of the house; Elizabeth had walked quickly to get rid of him; for the sake of her sister, she did not want to provoke him, so she replied with a meek smile and simply said,
es: She was already almost at the door of the house, for Elizabeth had continued walking to get rid of him. Out of consideration for her sister, she did not want to provoke him and only said with a smile:

en: “Come, mr Wickham, we are brother and sister, you know.
vi: - Hey, Mr. Wickham, we are brothers-in-law, you know.
tr: "Come on, Mr. Wickham, we are now like siblings.
es: ––Come on, Wickham; we are brothers.

en: Do not let us quarrel about the past.
vi: We should not argue about the past.
tr: Let's not fight because of the past.
es: Let's not argue about the past.

en: In future, I hope we shall be always of one mind.”
vi: In the future, I hope we always agree with each other.
tr: I hope we will always agree in the future."
es: I hope that from now on we won't have any reason to argue.

en: She held out her hand: he kissed it with affectionate gallantry, though he hardly knew how to look, and they entered the house.
vi: She extended her hand. He kissed her hand with a fond, flattering gesture, but he didn't know how to express it; and the two of them stepped into the house. Jane Austen Pride and Prejudice Translator: Diệp Minh Tâm
tr: She extended her hand; although Wickham did not know how to look at her, he kissed her hand with warm eagerness, and they entered the house.
es: He shook her hand and he kissed it with affectionate gallantry, although he didn't know what expression to wear, and they entered the house.

en: CHAPTER LIII.
vi: Chapter 53
tr: Chapter XI
es: CHAPTER LIII

en: mr WICKHAM was so perfectly satisfied with this conversation, that he never again distressed himself, or provoked his dear sister Elizabeth, by introducing the subject of it; and she was pleased to find that she had said enough to keep him quiet.
vi: Mr. Wickham was completely satisfied with this conversation, so much so that he never again felt the urge to provoke or upset his dear wife by bringing up old matters, and she was pleased to see that she had said enough to make him keep quiet.
tr: Mr. Wickham was so satisfied with this conversation that he never troubled himself again, nor did he provoke his dear sister Elizabeth by bringing up the subject; Elizabeth was pleased to see that he had spoken in a way that would shut his mouth.
es: Wickham was so chastened by that conversation that he never again exposed himself, nor provoked his dear sister Elizabeth to resume it. And she was glad to have said enough to ensure that he would not mention the subject again.

en: The day of his and Lydia’s departure soon came; and ms Bennet was forced to submit to a separation, which, as her husband by no means entered into her scheme of their all going to Newcastle, was likely to continue at least a twelvemonth.
vi: The day Mr. Wickham and Lydia were to depart had arrived, and Mrs. Bennet was forced to accept the separation. While her husband did not agree to the plan of the whole family going to Newcastle, the separation could last at least twelve months.
tr: The day they were to go with Lydia came quickly; since her husband did not agree to the plan of all going to Newcastle together, Mrs. Bennet had to resign herself to a separation that seemed to last at least twelve months.
es: The day of the young couple's departure arrived, and Mrs. Bennet found herself forced into a separation that seemed to be going to last at least a year, as it was in no way part of Mr. Bennet's plans for them all to go to Newcastle.

en: “Oh, my dear Lydia,” she cried, “when shall we meet again?”
vi: She exclaimed: - Oh! My dear Lydia, when will we meet again?
tr: "Oh my dear Lydia," he sighed, "when will we see each other again?"
es: ––Oh, sir!

en: “Oh, Lord!
vi: - My Lord!
tr: "Oh God, I don't know.
es: ––Oh, sir!

en: I don’t know.
vi: I don't know.
tr: "Oh God, I don't know.
es: I don't know!

en: Not these two or three years, perhaps.”
vi: Maybe two or three years.
tr: Maybe we won't see each other for two or three years."
es: Perhaps it will take us two or three years!

en: “Write to me very often, my dear.”
vi: - My dear, remember to write letters to mom often.
tr: "Write to me often, my dear.""
es: ––Write to me very often, dear.

en: “As often as I can.
vi: - I will try.
tr: "I write at every opportunity.
es: ––As often as I can.

en: But you know married women have never much time for writing.
vi: But you know, a married woman never has time to write letters.
tr: But you know, married women don't have much time to write letters.
es: But you know that we married women don't have much time to write.

en: My sisters may write to me.
vi: My sisters can write to you.
tr: My sisters can write to me.
es: My sisters will be able to write to me; they won't have anything else to do.

en: They will have nothing else to do.”
vi: They will have nothing else to do.
tr: They have no other work to do."
es: My sisters will be able to write to me; they won't have anything else to do.

en: mr Wickham’s adieus were much more affectionate than his wife’s.
vi: Mr. Wickham bid farewell with more affection than his wife.
tr: Mr. Wickham's farewell was much more amiable than his wife's.
es: Wickham's farewell was much more affectionate than that of his wife.

en: He smiled, looked handsome, and said many pretty things.
vi: He smiled brightly, looked handsome, and said many nice things.
tr: He smiled, looked pleasant, and said many sweet words.
es: He smiled, was very pleasant, and said charming things.

en: “He is as fine a fellow,” said mr Bennet, as soon as they were out of the house, “as ever I saw.
vi: As soon as the two people had left the house, Mr. Bennet said: - He is the man who has always been as good as I have ever seen.
tr: "A charming man," said Mr. Bennet, as they left the house, "he lacks nothing.
es: ––He is a very fine young man ––said Mr. Bennet as soon as they had left––; I have never seen another like him.

en: He simpers, and smirks, and makes love to us all.
vi: He is flashy, self-satisfied, and endears himself to all of us.
tr: He smiles, grins, and wins us all over.
es: He is a machine of smiles and flatters us all.

en: I am prodigiously proud of him.
vi: I am extremely proud of him.
tr: I am exceedingly proud of him.
es: I am extremely proud of him.

en: I defy even Sir William Lucas himself to produce a more valuable son-in-law.”
vi: I challenge even Sir William Lucas to see if he has such a fine son-in-law.
tr: I have even surpassed Sir William Lucas, for I have produced a more valuable son-in-law."
es: I challenge even Sir William Lucas to find a more valuable son-in-law.

en: The loss of her daughter made ms Bennet very dull for several days.
vi: The loss of a daughter left Mrs. Bennet in a daze for many days.
tr: Losing her daughter made Mrs. Bennet very sorrowful for a few days.
es: The loss of her daughter plunged Mrs. Bennet into sadness for several days.

en: “I often think,” said she, “that there is nothing so bad as parting with one’s friends.
vi: She said: - I often think there is nothing sadder than being away from a loved one.
tr: "I often think," he said, "there is nothing worse than being separated from the ones you love.
es: ––Many times I think ––he said–– that there is nothing worse than being separated from loved ones.

en: One seems so forlorn without them.”
vi: It is truly lonely when there is no loved one by your side.
tr: When your loved ones are not with you, you feel very strange."
es: One feels so helpless without them!

en: “This is the consequence, you see, madam, of marrying a daughter,” said Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth said: - Mom, you see, it's the inevitable result of marrying off a daughter.
tr: "This is the result of marrying off a daughter, Madam," said Elizabeth.
es: ––Well, you see, that is a consequence of marrying off daughters ––observed Elizabeth––.

en: “It must make you better satisfied that your other four are single.”
vi: You should feel happier when you think that there are still four unmarried daughters.
tr: "The fact that your other four daughters are single should comfort you."
es: It will make you happier if the other four of us remain single.

en: “It is no such thing.
vi: - It's not like that.
tr: "It's not like that.
es: That's not it.

en: Lydia does not leave me because she is married; but only because her husband’s regiment happens to be so far off.
vi: Lydia is away from her mother not because she got married, but because her husband's regiment is stationed far away.
tr: Lydia didn't leave me because she got married; she left because her husband's regiment was far away.
es: Lydia doesn't leave me because she got married, but because her husband's regiment is far away.

en: If that had been nearer, she would not have gone so soon.”
vi: If they were stationed closer, she wouldn't have to leave so soon.
tr: If it were nearby, she wouldn't have had to leave so quickly."
es: If it had been closer, she wouldn't have left so soon.

en: But the spiritless condition which this event threw her into was shortly relieved, and her mind opened again to the agitation of hope, by an article of news which then began to be in circulation.
vi: But her unhappy situation was short-lived, and her mind again opened to a glimmer of hope. A new piece of news began to spread.
tr: But the unpleasant mood that this event put her in passed quickly, and her mind was once again opened to the excitement of hope with news that had begun to circulate at that time.
es: But the discouragement that this event caused him was quickly alleviated, and his mind began to function again with great agitation at the series of news circulating at that time.

en: The housekeeper at Netherfield had received orders to prepare for the arrival of her master, who was coming down in a day or two, to shoot there for several weeks.
vi: The housekeeper at Netherfield had received orders to prepare for the master's return within a day or two, to go hunting for a few weeks.
tr: The housekeeper of Netherfield had received instructions to prepare for her master's arrival; he would be coming in a few days to hunt for a few weeks.
es: The housekeeper of Netherfield had received orders to prepare for the arrival of her master, which was to take place within two or three days, to engage in hunting for a few weeks.

en: ms Bennet was quite in the fidgets.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was quite anxious.
tr: Mrs. Bennet began to tremble with excitement.
es: Mrs. Bennet was extremely nervous.

en: She looked at Jane, and smiled, and shook her head, by turns.
vi: She looked at Jane, smiled, and shook her head:
tr: She looked at Jane, smiled, and kept nodding her head.
es: She looked at Jane and alternately smiled and shook her head.

en: “Well, well, and so mr Bingley is coming down, sister,” (for ms Philips first brought her the news).
vi: - Ah, ah, so Mr. Bingley is coming back, isn't he?
tr: "Oh my, so Mr. Bingley is coming, sister," (Mrs. Philips brought the news because.)
es: ––Well, well, so Mr. Bingley is coming, sister? ––for it was Mrs. Philips who first gave her the news––.

en: “Well, so much the better.
vi: Ah, that's good.
tr: "Well, that's very good.
es: Well, that's better.

en: Not that I care about it, though.
vi: But it's not like I care.
tr: Not that I care, though.
es: Although I don't care.

en: He is nothing to us, you know, and I am sure I never want to see him again.
vi: You know, he means nothing to our family, and I certainly never want to see him again.
tr: It doesn't mean anything to us, you know, I don't even think I want to see his face.
es: You know we have nothing to do with him and I don't want to see him again.

en: But, however, he is very welcome to come to Netherfield, if he likes it.
vi: But still, if he wants to, he is welcome at Netherfield.
tr: However, it's a good thing he's coming to Netherfield, since he likes it.
es: If he wants to come to Netherfield, let him come.

en: And who knows what may happen?
vi: And who knows what might happen?
tr: But who can know what will happen?
es: And who knows what might happen?

en: But that is nothing to us.
vi: But this means nothing to us.
tr: But that doesn't concern us.
es: But we don't care.

en: You know, sister, we agreed long ago never to mention a word about it.
vi: You know, dear, we agreed long ago never to speak a word about this.
tr: You know, sister, we decided long ago not to talk about this again.
es: You know that we agreed a long time ago not to say another word about this.

en: And so, it is quite certain he is coming?”
vi: By the way, are you sure he's coming back?
tr: So, is he definitely coming?"
es: Is it true that he's coming?

en: “You may depend on it,” replied the other, “for ms Nichols was in Meryton last night: I saw her passing by, and went out myself on purpose to know the truth of it; and she told me that it was certainly true.
vi: The other person replied: - You can believe it, because Mrs. Nicholls went to Meryton last night. I saw her passing by and went out to find out the truth; she told me that it was indeed true.
tr: "You can be sure," the other replied, "because Mrs. Nicholls was in Meryton last night; I saw her passing by, and I went out myself to learn the truth; she told me it was definitely true.
es: ––You can be sure of it ––replied the other––, because Mrs. Nicholls was in Meryton yesterday afternoon; I saw her pass by and went out determined to know the truth; she told me that yes, her master was coming.

en: He comes down on Thursday, at the latest, very likely on Wednesday.
vi: At the latest, he will arrive on Thursday, but most likely on Wednesday.
tr: He is coming no later than Thursday, probably on Wednesday.
es: He will come by Thursday at the latest; he might arrive on Wednesday.

en: She was going to the butcher’s, she told me, on purpose to order in some meat on Wednesday, and she has got three couple of ducks just fit to be killed.”
vi: She said she was going to the butcher to buy some meat for Wednesday, and she had just bought three pairs of ducks at the right age for slaughtering.
tr: The woman was going to town, she said, to order meat for Wednesday, and she bought three pairs of ducks, just ready to be slaughtered."
es: Mrs. Nicholls told me she was going to the butcher's to order meat for Wednesday and was carrying three pairs of ducks ready to be slaughtered.

en: Miss Bennet had not been able to hear of his coming without changing colour.
vi: Miss Bennet could not hear the news of his arrival without blushing.
tr: Miss Bennet's face blushed upon hearing of Mr. Bingley's arrival.
es: Upon hearing the news, Jane changed color.

en: It was many months since she had mentioned his name to Elizabeth; but now, as soon as they were alone together, she said,—
vi: For many months, she had not mentioned his name when conversing with Elizabeth, but now, as soon as they were alone together, she said:
tr: It had been months since Elizabeth had spoken of him; but now, as soon as they were alone, she said,
es: It had been months since she and Elizabeth had spoken about Bingley, but now as soon as they were alone, she said to her:

en: “I saw you look at me to-day, Lizzy, when my aunt told us of the present report; and I know I appeared distressed; but don’t imagine it was from any silly cause.
vi: - Lizzy, I saw you scrutinizing me when our aunt announced the news, and I know I appeared distressed. But don't think this is due to some foolish reason.
tr: "When my aunt gave this news today, I saw you looking at me, Lizzy; I know I seemed disturbed. But don't think it was for a foolish reason.
es: ––I have noticed, Elizabeth, that when my aunt was commenting on the news of the day, you were looking at me. I know it seemed like I was embarrassed, but don't think it was for some silly reason.

en: I was only confused for the moment, because I felt that I should be looked at.
vi: I was just momentarily confused because I thought I would be scrutinized.
tr: I was just confused for a moment because I felt like I was being watched.
es: I was confused for a moment because I realized you all were watching me.

en: I do assure you that the news does not affect me either with pleasure or pain.
vi: I want you to believe that I am neither happy nor sad about this news.
tr: Be assured that the news neither brought me joy nor sorrow.
es: I assure you that the news neither saddens nor pleases me.

en: I am glad of one thing, that he comes alone; because we shall see the less of him.
vi: I am only glad about one thing, which is that we will see him less, because he will return alone.
tr: I'm only pleased about one thing, that he is coming alone; then we will see him less.
es: One thing I am glad about: that he is coming alone, because that way we will see him less.

en: Not that I am afraid of myself, but I dread other people’s remarks.”
vi: It's not that I fear for myself, but I am tired of people's comments.
tr: It's not that I'm afraid of myself, but I'm horrified by what others might say."
es: It's not that I'm afraid for myself, but I fear people's comments.

en: Elizabeth did not know what to make of it.
vi: Elizabeth did not know what to think about this.
tr: Elizabeth could not understand what to make of this.
es: Elizabeth did not know what to think.

en: Had she not seen him in Derbyshire, she might have supposed him capable of coming there with no other view than what was acknowledged; but she still thought him partial to Jane, and she wavered as to the greater probability of his coming there with his friend’s permission, or being bold enough to come without it.
vi: If she had not met him at Derbyshire, she might have thought he dared to come here for the reason he stated. But she still did not think he had feelings for Jane, and she was torn between two possibilities: he returned because his friend permitted it, or because he had enough courage to defy the opposition.
tr: If she had not seen Bingley in Derbyshire, she might have believed that he came there with no other thought than what was said; but she still thought he was interested in Jane, and she was undecided between the possibility that he came there with his friend's permission, which was very likely, and the possibility that he came without his permission.
es: If she had not seen him in Derbyshire, she might have believed that he came only for the mentioned reason, but she did not doubt that he still loved Jane, and she even ventured to think that he came with his friend's approval or that he had dared to come without it.

en: “Yet it is hard,” she sometimes thought, “that this poor man cannot come to a house, which he has legally hired, without raising all this speculation!
vi: Sometimes she thought: "But it is strange that this poor guy cannot return to the house, where he is legally renting, without causing so much speculation like this!"
tr: "Still," he thought from time to time, "how unfortunate that this poor man cannot come to a house he has officially rented without arousing so much suspicion!
es: "It's hard," he sometimes thought, "that this poor man can't come to a house he has legally rented without raising all these suspicions.

en: I will leave him to himself.”
vi: “I will leave him be.”
tr: I will leave him to his own devices."
es: I'll leave him alone."

en: In spite of what her sister declared, and really believed to be her feelings, in the expectation of his arrival, Elizabeth could easily perceive that her spirits were affected by it.
vi: Although her sister had declared this and sincerely believed it to be her own feelings, Elizabeth could easily see that her sister's spirit was being affected.
tr: Despite what her sister had said about his arrival and what she believed to be her true feelings, Elizabeth could easily see that her mood was affected by it.
es: Despite what her sister said and believed in good faith, Elizabeth could notice that the expectation of Bingley's arrival affected her.

en: They were more disturbed, more unequal, than she had often seen them.
vi: Her sister was disturbed, unbalanced, more so than Elizabeth had ever seen before.
tr: Her mood became more uneasy, more changeable compared to before.
es: She was different and more troubled than usual.

en: The subject which had been so warmly canvassed between their parents, about a twelvemonth ago, was now brought forward again.
vi: The topic had been discussed enthusiastically by the father and mother about twelve months ago, and now it was being brought up for discussion again.
tr: About twelve months ago, the topic that was heatedly discussed between his mother and father has now been brought up again.
es: The topic that their parents had heatedly discussed a year ago came up again now.

en: “As soon as ever mr Bingley comes, my dear,” said ms Bennet, “you will wait on him, of course.”
vi: Mrs. Bennet said: - Dear, as soon as Mr. Bingley arrives here, of course you will go visit him.
tr: "As soon as Mr. Bingley arrives, my dear," said Mrs. Bennet, "you must go visit him."
es: ––My dear, I suppose that as soon as Mr. Bingley arrives, you will go visit him.

en: “No, no.
vi: - No, no.
tr: "No, no.
es: ––No and no.

en: You forced me into visiting him last year, and promised, if I went to see him, he should marry one of my daughters.
vi: She made me visit him last year, and promised that if I went, he would marry one of my daughters.
tr: Last year you forced me to visit and promised that if I went, you would marry one of my daughters.
es: You forced me to do it last year, promising me that he would marry one of my daughters.

en: But it ended in nothing, and I will not be sent on a fool’s errand again.”
vi: But nothing happened, and I cannot be sent on the errands of a fool.
tr: But nothing came of it; I won't go anywhere falling for such lies."
es: But it all came to nothing, and I don't want to make such a fool of myself again.

en: His wife represented to him how absolutely necessary such an attention would be from all the neighbouring gentlemen, on his returning to Netherfield.
vi: The wife explained to her husband that every polite neighborly man needed to show such concern when he returned to Netherfield.
tr: His wife explained to him that such an interest was absolutely necessary for the neighboring gentlemen if he were to return to Netherfield.
es: His wife pointed out to him how absolutely necessary that attention from all the gentlemen in the neighborhood would be as soon as Bingley arrived at Netherfield.

en: “’Tis an etiquette I despise,” said he.
vi: He replied: - I hate this kind of social nicety.
tr: "A habit I despise," said Mr. Bennet.
es: ––It is a label that irritates me ––replied Mr. Bennet––.

en: “If he wants our society, let him seek it.
vi: If he wants to associate with us, let him come find us.
tr: "If he wants our friendship, let him come and ask for it.
es: If he wants our company, let him seek it; he knows where we live.

en: He knows where we live.
vi: He knows where we are.
tr: Our place is well known.
es: If he wants our company, let him seek it; he knows where we live.

en: I will not spend my hours in running after my neighbours every time they go away and come back again.”
vi: I will not waste my time chasing after neighbors every time they return after leaving.
tr: I will no longer waste my time running after my neighbors because they come and go."
es: I cannot waste time running after the neighbors every time they leave and return.

en: “Well, all I know is, that it will be abominably rude if you do not wait on him.
vi: - Ah, I just know it would be truly impolite if you didn't go meet him.
tr: "Well, all I know is that if you don't visit, it will be terribly rude.
es: ––Well, it will be very rude of you not to visit him; but that won't stop me from inviting him to dinner.

en: But, however, that shan’t prevent my asking him to dine here, I am determined.
vi: But this doesn't stop me from inviting him to dinner, I have decided.
tr: However, that doesn't prevent me from inviting him to dinner. I'm determined, I mean.
es: ––Well, it will be very rude of you not to visit him; but that won't stop me from inviting him to dinner.

en: We must have ms Long and the Gouldings soon.
vi: We will soon invite Mrs. Long and the Gouldings.
tr: We must also get Mrs. Long and the Gouldings right away.
es: We will soon have Mrs. Long and the Gouldings at the table, and counting ourselves, we will be thirteen, so there will be just one place for him.

en: That will make thirteen with ourselves, so there will be just room at table for him.”
vi: With us as well, that makes thirteen people, so there will be a place for him at the table.
tr: If we include ourselves, we become thirteen people, and there's only one spot left at the table for him."
es: We will soon have Mrs. Long and the Gouldings at the table, and counting ourselves, we will be thirteen, so there will be just one place for him.

en: Consoled by this resolution, she was the better able to bear her husband’s incivility; though it was very mortifying to know that her neighbours might all see mr Bingley, in consequence of it, before they did.
vi: Comforted by this resolve, she felt more at ease with her husband's rudeness, although it was somewhat embarrassing to know that her neighboring families might see Mr. Bingley again before her own family had the chance.
tr: "I start to feel sad when he is coming," said Jane to her sister.
es: Consoled by this decision, she was perfectly prepared to endure her husband's discourtesy, although it greatly bothered her that, because of this, all the neighbors would see Bingley before they did.

en: As the day of his arrival drew near,—
vi: As the day of Mr. Bingley's return approached, Jane said to her sister:
tr: "I start to feel sad when he is coming," said Jane to her sister.
es: As the day of the arrival approached, Jane said:

en: “I begin to be sorry that he comes at all,” said Jane to her sister.
vi: - She began to feel sad that he would return.
tr: "I start to feel sad when he is coming," said Jane to her sister.
es: ––Despite everything, I am beginning to feel that he is coming.

en: “It would be nothing; I could see him with perfect indifference; but I can hardly bear to hear it thus perpetually talked of.
vi: It was nothing at all; but she could not bear to hear this matter being discussed endlessly.
tr: "It won't matter; I can remain quite indifferent to him, but I can't stand everyone talking about him.
es: I wouldn't mind at all and I will see him with the greatest indifference, but I can't stand hearing about him perpetually.

en: My mother means well; but she does not know, no one can know, how much I suffer from what she says.
vi: Our mother was distressed by what she said.
tr: My mother is well-meaning, but she doesn't know, no one can know how much her words upset me.
es: My mother does it with the best intentions, but she doesn't know, nor does anyone, the suffering it causes me.

en: Happy shall I be when his stay at Netherfield is over!”
vi: She could be at ease again when he no longer resided at Netherfield!
tr: I will be genuinely happy when he leaves Netherfield!"
es: I won't be happy until Bingley has left Netherfield.

en: “I wish I could say anything to comfort you,” replied Elizabeth; “but it is wholly out of my power.
vi: Elizabeth replied: - I wish I could say something to comfort you, but it is completely beyond my ability.
tr: "I wish I could say something to comfort you," Elizabeth replied; "but I can't.
es: ––I would like to say something to console you ––Elizabeth replied––, but I cannot.

en: You must feel it; and the usual satisfaction of preaching patience to a sufferer is denied me, because you have always so much.”
vi: You must know this, and I can no longer be content to advise someone who is suffering to be patient, because you always have plenty of patience.
tr: You must feel this; that familiar solace of urging patience to someone who is suffering has not been granted to me, because you already have so much of it."
es: You must understand that. And the usual satisfaction of recommending patience to those who suffer is denied to me because you never lack it.

en: mr Bingley arrived.
vi: Mr. Bingley had returned.
tr: Mr. Bingley arrived.
es: Bingley arrived.

en: ms Bennet, through the assistance of servants, contrived to have the earliest tidings of it, that the period of anxiety and fretfulness on her side be as long as it could.
vi: With the help of the servants, Mrs. Bennet devised ways to gather information as quickly as possible, to the extent that her time of anxiety and frustration was prolonged.
tr: Mrs. Bennet, with the help of the servants, managed to get the news as quickly as possible, regardless of how long her period of anxiety and distress would last.
es: Mrs. Bennet tried to obtain the first news with the help of the maids, to increase the anxiety and bad mood that consumed her.

en: She counted the days that must intervene before their invitation could be sent—hopeless of seeing him before.
vi: She counted the days she would need to wait to send an invitation to him, and felt despair at the thought of wanting to see him sooner.
tr: She counted the days that had to pass before the invitation could be sent, as she had no hope of seeing him earlier.
es: She counted the days that had to pass to invite him, as she did not hope to see him before then.

en: But on the third morning after his arrival in Hertfordshire, she saw him from her dressing-room window enter the paddock, and ride towards the house.
vi: But on the morning of the third day after he arrived in Hertfordshire, from the dressing room window, she saw him passing through the gate and approaching the house.
tr: But on the third morning of his arrival in Hertfordshire, she saw from her bedroom window that he was entering the lawn on his horse and approaching the house.
es: But on the third morning of Bingley's arrival in the county, she saw from her dressing room window that he was entering through the gate on horseback and heading towards the house.

en: Her daughters were eagerly called to partake of her joy.
vi: She called the girls to share her joy.
tr: The girls were invited to join in a flurry of excitement.
es: He immediately called his daughters to share his joy.

en: Jane resolutely kept her place at the table; but Elizabeth, to satisfy her mother, went to the window—she looked—she saw mr Darcy with him, and sat down again by her sister.
vi: Jane resolutely sat still, but Elizabeth wanted to please her. She walked to the window, looked outside, saw Mr. Darcy walking along, then returned to sit down beside her sister.
tr: Jane remained resolutely at her place at the table; but Elizabeth, to please her mother, went to the window – looked out – saw Mr. Darcy beside her, and sat down again next to her sister.
es: Jane refused to leave her place by the table. But Elizabeth, to please her mother, approached the window, looked out and saw that Bingley was entering with Darcy, and sat back down next to her sister.

en: “There is a gentleman with him, mamma,” said Kitty; “who can it be?”
vi: Kitty said: - Mom, there is a man going with Mr. Bingley. Who is he?
tr: "There is a gentleman with her, mother," said Kitty; "who could it be?"
es: ––Mom, another gentleman is coming with him ––said Catherine––. Who could it be?

en: “Some acquaintance or other, my dear, I suppose; I am sure I do not know.”
vi: - An acquaintance or something like that, my child, I guess; I'm sure I don't know.
tr: "He might be a friend, darling; I don't know."
es: ––I suppose some acquaintance of yours, dear; I don't know him. ––Oh! –– exclaimed Catherine––.

en: “La!” replied Kitty, “it looks just like that man that used to be with him before.
vi: - There! It looks like the guy who used to go with Mr. Bingley before.
tr: "Yo!" said Kitty, "he looks just like the man who used to be with you.
es: It looks like that gentleman who was with him before.

en: mr what’s his name—that tall, proud man.”
vi: What was his name! The tall, proud one.
tr: Mr. something. That tall, proud man."
es: The gentleman... what's his name? That tall and proud gentleman.

en: “Good gracious! mr Darcy!—and so it does, I vow.
vi: - Good heavens! Mr. Darcy! That's right.
tr: "Oh my God! Mr. Darcy! –I swear it's him.
es: ––Holy God! Mr. Darcy? Well, yes, it's him.

en: Well, any friend of mr Bingley’s will always be welcome here, to be sure; but else I must say that I hate the very sight of him.”
vi: Well, we can welcome any friend of Mr. Bingley who comes here, otherwise mother would have to say she doesn't want to see him.
tr: I mean, Mr. Bingley's friend is always welcome, but I must say I hate seeing this man."
es: Well; any friend of Mr. Bingley will always be welcome in this house; if it weren't for that... I can't stand the sight of him.

en: Jane looked at Elizabeth with surprise and concern.
vi: Jane looked at Elizabeth with astonishment and concern.
tr: Jane looked at Elizabeth with astonishment and concern.
es: Jane looked at Elizabeth with astonishment and interest.

en: She knew but little of their meeting in Derbyshire, and therefore felt for the awkwardness which must attend her sister, in seeing him almost for the first time after receiving his explanatory letter.
vi: She knew little about their meeting in Derbyshire, so she felt embarrassed for her sister now meeting him for the first time since receiving his explanatory letter.
tr: She didn't know much about their meeting in Derbyshire, so she felt the tension her sister must have experienced almost for the first time since receiving her explanatory letter.
es: She knew very little about her encounter in Derbyshire and, consequently, understood the horror that seeing Darcy almost for the first time after the clarifying letter must have caused her sister.

en: Both sisters were uncomfortable enough.
vi: Both sisters were confused.
tr: Both sisters were quite uncomfortable.
es: The two sisters were quite uneasy; each suffered for the other, and naturally, for herself.
