en: Each felt for the other, and of course for themselves; and their mother talked on of her dislike of mr Darcy, and her resolution to be civil to him only as mr Bingley’s friend, without being heard by either of them.
vi: Each worried about the other, while they did not hear their mother rambling on about her dislike for Mr. Darcy and her intention to be polite to him only because he was Mr. Bingley's friend.
tr: They were excited both for each other and for themselves; meanwhile, their mother was berating Mr. Darcy, saying that the only reason she decided to be kind to him, without either of them hearing, was because he was Mr. Bingley's friend.
es: Meanwhile, the mother continued to rant about her hatred for Darcy and her decision to be courteous to him only out of consideration for Bingley. None of the girls were listening to her.

en: But Elizabeth had sources of uneasiness which could not yet be suspected by Jane, to whom she had never yet had courage to show ms Gardiner’s letter, or to relate her own change of sentiment towards him.
vi: But Elizabeth had another reason for her confusion that Jane did not know, as she had not yet had the courage to show her sister Mrs. Gardiner's letter or to recount the changes in her feelings towards Mr. Darcy.
tr: But Elizabeth's discomfort had reasons that Jane could not guess; Elizabeth had not yet found the courage to show her Mrs. Gardiner's letter or to explain the change in her feelings towards Darcy.
es: Elizabeth was troubled by something Jane could not suspect, as she had never dared to show her Mrs. Gardiner's letter, nor to reveal the change in her feelings for Darcy.

en: To Jane, he could be only a man whose proposals she had refused, and whose merits she had undervalued; but to her own more extensive information, he was the person to whom the whole family were indebted for the first of benefits, and whom she regarded herself with an interest, if not quite so tender, at least as reasonable and just, as what Jane felt for Bingley.
vi: To Jane, he was merely the man who had proposed to her sister and been rejected; but to her, he was the man to whom the whole family owed a debt, the man she cared about, if not as passionately as Jane did for Mr. Bingley, then at least as reasonably and justifiably.
tr: To Jane, he could only be a man whose proposal she had rejected and whose worth she had not appreciated; but Elizabeth knew well that he was the man to whom the whole family owed gratitude, and she felt a reasonable and justified affection for him, if not quite love, at least as much as Jane felt for Bingley.
es: To Jane, Darcy was nothing more than the man whose proposals Elizabeth had rejected and whose merits she had undervalued. But to Elizabeth, Darcy was the man to whom her family owed the greatest of favors, and whom she regarded with an interest, if not as tender, at least as reasonable and just as the one Jane felt for Bingley.

en: Her astonishment at his coming—at his coming to Netherfield, to Longbourn, and voluntarily seeking her again, was almost equal to what she had known on first witnessing his altered behaviour in Derbyshire.
vi: Her astonishment at seeing him come – coming to Netherfield, to Longbourn, and voluntarily seeking her out again – was nearly equal to her astonishment at his changed demeanor in Derbyshire.
tr: His arrival – his arrival at Netherfield, at Longbourn, and his voluntary search for her again – astonished her as much as when she first witnessed the change in his behavior in Derbyshire.
es: Her astonishment at Darcy's coming to Netherfield, to Longbourn, seeking her again voluntarily, was almost equal to what she experienced upon seeing him so changed in Derbyshire.

en: The colour which had been driven from her face returned for half a minute with an additional glow, and a smile of delight added lustre to her eyes, as she thought for that space of time that his affection and wishes must still be unshaken; but she would not be secure.
vi: Her face turned pale for a moment, then became rosy again with a hint of blush, and a smile made her eyes sparkle even more as she thought of his feelings and wishes changing in Derbyshire.
tr: The color that had left her face returned half a minute later with an added brightness, and at that moment, thinking that Darcy's interest and dreams must still be alive, a smile of delight added a sparkle to her eyes. But she couldn't be sure.
es: The color, which had disappeared from her countenance, rushed violently to her cheeks, and a smile of pleasure brightened her eyes at the thought that Darcy's affection and desires remained the same. But she did not want to take it for granted.

en: “Let me first see how he behaves,” said she; “it will then be early enough for expectation.”
vi: She told herself: "First, let's see how he behaves, then there will still be time for wishes."
tr: "Let me first see how he behaves," he said; "it is still too early to hope for more."
es: "First, I will see how he behaves," he said to himself, "and then God will decide if I can have hopes."

en: She sat intently at work, striving to be composed, and without daring to lift up her eyes, till anxious curiosity carried them to the face of her sister as the servant was approaching the door.
vi: She sat attentively continuing the work she was doing, trying to stay calm, not daring to look up, until out of curiosity she looked at her sister's face, while a servant was approaching the room.
tr: She resolutely set to her crochet work, trying to appear busy, not daring to lift her eyes, until, as the servant approached the door, a curiosity filled with unease carried her eyes to her sister's face.
es: He set to work attentively and strove to remain calm. He did not dare to raise his eyes until his growing curiosity made him look at his sister when the maid went to open the door.

en: Jane looked a little paler than usual, but more sedate than Elizabeth had expected.
vi: Jane appeared slightly pale, but calmer than she thought.
tr: Jane looked paler than usual, but calmer than Elizabeth had expected.
es: Jane was paler than usual, but calmer than Elizabeth had believed.

en: On the gentlemen’s appearing, her colour increased; yet she received them with tolerable ease, and with a propriety of behaviour equally free from any symptom of resentment, or any unnecessary complaisance.
vi: When the two men entered, her face turned even redder, however, she greeted them with a moderate calmness, showing no signs of anger or excessive warmth.
tr: When the gentlemen appeared, her color heightened, yet she greeted them quite comfortably, with a dignified demeanor that showed neither any sign of resentment nor unnecessary joy.
es: When the two gentlemen entered, she blushed, but received them quite calmly, without showing any sign of resentment or unnecessary complacency.

en: Elizabeth said as little to either as civility would allow, and sat down again to her work, with an eagerness which it did not often command.
vi: Elizabeth only spoke a few words to everyone as social etiquette required, then sat down to continue her unfinished work, with her usual unnecessary eagerness.
tr: Elizabeth spoke to both of them only as much as politeness required and returned to her work with an attention that was not at all necessary for the task.
es: Elizabeth spoke to the two young men as little as politeness allowed, and devoted herself to her embroidery with more application than ever.

en: She had ventured only one glance at Darcy.
vi: She only glanced at Mr. Darcy once.
tr: She had dared to glance at Darcy only once.
es: She only ventured to cast a glance at Darcy.

en: He looked serious as usual; and, she thought, more as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, than as she had seen him at Pemberley.
vi: He was as solemn as ever, and she thought, more solemn than when he first came to Hertfordshire rather than when she met him at Pemberley.
tr: He looked as serious as ever; just as he appeared in Hertfordshire, she thought, rather than how he looked at Pemberley.
es: He was as serious as always, and it seemed to her that he resembled more the Darcy she had known in Hertfordshire than the one she had seen at Pemberley.

en: But, perhaps, he could not in her mother’s presence be what he was before her uncle and aunt.
vi: But, perhaps with the presence of his mother, he could not be himself as he was when he faced his uncle and aunt.
tr: But perhaps he couldn't be the same around his mother as he was around her uncle and aunt.
es: But perhaps in the presence of his mother, he did not feel the same as in the presence of her uncles.

en: It was a painful, but not an improbable, conjecture.
vi: This was a painful speculation but not without basis.
tr: It was a painful, but not impossible, conjecture.
es: It was a painful supposition, but not an improbable one.

en: Bingley she had likewise seen for an instant, and in that short period saw him looking both pleased and embarrassed.
vi: She also glanced at Bingley for a moment; seeing him display both joy and confusion.
tr: She had also seen Bingley for a moment, and in that short time, she saw that he was both pleased and uncomfortable.
es: He also glanced at Bingley for a moment, and it seemed to him that he was both happy and embarrassed at the same time.

en: He was received by ms Bennet with a degree of civility which made her two daughters ashamed, especially when contrasted with the cold and ceremonious politeness of her courtesy and address of his friend.
vi: Mrs. Bennet received him with polite manners, which embarrassed her two daughters, especially when she adopted a cold and formal demeanor while conversing with his friend.
tr: They had been greeted by Mrs. Bennet with a politeness that embarrassed her two daughters, especially when compared to the cold and formal politeness in her curtsy and conversation with his friend.
es: Mrs. Bennet received him with such fuss that it left her two daughters embarrassed, especially due to the contrast with her cold and ceremonious manner of greeting and treating Darcy.

en: Elizabeth particularly, who knew that her mother owed to the latter the preservation of her favourite daughter from irremediable infamy, was hurt and distressed to a most painful degree by a distinction so ill applied.
vi: Especially Elizabeth, because she knew her mother was grateful to Mr. Darcy for helping her beloved daughter avoid disgrace, felt sorrowful to the point of almost being in pain when she saw how clumsily her mother had shown favoritism.
tr: Elizabeth, knowing that her mother owed Darcy for protecting her favorite daughter from an irreparable disgrace, was deeply hurt and ashamed by such a grave misjudgment.
es: Particularly Elizabeth, knowing that her mother owed Darcy the salvation of her favorite daughter from such irremediable infamy, was deeply saddened by that rudeness.

en: Darcy, after inquiring of her how mr and ms Gardiner did—a question which she could not answer without confusion—said scarcely anything.
vi: Darcy inquired about Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, a question which she could not answer fluently, and then he did not ask much more.
tr: After Darcy asked her how Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were and received a vague answer, he didn't say much.
es: Darcy asked how Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were, and Elizabeth answered him with some unease. After that, she barely said anything.

en: He was not seated by her: perhaps that was the reason of his silence; but it had not been so in Derbyshire.
vi: He did not sit next to her, perhaps this was the reason for his silence, but in Derbyshire, he had not been like that.
tr: He wasn't sitting close to her; maybe that was the reason for his silence; but it hadn't been like this in Derbyshire.
es: He was not seated next to Elizabeth, and perhaps this was the reason for his silence; but it was not like this in Derbyshire.

en: There he had talked to her friends when he could not to herself.
vi: There, he could converse with her relatives when he did not know what to say to her.
tr: There, when he couldn't talk to her, he had talked to his friends.
es: There, when he couldn't talk to her, he spoke with his friends; but now several minutes passed without his voice being heard, and when Elizabeth, unable to contain her curiosity, looked up at him, she found him more frequently looking at Jane than at her, and often only looking at the ground.

en: But now several minutes elapsed, without bringing the sound of his voice; and when occasionally, unable to resist the impulse of curiosity, she raised her eyes to his face, she as often found him looking at Jane as at herself, and frequently on no object but the ground.
vi: But a few minutes passed and he still did not say anything. A few times, unable to restrain her curiosity, she glanced up at him, sometimes seeing him looking at Jane or at her, often looking down at the ground.
tr: But now, a few minutes had passed without his voice being heard; occasionally, when she couldn't resist her curiosity and raised her eyes to his face, she found him looking at Jane as much as at herself, and often with his eyes cast down.
es: There, when he couldn't talk to her, he spoke with his friends; but now several minutes passed without his voice being heard, and when Elizabeth, unable to contain her curiosity, looked up at him, she found him more frequently looking at Jane than at her, and often only looking at the ground.

en: More thoughtfulness and less anxiety to please, than when they last met, were plainly expressed.
vi: Clearly, he appeared thoughtful and unwilling to make a good impression as he had when they last met.
tr: It was clearly expressed that he was more thoughtful and less intent on pleasing than the last time they had met.
es: He seemed more pensive and less eager to please than in their last meeting.

en: She was disappointed, and angry with herself for being so.
vi: She felt disappointed, and angry with herself for feeling disappointed.
tr: Elizabeth was disappointed, and because she was disappointed, she was angry with herself.
es: Elizabeth was disappointed and displeased with herself because of it.

en: “Could I expect it to be otherwise?” said she.
vi: She thought: "I can wish for the opposite!"
tr: "Could I have expected it to be any different!" he said.
es: "How could I imagine it would be any different?" he said to himself.

en: “Yet why did he come?”
vi: But why did he come here?
tr: "But then why did he come?"
es: "I don't even know why she came here."

en: She was in no humour for conversation with anyone but himself; and to him she had hardly courage to speak.
vi: She had no spirit to converse with anyone except him, and not much courage to start a conversation with him.
tr: He didn't feel like talking to anyone else, but he didn't have the courage to talk to him either.
es: She had no mood to talk to anyone except him, but she lacked the courage to speak to him.

en: She inquired after his sister, but could do no more.
vi: She inquired about your sister, but didn't know what else to say.
tr: He asked about his sister's well-being, but he couldn't do anything else.
es: She asked him about his sister, but then she didn't know what else to say.

en: “It is a long time, mr Bingley, since you went away,” said ms Bennet.
vi: Mrs. Bennet said: - Mr. Bingley, you have been away for quite some time.
tr: "It's been a long time since you left, Mr. Bingley," said Mrs. Bennet.
es: ––A lot of time has passed, Mr. Bingley, since you left ––said Mrs. Bennet.

en: He readily agreed to it.
vi: He agreed with her.
tr: Mr. Bingley immediately accepted this.
es: ––Indeed ––said Bingley.

en: “I began to be afraid you would never come back again.
vi: - I began to worry that you would never return.
tr: "I was afraid you wouldn't come back again.
es: ––I was beginning to fear ––she continued–– that you would not return.

en: People did say, you meant to quit the place entirely at Michaelmas; but, however, I hope it is not true.
vi: People said you intended to leave for good around the time of Saint Michael's Day, but I still hoped it wasn't true.
tr: Everyone said so, that you were going to leave the house altogether by Michaelmas; but, nevertheless, I hope that is not true.
es: People say that by Saint Michael's day you plan to leave this region; but I hope that's not true.

en: A great many changes have happened in the neighbourhood since you went away.
vi: Many changes have taken place in this area since you left.
tr: Since you left, there have been many changes in our neighborhood.
es: Many things have happened in the neighborhood since you left; Miss Lucas got married and is settled in Hunsford, and one of my daughters also got married.

en: Miss Lucas is married and settled: and one of my own daughters.
vi: Miss Lucas got married and has settled down. And one of my daughters.
tr: Miss Lucas got married and left. One of my daughters as well.
es: Many things have happened in the neighborhood since you left; Miss Lucas got married and is settled in Hunsford, and one of my daughters also got married.

en: I suppose you have heard of it; indeed, you must have seen it in the papers.
vi: I think you have heard; in fact, you might have read the news in the papers.
tr: I assume you have heard; of course, you must have read it in the newspapers.
es: I suppose you must have known, surely you must have read it in the newspapers.

en: It was in the ‘Times’ and the ‘Courier,’ I know; though it was not put in as it ought to be.
vi: The news was published in the Times and the Courier, I know, though not in the right manner.
tr: It was written in the Times and the Courier, but of course, they didn't give it the space it deserved.
es: It was in the Times and in the Courrier, only it wasn't well written.

en: It was only said, ‘Lately, George Wickham, Esq., to Miss Lydia Bennet,’ without there being a syllable said of her father, or the place where she lived, or anything.
vi: The notice only stated “George Wickham, with Miss Lydia Bennet,” without mentioning her father, or her place of residence, or anything like that.
tr: It merely said, ‘Recently, George Wickham and Miss Lydia Bennet,' without a single word about her father or where she was from or anything else.
es: It only said: "Mr. George Wickham married Miss Lydia Bennet," without mentioning her father or where the bride lived or anything.

en: It was my brother Gardiner’s drawing up, too, and I wonder how he came to make such an awkward business of it.
vi: My brother-in-law Gardiner handled this; I don't understand how he could be so clumsy.
tr: It was my brother Gardiner's announcement, moreover; I don't understand how he managed to do such a clumsy job.
es: The notice must have been the work of my brother Gardiner, and I don't understand how he could have done something so curt.

en: Did you see it?”
vi: Did you read the news?
tr: Did you see it?"
es: Did you see it?

en: Bingley replied that he did, and made his congratulations.
vi: - Mr. Bingley replied that he had read it and offered his congratulations.
tr: Bingley said he saw it and offered his congratulations.
es: Bingley replied that he did and congratulated her.

en: Elizabeth dared not lift up her eyes.
vi: Elizabeth did not dare to look up, so she could not know Mr. Darcy's reaction.
tr: Elizabeth did not dare to lift her eyes.
es: Elizabeth did not dare to raise her eyes and could not see what expression Darcy had.

en: How mr Darcy looked, therefore, she could not tell.
vi: Elizabeth did not dare to look up, so she could not know Mr. Darcy's reaction.
tr: Therefore, she could not understand how Mr. Darcy looked.
es: Elizabeth did not dare to raise her eyes and could not see what expression Darcy had.

en: “It is a delightful thing, to be sure, to have a daughter well married,” continued her mother; “but at the same time, mr Bingley, it is very hard to have her taken away from me.
vi: The mother continued: - It is truly joyful to see a daughter have a good marriage, but Mr. Bingley, at the same time, it is truly sad to see her have to live far from me.
tr: "It is a very nice thing for a girl to make a good marriage," her mother continued, "but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very hard for me that she has to go so far away.
es: ––It is delightful to have a well-married daughter ––she continued saying––, but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very hard that she has gone so far away.

en: They are gone down to Newcastle, a place quite northward it seems, and there they are to stay, I do not know how long.
vi: They are going to Newcastle, quite far to the North, and they will settle there, because I think you have heard about him leaving the militia to join the army.
tr: They went to Newcastle, which I believe is quite far north, who knows how long they will stay there.
es: They have moved to Newcastle, which is very far North, I believe, and they will be there for I don't know how long.

en: His regiment is there; for I suppose you have heard of his leaving the ——shire, and of his being gone into the Regulars.
vi: They are going to Newcastle, quite far to the North, and they will settle there, because I think you have heard about him leaving the militia to join the army.
tr: His regiment is there; because I suppose you have heard that he left the --------shire regiment and joined the regular army.
es: My son-in-law's regiment is stationed there, because you may have heard that he has left the county garrison and has joined the regulars.

en: Thank heaven!
vi: Thank God!
tr: Thank God! he has some friends, perhaps not as many as he deserves."
es: Thank God he still has some friends, although perhaps not as many as he deserves.

en: he has some friends, though, perhaps, not so many as he deserves.”
vi: He also has a few friends, though perhaps not many who are worthy of him.
tr: Thank God! he has some friends, perhaps not as many as he deserves."
es: Thank God he still has some friends, although perhaps not as many as he deserves.

en: Elizabeth, who knew this to be levelled at mr Darcy, was in such misery of shame that she could hardly keep her seat.
vi: Elizabeth understood that she was referring to Mr. Darcy, and she felt so miserable with embarrassment that she almost didn't want to sit back down.
tr: Knowing that this was directed at Mr. Darcy, Elizabeth was in such miserable shame that she could barely stay in her place.
es: Elizabeth, knowing that this was directed at Darcy, felt so embarrassed that she could barely stay in her chair.

en: It drew from her, however, the exertion of speaking, which nothing else had so effectually done before; and she asked Bingley whether he meant to make any stay in the country at present.
vi: However, this made her try harder to continue the conversation, and she asked Bingley if he intended to stay here.
tr: On the other hand, this forced her to speak, as nothing else could have had such an effect; she asked Bingley if he was planning to stay in the countryside for a long time.
es: However, she made a supreme effort to speak and asked Bingley if he planned to stay in the countryside for long.

en: A few weeks, he believed.
vi: He replied that he would stay for a few weeks.
tr: A few weeks, said Bingley.
es: He replied that a few weeks.

en: “When you have killed all your own birds, mr Bingley,” said her mother, “I beg you will come here and shoot as many as you please on mr Bennet’s manor.
vi: The mother said: - When you have shot all your birds, I invite you to come here and shoot as much as you like in Mr. Bennet's estate.
tr: "When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley," said his mother, "please come here and shoot as many birds as you like on Mr. Bennet's estate.
es: ––When you have killed all your birds, Mr. Bingley ––said Mrs. Bennet––, come and kill all you want on my husband's property.

en: I am sure he will be vastly happy to oblige you, and will save all the best of the coveys for you.”
vi: I am sure he will be very happy to accommodate you and will provide every convenience for you.
tr: I am sure he will be exceedingly happy to host you and will reserve all the best partridges for you."
es: I am sure he will be very pleased and will reserve his best nests for you.

en: Elizabeth’s misery increased at such unnecessary, such officious attention!
vi: Elizabeth felt even more miserable because of such unnecessary and intrusive concern!
tr: In the face of such unnecessary, such absurd interest, Elizabeth's embarrassment increased even more!
es: Elizabeth's discomfort increased with such unnecessary and officious attention.

en: Were the same fair prospect to arise at present, as had flattered them a year ago, everything, she was persuaded, would be hastening to the same vexatious conclusion.
vi: She thought that now, even if she had as many desires as she did a year ago, which had made them proud, everything would still quickly lead to a sorrowful end.
tr: She believed that if the same good chance that had come their way a year ago were to arise now, everything would quickly lead to the same painful outcome.
es: She had no doubt that all those illusions that were reborn after a year would end again in the same way.

en: At that instant she felt, that years of happiness could not make Jane or herself amends for moments of such painful confusion.
vi: At that moment, she felt that many years of happiness could not compensate for Jane or herself for those moments of such painful endings.
tr: At that moment, she felt that even years of happiness would not be able to erase these bitter moments of shame for Jane and herself.
es: She thought that entire years of happiness could not compensate her and Jane for those moments of painful confusion.

en: “The first wish of my heart,” said she to herself, “is never more to be in company with either of them.
vi: She whispered to herself: "The first desire of my heart is to never get close to either of these two people.
tr: "My only wish," he said to himself, "is to no longer be near any of them.
es: “I desire only one thing,” he said to himself, “and that is to never see either of these two men again.

en: Their society can afford no pleasure that will atone for such wretchedness as this!
vi: Forming a relationship with them cannot create the joy that could soothe such restlessness.
tr: Their presence cannot provide the happiness to compensate for such shame!
es: All the pleasure their company might provide is not enough to compensate for this shame.

en: Let me never see either one or the other again!”
vi: Please don't let me meet these two people again!"
tr: I don't want to see either of them ever again!"
es: I wish I never had to meet them again!”

en: Yet the misery, for which years of happiness were to offer no compensation, received soon afterwards material relief, from observing how much the beauty of her sister rekindled the admiration of her former lover.
vi: However, the distress, which many years of happiness could not compensate for, was soon alleviated when she saw that her sister's beauty had rekindled the affection of her former lover.
tr: Nevertheless, the feeling that years of happiness could not compensate was considerably alleviated when she saw that her sister's beauty rekindled the admiration of her former lover.
es: But that misfortune, which years of happiness could not compensate for, was somewhat alleviated shortly after by noticing that her sister's beauty once again awakened the admiration of her former suitor.

en: When first he came in, he had spoken to her but little, but every five minutes seemed to be giving her more of his attention.
vi: When he first entered, he only had a brief conversation with Jane, but gradually he paid more and more attention to her.
tr: When Bingley first entered, he had spoken very little with her; but every five minutes, he seemed to pay her more attention.
es: At first, Bingley spoke very little with Jane, but with each moment he seemed more captivated by her.

en: He found her as handsome as she had been last year; as good-natured, and as unaffected, though not quite so chatty.
vi: He found her as pretty as the previous year, still gentle, still calm, though she spoke less than before.
tr: He found her as beautiful as last year, as harmonious and at ease; though perhaps not as talkative.
es: He found her as beautiful as the previous year, as sensitive and as affable, though not as talkative.

en: Jane was anxious that no difference should be perceived in her at all, and was really persuaded that she talked as much as ever; but her mind was so busily engaged, that she did not always know when she was silent.
vi: Jane deliberately acted as if there were no changes in her, believing that she was still as lively in conversation as she used to be. But her mind was always in turmoil, to the point that sometimes she didn't realize she was being silent.
tr: Jane feared that Bingley would find no change in her and truly believed she was talking as much as ever. But her mind was so full that she was not always aware of her silence.
es: Jane wished that no change would be noticed in her and believed she spoke as always, but her mind was so occupied that sometimes she did not realize her silence.

en: When the gentlemen rose to go away, ms Bennet was mindful of her intended civility, and they were invited and engaged to dine at Longbourn in a few days’ time.
vi: When the two gentlemen stood up to leave, Mrs. Bennet remembered the courtesy she had planned, so she invited them to dinner in a few days.
tr: When the gentlemen rose, Mrs. Bennet remembered the courtesy she had planned; they were invited to dine at Longbourn and agreed on a date a few days later.
es: When the gentlemen rose to leave, Mrs. Bennet did not forget her planned invitation. The two young men accepted, and it was agreed that they would dine at Longbourn in a few days.

en: “You are quite a visit in my debt, mr Bingley,” she added; “for when you went to town last winter, you promised to take a family dinner with us as soon as you returned.
vi: She added: Mr. Bingley, you still owe us a visit, because when you went to the city last winter, you promised to attend a family dinner with us as soon as you returned.
tr: "You owe me a visit, Mr. Bingley," she added, "because when you went to the city last winter, you promised to have a family dinner with us as soon as you returned.
es: ––You owed me a visit, Mr. Bingley,–– added Mrs. Bennet––, for when you went to the capital last winter, you promised to dine with us as soon as you returned.

en: I have not forgot, you see; and I assure you I was very much disappointed that you did not come back and keep your engagement.”
vi: You see, I haven't forgotten, and please believe that I will be very disappointed if you do not come back and keep your promise.
tr: You see, I haven't forgotten; and believe me, I was very hurt that you didn't keep your word when you came back."
es: You see, I have not forgotten. I was very upset that you did not come back to fulfill your commitment.

en: Bingley looked a little silly at this reflection, and said something of his concern at having been prevented by business.
vi: Bingley looked a bit absent-minded with this recollection, and mentioned some concern, as he had to attend to business.
tr: Bingley was a bit dumbfounded by these words and complained about being hindered by work and such.
es: Bingley seemed a little puzzled by that remark, and said he was very sorry, but that his affairs had detained him.

en: They then went away.
vi: Then they left.
tr: Then they left. Mrs.
es: Darcy and he left.

en: ms Bennet had been strongly inclined to ask them to stay and dine there that day; but, though she always kept a very good table, she did not think anything less than two courses could be good enough for a man on whom she had such anxious designs, or satisfy the appetite and pride of one who had ten thousand a year.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was very eager to keep them and invite them to dinner that very day, but although she always prepared a decent table, she thought there should be at least two main courses to befit a person for whom she had such ardent designs, or to satisfy the appetite and pride of a person with an income of ten thousand a year.
tr: Bennet very much wanted to invite them to stay for dinner that day, but although her table was always quite good, she thought that less than two courses would not be enough to please a man about whom she had such enthusiastic plans or to satisfy the appetite and pride of another who earned ten thousand a year.
es: Mrs. Bennet had been on the verge of inviting them to dine that very day, but despite the fact that one always ate well in her house, she did not believe that two courses would in any way be sufficient for a man who inspired such ambitious projects in her, nor to satisfy the appetite and pride of another who had ten thousand pounds a year in income.

en: CHAPTER LIV.
vi: Chapter 54
tr: Chapter XII
es: CHAPTER LIV

en: AS soon as they were gone, Elizabeth walked out to recover her spirits; or, in other words, to dwell without interruption on those subjects which must deaden them more.
vi: As soon as they left, Elizabeth walked out of the room to regain her composure, or in other words, to reflect on the events that had further clouded her mind.
tr: As soon as the guests left, Elizabeth went outside to lift her spirits, or in other words, to think uninterruptedly about matters that would further dampen her mood.
es: As soon as they left, Elizabeth went for a walk to recover her spirits or, rather, to ponder the cause that had made her lose them.

en: mr Darcy’s behaviour astonished and vexed her.
vi: Mr. Darcy's attitude surprised and annoyed her.
tr: Mr. Darcy's behavior had upset and distressed her.
es: Darcy's behavior had her astonished and angry.

en: “Why, if he came only to be silent, grave, and indifferent,” said she, “did he come at all?”
vi: She thought: "If he comes only to remain silent, solemn, and aloof, then why come at all?"
tr: "If he only came to be silent, serious, indifferent," he said, "why did he come?"
es: Why did he come ––she asked herself–– to be silent, serious, and indifferent?

en: She could settle it in no way that gave her pleasure.
vi: She didn't find any explanation that made her happy.
tr: He couldn't give a response that would please him.
es: He couldn't explain it to her satisfactorily.

en: “He could be still amiable, still pleasing to my uncle and aunt, when he was in town; and why not to me?
vi: ”You are still charming, still able to win over your uncle and aunt when you are in the city, so why seek me out?
tr: "While in the city, he was still polite and warm towards my uncle and aunt, so why isn't he like that towards me?
es: “If he could be kind and accommodating with my uncles in London, why not with me?

en: If he fears me, why come hither?
vi: If you no longer care about me, why remain silent?
tr: If he's afraid of me, why did he come here?
es: If he feared me, why did he come?

en: If he no longer cares for me, why silent?
vi: If you no longer care about me, why remain silent?
tr: If he doesn't care about me, why did he sit down and stay quiet?
es: And if he no longer cares about me, why was he so quiet?

en: Teasing, teasing man!
vi: Teasing and teasing, this guy!
tr: What an exasperating man!
es: What an irritating man!

en: I will think no more about him.”
vi: I shouldn't think about him anymore.”
tr: I won't think about him anymore."
es: I don't want to think about him anymore.”

en: Her resolution was for a short time involuntarily kept by the approach of her sister, who joined her with a cheerful look which showed her better satisfied with their visitors than Elizabeth.
vi: She could only maintain her intention for a moment, because her sister had approached with a cheerful demeanor, indicating that she was more pleased with the two guests than Elizabeth was.
tr: With her sister's arrival, she involuntarily adhered to her decision for a short while; Jane joined her with a cheerful demeanor that showed she was more pleased with the guests than Elizabeth.
es: Involuntarily, she maintained this resolution for a while, because her sister approached, whose cheerful appearance showed that she was more satisfied with the visit than she was.

en: “Now,” said she, “that this first meeting is over, I feel perfectly easy.
vi: She said: - Now that the first reunion is over, she feels completely relieved.
tr: "Now that I've gotten through this first encounter," he said, "I feel quite comfortable.
es: ––Now ––she said to him––, after this first encounter, I feel completely calm.

en: I know my own strength, and I shall never be embarrassed again by his coming.
vi: She knows her own determination well, and she will never be flustered when he comes.
tr: I know my own strength; his arrival won't bother me anymore.
es: I know that I am strong and that I will no longer be flustered in front of him.

en: I am glad he dines here on Tuesday.
vi: She is happy that he accepted the invitation to dinner on Tuesday.
tr: I'm glad he's coming for dinner on Tuesday.
es: I'm glad he's coming to dinner on Tuesday, because that way it will be clear that we treat each other simply as indifferent friends.

en: It will then be publicly seen, that on both sides we meet only as common and indifferent acquaintance.”
vi: At that time, everyone will see that they meet each other just like two ordinary and carefree acquaintances.
tr: Everyone will see, we both come together as ordinary, indifferent friends."
es: I'm glad he's coming to dinner on Tuesday, because that way it will be clear that we treat each other simply as indifferent friends.

en: “Yes, very indifferent, indeed,” said Elizabeth, laughingly.
vi: Elizabeth smiled and said: - Yes, truly very carefree.
tr: "Yes, quite indifferent," said Elizabeth, laughing.
es: ––Yes, very indifferent ––replied Elizabeth, laughing––.

en: “Oh, Jane! take care.”
vi: Hey Jane, be cautious!
tr: "Oh Jane, be careful."
es: Oh, Jane! Be careful!

en: “My dear Lizzy, you cannot think me so weak as to be in danger now.”
vi: - Dear Lizzy, you should not think that I am so weak as to be in danger.
tr: "My dear Lizzy, you can't think I'm that weak, the danger has passed for me."
es: ––Lizzy, dear, you are not going to believe that I am so weak as to be in any danger.

en: “I think you are in very great danger of making him as much in love with you as ever.”
vi: - I think there is a great risk that you will make him love you even more. *
tr: "I think you're in real danger now, you're making him fall in love with you again." -------------------------
es: ––I think you are in a very big one, because he loves you as always.

en: They did not see the gentlemen again till Tuesday; and ms Bennet, in the meanwhile, was giving way to all the happy schemes which the good-humour and common politeness of Bingley, in half an hour’s visit, had revived.
vi: During the time until Tuesday, they did not see him again, and Mrs. Bennet was busy with all sorts of happy calculations, rekindled by Mr. Bingley's cheerful and polite demeanor during his half-hour visit.
tr: They did not see their gentlemen again until Tuesday; meanwhile, Mrs. Bennet once more indulged herself in all those happy dreams brought to life by Bingley's cheerfulness and indiscriminate politeness during his half-hour visit.
es: They did not see Bingley again until Tuesday, and in the meantime, Mrs. Bennet indulged in all the hopeful plans that the gentleman's joy and constant sweetness had revived in her during half an hour of visit.

en: On Tuesday there was a large party assembled at Longbourn; and the two who were most anxiously expected, to the credit of their punctuality as sportsmen, were in very good time.
vi: On Tuesday, quite a few people were invited to Longbourn. The two young men, eagerly awaited, arrived on time like athletes.
tr: On Tuesday, a large gathering took place at Longbourn; the two most eagerly awaited individuals arrived right on time, not disappointing the confidence placed in their punctuality.
es: On Tuesday, a large group of people gathered at Longbourn, and the gentlemen who were most eagerly awaited arrived with perfect punctuality.

en: When they repaired to the dining-room, Elizabeth eagerly watched to see whether Bingley would take the place which, in all their former parties, had belonged to him, by her sister.
vi: As they entered the dining room, Elizabeth anxiously observed whether Mr. Bingley would choose his usual seat next to her sister, as he had done in previous gatherings.
tr: As they moved to the dining room, Elizabeth watched with excitement to see if Bingley would sit in the place that used to be his during previous parties, next to her sister.
es: When they entered the dining room, Elizabeth watched Bingley closely to see if he would take the place that had always been his at previous meals next to her sister; her prudent mother, thinking the same, was very careful not to invite him to sit next to her.

en: Her prudent mother, occupied by the same ideas, forbore to invite him to sit by herself.
vi: The cautious mother, with the same thought in mind, patiently invited him to sit next to her.
tr: Her shrewd mother, who had the same thought, restrained herself from inviting him to sit there.
es: When they entered the dining room, Elizabeth watched Bingley closely to see if he would take the place that had always been his at previous meals next to her sister; her prudent mother, thinking the same, was very careful not to invite him to sit next to her.

en: On entering the room, he seemed to hesitate; but Jane happened to look round, and happened to smile: it was decided.
vi: As he stepped in, he seemed hesitant, but Jane was looking around and smiling; thus, it was favorable.
tr: When Bingley entered the room, he seemed to hesitate; but Jane looked around and smiled: the decision was made.
es: Bingley seemed to hesitate, but Jane happened to smile around the room, and the matter was settled: Bingley sat next to Jane.

en: He placed himself by her.
vi: He sat down next to her.
tr: Bingley settled next to Jane.
es: Bingley seemed to hesitate, but Jane happened to smile around the room, and the matter was settled: Bingley sat next to Jane.

en: Elizabeth, with a triumphant sensation, looked towards his friend.
vi: Elizabeth felt triumphant and looked towards his friend.
tr: Elizabeth looked at Bingley's friend with a sense of triumph.
es: Elizabeth, with triumphant satisfaction, looked at Darcy.

en: He bore it with noble indifference; and she would have imagined that Bingley had received his sanction to be happy, had she not seen his eyes likewise turned towards mr Darcy, with an expression of half-laughing alarm.
vi: The gentleman displayed an air of indifference in a noble manner, and she would have thought he acknowledged that Bingley deserved happiness, if she had not seen his eyes also directed towards Mr. Darcy, with a look half anxious, half playful.
tr: Darcy met this situation with noble indifference; Elizabeth would have thought that Bingley had received permission to be happy, but she saw that his eyes also turned towards Darcy, with an expression of semi-joking fear.
es: He met her gaze with noble indifference; Elizabeth would have imagined that Bingley had already obtained his friend's permission to enjoy his happiness if she had not caught his eyes also turned towards Darcy, with a smiling but alarmed expression.

en: His behaviour to her sister was such during dinnertime as showed an admiration of her, which, though more guarded than formerly, persuaded Elizabeth, that, if left wholly to himself, Jane’s happiness, and his own, would be speedily secured.
vi: During the meal, Bingley's demeanor showed that he had feelings for Jane, though he was more reserved than before; but Elizabeth still believed that if he were allowed to be natural, their happiness would quickly become solid.
tr: Bingley's behavior towards his sister throughout the meal was so full of admiration that Elizabeth, although more cautious than before, felt that if Bingley were left entirely to his own devices, Jane's happiness, and consequently her own, would be swiftly secured.
es: Bingley's behavior towards Jane during the meal revealed the admiration he felt for her, and although it was more circumspect than before, Elizabeth was convinced that if it depended solely on him, their happiness and Jane's would soon be assured.

en: Though she dared not depend upon the consequence, she yet received pleasure from observing his behaviour.
vi: Although she did not dare to be certain about the future outcome, she was still pleased when observing his attitude.
tr: Even if she did not dare to be certain of the outcome, she took pleasure in observing Bingley's actions.
es: Bingley's behavior towards Jane during the meal revealed the admiration he felt for her, and although it was more circumspect than before, Elizabeth was convinced that if it depended solely on him, their happiness and Jane's would soon be assured.

en: It gave her all the animation that her spirits could boast; for she was in no cheerful humour.
vi: This lifted her spirits, as she had no other joy.
tr: This lifted her spirits somewhat; for she had no cheerfulness.
es: Despite not daring to trust the outcome, Elizabeth was very satisfied and felt as encouraged as her bad mood allowed.

en: mr Darcy was almost as far from her as the table could divide them.
vi: Mr. Darcy sat far from her, next to her mother.
tr: Mr. Darcy was as far away from her as the table could separate them.
es: Darcy was on the other side of the table, seated next to Mrs. Bennet, and Elizabeth understood how unpleasant such an arrangement was for both of them, and how little advantageous it was for anyone.

en: He was on one side of her mother.
vi: Mr. Darcy sat far from her, next to her mother.
tr: He was beside her mother.
es: Darcy was on the other side of the table, seated next to Mrs. Bennet, and Elizabeth understood how unpleasant such an arrangement was for both of them, and how little advantageous it was for anyone.

en: She knew how little such a situation would give pleasure to either, or make either appear to advantage.
vi: She knew that in such a situation, no one would be happy and no one would benefit.
tr: Elizabeth knew that such a position would be unpleasant for both of them and would not even give them the opportunity to behave comfortably.
es: Darcy was on the other side of the table, seated next to Mrs. Bennet, and Elizabeth understood how unpleasant such an arrangement was for both of them, and how little advantageous it was for anyone.

en: She was not near enough to hear any of their discourse; but she could see how seldom they spoke to each other, and how formal and cold was their manner whenever they did.
vi: She did not hear what they exchanged with each other, but she saw that they conversed little, and when they did, each had a serious and cold demeanor.
tr: She was not close enough to hear their conversation, but she could see that they rarely spoke, and when they did, their manner was formal and cold.
es: She was not close enough to hear what they were saying, but she could observe that they hardly spoke to each other and how cold and ceremonious their manners were when they did.

en: Her mother’s ungraciousness made the sense of what they owed him more painful to Elizabeth’s mind; and she would, at times, have given anything to be privileged to tell him, that his kindness was neither unknown nor unfelt by the whole of the family.
vi: Her mother's rudeness made her even more pained when she remembered how much her family owed him. Sometimes she wished to do anything to let him know that not the entire family was unaware or ungrateful for his kindness.
tr: Her mother's ingratitude made the sense of indebtedness to him even more painful for Elizabeth, and sometimes it seemed she would do anything to have the chance to say that not everyone in the family was unaware of or unappreciative of his kindness.
es: This antipathy of her mother towards Darcy made the memory of what everyone owed him more painful for Elizabeth, and there were moments when she would have given anything to be able to say that his kindness was neither unknown nor unappreciated by the entire family.

en: She was in hopes that the evening would afford some opportunity of bringing them together; that the whole of the visit would not pass away without enabling them to enter into something more of conversation, than the mere ceremonious salutation attending his entrance.
vi: She hoped that tonight she and he would have the opportunity to be close to each other, that they could talk more than just exchanging polite greetings when he first arrived.
tr: He held the hope that the evening would give them the opportunity to come together, that the entire visit would not end without providing a chance for conversation beyond the solemn greetings at the entrance.
es: She hoped that the afternoon would give her the opportunity to be by Darcy's side and that the visit would not end without exchanging more than just the simple greeting upon arrival.

en: Anxious and uneasy, the period which passed in the drawing-room before the gentlemen came, was wearisome and dull to a degree that almost made her uncivil.
vi: After the meal, while waiting for the young men to arrive, the time she spent anxiously and uneasily sitting in the living room dragged on in a tiring and tedious manner, to the point that it almost made her impolite.
tr: He was anxious and uncomfortable; the time spent in the living room before the gentlemen arrived was filled with a dullness and tedium that almost led to rudeness.
es: She was so anxious and uneasy that while waiting in the parlor for the gentlemen to enter, her unease almost put her in a bad mood.

en: She looked forward to their entrance as the point on which all her chance of pleasure for the evening must depend.
vi: She longed for them to walk in, the decisive moment to determine whether she would have an enjoyable evening or not.
tr: He eagerly awaited their arrival as the turning point for all the happiness of the evening.
es: Her entire hope for pleasure that afternoon depended on Darcy's presence.

en: “If he does not come to me, then,” said she, “I shall give him up for ever.”
vi: She told herself, "If he doesn't come to me, then I will ignore him."
tr: "If he doesn't come to me then," she said, "I will give up on him forever."
es: "If he doesn't come towards me," she said to herself, "I will give up."

en: The gentlemen came; and she thought he looked as if he would have answered her hopes; but, alas!
vi: The young men came over, and she thought he looked as if he had met all her expectations, but, alas!
tr: The gentlemen arrived; Elizabeth thought Darcy looked as if he might respond to her hopes; but where!
es: The gentlemen entered, and it seemed that Darcy was going to do what she longed for; but unfortunately, the ladies had gathered around the table where Mrs. Bennet was preparing tea and Elizabeth was serving coffee.

en: the ladies had crowded round the table, where Miss Bennet was making tea, and Elizabeth pouring out the coffee, in so close a confederacy, that there was not a single vacancy near her which would admit of a chair.
vi: The ladies had surrounded the table where Miss Bennet was making tea and Elizabeth stood beside her pouring coffee into the cups, leaving no space beside her for a chair.
tr: The ladies had gathered so closely around the table where Miss Bennet was making tea and Elizabeth was serving coffee that there wasn't even enough space for a chair to fit around Elizabeth.
es: They were all so crowded together that there was no free spot beside her nor room for another chair.

en: And on the gentlemen’s approaching, one of the girls moved closer to her than ever, and said, in a whisper,—
vi: As the men approached, one of the girls moved closer to her, whispering: “They cannot come between us, I am determined on that.
tr: Moreover, as the gentlemen approached, one of the girls moved even closer and whispered in her ear,
es: As the gentlemen approached, one of the girls came up to Elizabeth and whispered in her ear:

en: “The men shan’t come and part us, I am determined.
vi: As the men approached, one of the girls moved closer to her, whispering: “They cannot come between us, I am determined on that.
tr: "Men cannot come between us and separate us; I am determined."
es: ––The men will not come to separate us; I have already decided; we don't need them at all, do we?

en: We want none of them; do we?”
vi: We don't want them here, do we?”
tr: "We don't want any of them, right?""
es: ––The men will not come to separate us; I have already decided; we don't need them at all, do we?

en: Darcy had walked away to another part of the room.
vi: Darcy separated himself, going to a corner of the room.
tr: Darcy had walked to another corner of the room.
es: Darcy then went to another part of the room.

en: She followed him with her eyes, envied everyone to whom he spoke, had scarcely patience enough to help anybody to coffee, and then was enraged against herself for being so silly!
vi: She watched him, jealous of everyone he was talking to, almost losing patience to serve coffee to anyone, then angry with herself for acting ridiculous!
tr: Elizabeth followed him with her eyes, envied everyone he spoke to, found it hard to muster the patience to offer coffee to everyone, and then got very angry with herself for being so foolish!
es: Elizabeth watched him and envied everyone he talked to; she could barely muster the patience to serve the coffee, and she became furious with herself for being so foolish.

en: “A man who has once been refused!
vi: "A person who once refused!"
tr: "A man who has been rejected once!
es: “A man whom I have rejected!”

en: How could I ever be foolish enough to expect a renewal of his love?
vi: How could I be so foolish as to expect him to confess his love again?
tr: How could I be so foolish as to expect him to repeat his love?
es: I must be crazy if I expect his love to be rekindled.

en: Is there one among the sex who would not protest against such a weakness as a second proposal to the same woman?
vi: Is there any man who would not reject the demeaning act of confessing love a second time to the same woman?
tr: Is there a single man who would not resist the weakness of proposing to the same woman a second time?
es: There isn't a single man who wouldn't rebel against the weakness of making a second declaration to the same woman.

en: There is no indignity so abhorrent to their feelings.”
vi: According to their psychology, there is no humiliation more dreadful than that!”
tr: There is no other indignity that would hurt their feelings so much!"
es: There is no greater indignity for them.”

en: She was a little revived, however, by his bringing back his coffee-cup himself; and she seized the opportunity of saying,—
vi: However, she was a little excited when he returned his cup himself, and she seized this opportunity to ask him:
tr: Still, his face brightened a bit when he brought the empty coffee cup himself, and he immediately seized the opportunity to speak:
es: She perked up a bit upon seeing Darcy coming to return her coffee cup, and she seized the opportunity to ask him:

en: “Is your sister at Pemberley still?”
vi: - Is your sister still staying at Pembley?
tr: "Is your sister still at Pemberley?"
es: ––Is your sister still at Pemberley?

en: “Yes; she will remain there till Christmas.”
vi: - Yes, she will stay there until Christmas.
tr: "Yes; he will stay there until Christmas"
es: ––Yes, he will be there until Christmas.

en: “And quite alone?
vi: - And lonely?
tr: "All alone?" "Have all his friends left?""
es: ––And are you alone?

en: Have all her friends left her?”
vi: Have all your friends gone home?
tr: "All alone?" "Have all his friends left?""
es: Have all your friends left already?

en: “ms Annesley is with her.
vi: - Mrs. Annesley is staying with her.
tr: "Mrs. Annesley is with her.
es: ––Only Mrs. Annesley is accompanying her; the others have gone to Scarborough to spend these three weeks.

en: The others have been gone on to Scarborough these three weeks.”
vi: The others have gone to Scarborough for these three weeks.
tr: The others have gone to Scarborough for three weeks."
es: ––Only Mrs. Annesley is accompanying her; the others have gone to Scarborough to spend these three weeks.

en: She could think of nothing more to say; but if he wished to converse with her, he might have better success.
vi: She couldn't think of anything else to say, but if he wanted to talk to her, he could do better.
tr: Nothing else came to mind to say; but if Darcy had wanted to chat with him, he could have been more successful.
es: Elizabeth couldn't think of anything else to say, but if he had wanted to talk, how gladly she would have answered him!

en: He stood by her, however, for some minutes, in silence; and, at last, on the young lady’s whispering to Elizabeth again, he walked away.
vi: But he stood by her for a moment in silence, and when the other girl whispered into Elizabeth's ear again, he walked away.
tr: However, he stood silently beside her for a few minutes and finally walked away when the young lady whispered something in Elizabeth's ear.
es: Nevertheless, he stayed by her side for a few minutes, in silence, until the girl from before started whispering to Elizabeth, and then he withdrew.

en: When the tea things were removed, and the card tables placed, the ladies all rose; and Elizabeth was then hoping to be soon joined by him, when all her views were overthrown, by seeing him fall a victim to her mother’s rapacity for whist players, and in a few moments after seated with the rest of the party.
vi: When the tea table was cleared, they laid out the card games, and the ladies all stood up. Elizabeth hoped to be near him again, but all her wishes were overturned when he fell into the greed of his mother, who wanted another player. After a while, he had to sit with them.
tr: When the tea trays were cleared away and the game tables were set up, all the ladies stood up; Elizabeth was expecting that she would come to her side immediately, but then saw that her mother had fallen prey to the whist players' hunt and, a few minutes later, had sat down at the table with the rest of the group, shattering all her hopes.
es: Once the tea service was removed and the game tables were set up, all the ladies stood up. Elizabeth then thought she might be able to be with him, but her hopes were dashed when she saw her mother take hold of Darcy and force him to sit at her whist table.

en: She now lost every expectation of pleasure.
vi: Now she had lost hope for an enjoyable evening.
tr: Now she had lost all hope of happiness.
es: Elizabeth gave up all her illusions.

en: They were confined for the evening at different tables; and she had nothing to hope, but that his eyes were so often turned towards her side of the room, as to make him play as unsuccessfully as herself.
vi: The two were entangled at two different tables, and she no longer had any expectations, except for the occasional glance he cast in her direction, as if to ensure that neither he nor she could fully concentrate on the card games they were playing.
tr: They were confined to different tables throughout the evening, and aside from the frequent glances he cast her way, as if he wished her to be as unsuccessful in the game as he was, there was nothing left for her to hope for.
es: They were confined to different tables all afternoon, but Darcy's eyes turned so often to where she was that both of them lost all their games.

en: ms Bennet had designed to keep the two Netherfield gentlemen to supper; but their carriage was, unluckily, ordered before any of the others, and she had no opportunity of detaining them.
vi: Mrs. Bennet intended to invite the two gentlemen to stay for a late meal, but unfortunately their carriage was called before the others, and she had no opportunity to keep them.
tr: Mrs. Bennet had planned to detain the two gentlemen from Netherfield for dinner; but unfortunately, their carriage had been ordered earlier than the others, so she did not have the opportunity to keep them.
es: Mrs. Bennet had planned for the two gentlemen from Netherfield to stay for dinner, but they were the first to ask for their carriage and there was no way to detain them.

en: “Well, girls,” said she, as soon as they were left to themselves, “what say you to the day?
vi: As soon as all the guests left, she said: - My children, how do you find this evening?
tr: "Well, girls," she said as soon as they were alone. "What do you think of today?
es: ––Well, girls ––said the mother as soon as everyone had left––, what do you say?

en: I think everything has passed off uncommonly well, I assure you.
vi: Mother thinks everything is very beautiful.
tr: I think everything went extraordinarily well.
es: In my view, everything went perfectly today.

en: The dinner was as well dressed as any I ever saw.
vi: The dining table is set exactly as Mother wanted.
tr: The table was beautifully set.
es: The meal was as well presented as the best I've seen; the roasted venison was perfect, and everyone said the haunches were superb; the soup was fifty times better than the one we were served last week at the Lucas's; and even Mr. Darcy acknowledged that the partridges were very well done, and he must have two or three French cooks.

en: The venison was roasted to a turn—and everybody said, they never saw so fat a haunch.
vi: The venison is roasted perfectly, everyone says they've never seen such a plump leg of venison.
tr: The venison was cooked to perfection – everyone said they had never seen such a well-fed leg.
es: The meal was as well presented as the best I've seen; the roasted venison was perfect, and everyone said the haunches were superb; the soup was fifty times better than the one we were served last week at the Lucas's; and even Mr. Darcy acknowledged that the partridges were very well done, and he must have two or three French cooks.

en: The soup was fifty times better than what we had at the Lucases’ last week; and even mr Darcy acknowledged that the partridges were remarkably well done; and I suppose he has two or three French cooks at least.
vi: The soup is ten times better than the soup we had at Lucas's house last week, even Mr. Darcy admitted that the grouse was very delicious, and Mother thinks he has at least two or three French chefs.
tr: The soup was fifty times better than the one we had at the Lucases' last week; even Mr. Darcy said the partridges were marvelous, and he probably has two or three French chefs.
es: The meal was as well presented as the best I've seen; the roasted venison was perfect, and everyone said the haunches were superb; the soup was fifty times better than the one we were served last week at the Lucas's; and even Mr. Darcy acknowledged that the partridges were very well done, and he must have two or three French cooks.

en: And, my dear Jane, I never saw you look in greater beauty.
vi: And, dear Jane, Mother has never seen you as beautiful as today.
tr: Oh Jane, I have never seen you look so beautiful.
es: And, besides, dear Jane, you have never looked prettier than this afternoon; Mrs. Long confirmed it when I asked her opinion.

en: ms Long said so too, for I asked her whether you did not.
vi: Mrs. Long said the same, because Mother asked her how you looked.
tr: Mrs. Long said the same, because I asked her how you looked.
es: And, besides, dear Jane, you have never looked prettier than this afternoon; Mrs. Long confirmed it when I asked her opinion.

en: And what do you think she said besides?
vi: And what do you think she said?
tr: And do you know what else she said?
es: And what do you think she told me, moreover?

en: ‘Ah! ms Bennet, we shall have her at Netherfield at last!’
vi: "Ah! Mrs. Bennet, at last we shall see her settled at Netherfield."
tr: ‘Oh Mrs. Bennet, we will finally see her at Netherfield.'
es: "Oh, Mrs. Bennet, we will finally have her at Netherfield!"

en: She did, indeed.
vi: That's what she said.
tr: She really said that.
es: That's exactly what she said.

en: I do think ms Long is as good a creature as ever lived—and her nieces are very pretty behaved girls, and not at all handsome: I like them prodigiously.”
vi: Mother thinks Mrs. Long is really a good person - and her nieces behave quite well, and are not beautiful at all.
tr: I think Mrs. Long is the best person in the world – her nieces are very well-mannered girls, though they are not at all pretty, but I like them very much."
es: I think Mrs. Long is the best person in the world, and her nieces are very well-mannered girls and not at all unattractive; I like them very much.

en: “ms Long and her nieces.”
vi: Mother likes them very much.
tr: I think Mrs. Long is the best person in the world – her nieces are very well-mannered girls, though they are not at all pretty, but I like them very much."
es: I think Mrs. Long is the best person in the world, and her nieces are very well-mannered girls and not at all unattractive; I like them very much.

en: ms Bennet, in short, was in very great spirits: she had seen enough of Bingley’s behaviour to Jane to be convinced that she would get him at last; and her expectations of advantage to her family, when in a happy humour, were so far beyond reason, that she was quite disappointed at not seeing him there again the next day, to make his proposals.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was completely elated. She had seen Bingley's demeanor towards Jane, enough to make her believe that in the end, she would win his affection. In her high spirits, her expectations far exceeded all reason, to the point where she was quite disappointed not to see him return the next day to propose.
tr: In short, Mrs. Bennet was extremely delighted; she had seen enough of Bingley's behavior towards Jane to be convinced that he would eventually win her over; her expectations regarding her family's happiness, especially when she was in high spirits, were so beyond reason that she was greatly disappointed when she saw that Bingley did not come to propose the next day.
es: All in all, Mrs. Bennet was in a splendid mood. She had observed Bingley's behavior towards Jane enough to convince herself that he was finally going to propose. She was so excited and her fantasies about the great future awaiting her family went so far beyond reason that she was extremely upset when Bingley did not show up the next day to propose.

en: “It has been a very agreeable day,” said Miss Bennet to Elizabeth.
vi: Ms. Bennet said to Elizabeth: - What a pleasant day.
tr: "It was quite a successful day," said Miss Bennet to Elizabeth.
es: ––It has been a very pleasant day ––said Jane to Elizabeth––.

en: “The party seemed so well selected, so suitable one with the other.
vi: Mother chose the guests correctly; everyone gets along with each other.
tr: "The guests were well chosen, everyone was suitable for each other.
es: How select and cordial the party was!

en: I hope we may often meet again.”
vi: She hopes to see them often.
tr: I hope we gather often again."
es: I hope it happens again.

en: Elizabeth smiled.
vi: Elizabeth smiled.
tr: Elizabeth smiled.
es: Elizabeth smiled.

en: “Lizzy, you must not do so.
vi: - Lizzy, don't do that.
tr: "Lizzy, you shouldn't do this.
es: ––Don't laugh.

en: You must not suspect me.
vi: You shouldn't doubt me, making me suffer.
tr: You shouldn't suspect me.
es: ––Don't laugh.

en: It mortifies me.
vi: You shouldn't doubt me, making me suffer.
tr: It bothers me.
es: It hurts me that you are like this, Lizzy.

en: I assure you that I have now learnt to enjoy his conversation as an agreeable and sensible young man without having a wish beyond it.
vi: I want you to believe that now I have learned to take pleasure in conversing with a pleasant and reasonable person without any further expectations.
tr: I've learned to chat with Bingley like with a sensible young man, without imagining anything beyond that, believe me.
es: I assure you that now I have learned to enjoy his conversation and that I see in him nothing but an intelligent and kind young man.

en: I am perfectly satisfied, from what his manners now are, that he never had any design of engaging my affection.
vi: I am completely satisfied with his current attitude, seeing that he never intended to win my affection.
tr: I'm so pleased with his current behavior that he has never tried to win my love.
es: I love his behavior and I don't care that he has never thought of me.

en: It is only that he is blessed with greater sweetness of address, and a stronger desire of generally pleasing, than any other man.”
vi: It's just that compared to anyone else, he becomes more gentle in speech and has a more positive attitude in trying to please others.
tr: It's just that he has a sweeter manner and a stronger desire to please others than anyone else."
es: I only find that his manner is sweet and more attentive than that of any other man.

en: “You are very cruel,” said her sister, “you will not let me smile, and are provoking me to it every moment.”
vi: The younger sister replied: - You are really cruel, you don't want me to laugh, and you keep trying to annoy me like that.
tr: "You are very cruel," said his sister, "you neither allow me to smile, nor do you stop provoking me to smile at every moment."
es: ––You're cruel! ––replied her sister––. You don't let me smile and you're provoking me to do so at every moment.

en: “How hard it is in some cases to be believed!
vi: - In some cases, it is really difficult to get people to believe what you say.
tr: "Sometimes it is so difficult to be convincing!"
es: ––How difficult it is to be believed in some cases!

en: And how impossible in others!
vi: - And in other cases, it is unbelievable!
tr: "Most of the time, how impossible it is!"
es: ––And how impossible in others!

en: But why should you wish to persuade me that I feel more than I acknowledge?”
vi: - But why do you want to persuade me to feel more than what I have already said?
tr: "But why do you want to convince me that I feel more than I say?""
es: ––Why do you insist on convincing me that I feel more than I confess?

en: “That is a question which I hardly know how to answer.
vi: - This is a question I don't know how to answer.
tr: "This is a question whose answer I do not know well either.
es: ––I wouldn't know what to tell you.

en: We all love to instruct, though we can teach only what is not worth knowing.
vi: We all want to give advice, although we can only advise on things that are not worth knowing.
tr: We all love to give advice, but we can only manage to teach things that are not worth knowing.
es: We all like to give lessons, but we only teach what is not worth knowing.

en: Forgive me; and if you persist in indifference, do not make me your confidante.”
vi: Please forgive me, and if you insist on being distant, don't consider me your confidant anymore.
tr: Forgive me; but if you insist on remaining indifferent, at least don't make me your confidant."
es: Forgive me, but if you persist in your indifference, it's better that I not be your confidant.

en: CHAPTER LV.
vi: Chapter 55
tr: Chapter XIII
es: CHAPTER LV

en: A FEW days after this visit, mr Bingley called again, and alone.
vi: A few days later, Mr. Bingley came again, and he came alone.
tr: A few days after this visit, Mr. Bingley called again, alone.
es: A few days after that visit, Bingley returned to Longbourn, alone.

en: His friend had left him that morning for London, but was to return home in ten days’ time.
vi: His friend was busy going to London and would return in ten days.
tr: His friend had left him that morning to go to London, but he would return home within ten days.
es: His friend had gone to London in the morning, but was going to return within ten days.

en: He sat with them above an hour, and was in remarkably good spirits.
vi: He sat and chatted with them for over an hour, in a cheerful spirit.
tr: He sat with them for more than an hour; he was noticeably cheerful.
es: He spent an hour with them and was in excellent spirits.

en: ms Bennet invited him to dine with them; but, with many expressions of concern, he confessed himself engaged elsewhere.
vi: Mrs. Bennet invited him to have dinner with the family, but with a concerned look, he confessed that he was busy elsewhere.
tr: Mrs. Bennet invited him to dinner, but with many expressions of regret, he confessed that he had another engagement.
es: Mrs. Bennet invited him to dinner, Bingley said he was sorry, but he was already engaged elsewhere.

en: “Next time you call,” said she, “I hope we shall be more lucky.”
vi: She said: - When you come next time, I hope we will be luckier.
tr: "Next time you come," he said, "I hope we will be luckier."
es: ––Next time he comes ––replied Mrs. Bennet–– I hope we have better luck. ––I will be very pleased ––replied Bingley.

en: He should be particularly happy at any time, etc., etc.; and if she would give him leave, would take an early opportunity of waiting on them.
vi: He said he would be very pleased to accept at any other time, and if she allowed, he would seize the earliest opportunity to come and converse with them.
tr: Of course, he would be very happy, etc. etc.; but if he was allowed, he would come back to visit them at the first opportunity.
es: And he added that, if they allowed him, he would take any opportunity to visit them.

en: “Can you come to-morrow?”
vi: - Can you come tomorrow?
tr: "Can you come tomorrow?"
es: ––Can you come tomorrow?

en: Yes, he had no engagement at all for to-morrow; and her invitation was accepted with alacrity.
vi: Alright, he is not busy at all tomorrow and eagerly accepts her invitation.
tr: Yes, there was no promise for tomorrow; the invitation was accepted with pleasure.
es: Bingley said yes, as he had no commitments for the next day.

en: He came, and in such very good time, that the ladies were none of them dressed.
vi: He arrived, and arrived early, so early that the girls hadn't had time to dress properly.
tr: He arrived; and he arrived at such a good time that none of the ladies had dressed yet.
es: He arrived so early that none of the ladies were dressed.

en: In ran ms Bennet to her daughters’ room, in her dressing-gown, and with her hair half finished, crying out,—
vi: Mrs. Bennet rushed into her daughter's room, while she was still wearing her outer coat, her hair only half done.
tr: Mrs. Bennet, in her dressing gown, with her hair half done, burst into her daughter's room, screaming.
es: Mrs. Bennet ran to her daughters' room, in her dressing gown and half-combed, exclaiming:

en: “My dear Jane, make haste and hurry down.
vi: - Hey Jane, hurry up so we can go downstairs in time.
tr: "My dear Jane, hurry up, come down quickly.
es: ––Jane, dear, hurry up and go downstairs!

en: He is come—mr Bingley is come.
vi: He has arrived, Mr. Bingley has arrived.
tr: He has arrived. –Mr. Bingley has arrived.
es: Mr. Bingley has come!

en: He is, indeed.
vi: He really has arrived.
tr: –He has arrived, I swear.
es: It's him, without a doubt.

en: Make haste, make haste.
vi: Hurry up, hurry up.
tr: Quick, quick.
es: Come, Sara!

en: Here, Sarah, come to Miss Bennet this moment, and help her on with her gown.
vi: Hey, Sarah, come here right away to help Miss Bennet with her dress.
tr: Come on, Sarah, look after Miss Bennet, help with her dress.
es: Go immediately to help Miss Jane get dressed.

en: Never mind Miss Lizzy’s hair.”
vi: Don't worry about Lizzy's hair.
tr: Forget about Miss Lizzy's hair."
es: Don't worry about Miss Elizabeth's hair.

en: “We will be down as soon as we can,” said Jane; “but I dare say Kitty is forwarder than either of us, for she went upstairs half an hour ago.”
vi: Jane said: - We will come down right away, but I am sure Kitty is ready, as she went upstairs half an hour ago.
tr: "We will go down when we are ready," said Jane; "but I am sure Kitty is ahead of us, she went up half an hour ago."
es: ––We will come down as soon as we can ––said Jane––, but it seems to me that Catherine is ahead of us, because she went up half an hour ago.

en: “Oh! hang Kitty!
vi: - Hmph, never mind Kitty!
tr: "Aman, leave Kitty alone!
es: ––Look at what you're coming up with!

en: what has she to do with it?
vi: What does it have to do with anything!
tr: What does she have to do with it?
es: What does Catherine have to do with this?

en: Come, be quick, be quick!
vi: Hurry up, hurry up!
tr: Hurry up, hurry up!
es: You are the one who should go down immediately.

en: where is your sash, my dear?”
vi: Where's your shawl?
tr: Where is your belt, darling?"
es: Where is your corset?

en: But when her mother was gone, Jane would not be prevailed on to go down without one of her sisters.
vi: But the mother had gone downstairs, Jane did not want to go downstairs without one of her sisters going down with her.
tr: But when her mother left, Jane was unwilling to go downstairs without one of her sisters.
es: But when her mother had gone out, Jane did not want to go downstairs without one of her sisters.

en: The same anxiety to get them by themselves was visible again in the evening.
vi: The same anxious atmosphere was clearly present in the evening.
tr: The effort to leave them alone became evident in the evening as well.
es: In the afternoon, the mother again tried to get Bingley alone with Jane.

en: After tea, mr Bennet retired to the library, as was his custom, and Mary went upstairs to her instrument.
vi: After having tea, Mr. Bennet returned to the study as usual, and Mary went upstairs to practice music.
tr: After tea, Mr. Bennet withdrew to the library as was his custom, and Mary went upstairs to her piano.
es: After tea, Mr. Bennet retired to his library as usual, and Mary went upstairs to play the piano.

en: Two obstacles of the five being thus removed, ms Bennet sat looking and winking at Elizabeth and Catherine for a considerable time, without making any impression on them.
vi: Three of the five obstacles remained. Mrs. Bennet sat watching and winking at Elizabeth and Catherine for a long time without any response.
tr: With two of the five obstacles thus removed, Mrs. Bennet began making facial gestures to Elizabeth and Catherine to seize the opportunity, but they did not notice.
es: With two of the five obstacles gone, Mrs. Bennet began to look around and make signs and winks at Elizabeth and Catherine without them noticing.

en: Elizabeth would not observe her; and when at last Kitty did, she very innocently said, “What is the matter, mamma?
vi: Elizabeth did not want to look at her, and when Kitty finally noticed, she innocently asked: - Mom, what's going on?
tr: Elizabeth was not looking at her; finally, when Kitty saw her, she innocently said, "What is it, mother?
es: Catherine noticed it before Elizabeth and asked quite innocently: ––What’s wrong, Mom?

en: What do you keep winking at me for?
vi: Why do you keep winking at me?
tr: Why do you keep winking at me?
es: Why are you signaling to me?

en: What am I to do?”
vi: What should I do?
tr: What am I supposed to do?"
es: What do you want me to do?

en: “Nothing, child, nothing.
vi: - There's nothing, my child, nothing.
tr: "Nothing, my child, nothing.
es: ––Nothing, girl, nothing.

en: I did not wink at you.”
vi: Mom didn't wink at you.
tr: I didn't wink at you."
es: I wasn't signaling you at all.
