en: She then sat still five minutes longer; but unable to waste such a precious occasion, she suddenly got up, and saying to Kitty,—
vi: Then she sat still for a moment, but not wanting to let such an opportunity go to waste, she suddenly stood up and said to Kitty:
tr: Then he sat motionless for another five minutes; but since he couldn't risk wasting such a valuable opportunity, he suddenly stood up and said to Kitty,
es: She remained seated for five more minutes, but she was unable to waste such a precious opportunity. She suddenly stood up and said to Catherine:

en: “Come here, my love, I want to speak to you,” took her out of the room.
vi: - Come here, my dear, I have something to tell you. Then she led Kitty out of the room.
tr: "Come on, my dear, I want to talk to you," he said and took her out of the room.
es: ––Come, darling. I need to talk to you. And he took her out of the room.

en: Jane instantly gave a look at Elizabeth which spoke her distress at such premeditation, and her entreaty that she would not give in to it.
vi: Jane immediately looked at Elizabeth, showing that she was extremely confused, and she wished her sister wouldn't leave.
tr: Jane immediately gave Elizabeth a look that showed her distress at such a plan and asked her not to allow it.
es: Jane instantly looked at Elizabeth, showing her regret for such a premeditated departure and asking her not to leave.

en: In a few minutes, ms Bennet half opened the door and called out,—
vi: A moment later, she slightly opened the door and called in:
tr: A few minutes later, Mrs. Bennet partially opened the door and called out,
es: But a few minutes later, Mrs. Bennet opened the door and said to Elizabeth:

en: “Lizzy, my dear, I want to speak with you.”
vi: - Lizzy, my dear, I have something to tell you.
tr: "Lizzy, my dear, I want to talk to you."
es: ––Come, dear. I need to talk to you.

en: Elizabeth was forced to go.
vi: Elizabeth had to go out.
tr: Elizabeth had to leave.
es: Elizabeth had no choice but to leave.

en: “We may as well leave them by themselves, you know,” said her mother as soon as she was in the hall.
vi: The mother said, as soon as she reached the hallway:
tr: "We should leave them alone," said her mother as soon as she stepped into the hall.
es: ––Let's leave them alone, do you understand? ––her mother said to her in the hallway––.

en: “Kitty and I are going upstairs to sit in my dressing-room.”
vi: - Of course I know, I need to give you two some privacy. Kitty and mother will sit in the dressing room upstairs.
tr: "Kitty and I are going upstairs, we'll be sitting in my dressing room."
es: Catherine and I are going upstairs to my room.

en: Elizabeth made no attempt to reason with her mother, but remained quietly in the hall till she and Kitty were out of sight, then returned into the drawing-room.
vi: Elizabeth did not want to argue with her mother, but she still stood silently in the hallway until she and Kitty left, then returned to the living room.
tr: Elizabeth did not attempt to argue with her mother; she waited quietly in the hall until she and Kitty were out of sight, then returned to the sitting room.
es: Elizabeth did not dare to argue with her mother; but she stayed in the hall until she saw her disappear with Catherine, and then she returned to the drawing room.

en: ms Bennet’s schemes for this day were ineffectual.
vi: Mrs. Bennet's intentions for the day did not succeed.
tr: Mrs. Bennet's plans for that day were ineffective.
es: Mrs. Bennet's plans did not come to fruition that day.

en: Bingley was everything that was charming, except the professed lover of her daughter.
vi: Bingley was charming in every way except for proposing to her daughter.
tr: Bingley was delightful in every way, except as a potential suitor for her daughter.
es: Bingley was a model of kindness, but not the declared suitor of her daughter.

en: His ease and cheerfulness rendered him a most agreeable addition to their evening party; and he bore with the ill-judged officiousness of the mother, and heard all her silly remarks with a forbearance and command of countenance particularly grateful to the daughter.
vi: His easygoing and cheerful demeanor made the gathering very pleasant. He endured the mother's meddlesome and tactless behavior well, patiently listening to all her absurd remarks with a calm expression, which made the daughter appreciative.
tr: With his ease and cheerfulness, he was a wonderful guest for evening gatherings; he endured the mother's tedious meddling, listened to all her foolish remarks with patience and a dignified expression, and earned her daughter's great admiration.
es: His ease and cheerfulness greatly contributed to the liveliness of the evening gathering; he endured all the mother's indiscretions and impertinences and listened to all her foolish warnings with a patience and serenity that left Jane very pleased.

en: He scarcely needed an invitation to stay supper; and before he went away an engagement was formed, chiefly through his own and ms Bennet’s means, for his coming next morning to shoot with her husband.
vi: He did not need to be invited to stay for a late meal; before he left, he and Mrs. Bennet agreed that he would return the next morning to go hunting with her husband.
tr: He didn't even need to be invited to stay for dinner; before leaving, it was agreed, mostly through his and Mrs. Bennet's efforts, that he would come the next morning to go hunting with her husband.
es: He only needed to be invited to stay for dinner, and before he left, Mrs. Bennet extended a new invitation for him to come the next morning to hunt with her husband.

en: After this day, Jane said no more of her indifference.
vi: After this day, Jane no longer spoke of her coldness.
tr: After that day, Jane never spoke of her indifference again.
es: After this day, Jane no longer said that Bingley was indifferent to her.

en: Not a word passed between the sisters concerning Bingley; but Elizabeth went to bed in the happy belief that all must speedily be concluded, unless mr Darcy returned within the stated time.
vi: The sisters did not say a word to each other about Bingley, but Elizabeth was pleased to think that everything would end well, except that Mr. Darcy would return at the time as announced.
tr: Among the sisters, Bingley's name was not even mentioned; but Elizabeth went to bed with a happy belief that everything would be swiftly resolved if Mr. Darcy did not return on the stated date.
es: The two sisters did not speak a word about him, but Elizabeth went to bed with the happy conviction that everything would soon be resolved, if Darcy did not return before the indicated time.

en: Seriously, however, she felt tolerably persuaded that all this must have taken place with that gentleman’s concurrence.
vi: However, she seriously believed that all this must have happened with his consent.
tr: Seriously, it was as if she believed all this was happening with that gentleman's consent.
es: However, she was seriously convinced that all this would have happened just the same without the absence of said gentleman.

en: Bingley was punctual to his appointment; and he and mr Bennet spent the morning together, as had been agreed on.
vi: Bingley arrived on time, as both parties had promised, and he and Mr. Bennet spent the whole morning together.
tr: Bingley arrived for his appointment right on time; he and Mr. Bennet spent the morning together as planned.
es: Bingley arrived punctually at the appointment, and he and Mr. Bennet spent the morning together as agreed.

en: The latter was much more agreeable than his companion expected.
vi: He appeared more agreeable than Mr. Bennet had thought.
tr: Mr. Bennet was much more agreeable than his hunting companion had expected.
es: Mr. Bennet was much more pleasant than his companion had expected.

en: There was nothing of presumption or folly in Bingley that could provoke his ridicule, or disgust him into silence; and he was more communicative, and less eccentric, than the other had ever seen him.
vi: He showed no signs of boldness or recklessness that would provoke Mr. Bennet to mock him, or cause him to hold him in contempt and remain silent.
tr: In Bingley, there was not the slightest hint of arrogance or foolishness to provoke his sense of mockery or to disgust him into silence; the other was more talkative and less self-absorbed than he had seen him before.
es: There was nothing in Bingley of presumption or foolishness that the other could ridicule or be internally displeased with, so he was more communicative and less surly than usual.

en: Bingley of course returned with him to dinner; and in the evening ms Bennet’s invention was again at work to get everybody away from him and her daughter.
vi: He spoke more lively and maturely than Mr. Bennet had previously seen. Bingley returned with Mr. Bennet for dinner, after which Mrs. Bennet devised all sorts of ways to keep everyone away from him and Jane.
tr: Bingley, of course, returned with him for dinner; in the evening, Mrs. Bennet's wit once again began to work to keep everyone away from Bingley and her daughter.
es: Naturally, Bingley returned with Mr. Bennet to the house for lunch, and in the afternoon, Mrs. Bennet once again schemed to leave him alone with her daughter.

en: Elizabeth, who had a letter to write, went into the breakfast-room for that purpose soon after tea; for as the others were all going to sit down to cards, she could not be wanted to counteract her mother’s schemes.
vi: Right after tea, Elizabeth went into the breakfast room because she needed to write a letter, and since the others had sat down around the card table, she did not want to go against her mother's intentions.
tr: Elizabeth, who had a letter to write, withdrew to the breakfast room right after tea for this purpose; since the others were going to sit down for a card game, her mother's plans could not be opposed.
es: Elizabeth had to write a letter, and for that purpose, she went to the small drawing room shortly after tea, for as the others had sat down to play, her presence was no longer necessary to thwart her mother's plots.

en: But on her returning to the drawing-room, when her letter was finished, she saw, to her infinite surprise, there was reason to fear that her mother had been too ingenious for her.
vi: But after finishing the letter, she returned to the living room and, to her utmost surprise, she found a reason to fear that her mother had been too shrewd.
tr: When the letter was finished and she returned to the living room, she saw with great astonishment that her mother had reason to fear she was too skillful for her.
es: But upon entering the room, after having finished the letter, she saw with infinite surprise that there was reason to fear that her mother had gotten her way.

en: On opening the door, she perceived her sister and Bingley standing together over the hearth, as if engaged in earnest conversation; and had this led to no suspicion, the faces of both, as they hastily turned round and moved away from each other, would have told it all.
vi: When she opened the door, she saw her sister and Mr. Bingley standing together by the fireplace, as if they were having an earnest conversation. If that wasn't enough, their expressions when they hurriedly turned away and moved apart to sit down said it all.
tr: When she opened the door, she saw her sister and Bingley standing in front of the fireplace as if they were engaged in an excited conversation; even if this did not arouse suspicion, their faces as they hurriedly turned and moved away from each other would have been enough to tell everything.
es: Indeed, upon opening the door, she spotted her sister and Bingley alone, leaning against the fireplace as if absorbed in the most interesting conversation; and if this had not already given rise to all suspicions, their faces, as they quickly turned and separated, would have said it all.

en: Their situation was awkward enough; but hers she thought was still worse.
vi: Both looked embarrassed, but she seemed even more awkward.
tr: Their demeanor was quite strange; but Jane's condition seemed even worse.
es: The situation must have been very embarrassing for them, but Elizabeth was about to leave when Bingley, who, like Jane, had sat down, suddenly stood up, whispered a few words in Jane's ear, and left the room.

en: Not a syllable was uttered by either; and Elizabeth was on the point of going away again, when Bingley, who as well as the other had sat down, suddenly rose, and, whispering a few words to her sister, ran out of the room.
vi: No one spoke a word, and Elizabeth was about to leave when Bingley suddenly stood up, whispered a few words into her sister's ear, and then rushed out.
tr: Neither of them said a word; Elizabeth was about to turn back and leave when Bingley, who was seated like the other, suddenly stood up, whispered a few words to her sister, and rushed out of the room.
es: The situation must have been very embarrassing for them, but Elizabeth was about to leave when Bingley, who, like Jane, had sat down, suddenly stood up, whispered a few words in Jane's ear, and left the room.

en: Jane could have no reserves from Elizabeth, where confidence would give pleasure; and, instantly embracing her, acknowledged, with the liveliest emotion, that she was the happiest creature in the world.
vi: Jane could not be reserved with Elizabeth when she felt such joy that she wanted to reveal it. She immediately embraced her sister and, in the most vivid emotion, confessed that she was the happiest creature in the world.
tr: She couldn't hide anything from Jane Elizabeth, especially when revealing her secret would bring joy; she immediately hugged her and, with vivid excitement, said that she was the happiest person in the world.
es: Jane could not keep secrets from Elizabeth, especially not a piece of news that she knew would make her happy. She hugged her tightly and confessed with the most vivid emotion that she was the happiest woman in the world.

en: “’Tis too much!” she added, “by far too much.
vi: She added: - That's too much!
tr: "This is too much!" he added, "really too much.
es: ––It's too much! ––he added. It's too much!

en: I do not deserve it.
vi: You don't deserve that.
tr: I don't deserve this.
es: I don't deserve it.

en: Oh, why is not everybody as happy?”
vi: Oh dear! Why can't others have such happiness?
tr: Oh! why isn't everyone this happy?"
es: Oh! Why can't everyone be as happy as I am?

en: Elizabeth’s congratulations were given with a sincerity, a warmth, a delight, which words could but poorly express.
vi: Elizabeth congratulated her with all the sincerity, warmth, and joy that no words could fully express.
tr: Elizabeth sincerely, warmly, and joyfully expressed her congratulations, even if words fell short.
es: Elizabeth's congratulations were so sincere and so fervent, and revealed so much pleasure that it cannot be expressed in words.

en: Every sentence of kindness was a fresh source of happiness to Jane.
vi: Every affectionate word was a new source of happiness for Jane.
tr: Every kind sentence became a new source of happiness for Jane.
es: Each of her affectionate phrases was a source of joy for Jane.

en: But she would not allow herself to stay with her sister, or say half that remained to be said, for the present.
vi: But at this moment, she did not want to stay close to her sister for long, nor say anything more that needed to be said.
tr: But at that moment, she was not willing to stay with her sister and recount things superficially.
es: But she couldn't stay with Elizabeth nor tell her half of the things she still had to communicate.

en: “I must go instantly to my mother,” she cried.
vi: She exclaimed: - I want to go to mother immediately.
tr: "I must go to my mother immediately;" she exclaimed.
es: ––I'm going to see mom right away ––she said––.

en: “I would not on any account trifle with her affectionate solicitude, or allow her to hear it from anyone but myself.
vi: I don't want to belittle mother's worries and compassion, or let her receive the news through someone else.
tr: "I can never disregard her affectionate curiosity, nor can I allow her to hear the news from anyone but me.
es: I can't ignore her affectionate concern nor allow her to find out from someone else.

en: He is gone to my father already.
vi: He has gone to meet father.
tr: Bingley has already gone to my father.
es: He just went to talk to dad.

en: Oh, Lizzy, to know that what I have to relate will give such pleasure to all my dear family!
vi: Oh dear! Lizzy, just think about how the news I bring will make the whole family so happy!
tr: Oh, Lizzy, to know what great pleasure my news will bring to my dear family!
es: Oh, Lizzy! What I'm going to say will fill the whole family with joy.

en: how shall I bear so much happiness?”
vi: How can I endure such immense happiness!
tr: How will I endure so much happiness?"
es: How will I be able to withstand so much happiness?

en: She then hastened away to her mother, who had purposely broken up the card-party, and was sitting upstairs with Kitty.
vi: Then she hurriedly ran to find her mother. Her mother had already decided to break up the card game and was sitting upstairs with Kitty.
tr: Then he hurried to his mother; his mother had deliberately disrupted the card game and was sitting upstairs with Kitty.
es: He went hurriedly in search of his mother who had deliberately suspended the card game and was upstairs with Catherine.

en: Elizabeth, who was left by herself, now smiled at the rapidity and ease with which an affair was finally settled, that had given them so many previous months of suspense and vexation.
vi: Sitting alone, Elizabeth now smiled at how their love story had quickly and easily reached a settled conclusion - a love story that had caused them tension and anxiety for many months.
tr: Elizabeth, left to herself, smiled as she thought about how quickly and easily the matter that had left them in months of curiosity and tension was finally resolved.
es: Elizabeth stood smiling at the ease and speed with which a matter that had caused so many months of uncertainty and pain had been resolved.

en: “And this,” said she, “is the end of all his friend’s anxious circumspection!
vi: She thought: "And this is the outcome of all the careful worries in your friend!
tr: "This," he said, "is the end of all those fear-filled objections of your friend, the end of all the lies and deceit of your sister!
es: "Behold what it has come to," he said to himself, "the anxious circumspection of his friend and all the falseness and tricks of his sisters!"

en: of all his sister’s falsehood and contrivance!
vi: of all the deceit and tricks in your sister!
tr: "This," he said, "is the end of all those fear-filled objections of your friend, the end of all the lies and deceit of your sister!
es: "Behold what it has come to," he said to himself, "the anxious circumspection of his friend and all the falseness and tricks of his sisters!"

en: the happiest, wisest, and most reasonable end!”
vi: The happiest, wisest, most reasonable outcome!
tr: the happiest, the wisest, the most reasonable end!"
es: No happier, more prudent, or more reasonable outcome could have been given.

en: In a few minutes she was joined by Bingley, whose conference with her father had been short and to the purpose.
vi: In a moment, Mr. Bingley returned. The exchange between her father and him was brief and straight to the point.
tr: A few minutes later, Bingley came over; his meeting with his father had been short and to the point.
es: A few minutes later, Bingley entered, having finished his short conference with Mr. Bennet.

en: “Where is your sister?” said he hastily, as he opened the door.
vi: He hurriedly asked as he opened the door: - Where is your sister?
tr: "Where is your sister?" he said hurriedly, as he opened the door.
es: ––Where is your sister? ––he said as soon as he opened the door.

en: “With my mother upstairs.
vi: - She went upstairs to meet her mother.
tr: "Upstairs, next to my mother.
es: ––Upstairs, with mom.

en: She will be down in a moment, I dare say.”
vi: She will come down right away, I am sure of it.
tr: I think she'll come down right away."
es: I think she'll come down soon.

en: He then shut the door, and, coming up to her, claimed the good wishes and affection of a sister.
vi: Then he closed the door and approached her, receiving her congratulations and affection.
tr: Then he closed the door, came to her, and asked for her good wishes and support as a sister.
es: Then Bingley closed the door and asked for his congratulations, begging him to consider him as a brother.

en: Elizabeth honestly and heartily expressed her delight in the prospect of their relationship.
vi: Elizabeth expressed sincerely and warmly about the prospect between the two of them.
tr: Elizabeth expressed her sincere and enthusiastic happiness about their relationship.
es: Elizabeth told him with all her heart how happy she was about this future relationship.

en: They shook hands with great cordiality; and then, till her sister came down, she had to listen to all he had to say of his own happiness, and of Jane’s perfections; and in spite of his being a lover, Elizabeth really believed all his expectations of felicity to be rationally founded, because they had for basis the excellent understanding and super-excellent disposition of Jane, and a general similarity of feeling and taste between her and himself.
vi: They shook hands in utmost friendliness, and while waiting for her sister to come down, she had to listen to everything he wanted to say about his happiness. Even though he was in love, Elizabeth truly believed that all his expectations of happiness were based on reason, because there was a wonderful mutual understanding between them, Jane's extremely good character, along with the similarities in feelings and tastes between the two.
tr: They shook hands warmly; then, until her sister came down, she had to listen to what Bingley said about his own happiness and Jane's superior qualities; she was truly convinced that despite being in love, all his expectations of happiness were based on reason, because they were founded on Jane's perfect understanding, extraordinary nature, and the similarity of feelings and tastes between them.
es: They shook hands very cordially, and until Jane came down, Bingley talked about his happiness and the perfections of his beloved. Elizabeth did not believe his hopes for happiness were exaggerated, despite the love that blinded the young man, because Jane's good understanding and excellent heart were joined by the similarity of feelings and tastes with his fiancée.

en: It was an evening of no common delight to them all; the satisfaction of Miss Bennet’s mind gave such a glow of sweet animation to her face, as made her look handsomer than ever.
vi: This is an evening where each person rejoices in their own way. The contentment on Miss Bennet's face cast a sweet lively glow, making her more beautiful than ever.
tr: It was an evening filled with exceptional happiness for all; the satisfaction in Miss Bennet's soul gave her face such a sweet glow of liveliness that it made her look more beautiful than ever.
es: The afternoon passed amid general enchantment; Jane's satisfaction gave her face a light and an expression so sweet that it made her seem more beautiful than ever.

en: Kitty simpered and smiled, and hoped her turn was coming soon.
vi: Kitty, with her colorful smile, hoped that her turn would come soon.
tr: Kitty grinned, smiled, and wished for her turn to come quickly.
es: Catherine smiled, thinking that her turn would come soon.

en: ms Bennet could not give her consent, or speak her approbation in terms warm enough to satisfy her feelings, though she talked to Bingley of nothing else, for half an hour; and when mr Bennet joined them at supper, his voice and manner plainly showed how really happy he was.
vi: Mrs. Bennet could neither respond approvingly to her daughter's wishes nor express agreement with sweet words to satisfy her youngest daughter's heart, even though she spent half an hour talking only with Mr. Bingley about happiness. When Mr. Bennet came down to join them for supper, his words and demeanor showed that he was truly happy.
tr: Although Mrs. Bennet did not talk about anything else to Bingley for half an hour, she could not manage to give her consent or express her positive opinions in a manner warm enough to satisfy herself; when Mr. Bennet joined them at dinner, both his voice and actions showed how truly happy he was.
es: Mrs. Bennet gave her consent and expressed her approval in the warmest terms, which, nevertheless, did not manage to describe the joy she felt, and for half an hour she could talk to Bingley about nothing else. When Mr. Bennet joined them for dinner, his voice and appearance revealed his joy.

en: Not a word, however, passed his lips in allusion to it, till their visitor took his leave for the night; but as soon as he was gone, he turned to his daughter and said,—
vi: However, he did not say a word about this joy until Bingley had left, but as soon as he had gone, he turned to his daughter and said:
tr: However, not a single hint about the matter came out of his mouth until the guests asked for permission to leave for the night; but when they left, he turned to his daughter and said,
es: But not a word escaped his lips that alluded to the matter until the guest took his leave. As soon as he had gone, Mr. Bennet turned to his daughter and said:

en: “Jane, I congratulate you.
vi: - Jane, I congratulate you.
tr: "Jane, I congratulate you.
es: ––Congratulations, Jane.

en: You will be a very happy woman.”
vi: You will become a very happy woman.
tr: You will be a very happy woman."
es: You will be a very happy woman.

en: Jane went to him instantly, kissed him, and thanked him for his goodness.
vi: Jane went straight to him, kissed him, and thanked him for his affection.
tr: Jane went right up to him, kissed him, and thanked him for his kindness.
es: Jane ran to her father, gave him a kiss, and thanked him for his kindness.

en: “You are a good girl,” he replied, “and I have great pleasure in thinking you will be so happily settled.
vi: He replied: - You are a good daughter, and I am very happy thinking you will be happy in your married life.
tr: "You are a good girl," replied her father, "thinking that you will have such a happy marriage makes me very happy.
es: ––You are a good girl ––added the father–– and you deserve the luck you have had.

en: I have not a doubt of your doing very well together.
vi: I have no doubt that you two will get along well.
tr: I have no doubt that you will get along well.
es: You will get along very well.

en: Your tempers are by no means unlike.
vi: Your temperaments do not clash at all.
tr: Your temperaments are not different.
es: Your characters are very similar.

en: You are each of you so complying, that nothing will ever be resolved on; so easy, that every servant will cheat you; and so generous, that you will always exceed your income.”
vi: Each of you wants to indulge the other to the utmost, so there will be nothing that cannot be resolved; each of you is easygoing, so all the servants will deceive both of you; and each of you is generous, so you will always spend beyond your income.
tr: You are both so gentle that you will not insist on anything, so easygoing that every servant will deceive you, so generous that you will always spend more than your income."
es: You are so accommodating to each other that you will never resolve anything, so trusting that any servant will deceive you, and so generous that you will always spend more than you have.

en: “I hope not so.
vi: - I hope that's not the case.
tr: "I hope we don't spend it.
es: ––That certainly not.

en: Imprudence or thoughtlessness in money matters would be unpardonable in me.”
vi: Being wasteful or careless with money is unforgivable in your character.
tr: In matters of money, recklessness or thoughtlessness would be unforgivable from my perspective."
es: Carelessness or negligence in financial matters would be unforgivable for me.

en: “Exceed their income!
vi: The wife exclaimed: - The target exceeds the income!
tr: "Spending more than his income!" "Mr. Bennet, my dear," cried his wife, "what are you talking about?
es: ––Spending more than one has!

en: My dear mr Bennet,” cried his wife, “what are you talking of?
vi: Sir, what are you saying?
tr: "Spending more than his income!" "Mr. Bennet, my dear," cried his wife, "what are you talking about?
es: ––exclaimed Mrs. Bennet––. What are you saying?

en: Why, he has four or five thousand a year, and very likely more.”
vi: What, he has four or five thousand a year, maybe more.
tr: What do you mean, the child has four or five thousand a year, probably more."
es: Bingley has four or five thousand pounds a year, maybe more.

en: Then addressing her daughter, “Oh, my dear, dear Jane, I am so happy!
vi: Then she said to her daughter: My dear, dear Jane, I am so happy!
tr: Then turning to her daughter, "Oh my dear Jane, I am so happy!
es: Then, turning to her daughter, she added:

en: I am sure I shan’t get a wink of sleep all night.
vi: I surely won't be able to sleep tonight.
tr: I won't be able to sleep all night.
es: Oh, Jane, dear, my life, I am so happy that I won't be able to close my eyes all night!

en: I knew how it would be.
vi: I knew it would be like this.
tr: I knew it would be like this.
es: I always knew this would happen; I always said that in the end everything would work out.

en: I always said it must be so, at last.
vi: I knew it would be like this.
tr: I always said it would end like this.
es: I always knew this would happen; I always said that in the end everything would work out.

en: I was sure you could not be so beautiful for nothing!
vi: I was certain you couldn't be so beautiful without getting something in return.
tr: You couldn't be this beautiful for nothing!
es: I was sure that your beauty would not be in vain.

en: I remember, as soon as ever I saw him, when he first came into Hertfordshire last year, I thought how likely it was that you should come together.
vi: I still remember, right when I first met him, when he first came to Hertfordshire last year, I thought it was very likely the two of you would pair up.
tr: I remember, when he first came to Hertfordshire last year, I knew as soon as I saw him that you would come together.
es: I remember that as soon as I saw him the first time he arrived in Hertfordshire, I thought that you two had to get married.

en: Oh, he is the handsomest young man that ever was seen!”
vi: Oh! He is the most handsome young man I have ever seen!
tr: Oh, the handsomest man that ever lived!"
es: He is the most handsome man I have seen in my life!

en: Wickham, Lydia, were all forgotten.
vi: Wickham and Lydia were both forgotten.
tr: Wickham, Lydia, they were all forgotten.
es: Wickham and Lydia were forgotten.

en: Jane was beyond competition her favourite child.
vi: Jane had surpassed all comparisons with the daughter she cherished the most.
tr: Jane was his indisputably favorite daughter.
es: Jane was now her favorite daughter, without any comparison; at that moment, the others did not matter to her at all.

en: At that moment she cared for no other.
vi: At this moment, she no longer cared about anyone else.
tr: At that moment, no one else mattered to him.
es: Jane was now her favorite daughter, without any comparison; at that moment, the others did not matter to her at all.

en: Her younger sisters soon began to make interest with her for objects of happiness which she might in future be able to dispense.
vi: The younger sisters began to pay attention to her because of the benefits she might bestow in the future.
tr: Soon, the youngest sisters began to coax him for the objects of happiness he could distribute in the future.
es: The younger sisters soon began to ask Jane for everything they wanted and that she would be able to provide them shortly.

en: Mary petitioned for the use of the library at Netherfield; and Kitty begged very hard for a few balls there every winter.
vi: Mary asked to use the reading room at Netherfield, and Kitty began to insist on having a few balls there each winter.
tr: Mary asked for permission to use the library at Netherfield; Kitty also begged a lot to have a few balls every winter.
es: Mary wanted to use the Netherfield library, and Catherine begged her to organize a few dances there in the winter.

en: Bingley, from this time, was of course a daily visitor at Longbourn; coming frequently before breakfast, and always remaining till after supper; unless when some barbarous neighbour, who could not be enough detested, had given him an invitation to dinner, which he thought himself obliged to accept.
vi: From that moment, of course, Bingley became a daily visitor to Longbourn. He often arrived before breakfast and always stayed until supper, unless some terribly disliked, rude neighbor invited him to dinner, which he felt obliged to accept.
tr: From that time on, Bingley naturally became a daily visitor at Longbourn; he often arrived before breakfast and always stayed until late at night, except on those few days when a merciless neighbor, whom it would be inadequate to call inconsiderate, invited him to dinner and he was obliged to accept.
es: Bingley, as was natural, went to Longbourn every day. He often arrived before lunch and stayed until after dinner, except when some barbaric neighbor, never detested enough, invited him to dine, and Bingley felt obliged to accept.

en: Elizabeth had now but little time for conversation with her sister; for while he was present Jane had no attention to bestow on anyone else: but she found herself considerably useful to both of them, in those hours of separation that must sometimes occur.
vi: Elizabeth now had little time to converse with her sister, for when he was present, Jane paid attention to no one else, but Elizabeth found it very beneficial for both of them during the hours when the two were not together.
tr: Elizabeth no longer found much time to chat with her sister; with Bingley around, Jane had no inclination to pay attention to anyone else; but Elizabeth sometimes found that the hours of separation, which occasionally had to intervene, were quite beneficial to both of them.
es: Elizabeth had few opportunities to converse with her sister, for while Bingley was present, Jane had no eyes or ears for anyone else; but she was very useful to both of them during the hours of separation that were sometimes imposed.

en: In the absence of Jane, he always attached himself to Elizabeth for the pleasure of talking of her; and when Bingley was gone, Jane constantly sought the same means of relief.
vi: In Jane's absence, he always paid attention to Elizabeth because he enjoyed talking to her; and when Bingley was away, Jane always sought solace in the same manner.
tr: When Jane was not around, Bingley devoted himself to Elizabeth, because he enjoyed conversing with her; and when Bingley left, Jane felt the same need for relief.
es: In Jane's absence, Bingley always sought out Elizabeth to indulge in talking about his beloved; and when Bingley left, Jane constantly turned to the same consolation.

en: “He has made me so happy,” said she, one evening, “by telling me that he was totally ignorant of my being in town last spring!
vi: One afternoon, she said: - He made you feel very happy when he told you that he had no idea you were in the city during the spring!
tr: "It made me so happy," said Jane one evening, "that he didn't know I was in the city last spring.
es: ––You don't know how happy he made me ––she told her sister one night–– by telling me that he was unaware I had been in London last spring!

en: I had not believed it possible.”
vi: You couldn't believe such a thing.
tr: It had never even occurred to me that this could be possible."
es: It seemed impossible to me!

en: “I suspected as much,” replied Elizabeth.
vi: - I think exactly like that.
tr: "I had suspected," replied Elizabeth.
es: ––I figured as much.

en: “But how did he account for it?”
vi: But how does he explain this?
tr: "But how did he explain it?"
es: But how do you explain it?

en: “It must have been his sisters’ doing.
vi: - This must be because of your sister.
tr: "His sisters must have a job.
es: ––It must have been the work of his sisters.

en: They were certainly no friends to his acquaintance with me, which I cannot wonder at, since he might have chosen so much more advantageously in many respects.
vi: Surely your sister doesn't like seeing you involved with me. I'm not surprised by this because there could have been more favorable choices, in many respects.
tr: Of course, they didn't like him being friends with me, which doesn't surprise me, because in many ways he could have made a more advantageous choice.
es: The truth is that they didn't want anything to do with me, which doesn't surprise me, since Bingley could have found someone better from every point of view.

en: But when they see, as I trust they will, that their brother is happy with me, they will learn to be contented, and we shall be on good terms again: though we can never be what we once were to each other.”
vi: But I believe that once they see their loved one happy with me, they will be content, and everything will return to a good relationship, even if it can never be exactly as it was before.
tr: But when his sisters see that he is happy with me, which I am sure they will, they will learn to accept it and things will be good between us again; but we can never be as close as we used to be."
es: But when they see, as I suppose they will, that their brother is happy by my side, they will be content, and we will be friends again, although never as before.

en: “That is the most unforgiving speech,” said Elizabeth, “that I ever heard you utter.
vi: - This is the most generous speech I have ever heard you utter.
tr: "This is the most intolerant speech I've heard from you," said Elizabeth.
es: ––This is the most unforgivable thing I have ever heard you say in my life ––exclaimed Elizabeth––.

en: Good girl!
vi: Good girl!
tr: "Well done!
es: Wretch!

en: It would vex me, indeed, to see you again the dupe of Miss Bingley’s pretended regard.”
vi: Actually, it worries me to see you being deceived by Miss Bingley's feigned affection.
tr: I don't want to see you fooled by Miss Bingley's false interest again."
es: It truly irritates me that you believe in Miss Bingley's supposed friendship.

en: “Would you believe it, Lizzy, that when he went to town last November he really loved me, and nothing but a persuasion of my being indifferent would have prevented his coming down again?”
vi: - Lizzy, do you believe it? When I went to the city last November, I truly loved her, and it was only because I thought she was indifferent to me that I didn't want to return, not for any other reason!
tr: "Would you believe it, Lizzy, when he went to the city last November, he really loved me; he just didn't come back because he believed I was indifferent!""
es: ––Do you believe, Elizabeth, that when he went to the capital last November, he truly loved me and only the certainty that I was indifferent to him prevented him from returning?

en: “He made a little mistake, to be sure; but it is to the credit of his modesty.”
vi: - Surely you have made a small mistake, but this is only because you are modest.
tr: "It seems he made a small mistake; but even this shows his humility.""
es: ––He made a small mistake, actually; but this speaks very well of his modesty.

en: This naturally introduced a panegyric from Jane on his diffidence, and the little value he put on his own good qualities.
vi: In a very natural way, this made Jane sing praises about his shyness, about how he did not deliberately flaunt his good qualities.
tr: This remark naturally led Jane to launch into a praise-filled speech about Bingley's modesty and his disregard for his own merits.
es: This naturally led Jane to praise her fiancé's lack of conceit and the little value he placed on his own qualities.

en: Elizabeth was pleased to find that he had not betrayed the interference of his friend; for, though Jane had the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, she knew it was a circumstance which must prejudice her against him.
vi: Elizabeth was pleased to see that he had not revealed anything about his friend's intervention, because although Jane had the most generous and open-hearted nature in the world, if she understood, she would have a prejudice against Darcy.
tr: Elizabeth was glad that Bingley's friend's intervention was not revealed, because although Jane had the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, she knew that this situation would make her prejudiced against Darcy.
es: Elizabeth was glad that she had not betrayed her friend by speaking of his interference, for although Jane possessed the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, this might have created some prejudice against Darcy in her.

en: “I am certainly the most fortunate creature that ever existed!” cried Jane.
vi: Jane exclaimed: - Surely you are the luckiest creature!
tr: "I am the luckiest person in the world!" Jane exclaimed.
es: ––I am undoubtedly the luckiest creature on earth, exclaimed Jane.

en: “Oh, Lizzy, why am I thus singled from my family, and blessed above them all?
vi: Oh Lizzy, why are you treated so specially in the whole family, more specially than anyone else!
tr: "Oh, Lizzy, why was I chosen from my family, why did fortune smile upon me!
es: Oh, Lizzy, I feel so sorry to be the happiest in the house!

en: If I could but see you as happy!
vi: If only you could see me being as happy as this!
tr: If only I could see you this happy!
es: If only you were too!

en: If there were but such another man for you!”
vi: If there were another young man like that for me!
tr: If only there were such a man for you!"
es: If only there were another man like Bingley for you!

en: “If you were to give me forty such men I never could be so happy as you.
vi: - If you gave me forty young men like that, I would still never feel as happy as you.
tr: "Even if you give me forty men, I cannot be as happy as you.
es: ––Even if you gave me forty like him, I would never be as happy as you.

en: Till I have your disposition, your goodness, I never can have your happiness.
vi: If I don't have the qualities you possess, the virtues you have, then I still wouldn't have happiness like yours.
tr: Until I have your nature, your goodness, I cannot possess your happiness.
es: As long as I don't have your disposition, I will never be able to enjoy such happiness.

en: No, no, let me shift for myself; and, perhaps, if I have very good luck, I may meet with another mr Collins in time.”
vi: No, no, let me take care of it myself, and maybe if I'm really lucky, sooner or later I might meet another Mr. Collins.
tr: No, no, I will take care of myself; perhaps, if luck is on my side, I may encounter another Mr. Collins in time."
es: No, no; leave me as I am. If I am lucky, I might find another Collins in time.

en: The situation of affairs in the Longbourn family could not be long a secret.
vi: The love story in the Longbourn family could not be kept secret for long.
tr: The development in the Longbourn family could not remain a secret for long.
es: The state of the affairs of the Longbourn family could not remain a secret.

en: ms Bennet was privileged to whisper it to ms Philips, and she ventured, without any permission, to do the same by all her neighbours in Meryton.
vi: Mrs. Bennet had the privilege of whispering to Mrs. Philips, and without permission, the latter whispered to all her neighbors in Meryton.
tr: Mrs. Bennet hinted the news to Mrs. Philips, who, without any permission, spread it to all her neighbors in Meryton.
es: Mrs. Bennet had the privilege of communicating it to Mrs. Philips, who then proceeded to broadcast it without prior permission to the houses of all the neighbors in Meryton.

en: The Bennets were speedily pronounced to be the luckiest family in the world; though only a few weeks before, when Lydia had first run away, they had been generally proved to be marked out for misfortune.
vi: Everyone quickly assumed that the Bennet family was the luckiest in the world, though just a few weeks earlier, when Lydia had run away from home, they were considered to be unfortunate.
tr: The Bennets were quickly declared the luckiest family in the world, whereas just a few weeks ago, when Lydia first eloped, they were seen by everyone as the epitome of misfortune.
es: The Bennets were soon proclaimed the luckiest family in the world, despite the fact that a few weeks earlier, on the occasion of Lydia's elopement, they had been regarded as the most unfortunate people on earth.

en: CHAPTER LVI.
vi: Chapter 56
tr: Chapter XIV
es: CHAPTER LVI

en: ONE morning, about a week after Bingley’s engagement with Jane had been formed, as he and the females of the family were sitting together in the dining-room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window by the sound of a carriage; and they perceived a chaise and four driving up the lawn.
vi: One morning, about a week after Bingley proposed to Jane, while he and the women of the family were conversing, they heard the sound of a carriage and saw a four-horse carriage driving into the grounds.
tr: One morning, about a week after Bingley and Jane's engagement was broken off, while Bingley and the ladies of the family were sitting in the dining room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window by the sound of a carriage; they saw a four-horse carriage coming up the lawn.
es: One morning, approximately a week after Bingley's declaration, while he was gathered in the sitting room with the ladies of Longbourn, they were drawn by the noise of a carriage and looked out the window, spotting a landau with four horses crossing the lawn in front of the house.

en: It was too early in the morning for visitors; and besides, the equipage did not answer to that of any of their neighbours.
vi: It was too early for visitors to arrive, and moreover, none of the neighbors used such a carriage.
tr: It was an early hour for a visitor, and the carriage did not resemble that of any of their neighbors.
es: It was too early for visits and besides, the carriage's team did not belong to any of the neighbors; the horses were post horses and neither the carriage nor the livery of the footmen were familiar to them.

en: The horses were post; and neither the carriage, nor the livery of the servant who preceded it, were familiar to them.
vi: The carriage was drawn by horses with harnesses, and both the body of the carriage and the attire of the coachman looked unusual.
tr: The horses were rented; neither the carriage nor the uniform of the footman in front looked familiar.
es: It was too early for visits and besides, the carriage's team did not belong to any of the neighbors; the horses were post horses and neither the carriage nor the livery of the footmen were familiar to them.

en: As it was certain, however, that somebody was coming, Bingley instantly prevailed on Miss Bennet to avoid the confinement of such an intrusion, and walk away with him into the shrubbery.
vi: However, knowing for sure that someone was visiting, Bingley immediately signaled to Miss Bennet to avoid intruding on the family's privacy, and the two went out into the garden.
tr: But since it was certain that someone had arrived, Bingley immediately persuaded Miss Bennet to walk with him in the grove to avoid being taken captive by such an uninvited guest.
es: But it was evident that someone was coming to the house. Bingley proposed to Jane that they go for a walk in the shrubbery to avoid being separated by the intruder.

en: They both set off; and the conjectures of the remaining three continued, though with little satisfaction, till the door was thrown open, and their visitor entered.
vi: The remaining three continued to speculate but could not find an answer, until the door opened, and the guest stepped in.
tr: The two of them left; the other three continued to speculate, but they were not very successful until the door opened and the guest entered.
es: The two of them left, and the three who stayed in the dining room continued their conjectures, though with little satisfaction, until the door opened and the visitor entered.

en: It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
vi: It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
tr: The visitor was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
es: It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.

en: They were of course all intending to be surprised: but their astonishment was beyond their expectation; and on the part of ms Bennet and Kitty, though she was perfectly unknown to them, even inferior to what Elizabeth felt.
vi: Of course, they thought there would be some surprise, but they were surprised beyond imagination; Elizabeth was more surprised than both Mrs. Bennet and Kitty, even though these two had not yet become acquainted with the guest.
tr: They were all ready to be surprised, of course; but they were astonished more than they had ever expected; even though they did not know the lady at all, the astonishment felt by Mrs. Bennet and Kitty was mild compared to Elizabeth's.
es: It is true that everyone was expecting some surprise, but this one exceeded all expectations. Although Mrs. Bennet and Catherine did not know that lady, they were no less astonished than Elizabeth.

en: She entered the room with an air more than usually ungracious, made no other reply to Elizabeth’s salutation than a slight inclination of the head, and sat down without saying a word.
vi: Mrs. Catherine entered with more rudeness than usual, only slightly nodding in response to Elizabeth's greeting, then sitting down without saying a word.
tr: He entered the room with a more arrogant air than usual, barely nodding in response to Elizabeth's greeting, and sat down without saying a word.
es: He entered the room with an even more unpleasant air than usual; he responded to Elizabeth's greeting with a simple nod of his head and sat down without saying a word.

en: Elizabeth had mentioned her name to her mother on her Ladyship’s entrance, though no request of introduction had been made.
vi: When she entered, Elizabeth had told her mother her name, though no one had asked for an introduction.
tr: Although no introduction had been requested, Elizabeth had mentioned her name to her mother upon the lady's entrance.
es: Elizabeth had mentioned his name to Mrs. Bennet when His Lordship entered, although she had not requested any introduction.

en: ms Bennet, all amazement, though flattered by having a guest of such high importance, received her with the utmost politeness.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was extremely surprised, though somewhat self-satisfied, that such a respected person had come to visit, and she received the guest with utmost courtesy.
tr: Mrs. Bennet, who was astonished, greeted the important guest with great courtesy, even though it flattered her pride to host such a significant visitor.
es: Mrs. Bennet, astonished yet very proud to have a person of such high rank in her home, received her with the utmost courtesy.

en: After sitting for a moment in silence, she said, very stiffly, to Elizabeth,—
vi: After sitting for a moment in silence, the guest dryly said to Elizabeth:
tr: After sitting in silence for a moment, she said to Elizabeth in a rather tense manner,
es: They all sat in silence for a while, until at last Lady Catherine said to Elizabeth with great pomp:

en: “I hope you are well, Miss Bennet.
vi: - I hope you are still well, Miss Bennet.
tr: "I hope you are well, Miss Bennet.
es: ––I suppose you are well, and I assume that lady is your mother.

en: That lady, I suppose, is your mother?”
vi: I assume this lady is your mother.
tr: This lady must be your mother."
es: ––I suppose you are well, and I assume that lady is your mother.

en: Elizabeth replied very concisely that she was.
vi: Elizabeth replied affirmatively.
tr: Elizabeth briefly said that it was so.
es: Elizabeth answered concisely in the affirmative.

en: “And that, I suppose, is one of your sisters?”
vi: - And I think this is one of your sisters.
tr: "This must be one of your sisters, I suppose.""
es: ––And that other one I imagine must be one of his sisters.

en: “Yes, madam,” said ms Bennet, delighted to speak to a Lady Catherine.
vi: Mrs. Bennet replied, delighted to converse with a lady named Catherine: - Yes, Madam.
tr: "Yes, madam," said Mrs. Bennet, in the pleasure of speaking with the grand Lady Catherine.
es: ––Yes, ma'am ––Mrs. Bennet responded, very proud to be able to speak with Lady Catherine––.

en: “She is my youngest girl but one.
vi: It is the second youngest.
tr: "The one just older than the youngest.
es: She is the second youngest; the youngest of all got married recently, and the eldest is in the garden walking with a gentleman who I believe will soon become part of our family.

en: My youngest of all is lately married, and my eldest is somewhere about the ground, walking with a young man, who, I believe, will soon become a part of the family.”
vi: My youngest daughter is married, and the eldest one is walking somewhere in the garden with a young man, whom I believe will become a member of the family.
tr: My youngest just got married, and my eldest is somewhere around, on a walk with a young gentleman, who I believe will soon be part of the family."
es: She is the second youngest; the youngest of all got married recently, and the eldest is in the garden walking with a gentleman who I believe will soon become part of our family.

en: “You have a very small park here,” returned Lady Catherine, after a short silence.
vi: Lady Catherine said, after a moment of silence. - She has a very small garden here.
tr: "You have a small garden here," replied Lady Catherine after a brief silence.
es: ––You have a very small farm ––said His Lordship after a short silence.

en: “It is nothing in comparison of Rosings, my Lady, I dare say; but, I assure you, it is much larger than Sir William Lucas’s.”
vi: - Madam, I dare say nothing can compare to Rosings, but I believe it is even larger than Sir William Lucas's garden.
tr: "Compared to Rosings, it is indeed so, madam, certainly; but rest assured, it is much larger than Sir William Lucas's.""
es: ––It is nothing compared to Rosings, madam; one must admit it; but I assure you it is much better than Sir William Lucas's.

en: “This must be a most inconvenient sitting-room for the evening in summer: the windows are full west.”
vi: - This must be the most inconvenient room in the evening, during the summer; all the windows face directly east.
tr: "This room is not suitable for sitting in on summer evenings; the windows face directly west."
es: ––This must be a very uncomfortable room in the summer afternoons; the windows face completely west.

en: ms Bennet assured her that they never sat there after dinner; and then added,—
vi: Mrs. Bennet stated that the family never sat here after dinner, and added:
tr: Mrs. Bennet assured them that they did not sit there after dinner, then added,
es: Mrs. Bennet assured her that they were never there after dinner, and added:

en: “May I take the liberty of asking your Ladyship whether you left mr and ms Collins well?”
vi: - May I ask, how are Mr. and Mrs. Collins?
tr: "May I ask Ladyship if Mr. and Mrs. Collins were well when they parted?"
es: ––May I take the liberty of asking Your Lordship how you left Mr. and Mrs. Collins?

en: “Yes, very well.
vi: - Very well.
tr: "Yes, quite well.
es: ––Very well; I saw them the night before last.

en: I saw them the night before last.”
vi: I met the two people the evening before last.
tr: I saw them the previous night."
es: ––Very well; I saw them the night before last.

en: Elizabeth now expected that she would produce a letter for her from Charlotte, as it seemed the only probable motive for her calling.
vi: Now, Elizabeth thought she would hand over Charlotte's letter to be delivered to her, as this seemed to be the only reason for her visit here.
tr: Elizabeth must have brought a letter from Charlotte to her, she thought she would take it out and give it to her, because that could be the only possible reason for her visit.
es: Elizabeth hoped that she would now give her some letter from Charlotte, as this seemed the only likely reason for her visit; but Lady Catherine did not take out any letter, and Elizabeth remained perplexed.

en: But no letter appeared, and she was completely puzzled.
vi: But there was no letter, and she was utterly bewildered.
tr: But when no letter came out, she became even more confused.
es: Elizabeth hoped that she would now give her some letter from Charlotte, as this seemed the only likely reason for her visit; but Lady Catherine did not take out any letter, and Elizabeth remained perplexed.

en: ms Bennet, with great civility, begged her Ladyship to take some refreshment: but Lady Catherine very resolutely, and not very politely, declined eating anything; and then, rising up, said to Elizabeth,—
vi: With the utmost politeness, Mrs. Bennet earnestly invited the Lady to have some refreshments, but Lady Catherine firmly, and not very politely, refused all food and drink, then stood up and said to Elizabeth:
tr: Mrs. Bennet wanted to offer something to her ladyship with great politeness, but Lady Catherine very firmly and quite rudely refused to eat anything; then she stood up and said to Elizabeth,
es: Mrs. Bennet delicately entreated Her Ladyship to take something, but Lady Catherine firmly declined the offer without excessive politeness. Then, rising, she said to Elizabeth:

en: “Miss Bennet, there seemed to be a prettyish kind of a little wilderness on one side of your lawn.
vi: - Miss Bennet, there seems to be a beautiful patch of greenery on one side of the garden.
tr: "Miss Bennet, it seems you have a nice little wood on one side of your lawn.
es: ––Miss Bennet, it seems to me that over there, beside the meadow, there is a beautiful and secluded spot.

en: I should be glad to take a turn in it, if you will favour me with your company.”
vi: I would be very pleased to take a walk, if you would kindly show me the way.
tr: I would like to take a walk, if you would accompany me."
es: I would like to take a walk there if you would do me the honor of accompanying me.

en: “Go, my dear,” cried her mother, “and show her Ladyship about the different walks.
vi: The mother exclaimed: - Go, my child, so the Lady can see different scenery.
tr: "Go, darling," cried her mother, "show the lady our walking paths.
es: ––Come on, dear ––exclaimed the mother––, show His Lordship all the walks.

en: I think she will be pleased with the hermitage.”
vi: I think the Lady will like the solitude here.
tr: I believe she will like the hermit's hut."
es: I think he will like the hermitage.

en: Elizabeth obeyed; and, running into her own room for her parasol, attended her noble guest downstairs.
vi: Elizabeth obeyed, ran to her room to get an umbrella, and then escorted the important guest downstairs.
tr: Elizabeth agreed; she ran to her room, grabbed her umbrella, and accompanied the noble guest downstairs.
es: Elizabeth obeyed, ran to her room to fetch her umbrella, and waited downstairs for her noble visitor.

en: As they passed through the hall, Lady Catherine opened the doors into the dining-parlour and drawing-room, and pronouncing them, after a short survey, to be decent-looking rooms, walked on.
vi: As they walked along the hallway, Lady Catherine opened all the doors leading to the dining room and the drawing room, looked around, complimented the elegant rooms, and then continued walking.
tr: As they walked through the corridor, Lady Catherine opened the doors of the dining room and the sitting room, and after a brief glance inside, declared them to be well-kept rooms and continued walking.
es: As she passed through the hall, Lady Catherine opened the doors to the dining room and the drawing room, and after a brief inspection, declared that they were decent rooms, after which she continued walking.

en: Her carriage remained at the door, and Elizabeth saw that her waiting-woman was in it.
vi: The lady's carriage was still standing at the door, and Elizabeth saw the maid sitting in the carriage.
tr: Her carriage was waiting at the door; Elizabeth saw that her maid was in the carriage.
es: The carriage was still at the door, and Elizabeth saw that Her Ladyship's maid was in it.

en: They proceeded in silence along the gravel walk that led to the copse; Elizabeth was determined to make no effort for conversation with a woman who was now more than usually insolent and disagreeable.
vi: They walked along the gravel path to the grove; Elizabeth decided there was no need to attempt conversation with the woman who had now become more insolent and unpleasant than usual.
tr: They proceeded silently along the gravel path leading to the grove; Elizabeth was determined not to attempt to converse with the woman, who was now more arrogant and repulsive than usual.
es: They walked silently along the gravel path that led to the stables.

en: “After a short survey”
vi: They walked along the gravel path to the grove; Elizabeth decided there was no need to attempt conversation with the woman who had now become more insolent and unpleasant than usual.
tr: "How did I mistake him for my nephew?" he thought, while looking at his face.
es: Elizabeth was determined not to engage in conversation with that lady who seemed even more insolent and unpleasant than usual.

en: “How could I ever think her like her nephew?” said she, as she looked in her face.
vi: She thought to herself as she looked at the lady's face: "How could I ever have thought she was like her nephew?"
tr: "How did I mistake him for my nephew?" he thought, while looking at his face.
es: How could I ever say that she looked like her nephew?, he said to himself as he looked at her face.

en: As soon as they entered the copse, Lady Catherine began in the following manner:—
vi: As soon as they entered the orchard, Lady Catherine began:
tr: As soon as they entered the grove, Lady Catherine began to speak:-
es: When they entered a thicket, Lady Catherine said the following to him:

en: “You can be at no loss, Miss Bennet, to understand the reason of my journey hither.
vi: - Miss Bennet, you can easily understand the reason for my visit.
tr: "You probably won't be surprised to learn why I came here, Miss Bennet.
es: ––Surely you must know, Miss Bennet, the reason for my journey here.

en: Your own heart, your own conscience, must tell you why I come.”
vi: Your feelings, your conscience must tell you why I have come here.
tr: Your own heart, your own conscience should tell you why I came.""
es: Your own heart and conscience must tell you the motive for my visit.

en: Elizabeth looked with unaffected astonishment.
vi: Elizabeth appeared surprised in a calm manner.
tr: Elizabeth looked with emotionless astonishment.
es: Elizabeth regarded her with natural astonishment:

en: “Indeed, you are mistaken, madam; I have not been at all able to account for the honour of seeing you here.”
vi: - Madam, in fact, you are mistaken. I have no knowledge of the reason for your being received here.
tr: "Believe me, you are mistaken, madam. I did not understand what I owe the honor of seeing you here."
es: ––You are mistaken, madam. In no way can I explain the honor of your presence.

en: “Miss Bennet,” replied her Ladyship, in an angry tone, “you ought to know that I am not to be trifled with.
vi: The lady responded, with an angry tone: - Miss Bennet, you should know that I am not someone to be trifled with.
tr: "Miss Bennet," replied her ladyship in an angry tone, "you must know that I am not to be trifled with.
es: ––Miss Bennet ––replied His Lordship in an angry tone––, you must know that I do not like jokes; no matter how insincere you wish to be, I am not like that.

en: But however insincere you may choose to be, you shall not find me so.
vi: But although you may wish to deceive, you will find that I am not like that.
tr: Even if you choose to be insincere, you will find that I am not.
es: ––Miss Bennet ––replied His Lordship in an angry tone––, you must know that I do not like jokes; no matter how insincere you wish to be, I am not like that.

en: My character has ever been celebrated for its sincerity and frankness; and in a cause of such moment as this, I shall certainly not depart from it.
vi: My character has always been expressed through honesty and straightforwardness, and for a purpose such as this, my character will certainly not change.
tr: I am known for my frankness and honesty, and in a situation like this, I certainly will not abandon them.
es: My character has always been celebrated for its loyalty and frankness, and in a matter of such importance as the one that brings me here, I will deviate much less from my way of being.

en: A report of a most alarming nature reached me two days ago.
vi: Two days ago, I received very distressing news.
tr: A very alarming rumor reached me two days ago.
es: My character has always been celebrated for its loyalty and frankness, and in a matter of such importance as the one that brings me here, I will deviate much less from my way of being.

en: I was told, that not only your sister was on the point of being most advantageously married, but that you—that Miss Elizabeth Bennet would, in all likelihood, be soon afterwards united to my nephew—my own nephew, mr Darcy.
vi: I heard that not only is your sister about to marry advantageously, but also you, Miss Elizabeth Bennet, might very soon marry my nephew, Mr. Darcy.
tr: I was told that not only is your sister on the verge of making a very successful marriage, but you, Miss Elizabeth Bennet, are likely to follow her by uniting with my nephew, my only nephew, Mr. Darcy.
es: It has come to my attention that not only is your sister about to marry very advantageously, but that you, Miss Bennet, may possibly unite with my nephew Darcy afterwards.

en: Though I know it must be a scandalous falsehood, though I would not injure him so much as to suppose the truth of it possible, I instantly resolved on setting off for this place, that I might make my sentiments known to you.”
vi: Although I know this is merely a scandalous falsehood, and although I do not wish to hurt my nephew by considering it might be true, I immediately set out to come here to let you know what I think about this matter.
tr: Although I know this to be a dreadful falsehood, I would never wrong him by considering it possible, but I decided to come here immediately so that you may know my views."
es: Even knowing that this is a dreadful falsehood and although I do not wish to insult my nephew by admitting that there might be some hint of truth in it, I decided at once to come and communicate my feelings to you.

en: “If you believed it impossible to be true,” said Elizabeth, colouring with astonishment and disdain, “I wonder you took the trouble of coming so far.
vi: Elizabeth said, blushing with surprise and disdain: - If Madam believes that it is not the truth, I wonder why she took the trouble to come to such a distant place.
tr: "If you didn't believe it could be true," said Elizabeth, her face pale with astonishment and disgust, "I wonder why you bothered to come all this way.
es: ––If you truly believed that it was impossible –replied Elizabeth, red with astonishment and disdain–, I am amazed that you bothered to come so far.

en: What could your Ladyship propose by it?”
vi: What does Madam want to teach?
tr: What is her ladyship trying to convey with this?"
es: What is it that you intend?

en: “At once to insist upon having such a report universally contradicted.”
vi: - I want you to deny the news like that, right now.
tr: "Of course, to insist on denying such a rumor."
es: ––First of all, try to have that news corrected in all its parts.

en: “Your coming to Longbourn, to see me and my family,” said Elizabeth coolly, “will be rather a confirmation of it—if, indeed, such a report is in existence.”
vi: Elizabeth said coldly: - Your visit to Longbourn to see me and my family seems to confirm that news, if indeed there is such news.
tr: "Coming to Longbourn to see me and my family," said Elizabeth coldly, "will be more of a confirmation of this; that is, if such a rumor exists."
es: ––His coming to Longbourn to visit me and my family ––observed Elizabeth coldly––, will confirm it with more semblance of truth, if such news has circulated.

en: “If!
vi: - If that's the case, are you pretending not to know this news?
tr: "So, you pretend as if you don't know.
es: ––Has it circulated?

en: do you then pretend to be ignorant of it?
vi: - If that's the case, are you pretending not to know this news?
tr: "So, you pretend as if you don't know.
es: Do you intend to ignore it?

en: Has it not been industriously circulated by yourselves?
vi: Weren't you the one who painstakingly spread this news?
tr: Wasn't this skillfully orchestrated by you?
es: Haven't you yourselves taken the trouble to spread it?

en: Do you not know that such a report is spread abroad?”
vi: Do you know that this news has already spread widely?
tr: Don't you know that such a rumor has been spread around?"
es: Haven't you yourselves taken the trouble to spread it?

en: “I never heard that it was.”
vi: - I have never heard of such a thing.
tr: "I've never heard of it.""
es: ––I have never heard anything like it.

en: “And can you likewise declare, that there is no foundation for it?”
vi: - And you want to say that this news has no basis at all, right?
tr: "Can you also say that this is unfounded in the same way?"
es: ––And are you going to tell me as well that there is no basis for what I'm telling you?

en: “I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your Ladyship.
vi: - I do not want to pretend to have the same frankness as Madam.
tr: "I will not pretend to have the same level of frankness as Her Ladyship.
es: ––I do not presume to have as much frankness as Your Lordship.

en: You may ask questions which I shall not choose to answer.”
vi: She can ask questions that I have the right not to answer.
tr: You may ask questions, but I will choose not to answer."
es: You may ask me questions that I may not want to answer.

en: “This is not to be borne.
vi: - This is unacceptable.
tr: "It's unbearable.
es: ––It's unbearable!

en: Miss Bennet, I insist on being satisfied.
vi: Miss Bennet, I want a satisfactory answer.
tr: Miss Bennet, I insist on getting an answer.
es: Miss Bennet, I insist that you answer me.

en: Has he, has my nephew, made you an offer of marriage?”
vi: Did he, my nephew, propose to you?
tr: Did my nephew propose to you?"
es: Has my nephew proposed to you?

en: “Your Ladyship has declared it to be impossible.”
vi: - The lady said that this matter could not possibly happen.
tr: "The Lady expressed that this was impossible."
es: ––Your Honor has already declared that it was impossible.

en: “It ought to be so; it must be so, while he retains the use of his reason.
vi: - It is indeed so, it must be so, when my nephew still knows how to use reason.
tr: "It has to be that way; it must be that way, if he hasn't lost his mind.
es: ––It must be so, it has to be so as long as Darcy retains the use of reason.

en: But your arts and allurements may, in a moment of infatuation, have made him forget what he owes to himself and to all his family.
vi: But your art and allure can, in a moment of infatuation, make him forget that he owes a debt to himself and to everyone in his family.
tr: But your coquetries, your flirtations may have momentarily made him forget what he owes to himself and his entire family.
es: But her arts and seductions may have made him forget in a moment of blindness what he owes to his entire family and to himself.

en: You may have drawn him in.”
vi: You may have seduced him into that infatuation.
tr: You may have seduced him."
es: Perhaps you have dragged him into doing it.

en: “If I have, I shall be the last person to confess it.”
vi: - If I were like that, I would be the last person to confess to you.
tr: "If I did it, I would be the last person to admit it.""
es: ––If I had done it, it wouldn't be me confessing it.

en: “Miss Bennet, do you know who I am?
vi: - Miss Bennet, do you know who I am?
tr: "Miss Bennet, do you know who I am?
es: ––Miss Bennet, do you know who I am?

en: I have not been accustomed to such language as this.
vi: I am not accustomed to hearing such language.
tr: I am not accustomed to this kind of language.
es: I am not accustomed to that language.

en: I am almost the nearest relation he has in the world, and am entitled to know all his dearest concerns.”
vi: I am almost the closest person to my niece in this world, I have the right to know about all her closest relationships.
tr: I am almost the closest relative she has in the world and am entitled to know all her important matters."
es: I am almost the closest relative my nephew has in the world, and I have reasons to know what his dearest interests are.

en: “But you are not entitled to know mine; nor will such behaviour as this ever induce me to be explicit.”
vi: - But you have no right to know about my relationships, and such an attitude will never make me confess.
tr: "But you are not authorized to know mine; moreover, you cannot persuade me to be open with such an attitude.""
es: ––But you do not have the right to know what mine are, nor is your behavior the most appropriate to induce me to be more explicit.

en: “Let me be rightly understood.
vi: - I want you to understand me very clearly.
tr: "I must ensure that I am understood correctly.
es: ––But you do not have the right to know what mine are, nor is your behavior the most appropriate to induce me to be more explicit.

en: This match, to which you have the presumption to aspire, can never take place.
vi: This marriage, which you have impudently expected, will never happen.
tr: The union you dare to imagine can never happen.
es: ––Understand me well: that marriage to which you have the presumption to aspire can never take place, never.

en: No, never. mr Darcy is engaged to my daughter.
vi: No, never. Mr. Darcy is engaged to my daughter.
tr: No, never. Mr. Darcy is engaged to my daughter.
es: Mr. Darcy is engaged to my daughter.

en: Now, what have you to say?”
vi: Now, what do you have to say? - Just like this!
tr: Now, let's see what you have to say?"
es: What do you have to say now?

en: “Only this,—that if he is so, you can have no reason to suppose he will make an offer to me.”
vi: If that's true, you have no reason to believe that he will confess his feelings to me.
tr: "I will just say this; therefore, you have no reason to think that he will propose to me."
es: ––Just this: that if it is so, you have no reason to suppose that you will make any proposition to me.

en: Lady Catherine hesitated for a moment, and then replied,—
vi: Madam Catherine hesitated for a moment, then replied:
tr: Lady Catherine hesitated for a moment, then replied,
es: Lady Catherine hesitated for a moment and then said:

en: “The engagement between them is of a peculiar kind.
vi: - The engagement between the two of them is an unusual matter.
tr: "Their engagement is of a special kind.
es: ––The commitment between them is peculiar.

en: From their infancy, they have been intended for each other.
vi: Since they were young, they have been betrothed to each other.
tr: They were promised to each other when they were still babies.
es: Since their childhood, they have been destined for each other.

en: It was the favourite wish of his mother, as well as of hers.
vi: This is the earnest wish of his mother, as well as her mother.
tr: That was the wish of his mother, and mine too.
es: It was the greatest wish of his mother and hers.

en: While in their cradles we planned the union; and now, at the moment when the wishes of both sisters would be accomplished, is their marriage to be prevented by a young woman of inferior birth, of no importance in the world, and wholly unallied to the family?
vi: While the two were still in their cradles, we had planned their marriage, and now, as the wish of the two sisters is about to come true, their wedding is being hindered by a young woman of a lower class, of no importance in this world, completely unrelated to the family! Do you not care about the wishes of my niece's relatives?
tr: We planned this union while they were still in the cradle: but now, when the wishes of both families are about to be fulfilled, when both are about to marry, a young woman of lower status, with no importance in the world, and no family ties, is preventing this!
es: Since they were born, we have planned their union; and now, at the moment when the desires of the two sisters were about to be fulfilled, is it going to be thwarted by the intrusion of a girl of inferior birth, with no status, and completely unrelated to the family?

en: Do you pay no regard to the wishes of his friends—to his tacit engagement with Miss de Bourgh?
vi: About the implicit engagement of Miss De Bourgh?
tr: Do you have no respect for the wishes of his relatives? What about his silent engagement to Miss de Bourgh?
es: Do the wishes of Darcy's friends, regarding his tacit engagement to Miss de Bourgh, mean nothing to you?

en: Are you lost to every feeling of propriety and delicacy?
vi: Have you lost all sense of propriety and delicacy?
tr: Have you lost all sense of shame and decency?
es: Have you lost all sense of decency and delicacy?

en: Have you not heard me say, that from his earliest hours he was destined for his cousin?”
vi: Did you not hear me say that, since ancient times, my niece has been his intended?
tr: Didn't you hear me say that he was promised to his cousin from birth?"
es: Did you not hear me say that from his earliest age he was destined for his cousin?

en: “Yes; and I had heard it before.
vi: - Yes, I have heard that before.
tr: "Yes, I heard what you said.
es: ––Yes, I've heard it said; but, what does that have to do with me?

en: But what is that to me?
vi: But what does that mean to me?
tr: But what does that matter to me?
es: ––Yes, I've heard it said; but, what does that have to do with me?

en: If there is no other objection to my marrying your nephew, I shall certainly not be kept from it by knowing that his mother and aunt wished him to marry Miss de Bourgh.
vi: If no one else objects to my marrying your grandson, I certainly won't back down upon learning that his mother and aunt want him to marry Miss De Bourgh.
tr: If there is no other obstacle to marrying your nephew, of course, I will not give up just because his mother and aunt Miss de Bourgh want him to marry someone else.
es: If there were no other obstacle for me to marry your nephew, rest assured that our wedding would not be hindered by the assumption that his mother and aunt wished him to unite with Miss de Bourgh.

en: You both did as much as you could in planning the marriage.
vi: Both of them have done what they could to arrange the marriage.
tr: You have done your best by planning the marriage.
es: You two did what you could by planning that marriage, but its realization depends on others.

en: Its completion depended on others.
vi: Whether the marriage succeeds or not depends on others.
tr: Its realization depends on others.
es: You two did what you could by planning that marriage, but its realization depends on others.
