en: If mr Darcy is neither by honour nor inclination confined to his cousin, why is not he to make another choice?
vi: If Mr. Darcy does not wish to marry his cousin out of honor or affection, why can't he have another choice?
tr: If Mr. Darcy is not bound by honor or affection to his cousin, why shouldn't he make another choice?
es: If Mr. Darcy does not feel bound to his cousin either by honor or inclination, why should he not choose another?

en: And if I am that choice, why may not I accept him?”
vi: And if that choice is me, why can't I accept him?
tr: If that choice is me, why shouldn't I accept him?"
es: And if I am the chosen one, why should I not accept him?

en: “Because honour, decorum, prudence—nay, interest—forbid it.
vi: - Because honor, etiquette, caution - no, this is a right - prohibit it.
tr: "Because honor, decorum, common sense, and even interests forbid it.
es: ––Because honor, decorum, prudence, and even interest prevent it.

en: Yes, Miss Bennet, interest; for do not expect to be noticed by his family or friends, if you wilfully act against the inclinations of all.
vi: Yes, Miss Bennet, this is a right, for you should not expect my family and my nephew's acquaintances to acknowledge you if you deliberately act against everyone's wishes.
tr: Yes, Miss Bennet, interests; because if you knowingly act against their preferences, do not expect to be accepted by his family and friends.
es: Yes, Miss Bennet, interest; because you should not expect to be recognized by Darcy's family or friends if you stubbornly act against everyone's will.

en: You will be censured, slighted, and despised, by everyone connected with him.
vi: All those related to him will condemn, disdain, and scorn you.
tr: You will be ostracized, scorned, and ignored by everyone associated with him.
es: You will be censured, slighted, and despised by all of Darcy's relations.

en: Your alliance will be a disgrace; your name will never even be mentioned by any of us.”
vi: The marriage will be a disgrace, and no one in my family will want to mention your name.
tr: Your marriage will be a disgrace; your name will not be mentioned by any of us."
es: Your union will be a calamity; your names will never be spoken by any of us.

en: “These are heavy misfortunes,” replied Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth replied: - These are the heavy misfortunes.
tr: "These are grave misfortunes," replied Elizabeth.
es: ––Those are serious misfortunes ––replied Elizabeth––.

en: “But the wife of mr Darcy must have such extraordinary sources of happiness necessarily attached to her situation, that she could, upon the whole, have no cause to repine.”
vi: But Mr. Darcy's wife will surely be connected to the most wonderful sources of happiness, so she will have no reason to complain.
tr: "But Mr. Darcy's wife would have such extraordinary sources of happiness from being with him that there would be no reason to be upset about these.""
es: But Mr. Darcy's wife will surely enjoy such blessings that she will still feel very satisfied.

en: “Obstinate, headstrong girl!
vi: - You stubborn, headstrong girl!
tr: "Stubborn, headstrong girl!
es: ––Ah, stubborn and obstinate creature!

en: I am ashamed of you!
vi: I am ashamed of you!
tr: I am ashamed of you!
es: You make me ashamed!

en: Is this your gratitude for my attentions to you last spring?
vi: Is this how you repay the care I gave you last spring?
tr: Is this how you were going to thank me for the attention I showed you last spring?
es: Is that your gratitude for my attentions last spring?

en: Is nothing due to me on that score?
vi: Don't you feel you owe me something?
tr: Don't you owe me since then?
es: Is that your gratitude for my attentions last spring?

en: Let us sit down.
vi: Let's sit down.
tr: "Let's sit down.
es: Let us sit down.

en: You are to understand, Miss Bennet, that I came here with the determined resolution of carrying my purpose; nor will I be dissuaded from it.
vi: Miss Bennet, you should understand that I came here with the determination to achieve my goal, and nothing can sway me.
tr: You will understand, Miss Bennet, I came here determined to achieve my purpose; I will not give up.
es: You must know, Miss Bennet, that I have come here with the firm resolution to achieve my purpose.

en: I have not been used to submit to any person’s whims.
vi: I am not accustomed to submitting to anyone's whims.
tr: I have never bowed to anyone's whims in my life.
es: I will not give up.

en: I have not been in the habit of brooking disappointment.”
vi: I am not in the habit of enduring disappointment.
tr: I have never tolerated a no as an answer in my life."
es: I am not accustomed to submitting to anyone's whims; I am not made to endure disappointments.

en: “That will make your Ladyship’s situation at present more pitiable; but it will have no effect on me.”
vi: - This will make the current situation of the Lady even more pitiable, but it does not affect me.
tr: "This lady's current situation makes it even more pitiable, but it cannot affect me."
es: ––This may make His Lordship's current situation more distressing, but it does not affect me.

en: “I will not be interrupted!
vi: - I do not want to be interrupted.
tr: "Do not interrupt me.
es: ––I don't want you to interrupt me!

en: Hear me in silence.
vi: Be quiet and listen to me.
tr: Listen to me quietly.
es: Listen in silence.

en: My daughter and my nephew are formed for each other.
vi: My daughter and my grandson were raised to live together.
tr: My daughter and my niece were considered for each other.
es: My daughter and my nephew have been made for each other.

en: They are descended, on the maternal side, from the same noble line; and, on the father’s, from respectable, honourable, and ancient, though untitled, families.
vi: Both have maternal relations from the same noble lineage, and paternal relations from respectable, honorable families, though not titled.
tr: They come from the same noble lineage on their mother's side, and from respectable, honorable, and old families on their father's side, even if without titles.
es: On their maternal side, they descend from the same illustrious branch, and on their paternal side, from respectable, honorable, and ancient families, though without title.

en: Their fortune on both sides is splendid.
vi: The wealth of both sides is abundant.
tr: Their wealth on both sides is immense.
es: The fortune on both sides is splendid.

en: They are destined for each other by the voice of every member of their respective houses; and what is to divide them?—the upstart pretensions of a young woman without family, connections, or fortune!
vi: They have been paired together by the voice of every family member, what could possibly prevent them? The arrogant expectations of a young girl not from a noble family, with no good connections, no wealth.
tr: In the eyes of every member of both families, they belong to each other; so what will separate them? The arrogant dreams of a young woman without family, relatives, or wealth.
es: They are destined for each other by the vote of all the members of their respective houses; and what can separate them? The untimely pretensions of a girl of humble birth and without fortune.

en: Is this to be endured?
vi: And to endure this!
tr: Is this something to be endured!
es: How can this be admitted?

en: But it must not, shall not be!
vi: But no, it cannot be.
tr: Absolutely not, and it will not be.
es: But it will not happen!

en: If you were sensible of your own good, you would not wish to quit the sphere in which you have been brought up.”
vi: If she were sensitive to her value, she would not want to step away from the social standing in which she was raised.
tr: If you thought of your own good, you would not want to leave the environment in which you grew up."
es: If she looked out for her own good, she would not want to leave the sphere in which she was born.

en: “In marrying your nephew, I should not consider myself as quitting that sphere.
vi: - If I were to marry your grandson, I think I wouldn't have to leave my position.
tr: "I will not think that I have left that circle by marrying your nephew.
es: ––By marrying your nephew, I would not believe I am stepping out of my sphere.

en: He is a gentleman; I am a gentleman’s daughter; so far we are equal.”
vi: He is a nobleman, I am the daughter of a nobleman. Up until now, we are equal.
tr: He is a gentleman; I am also the daughter of a gentleman; in this respect, we are equal."
es: He is a gentleman, and I am the daughter of another gentleman; therefore, we are equals.

en: “True.
vi: - Correct.
tr: "Correct.
es: ––That's right; you are the daughter of a gentleman.

en: You are a gentleman’s daughter.
vi: You are the daughter of a noble father.
tr: You are a gentleman's daughter.
es: ––That's right; you are the daughter of a gentleman.

en: But what was your mother?
vi: But who is your mother?
tr: But who is your mother?
es: But, who is your mother?

en: Who are your uncles and aunts?
vi: Who are your uncles and aunts?
tr: Who are your uncles and aunts?
es: Who are your uncles and aunts?

en: Do not imagine me ignorant of their condition.”
vi: Don't think I know nothing about your circumstances.
tr: Don't think I'm unaware of them."
es: Do you think I am unaware of your status?

en: “Whatever my connections may be,” said Elizabeth, “if your nephew does not object to them, they can be nothing to you.”
vi: - No matter what my relationships are, if your grandson doesn't care, then it has nothing to do with you.
tr: "Whoever my relatives may be," said Elizabeth, "if your nephew does not object to them, they are none of your concern."
es: ––Whatever my relatives may be, if your nephew has nothing to say about them, you have even less to say ––replied Elizabeth.

en: “Tell me, once for all, are you engaged to him?”
vi: - Tell me definitively, do you have a romantic relationship with him?
tr: "Tell me honestly, are you engaged to her?"
es: Tell me once and for all, are you engaged to him?

en: Though Elizabeth would not, for the mere purpose of obliging Lady Catherine, have answered this question, she could not but say, after a moment’s deliberation,—
vi: Although Elizabeth might not answer this question merely to oblige Lady Catherine; after a moment of thought, she had to say:
tr: Actually, Elizabeth would not have answered this question to please Lady Catherine, but after thinking for a moment, she couldn't help but respond,
es: Although merely out of the desire to be thanked by Lady Catherine, Elizabeth would not have answered her question; she could not help but say, after a moment of deliberation:

en: “I am not.”
vi: - I don't have it.
tr: "No."
es: ––I'm not.

en: Lady Catherine seemed pleased.
vi: Mrs. Catherine seemed pleased.
tr: Lady Catherine seemed pleased.
es: Lady Catherine seemed pleased.

en: “And will you promise me never to enter into such an engagement?”
vi: - And can you promise me that you will never have such a relationship, can you?
tr: "Well, will you promise me that you won't get engaged?""
es: ––And do you promise me never to make such a commitment?

en: “I will make no promise of the kind.”
vi: - I don't promise anything about this.
tr: "I cannot make such a promise."
es: ––I will not make any such promise.

en: “Miss Bennet, I am shocked and astonished.
vi: - Miss Bennet, I am shocked and surprised.
tr: "Miss Bennet, I am shocked, horrified.
es: Miss Bennet! I am horrified and astonished!

en: I expected to find a more reasonable young woman.
vi: I had hoped to meet a more sensible young lady.
tr: I thought I would find a more reasonable young woman.
es: I expected you to be more sensible.

en: But do not deceive yourself into a belief that I will ever recede.
vi: But do not delude yourself that I will yield.
tr: But do not deceive yourself into thinking I will give up.
es: But do not delude yourself: I do not intend to yield.

en: I shall not go away till you have given me the assurance I require.”
vi: I will not leave unless you assure me of what I request.
tr: I will not leave here until you give me the guarantee I want."
es: I will not leave until you have given me the assurance I demand.

en: “And I certainly never shall give it.
vi: - And certainly, I never guarantee anything about this matter.
tr: "I will never give in.
es: ––Well, the truth is that I will never give it to her.

en: I am not to be intimidated into anything so wholly unreasonable.
vi: I am not easily threatened into accepting anything completely unreasonable like this.
tr: You cannot intimidate me into something so irrational.
es: Do not think that I will be intimidated by such a ridiculous thing.

en: Your Ladyship wants mr Darcy to marry your daughter; but would my giving you the wished-for promise make their marriage at all more probable?
vi: The lady wants Mr. Darcy to marry her daughter, but when I promise what she wants, will their marriage be more successful?
tr: Lady, you want Mr. Darcy to marry your daughter; but will giving you the promise you seek make their marriage possible?
es: What Your Ladyship wants is for Darcy to marry your daughter; but if I made you the promise you desire, would that marriage be more likely?

en: Supposing him to be attached to me, would my refusing to accept his hand make him wish to bestow it on his cousin?
vi: Suppose he loves me, will my refusal make him declare his love for his cousin?
tr: Assuming he loves me, will my rejection of his proposal make him propose to your daughter?
es: Suppose he is interested in me; if I refused to accept his hand, do you think he would offer it to his cousin?

en: Allow me to say, Lady Catherine, that the arguments with which you have supported this extraordinary application have been as frivolous as the application was ill-judged.
vi: Lady Catherine, allow me to say that the arguments you present to justify this extraordinary demand are as frivolous as the manner in which you make this ill-considered demand.
tr: Let me tell you, Lady Catherine, the reasons supporting this extraordinary request are as absurd as the request itself.
es: Allow me to tell you, Lady Catherine, that the arguments you have used to support your extraordinary demand have been as frivolous as the demand itself is thoughtless.

en: You have widely mistaken my character, if you think I can be worked on by such persuasions as these.
vi: You have mistaken my character if you think I can be persuaded by such means.
tr: If you think I will be influenced by such words, you are greatly mistaken about my character.
es: You have greatly mistaken me if you think I can be convinced by such reasons.

en: How far your nephew might approve of your interference in his affairs, I cannot tell; but you have certainly no right to concern yourself in mine.
vi: How your nephew will think of you when you interfere in his love affairs, I cannot say, but surely you have no right to interfere in mine.
tr: I do not know how much your nephew approves of your interference in his private affairs, but you have no right to interfere in mine.
es: I do not know to what extent your nephew will approve of your interference in his affairs; but you certainly have no right to meddle in mine.

en: I must beg, therefore, to be importuned no further on the subject.”
vi: Therefore, I ask you not to trouble me any further about this matter.
tr: Therefore, I ask you, please do not prolong this matter any further."
es: Therefore, I beg you not to bother me any further on this matter.

en: “Not so hasty, if you please.
vi: - Don't be hasty.
tr: "Not so fast.
es: ––Do not rush, please, I have not finished yet.

en: I have by no means done.
vi: I haven't finished speaking.
tr: I'm not finished.
es: ––Do not rush, please, I have not finished yet.

en: To all the objections I have already urged I have still another to add.
vi: With all the arguments I've made against you, I have one more thing.
tr: There is one more thing I want to add to all the objections I have made.
es: To all the objections I have raised, I must add one more.

en: I am no stranger to the particulars of your youngest sister’s infamous elopement.
vi: I know all the details about the scandal when your youngest sister ran away with a man.
tr: I am not unaware of the details of your youngest brother's disgraceful escape.
es: I am not unaware of the details of the infamous abduction of your younger sister.

en: I know it all; that the young man’s marrying her was a patched-up business, at the expense of your father and uncle.
vi: I know everything, I know that his marriage to the girl was just a patch-up measure, with the expenses borne by your father and your uncle.
tr: I know everything; the young man's marriage to her was a hastily arranged affair, orchestrated by your father and uncle.
es: I know everything. I know that the boy married her thanks to an arrangement made between his father and his uncle.

en: And is such a girl to be my nephew’s sister?
vi: And can such a girl be the sister-in-law of my nephew?
tr: Will such a girl become my nephew's sister-in-law?
es: And that woman is to be my nephew's sister?

en: Is her husband, who is the son of his late father’s steward, to be his brother?
vi: Can her husband, a son of a servant working for his grandfather, be the brother-in-law of my nephew?
tr: Will her husband, the son of her late father's steward, become his brother-in-law?
es: And her husband, the son of your father's former steward, is to become Darcy's brother?

en: Heaven and earth!—of what are you thinking?
vi: Good heavens! What do you think about this!
tr: God forbid! –what do you say to that?
es: For heaven's sake! What do you think?

en: Are the shades of Pemberley to be thus polluted?”
vi: Will the Pemberley estate be tainted like that?
tr: Will the shades of Pemberley be thus polluted?"
es: Are the ancestors of Pemberley to be desecrated in this way?

en: “You can now have nothing further to say,” she resentfully answered.
vi: She replied, annoyed: - Now you have nothing more to say.
tr: "You can't say anything else now," he replied with distress.
es: ––You have already said it all ––replied Elizabeth indignantly––.

en: “You have insulted me, in every possible method.
vi: You have humiliated me in every possible way.
tr: "You have insulted me in every possible way.
es: You have insulted me in every possible way.

en: I must beg to return to the house.”
vi: I beg you to return home.
tr: With your permission, I am returning home."
es: I beg you, let us return home.

en: And she rose as she spoke.
vi: And she spoke while standing up.
tr: He stood up while saying these words.
es: And upon saying this, he stood up.

en: Lady Catherine rose also, and they turned back.
vi: Lady Catherine also stood up, and both of them turned back.
tr: Lady Catherine also stood up and they turned back.
es: Lady Catherine stood up as well and they returned.

en: Her Ladyship was highly incensed.
vi: Lady Catherine was very angry.
tr: Her Ladyship was quite angry.
es: Her Ladyship was in a rage.

en: “You have no regard, then, for the honour and credit of my nephew!
vi: - So, you don't care about my nephew's honor and reputation!
tr: "So, you have no respect for my nephew's honor and dignity!
es: ––So, you have no regard for the honor and reputation of my nephew?

en: Unfeeling, selfish girl!
vi: You are an insensitive, selfish girl!
tr: Heartless, selfish girl!
es: You insensitive and selfish creature!

en: Do you not consider that a connection with you must disgrace him in the eyes of everybody?”
vi: Do you think your relationship with him is a disgrace in the eyes of everyone?
tr: Don't you ever think that being involved with you will ruin his reputation in everyone's eyes?"
es: Don't you realize that if he marries you, he will be discredited in the eyes of everyone?

en: “Lady Catherine, I have nothing further to say.
vi: - Mrs. Catherine, I have nothing more to say.
tr: "Lady Catherine, I have nothing more to say.
es: Lady Catherine, I have nothing more to say.

en: You know my sentiments.”
vi: You have understood my feelings.
tr: You know my thoughts."
es: You already know what I think.

en: “You are then resolved to have him?”
vi: - So you are determined to take my grandchild??
tr: "So, you're going to marry him, is that right?"
es: ––Are you, then, determined to achieve it?

en: “I have said no such thing.
vi: - I didn't say anything about such a matter.
tr: "I didn't say such a thing.
es: ––I have not said such a thing.

en: I am only resolved to act in that manner, which will, in my own opinion, constitute my happiness, without reference to you, or to any person so wholly unconnected with me.”
vi: I just firmly decided to act in a way that I believe will create happiness for me without involving you, or anyone else who has no relation to me.
tr: According to my own view, I am determined to act only in a way that will make me happy; I don't care what you or others who have nothing to do with me say."
es: I am only determined to act in the way that I believe is most convenient for my happiness without taking you or anyone who has so little to do with me into account.

en: “It is well.
vi: - Alright.
tr: "Alright.
es: ––Very well.

en: You refuse, then, to oblige me.
vi: So you refused my request.
tr: So you refuse.
es: Then you refuse to please me.

en: You refuse to obey the claims of duty, honour, and gratitude.
vi: You refused to comply with all the demands of duty, honor, and gratitude.
tr: You refuse to fulfill the requirements of duty, honor, and gratitude.
es: You refuse to obey the command of duty, honor, and gratitude.

en: You are determined to ruin him in the opinion of all his friends, and make him the contempt of the world.”
vi: You insist on ruining my nephew's life in the eyes of all his loved ones, causing him to be scorned by the world.
tr: You are determined to ruin him in the eyes of all his friends, to disgrace him before the world."
es: You are determined to humiliate my nephew in front of all his friends and make him the laughingstock of everyone.

en: “Neither duty, nor honour, nor gratitude,” replied Elizabeth, “has any possible claim on me, in the present instance.
vi: - All duties, honors, and gratitude cannot have any plea in a situation like this.
tr: "Neither duty, nor honor, nor gratitude," replied Elizabeth, "can influence me in such a situation.
es: ––Neither duty, nor honor, nor gratitude ––replied Elizabeth––, can demand anything from me in the present circumstances.

en: No principle of either would be violated by my marriage with mr Darcy.
vi: And my marriage to Mr. Darcy does not violate any principle at all.
tr: There is nothing in my marrying Mr. Darcy that violates these principles.
es: None of your principles would be violated by my marriage to Darcy.

en: And with regard to the resentment of his family, or the indignation of the world, if the former were excited by his marrying me, it would not give me one moment’s concern—and the world in general would have too much sense to join in the scorn.”
vi: And speaking of his family's outrage, even if the family were delighted about his marrying me, I wouldn't care in the slightest. Or speaking of the world's disdain, generally, the world must have too much consciousness to interfere.
tr: As for offending the family or the world's disdain, if his family gets excited about marrying me, it wouldn't worry me for a moment – and the world knows better than to concern itself with such matters."
es: And as for the resentment of your family or the indignation of the world, if the former are enraged by my marriage to their nephew, I wouldn't care in the slightest; and the world would have enough good sense to join me in my disdain.

en: “And this is your real opinion!
vi: - And that is her true opinion!
tr: "So this is your true opinion!
es: ––And this is your attitude, your final resolution?

en: This is your final resolve!
vi: This is your final decision?!
tr: This is your final decision!
es: ––And this is your attitude, your final resolution?

en: Very well.
vi: Very well.
tr: Very well.
es: Very well; I know what I have to do.

en: I shall now know how to act.
vi: Now I know how to act.
tr: I know what I will do.
es: Very well; I know what I have to do.

en: Do not imagine, Miss Bennet, that your ambition will ever be gratified.
vi: Miss Bennet, don't think your ambition will come true.
tr: Do not think that Miss Bennet will reap the rewards of ambition.
es: Do not imagine that your ambition, Miss Bennet, will ever be satisfied.

en: I came to try you.
vi: I came here to try to settle things with you.
tr: I came here to test you.
es: I came to test you.

en: I hoped to find you reasonable; but depend upon it I will carry my point.”
vi: I had hoped you were reasonable, so that I could persuade you.
tr: I hoped to find you reasonable; but be assured, I will do what I have set my mind to."
es: I hoped you would be a reasonable person. But rest assured that I will have my way.

en: In this manner Lady Catherine talked on till they were at the door of the carriage, when, turning hastily round, she added,—
vi: In such a tone, Lady Catherine continued to speak until they reached the carriage, then suddenly turning back, she added:
tr: Lady Catherine kept talking like this until they reached the car door; then she turned hastily and added these words,
es: Lady Catherine said all this until they reached the carriage door. Then she turned and said:

en: “I take no leave of you, Miss Bennet.
vi: - Miss Bennet, I am not saying goodbye to you.
tr: "I am not asking for your permission, Miss Bennet.
es: ––I do not bid you farewell, Miss Bennet; I send no regards to your mother; you do not deserve such attention.

en: I send no compliments to your mother.
vi: I do not wish to send my regards to your mother.
tr: I am not sending my regards to your mother either.
es: ––I do not bid you farewell, Miss Bennet; I send no regards to your mother; you do not deserve such attention.

en: You deserve no such attention.
vi: You do not deserve such attention.
tr: You do not deserve such attention.
es: ––I do not bid you farewell, Miss Bennet; I send no regards to your mother; you do not deserve such attention.

en: I am most seriously displeased.”
vi: I am extremely displeased.
tr: You have seriously annoyed me."
es: You have gravely offended me.

en: Elizabeth made no answer; and without attempting to persuade her Ladyship to return into the house, walked quietly into it herself.
vi: Elizabeth did not answer and did not want to try to persuade her to come back into the house.
tr: Elizabeth did not respond; without attempting to persuade her ladyship to return home, she quietly walked into the house on her own.
es: Elizabeth did not respond nor did she try to persuade Her Ladyship to come into the house. She left alone and slowly.

en: She heard the carriage drive away as she proceeded upstairs.
vi: She quickly turned away. She heard the sound of the carriage leaving as she ascended the steps.
tr: As she was going upstairs, she heard the carriage driving away.
es: As she was going up the stairs, she heard the carriage depart.

en: Her mother impatiently met her at the door of her dressing-room, to ask why Lady Catherine would not come in again and rest herself.
vi: Her mother anxiously came out to meet her at the living room door, to ask why Lady Catherine did not come back into the house to rest.
tr: Her mother impatiently met her at the door of the dressing room, asking why Lady Catherine had not come back in to rest.
es: Her mother, impatient, met her at the door of the dressing room to ask her why Lady Catherine had not come back to rest.

en: “She did not choose it,” said her daughter; “she would go.”
vi: Her daughter replied: - She doesn't want to, she wants to go.
tr: "She didn't want to," said the girl. "She was going to leave.""
es: ––He didn't want to ––said his daughter––. He has left.

en: “She is a very fine-looking woman!
vi: - She looks so beautiful!
tr: "What a pleasant woman!
es: ––What a distinguished woman!

en: and her calling here was prodigiously civil!
vi: And she is so polite to visit us!
tr: It was extremely kind of her to visit us!
es: And what courtesy on her part to come visit us!

en: for she only came, I suppose, to tell us the Collinses were well.
vi: Because mother thinks she came just to let us know that Mr. Collins' family is still doing well.
tr: because surely she came just to tell us that the Collinses are well.
es: Because I suppose she has come to tell us that the Collinses are well.

en: She is on her road somewhere, I dare say; and so, passing through Meryton, thought she might as well call on you.
vi: I am sure she was on her way somewhere, and when passing through Meryton, she intended to visit you.
tr: Obviously, she was going somewhere else and thought of stopping by to see you while passing through Meryton.
es: She must have been going somewhere and thought she could visit us while passing through Meryton.

en: I suppose she had nothing particular to say to you, Lizzy?”
vi: I don't think she had anything special to say to you, did she, Lizzy?
tr: She didn't have anything special to tell you, did she, Lizzy?"
es: I suppose she didn't have anything particular to say to you, right, Lizzy?

en: Elizabeth was forced to give in to a little falsehood here; for to acknowledge the substance of their conversation was impossible.
vi: Elizabeth had to tell a little lie because she couldn't possibly reveal the content of the conversation between the two.
tr: Elizabeth had to resort to a bit of lying at this point; because it was impossible to explain the subject of their conversations.
es: Elizabeth was forced to tell a small lie, because uncovering the subject of her conversation was impossible.

en: CHAPTER LVII.
vi: Chapter 57
tr: Chapter XV
es: CHAPTER LVII

en: THE discomposure of spirits which this extraordinary visit threw Elizabeth into could not be easily overcome; nor could she for many hours learn to think of it less than incessantly.
vi: Elizabeth could not calm the turmoil in her mind caused by that unusual visit, and for many hours, she could not stop thinking about it.
tr: It was not easy for Elizabeth to overcome the annoyance caused by this extraordinary visit; she could not manage to stop thinking about it for hours at a time.
es: Not without difficulty did Elizabeth manage to overcome the agitation caused by that extraordinary visit. She spent many hours unable to think of anything else.

en: Lady Catherine, it appeared, had actually taken the trouble of this journey from Rosings for the sole purpose of breaking off her supposed engagement with mr Darcy.
vi: It seemed that Lady Catherine had taken the trouble to come from Rosings with the sole purpose of preventing her relationship with Mr. Darcy.
tr: Lady Catherine had evidently gone to all the trouble of coming from Rosings to there just to break off her imaginary engagement with Mr. Darcy.
es: Apparently, Lady Catherine had taken the trouble to travel from Rosings to Hertfordshire with the sole purpose of breaking her supposed engagement with Darcy.

en: It was a rational scheme, to be sure!
vi: Indeed, this was a reasonable assumption!
tr: It was indeed a clever plan!
es: Although Lady Catherine was very capable of such a project, Elizabeth could not imagine where she had gotten the news of said engagement, until she remembered that his being such a good friend of Bingley and she being Jane's sister could have given rise to the idea, since the marriage of one couple predisposed to suppose the marriage of the other.

en: but from what the report of their engagement could originate, Elizabeth was at a loss to imagine; till she recollected that his being the intimate friend of Bingley, and her being the sister of Jane, was enough, at a time when the expectation of one wedding made everybody eager for another, to supply the idea.
vi: But Elizabeth could not understand how news of their relationship had spread, and she recalled that he was a close friend of Bingley, while she was Jane's sister. That was enough to spark the idea, when the desire for a marriage made everyone excited about another wedding.
tr: But Elizabeth had no idea where the rumor of their engagement could have originated; eventually, she thought that Darcy being Bingley's close friend, and him being Jane's brother, at a time when everyone was expecting one wedding, was enough to give rise to the idea of a second one.
es: Although Lady Catherine was very capable of such a project, Elizabeth could not imagine where she had gotten the news of said engagement, until she remembered that his being such a good friend of Bingley and she being Jane's sister could have given rise to the idea, since the marriage of one couple predisposed to suppose the marriage of the other.

en: She had not herself forgotten to feel that the marriage of her sister must bring them more frequently together.
vi: She herself had not forgotten that her sister's marriage would certainly bring her and Darcy closer together more often.
tr: She had not forgotten that her sister's marriage would bring them together more frequently.
es: Elizabeth had indeed thought that her sister's marriage would bring her and Darcy closer together.

en: And her neighbours at Lucas Lodge, therefore, (for through their communication with the Collinses, the report, she concluded, had reached Lady Catherine,) had only set that down as almost certain and immediate which she had looked forward to as possible at some future time.
vi: And thus, the neighbors at the Lucas house had concluded that this would surely and quickly happen, while she herself only hoped it could be possible in the future. She guessed that Lady Catherine had learned about it through the information exchanged between the Lucas and Collins households.
tr: So, their neighbors at Lucas Lodge (since they communicated with the Collinses, she concluded that the rumor had reached Lady Catherine through them) had conveyed what Elizabeth saw as a possibility for the future as if it were a done deal.
es: That must have been why the Lucases—through whose correspondence with the Collinses Elizabeth presumed the conjecture had reached Lady Catherine's ears—considered immediate what she had also believed possible for later.

en: In revolving Lady Catherine’s expressions, however, she could not help feeling some uneasiness as to the possible consequence of her persisting in this interference.
vi: However, upon reconsidering Lady Catherine's words, she couldn't help but feel some unease about the consequences of her insistence on intervening.
tr: However, while contemplating Lady Catherine's statements, she couldn't help but feel a bit uneasy about the likely outcome of her insistence on this intervention.
es: But upon reflecting on Lady Catherine's words, she could not avoid a certain uneasiness about the consequences that her interference might have.

en: From what she had said of her resolution to prevent the marriage, it occurred to Elizabeth that she must meditate an application to her nephew; and how he might take a similar representation of the evils attached to a connection with her she dared not pronounce.
vi: From her determined words to prevent the wedding, Elizabeth suddenly thought that she would surely persuade her nephew, and she dared not think how he would react to arguments about the detrimental aspects of their relationship.
tr: From what she said about her decision to prevent their marriage, Elizabeth thought she might be planning to make a request to her nephew; if she conveyed the same negatives of being related to him, Elizabeth dared not think how Darcy would respond.
es: From what she said about her resolution to prevent the marriage, Elizabeth deduced that she intended to confront her nephew, and she did not know how Darcy would take the relation of the dangers that their union entailed.

en: She knew not the exact degree of his affection for his aunt, or his dependence on her judgment, but it was natural to suppose that he thought much higher of her Ladyship than she could do; and it was certain, that in enumerating the miseries of a marriage with one whose immediate connections were so unequal to his own, his aunt would address him on his weakest side.
vi: She was not exactly sure of his feelings towards his aunt, but naturally, one could assume that he thought more highly of Lady Catherine than she could. It was certain that when listing the drawbacks of a marriage with someone of unequal social standing, his aunt would exploit his weakest points.
tr: She did not know the exact degree of his attachment to his aunt or how much he valued her opinions, but it was natural for him to hold Lady Catherine in higher regard than Elizabeth could; moreover, it was certain that while listing the troubles of marrying someone whose close relatives were so inferior to his own, his aunt would be appealing to his weakest point.
es: She was unaware of the extent of Darcy's affection for his aunt and how much he valued her opinion; but it was logical to suppose that he had more regard for Her Ladyship than she did, and she was sure that her aunt would touch a sore spot by enumerating the misfortunes of a marriage with a person from a family so unequal to his own.

en: With his notions of dignity, he would probably feel that the arguments, which to Elizabeth had appeared weak and ridiculous, contained much good sense and solid reasoning.
vi: With his notions of propriety, he might think that the arguments, which Elizabeth found weak and laughable, were reasonable and solid.
tr: Darcy, with his views on nobility that Elizabeth found weak and ridiculous, would probably feel that these claims were reasonable and thoroughly considered.
es: Given Darcy's ideas on that particular matter, Elizabeth believed it likely that the arguments that had seemed so weak and ridiculous to her might appear to him full of good sense and solid reasoning.

en: If he had been wavering before, as to what he should do, which had often seemed likely, the advice and entreaty of so near a relation might settle every doubt, and determine him at once to be as happy as dignity unblemished could make him.
vi: If before he seemed to hesitate, not knowing what to do, now the advice and encouragement of such a close relative could dispel all doubts and determine that he immediately becomes happy in a way that an unblemished dignity can help him be happy.
tr: If Darcy was undecided about what he should do until then, which often seemed to be the case, the suggestions and desires of such a close relative could dispel any doubt and lead him to happiness within the possibilities of unblemished nobility in an instant.
es: So if Darcy had hesitated before about what he had to do, which he often seemed to, the warnings and urgings of such a close relative might dispel all his doubts and incline him once and for all to be as happy as an immaculate dignity would allow him.

en: In that case he would return no more.
vi: In this case, he would not return to her anymore.
tr: In that case, he would not return.
es: In that case, Darcy would not return to Hertfordshire.

en: Lady Catherine might see him in her way through town; and his engagement to Bingley of coming again to Netherfield must give way.
vi: On the way, Lady Catherine might meet him in the city, and he would have to abandon the idea of returning to Netherfield with Bingley.
tr: Lady Catherine could stop by to see him while going to the city; and the promise he made to Bingley to return to Netherfield would be forgotten.
es: Lady Catherine would see him as he passed through London, and the young man would rescind his commitment to Bingley to return to Netherfield.

en: “If, therefore, an excuse for not keeping his promise should come to his friend within a few days,” she added, “I shall know how to understand it.
vi: She thought further: "Therefore, if in the next few days he makes excuses to his friends about not keeping his promises, I will understand the situation.
tr: "So, if instead of keeping the promise he made to his friend to return in a few days, he sends an apology letter," she added, "I know how to interpret that.
es: "Therefore," Elizabeth said to herself, "if in a few days Bingley receives an excuse from Darcy for not coming, I will know what to expect.

en: I shall then give over every expectation, every wish of his constancy.
vi: I will give up all hopes about his loyalty.
tr: Then I will put an end to every hope, every wish related to his commitment.
es: And then I will have to rid myself of all hope and illusion about his constancy.

en: If he is satisfied with only regretting me, when he might have obtained my affections and hand, I shall soon cease to regret him at all.”
vi: If he is only complacent with feeling sorry for himself, when he could win my affection, soon I might not regret anything about him anymore."
tr: If missing me will suffice for him when he could have my love and my yes, I will immediately stop missing him." ------------------------
es: If he is content to lament my loss when he could have obtained my love and my hand, I too will soon cease to lament losing him."

en: The surprise of the rest of the family, on hearing who their visitor had been, was very great: but they obligingly satisfied it with the same kind of supposition which had appeased ms Bennet’s curiosity; and Elizabeth was spared from much teasing on the subject.
vi: When they heard the news about the visitor, the rest of the family were extremely surprised, but they accepted Mrs. Bennet's explanation, and Elizabeth escaped everyone's teasing.
tr: The other family members were greatly surprised to hear who had come to visit; but they dispelled it with the same kind of assumption that satisfied Mrs. Bennet's curiosity, thus sparing Elizabeth from being pressed on the matter.
es: The surprise of the rest of the family upon learning who the visitor had been was enormous; but they explained everything in the same way as Mrs. Bennet, and Elizabeth was spared having to mention her indignation.

en: The next morning, as she was going down stairs, she was met by her father, who came out of his library with a letter in his hand.
vi: The next morning, as she was walking down the stairs, just as her father was coming out of the study, holding a letter in his hand.
tr: The next morning, while coming down the stairs, he encountered his father coming out of the library with a letter in his hand.
es: The next morning, when coming down from his room, he met his father who was coming out of the library with a letter in his hand.

en: “Lizzy,” said he, “I was going to look for you: come into my room.”
vi: He said: - Lizzy, I'm looking for you. Come into my room.
tr: "Lizzy," said her father, "I was just about to look for you; come to my room.""
es: ––Elizabeth ––he said to her––, I was looking for you. Come with me.

en: She followed him thither; and her curiosity to know what he had to tell her was heightened by the supposition of its being in some manner connected with the letter he held.
vi: She followed him, increasingly curious about what he would say to her, which she guessed was related to the letter in his hand.
tr: Elizabeth entered after her father; her curiosity about what he had to say increased even more when she thought it might somehow be related to the letter in her hand.
es: Elizabeth followed him and her curiosity to know what he had to communicate to her increased, thinking that it might be related to the previous day.

en: It suddenly struck her that it might be from Lady Catherine, and she anticipated with dismay all the consequent explanations.
vi: Suddenly, she guessed this might be a letter from Lady Catherine, and she became disheartened thinking about the explanations that would follow.
tr: Suddenly, she thought the letter might have come from Lady Catherine, and she anxiously considered all the explanations that would entail.
es: Suddenly, it occurred to her that the letter could be from Lady Catherine, and she anticipated with dismay what it might be about.

en: She followed her father to the fireplace, and they both sat down.
vi: The two people sat down near the fireplace, then he said:
tr: He followed his father to the fireplace; they sat together.
es: He went with his father to the fireplace and they both sat down.

en: He then said,—
vi: The two people sat down near the fireplace, then he said:
tr: His father began to speak,
es: Then Mr. Bennet said:

en: “I have received a letter this morning that has astonished me exceedingly.
vi: - Dad received this letter this morning. Dad was extremely surprised.
tr: "This morning, I received a letter that surprised me greatly.
es: ––I received a letter this morning that left me flabbergasted.

en: As it principally concerns yourself, you ought to know its contents.
vi: Since it mainly concerns you, you need to know the content.
tr: It actually concerns you, so you have the right to know its contents.
es: Since it mainly concerns you, you should know its contents.

en: I did not know before that I had two daughters on the brink of matrimony.
vi: Previously, Dad did not know he had two daughters about to get married.
tr: I did not know before that my two daughters were on the verge of marriage.
es: Until now, I didn't know that you had two daughters about to get married.

en: Let me congratulate you on a very important conquest.”
vi: Dad congratulates you on a very important conquest.
tr: Allow me to congratulate you on this very important achievement."
es: Allow me to congratulate you on such an achievement.

en: The colour now rushed into Elizabeth’s cheeks in the instantaneous conviction of its being a letter from the nephew, instead of the aunt; and she was undetermined whether most to be pleased that he explained himself at all, or offended that his letter was not rather addressed to herself, when her father continued,—
vi: Elizabeth's face turned red with joy when she immediately thought it was a letter from her nephew instead of her aunt. While she didn't know whether to be happy because he had calmed everything down, or upset because he didn't write to her directly, her father spoke up:
tr: The belief that the letter was not from her aunt but from her niece caused blood to rush to Elizabeth's cheeks; she could not decide whether to be pleased that Darcy had finally expressed himself or to be offended that he had not written the letter to her; her father continued,
es: Elizabeth was left stunned, believing that the letter was from the nephew instead of the aunt; and she wavered between being glad that Darcy was finally explaining himself, and being offended that he had not addressed the letter to her, when her father continued:

en: “You look conscious.
vi: - You seem alert.
tr: "It is understood that you know.
es: ––It seems like you can guess it.

en: Young ladies have great penetration in such matters as these; but I think I may defy even your sagacity to discover the name of your admirer.
vi: Young girls have the ability to see through such matters, but I think I can even challenge your sharp intellect.
tr: Young ladies have strong intuitions about such matters; but I think I can even surpass your intelligence in discovering the name of your admirer.
es: You girls have great intuition for these matters. But I think I can challenge your shrewdness by daring you to discover the name of your admirer.

en: This letter is from mr Collins.”
vi: This letter is from Mr. Collins.
tr: This letter is from Mr. Collins."
es: The letter is from Collins.

en: “From mr Collins!
vi: - Mr. Collins!
tr: "From Mr. Collins!
es: ––From Collins!

en: and what can he have to say?”
vi: And what did he write?
tr: What could he possibly have to say?"
es: And what does he have to say?

en: “Something very much to the purpose, of course.
vi: - Of course, it's something that goes straight to the point.
tr: "Something aimed at the purpose, of course.
es: ––As expected, something very timely.

en: He begins with congratulations on the approaching nuptials of my eldest daughter, of which, it seems, he has been told by some of the good-natured, gossiping Lucases.
vi: He began the letter with congratulations to Father on the upcoming wedding of his eldest daughter. It seems he heard the news from one of the kind-hearted, or gossiping, members of the Lucas family.
tr: Obviously, he heard from the good-hearted, gossiping Lucases, starting by congratulating on my eldest daughter's upcoming wedding.
es: He begins with congratulations on the upcoming wedding of my eldest daughter, of which he seems to have been informed by one of the kind and talkative Lucases.

en: I shall not sport with your impatience by reading what he says on that point.
vi: Father didn't want to test your patience, so he didn't read this part.
tr: I will not test your patience by reading what he said on that matter. Here's what he said about you.
es: I won't bore you by reading what he says about that point.

en: What relates to yourself is as follows:—‘Having thus offered you the sincere congratulations of ms Collins and myself on this happy event, let me now add a short hint on the subject of another, of which we have been advertised by the same authority.
vi: The part related to you is as follows: "After expressing the sincerest congratulations from Mrs. Collins and myself on that happy event, I now briefly address another matter.
tr: "After thus presenting the sincere congratulations of Mrs. Collins and myself on this happy event, let me add a brief word on another matter we learned from the same source.
es: What concerns you is the following: After having congratulated you on behalf of Mrs. Collins and myself for such a fortunate event, allow me to add a brief warning about another matter, of which we have been informed through the same channel.

en: Your daughter Elizabeth, it is presumed, will not long bear the name of Bennet, after her eldest sister has resigned it; and the chosen partner of her fate may be reasonably looked up to as one of the most illustrious personages in this land.’
vi: According to the same source, it is speculated that your daughter Elizabeth will soon no longer bear the Bennet surname. After the eldest daughter has taken another name, and the partner she has chosen is one of the most illustrious figures in this country." He spoke to Elizabeth while reading the letter:
tr: Your daughter Elizabeth, it is said, will not bear the Bennet name for long after her sister leaves; her chosen life partner also deserves to be admired as one of the most magnificent personalities in this land."
es: It is assumed that your daughter Elizabeth will not bear the name Bennet for much longer once her elder sister has left it, and that the partner she has been fortunate enough to secure can reasonably be considered one of our most illustrious personalities.

en: Can you possibly guess, Lizzy, who is meant by this?
vi: - Lizzy, can you guess who he is referring to?
tr: "I suppose you can guess whom I mean, can't you, Lizzy?"
es: ––Can you guess, Lizzy, what this means?

en: ‘This young gentleman is blessed, in a peculiar way, with everything the heart of mortal can most desire,—splendid property, noble kindred, and extensive patronage.
vi: "This young man is strangely endowed with many blessings, with everything that a mortal heart could dream of the most - magnificent wealth, noble lineage, and extensive patronage."
tr: "This young gentleman is specially blessed with everything mortal hearts might desire – a dazzling fortune, noble blood, and generous patronage.
es: That young man possesses everything one could desire in this world: superb properties, a distinguished family, and an extensive patronage.

en: Yet, in spite of all these temptations, let me warn my cousin Elizabeth, and yourself, of what evils you may incur by a precipitate closure with this gentleman’s proposals, which, of course, you will be inclined to take immediate advantage of.’
vi: However, despite such temptations, I must warn my cousin Elizabeth, and warn you, about the calamities that may arise from hastily accepting his proposal, which with these advantages, of course, no one would want to overlook."
tr: Yet despite all this charm, I must warn my cousin Elizabeth and yourself about the troubles you might face due to the sudden cancellation of this gentleman's proposals, which you would naturally wish to accept immediately."
es: But despite all those temptations, allow me to warn my cousin Elizabeth and yourself of the dangers you may face with a hasty acceptance of the proposals of such a gentleman, which, naturally, you might be inclined to consider advantageous.

en: Have you any idea, Lizzy, who this gentleman is?
vi: Lizzy, do you know who he is?
tr: "Do you have any idea who this gentleman is, Lizzy?
es: ––Do you have no idea who the gentleman is, Elizabeth?

en: But now it comes out.
vi: But here you will know: "The motivation that compels me to warn is this.
tr: But it is coming to light."
es: He's coming now.

en: ‘My motive for cautioning you is as follows:—We have reason to imagine that his aunt, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, does not look on the match with a friendly eye.’ mr Darcy, you see, is the man!
vi: We have reason to believe that his aunt, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, views the marriage with disfavor." He continued: - Mr. Darcy, my dear, it is him!
tr: "The reason I am warning you is this. We have reasons to believe that his aunt, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, does not look favorably upon the marriage." "Mr. Darcy, yes, our man is him!
es: The reasons I have for informing you are as follows: your aunt, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, does not look favorably upon this marriage. ––As you see, the gentleman in question is Mr. Darcy.

en: Now, Lizzy, I think I have surprised you.
vi: Now, Lizzy, I think I have surprised you.
tr: Now I must have surprised you, Lizzy.
es: I believe, Elizabeth, that you must be stunned.

en: Could he, or the Lucases, have pitched on any man, within the circle of our acquaintance, whose name would have given the lie more effectually to what they related?
vi: Could he, or the Lucas family, lie more blatantly than that when mentioning his name?
tr: Could Mr. Collins or the Lucases find another man among our acquaintances whose name would make their lies so obvious?
es: Neither Collins nor the Lucases could have chosen a name from our circle of friends that better reveals that what they are spreading is a falsehood.

en: mr Darcy, who never looks at any woman but to see a blemish, and who probably never looked at you in his life!
vi: Mr. Darcy, who always looks at women through their flaws, and who probably would never have looked at you in his entire life!
tr: Mr. Darcy, a man who looks at women only to find faults, and who probably has never even looked at you in his life!
es: Mr. Darcy, who only looks at a woman to criticize her, and who probably has never looked at you in his life!

en: It is admirable!”
vi: It's truly remarkable!
tr: They are magnificent, indeed!"
es: It's phenomenal!

en: Elizabeth tried to join in her father’s pleasantry, but could only force one most reluctant smile.
vi: Elizabeth wanted to chime in with her father's joke, but could only manage a forced smile.
tr: Elizabeth wanted to join in her father's amusement, but she could only manage a very joyless smile.
es: Elizabeth tried to joke with her father, but her effort resulted in nothing more than a very timid smile.

en: Never had his wit been directed in a manner so little agreeable to her.
vi: Never before had his manner of joking become so unpleasant to her as it was now. He asked:
tr: Her father's sarcasm had never seemed so unpleasant to her.
es: Her father's mood had never taken a more unpleasant turn for her.

en: “Are you not diverted?”
vi: - Are you distracted?
tr: "Didn't you have fun?"
es: ––Didn't it amuse you?

en: “Oh, yes.
vi: - Ah, yes.
tr: "Ah yes.
es: ––Of course!

en: Pray read on.”
vi: Please continue reading, Dad.
tr: Please continue."
es: Keep reading.

en: “‘After mentioning the likelihood of this marriage to her Ladyship last night, she immediately, with her usual condescension, expressed what she felt on the occasion; when it became apparent, that, on the score of some family objections on the part of my cousin, she would never give her consent to what she termed so disgraceful a match.
vi: - "Last night, after mentioning the possibility of this wedding, she immediately humbled herself as usual to give her opinion, when it was obvious that, due to much opposition related to my cousin, she would never accept what she called a disgraceful marriage.
tr: "After informing her ladyship of this marriage possibility last night, she immediately, as usual, condescended to express her feelings on the matter; it became clear that she would never consent to what she called a disgraceful union due to some objections related to my cousin's family.
es: When last night I mentioned to His Lordship the possibility of that marriage, with his usual condescension he expressed his opinion on the matter. If it were true, Lady Catherine would never give her consent to what she considers a most imprudent union due to certain objections to my cousin's family.

en: I thought it my duty to give the speediest intelligence of this to my cousin, that she and her noble admirer may be aware of what they are about, and not run hastily into a marriage which has not been properly sanctioned.’ mr Collins, moreover, adds, ‘I am truly rejoiced that my cousin Lydia’s sad business has been so well hushed up, and am only concerned that their living together before the marriage took place should be so generally known.
vi: I think I have a duty to quickly inform my cousin of this news, so that she and her noble suitor are aware of the situation and do not hastily proceed with the marriage without proper consent." He paused and then continued: - Mr. Collins continued writing like this: "I am truly delighted to see that Miss Lydia's unfortunate affair has been adequately covered up. I am only concerned that people will know they lived together before the wedding ceremony.
tr: I considered it my duty to immediately inform my cousin of this, so that he and his noble admirer would know what they were up against, and not rush into a marriage that had not been properly sanctioned. Mr. Collins then adds, "I was genuinely very pleased that my cousin Lydia's unfortunate affair had been so well resolved; my only concern is that it is widely known they lived together before the marriage.
es: I felt it my duty to communicate this as soon as possible to my cousin, so that she and her noble admirer know what is happening and do not rush into a marriage that has not been duly authorized. And Mr. Collins, moreover, added: I sincerely rejoice that the matter of your daughter Lydia has been resolved so well, and I only regret that the news spread that they were living together before the marriage had taken place.

en: I must not, however, neglect the duties of my station, or refrain from declaring my amazement, at hearing that you received the young couple into your house as soon as they were married.
vi: However, I should not forget my duties in my position, and I do not want to restrain my expression of surprise upon hearing that you welcomed the two into your home immediately after they were married.
tr: However, I will not neglect my professional duties and will not refrain from expressing how surprised I was to hear that you accepted the young couple into your home as soon as the marriage was solemnized.
es: I cannot forget what I owe to my position by refraining from expressing my astonishment upon learning that you received the young couple when they were married.

en: It was an encouragement of vice; and had I been the rector of Longbourn, I should very strenuously have opposed it.
vi: This is an attitude that encourages sin, and if I were the clergyman in charge of the Longbourn parish, I would actively prevent this.
tr: You have rewarded immorality; if I were the vicar of Longbourn, I would have strongly opposed this.
es: That was encouraging vice; and if I had been the rector of Longbourn, I would have resolutely opposed it.

en: You ought certainly to forgive them as a Christian, but never to admit them in your sight, or allow their names to be mentioned in your hearing.’
vi: As a Christian, you should certainly forgive, but you should never allow them to come near, nor permit others to mention their names to you."
tr: Of course, you must forgive them as a Christian, but you should never look them in the face again, nor allow their names to be mentioned."
es: It is true that you must forgive them as a Christian, but not admit them into your presence nor allow their names to be mentioned before you.

en: That is his notion of Christian forgiveness!
vi: That is his view on the magnanimity of a Christian!
tr: This is his definition of Christian tolerance!
es: ––This is his concept of Christian forgiveness!

en: The rest of his letter is only about his dear Charlotte’s situation, and his expectation of a young olive-branch.
vi: The rest of the letter only talks about the situation of his dear Charlotte and his wish for an olive branch.
tr: The rest of his letter is about his dear Charlotte's condition; she is expecting a child.
es: The rest of the letter refers only to the state of his dear Charlotte, and his hope of having an offspring.

en: But, Lizzy, you look as if you did not enjoy it.
vi: But, Lizzy, it seems you are not happy.
tr: But Lizzy, you seem displeased.
es: But, Elizabeth, it seems that you have not been amused.

en: You are not going to be missish, I hope, and pretend to be affronted at an idle report.
vi: I hope you will not become a lady and pretend to be insulted by such trivial news.
tr: I hope you are not offended; do not pretend to be upset by a silly letter.
es: I suppose you wouldn't get angry and take offense at this foolishness.

en: For what do we live, but to make sport for our neighbours, and laugh at them in our turn?”
vi: For what do we live, if not to endure our neighbors, and laugh with them in turn?
tr: Because why do we live? To amuse ourselves with our neighbors, and to laugh at them when it is our turn."
es: What do we live for if not to entertain our neighbors and laugh at them in turn?

en: “Oh,” cried Elizabeth, “I am exceedingly diverted.
vi: Elizabeth exclaimed:
tr: "Yo," shouted Elizabeth, "I had a great time.
es: ––Yes, I had a lot of fun ––exclaimed Elizabeth––.

en: But it is so strange!”
vi: - Oh! I have been overly distracted. These things are really strange. - Right.
tr: But it's very strange."
es: But it is so strange!

en: “Yes, that is what makes it amusing.
vi: The interesting thing is right there.
tr: "Yes, –that's why it's fun anyway.
es: ––Well, that's what makes it funnier.

en: Had they fixed on any other man it would have been nothing; but his perfect indifference and your pointed dislike make it so delightfully absurd!
vi: If they were talking about any other young man, it wouldn't matter at all; but while he is completely indifferent and she bitterly hates him, the matter has become amusingly absurd!
tr: If they had chosen another man, it wouldn't have been effective; but his absolute indifference and your obvious hatred make the matter wonderfully absurd!
es: If they had thought of another man, it wouldn't be anything special; but Darcy's absolute indifference and the deep grudge you hold against him is what makes the joke.

en: Much as I abominate writing, I would not give up mr Collins’s correspondence for any consideration.
vi: Although I don't like writing, I wouldn't ignore Mr. Collins's letter for any reason.
tr: I don't enjoy writing at all, but I wouldn't give up Mr. Collins' letters for any reason.
es: As much as it bothers me to write, I cannot do without Collins' correspondence.

en: Nay, when I read a letter of his, I cannot help giving him the preference even over Wickham, much as I value the impudence and hypocrisy of my son-in-law.
vi: No, when I read his letter, I couldn't help but like him more than Wickham, considering how I judge the brazen and hypocritical character of my son-in-law.
tr: In fact, when I read his letters, I can't help but find him more valuable than Wickham, even though I quite admire my son-in-law's baseness and deceitfulness.
es: The truth is that when I read one of his letters, he seems superior to Wickham, despite the fact that I consider my son-in-law the epitome of shamelessness and hypocrisy.

en: And pray, Lizzy, what said Lady Catherine about this report?
vi: Lizzy, tell me what Lady Catherine said about this?
tr: But please tell me, Lizzy, what did Lady Catherine say about this news?
es: And tell me, Eliza, how did Lady Catherine take it?

en: Did she call to refuse her consent?”
vi: Did she come here to object?
tr: Did she come to withhold her consent?"
es: Did she come to deny you her consent?

en: To this question his daughter replied only with a laugh; and as it had been asked without the least suspicion, she was not distressed by his repeating it.
vi: The daughter only responded to the question with a laugh, because he asked without any suspicion, she did not feel uncomfortable when he repeated the question.
tr: Elizabeth answered this question with nothing but a laugh; she was not bothered by her father's repetition since the question had been asked without any doubt.
es: To this question, Elizabeth responded with a laugh, and since her father had asked it without the slightest suspicion, she didn't mind ––that he repeated it.

en: Elizabeth had never been more at a loss to make her feelings appear what they were not.
vi: Elizabeth had never been so flustered to create an appearance contrary to her feelings.
tr: She had never struggled so much to show her feelings differently before.
es: Elizabeth had never found herself in a situation where she had to pretend that her feelings were something they were not in reality.

en: It was necessary to laugh when she would rather have cried.
vi: She needed to laugh out loud, when she actually wanted to cry.
tr: She had to laugh, even though she preferred to cry.
es: But now she had to laugh when she would have rather cried.

en: Her father had most cruelly mortified her by what he said of mr Darcy’s indifference; and she could do nothing but wonder at such a want of penetration, or fear that, perhaps, instead of his seeing too little, she might have fancied too much.
vi: Her father almost made her faint when he mentioned Mr. Darcy's indifference, and she only wondered why he did not investigate further. Or perhaps she also feared that instead of him knowing too little, she might have been too delusional.
tr: Her father had cruelly upset her with what he said about Mr. Darcy's indifference; faced with such a lack of understanding, she could do nothing but be surprised or perhaps fear the possibility that she was imagining too much rather than her father seeing too little.
es: Her father had cruelly hurt her by saying that about Darcy's indifference, and she couldn't help but marvel at her father's lack of intuition, or fear that instead of him having seen too little, she had seen too much.

en: CHAPTER LVIII.
vi: Chapter 58
tr: Chapter XVI
es: CHAPTER LVIII

en: INSTEAD of receiving any such letter of excuse from his friend, as Elizabeth half expected mr Bingley to do, he was able to bring Darcy with him to Longbourn before many days had passed after Lady Catherine’s visit.
vi: Instead of bringing a letter from his friend explaining why he couldn't return, as Elizabeth had half-believed, Bingley brought Darcy to Longbourn a few days after Lady Catherine's visit.
tr: As Elizabeth more or less expected, instead of receiving an apology letter from his friend, Bingley brought Darcy to Longbourn a few days after Lady Catherine's visit.
es: A few days after Lady Catherine's visit, Bingley not only did not receive any letter of excuse from his friend, but he also brought him to Longbourn in person.

en: The gentlemen arrived early; and, before ms Bennet had time to tell him of their having seen his aunt, of which her daughter sat in momentary dread, Bingley, who wanted to be alone with Jane, proposed their all walking out.
vi: The two arrived early, and before Mrs. Bennet had time to recount their meeting with his aunt, while her daughter sat in stunned silence, Bingley suggested a walk because he wanted some privacy with Jane.
tr: The gentlemen arrived early; under the fearful gaze of her daughter, Mrs. Bennet was about to tell Mr. Darcy that they had seen his aunt, but she didn't get the chance because Bingley, wanting to be alone with Jane, suggested they all go for a walk.
es: The gentlemen arrived early, and before Mrs. Bennet had time to tell Darcy that his aunt had come to visit them, which Elizabeth feared for a moment, Bingley, who wanted to be alone with Jane, proposed that they all go for a walk.

en: It was agreed to.
vi: Everyone agreed.
tr: The suggestion was accepted.
es: It was agreed upon, but Mrs. Bennet was not in the habit of walking and Mary could not afford to waste time.

en: ms Bennet was not in the habit of walking, Mary could never spare time, but the remaining five set off together.
vi: Mrs. Bennet was not in the habit of walking, and Mary had no time, but the remaining five set off together.
tr: Mrs. Bennet was not in the habit of walking, and Mary did not have the time, but the other five went out.
es: So the remaining five went out.

en: Bingley and Jane, however, soon allowed the others to outstrip them.
vi: However, it wasn't long before Bingley and Jane let the others go ahead.
tr: Bingley and Jane allowed the others to pass them.
es: Bingley and Jane soon let the others go ahead and stayed behind.

en: They lagged behind, while Elizabeth, Kitty, and Darcy were to entertain each other.
vi: The two slowed down at the back, allowing Elizabeth, Darcy, and Kitty to converse with each other.
tr: The two of them lagged behind; Elizabeth, Kitty, and Darcy were to entertain each other.
es: Elizabeth, Darcy, and Catherine walked together, but spoke very little.

en: Very little was said by either; Kitty was too much afraid of him to talk; Elizabeth was secretly forming a desperate resolution; and, perhaps, he might be doing the same.
vi: No one said much; Kitty was too shy to ask him anything, Elizabeth was silently preparing for a purpose, and perhaps Darcy was too.
tr: Neither of them spoke much; Kitty was too frightened of Darcy to speak; Elizabeth was inwardly reaching a hopeless conclusion, and perhaps Darcy was doing the same.
es: Catherine was too afraid of Darcy to chat; Elizabeth was making a desperate decision in her mind, and perhaps Darcy was doing the same.

en: They walked towards the Lucases’, because Kitty wished to call upon Maria; and as Elizabeth saw no occasion for making it a general concern, when Kitty left them she went boldly on with him alone.
vi: They went to Lucas's house because Kitty wanted to visit Maria, and because Elizabeth thought there was nothing to fear when Kitty wasn't with her, she boldly walked beside him alone.
tr: They walked towards the Lucases'; Kitty had wanted to visit Maria; without feeling the need to worry, Elizabeth continued to walk bravely alone with Darcy when Kitty left them.
es: They headed towards the Lucas' house because Catherine wanted to see Maria, and since Elizabeth thought this might interest her, when Catherine left them, she boldly continued walking alone with Darcy.

en: Now was the moment for her resolution to be executed; and while her courage was high, she immediately said,—
vi: Now was the time for her to carry out her intention, and while she still had enough courage, she immediately began:
tr: Now it was time to implement her decision, and while she still had her courage, she immediately said,
es: Then the moment came to put her decision into practice, and summoning her courage, she immediately said:

en: “mr Darcy, I am a very selfish creature, and for the sake of giving relief to my own feelings care not how much I may be wounding yours.
vi: - Mr. Darcy, I am a very selfish person, and while I tried to ease my own mind, I did not consider how I might hurt yours.
tr: "Mr. Darcy, I am a very selfish creature; I do not care how much I trouble you in order to ease my own feelings.
es: ––Mr. Darcy, I am a very selfish creature who cares only for my own feelings, without thinking that I might hurt yours.

en: I can no longer help thanking you for your unexampled kindness to my poor sister.
vi: I can no longer avoid thanking you for the unparalleled kindness you have shown to my wretched sister.
tr: I can no longer restrain myself; thank you for the unparalleled kindness you have shown to my poor sister.
es: But I can no longer go on without thanking you for your unparalleled kindness towards my poor sister.

en: Ever since I have known it I have been most anxious to acknowledge to you how gratefully I feel it.
vi: Since I learned of this, I have been anxiously seeking a way to express to you how deeply grateful I am.
tr: Since I learned of it, I have been eager to tell you how grateful I feel.
es: Since I found out, I have been longing to express my gratitude to you.

en: Were it known to the rest of my family I should not have merely my own gratitude to express.”
vi: If the rest of my family knew, I would not be speaking only of my own gratitude.
tr: If the other members of my family knew, I would not only express my own gratitude."
es: If my family knew, they would have done so as well.

en: “I am sorry, exceedingly sorry,” replied Darcy, in a tone of surprise and emotion, “that you have ever been informed of what may, in a mistaken light, have given you uneasiness.
vi: Darcy replied, surprised and moved: - I regret, deeply regret, that you have been informed about the matter, which in a way could be misunderstood, causing you to feel uneasy.
tr: "I'm sorry, extremely sorry," answered Darcy, with a voice full of astonishment and excitement, "I wouldn't have wanted you to learn something that might disturb you from a faulty perspective.
es: ––I am very sorry ––replied Darcy in a tone of surprise and emotion–– that you have been informed of something that, if misinterpreted, could have caused you some unease.

en: I did not think ms Gardiner was so little to be trusted.”
vi: I had thought I could trust Mrs. Gardiner to keep the matter confidential.
tr: I didn't think Mrs. Gardiner was so unreliable."
es: I did not think Mrs. Gardiner would be so indiscreet.

en: “You must not blame my aunt.
vi: - You should not blame my aunt.
tr: "You must not blame my sister-in-law.
es: ––Don't blame my aunt.

en: Lydia’s thoughtlessness first betrayed to me that you had been concerned in the matter; and, of course, I could not rest till I knew the particulars.
vi: Lydia carelessly revealed to me that you were involved in this matter, and of course, I could not be at ease without knowing the details.
tr: It was Lydia's carelessness that first made me think you were involved in the matter; then, of course, I couldn't rest until I learned the details.
es: Lydia's indiscretion was the first thing that revealed to me her involvement in the matter; and, naturally, I did not rest until I knew all the details.

en: Let me thank you again and again, in the name of all my family, for that generous compassion which induced you to take so much trouble, and bear so many mortifications, for the sake of discovering them.”
vi: On behalf of the entire family, I want to thank you, and thank you again, for the generous sentiment that made you go through such efforts and endure so much hardship to find the two people.
tr: On behalf of my entire family, I thank you again and again for your generous sacrifice, which caused you to go through so much trouble and endure so much hardship to find them."
es: Let me thank you a thousand times, on behalf of my entire family, for the generous interest that led you to take so much trouble and endure so many mortifications to find the whereabouts of the two.

en: “If you will thank me,” he replied, “let it be for yourself alone.
vi: - If you want to thank me, your thanks alone are enough.
tr: "If you are to thank me," replied Darcy, "let it be for your sake alone.
es: ––If you wish to thank me ––replied Darcy––, do so only in your own name.

en: That the wish of giving happiness to you might add force to the other inducements which led me on, I shall not attempt to deny.
vi: I do not want to hide the fact that my desire to bring you happiness was an additional motivation among other reasons that compelled me to do it.
tr: I will not attempt to deny that other motives were added to the wish of pleasing you.
es: I will not deny that the desire to ease your mind was added to the other reasons that drove me to do what I did; but your family owes me nothing.

en: But your family owe me nothing.
vi: But your family owes me nothing.
tr: But your family owes me nothing.
es: I will not deny that the desire to ease your mind was added to the other reasons that drove me to do what I did; but your family owes me nothing.

en: Much as I respect them, I believe I thought only of you.”
vi: While I still respect them, I only think of you.
tr: Though I respect them, I thought only of you."
es: I have great respect for them, but I thought only of you.

en: Elizabeth was too much embarrassed to say a word.
vi: Elizabeth was too embarrassed to say a word.
tr: Elizabeth was too embarrassed to say a single word.
es: Elizabeth was so confused that she couldn't speak.

en: After a short pause, her companion added, “You are too generous to trifle with me.
vi: After a moment of silence, he added: - You have an open-hearted disposition, so I trust you won't make fun of me.
tr: After a short silence, her companion continued, "You are too kind to play games with me.
es: After a short pause, her companion added: "You are too generous to mock me."

en: If your feelings are still what they were last April, tell me so at once.
vi: If your feelings are still the same as they were last April, just let me know right away.
tr: If your feelings are still the same as they were last April, tell me so at once.
es: If your feelings are still the same as last April, tell me at once.

en: My affections and wishes are unchanged; but one word from you will silence me on this subject for ever.”
vi: My feelings and wishes remain unchanged, but just one word from you and I will never bring this up again.
tr: My feelings and wishes have not changed, but a single word from you will silence me on this matter forever."
es: My affection and desires have not changed, but with a single word from you, I will not insist any further.

en: Elizabeth, feeling all the more than common awkwardness and anxiety of his situation, now forced herself to speak; and immediately, though not very fluently, gave him to understand that her sentiments had undergone so material a change since the period to which he alluded, as to make her receive with gratitude and pleasure his present assurances.
vi: The feelings in Elizabeth's mind had surpassed the usual awkwardness and worry for his situation. She felt compelled to confess. Though not very fluent, she immediately told him that her feelings had significantly changed from the moment he mentioned, so now she accepted his assertions with all respect and joy.
