tr: Feeling the unusual strangeness and anxiety in Darcy's demeanor, Elizabeth forced herself to speak; and immediately, though not very fluently, she made him understand that her feelings had undergone a great change since the time he mentioned, and that she accepted his recent words with gratitude and joy.
es: Elizabeth, feeling clumsier and more distressed than ever in Darcy's presence, made an effort to speak immediately, though not quickly, and conveyed to him that her feelings had undergone such an absolute change since the time he referred to, that she now received his proposals with pleasure and gratitude.

en: The happiness which this reply produced was such as he had probably never felt before; and he expressed himself on the occasion as sensibly and as warmly as a man violently in love can be supposed to do.
vi: Her answer created in him an immense happiness that he might never have felt in his life. He expressed to her the most sensitive and warm feelings that a person with intense love could articulate.
tr: The happiness created by this response was of a kind that Darcy had probably never felt before; he expressed himself sincerely and warmly, as might be expected from a man deeply in love.
es: The happiness that this response brought to Darcy was the greatest of his life, and he expressed it with all the warmth and tenderness that can be expected from a man madly in love.

en: Had Elizabeth been able to encounter his eyes, she might have seen how well the expression of heartfelt delight diffused over his face became him: but though she could not look she could listen; and he told her of feelings which, in proving of what importance she was to him, made his affection every moment more valuable.
vi: If Elizabeth could look directly into his eyes, she could see the overflowing joy in his heart, spreading across his face, transforming his entire being. But although she couldn't see, she could hear, and he wanted her to understand how important a position she held in his heart. He revealed the thoughts that made his love grow stronger each moment.
tr: If Elizabeth had dared to look into his eyes, she could have seen how the expression of heartfelt joy spread across his face and how well it suited him; but, even though she couldn't look, she could listen, and while Darcy proved how important she was to him, he spoke of the feelings that made his love more precious with each passing moment.
es: If Elizabeth had been able to look him in the eyes, she would have seen how well the delight that flooded his heart was reflected in them; but she could listen to him, and the feelings that Darcy confessed to her, which demonstrated the importance she had for him, made her affection increasingly valuable.

en: They walked on without knowing in what direction.
vi: The two continued walking without realizing which direction they were heading.
tr: They kept walking, not knowing which direction they were going.
es: They continued walking without worrying about the direction they were taking.

en: There was too much to be thought, and felt, and said, for attention to any other objects.
vi: There were too many things to ponder, to feel, to express.
tr: There were so many things to think about, to feel, to say that they couldn't pay attention to anything else.
es: They had too much to think about, to feel, and to say to pay attention to anything else.

en: She soon learnt that they were indebted for their present good understanding to the efforts of his aunt, who did call on him in her return through London, and there relate her journey to Longbourn, its motive, and the substance of her conversation with Elizabeth; dwelling emphatically on every expression of the latter, which, in her Ladyship’s apprehension, peculiarly denoted her perverseness and assurance, in the belief that such a relation must assist her endeavours to obtain that promise from her nephew which she had refused to give.
vi: Now she knew that they owed his aunt for the mutual understanding between them at present. After returning, she had gone to see him, telling him about her trip to Longbourn, about her motives, and about the conversation between her and Elizabeth. Out of anxiety, she emphasized Elizabeth's stubborn and resolute attitude, believing that by doing so she would hear him promise what she had refused to promise.
tr: Elizabeth soon learned that they owed their current understanding to her aunt's efforts; her ladyship had visited while returning via London, where she had recounted her journey to Longbourn, her purpose, and the subject of her conversation with Elizabeth; her ladyship had insisted on every expression that, in her opinion, clearly demonstrated Elizabeth's perversity and impudence, thinking that such a complaint would help in her effort to obtain the promise that Elizabeth had refused to give.
es: Elizabeth immediately knew that they owed their closeness to Darcy's aunt's efforts, who visited him in London upon his return and told him about her trip to Longbourn, the motives behind it, and the substance of her conversation with the young woman, emphatically highlighting the expressions that, in Her Ladyship's opinion, denoted Elizabeth's perversity and brazenness, confident that this account would help her in her endeavor to extract from her nephew the promise that Elizabeth had refused to give her.

en: But, unluckily for her Ladyship, its effect had been exactly contrariwise.
vi: But, unfortunately for the Lady, the result was completely contrary to her wishes.
tr: But, contrary to her ladyship's expectations, these had the opposite effect.
es: But unfortunately for Her Ladyship, the effect was counterproductive.

en: “It taught me to hope,” said he, “as I had scarcely ever allowed myself to hope before.
vi: He said: - This has given you hope that you previously did not dare to allow yourself to hope for much.
tr: "This taught me to hope," said Darcy; "I had not allowed myself to hope before.
es: ––Thanks to that, I conceived hopes that I would hardly have dared to formulate before.

en: I knew enough of your disposition to be certain, that had you been absolutely, irrevocably decided against me, you would have acknowledged it to Lady Catherine frankly and openly.”
vi: You have known your feelings well enough to be sure that if you were determined not to accept his love, you would have said so frankly and clearly to Lady Catherine.
tr: If you had been absolutely, irrevocably determined against me, I knew you well enough to be certain that you would have told Lady Catherine so openly and sincerely."
es: I knew your character well enough to know that if you had been absolutely and irrevocably decided against me, you would have told Lady Catherine with complete clarity and frankness.

en: Elizabeth coloured and laughed as she replied, “Yes, you know enough of my frankness to believe me capable of that.
vi: Elizabeth blushed and laughed: - That's right, I know quite well how straightforward you are, so I believe you could say something like that.
tr: Elizabeth blushed; she laughed while replying, "Yes, you know my frankness well enough to believe that I could do this.
es: Elizabeth blushed and laughed, replying: ––Yes, you knew my frankness well enough to believe me capable of that.

en: After abusing you so abominably to your face, I could have no scruple in abusing you to all your relations.”
vi: After having disgustingly insulted me to my face, you could unhesitatingly insult me in front of my loved ones.
tr: After speaking so ill of you to your face, I would not hesitate to speak ill of you to your relatives."
es: After having rejected you so odiously to your face, I could have no qualms about saying the same to all your relatives.

en: “What did you say of me that I did not deserve?
vi: - How did you talk about me? Did you say I was undeserving?
tr: "What did you say to me that I didn't deserve?
es: ––He didn't tell me anything I didn't deserve.

en: For though your accusations were ill-founded, formed on mistaken premises, my behaviour to you at the time had merited the severest reproof.
vi: Because, although your accusations are unfounded and based on mistaken premises, my attitude towards you before was indeed deserving of the harshest criticism.
tr: Your accusations were baseless, built on faulty assumptions, but my behavior towards you at that time deserved the harshest condemnation.
es: His accusations were unfounded, but my conduct towards you deserved the most severe reproach.

en: It was unpardonable.
vi: It was unforgivable.
tr: It was unforgivable.
es: That was unforgivable; it horrifies me to think about it.

en: I cannot think of it without abhorrence.”
vi: I cannot think about my past behavior without feeling disgusted.
tr: I can't remember it without feeling ashamed."
es: That was unforgivable; it horrifies me to think about it.

en: “We will not quarrel for the greater share of blame annexed to that evening,” said Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth said: - We should not argue about who was more to blame that evening.
tr: "Let's not argue about who was more at fault that evening," said Elizabeth.
es: ––We are not going to argue about who was worse that afternoon ––said Elizabeth––.

en: “The conduct of neither, if strictly examined, will be irreproachable; but since then we have both, I hope, improved in civility.”
vi: If we consider it strictly, each person's behavior was reprehensible, but since then, both of us have become more courteous - I hope so.
tr: "Neither of our behaviors was entirely blameless, if we think about it carefully; but since then, I hope, we have both made progress in terms of politeness."
es: Looking at it closely, we both had our faults. But it seems to me that we have both gained in courtesy since then.

en: “I cannot be so easily reconciled to myself.
vi: - I cannot easily be at ease about myself.
tr: "I can't make peace with myself that easily.
es: ––I cannot reconcile with myself so easily.

en: The recollection of what I then said, of my conduct, my manners, my expressions during the whole of it, is now, and has been many months, inexpressibly painful to me.
vi: For many months, even until now, whenever I think about what I said, my behavior, my attitude, my expressions throughout the incident, somehow I always feel pain.
tr: Recalling my words, actions, attitudes, and expressions from back then, which was months ago, gives me indescribable pain.
es: The memory of what I said and did on that occasion is and will be very painful for me for a long time.

en: Your reproof, so well applied, I shall never forget: ‘Had you behaved in a more gentlemanlike manner.’
vi: Your reproach was truly justified, I can never forget "if you had the manners of a gentleman."
tr: I will never forget the very proper scolding I received from you: ‘if only you had behaved more gentlemanly.'
es: I cannot forget her very accurate phrase: «If you had behaved more gentlemanly.»

en: Those were your words.
vi: These are your words.
tr: Those were your words.
es: Those were her words.

en: You know not, you can scarcely conceive, how they have tortured me; though it was some time, I confess, before I was reasonable enough to allow their justice.”
vi: You don't know, you can't understand, how these words have tormented me, though I must admit that it took some time for me to realize you were right.
tr: You have no idea how they tortured me, you can't even imagine; –still, I admit, it took me some time to accept that they were right."
es: You don't know, you can't imagine how much they have tortured me, although I confess that it took me a while to be reasonable enough to recognize the truth they contained.

en: “I was certainly very far from expecting them to make so strong an impression.
vi: - I never thought my words would make such a strong impression.
tr: "I really didn't expect them to have such a strong impact.
es: ––Believe me, I was far from imagining that they could cause such a bad impression on you.

en: I had not the smallest idea of their being ever felt in such a way.”
vi: I completely didn't think you felt that way.
tr: It never even crossed my mind that you would feel that way."
es: I had no idea that they would distress you in that way.

en: “I can easily believe it.
vi: - You can easily trust me.
tr: "I believe this.
es: ––I don't doubt it.

en: You thought me then devoid of every proper feeling, I am sure you did.
vi: At that time, I thought you weren't sensitive at all. You surely thought I felt that way.
tr: At that time, you thought I was emotionless, I'm sure.
es: Then you assumed I was devoid of any elevated feelings, I'm sure.

en: The turn of your countenance I shall never forget, as you said that I could not have addressed you in any possible way that would induce you to accept me.”
vi: I'll never forget the look on your face when you said I couldn't confess my feelings to you in any other way to make you accept.
tr: I will never forget the look on your face when you said it was impossible for you to accept me even if I made my offer in a different way."
es: I will also never forget your expression when you told me that no matter how I had approached you, you would not have accepted me.

en: “Oh, do not repeat what I then said.
vi: - Please don't bring up what I said back then.
tr: "Ah, then don't repeat what I said.
es: ––Do not repeat all my words from that day.

en: These recollections will not do at all.
vi: There is no use in remembering it forever.
tr: Remembering these won't be of any use.
es: We must erase that memory.

en: I assure you that I have long been most heartily ashamed of it.”
vi: I hope you understand that I have long felt truly ashamed of my words.
tr: Believe me, I've been ashamed of them for a long time too."
es: I swear to you that I have been sincerely ashamed of that for a long time.

en: Darcy mentioned his letter.
vi: Darcy talks about his letter.
tr: Darcy mentioned his letter.
es: Darcy spoke to her about his letter:

en: “Did it,” said he,—“did it soon make you think better of me?
vi: He asks: - Will my letter make you think better of me not long after?
tr: "The letter," he said, "did it have a quick effect on you thinking better of me?
es: ––Did it make you change your opinion about me?

en: Did you, on reading it, give any credit to its contents?”
vi: After reading it, do you believe what I wrote?
tr: Did you find the things described there believable when you read it?"
es: Did you believe its content?

en: She explained what its effects on her had been, and how gradually all her former prejudices had been removed.
vi: She explained to him the effects that the letter had created in her mind, and how all her initial prejudices were gradually erased.
tr: Elizabeth explained the effect of the letter and how her old prejudices gradually faded away.
es: She explained to him the effect it had had on her and how her previous prejudices had gradually disappeared.

en: “I knew,” said he, “that what I wrote must give you pain, but it was necessary.
vi: He said: - I know that what I write will cause you pain, but it is necessary to write it.
tr: "I knew," he said, "what I wrote would cause you pain, but it was necessary.
es: ––I already knew ––continued Darcy–– that what I wrote had to sadden you, but it was necessary.

en: I hope you have destroyed the letter.
vi: I hope you have destroyed the letter.
tr: I hope you have destroyed the letter.
es: I suppose you have destroyed the letter.

en: There was one part, especially the opening of it, which I should dread your having the power of reading again.
vi: There is one part in particular, the beginning, that if you read again will terrify me.
tr: There was one part in particular, the introduction, that I would be horrified if you had the chance to read again.
es: There was a part, especially at the beginning, that I would not want you to read again.

en: I can remember some expressions which might justly make you hate me.”
vi: I can remember a few words in the letter that might make you rightfully hate me.
tr: I recall some expressions that might justifiably cause you to hate me."
es: I remember certain expressions that could make you hate me.

en: “The letter shall certainly be burnt, if you believe it essential to the preservation of my regard; but, though we have both reason to think my opinions not entirely unalterable, they are not, I hope, quite so easily changed as that implies.”
vi: - I will burn the letter if you believe this will preserve my feelings for you. However, although we both have reasons to believe that my sentiments are not entirely steadfast, I hope they are not easily changeable.
tr: "The letter will certainly be burned, if you deem it necessary for the preservation of my admiration; but, although we both have reasons to think that my views are not entirely unchangeable, I hope they do not change as easily as this statement claims.""
es: ––We will burn the letter if you believe it is necessary to preserve my affection, but although we both have reasons to think that my opinions are not entirely unchangeable, they do not change as easily as you suppose.

en: “When I wrote that letter,” replied Darcy, “I believed myself perfectly calm and cool; but I am since convinced that it was written in a dreadful bitterness of spirit.”
vi: Mr. Darcy replied: - When you wrote that letter, you believed you were completely calm and gentle, but then you realized that at that time you still harbored a terrible bitterness.
tr: "When I wrote that letter," replied Darcy, "I believed I was extremely calm and composed, but since then I think it was written in a feeling of terrible rebellion."
es: ––When I wrote that letter ––Darcy replied, I believed myself to be perfectly calm and composed; but later I realized that I had written it in a state of tremendous bitterness.

en: “The letter, perhaps, began in bitterness, but it did not end so.
vi: - Perhaps the letter began in bitterness, but the ending was not like that.
tr: "The letter may have started with rebellion, but it didn't end that way.
es: ––It may have started with bitterness, but it didn't end the same way.

en: The adieu is charity itself.
vi: The concluding sentence itself speaks of virtue.
tr: Your farewell itself was the epitome of magnanimity.
es: The farewell was very affectionate.

en: But think no more of the letter.
vi: But we should not think about the letter anymore.
tr: But let's not think about the letter anymore.
es: But don't think about the letter anymore.

en: The feelings of the person who wrote and the person who received it are now so widely different from what they were then, that every unpleasant circumstance attending it ought to be forgotten.
vi: The feelings of the writer and the recipient are now vastly different from back then, so it is necessary to forget all the unpleasant circumstances that created those feelings.
tr: The feelings of the writer and the recipient are now so different from back then that all the unpleasant events associated with it need to be forgotten.
es: The feelings of the person who wrote it and those of the person who received it are now so different that all the unpleasant circumstances related to it should be forgotten.

en: You must learn some of my philosophy.
vi: You should follow my philosophy of life.
tr: You should learn a bit of my philosophy.
es: You must learn my philosophy.

en: Think only of the past as its remembrance gives you pleasure.”
vi: Only think about the past if there is joy in remembering it.
tr: Think only of as much of the past as you enjoy remembering."
es: From the past, you only need to remember what was pleasant.

en: “I cannot give you credit for any philosophy of the kind.
vi: - You cannot judge me philosophically like that.
tr: "I can't believe you have such a philosophy.
es: ––I cannot believe in that philosophy of yours.

en: Your retrospections must be so totally void of reproach, that the contentment arising from them is not of philosophy, but, what is much better, of ignorance.
vi: When I recall what happened, I have no intention of blaming, and I think your satisfaction here is not due to philosophy, but rather because you are carefree.
tr: Your view of the past is so far from the possibility of regret that the sense of peace arising from those memories can be explained not by philosophy, but even better, by ignorance.
es: Your memories must be so free from any reproach that the satisfaction they bring you does not come from philosophy, but from something better: the tranquility of conscience.

en: But with me, it is not so.
vi: But for me, it is not like that.
tr: But it's not the same for me.
es: But with me, it is different: I am confronted by painful memories that cannot and should not be driven away.

en: Painful recollections will intrude, which cannot, which ought not to be repelled.
vi: Painful memories still intrude, which I cannot and should not dismiss.
tr: Painful memories always remind themselves and it is not possible, nor should it be, to forget them.
es: But with me, it is different: I am confronted by painful memories that cannot and should not be driven away.

en: I have been a selfish being all my life, in practice, though not in principle.
vi: All my life I have been selfish, in attitude rather than in principle.
tr: Though not in my principles, in my actions I have been a selfish person all my life.
es: I have been a selfish person all my life in practice, though not in principles.

en: As a child I was taught what was right, but I was not taught to correct my temper.
vi: As a child, I was taught to know what was right, but I was not taught how to control my temper.
tr: As a child, I was taught what was right, but I was not taught to correct my temperament.
es: As a child, I was taught to think well, but not to correct my temperament.

en: I was given good principles, but left to follow them in pride and conceit.
vi: I learned about principles, but I was left to pursue those principles in pride and arrogance.
tr: I acquired good principles, but I was left to follow them with pride and arrogance.
es: I was instilled with good norms, but they allowed me to follow them laden with pride and presumption.

en: Unfortunately an only son (for many years an only child), I was spoiled by my parents, who, though good themselves, (my father particularly, all that was benevolent and amiable,) allowed, encouraged, almost taught me to be selfish and overbearing, to care for none beyond my own family circle, to think meanly of all the rest of the world, to wish at least to think meanly of their sense and worth compared with my own.
vi: Unfortunately for me, being the only son, I was spoiled by my parents to the point of becoming spoiled. My parents, although very good people themselves, allowed, encouraged, and almost trained me to become selfish and self-important, caring for no one outside my own family, looking down on the rest of the world or at least wanting to disdain their perceptions and true values compared to my own.
tr: Unfortunately, as the only son (and for years the only child), I was spoiled by my parents; they themselves were good (especially my father, a man full of love and care), but they gave me permission, encouragement, almost education to be selfish and domineering, to not care about anyone outside my family circle, to despise the rest of humanity, or at least to want to diminish their feelings and values compared to mine.
es: Unfortunately, I was an only child for several years, and my parents, who were good in themselves, particularly my father, who was the personification of kindness and love, allowed me, indulged me, and almost guided me towards selfishness and authoritarianism, towards indifference to everything that was not my own family, towards disdain for the rest of the world or, at least, to believe that the intelligence and merits of others were far inferior to mine.

en: Such I was, from eight to eight-and-twenty; and such I might still have been but for you, dearest, loveliest Elizabeth!
vi: I was like that, from eight to twenty-eight years old, and I would still be like that if it were not for you, my dearest Elizabeth!
tr: I was like this from the age of eight to twenty-eight, and I might still be, my beautiful, dear Elizabeth, if it weren't for you!
es: Thus, from the age of eight to twenty-eight, and it would still be so if it were not for you, dearest Elizabeth.

en: What do I not owe you!
vi: What do I not owe you!
tr: I owe you so much!
es: I owe you everything.

en: You taught me a lesson, hard indeed at first, but most advantageous.
vi: You taught me a lesson, initially a hard one, but the most beneficial.
tr: You gave me a lesson that was hard at first, but then very beneficial.
es: You gave me a lesson that was, indeed, very hard at first, but also very beneficial.

en: By you, I was properly humbled.
vi: You properly humbled me.
tr: Thanks to you, my feet are on the ground.
es: You humbled me as was fitting, you showed me how insufficient my pretensions were to flatter a woman who deserves all the flattery.

en: I came to you without a doubt of my reception.
vi: You showed me that all my arrogant expectations were not enough to win the heart of a truly worthy woman.
tr: I came to you without doubting that I would be accepted.
es: You humbled me as was fitting, you showed me how insufficient my pretensions were to flatter a woman who deserves all the flattery.

en: You showed me how insufficient were all my pretensions to please a woman worthy of being pleased.”
vi: You showed me that all my arrogant expectations were not enough to win the heart of a truly worthy woman.
tr: And you taught me how insufficient all my pride was to make a woman who deserves to be happy, happy."
es: You humbled me as was fitting, you showed me how insufficient my pretensions were to flatter a woman who deserves all the flattery.

en: “Had you then persuaded yourself that I should?”
vi: - So at that moment, did you believe that I should show you like that?
tr: "Did you believe I would accept it then?"
es: ––Did you think I was going to accept it?

en: “Indeed I had.
vi: - Yes, I do.
tr: "Of course.
es: ––Of course.

en: What will you think of my vanity?
vi: What do you think about my frivolity?
tr: What about my pride?
es: What do you think of my vanity?

en: I believed you to be wishing, expecting my addresses.”
vi: - My attitude was wrong, but I didn't mean it that way, I hope you believe me.
tr: I believed that you wanted and were waiting for me to make an offer to you."
es: I thought you were expecting and desiring my declaration.

en: “My manners must have been in fault, but not intentionally, I assure you.
vi: - My attitude was wrong, but I didn't mean it that way, I hope you believe me.
tr: "My actions may have been wrong, but believe me, they were not intentional.
es: ––I behaved badly, but it was unintentional.

en: I never meant to deceive you, but my spirits might often lead me wrong.
vi: I never wanted to deceive you, but my state of mind might have led me astray.
tr: I never thought of deceiving you, but my impulsiveness often leads me astray.
es: I never meant to deceive him, and yet many times I mistake.

en: How you must have hated me after that evening!”
vi: That night, how much did you hate me?
tr: How much you must have hated me after that evening."
es: How she must have hated me after that afternoon!

en: “Hate you!
vi: - Hate you?!
tr: "Hate you!
es: ––Hate her!

en: I was angry, perhaps, at first, but my anger soon began to take a proper direction.”
vi: At first, he was angry, but gradually the anger shifted in the right direction.
tr: Maybe I was angry at first, but my anger soon began to take the right direction."
es: Maybe I was resentful at first; but the resentment soon turned into something better.

en: “I am almost afraid of asking what you thought of me when we met at Pemberley.
vi: - I was almost too afraid to ask what you thought of me when we met again at Pemberley.
tr: "I am a little hesitant to ask what you thought of me when we met at Pemberley.
es: ––I hardly dare ask you what you thought upon finding me at Pemberley.

en: You blamed me for coming?”
vi: Do you blame me?
tr: Did you blame me for coming?"
es: Did you think it was wrong of me to have gone?

en: “No, indeed, I felt nothing but surprise.”
vi: - Actually, I don't blame you, I'm just surprised.
tr: "No, never; I was surprised, that's all."
es: ––None of that. I was just surprised.

en: “Your surprise could not be greater than mine in being noticed by you.
vi: - Your surprise cannot compare to mine, when you paid attention to me.
tr: "You would have seen the real surprise on me when I got caught by you.
es: ––Your surprise would not be greater than mine upon seeing you greet me.

en: My conscience told me that I deserved no extraordinary politeness, and I confess that I did not expect to receive more than my due.”
vi: My conscience tells me that I am not worthy of your utmost courtesy, I must confess that I did not expect to receive more than what I deserve.
tr: My conscience was telling me that I had no right to expect any extraordinary kindness; I confess that I was not expecting to see more than I deserved."
es: I did not believe I had the right to your attentions and I confess that I did not expect to receive more than what I deserved.

en: “My object then,” replied Darcy, “was to show you, by every civility in my power, that I was not so mean as to resent the past; and I hoped to obtain your forgiveness, to lessen your ill opinion, by letting you see that your reproofs had been attended to.
vi: - My intention at that time was, through courteous behavior within my ability, to show you that I wasn't so narrow-minded as to be upset about the past, and by showing that I had responded to your reproaches, I hoped you would forgive me and think less badly of me.
tr: "At that time my aim," answered Darcy, "was to show you with all my might that I was not narrow-minded enough to regret the past; to earn your forgiveness, to reduce your negative thoughts, and to make you see that your scoldings were taken into account.
es: ––I set out ––Darcy replied–– to demonstrate to you, with my utmost courtesy, that I was not so vile as to be hurt by the past, and I hoped to earn your forgiveness and mitigate the poor opinion you had of me by proving that I had not disregarded your reproaches.

en: How soon any other wishes introduced themselves, I can hardly tell, but I believe in about half an hour after I had seen you.”
vi: I am not sure when other aspirations came about, but I believe it was within half an hour after I met you again.
tr: I'm not exactly sure when other dreams emerged, but I think it was about half an hour after I saw you."
es: It is difficult for me to tell you how long it took for these other desires to mix in, but I believe it was about half an hour after having seen you.

en: He then told her of Georgiana’s delight in her acquaintance, and of her disappointment at its sudden interruption; which naturally leading to the cause of that interruption, she soon learnt that his resolution of following her from Derbyshire in quest of her sister had been formed before he quitted the inn, and that his gravity and thoughtfulness there had arisen from no other struggles than what such a purpose must comprehend.
vi: Then he mentioned that Georgiana was pleased to make her acquaintance, expressed disappointment when she had to hastily return home, and naturally, this led to the reason for her return. Now she knew that he had resolved to find her sister even before he left her inn, she also understood that his stern and contemplative demeanor at this moment was due to an internal struggle with the sole purpose of being understood.
tr: Then, she explained how happy Georgiana was to have met him and how saddened she was by his sudden departure, which naturally led to the reason for that departure; Elizabeth soon learned that Darcy had decided to follow him from Derbyshire to find his sister before leaving the inn, and that his distracted, thoughtful demeanor there was not due to any other struggle but solely to the obstacles in the way of such a purpose.
es: Then he explained to her how delighted Georgiana had been to meet her and how much she regretted the sudden interruption of their friendship. This naturally led them to discuss the cause of said interruption, and Elizabeth learned that Darcy had decided to leave Derbyshire in search of Lydia before leaving the inn, and that his seriousness and pensive appearance were due to no other thoughts than those inherent to the aforementioned project.

en: She expressed her gratitude again, but it was too painful a subject to each to be dwelt on farther.
vi: She expressed her gratitude once more, but both of them were still pained by the incident and did not want to say anything further.
tr: He expressed his gratitude again, but it was a subject too painful to be prolonged any further for both of them.
es: Elizabeth thanked him again, but the matter was too overwhelming for both of them, and they did not pursue it further.

en: After walking several miles in a leisurely manner, and too busy to know anything about it, they found at last, on examining their watches, that it was time to be at home.
vi: After leisurely walking a few miles and with their minds unburdened by other matters so they were unaware of the distance, they finally checked the time and thought they should head back.
tr: After walking a few miles aimlessly and preoccupied to the point of not noticing anything, they finally looked at their watches and saw that it was time to go home.
es: After walking several miles in complete abandonment and too busy to care about anything else, they looked at their watches and saw that it was time to go back home.

en: “What could have become of mr Bingley and Jane?” was a wonder which introduced the discussion of their affairs.
vi: "I wonder how Bingley and Jane are doing now?" was the pressing question for the discussion about that love story.
tr: "What will Mr. Bingley and Jane do, I wonder!" This question brought their relationship to light.
es: ––What could have become of Bingley and Jane? This exclamation led them to talk about each other's affairs.

en: Darcy was delighted with their engagement; his friend had given him the earliest information of it.
vi: Darcy was pleased to see them happy, his friend had previously told him.
tr: Darcy was quite pleased with their engagement; his friend had informed him of it immediately.
es: Darcy was very happy with his engagement, which Bingley had immediately informed him about.

en: “I must ask whether you were surprised?” said Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth asked: - Do you want to ask if I'm surprised?
tr: "May I ask if you were surprised?" said Elizabeth.
es: ––Can I ask you if it surprised you? ––said Elizabeth.

en: “Not at all.
vi: - He is not surprised at all.
tr: "Not at all.
es: ––By no means.

en: When I went away, I felt that it would soon happen.”
vi: When he left, he thought this would happen soon.
tr: I knew you would be close when you left."
es: When I left, I realized that the matter was imminent.

en: “That is to say, you had given your permission.
vi: - This means you have allowed him to move forward.
tr: "So you had given permission.
es: ––That is to say, you gave him your permission.

en: I guessed as much.”
vi: I guessed so.
tr: That's what I had assumed."
es: I already suspected it.

en: And though he exclaimed at the term, she found that it had been pretty much the case.
vi: And although he did not admit it was true, she thought it really was. He said:
tr: Although Darcy objected to this statement, Elizabeth understood that it was more or less the case.
es: And although he protested such terms, she found them to be very appropriate.

en: “On the evening before my going to London,” said he, “I made a confession to him, which I believe I ought to have made long ago.
vi: - On the evening before he went to London, he confessed to Mr. Bingley something he should have done long ago.
tr: "The night before going to London," said Darcy, "I made a confession to her, which I should have done much earlier.
es: ––The evening before my trip to London ––said Darcy–– I made a confession to him that I should have made long before.

en: I told him of all that had occurred to make my former interference in his affairs absurd and impertinent.
vi: He told him everything about his unreasonable interference.
tr: I told her all those events that made my previous interference in her affairs seem unnecessary and foolish.
es: I told him everything that had happened to make my interference absurd and impertinent.

en: His surprise was great.
vi: Mr. Bingley was extremely surprised.
tr: She was very surprised.
es: He was left speechless.

en: He had never had the slightest suspicion.
vi: He also explained to him that he was mistaken in thinking that your sister was indifferent to him, and since he could easily see that Mr. Bingley's feelings for her had not diminished, he was confident they would be happy together.
tr: She hadn't had the slightest suspicion.
es: He had never suspected anything.

en: I told him, moreover, that I believed myself mistaken in supposing, as I had done, that your sister was indifferent to him; and as I could easily perceive that his attachment to her was unabated, I felt no doubt of their happiness together.”
vi: He also explained to him that he was mistaken in thinking that your sister was indifferent to him, and since he could easily see that Mr. Bingley's feelings for her had not diminished, he was confident they would be happy together.
tr: I also told her that I believed I was wrong in saying that your sister was indifferent to her; it was very clear that her feelings for your sister had not changed, so I had no doubt they would be happy together."
es: I also told him that I had been mistaken in assuming that Jane did not love him, and when I realized that Bingley still loved her, I no longer doubted that they would be happy.

en: Elizabeth could not help smiling at his easy manner of directing his friend.
vi: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile at the ease with which he steered his friend.
tr: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile at her friend's ease in giving directions.
es: Elizabeth couldn't help but smile upon seeing how easily she managed her friend.

en: “Did you speak from your own observation,” said she, “when you told him that my sister loved him, or merely from my information last spring?”
vi: She asked: - When you told him that my sister loves him, did you say it based on your own observation, or just because of what I said earlier?
tr: "When you said that my brother loved her," he said, "did you say it based on your own observation, or based on what I told you last spring?"
es: ––When you told him that my sister loved him, was it because you had observed it or because I had confessed it to you last spring?

en: “From the former.
vi: - From your observations.
tr: "The first one.
es: ––For the first part.

en: I had narrowly observed her, during the two visits which I had lately made her here; and I was convinced of her affection.”
vi: You have observed her very closely, from the two times you came later, and you believe that she truly loves Mr. Bingley.
tr: During my two recent trips here, I observed him from a distance and believed in his love."
es: I observed her carefully during the two visits I made to her recently, and I became convinced of her affection for Bingley.

en: “And your assurance of it, I suppose, carried immediate conviction to him.”
vi: - And I suppose when you believe so, Mr. Bingley also believes you.
tr: "Your certainty must have immediately instilled belief in him.""
es: ––And his conviction also left him convinced, right?

en: “It did.
vi: - That's right.
tr: "Indeed.
es: ––That's right.

en: Bingley is most unaffectedly modest.
vi: Bingley is the most genuinely shy person.
tr: Bingley is genuinely humble.
es: Bingley is the most modest and least conceited man in the world.

en: His diffidence had prevented his depending on his own judgment in so anxious a case, but his reliance on mine made everything easy.
vi: He lacks confidence and cannot rely on his own judgment, so he depends on you, making everything easier.
tr: His shyness prevented him from trusting his own instincts on such an important matter, but trusting me made things easier.
es: His timidity prevented him from trusting his own judgment in such an important matter; but his submission to mine settled everything.

en: I was obliged to confess one thing, which for a time, and not unjustly, offended him.
vi: You must admit that something else made him feel justifiably offended for a while.
tr: However, there was something I had to admit that, for a while, and justifiably, upset him.
es: I had to tell him something that for a time, and quite rightly, had him very upset.

en: I could not allow myself to conceal that your sister had been in town three months last winter, that I had known it, and purposely kept it from him.
vi: You could no longer hide the fact that you knew the sisters had been residing in the city for three months but still did not inform him.
tr: It wouldn't have sat well with me not to tell him that I knew your sister stayed in the city for three months last winter and deliberately kept it from him.
es: I couldn't hide from him that his sister had been in London for three months last winter, that I knew it, and that I didn't tell him on purpose.

en: He was angry.
vi: He was angry.
tr: Of course, he was angry.
es: He was very angry.

en: But his anger, I am persuaded, lasted no longer than he remained in any doubt of your sister’s sentiments.
vi: But you believe he won't be angry with you for long once he has no doubts about the sisters' love.
tr: But his anger didn't last longer than his doubt about your sister's feelings.
es: But I'm sure he got over it when he was convinced that his sister still loved him.

en: He has heartily forgiven me now.”
vi: He has now fully forgiven you.
tr: He has now completely forgiven me."
es: Now he has forgiven me wholeheartedly.

en: Elizabeth longed to observe that mr Bingley had been a most delightful friend; so easily guided that his worth was invaluable; but she checked herself.
vi: Elizabeth wanted to remark that Mr. Bingley was the most charming and easily led friend, so her lover indeed had some talent. But she restrained herself.
tr: Elizabeth wanted to say that Mr. Bingley was a sweet friend, and that his being very easy to manage made him very valuable, but she restrained herself.
es: Elizabeth would have liked to add that Bingley was the most wonderful of friends for the ease with which he could be brought and taken, and that he was truly invaluable. But she restrained herself.

en: She remembered that he had yet to learn to be laughed at, and it was rather too early to begin.
vi: She remembered that he had not yet learned to endure jokes, and it was too soon to joke now.
tr: She remembered that Darcy still needed to learn to be teased, but it was a bit early to start.
es: She remembered that Darcy still had to learn to laugh at these things, and that it was too soon to start.

en: In anticipating the happiness of Bingley, which of course was to be inferior only to his own, he continued the conversation till they reached the house.
vi: In the belief of Bingley's happiness, which of course was not equal to his current happiness, he continued the conversation until they reached home.
tr: Darcy continued the conversation until they got home, imagining Bingley's happiness as pale in comparison to his own.
es: Speculating about Bingley's happiness which, of course, could only be inferior to theirs, Darcy kept talking until they reached the house.

en: In the hall they parted.
vi: They parted ways in the foyer.
tr: They parted in the hall.
es: They said goodbye in the hall.

en: CHAPTER LIX.
vi: Chapter 59
tr: Chapter XVII
es: CHAPTER LIX

en: “MY dear Lizzy, where can you have been walking to?” was a question which Elizabeth received from Jane as soon as she entered the room, and from all the others when they sat down to table.
vi: Everyone in the family asked her where she had been, but she only replied that the two of them had just wandered around here and there until she was no longer sure where she had gone.
tr: "My dear Lizzy, where could you have walked?" This was the question Jane asked Elizabeth as soon as she entered the room, and the same question was posed by all the others when they sat down at the table.
es: Elizabeth, dear, where have you been walking? This is the question that Jane directed to Elizabeth as soon as they were in their room, and the one that everyone else asked when they sat down at the table.

en: She had only to say in reply, that they had wandered about till she was beyond her own knowledge.
vi: Everyone in the family asked her where she had been, but she only replied that the two of them had just wandered around here and there until she was no longer sure where she had gone.
tr: She could only say that they had been walking, without looking at where they were going.
es: Elizabeth replied that they had been wandering until they reached the end of the path she knew.

en: She coloured as she spoke; but neither that, nor anything else, awakened a suspicion of the truth.
vi: She blushed when she answered, but this or other things did not make anyone suspicious.
tr: Her face turned red as she spoke; but neither this nor anything else raised any doubts about the truth.
es: As she said this, she blushed, but neither this nor anything else aroused the slightest suspicion about the truth.

en: The evening passed quietly, unmarked by anything extraordinary.
vi: The evening passed peacefully without anything special.
tr: The evening passed quietly, without anything unusual happening.
es: The evening passed quietly without anything extraordinary happening.

en: The acknowledged lovers talked and laughed; the unacknowledged were silent.
vi: The couple who had publicly declared their love exchanged words and joked, while the couple who had not yet declared their love remained silent.
tr: The accepted lovers talked and laughed, while the unaccepted ones were silent.
es: The official couples chatted and laughed, while the unofficial ones remained silent.

en: Darcy was not of a disposition in which happiness overflows in mirth; and Elizabeth, agitated and confused, rather knew that she was happy than felt herself to be so; for, besides the immediate embarrassment, there were other evils before her.
vi: Darcy did not have the temperament to express overwhelming happiness through jesting. Elizabeth was unsettled and confused; she recognized that she was happier than she felt; because besides the initial confusion, she also had unpleasant things ahead of her.
tr: Darcy was not someone who overflowed with joy when he was happy; the excited and bewildered Elizabeth knew she was happy, more than she felt it; because in addition to the current anxiety, there were other obstacles ahead of her.
es: Darcy's happiness never overflowed into joy; Elizabeth, agitated and confused, knew she was happy more than she felt it, for besides her immediate bewilderment, other things worried her.

en: She anticipated what would be felt in the family when her situation became known: she was aware that no one liked him but Jane; and even feared that with the others it was a dislike which not all his fortune and consequence might do away.
vi: She thought about her family's attitude when they learned about her love affair; she knew no one liked Darcy except Jane, and she feared that for the others, this was an aversion that even his wealth and status could not erase.
tr: She could predict what the family would feel when the situation was known; she knew that no one except Jane liked Darcy; she even feared that despite all his wealth and power, the others might hate him.
es: She foresaw the commotion that would arise in the family when they learned what had happened. She knew that no one in her household liked Darcy more than Jane did, and she even feared that neither his fortune nor his position would be enough to satisfy them.

en: At night she opened her heart to Jane.
vi: In the night, she confided her feelings to Jane.
tr: He confided in Jane at night.
es: At night, she opened her heart to Jane, and although Jane was not naturally suspicious, she could not believe what her sister was telling her:

en: Though suspicion was very far from Miss Bennet’s general habits, she was absolutely incredulous here.
vi: Although Miss Bennet was not in the habit of doubting anyone, she found it entirely hard to believe.
tr: Although doubt was not Miss Bennet's usual habit, she was definitely unwilling to believe it.
es: At night, she opened her heart to Jane, and although Jane was not naturally suspicious, she could not believe what her sister was telling her:

en: “You are joking, Lizzy.
vi: - Lizzy, you're joking with me.
tr: "You're joking, Lizzy.
es: ––You're joking, Eliza!

en: This cannot be!
vi: It can't be!
tr: It can't be!
es: That can't be!

en: Engaged to mr Darcy!
vi: Loving Mr. Darcy!
tr: –You're engaged to Mr. Darcy!
es: You, engaged to Darcy!

en: No, no, you shall not deceive me: I know it to be impossible.”
vi: No, no, you can't deceive me. I know this can't happen.
tr: No, no, you can't fool me. I know it's impossible."
es: No, no; you won't fool me. I know it's impossible.

en: “This is a wretched beginning, indeed!
vi: - Indeed, this matter is starting to get troublesome!
tr: "It really was a terrible start!
es: ––Well, this is off to a bad start!

en: My sole dependence was on you; and I am sure nobody else will believe me, if you do not.
vi: I only rely on you, and I am sure no one will believe me if you don't believe me.
tr: I only trusted you; if you don't believe me, no one will.
es: I only trusted you, but if you don't believe me, others will believe me even less.

en: Yet, indeed, I am in earnest.
vi: That's right, we love each other.
tr: Still, I'm telling the truth.
es: I'm telling you the absolute truth.

en: I speak nothing but the truth.
vi: I only know how to tell the truth.
tr: I'm telling nothing but the truth.
es: I'm telling you the absolute truth.

en: He still loves me, and we are engaged.”
vi: He still loves me, and we have made promises to each other.
tr: He still loves me; we got engaged."
es: Darcy still loves me and we are engaged.

en: Jane looked at her doubtingly.
vi: Jane looked at her, suspiciously:
tr: Jane looked at her with suspicion.
es: Jane looked at her hesitantly:

en: “Oh, Lizzy!
vi: - Oh dear, Lizzy, it can't be!
tr: "Oh Lizzy!
es: ––Elizabeth, it is not possible.

en: it cannot be.
vi: - Oh dear, Lizzy, it can't be!
tr: It can't be.
es: But I know you can't even stand him!

en: I know how much you dislike him.”
vi: I know how much you hate him.
tr: I know how much you hate him."
es: But I know you can't even stand him!

en: “You know nothing of the matter.
vi: - You don't know anything.
tr: "You know nothing.
es: ––You know nothing at all.

en: That is all to be forgot.
vi: The two of us have forgotten about that.
tr: These things will be forgotten.
es: We have to forget all that.

en: Perhaps I did not always love him so well as I do now; but in such cases as these a good memory is unpardonable.
vi: Maybe I never loved him as much as I do now. But in situations like this, constantly remembering the past is unforgivable.
tr: Maybe I never loved him as much as I do now. But in such situations, having a good memory is not a forgivable thing.
es: Maybe I haven't always loved him as I do now; but in these cases, a good memory is unforgivable.

en: This is the last time I shall ever remember it myself.”
vi: This is the last time I want to remember it.
tr: This will be my last remembrance as well."
es: This is the last time I remember it.

en: Miss Bennet still looked all amazement.
vi: Mrs. Bennet still showed signs of astonishment.
tr: Miss Bennet was still left in a state of astonishment.
es: Jane contemplated her sister with astonishment.

en: Elizabeth again, and more seriously, assured her of its truth.
vi: Once again, Elizabeth solemnly confirmed that it was true. Jane exclaimed:
tr: Elizabeth tried to convince her again, and this time more seriously.
es: Elizabeth reaffirmed with the utmost seriousness that what she was saying was true.

en: “Good heaven!
vi: - Oh my God!
tr: "Oh my God!
es: ––Heavens!

en: can it be really so?
vi: How can that be possible!
tr: Could it really be true!
es: Is it possible? Really?

en: Yet now I must believe you,” cried Jane.
vi: Now you have to believe me, but are you sure?
tr: But I have to believe you," cried Jane.
es: But now I believe you ––exclaimed Jane––.

en: “My dear, dear Lizzy, I would, I do congratulate you; but are you certain—forgive the question—are you quite certain that you can be happy with him?”
vi: I'm sorry, but are you sure you will be happy with him?
tr: "My dear Lizzy, I congratulate you – but are you sure? Forgive my question – I mean, are you absolutely sure you can be happy with him?"
es: Dear Elizabeth! I would congratulate you, I do congratulate you, but... are you sure, and forgive the question, completely sure that you will be happy with him?

en: “There can be no doubt of that.
vi: - There is no doubt anymore.
tr: "I have no doubt.
es: ––Without a doubt.

en: It is settled between us already that we are to be the happiest couple in the world.
vi: Both of us think we are the happiest couple in the world.
tr: We have decided among ourselves, we will be the happiest couple in the world.
es: We have already agreed that we will be the happiest couple on earth.

en: But are you pleased, Jane?
vi: But Jane, are you happy?
tr: Are you happy, Jane?
es: Are you happy, Jane?

en: Shall you like to have such a brother?”
vi: Do you want a brother-in-law like that?
tr: Would you like to have such a brother-in-law?"
es: Will you like having Darcy as a brother?

en: “Very, very much.
vi: - Of course I want to.
tr: "Indeed, very much.
es: ––A lot, very much, it is what can give Bingley and me the most pleasure.

en: Nothing could give either Bingley or myself more delight.
vi: Nothing would make Mr. Bingley or me happier.
tr: Nothing could make Bingley or me happier.
es: ––A lot, very much, it is what can give Bingley and me the most pleasure.

en: But we considered it, we talked of it as impossible.
vi: But we have considered it before and said that it couldn't happen.
tr: But we thought about it and discussed that it was impossible.
es: And you, do you really love him enough?

en: And do you really love him quite well enough?
vi: And do you truly love him?
tr: So do you really love him very much?
es: And you, do you really love him enough?

en: Oh, Lizzy!
vi: Lizzy, you shouldn't marry without love!
tr: Oh, Lizzy!
es: Oh, Elizabeth!

en: do anything rather than marry without affection.
vi: Lizzy, you shouldn't marry without love!
tr: Whatever you do, don't marry a man you don't love.
es: Do anything but marry without love.

en: Are you quite sure that you feel what you ought to do?”
vi: Are you sure you know what you are doing?
tr: Are you sure you love him enough?"
es: Are you absolutely sure that you feel what you should feel?

en: “Oh, yes!
vi: - Of course!
tr: "Ah yes!
es: ––Oh, yes!

en: You will only think I feel more than I ought to do when I tell you all.”
vi: I just think you feel more than know what to do when you tell me all about this.
tr: When I tell you everything, you will understand that I love you even more."
es: And you will be convinced that I feel more than I should when I have told you everything.

en: “What do you mean?”
vi: - What do you mean? - What?
tr: "What do you mean?"
es: ––What do you mean?

en: “Why, I must confess that I love him better than I do Bingley.
vi: I just want to confess that I love him more than you love Mr. Bingley.
tr: "I must confess that I love him more than Bingley.
es: ––Well, I must confess to you that I love him more than you love Bingley.

en: I am afraid you will be angry.”
vi: I'm afraid you'll be angry.
tr: I fear you will be angry about this."
es: I fear that you will be upset.

en: “My dearest sister, now be, be serious.
vi: - Hey, it's time to be serious now.
tr: "Dear brother, be serious though.
es: ––Sister, dear, you can't be serious.

en: I want to talk very seriously.
vi: I want to have a serious conversation.
tr: I want to talk seriously.
es: ––Sister, dear, you can't be serious.

en: Let me know everything that I am to know without delay.
vi: Tell me everything I want to know, right now.
tr: Tell me everything I need to know right away.
es: Tell me one thing I need to know right now: since when have you loved him?

en: Will you tell me how long you have loved him?”
vi: How long have you been in love with him?
tr: Come on, since when have you been in love with her?"
es: Tell me one thing I need to know right now: since when have you loved him?

en: “It has been coming on so gradually, that I hardly know when it began; but I believe I must date it from my first seeing his beautiful grounds at Pemberley.”
vi: - It came gradually, to the point that I found it hard to know when it started. But I believe it was when I saw the beautiful scenery at Pemberley.
tr: "It happened so gradually that I don't even know exactly when it started. But I guess it dates back to the time when I first saw those magnificent gardens at Pemberley."
es: ––That love has come to me so gradually that I hardly know when it began; but I believe it dates back to the first time I saw his beautiful Pemberley estate.

en: Another entreaty that she would be serious, however, produced the desired effect; and she soon satisfied Jane by her solemn assurances of attachment.
vi: However, she had to assure Jane that she was serious, and eventually, Jane believed her.
tr: The renewed request for seriousness had the desired effect; Elizabeth soon convinced Jane of the sincerity of her affection.
es: Jane once again asked for formality and Elizabeth then spoke solemnly, affirming that she adored Darcy.

en: When convinced on that article, Miss Bennet had nothing further to wish.
vi: Mrs. Bennet wished for nothing more.
tr: Once convinced on this matter, Miss Bennet had no other wish.
es: Jane was convinced and was entirely satisfied.

en: “Now I am quite happy,” said she, “for you will be as happy as myself.
vi: She said: - Now I am so happy, because you will be as happy as I am.
tr: "Now I am very happy," she said, "because you will be as happy as I am.
es: ––Now I am completely happy ––he said––, because you are going to be as happy as I am.

en: I always had a value for him.
vi: I have always held him in high regard.
tr: I have always valued him.
es: I have always had great esteem for Darcy.

en: Were it for nothing but his love of you, I must always have esteemed him; but now, as Bingley’s friend and your husband, there can be only Bingley and yourself more dear to me.
vi: If for no other reason than his love for you, I would have already valued him; but now he is both Bingley's friend and your husband, only Bingley and you are the dearest people to me.
tr: Even just because he loves you, I would always respect him; but now, as Bingley's friend and your husband, he is as valuable to me as both of you.
es: Even if it were only for his love for you, I would have to love him; but now that in addition to being Bingley's friend, he will be your husband, I will love only Bingley and you more than him.

en: But, Lizzy, you have been very sly, very reserved with me.
vi: But Lizzy, you have been too discreet, too reserved with me.
tr: But Lizzy, you have been very tight-lipped and very cautious with me.
es: But how quiet and reserved you have been with me!

en: How little did you tell me of what passed at Pemberley and Lambton!
vi: You have told me very little about what happened at Pemberley and in London.
tr: How little you told me about what happened at Pemberley and Lambton!
es: Why didn't you tell me what happened at Pemberley and in Lambton?

en: I owe all that I know of it to another, not to you.”
vi: I learned everything from others, not from you.
tr: All I know, I learned not from you, but from someone else."
es: I had to learn everything from someone else and not from you.

en: Elizabeth told her the motives of her secrecy.
vi: Elizabeth told her sister about the reasons why she had to be discreet.
tr: Elizabeth explained the reasons for her secrecy.
es: Elizabeth explained to her the reasons for her secrecy.

en: She had been unwilling to mention Bingley; and the unsettled state of her own feelings had made her equally avoid the name of his friend: but now she would no longer conceal from her his share in Lydia’s marriage.
vi: She could not mention Bingley, and while her mind was still in turmoil, she also wanted to avoid mentioning his friend’s name. But now she could not hide from her sister the fact that Mr. Darcy had helped with Lydia’s marriage.
tr: She was reluctant to talk about Bingley; the unsettled state of her own feelings similarly prevented her from mentioning her lover's name. But she would no longer hide her role in Lydia's marriage from him.
es: She had not wanted to mention Bingley, and the indecision of her own feelings made her avoid also mentioning the name of his friend. But now she did not want to hide Darcy's intervention in the matter of Lydia.

en: All was acknowledged, and half the night spent in conversation.
vi: Everything was acknowledged, and they talked with each other until very late.
tr: Everything was told, and half the night was spent in conversation. ----------------------
es: Everything was clarified, and the two sisters spent half the night talking.

en: “Good gracious!” cried ms Bennet, as she stood at a window the next morning, “if that disagreeable mr Darcy is not coming here again with our dear Bingley!
vi: The next morning, while standing by the window, Mrs. Bennet exclaimed: - My goodness! I hope that annoying Darcy doesn't come here anymore with dear Bingley!
tr: "My God!" cried Mrs. Bennet, as soon as she went to the window the next morning, "isn't that disagreeable Mr. Darcy coming here again with our dear Bingley!
es: ––Oh, I hope that disagreeable Mr. Darcy doesn't come again with our dear Bingley! ––sighed Mrs. Bennet as she looked out the window the next day––.

en: What can he mean by being so tiresome as to be always coming here?
vi: What does he mean by coming here and causing trouble like this?
tr: What could he mean by coming here so often?
es: Why is he so bothersome and comes here continuously?

en: I had no notion but he would go a-shooting, or something or other, and not disturb us with his company.
vi: Mother just wants him to go hunting, or do something to keep from causing a disturbance.
tr: Wasn't he supposed to go hunting and leave us in peace?
es: He could go hunting or do anything else instead of coming to bother us.

en: What shall we do with him?
vi: How are we going to deal with him?
tr: What are we going to do with him?
es: How could we get rid of him?

en: Lizzy, you must walk out with him again, that he may not be in Bingley’s way.”
vi: Lizzy, you must go for a walk with him again, so he doesn't bother Bingley.
tr: Lizzy, go for a walk with him again, so he doesn't get in Bingley's way."
es: Elizabeth, you'll have to go for a walk with him again so he doesn't bother Bingley.

en: Elizabeth could hardly help laughing at so convenient a proposal; yet was really vexed that her mother should be always giving him such an epithet.
vi: Elizabeth could hardly avoid bursting into laughter at this favorable suggestion, but she was still annoyed that her mother kept talking about him in such a manner.
tr: Elizabeth could hardly suppress her laughter in the face of such an appropriate offer; nevertheless, her mother's talking back and forth about her was truly upsetting.
es: Elizabeth almost burst into laughter upon hearing that interesting proposition, despite the fact that it hurt her that her mother was always insulting her.

en: As soon as they entered, Bingley looked at her so expressively, and shook hands with such warmth, as left no doubt of his good information; and he soon afterwards said aloud, “ms Bennet, have you no more lanes hereabouts in which Lizzy may lose her way again to-day?”
vi: As soon as they entered, Bingley looked at her meaningfully and warmly shook her hand, as if to let her know he understood everything, then he said loudly: - Mrs. Bennet, do you have another path for walking so that Lizzy can get lost again today?
tr: The moment they entered the room, Bingley gave her a meaningful look and shook her hand so warmly that it was clear he knew; immediately after, he called out, "Mr. Bennet, is there no other path around here where Lizzy might lose her way today?""
es: As soon as the two gentlemen entered, Bingley looked at Elizabeth expressively and shook her hand with such ardor that the young woman understood that he already knew everything. Shortly after, Bingley said: Mr. Bennet, don't you have any other paths where Elizabeth might get lost again today?

en: “I advise mr Darcy, and Lizzy, and Kitty,” said ms Bennet, “to walk to Oakham Mount this morning.
vi: Mrs. Bennet replied: - I advise Mr. Darcy, Lizzy, and Kitty to take the road to Oakham Mountain today.
tr: "Mr. Darcy, I recommend that Lizzy and Kitty walk to Oakham Mountain this morning," said Mrs. Bennet.
es: ––I recommend Mr. Darcy, Lizzy, and Kitty ––said Mrs. Bennet–– to go this morning to Oagham Mountain.

en: It is a nice long walk, and mr Darcy has never seen the view.”
vi: The road is truly beautiful; and Mr. Darcy has never seen the scenery of this place before.
tr: "It is a long, pleasant road; and Mr. Darcy has never seen the view.""
es: It is a long and beautiful walk, and Mr. Darcy has never seen that view.

en: “It may do very well for the others,” replied mr Bingley; “but I am sure it will be too much for Kitty.
vi: Mr. Bingley replied: - It might be suitable for the other two, but I believe it is too strenuous for Kitty.
tr: "It might be good for others," replied Mr. Bingley; "but I'm sure it will seem too long for Kitty.
es: ––This might be fine for the other two ––explained Bingley––, but it seems to me that Catherine would get tired.

en: Won’t it, Kitty?”
vi: Is that right, Kitty?
tr: Isn't that right, Kitty?"
es: Right?

en: Kitty owned that she had rather stay at home.
vi: Kitty understood that she should stay at home.
tr: Kitty said that she preferred to stay at home.
es: The girl confessed that she would prefer to stay at home; Darcy expressed great curiosity to enjoy the view of that mountain, and Elizabeth agreed to accompany him.

en: Darcy professed a great curiosity to see the view from the Mount, and Elizabeth silently consented.
vi: Darcy seemed eager to see the view from the mountain, while Elizabeth silently agreed.
tr: Darcy said he was eager to see the view from the mountain, and Elizabeth silently agreed.
es: The girl confessed that she would prefer to stay at home; Darcy expressed great curiosity to enjoy the view of that mountain, and Elizabeth agreed to accompany him.

en: As she went upstairs to get ready, ms Bennet followed her, saying,—
vi: As she walked up the stairs to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed, saying to her:
tr: As she went upstairs to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed her and said,
es: When she went up to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed her to say:

en: “I am quite sorry, Lizzy, that you should be forced to have that disagreeable man all to yourself; but I hope you will not mind it.
vi: - Lizzy, I'm sorry for forcing you to go with that annoying guy.
tr: "I'm very sorry, Lizzy, that I had to leave you alone with that grumpy man.
es: ––Lizzy, I'm very sorry that you are forced to be with such an unpleasant person; but I hope you do it for Jane.

en: It is all for Jane’s sake, you know; and there is no occasion for talking to him except just now and then; so do not put yourself to inconvenience.”
vi: But I hope you don't mind, you know, this is for Jane, as she doesn't have many opportunities to talk to Bingley.
tr: But I hope you don't mind: it's all for Jane's sake, really; you don't need to engage in conversation, just say a few things now and then. So, don't stress yourself."
es: Besides, you only have to talk to her occasionally. Don't trouble yourself too much.

en: During their walk, it was resolved that mr Bennet’s consent should be asked in the course of the evening: Elizabeth reserved to herself the application for her mother’s.
vi: While taking a walk, the two agreed that they would ask Mr. Bennet for permission this evening. Elizabeth wanted to take it upon herself to seek her mother's opinion.
tr: During the walk, it was decided to obtain Mr. Bennet's consent in the evening. Elizabeth reserved the task of seeking her mother's consent for herself.
es: During the walk, they decided that that very afternoon they would ask for the father's consent. Elizabeth reserved for herself the task of informing the mother.

en: She could not determine how her mother would take it; sometimes doubting whether all his wealth and grandeur would be enough to overcome her abhorrence of the man; but whether she were violently set against the match, or violently delighted with it, it was certain that her manner would be equally ill adapted to do credit to her sense; and she could no more bear that mr Darcy should hear the first raptures of her joy, than the first vehemence of her disapprobation.
vi: She was unsure how her mother would receive the news; at times she feared that his wealth and status would not be enough to stop her mother from detesting him. But whether her mother reacted with intense opposition or intense joy, her demeanor would certainly not align with Elizabeth's sensibilities, and she could no longer bear the thought of Mr. Darcy having to hear her mother's initial enthusiastic remarks from joy, though it would be better than her initial angry remarks from disapproval. **
tr: She couldn't decide how her mother would react; sometimes she doubted whether all his wealth and splendor would be enough to overcome her coldness towards the man. But whether she fiercely opposed the marriage or rejoiced intensely, it was certain that her actions would be equally far from common sense; she couldn't bear for Mr. Darcy to hear either the first excitement of her joy or the initial turmoil of her objection. --------------------------
es: She could not imagine how she would take it; sometimes she doubted whether all of Darcy's wealth and lineage would be enough to counteract the hatred she harbored for him; but whether she opposed the marriage violently or approved of it with equal vehemence, there was no doubt that her outbursts would not be any indication of good sense, and for that reason, she could not bear for Darcy to witness either the first raptures of joy or the initial expressions of disapproval.

en: In the evening, soon after mr Bennet withdrew to the library, she saw mr Darcy rise also and follow him, and her agitation on seeing it was extreme.
vi: In the evening, right after Mr. Bennet returned to the study, she saw Darcy stand up and follow him, her mind in extreme turmoil.
tr: In the evening, just after Mr. Bennet had withdrawn to the library, he saw Mr. Darcy get up and follow him, and at that moment he felt a great excitement.
es: In the afternoon, shortly after Mr. Bennet had retired to his library, Elizabeth saw Darcy rise and follow him.

en: She did not fear her father’s opposition, but he was going to be made unhappy, and that it should be through her means; that she, his favourite child, should be distressing him by her choice, should be filling him with fears and regrets in disposing of her, was a wretched reflection, and she sat in misery till mr Darcy appeared again, when, looking at him, she was a little relieved by his smile.
vi: She did not fear her father’s refusal, but she was worried that he would be upset, and it was because of her, his beloved daughter, that he would be saddened by her choice, causing him to regret her. She sat there, thinking endlessly in misery, until Darcy returned, and seeing him, she felt somewhat relieved by his smile.
tr: He was not afraid that his father would object, but the thought that his father's favorite daughter would upset him with her choice, that sending her off would leave him in tears and regret, was a painful one, and Elizabeth sat in agony until Mr. Darcy returned; seeing the smile on Mr. Darcy's face relieved her a little.
es: Her heart began to beat strongly. She did not fear that her father would oppose, but it would grieve him greatly, and the fact that it was she, his favorite daughter, who was causing him such distress and who would inspire him with so much care and sorrow with her unfortunate choice, made Elizabeth very sad. She was very downcast until Darcy re-entered and, upon looking at him, his smile gave her encouragement.

en: In a few minutes he approached the table where she was sitting with Kitty; and, while pretending to admire her work, said in a whisper, “Go to your father; he wants you in the library.”
vi: He came to her, whispering: "You should go see your father; he wants to meet you in the study."
tr: A few minutes later, Mr. Darcy approached the table where Kitty was sitting; pretending to look at the crochet work in his hand, he whispered in her ear, "Go to your father, he wants you in the library."
es: A few minutes later, Darcy approached the table where Elizabeth was sitting with Catherine, and pretending to look at her work, he whispered in her ear: ––Go see your father: he needs you in the library.

en: She was gone directly.
vi: He came to her, whispering: "You should go see your father; he wants to meet you in the study."
tr: Elizabeth went immediately.
es: Elizabeth dashed out.

en: Her father was walking about the room, looking grave and anxious.
vi: The father is walking around the room, showing a serious and anxious expression.
tr: Her father was pacing up and down the room, looking serious and worried.
es: His father was pacing around the room and seemed very serious and restless.

en: “Lizzy,” said he, “what are you doing?
vi: He says: - Lizzy, what are you doing?
tr: "Lizzy," he said, "what are you doing?
es: ––Elizabeth ––he said––, what are you going to do?

en: Are you out of your senses to be accepting this man?
vi: Are you out of your mind, accepting a guy like that?
tr: Have you lost your mind to accept this man?
es: Are you in your right mind to accept that man?

en: Have not you always hated him?”
vi: Didn't you always hate him?
tr: Didn't you always hate him?"
es: Didn't we agree that you hated him?

en: How earnestly did she then wish that her former opinions had been more reasonable, her expressions more moderate!
vi: Now she earnestly wished that her initial opinions had been more appropriate, and her initial words had been more gentle!
tr: Oh, how sincerely Elizabeth wished that her previous views and statements had been more moderate!
es: How Elizabeth regretted that her first impression of Darcy had been so unjust and her expressions so immoderate!

en: It would have spared her from explanations and professions which it was exceedingly awkward to give; but they were now necessary, and she assured him, with some confusion, of her attachment to mr Darcy.
vi: If that had been the case, she wouldn't have to explain and confess in such embarrassment, but she still had to try. With a few stumbling words, she persuaded her father to believe in her love for Darcy. The father said:
tr: She wouldn't have had to make extremely disturbing explanations; but now they were necessary, and Elizabeth, albeit with some haste, convinced her father that she loved Mr. Darcy.
es: Thus, she would have spared herself certain explanations and confessions that caused her great embarrassment, but which were unavoidable. Quite confused, Elizabeth assured her father that she loved Darcy deeply.

en: “Or, in other words, you are determined to have him.
vi: - Or in other words, you want to marry him.
tr: "So, in other words, you are determined to accept it.
es: ––In other words, you are determined to marry him.

en: He is rich, to be sure, and you may have more fine clothes and fine carriages than Jane.
vi: He is wealthy, of course, and you could have more luxurious clothes, more splendid carriages than Jane's.
tr: Wealthy, of course; you will have more beautiful dresses and more luxurious cars than Jane.
es: He is rich, that's true; you will be able to have better clothes and better cars than Jane.

en: But will they make you happy?”
vi: But would these things make you happier?
tr: But will these make you happy?"
es: But will all that make you happy?

en: “Have you any other objection,” said Elizabeth, “than your belief of my indifference?”
vi: Elizabeth asked: - Does Dad have any other reason to oppose besides believing that I'm indifferent towards him?
tr: "Do you have any objections other than thinking that I'm not interested?""
es: ––Is your only objection that you think I don't love him?

en: “None at all.
vi: - Nothing else.
tr: "Not at all.
es: ––No more, no less.

en: We all know him to be a proud, unpleasant sort of man; but this would be nothing if you really liked him.”
vi: We all know he is a proud, difficult person, but this doesn't mean anything if you love him.
tr: We all know that he is a proud, repulsive man; but if you really like him, it doesn't matter at all."
es: We all know he is a proud and unpleasant man; but this doesn't matter if you like him.

en: “I do, I do like him,” she replied, with tears in her eyes; “I love him.
vi: She replied, with tears at the corner of her eyes: - I care about him, I love him.
tr: "Yes, I like him," she replied, with tears in her eyes, "I love him.
es: ––Well, yes, I like him ––replied Elizabeth with tears in her eyes––; I love him.

en: Indeed he has no improper pride.
vi: In fact, he has no undeserved pride.
tr: In fact, he has no undue pride.
es: Besides, he has no pride.

en: He is perfectly amiable.
vi: He is completely likable.
tr: He is quite friendly.
es: He is the kindest person in the world.

en: You do not know what he really is; then pray do not pain me by speaking of him in such terms.”
vi: You don't know what he is really like, so please don't make me suffer by using such words to talk about him.
tr: You don't know him well; so please don't talk about him like that and upset me."
es: You do not know him. That is why I beg you not to hurt me by talking about him in that way.

en: “Lizzy,” said her father, “I have given him my consent.
vi: - Lizzy, I accept.
tr: "Lizzy," said her father, "I have given him my consent.
es: ––Elizabeth ––added her father––, I have given my consent.

en: He is the kind of man, indeed, to whom I should never dare refuse anything, which he condescended to ask.
vi: In fact, he is the kind of person whom I cannot refuse anything he has humbly begged for.
tr: He is not the kind of man I would dare to refuse anything he condescends to ask for.
es: He is one of those men, moreover, to whom you would never dare deny anything they condescended to ask of you.

en: I now give it to you, if you are resolved on having him.
vi: Now, I yield to your wishes, if you are determined to marry him.
tr: If you are determined to accept him, I now give you my consent as well.
es: If you are determined to marry him, I also give you my consent.
