en: But let me advise you to think better of it.
vi: But I want to advise you to think it through carefully.
tr: But I advise you to think carefully.
es: But let me warn you to think it over carefully.

en: I know your disposition, Lizzy.
vi: Lizzy, I know your nature.
tr: I know your character, Lizzy.
es: I know your character, Lizzy.

en: I know that you could be neither happy nor respectable, unless you truly esteemed your husband, unless you looked up to him as a superior.
vi: I know you cannot be happy if you do not truly love your husband, especially when he is not your equal.
tr: I know that if you do not truly love your husband, if you do not feel that he is superior to you, you can neither be happy nor at peace.
es: I know that you will never be happy or prudent if you do not truly appreciate your husband, if you do not consider him as a superior.

en: Your lively talents would place you in the greatest danger in an unequal marriage.
vi: Your lively talents will place you in the greatest danger in an unequal marriage.
tr: Your cheerful disposition would put you in great danger in a marriage that is not conducive to it.
es: The liveliness of your talent would put you in the gravest of dangers if you made an unequal marriage.

en: You could scarcely escape discredit and misery.
vi: You will find it hard to avoid scandal and suffering.
tr: You cannot avoid losing faith and becoming distressed.
es: You could hardly save yourself from discredit and catastrophe.

en: My child, let me not have the grief of seeing you unable to respect your partner in life.
vi: My dear, do not let me be heartbroken to see you unable to respect your life partner.
tr: My child, do not cause me the pain of seeing that you do not respect your life partner.
es: My daughter, do not give me the distress of seeing you incapable of respecting your life partner.

en: You know not what you are about.”
vi: Elizabeth was still emotional.
tr: You do not know what awaits you."
es: You do not know what that is.

en: Elizabeth, still more affected, was earnest and solemn in her reply; and, at length, by repeated assurances that mr Darcy was really the object of her choice, by explaining the gradual change which her estimation of him had undergone, relating her absolute certainty that his affection was not the work of a day, but had stood the test of many months’ suspense, and enumerating with energy all his good qualities, she did conquer her father’s incredulity, and reconcile him to the match.
vi: She replied with the most earnest and solemn demeanor. She repeated that Mr. Darcy had always been the one she chose; she explained the gradual change in her assessment of him. She expressed her firm belief that his love was not fleeting, but had been tested through many challenging months. She passionately recounted his virtues. Finally, she managed to convince her father's doubts; he yielded to her.
tr: Now, feeling even more emotional, Elizabeth responded in a serious and dignified manner; in the end, by reiterating that she truly liked Mr. Darcy, explaining that her opinion of him had gradually changed, assuring that his love was not a matter of a single day but had been tested by months of waiting, and listing all his good qualities in one go, she dispelled her father's doubts and secured his approval of the marriage.
es: Elizabeth, more moved than her father, responded with vehemence and solemnity; and in the end, she managed to overcome her father's disbelief by reiterating the sincerity of her love for Darcy, explaining the gradual change that had occurred in her feelings for him, assuring him that Darcy's affection was not a fleeting thing, but had withstood the test of many months, and energetically listing all his good qualities. To the point that Mr. Bennet approved the marriage without reservations.

en: “Well, my dear,” said he, when she ceased speaking, “I have no more to say.
vi: He spoke when she finished: - Well then, my dear, I have nothing more to say.
tr: "Well, my dear," he said, when Elizabeth had finished her words, "I have nothing more to say.
es: ––Well, dear ––he said to her when she finished speaking––, I have nothing more to say to you.

en: If this be the case, he deserves you.
vi: If that's true, he deserves you.
tr: If that is the case, it means he deserves you.
es: In that case, it is worthy of you.

en: I could not have parted with you, my Lizzy, to anyone less worthy.”
vi: Lizzy, I can't let you go with anyone less worthy than him.
tr: I wouldn't give you to someone less worthy, my dear Lizzy."
es: My Lizzy, I would not have given you to anyone who was worth less.

en: To complete the favourable impression, she then told him what mr Darcy had voluntarily done for Lydia.
vi: Having been favorably impressed by him completely, she recounted what he had done for Lydia.
tr: To complete the good impression he had created, he told his father about what Mr. Darcy had done for Lydia on his own.
es: To complete the favorable impression of her father, Elizabeth recounted to him what Darcy had spontaneously done for Lydia.

en: He heard her with astonishment.
vi: He was utterly astonished:
tr: His father listened to these in astonishment.
es: ––This is truly an afternoon of astonishment!

en: “This is an evening of wonders, indeed!
vi: - Indeed, this is an evening filled with wonders!
tr: "This evening is truly an evening of miracles!
es: ––This is truly an afternoon of astonishment!

en: And so, Darcy did everything; made up the match, gave the money, paid the fellow’s debts, and got him his commission!
vi: And so, Darcy did everything: arranged the marriage, provided the money, paid off his debts; helped him join the military!
tr: So Darcy did everything; arranged the wedding, paid the money, settled the man's debts, found a job!
es: So Darcy did everything: arranged the marriage, gave the money, paid the young man's debts, and secured his position?

en: So much the better.
vi: All the better.
tr: It couldn't have been better.
es: Better: this way I'll be free from a sea of confusions and accounts.

en: It will save me a world of trouble and economy.
vi: It saved father a lot of trouble and finances.
tr: He will save me from a world of trouble and expense.
es: Better: this way I'll be free from a sea of confusions and accounts.

en: Had it been your uncle’s doing, I must and would have paid him; but these violent young lovers carry everything their own way.
vi: If you do this, father will have to pay off his debts and he will, but the young lovers are determined to do things their way.
tr: If my uncle had done it, I would have had to pay him and I would have; but these wild young lovers do everything as they know best.
es: If your uncle had done it, I would have had to pay him; but these young and passionate lovers take care of everything.

en: I shall offer to pay him to-morrow, he will rant and storm about his love for you, and there will be an end of the matter.”
vi: Tomorrow, father will offer to pay off his debts; he will boast about his love for you, and that will be the end of it.
tr: Tomorrow I will offer to pay him; he will fume, rage, talk about his love for you, and the matter will be closed like that."
es: Tomorrow I will offer to pay him; he will protest and make a scene invoking his love for you, and the matter will be settled.

en: He then recollected her embarrassment a few days before on his reading mr Collins’s letter; and after laughing at her some time, allowed her at last to go, saying, as she quitted the room, “If any young men come for Mary or Kitty, send them in, for I am quite at leisure.”
vi: Then he recalled her embarrassment a few days earlier, when he read Collins' letter, and after teasing her for a moment, he allowed her to go outside - saying as she turned away: - If there is any young man who wants to marry Mary or Kitty, invite them in here, because father is very happy.
tr: Then, he remembered how uncomfortable Elizabeth was while reading Mr. Collins' letter a few days ago; after laughing at Elizabeth for a while, he finally allowed her to leave – and as she was leaving the room, he said, "If there are any young men coming for Mary and Kitty, send them in too, while I have nothing else to do.""
es: Then Mr. Bennet remembered how badly Elizabeth had felt while he was reading Collins' letter to her, and after joking with her for a while, he let her go and said as she was leaving the room: ––If any boy comes for Mary or Catherine, send him to me, as I am completely unoccupied.

en: Elizabeth’s mind was now relieved from a very heavy weight; and, after half an hour’s quiet reflection in her own room, she was able to join the others with tolerable composure.
vi: Elizabeth's mind was now relieved of a burden. After contemplating for about half an hour in her private room, she was calm enough to rejoin the gathering.
tr: A very heavy burden was thus lifted from Elizabeth; after calmly thinking in her room for about half an hour, she managed to join the others with a reasonable calmness.
es: Elizabeth felt as if a huge weight had been lifted off her shoulders, and after half an hour of quiet reflection in her room, she found herself ready to join the others, quite calm.

en: Everything was too recent for gaiety, but the evening passed tranquilly away; there was no longer anything material to be dreaded, and the comfort of ease and familiarity would come in time.
vi: Everything was quite new, so there was nothing enjoyable. The evening passed peacefully; there was not much to fear, and before long, the comfort of ease and familiarity would return.
tr: Everything was too new to be cheerful, but the evening passed quite peacefully; there was nothing significant left to worry about; the pleasure of comfort and familiarity would come with time.
es: Things were too recent to give in to joy, but the afternoon passed in the utmost serenity. She had nothing to fear, and the comfort of ease and familiarity would come in due time.

en: When her mother went up to her dressing-room at night, she followed her, and made the important communication.
vi: When her mother went up to the living room that night, she followed her, announcing an extremely special piece of news.
tr: When her mother went up to the dressing room at night, Elizabeth followed her and gave her the important news.
es: When her mother retired to her room at night, Elizabeth went in with her and made the important communication.

en: Its effect was most extraordinary; for, on first hearing it, ms Bennet sat quite still, and unable to utter a syllable.
vi: The effect was extraordinarily unusual, for at first, her mother sat quietly listening, unable to utter a word.
tr: The effect of the news was extraordinary; at first, Mrs. Bennet sat motionless, unable to utter a single word.
es: The effect was extraordinary, because at first Mrs. Bennet remained absolutely motionless, unable to articulate a word; and it was only after many minutes that she could comprehend what she had heard, despite the fact that she was usually not very reluctant to believe anything that meant some advantage for her family or a courtship for one of her daughters.

en: Nor was it under many, many minutes, that she could comprehend what she heard, though not in general backward to credit what was for the advantage of her family, or that came in the shape of a lover to any of them.
vi: For a moment, she could not understand what Elizabeth was saying.
tr: It took minutes for her to grasp what she had heard; nevertheless, she did not refrain from concluding that she had heard something beneficial for her family or that one of her daughters had received a proposal.
es: The effect was extraordinary, because at first Mrs. Bennet remained absolutely motionless, unable to articulate a word; and it was only after many minutes that she could comprehend what she had heard, despite the fact that she was usually not very reluctant to believe anything that meant some advantage for her family or a courtship for one of her daughters.

en: She began at length to recover, to fidget about in her chair, get up, sit down again, wonder, and bless herself.
vi: Then she began to collect herself, fidgeting in her chair, standing up, then sitting down again, bewildered and wondering, then exclaimed:
tr: Eventually, she began to recover, stirred in her chair, stood up, sat down again, marveled, and kept talking to herself.
es: Finally, she began to recover and become agitated. She would stand up and sit back down. She marveled and congratulated herself:

en: “Good gracious!
vi: - Oh my!
tr: "Oh my God!
es: ––Heavens!

en: Lord bless me!
vi: Thank my God!
tr: What has happened to me!
es: God bless me!

en: only think!
vi: Just think about it!
tr: Just think about it!
es: What are you saying, dear daughter?

en: dear me! mr Darcy!
vi: Oh dear! Mr. Darcy!
tr: Oh my! Mr. Darcy!
es: Mr. Darcy?

en: Who would have thought it?
vi: Who could have imagined!
tr: Who would have thought!
es: Who would have thought!

en: And is it really true?
vi: Is it really true?
tr: But seriously, is it true?
es: Oh, my dear Eliza!

en: Oh, my sweetest Lizzy!
vi: Oh, my dear Lizzy!
tr: Oh! My dearest Lizzy!
es: Oh, my dear Eliza!

en: how rich and how great you will be!
vi: You will be rich and famous!
tr: How rich and powerful you will be!
es: How rich and important you will be!

en: What pin-money, what jewels, what carriages you will have!
vi: You will have so much money, jewelry, and carriages.
tr: What allowance, what jewelry, what carriages you will have!
es: What a fortune, what jewels, what carriages you will have!

en: Jane’s is nothing to it—nothing at all.
vi: Compared to you, Jane is nothing - nothing at all.
tr: Jane's are nothing in comparison –really nothing.
es: Jane's situation is nothing in comparison, truly nothing.

en: I am so pleased—so happy.
vi: I am so happy, so joyful!
tr: How delighted I am –how happy I am.
es: How happy I am, how delighted!

en: Such a charming man!
vi: What a charming young man, so handsome, so tall!
tr: What a charming man!
es: What a charming man, so handsome, so well-built!

en: so handsome!
vi: What a charming young man, so handsome, so tall!
tr: –so handsome!
es: What a charming man, so handsome, so well-built!

en: so tall!
vi: Oh!
tr: –so tall!
es: What a charming man, so handsome, so well-built!

en: Oh, my dear Lizzy!
vi: Dear Lizzy!
tr: –Oh my dearest Lizzy!
es: Lizzy, my dear, forgive me for finding him so disagreeable before!

en: pray apologize for my having disliked him so much before.
vi: Forgive me for disliking him before!
tr: Please apologize on my behalf for never liking him before.
es: Lizzy, my dear, forgive me for finding him so disagreeable before!

en: I hope he will overlook it.
vi: I hope he will forgive me.
tr: But I hope he doesn't mind.
es: I hope he forgives me too.

en: Dear, dear Lizzy.
vi: You, my dear Lizzy!
tr: My sweet Lizzy.
es: Elizabeth, my heart!

en: A house in town!
vi: A house in the city!
tr: A house in the city!
es: A house in the capital!

en: Everything that is charming!
vi: Everything is so appealing!
tr: Everything is so classy!
es: Everything desirable!

en: Three daughters married!
vi: My God!
tr: Three of my daughters are married!
es: Three daughters married!

en: Ten thousand a year!
vi: My God!
tr: Ten thousand pounds a year!
es: Ten thousand pounds a year!

en: Oh, Lord!
vi: My God!
tr: Oh God!
es: My goodness!

en: what will become of me?
vi: What will become of me?!
tr: Something is happening to me.
es: What will become of me?

en: I shall go distracted.”
vi: I am overwhelmed!
tr: I am going to lose my mind."
es: I'm going to go mad!

en: This was enough to prove that her approbation need not be doubted; and Elizabeth, rejoicing that such an effusion was heard only by herself, soon went away.
vi: That was enough to know that she had agreed. Elizabeth was glad to see that only she had to hear such words.
tr: These were enough to prove that there could be no doubt about her consent: Elizabeth, who was happy just because she had heard such a storm herself, soon left the place.
es: This was enough to prove that his approval was undeniable. Elizabeth, delighted that those effusions had been heard only by her, left immediately.

en: But before she had been three minutes in her own room, her mother followed her.
vi: But she was only alone in her room for a moment. She followed her, exclaiming:
tr: But she had not spent even three minutes in her own room when her mother came after her.
es: But she had not been in her room for three minutes when her mother came in.

en: “My dearest child,” she cried, “I can think of nothing else.
vi: - My dearest child, I don't know what to think anymore!
tr: "My dearest child," she exclaimed, "I can't think of anything else!
es: ––Daughter of my heart! ––he exclaimed. I can't think of anything else.

en: Ten thousand a year, and very likely more!
vi: Ten thousand a year, maybe even more!
tr: Ten thousand a year, maybe even more!
es: Ten thousand pounds a year and maybe more!

en: ’Tis as good as a lord!
vi: It's like Heaven!
tr: Worthy of lords!
es: He's worth as much as a lord!

en: And a special licence—you must and shall be married by a special licence.
vi: And a special marriage license. You should marry with a special license.
tr: And a private wedding. You will have a marriage certificate from the Archbishop himself, as you should.
es: And a special license, because you must get married with a special license.

en: But, my dearest love, tell me what dish mr Darcy is particularly fond of, that I may have it to-morrow.”
vi: But my dearest child, tell me what Mr. Darcy likes the most so I can prepare it for tomorrow.
tr: But my dearest child, now tell me, what is Mr. Darcy's favorite dish, so we can prepare it for him tomorrow."
es: My dear, tell me what dish Darcy likes the most so I can prepare it for him tomorrow.

en: This was a sad omen of what her mother’s behaviour to the gentleman himself might be; and Elizabeth found that, though in the certain possession of his warmest affection, and secure of her relations’ consent, there was still something to be wished for.
vi: This is a forewarning of the mother's attitude towards him. Although she had been loved passionately by him and accepted by his relatives, Elizabeth understood that she still longed for a few other things.
tr: These words gave troubling hints about how her mother might behave towards the gentleman; although Elizabeth knew she had Darcy's sincere love and her family's consent, she still saw that something was missing.
es: This was a bad omen for what Mrs. Bennet's behavior towards the gentleman in question was going to be, and Elizabeth understood that despite having Darcy's ardent love and the consent of her entire family, something was still missing.

en: But the morrow passed off much better than she expected; for ms Bennet luckily stood in such awe of her intended son-in-law, that she ventured not to speak to him, unless it was in her power to offer him any attention, or mark her deference for his opinion.
vi: But the next day passed better than she thought, because fortunately Mrs. Bennet still had too much respect for her future son-in-law to dare to start a conversation with him, unless she wanted to show care or express respect for his opinion.
tr: But the next morning went much better than expected; because Mrs. Bennet, thankfully, looked at her future son-in-law with such admiration that she did not attempt to speak to him, except to show as much interest as she could or to indicate her agreement with his views.
es: But the next morning went better than she had thought, because, fortunately, her future son-in-law instilled such fear in Mrs. Bennet that she did not dare speak to him except when she could pay him some attention or agree with what he said.

en: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing her father taking pains to get acquainted with him; and mr Bennet soon assured her that he was rising every hour in his esteem.
vi: Elizabeth was delighted to see her father making an effort to be friendly with him, and before long, Mr. Bennet reassured her that he was growing to appreciate him more and more.
tr: Elizabeth was pleased to see that her father had taken the trouble to get to know him; soon after, Mr. Bennet reassured Elizabeth by saying that his esteem for him was increasing by the moment.
es: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing that her father was making an effort to become close with him, and he assured her, to top it off, that he liked him more each day.

en: “I admire all my three sons-in-law highly,” said he.
vi: He said: - Dad loves all three of his sons-in-law.
tr: "I like all three of my sons-in-law very much," she said.
es: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing that her father was making an effort to become close with him, and he assured her, to top it off, that he liked him more each day.

en: “Wickham, perhaps, is my favourite; but I think I shall like your husband quite as well as Jane’s.”
vi: Perhaps Dad loves Wickham the most, but he thinks he will love your husband as much as Jane's husband.
tr: "Wickham, I think, is my favorite; but it seems I will love your husband as much as Jane's.""
es: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing that her father was making an effort to become close with him, and he assured her, to top it off, that he liked him more each day.

en: CHAPTER LX.
vi: Chapter 60
tr: Chapter XVIII
es: CHAPTER LX

en: ELIZABETH’S spirits soon rising to playfulness again, she wanted mr Darcy to account for his having ever fallen in love with her.
vi: Elizabeth was in such high spirits that she felt like joking; she wanted Mr. Darcy to explain when he first began to love her.
tr: When Elizabeth's spirits quickly regained their former liveliness, she asked Mr. Darcy to tell her how he had fallen in love with her.
es: Elizabeth soon regained her cheerfulness, and she wanted Darcy to tell her how he had fallen in love with her:

en: “How could you begin?” said she.
vi: She asked: - How did this start?
tr: "How did it begin?" she said.
es: ––How did it all start? ––he said to her––.

en: “I can comprehend your going on charmingly, when you had once made a beginning; but what could set you off in the first place?”
vi: I can understand that you continued in an engaging way after you started, but when did you start?
tr: "I can imagine that once it started, it continued sweetly; but what first moved you?""
es: I understand that once you were on the path you kept going, but what was the first moment you liked me?

en: “I cannot fix on the hour, or the spot, or the look, or the words, which laid the foundation.
vi: - He cannot pinpoint the date, or the place, or the look, or the words that laid the foundation.
tr: "I cannot distinguish the hour, or the place, or the look, or the words that started it all.
es: ––I cannot pinpoint the hour, nor the place, nor the look, nor the words that laid the foundations of my love.

en: It is too long ago.
vi: It has been a long time.
tr: It was a long time ago.
es: It was quite some time ago.

en: I was in the middle before I knew that I had begun.”
vi: He was in the process of continuing before he knew he had started.
tr: I found myself in the middle of it before I realized it had begun."
es: I was already half in love with you before I knew that I wanted you.

en: “My beauty you had early withstood, and as for my manners—my behaviour to you was at least always bordering on the uncivil, and I never spoke to you without rather wishing to give you pain than not.
vi: - You have accepted my appearance, and regarding my gestures and attitude towards you, they are at least close to rudeness, and I often talk to you with the intention of hurting you.
tr: "At first, you resisted my beauty, and as for my behavior – my attitude towards you was always on the edge of rudeness, and I never spoke to you without a desire to hurt you.
es: ––Well, my beauty hardly moved you. And as for my manners with you, they bordered on rudeness. I never spoke to you except to annoy you.

en: Now, be sincere; did you admire me for my impertinence?”
vi: Now be honest with me, did you still love me at that time when I was being insolent to you?
tr: Now let's be honest; did you love me for my arrogance?"
es: Be honest: did you admire me for my impertinence?

en: “For the liveliness of your mind I did.”
vi: - Still, because of the liveliness of your soul.
tr: "I loved it for the vitality of its soul.""
es: ––For your vigor and your intelligence.

en: “You may as well call it impertinence at once.
vi: - You can call it insolent right here.
tr: "You could also call this arrogance.
es: ––You can call it impertinence, for it was little less than that.

en: It was very little less.
vi: It's not much less than that.
tr: It was on the verge of becoming so.
es: ––You can call it impertinence, for it was little less than that.

en: The fact is, that you were sick of civility, of deference, of officious attention.
vi: The truth is, you are fed up with politeness, respectful manners, or proper etiquette.
tr: The truth is, you were tired of politeness, meekness, and unpretentious closeness.
es: The truth is that you were fed up with courtesies, deferences, attentions.

en: You were disgusted with the women who were always speaking, and looking, and thinking for your approbation alone.
vi: You despise women who only speak, act, and think with the sole purpose of catching your attention.
tr: You were fed up with women who spoke, looked, and thought just to please you.
es: You were annoyed by women who spoke only to attract you.

en: I roused and interested you, because I was so unlike them.
vi: You noticed me because I am different from them.
tr: I warned you, I caught your interest, because I was nothing like them.
es: I irritated and interested you because I didn't seem like them.

en: Had you not been really amiable you would have hated me for it: but in spite of the pains you took to disguise yourself, your feelings were always noble and just; and in your heart you thoroughly despised the persons who so assiduously courted you.
vi: If you weren't genuinely charming, I would have hated you for this attitude. But despite the pain you want to hide, your feelings are always noble and just, and in your heart, you completely detest those who fawn over you.
tr: If you weren't truly friendly, you would have hated me for this; but despite the troubles you went through to hide yourself, your feelings were always noble and fair; deep down, you despised those who courted you with such care.
es: That's why, if you hadn't actually been so affable, you would have hated me; but despite the effort you took to hide it, your feelings were noble and just, and deep down you completely despised the people who so assiduously courted you.

en: There—I have saved you the trouble of accounting for it; and really, all things considered, I begin to think it perfectly reasonable.
vi: There, you have helped me save the trouble of explaining, and honestly, when considering everything, I think it is entirely reasonable.
tr: Look – I saved you the trouble of explaining; really, upon thorough reflection, I am starting to find this quite reasonable.
es: See how I have spared you the trouble of explaining it to me. And, the truth is, after all, I'm beginning to think that it's perfectly reasonable.

en: To be sure you know no actual good of me—but nobody thinks of that when they fall in love.”
vi: I did not know clearly about your goodness, that must be it. But no one thinks about this when they are in love.
tr: In fact, you never saw any good in me – but when one is in love, no one thinks about that."
es: I'm sure that now you don't find any merit in me, but no one notices that when they fall in love.

en: “Was there no good in your affectionate behaviour to Jane, while she was ill at Netherfield?”
vi: - When Jane was ill at Netherfield, wasn't your affectionate attitude towards her a good thing?
tr: Was there no kindness in the attention you showed Jane while she was ill at Netherfield?"
es: ––Was there no merit in your affectionate behavior towards Jane when she fell ill at Netherfield?

en: “Dearest Jane!
vi: - Dearest Jane!
tr: "Dearest Jane!
es: ––My dear Jane!

en: who could have done less for her?
vi: Who could treat her so poorly?!
tr: Who could have done less for her?
es: Anyone would have done the same for her.

en: But make a virtue of it by all means.
vi: But you can highlight this matter in every possible way.
tr: But still, consider it a virtue.
es: But interpret it as a virtue, if you wish.

en: My good qualities are under your protection, and you are to exaggerate them as much as possible; and, in return, it belongs to me to find occasions for teasing and quarrelling with you as often as may be; and I shall begin directly, by asking you what made you so unwilling to come to the point at last?
vi: You defend all my virtues, and even try to exaggerate them as much as possible. In return, I find every opportunity to tease and argue with you as much as I can, and I will start right now by asking you what made you finally not want to get straight to the point.
tr: My good qualities are under your protection, and you exaggerate them as much as possible; it falls to me to find a reason to argue with you again, to make you angry; well, I will start by asking you directly, why were you so reluctant to get to the point?
es: My good qualities belong to you now, and you can exaggerate them as much as you like. On the other hand, it is my duty to find occasions to contradict you and argue with you as often as I can. So I am going to start right now. Why did you take so long to talk to me about your feelings again?

en: What made you so shy of me, when you first called, and afterwards dined here?
vi: The first time you visited me and then stayed for dinner, what made you so shy with me?
tr: What was it that embarrassed you so much about me when you first came and dined here?
es: Why were you so shy when you first came and then when you had dinner with us?

en: Why, especially, when you called, did you look as if you did not care about me?”
vi: Especially when you arrived, why did you act as if you didn't care about me?
tr: Especially, why did you act as if you didn't care about me when you arrived?"
es: Why, especially, while you were at home, did you behave as if I didn't matter to you at all?

en: “Because you were grave and silent, and gave me no encouragement.”
vi: - Because you are solemn and silent, and you do not encourage me to be bolder.
tr: "Because you were serious and silent; you did not give me courage."
es: ––Because I saw you serious and silent, and you didn't encourage me.

en: “But I was embarrassed.”
vi: - But because I was confused.
tr: "But I was tense."
es: ––She was very violent.

en: “And so was I.”
vi: - And you too.
tr: "Me too."
es: ––And me too.

en: “You might have talked to me more when you came to dinner.”
vi: - You should have talked more with me when you came for dinner.
tr: "When you came to dinner, you could have talked to me more.""
es: ––You could have talked to me more when you came to eat.

en: “A man who had felt less might.”
vi: - Someone who thinks less about you would do that.
tr: "Someone who feels less could have spoken.""
es: ––If I had been less moved, I would have done it.

en: “How unlucky that you should have a reasonable answer to give, and that I should be so reasonable as to admit it!
vi: - Perhaps you have a reasonable answer, and I have a reasonable reason to accept it!
tr: "What a misfortune to have a reasonable answer for everything; and it's another misfortune that I am reasonable enough to accept it!
es: ––What a pity that you always have a reasonable answer, and that I am also so reasonable to accept it!

en: But I wonder how long you would have gone on, if you had been left to yourself.
vi: But I wonder how long you will continue like this, if everything is left to you?
tr: But, I wonder how much longer you would have continued if you were left on your own.
es: But if you had had to decide, we would still be waiting.

en: I wonder when you would have spoken if I had not asked you!
vi: I wonder when you will be willing to speak, if I do not ask you.
tr: When would you have spoken if I hadn't asked you?
es: When would you have told me something, if it is not I who starts?

en: My resolution of thanking you for your kindness to Lydia had certainly great effect.
vi: My intention to thank you for your kindness towards Lydia had a great effect.
tr: My decision to thank you for the kindness you showed to Lydia certainly had a great impact.
es: My decision to thank you for what you did for Lydia had a good effect; too much: I am scared; because how does morality stand if our happiness sprang from the breach of a promise?

en: Too much, I am afraid; for what becomes of the moral, if our comfort springs from a breach of promise, for I ought not to have mentioned the subject?
vi: I fear it was too great, because I should not have mentioned that secret, and if we feel comfortable about breaking promises, what will become of morality?
tr: Too great an impact, I'm afraid; but, if our happiness is born from the breaking of a promise, where is morality? because I had to avoid mentioning that subject.
es: My decision to thank you for what you did for Lydia had a good effect; too much: I am scared; because how does morality stand if our happiness sprang from the breach of a promise?

en: This will never do.”
vi: This way is not good.
tr: No, this won't do."
es: I should not have spoken about that, I will not do it again.

en: “You need not distress yourself.
vi: - You shouldn't torment yourself.
tr: "There is no need for you to strain yourself.
es: ––Don't torment yourself.

en: The moral will be perfectly fair.
vi: Morality will still be quite good.
tr: Morality is in its place.
es: Morality will remain completely intact.

en: Lady Catherine’s unjustifiable endeavours to separate us were the means of removing all my doubts.
vi: The indefensible efforts of Lady Catherine to prevent us are the means to dispel all doubts.
tr: Lady Catherine's unacceptable actions to separate us helped dispel all my doubts.
es: Lady Catherine's unclassifiable behavior to separate us was what dispelled all my doubts.

en: I am not indebted for my present happiness to your eager desire of expressing your gratitude.
vi: With the happiness I have, I do not owe you gratitude for your earnest thanks.
tr: I do not owe my current happiness to your desire to express gratitude.
es: I do not owe my current happiness to your vehement desire to express your gratitude to me.

en: I was not in a humour to wait for an opening of yours.
vi: My feelings at that time did not await your open-heartedness.
tr: I couldn't wait for you to bring up the subject.
es: I did not need you to tell me anything.

en: My aunt’s intelligence had given me hope, and I was determined at once to know everything.”
vi: What my aunt told me gave me hope, and I wanted to know everything immediately.
tr: What my aunt told me gave me hope, so I decided to learn everything as soon as possible."
es: My aunt's account had given me hope and I was determined to know everything at once.

en: “Lady Catherine has been of infinite use, which ought to make her happy, for she loves to be of use.
vi: - Mrs. Catherine has contributed greatly, and this must make her happy if she likes to contribute.
tr: "Lady Catherine has been of great benefit, which is something to be glad about, because she loves to be useful.
es: ––Lady Catherine has been, therefore, infinitely useful to us, something that should delight her as she loves being useful to everyone.

en: But tell me, what did you come down to Netherfield for?
vi: But, tell me, why did you come to Netherfield?
tr: But tell me, why did you come to Netherfield?
es: But tell me, why did you return to Netherfield?

en: Was it merely to ride to Longbourn and be embarrassed?
vi: Just to go to Longbourn and be confused?
tr: Was it to ride all the way to Longbourn and be inconvenienced, or did you have more serious intentions?"
es: Was it only to come to Longbourn to torment yourself, or did you think of achieving a more serious outcome?

en: or had you intended any more serious consequences?”
vi: Or do you have a more serious intention?
tr: Was it to ride all the way to Longbourn and be inconvenienced, or did you have more serious intentions?"
es: Was it only to come to Longbourn to torment yourself, or did you think of achieving a more serious outcome?

en: “My real purpose was to see you, and to judge, if I could, whether I might ever hope to make you love me.
vi: - My main purpose is to meet you. And if possible, I hope to make you love me.
tr: "My true purpose was to see you, and of course, to understand if there could be any hope of making you love me.
es: ––My true purpose was to see you and to find out if I could still hope that you loved me.

en: My avowed one, or what I avowed to myself, was to see whether your sister was still partial to Bingley, and if she were, to make the confession to him which I have since made.”
vi: The reason I gave, or the reason I created for myself, is to see if your sister still loves Mr. Bingley, and if she does, I will confess to Mr. Bingley about what I confessed afterward.
tr: The purpose I expressed, or the one I expressed to myself, was to see if your sister still had feelings for Bingley and, if she did, to tell Bingley the truth, which I already did."
es: What I was confessing or confessing to myself was to see if your sister still cared for Bingley, and, if so, to reiterate the confession I had already made to him once before.

en: “Shall you ever have courage to announce to Lady Catherine what is to befall her?”
vi: - If you have the courage to confess to Lady Catherine, how do you think she will react?
tr: "Do you have the courage to tell Lady Catherine what awaits her?""
es: ––Will you have the courage to inform Lady Catherine of what awaits her?

en: “I am more likely to want time than courage, Elizabeth.
vi: - Elizabeth, maybe you need more time than courage.
tr: "It seems like I need more time than courage, Elizabeth.
es: ––Maybe I'm more short on time than courage.

en: But it ought to be done; and if you will give me a sheet of paper it shall be done directly.”
vi: But I will do this, and if you give me a piece of paper, I will write it immediately.
tr: On the other hand, it needs to be told; give me paper, I'll tell it right away."
es: Let's do it right now. If you give me a sheet of paper, I'll do it immediately.

en: “And if I had not a letter to write myself, I might sit by you, and admire the evenness of your writing, as another young lady once did.
vi: - And if I didn't have to write it myself, I would sit by your side to praise your straight lines, just as a woman once did.
tr: "Even if I didn't have a letter to write, I would sit beside you and admire the neatness of your writing, just like another young lady once did.
es: ––And if I didn't have to write another letter, I could sit by your side and admire the uniformity of your handwriting, as a certain young lady did on another occasion.

en: But I have an aunt, too, who must not be longer neglected.”
vi: But I also have an aunt whom I must not forget.
tr: But I also have an aunt who should not be neglected any longer."
es: But I have an aunt whom I don't want to leave forgotten for any longer.

en: From an unwillingness to confess how much her intimacy with mr Darcy had been overrated, Elizabeth had never yet answered ms Gardiner’s long letter; but now, having that to communicate which she knew would be most welcome, she was almost ashamed to find that her uncle and aunt had already lost three days of happiness, and immediately wrote as follows:—
vi: Elizabeth had not yet written a reply to Mrs. Gardiner's long letter because she did not want to admit her feelings for Mr. Darcy. But now, with this news to write about, which she knew the reader would be very happy to hear, she was ashamed to think that her uncle and aunt had lost three days of happiness. Immediately, she wrote to them:
tr: Due to her reluctance to admit how much her closeness with Mr. Darcy had been exaggerated, Elizabeth had not yet responded to Mrs. Gardiner's long letter, but now that she had something very pleasing to tell, she felt ashamed that her uncle and aunt had already lost three happy days and immediately wrote the following letter:
es: For not wanting to confess that they had exaggerated their intimacy with Darcy, Elizabeth had not yet replied to Mrs. Gardiner's long letter. But now, being able to announce to them what would be so well received, she almost felt ashamed that her uncles had missed out on three days of enjoying that news. Her letter was as follows:

en: “I would have thanked you before, my dear aunt, as I ought to have done, for your long, kind, satisfactory detail of particulars; but, to say the truth, I was too cross to write.
vi: " My dear aunt, I should have thanked you earlier for the long, heartfelt letter, detailing everything that you wrote to me. But I must confess, I was so overwhelmed that I couldn't respond.
tr: "I should have thanked you earlier, my dear aunt, for enlightening me in such a long, understanding, and satisfactory manner about the details, but to be honest, I was too astonished to write.
es: Dear Aunt, I would have thanked you earlier, as was my duty, for your extensive, kind, and satisfactory description of the event you know about; but you will understand that I was too distressed to do so.

en: You supposed more than really existed.
vi: You guessed more things than what actually happened at that time.
tr: You have assumed more than what is actually the case.
es: Your suppositions went beyond reality.

en: But now suppose as much as you choose; give a loose to your fancy, indulge your imagination in every possible flight which the subject will afford, and unless you believe me actually married, you cannot greatly err.
vi: But now, you can speculate as much as you like, let your mind wander far, let your imagination illuminate every aspect related to the matter, and you will not be mistaken in anything unless you believe that I have gotten married.
tr: But now you can assume whatever you wish; let your dreams run wild; let your imagination soar as far as it can, and if you do not believe that I am truly married, you could not be more mistaken.
es: But now you can suppose whatever you please, you can let your imagination run wild, you can allow your fancy to fly freely, and you will not be more mistaken than if you imagine that I am already married.

en: You must write again very soon, and praise him a great deal more than you did in your last.
vi: You should write more to me and praise him more warmly than in the letter.
tr: Write again at the first opportunity and praise him even more than you did last time.
es: You must write to me soon and praise Darcy much more than you did in your last letter.

en: I thank you again and again, for not going to the Lakes.
vi: I thank you and uncle, I want to thank you forever, for the decision not to go to the Lake District.
tr: Thank you repeatedly for not going to the Lake District.
es: I thank God a thousand times over for not having gone to the Lakes.

en: How could I be so silly as to wish it!
vi: How foolish I was to want to go!
tr: How could I have been so foolish as to want to go there!
es: What folly on my part to have desired it!

en: Your idea of the ponies is delightful.
vi: Your idea about the little horses is really wonderful.
tr: Your idea of a pony is marvelous.
es: Your idea of the ponies is magnificent; every day we will tour the estate.

en: We will go round the park every day.
vi: The two of us will drive around the garden.
tr: We will walk around the grove every day.
es: Your idea of the ponies is magnificent; every day we will tour the estate.

en: I am the happiest creature in the world.
vi: I am the happiest creature in the world.
tr: I am the happiest person in the world.
es: I am the happiest creature in the world.

en: Perhaps other people have said so before, but no one with such justice.
vi: I am the happiest creature in the world.
tr: Perhaps others have said this before, but none have been so right.
es: Perhaps others have said it before, but no one with as much justice.

en: I am happier even than Jane; she only smiles, I laugh.
vi: I am happier than Jane, she only smiles, I often laugh out loud.
tr: I am even happier than Jane; she merely smiles while I laugh out loud.
es: I am even happier than Jane. She only smiles. I laugh out loud.

en: mr Darcy sends you all the love in the world that can be spared from me.
vi: Mr. Darcy sends to you the love that he can spare from me.
tr: Mr. Darcy sends you his endless love, of course, whatever he can spare from me.
es: Darcy sends you all the love he can spare from me.

en: You are all to come to Pemberley at Christmas.
vi: I hope your whole family will visit Pemberley during the Christmas holiday.
tr: You will all come to Pemberley for Christmas.
es: You will all come to Pemberley for Christmas.

en: Yours,” etc.
vi: Your uncle and aunt's niece/nephew "
tr: Yours..."
es: Darcy's letter to Lady Catherine was different.

en: mr Darcy’s letter to Lady Catherine was in a different style, and still different from either was what mr Bennet sent to mr Collins, in return for his last.
vi: Mr. Darcy's letter to Lady Catherine had a distinctly different style, and it was also different from Mr. Bennet's letter to Mr. Collins.
tr: The letter Mr. Darcy wrote to Lady Catherine had a different tone; but what was truly distinct was the letter Mr. Bennet wrote in response to Mr. Collins' last letter.
es: And even more different was the one Mr. Bennet sent to Mr. Collins in response to his last one:

en: “Dear Sir,
vi: " Sir,
tr: "Dear Sir,
es: Dear sir,

en: “I must trouble you once more for congratulations.
vi: I will bother you, as you have to congratulate again.
tr: I have to once again offer my congratulations to you.
es: I have to trouble you once more with the matter of congratulations: Elizabeth will soon be Mr. Darcy's wife.

en: Elizabeth will soon be the wife of mr Darcy.
vi: Elizabeth will soon become Mrs. Darcy.
tr: Elizabeth will soon be Mr. Darcy's wife.
es: I have to trouble you once more with the matter of congratulations: Elizabeth will soon be Mr. Darcy's wife.

en: Console Lady Catherine as well as you can.
vi: Please try to console Lady Catherine.
tr: Console Lady Catherine as much as you can.
es: Console Lady Catherine as best as you can; but if I were you, I would stick with the nephew.

en: But, if I were you, I would stand by the nephew.
vi: But, if I were you, I would side with the nephew.
tr: But, if I were you, I would get close to the nephew.
es: Catherine as best as you can; but if I were you, I would stick with the nephew.

en: He has more to give.
vi: He has more good things to offer.
tr: He has much more to offer.
es: He has more to offer.

en: “Yours sincerely,” etc.
vi: Sincerely "
tr: Yours sincerely."
es: I greet you attentively.

en: Miss Bingley’s congratulations to her brother on his approaching marriage were all that was affectionate and insincere.
vi: Miss Bingley's congratulations to her brother on his upcoming wedding were affectionate and insincere.
tr: Miss Bingley's congratulations to her brother on his impending marriage were full of sweetness and insincerity.
es: The congratulations from Miss Bingley to her brother on the occasion of his upcoming wedding were very affectionate, but not sincere.

en: She wrote even to Jane on the occasion, to express her delight, and repeat all her former professions of regard.
vi: She even wrote to Jane to express her joy and to repeat her previous expressions of affection.
tr: She even wrote to Jane because of the marriage, expressed her joy, and repeated all her former displays of affection.
es: She also wrote to Jane to express her joy and to repeat her previous expressions of affection.

en: Jane was not deceived, but she was affected; and though feeling no reliance on her, could not help writing her a much kinder answer than she knew was deserved.
vi: Jane was not deceived, but she was still touched; and although she did not trust her sister-in-law, she replied more kindly than what the sister-in-law deserved.
tr: Jane was not deceived, but she was affected; although she did not trust her, she could not help but write a much kinder response than she knew was deserved.
es: Jane was not deceived, but she felt moved, and although she did not trust her, she could not help but send a reply much kinder than she thought she deserved.

en: The joy which Miss Darcy expressed on receiving similar information was as sincere as her brother’s in sending it.
vi: After receiving similar news, Miss Darcy's joy in writing to her brother was as genuine as his own happiness.
tr: The joy Miss Darcy expressed upon receiving the same news was as sincere as the joy of her brother who sent the news.
es: The joy that Miss Darcy felt upon hearing the news was as genuine as her brother's when he communicated it to her.

en: Four sides of paper were insufficient to contain all her delight, and all her earnest desire of being loved by her sister.
vi: The four pages were not enough to express all her delight and her desire to be loved by her sister-in-law.
tr: Two pages, front and back, were not enough to convey her satisfaction and her desire to be loved by her sister-in-law.
es: She sent a four-page letter that still seemed insufficient to express all her satisfaction and her strong desire to gain her sister's affection.

en: Before any answer could arrive from mr Collins, or any congratulations to Elizabeth from his wife, the Longbourn family heard that the Collinses were come themselves to Lucas Lodge.
vi: Before receiving a reply from Mr. Collins, or congratulations from his wife to Elizabeth, the Longbourn family received news that Mr. and Mrs. Collins would be returning to the Lucas household.
tr: Before receiving a reply from Mr. Collins or congratulations from his wife to Elizabeth, the Longbourn family heard that the Collinses would personally come to Lucas Lodge.
es: Before any response from Collins or congratulations from his wife to Elizabeth arrived, the Longbourn family learned that the Collinses were coming to the Lucas' house.

en: The reason of this sudden removal was soon evident.
vi: It wasn't long before they realized the obvious reason for the trip.
tr: The reason for this sudden departure was soon understood.
es: The reason for such a sudden move was soon known.

en: Lady Catherine had been rendered so exceedingly angry by the contents of her nephew’s letter, that Charlotte, really rejoicing in the match, was anxious to get away till the storm was blown over.
vi: Lady Catherine had become extremely angry after receiving her nephew's letter, to the extent that Charlotte wanted to stay away until the storm passed, but she still shared in the couple's happiness.
tr: Lady Catherine was so enraged by the contents of her nephew's letter that Charlotte, who was genuinely happy about the marriage news, wanted to stay away until the storm passed.
es: Lady Catherine had become so furious upon receiving her nephew's letter that Charlotte, who was genuinely happy about the wedding, wanted to leave until the storm subsided.

en: At such a moment, the arrival of her friend was a sincere pleasure to Elizabeth, though in the course of their meetings she must sometimes think the pleasure dearly bought, when she saw mr Darcy exposed to all the parading and obsequious civility of her husband.
vi: At a time like this, her friend's presence was indeed a joy for Elizabeth, although when they met again, she sometimes had to acknowledge that the joy came at a high price, seeing Mr. Darcy having to endure all the ostentatious and obsequious manners of her friend's husband.
tr: The arrival of her friend at such a moment sincerely delighted Elizabeth; however, when they came together, she must have thought that this joy came at a heavy price upon seeing Mr. Darcy subjected to all the noisy and slavish politeness of her friend's husband.
es: The arrival of her friend at that moment was a great pleasure for Elizabeth; although during their meetings this pleasure diminished when she saw Darcy exposed to Collins' pompous courtesy.

en: He bore it, however, with admirable calmness.
vi: However, he endured it commendably.
tr: Nevertheless, Mr. Darcy endured these with admirable calmness.
es: But Darcy endured it all with admirable serenity.

en: He could even listen to Sir William Lucas, when he complimented him on carrying away the brightest jewel of the country, and expressed his hopes of their all meeting frequently at St. James’s, with very decent composure.
vi: He could even listen to Sir William Lucas's words when he praised Collins for having taken away the brightest gem in the land, and with proper demeanor, expressed every hope that they would meet again at St. James's.
tr: He even listened with a very dignified manner to Sir William Lucas, who complimented him on taking away the brightest jewel of the neighborhood and expressed his hope of meeting frequently at St. James's.
es: He even attended to Sir William Lucas when he came to congratulate him on winning the brightest jewel of the county and expressed his hopes that they would all meet at St. James.

en: If he did shrug his shoulders, it was not till Sir William was out of sight.
vi: Only when Sir William was out of sight did he shrug his shoulders.
tr: When he was about to shrug, he waited until Sir William was out of sight.
es: Darcy shrugged, but only when Sir William could no longer see him.

en: ms Philips’s vulgarity was another, and, perhaps, a greater tax on his forbearance; and though ms Philips, as well as her sister, stood in too much awe of him to speak with the familiarity which Bingley’s good-humour encouraged; yet, whenever she did speak, she must be vulgar.
vi: The rude demeanor of Mrs. Phillips was a torment, perhaps the greatest torment, for his endurance. Although Mrs. Phillips, like her sister, respected him too much to adopt the familiar attitude that Mr. Bingley cheerfully encouraged, whenever she spoke, she revealed her rudeness.
tr: Mrs. Philips's wildness, however, became another source of distress that truly tested her patience; like her sister, Mrs. Philips was so intimidated by her that she couldn't speak to her with the ease they derived from Bingley's good nature, but when she did speak, she became even wilder.
es: The vulgarity of Mrs. Philips was another and perhaps the greatest of the contributions imposed on her patience, for although this lady, like her sister, had too much respect for her to speak to her with the familiarity that Bingley's good humor allowed, she could not open her mouth without saying something vulgar.

en: Nor was her respect for him, though it made her more quiet, at all likely to make her more elegant.
vi: Her respect for him only made her speak less, but did not help her become more elegant.
tr: Although her respect for her led to speaking less, it did not make her more graceful.
es: Not even that respect, which earned her a bit, managed to give her any elegance.

en: Elizabeth did all she could to shield him from the frequent notice of either, and was ever anxious to keep him to herself, and to those of her family with whom he might converse without mortification; and though the uncomfortable feelings arising from all this took from the season of courtship much of its pleasure, it added to the hope of the future; and she looked forward with delight to the time when they should be removed from society so little pleasing to either, to all the comfort and elegance of their family party at Pemberley.
vi: Elizabeth did everything to ensure he was not overly noticed by the two ladies, always wanting him to stay close to her or with family members with whom he could converse comfortably. Although such feelings somewhat diminished the joy of a couple newly in love, this situation created hope for the future. She looked forward to the day when the two would break away from such unexciting relationships, to live together in comfort and elegance with his family at Pemberley.
tr: Elizabeth did her utmost to shield Mr. Darcy from the frequent attentions of both, staying vigilant to keep him reserved for herself and the family members who could be spoken of without shame; although the discomfort arising from all this took away much of the pleasure of the courting season, it contributed to the hope for the future; Elizabeth began to eagerly anticipate the time when they would escape that tedious company and enjoy the comfort and elegance of family life at Pemberley.
es: Elizabeth did everything she could to protect him from everyone and always tried to keep him close to her or to the members of her family whose conversation did not mortify him. The annoyances that all this brought took away a good part of the pleasures of the courtship, but added greater hopes for the future. Elizabeth thought with delight about the future, when they would be away from that society so unpleasant for both of them and enjoying the comfort and elegance of their family gatherings at Pemberley.

en: CHAPTER LXI.
vi: Chapter 61
tr: Chapter XIX
es: CHAPTER LXI

en: HAPPY for all her maternal feelings was the day on which ms Bennet got rid of her two most deserving daughters.
vi: All of Mrs. Bennet's feelings of happiness were about the day she got rid of her two most deserving daughters.
tr: The happiest day of all maternal feelings was the day Mrs. Bennet got rid of her two most virtuous daughters.
es: The day Mrs. Bennet parted with her two best daughters was of great bliss for all her maternal feelings.

en: With what delighted pride she afterwards visited ms Bingley, and talked of ms Darcy, may be guessed.
vi: After that, the pride she would feel when visiting Mrs. Bingley and what she would say to Mrs. Darcy could only be speculated.
tr: It can be imagined that she then visited Mrs. Bingley with delightful pride and spoke of Mrs. Darcy.
es: One can imagine with what delightful pride she later visited Mrs. Bingley and spoke of Mrs. Darcy.

en: I wish I could say, for the sake of her family, that the accomplishment of her earnest desire in the establishment of so many of her children produced so happy an effect as to make her a sensible, amiable, well-informed woman for the rest of her life; though, perhaps, it was lucky for her husband, who might not have relished domestic felicity in so unusual a form, that she still was occasionally nervous and invariably silly.
vi: Her earnest desire to establish families for her daughters had come true, and this created such great happiness that she became a sensible, pleasant, and understanding woman for the rest of her life. Although her husband might not quite match the family's unusual decorum, he was fortunate that her nerves still occasionally became as tense and foolish as before.
tr: I wish I could say that, for the sake of her family, the success she achieved in her passion for marrying off her children made her a reasonable, charming, and sensible woman for the rest of her life; yet, perhaps, her continuing to be occasionally nervous and always foolish was fortunate for her husband, who might not have appreciated an extraordinary familial happiness.
es: I would like to say, for the sake of her family, that the fulfillment of her most fervent desires in seeing so many of her daughters well married had the happy effect of turning her into a sensible, kind, and judicious woman for the rest of her life; but perhaps it was a blessing for her husband (who would not have been able to enjoy the happiness of home in such an unusual form) that she remained occasionally nervous and invariably foolish.

en: mr Bennet missed his second daughter exceedingly; his affection for her drew him oftener from home than anything else could do.
vi: Mr. Bennet missed his second daughter very much, so his affection for her drew him out of the house more often than other reasons.
tr: Mr. Bennet missed his second daughter immensely; his love for her caused him to be away from home more frequently than anything else could.
es: Mr. Bennet missed his Elizabeth greatly; his affection for her drew him out of the house more frequently than anything else could have.

en: He delighted in going to Pemberley, especially when he was least expected.
vi: He felt happy whenever he went to Pemberley, especially when everyone was surprised.
tr: He enjoyed going to Pemberley, especially at the most unexpected times.
es: He delighted in going to Pemberley, especially when they least expected him.

en: mr Bingley and Jane remained at Netherfield only a twelvemonth.
vi: Mr. Bingley and Jane stayed at Netherfield for only twelve months.
tr: Mr. Bingley and Jane stayed at Netherfield for only twelve months.
es: Bingley and Jane stayed in Netherfield for only a year.

en: So near a vicinity to her mother and Meryton relations was not desirable even to his easy temper, or her affectionate heart.
vi: Even his easy-going nature or her affectionate heart did not much enjoy living close to her mother and Meryton.
tr: Living so close to Jane's mother and relatives in Meryton was too much for both Mr. Bingley's easy-going nature and Jane's loving heart.
es: The proximity of her mother and the relatives from Meryton was not desirable even considering Bingley's easygoing nature and Jane's loving heart.

en: The darling wish of his sisters was then gratified: he bought an estate in a neighbouring county to Derbyshire; and Jane and Elizabeth, in addition to every other source of happiness, were within thirty miles of each other.
vi: The earnest desire of his sisters was fulfilled; he bought an estate in the countryside near Derbyshire. Jane and Elizabeth, besides their sisterly bond, now lived only thirty miles apart.
tr: Then the greatest wish of the two sisters came true; Mr. Bingley purchased an estate in a county adjacent to Derbyshire, and Jane and Elizabeth, in addition to every other source of happiness, came within thirty miles of each other.
es: Then the golden dream of Bingley's sisters came true; he bought an estate in a county near Derbyshire, and Jane and Elizabeth, to their utmost happiness, were only thirty miles away.

en: Kitty, to her very material advantage, spent the chief of her time with her two elder sisters.
vi: Kitty, with many material advantages, mainly spent her time staying with her two eldest sisters.
tr: Kitty wisely spent most of her time with her two elder sisters.
es: Catherine, solely for her material interest, spent most of her time with her two older sisters; and by frequenting a society far superior to what she had always known, she made remarkable progress.

en: In society so superior to what she had generally known, her improvement was great.
vi: Although her new familial connections were of a much higher class than her friendships, she made significant personal progress.
tr: She made great progress within a society far superior to the one she had previously known.
es: Catherine, solely for her material interest, spent most of her time with her two older sisters; and by frequenting a society far superior to what she had always known, she made remarkable progress.

en: She was not of so ungovernable a temper as Lydia; and, removed from the influence of Lydia’s example, she became, by proper attention and management, less irritable, less ignorant, and less insipid.
vi: She did not have the uncontrollable temperament of Lydia, and once she was out of Lydia's influence, with proper care and management, she became less irritable, less ignorant, and less insipid.
tr: Her nature was not as headstrong as Lydia's, and with Lydia's example removed from her view, and with the necessary attention and guidance, she became less troublesome, less ignorant, and less tiresome.
es: Her temperament was not as indomitable as Lydia's, and away from her influence, she became, thanks to proper attention and guidance, less irritable, less ignorant, and less insipid.

en: From the further disadvantage of Lydia’s society she was of course carefully kept; and though ms Wickham frequently invited her to come and stay with her, with the promise of balls and young men, her father would never consent to her going.
vi: Of course, she was carefully kept away from Lydia's connections, and although Mrs. Wickham occasionally invited her to stay with promises of balls and young men, her father never allowed her to go.
tr: She was carefully kept away from Lydia's companionship to avoid any harm; although Mrs. Wickham often invited her to stay with promises of balls and young men, her father did not allow her to go.
es: As was natural, she was carefully kept away from the previous disadvantages of Lydia's company, and although Mrs. Wickham invited her many times to her house, with the promise of dances and suitors, her father never consented to her going.

en: Mary was the only daughter who remained at home; and she was necessarily drawn from the pursuit of accomplishments by ms Bennet’s being quite unable to sit alone.
vi: Mary is the only daughter still left in the house. Being drawn into the pursuit of Mrs. Bennet's achievements, she could not sit still by herself.
tr: Mary was the only girl left at home; she withdrew from the struggle for success because Mrs. Bennet could not be left alone.
es: Mary was the only one who stayed in the house and was forced to stick close to Mrs. Bennet, who did not know how to be alone.

en: Mary was obliged to mix more with the world, but she could still moralize over every morning visit; and as she was no longer mortified by comparisons between her sisters’ beauty and her own, it was suspected by her father that she submitted to the change without much reluctance.
vi: Mary had to integrate more with the world, but she still preached morality on every morning outing. Since she no longer had to suffer from the comparisons of beauty between her sisters and herself, her father thought she submitted to the change without much resistance.
tr: She had to be more involved with the world, but did not neglect to pontificate about her morning visits; her father thought she submitted to the change without much resistance since she was no longer vexed by the comparison of beauty among her sisters.
es: For this reason, she had to mingle more with the world, but she could still moralize about all the morning visits, and since she was no longer mortified by comparisons between her beauty and that of her sisters, her father suspected that she had accepted the change without displeasure.

en: As for Wickham and Lydia, their characters suffered no revolution from the marriage of her sisters.
vi: As for Wickham and Lydia, their status did not change due to the weddings of the two elder sisters.
tr: As for Wickham and Lydia, their characters underwent no change due to their sister's marriage.
es: As for Wickham and Lydia, their sisters' weddings left them just as they were.

en: He bore with philosophy the conviction that Elizabeth must now become acquainted with whatever of his ingratitude and falsehood had before been unknown to her; and, in spite of everything, was not wholly without hope that Darcy might yet be prevailed on to make his fortune.
vi: He calmly accepted that Elizabeth must now know all about his ingratitude and mistakes that she was unaware of before, and despite what had happened, still hoped to gain material benefits from Darcy.
tr: Wickham steadfastly endured the belief that Elizabeth must now have learned of his ingratitude and deceit, which she had previously been unaware of; but despite everything, he did not entirely lose hope that Darcy could be persuaded to give him his inheritance.
es: He philosophically accepted the conviction that Elizabeth would now know all his falsehoods and all his ingratitude that she had previously ignored; but nevertheless, he still harbored the hope that Darcy would influence his fortune.

en: The congratulatory letter which Elizabeth received from Lydia on her marriage explained to her that, by his wife at least, if not by himself, such a hope was cherished.
vi: Lydia's congratulatory letter to Elizabeth showed her that at least his wife, if not he himself, still harbored such hopes.
tr: The congratulatory letter Lydia sent to Elizabeth due to her marriage indicated that this hope, if not Wickham's own, was kept alive by his wife.
es: The congratulatory letter for her marriage that Elizabeth received from Lydia implied that such hope was cherished, if not by him, at least by his wife.

en: The letter was to this effect:—
vi: Lydia's congratulatory letter to Elizabeth showed her that at least his wife, if not he himself, still harbored such hopes.
tr: The letter was as follows:
es: It read as follows:

en: “My dear Lizzy,
vi: “Dear Lizzy
tr: "My dear Lizzy,
es: My dear Lizzy,

en: “I wish you joy.
vi: I wish you happiness.
tr: I wish you joy.
es: I wish you the greatest happiness.

en: If you love mr Darcy half so well as I do my dear Wickham, you must be very happy.
vi: If you love Mr. Darcy half as much as I love Wickham, you will be very happy.
tr: If you love Mr. Darcy half as much as I love my Wickham, you must be very happy.
es: If you love Mr. Darcy half as much as I love my beloved Wickham, you will be very happy.

en: It is a great comfort to have you so rich; and when you have nothing else to do, I hope you will think of us.
vi: It is quite pleasant to have such a wealthy sister, and when you have nothing to do, I hope you will think of the two of us.
tr: It is a great comfort to think that you are so wealthy; I hope you will think of us when you have nothing else to do.
es: It is a great comfort to think that you are so rich; and when you have nothing else to do, remember us.

en: I am sure Wickham would like a place at court very much; and I do not think we shall have quite money enough to live upon without some help.
vi: I believe Wickham is very eager to have a position in the court, but I don't think we have enough money to live without assistance.
tr: I am sure Wickham would love to have a position at the palace; I don't think we will have enough money to live without some help.
es: I am sure that Wickham would very much like a court appointment, and we will never have enough money to live there without some help.

en: Any place would do of about three or four hundred a year; but, however, do not speak to mr Darcy about it, if you had rather not.
vi: Any amount will do, around three or four hundred a year. But don't say anything to Mr. Darcy if you don't want to.
tr: Any position with an annual income of three or four hundred would do; still, don't mention this to Mr. Darcy if you don't want to.
es: I mean a position of about three or four hundred pounds a year; but, in any case, do not mention this to Darcy if you do not think it appropriate.

en: “Yours,” etc.
vi: Your younger sibling
tr: With my love."
es: I mean a position of about three or four hundred pounds a year; but, in any case, do not mention this to Darcy if you do not think it appropriate.

en: As it happened that Elizabeth had much rather not, she endeavoured in her answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind.
vi: Because Elizabeth did not like it at all, when replying, she tried to put an end to all such pleas and expectations.
tr: Since Elizabeth did not want it at all, she tried to cut off any such requests and expectations in her response.
es: And as it happened that Elizabeth found it very inconvenient, in her reply she tried to put an end to all such pleas and dreams.

en: Such relief, however, as it was in her power to afford, by the practice of what might be called economy in her own private expenses, she frequently sent them.
vi: However, she still assisted her sister within her means, by saving on her own expenses.
tr: But the help she could afford, she saved up by economizing on her personal expenses and frequently sent it to them.
es: But she often sent all the help that her practice of what she called economy in her private expenses allowed.

en: It had always been evident to her that such an income as theirs, under the direction of two persons so extravagant in their wants, and heedless of the future, must be very insufficient to their support; and whenever they changed their quarters, either Jane or herself were sure of being applied to for some little assistance towards discharging their bills.
vi: She clearly saw that their combined income could never be enough for them to be wasteful in their destitution, and in a lifestyle that disregarded the future. Whenever they changed residences, they turned to Jane or Elizabeth for a little help in settling outstanding bills.
tr: She knew from the beginning that two people with such expensive desires, incapable of thinking about tomorrow, could not manage with such a small income; whenever they changed cities, they would either turn to Jane or her with a small request for help to pay the bills.
es: It was always evident that the income managed by people as extravagant as the two of them and so careless about the future, would be insufficient to sustain themselves. Every time they moved, either Jane or she would receive some plea for help to pay their bills.

en: Their manner of living, even when the restoration of peace dismissed them to a home, was unsettled in the extreme.
vi: Even when peace was restored, allowing them to return home, their way of life remained unstable.
tr: Even when peace was signed and they were brought home, their lifestyle was extremely chaotic.
es: Their life, even after peace confined them to a home, was extremely hectic.

en: They were always moving from place to place in quest of a cheap situation, and always spending more than they ought.
vi: They always moved from place to place to find cheaper living arrangements, and always spent more than their income.
tr: They were always moving from place to place in search of a cheaper house and always spending more than they earned.
es: They were always moving from one place to another in search of a cheaper house and always spending more than they could afford.

en: His affection for her soon sunk into indifference: hers lasted a little longer; and, in spite of her youth and her manners, she retained all the claims to reputation which her marriage had given her.
vi: His love for the youngest sister soon grew cold; her love lasted a little longer. Despite her youth and temperament, she bore all the gossip and slander that her marriage had caused.
tr: Wickham's love for Lydia soon turned into indifference; Lydia's lasted a bit longer; despite her youth and temperament, she maintained all the privileges that her marriage provided her.
es: Wickham's affection for Lydia soon turned into indifference; Lydia's lasted a bit longer, and despite her youth and demeanor, she retained all the rights to the reputation that her marriage had given her.

en: Though Darcy could never receive him at Pemberley, yet, for Elizabeth’s sake, he assisted him further in his profession.
vi: Although Darcy never wanted to welcome him at Pemberley, to help Elizabeth, he still supported him in advancing his career.
tr: Darcy never accepted Wickham at Pemberley; nevertheless, for Elizabeth's sake, he helped him advance in his profession.
es: Although Darcy never received Wickham at Pemberley, he helped him progress in his career out of consideration for Elizabeth.

en: Lydia was occasionally a visitor there, when her husband was gone to enjoy himself in London or Bath; and with the Bingleys they both of them frequently stayed so long, that even Bingley’s good-humour was overcome, and he proceeded so far as to talk of giving them a hint to be gone.
vi: Lydia occasionally visited when her husband was enjoying himself in London or Bath. With the Bingley family, both Lydia and her husband often stayed for quite a long time, to the point where even Bingley's easygoing nature was exhausted, and he eventually found a way to subtly hint to the two that it was time for them to leave.
tr: Lydia occasionally came to visit there when her husband went to London or Bath for pleasure; but the two of them stayed so long at the Bingleys' so often that even Bingley's patience ran out, and he went so far as to mention that he might hint at them to leave.
es: Lydia paid them a visit now and then when her husband went to have fun in London or went to take baths. They often spent seasons with the Bingleys, to such an extent that they managed to ruin Bingley's good humor and he hinted that they should leave.

en: Miss Bingley was very deeply mortified by Darcy’s marriage; but as she thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley, she dropped all her resentment; was fonder than ever of Georgiana, almost as attentive to Darcy as heretofore, and paid off every arrear of civility to Elizabeth.
vi: Miss Bingley was very distressed when Mr. Darcy got married, but because she thought she should retain the right to visit Pemberley, she set aside all her resentment, became closer to Georgiana, and treated Elizabeth well, albeit belatedly.
tr: Miss Bingley was extremely upset about Darcy's marriage; but she wisely decided to forgo her resentment in order to retain the right to visit Pemberley, showed even more affection towards Georgiana, continued to behave as attentively as ever towards Darcy, and fulfilled all her duties of courtesy towards Elizabeth without fail.
es: Miss Bingley was very resentful of Darcy's marriage, but as soon as she felt entitled to visit Pemberley, her resentment passed: she was crazier than ever about Georgiana, almost as attentive to Darcy as before, and so courteous to Elizabeth that she paid her overdue respects.

en: Pemberley was now Georgiana’s home; and the attachment of the sisters was exactly what Darcy had hoped to see.
vi: Georgiana now lives permanently at Pemberley; the relationship between sister-in-law and brother-in-law is just as Mr. Darcy had hoped.
tr: Pemberley was now Georgiana's home; the sister-in-law and sisterly love was exactly as Darcy had hoped to see.
es: Georgiana then stayed to live at Pemberley and grew fond of her sister as much as Darcy had anticipated.

en: They were able to love each other, even as well as they intended.
vi: They love each other, and they love each other as much as they had intended.
tr: They managed to love each other as much as they initially wanted.
es: The two loved each other tenderly.

en: Georgiana had the highest opinion in the world of Elizabeth; though at first she often listened with an astonishment bordering on alarm at her lively, sportive manner of talking to her brother.
vi: Elizabeth has a very good opinion of Georgiana, though at first she often listened with astonishment, almost to the point of alarm, at the lively, spirited manner in which the younger sister spoke to her brother.
tr: Georgiana was the person who admired Elizabeth the most in the world, even though at first she often listened to her lively, playful way of speaking with her brother with a surprise that bordered on fear.
